column2: CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Julius Rosenwald, merchant and philanthropist, died in his sleep this afternoon at 2:55 o'clock at the age of 69. His wife and his five children were at the bedside as Dr. Herbert Pollock, attending physician, announced that he was dead.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's annual message to the Legislature, delivered today, was as follows:

Electric light and power companies in the United States will spend $455,000,000 for expansion and improvement in 1932, according to an annual survey completed.yesterday by Electrical World. The budget is about 28 per cent less than actual expenditures in 1931, due principally to a drop in construction of generating plants.

Cash, United States Government short-term obligations and municipal bonds constitute about 53 per cent of the net assets of the General American Investors Company, according to its annal report, which shows that as of Dec. 31, last, the net asset value of common stock was $1.27 a share, against $5.53 a share a year before.

Remaining at ten goals, Thomas Hitchcock Jr., America's international captain, continues at the top of the ranking list of the United States Polo Association, the only ten-goal player in the country and one of the three of the world. Captain C.T.I. Roark of Great Britain and Lewis Lacey of Argentina are the only other ten-goal players in the game.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Mahatma Gandhi's Congress party followers are endeavoring to induce the cancellation of more than u1,000,000 in orders now being filled in British industrial towns, according to the Bombay correspondent of The Daily Express.
BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 6 -- There is a three-fold menace in the worldwide depression, in the opinion of Miss Jane Addams, who is convalescing from an operation in Johns Hopkins Hospital.

Appealing to those who have not yet helped the city's needy, Mayor Walker declared yesterday that it was time for persons who have shown "no interest in humanity" to realize that their contribution would be as much for their own protection as for the benefit of persons directly helped.

The action of Leo J. Flynn, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, in recommending Federal regulation of interstate motorvehicle operation and also amendment of anti-trust laws to facilitate acquisition of motor lines by railroads was hailed yesterday in railroad circles as a constructive move.

When the Dreyfus case was crowding the horizon with alarm, Romain Rolland's "Wolves," which Maurice Schwartz put on at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre last evening, must have had an appeal that is less concrete now. Using the cut-throat background of the French Revolution, M. Rolland's play shows how inadequate the voice of justice sounds when the patriots are bellowing their muttonheaded devotion to the country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The report of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency on the bill for the Creation of a Reconstruction Finance Corporation is as follows:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The establishment of a Pacific-Dutch East Indies conference by Pacific steamship lines was approved by the Shipping Board today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Democrats here were elated today at the election of William N. Rogers in New Hampshire and took the position that this result and the Democratic victories in Michigan and New Jersey indicated a victory for the party in the Presidential election in November.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Jan 6 -- Eli Newmark, so-called "slot machine king" of Ocean County, was sentenced to six years in the State prison and a fine of $1,500 by Judge Arthur German Gallagher. The prison, sentence, representing three of the eleven indictments to which Newmark pleaded guilty two weeks ago for possession of slot machines, was suspended.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Army got away to a flying start at basketball today, opening the season with a victory over McGill University of Montreal by a score of 36 to 18. Both teams displayed much wildness in passing and poor direction in shooting at the outset, but Army was first to settle down, and at the half was leading the Canadians by a 14-to-8 count.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Storms from Portugal to Scandinavia and floods in many parts of Europe caused six deaths today and distress for several shipa.

Readers who sent $2,322.98 additional to the Neediest Cases yesterday wrote that they could not get away from the thought that the procession of misfortune which passed through the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES until last Sunday is about to be halted short of relief.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Governor Roosevelt's recommendations for meeting the current strain on government and business as set forth in his annual message to the Legislature today, elicited praise from the Democratic members and a cautious but not unfriendly response from the Republican leaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A slight brightening of American foreign trade in November was pictured today by the Commerce Department in figures showing increased purchases by Asia and a break in the rate of general recession. The month's total of $343,272,212 was a decline of 30 per cent from November in 1930.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Intent on speeding the new tariff bill through the House before Saturday night to make way for a tax bill and President Hoover's proposal for the reconstruction finance corporation, majority members of the Ways and Means Committee gave notice today that they will wait no longer than tomorrow to hear the views of the administration on the proposed amendments to the Smoot-Hawley act.

Competition In the metropolitan Class C squash racquets team championships was resumed yesterday with six of the seven scheduled matches being played. The meeting between the Englewood Field Club and Plainfield Country Club was postponed until Sunday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Eluding a police chase in which shots were fired after he had fled from the scene of a collision, in Hartsdale, Joseph Shay, 30 years old, a taxicab driver of 5 Maple Street, was burned to death tonight when his taxicab crashed into another automobile here.
TIENTSIN, China, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Uneasiness among the Chinese in Tientsin was increased today by another demonstration march through the Chinese city by troops of the Japanese garrison.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Hopeful that Congress will listen tomorrow to their pleas for work, an army of jobless estimated to number about 15,000, led by Father James R. Cox of Old St. Patrick's Church of Pittsburgh, reached Washington tonight and was escorted toy police to an open field in Southwest Washington.

If Thomas Bell, 31-year-old mechanic, who appeared in Federal Court Tuesday and made the strangest request heard there in years, vists the chambers of Judge Alfred C. Coxe in the Woolworth Building today he will discover that Judge Coxe is eager to be of service in the case.

At least 50,000 miles of track -- 20 per cent of the entire track mileage of the country's railroads -- is no longer necessary in rail service and should be abandoned as rapidly as possible, together with many stations and buildings, it was asserted yesterday by Thomas F. Woodlock, former member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, in a talk at the New School of Social Research.

Charles F. Kerrigan, assistant to Mayor Walker, wants the Legislature to end the life of the Hofstadter committee because he and his friends "fear the further disclosures to come," according to a formal statement issued yesterday by Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the joint legislative investigating committee.

The Coal Merchants Association will be advised today by officials of the striking teamsters and coal drivers whether they will call a meeting of union members as soon as possible to take up a proposal advanced yesterday by Health Commissioner Wynne that the union members agree to arbitrate the question of a 10 per cent wage reduction.

The formal inaugural of another training campaign for Babe Ruth, which has come to be something of an annual event like ground-hog day, was staged in the gymnasium of his special trainer, Artie McGovern, yesterday with the usual display of pomp.

The Community Councils of the City of New York, Inc., in joint meeting last night in the Municipal Building, went on record as opposed to transit unification as impractical, and adopted a resolution demanding an end to the use of wooden cars by the I.R.T. and the B.M.T. on the Astoria-Queensborough line.

It was one of the tenets of Mr. ROSENWALD'S philosophy of philanthropy that large sums of money should not tie stored up for use centuries hence, but should be spent either during the giver's life or, at most, within a single generation after his death.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Officers of the Ontario County Trust Company here announced today that the bank, which was placed in the hands of the State Ranking Department on Oct. 6 for the protection of depositors, would be reopened on Saturday morning.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 -- Creation of a $20,000,000 credit corporation to release frozen bank assets, especially first mortgages on homes held by closed trust companies, and a reduction of 10 per cent in all State salaries above $2,000 as a step toward bringing the cost of government to the lowered price level, were recommended by Governor Joseph B. Ely today in his annual message ta the Legislature.

The theft of two diamond brooches and a cigarette case, valued at about $10,000, from the home of Mrs. W. Thorn Kissel, wife of the Wall Street banker, at 33 East Sixty-seventh Street, last Monday afternoon, was disclosed yesterday by tne police.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 6 -- The Princeton hockey team fought the University of Toronto sextet to a 2-2 draw tonight before the game in Hobey Baker Memorial Rink was called in the third period on account of a dense fog.

Members of the Frostbite Yacht Club agreed yesterday to hold their second midwinter sailing race on Saturday. As the first one was held on Manhasset Bay, the coming one will be off the Westchester shore, probably at Larchmont.

Leaders in all walks of life, including industry, finance, education, religion, social service and government, yesterday paid tribute to Julius Rosenwald, who died in Chicago. Among those who joined in the commendations were Governor Roosevelt, Lieut. Gov. Lehman, Mayor Walker and former Governor Smith.

The Bronx Tigers defeated the Boston Bruin Cubs, 5 to 3, in the roughest, game of the Canadian-American League season in New York at the New York Coliseum last night, before a crowd of 1,500. By winning the Tigers broke a triple tie and moved into undisputed possession of second place.

With the disclosure by Police Inspector Ernest Van Wagner of Staten Island that Sergeant Albert L. Smith of the Army Ordnance Department at Camp Dix, N.J., wanted in connection with the killing of his wife, was seen last Sunday night leaving for the West, the local and Federal authorities concentrated their search yesterday in that part of the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Secretary of State Stimson told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that the United States regards the forthcoming disarmament conference at Geneva as the most important international discussion in which it has ever prepared to participate.

Pig iron production figures for December, as reported by The Iron Age, show a daily average of 31,625 tons and both this and the month's total of 980,376 tons make new low records for the past ten years. Excepting July and August, 1921, the daily output was the smallest since November, 1900.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6 -- After a widespread hunt in rain and fog, planes and many other searchers reported no trace today of the missing women fliers, Mrs. Ruth Stewart, 29, of St. Louis and Mrs. Debbie Stanford, 25 of Indianapolis.

Aroused over a reported proposal for reduced wage scales for men employed on the new East River subway tunnel which will run from Rutgers Slip, Manhattan, to Jay Street, Brooklyn, tapping the city's subway system on the Eighth Avenue line at Sixth Avenue and Fourth Street, Manhattan, 400 members of a tunnel and subway workers' union threatened yesterday to strike unless the contractors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Breaking down the opposition of Senator Norris of Nebraska and other Republican insurgents, the Senate, by a vote of 54 to 17, displaced this afternoon the election of a President pro tempore as unfinished business and thereby laid the way open for consideration of important measures.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. yesterday..3 /4 to 4 per cent for the best names Tuesday....3 /4 to 4 per cent for the best names The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 -- Informed of press reports from Washington that the State Department did not regard Ambassador Debuchi's verbal expression of regret over the attack upon United States Consul Culver B. Chamberlain by Japanese soldiers at Mukden as "adequate redress," a Foreign Office spokesman said nothing had been learned officially of the alleged dissatisfaction.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 6 -- With Porter Bedell, right guard, playing a brilliant defensive game, and Elliptt Loughlin, left forward, tallying nineteen points, the Naval Academy basketball team defeated Franklin and Marshall College today, 37 to 25.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- New urgency is given to the Manchurian question from the Soviet viewpoint not only by the Japanese occupation of Chinchow and the reports that the Japanese are planning to advance to Tientsin and Peiping, but more particularly by the "White Guard" rioting at Harbin.

BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- Persistent reports that the bankers attempting to work out a new credit stabilization agreement to replace the present one had given up the effort to find a definite solution of the German short-term debt problem and would confine themselves to proposing merely a prolongation of the present agreement with slight modifications for one year were denied in well-informed banking quarters today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- Thomas R. Carew, undertaker, died here today at the age of 84. His career was closely linked with the early history of San Francisco and of the State. A native of Australia, his father had come to California in 1846. He came here with his mother in 1851.

A field goal by Cohen, centre, in the final seconds of play in an overtime period enabled the Erasmus Hall High School five to turn back the Bush-wick High quintet, 23-22, at the Erasmus court yesterday. Cohen registered a goal in the final minute of the regulation play to deadlock the tally at 19-all.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- With Senator John A. Hastings renewing his attack on Samuel Seabury, the Republican majority in the Legislature gathered here for the opening of the session today apparently committed by desire or political exigency to continue the Hofstadter Committee.

Bennie Alien continued to bold the lead in the State pocket-billiard tournament at Dwyer's Billiard Academy last night. The Kansas City cue expert scored his fifth consecutive victory by disposing of Marcel Camp of Detroit, 125 to 33, in fourteen innings.

Broad and vigorous rallies in the securities and grain markets here and at Chicago coincided yesterday with unconfirmed reports of a Franco-British accord on the reparations problem and assurances of a quick passage of the reconstruction finance bill by Congress.

Julius Rosenwald was born in Springfield, Ill., on Aug. 12, 1862, in a street where Abraham Lincoln once made his home. Mr. Rosenwald's father was a storekeeper and, while the millionaire merchant could say in later years that he had never known poverty, his family's means were limited.

New York of other days will come to life next week when the Museum of the City of New York will open its new building in Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets. On Tuesday the Colonial brick and marble structure will be opened to the public, after a private opening for invited guests on the previous day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- The War Department has approved the expenditure of $165,000 to lengthen Pier 2 of the Army transport docks here to care for the transport Republic, which now plies between New York and the Orient by way of this port.

It is too early to judge whether the survey of the book industry, just completed by Mr. O.H. CHENEY and his staff, will have the beneficial results desired by both surveyor and surveyed. There can be no question that the banker, in his first discussion with a few publishers about two years ago, and in the subsequent elaboration of the economist's point of view on publishing and bookselling, wished to be helpful.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 6 -- The Englewood Field Club team gained undisputed possession of first lace in the New Jersey Women's quash Racquets League today when it defeated the Prettyrock Tennis Club of Prlnceton, with which it had previously been tied, In a match at Englewood, 3 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The first deficiency bill, carrying an emergency appropriation of $25,159,642.7I5 for expenses in the fiscal year 1932, about $14,403,000 less than the original budget estimate, was passed by the House today after argument over the appropriation of $760,000 for remodeling the old House office building.

Appearing last night in Carnegie Hall as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Ossip Gabrilowitsch presented an uncommonly well-balanced program, and one which met with an enthusiastic reception from the audience. This is not to say that a more modern note in the list would have bee unwelcome.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Secretary Adams today told the House Naval Committee that he had testified with the complete knowledge of President Hoover when he asserted before the committee yesterday that the Vinson $616,000,000 naval replacement bill would mean greater economy and efficiency in the navy.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- An action against stag hunters for alleged cruelty to tame animals was taken today by the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals as a result of public protests over the chasing of a deer which recently swam for its life In the sea near Hythe, Kent.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 --Among comments from Philadelphians on the death of Julius Rosenwald were the following:

Ten teams survived the elimination round of the artists' and writers' bridge tournament, which was begun last night at the Hotel Roosevelt under the auspices of the advisory council of Bridge Headquarters, Inc., sponsors of the new "official" system of bidding.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Gold, frankincense and myrrh, the traditional gifts of the Magi to Christ, were presented on behalf of King George today to the Chapel Royal at St. James's Palace by two members of the royal household and offered up by Prebendary Percival, Precentor of Chapels Royal.

Something of a stir in the national professional squash racquets championship was caused by the world's squash tennis titleholder, Frank Ward of the City A.C., as he captured both his first and second-round matches in the tourney which started yesterday at the Downtown A.C.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Booms of aspirants for the Democratic nomination for President will be brough out into the open at the gathering of party members here for the Jackson Day dinner Friday night and the meeting of the national committee on Saturday.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Prime Minister MacDonald may attend the reparations conference at Lausanne provided it is held the week beginning Jan. 18, Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, told a meeting of the Foreign Press Association here today. Sir John, who stated that Britain wanted the debt talk quickly, intimated that Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in addition to the Prime Minister and himself, would attend the conference.

Ellsworth Vines s announcement that Davis Cup tennis and university studies didn't mix and that be was dropping the studies brought quick action yesterday from the United States Lawn Tennis Association urging him to reconsider.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Declaring that "many of our banking methods and our banking laws are not in keeping with the changing conditions and changing practices," Superintendent of Banks Joseph A. Broderick renews his recommendation for a general revision of the banking laws in his annual report to the Governor and the Legislature today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Two of seven defendants in the Foshay $1,000,000 mail fraud case today pleaded guilty to one of seventeen charges on which each was indicted. Short of funds to undergo a new trial after the jury disagreed in the first one, they decided to throw themselves on the mercy of the court.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 6 -- John Lennie, chairman of the Sewanhaka High School Board; William L. McQueen, a trustee, and Mrs. Louise Hinkle, clerk, were indicted here today in connection with the investigation into the fiscal affairs of the high school.

Columbia's reign of supremacy in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League received a severe jolt last night in the Morningside Heights gym before 1,500 persons when Princeton defeated the Lions. 35 -- 32, in the opening game of the title campaign.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 6 -- From a score of outstanding citizens who had known the friendship of Theodore Roosevelt, and who made their twelfth annual pilgrimage to the late President's grave here through the high wind and driving rain this morning, a youth of 21, clad in a worn leather lumberjacket that concealed a flannel shirt, and a cap, stood apart, content to escape notice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is much to be regretted that the admirable editorial In THE TIMES "Lift Up Your Hearts" will not be read by every American citizen. It is throughout a most suggestive, inspiring and informing production.

In the First New Hampshire District, as previously in the Eighth Michigan and Fifth New Jersey, the Republicans were beaten fairly and squarely. The cardinal issue was support or repudiation of the Administration. The total vote was nearly 52,000 -- a high figure for a special election and more than half the total registration.

A decision which is expected to strengthen the position of bondholders' committees in pressing their claims against municipalities is that of the Florida Supreme Court bearing directly on the position of the holders of defaulted municipal bonds, according to a report of the Coral Gables (Fla.) bondholders' committee written by Thomson, Wood Hoffman, municipal bond attorneys, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Approval of the proposed revision of the plans of the Interstate Commerce Commission so as to weld the railroads of the East into four systems was voiced today by Daniel Willard, presdent of the Baltimore and Ohio, on behalf of the executives of the major Eastern trunks lines.

Foreign loans again led the general bond market into higher ground yesterday, with the exception of United States Government bonds, which were irregularly lower. Buying was brisk in both foreign and domestic corporation bonds and a long list of issues gained several points for the day.

Butter. Receipts. 19.033 packages. The recent sharp downward swing was checked yesterday under broad call buying and the position at the lose seemed steadier. A larger volume of butter was bought under the call than we have seen for some months past, and with Chicago prices fractionally higher a little more confident tone seemed in evidence.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "Intercollegiate football is an academic nuisance. It should be abolished," says The Columbia Spectator, as quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

GENEVA, Jan. 6 -- China is now confining itself to asking the Council of the League of Nations to take "whatever steps it considers appropriate" in Manchuria, Dr. Victor Hoo Chi-tsai, 'secretary of the Chinese delegation, who has arrived from Paris, explained here today.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Jan. 6 -- Strict government control of the traffic in intoxicating liquors, a ban on sales in holiday periods and limitation of stocks of authorized dealers are features of the proposed law which the government will place before Parliament in the special session called for Jan. 19.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Julius Rosenwald, the philanthropist who died today, managed to cram into a few published utterances his entire philosophy of life. From those scanty statements it is possible to extract a group of meaningful sentences that characterize, as no biography possibly could, the man who gave millions to benefit humanity.

The present is one of the outstanding periods in American literature, with many valiant authors bearing torches to light up new, heretofore dark vistas of human experience and to teach modern Americans valuable lessons in living, according to the message which Stuart P. Sherman gives in a collection of essays which Farrar Rinehart are publishing posthumously in book form under the title of "The Emotional Discovery of America."

After having been kidnapped and driven around the Gowanus district of Brooklyn for about an hour late last night by four gunman, a man with two cards in his pockets giving the name of John McEvilly, a member of the Edward A. Cummings Post 819, American Legion, and of the Loretta Council, K. of C., was shot five times and instantly killed at 156 Sixth Street, Brooklyn.

Both spot and contract commodity markets surged ahead yesterday, good size advances being registered in a number of staples. In the cash articles, grains, lard, cotton, rubber and some of the metals were up, while in futures there were gains in rubber, hides, silk, coffee and cocoa.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Lojie Alterie, a former Chicago gangster arrested in Denver, and five men held here were reported named by the grand jury today in four indictments charging membership in a mid-Western kidnapping ring.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Ellsworth Vines, national tennis champion, reiterated today his decision to discontinue college work and concentrate on Spring tennis preliminary to Davis Cup play.

The first of the Sert Dances in aid of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children will be held tonight in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Edwin M. Post Jr., heads the committee that has arranged the dances for Thursday nights this month and next, the proceeds from which will be used for the care of destitute women and children who are patients at the infirmary.

Voters throughout the country approved new State and municipal bond issues amounting to $474,489,522 in 1931, compared with $626,059,337 in 1930, $420,995,934 in 1929 and $783,412,085 in 1928, according to figures compiled by The Daily Bond Buyer. Last year bond proposals in an aggregate amount of $133,474,369 were rejected, compared with $280,093,532 in 1930, $295,386,040 in 1929 and $536,889,610 in 1928.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Existence of a gang of 150 bank robbers, all former convicts, their activities directed by the "master mind" of a socially prominent business man, who have looted mid-Western banks of more than $10,000,000 in the last ten years was revealed today by Alexander Jamie, director of the investigations of the "Secret Six," crime investigating body fostered by the Chicago Association of Commerce.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 6 -- The diplomatic relations of Uruguay and Argentina are rapidly becoming strained as a result of Sunday's attempted revolt in the Province of Entre Rios, the Argentine Ambassador here having presented a note to Foreign Minister Blanco which the Ambassador told reporters is a formal protest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Several large estates throughout the country are faced with virtual confiscation through taxation, according to tax authorities, who were preparing today to ask Congress for relief measures.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Wheat on the Board of Trade here today made an immediate response to the strength in the stock markets, and, while the volume of business was not large, no pressure of consequence appeared until the price had advanced about 1 cent from yesterday's finish.

The seventy-nine precinct offices of the Emergency Home Relief Bureau, upon order of Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor, suspended temporarily their work of receiving applications yesterday after Commissioner Taylor had been informed by the office of Controller Berry that the money to pay relief was not available at present.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A furious attack in the last two minutes of play carried Chicago's Black Hawks to a 4-to-2 victory over Detroit's Falcons in a hard-fought National Hockey League game tonight.

A return to prosperity for American railroads, based on the three main factors of more liberal regulation, better protection from the competition of bus and truck lines and the probable acceptance of a wage cut by the railway brotherhoods, was predicted yesterday by Professor William Z. Ripley of Harvard University, long known as a student of transportation problems.

Stock issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $4,411,430,601 in market value in December, according to the Exchange's monthly report, issued yesterday. In November the market value decreased $3,141,381,918.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note that the International Representative Women's Indian Association is concerning itself with what must seem to every student of Indian affairs a very minor item in the complex list of Indian problems -- namely, the marriageable age for Hindu girls.
Vincent Richards, conqueror of William Tilden on three occasions in amateur competition in 1926, is still seeking his first victory over the Philadelphia veteran in championship professional play.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Dale (Red) Jackson, co-holder of the world's endurance airplane record, was killed late today when an amphibian plane in which he was stunting above the municipal airport fell about 2,000 feet to the ground.

"Whistling in the Dark," the Laurence Gross-Edward Childs Carpenter play of which Ernest Truex will be the star, will open next Thursday night at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre. Frank Craven has staged the play, which will begin a New Haven engagement tonight. Besides Mr. Truex the company includes Edward Arnold, Arthur Vinton, Claire Trevor and Ralph Theadore.

The Frenchwoman who under the pseudonym "Colette" has won a wide literary reputation and has been made a chevalier of the Legion of Honor is represented among the books issued today. The volume called "Recaptured" will be issued by Doubleday, Doran Co.

Having opened the new year with two or three days of hesitant or drooping markets, calculated to prolong the mental fog with which Wall Street has surrounded itself, yesterday's markets awoke into something like vitality. The day's recovery was not spectacular; it was the uniformity of trend that attracted notice.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Undoubtedly all you said in your editorial "Street Begging" is quite true.

A farther stay of the Supreme Court order enjoining the city from operating its emergency bus lines in Manhattan and Queens was granted yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, which extended the time limit to April 1.

A British syndicate headed by Lord Southborough, a prominent figure in the British business world, has signed a long-term contract to lease an entire building to be erected in the Rockefeller midtown development popularly known as Radio City, it was announced yesterday by the Metropolitan Square Corporation.

Among the 250 passengers who sailed yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Resolute for a world cruise were Harry A. Mackey, former Mayor of Philadelphia, and Mrs. Mackey, who are going only as far as Egypt. They plan to be home again by the first of March, as the primaries in Philadelphia will be in April and Mr. Mackey may be nominated for the Senate to run against Representative James M. Beck.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 6 -- Dinner guests tonight of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Miller included Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Hall, Mr. and Mrs. George Warren Fuller, Mr. and Mrs. Karl Dolge, Mr. and Mrs. Gail G. Grant, Mr. and Mrs. W. Jerome Pickering, Commodore and Mrs. Vincent B. Ward, Mrs. Joseph Fahys, Mr. and Mrs. Earl Deakin, John Cooper and John Volk.

The Sanitary Commission has been sharply criticized of late for failing to clean up the city. It has been charged with undue delay in building incinerators and rounding out plans for sewage disposal, and with fixing inadequate specifications for garbage trucks.

A change in the management of three, prominent concert musicians was made known yesterday with the announcement that Maria Jeritza of the Metropolitan Opera, Fritz Kreisler, violinist, and Sergei Rachmaninolf, pianist and composer, had completed negotiations transferring their entire professional management to the National Broadcasting Company's Artists Service.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Jan. 6 -- W. Joseph Ford, California attorney, who first gained prominence as Assistant District Attorney when he prosecuted the McNamara brothers for the dynamiting of the Los Angeles Times Building in 1911, died suddenly here today of heart disease at the age of 54.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 6 -- The Civil Service Commission directed today that all aliens be dropped from public payrolls as soon as other workers can be found for the places. In exceptional cases two or three months will be allowed for the changes, but in most instances action is expected before that time.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 6 -- The seven-furlong track record was lowered twice and three other records were broken today at Tropical Park as the result of some of the keenest competition of the meeting thus far over a strip that is becoming increasingly fast under use and good weather.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) --The Senate was informed today that an unpublished report on the Mooney-Billings case which it had called on President Hoover to produce cannot now be found.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- World diplomatic pressure on Japan in the Manchurian crisis now promises to take the form of separate representations by the powers to emphasize their treaty rights in China, of which Manchuria is held to be an integral part.

Brisk rallies in some market leaders and steady gains in the general list of active stocks marked trading yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange, with few of the advances attaining proportions similar to the upturns on the Stock Exchange. Among the widest advances were those in Aluminum of America, American Gas and Electric, American Light and Traction, Electric Bond and Share and Gulf Oil.

Easier conditions continued to be noted in the money market, street loans being made at 2 3/4@2 1/2 per cent. The Stock Exchange rate, however, was maintained at 3, as previously. Time money was dull and unchanged. Acceptances were in demand, the Federal and outside interests combining in the demand for bills.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 6 -- Frequent fire drills stood 1,400 boys and girls in good stead here today when a motion-picture film ignited at Junior High School 1. H.P. Collins, the principal, extinguished the flames as the children calmly marched from the building.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Mrs. Rosemary Ames Kepping, young American actress, was married to Robert Alexander (Bertie) Meyer, theatrical producer of London, at the Register Office today.

The Jamaica High, sextet gained the league lead by defeating Brooklyn Tech, 2-1, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night, where play In the P.S.A.L. hockey tournament was resumed after a Christmas holiday respite.

Whether It represented a frightened retreat by bearish speculators or reflected developments of greater significance, the stock market's performance yesterday put Wall Street in a cheerful frame of mind for the first time this year. Trading on the Stock Exchange was considerably more active than on the day before, the day's turnover of 1,800,000 shares comparing with a trifle more than 1,400,000 shares on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat, of Texas, offered a resolution in the House today seeking the impeachment of Andrew W. Mellon, Secretary of the Treasury.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- From the moment the Legislature swung into action today, leaders of the Republicans started to work for a short session. Senator Fearon and Speaker McGinnies hope to be able to bring about final adjournment by the latter part of March.

An offer to acquire control of the Reliance International Corporation, a general management investment trust with, assets valued at about $5,714,000, by an exchange of shares, has been authorized by directors of the American International Corporation, one of the oldest investment trusts in the country.

A slight improvement in steel operations this week is reported by Iron Age in its review of the industry. The average of steel ingot production is estimated at 24 per cent of capacity, but in some regions it has risen to 40 and even 50 per cent. At this time a year ago the rate for the industry at large was 41 per cent.

Trying marital suits at the rate of one every fifteen minutes in Brooklyn's new matrimonial court. Supreme Court Justice Fawcett cleared the Supreme Court undefended matrimonial calendar yesterday for the first time in its history.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Disarmament talks among Arthur Henderson, Sir Eric Drummond, Secretary General of the League of Nations, and A. Aghnides, Chief of the Disarmament Section of the League, will be opened here tomorrow to prepare for the Geneva meeting on Feb. 2.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 -- Harvard's hockey team continued on its winning stride tonight, following its victories over McGill, Queens and Princeton by defeating St. Mary's College of Winona. Minn., 11 to 2, at the Boston Garden. At the end of the first period the Crimson lead 2 to 1, but midway through the second flashed an offense that resulted in six goals.
NEW YORK. Captain the Hon. B.E.H. Clifford, son of Baron Clifford of Chudleigh, England, is at the Ambassador.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 -- Judge Frederick P. Cabot of the Boston Juvenile Court, a national authority on child delinquency, died tonight at Phillips House of the Massachusetts Gen Hospital, where he had undergone an operation. He was in his sixty-fourth year.

Robert Hallowell's skyscrapers learned to dance last season. This year, as a just opened exhibition at the Montross Gallery bears witness, the steps of this majestic dance have been more amply mastered. There is less stridulous emphasis in both design and color. That the dance is more sauve does not, however, subtract too heavily from an earlier promethean allegro.

Appointment of Major Gen. McCOY as our representative completes the membership of the commission of inquiry on Manchuria set up in the League Council resolution of Dec. 10. Great Britain, France, Germany and Italy have already named their delegates.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Petabit, the Colgate Stable's 4-year-old brown filly, liked the muddy going at Jefferson Park today and galloped off with the Times-Picayune Purse, feature event.

LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- If the objects of Mahatma Gandhi's civil disobedience movement were achieved, no form of government would be possible, the govrnment of India declared in a statement made public at the India Office tonight.

In tone and diction Assistant Mayor KERRIGAN'S attack on Judge SEABURY and the Hofstadter city inquiry committee shows that the Walker Administration is confident that the time is ripe for tattle. No big fish have come into Judge SEABURY'S net; none of the real higherups has been presented for indictment and few for examination; the State is looking around for needed revenues by means of new taxation.

HASTINGS, England, Jan. 6 -- The exciting race between Salo Flohr of Prague and Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, in the international masters' tournament of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club ended today in favor of Flohr, who emerged as victor with a score of 8-1.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- The State Athletic Commission during the last year suspended 357 boxers, twenty-one wrestlers and nire clubs and revoked the licenses of two boxers, it was revealed today by Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn in his annual report to the Legislature.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 6 -- Unsuccessful in getting more than $40 in the Raritan Township home of J. P. Stevens, near the Plainfield Country Club, early this morning, a lone house-breaker went to the next-door home of W. Manning Barr, where he aroused Mr. and Mrs. Barr from sleep at 3 o'clock this morning before escaping with jewelry valued at $15,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Criticism of the Federal administration for failure to come to the aid of business and industry to redeem the country from economic depression was voiced by Governor Roosevelt today in delivering his annual message before a joint meeting of Senate and Assembly which opened the 1932 session of the Legislature.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 6 -- Win Day of Chicago, the defending titleholder, carried off the medal in the final qualifying round for the Miami midwinter amateur championship over the Miami Country Club course today.

DELHI, Jan. 6 -- While scores of All-India National Congress leaders pledged to civil disobedience were being rounded up in all parts of India, party funds being confiscated, offices being closed and flags hauled down a number of moderate Indian leaders who are prepared to speak freely on constitutional matters were summoned to a conference by the Viceroy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The bill to create the proposed $2,000,000,00 Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the central feature of President Hoover's economic and financial recovery program, was favorably reportet to the Senate today, but Senator Blaine, Republican insurgent of Wisconsin, blocked its immediate consideration.

Commissioner John J. Dietz of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity announced yesterday he would submit a petition to the State Water Power and Control Commission within the next few weeks for permission to develop additional subsurface sources of water supply on Long Island which would yield to the city an estimated maximum of 99,000,000 gallons of water a day and increase the city's total supply by 10 per cent.

Directors of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 87 1/2 cents a share on the preferred stock, or at the annual rate of 7 per cent on the $50 par stock, and a dividend of 62 1/2 cents a share on the common stock, which, if maintained the remainder of the year, is at 5 per cent on the $50 par shares.

Discouraged over his failure to obtain enough money to play the stock market and recover $175,000 lost in the market two years ago, Robert Davis Cochran, 48 years old, formerly in the paint business in Sewickley, Pa., shot himself dead early yesterday morning with a rifle in the basement at 243 West Seventy-first Street, where he conducted a rooming house.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 6 -- Yale was outscored by the New York-Boston hockey combination tonight in a tryout of players who may figure on the United States Olympic team at Lake Placid. The visitors blanked the Elis, 4 to 0, carrying the offensive consistently to the collegians.

Thomas Aloysius Bell, 31-year-old unemployed mechanic who on Tuesday asked United States District Court Judge Alfred C. Coxe's sanction so that he could take a job in a speakeasy as a bartender, but who did not receive any promise of immunity from arrest, called on Judge Coxe in chambers yesterday and showed him a telegram offering a few days' work.
MONTREAL, Jan. 7 -- The New York Rangers were beaten 4 to 3 by the Montreal Maroons in a National Hockey League game tonight, breaking the Rangers' string of eleven unbeaten performances.

Mrs. S. Stanwood Menken, wife of the attorney, who was robbed last June of $150,000 jewelry when three hold-up men broke into her home at 34 West Fifty-second Street, has lost two more articles of value in her collection, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Secretary of State Stimson's note to China and Japan is undoubtedly the most important document in the long list of papers on the Manchurian situation. It is not a warning; it is not a remonstrance. It is a full and frank declaration of American policy, stated officially for the first time although previously indicated in a press statement issued on Dec. 10.

The identities of two members of the Stock Exchange who made arrangements several days ago to sell their seats for $122,000 each, the lowest price at which memberships have been sold since 1925, were disclosed yesterday by the Exchange. The men are Philip G. Cameron, floor partner of Tooker Co., and Charles A. Zubrod, one of the floor partners of McGlinn Co.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 7 -- A blanket finish in the Dade County purse thrilled spectators at Tropical Park today as Apprentice Jockey Hank Mills brought J.V. Stewart's Chancellor home to a nose victory over M.S. Ingleright's Gold Mint. Deemster was a nose in back of Gold Mint to take the show.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 7 -- The text of Governor Ritchie's address tonight at the annual Jackson Day dinner of the Concord Club was as follows:

Direct Federal relief for the problem of unemployment would be "unsound and unwise," in the opinion of George A. Hastings, administrative assistant to President Hoover. Mr. Hastings spoke last night at a dinner held by the Republican State Educational League at the Women's National Republican Club.

Assurance to the Zionists of America that Great Britain will fulfill the letter and the spirit of the Balfour Declaration for the building of a Jewish homeland in Palestine was cabled last night to the Zionist Organization of America by Sir Philip Cunliffe-Lister, Secretary of State for the Colonies In the British Cabinet.

Marked progress in the care of homeless, maimed and sick animals in New York City is shown in the annual reports made yesterday to the board of managers of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals at their sixty-sixth annual meeting, held at 50 Madison Avenue, the society's headquarters.

After renewing at 3 per cent, Stock Exchange call money dropped to 2 1/3 per cent in the early afternoon. Outside funds also traded at the minimum figure. Time money market was listless, actually very little new business being involved. There was renewed demand for acceptances by the Federal and outside banks, which was a feature.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Soon after his return to London today Prime Minister MacDonald approved the British policy on reparations which it is hoped will lead to an agreement with France on the eve of the Lausanne conference.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whatever party may win in the Presidential election, the vital interests of the people demand that the preceding campaign be short. The period usually given to this political contest, three and a half to four months, beginning with the adjournment of the last of the nominating conventions in June or July has extended to election day.

It is in keeping with the legislative record of Senator BLAINE of Wisconsin that he should have obstructed the path to industrial recovery. Search the list of his activities in Washington and you will find a long series of "blocks," protests, attacks -- and unending oratory.

Prices advanced 10 points at the opening of the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but the improvement in the stock market failed to attract outside support, and reselling of cotton in the last hour closed the list 1 to 4 points lower than on Wednesday.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The soundness of Britain's system of liquor control is upheld by the long-awaited report pf the royal commission on licensing which was made public here today.

The first performance of a new symphony by Bernard Wagenaar, an instructor at the Juilliard Graduate School, will be played this season by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Arturo Toscanini conducting. The conductor, who recently sailed for Europe, is expected to return some time in March.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 8 -- Proposals for an increase in the forces which Japan permanently maintains in Manchuria to guard the South Manchuria Railway will be discussed at an early conference between the War Office and the general staff of the army, according to the newspaper Nichi Nichi, which is usually well informed in regard to army matters.

The directors of Copper Exporters, Inc., yesterday approved the principles under which the association will work and called a meeting of all members and those proposing to be members for this afternoon finally to approve the new regulations under which the association will operate.

MUKDEN, Jan. 7 -- The necessity of completing the eradication of banditry in Manchuria within the next sixty days is imperative. General Shigeru Honjo, commander of the Japanese forces, asserted this afternoon. Otherwise Japan must face the impossible situation of having to feed the major portion of Manchuria's 30,000,000 of inhabitants before next Autumn, he said.

Readers who recognized that contribution for the relief of the Neediest Cases are dwindling and will soon stop, sent $425 yesterday. Many wrote that they wished to be included as a matter of conscience before the fund finally closes.

A dogged young process server who burst unceremoniously in upon a public hearing of the joint legislative investigating committee yesterday thrust a legal document into the hand of its startled and outraged chairman just in time to save State Senator John A. Hastings from the sting of its punitive powers.

Deploring the "continuing neglect" to provide an adequate sanitation system for the city and harbor, George McAneny, president of the Regional Plan Association, appealed yesterday to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York "to wake up the town," and called upon the Board of Estimate to hasten its choice of a plan.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- Early action by the Court of Appeals on the pending litigation involving the constitutionality of the Congressional redistricting plan is in prospect. The redistricting plan was adopted by the 1931 Legislature, controlled, as is the present, by the Republicans, through a concurrent resolution which did not admit of exercise by the Democratic Governor of his veto power.

NEW YORK. The second Junior Assembly of this season will take place tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor and Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Whitfield will give dinners at the hotel in advance of the dance for their respective debutante daughters, Miss Katrin R. Vietor and Miss Primrose Whitfield.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- An army of the unemployed descended on the Capitol today under the leadership of a priest, who presented to Congress the petition of his 12,000 haggard, unshaven followers for jobs. Then the leader turned to the White House.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court has again stayed the order enjoining the city from operating its "emergency" bus lines, thus tempering justice, and even the clear meaning of the English language, with mercy toward those unfortunate enough to be still dependent on this outlaw facility.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Admission tickets to theatrical productions costing more than $3 are taxable, even though the performance is divided into more than one part and the tickets are sold separately as long as the buyer is required to buy tickets to all parts, according to a ruling made by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- City employes searched today without success on the city dumps for three platinum and diamond rings valued at $2,500, which Mrs. Owen Kildare-Adams of 570 Webster Avenue here, author and lecturer, had thrown by accident into her garbage can Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Plenty of wheat seemed to be for sale today on scale orders on the Board of Trade here, but commission house buying was of enough volume to absorb the selling and advance the May to 58 cents, the best figure since Dec. 19.

The American Bankers Association, representing virtually all banks in the country, has appealed to Congress for drastic curtailment of governmental expenditures so public confidence in the high credit of the government may not be impaired.

The Yale Club's Class B. squash racquets team kept its record free from defeat in the Metropolitan League's New York group last night when it invaded the Union League Club, but its 4 to 1 victory represented a series of grueling battles, every one of which involved either extra games or extra-point games.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Showing an increase of $2,755,300 over 1930, the American production of gold in 1931 amounted to 2,265,881 ounces, valued at $48,907,100, the Bureau of the Mint announced today. As compared with 1915, the year of greatest production, the 1931 figure was lower by $52,128,600.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 7 -- Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in Woodrow Wilson's Cabinet, met Allen Prewitt, a stripling of the bar, in argument before the Kentucky Court of Appeals today in the case of The Knoxville News-Sentinel against Judge Henry R. Prewitt of Montgomery County.

Savings banks throughout the State pledged support yesterday to the East New York Savings Bank, with three offices in Brooklyn, on which a rush of depositors anxious to withdraw their funds descended yesterday following withdrawals of slightly above average Wednesday afternoon.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Sir William Mills, who gave his name to the Mills hand grenade, of which 75,000,000 were supplied to the allied armies during the World War, died today.
LONDON, Jan. 7-- David Lloyd George returned to England today rejuvenated by' his trip to Ceylon and ready to take up the cudgels against the National Government again.

Senators Copeland and Wagner of New York have informed Russel Law, advertising agency, 131 Cedar Street, that they are carefully studying the retroactive feature of the new income tax law proposed by the Washington administration. Senator Copeland in his letter indicates that he will oppose it.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody of San Francisco, who returned to the women's national tennis championship in 1931 to win the crown for the seventh time, equaled the record of Mrs. Molla Bjurstedt Mallory in being ranked first for the seventh time yesterday in the lists given out by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

One of the most harrowing scenes ever put on the stage occupies the second act of "Never No More," which was played at the Hudson last evening. Outside the one-room shanty that fills the stage a Negro is burned. James Knox Millen, who wrote the play, has mercifully spared us the grizzliest details.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending Jan. 6, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,933,000,000, a decrease of $86,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $578,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.
LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Alice Riddle Kindler, who is having an exhibition at the Delphic Studios until Jan. 17, is a Philadelphia painter who has lived in France for the last nine years. She is the wife of Hans Kindler, well-known 'cellist and director of the newly organized National Symphony Orchestra in Washington.
New Jersey realty deals in the metropolitan area reported yesterday were confined almost exclusively to small housing properties.

Unless Controller Berry makes available by the end of the month cash sufficient to carry out the plans of the city's Work Relief Bureau -- whose $15,000,000 program he approved -- this agency will cease functioning just as the city's $5,000,000 Home Relief Bureau's program was suspended abruptly on Wednesday, it was reported yesterday afternoon following a hurried emergency meeting of Mayor Walker's "kitchen cabinet" at the City Hall.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 7 -- Aggravating China's governmental difficulties and possibly paving the way for a return to power of Chiang Kai-shek, Wang Ching-wei reorganizationist leader, resigned his membership on the standing committee of the Central Political Council of the Nanking Government today, pleading the ill health which has kept him in a Shanghai hospital for some weeks.

Increased power comes to the House leadership with the election of a Democrat in New Hampshire, and the record of Speaker GARNER and his colleagues thus far justifies the grant of authority. The Democratic majority, while not large, even with the addition of Representative ROGERS, is cohesive, and the Speaker has kept it on the job.
The High School of Commerce basketball team defeated Theodore Roosevelt High, 25-20, yesterday at the latter's gymnasium.

Winston F.C. Guest, polo internationalist who was lowered in his outdoor handicap Wednesday, remains at ten goals, the head of the list in the indoor game, according to the early season adjustments made by the handicap committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will some one explain to me why the most obvious remedy for the reduction of government expenditure is completely overlooked? There are many who favor reduction of salaries and consolidation of various bureaus, but no one has yet suggested reduction of the interest-rate of bonds issued by the Federal Government and its subdivisions.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- Action by Governor Roosevelt on the charges made by Samuel Seabury against Sheriff Thomas M. Farley appeared tonight to be imminent.

The lives of 1,400 children have been saved, while approximately 17,000 more have been spared the ravages at diphtheria, as a result of the work of the Diphtheria Prevention Commission in the last three years.

The assignment of the eighteen men on the American Olympic speedskating squad to specific events for the final Olympic tryouts at Lake Chadwick, Newburgh, on Sunday, was made yesterday by Coach William M. Taylor, who has had the candidates in rigorous training at Bear Mountain fop the past month.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Hopes for international cooperation in war debts and reparations bad an invigorating effect on financial London today. The Stock Exchange was more cheerful than in some time. Business was not large, but prices were higher in nearly every section of the market.

Schedules for the annual P.S.A.L. senior high school fencing and senior high dual meet swimming championship tournaments, which are to start next month, were announced yesterday by John J. McHugh, inspector of athletics of the P.S.A.L.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Mrs. Ruth Stewart had 700 hours in the air and was a participant in two air derbies.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- Hans Nusslein, professional tennis champion of Germany, playing in his first American singles match, easily defeated Alien Behr of New York in the Eastern professional tournament at Convention Hall tonight, 6 -- 2, C -- 3, 6 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- An early vote in the House on the prohibition issue was forecast, today when the Judiciary Committee indicated its willingness to consider a wet measure as soon as the anti-dry forces agree upon the general nature of the bill or resolution they desire.

Sidney S. Lenz and Commander Winfield Liggett Jr. staged an exciting comeback last night in the next-to-last session of their 150-rubber contract bridge match against Ely Culbertson and his partner and at the close of play had cut the lead of their opponents to 8,770 points, gaining 5,405 points in the session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Consideration of the administration's $2,000,000,000 reconstruction finance corporation bill, proposing far-reaching plans to strengthen the credit system of the nation, began in the Senate today. The debate indicated that partisan feeling would not long delay its passage and that its essential provisions would be preserved.
The second national concert sponsored by the National League of American Pen Women will be presented on the evening of Jan. 14 at the Anderson Studios.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted.
MOSCOW, Jan. 7 -- Fifty persons were killed and many others injured in a rear-end train collision Saturday about nine miles northwest of Moscow, it was learned today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 7 -- At Mirador, her villa, Mrs. William Seward Webb entertained tonight with a dinner.

Work on the new $400,000 addition to the New York Academy of Medicine at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street will be started within four weeks, Dr. Linsly R. Williams, director of the academy, announced last night at the annual meeting, which was preceded by a testimonial dinner to him.

Security markets continued yesterday to rally, new highs on the movement being reached by almost all leading stocks, and sharp gains being made in all sections of the bond market except for United States Government obligations. Bank stocks, which gave the first indications of the rally late on Monday, were affected by profit-taking in the afternoon and generally lost ground on the day.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Jan. 7 -- The Bank of Rockville Centre Trust Company assumed today the assets and liabilities of the First National Bank of Rockville Centre, with the cooperation of the Nassau County Clearing House Association, which was organized by representatives of fifty Nassau banks at a meeting in the Garden City Hotel last night.

Electric power output, according to the National Electric Light Association, last week dropped to 1,523,652,000 kilowatt-hours from 1,564,652,000 kilowatt-hours for the preceding week and 1,597,454,000 kilowatt-hours for the corresponding week last year.

After an argument with his wife and her mother in which he hit the latter on the head with a chair, Henry Dodenhoff, 28 years old, of 1,360 Ogden Avenue, the Bronx, an instructor in chemistry at Brooklyn College of the College of the City of New York, shut himself in the bathroom in his apartment late yesterday afternoon and, according to the police, committed suicide by swallowing a chemical mixture.

The four-day national sales meeting of the home construction division of Sears, Roebuck Co. closed yesterday with a luncheon at the Hotel New Yorker which was attended by outstanding spokesmen for architecture, construction and real estate.

Eighty-seven per cent of the one-year 5 per cent notes of the Arizona Edison Company's issue of $1,500,000 have been deposited with the Chatham Phenix National Bank and Trust Company to be exchanged for new two-year 6 1/2 per cent notes, it was announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Camp Douglas, 3-year-old ace of J.J. Coughlin's stable, ran his Winter season record to three straight when he defeated a good field at one mile in the Al Tauzier Purse at Jefferson Park today.

Edgar T. Appleby, national amateur 18.2 balkline champion, last night defeated the challenger, Ray V. Fessenden. Madison, Wis., in the opening block of their 900-point match at the New York A.C. The score was 300 to 192, Appleby winning after two and one-half hours of play with an unfinished run of 17. His high run was 72, made in the twenty-third inning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The $616,000,000 ten-year naval replacement program was submitted to President Hoover today by Carl Vinson, chairman of the House Committee on Naval Affairs. The conference lasted nearly an hour, Mr. Vinson explaining the bill item by item.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Turning a deaf ear to the administration's opposition to curbing the power of the President in raising or lowering duties under the flexible tariff, the Ways and Means Committee today voted a favorable report on the Democratic tariff bill and set the stage for its consideration on the floor tomorrow.

A Fine Type of Citizen. ARTHUR S. SOMERS had for forty years served the city in a most efficient and disinterested way while meeting his large responsibilities in business and commerce. He had given, to the public an example of devotion rare among men of such large and varied private interests.

Christopher (Bat) Battalino, rugged Hartford Italian, crawls through the ropes in Madison Square Garden tonight to make his sixth defense of the world's featherweight title.The Connecticut lad, established now as one of the greatest fighting champions under pressure the ring has known, is to tackle Lew Feldman, Brownsville challenger, in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds.

A production of Sophocles's "Electra." with Blanche Yurka and Mrs. Patrick Campbell co-starred, will begin a series of four special matinees at the Selwyn Theatre this afternoon The curtain will rise at 3 o'clock.

What was considered by the police as a possible solution of the mysterious disappearance last Dec. 28 of Alesandro Di Sabato and his wife and four daughters from their combination home and private banking and steamship ticket office at 2,133 First Avenue was uncovered yesterday by Martin Binder, Assistant District Attorney.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Following the burial with simple rites today of Julius Rosenwald, merchant and philanthropist, it became known that in the last few days of his life he gathered his five children about his bed and enjoined upon them the duty of seeing that the work he had begun and carried so far was completed.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Visits of Western Democratic leaders to the Executive Mansion to pay their respects to Governor Roosevelt on their way to the national committee meeting in Washington continued today with a call by Richard F. Mitchell, National Committeeman from Iowa.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- As the result of a slack demand for credit and low interest rates last year, the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank for the second consecutive year failed to earn its dividends and resorted to surplus to pay returns to the member banks which own its stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt will be put before the country as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President by the State Committee of North Dakota at a meeting Jan. 14, called for the purpose of fixing the date of the State convention.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 7 -- Sunday's abortive revolt in Argentina has been eclipsed by the diplomatic tension with Uruguay which has grown out of it. Both the Uruguayan and Argentine Foreign Offices are continuing to refuse to make public Argentina's formal protest to Uruguay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The full text of the State Department's statement in defense of its general policy with respect to foreign loan flotations in the United States, and, in part, in reply to the allegations of Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, follows :

BAT BATTALINO holds the world's featherweight crown and Lew Feldman will attempt to wrest it from him at the Garden this evening. There has been some disposition to inquire: "And who is Lew Feldman?" That may be taken as a point in his favor.

The Diphtheria Prevention Commission appointed three years ago by Commissioner SHIRLEY W. WYNNE, under the chairmanship of Mr. THOMAS LAMONT, has completed its three years of private service in cooperation with the New York City Department of Health.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 7 -- With campaign songs, "Ritchie for President" buttons and all the old-fashioned fanfare of politics, the Presidential boom of Governor Albert C. Ritchie, favorite son of Maryland; was opened here tonight at the annual Jackson Day dinner of the Concord Club.

The audience that gathered in Town Hall last night to hear Lotte Lehmann's first song recital in this city was not only impressed, but thrilled. It has been a good many years-more years, at least, than the writer has spent in this city -- since any local song recital has offered such excitements and distinctions.

Joseph Bauman, 20 years old, who was the fifteenth person to be convicted of murder in the first degree in General Sessions in 1931, establishing a record, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Freschi to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing during the week of Feb. 15.

Jack Summers, coach at M. I. T., will have an opportunity to continue his string of conquests as national professional squash racquets champion when he opposes Dan Martella of the Wilmlngton Country Club today in the final of the tourney at the Downtown A.C. courts.

The retirment in the first six days of the year of all the additional Federal Reserve Bank credit absorbed by the market a week ago for year-end "window-dressing" was reflected in yesterday's Federal Reserve statements covering the position of the system as of Wednesday night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Distress arising from unemployment has many ramifications. One of of the phases of distress is due to the fact that many are unable to clothe themselves properly to seek work or to take temporary relief job.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7 -- In opening Yale's varsity indoor rowing practice today, Head Coach Ed Leader boated an eight in the first of the three tanks in the new Payne Whitney gymnasium to be completed.

A committee has been formed to represent the small minority interest of the American Cigar Company in negotiations with the American Tobacco Company, which holds large percentages of both the preferred and common stocks of the American Cigar Company.
Residential and business properties in Manhattan changed hands yesterday in trading by operators and investors. Another west side purchase by the New York Central Railroad also was reported.

The investigation by the Interstate Commerce Commission of the purchase by the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway of 25,000 shares of St. Louis-San Francisco Railway stock will be devoted to purchase price, commissions paid and the purpose behind the transaction, it was ascertained yesterday.
GENEVA, Jan. 7 -- Geneva is pleased by the United States invocation of the Nine-Power pact in regard to Manchuria. Only a brief report of the move had reached here late tonight.

PELHAM, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- Showing the way at half time, 20 -- 12, the Pelham High School five turned back Rye High, 35 -- 19, today. The victory was the second in three games for the home team. Seymour Grass Pelham right forward, starred with ten points.

Butter. Receipts, 11,275 packages. The market is burdened under a heavy surplus of fine butter. There was Just enough buying supportearly to hold values about sustained but trade ruled very dull later yesterday morning and the tone at the close was decidedly weak with marked pressure to sell in evidence.

MIAMI, Jan. 7 -- Under threatening skies the all-American air races, sponsored annually by the city of Miami, were opened here this afternoon by Mayor R.B. Gautier. Three fifteen-mile races were flown, and, as has come to be a custom on the opening day, the service pilots completely dominated the show.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Establishment of personal registration and installation of voting machines in every county will be urged in the annual report of Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, which will go to the Legislature Monday night.

As the demand for water increases every year with the rapid growth of population in Greater New York, and as the city will probably not be able to draw upon the tributaries of the Delaware until from 1938 to 1940, it becomes necessary, in the judgment of Commissioner DIETZ, to develop further the subsurface sources of Western Long Island by sinking wells.

For the first time in the history of the United Hunts Racing Association, the Board of Directors of which met yesterday, the probability exists of holding the Spring race meeting in conflict with the regular New York racing season of the Jockey Club.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The news that the United States had invoked the Nine-Power and Briand-Kellogg pacts in notes to Japan and China took London by surprise tonight just when it thought the Manchurian affair had died a natural death in the arms of Japan.

Town Topics has suspended publication, temporarily at least, as a result of the Attorney General's investigation into its stock-selling methods. Notification of the suspension was given yesterday by George H. Combs Jr., attorney for the periodical, to Deputy Attorney General Paul J. McCauley, who has been carrying on the investigation which studied also the activities of The Tatler and American Sketch, another society journal.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 7 (AP). -- The State Banking Department has taken possession of the Agricultural Trust and Savings Company of Lancaster. The institution's last report showed total resources of $2,474,000, deposits of $1,515,000, capital of $300,000, surplus of $200,000 and undivided profits of $2,200.

Speyer Co. and the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation, as fiscal agents for Kingdom, of Bulgaria 7 per cent settlement loan of 1926, announced yesterday that they had purchased and canceled $71,000 of bonds of the issue for account of the semi-annual sinking fund.

The Sert Room or the Waldorf-Astoria was the scene last night of the first of eight entertainments known as the Sert Dances. The series is being given for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, and has been arranged by a committee headed by Mrs. Edwin Main Post Jr. Special features of the party included dances by Biddle and Caperton, music by the Berkes Hungarian Gypsies and songs by Morton Downey.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The majority report of the Ways and Means Committee on the Democratic tariff bill reads as follows:
MADRID, Jan. 7 -- A liberal policy will be pursued by the Roman Catholic Church in Spain.

A proposal by Health Commissioner Wynne that the striking coal drivers arbitrate with the Coal Merchants' Association the proposed 10 per cent wage cut, with other conditions remaining the same as under the 1931 wage agreement, was approved by a two-thirds vote of more than 1,000 members of Local 533 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers, at a meeting last night in Lexington Hall, 109 East 116th Street.

The public interest in commodities forecasts tremendous potentialities for trading activity on commodity exchanges, said H.H. Pike Jr., president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, in his annual address yesterday to members. He said in part:

The New York Central Railroad has reopened its fight for a 40 per cent increase in commutation rates on its lines entering this city, it was revealed yesterday. No formal announcement came from the railroad, but the Public Service Commission ordered public hearings which will begin on Jan. 21.

January makes its accustomed contribution to the entertainment of tens of thousands through the extraordinary hospitality of the Metropolitan Museum. For four succeeding Saturday nights symphony concerts, conducted by Mr. DAVID MANNES, will be given in the great spaces of the foyer of the Museum.

The licenses of a night club in Manhattan and a dance hall in Brooklyn have been suspended, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Mulrooney, who said that the action against the night club was taken for "raising the check of a patron" and that against the dance ball for "harboring a criminal."

Mrs. Grace Eames Doherty, wife of Henry L. Doherty was sued in the Supreme Court yesterday for $500,000 damages by Natalie MacDonald Hall, an artist, on the ground that Mrs. Doherty appropriated designs invented by Mrs. Hall for the embellishment of pleasure and sport automobiles and asserted that the designs were the work of her daughter, Helen Lee Eames Doherty.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 7 -- The State prepared today to hang Louis Ross, who was identified today in Clarksburg as "Frank Pauletta," who escaped through a sewer from the Harrison County Jail in 1914, four days before he was to have been hanged for murder.

underlying strength in commodity markets was again evident in yesterday's trading, with particular interest in the upswing in cash grains In futures, there was marked improvement in coffee, rubber and silk. Coffee and sugar were moderately lower.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The police vice squad tonight raided the play "Lysistrata" at one of the largest theatres here and arrested nearly all of its cast of seventy.

Spotty Trends in Retail Trade. Consumers are continuing to buy borne furnishings quite readily, reports from retail executives here indicated yesterday. In apparel, however, there is a noteworthy tendency to seek garments reduced from former prices instead of new merchandise especially bought to sell at a low figure, comment in one quarter indicated.

In its report last month to Congress the Interstate Commerce Commission predicted that It would have something more to say at an early date on the subject of motortruck competition with the railways. It has now published an extensive survey made by one of its examiners, who reaches the conclusion, after testimony given by several hundred witnesses representing all interested parties, that Federal regulation should be extended to interstate traffic on the highways.

Taamrat Emmanuel of Addis Abeba, Abyssinia, who has been in the United States in behalf of the Abyssinian Jews, is among the passengers sailing on the Cunard liner Mauretania today, en route to his home via London. Mr. Emmanuel has been working here in conjunction with the American Pro Falasha Committee, Inc., at 305 Broadway, for the fund which is being raised for the religious and educational rehabilitation of the Abyssinian Jews.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Presldent and Mrs. Hoover were hosts tonight at the second official dinner of the White House season, entertaining sixty-three guests in honor of Vice President Curtis.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The exact stock holding's of Julius Rosenwald in Sears, Roebuck Co. could not be ascertained tonight, but close associates estimated his holdings at about 1,000,000 shares, or about one-fifth of the total stock of the company.

Secretary STIMSON sees this country playing a "quiet" but most important part at the Disarmament Conference next month. Ours is bound to be a quiet role, because, as Mr. STIMSON explained to the House Foreign Affairs Committee, we are not directly concerned with the problems confronting the conference.

Newspaper editors throughout the country expect the next President of the United States to be a Democrat, probably Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York or Newton D. Baker of Ohio, according to a survey made by G.F. Shearwood for the Publishers' Service Magazine.

The principal of foreign government. State and municipal bonds in default since the turn of the century aggregates $19,732,500,000, according to a report to be published shortly by the Foreign Policy Association, prepared by Dr. Max Winkler, an authority on foreign investments.
LA FAZ, Argentina, Jan. 7(AP) -- Police set fire today to an island forest in an effort to burn out the three Kennedy brothers who led a brief rising on Sunday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 7 -- Disposing of a large estate, the bulk of which goes to the widow and five children, the will of Charles Oliver Iselin, noted yachtsman and banker, who died at Glen Head, L.I., on Jan. 1, was filed here for probate today.
TIENTSIN, China, Jan. 7 (AP). -- Japanese troops formally occupied the city of Shanhaikwan today, marking their furthest advance southward since they expelled the Chinese from Chinchow.
