BOSTON", Jan. 7 -- Confidence in the future of American Industry and of higher standards of living throughout the world was voiced by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, in an address before the Chamber of Commerce today.

Several corporations are considering the substitution of preferred stock for common stock in future offerings to employes because of the violent fluctuations of the latter securities in recent years, the National Industrial Conference Board, Inc., reported yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- The Bourse continued its progress today, most stocks showing further gains. The news of Wall Street's advance stimulated the market here and optimism over the war debt negotiations helped the situation. Bank of France shares rose 275 francs and Suez Canal 170, and other leaders grained.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 7 -- The central banks of Chile, Peru, Bolivia, Ecuador and Colombia plan to undertake immediately the withdrawal of gold reserves on deposit in London for transfer to a gold standard country, probably the United States, it was said today on high authority.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 7 (AP). -- Pennsylvania's mountains, "grave yard of aviators," today yielded the broken bodies of two young women on the eve of their projected New York to Buenos Aires flight.

Shipments of all Chrysler Corporation automotive produces in 1931 were 102 per cent of the total of 1930, comparing with an average of 75 per cent for the entire industry, according to a report made yesterday by Walter P. Chrysler. The corporation shipped 270,927 cars and trucks, against 266,169 in 1930.

The New York Curb Exchange did not share in the buoyancy which attended trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, except in isolated instances, but the undertone was distinctly stronger and the main body of stocks was firmer. The most active leaders showed moderate gains or losses for the day.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- The Republican majority in the Legislature may take the Democratic Governor "for a ride" when consideration of his executive budget becomes the business before the law-making body.

As a measure to spur business and, at the same time, effect a saving to the Postoffice Department, Airports and Airlines, in its issue to be distributed tomorrow, will advocate the carriage by air of all first-class, nonlocal mail in the United States at a letter rate of 2 1/2 cents.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 7 -- Seven more members of the Salamanda Fire Company of Oceanside, L.I., including the assistant chief, were arrested here today on arson charges after they had admitted, according to the police, that they had started several fires during the last two years, because there was no activity for their department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A warning by the State Department to bankers in October, 1925, to notify their clients of the risks involved in German bonds was revealed today when the department, aroused by criticisms of its foreign-loan policy before the Senate Finance Committee, issued a statement as to its activities in regard to the flotation of foreign loans in this country.

Although conceding the complete financial stability of the city despite the world-wide economic slump, bankers with whom Controller Charles W. Berry is negotiating for a loan of about $90,000,000, have suggested modification of some of the city's fiscal policies to conform more closely with existing conditions, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The market for hogs advanced 5 to 15 cents today, but reacted in the late trading to about the average of the previous day and 5 to 10 cents under the best prices of Wednesday. Light weights were wanted by shippers early, but when these orders had been filled that class led the decline.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The Earl of Kimberley, father of Lord Wodehouse, international polo player, died in London tonight at the age of 83. Lord Wodehouse succeeds to the title.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 7 -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y. was forced to play nineteen holes to defeat John Brown, Portland, Me., today in the opening round of match play for the Miami midwinter amateur championship over the Miami Country Club course.
BOMBAY, Jan. 7 (AP). -- The legality of the arrest of Mahatma Gandhi, leader of Indian Nationalists in their struggle for independence, will be tested in the courts.

The New York Society of Women Artists, which exhibited formerly in the Anderson Gallery, the Art Centre and the Brooklyn Museum, opened its own gallery in the Squibb Building, Fifth Avenue and Fiftyeighth Street, yesterday afternoon. The new quarters, occupying about half of the thirtieth floor, are large and light, with walls painted in the light neutral tone best suited to the display of modern pictures.

BERLIN, Jan. 7 -- Chancellor Bruening called in Adolf Hitler today and for an hour and a half discussed with the National Socialist chieftain the question of prolonging President von Hindenburg's term beyond May 5 through a parliamentary amendment to the Constitution and of postponing the elections to the Prussian Diet, also scheduled for the Spring.

Five men and two women were injured, several hundred others barely escaped injury and forty more were spattered with paint yesterday morning at Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway when a scaffold gave way at one end and two painters plunged forty feet to the stairs of the B.M.T. subway.

St. Stephen's College at Annandale-on-Hudson, an affiliated school of Columbia University, needs $1,000,000 immediately and further benefactions later, it was announced yesterday in an appeal signed by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University and Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell, warden of the college.

The United States uses more cigarettes than any other country in the world, according to Count Corti's book, "A History of Smoking," which Harcourt, Brace Co. will publish today. There has been a great increase in the use of tobacco within recent years the world over, the trend being caused largely by the nervous tensions aroused during the war, the book says.

The upward sweep of prices on stock market and bond market continued yesterday. The advance was again conservatively gradual in stocks, but emphatic enough both in home and foreign bonds to present a picture of rapidly changing values which would have excited incredulity in the scrutinizer of any daily "bond table" before the middle of 1931.

HONOLULU, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Governor Lawrence M. Judd said today that he was doing all in his power "to correct the situation" when informed by the Navy Department at Washington that the men of the fleet would not be allowed ashore in Honolulu during February fleet manoeuvres unless crime conditions were abated.

Patrick J. Cohalan of the New York A.C., who won a ranking in Class A for the first time by his splendid play last season, defeated Robert J. Lamer of the Yale Club last night as play in the'annual invitation Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament got under way on the courts of the Yale Club.

The management of the Transamerica Corporation is carrying into the camp of A.P. Giannini here the battle for proxies to be voted at the annual meeting of the company in Wilmington, Del., on Feb. 15. This was disclosed last night by a second meting of stockholders of the corporation in the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The admirable letter of John Healy in this morning's issue asks why 1/29' American ships are in evidences when foreign vessels, loaded with American passengers and manned by foreign crews, gayly ply the seven seas on vacation cruises, even if some of these are "to nowhere."

A penitentiary term of not more than three years was imposed by Judge Levine in General Sessions yesterday on Edward Burrows, 51 years old, of 375 Weirfield Street, Brooklyn, for the theft of $911 in fines he had collected when temporary cashier of the Traffic Court, in which he was an attendant.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- An English woman, Miss Jill Cossley-Blatt, has just returned from a visit to a Himalayan, tribe in the heart of Tibet whose members live to be centenarians. She was accompanied by Dr. Irvin Baird.

Three bandits entered a jewelry store at 120-15 Liberty Avenue, Richmond Hill, last night. They locked the proprietors and two clerks in an office in the rear, then carried off the entire stock valued at $25,000 and fled in an automobile.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Demands that the extent of present holdings in other railroad companies by the Pennroad Corporation and the Pennsylvania Company, Pennsylvania Railroad affiliates, be read into the record featured the hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission today on the proposed four-line plan of Eastern railroad consolidation.

A general upward sweep of prices of foreign bonds and domestic corporation issues yesterday characterized dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange. The domestic group, again led by rails, advanced briskly, with a long list of issues gaining to 8 points.

There was a further decrease of $23,000,000 in brokers' loans in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly report of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, bringing the total down to $568,000,000, the lowest figure since Feb. 1,1918, when brokers' loans were $510,179,000.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- White a conference was being held at the Ministry of Labor today concerning the status of foreign artists on the English stage and in music hall, concert and broadcasting work, the Four Harmony Kings, American Negro singers, who have been appearing in Great Britain for seven years, came under the official ban.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- War Minister Andre Maginot's death has brought about the immediate prospect of an extensive change in the composition of the French Cabinet. That change will almost inevitably cause a delay in the opening of the proposed Lausanne reparations conference.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 7 -- The United States Government today sent an identic note to the Japanese and Chinese Governments invoking its own rights and those of its citizens in Manchuria under the NinePower China treaty of 1922 and the Kellogg-Briand anti-war pact.
BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- The international stock market indices of Jan. 2 are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

In the "Iconography of Manhattan Island" is quoted the following entry in a diary of the year 1822, recording a visit to the dueling ground in Weehawken where ALEXANDER HAMILTON was killed by AARON BURR:

J. Nelson Cooper, representing the president and fellows of Harvard College, has applied to the Board of Standards and Appeals for permission to erect and maintain a business building with stores on the property at 2,332 to 2,340 Grand Boulevard and Concourse.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 8 -- Because of losses sustained in its operation of a fleet of taxicabs here and in the suburbs, through its control of Yellow Cab, Inc., the Public Service Coordinated Transport today announced that on Jan. 15 it would abandon the 50-cent limit on rides within Newark city limits and operate on a straight meter rate.

In conjunction with preparations for the annual Beaux-Arts Ball -- "A Pageant of Old New York and the First Inaugural Ball of the United States of America" -- to be held on Jan. 22 at the Waldorf-Astoria, the Museum of the City of New York will hold an exhibition of authentic historical costumes of the Revolutionary period, from Jan. 12 to Jan. 22.

A plan for adjusting salary scales to net income was announced yesterday by A.W. Robertson, chairman of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company. Under it a reduction of 25 per cent in salaries made last Summer will be increased to 30 per cent, but if earnings should justify, this percentage would be cut on a sliding scale to a minimum of 10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Money in circulation during December showed an increase of $112,000,000 to a total of $5,648,300,000 at the end of the year, as compared with the record peak of $5,698,214,000 in October, 1920, according to Treasury figures issued today.

COPIAGUE, L.I., Jan. 8 -- Lonesome for her mother, who had been visiting friends in Flushing so that her unemployed father might have more of the $12 he earns weekly as an emergency worker to support their five children, Gladys Stevens, 13 years old, walked nine miles carrying in her arms her youngest charge, her 2-year-old sister, Joan, in an effort to see her.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The outlook for harmony at tomorrow's meeting of the Democratic National Committee was increased today when several influential dry Democrats after conferences with John. J. Raskob, the national chairman, agreed that a resolution should be passed referring his proposed "home-rule" liquor control plank to the national convention without recommendation.

Butter. Receipts, 17.004 packages. The market broke 1 @ 1 1/2 during the morning yesterday: trading was under greatly increased pressure the move the heavy accumulation in first hands. The break in prices since Just before the New Year holiday has now totaled 6 1/2 c and it is very doubtful whether bottom has yet been reached.

Rallying strongly in the second period, after trailing, 11 -- 5, at the end of the first half, the Manhattan College basketball team defeated the N.Y.A.C. quintet last night, 23 -- 20, on the losers' home court. This was the second victory of the week for the winners and their sixth out of nine starts this season.

Withdrawals subsided at the East New York Savings Bank and its two branches in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon as soon as it became evident that all depositors who wanted their funds were paid promptly. Many who withdrew their money Wednesday and Thursday deposited their funds again when the news spread that the bank had on hand at its opening more than $8,000,000.
The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club basketball team rolled up an early lead to defeat the Georgetown University quintet on the former's floor in Brooklyn last night, by the score of 39 to 28.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- A Democratic drive to pass the new tariff bill by the end of the week opened in the House today.

The city is committed to a $20,000,000 program of work and home relief. It will surely go through with it. There is no ground for apprehension on that score, or for criticism of Controller BERRY. The trouble is not with his heart but with his pocketbook, momentarily depleted.
MIAMI, Jan. 8 -- Tonight in his cell in the Dade County jail, which occupies the seventeenth and eighteenth floors of Miami's new City Hall, Forsbrey ridiculed the charge against him.

The unanimous approval of more than thirty representatives of real estate, business and civic organizations for a year's delay in enforcement of the reconstruction provisions of the multiple dwellings law was recorded yesterday in a resolution adopted for presentation to the State Legislature.

After an interval of a week in which no new offerings of securities were made, new issues in the amount of $2,672,000 were placed on the market this week. The total consisted of long-term municipal bonds, four issues, ranging in size from $1,000,000 down to $250,000.

Secretary STIMSON'S latest official communication to the Governments of Japan and China is plainly the result of an important, and it may be critical, decision by the American Government to act in this matter on its own. The note was made known to the representatives of Great Britain, France, Italy and other nations, but was not necessarily approved by them in advance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Criticism of the Hoover Administration, as lacking in leadership in a period of great depression was voiced tonight by three former Presidential candidates, Alfred E. Smith, John W. Davis and James M. Cox, in speeches at the Jackson Day Dinner, the traditional quadrennial nation-wide gathering of Democrats in the national capital.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange strengthened yesterday and closed around the top at net gains of 8 to 10 points. Following a setback on Thursday, the market moved upward in sympathy with the improvement in securities, and commission house interests became more active buyers than for some time.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Jan. 8 -- A seven-point "victory platform" for the Democratic party, together with in appeal for a return to "old and sound principles of government" was submitted by former Senator James A. Reed at the annual Jackson Day dinner here tonight.

Reynolds Forsbrey, murderer, house-breaker, jail-breaker, regarded two decades ago as "the most dangerous criminal in America," but paroled from Sing Sing prison last July by Governor Roosevelt as "completely rehabilitated," was arrested in Miami, Fla., yesterday with four companions for participation in a $5,000 hold-up in the Consolidated Ticket Offices.

Seventy-nine contributors brought the Neediest Cases Fund $1,674.69 nearer to last year's response yesterday. They wrote of their awareness that last year's total had been this year's objective, not as a numerical quota, but as the sum of the certified needs of actual cases.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- Final union of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America and the United Presbyterian Church of North America, embracing a total membership of 2,200,000, is expected in 1934, a joint committee on organic union announce here today in stating that "definite progress" had been made in the negotiations.
WASHNGTON, Jan. 8 -- In his speech at the Jackson Day dinner here tonight John W. Davis said:

Heavy buying of foreign bonds and domestic corporation issues, particularly in the case of the rails in the latter instance, caused advances yesterday that eclipsed even the substantial gains made on the days immediately previous. A long list of issues sold at the best prices in many weeks, and the losers for the day were comparatively few.

An early "showdown" on the 5cent fare issue, with Controller Charles W. Berry lined up against the policy supported by Mayor Walker and his transit advisers since his first election to office, was forecast yesterday as the result of the survey of city finances by leading banking houses at the Controller's request.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- Although suffering from a heavy cold, Big Bill Tilden of Philadelphia, world's professional tennis champion, defeated Albert (Pat) Burke of Ireland and France in the semi-final round of the Eastern professional tournament at Convention Hall today, 6 -- 1, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.

New features in automobile design and mechanism will be revealed with the opening at 2 P.M. today of the National Automobile Show in the Grand Central Palace. This major exposition of the industry, the thirtysecond one held annually in New York, will bring together approximately 300 different models, representing more than thirty makes of passenger cars, all of American manufacture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A treaty-limit navy was urged by Admiral Pratt before the Senate Naval Committee today. He declared that navy men "are not militarists, but no sane man believes war can be prevented altogether."
While business generally remains unsatisfactory, there are signs of improvement in spots, according to the weekly reviews of the commercial agencies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The plan to establish public defenders by law to defend accused poor persons, which I have been actively urging for nearly twenty years -- and which has encountered considerable opposition from time to time from bar groups in particular -- is now in the forefront of various proposed reforms in the criminal law.

The Roerich Museum on Riverside Drive opens privately today an exhibition of contemporary Japanese paintings, which will be available to the public, beginning tomorrow, until Feb. 9. It is expected that Katsuji Debuchi, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, and Mme.

The New Utrecht High School hockey team registered a 2-to-1 victory over Thomas Jefferson High in a P. S. A. L. contest at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The victory enabled New Utrecht to move into a tie for fourth position with Brooklyn Tech.

Establishment of a judicial council for New York State to facilitate cooperation between the Legislature and the courts in line with recommendations made by Presiding Judge Benjamin N. Cardozo of the Court of Appeals in 1921, and later by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, is advocated by the City Club of New York in a report just transmitted to the legislative committee which is investigating the administration of justice in the State.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Norman S. Taber, chairman of the Brown University Athletic Council, today announced that De Ormand (Tuss) McLaughry, head coach of football, would continue in that capacity. The possibility that McLaughry would go to Princeton University had been reported.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Financial operations of the Democratic National Committee in 1931 centred around the borrowing from and refinancing of loans to Chairman John J. Raskob and the County Trust Company of New York, of which Alfred E. Smith is chairman of the board and Mr. Raskob a director, according to a statement filed today with the clerk of the House by James W. Gerard, party treasurer.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- The British Empire building in Radio City will be a "little bit of the British Empire in the very centre of New York," according to Lord Southborough, head of the British syndicate which contracted for the building.

Striking members of four local unions of the International Brotherhood of Chauffeurs and Teamsters will return to work today pending arbitration of a 10 per cent wage reduction, according to an agreement signed by representatives of the union and of the Coal Merchants' Association last night in the office of Burns Brothers, 500 Fifth Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The news item in THE TIMES of Jan. 1, relating to calendar reform in the Supreme Court, New York County, permits the implication that the committee on law reform of the Association of the Bar claims credit for this improvement in practice.

The transit industry of the United States carried 14,212,362,000 passengers and took in revenues of $1,307,511,000 in 1931, according to a survey of electric railways, bus lines and organized taxicab systems throughout the country by the Transit Journal, formerly the Electric Railway Journal.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 8 (AP). -- The Kentucky Court of Appeals late today refused to force Judge Henry R. Prewitt to admit Knoxville NewsSentinel reporters to his court at Mount Sterling.

"You are going to be elected, 'ALBERT mine," sang the Baltimore choristers, and Governor RITCHIE'S Presidential boom was officially launched. Next week Governor ROOSEVELT of New York will be asked to say something definite to his North Dakota supporters so that they may enter him in their Presidential primary.

Columbia College has established fellowships which will enable graduating students of merit to continue their studies at either Oxford or Cambridge University, it was announced yesterday by the Columbia Alumni News. The new honors are known as the Euretta J. Kellett Fellowships and have an annual minimum stipend of $2,000.

Weather Handicaps Retail Trade. Retail trade during the week fell below expectations, largely because of weather conditions, reports from retail executives here yesterday indicated. Consumer purchasing started the week fairly briskly, but the handicap of two days of almost continuous rain was reflected in poor sales in most departments.

Nathan L. (Nigger Nate) Raymond, California gambler who was one of the principal witnesses in the murder inquiry into the murder of Arnold Rothstein in November, 1928, failed to appear for trial in General Sessions yesterday on a grand larceny and two forgery indictments, and his $7,500 bail was forfeited by Judge Corrigan.

The volume of retail trade in Canada is being maintained at a surprisingly stable level, if the general index of the retail sales of chain stores may be accepted as indicative of the total volume of the retail trade of the country, says the January letter of the Royal Bank of Canada.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Representative Horr of Washington charged today that "the Federal Radio Commission is one of the most extravagant and arbitrary of the government agencies."

Property known for many years as the Palliser tract, at Irvington, Westchester County, consisting of twenty-seven acres, has been acquired by an investor. The land was reported held at $50,000 and was sold through Kenneth Ives Co. It is near Sunnyaide Park close to the homes of Frederick R. Phillips and the M.S. Beltzhoover estate.

While crowds of men and women whose destitution had been certified by investigators clamored for food at the seventy-nine precinct offices of the Home Relief Bureau, it was disclosed that the abrupt suspension of the work of this bureau had developed strains in other quarters that had been assisting large numbers of needy families.

Ely Culbertson and his approachforcing bidding system emerged the victors in his 150-rubber contractbridge contest with Sidney Lenz, sponsor of the 1-2-3 system, when the month-long struggle came to its close at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria late last night.

James Branch Cabell, who announced that his novel, "The Way of Ecben," published in 1929, marked his final effort as a novelist, is back again among the creative writers. The famous American novelist, author of "The Silver Stallion," "Jurgen" and other well-known works, has written "These Restless Heads," which Robert McBride Co. will publish on Feb. 4.

Despite the export of $4,197,000 of gold to Europe yesterday, gold transactions reported by the Federal Reserve Bank showed a net gain of $7,209,000 to the country on the day. The rise was due to the receipt of $10,106,000 at San Francisco from the Orient and a drop of $1,300,000 in earmarked gold here.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 8 -- The United States decision to invoke the Nine-Power treaty was received with the greatest satisfaction at Nanking, where an optimistic view was taken of the Manchurian issue. It is admitted, however, that China wonders why the United States failed to take this step much earlier in the dispute.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Senate Finance Committee was told to day that $415,000 in commissions was paid to Juan Leguia, son of Augusto Leguia, former President of Peru for acting as agent in three loans to Peru totaling $100,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am so much in sympathy with the contention of the Rev. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the Church of the Ascension, that our churches should be open during the week with useful ministries, that I reluctantly point out an inference from the report of his address in THE TIMES of Jan. 6 that the churches are not concerned about homeless men and women.

Chancellor BRUENING has invited the cooperation of ADOLF HITLER in prolonging President HINDENBURG'S tenure of office and in postponing the Prussian elections. It is a move which lends itself equally well to interpretation as simple and natural or as charged with the deepest guile.

A total of 1,414 entries in 166 interests has been named for the forty-fifth Futurity, which will be run at Belmont Park in the Fall of 1934, according to announcement yesterday from Victor Schaumburg, racing secretary of the Westchester Racing Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When the repeated issues of greenbacks during the Civil War inflated the currency and forced up the price of gold, it became necessary to limit their issue and pledge the United States never to increase the amount.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8. -- A sevenyear career as a "physician and surgeon," which was interrupted on one occasion by service as a ditch digger for a Long Island subway operation, was ended here today for "Dr." Charles Borromeo Smith, 30 years old, who was arrested and held in $1,000 bail charged with practicing medicine without a license.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- General Charles Gates Dawes announced tonight that he would resign as Ambassador to Great Britain to take effect after the general and preliminary work of the disarmament conference has been completed at Geneva, where he will head the American delegation.

VIENNA, Jan. 8. -- The report of the Austrian National Bank for the end of 1931, issued today, shows that as a result of a decrease in holdings of foreign exchange and an increase in note circulation to the highest figure yet attained, the note issue cover has dropped to 24.2, only .2 of one per cent ahove the legal minimum' to keep Austria theoretically -on the gold standard.

Three gunmen, in a speeding sedan careened down Seventh Avenue last night pursued by two mounted policemen with drawn revolvers. The chase, which was begun following the hold-up of a cordial shop at Columbus Avenue near Eighty-fifth Street, ended suddenly when the bandits' rented car crashed into another on Fifty-third Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

Almeric Hugh Paget, wealthy British capitalist, who is Baron Queenborough, has been sued in the Supreme Court here by his American wife, Edith Starr Faget, for a separation on the grounds of cruelty, inhuman treatment and abandonment. The suit was disclosed yesterday when Lady Paget took steps to have a receiver appointed for property in this State owned by her husband as security for any award of alimony that may be made to her.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- America's picturesque statesman, Charles Gates Daves of the underslung pipe and vibrant language, has been mentioned in speculation over this year's Republican Presidential nominee. He put aside this speculation as "nonsense."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8 -- A blimp, an autogiro and an ordinary airplane joined today in an unscheduled feature event of the second day's program of the all-American air races, a rescue in the Everglades.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- President Hoover, in a new appeal for governmental retrenchment today, declared that "we cannot squander ourselves into prosperity."
Housing deals again provided the major part of the New Jersey realty activity reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Judge Ira E. Robinson, member of the Radio Commission from the Second Zone, tendered his resignation to the President today, effective Jan. 15. His term of office was to have expired on Feb. 23.

MOUNT STERLING, Ky., Jan. 8 (AP). -- A 19-year-old farm boy, who was plowing on a near-by hillside the day of the Evarts battle, bolstered the contention of William Hightower's attorneys today that deputy sheriffs fired first in the fight between jobless miners and deputy sheriffs.

An indictment charging perjury in his testimony before Referee Samuel Seabury at the recent Appellate Division investigation of the magistrates' courts, was returned yesterday by the grand jury against John C. Weston, 59 years old, former subpoena server and prosecutor in the Women's Court.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- The stock market today remained steady, with signs of a return to trading by the public, which for some time has practically abstained from any participation in the market. Toward the close there was a tendency to profit-taking on the part of professionals, but a slight decline did not cancel the gains at recent sessions of the Bourse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Admiral Richard H. Leigh, now commanding the Battle Force of the United States Fleet, was named today Commanderin-Chief of the fleet to succeed Admiral Frank H. Schofield, who will return to Washington as a member, probably president, of the General Board.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Secretary Stimson's note invoking the Nine-Power treaty in connection with the Manchurian affair is being studied by Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Minister. His reply to Washington is not expected before Sunday.

Senator NORRIS'S persistence is one of his many admirable qualities. For years that outrun memory the Senate has passed his joint resolution proposing the so-called "lameduck" amendment. With an equal but malicious regularity the House has burked it or monkeyed with its provisions.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 8 -- The Great Neck Free Church, the first church in that community, was ordered dissolved by an order of Supreme Court Justice Druhan filed in the County Clerk's Office here today, because it has no more parishioners.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 8. -- The diplomatic tension between Argentina and Uruguay appears to be lessening rapidly and the belief is growing that the incident of the Entre Rios revolt will be settled in a manner satisfactory to both countries.

Despite the widespread belief that the building industry is in serious straits, approximately $4,000,000,000 was projected in construction work in the United States during 1931, according to speakers who reported last night at the opening of a nation-wide drive for prosperity to be conducted weekly henceforth by radio.

HAVANA, Jan. 8 (AP) -- H.D. Bonesteel's Vacillate, 5-year-old daughter of Volta-Compose, accounted for the best offering of the seven-race program at Oriental Park today, a six-furlong dash for 4-year-olds and upward.

Bomar Cramer, a young Texas pianist who has studied under two scholarships at the Juilliard Music School with Josef Lhevinne, played a recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternon in which he demonstrated his skill in compositions ranging from Bach and Beethoven to the modernists, Scriabine and Ravel.

Sharing of jobs to prevent further discharge of workers is advocated by the American Engineering Council in a statement sent to engineer employment committees throughout the country. "Wherever there is a job it can be divided or shared," is suggested as a national emergency slogan.

The four-game winning streak of the Boys High School basketball team was brought to an end yesterday when it bowed to New Utrecht High five, 26-23, on the victor's court. Bill Wynne, left forward for the losers, annexed scoring honors with thirteen points.

Samuel Seabury charged at a public hearing of the Hofstadter committee yesterday that Charles W. Culkin, a prominent Tammany district leader, had embezzled more than $25,000 in interest on funds entrusted to his care as Sheriff of New York County. Mr. Seabury introduced a mass of documentary evidence to support his charge.

There was an unusually large attendance at the second, for this season of the Junior Assemblies, which took place last night at the Ritz-Carlton in a setting of Spring flowers. King Alfred jonquils and snapdragons combined with smilax decorated the ballroom and the balconies, each end of which was banked with woodwardia trees.

Heirloom jewelry valued at $25,000, which was stolen, buried for a time in Central Park, and subsequently entrusted to a man whose last address was the Municipal Lodging House, was held at Police Headquarters yesterday for return to the owner, Baxter L. Duke of 285 Riverside Drive.

Although the Stock Exchange call loan rate held at 2 1/2 per cent throughout the day, street trading went on at 2. House money was in good supply on the board, but bank funds were small. There was a fractional hardening in time money, to 3 3/4 to 4 per cent.

In a memorandum addressed to the Senate Committee on Finance the State Department reviews the record of the curiously informal and wholly extra-legal censorship which it has maintained for nearly ten years over loans by American banks to foreign governments and private interests.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The stock market today lost some of its recent firmness because of profit-taking, although the undertone in most sections was firm. Sterling exchange on New York opened higher at $3.42, but reacted to $3.40 3/4. British Government funds maintained yesterday's better tendency until sterling reacted, when the war loan dropped to L97.

Commodity prices were mixed in their trend yesterday, advances and declines being found in both cash and future trading. Cash grains, dairy products and lard were lower, but cotton and rubber improved. In futures, coffee and cocoa dropped, but sugar, rubber, silk and hides rose.
Fordney of Michigan. Among the members of Congress whose names go down in history and whose identity is clear, at least to contemporary newspaper readers, are tariff-makers.

The Republican women of the State will send three delegates at large to the Republican National Convention in Chicago, if a request embodied in a resolution to be submitted to W. Kingsland Macy is granted by the Republican State Chairman.

Gavin Brackenridge of the Princeton Club and R. Mason Kirkland of the New York A.C., sixth and eighth, respectively, in the national ranking, were eliminated from the Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club last night while Harry F. Wolf, the national champion from the N.Y.A. C., was winning his first match.
With only a few changes in fee ownership reported, realty trading in Manhattan yesterday was featured by leasehold deals.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8. -- "A brief for the defense, but not an impartial review of the case" was the general comment on the Wickersham committee findings in the Mooney case by San Francisco police and prosecutors.
The United States Golf Association, the game's controlling body in this country, will hold its annual meeting this morning, starting at 11 o'clock, at the Hotel Biltmore.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 -- State regulation of horse racing and the legalization of betting are sought in a bill filed with the Legislature today by Representative Eugene P. Durgin of South Boston. His proposed legislation would impose heavy taxes on race meetings, with the revenue thus derived to be employed in financing the old-age assistance act.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3 -- New York golfers won the major honors in the second round of match play for the Miami midwinter amateur championship over the Miami Country Club course today, representatives of the Empire State winning three of the four matches.

BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- Chancellor Heinrich Bruening continued today his conferences with Parliamentary leaders over the prospect of obtaining a constitutional majority in the Reichstag for an indefinite extension of President von Hindenburg's term in office.

DOYLESTOWN, Jan. 8. -- Stanley Wismer, a schoolboy and part-time farmhand, 14 years old, shot and killed his employer today to get an automobile to visit his ill mother in Hatfield, seventeen miles away. Ironically, he found after he had slain his employer and driven off in the car, that he did not know the route to Hatfield, and wound up at the home of a marrie step-sister in Lansdale, ten miles from Doylestown.

BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- It may now be safely taken for granted here that Chancellor Heinrich Bruening will definitely advise the creditor powers, which meet at Lausanne shortly to consider the debts-reparations question, that Germany's capacity to make further reparations payments is at an end.

Bank clearings for the first week of the new year were relatively higher than at the close of 1931. The total of $6,495,345,000 for twenty-two leading cities in the United States was, however, 40 per cent under that of a year ago. At New York the amount was $4,369,233,000, a reduction of 44.8 per cent, while the aggregate for cities outside of New York of $2,126,112,000 was 35 per cent smaller.

The aggregate of new municipal financing scheduled for award next week will show a sharp decline from this week's total. Forty-six communities throughout the country will enter the market with new bond and note issues totaling $7,834,810, compared with this week's volume of $21,238,358.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- While the reaction of the world powers to Secretary of State Stimson's note asserting United States rights in Manchuria was being awaited, intensive study of the government's declaration today in diplomatic circles here developed the opinion that an important step has been taken toward implementing the Kellogg-Briand anti-war treaty.

GENEVA, Jan. 8 -- The total of 26,000 troops which British observers informed the League of Nations Japan had in Manchuria on Jan. 1 is understood to have grown now to 50,000, according to a French report, which has not been made public here.

Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, by an unfinished run of 108, not only won his match last night, but also set a new high-run record for the State pocket-billiard championship at Dwyer's Broadway Academy.

For the third successive year, Jack Summers, coach at M.I.T. and former New England champion, captured the national professional squash racquets championship yesterday by defeating Dan Martella of the Wilmington Country Club, Wilmington, Del.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Hack Wilson, leading home-run hitter of the National League in 1930 and batting failure of last season, acquired recently from Chicago by the world's champions Cardinals, is this year's first big league hold-out.

WARSAW, Jan. 8 -- Prince Dimitri Ghica, the Rumanian Foreign Minister, arrived here this morning and began a two-days' conference with the Polish Government on the questions of a non-aggression pact with Russia and disarmament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover will be the guest of honor at a luncheon in New York City tomorrow of the Women's National Republican Club marking its anniversary.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 8 -- The Princeton varsity hockey team had little trouble defeating the Williams sextet tonight, 7 to 0. McAlpin, Tiger centre, scored two goals to lead his team to its first victory in five starts.

While the hero and heroine of "Electra" are preparing to avenge the murder of their father in the production staged at the Selwyn yesterday afternoon, it is possible for a theatregoer to meditate quietly on the uses of Greek tragedy in the modern American theatre.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Jan. 8 -- Led by Captain Jack Coey, centre, who tallied twelve points, the Glen Ridge High School basketball team posted its second victory of the season by defeating Hasbrouck Heights High today, 39 to 14.
MOSCOW, Jan. 8 -- The State grain collections for the Soviet Union have reached a figure of 103.1 per cent as compared with the amount collected by the same date a year ago, Pravda announces today.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 8. -- Charges by a sub-committee of the Wickersham Commission on Law Observance that the prosecution and police violated the law in the trial of Thomas J. Mooney in San Francisco in 1917 were revealed today when the report, previously withheld by the commission, was submitted to the Senate by Attorney General Mitchell.

The members and prospective members of Copper Exporters, Inc., at a meeting yesterday approved temporary rules under which the association will operate in January. The permanent rules, which were agreed to in principle in December, when producers reached an understanding on a curtailment program, were sent to counsel for drafting in final form.

Christopher (Bat) Battalino, Hartford Italian, failed yesterday to reach the featherweight poundage of 126 pounds at 2 o'clock and forfeited his world's featherweight title, it was announced by Secretary Bert Stand of the State Athletic Commission.

PARIS, Jan. 8. -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, who has been liaison officer between London and Paris in preparation for the Lausanne reparations conference, arrived in Paris this evening and will continue his conversations tomorrow with the technical advisers of the French Government and with Finance Minister P. E. Flandin which began before Christmas.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Officials of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad announced today that 4,500 men employed in its mechanical department had accepted voluntarily a 10 per cent reduction in wages, effective on Jan. 15.

OCEAN GROVE, N. J., Jan. 8. -- Newark South Side High rolled up a 61-to-32 score against Neptune High on the Neptune court today. It was the third straight victory for South Side, which is "ndefeated. Goldsatten, left forward, scored 31 points for the winners.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 8 -- Nineteen new petitions for injunctions (amparos) against the Federal religious law were filed today by Catholic priests, bringing the total so far to thirty-one. In church circles it was said that up to 300 petitions might be filed, five or six at a time, giving a forecast of protracted litigation in the church's fight against the limitation and registration of priests.

Supreme Court Justice Strong in Brooklyn denied yesterday an application for a mandamus order requiring the Board of Transportation to file plans with the Board of Estimate for the construction of a subway to Whitestone, L.I. The court held that it was without authority to issue the order, but acknowledged "the extreme necessity of immediate and favorable action by the Board of Transportation.''

The criminal and the "so-called rich and fashionable" classes drink most of the liquor consumed in the United States, Miss Bertha Rembaugh, trustee of the New York State Women's Committee for Law Enforcement, said last night in a debate on prohibition with Mrs. Courtlandt Nicoll, national vice chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

King Knaubale of Ubangi arrived here yesterday with several of his queens. He came on a theatrical tour, which unfortunately got off to a bad start. In fact, the first local performance was a free one; it took place on Ellis Island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Allocation of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad to the New York Central Lines as proposed in the four-system plan for the East, was essential if the Central was to continue the service now provided to communities on its lines, Patrick E. Crowley, its former president, informed the Interstate Commerce Commission today at a hearing on the proposal.

Again outscoring his opponent in the second block of their 900-point challenge match for the national amateur 18.2 balkline championship at the New York A.C., Edgar T. Appleby of New York last night defeated Ray V. Fessenden of Madison, Wis., 300 to 229, in thirty-four innings.

Evidence of graft in Coast Guard stations on the outer Long Island shore has been gathered by investigators of the department under Rear Admiral F.C. Billard in Washington and four men have been courtmartialed and a score of men are under arrest awaiting trial, it was announced yesterday.
HONOLULU, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Joseph Kahahawl was kidnaped today and killed.

Columbia oarsmen of the past five years, who rowed in some of the greatest Blue and White crews in the history of the Morningside Heights institution, are planning to assemble at Poughkeepsie next June to train for the Olympic trials.

THERE are some Important matters that should bE considered by the officials of the United States Golf Association when they assemble for the annual meeting today. A sweeping revision is necessary in some departments of the game.

The nominating committee of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday nominated H.H. Pike Jr. for a second term as president. Frank C. Russell was nominated for a second, term as vice president and Earl B. Wilson was nominated for treasurer to succeed David E. Fromm.

HONOLULU, Jan. 8. -- Mrs. Granville Fortescue, prominent socially in New York and Washington; Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie of the United States Navy, her son-in-law, and E.J. Lord, an enlisted man of the navy, were arrested today on a charge of kidnapping and murdering Joseph Kahahawai, a Hawaiian youth this morning.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted.

The proposed amendment to the sanitary code to permit Grade B milk pasteurized after 9 P.M. one day to be labeled as if pasteurized the following day would be unfair to distributers of milk pasteurized in the country, it was declared by some of the witnesses yesterday at the open hearing conducted by the Board of Health on the proposal.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Senate today made rapid progress in considering the administration's $2,000,000,000 reconstruction finance corporation bill.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Stephanite, 5-year-old brown son of Stephen the Great-Thimble and an even-money favorite, today won the feature race at Jefferson Park, a $700-claiming event at a mile and a sixteenth for 3-year-olds and upward.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- The Cathedral Boys High School basketball team, which is setting the pace in the Manhattan division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association with an undefeated record, turned back the Iona School five, 28 -- 12, today for its fourth straight triumph in the league.
Tolentine High School of the Bronx scored its tenth straight victory of the season yesterday at the Seventyfirst Regiment Armory, defeating Dwight School, 24-9.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- The action of wheat today on the Board of Trade here in the face of the strong rally in the stock market was disappointing to the trade. The East put sufficient wheat into the market at the start to prevent any tendency to show strength, and while holders of bids bought on the break, as did houses that were sellers yesterday, the close was 3/8 to 1/2 cent lower.

Robust advances occurred on the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon, but the market was hesitant in the early dealings and for a time displayed sagging tendencies. The total volume was about 2,000,000 shares, against slightly less than 2,200,000 shares on the day before.
Brisk advances in leading stocks and bonds occurred on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday. The undertone of the market was firm throughout the list, many issues rallying 1 to 3 points.

Maria Carreras, pianist, who has not been heard here for three years, appeared in recital last night at Carnegie Hall. Her program included four transcriptions from Bach, two by A. Kelberine, presented here for the first time, and two by Bussoni; Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 31, No. 2; the Mozart-Siloti Variations, "Ah, vous dirai-je, maman"; Chopin's Sonata, Op. 58; Liszt-Siloti's "Benediction de Dieu dans la Solitude" and Busoni's transcription of Liszt's "Mephisto Waltz."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Maintain ing that the "stringency" of the Vol stead act had transformed America into a nation of hard-liquor drinkers. Professor Yandell Henderson of Yale University and Dr. Charles Norrls. Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, declared that beer drunk in normal quantities was harmless to students.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 8. -- Adolfo Costa Du Rels has been appointed delegate to the disarmament conference in Geneva. Senor Costa was many years Counselor of the Bolivian Legation in Paris and delegate to the League of Nations. Lieut. Col. Luis Serrano will complete the delegation as military counselor.

RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- Major Norris A. Clowes, who was a widely known editor of daily newspapers in Manhattan and Brooklyn for more than a half century, died at the home of his granddaughter, Mrs. George W. Young, today at the age of 91.

After a heated argument in which Samuel Seabury denounced State Senator John A. Hastings as "a paid and bought agent of private interests seeking favors from the City Government," Supreme Court Justice Druhan in Brooklyn refused yesterday to modify his temporary order restraining the Hofstadter committee from certifying Senator Hastings for contempt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The text of ex-Governor Smith's address at the Jackson Day dinner, sent out on the air over a National Broadcasting Company network, was as follows:

The Five O'clock Club at 151 West Fifty-fourth Street, one of the most fashionable night clubs in the midtown part of the city, was raided, the manager and five employes arrested and about 250 men and women patrons, all in evening dress, ordered to disperse late last night after evidence had been gathered in an unusual fashion by a policeman attached to the staff of Inspector Thomas Walsh.

The Japanese Room of the St. Regis was crowded last night for the annual supper dance for the benefit of the Prosperity Shop, an institution at 1,279 Third Avenue which, through, the sale of various articles, aids the work of several philanthropies.

Five receivership orders in foreclosure proceedings were signed in the Supreme Court yesterday, the largest being in a suit of Liberman Brothers Corporation against Kedansky and Levy, Inc., and Edward Kaye and A. Morris Levy, on a lease of the property at 424 Madison Avenue, at the southwest corner of Forty-ninth Street.

United States. WEIGHT CLERK -- Applications must be on file not later than Jan. 27. A vacancy in the position in the Navy Yard, Brooklyn, N.Y., at $2,000 a year and vacancies occurring in that vicinity in positions requiring similar qualifications, at approximately the same rate of pay, will be lled from this examination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (NANA) -- One of the greatest athletes ever turned out by West Point will take command of that institution next May, when Major Gen. William Durwood Connor relieves Major Gen. William R. Smith.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The text of former Governor James M. Cox's address at the Jackson Day banquet tonight was as follows:

Recommendations for drastic changes in the New York State banking law, calculated to make unnecessary the wholesale closing of banks with slow assets, were presented yesterday by J. Stewart Baker, president of the New York State Bankers' Association, at the midwinter meeting of the association in the auditorium of the Federal Reserve Bank.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Jan. 8 -- Bucknell opened its basketball season with a 35-to-32 victory over Western Maryland tonight.

Indoor polo, both in Manhattan and Brooklyn, faces the most interesting evening of the new season, tonight. The 10-goal Winston Guest and his Optimists return to action at Squadron A in Manhattan, opposing the always interesting Pennsylvania Military College team in its first metropolitan appearance of the season, and the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn is the scene of two games in which stars appear.

The decrease in factory workers employed in New York State in December, slightly more than 1 per cent, would not be especially significant in normal circumstances. Industrial Commissioner Frances Perkins said yesterday in explaining a monthly report on the subject issued by her department.

The fifth national merchant marine conference will be held in the United States Chamber of Commerce Building in Washington on Jan. 27 and 28, it was announced here yesterday. The agenda of the conference, which includes reports and discussions of matters pertaining to foreign competition, government aid, legislation, the coastwise and intercoastal situation, competition of government marine services with privately owned lines and other matters, have been approved by the United States Shipping Board.

A service in observance of the bicentennial of George Washington, will he held tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine under the auspices of the General Citizens' Committee and the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 8 -- New six and seven furlong track records were set at Tropical Park today as Jockey Hank Mills scored another triple to bring his total number of winners at the meeting to twenty-two. Three of the seven favorites won, all at odds-on, but two other odds-on choices met defeat.
MUKDEN, Jan. 8 -- Washington's new diplomatic venture in regard to the status of Manchuria has been received in Mukden with general dismay.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 8 -- Colonel Robert R. McCormick, owner of The Chicago Tribune, today left the Breakers, where he has been stopping, for Miami to attend the air meet. Tomorrow he will fly to Nassau to spend a short time before departing for Chicago.

Sales by dealers of the General Motors Corporation to consumers in the United States totaled 53,588 cars in December, compared with 34,673 in November. The total for December, 1930, was 57,989 cars. For the twelve months of 1931, sales to consumers were 937,537 cars, compared with 1,057,710 in 1930.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Controller General James H. McCarl in a report to Congress today, severely criticized the Shipping Board and the Merchant Fleet Corporation for what he characterized as unwarranted expenditures, the free gift of supplies, equipment and stores valued at about $982,321.70 to purchasers of vessels, including the Leviathan, George Washington, Republic and President Harding.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 8 -- Baron Long, one of Agua Caliente's triumvirate of horse owners, told today how he engineered yesterday's betting coup on the track here which resulted in sorrow to many Eastern and Northern bookmakers.

BOMBAY, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The government of India stiffened its policy still further today by promulgation of a new ordinance empowering judges to pass any sentence, including the sentence of death, upon any person convicted of disobeying the series of emergency orders recently enacted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Diverse ideas on unemployment relief were advanced here today by the leading representatives of American labor and one of the foremost employers of labor. William Green called upon the Federal and State Governments for appropriations to provide work.

The Seventh Regiment basketball team made an auspicious start in Eastern Athletic Club League play by upsetting the Penn A.C. of Philadelphia, 33 to 28, at the winner's court last night. It was the opening circuit game for both teams.

Stocks and bonds improved their position further yesterday in circumstances that indicated that fresh impulses to the advance were being supplied. The upturn in the share market on the Stock Exchange developed in the afternoon after many of the issues had marked time for two or three hours, but the net advances were large in fifteen or twenty stocks.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 9. -- The Emperor returned all the Cabinet resignations to Premier Inukai today and commanded him to remain in office.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Governor Roosevelt announced today that soon after his executive budget bill has been placed before the Legislature, he would invite the Republican leaders to join him in a round-table conference to discuss the fiscal program of the session.

A Cricketer In India. THE world may be doubtful whether "Over the Hill to the Poorhouse" or "Around the Corner to Prosperity" is in rehearsal, but thus far in the year the most gigantic dramatic production is even now beyond Hollywood 'Superlatives.

The continued thaw of the past week yesterday forced Joseph K. Savage, chairman of the Olympic speed-skating committee, to cancel the final Olympic tryouts at Newburgh today and to shift to Albany the trials which were to have determined the men who will bear the American shield at Lake Placid next month.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Twenty-seven games are on the Spring schedule of the Philadelphia Athletics, it was announced at Shibe Park today.

AN eminent financier, whose acceptance or refusal of a national or international finance proposition influenced the immediate destinies of nations, in talking with his insurance broker about his personal coverage, laughingly remarked:

TURNING the pages of history back for a century and a quarter, we find that the efforts of pioneers to build and operate steam-driven motor vehicles in England were immediately hampered by legislation requiring that a man on foot carrying a red lantern by night and a red flag by day should precede each horseless vehicle driven on the public highway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Declaring that it is time "for the Hoover men to stand up and be counted," Senator Moses has filed for candidacy as a delegate at large to the Republican National Convention "pledged to Hoover."

GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 9. -- John J. Raskob has bought the old Hedgepeth and Cheek places, comprising 1,600 acres in the Deep River section of Moore County, best known for the Pinehurst development, it was announced today by agents. The price is not disclosed.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt recorded a plurality of more than two to one over his nearest opponent as the outstanding candidate for Presdent in a poll of the senior class of the College of the City of New York, the results of which were made public yesterday.
MONTREAL, Jan. 9. -- Outplayed in the first period, the Maroons swept from behind to beat the New York Americans 4 to 2 in a National Hockey League game tonight.

HONOLULU, Jan. 9. -- An ominous calm prevailed in Honolulu today following the kidnapping and killing yesterday morning of Joseph Kahahawai and the arrest of Mrs. Granville R. Fortescue and her son-in-law, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, U. S. N.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Bank debits outside New York City for the holiday week ended Jan. 2 were less than in both the preceding week and the same week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

To laymen the address, reprinted in The American Historical Review, of Professor CARL BECKER of Cornell as president of the American Historical Association is meat and drink. He makes "Every Man His Own Historian." He shows that we are the greatest of history clubs, the models and masters of the professionals.

DEMANDS of motor truck users for new units to replace wornout equipment will be very insistent with the revival of business activity in general. The return of normal business conditions will result in output equal to the banner years immediately preceding 1929, when the peak was reached.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP). -- The erection, of government buildings in the Federal building program will go on without check until 1934 at least, despite the slashing of $100,000,000 oft the construction program by the Budget Bureau.
LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 9 (AP). -- A mail pouch containing $99,100 in currency, several packages of valuable jewelry and a bundle of securities was recovered by postal inspectors and Lowell police today.

THE program, promulgated early last year by the board of directors of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce to change the taking of inventories from Winter to Summer, with a corresponding change from Summer to Winter for new model announcements, has potential benefits that extend far beyond the automobile Industry itself.

Perversion of ideas on economic questions is no knew phenomenon in such times as these. The "free-silver-coinage" infatuation of 1894, the clamor of 1874 for reversion to fiat money, were as essentially a part of the history of those hard times as were the fall in prices and the spread of unemployment.

PHILADEPHIA, Jan. 9. -- Staging one of his old-time rallies, Bill Tilden of Philadelphia tonight won the final in the Eastern professional tennis tourney in Convention Hall by beating the young German title-holder, Hans Nusslein.

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- After completing what was generally characterized as a fairly satisfactory Christmas business, local department stores are now having their usual January clearing sales. It is reported that the volume of business is somewhat below a year ago.

BERLIN, Dec. 28. -- If a German Prince these days is not to be a square peg in a round hole he must, in a manner of speaking, unprince himself. Thus, Prince Christopher of Hesse, nephew of the former Emperor, runs an auto sales shop in Berlin.
HONOLULU, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Nervous women kept the doors of their homes locked here today as authorities took steps to deal with the case of the slaying of Joseph Kahahawai, a young Hawaiian yesterday.

AT intervals, the Advisory Committee on Spoken English of the British Broadcasting Corporation submits lists of word pronunciations for its radio announcers. The committee's latest recommendations follow:

BIRTH-CRIES of new matter in the process of creation, says Millikan of the cosmic rays. Death-rattle of matter comitting suicide as it radiates itself way, insists Jeans. Einsteinians ingle their voices in the controversy to advance the romantically rresting suggestion that the rays re relics of the remote past -- ghosts hat wander aimlessly in a closed, elativistic universe, trying to tell us the story of creation.
IN a foreword to this book Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was Assistant Secretary of the Navy during the World War, sums up Robley D. Evans in one striking sentence:

WHERE are certain self-appointed economists who would have us believe that the real cause of the depression is the too rapid progress of civilization. Too many luxuries, they say, are within the reach of too many people.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Repudiation or chaos is the world's choice, Alexander Shaw, a director of the Bank of England and deputy chairman of the Peninsular and Oriental Steamship Line, declared today in discussing the war debts and reparations.

The longest meeting in the history of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association came to a close at the Hotel Vanderbilt last night with a sweeping victory for the regular ticket of "The Committee of 100" in the election of officers and delegates for 1932.

PARIS. LITERARY prizes have their partisans and enemies in France, as elsewhere. The partisans Insist that the resulting controversies and the Interest taken by the newspapers draw to books a public which ordinarily would neglect them.
HISTORY has a curious way of repeating itself, of restating old problems under new conditions, and of demanding always the same constant attention to fundamental laws of conduct.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 -- Death from a heart attack came to Frederick O'Brien, author, lecturer, traveler and former newspaper man, in his home at Sausalito today. He was 62 years old.

THE return of La Argentina for her fourth season in New York has brought with it such a full measure of success as to give pause to those whose experience with American audiences has led them to prophesy that it could not be done. Three years, it hae besn said, is the limit for any dancer unless some sort of change in the type of program is introduced.

In finding in favor of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway and others against the Arizona Grocery Company in a decision announced Monday the United States Supreme Court established what was described in railroad circles as an important restriction on the Interstate Commerce Commission in regard to awarding reparations to shippers for charges levied under tariffs which the commission had found reasonable.

Founded by three brothers who were formerly in the employ of the Federal Government, a new organization which specializes in all "departmental prohibition matters," dispensing service and advice at the rate of $100 a year to each of its clients, was revealed yesterday in the investigation of bail-bond runners, solicitors for attorneys, and selfstyled fixers, begun last week by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney.

A smartly schooled New York University basketball team repulsed a stubborn Georgetown University quintet, 26 to 18, at the 102d Engineers Armory last night. It was the winners' third victory in four starts this season. N.Y.U. gained an early lead, which it maintained throughout the battle.

CHANGED though it may be from the actual career of Mata Hari, the Dutch dancer and spy, the picture that bears her name which is now attracting hosts to the Capitol is an entertainment of no mean value in which that mysterious actress, Greta Garbo, gives another flawless portrayal.

COPENHAGEN. RARELY has the low ceiling been used so dramatically and effectively in offering pleasure to the eye as in the entrances and stairways of the "Nye Scene" in the Danish capital. This new building for the theatre and the radio has recently been opened as an "annex" to the old Royal Theatre with its venerable architectural and historic traditions.

The collection of "Paintings From Knole," shown by courtesy of Lord Sackville, goes on view today at Averell House, 142 East Fifty-third Street. The exhibition is being held for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Aid and will be current for ten days.

Mrs. Marius de Brabant gave a dance last night at her home, 7 East Fifty-first Street, for Miss Lucile Thornton Thieriot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot, who was introduced to society in the Autumn at a large dance given by her parents at their home on Long Island.

PARIS, Jan. 8. -- Paris social activities have not been at such a low ebb for a long time. The world-wide economic and political uncertainties are reflected in the rare gatherings where fashionable folk meet. But New Year's Eve celebrations, while not as uproarious as hitherto, still showed traces of the old-time gayety.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- The December report of County Register Arthur Maudlin, made public today, shows a drop in mortgages but an increase in deeds filed. Last December 1,208 deeds were filed, in comparison with 1,161 in December, 1930.

Now that Missouri's Congressional reapportionment act has been held invalid by the State's highest court, on something of the same ground on which a similar decision by the Court of Appeals of New York was based, it is certain that the United States Supreme Court must deal with tangled aspects of the question.

THROUGHOUT eighteen years of experience in the equipment manufacturing field of the motor industry, I have never ceased to marvel at the ingenuity of automotive engineers in, year after year, adding fresh and appealing new improvements that make for greater comfort, increased safety, longer life and better values.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 9. -- The Montclair Athletic Club basketball team won its first Eastern Athletic Club League game of the season by defeating the Penn A. C., 28 to 20, on its home floor tonight.

CERTAIN wholesome and highly commendable developments have grown out of the past two years of genual business dullness, all of whlch should have a 'favorable reaction on the potential market for 1932.

MODERN roads and modern cars combine to reduce the fatigue of driving. One of the greatest joint accomplishments of present-day road builders and automobile manufacturers has been to make it possible to drive with much less nerve strain than formerly.

LONDON. PEOPLE who keep their savings in stockings or other hiding places are, causing considerable worry to bankers and governments at present, for hoarding, often prevalent in times of depression, slows up the wheels of trade.

THE storm of unrest long brewing in India has broken at last, and the country is faced by a crisis as dangerous as it is dramatic. The outstanding fact concerns Mabatma Gandhi. For the fourth time in his career he has been placed under arrest as a political prisoner.

DETROIT, Jan. 7. -- The Democratic party in Michigan is so weak that, although it puts a full ticket in the field every two years, it elects a Governor about once in a quarter-century and then usually because of a factional fight among Republicans. But this year the leaders are hopeful of victory, for they sense a general dissatisfaction with Republican rule among the voters, due to hard times and high taxes.

Agents of Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator, who announced when he took office on July 1, 1930, that New York State could be mopped up and dried, arrested last year more than twice as many persons as had been arrested in 1930 and seized four times as many gallons of liquor.

NEW YORK traffic control is evolving into a machine like a well-oiled, finely adjusted watch. The impression of a cheap alarm clock, noisy and erratic, still is strong. But the system actually gets more civilized. Measurements of clangor show fewer decibels bashing eardrums.

No material change occurred last week in the amount of bonds called for redemption in January or future months before their maturity dates, the volume remaining small, as in the previous two weeks. The total for this month is now $70,336,000, compared with $21,856,000 called in December, and $57,372,000 redeemed in January, a year ago, at similar dates.

Rare Oriental paintings, sculptures of the early Bronze Age and ancient Greece, and works by contemporary sculptors and painters will be offered at auction next Friday afternoon and evening and Saturday afternoon, when the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., will dispose of the art collections of H. Barstow Farr of New York and of his mother-in-law, Mrs. Chauncy Blalr of Chicago and Chambesy, Switzerland.

DIRT and waste are especially abhorrent to Henry Ford. The thousands of letters that he repeives from crank inventors with new ideas about cheap automobiles, from beggars who plead for anything from ten to a million dollars and from jealers in antiques who want to stock the Ford museum at a price, go through the pulp mill and are ultimately converted into cardboard in Which the smaller parts of his automobiles are wrapped and sold.

TWENTT years ago tomorrow the board of trustees of Princeton elected Dr. John Grier Hibben, then Stuart Professor of Logic, to the office of President of the university. That evening many of the students gathered in the tap room in old Nassau Tavern; between choruses of "Old Nassau" and "The Orange and the Black" they chanted a swinging tune with words that run like this:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9 -- Yale's wrestling season was opened today in the gymnasium when the Varsity defeated the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 21 1/2 to 8 1/2. points, and the freshmen scored a 28-to-10 decision over their Tech class rivals.

The hard-skating Crescent Athletic Hamilton Club hockey team continued undefeated in the Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League, beating the St. Nicholas Hockey Club, 3-0, last night in the New York Coliseum before 2,500 spectators.

Further improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday advanced May contracts to the highest figure recorded since the latter part of November, but week-end realizing in the final trading left the list unchanged to 3 points higher than on Friday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9. -- In winning the 220-yard swim this afternoon in the Carnegie swimming pool during the annual swimming competition between the Yale Freshmen and the New Haven High School, Robert Johnson of the high school team made the fastest time for the distance ever recorded in a Yale class meet.

The audience which attended the concert given by the Kedroff Quartet last night in the Town Hall listened to the unique performance with a pleasure not the less pronounced for the fact that they are now an accustomed experience but also with regret occasioned by the announcement on the program sheet that the ouartet's present tour of America, which is its fifth, is its "farewell" for an indefinite period to the United States and Canada.
FOLLOWING its usual holiday cat-nap the art season has resumed activities with cosiderable verve, providing us with a week of openings extremely varied in theme and lively in interest.

THE automobiles brought out for this year are probably more complete than any in preceding seasons, manufacturers having directed every effort to include In their products a great variety of improvements designed to provide better performance and higher speeds with economy in operatlon.

ALBANY. THE 962' miles of highways built in New York State during the 1931 season cost approximately $58,000,000, and it was the best season, so far as real accomplishment is concerned, of any year since the State took over the construction of roads.

THE coral and amber forests at the bottom of the West Indies, where J. E. Williamson has spent the better part of two decades photographing the weird flora and fauna of a world strange to men, will once more give up their secrets for the motion picture camera.

BUFFALO, Jan. 7. -- The older School of transportation students this city feel some elation over the record made by the Barge Canal in the season of 1931. It is considered significant that in a year when nearly all other business has decline heavily canal traffic has increased.

PRICE recessions, intanoe competition and the paradoxical situation, of greater car mileage with fewer tire replacements were the major factors responsible for the tire Industry's not coming up to expectations during 1931. The year ended with the smaller tire-manufacturing companies making a relatively better showing from the Standpoint of profits than the larger concerns.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- Unless the United States have a share in it the conference on reparations will be a meeting of debtor nations. The problem of German payments, after the first preliminary squabble, will recede into the background anyhow, because no money is to be obtained from that quarter.

DESPITE the expenditure of large sums by foreign governments to subsidize private flying, this category of American aeronautics, as distinguished from commercial and military flying, leads the world. While the development and training of private fliers has been a hindrance, rather than a help, to British, French, Italian and other foreign aviation, amateur and sport flying in America has grown independent of other branches of aviation and now occupies an important place in the industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP). -- A Senate committee today concluded hearings on proposals for direct Federal unemployment relief with scores of recommendations for government aid, but with the word of Walter Gifford, President Hoover's relief director, that it is not necessary.

FIFTY jinrikishas were delivered to the Paramount studios in Hollywood on two hours' notice last week. If the order had been for a fleet of 1932 custom-built automobiles or airplanes, Babylonian chariots, medieval wagons. Eskimo sledges or African kiddle cars, the chances are it would have been filled at any major studio with equal dispatch.

BOSTON. TWO big tunnel jobs, a comprehensive street widening plan and extension of the existing centrally controlled automatic traffic light signal system were the major items in Boston's traffic control plans during the year 1931.

HELSINGFORS. BY day the Baltic is an honest Lutheran sea, devoted to fish, fog and freights, but at night it ceases to be Lutheran and becomes a dark playground of scurrying rats and tom cats on the prowl.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9. -- S.J. Wittman, a tall, scholarly looking engineer from Oshkosh, took first honors for the all-American air meet today with his little home-made racing plane. Flying in two races, between which his engine hardly had time to cool, he set up the fastest time of the meet, 166.9 miles an hour, and flew away from all competitors.

Contending that continued liquidation is not essential to general business recovery, Dr. Frederick C. Mills, professor of economics and statistics at Columbia University, yesterday urged a program of positive economic action to support the general price structure, involving a bond issue for public works and more aggressive open market operations by the Federal Reserve Banks.

A week from tomorrow will mark the opening of the 1932 dog show season, which, if present plans of clubs throughout the country are carried out, will be another gala campaign of high-class exhibitions.

SURVEYING the fabuloua material resources of these United States, Herbert N. Casson, a London editor, says: "This silly business depression is in your heads." There is so much truth in this diagnosis that it hurts. Undoubtedly, we shall go forward as soon as we decide to go.
