Exceptionally heavy buying during the early days of the furniture trade opening in Chicago last week is believed by producers to have eliminated any possibility of a price break in the industry this season. Manufacturers, it was pointed out, are so heavily committed by orders received through the unexpected demand which developed at the market that it would be ruinous for them to reduce quotations now.

THE first book mentioned above is a reduced and popularized version of the second. Both relate the fascinating story of the reconstruction of the now famous Temple of the Warriors in the ruined Maya city of Chichen Itza, Yucatan. No archaeologist concerned with the American field can afford to be unfamiliar with the second book.
THE experiences, thirty-three years apart, of two men called at factories to take delivery of at automobiles and drive them home offer clear-cut illustrations of the advances made in motor cars.

WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART -- Second exhibition, devoted to watercolors, prints and drawings. Opened Jan. 5, closes Feb. 4. General review of tendencies on last Sunday's art page, briefly noticed on the day of the opening.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 9. -- The steamer St. John, built for the Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc., at a cost of $3,500,000 was launched this morning at the Tewport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company's plant.

THE radiophone pushed ahead in 1931 by stringing many new wires and invisible waves around the globe. To the links existing in the beginning of 1931, by which more than 30,000,000 telephone subscribers in North and South America, Europe, Australia, Java and French India could hold transoceanic speech with each other, have been added other links, mostly supplemental in character but called epochal in the history of communications.

This is Presidential election year and it began in an atmosphere of politics. A thick fog of oratory, booms and prohibition reform plan hung over Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington. The occasion was a called meeting of the Democratic National Committee, just after the election of W.N. Rogers as a Damocratic Representative in Congress from the First New Hampshire District.

All the nations of the world that make any motion pictures at all contribute their quota to New York screens. The film fan can leap from Spain to Italy, jump across to England, get an eyeful of Germany, run over Russia and drop down to far-away New Zealand without actually leaving Manhattan or making any outlay beyond modest admission prices and subway fares.

To the Editor of The New York Times: IN his article on American art of Jan. 3 Albert Sterner complains that Mr. Kootz has committed the grievous Bin of discrimination in listing America's genuine artists. Mr. Sterner says that in this list there is "an utterly unwarranted inclusion and exclusion" of artists, and yet Mr. Kootz in his book, "Modern American Painters," has very well warranted their selection.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Bat Battalino can grow into another Primo Camera if he wants to but he will be recognized as world's feather-weight champion by the National Boxing Association for another four months at least.

THE unexpected events in Manchuria now attracting worldwide attention have invested this scholarly book by the president of the Brookings Institution at Washington with the timeliness which never entered the mind of its author.
LONDON, Jan. 9. -- The British Government decided today it was not necessary to follow the lead of the United States and send a note to Tokyo about the observance of the Nine-Power treaty.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- A concurrent resolution petitloning Congress to call a constitutional convention to consider repeal or modification of the Eighteenth Amendment was approved today for adoption by the 1932 Legislature, which convenes Tuesday, at a caucus of the Republican Senate majority here.
DESPITE a number of adverse circumstances confronting the American automobile exporter, the optimist in search of favorable trade prospects abroad for 1932 will not go altogether unrewarded.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- The Bourse ended a satisfying week by maintaining yesterday's advance. Although there was a slight retrogression at the close, due to profit-taking by speculators, final quotations generally showed substantial advances. The improvement here was partly a reflection of the good day in Wall Street yesterday, but it is noted that the advances were made despite uncertainty over the political situation and a further drop in sterling exchange.

CHICAGO. THE lot of the motorist in Cook County, of which the Chicago metropolitan area comprises the major part, was markedly improved in the pact year by the accomplishments of numerous agencies controlling highway construction and traffic regulation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Wheat made a firm start and a weak finish today on the Board of Trade here. Scattered buying was in evidence at first, and the action of stocks had some effect, but an upturn of 5/8 cent ran into hedging sales. As the outside trade was not large a break of 1 3/8 to 1 1/2 cents from the best figures followed.

SIR WILLIAM HENRY BEVERIDGE, director of the London School of Economics, will be the speaker in the international broadcast from London listed for 12:30 P. M. today over WABC and associated stations. Sir William will speak on "The Economic Outlook for 1932."

NECESSITY is usually spoken of as a hard master, but the motor car shows of 1932 will demonstrate that, today at least. necessity has singled out the car buyer as a beneficiary of engineering and manufacturing thought and action.

It is evident that America, together with the countries of Western Europe, is adjusting itself to economic necessities following the war period. That all persons may expect to share in the adjustment is certain. Retrenchment may become the favorite sport of Legislatures.

AN enterprise upon which the Behavior Research Fund and the Institute for Juvenile Research of Chicago are jointly engaged may quite possibly be an important factor in the revolution that begins to seem inevitable in the attitude of society toward crime, criminals and punishment.
Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee sought yesterday to learn whether interest on official funds found its way into Sheriff Thomas F. Farley's "wonderful tin box."

YEAR by year the vogue for Winter sports has been growing in the United States. And this year a climax is reached. Between Feb. 4 and 13 the 1932 Winter Olympic Games -- a frozen companion to the international contest at Los Angeles next Summer -- will be held at Lake Placid.

PARIS, Jan. 8. -- War Minister Andre Maginot's death has removed from French political life not only one of its pivotal but one of its most sympathetic figures. Among his colleagues Maginot was physically a giant, and If he had some of those weaknesses which Napoleon asserted was inherent in all big men he had also many of the finest qualities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- A heavy preponderance of sentiment for Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President is shown by Interviews with members of the Democratic committee here today.

IT is estimated from all available information that the number of persona killed in motor vehicle accidents in 1931 was approximately 34,500. This represents an increase of 5 per cent above the number killed in such accidents in 1930 end an increase of 163 per cent over the number killed in similar accidents in 1920.

The demand for crude oil, Including natural gasoline and benzol, in November was 78,907,000 barrels, compared with 78,606,000 barrels in November, 1930, an increase of 0.4 per cent, according to a compilation by William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist, from data of the United States Bureau of Mines.

A huge public works program throughout the nation of four to six billion dollars within the next year and a half appears to be entirely feasible, in the opinion of a group of economists who met in this city recently at the request of William Randolph Hearst, it was announced yesterday, when the report of the meeting was made public.

More than 20,000 unemployed men and women, ranging in age from 18 to 60 years, were retrained for new trades and occupations during 1931 in the city's continuation schools, with the result that many of them have obtained jobs previously closed to them, Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and continuation centres, announced yesterday.

WHEN he fouled Max Schmeling into a world's heavyweight championship at the Yankee Stadium. Jack Sharkey received his full share of the purse. This was because the Boxing Commission, at the request or demand of the Schmeling forces, had waived the commission rule that a fighter who fouls out shall be paid only part of his purse, a proportionate deduction to be made for the rounds not fought due to the soul.

Katsuji Debuchi, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, called this country and Japan "partners and not rivals in the trade of the Pacific" in an address yesterday afternoon at the opening of an exhibition of contemporary Japanese paintings in the Roerich Museum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- An almost unrelieved low level of business activity in a number of our foreign markets during 1931 was described in the weekly survey of conditions abroad by the Department of Commerce.

HAVE you noticed the gradual elevation of the waistline? Perhaps not; it has come about so quietly. But there it is, and when Spring clothes are ushered in with all the usual fanfare, you will see that many of the youngest, slim-looking things have a subtly higher-waisted effect.

IT was to have been a story on how that prince of voyageurs, that father confessor to melodrama's hapless heroines, A. H Woods, looks at show business after sitting on its sidelines for the first time in thirty years of good, bad and indifferent first, second and third acts.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt celebrated her seventy-third birthday in a quiet manner at her home, 120 Paine Avenue, this city.

FROM orchids to elephants, from rubbish to gold bars and precious stones, from giant logs to highly polished furniture, from coal and iron ore to finely finished machinery, from live stock to canned meats, the country's wide variety of transportation needs are satisfied by motor trucks on trails, streets and highways.

The Court of Appeals was petitioned yesterday to hear, at a special session on Jan. 25. arguments on the validity of the Republican reapportionment measure passed, in the form of a joint resolution, at the 1931 session of the Legislature.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9. -- Celeste A. Durand, 18-year-old entrant from Brooklyn, scored an upset today when he won by a margin of 2 up from Lee Chase Sr., former New York State champion, in the semi-final round of the Miami midwinter amateur championship on the Miami Golf Club course today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Funeral services with full military honors were held at Arlington National Cemetery today for Second Lieutenant E. H. Bobbitt Jr., who met his death in the West Virginia mountains while flying to his Hot Springs (Ark.) home for the holidays.

PALM BEACH. -- With the holiday rush well behind, with members of the younger set safely back in schools and colleges, and practically all the smart clubs and hotels running at full tide, Palm Beach colonists have settled down to the full schedule of activities usual to the first three months of each year.

THE figure of Sainte-Beuve is curious because of the diversity between his life and his work. He was not really a gentleman. In spite of Professor Glese's determined defense; and neither was he as great a literary critic as "Sainte-Beuve:

Eighty prominent members of the medical profession united last night in honoring Dr. Max Einhorn, the inventor of the Einhorn tube and one of the foremost gastro-enterol-ogists of the world, at a testimonial dinner held in celebration of his seventieth birthday at the Hotel Astor.

THE fifth of a series of broadcasts on political education under the general title "1932 and After" is now on the air sponsored by the Voters' Service of the National League of Women Voters. The talks are presented on Tuesday nights from 8 to 8:30 o'clock over an extensive network with WEAF as the New York outlet.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Spanflow, a 5-year-old son of Spanish Prince II, which confines most of his racing to heavy tracks, won another muddy affair today "when he carried the silks of Mrs. D. Levy to victory in the Martin Behrman Memorial Purse, feature at Jefferson Park.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- After losing the first two bouts, the Princeton varsity wrestling team made a clean sweep of the last six matches to defeat the Rutgers grapplers, 26 to 8, today, in the opening meet of the season for both teams.

Mrs. Hettie Dyhrenfurth. wife of Professor Guenther O. Dyhrenfurth, leader of the German scientific expedition to climb Mount Kanchenjunga in the Summer of 1930, arrived yesterday on the motorship Augustus of the Italia America Line from Genoa to exhibit, the film taken in the Himalayas and also to deliver a series of lectures on the subject.

MADRID. SPAIN has finished laying out the course for a leap from the sixteenth century to tne twenty-first. She has made her Constitution and promulgated it. The Cortes which framed it is now the first congress to act under its provisions.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Ambassador Charles G. Dawes stepped off a trail from Washington today and in a characteristic manner replied to questions about Presidential aspirations:

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP). -- The Daily News says it has learned that about $30,000,000 is left to the heirs of the late Julius Rosenwald in his will, which will be filed for probate in a few days. The sum, the newspaper says, is over and above amounts disposed of in charity bequests.

Simultaneously with the announcement that E.H. McCarty, formerly vice president and general manager, had been elected president, the Nash Motors Company made public yesterday its income report for the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, showing earnings of $4,807,680 after expenses, reserves, depreciation and State and Federal taxes.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- A heroic size statue of Sir Ernest Shackleton, the Antarctic explorer, was unveiled today on the wall of the Royal Geographical Society's building in South Kensington, only a stone's throw from the American Embassy.
Just what effect did the withdrawal of Bobby Jones from competitive golf have upon the gates at the amateur and open championships last year?

DETECTIVE skill seldom is needed to determine a painter's nationality through his work. He may be the most convinced of internationalists, his work, if worthy of any consideration at all, soon betrays him. Emil Carlsen, whose recent death removes from American art circles one of the finest and most accomplished of painters, was born in Denmark but lived the larger part of his long life in this country.

ATLANTA, Jan. 7. -- More than one hundred of Atlanta's patrolmen, or about one-third of the uniformed police force, "habitually use intoxicating beverages and with billy and gun and under the influence of liquor patrol the streets and highways," according to the latest charges made by John A. Manget, president of the Greater Atlanta Prohibition and Law Enforcement Club.
WITH the ever-increasing use of motor cars, no traffic problem has caused ocean resorts more concern than that of dealing with the parking of automobiles.

CONTENT makes her home in the country. So agreed the Governors of New York and Connecticut last month at an after-dinner chat. A group of neighbors from the metropolitan area listened approvingly. More than 600 had come together in the centre of Manhattan to break bread with the executives.

Many Men of Many Minds. THE NEW YORK TIMES did well to publish the letter from Hyacinthe Ringrose on "Comfort Found in the Encyclical." I am sure I would like to live in a world full of Hyacinthes. There would be more kindly tolerance and less cocksure fanaticism in such a place.

THE automobile industry enters 1932 in a healthy condition, physically and mentally. Plant facilities are shipshape and new products of surpassing merit are launched upon the market. Never in its long history has the industry functioned so brilliantly, efficiently and economically in expressing itself to motor-car buyers in particular and to the transportation world in general.

The market value of the common stocks of seventy-five leading corporations had recovered $1,764,750,386 on the New York Stock Exchange at the close of trading yesterday from the low points reached on Jan. 5, or last Tuesday. These stocks constitute 57.05 per cent of the number of common shares listed on the Exchange, indicating an aggregate gain in all listed stocks of more than $3,000,000,000.

The wind-up of the year's business proved a popular subject of discussion with merchants who arrived in the market here during the week, according to the report especially prepared for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. In many instances, comments indicated that the decrease in sales for the holiday period was not as great as anticipated, actually ranging from 8 to 15 per cent, according to locality,

IF the name of Joseph Hawley is known at all today to the common reader it is as a name from the story of Jonathan Edwards's stormy occupation of a Northampton (Mass.) pulpit in the mid-eighteenth century. As one of the party in opposition to Edwards's stringent doctrine Hawley rendered stout and occasionally acrimonioua service in the successful effort to drive the famous divine from the Connecticut Valley.

THE echoes of Japan's adventure in Manchuria are resounding through the world With the retreat of the opposing Chinese forces behind the Great Wall, the first chapter of that adventure is drawing to a close. But there are other chapters in the writing, and so this is an opportune time to review the situation.

Charles W. Smith, who hails from Waynesboro and lives in Richmond, Va., is having an exhibition of woodblock prints at the Art Centre until Jan. 16, He is interested in his subject matter and in problems of design rather than in technical refinements of print-making.

THE history of the automobile has been one of steady advancement all along the line. While it is true that the newest cars quite naturally mark the peak of automotive development, other years have made their contributions to the art and science of motor car building as we know it today.

THE Brooklyn Museum opens today an exhibition of recent accessions to the print department, including a group of sixteen Rembrandt etching's, among them "Christ Healing the Sick," known as the "Hundred Guilder Print."

ALL is far from quiet on the artistic front in Austria with the arrival of the New Year, judging from accounts of the situation found in late Vienna and Berlin newspapers. In opera circles the wage question is still open in some individual cases, and among the personnel and patrons of the Burgtheater there is considerable perturbation regarding the plans of the new State theatre director.

Ten members of the United States Senate would favor discussion of total disarmament by the United States delegation at the Geneva conference next month if such a proposal were submitted by representatives of three other participating powers, according to Alfred Lief, author, 135 West Seventy-ninth Street, who yesterday made public the first results of a survey of Senatorial views on the subject which he has under way.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Democratic tariff bill, submitted by the Ways and Means Committee only yesterday and providing chiefly for curbing the powers of the President under the flexible provisions of the Hawley-Smoot act, was passed in the House tonight by a vote of 214 to 182.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- An orderly naval building program was termed essential for the support of American shipyards by Rear Admiral George H. Rock, Chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair of the Navy Department, in testimony today before the Senate Naval Committee.
CHESTER, Pa., Jan. 9. -- Pennsylvania Military College opened its basketball season today by easily winning from South Jersey Law School, 57 to 24.

Shipments of fresh fruits and vegetables from Texas, California, Florida and Virginia showed a great increase last week over those of the previous week, the combined forwardings of 27 principal products totaling 12,444 cars, as compared with the movement of 8,250 carloads during the Christmas week and 14,655 carloads for the corresponding week last season.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The article in THE TIMES on "Wolf Savagery" is interesting. I would like to add a word on the subject.

GENIUS, it is said, does its greatest work when under handicap or stress. Blind Milton dictated "Paradise Lost" to his daughter; John Bunyan wrote "Pilgrim's Progress" while in a debtor's jail; Steinmetz, the great electrical wizard, was a sickly hunchback.

THE use of pictures is rapidly developing among home decorators an increased knowledge of their ornamental possibilities and among artists a greater interest in new methods of framing. Some painters enhance the decorative quality of their work by frames of naturally finished wood or silvered and colored frames or those combined with new designs of moldings and varied hues of mats.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- Early adoption of the State's fiscal program, including the new taxation schedule, was urged today by Senator John J. Dunnigan and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut. Democratic leaders in the legislature, in a joint statement issued here.

Several long term leases of properties added a touch of interest to the realty market yesterday. The vacant plot 75 by 100 feet at 615-19 West Fiftieth Street, west of Eleventh Avenue, was leased for Improvement with a single-story building for the manufacture and distribution of bakery products by the Gattfried Baking Company from the Kofaler-CAmpbell Company.

PARIS. IN this, puzzled world there is no one at this time more puzzled than M. Jean Pierre Dupont, citizen of France. Twelve years ago he climbed out of the mud in which he had been fighting for four years and went home believing that he and his pals had "made the world safe for democracy."

Foreseeing a keen demand from English manufacturers during the next six months for British rights to patents owned by American producers, the patent and trade-mark committee of the American Manufacturers' Export Association yesterday urged Americans desiring to realize on such rights to make special efforts now.

A gang of stock forgers which in recent months has flooded the country with forged certificates of the General Motors Company, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the B. M. T. with a total market value of more than $5,000,000 was broken up yesterday, the police believe, by the arrest of eight men, one of whom had forged certificates in his possession.

At its opening yesterday in Grand Central Palace, the National Automobile Show drew one of the largest crowds in its history, according to the management, who saw in the public response an auspicious beginning for the industry's new year. Hundreds of visitors had gathered or the sidewalk and in the lobby of the building before the doors were opened at 2 P.M.

ON a Winter day just twenty-five years ago, when the future of the automobile was still in the balance, a young motor car salesman of Elmira, N.Y., took over the then small Overland factory in Indian-apolis and set out to pull it through its difficulties and make it a success.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- Opinion seems evenly divided in political circles as to whether Premier Laval next week will be able to form a government of republican concentration, which is regarded as essential for the proper representation of France at the conferences at Lausanne and Geneva.

THE first of a series of concerts devoted to new symphonies by composers labeled "participants in the work of creating proletarian music," recently given in the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow, didn't reveal anything startling in the line of composition. It was welcomed by Professor E. Braudo, in the Moskauer Rundschau of Dec. 20, as the first step along the way to a vigorous propaganda for new Soviet symphonic creations.
Colonel Stimson's note to Tokyo and Nanking on the Manchurian situation raises a number of nice questions, both as regards international legal relations and international political relations.

The rooms of the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., were crowded yesterday afternoon for the auction of 100 important American antiques offered by Israel Sack. The 100 pieces brought a grand total of $105,890.

Gustav Mahler, a leader of New York's opera and Philharmonic concerts a quarter-century ago, held the lion's share of attention at the Boston Symphony Orchestra's matinee in Carnegie Hall yesterday. Though the start was delayed owing to weather, half a hundred late subscribers heard the first half-hour movement of Mahler's Ninth Symphony over the radio reproducer in the hall's no and spacious lounge.

MUCH of the present-day graphic art is either so pure (one hears, over and over again, the term, "pure design") that human beings fraught with all sorts of comfortable and uncomfortable impurities cannot make any sort of contact with it, or it is so unholy clever that most of us, being more or less commonplace in our shortcomings, cannot make either head or tail of it.

To the Dramatic Editor: Last Sunday C. M. W. Jr. wished, to ascertain what becomes of "bit" players and mentioned the darkhaired girl with the low voice in "If I Were You" among a group of three as a "personality worthy of better things."

Talking films may be tried out this Spring as an aid in teaching such subjects as biology, geography, nature-study and civics in the city's schools, it was announced yesterday. For twelve years silent motion pictures have been used in city classrooms, but the school authorities await the experiment to determine whether talking pictures should be shown instead.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 9. -- Louisiana's Gubernatorial campaign, unusual because Governor-Senator Huey P. Long is arrayed against his brothers and aligned with the old regular organization of New Orleans which for years he had denounced as a "ring." will turn into the home-stretch Monday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- Army defeated Williams, 4 to 2, in a fast hockey game played in the West Point Arena tonight. The Cadets outskated their college rivals and displayed better stickwork throughout.

A moderate decline on the Stock Exchange yesterday brought the conventional week-end explanation that profit-taking was responsible. The selling became more aggressive in the last half hour and prices were whittled down somewhat sharply. This did not occur, however, until many of the leading issues had advanced into new high ground for the advance.

AUGUSTA, Ga. -- A casual glimpse into the immediate program for the 1032 tourist season here forecasts fox and drag hunts and amateur horse racing. These events are interspersed with golfing on two courses, the Forest Hills and the Country Club Hill links.

The response to the twentieth annual appeal for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases is drawing to a close. Sixty-three contributors, who added $1,206.60 yesterday, brought the total to $284,341.18. It is within $61,449.47 of last, year's fund, which was this year's objective.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Numerous second-hand versions of certain views which expressed at recent sessions of the American Statistical Association in Washington differ so sharply from the views actually expressed that it seems worth while to clarify a few points.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7. -- Southen California is so filled with master minds that a celebrity, more or less means little in the everyday life of the community.

PRINCETON, N.J. Jan. 9. -- The Princeton varsity swimming team opened its season tonight by overwhelming the Rider College team, 58 to 15. The visitors captured only one first place, Kelley winning the fancy dive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Miss Frances E. Willis of Redlands, Cal., one of two women vice consuls in the foreign service, who is stationed at Santiago, Chile, but now in the United States on leave, has been appointed and confirmed as a secretary in the diplomatic service and has been designated third secretary of the legation at Stockholm.
ADMITTED by manufacturers, dealers and the motoring public is the fact that motor cars for 1932 reveal the greatest dollar-for-dollar value the motor car industry has yet offered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 3 a dispatch from Walter Duranty was published under the heading "Soviet Plans Fight on Discount Racket," supplemented by the headline, "Secret of Game Lies in Masking the Fact That Payment Is Almost a Certainty."
ALTHOUGH the wheels of commerce and industry have not been revolving so rapidly during the last year, those rolling in rubber tires conquered more miles of highway in 1931 than ever before.

ONE can scarcely go wrong on a mystery story by R. A. J. Walling. He is a master at the technique of this type of fiction, and his books are peopled with real human beings instead of mere puppets. In this story we meet a detective with no previous experience in murder cases.

DURING the put year the motor bus industry continued to attract more than ordinary attention. While expansion was not so widespread as in previous years, nevertheless buses, for economic reasons, continued to replace ether means of public transport in many localities.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9 -- Leading from the start, the Princeton basketball team won its seventh straight game of the season and its second consecutive Eastern intercollegiate League game by defeating Cornell tonight, 33 to 23. Siebert, with five goals, led the Princeton attack, sharing scoring honors with Hatkoff, Cornell ace.
TOKYO, Jan. 9. -- Secretary Stimson's note in regard to Manchuria is treated seriously by the press, which disputes his suggestions with vigor but without excitement or appeals to mob feeling.

Los Nanduces marked up another metropolitan indoor polo circuit triumph in the ring of the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night when they downed the Squadron C trio, 18 1/2 to 9, after giving away two goals. The winners showed marked superiority throughout most of the game, but found the cavalrymen suddenly coming to life in the final chukker.

PLANTS, like human beings, suffer from a variety of diseases; also, they require encouragement to enable them to produce vigorous bloom and fruit. At the Boyce Thompson Institute for Plant Research at Yonkers a group of scientists is at work on many tasks which are designed to aid the nurseryman to improve the quality of his stock, and to eliminate the scourges which nature visits upon vegetation.

The formation of an Inter-Faith Council to promote cooperation between Protestant, Catholic and Jewish student religious organizations in the New York University Washington Square division was announced yesterday by Professor Samuel L. Hamilton, chairman of the Department of Religious Education in the university's School of Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Legalizing of 4 per cent beer was recommended to aid the farmers, the unemployed and Government revenues by witnesses before a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Manufactures today, when the hearing was continued on two beer bills of Senator Bingham, Republican, of Connecticut.

BERLIN, Dec. 23. THE Reinhardt theatrical concern which controls six theatres in Berlin has not been doing so well this season. Even the historic Deutsches Theater has fared well only through a revival of Schiller's "Kabale und Liebe," which Reinhardt himself staged.

VIENNA, Jan. 7. -- One of the good auguries which 1932 brought to a part of the world which even more than most needs such harbingers of better and more peaceful times has been the commencement at Riga of negotiations for a compact of nonaggression between Russia and Rumania.

IF you want to get a glimpse into the heart of the new Italy, read this quaintly interesting book by John Gibbons, who has already made himself known to English and American readers by his previous volume, "Trampine Through Ireland."

WITH most of their preparations for it completed, younger members of society are looking forward to the annual Bal Guignol to be held on Friday in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the reconstruction unit of the Post-Graduate Hospital.

PARIS, Jan. 7. -- Schiaparellis weatherproof wig of blonde waxed real hair, designed by Anotine to replace the ski cap, is the sensation of St. Moritz. She wears a silver, lacquered, curled wig with direcloire evening gowns. Nikitina's all while ski costume attracts attention also.

The Philadelphia racquets player triumphed in the annual match with the New Yorkers yesterday by 4 to end their No. 1 team of Edward M Edwards and Joseph R. Rowland scored a stunning surprise by turning back the national doubles chaimpions, Clarence C. Pell and Stanley G. Mortimer, in the contests at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

William Mitchell Berrien, who had been associated with the real estate firm of Horace S. Ely Co. of Manhattan for the last forty-three years, died yesterday after a year's illness at his home, 110 Madison Avenue, Flushing, Queens, He was seventy-two years old.

An attempt to extort money from Dr. Griswold D. Nammack, Queens physician and president of the medical board of St. Joseph's Hospital, resulted yesterday in the arrest of Mrs. Rose Amorosa, 29 years old, of 1,363 Clinton Street, Far Rockaway, and one of her six children.
I AM optimistic regarding the outlook for the automobile Industry. This optimism is based on two simple but important factors.

THIS book la not only about Roosevelt; it Is a self-portrait of a man of the old West who played off his own bat, even when a President was around. Jack Wlllls was a Montana hunter, bred in the take-no-man's-dust ways of self-reliance, when Roosevelt, callow and enthusiastic and after a white antelope goat, first ran across his in 1886.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9. -- Johnny Winter of the Yale defensive line tonight broke a 3 to 3 tie within two minutes of the close of a ten minute overtime period, presenting the Blue with a 4 to 3 victory over Dartmouth. The Eli outscored Dartmouth in New York City, 13 to 4, a fortnight ago.
IPREDICT, for 1932, automobile business equal to 1931 or better. Viewed conservatively, the replacement market alone is sufficient to insure a production equal to 1931.

BOSTON, Jan. 7. -- There is no disguising the fact that President Hoover sustained a rebuke in the New Hampshire election last Tuesday. Confident Democrats, with a very popular candidate, took possession of a district which contains half the population of the State, and for the third time in twenty years elected their nominee for Congress.

Mrs. Herbert Hoover, who came to New York to attend the eleventh anniversary luncheon of the Women's National Republican Club, was the guest at dinner last night of Charles D. Hilles, New York member of the Republican National Committee, and Mrs. Hilles at their residence, 45 East Sixty-second Street.

IN view of the fact that automobile manufacturing activity went on at a very much reduced level last year, one might have expected that car makers would have stinted their efforts to provide something novel and attractive, so far as the bodies displayed at the Show are concerned.

Most of the markets presented yesterday the picture familiar at the week-end, after a week of rising Prices. Professional Wail Street could not, if it would, forego action according to that time-honored tradition; which had its origin, no doubt, in the idea that something which would reverse the market's idea of things might happen over Sunday.

Reports from Washington state that the American delegation will go to the world conference on armaments next month with instructions to oppose the "budgetary" method of limitation. Such instructions would maintain the position taken by the United States in the preliminary consultations at Geneva.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 7. -- What with Chicago unable to pay its School teachers, 26,000 employes in Philadelphia demanding their back pay and other large cities in a financial mess, this city, although providing generous emergency relief, not only finished the year with a treasury balance of $3,175,000 but faces financial stability in the future so far as its City Government is concerned.

Myra Hess, pianist, returned to her New York public yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. She found a house that was packed; and an audience that eagerly awaited her Miss Hess made a special essay in program making. She played two Beethoven sonatas, the Fantasie Stucke and the Symphonic Studies of Schumann.

The average retail price of gasoline in 1931 throughout the United States, both including and excluding the State tax, was the lowest for any year since any reliable records have been kept. The service-station price in fifty cities, including at least one city in each State, averaged 16.86 cents a gallon, including the State tax, or 26 per cent less than in the five-year period 1926 to 1930, both years inclusive.

THAT America's motor manufacturers have responded as a unit to the nation's call for industrial leadership in an attempt to bring about a certain return to better times, I believe, is evidenced by the startling, value-plus creations that are being displayed at this year's auto show.

DEVELOPMENT of properly designated secondary routes through American cities so that cross-country motorists need not be delayed by traffic congestion in business districts is one of the biggest steps in solving the nation's transportation problem.

To the Dramatic Editor: Kenneth Macgowan's interesting and valuable account of production costs, unwittingly perhaps, maket an implication in regard to the rehearsal expenses of "Lean Harvest," which, as the designer of the production, I may be allowed to correct.

THERE are certain individuals whose personalities have caught the imagination of mankind. They are not, of necessity, the most important persons nor the people whose names will lire longest in history. But, for the moment, they may be described as the supermen of publicity.
BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- The M.I.T. varsity swimming team opened its season with a 42-to-S5 victory over Amherst in the University Club pool tonight.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- With the holiday season out of the way. Bermuda has settled back to its normal, and unique, way of living. The holiday rush was greater than it has ever been before, the harbor being filled with cruise ships, in addition to the regular liners.

BERLIN. NEXT November Gerhart Hauptmann will complete his seventieth year. At that age man begins to see his childhood and youth in a new light, curiously transfigured. Things and moods he had forgotten for decades he now sees and feels with an intensity that would appear miraculous did be not experience it more deeply from day to day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Mrs. Mary Isabel Wood, 58 years old, wife of Professor Frank E. Wood of the department of anthropology of the University of Chicago, was struck and seriously injured today by an automobile driven by Mrs. Frances Breasted, wife of Dr. James H. Breasted, director of the Oriental Institute of the university, as she was crossing Fifty-seventh Street at Blackstone Avenue.

WASHINGTON. HIGHWAY building enjoyed the greatest year in its history in 1931. When final figures are compiled they are expected to show that more than 50,000 miles of surfaced highway have been added to State and county systems, bringing improved mileage in the United States to approximately 730,000 out of a possible 3,000,000 miles.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 9. -- By a special technique I have found it possible for the first time to watch directly in the living organism two fundamental activities of nerve fibers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Speculation over General Dawes'a intention to resign as Ambassador was largely, although not entirely, stilled with his assertion in Chicago that Presidential nomination talk about him was "all damn nonsense."

AN encouraging sale of boxes and seats has been reported for several forthcoming performances of Broadway attractions which have been taken over to augment the funds of philanthropic organizations. Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell heads a group of members of the Women's Auxiliary of the Union Settlement that has arranged the performance of "Berlin" on the night of Jan. 20 at the George M. Cohan Theatre for the benefit of the settlement.

Distribution became the new monarch of the contract bridge world yesterday as a result of the Lenz-Culbertson match, which was completed at the Waldorf-Astoria on Friday night after 150 rubbers had been played, with Ely Culbertson and his partners finishing with a lead of 8,980 points.

THE COLOPHON, whose quarterly appearance gladdens the hearts of all bookmen who have made its acquaintance, arrives with this number at the end of its second year. As its readers have come to know, The Colophon is more properly a book than a magazine, a book that comes forth revivified with every issue, a new transformation of its previous self.

In a statement advocating unification and city ownership of subways as a means of saving probably $41,000,000 in connection with Federal and State taxes alone, Charles F. Noyes, president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., yesterday warned city officials and bankers with whom they are conferring on the municipality's finances that they were at the crossroads, and that the future of the real estate market here was in their hands.

SIR WILLIAM TEMPLE (16281699) has an almost stainless reputation. In the annals of his time and during his own life he was held in high repute. Yet after admitting his merit, few have ever been really concerned about him.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Cheerfulness pervaded the Stock Exchange today and pushed British Government funds and Anglo-American stocks upward. Although sterling exchange declined slightly to $3.40, the war loan, the funding loan and the conversion loan each rose 1/3 to 97 1/3, u86 1/3 and u75 1/3, respectively.

Today will mark the closing of the Christ Child cribs, which have been in place since Christmas in many ritualistic churches. In a number of edifices there will be a "candle service" symbolizing Christ as the Light of the World, and during this a candle will be passed about the congregation.

Assailing the city's great banking institutions for alleged "squeezing" of the municipality in the pending negotiations for a short-term loan of $90,000,000 or more to meet maturing obligations and make possible the city's $20,000,000 program for home relief and unemployment aid, Mayor Walker appealed yesterday to the Federal Government for cooperation in making available the necessary funds.

Check exchanges in 178 cities of the country in 1931 aggregated $410,338,166,564, a decline of 24.5 per cent from the turnover in 1930, and the smallest for a year since 1922. The record total was $715,171,848,285, established in 1929.
British Banker, in an Address Bruadcast from London.

As noted previously, holiday influences not readily susceptible to precise statistical measurement tend to become exaggerated at extremes of the business cycle, and in the recent holiday period the various components of the weekly business index have run true to form by displaying unusually erratic fluctuations.

There has been wide comment, in a spirit of fair play, upon the injustice of holding President HOOVER responsible for the ills which have befallen the country under his Administration. Many letters have come to THE TIMES endorsing a recent editorial in protest against the habit of holding him accountable for everything that has happened since he became President.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 9. -- The Navy five, outplayed in the first half, registered sixteen points in the second period to defeat Virginia here tonight, 25 to 24, before a crowd that packed Memorial Gymnasium.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- Just as Barkis was willin', eleven intrepid skippers of racing yachts on Long Island Sound were on hand today to become initiated into the Frostbite Yacht Club, or once again to take a Winter sail. The repeaters were undaunted by their experience last week when King Winter shook his beard of snow.

New Utrecht High School's hold on the city P. S. A. L. senior high school track and field championships, which has extended for six successive seasons indoors and eight straight years outdoors, will be threatened at the 245th Coast Defense Armory (formerly the Thirteenth Regiment Armory) in Brooklyn on Friday night when the annual city P. S. A. L. senior high indoor championships | will be contested.

IT was the novelist J.H. Rosnyaine who coined the word "astronautics," meaning the science and art of voyaging from star to star. How utterly puerile and inconsequential seem the transaltantic and world flights of our boldest aviators compared with the stirring implications of that single word!

Gerard B. Lambert expects to put Vanitie in commission next Summer, so there will be three America's Cup yachts leading the canvas racing fleet this year. Mr. Lambert has not considered as yet whether he will have any changes made in Vanitie's rig.

LONDON. AT the beginning of 1931 a great number of new motoring laws of a revolutionary nature were put into operation in England. They were embodied in the new road traffic act. This act has now been in force for a full working season with highly interesting results.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The present emergency is as abnormal for the American nation as was the war emergency. Like the war, to overcome it the energies of the entire nation must be mobilized for concerted action.

In the reports from Washington and the comments from other sections of the country on Representative Vinson's proposed $600,000,000 naval construction bill, designed to give the United States Navy parity in fact instead of in theory, one important aspect of the measure has been largely overlooked.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- The English Singers gave a concert tonight at the new White Plains High School, Mamaroneck Road, White Plains. The proceeds will go toward the scholarship fund of the Winbrook School. Mrs. Alfred Levinger and Mrs. Robert K. Haas of Scarsdale were in charge of the benefit concert and were assisted by Mrs Arthur Besse, Mrs. Allen Richardson.

New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday covered a variety of property ranging from a farm estate to small dwellings. Flats, taxpayers, garages and vacant parcels were included in the turnover.
The Kmigrant Industrial Savings Bank took a mortgage for $I2,000, due Jan. 8. 1937, at 5 1/2 per cent, from Charles C. Clltton on 109 West Seventy-eighth Street.

NEXT Wednesday, Jan. 13, is the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of Horatio Alger Jr., author of more than one hundred books for boys. These books, such as "Ragged Dick;" "Mark, the Match Boy;" "Rough and Ready;" "Phil, the Fiddler;" "Luck and Pluck," and many others, furnished the main part of the chosen reading of boys of a generation or two ago.

THE creative mind as a factor in social growth and change is the centre of the system of sociology which Professor Maclver here sets forth, with the caution that only the Interpretation is new. The things it deals with are "well known."

NEGRO literature consciously produced -- and as a development apart from folklore and song -- has been studied mainly in its most recent phases. What went before this? The importance of the Negro folk background we understand.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Before he shot and killed himself in the presence of two friends, Fred W. Weaver, 23 years old, of 628 East Twenty-fourth Street here, forced one of them at the point of a pistol to type his will bequeathing his effects to his companions, the police said today.

EVEN to the present day, the name Babylonia is a synonym for splendor and cruelty and corruption. Her famous hanging gardens, which were among the world's wonders; the magnificence of her palaces, the wealth she amassed, and the lust of conquest which urged on her great King, Nebuchadnezzar II, to victory over the greater part of the ancient world.

AFTER a fairly brisk start, rainy weather reduced trade activity in the week so that various promotions did not attract the response which was expected. Demend was Quiet in most departments and the women's wear lines failed to make much progress. Men's wear stores also reported subnormal business for the beginning of their regular sale period.

LONDON, Dec. 24. SOME years ago it became temporarily a fashion for playgoers, who do not ordinarily seek their entertainment at any place more than a mile from Charing Cross or the Haymarket, to direct their steps or their motor cars across the bridges of the Thames and to search for the cruder drama in the south of London.

EACH year civilization becomes more hazardous and complicated. During 1931, there were about 35,000 people killed, 1,000,000 injured, and $900,000,000 lost in property damage due to traffic accidents. The cost of congestion is estimated at three billion dollars.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 UP). -- A Democratic reply oday to President Hoover's latest call for governmental economy was, in effect, that Mr. Hoover should practice what he preaches.

Cities Are Also Ideas. WHAT Manchester thinks today London will think tomorrow" is a saying that has made each city think the other is deplorable. No wonder Londoners felt ironic when the Lord Mayor of Manchester on returning from the United States reported that he had found here no less than thirty-two Manchesters.

The second performance this season of Wagner's "Lohengrin" was presented at the matinee yesterday by the Metropolitan Opera Company with Maria Mueller as Elsa and Max Lorenz as the knight of the Holy Grail. Others were Karin Branzell, Ivar Andresen, Frledrich Schorr and George Cehanovsky.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- It is understood in Paris that, according to the terms of an agreement reached this week. Rumania has undertaken to supply and France has agreed to purchase a minimum of 400,000 tons a year of oil and petroleum derivatives. France's total present requirements are 3,000,000 tons a year.

The Saturday discussion luncheon of the National Republican Club, held weekly in the club's headquarters at 54 West Fortieth Street, developed yesterday into a defense of the Republican National Administration and a criticism of the Democrats as destructive rather than constructive in their course of action.

BERLIN, Dec. 23, 1931. IF Berlin has had to wait nearly two years to acquaint itself with "The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny," the reasons have been principally economic. The State and civic operas produce rubbish enough, in all conscience, but they seem to have drawn the line at aggravating their budgetary troubles with a work whose breath of life has hitherto been the breath of scandal.
The King of Ubangi, dressed in the regal garments of strips of yellow and brown flannel, visited Station WOV yesterday and broadcast his views on marriage and other subjects.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- Nassau has always counted many Americans among its visitors, but for the past two seasons a number of English and Canadian tourists have also been coming here. Recent arrivals were the Right Hon. Winston Churchill, Mrs. Churchill and their daughter, Miss Diana Churchill.

ROME, Jan. 3. -- The Ministries of Foreign Affairs, War, Navy and Aeronautics have begun intensive work in preparation for the forthcoming general disarmament conference at Geneva. Periodical meetings are being held by Foreign Minister Grandi, General Gazzera, Minister of War; Admiral Sirianni, Minister of Navy; Deputy Riccardi, Under-Secretary of Aeronautics, representing General Balbo, Minister of Aeronautics, who is absent from Italy.
LANCASTER, Pa., Jan. 9. -- Three new records for the Fackenthal Natatorium were established by Franklin and Marshall swimmers today in defeating Manhattan College by 44 to 15.

THE future of the automobile business is what it always has been -- opportunity for those who meet the needs and wants of the public. There is a constantly increasing need of automotive transportation, and those companies which are able to produce newer, better-built automobiles that offer greater value for less cost to the consumer will enjoy added public patronage.

LONDON. J.B. PRIESTLEY says he used to think that America had a real book-buying public and that England had not but he knows now that he was mistaken. When the general slump came there was a landslide in the American book trade.

SMOKERS who are having trouble in adhering to their resolutions to lead nobler and more abstemious lives will find much to console them in this edifying volume. The story of tobacco from the time of Columbus very nearly down to the present day is largely that of an unsuccessful attempt to swear off.

THE various movements in and out of Congress in the endeavor to secure the repeal or modification of the Eighteenth Amendment indicate the prominencs that the constitutional aspects of national prohibition will probably have in the political campaigns of 1932.

IT is highly improbable that a native American speech flowing from a pure racial origin like that of the Latins and Teutons will ever become a reality. In our conglomerate nation too much lingual wash from Europe. Asia, Africa and Polynesia has polluted the stream of our English pure and undefiled to allow us a verbal harmony.
MOSCOW, Jan. 9. -- The news of the Japanese occupation of Shanhaikwan was received here without comment except for a brief note in the newspaper Pravda, saying:

BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- Chancellor Bruening made a formal statement today in which he said the actual facts left no room for deliberation as to what stand to take on reparations -- that they would have to cease for the two-fold reason that they were impossible for Germany and ruinous for the world.

GENEVA, Jan. 8. -- The Democrats' tariff bill arouses among local supporters of the Wilsonian institution a melancholy akin, to that which Brutus'a stab caused Caesar. They might welcome the bill as at least an effort to reduce tariffs but it is represented to them in the press as doomed to failure and constituting merely an insincere effort to seek a party advantage.
Brady Refuses to Let Rice lnclude Broadhurst Play in Repertory.

OUT of her retirement Sun Soong Chlng-ling-the Westerners know her as Mme. Sun Yat-sen -- has emerged briefly to play a part in the establishment of a new regime in chaotic China and then to move back quickly into the recesses in which she hides.
WESTFIELD, N. J., Jan. 9. -- The Allenhurst Polo Club gave Westfield Polo Club its first defeat in nine starts by winning tonight in the Westfield Armory, 11 goals to 7.

PORTO RICO, Jan. 9. -- Despite the fact that when Governor Roosevelt left here in December to spend the Christmas holidays at home he fixed the time for his return to Porto Rico, those most closely associated with him could not explain to themselves his reason for taking with him his entire private file, which he had left here on all previous trips to the United States.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Kenkichi Yoshizawa, who will become Foreign Minister of Japan, declared today that his government "has no intention of interfering with any American or other foreign rights or privileges in Manchuria."
Secretary of State, at a Hearing Before the House Euelgrn Affairs Committee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- The public-school system of Chicago is threatened by two perils. First, complete cessation of functions through lack of revenue; second, dismemberment of Its educational program by a process of drastic economy which will be necessary even if legislative action makes revenue available.

SINCE nothing is quite so uncertain as the procedure of the gentlemen who write the pieces that eventually come to Broadway, strange and even cock-eyed histories proverbially attend their composition. A luncheon conference can turn a would-he tragedy into a comedy and make a Pulitzer prize winner out of a farce.

IN returning to novel writing after a lapse of several years, Robert HerricK, in "The End of Desire," again exhibits the same high seriousness, the same fearlessness in dealing with life that made his earlier work in "The Common Lot" and "Together" notable in their day and notable in the history of the American novel.

ITHACA. N. Y., Jan. 9. -- New material about Ezra Cornell, founder of the university which bears his name, has been made available by relatives on the occasion of his 125th birthday, which will be observed in traditional Founder's Day celebrations by Cornell alumni throughout the world Jan. 11.

PARIS. Dec. 24. LENORMAND is one of the three the evolution of the contempoor four dramatists who count in rary French theatre. Not only does he always aim at the highest, but he possesses an understanding of the deeper and indeed of the darker recesses of the human heart, which gives a vivid reality to his explorations of the subconscious.

The Savage School of Physical Education girls' basketball team extended its string of victories to nineteen in a row over a two-year span when it vanquished an alumnae six, 25 -- 22, yesterday on its home court. Five of the triumphs were accounted for this season.
SHOULD a symphony be applauded between the movments, or should it not be applauded?

NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. A. Hamilton Rice gave a small dance last night at the Waldorf-Astoria for Mrs. Rice's granddaughter. Miss Eleanor Widener Dixon, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fitz Eugene Dixon of Philadelphia.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9. -- Tale University will send out soon an expedition for a four months' exploration of the deep sea waters and ocean currents of the Gulf of Mexico under the leadership of Professor Albert E. Parr, scientific director of the Yale Oceanographic Expeditions and curator of the Bingham Oceanographic Collection at Yale.

IN the final casting of characters for the brilliant pageant of the Beaux-Arts ball on Jan. 22 at the Waldorf-Astoria, it has been decided, according to a recent announcement, that Kenneth M. Murchison, chairman of the ball's executive committee, will assume the role of George Washington.

In view of the tremendous success of the revival of Offenbach's "La Vie Parlsienne" at the Mogador Theatre in Paris, where it has had more than 400 performances, another operetta, "Orphee aux Enters" by Offenbach, will be produced there. The directors of the Mogador Theatre have assembled an "all-star cast," at the head of which will be Max Dearly, Mile.

MR. WEIGAL seems to think it was quite worth while to have been a part of the famous Florida land boom, even if that experience did include being parted from his money and sent out of "paradise" no better off than when he went in.

THE name of Edward Garnett is perhaps better known to those who have to do with publishers than it to those whose only contact with books is that of reader. But as literary adviser to scores of English writers prominent during the earlier part of the century -- and among these was Joseph Conrad -- Mr. Garnett became one of the most important figures in literary London.

ONCE more the air transport operators are thinking in terms of lower costs per mile, higher speeds and lower charges. The recent cuts on United Air Lines and Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., followed by similar cuts on its long-haul service by American Airways, may be Winter tariffs with possible increases kept in mind for the time when, the warm weather comes and more people want to fly.

The total amount of arrears and current taxes collected by the City of New York on the 1931 tax levy is $478,392,000, or an increase of $1,452,000 over the 1930 total of $476,940,000, according to figures obtained yesterday from City Collector William Reid Jr., who said that despite the depression the city's tax collections were "about normal."

Acceptance of a 10 per cent reduction in wages by 4,500 men in the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company's shop union brought the total of railroad wage earners who have accepted such reductions to more than 34,000 persons. Supervisory officials of the New Haven are also to receive a 10 per cent reduction in salaries at a date not yet announced.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- Mrs. Violet E. Fahnestock, this city's only woman magistrate, known for her activity in behalf of the prohibition law, died today in the Presbyterian Hospital. She underwent an operation in November, but suffered a relapse a few days ago.

The Brooklyn Prep ice hockey team, defending champion, strengthened its hold on first place in the Catholic Kigh Schools Athletic Association's fourth annual ice hockey tournament by battling to a 1-1 dead-lock with the La Salle Military Academy sextet of Oakdale, L. I., at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

PREPARATIONS are well under way for the Russian Students' Ball to be held at the Ritz-Carlton on Jan. 29. Frequent meetings are being held to whip the details in shape for this annual event, which is enlisting the aid of many prominent men and women, and well-known Russians now in this city.

BRUNO WALTER will take over the direction of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on Thursday evening for a period of seven weeks. He will appear here until Feb. 28, and will also be on tour with the orchestra the week of Jan. 25.
BERLIN, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Reichs-bank's statement as of Jan. 7 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

Two statements of new subsidies for the betterment of conditions of French national theatres have been announced in Paris. An appropriation of 21,000,000 francs has been adopted by the Senate for the restoration and management of the museums and national theatres, of which 4,000,000 will go to the Grand Opera in Paris, 1,000,000 francs to the Opera-Comique and 1,000,000 to the scenic studios of this theatre and to those of the Odeon.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9. -- Two athletes from the metropolitan district are included in the University of Pennsylvania first varsity crew combination that started rowing on the machines this week. They are Jack Bainbridge of Staten Island and Al Elgar, New York City.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 9. -- Led by Captain Gene Ward, left forward, who tallied five goals from the floor and two from the penalty line for a total of 12 points, the St. Paul's School basketball team triumphed over the Fanwood School five, 35 to 30, today.

RADIO is turning the tide for opera. Letters of appreciation received by the National Broadcasting Company as the result of broadcasting several acts from three Metropolitan operas, "Hansel and Gretel," "Norma" and "La Boheme," have done much to convince the broadcasters and the opera directors that opera is by no means on the wane in America, as many have asserted from time to time.

BOSTON, Jan. 7. -- The agitation for reduced expenditure and general economy is producing verbal results at least In this State. On Monday many Mayors made inaugural addresses in Massachusetts cities, and every one of them emphasized the need of reducing budgets, taxation, special enterprises however desirable in themselves, and in general cutting the municipal coat according to the cloth.
MADRID, Jan. 8. -- The Liberals of Spain are finding that, although a form of government may be swept out, as was the monarchy, much debris remains.

Columbia and City College inaugurated the twenty-sixth season of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association last night in the Columbia pool and the Lions toppled the Lavender, 47 -- 24. Although Columbia was favored to win, it was not expected to triumph by the margin that it did.

HERE is a history of Chinese art which, as the author states in the preface, "fixes the style of each period by its forms and colors, the unity of this style throughout the various forms of art, its relation to its time and its connecting threads from century to century."

SPECIAL performances at the Metropolitan Opera House in the near future will aid the enterprises of several philanthropic organizations. Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "Rigoletto," with Mme. Lily Pons, Lauri-Volpi and De Luca in the leading roles, which will take place on Friday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Greenwich.

MRS. VINCENT ASTOR, with the assistance of a large group of prominent men and women, has planned an unusual entertainment for the benefit of the National League for American Citizenship which will take place tonight at the Ziegfeld Theatre and the Club Richmond.

With the defending champion, Ben Yedlin, Trinity Club, at the top of his game in winning handily from Thomas Gray, unattached, play. started yesterday in the metropolitan A.A.U. one-wall handball championship singles tournament at the Downtown A.C. Yedlin won by 21 -- 2, 21 -- 4.

BERLIN, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Adoif Hitler talked today with Chancellor Bruening and also with Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, head of the Nationalist party. Then there was a conference between Dr. Hugenberg and the Chancellor.

WITH the year 1931 bringing an approximate increase of 12 per cent in tourist traffic on Long Island, counties, cities and townships on the island have been engaged in a broad program of highway improvements to meet the influx of motorists.

An action involving patent rights to the rival container car systems operated by the New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads was started yesterday through the filing or a bill of complaint against the Pennsylvania in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York by the Less Carload Lots Company and the L.C.L. Corporation.
SEATTLE, Jan. 9 -- Clark P. Bissett, professor emeritus of the University of Washington, a recognized authority on Abraham Lincoln, died in La Jolla, Cal., tonight. He would have been 67 on Monday.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- The news of Chancellor Breuning's declaration to Sir Horace Rumbold, British Ambassador in Berlin, that Germany was unable to pay reparations, created a sensation in London today. Although the Foreign Office confirms the fact of the statement officially, it remains extremely reticent as to its effect.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The following report on the attack on the wife of a naval officer alleged to have been committed by Horace Ida and David Takai, Japanese; Beung Ahakuelo and Joseph Kahahawai Jr., Hawaiians, and Henry Chang. Chinese, was sent to the Secretary of the Navy on Dec. 23 by Rear Admiral Tates Stirling Jr., U. S. N., commandant of the Fourteenth Naval District at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii:

Still undefeated in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo Circuit, the Optimists rode from the ring of Squadron A last night on the long end of a 12 1/2-to-11 score, victors over the young, fast and game Pennsylvania Military College team, which had given Winston Guest's trio its hardest fight of the season.

NEW York Society of Women Artists -- This group opened a new gallery last Thursday for the Squibb Building. The exhibition is composed of work by all of the members and remains until the end of the month. Reviewed Jan. 8.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation on Dec. 31, 1931, amounted to 2,735,353 tons, the lowest level for any month-end since Dec. 31, 1910, when unfilled orders made a total of 2,674,757 tons. The net decrease last month was 198,538 tons, which was larger than had been generally expected.

EACH year the motoring public is offered new automobiles which are proclaimed as better in every respect than those of previous models. Comparatively few motorists are in position to test these claims except by the rather unsatisfactory method of comparing new cars with the ones they are discarding.
Under-Perrftary of Slate, in a Speech Before the women's National Republican Club Jan 6.

MARISTAN CHAPMAN, whose latest novel, "The Weather Tree," has just been published by the Viking Press, has a dual personality. There is no psychic nonsense about it, either, for Maristan Chapman is two persons, Mary Chapman and Stanton Chapman, her husband.

THE resourceful Rosenbach Company has been running two shows which are stealing a little of the limelight of the coming Lothian sale. The exhibitions will clear out on Jan. 16, eleven days before the all-Important auction is scheduled to begin.

BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- A cartel of all the German banks to set interest rates on deposits as well as credits was organized tonight to scale down the interest rates under the supervision of the Banking Commissioner.

"The Allied Governments owe us $10,000,000,000. They cannot pay because they cannot collect at present from Germany, but they must stop talking cancellation or repudiation and about making payments to us conditional upon German reparations and come to us as honest debtors and tell us what they can pay per annum in interest and sinking fund."

VIENNA, Jan. 9. -- Alleging that Maria Jeritza had ordered from him an opera written especially for her and had refused it on its completion, Dr. Max von Oberleithner, composer Of "The Iron Saviour" and other operas, today sued the Metropolitan Opera Company prima donna in Vienna Civil Court for $6,500.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the heading "Starlings a Menace" THE TIMES publishes a letter which is truly depressing. The habits which your correspondent ascribes to the starlings are those of the grackles, which, indeed, will rob nests and attack young birds and smaller species.

THAT delicate, vicious and peculiarly artificial period of French social history that existed during the eighteenth century receives ample and loving treainent by Karl Toth in "'Woman and Rococo in France." Basing his study on the career and literary output of that minor figure of the era, Charles-Pinot Duclos.

MOTOR car buyers this year are offered the greatest values in the history of the automobile industry. This great buying opportunity exists because the industry is now measuring progress with a new yardstick. In former years, the achieving of higher production records was regarded as progress.

Punctuated by a series of vocal explosions in Washington, the controversy over the State Department's ten-year-old policy of scrutinizing foreign loans has been revived into a first-rate sensation. To investment bankers the discussion has its ironical aspects, since there has been no occasion in many months for the department to exercise the sanctioning power which it assumed in 1922.

ONCE, when frontier days on the West. Coast were still 3 recent memory, one who bad taken a plentiful share in them was telling a newcomer about the valiant deeds and the gun fights at one of his friends. "Was he killed?" asked the tenderfoot.

In less than thirty minutes from the time President H.H. Ramsay performed the duty of bidding the delegates be seated at the annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore, the United States Golf Association yesterday disposed of 1931 and made all of its plans for 1932.

ANOTHER year of universally acknowledged depression has passed into history, and with its passing there cornea out of the economic gloom seeming evidence that the automotive industry has weathered a sterna that engulfed and proved fatal to many other activities in the business world.

WARSAW, Jan. 9. -- In a press conference today the Rumanian Foreign Minister. Prince Dimitri Ghica, confirmed a report that negotiations on a non-aggression pact had been begun at Riga by the Rumanian envoy there and special Soviet delegate.

Profit-taking in issues that had rallied strongly in the week brought moderate recessions yesterday in leading shares on the New York Curb Exchange, although Lehigh Coal and Navigation and Swift International pushed forward again, together with several less active issues.

CARD parties, in conjunction with luncheons and teas, have been arranged by several charitable organizations for the next two weeks. In aid of their many undertakings for the relief of the needy the Ladies of Charity of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York will hold their annual card party on the afternoon of Jan. 23 at the Plaza.

IN a survey of the various current lists one is particularly struck by the predominance of piano items with which all the local companies are represented, more especially Victor -- by reason of its annual special list, on which the recently noticed Paganini Variations of Brahma appeared as a companion piece to the Handel Variations in the regular December release.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Settlement of the railroad consolidation question in the East as a means of expediting establishment of storedoor delivery in New York and other large cities was urged by W. M. Clement, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad in charge of operations, at today's hearine before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Only about 10 per cent of the 708 recent candidates for licenses to teach English in the city's high schools passed the Board of Education's examinations qualifying them for teaching positions in that subject, it was disclosed last week with the issuance of a new eligible Hat by the Board of Examiners.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was indeed a shocking experience to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES the heading "Holds Philosophy Is Not for Masses," which was given to Professor Cohen's address before the annual meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9. -- The Harvard varsity White team dropped from first place in Class A of the Massachusetts Squash Racquets League when it lost a 3-2 match to the Newton Center Club today. The varsity Red team won a Class A match from the Union Boat Club, 3-2, -but it did not change the standing of the Red team.

A remarkable record is that of New York University's women swimmers, soon to open their 1932 campaign. Over a period of seven sessions since the sport was introduced in 1924 at Washington Square, the Violet naiads have lost only two dual meets of the thirty-six in which they have engaged.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- Chancellor Bruening's declaration to the British Ambassador to Berlin regarding the impossibility for Germany, to continue paying reparations reached Paris today, first in the form of a blunt statement, which was later considerably attenuated.

LONDOX. BRITISH listeners are anxiously awaiting the full transition of the British Broadcasting Corporation to the new central headquarters of Broadcasting House, in the West End of London. The old remodeled buildings, at Savoy Square, which have served as the national broadcasting headquarters for the past eight years are to be abandoned this month when the cradle of British broadcasting is moved into the new house that radio built at Portland Place and Langham Street.

PARIS, Dec. 23, 1931. LAST Spring I had occasion to call the attention of the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES to a young Russian composer, Igor Markevitch, whose concerto for orchestra (the first work of his I had heard) had given me an extraordinary impression of creative power and originality.

Henry L. Mencken, editor and critic of life, politics and religion, sailed for a rest on the North German Lloyd liner Columbus yesterday, leaving behind him a series of pungent quotations on various topics in which he praised the quality of Baltimore beer, swept religion from the intelligent plane and intimated that he did not favor repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment because it was more fun to ignore than to repeal.

Alien (Dusty) Cooke, New York Yankee outfielder, was resting comfortably at the Medical Arts Sanitarium last night following an operation on his right shoulder to correct an ailment which developed as an outgrowth of the injury which the player sustained in a fall last Spring.

The gunners of the New York A. C. returned excellent scores over the Travers Island traps yesterday. The best work was done by B. M. Higginson, who broke 99 out of a possible 100 targets, to take the High Scrathch Cup.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- Southern Pines is now rapidly filling with visitors from the North and many events are being arranged for January and February. On Saturday, Jan. 23, the new Pine Needles Inn, located on the crest of Knollwood Heights overlooking the picturesque pine country of the sandhill hill resort section, will open its fifth season under the management of A. E. Richardson, who has long been connected with fine hotels.

WITH nearly 300 glistening automobiles on display, the National Automobile Show opened yesterday in Grand Central Palace. It will be closed today, but will reopen tomorrow and continue throughout the week, from 10 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. daily.
LONDON, Jan. 8. -- If any villain emerges from the piece which the Royal Licensing Commission has just set before the British public it is not the drink habit but the drink trade.

A spirited City College quintet brought an abrupt halt to St. John's eight-game winning streak at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium last night, conquering the hitherto unbeaten Vincentians, 28-18, in one of the most exciting games ever played at the Lavender gym.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 -- Western F. Hutchins, one of the oldest active newspaper men in the country, died at the Baker Memorial Hospital this morning at the age of 85. He had been ill twelve days.
PINEHURST, N.C. -- Pinehurst Field Trials Club, One of the pioneer bird dog organizations of America, will hold a comprehensive sports program during the coming week.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9. -- Dartmouth proved too strong for Pennsylvania tonight in the opening of the Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball season for both teams and won at the Palestra, 23 to 19, before a crowd of 4,000 rooters.

UNIVERSAL has found its tentative excursion into the more sinister phases of life profitable enough to warrant a cycle of films on the "Dracula" and "Frankenstein" order. Just now the studios are occupied with Edgar Allan Poe's macabre story, "Murders in the Rue Morgue."

Speculation is active in public utility circles regarding the regulatory legislation that will he enacted this year, according to Page Golsan. vice president of Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., engineers. Utility executives, bankers and engineers and the numerous investors in utility securities are interested in what the year may bring, he says.

Burleigh Grimes, the much-traveled hurler with the moist delivery, now cultivating his 230 acres near New Haven, Mo., takes time off occasionally from his farm chores to philosophize on baseball in general and his own diamond doings in particular. Attired in a hunting cap, blue shirt, leather coat, khaki trousers and high boots, the courageous right-hander discussed his most recent shift, Hack Wilson and Pepper Martin, the other day.

JAMES KNOX MTLLEN of Memphis had his doubts as to whether the hard rock of Manhattan would be as responsive to his efforts as was the Mississippi delta. Yet when 4,000 acres of his cotton brought forth smaller rewards than did his 4,000 copies of "How to Live On a Dollar a Week" his love of the levee quickly and understandably grew cold.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Prime Minister MacDonald will close the round-table conference on Burma Tuesday with a declaration which is expected to give a responsible, constitutional government to Burma and its 13,000,000 people.
