WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Dwight F. Davis of St. Louis tendered his resignation as Governor General of the Philippines today to President Hoover, who accepted it with regret and immediately sent to the Senate the nomination of Theodore Roosevelt of New York, Governor of Porto Rico, to be his successor.

Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland, former world's champion, by defeating Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia yesterday afternoon and Bennie Alien of Kansas City last night finished the State pocket billiard championship tournament at Dwyer's Broadway Academy unbeaten, with seven straight victories and the title.

Acceptance of the republican regime by the Spanish episcopate is announced in a statement by the Papal Nunclo at Madrid. That a serious conflict between Church and State was not among the near probabilities has for some time been evident. Nevertheless, it is a gain for stability that the bishops should rally formally to the republic.
BILLIARDS. Pocket billiard exhibition match. Ralph Greenleaf vs. Arthur Woods, at Strand Academy, Broadway and Forty-seventh Street ...................... 3 and 8 P.M.

THE executive committee of the Current Events Contest, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and held in twenty leading educational institutions, has adopted the policy of issuing a monthly test paper. Hero are the test questions and answers for December as furnished by the United States Naval Academy, the representative of this institution being a member of the executive committee.

HOLLTWOOD, Cal. THERE was a time when tourists stepped off the train, demanded to be taken to see where the pictures were made, and were. Even in those days they could not sea much, but they could see at least where the scenery stood and they were properly awed.

Retail sales volume during 1931 registered a decline of 11.5 per cent for the country as a whole, according to the "flash" report on dry goods and department store business, issued yesterday by the controllers' congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Canadian trade has been less seriously affected by the depression than has the trade of other nations of the European and American Continents and it probably will recover more quickly than business elsewhere, according to opinions of leaders of Canadian industry and finance which appear in The Montreal Gazette's commercial and financial review for 1931.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 9 Army's swimming team won from the New York University tankmen today in the opening meet of the cadets' season by 40 to 31.

DICTATORSHIPS we always have with us. Count Sforza writes by way of introducing his interesting survey of the present crop in Europe. Never have we been wanting in men ambitious to seize personal power. That their number and their virulence should increase after the storm and stress of the World War is not, he adds, surprising.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- New proof that Prime Minister MacDonald broke lifelong friendships by breaking with the Labor party is contained in an article by Lord Passfield, who was Sidney Webb, in the current issue of The Political Quarterly.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9. -- Macdonald Smith stepped out in front of 131 of his fellows today to lead the first round of the Los Angeles open championship with a sparkling 69.

Wall Street has expressed its satisfaction with the progress of constructive elements in the financial and industrial situation as shown in the first prolonged rally of the year. The prices have moved steadily upward, with only a slight breathing spell yesterday, for four consecutive days, increasing the total value of all listed securities about $3,000,000,000 over the low level reached last Tuesday.

The short interest in stock issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange make a total of 2,842,072 shares on Dec. 31, or 803,570 shares fewer than the 3,745,642 on Nov. 30, the last previous figure issued by the Exchange, it was announced yesterday. The figures issued yesterday showed the fluctuations in the short position in December.

DURING times of depression the pendulum swings too far, just as it does during a period of good business conditions. And it is usually the tendency of the man on the street to follow that pendulum, swinging beyond the actual facts of the business situation, rather than with the situation itself.
MADISON, Wis., Jan. 9. -- Wisconsin will become the first State in the nation to have an unemployment insurance law when a measure, passed today by the Senate, is signed by Governor La Follette.

TOMORROW marks the 174th anniversary of the birth of Alexander Hamilton. He was born of course, many hundreds of miles from Manhattan Island. Nevertheless, on that day, as a tribute to Hamilton, as the most distinguished citizen contributed by the metropolis to the nation, the new building of the Museum of the City of New York will be opened to the public.

The recent discussion by Dr. Henry Suzzallo, president of the Carnegie Foundation, and others, of the part fraternities should play in promoting high scholarship in the colleges calls attention to a new plan designed for that purpose which is being tried this year at Lafayette College, at Easton, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The situation in the Honolulu area, growing out of attacks on more than forty women, and the arrest of Lieut. Thomas H. Massie and Mrs. Granville R. Fortescue in the Kahahawai killing, has grown so tense that the Navy Department today canceled the proposed visit of the United States Fleet to the Island of Oahu, on which Honolulu is situated, during the February manoeuvres.

OMAHA, Jan. 7. -- In the last eighteen months there have teen eight unexplained shootings of the gangster type in or near this city. Four of them have resulted in the deaths of the victims. With one exception all were underworld characters known to have been engaged in bootlegging activities.
THE NASH MOTORS COMPANY if not exhibiting its 1932 ears at the show, but will bring out an entirely new line just before the opening of the Spring buying season, it is announced.

THE bomb squad of the New York Police Department, members of which have taken an active part in tracing the bombs recently sent to representatives in this country of the Italian Government, has been in existence nearly thirty years. It was founded in April, 1903, when Detective Joseph Petrosino began to be a terror to bombers, and it was first known as the Italian squad.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Led by Fred Kammer, who scored three goals, the Princeton hockey team overwhelmed Amherst today in the Hobey Baker Memorial Rink, 13 to 0. for its second victory in two days. Captain Barber and Cook each scored twice, while the remaining six goals were contributed by as many men.

THERE is a thoroughly professional appearing gentleman with, long, romantic whiskers, who maintains an office right here in Manhattan and gravely states that he is not a reformer exactly, but a "corrector of misinformation." Only the other day he informed me that he had been obliged to correct an error relative to the manufacture of the first automobile.

Major Granville Roland Fortesque, whose wife and son-in-law are under arrest in Hawaii on a charge of murdering a Hawaiian youth who was alleged to have attacked Major Fortesque's daughter, is ill of pneumonia in the Medical Centre here, it was learned yesterday.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Jan. 9 -- Williams opened its swimming season with a 51-26 victory over Union today. Beattie of Williams set a new college record for the 100-yard event, covering the distance in 0:57.4. Oppenheim made a new Union mark of 5:48.6 for the 440-yard event.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I SHOULD like to correct obvious misunderstandings of my article by two of your correspondents.

ROME, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini received today his first Papal decoration, the Order of the Golden Spur, possessed by only nine other persons, including King Fuad of Egypt, and former King Amanullah of Afghanistan. The decoration was presented at the Palazzo Venezia this morning by the Papal Nuncio, Mgr. Borgongini Duca.

BEATING an opponent at his own game has long been the favorite method of many successful fighters. And it beat describes the mode of attack used by Chrysler Motors engineers to beat engine vibration, which for years has been the common enemy of all automotive Engineers.

GEORGE ARLISS, with "The Man Who Played God" behind him, will rest for three or four weeks before beginning active preparation for his next film. Several stories, the Warner offices report vaguely, are under consideration and the nature and title of the new picture will be determined later in the month.

Staging a spirited drive in the final minutes of the game, the Fordham University quintet registered a 28-to-23 triumph over a strong fighting St. Peter's College five from Jersey City, before 2,000 spectators in the Fordham gymnasium last night.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP). -- The trek of English soccer football clubs toward Wembley, where the final of the English Football Association Cup competition will be played, reached its first big stage today when the third round was played. Sixty-four clubs, including the big first and second division teams, were engaged.

IN my twenty-five years' experience with the automotive industry we have seen many ups and downs, times of encouragement and times of uncertainty. In the early development of the industry there was a justifiable occasion for uncertainty because the ultimate position of the motor car as a contribution to progress had not been established.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 9. -- In the opening swim meet of the season for Lehigh the Brown and White went down to defeat before Rutgers today, losing 38 to 30.

MOSCOW, Jan. 8. -- An interesting but little-heralded International conference is about to open at Copenhagen, where the Danish Government has convened the chiefs of governmental press departments to discuss the official attitude toward and the handling of world news, with particular reference to international questions, disarmament and debts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- An investigation of charges by New York and New Jersey warehouse and storage companies that railroads serving the Port of New York were suffering financial losses in duplicating their services at less than cost was ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The second move in the administration's program for dealing with the economic situation was made today when Senator Thomas of Idaho introduced in the Senate and Representative Beedy of Maine offered in the House a bill to create a "depositors' relief corporation" with an initial capital of $150,000,000 to aid depositors in banks which have closed their doors since Dec. 31, 1930, or which fail in the future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- With complete harmony on the surface, in strong contrast with its last meeting, the Democratic National Committee today voted to hold tha national convention at Chicago, beginning June 27.

A strong recovery in prices for securities and com odities which appeared on Tuesday and Wednesday and continued to yesterday was the outstanding development in business last week. This rally was stimulated partly by a feeling that the conversations of the German Chancellor, Heinrich Bruening.
BOMBAY, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Jubbulpore's Nationalists lost their position today on the main street of the city, where they had been squatting since last Tuesday.

BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- In this time of economic chaos when all established maxims and methods have begun to be questioned and it rains prescriptions and plans from cranks and experts, much interest attaches to the ideas of Professor Erwin Baur, director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Breeding Research at Muencheberg, on the reorganization of agriculture.

TWO stars join the opera this week in the Metropolitan's usual turnover at midseason Following a second hearing each for "Donna Juanita" with Jeritza and "Lucia" with Lily Pons, Lawrence Tibbett sings with Bori in "Traviata," Gertrude Kappel returns in the first "Siegfried" and the eleventh week ends with first times of "Rigoletto" and "Trovatore" and a popular "Carmen."
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9. -- The second Victory in three starts at this meeting cams to M.S. Ingleright's Jaz Age when he won the Tropical Park Clubhouse Purse, feature at Tropical Park today.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 9. -- Holland's gigantic new flying boat, which will be twice as large as the Do-X, will be planned and built with the utmost care, according to Frits Koolhoven, head of the Koolhoven Aircraft Company of Rotterdam, which is undertaking the project.

According to one tradition about Genesis, it was the original intention to create the world in five days, but a Republican insurgent Senator insisted on holding things up for twenty-four hours until he could look into the matter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Peace-in-the-Hills" (a disguised name to point a moral!) is five miles from the nearest hamlet, ten miles from the nearest town. It is framed in blue sky and, even on this mid-winter day, warmed by golden sun. The air is so charged with oxygen that we who daily breathe it often wonder whether we have not found the secret of endless life.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- Sulky racing seems likely to have a prominent place in the Winter sports program here with the recent arrival of Jay Gould Day with his string of horses. With him is his trainer, Orman Lauer, who for the last sixteen years has been associated with well-known stables.

While Frank J. Taylor, Welfare Commissioner, was busy yesterday in a series of conferences, which he hoped would help the Home Relief Bureau out of the embarrassment caused by Controller Berry's announcement that the $5,000,000 to carry on the work of relief at the seventy-nine precinct stations was not yet available, signs developed in other quarters tending to show that the unemployment emergency was grave and increasing in severity.

BALTIMORE. BALTIMORE, in improving its main traffic arteries during 3931, chiefly for the expedition of automobile traffic, spent more than $3,000,000. For 1932 an ambitious program, in keeping with the pconomy plan of Mayor Howard W. Jackson, has been mapped out.

Dr. Brubacher's forceful suggestion elsewhere on this page that the novice teacher be fully licensed only after three years of successful experience meets this week a loud antiphonal chant from Ohio. Dr. Louis A. Pechstein, dean of the Teachers College of the University of Cincinnati.

The democracy of Prince Charles of Belgium is no longer news here. In Belgium, however, it is still regarded, with incredulity. When the Prince traveled homeward on the liner Westernland he became attached to Leslie J. Fountain, second purser.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP). -- Constance Bennett, motion picture actress, who recently married the Marquis Henri de la Falaise, filed a petition today in Probate Court seeking the adoption of Dennis Arthur Armstrong.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- Belgium and Rumania today joined the nations of the world which will have teams in the third Winter Olympic games Feb. 4-13.

MIAMI -- The third annual air tour sponsored by the Florida State Aviation Association, leaving here tomorrow, will be unique in many ways. The tour will come as a finale to the fourth annual all-American air meet which opened last Thursday and ended yesterday.

Many of the leading women track and field stars in this section of the country will be seen on Saturday night at the Paterson Armory when they take part in the second annual Golden Shoe track meet of The Paterson News.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The suggestion by a spokesman for the Japanese Government to Tokyo that Japan might seek a conference to revise the Nine-Power Treaty so as to give a clearer identification of the term "administrative integrity of China" was received with interest but some reserve today.

THIRTY young women under the direction of Miss Olive Whitman are working to make the performance of "Peter Ibbetson," at the Metropolltan Opera House on Jan. 29 in aid of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance, a great success.

Praise of President Hoover's policies throughout the economic crisis and a prediction that the situation would improve shortly and that Mr. Hoover would be re-elected in November were voiced by Arthur M. Hyde, Secretary of Agriculture, in addressing 1,200 members of the Women's National Republican Club at the club's eleventh annual luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

DESSAU. WHEN, early last Spring, it was learned that Professor Hugo Junkers had obtained an order from the German Ministry of Transportation to build a high-altitude airplane which was to be capable of rising to the unconquered heights of the stratosphere and of traveling at an average speed far superior to that of any plane ever constructed, the announcement created a sensation among airplane designers the world over.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP). -- John J. Curtis's Flying Heels, hero of the 1929 Pimlico and Agua Callente Futurities, and since a feared member of the Eastern Handicap Colony, has been honored with top weight in the Inaugural Handicap, the $2,500 event at six furlongs which will feature the opening at Hialeah Park next Thursday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 7. -- The unanimous decision by the Missouri Supreme Court this week sustaining Governor Caulfield's veto of the Congressional districting bill passed by the last General Assembly and thereby automatically wiping out all Congressional districts in the State has caused much political confusion, and party leaders, both Republican and Democratic, are wondering how to proceed with the next election.

WHAT new developments will the cars of future years bring? This is always a question pressing for answer by the automobile engineer, no matter how many new features and refinements his current product may incorporate.

ALTHOUGH it has lately been the subject of a great deal of discussion in the automotive industry, general adoption of genuine, tear-drop design in body building is still a matter of the future, in the opinion of George M. Graham, vice president in charge of sales of Rockne Motors Corporation.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 9. -- J. F. Calllnan's five-game victory over A. L. Glidden Jr. in the No. 1 match decided a New Jersey division Class B Metropolitan League squash racquets contest in favor of Montclair Athletic Club on the courts of the Englewood Field Club this afternoon.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Jan. 7. -- The determination, of the high plains farmer, hit by a depressed wheat market and a live stock market that has faded almost into nothingness, to keep his farm home, his land and his agricultural plant will carry him through, according to John Fields, president of the Federal Land Bank at Wichita.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. BALIEFF'S "Chauve-Souris" and -- no foolin' -- "East Lynne" have been the only matters of first-night interest this week. And the calendar for next week is vacant of premieres. In other words, the flurry of holiday openings has been followed by a lull.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- Army defeated Johns Hopkins University at basketball today, 35 to 27. The game promised to be a rout for the Army five, but a Johns Hopkins rally late in the first half, when Army was leading by a 10-to-4 count, lessened the gap, and thereafter the teams played on almost even terms.

THERE ought to be a law." There is ample evidence in the year's legislative record that a substantial portion of the nation's populace not only concurred with, the above sentiment, but endeavored to follow the word with the deed.

COMMODITY PRICES Lower levels were established in a majority of commodity articles yesterday. Particular weakness was found in butter and eggs, both of which showed sharp declines from a week ago. Grains also slumped. In futures, rubber was lower, while hides, silk and sugar were irregular. Slights gains were registered in coffee and cocoa.

A youth who came to this country on passage money borrowed from her was haled into court yesterday on the complaint of Mrs. Mary Gonch, 36 years old, of 1,151 Hoe Avenue, the Bronx, who charged him with an attempt to asphyxiate her and the four other members of her household.

Supporters of Governor Roosevelt's candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President returned yesterday from the meeting of the national committee in Washington, convinced that the meeting had greatly enhanced his prestige and increased his following in the Democratic ranks.

Paul De Bruyn, national marathon Champion of Germany, yesterday added another brilliant episode to the list of sparkling feats he has achieved since his arrival in this country two years ago. In winning the fast time prize in the invitation handicap road run held under the auspices of the St. Anselm's Athletic Club in the Bronx, De Bruyn equaled the course record of 22:40, set by John. Brennan, New York Central A.A. star, last week.

BERLIN, Jan. 8 -- Under the Influence of the Wall Street market prices have improved on the unofficial Berlin curb market during the whole of this week, with distinctive strength both in stocks and bonds. Trading was more active in highpriced shares, but cheap stocks had the larger percentage advance, many selling on Friday 25 to 30 per cent above the low figure of December.
BEIRUT, Syria, Jan. 10. -- The long discussed question of whether Syria is to be a monarchy or a republic has been brought to a head by the nomination of a President.

The multiple dwelling law committee, while willing to consider additional relief for the real estate and business associations which on Friday had requested a year's delay in enforcement of the reconstruction provisions of the dwellings law, will not accept the excuse of "economic depression" to lower housing standards in this city.

Maurice Campbell, former Prohibition Director for the New York district and Edward B. Dunford, general counsel for the Anti-Saloon League, debated the prohibition question yesterday over the radio from Station WOR.

MIAMI, Jan. 10 -- As twelve parachute jumpers from the same plane descended over a crowd of 10,000 spectators here today, the final event was reached in Miami's annual allAmerican air meet. One of the leapers landed in the grandstand, two others among parked automobiles and several manoeuvred their way safely among planes at rest near the hangars.
Science is faced with another inexplicable phenomenon. It is a mystery of some twenty years' standing, and it has to do with a wolf.

Tall new apartment buildings, streets extended and widened, rickety old houses demolished, basements turned from unwholesome living quarters into modern shops, are all described in recent news ,of Greenwich Village. For several years that part of New York which knows the Village only through the papers and by hearsay has taken for granted the disappearance of the former artistic atmosphere.

Agnes de Mille's dance program at the Guild Theatre last night was perhaps the most thoroughly successful of the programs she has offered hereabouts. Little by little Miss de Mille is evolving a type of performance that is entirely her own and that fits her peculiar talents as a regulation dance recital can never be made to do.

Aided by an allowance of two minutes and thirty seconds, William Marinan, 18-year-old novice, captured first place in the weekly handicap road race conducted by the Manhattan Athletic League under the auspices of the Good Shepherd A.C. on Riverside Drive yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Declaring for a fight "to the limit" to the Senate pass an amendment to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation bill to enable municipalities to obtain loans through it, Senator Copeland, who introduced the amendment Saturday at the request of Mayor Walker of New York City, asserted that he would act tomorrow in the Senate.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The British Cabinet will meet tomorrow to debate the reparations and war debt issues. The Burma conference was originally scheduled for discussion, but the reparations development thrust every other political issue into the background for the time being.

In his annual message to stockholders, cabled from Berlin, Albert B. Wiggin, chairman of the governing board of the Chase National Bank reviews the events of the past "year of disillusionment" and finds that while no mere optimism or legerdemain in the use of credit can restore the buoyant prosperity of 1929, sentiment is worse than the facts.

The National Automobile Show in Grand Central place was closed yesterday, but it will reopen at 10 o'clock this morning. Today will be International Day, and hundreds of foreign representatives of manufacturing companies and motor organizations will attend the exhibition.

There has just been completed a survey of a movement, begun forty years ago, that now touches most of the countries of the earth. It may be called an "adventure," since those who have carried its gospel and service have been for the most part possessed by the spirit of pioneers making experiment in new and strange fields.

Leon Lenz, whose pungent comedy, "My Wife's Perfume," was piquantly presented in Italian by the Teatro d'Arte at the Little Theatre, last evening, reveals himself no less a qualitative mathematician than, a quantitative wit and humorist. His dramatic diagram is scientifically precise -- with different dialogue it might serve as the setting for a tragedy.

The immediate reopening of the city's seventy-nine home relief stations, even if "extraordinary measures" are required to raise the necessary funds, was urged upon Mayor "Walker and the other members of the Board of Estimate yesterday in a letter sent them by special messenger from the advisory committee of social agency executives associated with Welfare Commissioner Frank G. Taylor in the home relief program.

Almost in the geometric centre of the Bronx Zoo lies the prairie dog village. It is a bare sort of enclosure, filled with humorists sitting on their haunches and looking at the antelope. In the Spring and the Summer hundreds of residents appear and in the colder months none is visible above ground.

Transatlantic passenger ships suffered a severe loss of patronage during 1931, all routes and most of the classes of service reporting totals far below those of 1930. Passengers on all routes on the Atlantic totaled only 939,468 during the year, according to the figures compiled by the Transatlantic Passenger Conference.

The condition of Major Granville Roland Fortescue, ill of pneumonia in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Centre, turned for the worse yesterday after a fairly comfortable night. He was reported last evening to be in a serious condition, but not in immediate danger.

Eddie Ran, Polish boxer, who is one of the hardest bitters in the welterweight division, meets Jimmy McNamara of the west side tonight in the St. Nicholas Arena ring. They are to meet in the ten-round feature bout of a boxing card arranged for the benefit of The Daily Mirror hospital radio fund.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 10 -- Fenghua, General Chiang Kai-shek's mountain home in Chekiang Province, is likely to be a Chinese Mecca for the next few days, as large numbers of government leaders are making pilgrimages there to request him to return to Nanking.

Governor Roosevelt is expected to act today in the case of Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, one of Tammany Hall's most influential district leaders, whose removal has been demanded on the basis of his testimony before the Hofstadter committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Outwardly official Washington continued aloof tonight on the whole question of debts and reparations, but there appeared a definite under-current of intense interest in Europe's discussions of the problem.
ROME, Jan. 10. -- Another masterpiece of ancient sculpture has been found during the excavations of the Roman baths at Porto Danzio, on the seaside about forty miles south of Rome.
HAVANA, Jan. 10 (AP) -- H.D. Bonesteel's 5-year-old mare Vacillate, ridden by Buddy Ensor, was a driving winner in the Iroquois Handicap, feature offering at Oriental Park today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- Continuing its second season of archaeological work at Tell Billa in Mesopotamia, a University of Pennsylvania Museum expedition led by Dr. E.A. Speiser has unearthed a Highly colored hematite figure of a bull, decorated with gold trappings, and has found other relics dating back as far as the ninth century B.C., according to word received from Dr. Speiser by Horace H.F. Jayne, director of the museum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Whether an open campaign against the renomination of President Hoover is to be made depends to a large extent on a decision expected momentarily from Senator Hiram Johnson of California. The restless State of North Dakota, which has a law requiring the filing of candidacies in the Presidential primary before Jan. 22, is forcing the issue in both parties.

"Harmony" was the watchword at the meeting; of the Democratic National Committee. In an atmosphere of politeness, Chicago was chosen as the convention city; a date after the Republican convention was set; and an allotment was fixed so that no States lost a delegate while some gained them.

To the Editor of The New York times I am smiling smugly to myself over your "Slump in Popcorn," because every Sunday evening without fail I pop rge bowlful and am never at ioss to find helpers to eat it. Those fragrant, white, tender kernels, yellow with butter, just salty enough, are supper enough in any setting -- along with cool milk and a big, stiff, leafy salad.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The active business of the year has begun with a distinctly more optimistic feeling about international cooperation in the war debt and reparations problem. In financial London, hopes are growing that Great Britain and France may agree on the policy to he pursued, especially since it is rumored that the French Premier is anxious to arrange an informal meeting at London to explain France's financial policy.

GENEVA, Jan. 10. -- The League of Nations Secretariat plans to publish daily during the arms parley the world's first telegraphic press review, covering the previous day's editorials throughout the world.

BERILN, Jan. 8 -- The first week of the new year has witnessed a slight improvement in business sentiment. This has been mainly due to the advance of prices on the international securities market, particularly the recovery in Germany's foreign bonds.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- A showdown on a new fiscal program, for the State looms as legislators begin to assemble for the sessions of the coming week, with Governor Roosevelt to submit on Tuesday his annual budget and details of his plan to raise about $140,000,000 through additional taxation.

HONOLULU, Jan. 10 -- An early trial in the Hawaiian, territorial courts is desired by Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, U.S.N., and his mother-in-law. Mrs. Granville Fortescue, who, with two naval enlisted men, are held aboard the receiving ship Alton on charges of murdering Joseph Kahahawai, one of five men accused of an attack on Mrs. Massie.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Arkansas probably will send to the United States Senate its first elected woman member on Tuesday, when the widow of "Fighting Thad" Car-away stands as a candidate to succeed her husband. She is now serving by appointment.

Sugar, coffee, cocoa, hides and rubber all failed to react to the rally in securities and the other commodities with sufficient strength last week to wipe out the losses established earlier in the week. All closed with small losses.

GENEVA, Jan. 10 -- Press reports that Japan may blockade China in reprisal for the Chinese boycott are regarded as disquieting in League of Nations circles. Officials take them the more seriously because they have been aware for some time that Tokyo was contemplating this step.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- A Congressional investigation of conditions in Honolulu is likely to grow out of the murder of Joseph Kahahawai, the arrest in the case of Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, U.S.N., and his mother-in-law, Mrs. Granville Fortescue, and the subsequent order from, the Navy Department that men of the United States fleet shall be barred from landing at that city in the course of the Pacific manoeuvres next month.

Investigation of the murder of Miss May Savage, 21 years old, who was shot while waiting for her chum, Eva Gladstein, 18, in Miss Gladstein's beauty shop at 644-A Elton Street, Brooklyn, last Saturday night, led the police to believe yesterday either that jealousy had been the motive for the crime or that it had been a case of mistaken identity.

Honors in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League's first week of competition were monopolized completely by Princeton University's quintet, which not only is leading the circuit at the end of the initial week of play, but also gained the distinction of ending Columbia's long reign over its league rivals by defeating the Lions last Wednesday night in the first game of the campaign, 35 to 32.

MANILA, Jan. 10 (AP) -- In deference to the current independence campaign being carried on at Washington, Filipino leaders today guarded comment on the nomination of Theodore Roosevelt to be Governor General of the Philippines.

The reduction in inventories and the indications of relative stability in prices of important commodities are two of the most significant trends of current business, says The American Bankers Association Journal. Progress made by basic American industries in readjustments to a lower level of prices, wages and other costs has been largely obscured by financial disturbances, the Journal says.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP). -- The State Department of Education is, giving its full attention at the start of the new year to the task of maintaining school standards in the face of curtailed public revenues.

The New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., held a luncheon yesterday in the Fraternity Clubs building, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, having as its guest Samuel L. (Roxy) Rothafel, whom it recently elected an honorary member. Mr. Rothafel told of the emphasis that would be laid on all forms of dancing in Radio City, which, he stated, would be open to the public in about thirteen months.

Elaborating on his statement made on the previous Sunday, in which he praised several prominent clergymen of New York for their courage and excellent leadership, Dr. Robert Norwood in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, asserted that the clergy of the United States have more actual intellect, more thorough scholarship, more common sense, more actual hardihood, than any other group of men in America."

More than 52 per cent of the assets of the Capital Administration Company, valued at market prices, was invested in United States Treasury certificates. State and municipal bonds, according to the report issued yesterday for the year ended on Dec. 31.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Lily Pons, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, will make her second appearance in opera in Westchester at the County Centre here on April 8. Mme. Pons's first appearance was last April 25, when she sang the title role in "Lucia di Lammermoor" in the third of the Metropolitan's Westchester performances.

The story of the Seabury investigations is being put into a book by two young men who have assisted Judge Seabury in his work and the volume will be issued in April by G.P. Putnam's Sons under the title of "The Insolence of Office." The authors are William B. and John B. Northrop.

The pledging of fifty-seven students to the eight fraternities comprising Violet Blace, an inter-fraternity council at the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance has just been announced by Seymour Sunshine, president of the Council.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 10 -- The Pasadena Stable's Joe Flores, an outsider in the betting, made the most of a light impost to defeat six tried handicap performers and win the $2,500 added California Handicap feature today.

A special Washington bicentennial service was held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon, under the auspices of the General Citizens' Committee and the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 10. -- According to a Mukden report, a surprise midnight raid on Tahushan, important railway junction, was made by 300 bandits, who were repulsed after a two-hour battle in the darkness. Lieutenant Namehugi and a sergeant were killed and five Japanese privates wounded.

TUNKHANNOCK, Pa., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Cheered by prospects of a warm battle in the Republican ranks, Democrats of the Fifteenth Congressional District plan to pick their candidate for this year's election in caucus here Jan. 21.

The Jewish people faced their most serious crisis in the last half-century, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise told members of the United Rumanian Jews of America at the dinner closing their twenty-third annual convention at the Hotel McAlpin last night. Dr. Wise said more militant interests by American Jews in the fortunes of their fellow-Jews in Germany and other countries was essential if 1932 was not to be looked back upon as a "year of tragedy."

MANILA, Jan. 10 -- The final reaction to the appointment of Colonel Theodore Roosevelt to be Governor of the Philippines is apathetic. He is practically unknown to Filipinos, not committed on the question of independence, and has had little or no contact with the various Philippine missions to the United States.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 10 -- President Hoover was praised here today for his dry stand and his stability in times of stress by Clinton Howard, chairman of the United Committee for Law Enforcement, who opened a campaign under the auspices of the Prohibition Loyalty League "to bring Massachusetts back into the Union in support of the Constitution."

BERLIN, Jan. 10 -- The German official position on reparations as restated by Chancellor Bruening yesterday suggested no departure from previous official utterances since the publication of the report of the Basle experts, and official quarters today appeared at a loss to account for the flurry occasioned abroad by the Chancellor's reiteration of the German standpoint.

With the thirty-fifth annual convention of the New Tork State Association of Builders scheduled here for Jan. 27 and 28 leaders in the construction industry in the eastern part of the country are speculating on what New York will do with its building trades wage adjustment problem.

Ossip Gabrilowitsch, conductor of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, concluded his week as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. The program, completely changed from those of last Wednesday evening and Friday afternoon, was the orthodox hind that is no longer orthodox; it consisted of Schubert's "Rosamunde" overture, Beethoven's Fifth Symphony and Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Scheherazade."

The appointment of receivers in mortgage foreclosure suits, according to present practices in the courts, is nothing more than "another racket," according to a report made public yesterday of the result of an investigation by the City Club. It will be sent to the State Legislative Commission to Investigate the Administration of Justice.

With every seat taken and the aisles jammed, the annual celebration of Mission Sunday in the Archbiocese of New York was observed at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon before a crowd estimated at 7,000. Hundreds who had been unable to gain admission waited outside to see the procession of 300 young boys and girls wearing replicas of the religious habits worn in more than 150 mission communities.
MOSCOW, Jan. 10 -- The United States note to Japan is featured on the front pages of the Soviet press under wide headlines.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The values delivered by Germany to the allied countries in fulfillment of the reparation duty imposed upon her by the Versailles Treaty are a subject of controversy, the German Government asserting that at least 53,900,000,000 marks have been paid, whereas the allied governments in their official accounting credit Germany with only 20,200,000,000 marks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Improvement in sentiment and buying of leading lines of merchandise, with indications of enlargement as the year advances, marked conditions last week here and throughout the West. Realization that supplies of wholesale and retail distributers are the smallest in years was reflected in more orders from consumers and distributers in all parts of the country.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Boston's Bruins and the Chicago Black Hawks battled through seventy minutes of play tonight to a 1-to-1 tie, thereby failing to break their tie for possession of second place in the American group of the National Hockey League.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Sir Howard Frank, head of the estate agency firm of Knight, Frank Rutley, died suddenly tonight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- The Railway Labor Executives' Association was today considering statistics on the average earnings of railroad workers, to be presented when they meet with the presidents representing the railroad managements of the country here on Thursday.

The fiftieth anniversary of the beginning of the Jewish colonization work in Palestine and the thirtieth anniversary of the establishment of the Jewish National Fund were jointly observed last night with dinner at the Hotel Edison, at which Nahum Sokolow, president of the World Zionist Organization, was the guest of honor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Two lists from which he will select new incumbents for vacancies In the dinlomatic and colonial services are before President Hoover.

A stroke of good fortune which enabled them to trace a $100 bill as it was passed from hand to hand was responsible, the police disclosed yesterday, for the arrest of the eight men on Saturday as members of a band of stock forgers alleged to have disposed of $5,000,000 worth of spurious certificates of the B.M.T., General Motors and American Telephone and Telegraph Companies.

Roger Q. "Williams, veteran transatlantic flier, had an unusual airplane accident which resulted in injuries to eight persons yesterday evening when he landed his plane at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn after a short sightseeing flight with five passengers.

The Trans-Lux newsreel house has thirty-two subjects on its new program, including the Tulane-Southern California football game, air views of the Mississippi floods, the arrest of Gandhi in India and a newsreel resume of India's political troubles since 1920, Japanese troops concentrating at Mukden for an offensive, Babe Ruth in training for the next baseball season and the arrival of Dr. Adolph Lorenz and Professor Einstein in this country.

The three-day exposition of building maintenance merchandise sponsored by the Real Estate Board of New York will be officially opened by Mayor Walker on Thursday. The exhibit is being held in the Empire State Building and is intended to show the various types of supplies, materials and apparatus used in every phase of the operation of large office buildings and apartment houses.

TOKYO, Jan. 10. -- The bloodiest encounter Japanese troops have yet had with bandits occurred this after-noon when four officers, including the regimental commander, Lieut. Col. Gentaro Koga, and fifteen privates were killed in a fight between a Japanese cavalry regiment and a bandit force estimated at 5,000 men at Chinshi, inland city about fifteen miles west of Lienchan.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan 10 -- In a return shoot over the traps of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today the representatives of the Engineers Club of Roslyn were defeated by the yachtsmen by four targets in a five-man team race. The best five gunners of the home club ran up a total of 467 out of a possible 500 targets.

The movement for the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and the lack of prohibition enforcement in New York City were attacked from pulpits here yesterday. Criticism was aimed particularly at John J. Raskob, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

MIAMI, FLA., Jan. 10 -- Celeste A. Durand, 18-year-old Brooklyn golfer, won the Miami mid-Winter amateur championship today, defeating Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., by 1 up on the Miami Country Club course in one of the greatest comebacks ever witnessed in a tournament here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- After two hours of speeches, punctuated by whistling, shouting and applause, a meeting sponsored by the "Women's International League today adopted a resolution calling on President Hoover to instruct the American delegation at the coming arms limitation conference to take the leadership in bringing about world disarmament.

CANNES, France, Jan. 10 -- Police identified today the American whose body was found washed up on the Cannes beach yesterday as Thomas Clark, aged 67, and according to papers in his possession, born in New York.

Addresses on Germany, Manchuria, banking problems in a period of depression and other subjects relating to the current economic situation, with particular reference to savings bank activities, will be included in the program of be Eastern Regional Savings Conference, to be held in the Hotel Roosevelt on Jan. 28 and 29 under the auspices of the Savings Division of the American Bankers Association.

In the good task or shaving1 Federal expenditure, Senator HARRISON has incidentally reinvigorated himself at the purest fount of Federal "literature." Of all the streams that issue thence, those of the Department of Agriculture are the most precious.
IF it isn't beneath the dignity of the bar and bench, some of our brighter legal minds should look into the game laws that govern or are supposed or alleged to govern affairs pugilistic.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 10 -- Complimenting her house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Munson H. Treadwell of Paris and Mr. and Mrs. Lorenzo Mitchell-Henry of London, Mrs. Alexander A. McKay entertained with a tea this afternoon at her villa Dr. and Mrs. Alfredo Ovien of Havana, who were to have joined the house party today, have postponed their visit for a fortnight.
The Bronx Hockey Club ran up a score of 23 to 0 to defeat the Bridgeport Hockey Club of the New England Hockey League at the New York Coliseum yesterday before a crowd of 3,000 spectators.

E.S.S. Carroll and A.L. Burns tied for the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Each finished the regular shoot by breaking 94 out of a possible 100 targets. Brilliant sunlight was responsible for the low total, as the sun reflected off the waters of the Sound, making it difficult for the nimrods to see the targets.

Back on its old-fashioned basis of a weekly change of actors' names and faces, the Palace has mustered nine acts of excessively varying quality with which to summon home such faithful patrons as may lately have fallen into the habit of seeing a promising show repeated for as many as nine weeks.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Just one week old, the Western conference basketball championship race already is in a turmoil.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 10 -- The first week of 1932 saw all Argentine grain exports above both the previous week and the corresponding week of 1931. Corn shipments were nearly double those of the first week of 1931. Trading was more active, and the prices of wheat, corn and flaxseed rose.

Dealers in securities in this State would be compelled to file character statements with the Attorney General under an amendment to the Martin act recommended in the annual report of Assistant Attorney General Paul J. McCauley, in charge of the State Bureau of Securities.

It is reassuring to note that Congress seems disposed to meet exceptional circumstances in an exceptional spirit. There has been, and of course will be, a certain display of partisan feeling in both the House and the Senate. That cannot be ruled out on a point of order.

The Elizabeth Town and Country Club squash tennis team strengthened its hold on first place in Class C of the New Jersey Group metropolitan team championship squash tennis tournament by triumphing over the Essex Club representatives of Newark, 4 to 2, on the victor's courts in Elizabeth yesterday.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Setting out in the first clearing they have had, the skippers of the Frostbite Yacht Club engaged today in their third series of Winter dinghy races.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Along with many friends with whom I have talked on the subject, I am sorry to learn that "Washington Crossing the Delaware" has been taken down from its place on the walls of the Metropolitan Museum. Whatever its critics may deign to say of the canvas, it has long been regarded as a good enough "illustration" piece.

The annual Wagner matinee cycle will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House, beginning Feb. 12. It will include six operas: "Tannhauser," "Tristan und Isolde" and the entire Ring des Nibelungen, without cuts, comprising "Das Rheingold," "Die Walkure," "Siegfried" and "Gotterdammerung."

China's difficulties with Japan are closely linked with the tremendous social and economic upheaval now going on in China, and there can be no real stability in the Far East until China has completed successfully her transition period or definitely failed, according to a discussion of the Far Eastern problem in Volume 6 of The Encyclopedia of the Social Sciences, which Macmillan is issuing.

BASLE, Switzerland, Jan. 10 -- Chancellor Bruening's declaration that Germany can never pay reparations had a numbing effect on the monthly meeting of the central bank governors at the Bank for International Settlements today. The meeting lasted only an hour and accomplished nothing important.

The New York Giants soccer team defeated the New York Americans by 7 to 2 in a first-round National Challenge Cup tie at the Polo Grounds yesterday before 2,000. The victors were in front at half time by 3 to 1.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. David Swing Starring and the Misses Carolvn and Elizabeth Starring have left the Plaza for their home in Green Farms, Conn.

The metropolitan amateur boxing championship tournament will get under way at Madison Square Garden at 7 o'clock tonight, with 100 of the leading amateurs in the district in the race for the eight titles. The tournament will be concluded on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- President Hoover has prepared two special messages to Congress which he is withholding for a time, but, according to administration circles, neither has any direct reference to prohibition.

A drive against a ring of racketeers posing as immigration, inspectors and preying upon aliens illegally in this country is being pushed by immigration authorities and the police as a result of the arrest and conviction last week of two members of the band, according to Edward Corsi, Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The need for an organized program of education for prisoners, academic, vocational and cultural, is stressed in a special report of the Lewisohn Commission in prison administration which will be presented to the Legislature tomorrow.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- John Lowry, posting a card of 90 -- 16 -- 74, carried off the low net honors at the fifth weekly qualifying round of the annual Snowbirds golf tournament held by the members of the Siwanoy Country Club over the club's course today.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- Prime Minister MacDonald issued a statement tonight asserting that Chancellor Bruening's call for the termination of reparations at the Lausanne conference was not unexpected, in view of the conditions disclosed by the report of the Young Plan experts at Basle.

NEW DELHI. Jan. 10. -- A new constitution for India before the end of March, 1933, is the hopeful prophecy of the London round table conference delegates, who were returning to their homes today after week-end talks with the Viceroy, the Earl of Willingdon.

Reserves of moral strength and idealism are the greatest guarantee of the United States, or of any nation, in times of stress such as the present, said the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, minister of All Souls Unitarian Church, in his sermon yesterday. He spoke in the hall of the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street, where the congregation is meeting temporarily.

On the eve of the reparations debate at Lausanne and the disarmament conference at Geneva there are party manoeuvres under way on both sides of the Rhine. The German Chancellor discusses cooperation with HITLER. The Laval Ministry in France is expected to resign and reorganize.

Captain Hugo Bergman, Manual Training wing, and Joe De Lorenzo, Jamaica centre, are still tied with five goals apiece for first place in the individual scoring race among the P.S.A.L. hockey players, although both failed to add to their totals during last week's play, when the competition was resumed after the Christmas vacation period.

The dinner in honor of Samuel Levy, which marked the end of the annual drive for funds of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, held at the Hotel Commodore last night, netted the federation more than $43,000, it was announced, and brought the total received for the support of the ninety-one institutions affiliated with the federation to within a few thousand of the goal of $5,138,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Wheat traders are in a position in which they are afraid to sell short with the expectation of getting more than a small profit or to make large purchases and take advantage of small bulges to obtain gains. The result was that prices on the Board of Trade here fluctuated last week within a range of 3 cents a bushel and the net losses were only 3/8 to 5/8 cent.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 -- Macdonald Smith, after stroking the Hillcrest Country Club's golf course yesterday in 69, added a sensational 68 today for a total of 137 for the first 36 holes of the Los Angeles Open-Championship. This placed him five strokes below par and the same number in front of the field.

In reshaping the prison policies of New York State, Governor ROOSEVELT and the legislative leaders have come to rely heavily on the advice of the temporary commission established two years ago to investigate prison administration and construction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Friends of former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York have urged him to become an active candidate for the Democratic nomination for President against Governor Roosevelt, but Mr. Smith so far has resisted all attempts to get him to do so.

Despite the fact the Ulen Co., in which it has large interests, was obliged to defer preferred dividends and pass common dividends during the year, the net income of the American International Corporation was sufficient to cover interest and all other charges and leave a balance to surplus of $168,889, according to the annual report issued today.

The "political ring" that governs New York is actuated, not by public responsibility but by the spirit of racketeering, Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick charged yesterday morning in his sermon at Riverside Church.

Last season's finalists in the A. A.U. national amateur hockey championship play-offs, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club and the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, battled to a 1-to-1 tie yesterday in the feature game of a double-header at Madison Square Garden.

BOMBAY, Jan. 10 (AP). -- Two disturbances, in one of which a crowd estimated at 12,000 persons rescued three prisoners from a police station, were reported today in India's struggle against British authority.

GLENDORA, Miss., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Saddened refugees, aided by the Red Cross, were returning home this week-end to mop out their dwellings in the wake of flood disaster. No further rise was reported in the mad Tallahatchie River or its tributaries. The valley a month ago was flowering in agriculture, but now is buried in mud and water.

Zora Hurston's "The Great Day," drawn from four years' salvaging of rare Negro folklore in the deep South and some of the nearer Atlantic islands, was performed by a choral and dramatic ensemble in scenic background at the John Golden Theatre last night for the first time here.

Buying in the wholesale apparel markets proved a disappointment last week in all lines excepting men's wear. Compared with the corresponding week last year the volume of purchases of women's dresses, coats and other garments was small, but producers expect the situation to adjust itself this week when many stores are scheduled to place orders for current and Spring sale.

No Tax Strike. All things considered, the city met one test of its credit successfully at the close of the year. The amount remaining uncollected on the 1931 tax levy at that time was a little less than 97 millions.

A request that parishioners of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Avenue, eat less and use the money saved to feed ,the destitute, was made yesterday morning by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich. He asserted that most persons in the congregation could easily reduce the number of courses in at least one meal a day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- A scarcity of fancy heavy steers and light yearlings and a fair supply of plain steers showing sufficient quality for Eastern, buyers resulted last week in a good trade here and a close 25 to 50 cents higher for these grades, while medium steers, with a surplus supply, finished the week at a decline of 25 to 50 cents.

The opinion that the Eighteenth Amendment should be nullified by the passage of a superceding amendment, expressed yesterday in Brooklyn by Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut, former, dean of the Yale Graduate School, evoked a storm of heckling and a challenge from one man In the audience to "debate the prohibition question."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- President Hoover is represented as strongly opposed to the Democratic tariff bill as it passed the House, and, in the opinion of most Republican leaders, he will veto it if it comes to him with the provision which takes from the Executive the power to pass on recommendations of the Tariff Commission and gives it to Congress.

As long as the nations cling to economic nationalism the world depression cannot be cured, Sir William H. Beveridge, director of the London School of Economics, declared yesterday in a radio address broadcast from London over the WABC-Columbia network.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 10 -- Trading in cotton was interrupted last week by holidays, but activity increased toward the end of the period. There was also some recovery in prices, the net gain being almost $1 a bale. The stock market influenced cotton values, but the latter responded more promptly to the late improving tendency in stocks than they had done in the earlier declines.

Declaring that the Polish Government is doing nothing to improve the situation of the Jews, the Federation of Polish Jews of America, in a statement released through the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, announced yesterday its withdrawal from the Polish-Jewish Good-Will Committee here on the ground that to retain its membership "would lead to a distorted view of the Jewish situation in Poland to those unacquainted with the actual state of affairs there."
Two plays will open tonight in the Broadway theatres -- "Black Tower," at the Sam H. Harris, and "Three Men and a Woman," starring Walker Whiteside, at the Lyceum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A bill to legalize the right to work and compel employers to distribute jobs according to quota will be offered in the House tomorrow by David J. Lewis, Democrat, of Maryland. Some of the features of the measure include the employment stabilization program recently suggested by Gerard Swope president of the General Electric Company.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- In the rubber market here today plantation grades were quiet and barely steady. Smoked sheet spot sold at 3 1/8d a pound value, January at 31/8d value, February at 33-16d to 3 1/8d buyers, March at 3 1/4d to 33-16d buyers, April-June at 3 3/8d to 3 1/4d buyers, July-September at 3 1/2d to 37-16d value, October-December at 311-16d to 3 5/8d sellers, crepe spot at 3 5/8d value.

The New York Rangers regained their winning stride last night by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. After being outplayed in the opening session, the New York skaters, leaders in the American group, returned to the ice with a savage, desperate attack which enabled them to roll up a 2-0 triumph over their rugged opponents from the North.

President HOOVER'S appointment of the Governor of Porto Rico to be Governor General of the Philippines is an instance of calling a man to be ruler over many things who has been faithful in ruling over a few. Into the work of the Porto Rican Government THEODORE ROOSEVELT has, during his term of office there, thrown himself with great energy and intelligence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Dec. 23 appeared a letter from Charles N. Whinston, headed "Labor and Dwellings Law," in which occur certain statements indicating a misunderstanding of the activities of the Labor Department in enforcing the law regarding manufacture in tenements.

The organization of the Interports Transportation Corporation, which will transport coal, granite, fertilizer, stone products and other bulky materials between New York and New England ports, was announced yesterday. The company will take over the business of the Bee Line Transportation Company of Boston and New York, and will be closely affiliated with the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, 17 Battery Place.

A moral and spiritual fear of the United States, based primarily upon the "Hollywoodizing" of this country, pervades the world and affects all our international relations, the Rev. Dr. George Luther Cady, secretary of the American Missionary Association, said yesterday in a sermon at the Congregational Community Church of the Circle, Mount Vernon.

Eunice Norton, pianist of uncommon youth and grace, a native of Minneapolis, and sent by musical patrons of that city to study with Mattay in London and Schnabel in Berlin, made what was announced as her New York recital debut yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 9 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 65.3, which compares with 66.3 a week ago, 66.7 two weeks ago, 67 three weeks ago and 67.1 four weeks ago. The highest average of 1931 was 78.5, in the week ended Jan. 3; the 66.7 of Dec. 26 was the lowest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- By a vote of 63 to 8, the Senate, after a debate which ran into the midnight hour, tonight passed the first of the administration's major relief measures -- the $2,000,000,000 reconstruction finance corporation bill, after accepting some amendments and rejecting many others, including that offered by Senator Copeland authorizing the corporation to make loans to municipalities.

Butter. Receipts, 55,698 packages. The market showed extreme irregularity yesterday. Early can sales of extras were effected at 23c, 1/2c below Saturday's level. This move, however, brought out freer buying interest, partly of a speculative character and values recovered to a range of 23 1/2@24c at the close.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- With his budget ready for submission and his annual message out of the way, Governor Roosevelt will be in a position to decide on several important appointments of importance.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- A man was suffocated by smoke and two others were injured early today when fire destroyed a large part of the interior of the Historic Gartenhaus, formerly known as the Red Lion Inn. Five men and a woman who were sleeping on the upper floor were roused by a fireman and escaped just in time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Declar- ing that the "heroic efforts" of cities and local charitable organizations have "failed tragically" to meet the unemployment problem, Senator La Follette advocated tonight in a na- tion-wide radio broadcast the float- ing of a $5,500,000,000 bond issue after the manner of the World War Liberty Loans drives.
A mild form of subway crush gave a contemporary touch to the opening yesterday of the home of New York's past, the new building of the Museum of the City of New York.

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- Chancellor Bruening's project to have President von Hindenburg's term of office prolonged beyond May 5, through the adoption of constitutional amendments by the Reichstag, has been definitely defeated through the opposition of the National Socialist and Nationalist parties.

John J. Monaco, 45 years old, of 787 East 185th Street, the Bronx, was dismissed yesterday from his position as assistant clerk of the Essex Mar- ket Court by Chief Magistrate James E. McDonald, who announced that he would send a report of the case to District Attorney Crain.

Domestic corporation bonds were buoyant on the Stock Exchange yesterday with a long list of issues furthering their improvement of last week by a point or more. Foreign loans, however, were irregularly lower, and United States Government bonds were weak.

Out in Kansas, where every farmer has a pain and every politician a panacea, they are beginning to wonder whether "conservatism called "constructive may be coming out of "the clouded skies" of public affairs. Our Watch-Tower correspondent at Topeka was musing on these matters the other day.

An attempt to organize a "strike" of Washington Heights residents against the present electric light rates, which would include the refusal to pay bills, will be made by Communist leaders, it was declared yesterday at a hearing of the Public Service Commission on the application of the Washington Heights Taxpayers Association for a reduction in domestic consumer rates of the New York Edison and the United Electric Light and Power Companies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Respond- ing to a resolution by Senator Bing- ham, who contends that 4 per cent beer would aid unemployment, Secre- tary Lamont today reported to the Senate that 77,779 persons were en- gaged in making distilled malt and vinous liquors in 1909, that the number jumped to 86,811 in 1914 and fell to 46,081 in 1919.

Each of the fifty magistrates in the city will get an opportunity to see the conditions under which convicts live when they assemble for an inspection of the Welfare Island Penitentiary on Jan. 21 at the invitation of Richard C. Patterson Jr., Commissioner of Correction.

Last week's decision of the United States Supreme Court in the "grainrate case" is of high importance both as defining the rights of the railways under the Transportation Act and as setting forth the duties of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

BOMBAY, Jan. 11. -- Mrs. M.K. Gandhi, 60-year-old wife of the Mahatma, was arrested today, a week after her husband was jailed. This was the first time she was taken into custody although she carried on much All-India Congress propaganda in last year's campaign of civil disobedience.

An extraordinary pianist and a master musician, Egon Petri, made his American debut last night in the Town Hall. Mr. Petri's high reputation as virtuoso and pedagogue had preceded him. Born in Hanover, he is 51 years old, the son of the violinist, Henri Petri.

More than forty men representing almost every organized group in the legitimate theatre met yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor to plan a united and national campaign against the 10 per cent admissions tax recently proposed by Secretary of the Treasury Mellon.

Finally they exterminate Dr. Eugene Ludlow in "Black Tower," which was acted at the Sam H. Harris last evening. And a good thing, too. No fiend could be more treacherous. In Walter Kingsford's unctuous acting the doctor is a man of honeyed speech, deferential manners and Old World courtesy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It Samuel Untermyer and former Transit Commissioner Lockwood have finished their mutual admiration contest, and are through throwing bouquets at each other, the people of New York might give thought to the real problem of the transit situation and the best solution of it.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 11. -- President Ortiz Rubio revealed in Congress tonight that a moratorium on Mexico's foreign debt had been extended to Jan. 1, 1934, by agreement between the Ministry of Finance and the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, in New York.

An exhibit to arouse the public to the importance of clean air and clean streets will open today at the New York Academy of Medicine, 103d Street and Fifth Avenue, and continue for one week. It contains models and pictures of street cleaning apparatus, ventilating machines, stokers, graphs and charts and instruments used in measuring air contamination.

Shipments of automobiles by the Chrysler Corporation last year made a total of 270,927 units, or 2 per cent more than the 266,169 shipped in 1930, it was announced yesterday. This increase was contrasted with an estimated decrease of 25 per cent in the shipments for the entire automobile industry in 1931.

Despite recent charges of bribery against a score of Coast Guardsmen, the personnel of the service as a whole is "honest and heroic," Howard W. Ameli, United States Attorney in Brooklyn, declared yesterday at the annual union meeting of ministers held under the auspices of the Anti-Saloon League of New York in the Union Methodist Church, 233 West Forty-eighth Street.

The year 1931 was the warmest on record in New York City in sixty-three years, was very clean atmospherically and was unusually dry, according to the sixty-third annual report of the New York Meteorological Observatory in Central Park, made public yesterday by David R. Morris, meteorologist in charge.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 11. -- Mrs. William Hunninghouse, president of the Huntington Dog Club, Inc., announced today a reward of $100 for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons guilty of torturing pet animals. During the past week a number of cases of torture and mutilation of animals has been reported to authorities.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted.

Prices fluctuated nervously on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday in a small volume of trading, and closing quotations showed a mixture of gains and losses. Domestic bonds were generally weak, but some brisk gains appeared in the foreign group.

The State began presenting evidence yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Nathan L. (Nigger Nate) Raymond, California gambler, on one of three indictments in connection with a $6,000 loan obtained on two stolen stock certificates, in 1928, from the branch of the defunct Bank of United States, at Broadway and Sixty-eighth Street.

The painting of "Washington Crossing the Delaware," which hung in the Metropolitan Museum of Art many years, and which was removed temporarily to provide wall space for the H.O. Havemeyer collection, will be taken from the storeroom and shown at the entrance to the American wing, on the second floor, during the period of the museum's Washington Bicentennial Exhibition beginning Feb. 16.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Free competitive grain markets and the abolition of government interference were declared to be essential to business recovery today by Peter B. Carey in accepting the presidency of the Chicago Board of Trade.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 11 (AP). -- In a dramatic sequel to the greatest manhunt in Cincinnati's history, Charles Bischoff, 45-year-old shoemaker, weary and unshaven, confessed today to kidnapping and assaulting six-year-old Marian McLean last month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Wets of the House planned today to challenge the dry followers of the administra- tion on prohibition by proposing sub- stantially the Wickersham Commis- sion's suggested change for the Eighteenth Amendment.

The erection of tariff walls by every nation on earth eventually will lead to an international reaction in favor of free trade, that will tear down barriers and enable the streams of commerce to flow more freely, Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, predicted last night at a dinner at the Hotel Plaza, given by the Pilgrims in honor of William Duncan Herridge, the Canadian Minister to this country.

Mr. and Mrs. George Dupont Pratt or 580 Park Avenue and Glen Cove, L.I., will send out invitations shortly for the marriage of Mr. Fratt's daughter, Miss Dorothy D. Pratt, to Samuel Croft Register 2d of Brookville, L.I. It will take place on the afternoon of Feb. 6 in St. John's Church of Lattingtown, L.I. Bishop Frank Du Moulin, the rector, will perform the ceremony.

Indictments charging first-degree forgery were returned by the grand jury yesterday against eight men who were arrested last Saturday in an alleged conspiracy to circulate $5,000,000 in bogus stock certificates of the General Motors Company, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the B.M.T.

The fossil of an extinct anthropoid ape, higher on the scale of evolution than the gorilla, man's nearest living evolutionary neighbor, was displayed on the screen last night by Dr. William K. Gregory of the American Museum of Natural History during a symposium on "The African Great Apes, the Gorilla and Chimpanzee," held under the auspices of the biology section of the New York Academy of Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Unexpected opposition to the authorization of $450,000 for expenses of the American delegation to the Geneva armament conference, led by Representative Blanton, Democrat, of Texas, blocked passage of an appropriation resolution in the House today.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Real estate now carries 80 per cent of the entire burden of taxation in New Jersey and should not carry more than 50 per cent. Harry A. Taylor of East Orange, the new president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, declared in his inaugural address at a meeting of the association's board of governors at the Robert Treat Hotel here today.
ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- With the Leg- islature resuming its sessions to- night, the selection of Fred L. Porter as chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee was an- nounced by Speaker McGinnies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Another new year has opened on a world all at sixes and sevens. It finds starvation and superabundance staring each other in the face, and so-called statesmen not knowing which way to turn. Meanwhile petty party politicians, eager for plunder and place, are wholly absorbed in gaining prestige and power for personal aggrandizement rather than for public service.

Eddie Ran, hard-hitting Polish welterweight, knocked out Jimmy McNamara, west side lad, in the second round of the scheduled tenround feature last night of a series of bouts conducted at the St. Nicholas Arena in the interests of The Daily Mirror Hospital Radio Fund

PARIS, Jan. 11. -- While shaken at the opening today by the effects of Chancellor Bruening's declarations, the Paris Bourse survived the shock without a panic and during the day regained its poise and a considerable part of the opening losses.

One Progressive Senator after another has refused to shake hands with opportunity and become a candidate against Mr. HOOVER in the Republican Presidential primaries. Each brother has resigned the flattering prospect to some other brother.

Sharp criticism of the delays that have characterized the city's rapid transit policy are contained in a report submitted by the Republican advisory committee to the Republican County Committee, made public yesterday by James Marshall, chairman of the advisory committee.

MONTREAL, Jan. 11 (Canadian Press). -- Only five scoring points separate eight players in the struggle for point-making honors in the National Hockey League, according to the weekly figures released tonight from the office of President Frank Calder.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- Chancellor Bruening's week-end statement regarding Germany's attitude toward reparations was reflected in a weakening of sterling exchange today, the pound being offered against both dollars and francs. The New York rate opened around Saturday's closing at $3.40 and declined to $3.37 before firming to $3.38 1/2.

A new type of car said to embody many features of airplane construc- tion, such as a highly streamlined body and wheels independently sus- pended without an axle, was demonstrated yesterday by its designer, J. V. Martin, head of the Martin Aero- plane Factory of Garden City, L. I.

BOMBAY, Jan. 11 (AP). -- The boycott against British goods, declared by the All-India Nationalist Congress, has succeeded in cutting business in Bombay to one-fourth its normal volume. The Bombay Cotton Exchange, second largest in the world, has dropped from 100,000 bales a day to less than 100, a daily loss amounting to about $3,000,000.

Tammany is viewing with no little concern the situation that has arisen in the past week as the result of the city administration's difficulties with the bankers over its finances. Closing down of the city's relief agencies may prove a serious blow to Tammany among the rank and file of the voters, it was admitted yeaterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 (AP). -- It was understood tonight that both Adolf Hitler and Dr. Alfred Hugenberg were writing letters to Chancellor Bruening explaining that they revered President von Hindenburg and wanted to see him re-elected, but insisted that it be done constitutionally -- that is, by popular vote.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11. -- Dartmouth's basketball team defeated Yale tonight, 21 to 20, and the Hanoverian five went back to New Hampshire tied with Princeton for the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11. -- Nearly a month ago Hear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., commandant of the Fourteenth Navy District with headquarters in Honolulu, warned the authorities of that city to keep the five accused attackers of Mrs. Thomas H. Massie in jail for their own safety and the peace of the community.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 11. -- The admission that Harold Savage, all-round school athlete who led the Bridgeport Central High School teams to several State triumphs in the past year, has lived for years under the identity of a younger and deceased brother and was over the 20-year age limit, threatened an upheaval today in Connecticut interscholastic sports and also laid open to question his school's claims to State championships in baseball, football and basketball.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Thomas Price, secretary of the Union Pacific Railroad and storm centre in equestrian circles here since his elec- tion to the presidency of the New Jersey Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in 1925, an- nounced today that he would retire from the latter post on the expira- tion of his term next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Testimony that he was "severely reprimanded" by an official of the Department of Commerce for his warnings on flotation of Peruvian bond issues in the United States in 1928, was given today by Oliver C. Townsend, who was the commercial attache at Lima.
