HONOLULU, Jan. 11 (AP). -- How the two women principals in the Honolulu attack and murder cases applied for permits to carry weapons, and how one of them later purchased a pistol, became known today.

BREMEN, Germany, Jan. 11. -- The District Attorney has started an investigation of certain stock transactions of the North German Lloyd which complainants charge have violated the legal publicity requirements.

BALBOA, C.Z., Jan. 11. -- The Panama Pacific liner California won a race against death early today when it plowed into Panama Bay at full speed to save the life of George C. Richards, first assistant engineer, who lives at 950 Plymouth Street, San Francisco.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 11. -- Fast play by the Bates sextet beat Bowdoin, 3 to 1, in a State series game on the Delta today. Bowdoin tied the count in the second period on spectacular work by McLaughlin. Swett made the winning tally a few minutes later.

Herbert N. Rawlins Jr., former national and metropolitan squash racquets champion, started his campaign to regain the latter title at the University Club last night with a straight-game victory over E.M. Jonklaas of the Rockaway Hunt Club, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 7.

PARIS, Jan. 11. -- France's refusal today at Basle to extend to Germany the Bank of France share in the $100,000,000 credit to the Reichsbank which, expires on Feb. 4 was hailed this evening in Paris as a just and emphatic reply to Chancellor Bruening's reported words last Friday.

In its zeal to expose a few cases of imprudent foreign loans, floated in the United States since the war, the Senate Finance Committee appears to be ignoring the economic and commercial principles which caused that general movement. It was simply that America, after becoming the chief creditor nation, assumed the historic role of one.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11. -- O.F. Woodward's Chatover, making his first start since the Bowie meeting, proved a comparatively easy winner of the feature race today at Tropical Park in which he was made a 3-to-5 choice despite his long lay-off. The 6-year-old son of Chatterton and Day's Over was a length in front of Tantalizing at the end of the six furlongs and was timed in 1:12 flat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP). -- The authorization of new warships was held up before Congress today as one means by which arms limitation conferences could be made successful. Admiral William V. Pratt, chief of operations, and Representative Darrow sponsored the idea before the House Naval Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The Democratic tariff bill, which passed the House Saturday, reached the Senate this morning only to be met by a move on the part of some Re- publicans to kill its main provisions and substitute a proposal for placing oil and copper under the protection of the Hawley-Smoot act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Open market policies of the Federal Reserve System, plans for strengthening the financial structure and the Presidential reconstruction program were discussed today when governors of the Federal Reserve banks met here as the open-market committee. Easing of the money market was expected to be the policy pursued in the next half year.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 11. -- In its annual report today to Governor Larson, the Public Utility Commission asked for greater power in the regulation of railroads, grade crossing eliminations, privately owned toll bridges and radio broadcasting stations.

Winfield R. Sheehan, vice president and general manager of the Fox Film Corporation, has received a three months' leave of absence to recover from a nervous breakdown, it was announced yesterday by the company. According to his brother, Clayton Sheehan, he is paying the penalty "for working eighteen hours a day for twenty years."

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 11. -- Eric Nelson and Donald J. Ross of Little Compton, Mass.; Eric Thomson of Springfield, Mass., and R.C. Shannon of Biddeford, Me., on one team, and Herbert D. Vail of Glen Cove, L.I.; W.W. Windle of Worcester, Mass.; Charton L. Becker of Antwerp, N.Y., and G.M. Howard of Halifax, N.S., on another team, tied for first place in the golf tournament of the Tin Whistles today.

Notwithstanding that the official rate for call loans on the Stock Exchange ruled at 2 1/2 per cent, there were reports that some banks were able to arrange renewals at 3. This disparity in quotation was further widened by reason of the fact that street trades were done at 2, and Federal funds sold 3@3 1/4.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Jan. 11. -- Livingston Davis, Belgian Consul, former high official in the Navy Department and one of Brookline's wealthiest citizens, snot and killed himself today in a woodshed on an estate about 400 yards from his home at 240 Dudley Street.
District Attorney Crane took a hand yesterday in the investigation into the reported appropriation of interest on official funds by former Sheriff Charles W. Culkin.

See Trade Drop for Half-Month. Unless there is a decided pick-up in sales tor the remaining four days of the half-month, retail dollar volume is expected to register the poorest results for any similar period since the depression started, according to local retail executives.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Vice President Curtis was the guest of honor at the mid-season Bachelors' Cotillion, given tonight at the Mayflower Hotel and attended by 300 members of official and resident society and others from out of town, including Princess Koudacheff, who came from New York, Lady Lister Kaye, who arrived last week for her annual visit on her way to Palm Beach, and a group of young people from Baltimore.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 11 (AP). -- Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, is of the opinion that France would have seized the left bank of the Rhine had Germany's reparations announcement come a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The assertion of Chancellor Bruening that Germany could make no further reparations payments was viewed here today as prompted by political conditions in Germany. It came as no great surprise to administration officials, because it had been assumed that such a declaration would be made at the Lausanne Reparations Conference, if not before.
RENO, Nev., Jan. 11. -- Marguerite Edyth Totten Fanning filed suit today for divorce from Russell Moore Fanning on grounds of desertion and non-support.

Tremendous changes in child training, education and in our general understanding of human behavior are resulting from scientific psychological research, seven psychologists, each a member of the faculty of a leading American university, declare in a symposium presenting an appraisal of the more significant achievements and aims of psychology in many fields.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 11. -- The difficulties in connection with the negotiations now going on at Riga to improve the troubled Russo-Rumanian frontier conditions have been intensified by the killing of six young men near Soroca, Bessarabia, last night.

Jim McMillen. 217 pounds, former University of Illinois football player, last night won the right to meet Jim Londos for the title when he defeated Ray Steele, 215, California, in the main wrestling bout at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

Surrogate John P. O'Brien reserved decision yesterday on the petition of Charlotte M. Fixel, former chorus girl, to have herself declared the common-law wife of the late Abraham L. Erlanger, so that she can share in the theatrical producer's fortune, which is estimated at $75,000,000.

MULLING over Connie Mack's all-star baseball nine that he picked recently for discussion at Hot Stove League meetings, for no apparent reason there came to mind an all-star golf nine. The ball players were all professionals, of course. Just for the fun of it the golf nine was picked from among the amateurs. To make it easier the field was limited to amateurs of this country.

The annual chase for the metropolitan amateur boxing championships started at Madison Square Garden last night, when the preliminary round bouts of the title tournament were contested. A crowd of 8,000 persons witnessed the bouts, which provided considerable action.
NEW YORK. William Duncan Herridge, the Canadian Minister, is at the Plaza.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Professional operations are largely responsible for the fluctuations in the wheat market. Local traders on the Board of Trade sold early today on the dip in stocks, but gave it up when they found fair support as the May neared 56 cents a bushel.

Sales and shipments of carded cot- ton cloths during 1931 exceeded pro- duction by respective percentages of 3.6 and 2.5, according to figures is- sued yesterday by the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York. Output for the year totaled 2,784,402,000 yards, as compared with 2,819,723,000 yards in 1930.

Passalc, N.J. A new issue of $1,900,000 city of Passaic (N.J.) 6 per cent bonds, due on Dec. 30, 1933 to 1935, will be placed on the market today by B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc. The bonds, which are issued for tax-revenue purposes, will be priced to yield 5.25 per cent.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 11 (AP). -- Rhode Island interests today opposed as "most disastrous," a plan to place holdings of the Pennsylvania Railroad in the Boston Maine and New Haven Railroads under a trusteeship.

An open avowal of the intention of organizing for the Presidential primaries was made yesterday by James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, and the head of the Roosevelt boom for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- The British Cabinet held its first meeting of the year this afternoon to approve the government's Burma policy, which is to be announced tomorrow by Premier MacDonald at a final meeting of the Burma round table conference.

Both the National and Columbia broadcasting systems will report over nation-wide networks the Olympic Games at Lake Placid from Feb. 4 to 13, it was announced yesterday. The N.B.C. plans have been completed, while the C.B.C. details have not as yet reached final form.

The issue over municipal relief and retrenchment has developed in such a way as to cause misunderstanding and bitterness. At first it was reported that Controller BERRY thought that the emergency had been exaggerated. This he vehemently denies, at the same time pledging all his efforts to raise the funds necessary to carry on the work of relief to which the city is pledged.
CARLSBAD, N.M., Jan. 11. -- The whole front of Sitting Bull Falls, a beautiful waterfall in the Lincoln National Forest, higher than Niagara Falls, has caved in.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 11. -- The technical details of the huge Koolhoven flying boat, which will be twice the size of the German Dc-X, became known today.

To Wall Street the course of the stock market yesterday was extremely interesting. There were opening declines of 1 to 2 points in leading issues on the Stock Exchange, but later the whole market rallied sharply, the railway shares setting the pace.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- A writ of mandamus compelling the Board of Review of Cook County to place more than $15,000,000,000 of additional personalty on the 1930 assessment rolls was issued today by Superior Judge Williams Roy Massena, attorney for the board, obtained an appeal from the order and the case will go to the Supreme Court.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 11. -- Edna Ferber defended herself in a lecture at Yale University today from criticisms which she has received over a description of a Connecticut house and characters in her novel, "American Beauty."

BASLE, Jan. 11. -- The Bank of France reserved at a meeting of the World Bank board here today the right to veto the extension of the $100,000,000 credit to the Reichsbank which expires on Feb. 4. It is thereby assured that France during the first ten days of the Lausanne conference will have decisive control over German currency.

Increased selling from cotton producing sections lowered quotations yesterday at the opening of the Cotton Exchange, but the prices steadied and at the close were 1 to 6 points higher than on Saturday. At one time, May reached 2 points under last week's high level, and the market held within a range of about 10 points throughout the session.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 11. -- A fleet of 100 taxicabs bearing machine guns manned by carabineers apparently held in check a general strike today in Santiago.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Craig B. Hazlewood, chairman of the committee for the protection of holders of first mortgage bonds sold through the American Bond and Mortgage Company, has announced that a plan for reorganization of the Park Central Hotel of New York has been adopted jointly by two bondholders committees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Brief ceremonies in memory of Alexander Hamilton, first Secretary of the Treasury, were held under the auspices of the Sons of the American Revolution today on the 175th anniversary of his birth.
"The Animal Kingdom," Philip Barry's new comedy, with Leslie Howard as its star, will be presented by Gilbert Miller and Mr. Howard at the Broadhurst Theatre tonight.

Mrs. Irving D. Harris was accused by her husband in the Supreme Court yesterday of leaving their home last November, of taking their year-old son John Wakefield Harris with her, and of refusing to return to her husband or permit him to see the child.

Tommy Loughran, Philadelphia's veteran heavyweight, will be the first out-of-town boxer to be affected by the rigid enforcement of the State Athletic Commission's rule requiring boxers of other localities to be in the city five days in advance of a local match for which they are scheduled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Law-abiding citizens of Hawaii, and this includes American and foreign as well as the native-born, deplore and condemn the crime of which Mrs. Thomas H. Massie was the victim, Victor S.K. Houston, the delegate in Congress from Hawaii, declared today.

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- The conclusion of the bankers' negotiations for the further stabilization of Germany's foreign credits is expected about the end of this week in financial quarters. While there are still many details unsettled, the representatives of the creditors have been reconciled on the whole to conditions which are believed to be acceptable to the German debtors.

News stands selling magazines which are considered obscene by the License Commissioner may have their licenses to sell all newspapers and periodicals revoked by that official, it was said yesterday in a formal opinion given to License Commissioner James Geraghty by Arthur J.W. Hilly, Corporation Counsel.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Receipts of hogs today were the largest for the second Monday in January since 1926 and prices declined 10 to 15 cents from Friday's level and were steady to 10 cents lower than on Saturday, heavies showing the most weakness.

Jacob Share, who had been a trusted employe of the Postoffice Department for fourteen years, dur- ing nine of which he served on the lower east side, attached as a letter carrier to Station B at 45 Suffolk Street, heard himself denounced yes- terday as the meanest man in the department.
The High School of Commerce five defeated De Witt Clinton, 21-14, in the Commerce gymnasium yesterday.

Vincent Coll, 23-year-old gang leader, acquitted last month of the murder of Michael Vengali in the so-called East 107th Street "baby killing," returned to police custody yesterday. With his bride, Lottie, whom he married soon after his acquittal, and two of his retainers, he was taken to Police Headquarters last night on a charge of conspiracy.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 11. -- B. F. Fairless, executive vice president of the Republic Steel Corporation, reported today that some leading automobile builders had placed their usual quarterly contracts at the end of 1931 and were giving releases against the contracts, and that in consequence the company's sheet and strip mills bad increased operations.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- Governor Roosevelt today expressed the hope that there would be the fullest measure of cooperation from the Legislature in expediting the passage of his Executive budget bill, which will be presented at the session tomorrow.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 (AP). -- Dick Morris, a 4-year-old from the Knebelkamp Morris Stable, won his fifth consecutive race today when he outclassed a field of sprinters in the six-furlong feature at Jefferson Park.

A Christopher Street property acquired sixty-eight years ago by Jeremiah W. Dimick, rug merchant, has been sold by his estate to the Castle Craven Hotel Corporation. The motion picture house on the site, at 121-23, has been occupied for fifteen years by the New Hudson Theatre, under the management of the E.R. S.W. Amusement Corporation.

ROME, Jan. 11. -- The Rassegna Storica del Risorgimento, the official publication of the National Italian Historical Society, today published a special edition containing an article by its editor, Professor Eugenio Casanova, who is also director of the Italian State Archives, confirming the authenticity of the disputed Lincoln letter supposed to have been addressed in 1853 from Springfield, Ill., to the Italian scientist, Macedonio Melloni.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Mainte- nance by the United States of ade- quate naval and military forces "based on the strength and effective- ness of armament throughout the world" was recommended to President Hoover today by a delegation representing the editorial board of The Seventh Regiment Gazette, a publication of the Seventh Regiment of the New York National Guard.

Tripping and Tripped In a fine burst of sentiment about never putting "humanity above dollars," Mayor WALKER referred to the number of benefit performances he has attended, sometimes as many as three or four in one night.

Pleas for a law to ban slot machines of the type used for gambling, for an adequate blue-sky law, and for changes in criminal procedure such as requiring notice of an alibi defense and allowing waiver of jury trial, were heard yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel McAlpin of the New York County Grand Jurors Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The case involving the attack on Culver B. Chamberlain, United States Consul at Harbin, who was attacked by a Japanese civilian interpreter and two Japanese military police in Mukden, Manchuria, on Jan. 3, is to be closed with punishment of the three assail- ants, which Secretary Stimson con- siders adequate.

Resignations of Dr. Henry Klaus, medical director, and the four physicians with whom he served as medical council of North Hudson Hospital in Weehawken were accepted yesterday by the Board of Governors of the institution. The council of five who are still members of the medical staff, resigned in protest against amended by-laws of the hospital which they contend usurp their rights to recommend appointments to the medical council and staff.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Charles G. Dawes flatly put a stop today to speculation over whether his intention to resign as Ambassador to Great Britain might mean his candidacy for the Presidency. He declared it an insult to him to intimate that President Hoover would not have "my loyal and entire support."
MOSCOW, Jan. 11. -- Chancellor Bruening's demand for the ending of reparations was featured in the Soviet press today, but without commerit in any newspaper and somewhat cautious headlines.

The sum of $504,427 has been raised thus far to defray the expenses of free hospital treatment for those who are unable to pay, it was an- nounced yesterday at the annual meeting of the corporation of the United Hospital Fund by Otis Ever- itt, assistant treasurer.

In as punishing and swiftly paced a match as the season has witnessed, Edward G. McLaughlin of the Columbia University Club, third in the national ranking, defeated Milton Baron of the Fraternity Club last night in the Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club.

The Chatham Phenix National Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday to foreclose a mortgage on 415-19 Fourth Avenue, southeast corner of East Twenty-ninth Street, on which $1,163,000 of a total of $1,230,000 in consolidated mortgages is due.

The nomination of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler for the Presidency, by both the Democratic and Republican parties, was advocated yesterday in the leading editorial of the Columbia Spectator, student publication of Columbia University.

An ex-convict, sought in connection with a shooting and hold-up earlier in the day, was shot dead by detectives yesterday afternoon, as he leaped, pistol in hand, into a courtyard from the window of his furnished room on the ground floor of 331 Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn.

Following Saturday's "week-end reaction," yesterday's stock market resumed the upward movement. Domestic bonds also extended their recovery, a list of considerable length allowing gains for the day of 4 and 5 points. Foreign bonds were somewhat more uncertain, some of them rising further while others lost a point or two, and United States Government securities slipped off 1/4 to 7/8.

Delegations of automobile men from Detroit, Chicago and other cities yesterday visited the Nations Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace, swelling the attendance at the first full day of the exhibition which opened Saturday afternoon.

The cutting by 10 per cent of all salaries of $250 a month or more and the serving of notice for a 15 per cent wage reduction on about 50,000 unionized workers was announced yesterday in behalf of the Railway Express Agency, Inc., by R.E.M. Cowie, its president.

TOKYO, Jan. 11. -- The destruction of half of a Japanese cavalry de- tachment numbering eighty men has given to the public here an illus- tration of the difficulty of controlling a territory overrun by armed bandits.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11. -- Roam- ing the left side of the San Francisco Seals' infield is a big, black-haired youngster, businesslike, efficient, the best shortstop in the minor leagues.

Tuneful and abounding in dances, Offenbach's "La Vie Parisienne" gave a new glimpse of France's second empire gayeties to a first audience on upper Fifth Avenue last night, when the New York Opera Comique, Inc., revived this companion piece of the famous "Belle Helene" and "Orpheus aux Enfers" after forty years for a single week's run.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The Fed- eral Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Jan. 6 shows decreases for the week of $153,000,000 in loans and investments, $96,000,000 in net demand deposits, $44,000,000 in time deposits, $56,000,000 in government deposits, $202,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks and $290,000,000 in reserves with Federal Reserve Banks.

BOSTON, Jan. 11. -- Max Sehmeling of Germany, heavyweight champion, tonight came figuratively into the back yard of Jack Sharkey, his American rival, and a crowd of 10,000 watched Schmeling go through three rounds of exhibition boxing.

ADOLF HITLER has declined BRUENING'S invitation to join in prolonging President HINDENBURG'S term of office. This leaves the Fascists and their allies, the Hugenberg Nationalists, free from entangling alliances. HITLER'S decision may have been influenced by the news from the latest regional election in the miniature State of Lippe, with a population of about 175,000 and a Diet of twenty-one members.

Net operating income of 171 Class 1 railroads dropped sharply in November, although not by so large a percentage as in the preceding months last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Bureau of Railway Economics. Net operating income of the roads was $37,064,000 in November, against $62,564,000 in November, 1930, a decline of 40.7 per cent.

TIENTSIN, China, Jan. 11. -- A week after the Japanese occupied Chinchow, the Peiping-Mukden Railway from there to Shanhaikwan was in the utmost confusion and rigorous military discipline still prevailed.

The heads of all city departments, as well as the five Borough Presidents, were ordered yesterday by Mayor Walker to begin immediately a policy of "the most rigid economy compatible with the city's necessities."

To leaf through, pages of travel advertisements assures that Americans are prone to travel to improve their minds. At least copy-writers obviously think so. Other reasons, of course, they admit. They dangle the bait of sunshine and fragrant pines, "adventure, luxury, sunshine, joy-of-living," or the prospect of a "great time."

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- The continua- tion of the Japanese aggression against China would be certain be- fore long to lead to Communist revo- lutions in the latter country, in which case the Red fire would surely leap over into India and, apart from the political danger involved, would close to the distressed Occident the most important Asiatic markets, in the opinion of the newspaper Deu- tsche Allgemeine Zeitung.

The directors of the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation will meet tomorrow to formally approve the purchase of the Prairie Oil and Gas Company and the Prairie Pipe Line Company, negotiations for which have been going on since last May, when they were resumed after having been dropped in the Autumn of 1930.

Harald Kreutzberg opened his fifth American season last night at the Cort Theatre, bringing with him by way of novelty a group of four dancers to assist him, and leaving behind him Yvonne Georgi, who has been his partner for the last three years.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Tuesday, Jan. 12. -- The Midland Bank became a part of the Cleveland Trust Company as a result of a combination consummated yesterday, officials of both banks announced early today.

The Yale Club squash team maintained its winning streak in the Class C series of the metropolitan league championship by scoring a clean sweep in the match with the Princeton Club on the victor's courts last night.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 11. -- Weights for nominees for the Agua Caliente Handicap, with a guarantee of $50,000, to be run March 20, were announced at the Jockey Club today. Phar Lap, Australian wonder horse, is assigned the top impost of 129 pounds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The back-ground of the present disturbance in Hawaii is political, not racial. A purely local event, which is not less horrifying, of course, because of that, has apparently stirred a nation. It seems to me the true picture of the matter is deserving of some report.

WARSAW, Jan. 11. -- Foreign Minister August Zalesld, alluding to the Lausanne conference in a speech today at a luncheon given by the Foreign Press Association, said he believed the recent statement of Chancellor Bruening of Germany on reparations had created an entirely new situation, and he could not see how the conference would be able to discuss the Basle experts' memorandum in the light of the Chancellor's stand.

HONOLULU, Jan. 11. -- A move toward calling a special session of the Hawaiian Legislature to deal with the outbreak of crime in Honolulu was made today while a grand jury was being chosen which will decide on whether Mrs. Granville Fortescue of New York, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and two navy enlisted men shall be indicted for the murder of Joseph Kahahawai.

The feeding and clothing of needy children must take precedence here over the teaching of the three R's as the primary aim of the public schools at present, Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 11. -- Revival of steam power for airplanes will be definitely started in Cleveland within the next thirty days. Small model working units, designed to use in modernized town the same power that took Professor S.P. Langley on his famous tryouts in the '90s, will be carried into the air to check calculations with the actual per- formance.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11. -- Macdonald Smith, veteran of a thousand golfing battles, today won the Los Angeles open championship for the third time in seven years, covering the seventy-two holes in 281 strokes, three under par.

Making a plea for downward re- vision of tariffs throughout the world, J.D. Mooney, president of the General Motors Export Corporation, yesterday urged a break-up of the "present deadlock in international trade arising from artificial trade barriers."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The Navy Department has ordered Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., commandant at Pearl Harbor, not to release Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and Seaman Edmond J. Lord to the civil authorities unless directed to do so by the Navy Department.

FOREIGN emissaries of sport are reaching our shores these days to participate in the Winter Olympic Games at Lake Placid while most of our own athletes are in the throes of serious preparation. Not the least among those already designated to represent this country in the Olympic: is Miss Maribel Y. Vinson.

The material and spiritual problems of the millions of untouchables of India were discussed yesterday by Miss Katherine Mayo, author and investigator at an international missionary meeting in St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and Sixteenth Street.

Additional contributions of $1,573,75 for the Neediest Cases were received yesterday, bringing to $285,914,93 the total raised in response to the twentieth annual appeal in their behalf. The total is within $59,875,72 of last year's fund.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11. -- The Yale indoor polo team will make a trip to Cincinnati and Cleveland the coming week-end and will play a ten-game schedule this season, including matches with Harvard. Princeton and the Army. It will also play in the intercollegiates.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11. -- The Yale Dally News, in the first issue published from its handsome new building on York Street, advised Yale today to follow Harvard in abolishing Spring football practice.

The 1932 Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association will be held over the course of the West Hills Racing Association at Huntington, L.I., it became known yesterday. The probable date is June 11.

Many art-lovers will be grateful to Maud Dale for assembling the Fantin-Latour exhibition, which opens privately today and to the public tomorrow at the Museum of French Art, 22 East Sixtieth Street. The pictures are hung in the new galleries that were given to the French Institute last year by Mr. and Mrs. Chester Dale.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 11. -- It now ap- pears likely that General Chiang Kai-shek will return to Nanking as the "saviour of China" rather than as a detested dictator. Meanwhile the quandary of the present Nanking Government la growing more complex.

The problem of resuming the city's unemployment relief work, brought to a standstill by the financial crisis in which the city now finds itself, was put squarely up to Mayor Walker yesterday by Controller Berry in a letter to heads of welfare organizations cooperating with the Home Relief Bureau.

What the Brooklyn police described as the "slickest" ring of automobile thieves tracked down in many a day was broken last night with the arrest of three men in a Brooklyn apartment, the confiscation of a quantity of bogus bills of sale, Motor Vehicle Bureau forms and an ingenious "jumper box" or lock-bridge used by the three to start the motors of locked cars.

Additional contributions of $594.88 to the Neediest Cases Fund were received yesterday in response to the twentieth annual appeal. They brought the total to date up to $286,509.81, within $59,280.84 of last year's fund.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 12 -- Although Harvard has dropped Spring football practice as a formal sport this year, Carl Hageman, captain of the varsity team, has received a prompt response from eighty players who have signified their intentions of working out every Monday afternoon for eight weeks.

The first step in Mayor Walker's recently announced policy of "the most rigid economy compatible with the necessities of the city" was taken yesterday by the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate, which postponed indefinitely consideration of items calling for the expenditure of $110,115,121.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- At the direction of Governor Roosevelt, Conservation Commissioner Morgenthau, chairman of the Governor's Agricultural Advisory Commission, has called a meeting of that body next Tuesday to consider the milk problem throughout the State and the farm credit situation, which affects particularly the western part of the State.
Mayor Walker last night broadcast a welcome to automotive leaders and out-of-town visitors gathered here to attend the thirty-second annual National Automobile Show at Grand Central Palace.

More than one-fourth of the 5,330 minors sheltered by the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children in 1931 were Negroes, according to the annual report of Colonel Ernest K. Coulter, general manager, adopted at the fifty-seventh annual meeting of the organization yesterday at 2 East 105th Street.

Another home has been offered for the painting "Washington Crossing the Delaware." A plan to "erect a marble art shrine" for the large canvas in Fort "Washington Park, "among inspiring surroundings of imperishable white marble and green verdure and trees," has been announced by John Mara, Democratic leader of the Twenty-third Assembly District, Manhattan, and executive member of the Minqua Club, the Tammany organization, of the "Washington Heights and Inwood section.

COLONEL, EDDIE RICKENBACKER was talking about speed in general and the Indianapolis 500-mile auto race in particular, and over in the corner was a round-faced, rather elderly man, wearing spectacles and smoking a cigar. He was just listening placidly. He didn't look as though he ever went anywhere in a hurry. He seemed more like a man, who could sit quietly, smoke a cigar and watch the dizzy whirl go by with contentment.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 12 -- Mrs. Anna M. Hunninghouse, president of the Huntington Dog Club, received today a telegram from Assemblyman Louis A. Cuvillier announcing his intention to offer a bill in the State Legislature making it a felony to "assault or kill a dog out of spite or without justification."

Samuel Seabury, who prepared the charges which Governor Roosevelt has directed Sheriff Thomas M. Farley to answer, was expected yesterday to ask the Governor to remove from office Borough President John A. Lynch of Richmond.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The patriotic efforts by income tax and surtax payers throughout the country to help the government over its financial emergency by prompt payment of the instalments due Jan. 1 were reflected in tonight's Exchequer returns.

Following are the items transferred yesterday by the Board of Estimate from the day's calendar to the so-called "suspense calendar" in the shelving for the time being of city projects totaling $110,000,000:

The Gusmit Realty Corporation and the Baring Realty Company filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against Eliphalet L. Davis and the Reldnas Hall Corporation to foreclose a mortgage for $82,500 given in 1926 on the property at the southwest corner of 122d Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on which $66,605 is due.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Coast guardsmen of the Longport station seized a skiff early today at Great Egg Harbor Inlet, loaded with 500 cases of liquor of a value estimated at $25,000, the first evidence of activity by the rum fleet off this city in several months, they said.
The four-story brick flat at 18-20 Enos Place, near Sip Avenue, Jersey City, was bought by the Mortgage Purchasing Corporation from Mrs. Margaret Herbermann of Montclair.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Hoover in nominating Judge James H. Wilkerson of the Federal District Court at Chicago today to be a judge of the Seventh United States Circuit Court of Appeals, personally announced to the newspaper correspondents that the promotion was in part a recognition of Judge Wilkerson's "splendid service" in curbing gangster activities in Chicago.

The city's efforts to borrow money from the banks for emergency use and all plans for relieving unemployment through public works financed by bond issues, were attacked yesterday afternoon by Francis H. Sisson, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company at a tea given by the Republican Committee of One Hundred at the Hotel Carlyle, 35 East Seventy-sixth Street.

Edward L. Lee, New York Athletic Club, national amateur three-cushion billiard champion, won the second straight block of his challenge match with Charles D. Gill, New York Lodge of Elks, 50 to 37, in 58 innings at the Amateur Billiard Club last night.
BOMBAY, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A bonfire of foreign cloth burned tonight in Bombay as a symbol of the Indian Nationalist boycott campaign for the country's independence.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Six thousand five hundred meteors have been observed by the joint expedition of Harvard and Cornell Universities, which is making a comprehensive meteor study at Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Ariz., in an effort to throw new light on the evolution of the universe.

LANCASTER, Pa., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Lancaster Trust Company suspended business today while a number of city business leaders worked with the bank officials to effect a reorganization of the institution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The high hopes entertained by Secretary Stimson for the outcome of the Geneva disarment conference are not held by Admiral William V. Pratt, Chief of Naval Operations and ranking adviser at the London Naval Conference, the latter told the House Naval Affairs Committee today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 12 -- Arnold Minkley of Detroit returned a 78 to take first place today in the final qualifying round of the annual invitation tournament of the Miami-Biltmore Country Club, play in which begans on Thursday. Minkley equalled the score turned in by Tubby Price of Miami in the first test yesterday to tie for the medal.

Major William Kennelly was elected president of the New York Athletic Club for the seventh, consecutive year at the sixty-fifth annual election of officers, held at the city clubhouse yesterday, and thereby achieved the distinction of being the second to hold that office for seven years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why do prohibitionists block the efforts of the antis toward temperance and honesty? Call a speakeasy a saloon -- that is what it is, an unlicensed saloon -- and let the country see that not a saloon has been closed. There are five times as many saloons now as there were before national prohibition, and there are all kinds to suit every possible purse and condition.

OTTAWA, Jan. 12 (Canadian Press) -- While the conscription of men for military service and the expenditure of millions of dollars on armaments continue, the danger of war will exist, Prime Minister Bennett declared here today following the acceptance of an anti-war petition compiled by the League Nations Society in Canada and the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.

The development in this country of a spirit of cooperation in the approach to the perplexing international problems of debts and tariffs is one of the major requirements for the restoration of world confidence and recovery from the depression, Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the National City Bank, yesterday told stockholders of the institution at their annual meeting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Oliver Wendell Holmes, veteran jurist and liberal and lovable philosopher, resigned today as an associate justice of the Supreme-Court because of the condition of his health.

An investment deal in the Fifty-ninth Street shopping zone in which the buyer expressed confidence in the future of real estate values in that area was announced yesterday. The buyer, J. Clarence Davies, purchased 645-7 Madison Avenue, between Fifty-ninth and Sixtieth Streets.

White more than 9,000 persons, a record gathering for a wrestling show in the New York Coliseum, cheered him wildly, George Calza, Italian challenger, last night pinned Sandor Szabo, Hungarian, in 32 minutes 31 seconds of the feature match with a reverse body slam.

At the annual dinner of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, held in the Hotel Commodore last night, Merle Thorpe, editor of Nation's Business, attacked "governmental bureaucracy" and declared that "we shall not see better times for a period of years, and then only after a political revolution or worse," if the United States Government undertakes to carry out a program of direct Federal aid for the unemployed.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 -- Thousands of school teachers, police, firemen and other city employes in five Massachusetts cities are payless, or will not receive their wages next pay day, the treasurers of the cities admitted today.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross returned to London from Paris tonight without, it is understood, having achieved any great progress toward an Anglo-French accord on the reparations question. The talks naturally were hampered by Chancellor Bruening's declaration that Germany could not pay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your remark that the Republicans are being justly punished by the voters for the wild promises of the 1928 campaign tells only half the story. Jurors and executioners are as guilty as the defendants; the depression falleth alike on the just and the unjust, but about 60 per cent of the electorate is getting what it deserves.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The 21-year-old Earl of Jersey and Miss Patricia Richards, an Australian girl two years his junior, were married in a brilliant ceremony at St. Margaret's, Westminster, this afternoon. Miss Lucille Browne of New York was one of the bridesmaids.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Imre de Josika Herczeg gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for Countess Bethlen.
Mrs. John Aspegren gave a luncheon yesterday in the Georgian Room of the Pierre for Miss Lucile Thieriot and Miss Peggy Sykes, de butantes. In the party also were:

Charles (Vannie) Higgins, whose repeated encounters with the police in the last five years have won for him notoriety closely approaching that of the late Jack (Legs) Diamond; Morris Grossman, chief of police of Long Beach, L.I.; seven of the latter's subordinates and eight other persons went on trial yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn charged with conspiracy to violate the prohibition law.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- The possibility that France might refuse to prolong its share of the Reichsbank's foreign rediscount credit beyond March 4 has introduced an entirely unexpected new factor into the political situation. It is felt in financial circles that here again France holds a powerful weapon with which to direct the course of the forthcoming reparations conference.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 12 -- Coach Eddie O'Donnell of the Yale wrestling team announced today that an intramural wrestling tournament would be held between the college and the Sheffield Scientific School, the two undergraduate departments. Captain Edward Rotan of the varsity team said tonight he believed the contest would lead to the development of intramural competition in the university.

Science is once more confronted with the problem of spontaneous generation, believed to have been settled once and for all by Pasteur more than seventy years ago, Dr. Thomas Milton Rivers, of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, said last night at a round-table conference on general phases of animal virus diseases, held at Columbia University under the auspices of the American Institute.

The Legislature that met at Trenton yesterday is equally divided politically. The Senate has fourteen Republicans to six Democrats, the Assembly thirty-four Democrats to twenty-six Republicans -- forty to forty on joint ballot. A Republican Governor submitted his last message and on Tuesday next his successor, a Democrat, will be inaugurated, who will in turn make his recommendations.
The following is the text of Samuel Seabury's charges against Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, as made public here and in Albany after Governor Roosevelt directed the Tammany officeholder to answer them:

BOSTON, Jan. 12 -- The New York Rangers broke their Boston Garden jinx tonight and defeated the Bruins, 5 to 3, in an overtime contest crowded with rugged play. The game, the first one the Rangers have captured in this city in three seasons, was the Bruins' fifth consecutive extra-session clash.

PARIS, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Premier Pierre Laval, who headed the government of France for just ten days short of a year, presented the collective resignation of his Ministry to President Doumer at the Elysee Palace tonight.

Following close upon the report that a syndicate of British capitalists had leased for a long term of years a building to be erected at Fiftieth Street and Fifth Avenue in the Radio City group, announcement was made yesterday that the French Government had leased new quarters in the Fuller Building at the northeast corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue.

Nathan Milstein, violinist, who appeared in recital last night in Carnegie Hall, gave an uneven and interesting performance. The best part of his concert took place when it was half over. Nervousness might account for earlier shortcomings. The finest performance of the evening was that of Corelli's "La Folia."

Philip Barry has written one of his best, "The Animal Kingdom," put on at the Broadhurst last evening. In the principal role Leslie Howard gives one of his richest performances. In fact, the news of the drama is uncommonly exhilarating this morning from nearly every point of view.
A first-round match and nine in the second round were completed in the metropolitan squash racquets championship on the courts of the University Club last night.

A chance meeting in Miami, Fla., 1,387 miles from home, between a Brooklyn woman, whose home was robbed five weeks ago of $5,000 in cash and jewelry, and a man whose face seemed to her "vaguely familiar," resulted yesterday in the arrest of the man as one of the three responsible for the robbery.

Newton D. Baker as a man of strong liberal mind, international outlook and sound intellect developed under the influence of three men -- his father, the late Tom Johnson of Cleveland and Woodrow Wilson, in whose Cabinet he served as Secretaary of War -- was considered biographically by Frazier Hunt, war correspondent and author, in a "personality sketch" radio talk over an NBC network last night.

The New York Police Department is determined to drive Vincent Coll and his gang out of town. Notice to that effect was served yesterday on Coll a short time before charges of conspiracy to commit crime, brought against them by the police, had been dismissed in court for lack of evidence.

More than 1,400 newsdealers at city stands were warned yesterday that their licenses would be revoked unless they discontinued the sale of obscene publications, and District Attorney Grain announced that a police drive against such papers would be made.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Displaying unusual speed, with the leaders on both sides apparently in earnest about their promise to labor diligently for an early adjournment, the Senate passed two bills today to relieve financial stress on municipalities and advanced to order of final passage two important measures for banking law revision.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 12 -- Despairing of the immediate possibility of inducing the three members of the standing committee of the Central Political Council to return to Nanking, the government leaders in Shanghai decided today to take their own measures to get the government machine running.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Jan. 12 -- State and county policemen scoured the marshlands surrounding Newport and Dividing Creek tonight to capture more than a score of rumrunners. The fugitives escaped early today when Louis Marshall and Willis Bull, troopers, seized two scows, two motor boats, two trucks and $50,000 in liquor which was being transferred from the boats to the trucks at a dock on the shore of Oranocas Creek.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Few changes were made in the directorates of banks in this district at stockholders' meetings today.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Governor Roosevelt called upon Sheriff Thomas F. Farley today to reply to the charge of Samuel Seabury that he was unfit to hold public office and should be removed.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Stockholders of the Peoples Bank and Trust Company elected thirty-nine directors at the annual meeting today. The directors are from the old boards of the Peoples, the City Trust Company and the Lincoln National Bank, which were merged recently under the name of the Peoples Bank and Trust Company.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company reports for 1931 record earnings of $36,396,816, or $3.63 a share on the 10,000,000 shares of common and Class B common, stock outstanding. This compares with $34,256,664 for 1930, or $3.42 a share. These earnings are after deduction of all charges, including provision for interest, Federal and State income taxes and depreciation.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 12 -- A.W. Abbott's Gay Bird, a gelded son of Wrack from Gay Plumage, equaled the six-furlong track record of 1:11 at Tropical Park today after a bitter duel which resulted in one of the closest finishes of the meeting.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 12 -- The Swedish and Norwegian budgets were introduced in their respective Parliaments today, both showing the effect of the prevailing economic depression.

Casa Canfield, who was elected president of Harper Brothers last Spring, is scheduled to become the new president of the National Association of Book Publishers at the annual meeting of that organization next Tuesday at the Hotel Ambassador.

A series of public organ recitals that have been heard by more than 1,000,000 persons over a period of twenty-four years will end on Monday, Jan. 25, when Professor Samuel A. Baldwin presents his farewell concert in the Great Hall of the College of the City of New York.

Former City Magistrate Francis X. McQuade won yesterday his suit against Charles A. Stoneham and John J. McGraw as officers and directors of the National Exhibition Company, owner of the New York Giants, to compel them to pay him $10,000 a year back salary as treasurer since May, 1928.

Steam for Airplanes. The tests soon to be made in Cleveland with small steam-driven airplane models naturally recall the historic work of SAMUEL P. LANGLEY. In 1896 he designed and built a quarter-size plane driven by a small steam-engine of his own invention.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 12 -- Upholding the most important action of Wisconsin's strict utility regulation law, the State Supreme Court held today that the Public Service Commission could levy costs of investigations against utilities investigated.

NAPLES, Jan. 12 -- Fears that bombs were among the mails on the American export steamer Excalibur were completely dispelled today when not two packages, as had been reported, but four addressed to King Victor Emmanuel and other prominent Italians were found and all contained completely harmless objects.

The St. Ann's Academy quintet defeated La Salle Academy, 18 to 17, yesterday in a Manhattan division, C.H.S.A.A., basketball game played in the East Fifty-fourth Street gymnasium and moved into second place in the division standing.

Colonel William J. Donovan, former Assistant Attorney General under President Coolidge; Henry Guiness, London banker, and Gustav Hoist, composer, are due tonight from Europe in the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others aboard are:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- China's reply to the communication of the United States to China and Japan, asserting American rights in Manchuria, was not received today at the State Department or the Chinese Legation, although unofficial reports from Nanking said it had been delivered to Willys R. Peck, the American Consul General.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Conditions in most sections of the Stock Exchange today were cheerful, with prices on an upward trend. Dealers were more confident regarding the financial outlook, while the latest trade figures helped sentiment. Sterling was somewhat better in the foreign exchanges, the New York rate rising to $3.41.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In considering the various causes which jointly are responsible for the last act in that Hawaiian tragedy which has brought unspeakable anguish into more than one home and aroused the indignation of many, the American people should not fail to take account of one fundamental cause of crime, too often ignored.

A special squad of twenty patrolmen and a sergeant, organized only yesterday afternoon, went into action in the theatrical district last night in a new drive to rid the midtown section of men and boys who solicit automobile owners for tips to watch their cars while they are parked on side streets, abusive beggars, urchins who dance for pennies on the sidewalks and in theatre lobbies, speakeasy guides and others.

At the New York Academy of Medicine is now an exposition in the science and art of keeping cities clean. It contains models and pictures of street-cleaning machines ventilators and smoke consumers, as well as the ingenious instruments used in measuring air pollution.

Today is the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of HORATIO ALGER Jr. and also the seventy-eighth anniversary of the founding of the earliest branch of the Children's Aid Society -- the Brace Memorial Newsboys' Home -- whose particular hero and hero-maker he was in the early days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Chairman Metcalf of the Senate committee taking testimony on the Bingham 4 per cent beer bill, termed newspaper accounts of the hearings unbiased today and invited presentation of any evidence that newspapers were withholding space from the dry side of prohibition.

Albert S. Osborn, writing expert, testifying yesterday for the State in the General Sessions trial of Nathan L. (Nigger Nate) Raymond on a theft charge growing out of his placing stolen stock certificates with a bank as collateral on a $6,900 loan, for the first time in the history of criminal trials in this country used an ultra-violet ray machine to demonstrate a forgery.

Closer international cooperation and understanding as the best means to free the world from "slavery to war" was urged by the five speakers at the annual convention of the Students' International Union, world-wide organization to promote the study of international problems, held yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, 2 East Ninety-first Street.

After advancing to the highest levels reached since the latter part of November, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased in the last hour yesterday and closed 1 point higher to 6 points lower than on Monday.

Trading was stagnant on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, prices fluctuating only fractionally in the stock and bond sections, but there were brisk advances in all series of Middle West Utilities convertibles and a few other public service bonds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A few weeks ago descriptive details of the new Washington bicentennial postage stamps were printed in newspapers. The information regarding the stamp of the lowest denomination read as follows: "A miniature by Charles Wilson Peale -- painted when Washington was 25 -- is to be used for the bicentennial one-half-cent stamp.

World shipbuilding, as the result of a continued shrinkage during the last three months of 1931, is now on a lower basis of production, not only than at any time since the war, but for many years prior to the conflict, according to a statement by Lloyd's Register of Shipping covering returns from all countries except Russia for the quarter ending Dec. 31.
Leading from start to finish, St. John's of Brooklyn defeated St. Francis, Brooklyn, on St. Francis's court last night, 38 to 8.

Vera Brodsky, pianist, who is well known to radio listeners, played the piano part in the Mozart piano quartet No. 1 in G minor last night with the Roth Quartet at Barbizon-Plaza Hall, Sixth Avenue at Fifty-eighth Street. The quartet played for the first time a new composition dedicated to the Hungarian musicians by Bronislaw Martinu.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- New steps in cooperation with the administration and the treasury toward bank rehabilitation were said to have been the topics discussed at the final session today of the governors of the Federal Reserve Banks and members of the Federal Reserve Board.
James A. Farrell, president of the United States Steel Corporation, announced last night at his home, 944 Fifth Avenue, his intention to retire as president of the corporation on April 18.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The French Cabinet has resigned. All the tortuous efforts and intrigues of the past ten days since it became known that Andre Maginot's illness which ultimately led to his death would prevent his holding his office have led Premier Laval this evening to hand to President Doumer the collective resignation of the Cabinet.

The State of Tennessee has entered into a tentative agreement for the sale of $2,000,000 of its obligations, $1,000,000 of bonds, due in 1941, and $1,000,000 of notes, due $500,000 in three months and $500,000 in six months, to a syndicate headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, the Chase National Bank, the National City Bank and the American Ntaional Bank of Nashville, Tenn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Secretary of State Stimson and Francis White, Assistant Secretary of State, were pictured in testimony before the Senate Finance Committee today as having taken an active part in ironing out an alleged misunderstanding between the Colombian Government and a syndicate headed by the National City Company, which early in 1931 temporarily withheld a payment of $4,000,000 on a $20,000,000 credit arrangement with Colombia.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- Mrs. William H. Hughes, wife of a socially prominent retired business man, was found dead in a bedroom of her home in Bryn Mawr today with a bullet wound in her head.

The Sedalia Singers, who appeared here in recital last year, gave another of their programs, devoted for the most part to Negro music, at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The singers are a group of young men and women, students of the Alice Freeman Palmer Memorial Institute, Sedalia, N.C.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 12 -- Attended by a brilliant company, the Palm Beach Playhouse, Inc., initiated its second twelve weeks' season tonight with Rachel Crothers's "Let Us Be Gay'' at the theatre on Royal Palm Way. Emil Ross and Howard Bailey played leading roles, and every member of the repertory company, the majority of whom are new this year, was included in the cast.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Negotiations for the acquisition of the mail order business of the National Bellas Hess Company by the Chicago Mail Order Company have been resumed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Cottonseed crushed during the five-month period, Aug. 1 to Dec. 31, was reported by the Census Bureau today as having totaled 2,957,967 tons, compared with 3,135,430 tons the same period a year ago, and cottonseed on hand at mills Dec. 31 totaled 1,400,325 tons, compared with 991,464 tons a year ago.
Basing judgment upon the first few slashes at the major league payrolls for 1932, the shrill cry of the holdout will be heard this Winter from coast to coast.

Weakness in dairy products -- butter and eggs -- stood out as the most important price change of the day in the cash markets. Grains also sagged. Strength was noted in copper and tin, but zinc was lower. In futures, the price trend was irregular. Coffee, cocoa, sugar and silk were higher, but hides were lower.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- A powerful field of approximately twenty of the best horses quartered at Hialeah Park probably will be entered for the $2,500 Hialeah Inaugural Handicap of six furlongs, which will be the opening-day feature at the Miami Jockey Club's Beautiful Hialeah course Thursday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Seven four-man teams and a like number of two-man teams are entered for the national A.A.U. bobsled championships on the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic bobsled run Friday and Saturday to determine America's representatives for the third Winter Olympics next month.

Thus far Governor ROOSEVELT has dealt with the charges against Sheriff FARLEY of New York County alertly and well. He put aside the Tammany quibble that Judge SEABURY had unwarrantably sought to put the weight of the legislative committee behind his letter asking the Sheriff's removal and had deliberately obscured the fact that his charges were made only as by a private citizen.

Dr. Henry Moskowitz, adviser to the League of New York Theatres, named yesterday the "steering" committee that will represent the organized legitimate theatre in its impending fight on the 10 per cent admissions tax recently proposed by Secretary of the Treasury Mellon.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The round-table conference on Burma, which assembled in London six weeks ago to devise a constitutional means for the separation of that country from India, ended its deliberations today with a statement from Prime Minister MacDonald on what the British Government was prepared to do.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 12 -- Harvey S. Firestone retired today as president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and was made chairman of the board. He was succeeded as president by John W. Thomas, vice president. Ross J. Cope became, president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of California, of which he had been vice president.

HONOLULU, Jan. 12 -- A threat was made by Honolulu business men today to appeal to Washington unless Hawaii cleans house itself, while a joint committee of Senators and Representatives urged Governor Lawrence M. Judd to call a special session of the Legislature primarily to reorganize Honolulu's police force.
HAVANA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Buddy Ensor, one of America's outstanding jockeys a decade ago, rode into the limelight again today when he scored with two of his mounts at Oriental Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, with a contemplated lending capacity of $2,000,000,000, will be in operation a few days after Congress finally passes the bill for its creation, President Hoover told Senate leaders with whom he conferred today.

Senator Simeon D. Fess of Ohio, chairman of the Republican National Committee, pictured President Hoover as "the outstanding leader of the world in the interest of relieving the backs of the people from the burdens of armament," in an address he delivered last night before a rally of Brooklyn Republicans, at Kismet Temple, 92 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,234,200 barrels, compared with 2,209,100 barrels in the preceding week, an increase of 25,100 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production east of California averaged 1,728,600 barrels daily, against 1,709,400, an increase of 19,200 barrels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Couzens resolution directing the Radio Commission to make a survey and report on the commercial uses of broadcasting was adopted in the Senate today and included an amendment by Senator Dill asking for information on the facilities afforded by the broadcasting companies to educational instruction.
PARIS, Jan. 12 -- More than 2,000 arrests were made by police today of manifestants who sought to parade before the Chamber of Deputies at the opening session.

In order to make it convenient for President Hoover to continue his custom of inaugurating the baseball season in Washington by throwing out the first ball, the major league opening date has been advanced to April 11 in the case of the Washington team, according to the announcement of the league schedule committees in concluding their meeting here yesterday.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange showed considerable irregularity yesterday, with trading slightly heavier than on the previous day, approximating $15,500,000. Measured by the averages on high-grade domestic corporation and foreign loans, the market wag only slightly lower for the day.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 -- Under the headline, "Bomb or Firecracker?" today's issue of Economic Life publishes the first editorial comment here on Chancellor Bruening's stand against reparation payments. Starting with the premise that Dr. Bruening's demand could be accepted, it sees "the demolition of the basic foundation of the Versailles treaty because reparations are the most powerful weapon in French hands for political pressure on Germany."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Stabilization of the bituminous industry through "industrial self-government" is sought in identical bills introduced in Congress today by Senator Davis and Representative Kelly of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- James R. Beverley of Amarillo, Texas, Attorney General of Porto Rico, is under serious consideration for appointment as Governor of Porto Rico to succeed Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, although President Hoover was said today not to have made a final decision.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- To meet large deficits resulting from a sharp falling off in the State's revenues and to balance the budget for the 1932-33 fiscal year, Governor Roosevelt in his annual Executive budget bill, submitted to the Senate and Assembly today, has recommended these tax increases:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Tribute to Justice Holmes was expressed by Senator David I. Walsh of Massachusetts on the floor of the Senate today.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Governor Roosevelt today saved Kendall Lytton, a New York Negro, from death in the electric chair next week for the murder of Morris Lefkowitz, a tailor, during a hold-up on Feb. 7.

HELSINGFORS, Jan. 12 -- The Finnish Cabinet is preparing at high speed the new bill regulating the sale ond consumption of alcohol, which will be introduced into Parliament on Jan. 19 to repeal the present prohibition law.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 12 -- A wooden chessboard mounted with silver laid in ivory and a leather bag containing ebony and ivory chess men discovered in ancient tombs by the Nubian archaeological mission, south of the great temple of Abou Simbel, on the hills of Doha on the east bank of the Nile, are the most recent finds giving an insight into ancient Egyptian life and the cult of life after death.

Market sentiment was slightly less cheerful yesterday and the active issues on the Stock Exchange ended the day with moderate losses. The volume of trading was smaller by about 400,000 shares than on the day before. Prices were higher at the opening, hut during the remainder of the day there was an irregular decline.

Stevens Prep School's basketball team registered its sixteenth straight victory by upsetting Montclair Academy, 29 to 26, in an overtime game at the winner's gymnasium at Forest Gardens, Hoboken, yesterday. Seven of these triumphs have been recorded this season.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 12 -- Asserting that prosperity no longer could be pointed to as a result of the prohibition law, Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, chairman and founder of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, pleaded here tonight for an end to the era of lawlessness, crime and corruption which had followed in the wake of "the nation's noble experiment."

About forty per cent of the $18,248,000, raised by popular subscription by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, headed by Harvey D. Gibson, already has been spent for jobs for the unemployed and for direct relief, it was revealed yesterday.

Real estate in this city worth $5,500,000 has been, forced into foreclosure and will be put up at auction next week. The usual run of residential buildings is listed for sale, with five lofts, a taxpayer and a garage.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Passage of the reconstruction finance bill by the Senate had no effect today on the grain markets, which averaged lower after ignoring a rally in stocks early. The finish was within a fraction of the inside figures, wheat being off 3/8 to 1/2 cent at the last.

Sir John Aird, president of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, at the annual meeting in Toronto yesterday said Canada seems to be moving steadily, though slowly, toward economic recovery. He pointed out that while severe financial storms raged in Continental Europe, Great Britain and the United States, the Canadian banking structure stood firm and unshaken.

Plans for the future operation of the National Bellas Hess Company, Inc., $30,000,000 mail order concern, are in an indeterminate stage, it was said on good authority here yesterday, following several meetings of the board of directors which began on Monday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 12 -- The election of Mrs. Hattie W. Caraway as United States Senator, an honor never before accorded to a woman at the polls, was assured in early returns tonight from today's special election in Arkansas.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Bank law revision to prohibit speculation by banks and permit a 100 per cent assessment on stockholders and temporary suspension of the 6 per cent interest limit on municipal financing were recommended today by Governor Morgan F. Larson in his final message to the Legislature after it convened for its 165th session at 12:10 o'clock this afternoon.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The Bourse situation improved steadily today and practically the whole list closed with substantial gains. Observing that offers had completely died down and that there was nothing left for sale, speculators took occasion to repurchase, which made the final stage of today's session fairly animated.

Charged with having beaten a 12-year-old girl with a leather strap until her body was a mass of bruises in an attempt to make her confess a theft, Mrs. Louis Vogelsang, 26, a Queens social and civic worker, and her mother, Mrs. Antoinette Labanowski, 66, both of 53-26 Thirty-fifth Street, Long Island City, were held in $2,000 bail last night by County Judge Thomas Downs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, son of the famous "Autocrat of the Breakfast Table" of the same name, was the only surviving officer of the Civil War in high official position, in Washington.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which will soon sell to American investors $500,000,000 bonds guaranteed by American taxpayers, in order to liquidate our nation's embarrassed banks, is recognized as the best way out of a serious nation-wide financial situation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Scores of decisions and opinions testify to the liberalism of Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes. His dissenting opinions in important cases already, during his lifetime, have received the praise even of those opposed to the fundamentals of his philosophy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Leaders of the twenty-one standard railway unions representing 1,500,000 employes met here today to build their part of the machinery that will begin operating on Thursday when they start negotiating with the spokesmen of all Class 1 railroads in the United States concerning unemployment and a possible voluntary wage reduction by the workers.

BOSTON, Jan. 12 -- The final tryout game to determine the make-up of the hockey team, which win represent the United States in the Olympic Winter Games at Lake Placid next month, will be played in the Boston Arena tomorrow night between the Boston-New York combined team and the University of Minnesota.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The members of the European steel cartel, after a week spent in consulting and clarifying the views of the various countries, convened in full session here today to continue their efforts to reach an agreement on an international sales organization for beams and semi-finished products.
Following are reports of annual meetings of banks at which changes in boards of directors or other important proceedings took place:

A penny a person was the measure adopted by the Olympic finance committee for cities with populations above 15,000 in its drive for funds to defray the expenses of America's participation in the 1932 Olympic Games at Los Angeles, according to an announcement by the American Olympic Committee yesterday.

John Foster Archbold, who was a son of the late John D. Archbold, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, and who managed his father's estate, left property appraised yesterday at $15,176,761 gross and $14,097,597 net. Mr. Archbold, who had inherited about $8,000,000 from his father, died on Jan. 5, 1930.

The Metropolitan Chain Stores, Inc., through its president, H.L. Green, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court for itself and three of its affiliates in Virginia, Texas and Oklahoma, all of "which have offices at 71 West Twenty-third Street.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 -- Following the re-election of directors and officers of the Guardian National Bank of Commerce today the directors organized a governing committee to have full control of all major policies. Henry E. Bodman, counsel for the Guardian Detroit Union Group, Inc., was elected the committee's chairman.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- The Colgate quintet defeated Fordham tonight, 28 -- 19, in one of the hardest-fought games the home team has played this year.

More persons are living in basements in New York for cheaper rent, surrounded by dampness and fiith, than ever before, Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott, head worker of Hudson Guild, told members of the civic group of the women's organization of the Free Synagogue at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the synagogue house, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- Following today's formal notification to Chancellor Bruening that neither Adolf Hitler's National Socialists nor Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's Nationalists would support the government's project to have President von Hindenburg's term of office prolonged through act of the Reichstag, the President this evening requested Dr. Bruening to abandon further search for such a substitute for a popular election.

That "intolerable conditions" in Hawaii were not in any way due to racial differences, but had arisen be cause of the indifference, of civic and political leaders, Mrs. George F. Straub of Honolulu, vice chairman of the Hawaiian League of Women Voters, said yesterday in an interview at a luncheon of the New York City League of Women Voters at the Windsor Garden.

The Mayor's Official Committee on Unemployment Relief, the only direct relief agency maintained by the city after the closing of the Home Relief Bureau, is coming to the end of its resources and may be compelled to cease operations in two weeks.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Justice Logan, a 2-year-old son of Justice F. and Jane Logan, making his first start, established a new track record for the quarter of a mile in winning the Fred Digby Purse at Jefferson Park today.

So far as the stock market was concerned, yesterday was a period of pause. Changes in price were as a rule slight hut they were prevalently downward. For the most part the day's losses ranged around 1 point, with merely fractional reaction general.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Appended is the text of the message Governor Roosevelt today transmitted to the Legislature with the budget:

Last Monday morning there appeared in the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES a story regarding the howling of a wolf. The wolf's name is Bucko and for years he has dwelt in the Central Park Zoo. Each day it has been his custom to howl mournfully just at noon -- each day, that is, except Sunday.

Plunging six stories from the apartment of a friend at 320 East Fifty-third Street early yesterday morning, Miss Mildred Fisher, 32 years old, who is believed to have lost about $80,000 in the stock market recently, was injured fatally. She died in Metropolitan Hospital two hours later.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Appropriation of almost $9,500,000 for park expansion and construction of highways and institutions in Queens and the remainder of Long Island is proposed in Governor Roosevelt's budget, these being the main items recommended for the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Secretary Mellon and Under-Secretary Mills of the treasury, will appear before the House Ways and Means Committee tomorrow in the first hearing on the proposed revision of Federal taxes.

Girls and young women unemployed at present because of the depression must be protected, former Governor Alfred E. Smith and other speakers said yesterday at a meeting held on behalf of the Committee of Fourteen at the State Chamber of Commerce Building, 65 Liberty Street.

Buyers Here Below Year Ago. Although the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday exceeded the total reached in the previous week, the figures remained well behind the total for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Board of Trade's returns of Great Britain's foreign trade in December are as follows: Exports of British products, L32,070,000; re-exports, foreign goods, L5,530,000; total exports, L37,600,000; imports, L77,020,000; excess of imports, L39,420,000.

There is a need for something more than temporary alleviation of suffering through emergency aid, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told the New York City League of Women Voters yesterday. The very necessity of emergency aid shows "something wrong with our type of civilization, something out of joint with the world," she said, "and these problems must be studied and solutions found."

When EDMUND BURKE was thinking of entering public life, he asked Dr. JOHNSON if a certain literary indiscretion of his younger days would handicap him. The great authority first thundered out: " No," but then added, reflectively: "It might be mentioned at an election."
The first move in what is believed to be a new and aggressive anti-deflation campaign was taken yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- Secretary of State Stimson's comment on the United States note in the Sino-Japanese conflict ended German expectations that the United States would interfere devisively in the Far East and has revived speculation on the general American foreign policy and its likely evolution with respect to European affairs.

ROME, Jan. 12 -- A plea to "wipe the slate clean of the tragic book-keeping of the war" -- in other words, for cancellation of reparations and war debts -- was contained in a leading article printed this morning by Il Popolo d'Italia of Milan, Premier Mussolini's personal newspaper, commenting on the approaching conference at Lausanne.

The New York Americans fought hard and savagely to subdue the Montreal Maroons in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night and capitalized on their rivals' penalties to triumph, by 2 -- 0.

Efforts to avert a strike of 30,000 workers affecting 150 shops making dresses, broke down yesterday when the final conference between representatives of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union and the Dress Manufacturers' Association in the Hotel Governor Clinton adjourned in a deadlock.

Development of the 1,500-acre Marine Park in Brooklyn, the 850-acre Great Kills Park at Crook's Point, S.I., Hunter Island in the Bronx and Hillside and Alley Pond Parks in Queens as sport areas, patterned after the latest park innovations of the Germans and other Europeans, was advocated yesterday at the annual meeting of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., by its president, Nathan Straus Jr.

Mr. Justice HOLMES has left the Supreme Court bench, but will sit there still, an illustrious and beloved figure, so long as that tribunal or its memory endures. He has impressed himself indelibly upon American constitutional law. He has touched the popular imagination and earned universal respect.
