The early abolition of the tin can and the extension of dehydrating processes by which fresh vegetables and fruits may be sold to housewives in small envelopes containing sufficient to supply their families were predicted last night by Professor C. W. Thomas, formerly of Columbia University, in a lecture before the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in the Engineering Auditorium, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Willa Gather's "Shadows on the Rock" was the most popular novel in America during 1931 and "The Education of a Princess," by Grand Duchess Marie of Russia led the non-fiction field, according to the annual survey by Baker Taylor, which will appear in that company's publication, The Retail Bookseller, in the Jan. 15 issue.

Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club, former nations amateur squash tennis champion stood perilously close to defeat yesterday when he trailed Burdett H. O'Connor of the Crescent Athletic Hamilton Club at 5 -- 11 and 9 -- 13 in the final game of their quarter-final match in the Clyde Martin Memorial tournament at the Yale Club.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Jan. 13. -- Mrs. Agnes B. Ilsley, a member of society and hunt club circles here and in Washington, Milwaukee and New York, and her maid, Mrs. Mina Daughtry Buckner, aged 65, were found murdered this morning in their beds at the Ilsley mansion house estate.

New York is fortunate in having an organization like the Park Association, vigilant for the protection of parks and zealous for their expansion. At the annual meeting of the association Senator STRAUS put in a good word for the present City Administration.

New York experienced the warmest January day on record yesterday. With temperatures averaging 29 degrees above normal, and the maximum at 67.3, heavy wraps were cast aside, radiators throttled and windows opened wide. High humidity accentuated the abnormal temperatures.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Is the McFee-Rolls-Royce-Ford discussion closed, or may a mere outsider jump in with a few remarks?

Playing under almost impossible conditions, with the warm weather oppressive and the floor and walls of the court slippery from moisture, eight players, headed by J. Lawrence Pool of the Harvard Club, national titleholder, and Herbert Noel Rawlins Jr. of the Racquet and Tennis Club, former champion, reached the quarter-finals of the metropolitan squash racquets championship last night at the University Club.

The directors of the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation, the Prairie Pipe Line Company and the Prairie Oil and Gas Company formally approved yesterday a plan for consolidation of the properties and assets under the name Consolidated Oil Corporation.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 13. -- Mukden telegraphs that the apprehension felt there as a result of meager reports of the severe losses suffered by a Japanese cavalry regiment moving toward the Jehol border Saturday was dispelled today by assurances of the safety of the regimental flag.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Plans for balancing the budget by economies and increased taxation were described before the Ways and Means Committee today by Secretary Mellon and Under-Secretary Mills of the treasury. The government's credit must not be impaired, the officials said, with a warning against borrowing.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, British Treasury expert, who returned from Paris last night, was closeted all day today with Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary: Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Walter Runciman, president of the Board of Trade.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- Grain traders were skeptical today about the effectiveness of any of the numerous ideas proposed in and out of Congress to bring about higher levels of commodity and other quotations, and the price of wheat on the Board of Trade here held within a range of around 1 cent all day.

Emerging from "a self-imposed exile" of nearly four years, Vincent Canade puts in an appearance today at L'Elan Galleries, 50 East Fifty-second Street, where an exhibition of his canvases has been installed. In seclusion Canade strove, one learns, to keep as far as possible away from "the ballyhoo of art."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Cary Spring entertained tonight with a dinner at Wewoka Cottage, having members of their house party, which included Mrs. Montgomery Brackett, Huntley Spaulding, former Governor of New Hampshire; Parker Whittemore and Rodney Brown, also Bishop and Mrs. Nathaniel Seymour Thomas, Mrs. William Guy Noll and Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Sweatt.

A woman now sits in the United States Senate by right of election, Mrs. CARAWAY of Arkansas. She stood at the polls in her State against two male opponents and, in a light vote, was easily the winner. For a few weeks she was a member of the Senate by appointment of the Governor -- the second woman thus to serve.

Bruno Walter, German orchestra conductor, arrived here yesterday on the Berengaria to fill a seven weeks' engagement with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, beginning this evening with a concert at Carnegie Hall. He left the boat at Quarantine, was taken direct to the Battery and hurried to Carnegie Hall to conduct a rehearsal of the orchestra.

The steering committee formed after the general meeting of theatrical men at the Hotel Astor on Monday met yesterday at the offices of the League of New York Theatres to make plans for fighting the proposed 10 per cent Federal tax on theatre admissions.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- With followers in various States taking formal action looking to his nomination as a Presidential candidate. Governor Roosevelt will deliver tomorrow night at the "victory dinner" at the Hotel Astor the first political speech he has made since the Naional Democratic Committee held its meeting in Washington.

Operations in the steel industry increased slightly in the last week, but producers are "disappointed by the lack of significant improvement in business since the year-end lull," according to Iron Age. Ingot production is estimated at slightly more than 25 per cent, compared with 24 per cent in the previous week.

The extension of the recently inaugurated program of intramural athletics at Manhattan College to include student competition in rowing, a branch of sports entirely new to the college, was announced yesterday by John F. (Chick) Meehan, director of physical education.

A sweeping rally carried to higher levels yesterday almost all leading stocks on the New York Curb Exchange. Trading volume was larger than on the preceding days of the week. Domestic bonds were somewhat higher, while foreign issues felt the full force of the rally.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Syracuse won its eighth basketball victory in nine starts by defeating Fordham, 22 to 16, in a fast game at Archbold Gym tonight.

Under a reorganization of the $50,000,000 City Stores Company resulting from recent conferences between the stockholders and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and the Bankers Securities Corporation, its banking creditors, the debt of the company is reduced from $11,800,000 to approximately $10,000,000, leaving the company with no indebtedness to banks directly or through its subsidiaries, it was announced yesterday.

Protest against the methods used by city officials to drive obscene publications off the news stands was made yesterday to James Geraghty, Commissioner of Licenses, and to District Attorney Thomas C.T. Crain by the National Council on Freedom from Censorship, of which Hatcher Hughes is chairman.
THE hockey fan was indigent Thumping the table briskly, he said in part:

For the second time this week, Vincent Coll, 23-year-old gang leader, found himself an unwilling guest of the police yesterday afternoon when detectives, apparently acting under instructions to take him into custody on sight, closed in on him and his bride at Eighth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, questioned him for two hours at the West Forty-seventh Street station and then released him.

In his testimony yesterday before the Ways and Means Committee, Secretary MELLON" cited the same figures for prospective deficits in 1932 and 1933 used by the President a month ago. These estimates may prove to be inaccurate. During the first half of the fiscal year 1932 (July to December) the Government's expenditures exceeded revenues by $1,385,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Expenditures for direct family relief in fifty-six large cities reporting to the Children's Bureau of the Labor Department were $30,066,641 for the first nine months of 1931, an increase of 127 per cent over the $13,226,784 expended in the corresponding period of 1930 and 348 per cent over the $6,705,576 spent in the same cities in the same period of 1929.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Testimony for and against the reappointment of Fred A. Bradley as Collector of Customs at Buffalo was taken under advisement by a Senate finance subcommittee today after he had denied all charges made against him. The subcommittee is expected to report to the full committee in a day or two.

In the first serious accident since the west side elevated speedway was opened last year, one man was killed, another was seriously injured and a third, wearing a clerical collar, was severely shaken and became hysterical last night when the small coupe in which they were proceeding up-town on the speedway skidded on the wet paving at a point near Gansevoort Street, crashed into the railing on the southbound artery and burst into flames.

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- The Boston-New York Olympic hockey combination experienced little trouble tonight eliminating the University of Minnesota team in the series to determine the United States representative in the coming matches at Lake Placid.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Following in full is Secretary Mellon's statement on the need for additional taxation made today before the Ways and Means Committee:
BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- Scoring practically at will, Harvards 'junior varsity hockey team chalked up its third straight victory of the season today, crushing Andover, 11 to 0, on the Boston Garden rink.

In Canada the reduction in industrial output in 1931 was relatively less than in some of the major manufacturing countries of the world, according to S.H. Logan, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, who says that the decline was about 17 per cent for 1931, against 20 per cent in 1930, while the fall in the general price level was 12 per cent in 1931, against 18 per cent in 1930.

There was no playing of municipal trumpets yesterday to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of Horatio Alger Jr., nor were there, so far as could be learned, any pilgrimages to his grave, but there were, doubtless, thousands of men throughout the country who traveled in imagination back to boyhood and recalled the author, who before the days of stainless steel specialized in untarnishable virtue.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- Sir Walter Layton, who drew up the report of the Wiggin committee of international bankers on German credits last Summer and was also part author of the recent Basle experts' report on reparations, declared tonight that Germany could clearly pay something and a plan could be devised which would not be greatly harmful.

The growth of the Jewish Conciliation Court of America as an agency for the settlement of civil difficulties of an intimately Jewish nature, and the consistent backing of its decisions by the State Supreme Court, were discussed yesterday in the annual report of Louis Richman, executive secretary.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Jan. 13. -- The performance of the airship Akron under the severe conditions of Winter and storm flying which were encountered in the cruise which ended yesterday morning was said by Lieutenant Commander Charles E. Rosendahl today to have fully dispelled all rumors of inefficiency and justified the navy's purchase of the gigantic craft.

Directors of Stone Webster, Inc., voted yesterday to recommend to stockholders an adjustment of the book value of the corporation's assets and capital to reflect present conditions and values. A letter has been addressed to all stockholders enclosing a form of consent to the changes proposed.
Benn W. Levy, who has two plays. "The Devil Passes" and "Springtime for Henry," at present on Broadway, will leave today for Hollywood to make film adaptations for Universal.

Six striking Colonial women's costumes have been presented by H.R. Mallinson Co. in cooperation with the Brooks Costume Company to the committee for the annual Beaux-Arts Ball -- "A Pageant of Old New York and the First Inaugural Ball of the United States of America" -- to be held on Jan. 22 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Instead of sleeping in the daytime, as they traditionally are supposed to do, actors will soon be going to school. The Actors' Equity Association announces through the January issue of its publication, Equity, that in order to acquaint new members with the ideals and achievements of the organization it will require candidates to attend a course of lectures, beginning in April, and undergo an examination.

At least two of the shipping bills submitted to Congress will be opposed by shipping men of the metropolitan district, speaking through the Merchants Association, the Maritime Association of the Port of New York and the Shippers' Conference of Greater New York.

Plans for enlarging the audience for opera by demonstrating that it is not a purely top-hat affair, but "a great show" were outlined here yesterday by Herbert Witherspoon, vice president of the Chicago Civic Opera Company and former basso of the Metropolitan Opera, in an interview at the Yale Club, where Mr. Witherspoon is staying during a three-day visit to New York.
MILAN, Italy, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Premier Mussolini advised Europe in an article today in his newspaper, Popolo D'Italia, to cancel reparations as the first step toward world economic recovery.

KEMPTEN, Germany, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Wilhelm Frick, former Thuringian Minister of the Interior and a National Socialist, said today in a speech that President von Hindenburg could not be re-elected by popular vote unless he compelled Chancellor Bruening to resign.

The Demotte Galleries, in East Seventy-eighth Street, will have on view until Feb. 9 a group of Coptic textiles from their own collection. These fragments, rescued from tombs at Sakkahar and Achmim, in Upper Egypt, are principally the medallions and borders with which the Christian inhabitants of the Nile Valley from the fourth century to the seventh adorned their plain white robes.

MOSCOW, Jan. 13. -- Today's issue of Pravda features a Tass News Agency report from Shanghai on the Japanese advance in Jehol Province, which threatens Peiping from the northwest "to avoid complications which might arise from a conflict along the Tientsin-Peiping Railroad."

TOKYO, Jan. 13. -- Japan's reply to Secretary Stimson's note will probably be handed to W. Cameron Forbes, United States Ambassador, tomorrow and will be a colorless document. The reply will not invite further controversy, which Premier Inukai considers undesirable in a case where a change of policy is impossible.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Representative Patman of Texas appeared before the Judiciary Committee today to present what he said was further "proof" that Secretary Mellon had violated a Federal statute enacted in 1789, by holding office while owning wholly or in part stock in banks, industries and shipping vessels.

Although the stock market extended its recent advance yesterday, it was the demand for United States Government bonds that must have struck even the most casual observer as the outstanding development of the day. Led by the long-term Treasury issues and the Liberties, the whole bond market made impressive headway and the volume of business was the heaviest since the end of December.
Thirty-four contributors added $427 yesterday to the Neediest Cases Fund in response to the twentieth annual appeal. The total to date is $287,057.81, within $58,732.84 of last year's final total.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 13 (Canadian Press). -- The Dominion Bureau of Statistics index number of wholesale price, on the basis of 100 for 1926, fell from 70.6 in November, 1931, to 70.3 in December, according to a report issued today. There were eighty-four higher quotations in December than in November, seventy-five were lower and 343 remained unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- The House today paid honor to Justice Holmes. In an address, Representative McCormack of Massachusetts said the aged justice had "won the respect and friendship of the nation."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The progress of President Hoover's Reconstruction Finance Corporation bill toward passage in the House was marked today by an attack by Representative McFadden who called the bill a scheme to give "financial looters" a chance to dispose of evidence that would send them to prison.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 13. -- It will be incumbent upon the Naval Academy at Annapolis to erase the date, "1834," from the pedestal supporting its statue of Andrew Jackson if evidence disclosed by the Newark Museum authorities today concerning another statue of "Old Hickory," lent to them by "William B. Leeds of New York is not controverted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Testimony that beer containing 4 per cent alcohol would help rather than harm the human system if taken moderately was given by scientists and physicians today before the Senate manufactures subcommittee at hearings on the Bingham bill to legalize such a beverage.

The first in a series of four "Evenings Abroad" for the benefit of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service was held last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis. The entertainment, called "A Night in Holland," featured Jack Powell of "The Laugh Parade"; Percy Renwick and Dolly Conneliy in songs and piano numbers, Rosita Ortega, Spanish dancer; Aileen Stanley, Angelo de Soto in songs.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 13. -- A desperately fighting Navy team, with four consecutive victories behind it, was vanquished in the last ten minutes of its basketball game with the University of Pennsylvania today. The score was 27 to 25.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- Although Britain's overseas trade returns for December under the new anti-dumping legislation show an increase in exports and a decrease in imports, there was an adverse balance on the year's trading of u408,000,000 (the pound yesterday was quoted at $3.414).

The West Side Association of Commerce will seek to hold the Board of Transportation to its promise to have the Eighth Avenue subway in operation about April 1, according to a decision announced at the annual meeting of the organization yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 13. -- Joseph E. Widener's Hialeah Park race track recently revamped and beautified at a cost of approximately $l,300,000, will inaugurate its 1932 season tomorrow as thoroughbreds thunder down the stretch in the first seven races of a 39-day meeting.

Within forty-eight hours Mayor Walker wall submit to the city's eight leading banking houses a retrenchment program which will stop short only of any fundamental change in the administration's five-cent fare policy, it was indicated yesterday a City Hall.

Charles (Vannie) Higgins, the racketeer, on trial with sixteen others for conspiracy to violate the prohibition act, was identified in Brooklyn Federal court yesterday by Frederick Grube, newspaper reporter, as one of the men who surrounded and beat him at Long Beach on Sept. 15, 1930, when he discovered a group of policemen and rum-runners unloading a cargo of liquor.

Four paintings by famous artists were stolen from the home of Floyd B. Odlum at 101 Greenway North, Forest Hills, Queens, the police revealed yesterday. Mr. Odlum, who is the president of the Atlas Utilities Corporation and a director of other companies, differing from published reports of the pictures' value, said they were worth "somewhere in the neighborhood of $20,000."

Laszlo Fodor, who wrote "I Love An Actress" and "A Church Mouse," is author also of "Jewel Robbery," which brought Mary Ellis and Basil Sidney into the Booth last evening. It comes closer than either of the others to being a continuously amusing play.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 13. -- With Mrs. W. McKay Sturgis of the Prettybrook Tennis Club, Princeton, defending her crown, the second annual New Jersey State women's squash racquets championship got under way today on the courts of the Montclair Athletic Club.

HURST PARK, England, Jan. 13 (AP). -- In a close finish today M.D. Blair's Prince Cherry won the New Year Handicap steeplechase, worth u300, with B. Warner's The Wrecker second and Burglar, owned by G.H. (Pete) Bostwick of New York, third.
The Trinity High School basketball team scored its sixth victory in eight starts this season by halting the St. Paul's School quintet of Garden City, L.I., 38-18, on the victor's floor yesterday.

HAVANA Jan. 13 (AP). -- Port O'Play, the Emerson Brothers' 6-year-old brown gelding by The Porter -- By Play, won the fifth race, feature of an ordinary card, at Oriental Park today in a driving finish from Athol.

Barge Canal Bullheads The State Conservation Department has gone to the rescue of thousands of fish left swarming in waterholes and puddles when the Barge, Canal between Waterford and Mechanicville was lowered for the Winter.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- The recovery on the Bourse continued today despite what financial circles regard as an unfavorable influence in the international situation. Soon after the opening there was a period of weakness, which soon disappeared when Suez Canal, one of the leading stocks, became active and other shares followed its gains.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- "The great collegiate problem is overemphasis of football," Chaplain Arthur B. Kinsolving of West Point asserted today in opening a conference on "Youth and the Church" at the annual synod of the Episcopal province of New York and New Jersey at Christ Church here today.

A contract bridge team made up of Peter Dolan and Harold Goldman of The Sun, Edwin E. Zoty of the Macfadden Publications and George H. Copeland of THE NEW YORK TIMES won the artists' and writers' tournament conducted under the auspices of the advisory council of Bridge Headquarters, Inc., in the final round concluded this morning at the Hotel Roosevelt.
ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- In a burst of activity the Legislature gave final approval today to a series of bills to relieve financial stress on municipalities.
United States Government bonds led a brisk rise yesterday in the security markets as Wall Street grasped the full significance of the more liberal credit policy of the Federal Reserve Bank.

SUKKUR, India, Jan. 13. -- The Lloyd Barrage, a vast stone and concrete structure stretching nearly a mile across the River Indus here to transform the rainless desert of 5,000,000 acres into fertile fields was opened today by the Viceroy, Earl Willingdon.

Whatever may have been the inspiration of yesterday's fresh advance on the Stock Exchange, Wall Street ascribed the upswing to what has been described as the Federal Reserve's anti-deflation policy. It is assumed that the demand for stocks has been stimulated by the recent adoption of such a policy.

With attendance continuing far ahead or last year, sponsors and exhibitors of the National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace yesterday were reported to be "gratified, indeed" by the demonstration of public interest.

Reaffirming the known intention of our Government, Secretary STIMSON definitely stated yesterday that the United States will have no representative at the coming Lausanne conference. Apparently, there will not be even an "unofficial observer." Yet, from a distance, it is certain that the United States will be "the observed of all observers."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- A modification of the North Atlantic Passenger Conference agreement was approved by the Shipping Board today, providing for a reduction of 20 per cent in one-way or round-trip fares to officials of amateur athletic associations accompanying teams, and to members of the international Olympic committee and national committees traveling to the Olympic Games to be held at Los Angeles and Lake Placid up to the end of this year.

Thomas L. Chadbourne, who devised what is known as the Chadbourne plan for international control of sugar, returned from Paris conferences of the International Sugar Council yesterday on the Cunard liner Berengaria, confident that when the meetings are resumed the plan will be worked out successfully.

The bankers' bill market underwent adjustment yesterday to the new condition in the money market created by the action of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York on Tuesday in suddenly cutting its bill-buying rate to levels below those prevailing in the open market.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Representatives who want the navy built to treaty limits found themselves today in a no-compromise war of their own making.

At a meeting yesterday, all the directors of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce reiterated their opposition to proposals for Federal taxation of motor vehicles. The directors, it was announced, would appear in a body at a hearing of the Ways and Means Committee in Washington on Jan. 23.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 13. -- A large crowd witnessed a fitting close to the first meeting of the Gables Racing Association at Tropical Park today as Jockey Hank Mills, whose riding has been the sensation of the session, brought Joseph H. Johnson's 3-year-old gelding Felaxe home first in the feature Coconut Grove Purse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The Supreme Court paused in its duties today to hear Chief Justice Hughes read correspondence between its members and Oliver Wendell Holmes, who retired yesterday as associate justice after serving more than twenty-nine years.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Fear for a serious breaking down of standards because of the abnormal competition both, for jobs and for business was voiced here tonight by Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in an address at the dinner of the province of New York and New Jersey synod of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 13. -- One of the oldest and most valuable existing parchment manuscript volumes of the Koran has just been reported as missing from a repository containing thirty-four other equally precious volumes in the mosque of El-Aksa here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Creation of "emergency rediscount privileges" in the Federal Reserve System as a means of decentralizing credit and forming a broader basis for the issuance of Federal Reserve notes was advocated today by Senator Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, in a speech in the Senate.

The prospect for reopening the stations of the Home Relief Bureau, closed because of the financial difficulties confronting the city, grew brighter yesterday when Jesse Isidor Straus, chairman of the Temporary State Relief Administration, offered to set aside $1,000,000 of the State's $20,000,000 relief fund so that the bureau might resume operations immediately.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- For the present, President Hoover, according to information in Congressional quarters close to the administration, will devote his entire time to domestic problems.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Disciplining the Governor of Hawaii or other administrative Territorial officers will not reach the source of the tragic situation which has flared up there in recent months. The cause lies far deeper and arises from a condition which few people in this country realize.

Charges that relief organizations operating in Harlem do not attempt to provide adequate employment in comparison with the aid given to white workers in the same locality were heard yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York Urban League at the league's headquarters, 202 West 136th Street.

With more than a year long program of sports endeavor carefully mapped out, and with the hope that it will culminate in a victory in the Liverpool Grand National of 1933, G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, America's leading steeplechase rider, arrived yesterday from England on the Berengaria.

HONOLULU, Jan. 13. -- Hawaii began officially today the task of setting its house in order. Shortly before noon Governor Lawrence M. Judd, acting on the recommendation of a joint committee from the House and Senate of the 1931 Territorial Assembly, called a special session of the Legislature which will convene here Monday morning for consideration of police legislation, taxation and legislation affecting education.

The American Superpower Corporation reports for 1931 income from cash dividends and interest amounting to $5.574,463, the largest revenue from this source for any year excepting 1930, when the figure was $6,144,726. Profits on sales and commissions, however, were only $16,748, the lowest on record, comparing with $2,581,247 in 1930.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Gilbert M. Tucker, son of the founder of The Country Gentleman and its publisher for many years, died today at his residence in the Philip Schuyler Apartments at the age of 84. For several years he had been almost blind.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 13. - -Old Man Par, even with the aid of his best defenders, rain and wind, was bested by three strokes in the first round of the $15,000 Agua Caliente open tournament today when Fred Morrison, Culver City, Cal., professional, shot a 69 to lead the field.

The league leading Jamaica High School hockey team was held to a scoreless tie by New Utrecht in a P.S.A.L. encounter at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The battle was one of the closest fought of the current season.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Maintaining an early lead, the New York University basketball team defeated Rutgers, 39 -- 24, in the Rutgers gym tonight. This was the second defeat in as many games for the Scarlet outfit and the fourth victory for the Violet in five contests.

The New York Board of Jewish Ministers, comprising leaders of the principal Jewish congregations in New York, by a vote of 20 to 3 rejected yesterday afternoon the report of its own interfaith committee which had recommended that the State Board of Regents grant college credits to high school students for studying the Bible as "religion."

More than 2,000 Chevrolet dealers from all over the country were praised last night by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors; R. H. Grant, vice president; W.S. Knudsen, president of the Chevrolet Company, and H.J. Klingler, vice president, for putting Chevrolet first in automobile sales throughout the United States during 1931.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight champion, boxed a round each against three sparring partners tonight in the 113th Infantry Regiment Armory before about 3,500 fight fans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP). -- The House Merchant Marine Committee today set out to determine for itself what the Shipping Board has been doing for the last eight years, particularly with reference to its recent sale of the United States Lines.

The Columbia basketball team amassed its highest score of the season last night when the Lions, playing on their own floor, overwhelmed the Cooper Union quintet by 73 to 19. The score at half-time was 41 to 12.

The annual report of the law division of the State Attorney General's office, which handles cases dealing with labor and workmen's compensation laws, was made public yesterday by Assistant Attorney General Joseph A. McLaughlin. It shows that $239,601 compensation was collected in 1931 from employers who sought to evade the labor laws.

Net railway operating income of the Chicago North Western Railway in December was about 5200,000, an increase of about $800,000 from November, but far short of meeting the monthly proportion of fixed charges, Fred W. Sargent, president, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Another incipient movement to challenge President Hoover's renomination by the Republican National Convention was disclosed today when it was learned that Senator Borah of Idaho had received many letters urging him to be a candidate.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday. .3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names Tuesday . . . 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

The tremendous tax burden which has fallen upon Europe, as upon the United States, makes it seem unlikely that there will be any further payments of war debts and reparations, said James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, in a speech last night before members of the League of Business and Professional Women at the Hotel Sutton, 330 East Fifty-sixth Street.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- The foreign exchange market is inclined to adopt a waiting attitude pending further developments in the reparations situation. Dealings were light today, with rates showing little alteration. Sterling on New York eased to $3.40 3/4, stiffened later to $3.41 1/4 and fell back again to $3.41.

F.W. Williamson presided at a meeting of the New York Central Railroad board yesterday as the sole head of the organization. The office of chairman of the executive committee, held by the late A.H. Harris, has been ended, thus bringing to a close a system of headship which was in some cegree dual.

An early advance in United States Government bonds yesterday on the Stock Exchange caused a general rush to buy bonds of all descriptions and the turnover for the day rose to $17,751,000, the largest amount since Dec. 30, when tax selling was an important factor.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- Jouett Shouse, executive secretary of the Democratic National Committee, came here from Washington today to make preliminary arrangements for the National Convention in June and to address State party leaders at a "victory dinner" tomorrow night.

At least fifty "Victory Dinners" will be held in thirty-three States tonight by the Democratic Victory Campaign Committee in an effort to raise $1,500,000 to "put the party in fighting shape for the 1932 Presidential campaign."

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- On the eve of the joint unemployment conference tomorrow of railroad presidents, representing all Class 1 roads in the United States, and the heads of twenty-one rail unions representing 1,900,000 employes, an important official close to the highest authorities on the employers' side, asserted today that the roads would negotiate successfully a 10 per cent voluntary wage "deduction" (not reduction) for one year in return for concessions assuring increased employment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- That laxity on the part of the Hawaiian authorities has convinced lawless elements in Honolulu that assaults on women could be committed "without serious consequence" to the perpetrators is charged in a report of a sub-committee of the House Committee on Naval Affairs which was submitted tonight to Chairman Vinson of the committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- A widespread and violent attack in Belgian
Textile High School's basketball team, registered its fifth victory in seven games by defeating Theodore Roosevelt High, 26-12, yesterday in the Textile gymnasium. At half-time Textile led, 17-3.

EDMONTON, Alta., Jan. 13 (Canadian Press). -- Mounted police at Aklavik laid plans tonight for the capture of a hermit trapper whose stand in his lonely cabin eighty miles up the old Yukon Trail has frustrated two attempts to arrest him.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Army won its third straight basketball game today, defeating Duke University, 25 to 23, in one of the hardest fought games played on the Army court in some time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Confronted with a difficult task in the selection of a man to succeed Oliver Wendell Holmes, who resigned yesterday as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, President Hoover will make a decision as quickly as is consistent with proper consideration of so important an appointment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- A Blight illness which confined Senator Smoot, Republican, of Utah, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, to his home today caused postponement until tomorrow of the niquiry into State Department activities in connection with foreign bond issues in the United States.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, writing on prohibition in the current issue of Liberty, advocates a new plan under which he says it is constitutionally possible for the people of any State to pass liquor control bills of their own and obtain exemption from the Eighteenth Amendment.

TSINGTAO, China, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Five hundred steel-helmeted marines, carrying fixed bayonets, patrolled the streets of Tsingtao today while thousands of Chinese fled the city in fear of a possible recurrence of yesterday's rioting.

Six new champions were crowned in the Metropolitan A.A.U. boxing tournament which ended at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 8,000 persons witnessed the program, consisting of twenty bouts, and was satisfied with having seen an interesting card.

HAVANA, Jan. 13. -- Cuban tobacco manufacturers today notified the tobacco workers that unless a reduction in the wage scale to the level in force in 1914 were immediately accepted all the factories would be shut down on Saturday.

Mortimer N. Buckner, president of the National Credit Corporation, has issued a call for payment of a second instalment of 10 per cent of subscriptions to the gold notes of the corporation, payable next Monday. The amount called for is approximately $50,000,000, which will bring the payments made to about $100,000,000, or one-fifth of the corporation's subscribed funds.

More than 200,000,000 Europeans are living under the worst kind of tyranny and terror. H. Hessell Tiltman, author of the authorized biography of Premier MacDonald writes in his new book, "The Terror in Europe," to be published today by Frederick A. Stokes Company.

The legal barrier that has stood between the Hofstadter Committee and the citing of State Senator John A. Hastings for contempt was removed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Byrne on the eve of a public hearing at which evidence will be produced to show that former Sheriff Charles W. Culkin has banked $2,000,000 in the last five years.

All people famous in the theatre are asked their opinion of the rivalry between the films and the stage when they get away from the scene of their triumphs. Few of them have anything fresh or novel to say on the subject, but MAX REINHARDT, visiting in Manchester, England, lately, contributed an original idea.

The Board of Education fell in line yesterday with Mayor Walker's order to all city departments to exercise strict economy. At a meeting in the afternoon, following a conference of school officials with Budget Director Kohler, the board deferred the immediate appointment of 600 elementary and junior high school teachers and shelved for the time-being any appropriations that were not considered of absolute necessity.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 13. -- A drama of life and death in which the stepdaughter of Robert W. Bingham, publisher of the Louisville (Ky.) Courier-Journal, gave up an oxygen administering device in order that the son of a Los Angeles newspaper city editor might have a chance for recovery became known today with the death of 12-year-old Patten Levings.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- The secret marriage of Miss Elsie Janis to 26-year-old Gilbert Wilson of Los Angeles became known here today. Rumors of the marriage on New Year's Eve were repeated so often that Miss Janis had to admit, she said, that she had made her "debut on the stage of matrimony."
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Malcolm McAlpin, Princeton centre, scored two goals and assisted in a third to give the Princeton varsity hockey team a 3-to-1 victory over Clarkson Tech tonight.

Another cut of 1/8 in acceptance yields on maturities from 90 days forward to bring these more in line with the discount on the shorter dates was the only development of importance in the day's money market. The change was made late in the afternoon as a result of the strong demand for bills, which, however, were notably light in supply.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 13 (AP). -- Twelve deaths and injuries to more than 150 persons resulted from tornadoes and heavy rainfall that swept the Central Southern States last night. Hundreds were made homeless.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- Cornell University announced an eight-game football schedule for 1932 today. The University of Buffalo and Albright College appear on the cards for the first time, the former replacing Clarkson Tech in the opening game and Albright taking Alfred's place.

NEW YORK. After the first meetings yesterday of the boards of directors of banks elected or re-elected on Tuesday, changes in officers were announced by several institutions. In addition, annual meetings of some banking institutions were held, with changes as indicated in the following reports:

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 13 (AP). -- The president-and the business agent of a local motion-picture operator' union confessed today that they caused the bombing Monday night of Loew's Midland Theatre and said their object was to strike a blow a a rival union.

Our sister Republic of Turkey has been sorely afflicted by the "smuggling problem." Prime Minister ISMED Pasha said at the beginning of National Savings and Economy Week last month that the Treasury was choused out of from twenty to twenty-five millions of Turkish pounds a year by the organized contraband traffic in articles which are the subject of State monopolies.

The refined sugar market was almost inactive yesterday as a result of a price confusion which left many buyers in much doubt as to its outcome. The latest news was that the price of refined had dropped to 4.15 cents a pound, or the lowest level since May 19, 1914.

The American Association for the Advancement of Atheism, the League for Industrial Democracy, and the "reconciliation tours" conducted in this city with visits to radical leaders, were assailed yesterday by Mrs. Finley J. Shepard, the former Miss Helen Gould, as dangers to youth and "movements for the breakdown of things our ancestors stood for."

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- Edward L. Casey, Harvard varsity football coach, today was nominated by Governor Ely as State Boxing Commissioner to succeed Eugene Buckley, whose term expired Dec. 2. The term is for three years at an annual salary of $3,000.

The gayer, if not the lighter, side of Latin-American art is beautifully exemplified in the caricatures by Conrado W. Massaguer, Cuban draftsman and editor, which Gimbels is showing in the seventh floor gallery until Jan. 23. Like Covarrubias, Massaguer combines humor and devastating satire with unquestionable technical excellence.

BELLEFONTE, Pa., Jan. 13. -- A convict detailed as a guard at the home of Dr. Asa Lee Hickok, chief of the psychopathic ward at Rockview State Penitentiary here, attacked Miss Elizabeth Hickok, 22 years old, in her parents' absence today and murdered her with a butcher knife.

FARGO, N.D., Jan. 13. -- A resolution endorsing Governor Roosevelt for the Presidential nomination and requesting him to permit his name being put on the North Dakota Presidential preference primary ballot March 15 was prepared today by the Democratic State Committee to be introduced at the State convention in Valley City tomorrow.

BERLIN, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Germany's patriotic youth, as represented in the Young German Order, today filed a petition for a national plebiscite on the question of extending for another seven years the term of President Paul von Hindenburg.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Accompanying the American delegation to the international disarmament conference when it sails next Wednesday for Geneva will be an "observer" delegation made up of four women appointed by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt to represent the conference on the cause and cure of war which has been called to meet here next monday.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (Canadian Press). -- Soccer fans in England were treated to eight replays from the third round of the English Football Association cup competition today. A crowd of 33,000 saw the Bolton Wanderers lose to Preston North End, 5 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Accompanying the American delegation to the international disarmament conference when it sails next Wednesday for Geneva will be an "observer" delegation made up of four women appointed by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt to represent the conference on the cause and cure of war which has been called to meet here next monday.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (Canadian Press). -- Soccer fans in England were treated to eight replays from the third round of the English Football Association cup competition today. A crowd of 33,000 saw the Bolton Wanderers lose to Preston North End, 5 to 2.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 13. -- This evening's Brussels papers give a prominent place to a Belga News Agency announcement that United States Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson received apologies from Foreign Minister Paul Hymans yesterday afternoon for recent attacks upon the United States Government and President Hoover in the Belgian press. M. Hymans is said to have pointed out that these newspaper comments did not represent the official Belgian attitude.

WARSAW, Jan. 13. -- Ten of the eleven defendants in the Brest-Litovsk trial were found guilty today of plotting to overthrow the government by force and were sentenced to terms of from one and one half to three years at hard labor.

HONOLULU, Jan. 13 (AP). -- A charge of attempted criminal assault was filed here today against Philander B. Gray, 31 years old, on complaint of a Portuguese woman. The incident occurred while the city was recovering from the stir over recent cases of attack and the killing of one alleged assaulter.

Finland and England contributed yesterday to the ever-increasing group of competitors who are arriving in the United States for the Winter Olympic Games at Lake Placid from Feb. 4 to 13. The English delegation was a small one, both in point of numbers and in size.

Edwin Markham will celebrate his eightieth birthday in April by publishing his fifth book of verse. The new books will contain eighty poems written by him since his previous book was published twelve years ago and will be entitled "New Poems: Eighty Songs at 80."

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 13. -- A 67-year-old grandmother who has lived in Duluth thirty-five years admitted today that it was she who was described by Sir Thomas Lipton as the only woman whom he ever loved.
VIENNA, Jan. 13 (AP). -- Josef Kuderna, 47-year-old curio dealer, was arrested today and confessed to forging documents tending to prove he was an heir to the vast Wendel fortune in New York.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 13. -- A fire this morning which destroyed the dressing rooms and animal tents of a large German circus playing here is believed by the police to have been traced to anti-German incendiaries.

The Radio Corporation of America has employed $5,000,000 of its own funds to take up one-half of that part of the 6 per cent debentures of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation issued under the reorganization of the company recently approved by stockholders that had not been subscribed by other stockholders, David Sarnoff, president of Radio Corporation, said last night.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Instead of a deficit in the State treasury of between $3,000,000 and $4,000,000 at the end of the current fiscal year, June 30, there will be one of only about $731,282, it was estimated today by John McCutcheon, State Controller.
The Downtown A.C. squash racquets team was among the victors last night in the Group 1 matches of the Class C Metropolitan League series.

Captain Fred Nutter, 86 years old, listened attentively yesterday in Special Sessions Court in St. George, S.I., as his brother, Captain Edgar, 74, told from the witness stand how Captain Fred one hot day last August laid into him with a monkey wrench and cut his scalp.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 13. -- Government leaders headed by Sun Fo, President of the Executive Yuan, returned to Nanking this morning with the intention of establishing a special political commission to take over the government administration, notwithstanding the continued absence of General Chiang Kaishek, Wang Ching-wei and Hu Han-min.

Bruno Huhn mustered the sixty-four veterans of the New York Banks Glee Club in review at the opening concert of that organization's fifty-third season last evening in Carnegie Hall. There were fresh voices among these singing men from the financial district, fresh enthusiasm for the music rehearsed in private since last Fall.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Carscallen will give dinners at the Plaza tonight and on Jan. 27.

The proposed heavyweight championship ring battle between Max Schmeling, the titleholder, and Mickey Walker, former middleweight champion, yesterday was declared definitely off as a proposed attraction for Miami, and, from indications, will be abandoned for the Winter.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 13. -- In the third annual game for the city hockey title, the New Haven Eagles of the Canadian-American League tonight outscored the Yale six, 3 to 1. Yale won last year by exactly the same score and the Eagles triumphed two seasons ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to "A German," writing in THE TIMES, Germany prior to the Young Plan paid for reparations 35,270,000,000 gold marks, of which France received 52 per cent, or 18,340,000,000 gold marks. He further states that, according to French authority, the total French disbursement for the reparation of damages in the zone of war and occupation is 85,000,000,000 francs, or 14,000,000,000 marks.

Copyright, 1932. by NANA, Inc. HONOLULU, Jan. 13. -- From the woman's viewpoint, conditions in Honolulu, with womanhood ravished, reveal that Christian principles have been outraged. American government practices have been debased to the end that Honolulu is now being advertised to the world as a disorderly community.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Ken Fairman, with eleven points, led the Princeton varsity basketball team to its eighth consecutive victory of the season today, when the Tigers defeated Lehigh, 31 to 21, after holding only a one point advantage at the half-time.

An error on the part of customs officials in classifying a large shipment of leather imported by Roberts Porter of Chicago won that company a substantial reduction in duty assessments in the United States Customs Court yesterday. The leather was classed as dressed and finished horsehide, which is subject to a tariff of 25 per cent under Paragraph 1530 of the 1930 tariff law.

Harold Samuel, who has had extraordinary success in this city as a specialist in Bach, returned last night to Town Hall to find an enthusiastic audience waiting for him. There must be more than one pleasure in a meeting of this kind for the artist.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES's account of yesterday's argument before the Public Service Commission on the subject of the rates charged in the city of New York for electric service might lead a reader to infer that the violent protests against the existing rates, delivered by certain speakers who are described as Communists, were a part or adjunct of the case presented by the Washington Heights Taxpayers' Association.
The Columbia University Club's Class A squash tennis team added to its string of victories last night, scoring its eighth consecutive triumph to remain at the top in the metropolitan league race.
PARIS, Jan. 13. -- Pierre Laval is again Premier of France. He is now also Minister of Foreign Affairs in succession to Aristide Briand.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13 (AP). -- The Paul Hirtenstein Purse, fifth race and feature event of the Jefferson Park card today, went to Estin, W. T. Perry's 9-year-old black gelding.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The "best minds" in the Republican organization will be called in to review Governor Roosevelt's budget bill and recommendations for emergency taxes, as included in his executive budget message which was submitted to the Senate and Assembly yesterday.

Drys are using economic boycotts against persons who come out openly against prohibition, causing "widespread fear" in many who are opposed to the law to express themselves publicly, it was charged yesterday in an address by Mrs. John S. Sheppard, New York State chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- Maintaining that present returns to producers for milk are so low that dairy farmers are suffering an unbearable financial loss, delegates to the annual convention of the New York State Holstein-Frlesian Association, went on record today calling for "mass action" to remedy conditions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The first formal opposition to the administration's plan for increase of taxes, outlined yesterday by Secretary Mellon and Ogden L. Mills, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, was made before the Ways and Means Committee today by C.B. Clark of Detroit, representative of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, and seven other allied merchants' groups, employing, it was said, 1,250,000 persons.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 14 -- The crack St. John's College five of Brooklyn had little trouble in disposing of Loyola College of Baltimore tonight, outpassing and outshootlng its opponent to score by 41 to 30.

Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, like his predecessor, Charles W. Culkin, helped himself to some of the interest on official funds, Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, sought to show yesterday at one of the committee's public hearings.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- A January thaw enveloped America's Winter sports capital today, forcing indefinite postponement of the first of the Winter Olympic preliminaries and tossing the entire program into something of a turmoil.

The United Fruit Corporation reports net income for 1931 of $6,779,363 after depreciation, interest and estimated Federal taxes, comparing with $12,411,507 in the preceding year. The net income in 1931 was equivalent to $2.31 a share on the 2,925,000 no par shares, compared with $4.14 a share earned in the preceding year.

Brokers and managing agents of buildings in Manhattan continued yesterday to report renting for business purposes in large volume. Most of yesterday's activity of this type centred in the midtown area. Old as well as new buildings attracted tenants, according to announcements of new contracts yesterday made by brokers.

Last year marked the sixth consecutive decline since 1925 in this country's building permit values, while the December total was the lowest monthly figure since March, 1919, Bradstreet's reported yesterday.

BASLE, Jan. 14 -- The present outlook is that the Lausanne conference will not be long and will be limited to making a very short provisional arrangement, according to banking sources here in constant and close touch with all the interested European central banks.

Ford Madox Ford's book of reminiscences, "Return to Yesterday," which was suppressed in England because of a story in it that King George had threatened to abdicate during a political crisis in 1914, will be published today in this country, in its full text, by Horace Liveright, Inc.

Gifts of $24,126 for the relief of needy members of the musical profession were announced by Walter Damrosch at the first public meeting of the recently organized Musicians' Emergency Aid of which he is chairman, held at Steinway Hall, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon.

The United Corporation reports for 1931 a net profit of $18,445,327 after expenses and charges, equal after preferred dividends to 75 cents a share earned on 14,531,197 shares of no-par common stock, comparing with $16,079,527, or 78 cents a share earned on 12,360.531 common shares in 1930.

Harry D. Kline, for seven years managing director of the Chanin theatrical interests, has relinquished that post, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Kline, a veteran theatrical man, supervised the bookings and managed the Chanin houses when they included the Masque, Royale, Majestic, Biltmore, Wallack's, Mansfield and the Chanin Auditorium.

William Woodward as chairman again heads the seven stewards of the Jockey Club, the group which directs the conduct of thoroughbred racing in this State, as a result of the meeting of the stewards held yesterday. The stewards are elected from among the fifty members of the Jockey Club, a quorum of which body held a meeting earlier in the day and reelected as stewards Messrs, George H. Bull, A.H. Morris and Joseph E. Widener.

A general sales tax would offer greater opportunities for commercial bribery and strike "another blow to business ethics," in the opinion of John T. Flynn, author of "Graft in Business" and other commercial topics, who spoke yesterday at a luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York in the Hotel Commodore.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Washington's decision not to send any representative to the Lausanne conference is interpreted in Paris as intended to indicate clearly once more that in American official opinion the reparations problem is exclusively a European concern and there can be no link between reparations payment or non-payment and the continued fulfillment of the European debt obligations toward the United States.

Franklin D. Mooney, president of the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company, operator of the Ward Line, has asked the Shipping Board to stop duplication of services by ship lines helped by government loans or contracts.

READING. Pa., Jan, 14. -- Alex C, Schwarz, amateur wing-shooting champion, of the East, with 35 straight fliers, carried off highgun honors today in the inauguration of the Hercules Gun. Club's mid-Winter white flier classic, a three day tournament over the Reading Fair Ground traps.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Jan. 14 (AP). -- Four Negro men and one woman were held tonight by authorities as material witnesses in connection with the murder of Mrs. Agnes Boeing Ilsley, wealthy sportswoman and her maid.
DERRY, N.H., Jan. 14 -- Carl M. Cotton, for ten years Superintendent of Schools in this town and Londonderry, was found dead on the floor of his office here today with a rope tied about his neck.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- An incident of international sports arising from an obscure point of letter writing etiquette and threatening, it seemed, to leave the 1932 Walker Cup golf matches unplayed, torfight was well on its way to' peaceful and satisfactory conclusion.

Many supper parties will be given in connection with the Bal Guignol, which will take place tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the reconstruction unit of the Post Graduate Hospital. During the supper an elaborate entertainment featuring Broadway stars of current attractions will be given.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14. -- Six New Yorkers are among the fifteen Harvard alumni who have been nominated for the position of overseers. Ballots will be mailed in April to all holders of degrees eligible to vote.

The Guaranty Trust Company as fiscal agent for Toho Electric Power Company, Ltd. (Japan) first mortgage (Kansai division) sinking fund 7 per cent bonds, series A, due on March 15, 1955, announced yesterday that $275,000 principal amount of the issue had been, drawn by lot for redemption on March 15, 1932, for account of the sinking fund.

The New York A. C. fencing team last night won the national junior sabre team championship by defeating the New York University seconds, 6 to 3, and the Columbia trio 5 to 4, in the final round-robin of the evening's competition on the New York A. C. strips.

A LOCAL golfer packed his clubs and went South yesterday. Too hot to play oh the links around here. The lads who received skates for Christmas are trading them in for bathing suits. If it gets any warmer, those foreigners who came here for the Olympic ski events will have to put wheels on their skis to make a go of it. Either that or move the whole program to Greenland's icy mountains.

Readers, critics and writers know very well what is now meant by the term realism. It covers a whole school of the arts and may be applied to painting as easily as to novels. Usually it is thought of as something comparatively new, a method peculiar to the clear-eyed moderns who shrink from the task of putting down what they see only if it might appear romantic or sentimental.

Despite the rising trend of security prices, there was a further drop of $5,000,000 in brokers' loans, as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday for the week ended on Wednesday. The total was reduced to $563,000,000, which is the lowest figure since Feb. 1, 1918, when brokers' loans were $510,179,000.

NEW YORK. Dr. Victor C. Thorne will give a dinner tonight in the Pillement suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for his daughter. Miss Harriet Van Schoonhoven Thorne, and William E. Weaver, whose marriage will take place tomorrow afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 14. -- Flying Heels, brown son of the Kentucky Derby winner Flying Ebony, carried top weight of 126 pounds to an impressive victory in the Inaugural Handicap, feature at Hialeah Park, which opened its thirty-nine-day meeting before 12,000 persons today.

Four women were injured yesterday afternoon when a swerving automobile sidewiped an Eighty-sixth Street crosstown bus on the transverse road in Central Park. One of them may have a fracture of the spine.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York made no change yesterday in its 3 1/2 per cent rediscount rate, established on Oct. 16 last, nor did the statements of the local Reserve Bank or the Reserve System reveal any evidence of the new efforts to combat deflation started last Tuesday by a cut in the bill-buying rate of the bank of issue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Postmaster General Walter G. Brown threw President Hoover's hat into the ring today for another four-year term in the White House.

Emmett Everett, 23 years old, against whom charges that might have meant life imprisonment under the Baumes laws were preferred by his father in the Bronx last Fall, following the "theft" by the young man of the family automobile, was rearrested on similar charges yesterday in front of 17 Battery Place.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14 -- Mrs. Louis A. Daus was elected president of the Palm Beach Woman's Civic Club at the annual meeting and luncheon of the club held yesterday at La Chaumiere. Other officers chosen were Mrs. Frederic Foster Carey, vice president; Mrs. D.M. Shepley, second vice president; Mrs. C.G. Donnelly, secretary and treasurer, and Miss Daisy Erb, corresponding secretary.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 14. -- Led by Leo Diegel, entrants in the $15,000 Agua Caliente golf tournament today burned up the 6,838-yard course, playing havoc with, par and bringing the scores for the first two rounds of play below anything done in the two previous meetings for the world's richest golf prize.

HAVANA, Jan. 14 -- An amnesty bill, absolving all those involved in the August rebellion as well as those members of the armed forces of the nation under indictment for crimes committed since the revolutionary disturbances began in 1930, was signed by President Machado this morning, to become law immediately upon publication in today's issue of the Official Gazette.

A plan for reorganization of the Snider Packing Corporation has been prepared by a reorganization committee with the approval of some of the more important holders of its notes and stock, including T.H. Blodgett, chairman of the board, it was announced yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 14 -- The Chamber of Deputies last night unanimously approved the measure evolved by Luis Montes de Oca, the Minister of Finance, under which the agreements reached by Mexico with the international committee of bankers headed by Thomas W. Lamont, dated July 25, 1930, and Jan. 29, 1931, are declared ineffective.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 14. -- The latest weekly report of the Netherlands Bank has produced a favorable impression here.

In India the Viceroy has found time from his pressing duties in a tense political situation to dedicate a great irrigation dam at Sukkur on the lower Indus in the district of Sind. It is to bring into cultivation an area of five million acres at a cost of $75,000,000 and to provide for a farm population of 2,500,000 souls.

In more than seventy-five cities the Democratic party last night held "Victory dinners " under the auspices of the national committee and Mr. JOHN W. DAVIS, chairman of the movement. The New York gathering heard the chairman himself expound the price of the victory.

The Triangle Club, formerly the Club Abbey, at 207 West Fifty-fourth Street, scene of a gang fight between Dutch Schultz and his opponents last year, was again an object of police scrutiny early this morning when detectives of Inspector Thomas Walsh's staff, accompanied by Federal agents, raided the premises and arrested George Clark, manager, and seven employes on charges of possessing liquor.
ROME, Jan. 14 -- The former Hungarian Premier, Count Stephen Bethlen, arrived in Rome early this morning for a ten-day stay.

"If Booth Had Missed." the play by Arthur Goodman which won the Long Play Tournament last Spring, has been put in rehearsal by William A. Brady, Ltd., in association with Walter Hartwis. Milton Smith is directing under Mr. Hartwig's supervision.

VALLEY CITY, N.D., Jan. 14 -- Stirred to a high pitch of optimism in the belief that 1932 will be a Democratic year, North Dakota Democrats at their State convention here today unanimously endorsed Governor Roosevelt as the party's candidate for President and urged him to allow his name to be put on the Presidential preference ballot in the primary election March 15.

The Hart House String Quartet of Toronto appeared in its only recital here this season at Town Hall last night, playing three quartets by Haydn, Brahms and Debussy. The group was founded seven years ago by Vincent Massey, former Canadian Minister to Washington, and Mrs. Massey, and has played recitals in England, Europe and in the leading cities of this country from coast to coast.

Arthur J. Daly, 24 years old, a former resident of Boston, and with polished manners, a glib tongue and a dubious past, who eluded the authorities last April when he disappeared from the Caronia of the Cunard line, leaving behind him a note in which he declared that he intended to leap overboard, is again in the hands of the police.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Efforts of New York and other large cities to obtain relief from their frozen credit conditions through the new Reconstruction Finance Corporation met final failure in the House today.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Too much must not be expected from next month's world disarmament conference at Geneva, a group of English Mayors was warned today by Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Secretary, and Viscount Cecil of Chelwood.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens and members of his Cabinet receiving salaries of more than $5,000 a year have voluntarily accepted a 10 per cent reduction as part of the city's present economy program. Mr. Harvey made this announcement following a meeting of his Cabinet in Queens Borough Hall, Long Island City, late yesterday afternoon.

The Attorney General's drive against stock selling by two society-gossip magazines was brought to a successful close yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Druhan in Brooklyn signed an injunction, consented to by the publishers of The Tatler and American Sketch, prohibiting the further sales of stock in the publication.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 14 -- The text of the address of Alfred E. Smith at the Victory Dinner here was as follows:

PARIS, Jan. 14. -- The International Aero Federation opened its three-day annual meeting here today at the Aero Club of France with about seventy delegates, representing a score of nations, in attendance. The committee meetings started yesterday, but it was not until this afternoon that Air Minister Dumesnil formally inaugurated the conference.
The text of the address by John W. Davis, general chairman of the Democratic Victory Campaign for 1932, delivered at the Hotel Astor last night, follows:

Eventual reduction in the loss of lives of women in childbirth in New York State to a rate at least as low as that of Holland and the Scandinavian countries, where it is now the lowest in the world, was predicted yesterday by Dr. Linsly. R. Williams, director of the New York Academy of Medicine, at the fourteenth annual meeting of the Maternity Centre Association.

The false Spring gave Winter another roasting yesterday in the Eastern part of the country, setting new high temperatures for the month of January in New York and many other communities, bringing flowers into bloom three months ahead of time and generally putting the cold season to rout.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Hardly a paper in Paris overlooked the opportunity today to print gloomy prophecies and solemn warnings over what they call the "policy of inflation in the United States," basing their opinions, of course, on the formation of the National Credit Corporation and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in Washington.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 14. -- Mrs. Sarah Fownes Wadsworth of Pittsburgh won the Silver Foils golf tournament today by finishing all even in the eignteen-hole competition match play against women's par. Mrs. Heman Gifford of New York was second with the score of 1 down.

PARIS, Jan. 14. -- For the third successive day the Bourse stock list rose and today's session witnessed really animated trading for the first time since the present upswing began Both cash and term transactions were increased by orders from the public as well as from professionals, and there were also many orders for foreign account.

With the announcement in Albany yesterday that the State was advancing to this city $15,000,000 of the $22,000,000 due in State school aid money, Mayor Walker wired all his department heads to rush reports on the extent of their department budget cuts.

Several readers of THE TIMES have inquired why railways or other companies which report a large accumulated surplus should have been reducing dividends. Why should they not draw now on the accumulations of prosperous years, which were not then distributed in increased dividends, in order to maintain the existing dividend-rate in a period of fall of earnings?

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- There is no ingongruity in Great Britain enforcing drastic repressive measures in India at the moment she is planning a constitutional government for that country, Sir Samuel Hoare, Secretary of State for India, told newspaper men today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We are a nation of business men. A sum of $250,000,000 a year (the debts) seems to be the obstacle in the path, of international progress, which affects us very greatly -- and we also have a Congress.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Premier Laval, who yesterday remade his Cabinet, excluding only Aristide Briand from the list, today called on his predecessor at the Foreign Ministry and, according to a communique issued this evening, "insisted strongly on the importance to the country and to the cause of peace of the private collaboration of Aristide Briand."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 13, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,887,000,000, a decline of $46,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $712,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- Immediate entry of the United States into the League of Nations "as a member on a 100 per cent basis" was urged at the annual convention of the League of Nations Association here today, together with a plea for readjustment of intergovernmental debts and reparations.
DETROIT, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Detroit's Falcons kept up their home winning streak tonight, downing the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 to 0, in a fast National League Hockey game.

Predicting that at least $50,000,000 could be cut from the cost of building construction in any normal year through the adoption of a more flexible and modern building code, the Merchants' Association submitted a new code in tentative form to Mayor Walker yesterday after spending more than three years in formulating it.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- Sir Josiah Stamp, director of the Bank of England, in addressing a luncheon at Birmingham today said there was much mischievous misunderstanding abroad concerning the circumstances in which Britain departed from the gold standard.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 -- Alfred E. Smith asked the Democrats of Massachusetts tonight to join in a united endeavor to restore their party to power in the nation by abandoning their traditional custom of finding fault with the Republican party and launching a constructive program of their own.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Unless something entirely unexpected at present develops between now and Jan. 25, the British delegation to the reparations conference will go to Lausanne prepared to agree on a short-term moratorium for Germany and convinced that nothing beyond some such temporary hand-to-mouth device can be expected at that time.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 14. -- Four Princeton indoor polo teams will play twenty-two games this season, according to the schedules announced today for the first, second and third varsity teams and the freshmen trio. The featured games on the first varsity schedule are those with Harvard, Yale, Army and P. M. C.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Creation of a joint legislative committee to investigate the administration of the Banking Department by Superintendent Broderick is proposed in a resolution offered today in the Senate by Senator John A. Hastings of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Major Gen. Ninamiya, Japanese commander of gendarmes, and his subordinate officers in Mukden, Manchuria, have been subjected to punishment because they were responsible for the discipline of the soldiers who attacked Culver B. Chamberlain, the United States Consul, on Jan. 3.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 14 -- In an effort to help relieve unemployment conditions in the building trades of Princeton, the board of trustees of Princeton University authorized today the construction of a new dormitory to house sixty-five undergraduates.

Welcoming the 700 persons who attended the dinner of the Society of Automotive Engineers at the Hotel Pennsylvania, on behalf of the city of New York last night, Mayor Walker complimented them on having staged "the hest automobile show in history."
PARIS, Jan. 14 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:
The text of the address of Governor Roosevelt at the Democrats Victory Dinner in the Hotel Astor follows:

Roderick Stephens, president of the Stephens Fuel Company and owner and member of the crew of the yacht Dorade, which won the transatlantic race last Summer, has been elected a vice president of the National Bronx Bank.

HONOLULU, Jan. 14 -- Governor Lawrence M. Judd of Hawaii announced today that the first action of the Legislature, when it meets in special session Monday, will he to consider the bill for the creation of a Honolulu Police Commission.

Synthesis of a chemical which produces cancer in animals, regarded by experts as an important step in the search of science for the cause of the disease, is reported in the new issue of The American Journal of Cancer, out today.

The scramble to operate buses on the city streets, in which already more than seventy applications have been filed with the Board of Estimate, has been further complicated, it was disclosed yesterday, with the filing of an application by Bus Transfer, Inc., a new corporation, for franchises to operate bus lines on three of the principal avenues and on several important crosstown routes in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 14 -- Secretary Mellon was accused before the House Judiciary Committee today by Representative Patman of having used his "official" influence to negotiate a fifty-year oil concession with the Republic of Colombia for the Colombian Petroleum Company, which Mr. Patman asserted, was controlled by the Mellon interests.

Chief Boatswain George M. Schellenger, in command of the Atlantic Beach Coast Guard station, three miles west of Long Beach, testified in the Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday that he had received an offer, which he had refused, of a bribe of $50,000 to keep his men away from Long Beach while liquor cargoes were being unloaded there.

Buying enthusiasm in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday ran the gamut from United States Government bonds to defaulted foreign, loans, but it was difficult to decide whether the government's obligations for domestic railroad bonds made the best showing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES printed an account of an address by a minister, in which he urged his congregation to spend $1 a week less for food and to give that dollar to the unemployed. If this minister's parishioners follow his advice, all of the grocers, butchers, bakers and other tradesmen with whom they deal will find their receipts lessened.

Under the most active trading in recent weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced again yesterday and reached the highest figures of the movement. July sold at 7.06 cents a pound, or more than 90 points above the low records of the season and less than $1 a bale from the high point reached in October.
MONTREAL, Jan. 14 (AP). -- The high-scoring Toronto Maple Leafs, pace-setters in the international group of the National Hockey League, handed the Montreal Maroons a 6 to 4 setback tonight.

The astronauts who would a-rocketing go to the moon and the nearer planets might ponder the implications of a preliminary report on meteors just issued by Dr. S.L. BOOTHROYD of Cornell. " We already " have observed nearly * * * 6,000 " naked eye meteors in three lunations and nearly * * * 500 telescopic meteors in one lunation."

Persons have related (but ALLAH is all-knowing) that there was once a city which fell on evil days. And the treasurer appeared before the Sultan of that city and bowed himself to the ground, and said, " O my " Lord, foreign dervishes have taken " our gold, and our money-bags are " empty, and how shall the Sultan "feed his faithful ? "

The Committee of Twenty on Street and Outdoor Cleanliness embarked yesterday on a campaign to improve the sanitary condition of the city's pushcart markets. The organization met at the Academy of Medicine and a subcommittee was appointed to investigate the pushcart markets and other sidewalk displays of food, taking photographs to show specific violations.

Bruno "Walter, appearing last night as guest conductor with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, had a triumph richly deserved. Mr. "Walter had not conducted here since the season of 1924-1925. The instant the string choir sounded the opening harmonies of a Handel "Concerto Grosso," with a tone superb in its depth, fullness and virility, the audience realized the presence of an authoritative and inspired interpreter.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Three measures to relieve financial stress on municipalities became law today when Governor Roosevelt signed bills sponsored by Senator Hickey of Erie and rushed through both houses as the first legislation of the session.
