JERUSALEM, Jan. 14 -- Six hundred teachers in Jewish schools under the auspices of the Jewish Agency for Palestine went on strike throughout the country at noon today, 23,000 schoolchildren receiving a forced holiday.

Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club, former amateur champion and second in the national ranking, was eliminated from the Clyde Martin Memorial squash tennis tournament last night at the Yale Club.

Announcement by Postmaster General BROWN, who is understood to be the leading political manager for the President, that Mr. HOOVER desires and will seek renomination might seem superfluous. It is like trying to make a sensation out of the obvious -- a solemn way of asserting what nobody had doubted.

One of the largest realty transactions recorded in New Jersey this year was closed yesterday when Pathe News, Inc., of 1,560 Broadway, New York City, sold the motion picture studio at Cgden Avenue, Congress Street and Paterson Plank Road, Jersey City, to Consolidated Film Industries, Inc., of 1,776 Broadway, New York City.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 14. -- Jack B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N. Y., defending champion, eliminated Arnold Minkley, Detroit, who tied for the qualifying medal. 1 up, in the first round of match play today in the annual Miami-Biltmore invitation tournament on the Miami-Biltmore Country Club course.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee voted yesterday to lend $1,000,000, subject to approval of its counsel, to the Department of Public Welfare to reopen the sixty-nine registration stations of the Home Relief Bureau throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A new radio beacon on Scotland Lightship will be available about Jan. 22 for all vessels entering and leaving New York Harbor, the Lighthouse Service announced today. Scotland Lightship is on the axis to the old South Channel, still used by many coastwise craft.
To the Editor of The New York Times: With reference to the budget message of Governor Roosevelt, I think a great many persons will agree that the increases in some of the taxes are quite drastic.

Aside from a fractional recession in time-money quotations, all dates, to 3 1/2@3 3/4 per cent, there were no other changes of importance registered in the money market. Stock Exchange call loans held at 2 1/2 per cent, as previously, while outside trades went at 2 1/4.

The upward movement on the New York Curb Exchange continued yesterday, a long list of issues establishing new high prices for the movement. Trading increased moderately and many issues that had been dormant recently appeared on the tape. All groups participated in the advance with probably the greatest strength in utility preferred shares.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Magna Mater, a 3-year-old filly with a liking for heavy going, won her second race over the Jefferson Park oval today, leading a field of platers home in the six-furlong feature.

The New York State Women's Committee for Law Enforcement at a meeting yesterday voted to send a letter to Congress objecting to the proposed national referendum on the Eighteenth Amendment, and adopted a resolution to request the Republican State Committee to include two women drys in the proposed delegation of three women to the Republican National Convention in Chicago.

Definite indications that the present National Automobile Show at the Grand Central Palace would surpass last year's in point of attendance as well as actual and prospective sales were seen in statements given out last night by the committee in charge of the show.
HAVANA. Jan. 14 (AP). -- Signalizing the seventeenth anniversary of the opening of Oriental Park, the Anniversary Purse at six furlongs featured the program today.

The story of human history from a fresh point of view is presented by Gerald Heard, author of "The Ascent of Humanity" and "Social Substance of Religion" in a new book, "The Emergence of Man," published by Harcourt, Brace Co. The new volume emphasizes the spiritual development of man and subordinates material progress.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14. -- Ranking women fencers of New York and Philadelphia will participate on Saturday in an invitation tournament to be held here in conjunction with the men's Olympic sabre fencing trials at the Penn A. C.

BERLIN, Jan. 14 -- The editorial in II Popolo D'Italia, demanding the cancellation of inter-European political debts, which is generally ascribed here to Premier Mussolini, occupies the front pages of the German newspapers and is endorsed warmly in editorial comments, which, however, diverge as to whether Signor Mussolini means to make a plea for a united European front against the United States.

Tuesday, Jan. 12 Mr. LUCE of Massachusetts rises to a question of privilege, which the Speaker permits him to state. In the Congressional Record Mr. LUCE, an eminent authority on parliamentary procedure, finds himself represented as guilty of a violation of parliamentary law.

Springtime in January. No one does anything about the weather, despite MARK TWAIN'S complaint. But the weather continues to do things about itself. The Sun reported yesterday that an elm tree in Bryant Park was "black with birds."

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Negotiations on unemployment and a voluntary and temporary wage reduction of 10 per cent by railroad employes struck a snag today when Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, reported to the union Spokesmen that some of the roads had not given full authority to the president's committee of nine to negotiate "to a conclusion."

Steve Hamaa will make his bid for recognition a a heavyweight championship contender tonight when he clashes with Tommy Loughran, Philadelphia veteran, in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden. The battle will be the feature of a card which includes three other ten-rounders.

MOUNT STERLING, Ky., Jan. 14 (AP). -- A jury of blue grass farmers and a barber today convicted William Hightower, 77-year-old Evarts coal miner, of counseling the death of a Harlan County deputy sheriff and fixed his penalty at life imprisonment.

BERLIN, Friday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Renewal of Germany's short-term credits, amounting to 4,400,000,000 marks [about $1,000,000,000], upon payment of 250,000,000 marks, was said by the Vossische Zeitung today to have been agreed upon by a committee of foreign bankers.
The second of The Jinks, a series of four supper dances, was given last night in the roof garden of the Pierre. Among those who entertained parties were:

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 14. -- Three seeded stars advanced to the semi-final round of the women's second annual New Jersey State squash racquets championship tournament, while the fourth was the victim of an upset in the second day of competition today at the Montclair A. C.

The "call to arms" of the Democratic party in preparation for the Presidential campaign, heard all over the country at threescore "Victory Dinners," was sounded here last night by Governor Roosevelt, who, pleading for a campaign free from prejudice, deplored the present tendency "to blame all our present troubles on the President."

A finance commission which will take charge of the investment of all funds of the United Lutheran Church in America will begin functioning within a few weeks, it was disclosed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the church body, after a meeting of the executive board.

TOKYO, Jan. 14 -- The Foreign Office tonight published translations of the secret agreements concluded in 1905, when China confirmed the transfer to Japan of Russian rights in Manchuria. The agreements were kept secret at China's request and were merely recorded in the minutes of the proceedings.
An exhibition of paintings from the studio of Robert Spencer, N. A., who died last year, is being held at the Ferargil Galleries until Feb. 1 through the courtesy of Mrs. Spencer.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 14 (AP) -- A new and simplified treatment for pernicious anemia, eliminating many of the uncertainties and difficulties of present treatments, has heen perfected by research scientists at the University of Michigan.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP). -- Social registerites from the Florida Gold Coast formed a blazing pageant of 1932 sports styles as they watched the thoroughbreds in competition under legalized pari-mutuel wagering today.

J. Lawrence Pool of the Harvard Club, the defending titleholder; Herbert Noel Rawlins Jr. of the Racquet and Tennis Club, former champion; George D. Debevoise of the Racquet and Tennis Club and Ralph Powers of the Harvard Club entered the semi-final round of the metropolitan squash racquets championship tourney on the courts of the University Club last night.
A goal by Marty Barry, centre for the Boston Bruins, robbed Joan Ross Roach. Ranger goal tender, of a shut-out victory in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

In yesterday's stock market, although prices ended pretty uniformly at a net advance, there were some signs of slackening in the pace. Mat shares went 2 to 3 points higher in the early market, but most of them lost later a good part of the rise. This was natural enough from the "Wall Street viewpoint, seeing that the "averages" had already move up 20 per cent almost within a week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was with interest and with hope that many of us read the prediction in THE TIMES that "Changes are slated for some of our leading banks and their security affiliates, at the annual stockholders' meetings to be held during the next two weeks."

Brazil has balanced its budget and expects to meet all of its foreign and internal obligations by reason of the rigorous economies which have been effected, increased hours of labor and whole-hearted cooperation of the entire nation in rehabilitation, according to Finance Minister Oswaldo Aranha in an interview with the Agencia Brasileira cabled yesterday to the Pan-American Information Service here.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 14 -- It became known today that the former Nanking Government, headed by General Chiang Kai-shek, not only cleaned out the National Treasury but obligated the new regime to pay a considerable amount of post-dated bills. At present the National Treasury is empty.

The last of the season's Friday Assemblies will be held tonight in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton. This series of dances is arranged annually for young married couples and debutantes of recent years. The guests will be received by Mrs. Hugh Campbell Wallace, chairman of the committee, and Mrs. James Russell Lowell.
TRENTOK, Tenn., Jan. 13 (AP). -- Eight members of a family were killed and five injured when a tornado ripped their farm home to pieces as it struck Katon and Lex, small towns near here, tonight.

Weather Upsets Retail Plans. The kind of weather which has been experienced during the last few days has completely upset retailers' calculations for the period, and consumer response to sales offerings of seasonal merchandise has dropped much below expectations.

HONOLULU, Jan. 14 -- Mrs. Eva Stotesbury of Philadelphia in a message to Mrs. Granville Fortescue, held for the murder of a Hawaiian who was accused of attacking her daughter, said she "would have done the same . . . and so would any other good mother."

An unusually large audience for Thursday evening, the least favored of the Metropolitan Opera's subscription series, welcomed Lawrence Tibbett in his first appearance of the season and Lucrezia Bori in her season's first performance of the role of Violetta in Verdi's "La Traviata."

H.S. Brown, examiner of the United States Shipping Board, heard testimony yesterday at 45 Broadway on the complaint of the Atlantic Refining Company of Philadelphia against the Ellerman Bucknall and other lines that rates charged for the transportation of petroleum products from Philadelphia to South Africa are discriminatory in favor of similar shipments out of New York.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Unless a contrary decision is reached when the executive committee of the Republican State Committee meets here next week, the party leaders in the Legislature will await a decision from the United States Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the Congressional reapportionment before they attempt to strike a bargain with Governor Roosevelt for a new plan that he will give standing by adding his Executive approval.

"When the Bough Breaks," a play by Jerome Sackheim, which has been on the verge of production several times, will go into rehearsal Sunday upon the arrival from the Coast of Pauline Frederick, who will be starred. Miss Frederick's supporting cast will include Malcolm Duncan and Maude Durand.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Two mid-Western Democratic Senators tonight blamed the Republican Administration for the nation's economic troubles.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- A more confident feeling concerning the international financial outlook was reflected on the London Stock Exchange today where dealers reported a further expansion of business. With favorable American and Continental advices, the upward trend of prices continued.

Advancing tendencies on the Stock Exchange yesterday indicated that speculative enthusiasm had abated only slightly. It was again asserted positively in commission-house circles that the forces of reaction had been routed. However, the market fell back some distance in the late dealings and the final prices were well below the day's high levels.
CAIRO, Jan. 14 -- The Egyptian Ministry of Finance has just completed framing a project whereby taxes on all motor vehicles used in this country would be increased several hundred per cent.

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 14 (AP). -- Miss Helen Joy Morgan, daughter of a wealthy Flint business woman, was sentenced to a prison term of from twenty to twenty-five years today for slaying Leslie Casteel, her garage mechanic sweetheart, last April.

Continuing its campaign for more uniform practices in preparing reports of listed companies, the New York Stock Exchange has sent a letter to the presidents of such concerns requesting their cooperation for the benefit of the companies themselves, of shareholders, of accountants and of the investing public.

Cardinal Hayes named two new pastors yesterday, promoted another, transferred three assistants and assigned to a parish as an assistant each of the ten young men whom he recently ordained to the priesthood half a year ahead of the normal time because of a shortage in the Archdiocese.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14. -- Pennsylvania launched its first shell of the year on the Schuylkill today, at least a month earlier than the usual outdoor start for the Red and Blue. Several of the crewmen, because of the high temperature, were stripped to the waist as they paddled up the course in Fairmount Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Airport development continued during the past year throughout the country, and on Jan. 1 there were 311 more airports and landing fields than a year ago. Colonel Clarence M. Young. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aviation, announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- A prediction that the Democrats would win a "sweeping victory" in November if the party would shun overconfidence and factional differences was made tonight by Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Democratic National Executive Committee, in addressing more than 1,500 Middle Western Democrats at the "Jackson and Victory" dinner.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Appointment of Benjamin N. Cardozo, chief judge of the New York Court of Appeals, to succeed Oliver Wendell Holmes, who resigned this week as associate justice of the Supreme Court, was recommended today to President Hoover by Senator Wagner of New York.

A historical painting of George Washington, said to have been recently discovered and of much artistic value, showing the father of his country three-quarter length in a black coat with white lace jabot and cuffs, brought $3,200 from A. Leprand at last evening's sale of Currier Ives lithographs and other items from the Michaelson Gallery held at the National Art Galleries.

Leo Lermond and Gene Venzke, both of the New York A.C., and each an outstanding candidate for the American Olympic team, yesterday sent in entries for the Jefferson Club track games to be held at the 245th Coast Defense Armory, Brooklyn, tomorrow night.

The De Witt Clinton High School basketball team scored its fifth victory in six games, defeating Franklin K. Lane High, 35-10, yesterday in the De Witt Clinton gymnasium. The victors led at half time, 16 -- 7.
BOSTON, Jan. 14. -- Harvard's varsity hockey team followed its victories over Princeton, McGill Queens, Toronto and St. Mary's by beating the University of Minnesota six tonight, 7 to 6.
HONOLULU, Jan. 14 -- This city is neither riot-ridden nor race-mad. Hawaii condones neither assaults on women nor the lynching and murder of persons in the custody of the courts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A decline in railway employment in November to 1,169,229, the lowest point in recent years, was shown in Interstate Commerce Commission figures today. Total employment in November was 56,170 less than in October and 16.15 per cent below November, 1930.

The Italian Superpower Corporation reports for 1931 a net income of $1,204,222 after charges, expenses, taxes, loss on foreign exchange and loss on sale of securities. This is equal, after dividends accrued on the preferred stock, to 41 cents a share on the combined class A and B common shares.
The identities of two prospective buyers of Stock Exchange seats at $132,000 each were disclosed yesterday by the Exchange. Arrangements for the purchases were made several days ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President and Mrs. Hoover entertained at dinner tonight in honor of the members of the diplomatic corps which now represents fifty-one countries, and is the largest maintained in any capital.

With a larger entry than any of its twenty-eight rivals for the team title, New Utrecht High School hopes to capture the city P. S. A. L. senior high school indoor track and field team championship for the seventh straight year in the twenty-ninth annual meet to be held in the 245th Coast Defense Armory in Brooklyn tonight, starting at 8 o'clock.

First Bond Trust Shares, a fixed investment trust "with a portfolio of bonds of twenty-four public utility and railroad companies, has been formed by G.L. Ohrstrom Co., Inc. Each share of the trust, which will be offered publicly soon, represents one five-thousandth of an interest in a unit consisting of one $1,000 bond of each of the following issues:
LONDON, Jan. 14 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The Bank of Manhattan Trust Company, plaintiff in a foreclosure auction sale of the fifteen-story Park Crescent Hotel, at the north corner of Riverside Drive and Eighty-seventh Street, bid in the property yesterday for $1,987,500. The bank was the trustee in the action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during December was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 415.517 bales of lint and 44,491 of linters, compared with 428,870 and 52,687 in November and 405,518 and 43,522 in December, 1930.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Jan. 14 -- Three masked men, two of them armed with pistols and the other with a black-jack, entered the home of Mrs. May Schattman at Colton Avenue and Edward Street, here, at 8:10 tonight and robbed her of $11,000 worth of jewelry she was wearing and took $55 from Norman Roe, member of a prominent Patchogue family, who was waiting to escort Mrs. Schattman to dinner.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- An emergency 10 per cent ad valorem revenue tariff of wide application, with preference for the dominions, it was reported in several quarters tonight, practically has been decided upon by the Cabinet subcommittee, following compilation of published returns showing Britain's adverse trade balance last year amounted to u408,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The cry of the farmers for increased revenues, heightened by political exigencies, re-echoed through the land until an industrial and financial panic set in. Whatever the cause may be, the effect is sad. Untold misery exists, but the undaunted American spirit knows no defeat.

With a larger entry than any of its twenty-eight rivals for the team title, New Utrecht High School hopes to capture the city P. S. A. L. senior high school indoor track and field team championship for the seventh straight year in the twenty-ninth annual meet to be held in the 245th Coast Defense Armory in Brooklyn tonight, starting at 8 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Vinson naval construction bill was endorsed today by Rear Admiral William A. Moffett, Chief of Naval Aeronautics, and Rear Admiral Frank B. Upham, who told the House Naval Committee that the passage of the bill would do more to bring the United States back to a proper position in naval strength and insure rather than retard the peace of the world, than any other measure so far introduced.

A Harlem deal was announced yesterday by Max Kambach, broker, who sold the two three-story buildings at 241-3 East 124th Street for Mary Henderson to Albert Seufer for investment. The property is 40 by 100 feet and was sold with furnishings.

HAVANA, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Band Time, 3-year-old son of High Time-Bayamo, which races for Dixiana, and ridden by C. McCrossen, was a clever winner of the five-and-one-half-furlong feature at Oriental Park today.

J. Lawrence Pool of the Harvard Club, national amateur squash racquets champion, and Herbert Noel Rawlins Jr. of the Racquet and Tennis Club, former champion, winner and runner-up, respectively, in the metropolitan championship last year, will meet for the local title again today at 3:30.

The net asset value of common stock of the Tri-Continental Corporation declined from $10.30 a share at the end of 1930 to 14 cents a share at the end of 1931. The recent rally, however, lifted the stock to $1.11 a share on Jan. 13, according to a statement appended to the annual report yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- By a vote of 50 to 9, the Senate today called upon the Appropriations Committee in reporting bills for the fiscal year 1933 to make such decreases as could be done "without impairing the necessary power of the government to per form its duty in meeting the present financial crisis."
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I add a postscript to the two recent communications concerning popcorn?
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15. -- Four seeded stars advanced to the semifinal round of the Philadelphia and district women's squash racquets championship by winning their matches on the Merion courts today.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Canada has overtaken her previous unfavorable balance of trade for the present fiscal year and has converted it into a favorable balance of $10,744,995, according to a report issued today by the Department of National Revenue.

Claiming a right to the interest on official funds, Sheriff Thomas M. Parley told the Hofstadter Committee yesterday that he would go right on taking it, making certain in the future that he got it all instead of a mere fraction of the total.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Although President Hoover today put a ban on discussion of his candidacy for renomination with his callers, his friends went ahead with plans to elect Hoover delegates to the Republican National Convention and to enter him as a candidate in States having preferential primaries, whereever this course seemed to be advisable.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Wheat today reversed its action of yesterday on the Board of Trade here, breaking early, only to rally and close strong at net gains of 1/4 to 1/2 cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- An emergency call from the offices of Dr. Julius Klein, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, today brought Washington police and detectives from headquarters post haste to the department's new $17,500,000 building following the delivery for Dr. Klein of a package, which, it was feared, was a bomb.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Lieutenant Tremain M. Hughes, flying officer of the New York State Police, and Corporal Theophilus Gaines were instantly killed tonight when the State Police plane crashed east of Cazenovia.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Soviet Russia has completed the organization and equipment of an army of 1,000,000 men, with 3,000,000 ready for call, according to a declaration today by General Robert Bourgeois before the French Senate's Army and Foreign Affairs Commissions.

A dignified man of 65, who three years ago had $1,500,000 "safely" tucked away in investments and who took pleasure in satisfying every expensive whim of his wife and daughter, sat in a downtown printing office yesterday and said he was ready to start all over again.

By the margin of one point, New Utrecht High School captured the city P.B.A.L. senior high school indoor track and field championship for the seventh straight year and the eighth time in nine seasons at the 245th Coast Defense Armory in Brooklyn, last night before a record capacity crowd of 3,300.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Increasing investments in some sections and a steady flow of repayments on mortgage loans have led the nation's building and loan associations to expect that their receipts this year will compare favorably with those in more prosperous years.

A program for business recovery, sanctioned by leading economists and based in general on the use of credit facilities to reverse the present process of deflation, was announced by a recently formed advisory board of economists yesterday, through Warren M. Persons, former Harvard professor and the board's chairman.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Although Andre Tardieu today took over the Ministry of War as successor to the late Andre Maginot, Foreign Minister Aristide Briand, who is to be superseded by Premier Pierre Laval, made no move to vacate the Quai D'Orsay.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- Following, in full, is the address delivered today by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler at the annual convention of the League of Nations Association:

In its third downward adjustment to meet the reduction of the billbuying rate of the Federal Reserve Bank, made Tuesday, the acceptance market yesterday cut discounts on sixty and ninety day bills one-eighth of 1 per cent. This brought rates for all paper up to ninety days' maturity into agreement at 2 7/8 per cent bid, 2 3/4 per cent asked.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Maurice Leon in his letter to THE TIMES questions the good faith of the present Germany in regard to her international obligations, which cannot remain unchallenged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Twenty judges and lawyers, representative of the legal profession in every section of the country, have been brought to the fore for the Supreme Court vacancy left by the resignation of Oliver Wendell Holmes.
SWAN LAKE, Miss., Jan. 15 (AP) -- A new ten-foot flood swept down on a thousand Tippo Basin homes tonight as the families, unaware of the danger, slept in their already surrounded houses.

Two outstanding results of unemployment are an extreme nervous state among individuals and families affected by it, the harmful effects of which cannot be ascertained at present, and a sudden desire of many children to attend school, it was said yesterday by Miss Amelia H. Grant, director of the Department of Health nursing bureau.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Foreign confidence in Britain's ability to effect an economic recovery rather than material improvement in her situation is held to have been responsible for the rise in the value of the pound in the past few days. The New York rate touched $350, today.
MILLERSBURG, Ohio, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A Holmes County grand jury refused today to indict James Stenhouse, who confessed slaying his 2year-old son, David Oscar, as an act of "mercy."

The will of Arthur S. Somers, senior member of the Board of Education and one of the city's business and civic leaders, was filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn. It disposes of an estate in excess of $1,500,000 to three sons.

A diamond necklace, worth in normal times perhaps $75,000, is the latest treasure found in the possession of Mrs. Ida E., Wood, the 93year-old recluse of the Herald Square Hotel. For years it had lain, covered with crumpled and tattered paper, in an old cracker box in the room she would not leave.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 15 -- In the most exciting game seen here this season Carnegie Tech's basketball team defeated New York University, 30 to 25, before a capacity crowd of 4,000 fans.

NEW ROCHELL.E, Jan. 15 -- De La Salle Institute's basketball team, scored its first C.H.S.A.A. victory by defeating Iona School, 23 to 20, on the latter's court tonight. Jim Casey, centre on the winning quintet, was high scorer, tallying two field and five foul goals.

LIVERPOOL, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 883,000 bales, against 913,000 a week ago, 921,000 two weeks ago, 866,000 three weeks ago and 1,055,000 a year ago; of which American 411,000 bales, against 422,000 a week ago, 425,000 two weeks ago, 373,000 three weeks ago and 579,000 a year ago.

Harbor shipping interests united with Bronx commercial groups yesterday morning in urging the construction of a new vehicular bridge across the Bronx River at Westchester Avenue at a public hearing at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Henry P. Fletcher, former Ambassador to Mexico, who has been conspicuously discussed as the successor to General Dawes as Ambassador to Great Britain, will not be appointed to that post, according to friends who have urged his selection on the President.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Complete breaking of the morphine habit in six days by a treatment new to medicine was reported today at Cornell University. The narcotic patient was apparently cured with little discomfort.

It is made a reproach to Mr. HOOVER that he delayed so long in initiating the bold program of relief legislation, which, it is said, he should have set on foot immediately after the collapse of October, 1929. This differs from earlier criticism of the optimistic propaganda emanating from the White House during the first year of the depression.

Corse Payton, veteran actor of stock companies, and Henrietta Browne, who has played more than 1,000 engagements in the old melodrama "Over the Hills," which she wrote twenty years ago, began suit yesterday in Federal court, alleging that the talking picture, "Over the Hill," produced last year by the Fox Film Corporation, had been pirated from Miss Browne's play.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A general denial of allegations made against Secretary Mellon by Representative Patman of Texas, who is seeking to impeach the Secretary, was made before the House Judiciary Committee today by Alexander W. Gregg, counsel for Mr. Mellon.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Disturbances by approximately 400 stable hands at Hialeah Park race track, who went on strike when they were denied privileges of sitting in the jrrand stand and paddock, were quelled today after a policeman fired his pistol at a stable employe who threatened him with a pitchfork.

Harry L. Lurie, director of the Bureau of Jewish Social Service Research, who had been lent as executive director to the Emergency Work Commission's job bureau, in charge of the expenditure of $15,000,000 in unemployment relief, appropriated by the Board of Estimate, has resigned, it was announced yesterday by Cornelius N. Bliss, chairman of the Emergency Work Commission.

Tokyo has made public a secret agreement between Japan and China which dates back to 1905 and departs in some respects from the popular conception of secret treaties. The agreement was part of the Treaty of Peking in which China accepted the results of the Russo-Japanese War as embodied in the Treaty of Portsmouth.

GENEVA, Jan. 15 -- The League of Nations' finance committee began a secret examination of Austria's troubles today. It heard Chancellor Buresch and Finance Minister Weidenhofer, Dr. Richard Reisch, president of the Bank of Austria, and the League's financial representative in Vienna, Rost von Tonningen.

READING Pa., Jan. 15 -- Fred G. Ford of Detroit today won the sixteenth annual Great Eastern Handicap, emblematic of the amateur wing shooting championship of the East, after a tie with David J. Tobias of Lebanon, Pa., and Fred J. Martin, Detroit veteran, at twenty-five straight fliers each.

Freezing temperatures tonight should drive off the Spring-like atmosphere which for the past three days has deceived the buds, the birds and the bees in the East, according to the promise of meteorological charts read yesterday by James Henry Scarr, head of the Weather Bureau.

TIENTSIN, China, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Chinese troops had driven the Japanese out of the focul city of Tahushan on the Peiping-Mukden Railway, Chinese newspapers said today, and had inflicted 100 casualties in a battle still progressing in Southwest Manchuria.

The National Automobile Show manifested as perhaps never before the courage and enterprise of an undaunted industry. Makers of cars and all the hosts associated with them can go home confident that if the depression is to be conquered, theirs is the will and the energy and the fearlessness to conquer it.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., Jan. 15 -- Los Angeles woke up this morning to find its rose bushes, palm trees, outdoor patios and movie location sites buried under a mantle of real snow.

Many builders and real estate men who began a detailed study yesterday of the proposed new building code for the city expressed satisfaction over the revised regulations and predicted that they would act as a spur to new construction work as the result of lowered costs.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Jan. 15 -- Eleven patients were carried to safety today down improvised chutes of planking to an adjacent elevation from the Ivy Hall Sanitarium here when fire swept through a wooden wing of the building.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- The public had its first chance yesterday to view the designs for the new Palace of the Soviets, which will rise from the site formerly occupied by the Cathedral of Christ the Saviour and where now there is nothing but a mass of debris.

Katharine Cornell will end her long and successful engagement in Rudolf Besier's play, "The Barretts of Wimpole Street," at the Empire Theatre, on Saturday evening Feb. 13. The announcement of the closing came as a surprise to Broadway yesterday, in view of the fact that Miss Cornell's company is still doing excellent business.
The Manual Training hockey team lost an opportunity to share the P. S.A.L. leadership with Jamaica High, when it was held to a scoreless tie by Brooklyn Tech at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- The publication of a letter from Premier Mussolini of Italy to Francois Coty, publisher of Figaro and L'Ami du Peuple, is the latest incident in a campaign which the Left press of France is directing against the Corsican perfume manufacturer whose troubles have been great since he took over the direction of the Fascist movement in France and ran furiously counter to Foreign Minister Briand in his newspapers.

Groping through the heavy fog blanketing the sea in a search for rum-runners yesterday afternoon, the destroyer Herndon, flagship of Coast Guard Division 3, was rammed and disabled fifty-five miles south of Montauk Point by the freighter Lemuel Burrows, bound from Boston to Norfolk for a cargo of coal.

BOGOTA, Aug. 7 -- Summing up the year's record and analyzing Colombia's position for the press, President Olaya Herrera said today he was optimistic regarding Colombia's future because of the stability of Colombia compared with other Latin-American governments.

Wilson Co. report for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1931, a consolidated net loss of $2,017,155 after inventory losses, depreciation and interest charges. This contrasts with a net profit of $2,542,656 for the preceding year, equivalent to $8.89 a share on the 286,026 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock then outstanding.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 15 -- New York's golfers made a clean sweep in winning their second-round matches in the Miami-Biltmore invitation tournament on the club course today.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Although the undertone was firm on the Stock Exchange today, some profit-taking caused an irregular tendency. Continued support from the Continent was mainly responsible for a further rise in sterling, the New York rate opening at $3.50, the highest quotation since November.

Joseph Milner, head of the real estate firm bearing his name at 285 Madison Avenue, called upon the Real Estate Board of New York yesterday to hold a public meeting of its entire membership to devise ways and means not only to meet the emergency in the city's affairs but also "to prepare for an even more serious condition before us in connection with the city's finances which so intimately concern real estate."

The Annalist index of business activity closed the year 1931 with a slight upturn, following two years of decline interrupted only by the false revivals of the Spring of 1930 and the Spring of 1931. The preliminary figure for December was 65-8, against 65.0 for November and 76.1 for December, 1930.

Contributors to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Fund have received a bulletin published by the committee, presenting an account of disbursements. It is proper that this should be done, especially as the report contains news of needs still to be met as well as of distress already relieved.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Jan. 15 -- Ten matches ushered in the annual Stockton Cup bonspiel at the Country Club today, with the first Country Club of Brookline team opening its defense of the Stockton Cup with a 22-to-3 victory over the second Winchester quartet.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Postponing consideration for the present of the problem concerning the legal Btatus of the proceedings which came close to wrecking the possibility of a joint conference on wages and unemployment, spokesmen for the railroads and for 1,500,000 employes sat down this afternoon in an effort to reach an amicable adjustment of all matters in dispute.

HONOLULU, Jan. 15 -- The preliminary hearing in the case of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and two naval enlisted men charged with killing Joseph Kahahawai last Friday, which had been set for tomorrow in district court, is likely to be abandoned.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Wets and drys Joined issue here today as wets of both major parties in the House agreed upon a "home-rule" constitutional amendment for the chief part of their program on which they will seek a record vote and as 500 delegates to the Anti-Saloon League convention, opening a five-day session, pledged resistance to any referendum on the Eighteenth Amendment or legislation modifying the Volstead act.

Bank clearings in leading cities in the United States in the week ended on Thursday amounted to $5,874,646,000 or 26.3 per cent less than in the corresponding week a year ago, according to Dun's Review. In New York City the total was $4,046,863,000, a reduction of 25.3 per cent, while the aggregate for cities outside of New York was $1,827,783,000, a decrease of 28.4 per cent.
Prizes were awarded yesterday to 218 pupils for essays on the effect of the economic welfare of other nations on the United States and its families, by the State Chamber of Commerce.
WARSAW, Jan. 15 -- The Opposition deputies convicted at the BrestLitovsk trial were loudly cheered when they appeared at a plenary meeting of Parliament today.

The refusal of former Governor Alfred E. Smith to put himself forward openly as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination while in Boston for the "Victory Dinner" there renewed speculation here yesterday as to whether Mr. Smith intended to make any open avowal of his willingness to be his party's candidate again.

The Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, pastor of the Central Congregational Church, Brooklyn, radio preacher and former president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, was hailed yesterday as "ambassador of peace to the world from the joint religious forces of America" at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore tendered to him by the World Alliance for International Friendship through the Churches, of which he is vice president.

The Cathedral Boys High basketball team tightened its hold on first place in the Manhattan C.H.S.A. A. standings by winning its fifth triumph in as many games by halting the All Hallows School five, 27 to 12, on the losers' court yesterday.

Doing Well to Be Angry. It has sometimes been objected to Governor ROOSEVELT that he is too calm, too poised, too little given to indignation. But at least on certain occasions he is able to express burning wrath.

Walter J. Smith, 22 years old, youngset son of former Governor Alfred E. Smith, was arrested shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday morning as the driver of the automobile that half an hour earlier struck and killed Harry Wallace, 60 years old, of 319 Bowery as he was crossing Lexington Avenue between 128th and 129th Streets.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- The declarations of the German Chancellor, Dr. Bruening, have had the result, which to us is deplorable, of rendering more difficult and at present almost impossible action by those who desire to see the establishment of a loyal reconciliation between Germany and France on the basis of reason.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Discovery of two spiral nebulae or "island universes" in the constellation of the Gemini, which apparently are moving away from the earth at the rate of about 15,000 miles a second, was announced today through the Carnegie Institution.

The complete cast of Milton Aborn's revival of "Robin Hood," opening Jan. 27 at Erlanger's Theatre, will include Charlotte Lansing, Eleanor La Mance, Vivian Hart, Helen Bertram, Howard Marsh, William Danforth, Frank Lalor, John Cherry and Fred Patton.

Just about the time it was beginning to be feared that the Giants would soon have to show some concern about having a sufficient number of men to go around, what with the holdout situation as it is, the New York Club learned yesterday they had a player on their roster whom they had almost forgotten.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Senate Committee on Territories and Insular Affairs will hold a preliminary hearing tomorrow to determine whether the Senate should proceed with an investigation of crime conditions and the administration of justice in Honolulu.

MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- It was like a scene from an old storybook at the Moscow Hippodrome today when the Russians entertained their Oriental guest, Timoor Tash, Minister of Court or Grand Vizier to the Persian potentate, Shah Riza Khan, a tough soldier who rose from non-commissioned rank to sit on the Peacock Throne.

MADRID, Jan. 15 -- Dispatches leaking through the strict Portuguese censorship today quote the British consul in Lisbon as stating it had come to his attention that there have been expressions of surprise in Lisbon that the British fleet, which visited the Portuguese capital only a year ago, was there again.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- A counter offensive against the drive of "isolationists" in the Senate to keep the United States out of world affairs, combined with a demand for a more active policy and wider cooperation by this country in world reconstruction, was begun today by the League of Nations Association in session here.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 15 -- Baron Long's little joke on the bookmakers backfired today and be was placed in the unique position of having been ruled off his own track by the stewards whom he pays.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 15 -- That emphasis will be laid on the practical and economical rather than the theoretical aspects of their Winter program was decided today by members of the Garden Club of Palm Beach, meeting for the first time this season at the home of Edward Lowber Welsh.

No meeting of the League of Nations Association would be complete without a word from NEWTON D. BAKER, and the gathering at Philadelphia was no exception. From the time when WOODROW WILSON proposed the League at the Peace Conference, Mr. BAKER has been an unremitting advocate of American adhesion.

HONOLULU, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Governor Lawrence M. Judd of Hawaii, in further answering Congressional charges that local officials were to blame for conditions here, reported today to Secretary of the Interior Wilbur on the case of Isadore Wolfe, a sailor who died here in 1927 as the result of injuries received in a fight with civilians.

Despite the substantial recoveries in bond prices this week, new offerings amounted to only $17,302,371, compared with $2,672,000 last week. An idea of the comparative inactivity of the distribution of new issues may be gained from the fact that during the second week of January, 1931, a total of $257,001,000 of new bonds was placed on the market.

Fog-bound in the harbor for three hours and meeting springlike weather when their boat docked, the Swedish Olympic athletes arrived in New York yesterday with a feeling of trepidation in regard to the forth-coming Winter Olympic Games. They shed their overcoats as the S.S. Drottingholm proceeded up the Hudson and were much alarmed at finding the weather so balmy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Senator Walsh of Massachusetts, who has advocated increasing the currency to assist credit, today wrote to Secretary Mellon asking whether he would approve a $1,000,000,000 issue of 2 1/4 per cent circulation bonds to be used as a basis for increasing currency circulation.

A warning has been spread generally through the Police Department that its members of all ranks may have to accept salary reductions as a result of the city's financial difficulties, and the rank and file of the men have been advised that it may be wise for them to accept the cuts voluntarily rather than to wait for legislative action, it was disclosed last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan.15 -- The United States must not cancel the debts of the foreign nations to this country, no matter how complicated or involved the European debt and reparations question becomes, Senator David A. Reed, Republican, of Pennsylvania, member of the Senate Finance Committee, said in a statement tonight.

The schedule of new State and municipal bond and note issues for award next week totals $6,743,777, one of the smallest weekly totals in many years. This amount compares with this week's revised figure of $9,009,810. Nearly half of next week's aggregate is accounted for by a single issue, that of $3,250,000 by the State of California, with the remainder made up of thirty-two offerings, for amounts of less than $400,000 each.
A thrilling victory in the 200-yard relay race, the final event on the program, gave Columbia's swimming team a 36-to-35 triumph over the Newark A.C. last night in the Columbia pool.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Further light was thrown today on the question of French purchases of wheat, which have been creating great interest here following the rumor that France was buying 20,000,000 bushels from Canada.
Roxy announced yesterday that he would be back on the air again in "a few more weeks" in an address before the Woman's Forum at the Hotel Roosevelt.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Owing to the midmonth settlements the Bourse opened irregular today and trading was quiet in the early part of the session. Money was plentiful officially at oneeighth of 1 per cent, while carry-overs were arranged at one-sixteenth of 1 per cent and even at par in some instances.

Harry Braun, violinist, made his first appearance in recital here last night at Carnegie Hall. He is the young violinist whose $25,000 violin, the gift of August Heckscher, slipped from his grasp and was crushed beneath a truck at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street some months ago.

James E.D. Catillaz, 28-year-old art appraiser and former collector of antiques, plunged to his death from the twentieth floor of the Hotel Shelton, Forty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue, shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

BOMBAY, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Mohandas K. Gandhi, who is almost as great an idol among India's unlettered multitudes as the Mahatma himself, was sentenced at Surat today to serve six weeks in prison for urging the villagers to adopt her husband's principles of boycott and civil disobedience.

District Attorney CRAIN has directed an assistant to lay before the grand jury next week the case of former Sheriff CULKIN, whom Mr. SEABURY charges with embezzlement in the receipt of interest on funds in his official custody, and that of Deputy City Clerk McCORMICK, who, according to his own story, got $168,000 from tips bestowed upon him by the happy couples whom he united in marriage.

PROBABLY the biggest crowd that turns out to watch any sports event is the gathering along the Thames when Oxford rows Cambridge. There is no way of checking up accurately on rowing galleries and some of the estimates may be too liberal, but it has been estimated that as many as 250,000 persons have, on occasions, caught at least a glimpse of the Cantabs rowing the Oxonians in their annual water festival.

BELGRADE, Jan. 15 -- King Alexander had the opinion of university students as to his dictatorial regime brought home to him today while driving back from Parliament to the palace. He saw the street outside the university strewn with bricks and tiles, flung by students at the police in the course of a demonstration against his dictatorship.

Although the outlook is viewed as encouraging because of low inventories and delayed purchasing, there was little in the last week's news to indicate that an upturn in business is under way yet, according to the weekly trade reviews.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- Phar Lap, "red terror" of the Australian turf, whose name was taken from Senegalese and means "wink of the sky," arrived today and the occasion drew out a crowd comparable to the visit of a foreign dignitary.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Herbert L. Nichols of Chicago and John K. Garrigues of Wilmington today were appointed receivers by Chancellor J.O. Wolcott for the American Commonwealths Securities Corporation of New York upon application of Daniel A. Hegarty of New York, a creditor.
TOKYO, Jan. 15 -- Inquiries in authoritative Russian and Japanese quarters show that neither side is looking for trouble in North Manchuria at present.

Norman Coke-Jephcott, called several weeks ago to be organist and choirmaster of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, will assume his post tomorrow with the 11 o'clock morning service. He succeeds Dr. Miles Farrow, the organist for twenty years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have welcomed 1932 in a most flattering fashion with optimistic speeches and shouts. Surely a new year so enthusiastically wooed could not, with a clear conscience, fail us in fulfilling its obligation.
Sales of flat houses featured realty dealings reported yesterday in the New Jersey metropolitan area. A taxpayer and several dwellings also changed hands.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- Preceding the wedding tomorrow at the Church of the Redeemer, Bryn Mawr, of Miss Elizabeth Browning Donner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Donner of Villanova, to Elliott Roosevelt, son of Governor and Mrs. Roosevelt of New York, the wedding party and the bride-groom's parents were guests of honor at separate functions in this city tonight.

Gold transactions ware large again yesterday, as European central banks withdrew for shipment metal that they had previously earmarked here. The amount released from earmark was $15,723,000, while $16,678,000 was exported to Europe. Imports of $111,400 from Mexico were received, making the day's net loss $843,600.

While the Democratic members of the Hofstadter investigating committee have been contending that the Sheriff of New York County is entitled to the interest on litigants' funds entrusted to his care, although Samuel Seabury termed it "larceny and embezzlement," Brooklyn historians yesterday recalled the unusual administration of the late James Robinson Howe, who served as Register of Kings County in 1900 and 1901.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- The philanthropy of Julius Rosenwald is to continue under the terms of his will, which was drawn in the last week of his life.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 15 -- Gene O'Brien scored a pair of baskets in the last two and one-half minutes of play to give the M.I.T. varsity basketball team a thrilling 14-12 victory over Harvard in their thirteenth annual contest in the Harvard gym tonight.

Discrepancies between prophecies made by prohibitionists in the campaign for ratification of the Eighteenth Amendment and actual conditions today are listed by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform in a report made public yesterday to mark the twelfth anniversary of national prohibition.

As the date for the Lausanne conference draws near, it becomes plain that no extreme positions will be taken by it. Sweeping statements have been issued by spokesmen for the various Governments represented, but have been later qualified and made more moderate.

Tommy Loughran came to the end of the trail last night. The Philadelphia veteran of thirteen years of ring warfare, 29 years old, former light-heavyweight champion of the world, was overtaken by youth and the finishing right hand of young Steve Hamas, Passaic (N. J.) ex-collegian, last night in Madison Square Garden, and was knocked out in the second round of what was to have been the ten-round feature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A cool, agile guard by the name of George Slott twisted himself underneath the basket in the tense atmosphere of the Tech gymnasium tonight with only three seconds of the game remaining and dropped in the field goal that enabled the crack basketball team of St. John's of Brooklyn to defeat a fighting Georgetown University five, 27 to 26.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Howard Phipps, who have been at the Pierre since returning from their wedding trip in Europe, will leave on Monday for Palm Beach.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 15 -- Mukden reports that a Japanese force under Major Hayama, its strength unknown here, occupied Tungliao yesterday and drove out 3,000 Chinese troops described by Japanese headquarters as bandits and irregulars. However, a foreign newspaper man just returned reports as follows a conversation with the Colonel of the Third Chinese Cavalry, isolated at Tungliao with no exit except into inner Mongolia:
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Japanese note, addressed to Mr. Forbes, follows:

In order to facilitate the borrowing of sufficient funds to enable the city to meet current expenses and maturing obligations between now and May 1, when tax collections begin, Mayor Walker submitted yesterday to spokesmen for the city's leading banks his program of "the most rigid economy compatible with the necessities of the city," together with a summary of the steps already taken toward its fulfilment.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 Sponsorship of bills to put the proposed tax increases into effect will probably be decided at conferences early next week, it was said at the Capitol today.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15 -- Rudolph Spreckels's Judge Schilling, well known as a top-flight sprinter on the New York tracks, proved an easy winner of the Homestead Purse, sixfurlong feature at Hialeah Park today.
SWARTMORE, Pa., Jan. 15 -- A fast-moving Swarthmore College basketball team turned in a 51-to-37 triumph over the University of Delaware tonight.

The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation shows a net loss of $1,049,917 for 1931, exclusive of an unrealized loss of $13,125,895 on securities held but including a loss of $1,096,910 on securities sold, according to the annual report made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- An amendment to the Federal Radio law, whereby cleared channels could not be used for more than 2,300 miles, was offered today in the Senate by Senator Dill of Washington. He explained that he desired to prohibit the Federal Radio Commission from preventing a station on one coast, Atlantic or Pacific, using the same wave length as a station on the other coast.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- After four days, in which very little progress was made, the conference of members of the European steel cartel adjourned today. According to present plans, a meeting will ba held shortly in London, where it is understood an effort will be made to induce British producers to join the sales organization to control steel output.

The last for this season of the series of subscription dances called the Friday Assemblies was held last night in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton. The dances are given for young married couples and debutantes of former years. The guests were received by Mrs. Hugh Campbell Wallace, chairman of the committee, and Mrs. James Russell Lowell.

Statistics on short sales in December, which appear in the current edition of The New York Stock Exchange Bulletin, show that the operations of "in-and-out" short sellers, who cover their commitments daily, declined steadily last month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A statement by President Enrique Olaya Herrara of Colombia on Aug. 7, 1931, as reported in El Tiempo, a Bogota newspaper, that in 1930 Secretary Mellon had advised him to settle Colombia's oil disputes as a means of hastening Colombia's economic recovery was produced today by Senator Johnson of California at the Senate Finance Committee's investigation into the flotation of foreign securities in this country.

One-sixth of the exterior surface of the ten buildings in the Rockefeller midtown development, popularly known as Radio City, will be of aluminum, the Metropolitan Square Corporation revealed yesterday in announcing the award of initial contracts for metal spandrels to the Aluminum Company of America.

Stocks engaged yesterday in what Wall Street hoped was the once-familiar process of "consolidating gains." The rallying tendencies on the Stock Exchange were checked to some extent and the marked moved forward rather laboriously. The general list closed just about where it was at the end of the previous day, with no changes of consequence in either direction.

Taking the lead at the start, the Thomas Jefferson High School basketball team defeated the Columbia freshipen, 45 -- 18, yesterday in the Morningside gymnasium. The schoolboys, coached by Sam Schoenfeld, former Columbia star, held a 24-9 lead at half time.
The National Automobile Show will close at 10:30 o'clock tonight, marking the end of what is considered one of its most successful sessions in several years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Young Men's Christian Association of New York City is completing its eightieth year of service with men and boys. In all this period there has never been a time when so many young men needed the help of the association as now.

The second session held last evening of the sale of the collections of Mrs. Chauncey Blair and H. Bartow "Farr realized $32,782.50, making a grand total of $47,777.50 for the day, including the receipts of the afternoon session.

Professor John. Dewey urges mankind to put less emphasis on the control of the physical energies of the world and more on the control of man's "inner self" in an introduction he has written for a new book by F. Matthias Alexander entitled "The Use of the Self."

William Masiello, 23 years old, and his brother, Carmine, 20, returned to their home, 18 Nevins Street, Jersey City, last night after having spent two days at Ellis Island. They and their brother, Sam, 18, eventually may be deported to Italy on the ground that they are in this country illegally, but there was much gladness last night at the reunion of the three brothers and their parents.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 15 -- Rutgers Prep scored its second basketball victory of the season by trouncing the Montclair Academy five, 24 to 8, tonight. Speedy passing featured the Rutgers victory, with Lind and Keating leading the attack with 7 and 6 points, respectively.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- King Levinsky, Chicago's heavyweight threat, continued his victorious march tonight by scoring a surprising ten-round victory over the rugged Basque Woodchopper, Paulino Uzcudun, in the Chicago Stadium.

Under the heaviest buying done by consumers this year, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced again yesterday, reaching the highest level of the movement. Although the rise above 7 cents for July contracts attracted more selling and a setback at one tune wiped out all the morning gains, trade absorption created resistance and closed the list unchanged to 3 points higher than on Thursday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- More than a third of the State budget consists of aid given to school districts and it these sums are cut down it would constitute no real saving, but would throw the burden of school support back on the localities, Mark Graves, director of the State budget, told the convention of New York State Publishers which opened here today.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens said yesterday that he and the seven other members of his cabinet who receive salaries exceeding $5,000 a year each would send 10 per cent of their salary checks back to the Controller as a result of the city's inability to reduce their pay 10 per cent.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Depression or no depression, your ticket to American League baseball games will cost just as much next season as last.

That Herbert Meyer has taken a startingly long stride forward must be apparent to all who, having folowed his work with interest in the past, now pay a visit to the Macbeth Gallery, where a group of recent paintings is displayed.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 16 -- Japan's reply to the note of the United States invoking the Nine-Power Treaty in the Manchurian conflict was handed to Ambassador W. Cameron Forbes at 11 o'clock this morning.

MONTREAL, Que., Jan. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Beaudry Leman, general manager of the Banque. Canadienne Nationale and past president of the Canadian Bankers' Association, said today at the annual meeting of the bank's stockholders that the depreciation of the Canadian dollar had been caused largely by the flotation of Canadian loans in the United States.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Torrential rains swept down Tijuana Valley today, forcing a complete and disorderly rout of golf's luminaries as they plotted a third-round campaign in Agua Caliente's $15,000 open championship.

Trading was quiet and uneventful on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, with few of the leading stocks moving more than one-eighth point either way. Among the issues advancing moderately were Aluminum of America, Deere Co., St. Regis Paper and Ford of Canada A. Pennroad Corporation gained slightly, as did Brazilian Traction.

Domestic corporation bonds were mildly reactionary yesterday and United States Government bonds lost part of the previous day's gains, but foreign loans as a group held steady on the Stock Exchange. Losses in the domestic group, for the most part, ranged up to 4 points, but the list was punctuated with some fairly good gains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Ambassador Charles G. Dawes arrived from Chicago today and went to the White House to be the guest of President Hoover. He will leave next week for Geneva as chairman of the American delegation to the general disarmament conference which will convene on Feb. 2.

Mr. and Mrs. T. Wallace Orr of the Waldorf-Astoria gave a dinner-dance in the Jansen suite of the hotel last night for Miss Constance Percival, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Percival of Boston, and Louis F. Bertschmann of this city, who will be married on Jan. 23 at the home of Miss Percival's parents.

Trade Off Sharply for Week. Unless there is a sharp pick-up in retail trade today, the results for the week will be comparatively poor, retail executives agreed here yesterday. But little headway was made in the reduction, of specially purchased Winter apparel offered by the stores, and this will have the tendency of slowing up additional purchases in the wholesale markets.

Consumption of refined sugar in this country in 1931 declined 2.218 per cent from 1930, or to 5,475.204 tons, according to estimates by The Weekly Statistical Sugar Trade Journal. A summary by the journal follows:

The legality of the subpoena served on State Senator John A. Hastings by the joint legislative committee was argued in court again yesterday when the Appellate Division in Brooklyn heard Senator Hastings's appeal from the Supreme Court order upholding the summons.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- The Manhattan College freshman quintet broke the Poughkeepsie High School's winning streak of six straight tonight by taking a 31-24 game. Poughkeepsie held the score even until the last period began when the Jaspers pulled away on baskets by Coons and O'Dell.

A total of eighty-seven colts and fillies remain eligible for the Withers of 1932, it was learned yesterday at the offices of the Westchester Racing Association, which annually renews the famous test of a mile at Belmont Park.

Appealing last night to members of the Advertising Club of America at the Hotel Lincoln to support the movement to form a new citizens' party here, William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Committee of 1,000, said the findings of the Hofstadter legislative committee showed the "folly of expecting a good city government from either of the two great national parties."

Communist demonstrators who staged a protest against unemployment in lower Manhattan yesterday caused a brief melee with mounted and foot policemen on the west side of City Hall Park in which clubs were freely swung in dispersing the crowds.

Litigation between the New York Anti-Saloon League and Orvllle S. Poland, its legal adviser for a number of years, was disclosed yesterday with the filing of a suit in the New York County Supreme Court whereby Mr. Poland seeks to collect $8,084 from the dry organization for services he says he rendered in 1929 and 1930.

MANILA, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Lieutenant Zettel, who had been here since June, 1930, is survived by a widow and one child. Lieutenant Meguire, who came to the islands only last month, leaves a widow. The three enlisted men in the plane escaped serious injury.

Proposals to change the penal laws to fix a minimum sentence of one year for first offenders were attacked yesterday by three General Sessions judges as "absurd and illogical" at a hearing in the Bar Association Building before the Commission to Investigate Prison Administration and Construction.
HARBIN, Manchuria, Jan. 15 -- For the first time since Japanese troops occupied Manchuria, Chinese troops were reported to be fighting among themselves about sixty miles east of Harbin today.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15 -- From far away Australia came the Julius totalisator introduced to the American race wagering public as Hialeah Park, started its thirty-nine-day meet yesterday. For brevity, the huge machine with its electrical arms is called the "Australian tote."
RYE, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- New Rochelle's hockey team came from behind in the final period to score all its goals and defeat the Mount Vernon sextet, 3 to 2, tonight.

The Seamen's Bank for Savings filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against Mrs. Margaret A. Shayne, trading as C.C. Shayne Co., to foreclose on a mortgage covering the property beginning on the south side of Forty-second Street, 250 feet west of the southwest, corner of Sixth Avenue, and extending 23 feet east on the avenue.

New York's air may have much less soot than London's, but in this city's congested traffic areas traffic policemen and others would be killed by carbon monoxide if they were not frequently relieved from exposure to the insidious gas, according to officials of the New York Academy of Medicine.

Many younger members of society thronged the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night for the annual Bal Guignol in aid of the reconstruction unit of the Post-Graduate Hospital. The dance, always one of the popular philanthropic entertainments of each Winter, is arranged by debutantes of the current year and recent seasons.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Strife followed funeral services today for Mrs. Agnes Boeing Ilsley as a result of a State policeman's objecting to the presence of photographers taking pictures of the services.

BUFFALO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- In St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Cathedral, standing on the spot in the heart of Buffalo where another cathedral was burned during the War of 1812, the final step was taken today in the creation of a new diocese in Western New York.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club team practically clinched the title in the Class B squash tennis championship race of the metropolitan league by annexing its sixth consecutive victory of the season last night.

The joint conference of railway presidents and representatives of rail unions on the question of wages began yesterday at Chicago in circumstances which seem to favor an agreement. The carriers have asked their employes to accept a voluntary reduction of 10 per cent without recourse to the cumbersome machinery of adjudication provided by Federal legislation.

Except for a cut of 1/8 in acceptance yields, 60-90 day maturities, the money market was uniformly quiet and firm throughout, no other section developing any variation in quotation from that of the preceding day. This applied to Stock Exchange call loans, time money and commercial paper.
The St. Ann's Academy basketball team downed McBurney School, 26 to 13, yesterday in the McBurney gymnasium. St. Ann's barely led, 10 to 9, at the half, but drew away in the closing period.

VIENNA, Jan. 15 -- Members of the Heimwehr and seven members of the Socialist equivalent, the Schutzbund, were arrested today, the four for attempted murder of the Austrian Minister of the Interior, Herr Winkler, and the seven in connection with confiscation by the police during the last two days of weapons and bombs in or en route to Socialist headquarters.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 15 -- Two convicts were stabbed severely and five others were slightly cut in a pitched battle in the recreation yard at the New Jersey State prison here today. A table knife that had been ground to a keen edge, a potato paring knife and several safety razor blades were found on the ground by guards.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "No Slump in Health" raises some questions at first reading due to the use of the word "health" to represent low mortality. If one who has spent a quarter-century in studying the subject may raise a technical objection, it appears that "viability" is the word for this purpose, while "health" should rather indicate low morbidity.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Chemical Bank and Trust Company of New York and Jerre L. Dowling of New York are accused of causing the closing of the Peoples' State Bank of South Carolina by "libelous and slanderous statements" in a suit for $10,000,000 filed at Charleston.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Over the heads of Mount Whiteface, Saddleback and Haystack, this evening fell a deep purple haze, unfailing harbinger of snow and cold in the Adirondacks. Nature seemed about to smile again on the scene of the third Winter Olympic Games.

Possibly because they were fatigued after the exhausting advances of the recent past, the security markets resumed yesterday a slow, measured tread. This was true not only of stocks but of bonds as well. The latter, as a matter of fact, turned reactionary, but only moderately so.

The Institute for Child Guidance, one of the pioneer psychiatric clinics for children in this city, is soon to pass out of existence owing to withdrawal of financial support by the Commonwealth Fund, which has been forced by the economic depression to curtail its activities.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- Army defeated St.' Stephen's College of Annandale, N.Y., tonight at hockey by a score of 9 to 0.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 16 -- M. I.T. won its third game in four nights by defeating Brown, 42 to 26, tonight. Gene O'Brien led the Engineers to victory with seventeen points.

Sheriff Thomas M. Farley's admission that he appropriated interest on official funds will be cited to Governor Roosevelt by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee, it became known yesterday, as a further reason why Farley should be removed from office.

The question of renewing an emergency loan of $100,000,000 to the German Reichsbank has been discussed at Basle. This credit, which expires on Feb. 4, was originally advanced last June, shortly after President HOOVER'S proposal of a moratorium and at a time when Germany seemed headed for disaster.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Shakespeare's Birthday on April 23 will be especially memorable, for then the new Shakespeare Memorial Theatre at Stratford-on-Avon, to which America contributed largely, will have its public opening.

ABRIEF tour of the country via the out-of-town papers is not without its rewards. It discloses, for instance, that Mrs. Leslie Carter is appearing this week with her daughter. Mary Carter Payne, in a Cincinnati stock production of one of her most reliable vehicle.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The Colgate swimming team opened its season today with a victory over Union by a score of 46 to 25. Lea Lockwood, Colgate captain, equaled the pool record in the 100-yard dash in 0:57 2-5.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 -- The one-mile track record was broken at Hialeah Park today as another large crowd turned out to see the sport on the first Saturday of the thirty-nine day meeting which is being held at the remodeled course of the Miami Racing Association.

MR. GLEB BOTKIN is a son of Dr. Eugene Botkin, court physician to Emperor Nicholas II and one of those few men who, of their own free will, followed the imperial family to their Siberian exile and shared with them their tragic fate in 1918.

When the Matson line's Mariposa sailed yesterday on her first cruise, among her passengers was Miss Emily F. Wilson, 91 years old, who has closed her New York apartment at 160 East Forty-eighth Street to go to Honolulu for the Winter.
GLENDORA, Miss., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Water from the swirling Tallahatchie, Coldwater, Yalobusha and Yazoo Rivers spread out today in six Mississippi counties, marooning hundreds of people.

Mayor Walker and spokesmen for the banks from which the city seeks a substantial short-term loan to tide it over until tax collections begin on May 1 will confer today at the home of one of the bankers in an effort to bring assurance that at least enough money will be made available to meet the city's $32,500,000 obligation which matures on Wednesday.
BOMBAY, Jan., 16 (AP) -- One person was killed and two were injured when police fired into a mob that had stoned them at Berhampore, Bengal, today.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 16 -- Big, good-natured Fred Morrison of Culver City, Cal., proved today he was an even better golfer in good weather than in the rain by touring the long course in 68 to take a two-stroke lead with 211 after fifty-four holes in the Agua Caliente $15,000 open.

OTTAWA, Jan. 13 -- Theoretical science will be linked to the practical demands of commerce and Industry by the new $3,000,000 laboratory plant of the National Research Council, built and equipped by the Dominion Government, which will be put into service soon and will be formally opened with appropriate ceremonies in the Spring during the annual meeting in Ottawa of the Royal Society of Canada.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 16 -- Dr. John Grier Hibben, who already has announced his intention of retiring in June after having served for twenty years as president of Princeton University, summarizes in his annual report, which has been submitted to the board, of trustees, the development of the university during his administration.

The main difference in policy between the American and the British investment trusts, according to a recent study made by Lloyd's Bank of England, are that the British sponsor thinks in terms of yield, while the American thinks in terms of capital appreciation, and the British sponsor considers diversification from the standpoint of the world at large, while the American is more inclined to limit his diversification to industries within this country.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 -- Reports from Nanking that the Chinese Government intends to break off diplomatic relations with Japan and ask the League of Nations to invoke Article XVI of the covenant are regarded here as gestures for the domestic audience and intended to strengthen the Canton faction, whose government is already regarded as tottering.

IN "Mr. Darby" the English tradition less renews than repeats itself, showing at once the original force it had and the loss of power it has gradually sustained. Critically, at any rate, one is forced to these conclusions, though the casual reader will doubtless, with excellent reason, never give them a thought; he will simply look upon the book as the good entertainment it is.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 16 -- Many banks and title companies could have avoided failure if they had used enough foresight, C. Gough, Deputy Commissioner of State Banking and Insurance, today in addressing the annual convention of the New Jersey Title Association here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I HAVE just reread Mr. Jewell's book "American," and I recommend it to those who may intend to contribute a letter to this debate. He has made it clear that the most serious obstacle in the way of an American school lies in our habit of imitation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES in its last issue of 1931, to which we will all look back as the year of depression and uncertainty, made public the most astounding piece of news that it has ever been my good fortune to read.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 16 -- The Princeton varsity swimming team scored an impressive 62-to-9 victory over the Lehigh swimmers today. The Tigers captured every first place and all except one of the second places.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 16 -- The government's final figures for 1931 show that Ontario's production of gold in the year was a new high record, being $7,177,591 greater than the $35,518,862 reported for 1930. The total was $42,696,453. It was only in the last three months that the goldmining companies obtained the premium paid for the metal by the Dominion Department of Finance.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Announcement has just been made that a team composed of leading English tennis players will visit Bermuda next month to take part in the annual championships, Feb. 22-27. Among those from whom definite word has been received are Miss Betty Nuthall.
LONDON, Ky., Jan. 16 (AP) --A quarrel over a mountain girl broke up church services at New Salem today and ended with four dead, two believed dying and another man shot through the arm.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The stock markets ended the week cheerfully, with satisfaction felt over the course of trading in the last two weeks. Sterling again was fairly firm, with quotations only slightly changed from yesterday's closing levels. The New York rate was a trifle higher at $3.49.
