DON HEROLD'S new book recounts the story of his trip to Europe in letters to "Dear Betsey" at home. He begins with the farewells as he left New York and ends with a few reminiscent comments after he reaches home again.

GENEVA, Dec. 22 -- Camembert is at odds with Gruyere and Gorgonzola. So interlocked has international business become that this cheese difficulty threatens to develop into a general trade war among France, Italy and Switzerland, with Germany drawn in in the end.

LONDON. SOME enthusiastic golfers will tell you that the Prince of Wales would far rather be a scratch man at the royal and ancient game than be the King of England. That, of course, is merely their way of illustrating the present tremendous golfing enthusiasm of the heir to the throne, who has just accepted the presidency for next year of the Royal North Devon Club at Westward Ho!

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C. Z., Jan. 12. -- The recent charges of Representative Will R. Wood of Indiana that the United States Government is in direct competition with private shipping by the operation of the government-owned Panama Railroad Steamship Line have brought local newspapers to the defense of the line, as a necessary canal auxiliary and convenience for American Government employes living in the Canal Zone.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The new $900,000 Westchester County Jail at East View was opened today. Under a heavy gruard of armed deputy sheriffs, the 59 prisoners were transported in two hours this morning from the 75-year-old jail in this city.

A sweeping Democratic victory in the coming Presidential election was predicted yesterday by Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in an address at the annual luncheon of the Women's Civic Organization at the Hotel Commodore. More than 600 women were present.

The use of vacant lots in the uptown business section for automobile parking pending a revival in the business industry will be curtailed as a result of the decision handed down by Supreme Court Justice Lydon in a suit by Willis W. Smith against Borough President Samuel Levy.

Rallying strongly through the third and fourth periods against Los Nanduces, a team that furnished unexpected opposition all through the first half, the Optimists came thorugh a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League match at Squadron A Armory last night by a score of 7 to 4 and rode from the ring still undefeated this season.

With his highly effective game mowing down the sternest sort of opposition, Harry F. Wolf, the national squash tennis champion, gained his second successive victory in the Clyde Martin Memorial tourney at the Yale Club yesterday by defeating Edward R. Larigan of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in the final, 15-Il, 17-14, 15-9.

PALM BEACH -- Midway between the gay social activity of last week, when night clubs and hotels made their initial bows to the season, and the start of the annual Lake Worth golf battle to be waged on the Royal Poinciana links, lie two serious events on which attention of the colonists is centred this week.

AFTER several years of careful experiment and study, the long projected London to Cape Town route of Imperial Alrways is about to be opened. At the Start the saving over the fast steamship service between the Cape and Southampton will be small, a mere five days, but while the express steamers ply their course straight and without stop, the airplanes land every few hundred miles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The President and Mrs. Hoover led a caravan of twelve automobiles which informally opened today the new $7,500,000 Arlington Memorial Bridge, the capital terminus of the Mount Vernon Boulevard, which is soon to be opened to traffic.

THE stage of art is packed with incident and crowded with, exhibitions barely escaping collision as they hastily come and go. This, no doubt, is the reason that these hurrying shapes are almost wholly two-dimensional. An exhibition of such pronounced third dimension as that of French art now open at Burlington House, London, has not been seen here within the long memory of this writer.

CHICAGO. Jan. 16 -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade here was big and broad today, in striking contrast with the situation that had prevailed since the turn of the year. Numerous rumors, some of which received nation-wide distribution and all of which lacked confirmation, were bases for general and heavy buying which brought a rally of 2 1/2 to 3 1/8 cents from the early lows.

Considering the scope of the advance in stocks since Jan. 5, yesterday's week-end reaction was unusually small. The day's loss was in most shares only fractional; those which declined a point or more regained ground before the close. In bonds the day's movement was conflicting, but advances apparently predominated.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 16 -- Taking the relay by a fraction of a foot, the University of Pennsylvania swimming team defeated the Rutgers natators, 42 to 28, in the Ballantine pool today in an I.S.A. meet. Grandy, Weeks, Strong and Stinson made up the victorious quartet.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The second in a series of concerts was given last night at the new White Plains High School. The Stradivarius String Quartet and Fraser Gange, baritone, appeared. The members of the quartet included Gerald F. Warburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix Warburg of White Plains, Alfred Pochon and Nicholas Moldavan, former members of the Flonzaley String Quartet, and Wolfe Wolfinsohn.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15 -- The demonstration has been painful, but it appears likely to prove profitable. New Orleans has come to realize that progress gnaws more rapidly than decay and that unless strict measures are enacted without delay it will lose that old-world heritage of architecture, the Vieux Carre, which has helped so much to make it famous.

SITTING in the shadow of a socalled modernistic building which rose across the street, Frank Lloyd Wright. like a father ashamed of the way in which his son has gone, expressed regret at the form taken by buildings that had their inspiration in his ideas.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 16 -- The crippled Coast Guard destroyer Herndon was towed into the harbor this morning, while the collier Lemuel Burrows of Boston, which rammed the patrol vessel yesterday afternoon, proceeded to New York.

WHILE Edward G. Robinson is completing his Continental fling, the Warner assistants are beginning to gather the various strings together for his new picture, "Two Seconds." Last week Preston Foster, who appeared in the stage play, was drafted to play the same part in support of Mr. Robinson.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 SO far 1932 is a lean year at the Boston theatres. Audiences, plays, prospects are all meager. One after another, the plays go down like ninepins. The subscription list of the Professional Players could not save "Mrs. Moonlight" from extinction half way througuh its stay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Harold Calender's article on the Nazi mind in your issue of Jan. 3 is a very fine piece of work, as anything he writes, but fails, in my opinion, in one instance at least, to draw a logical conclusion.

GLUT: too much wheat, too much cotton, too much coffee, too much oil, too much steel, too much coal, too much copper, too many peaches, too many automobiles, too many tires, too many shirts. In a word, a superabundance of all the necessities and luxuries of life.
RADIO is looking forward to the biggest political job it ever handled -- the Presidential campaign of 1932.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- "Short selling" of securities on the New York Stock Exchange will be the subject of a legislative investigation if a concurrent resolution to be introduced in the Legislature on Monday by Senator Burchill of New York City wins favor with the lawmakers.

STYLES in driving change. The man at the wheel today is in some respects as different from the driver of yesterday as the new car at the Automobile Show is unlike the discarded model creaking toward the junk heap.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although Paderewski's Carnegie Hall recital of Jan. 23 had not yet been advertised in the New York papers, the box office informed me on last Saturday, Jan. 2, that the only seats remaining unsold were in boxes at $5.50 and $7.70 a seat.

MOUNT TAURUS on the Hudson River may become part of the State's park lands. Its beauty is now threatened by a quarrying company, which has begun mining its valuable granite, but this very threat has led to a campaign to obtain from the Legislature sufficient funds to buy the mountain and maintain it as a public park.
J. Lawrence Fool, national amateur squash racquets champion, retained his metropolitan title yesterday at the University Club.

HONOLULU, Jan. 16 -- John Cary Lane, for the past ten years High Sheriff of the Territory of Hawaii and Warden of Oahu Prison, today submitted his resignation to Governor Judd. It was accepted. Five prison guards were dismissed.

JAPAN has been asserting her right to run her own show in her part of the world; her adventure in Manchuria is another step in her challenge to the doctrine of European eminent domain in Asia. In a different but no less serious way, Gandhi's uncompromising defiance of the British Government is also a challenge to white supremacy over Asiatic peoples.

THE International Society for Contemporary Music has arranged tentatively the programs for the festival this year which is to be held in Vienna in June. Not a single American work has been selected for performance either at the orchestral or the chamber-music concerts.

THE Man I Killed," Ernst Lubitsch's production of a play by Maurice Rostand, will be presented at the Criterion on Tuesday evening. Ernest Vajda and Samson Raphaelson adapted Rostand's drama for the screen. The featured players are Lionel Barrymore, Nancy Carroll and Phillips Holmes.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Jan. 16 -- The elimination of the first Country Club team of Brookline, defending champion, marked the second day's play in the annual Stockton Cup invitation bonspiel of the Country Club today.

Patrolman Dominick Langan saw a boy standing uncertainly outside the subway exit at 145th Street and Lenox Avenue about 2 o'clock yesterday morning. The lad was crying and Langan took him to the station house, where questioning disclosed that he was Peter Farcella, 12 years old, and that he lived at 75 Old Broadway.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- American radio importers woke up this morning to find their great and growing market in France had been virtually turned over by a new decree to Holland and Germany. This sudden move by the French already has led to vigorous protests to the American Embassy, which will be repeated in Washington, against what is termed discrimination against American goods.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Senate Committee on Territories and Insular Affairs is expected to report adversely on the resolution of Senator McKellar of Tennessee for a Senatorial investigation of the Hawaiian situation and to recommend that the Senate, before authorizing it, await the completion of the inquiry directed by Attorney General Mitchell.

By way of bringing about sharp relief to a possible fear that there may be a serious hold-out situation in the ranks of the Giants this year, Secretary Jim Tierney announced yesterday that Melvin Ott, erstwhile boy wonder of the McGraw forces, and Carl Hubbell, talented left-hander, had signed their 1932 contracts.

A SIGNIFICANT fact which is gradually invading the consciousness of the most superficial student of music history will be emphasized by the program of the concert to be given by the Schola Cantorum, Hugh Ross conductor, next Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Innumerable presentations have been made to specify the causes that underlie the state of world-wide depression. I shall leave out of my argument the comparative degree of truth that attaches to any or all of them.

IN the mountains of Eastern Kentucky "clever," when applied to people, means kind, generous, friendly, and Mrs. Gardner uses it in that sense in her title, whose significance includes both the country and its people, whether native or from the outside.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 16, -- In a thrilling game today the Naval Academy, basketball team won from Duke University by 36 to 35.

AS all the world knows, the ugly looking and sounding word that is the title and theme of this book is the name of a famous Soviet organization as crookedly hideous as its sobriquet. It is the popular and universally used abbreviation of three long Russian words filling an entire line whose English translation is "General Political Administration of the State."

ATLANTA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A small tin trunk that lay for many years in the vaults of an Atlanta bank has yielded a valuable collection of letters and manuscripts of Joel Chandler Harris, author of the "Uncle Remus" stories.

FRANKFURT-ON-THE-MAIN, Jan. 15 -- Underwriting an abortive bootlegging cruise to the United States cost the Frankfurt General Insurance Company $500,000 or $1,500,000 if all the indirect losses are included, it was brought out in an investigation of the company's affairs.

While thousands of jobless teachers, bitter or apathetic, still clamor vainly at school doors, good permanent positions inside go begging for lack of qualified applicants. In the midst of a national oversupply of licensed pedagogues, New York State at the moment is issuing an S 0 S for well-trained teachers of commercial subjects in secondary schools.

MUKDEN, Dec. 14. -- The headquarters of General Honjo, commander of the Japanese military forces in Manchuria, seems to view the course of events in this turbulent part of the world much more placidly than the general trend is viewed from Geneva, Paris, or other interested quarters.

To the Dramatic Editor: Instead of "Pippa Passes" we have "The Devil Passes." Meanings ought not be read into Benn Levy's play which the author did not intend, but it seems to me he has written a satire so subtle that it has escaped the notice of the majority of critics and playgoers.

Unemployment was discussed this week at the midwinter meeting of the Westchester County Children's Association at the Cosmopolitan Club, 133 East Fortieth Street. Jesse I. Straus, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Employment Administration, told of the work of that body and Carll Tucker, chairman of the Emergency Employment Committee of the Children's Association, reported on the work of his committee.

WHAT is an American? Let me answer easier questions first. What is a Canadian? Any man or woman who by birth or adoption has made a home in that part of North America known as Canada. To answer the question, "Who is a Mexican?" is equally easy.

DURING the World War thousands of men were stationed for short periods of time on Long Island, at what was then known as Aviation Field No. 2. This field consisted of about 450 acres of land that had heen leased by the government, just east of Garden City and adjoining Camp Mills.

Unable to borrow in New York on satisfactory terms, Canadian provinces and municipalities are floating loans at home. The latest Canadian community to plan an internal loan is the city of Montreal, which will offer on Tuesday an issue of $15,000,000 of bonds through the Bank of Montreal and La Banque Canadienne Nationale.

ROME, Jan. 16 -- A Cabinet council today completed examination of Italy's budget estimates for the next fiscal year, from July 1, 1932, to June 30, 1933. The total of $1,103,000,000 for expenditures, tentatively fixed by a Cabinet council on Dec. 19, underwent a slight downward revision.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 16. -- "There is no well-thought-out system of liquor control in the bill presented by Senator Hiram Bingham to Congress," according to Dr. Henry W. Farnam, for many years professor of economics at Yale.

SINCE last June, when President Hoover recommended a year's moratorium on Intergovernmental debts and reparations, the use of such postponements as a means to help countries through economic difficulties has spread widely. Mexico recently announced a second moratorium on its foreign debt; in July, 1930, it had arranged a two-year delay, and when this was found insufficient, It obtained an additional postponement for eighteen months, or until Jan. 1, 1934.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 16 -- Miss Mary Ladewig of the Meadowbrook A.C., Philadelphia, contributed a surprise when she captured the women's interassociation fifty-yard dash at the Paterson Armory tonight. Competing against a strong field, which included such nationally-knovm stars as Miss Mary Carew, Miss Louise Stokes and Miss Eleanor Egg, Miss Ladewig flashed a burst of speed which enabled her to come through with the victory in 6 2-5 seconds.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 16 -- The esthetic quality in the art of the American Indians of the Delaware Valley is related to some of the finest examples of ultra-modern sculpture, particularly where the Indian stone masks are concerned, in the opinion of J. Horvard MacPherson, Trenton artist and authority on the Delaware Valley Indians.

In an article in Le Temps of Paris Professors Camille Bloch and Pierre Renouvin of the Sorbonne recently gave a hitherto unsuspected reason why Article 231 of the Treaty of Versailles warn inserted. This is the famous "guilt" article which indicts Germany and her allies as having forced the war upon the Allies.

AT the thirty-third annual dinner of the Society of the Genesee, on Jan. 25 at the Commodore, the guest of honor will be a former resident of Rochester, Miss Lillian D. Wald, founder and head of the Henry Street Settlement.

PARIS. EVEN the dullest of between-seasons in Paris offers some items of sartorial interest to style prophets. An odd frock specially designed for a chic private client by a great couturier drops a hint as to his future intentions.

GUATEMALA CITY. A PAIR of compasses and a map show less than 300 miles between Guatemala City and Flores, the northerly town in the heart of the Peten chicle forests. Yet until recently the journey from Guatemala took from two to three weeks, depending upon steamer connection and the depth of mud on mule trails.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 -- A charmingly naive incident marked the transition of this city's government from the old and notoriously loose organic law to the new charter, The board of supervisors resolved itself into an elementary school of which City Attorney John J. O'Toole was the teacher to instruct the pupils in their powers and duties under the reorganization.

Some of those speculators who, unabashed in the face of' an increasingly hostile sentiment, have kept a snug position on the short side of the stock market became acquainted last week for the first time with the margin clerks of their brokers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Did you ever hear of the "Quarter Acre Clause"? It is one of the reasons why the Irish hate England. A brief examination of it will show that our relief agencies and organizations have learned nothing in the past 85 years.

Walter H. Merrall of 70 East Seventy-seventh Street, for the last twenty years president of the well known grocery firm of Acker, Merrall Condit Company, died late last night in the Harbor Hospital, 667 Madison Avenue, of cirrhosis of the liver, after a short illness.
To the Drumatic Editor: I always become resentful when I hear that some producer is having casting difficulties. This feeling is shared by many members of my profession.

VATICAN CITY, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Fifty members of the Vatican Library staff, including ten catalogue girls, heard a brief address by Pope Pius XI tonight in which he thanked the world for the interest and sympathy manifested when the roof of a section of the library collapsed last month.

DETROIT. IN contrast with the mood of trepidation in which they departed for New York, motor company executives returning from the National Automobile Show reveal a marked spirit of optimism and confidence. The 1932 model automobile has ''gone over."

"Share With Others' Day" will be observed by many churches today, and of this number not a few will hold "Cheer-Up Services." Several clergymen will preach on the need of a greater study of the Bible. Already the ritualistic churches are beginning to prepare for Lent, Ash Wednesday coming this year on Feb. 10.

THE Museum of Science and Industry, founded by Julius Rosenwald, has lifted a piece of the Las Cruces trail in the republic of Panama and has shipped it bodily to Chicago for installation in its new home in Jackson Park.

BERLIN, Jan. 16 -- Adolf Hitler made another appearance in court today, being acquitted on a charge of having slandered Captain Stennes, former leader of the National Socialist storm detachments in Berlin, by calling him "a police stool pigeon."

BARCELONA, Jan. 2 -- The members of the Jesuit order in Spain plan to carry on normally in their colleges and churches, and with respect to their other activities, just as if no Article XXTV of the new Spanish Constitution, with its clause providing for their early dissolution, had ever been adopted.

WASHINGTON Jan. 16 -- Retail food prices in fifty-one cities in the United States showed an average decline of about 2 per cent in the month ended Dec. 15, and were 16 2-3 per cent lower than on Dec. 15, 1930, the Labor Department reported today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 16 -- The first annual convention, of the Young Republicans of New Jersey here, called by William S. Greene Jr. of West Orange, chairman of the organization, to express "dissatisfaction with the manner in which Republican politics, have been administered," became a Hoover rally tonight.
WEST POINT N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Army defeated Lehigh at basketball today by a score of 43 to 23. It was the cadets fourth virtory in as many starts.

BOMBAY, Jan. 16 (AP) -- India has shipped more than $100,000,000 worth of gold to London since Great Britain abandoned the gold standard. If shipments are continued at the present rate, they are expected to double last year's entire world output of gold, which was approximately $420,000,000.

LONDON. MUSICAL activities touch a low ebb with the passing of the old year; and before the broadcasting era nothing of importance happened often for a period of three or more weeks. Nowadays, however, the B.B.C., being independent of immediate public support, can step in the breach and provide attractive programs in spite of the season.

Gene Venzke, the trimly hunt, miler from the New York A.C., served notice last night that he is the coming star of the present indoor season and a possible. Olympic champion when he spread-eagled a field that included Leo Lermond and Frank Crowley to win the 1,500-meter invitation run that featured the benefit track and field meet, of the Jefferson Club at the 245th Coast Defense Armory.

COLOMBO, Dec. 8.-That the rich man as well as the poor man is affected by the trade depression is indicated by the drop in the consumption of all kinds of liquor in Ceylon last year. Statistics prepared by the Excise Commission show that the decrease has been gradual since 1926 when the depression began really to be felt in Ceylon.

ON parade, every regiment in the United States Army now carries on its colors or standard a distinctive coat of arms, emblazoned in gold and silver and covered with trimmings of sable, vert, gules, azure and other hues, portraying in terms of heraldry its outstanding achievements on the field of battle.
AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 16 -- A powerful Williams basketball machine subdued Amherst tonight, 38 to 19, rolling up its fifth consecutive victory and gaining the first leg on the Little Three hoop title.

On his forthcoming expedition to the Antarctic Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd intends to establish a subbase in the interior of the continent, at the foot of the Queen Maud mountain range, and spend a polar Winter there making scientific observations, he revealed last night at the twenty-eighth annual dinner of the Explorers' Club at the Hotel Biltmore.

IF the so-called smoke nuisance were better understood; if people generally recognized that it embraces far more than is visually apparent; if they considered its cost to the individual and to the community, there would be no difficulty in securing the enactment and enforcement of adequate laws.

SAVE for Guglielmo Ferrero, Mr. Baker is the only historian who has firmly grasped the idea that ancient Rome contains the story of the modern world, and that by an analytical and selective study of its great men we can read our own future.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 16. -- Scoring in each, period, the princeton varsity hockey team defeated Dartmouth tonight, 4 -- 0. Art Lane led the Princeton attack with two goals. while Kammer and Poole scored one apiece.

Continuing its policy of showing "art with a social purpose," the John Reed Club is holding until Jan. 31 a joint exhibition of work by Eitaro Ishigaki and William Siegel. Ishigaki, whose contributions to the exhibitions of the Independents have seldom failed to elicit comment, seems in his work more American than the Americans.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- For the sixth time in the last five years Notre Dame defeated Pennsylvania in basketball by taking tonight's game at the Palestra, 32 to 25, before a crowd of 6,000 spectators. Since the series started, in 1928, the Red and Blue has never tasted victory.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- Outstanding among all of Julius Rosenwald's varied contributions to humanity was his work in behalf of bhe American Negro, in the opinion of Jacob Billikopf of this city, who had been associated with Mr. Rosenwald in welfare activities for a quarter of a century.

Flowers bloomed all aver the United States last week, and the Democrats held more "Victory dinners." The portents of 1932 continued to be curious and strengthened the belief of superstitious people that miracles were at hand Among them they envisaged the first failure of the Republican party to renominate an incumbent elected President who was willing to have the honor; and, quite illogically, the synchronous and sudden return of prosperity.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 16 -- The "chastened spirit induced by the vicissitudes of severe depression" among the great body of American business leaders has not lessened the need for the public safeguards against abuses of collective effort. Professor I. Lee Sharfman of the University of Michigan, told the Adult Education Association Conference on Economic Planning today.

Lacrosse, the old Indian game, is attracting much interest among women athletes in this country. A national organization, the United States Women's Lacrosse Association, was formed last September, and since then divisions have been organized in several cities -- among them New York.

LONDON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The position of clubs at the top of the averages in the English Soccer League were not disturbed by today's matches. Everton, first division pacesetters, won from Sunderland, 4-2, and held its lead, while West Bromwich Albion, second club, defeated Blackpool, 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Joseph C. Grew, Ambassador to Turkey and former Under-Secretary of State, was mentioned today as a likely successor of W. Cameron Forbes as Ambassador to Japan, but a report that the Japanese Government had been approached with an inquiry as to his acceptability lacked official confirmation.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Both French and Americans here have been much interested in recent events across the Channel. The opening of the French exposition of paintings in London is meeting with great response here, and, it is rumored, will be reproduced in Paris after the closing of Burlington House in March.

When the new Congress met in December, there were the usual expressions of fear that it would only make the depression worse. A tradition, or superatition, has grown up that Congress in session is always bad for business. Doubtless there has often been only too much warrant for this feeling.

PARIS, Jan. 2. THE disappearance of Jean Giraudoux's "Judith" from the Theatre Pigalle, after a relatively small number of performances, was perhaps to be expected; for even in Paris there can hardly be a public large enough to insure a long run in a big house for such an artistically ambitious and intellectually subtle piece of work.

Passing and shooting with bewildering rapidity and accuracy on the attack, and holding the Jaspers so tightly in check on the defense that the Green had to do most of its shooting from a distance. City College had little difficulty downing Manhattan College, 31 -- 20, for its ninth basketball victory of the season last night at the 102d Engineers Armory.

HERE is at once the most informative and the most gripping account of lighter-than-air progress and promse that has been offered in book form. Commander Rosendahi, fitted by experience and unique opportunities in this branch of the naval air service to understand its full background, tells simply and forcefully the history of the rigid airship in America.

Lord Mayor's Uncanny House. GHOSTLY sounds and dins in the Mansion House of London were mentioned by Lord Mayor Jenks when apologizing for the absence of his wife at a ceremonious distribution of regimental shooting prizes. She had had a disturbed night.

CORNING, N.Y., Jan. 16 (AP) -- The gayety of a family party returning from a farm dance was turned abruptly into tragedy early today when their crowded automobile crashed into a fast Erie passenger train at Addison, fatally injuring a mother and father, two of their five children and another man and injuring the other Seven occupants.

SOON after midnight the last theatregoers have clattered down the steps of the Times Square subway station. A few revelers drift in and out. Newsboys flit across platforms, eagerly moving. The tide of life which has flowed there all day long is ebbing, leaving exposed the bare and ugly outlines of this human conduit.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 11. -- The coffee harvest is at its height and, as this commodity is the chief export of Costa Rica, the quantity produced and the price it brings are of the greatest importance to the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Secretary Stimson has decided to consider placing before the Senate Finance Committee official correspondence of the State Department relating to loans to Colombia and the granting of the Barco oil concession to the Mellon-Morgan interests.

Comparative steadiness of foreign loans in the face of irregularly lower prices of bonds of domestic corporations and the United States Government featured dealings on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The losses in the two last named groups did not amount to much and trading slowed down considerably on the decline.

THE radio industry is beginning its 1932 campaign. The manufacturers look to this year as one that will start them on the upward climb to a new prosperity. They point to the fact that politics on the air have always stimulated the sale of radio sets, tubes and associated apparatus.

Fourty-four members of the class of '82 of Columbia University, of which Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler was a member, will attend the Butler Day dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday evening1, Feb. 11, which will celebrate Dr. Butler's thirtieth anniversary as president of Columbia University, his fiftieth as a Columbia graduate, and the seventieth of his birth, it was announced yesterday by the Columbia Alumni Federation.

The report in the news columns that the Neediest Cases Fund has reached a total beyond that which seemed probable two weeks ago is most gratifying. While it is still short of the goal which was set by The contributions of 1928, 1929 and 1930, it has exceeded that of 1927 and in purchasing values has doubtless passed beyond that of any previous year.
ATLANTA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Under the leadership of its bachelor Executive of 34 the State of Georgia has adopted the pay-as-you-go plan for its annual business of $32,000,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16. -- Dr. John Huffman of Elizabeth, N.J., holder of the national championship. failed to place in the first half dozen in the Olympic saber trials held at the Penn A. C. today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- A militant program to keep adherence to the League of Nations an active issue before the country until the United States joins was adopted by the League of Nations Association at its closing session today. Speakers declared that, after a lapse of ten years, the League was hack as an issue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Notes from Japan and China in which they restated their positions on Manchuria came to the State Department today and brought forth the information that the United States would simply stand on the declaration it made Jan. 7.

Under the present bankruptcy law virtually every bankrupt gets his discharge "for the asking," as Solicitor General THACHER puts it. In the last fiscal year but one there were no assets above exemptions in two-thirds of the cases. In The Yale Law Journal Professor DOUGLAS reports the results of a study of some 1,500 bankrupts, urban and rural, in Boston and New Jersey.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16 -- While more than 55,000 men and women, some in furs, others in tattered clothing, cheered, Father James R. Cox predicted the formation of a new political party of the jobless and disclosed himself as a possible candidate for the Presidency this afternoon at a great unemployment demonstration at Pitt Stadium.
WHAT in the world has the League of Nations to do with poetry?" so writes to me an eminent American poet. "For Heaven's sake, let the League keep to its own business!"

BERLIN, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Chancellor Bruening took a hand in the bankers' conference which has been considering Germany's short-term credits for several weeks and gave them an outline of his view of the country's financial condition.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 12. -- Confusion regarding restrictions on exchange and the possibility of an issue of paper money may be the cause of a drop in the value of the colon, the monetary unit of Costa Rica, which has been stabilized at 25 cents in American gold for many years as the result of the operation of the so-called "caja de conversion," an exchange deposit.

Dr. HUMASON'S discovery that two nebulae in outer space are rushing away from us at the prodigious velocity of 15,000 miles a second cannot but strengthen the case of LEMAITRE and DE SITTER, Who hold that the universe is something like a huge expanding soap-bubble. Of the hundreds of nebulae far beyond the Milky Way not one is apparently approaching us.
Sixty Democratic Victory Dinners were held throughout the nation on Thursday, so that whatever happens next November we Democrats will have made sure of a good meal anyhow.

Contending that the inhabitants of Germany have gradually lost confidence in the durability of their present economic system and have resorted in some instances to the exportation of capital in a way that defies effective control, the Union for German Science has Issued in English the conclusions of a detailed study blaming high interest rates largely for the plight of German Industry, transportation and agriculture.

IN this book M. Ozenfant is more concerned with the essence of art in general than with merely tracing the sources of "modern art" to the various romantic movements germinated by the rebellious forces of 1789. In more ways than the title indicates he has written a brilliant, provocative, and, at times, illuminating dissertation on the essence and functions, not only of "modern art," but of all art: poetry, music, painting, sculpture and architecture.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 -- Last year at this time the Legislatures of all six New England States were in session, and the six New England Governors had read before them their several reviews of conditions and had offered their respective recommendations.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. TO those cynics who believe that economy in Hollywood will forever remain purely conversational, proof of error came this week. For the first time, perhaps, economy is being taken seriously.

SCHENECTADY, Jan. 16 -- "Bullets of sound" which bound back to the boat from which they are sent and warn the pilot of fog-screened obstacles in his path have been used in an acoustical navigating device announced here today by Chester W. Rice, an engineer of the General Electric Company.

WHATEVER else may be said of it, and plenty could be said, last week may go down as one of the greatest displays of self-abnegation in recent history. It was not a week of fasting and prayer, but it was unquestionably a week of resignation.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 16. -- In their fight against the erection of high-tension cable lines on eighty-foot towers through the country, the people of Westchester apparently are united. No one here has yet voiced approval of the proposed plans of the Niagara Hudson Power Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Publication in THE TIMES of a letter suggesting that now is a good, time to introduce rugby football into collegiata circles brings some slight flutter of response from the Pacific Coast.

OTTAWA, Jan. 13 -- The death of Sir George Foster, full of years and honors, after a half century given to the public life of Canada, has served to remind the public that the little band of titled Canadians is diminishing as the years go on. Meeting the wishes of the Dominion Parliament, the King has conferred no titles on Canadians in the past thirteen years.

THE theatre being a strange sort of race track, on which sentiment, contracts and the instinct for travel are all pretty much tangled up with each other, Diana Wynyard was a 1-to-10 shot to arrive in Now York, 7-to-10 to piace in the cast of "The Devil Passes" and at least 1-to-1 to show well in Mr. Levy's movality play at the Selwyn.

The recent advance in public utility securities, especially bonds and preferred stocks, is expected to result in early resumption of operations for refunding and new financing through investment bankers throughout the country. Some minor issues have been announced for early offering, and it is indicated that large issues are being studied by bankers for flotation within two or three weeks and later.

WEATHER conditions were highly unfavorable to retail trade for most of the week in this section and volume slumped materially. The stores did a fair business on various home furnishings, which are featured in sales at this time, but seasonal offerings of cold-weather apparel received little response.

IN tracing the growth of rackets from their intergang phases to their present national scope, Mr. Pasley reports that New York is the most heavily infested of all American cities with this particular form of criminal enterprise. He admits that Chicago was the cradle of the racket, but maintains that New York has far outstripped all competitors and has developed a form of extortion which is better organized and which produces less bloodshed.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Cabinet's prohibition repeal bill, which would set up a government-controlled source of liquor supply without private profit, was made public today preparatory to presentation at a special session of the Diet Tuesday.
WE are in the midst of a grave emergency. It is essential to raise additional revenue, not just to cover current expenditures but to maintain unimpaired the credit of the United States Government.

Rene pugnet, accomplished master of the French liner Paris, has many diversions which render less dull perpetual traveling on the same ocean route. Beneath the technical knowledge and stability his profession requires, Captain Pugnet is an artist and romanticist. He was a flier of distinction in France and during the war was ship captain and airplane pilot.

OTTAWA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Peter H. Bryce, former chief medical officer of the Federal Department of Health and First Canadian to be elected president of the American Public Health Association, died yesterday at sea while on the way to the West Indies. He was 78 years old.

SEVERAL debutantes, under the direction of Miss Mary Austin Phipps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Phipps, will sell flowers and cigarettes at the performance of "Berlin" on Wednesday night at the George M. Cohan Theatre, which has been taken over by the members of the Women's Auxiliary of Union Settlement in aid of that organization.

A shipment of $4,625,000 gold from Argentina was received yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The metal was sent by the Banco de la Nacion and arrived on the Northern Prince, $2,000,OOO being consigned to the Guaranty Trust Company.

A scroll of honor as "Thomas Jefferson Guest at Monticello" was presented yesterday to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd by the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation in recognition of the explorer's "inspirational and heroic service to his country" and of his leadership in the fields of science and discovery.

MID-SEASON at the opera will be reached with next Saturday's first "Barber," in addition to tomorrow's "Peter Ibbetson." The Metropolitan's twelfth week brings back both Edward Johnson and Siegfried Tappolet.

More than 38,000 members of the city educational system, concerned over the possibility that their salaries might be reduced or their salary increases withheld, have been asked to contribute fifty cents each to a fund started by their joint salary committee for the protection of their present salaries and this year's statutory increases, the latter amounting to $1,438,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- American foreign trade for 1931, in both exports and imports, fell $2,389,799,000 below that of 1930. Exports for 1931 were valued at $2,424,183,000 against 1930 shipments valued at $3,843,181,000, while imports in 1931 aggregated $2,090,107,000 compared with $3,060,908,000 in 1930.

CHORAL music sung by the choirs and glee clubs of seven women's colleges will be broadcast in a series of seven Monday programs scheduled to begin Feb. 1 at 3:45 P.M., over WABC and affiliated stations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The fall of the pound and, even more important, the duties just imposed on many necessary imports into England, are having very serious effects on European finance. Already two countries have ceased payments and a third is about to follow suit.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- As the author of "The Economic Consequences of the Peace" which first drew the attention of the public to the economic extravagance of the reparations clauses in the Versailles treaty, J.M. Keynes has been regarded as one of the leading authorities on the repartions question.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The results of prohibition were lauded tonight by speakers before the ennial convention of the Anti-Saloon League.

There is an unfortunate misconception about Verdi's "Il Trovatore," produced yesterday afternoon before an enormous audience in the Metropolitan Opera House. That is, that the opera being almost fool-proof, and certain, by virtue of Verdi's melodic genius, to fascinate an audience, it is not necessary to bestow on it the superior pains or the superior talents devoted to other works of the lyric repertory.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 16. -- The Brown swimming teams, varsity and freshman, both won from Massachusetts Institute of Technology teams today. The varsity won, 56 to 21, and the freshmen, 39 to 23.

MOSCOW, Jan. 16 --Foreign diplomatic circles here are considerably enlivened over a Tass News Agency dispatch, published today, to the effect that Soviet Ambassador Troyanovsky in Tokyo had "made representations" on Jan. 12 to Premier Inukai of Japan about North Manchurian developments.

AIKEN -- Winter residents and visitors in Aiken are entertaining themselves at the present mainly in the field of hunting. Doves are plentiful in the surrounding countryside, and each day finds several parties repairing to near-by dove fields for a few hours of sport.

IN this third volume from the pen of Dr. Aveling, university reader in psychology in the University of London, the serious student of psychology is given a thoroughly up-to-date treatise on certain problems of life and mind, soul and body, freedom and determinism, personality and character.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Unceasing devotion to Benito Mussolini and a "heartfelt wish for his noble, fervid and disinterested labor," is expressed in the last "spiritual testament" of the late Arnaldo Mussolini, brother of the Italian Premier, a copy of which was received here today.

HARBIN, Jan. 16 -- Harbin remains under rigorous martial law following the fighting between White Russians and Chinese police Jan. 3 and 4. The streets are patroled night and day by police in squads of four to six men each, equipped with brand-new rifles which are authoritatively said to have come from Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang's great arsenal at Mukden, which was seized by the Japanese.

Small lots of bonds of several municipalities were added last week to the list of bonds called for redemption this month before their maturity dates and increased the total for January to $70,486,000, compared with $22,002,500 in December and $57,899,000 in January, 1931.

IN both England and Prance candles often are used as a means of measuring time at auctions. Only recently a piece of land was rented "by candle" at Aldermaston, in the English county of Berkshire. This plot, known as Church Acre, is rented for the profit of the Church of England every three years.

WHEN such a harrowing play as "Never No More" appears on, the stage the stricken theatregoer instinctively inquires "What good can it do?" Having been tortured almost beyond endurance by the horrors of a Southern lynching, a theatregoer casts about blindly for some sort of mental or emotional balm, and it soothes him to conclude that exhibitions of painful truths accomplish no good.

Jamaica High School's hockey team, defending city P. S. A. L. champion, will have a chance to win the title for the sixth time in seven seasons when it meets the Manual Training High sextet in one of the two final games of the tourney scheduled for Friday night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

If the reader has not yet seen the exhibition of pastels and gouaches by Edgar Degas and Camille Piesarro at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, there is still time. The exhibition does not close until Jan. 25. And it should on no account be missed, for there are some of the finest pastels by Degas shown in this city in a long while.

To the Editor of The New York Times: ITRUST you will allow me to make a few supplementary (and I promise you final) statements to my letter of Jan. 3 on the discussion of Mr. Kootz's article, "America iiber Alles."

THE Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which Congress has just been discussing, is the keystone in President Hoover's program for economic recovery -- those proposals made, as he expressed it, "to check the further degeneration in prices and values, to fortify us against continued shocks from world instability and to unshackle the forces of recovery."

An unusual collection of air mail stamps will be exhibited to the members of the Collectors' Club at 30 East Forty-second Street next Wednesday evening. The stamps will be shown by John Aspinwall of Newburgh who is credited with having one of the most complete and valuable collections of air mail stamps in the world.

ANDOVER, Mass., Jan. 16 -- Yale freshmen broke two pool records in their 46-to-29 victory over Andover swimmers today. The relay team set a mark of 1 minute 41 1-5 seconds and Livingston swam the 100-yard free style in 56 1-5 seconds, clipping three-fifths of a second off the mark made by Munday of Yale last year.

INTO special prominence Came two museums last week. The new building of the Museum of the City of New York opened with an animation described as resembling "a mild form of subway crush"; also as recalling "the aisles of a department store during the week before Christmas."

Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink will make an appearance with the Metropolitan Opera Company this season after an absence of two years. General Manager Giulio Gatti-Casazza announced yesterday that she would appear as Erda in Wagner's "Das Rheingold," at a matinee performance on Feb. 26, taking the place of Doris Doe, American contralto.

LONDON THE great exhibitions of Flemish, Dutch and Italian art that have been held in the London Royal Academy in recent years are followed this year by an exhibition of French art that is equally comprehensive and imposing.

MOST people visited New York's thirty-second National Automobile Show at the Grand Central Palace last week with the idea of buying automobiles. Most people in this country have to have some form of automobile to exist, certainly to get results.

It is theoretically possible to construct skyscrapers 7,000 feet high, but economic considerations, such as space for elevator shafts, will keep skyscrapers "dawn" to their present height, Raymond M. Hood, one of the architects on the Radio City development, declared last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

THE scientific study of the music of our Indian tribes through phonograph recording has long been in progress; texts of the words, too, have been taken down phonetically. But this book, by Miss Bessie and Miss May Evans of the Peabody Conservatory of Music, is the first scientific analysis of the Indian dance steps.

DETROIT, Jan. 16 -- Secretary of Agriculture Arthur N. Hyde, speaking here tonight over a nation-wide network of the Columbia Broadcasting System, told Democrats who are making "political thunder" from the economic and international problems arising from war debts "to remember that it was Woodrow Wilson, William G. McAdoo and Carter Glass, and not Herbert Hoover, who made those loans after the war had closed and without a legal right to do so."

With more than 150 manufacturers represented by 200 exhibits, the twenty-seventh annual National Motor Boat Show will open at the Grand Central Palace next Friday evening, beginning at 7 o'clock, and continuing through Saturday of the following week.

PAWLING, N. Y., Jan. 16. -- Holding its opponents to a single point in the second half, Trinity School's quintet tonight defeated the Pawling School five, 25 to 12. The losers had an 11-7 lead at half time but Trinity came on to win. Hugh Riddleberger, Trinity's left forward, was high scorer with 4 field and 5 foul goals for 13 points.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Army swimmers won from Fordham today, 41 to 30. The events were closely contested, but Army won five first places of the eight events contested.

THE international struggle for the markets of South America is bringing about a concerted effort on the part of the largest airline groups of Europe to form a united front against the aggressive American airlines. These now operate on frequent schedules between cities of the United States and Buenos Aires.

WHILE there may be occasional inaccuracies in her books and while her characters frankly talk the speech of today, Eloise Lownsbery has the gift of making the past genuinely alive. We follow the adventures of her characters with interest, and the way in which she fills in her background is a real contribution toward giving young people an understanding of a historical period.

HERALD KREUTZBERG upset several cherished traditions of the dance world by his performances last week at the Cort Theatre. For one thing, he exploded the theory that all dancers from Germany -- or at least from the German schools, for Mr. Kreutzberg is said to be Viennese -- are solemn and heavy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Certain, present-day historians engaged in the merry process of "debunking" some of our American idols who belong to the ages are not infrequently led into strange bypaths, not to speak of "dramatics." In an article anout Washington in a current issue of a magazine I find the following paragraph:

A BUCKLE which is not really a buckle at all is one of the newest jewel fashions in Paris. It serves the purpose of a buckle but is tied in place rather than pinned, thus saving lots of wear and tear on your favorite gown.

Inquiry by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad for prices on 4,000 tons of 130-pound rail served yesterday to accentuate the present dearth of orders of this kind from railroads. Only about six companies have placed orders for rails to be used this year.

Swimmers of Evander Childs High School gained the scoring honors in the Columbia University annual interscholastic water carnival in the 73-foot Morningside Heights pool yesterday. They ran up a total of 15 points; as against 11 points earned by the contenders of George Washing High School, next in line.

The moderate declines on the Stock Exchange yesterday were again ascribed to week-end realizing. The speculative element took little interest in the day's proceedings; the small volume of business showed that plainly. The theory of many "tape watchers" was that the apparent assurance that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is to be set up shortly had induced profittaking by traders who had purchased stocks for the impetus which that development promised.

At the end of June, 1776, two events of considerable importance in American history were taking place. One was the debate in the Continental Congress which led early in July to the Declaration of Independence. The other was the founding of San Francisco.

FREEPORT, L.I., Jan. 18 -- Patrick J. Conway, a founder and formerly for twenty-seven years president of the Irish-American Athletic Association, in whose colors some of the greatest American track and field stars have performed, died here tonight at 94 Lillian Avenue, the home of a daughter, Mrs. Josephine V. Healey.

WHEN the ship of state strikes a typhoon, all eyes are directed to the captain issuing his orders from the bridge. In India, at this moment, destiny depends on the office of Viceroy and Governor General; and that office is held by Lord Willingdon.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Streets and byways of Rochester, whether by luck or design, have upheld for another year their reputation of being the safest in the United States, according to 1931 statistics being compiled by the Police Department's record bureau.

NEW YORK'S financial problem was brought emphatically to public attention last week with the announcement that conferences were proceeding between administration officials and bankers with a view to arranging a $140,000,000 loan to tide the metropolis over its present stringency.

AS the time approaches when Annie Russell will make her return to the theatre on a college stage in Florida, rumors creep north from Winter Park of an enthusiasm warmer than any which that section of the land has known since the old -- or citrus fruit and real estate boom -- era.

FROM their safe refuge across the Rhine the emigres of the French Revolution raged at the French Republic and worked for its overthrow. Some thing like that is going on today among the Spaniards. Revolution has sent the King into exile and along with him a host of royalists "plus royalistes que le roi."

The Holy Trinity hockey team upset advance expectations by holding Le Salle Military Academy to a scoreless tie last night in the fourth annual Catholic High School Athletic Association hockey tournament, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

OXYGEN-CHAMBERS are used in treating pneumonia, heart diseases and afflictions of the breathing organs. The first chamber was introduced by Dr. Haldane in England in 1918. Such was its success that others were soon installed in the University of Cambridge, Guys Hospital, London, the Rockefeller Institute and the Presbyterian Hospital, New York, and the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, to mention but a few of the more important medical institutions.
MONTREAL, Jan. 16 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadians came from behind tonight to gain a 2-2 tie with the crippled Boston Bruins in a ragged and often dull National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON. WHEN Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes handed in his resignation from the Supreme Court bench to President Hoover, last Monday, he brought to a close one of the most outstanding judicial careers in the history of American law and removed from public life one of its saltiest and most beloved personalties.

Wall Street believes that the attempt to check the deflation by means of central-bank operations in the money market, which were abandoned by the Federal Reserve authorities last October in the face of unprecedented European demands upon this Country for gold and a wave of domestic hoarding, is to be resumed.

LAKE PLACID -- All Winter sports enthusiasts will turn out this week to see the demonstration of "ski-gliding." This sport, recently introduced in Norway, will make its debut in Lake Placid on Wednesday, when Halvor Garos and Theodore Sikorsky, who created this idea and tried it out successfully in Europe, will exhibit this thrilling recreation.

The Savage School of Physical Education, girls basketball team, which has not met with a reverse in two years, increased its string of consecutive triumphs to twenty, six of which were accounted for this season, by routing Hunter College, 33 -- 20, on the Savage court yesterday.

BETH MERRILL, who was under the management of the late David Belasco for ever and ever so long, may soon emerge from a protracted spell of inactivity to appear in a play from the German, at present called "The Sickness of Youth," a literal translation of the title.

PROFESSOR MASON, as one of the elder line of living American composers, has the interests of the American composer at heart and is concerned about him. The American composer is not duly recognized in the offerings of the conductors of our orchestras.

The passage of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation bill by both houses of Congress and the conciliatory attitude with which the delegates to the railroad labor conference in Chicago finally met, together with the fact that the Federal Reserve System appears to have embarked on a policy to halt deflation, all served to create a better feeling in the financial community last week.

AMONG horticulturists everywhere, and especially those of England and the United States, the name of "Chinese" Wilson is held in high regard and admiration. He himself liked the sobriquet which linked him with the country where he spent so much time, enjoyed so many hardships and found such large numbers of the flowers, shrubs and trees whose introduction to Western gardens brought him fame.

THE special matinee cycle of Wagnerian music-dramas at the Metropolitan Opera House will begin this year with a performance of "Tannhauser" on Friday afternoon, Feb. 12. "Tristan und Isolde" will be sung on Thursday of the following week, and on succeeding Thursdays and Fridays the four operas of "Der Ring des Nibelungen" will be presented.

Municipal bankers have been and are being besieged by State and municipal officials from all sections of the country, who demand to know why their communities, with generations of history of prompt payments of their obligations behind them, cannot borrow money readily for their legitimate needs.
SUPPOSE that in a certain country one of its most distinguished and popular citizens, being of marriageable age, took to himself a bride and sought the seclusion of the North Woods for his honeymoon;

A program which will mobilize parents of school children, 35,000 teachers and principals, social agencies and the new Bureau of Child Guidance of the Board of Education for the correction of cases of maladjustment, academic backwardness and nervousness among public school pupils will be begun at the opening of the Spring term next month.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- For the first time in many months the Paris Bourse today ended a week on an upward note, continuing the firm tendency of the preceding few days. When the session opened there was a considerable amount of profit-taking, with a consequent fall in prices.

The committee of New York bankers in charge of working out a "standstill" agreement between the American creditor banks and the Hungarian debtor banks has abandoned further efforts along this line because the Hungarian banks have notified them that they would not have sufficient exchange to pay the interest and commissions on the short-term debts due American bankers.

BERLIN. WHILE the Nationalist Socialist movement has not yet taken over the political power in Germany, it has very nearly captured the universities. Among the students the tide of nationalism is rising rapidly, and the elections to the student councils this Winter show that the Nazis are by far the strongest political party, if not actually in a majority.
Victorious for the past eight years, Cambridge University already has started work for its annual classic with Oxford, which this year will be held on March 19.

LIKE a fresh breeze from the prairie, like a bolt from the blue, like a flower needs the sunshine, Hubert J. Metuchen, Los Angeles wag and critic temporarily without a vehicle, arrived in these Eastern parts a few days ago.

EIGHTEENTH-CENTURY furniture of distinctly English design, of types little known in the American Colonies, is proving increasingly popular with room decorators. The pieces are characterized by emphasis on carved ornamentation, the use of upholstery in old needlework or damask, and occasionally by shapes that show strong French influence.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16. -- Governor Roosevelt of New York and Governor Pinchot of Pennsylvania, the former a Democratic candidate for President and the latter spoken of as a possible Republican opponent for President Hoover, were closeted for more than an hour in Mr. Roosevelt's suite at a hotel here today prior to the wedding of the New York Governor's son, Elliott, to Miss Elizabeth Browning Donner, at Bryn Mawr.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- optimistic predictions for national advertising this year, especially with regard to the automobile industry, were made toy W.A. Thompson, manager of the advertising bureau of the American Newspaper Publishers' association, in an address before the New York State Publishers' Association here today.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 16 -- Kenneth Byard, 19 years old, proprietor of a boarding kennel at Oceanport, near here, died early today in the Hazard Hospital in Long Branch of a gun-shot wound he receired last night. Vincent Pulignano. 17 years old, of Long Branch, a friend of Byard, has been held without bail on a charge of manslaughter, although before he died Byard explained that the shooting was an accident.

GENOA. A PLAY recently performed in Paris, called, in the original Italian version, "Campo di Maggio," by Giovacchino Forzano, has just been published by Barbera of Florence. The French press (no doubt encouraged, for the purpose of publicity, by the management of the Theatre Ambigu) more or less insinuated that the real author of this drama in three acts is no less a personage than the Italian Prime Minister and leader of fascism himself.

THE symposium here presented by Edward H. Cotton, Unitarian clergyman, journalist, lecturer and author of half a dozen books, mostly of biographical character, contains contributions by sixteen famous scientists. Of these, nine articles were written especially for this volume.
The fund for the Hundred Neediest Cases of 1931 is now $292,908.26 -- $52.882.39 short of the 1930 fund, which reached a total of $345,790.66.

THE danger of generalizing about the characteristics of the "typical" American is obvious. A hundred and twenty million persons of all races, subjected for longer or shorter periods to such influences as the frontier, free land, almost unlimited opportunity, the comparative absence of social or caste barriers, unrestricted Immigration, and others, cannot be reduced to a single type.

SIGURD CHRISTIANSEN'S novel. "Two Living and One Dead." which was awarded the first prize of 10.000 kroner as the best novel submitted for the Inter-Scandinavian literary contest of 1931, has been transiated from the Norwegian by Edwin Bjorkman and will be published in March by Liveright, Inc.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 14 -- An Important new political factor has made its appearance in the embattied State of Minnesota, which has a Farmer-Labor Governor is normally Republican, and came near electing a Democratic United States Senator at the last election.

Although the world depression, new tariff walls and depreciated currencies have intensified the foreign trade problems of the United States in the last year, there is no basis for the view that this country is destined to lose permanently a large part of its export business, according to Philip D. Wagoner, president of the underwood Elliott Fisher Company.

MANILA, Dec. 18. -- E. D. Hester, American trade commissioner and technical adviser to the office of the Governor General, has returned to Manila from an extensive survey of the provinces of Cagayan and Isabela. He reports that phenomenal progress has been made in that district, and that it holds out the eventual hope of the solution of the problem of Filipino emigration.

HAVANA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The riding of Jockey Johnny Gilbert featured a card, of seven claiming events at Oriental Park today. Gilbert scored with three of his mounts and placed third with another as George Collins's Justina, a 5-year-old mare from Lexington, Ky., captured the six-furlong feature.

HONOLULU, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The preliminary hearing of Mrs. Granville R. Fortescue; her son-in-law, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, U.S.N., and two navy enlisted men, charged with the murder of Joseph Kahahawai, suspected attacker of Mrs. Massie, was continued today in police court until Jan. 23 on motion of the prosecution.
BOSTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Boston's latest gang shooting was solved and a long search by New York police ended today in the accident ward of the Massachusetts General Hospital.

To the Editor of The New York Times: AFTER reading "America iiber Alles" and the various replies following, I feel moved to have my say from a greater distance. While New York is raging pro and con over the Rivera show, I am in Mexico City looking at the fine frescoes by Rivera, Orozco and others not known to our Parisians.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 16 -- Probably the finest of the many brilliant polo trios that have represented Yale University broke the year and a half winning streak of the First Cleveland Cavalry team tonight with a brilliant 16-to-11 1/2 victory.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Bronx Tigers continued to exercise superiority over the Springfield Indians by taking a 5 -- 2 decision tonight. The victory marked the fourth the New Yorkers have registered over the defending Canadian-American Hockey League champions.

A drastic reform in real esate procedure in New Jersey is suggested by Harry Jay Greenwald, vice president of Allied Realty Associates, and he urges that it be brought to the attention of the State Legislature. It is directed against the reckless development of land.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Columbia won its first Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight, defeating Cornell in a free-scoring game, 49 -- 36. The Lions took the lead on a field goal by Hartman and held it without a serious threat until the final whistle. The defeat was Cornell's second in the league campaign.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan, 2, 1932. SIMULTANEOUSLY with the return some weeks ago to native direction, the Teatro Colon reverted to the speculative type of production which has been the rule rather than the exception at our of a house for various seasons past.

WITH the interest in the approaching Lothian sale of valuable manuscripts, incunabula and Americana running high, it may be timely to call attention to an important contribution to the study of these subjects by an American scholar.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Army fencers, in their first match of the season, won from the swordsmen of the New York Athletic Club today in a three-weapon engagement with foils, sabers and swords, by a score of 20 to 14.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For several months last Winter New York City's lovers of good music were given a rare treat and at the same time contributed materially toward relief for the unemployed through the series of Sunday morning symphony concerts given at the Roxy Theatre by the large orchestra composed of unemployed musicians.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A Japanese infantry brigade marched westward from Chinchow today to even the score with Chinese irregular troops who fell upon a small detachment of Japanese cavalrymen last week, killing twenty of them.

IN the long struggle between North and South which culminated in the Civil War there was a kind of Northerner to which history has paid scant attention. This sort of Northerner was at first unkindly described in his own section as a "Northern man with Southern principles," which was accurate enough but too long an epithet to be handy.
Belle Keeler sold the two four-story brick flats on a plot 51 by 112 feet at 683-685 Ocean Avenue, north-east corner of Kearny Avenue, Jersey City, to Joe and Jenny Kerr.
Three interesting and exciting polo games were played at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn, last night, the maximum margin of victory being only one goal and the minimum one-half goal.

MONTREAL -- Indoor sports events are the principal attractions on the Montreal program for this week. The annual Canadian covered court tennis championships will be contested on the courts of the Montreal Indoor Tennis Club, commencing on Tuesday, the finals to be played on Saturday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 16 -- Princeton Preparatory School's basketball team opened its season here this afternoon by defeating the school alumni five by a score of 38 to 25. Coach McCabe of Prep, former court star at Princeton University, entered the game for the alumni in the second period, scoring two field goals.

The tortuous development of the repaations question from its genesis on the fateful day of the signing of the Versailles treaty up to the present crisis, presents itself to the mind of Germany and the Germans as the reaction of a sequence of vicious circles, each of which begins and ends with and as a catastrophe.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 16 -- Harvard varsity and freshman squash racquets teams won three matches and lost a like number in the State League competition today.

GENEVA, Jan. 16 -- The League of Nations finance and economic committees, now meeting here separately, will together, tackle the world's ills Monday night in the first joint meeting they have held in years. They have been led to this especially by the difficulties met in trying separately to handle reconstruction problems.

Following the break in the midwinter warm spell, with a fall in temperature yesterday and the promise of snow for today, the Weather Bureau predicts another period of "fair and warmer" beginning tomorrow.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 13. -- Australia has begun the New Year with confidence. No magical return to prosperity is expected, but the Common-wealth cannot but profit from the resolute measures already taken to meet the depression and from the restoration of stable government at Canberra.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 16 -- With three of the four contestants New Yorkers, an Empire State final developed today in the annual Miami-Biltmore invitation tournament, over the course of the Miami-Biltmore Country Club.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 -- Russia's proposal for a non-aggression pact will be answered after the Japanese Government has studied it thoroughly. Japanese officialdom has a temporary complex against general agreements dealing with hypothetical futures and has no opinions to express for publication on this proposal.

Business failures in 1931 numbered 26,381, compared with 24,107 in 1930, according to statistics compiled by Bradstreet's. This was the largest number for any year since the records were begun. The liabilities involved were $2,280,829,316, compared with $1,441,439,445 in 1930 and $628,047,146 in 1929.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and "dean" of railway presidents, appealed today to the leaders of the twenty-one standard railroad unions, acting for 1,500,000 men, to endorse the "blank check" which the labor chieftains had received from their men.

HAVANA, Jan. 11. -- The experiment in relief work among the unemployed being tried out by the Cuban Government which is establishing concentration camps to take care of the jobless and homeless, where they not only receive food and lodging but free medical attention, is proving a success according to Dr. Octavio Zubizarreta, Secretary of Interior, who invited newspaper men to inspect the old Purisima market, Havana's point of concentration for indigents.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 16 -- The individual brilliance of Dartmouth's sophomore basketball star, Jake Edwards, enabled the Green, to trounce Princeton tonight, 31-13, and move into undisputed first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Harry Wallace, 60 years old, who was killed early Friday by an automobile operated by Walter J. Smith, "youngest son. of former Governor Smith, was identified yesterday at the Bellevue Morgue by one of his four adult eons as a former department store buyer who had lived in a rooming house at 128 East 128th Street, and not at 319 Bowery, the address given out by the police, where the Holy Name Mission is located.

A SPECIAL performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor," with Mme. Lily Pons, Martineill and De Luca in the leading roles, will take place on the afternoon of Feb. 5 at the Metropolitan Opera House in aid of the scholarship fund of the Vassar Club of New York.

The seventy-nine stations of the Home Relief Bureau, operating under the city Department of Public Welfare, will be reopened tomorrow morning, it was announced yesterday by Frans J. Taylor, Welfare Commissioner.

What magic can the talking film perform in the classroom! The Harvard Graduate School of Education is now beginning an experiment to answer the question, aided by a grant from the Carnegie Foundation, and the Board of Education of New Yorke City has lately indicated its intention to consider the problem.

The bill before the Legislature to create a banking board or commission to supervise the financial institutions of the State was attacked as "one of the most dangerous and unsound legislative proposals that have ever been advanced" in an address last night by George L. Bliss, president of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

CAIRO, Jan. 16. -- Will Rogers paid a "flying visit" to Cairo, arriving yesterday afternoon by plane from Singapore and taking off again at dawn this morning en route to Paris, where he will meet his wife. That will end more than 9,000 miles of a flying trip completed within ten days ] which began at Singapore.

A full page of pictures in our rotogravure section today is concerned with the Soviet automobile plant at Nizhni-Novgorod, recenty completed at a cost of nearly $150,000,000, and designed to produce 150,000 cal's a year. The most vivid effect is conveyed not by the pictures of plant and equipment, but of the peasant recruits who are being trained to operate the machines.
VANDALJA. Ohio, Jan. 16. -- High average trapshooting honors for the United States, Canada and the Canal Zone go to Fred Harlow of Newark, Ohio, according to official averages for 1931.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 16 -- Marking the opening of the Embassy Club on Royal Palm Way tonight was a dinner dance attended by a large and brilliant gathering of colonists. Yellow roses with delphinium and African daisies adorned the tables and the dance patio was overhung with blue and yellow lights.

MAMARONECK. N.Y., Jan. 16. -- C.L. Smith, W.H. Mills and C.M. Mitchell each carded 46 to tie for the High Scratch Cup at the Country Club Beach traps today. In the shoot-off Smith broke 25 straight to triumph. Mills had 22, Mitchell 21.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The question, of the desirability of reverting to a bi-metallic monetary basis is now so much in the public mind that the following notes may be considered to be of some interest:

GOETA LJUNGBERG, Swedish dramatic soprano, and Armando Borgioli, Italian baritone, will make their debuts in this country this week with the Metropolitan Opera Company. Miss Ljungberg will appear on Wednesday as Sieglinde and Mr. Borgioli will sing Don Carlo in Verdi's "Forza del Destino," on Friday.

VIENNA, Jan. 1 THE Vienna theatrical season of 1931-32, though it baa hitched its wagon to the dark star of economy, as regards both, the private and the State-supported stages, still has not disproved the maxim that the public will nearly always go to see a really good thing.

Four paintings by famous artists, stolen eight days ago from the home of Floyd B. Odium at 101 Greenway North, Forest Hills, Queens, were recovered yesterday by the police, after four men and a woman had been arrested in connection with the theft.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Gettin Even, one of the most consistent of the older horses performing at the Jefferson Park track, led a smart field over one and one-six-teenth miles to win the $2,000 Louisiana Handicap today.

HAMILTON, N.J., Jan. 16. -- Two foul goal by Johnny Acropolis, Colgate forward, with less than a minute and a half to play gave Colgate an 18-to-17 victory over Syracuse tonight before an overflow crowd of 2,600.

THE question -- what is an American ? -- is not capable of categorical answer. We must first define the term more closely, racially, geographically, socially and even as to the age, sex and education of those to be considered, for there are wide differences in our "American" from all these points of view.

LAKELAND, Fla., Jan. 14 -- Because of the immensity of Florida's citrus industry, the 25 per cent reauction of railroad rates, which has just been approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission, is highly encouraging to growers and others who have been working for better marketing facilities and methods.

THIS new volume of the "Economic and Social History of the World War," edited by Professor James T. Shotwell, was written by an author who is eminently fitted by both theoretical knowledge and practical experience to treat of the subject with which he deals.
Clouds and Sunshine. THE Meteorological Observatory in Central Park reports that New York City in 1931 had much more sunshine and much less atmospheric pollution than usual, thanks to the depression.

WHEN Martin Beck came back recently to what must have been familiar surroundings on the sixth floor of the Palace Theatre building there was reported to be no small twitter in that hive of vaudeville's booking, exploitation, publicity and personnel offices.

SINCE the civic light opera has been occupying and more than often filling the Erlanger Theatre, there have been a number of inquiries as to recordings from its repertoire and from the whole field of comic opera. Outside of the Gilbert and Sullivan comedies, it has been difficult to discover anything worth recommending, for the simple reason that this particular type of music stands in an unfortunate position so far as records are concerned.

Butter. Receipts, 4,928 packages. The market closes with no change in price levels and the tone at the moment seemed steady, although the immediate outlook is still uncertain. Prospective receipts for Monday are expected to be heavy and there will undoubtedly be steady pressure to keep stocks moving.
