RECENT troublesome events in the Hawaiian Islands, which have come to a crisis in the pending trial for murder of four Americans and in demands by the Senate for an investigation of conditions there, have been complicated by the fact that the island population is an extremely mixed one.

THIS book is a notable service rendered by a citizen to the civic mind of his country. Professor Phelps Hall has revealed Gladstone as the great exemplar of public life, on a canvas no less dignified than Morley's presentation portrait but more manageable in its dimensions.

New light on the controversy over the use of grades and credits for rating students appears in the annual Inglis lecture delivered by Dr. William Setchel Learned, assistant secretary of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, under the auspices of the Graduate School of Education at Harvard University.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- President Hoover's advice to Premier Laval that Europe must settle its reparations differences before the entirely separate question of Europe's debts to the United States can be discussed again was the immediate reason behind the French Premier's invitation to Ambassador Walter E. Edge to come to visit him this morning.

A wide expansion, much of it unhealthy, will occur in the voluntary chain-grocery field in coming months, V.H. Pelz, director of research for the American Institute of Food Distribution, told THE TIMES here yesterday. The growth, he added, will be accompanied by a heavy death rate among new and existing chains which are poorly set up and indifferently managed.

NEW YORK. Harris Fahnestock and his daughter. Miss Faith Fahnestock, accompanied by Mrs. G.G.V. Hyde and Miss Patricia Coffin, will sail next Friday on the Conte Biancamano for Italy and Egypt. Later they will go to France.

UP to and including 1880." the United States Census Bureau declared in its report for 1890, "the country had a frontier of settlement, but at present the unsettled area has been so broken into by isolated bodies of settlement that there can hardly be said to be a frontier line.

Cardinal Hayes will sail on Jan. 22, on the Carinthia of the Cunard Line, for the Bahama Islands, to install the Very Rev. Bernard Kovenhoerster as Prefect-Apostolic of the islands, to which office the priest was recently raised by Pope Plus XI.

THE recent dedication of a memorial altar in the Chapel of St. Cornelius the Centurion on Governors Island to Edmund Banks Smith, former chaplain, marks another epoch in the history of the chapel and of this old military post.

Percy Grainger, American pianist by choice, and still retaining the quick step and refreshing breeze of open-air that first swept him into unique favor as a youth from the Antipodes, returned to the platform at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon in a recital marked, as always, by spontaneous enthusiasm on both sides of the footlights.

AS 1932 settles into its stride, the United States has reached one of those periods of stock-taking and soulsearching which have come at intervals in its history and which are a mingling of the intensely practical and the idealistic. At the same time, after more than three centuries of almost constant immigration, the flow into this country has ended and the mingling of the old races is having opportunity to form a new one.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. - George A. Armstrong, of New York City, third secretary of the embassy at Warsaw, has been promoted to be second secretary there. Other changes in the foreign service the past week were announced by the State Department today as follows:

Prices of stocks and bonds eased moderately in dull trading yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange, with a few issues going against the trend. The less active securities remained steady, on the whole, and the undertone was one of confidence despite profit-taking in the leaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The continued low level of business in many of the foreign markets of the United States was reflected in the weekly survey made by the Department of Commerce. The survey follows in part:

BELGRADE, Jan. 14 -- Tuesday's demonstrations of Zagreb University students and Bosnian and Dalmatian peasants are only the latest eruptions of smoldering dissatisfaction in Yugoslavia with the Dictatorship -- whether unadorned or disguised in its present pseudo-Parliamentary form -- under which the nation has been living for the last three years.

Fifty hoboes, invited guests of a "wealthy widow" who wanted to do something for the jobless, dined in style last night at the Arsenal Restaurant in Central Park. They stowed away helping after helping of roast beef or baked Virginia ham, mountainous quantities of vegetables and from two to five cups of coffee apiece.

That there is greater interest in the showing of dogs than in many years is evidenced by the number of entries received for the thirtieth annual exhibition of the Pekingese Club of America, which will inaugurate the 1932 Eastern season at the Hotel Roosevelt tomorrow.

LONDON. TO THE ordinary Englishman who does not travel abroad or worry about international finance, Great Britain's suspension of the gold standard has made little practical difference. There is no inflation, and internal prices have hardly changed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Further action in the Senate on the $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation measure, the largest single part of the administration's program for economic relief, was delayed today when Senator Blaine of Wisconsin objected to the motion of Senator Walcott of Connecticutt to substitute the House bill for the Senate bill and send it immediately to conference.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 16 -- Navy was given considerable opposition in its first swimming and water polo meet of the season today by C.C. N.T., but victories were scored 46 to 25 in the swimming and 55 to 17 in the water polo. Both were Intercollegiate Swimming Association events.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 16 -- The remains of ancient walls dating from 200 B.C. to 800 B.C., indicating that the Israelitish Kingdom of Samaria proceeded the Roman forum previously found in the same place, were among the discoveries of the excavation season just completed at Sebastia, Northern Palestine, near Nablus (ancient Shechem).

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I, as editor of Psychic Research, the journal of the American Society for Psychio Research, make a short rejoinder to the letter of Ranulph Kingsley appearing in THE TIMES ?

BUFFALO. Jan. 16. -- Colonel William A. Taylor, commander of the 369th Infantry of New York City, was elected and installed as president of the National Guard Association of New York State at the final session this morning of its convention.

GENEVA, Jan. 15 -- The League's annual survey of world commerce just issued for 1930 portrays statistically, in a mass of data on the first full year of depression, the decline of the United States and the rise of the Soviet Union.

AFTER months or effort that has entailed delving into old volumes for authentic historical data on old New York, the executive committee for the annual Beaux-Arts Ball is completing final preparations for this event, which will be held on Friday night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE executive of a radio network was once asked what he considered the remedy for excessive sales plugging on the air. He replied, "public opinion." And now with the increase in commercialism there is more and more talk among listeners that too much talk drives them away from their sets.

Announcement has just been made by the Metropolitan Museum of Art of the election of five new trustees to fill vacancies in the board caused by deaths. Although the election took place on Dec. 21, when a new president and vice president of the museum were chosen, announcement was deferred by the museum.

LONDON. CRISIS may follow crisis in international politics and finance, but the art world remains unperturbed. Our strained relations in these matters with our neighbors across the Channel nave not interfered with the holding of the exhibition of French art treasures just opened at the Royal Academy.

Fencing, a sport which has increased greatly in popularity during the last few years in public high and private school athletic circles in New York City and vicinity, is expected to attract more interest than ever before during this season.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The twenty-fifth annual target tournament of the Pinehurst Gun Club is one of the outstanding events on the sports program here for the coming week. This gathering of marksmen and women trap-shooters will have, it is believed, 150 entries competing for prizes totaling $2,000 in value.

The thirty-second National Automobile Show in Grand Central Palace closed last night. Shortly before the closing the management announced that attendance had been greater than at any time in the last five years. "including the record year of 1929."

FICKLE Parisiennes, already tired of Winter sports, are returning to Paris and preparing to finish out the season on the Riviera or in Northern Africa. Worth has anticipated their needs by designing four new costumes, which give some hint of his ideas for Spring.

EASTON, Pa., Jan. 15. -- The Lafayette College five sprang a surprise here tonight by defeating Bucknell by the score of 36-26. With the score deadlocked at 12-12 at halftime, the Maroon put on a spurt in the second half to score twenty-four more points.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 16 -- Harvard's varsity and freshman wrestling teams scored one-sided victories over their Spring-field rivals in the Harvard gymnasium today. The Crimson varsity won by 25 1/2 to 4 1/2, and the freshmen by 29 to 5.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, wife of the Philadelphia banker, tonight issued a statement concerning her recent cable to Mrs. Granville Fortescue, in Honolulu, saying she was satisfied to endure the notoriety aroused by her message if it would help her friend.

Stockholders of the Grlidden Company, paint and varnish manufacturer, will vote at their annual meeting on a plan for granting options for the sale of the company's shares to officers and employes and on the creation of a bonus fund to be available to the officers and employes for the purchase of the shares.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. l6. -- Palm trees did not sprout along the shores of Manhasset Bay today. As soon as the activities of the Frostbite Yacht Club were resumed this afternoon the thermometer came down off its unseasonable perch and the Winter dinghy sailors found their windbreakers, woolens and furs a necessary adjunct to their performances.

The coming city P. S. A. L. senior high school championship basketball tournament, which will get under way early next month and continue until late in March, should develop into one of the most evenly contested court tourneys in the league's history, judging from the performances of a number of the teams in games to date.

Basketball again is attracting its full share, of interest as an intramural activity at Wells College and all four or the class sextets have been practicing deligently since their return from the Christmas holidays for the campaign which is soon to open.

ALTHOUGH everything else is going down, the movement in fashion, perversely enough, is decidedly upward. Daytime hems, it is predicted, will be a little shorter; skirts are mounting to new high waistlines, and necklines are about as high as they can be So perhaps it is only logical for hats to climb closer to the top of the head than ever, and climlb they do.
BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Jan. 16 -- The Blair Academy swimming team defeated Allentown (Pa.) High School by the score of 48 to 27 today. Blair took seven first places to Allentown's one.

East side theatregoers packed the Folks Theatre at Second Avenue and Twelfth Street last Wednesday night and saw a drama, heard a concert and witnessed a "goldene chasseneh" or golden wedding, all for the price of one ticket.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 14 -- Of great interest to the Democratic party nationally, to observers of Newton D. Baker in particular, and of surprise akin to shock to political seers of this city, was the peculiar triumph of the Cleveland organized Democracy this week in nominating County Prosecutor Ray T. Miller for Mayor at a primary election looking to finals next month.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16. -- New York University obtained an even break in its engagements with local fives by defeating the Pittsburgh Panthers, 37 to 32, at the Pitt Pavilion tonight. The Violets lost to Carnegie last night.

PARIS, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Premier Pierre Laval informed American Ambassador Walter E. Edge today of France's desire to postpone the Lausanne reparations conference until the European views could be harmonized, it was learned in authentic quarters.

MANY well-known men and women are devoting much of their time and are sparing no efforts to make the forthcoming Century Ball on Jan. 29 a great success and thereby add a substantial sum to the treasury of the Leake and Watts Orphan House, which this year is celebrating its 100th anniversary.

The comparative unfamiliarity of the railroad industry with the railway labor act was brought into prominence by the delay in starting the current conference on wages and employment between the managements and labor in Chicago. Scheduled to start on Thursday, the meeting was postponed repeatedly at the requests of the management committee until Friday afternoon because of a tardy raising of certain points under the act.

Problems facing the trust business in the present unusual state of business and financial affairs will be the major subjects of discussion at the annual midwinter conference of the trust division of the American Bankers' Association, to be held in the Hotel Commodore on Feb. 16, 17 and 18.

Captain Sigurd N. Wessberg, 68 years of age, who sailed the seas for twenty-five years in every capacity from cook to captain, will make his first trip through the Panama Canal when he sails as a passenger Friday on the Standard Oil tanker Brilliant, leaving from Providence, R.I.

Since his murder at an early age, when he was the most influential figure in the government, his life has been a matter for dispute among historians and biographers.

The schedule for the first Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. dual meet swimming championship tournament, which will start on Sunday afternon, Feb. 7, at the Columbus Council K. of C. pool in Brooklyn, has been announced by George Bahlman of Brooklyn Prep.

TIENTSIN, China, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Reports from Shanhaikwan today said the Japanese Army had cut the Chinese-British-owned Peiping-Mukden Railway north of there, and announced the intention of taking completes charge of operating the line between Shanhaikwan and Mukden.

A peaceful army is being mobilized in every election district in this State to support "humane" candidates at coming elections, Mrs. Diana Belais, president of the New York Anti-Vivi-section Society, announced at a mass meeting of the organization at the Hotel Taft yesterday afternoon.

FOR its production of Vieki Baum's "Grand Hotel," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has selected a blue-ribbon cast to flutter around Greta Garbo, who will have the lead in the role of Grusinskaya, the dancer. John Barrymore will be seen as Baron von Geigen.

The movement started by New York City firemen for an eight-hour work day was endorsed yesterday by the American Federation of Labor. Assurance of the federation's support was conveyed by William Green, president of the federation, in an address last night at the fifteenth annual reception and ball of the Uniform Firemen's Association of Greater New York at Madison Square Garden.

A thirty-five-foot strand of hightension electric wire, emitting a vivid stream of blue sparks and twisting right and left, frightened hundreds of pedestrians and motorists in downtown Brooklyn yesterday at 4:45 P.M. after an overhead trolley wire on Court Street near Livingston Street had snapped.

The wholesale markets reflected increased activity during the week, and although, buying has been comparatively slow, the retailers in the market have shown confidence in the new lines, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

HAVANA -- Officials of the Havana and Miramar Yacht Clubs are busily engaged with details for the International championship regatta in the star class fleet to be held in February, and the Cuban championship golf tourney, also to be held next month, makes a second sports feature on the Winter colony's program.

DURING the comparative lull in purchase of planes which has marked the last twelvemonth there has been no lagging of interest in the advancement of design and performance. Just as in the automobile field a year of lessened production has been marked by the introduction of important mechanical advances, so in the field of airplane design distinct progress has been mada.

MIAMI -- Week-end entertaining in connection with the horse racing at Hialeah Park is proving an attraction for the Winter colony now gathered here. The scale upon which the entertainment is to be maintained is evidenced by the names of scores of persons, prominent socially and in business life, included in the list of boxholders for the coming week-end.

ENCOURAGED by the interest taken in its first "Regional Miscellany" (also called "FolkSay") the University at Oklahoma now stands sponsor for a second book compiled on the identical plan. Young, who was born in 1846, and when still a young woman made the journey from Kentucky into Kansas in a covered wagon.

Construction of the electric transmission line between the Albany area and Westchester County by the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation is now at a peak of activity, with 1,800 men and every form of equipment scattered over a wide territory on the right-of-way.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- With unquestionable skill and that quiet smiling manner which never leaves him, Premier Pierre Laval this week has dropped Aristide Briand from his Cabinet. However, one looks at it, and, however, one esteems M. Briand's character and policy the event is of tremendous importance For it marks a turning point in French history.

THE length of feature pictures is about the only thing in the industry that has not changed since the introduction of sound. A new kind of lighting has been introduced, make-up has been improved and the microphone has transformed the appearance of the studios.

A commission suit with a novel angle was decided by the Appellate Division on Friday when the court dismissed the complaint in an action by Sidney L. Warsawer against George Kremer, who was impleaded as a defendant with Josephine F. Burghard.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Of the several countries now in diplomatic negotiation with Russia over the drafting of non-aggression, treaties none is so large a State as France, and the results are being watched here with keen interest.

FOLLOWING the closing of the New York Automobile Show last night, the Brooklyn show will open tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock and continue through the week. As in past years, it will be held at the 106th Infantry Armory, Bedford and Atlantic Avenues.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- Many social and sports activities have been scheduled for the Winter colony here during the remaining days of January. One of the most colorful events will be an old-fashioned square dance, to be held at Southern Pines Country Club on Jan. 29 for the benefit of the unemployed.

BACK of the news report that Dr. Charles F. Burgess had invented a brick that floats, because it weighs only one-fifth as much as an ordinary brick, and that will make it possible to speed up the erection of brick buildings, lies a story of progressive research.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 16 (AP). -- Andrew J. Volstead, author of the prohibition enforcement act, wrote today to Senator Bingham of Connecticut that his bill to legalize 4 per cent beer "opens wide the old saloon doors, brass rails and all."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Five hundred women from more than forty States, representing eleven national organizations affiliated with the Conference on the Cause and Cure of War, called for the first time by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt in 1925, are expected to attend the seventh conference, which will open Monday for a four-day session.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Falling temperatures brought relief and normalcy to the village of Lake Placid today, promising all the snow and ice the Winter Olympics can possibly use, and ending a crisis in the lives of the villagers.

CAPE TOWN. THE hunting of snakes and lizards for their skins is now proving highly profitable in Zululand, a sun-tanned adventurer from that region reported recently. "Yes, snakes," said he. "They are making shoes of them nowadays, and they can't get enough.

IN number of adherents, stamp-collecting is one of the world's greatest hobbies. Any new issue of commemorative stamps is quickly absorbed by collectors, as was demonstrated, by the rush to buy the recent George Washington bicentennial issue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- While President Hoover was represented as absorbed, in his relief program and not concerning himself with the moves of his strategy board to place his name in the primary elections, the White-House today was besieged by a throng of politicians.

The develonment of new products and the reduction in costs of present ones through scientific research have been major aims of the chemical industry and of manufacturing chemists during 1931, according to the annual report of the committees of these trades, which will be presented to the drug, chemical and allied trades section of the New York Board of Trade, Inc., at its annual meeting on Tuesday here.

Under steady trade buying, prices on the Cotton Exchange strengthened further yesterday and closed the highest in the last two months. An advance in the basis at some Southern markets and a sharp rise in wheat closed the list near the top, changes ranging from a gain of 6 points to a loss of 3 points on the day.

BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- The World Disarmament Conference will have much to do with, the term "security," and in French usage, says Professor Hermann Oncken of the University of Berlin, "security is only another formula for a limitless lust for power, making French hegemony and German impotence the twin pillars of a just world order."

Private bankers were taken to task for attempting to "dictate the government's unemployment policy" and a Federal program of public works financed by surtaxes on high incomes was urged by speakers yesterday at a luncheon of the League for Industrial Democracy in the Hotel Woodstock.

The Bronx Hockey Club team scored its initial Metropolitan League victory at the New York Coliseum last night by defeating the New York A. C., 2 to 1, after a rough battle. About 1,500 witnessed the contest.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 14 -- Criticism of the management of the Evansville State Hospital, an institution for the insane, by the Board of State Charities has served to reopen the ancient controversy between the modern and old schools of psychiatrists.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- What Germany will demand at the Geneva Disarmament Conference will not be the right to arm but, on the contrary, the limitation of the armaments of other countries, Rudolf Breitscheid, Social Democratic leader in the Reichstag, said tonight in an address outlining his party's attitude on the great international questions.

FOR the first time definite statistics showing the part which broken glass plays in automobile accidents have been made available by the Automobile Accident Prevention Bureau of New York, it is reported. According to a recent survey conducted for this organization under the supervision of Ernst Ernst, certified public accountants, 45 per cent of those injured in automobile accidents are cut by broken flying glass.

THE highway that runs along the shore of the Gulf of Mexico from Jacksonville to Houston and beyond has been known for years as the Old Spanish Trail, and undoubtedly it will continue to bear that name for a long time to come, even though it is designated on most maps merely as U.S. Route 90.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- White badged members of the dry organizations now meeting in convention here crowded the Senate galleries today to listen to a thirty-page prohibition speech by Senator Sheppard of Texas, co-author of the Eighteenth Amendment, and broke into applause as he concluded.

Business in cash markets developed a better price trend than that in futures. Spot wheat, corn, rye and oats in the grains scored substantial advances, while lard and cotton also went along with the forward movement. In futures, slight gains were made in coffee, sugar and cocoa, but hides, silk and rubber were irregular.

NEW YORK'S annual automobile show brought several good radio programs to a nation-wide audience. Paul Whiteman with his orchestra in Chicago led a novel broadcast in which the program was picked up at several points across the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the holiday week ending Jan. 9 showed an increase over the preceding week, but were lower than a year ago, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The New York Americans met with unlooked-for opposition from the Hakoah A.C., leader in the German-American League, at Starlight Park yesterday in the charity soccer game played for the benefit of William Abner, who is still in Fordham Hospital with a broken leg.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Jan. 17 -- The Victoria Rink from Quebec today won the final in the Stockton cup curling competition, defeating the Brookline Country Club's No. 3 team, 14 to 10, to take the famous trophy to Quebec for the first time in more than fifteen years of competition and to deprive the Brookline curlers of possession of it for the first time since 1928.

Byrd preparing for a new venture into the Antarctic regions, in line with the announcement made at the Explorers Club on Saturday evening, it became known, yesterday that the scientists and other members of the last expedition were still tabulating the data gathered on the last trip to Little America, and would be until next September.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- Eleven railroad men will be put on trial here tomorrow charged with responsibility for the most terrible wreck in Russia since the Bolshevist revolution. This disaster occurred on the evening of Jan, 2 and resulted in the death of sixty-five persons and injury to 131.

Inez Lauritano, 21-year-old violinist, who played her first concert at the age of 6, appeared yesterday in a concert of the Young American Artist Series at the Barbizon Hotel, with her teacher, Louis Persinger, at the piano. Her program included Vitali's Ciaccona, Paganini's Concerto in D major and a group of airs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- An increase in net income for the twelve months ended on Dec. 31, 1931, over the previous year was reported yesterday by the Peoples Gas, Light and Coke Company despite a decrease in gross operating revenue. Net income for 1931 was $7,561,582, in comparison with $7,197,072 for 1930 -- a gain of $364,510.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Interest in efforts of the Federal Reserve System to cooperate with the administration to stimulate banking confidence and business recovery will be centred chiefly in New York this week, when it is expected that policies agreed upon at the meeting of the Reserve Bank governors held here recently will take concrete form.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- No concessions were made today by the spokesmen for the railroads when they met and continued discussion of the unemployment program presented to them by the chiefs of the twenty-one standard railway unions.

CANTON, S.D., Jan. 17 -- Roy Mikkelson of the Norge Ski Club of Chicago, captured distance honors from Caspar Oimoen, national champion, jumping for the Sioux Valley Club, in the Olympic ski tryouts today.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Europe entered the last week before the world reparation parley, tentatively set for Jan. 25 at Lausanne, in an atmosphere of mingled hope and fear.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- At a mass meeting under the auspices of the National Socialist Students' Association here tonight, Adolf Hitler delivered an ardent address in which he declared that the one hope and possibility for a truly united Germany and for her political and economic restoration lay in the victory of the National Socialist movement and the consequent acquisition by the nation of a totally different political organization.

Seventeen candidates, several participating in the sport for the first time, engaged in the second weekly workout of the New York section of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association yesterday on the hockey field in Central Park. A practice session which started at 2:30 o'clock was not concluded until nightfall.

Citing increased motive power, greater use of automobiles in adverse weather, highway congestion and increased "family" use of cars, the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters announced yesterday increased rates for automobile public liability and property damage insurance in New York State.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is humor in THE TIMES headline "New Equity Members Must Go to School," but there is a little bite in it too. We would like to feel that our new plan was sympathetically received, and I think it will be when, it is better understood.

A patrolman was shot and gravely wounded early yesterday morning by two robbers who had just held up a taxi driver and stolen $9. He had come into sight suddenly and the pair, apparently frightened, had fired without warning. His shield, gleaming in a street light, furnished the target.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Confidence in a gradual revival in all lines of trade and industry has received fresh impetus from the assistance that is expected to come from the Reconstruction Finance act. Increased buying of raw and manufactured articles is looked upon as the leading factor that will stimulate interest everywhere.

Declaring that capitalism has proved itself a complete failure in the United States, Theodore Dreiser urges the abolition of all private fortunes and the confiscation of all basic industries by a new central government resembling the Communist Central Committee in Moscow in his new book, "Tragic'America," to be published today by Liveright, Inc.

Miss Eleanor Holm of the Women Swimming Association cracked the world's record for the 150-yard back stroke, and her clubmate, Miss Sussan Robertson, won brilliantly in the metropolitan A.A.U. senior 500-yard free-style championship at a water carnival in the seventy-five-foot W.S.A. pool yesterday.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- While the German Foreign Office has not received formal notification that Britain and France would move for a postponement of definitive action on reparations at Lausanne next week, official and political circles believe the conversations between London and Paris in the past week indicate both powers have taken positions which prevent final action on reparations this month.

The year is very young, yet it has already established some interesting "market records." For one thing, the present month's 24 per cent recovery in stock market averages is more than double the advance of any January since the war. The recovery in bonds, which in some ways is more important, makes very similar comparison.

Vicki Baum, the author of "Grand Hotel," spoke of sauerkraut and slender girls, newspaper comic strips, American ice boxes and shoes, the politeness of the men, soft drinks, perfect roads and jazz, in reviewing her impressions of her stay in the United States in a radio broadcast from Berlin yesterday over the WABC-Columbia system.

The New York Americans gained some measure of revenge for the two overwhelming defeats dealt them this season by the Toronto Maple Leafs when they conquered the Canadian sextet at Madison Square Garden last night. Smarting under the sting of the pair of one-sided losses they sustained at the hands of the Leafs earlier in the campaign.

Increased activity featured the wholesale markets here during the week, although reports on retail clearance sales indicated that unusually warm weather proved a serious deterrent to consumer purchasing. New Spring merchandise received most attention, with decided interest shown in suits, which are believed to be headed for a notably successful season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Similar bills to amend the national prohibition act to enable patients who need liquor for medicinal purposes to obtain it in the "necessary quantity" on physicians' prescriptions and to enable physicians to prescribe such liquor without recording in government offices the diseases from which their patients are suffering will be introduced in the Senate and House tomorrow.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Visitors were not permitted in the hospital room today where Estelle Taylor, motion picture star, is suffering from a fractured cervical vertebra received in an automobile accident several weeks ago. Her neck has been placed in a plaster cast.

A succession of gales across the Atlantic from the mouth, of the English Channel to Nantucket Lightship caused the President Harding of the United States Lines to be forty-eight hours late when she arrived yesterday from Hamburg, via Southampton and Cherbourg.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- An abundance of common to good steers led last week to declines of 50 cents to $1 a hundredweight in prices here, while best yearlings and medium weight steers were off only 25 cents. Sales at $4.50 to $8.50 were more numerous than at $9.50 to $11.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- President Hoover today definitely narrowed the lists before him of men to fill some of the nation's highest appointive posts, with at least one selection due before the week in out.

The net income of the Detroit Edi- son Company after all charges, taxes and depreciation, including depreciation charged to surplus, amounted to $9,929,136 for 1931, equal to $7.80 a share earned on 1,272,260 shares of Capital stock compared with $11,116,667, eaual to $8.75 a share on 1,270,601 capital shares, in 1930.

The modern world is "a conspiracy to destroy all that is pure and noble in Christian womanhood," Cardinal Hayes declared yesterday at the 9 o'clock mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, warning the 700 young women members of the Carroll Club who were present for their annual corporate communion that they were "living in the most dangerous period in the history of all womanhood."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Raymond V. McNally in a recent letter to THE TIMES takes issue with my position, and that of others who believe that national economic planning is the cure for our present ills, on the ground that society, not industry, is at fault.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 17 -- Fred Morrison, giant golfer from Culver City, Cal., won the world's richest golfing stake today, the $15,000 Agua Caliente open, by playing the final eighteen holes in 73, one over par, for a seventy-two-hole grand total of 284.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has begun a series of one-reel motion-picture films illustrating the theory and practice of contemporary American painters, sculptors, etchers and workers in other fields of art.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 17 -- Recent archaeological discoveries at Monte Alban, in the State of Oaxaca, are hailed as unequaled in this hemisphere and probably rivals anything yet unearthed even, in Egypt, and they appear to be increasingly marvelous as reports from the axcavators continue to reach this capital.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 17 -- A conference of national political issues in which faculty members and undergraduates of Eastern colleges will join with leaders of the Democratic and Republican parties will be held at Princeton University late in April, De Witt Clinton Poole, chairman of the advisory board of the School of Public and International Affairs, announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- In the matter of economy the time has come, Senator Reed Smoot, chairman of the Finance Committee, said tonight, for Congress to practice what it preaches by stopping up "that old rat-hole in the Congressional Record." Use of it at $40 a page cannot be defended, he declared.

Two gunners tied for the High Scratch Cup and an equal number deadlocked for the high handicap honors at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. In the shoot for the scratch trophy, J. H. Wantling and T.H. Lawrence each broke 99 out of a possible 100 targets.
Coffee futures displayed strength last week, but sugar, rubber and hides all closed with losses on the local commodity exchanges, moving independently of the strength in other markets.

Several card parties of the near future will aid the activities of various philanthropic organizations. The annual card party for the benefit of the charitable enterprises of the Ladies of Charity of the Catholic Charities in the Archdiocese of New York will take place on Saturday afternoon at the Plaza.

A worried mother and father, pictured in a recent Punch cartoon, were deploring the "ultra-modern" ways of their young daughter. She insists upon helping with the housework, does not drink or smoke and goes to bed early. What could be done about it?

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- Turning in a card of 80-13-87, C.E. Black carried off the low net honors in the sixth weekly qualifying round of the annual Snowbirds' golf tournament held by the members of the Siwanoy Country Club over the club's course today.

Opposition to any reduction of the pay of New York City policemen as a result of the city's difficulties in borrowing money was voiced yesterday in a letter from Robert Daru, f ormer Assistant District Attorney, to Joseph P. Moran, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

Preaching yesterday in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick discussed the weaknesses of what he termed superficial, "fair weather" modernism as contrasted with old-fashioned religion and its powerful spiritual driying force.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- William Henry Murray, Governor of Oklahoma, who is happy to be saluted as "Alfalfa Bill," and has been urged by many admirers as a Democratic candidate for President on a platform of "bread and butter, bacon and eggs," came to Washington today and breezily discussed national questions.

A man described by the police as "a west side guerilla" and with "a reputation for toughness out of all proportion to his size" got a thirty-day sentence to the workhouse yesterday for attempting to "terrorize" a woman news dealer in to selling papers at night above the prescribed rates.

More than 500 persons including representatives from forty patriotic, historical and genealogical societies,, participated in the fourteenth annual religious service of the National Society of Colonial Dames of America in the State of New York held yesterday afternoon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

An independent committee to protect the interests of investors holding $800,000,000 in bonds on New York City real estate, of which more than $100,000,000 has been defaulted, has been organized here, it was announced yesterday by George E. Roosevelt, of Roosevelt Son, whose name heads the list of the committee's members.

Last week two suits were brought by doctors, both for hospital patients, both dismissed. The fees involved were not large and the cases were not important except on principle. The patients had paid their hospital bills, apparently unaware that the physicians, who were not of their choosing but were brought in by some hospital authority, would present separate bills.

Faith as the only revelation of God to mankind was the subject of the sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Minot C. Morgan, junior copastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. Dr. Morgan also reviewed briefly the essential beliefs of the Swiss preacher Karl Bart and his followers, showing their emphasis on faith.

Vicente Escudero, the Spanish Gypsy dancer, proved in his American debut last night at Chanin 's 48th Street Theatre that all the extravagant things said about him in his European appearances were well based in fact. One of the most brilliant audiences of the season crowded the theatre from top to bottom and let him know in unmistakable terms that he met with its approval.
LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- An Exchange Telegraph dispatch from Har- bin today said Japanese forces were bombing Yushu, near Kirin, Manchuria.

How to be simultaneously a candidate for renomination and give full time and thought to administrative duties has always been the problem of American Presidents. In the case of Mr. HOOVER it is more acute than usual because of the state of the nation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Brown University will award five scholarships of $400 each, covering tuition, to members of the class who enter next September. The scholarships will carry the name of John Hay in honor of one of Brown's most famous alumni, member of the class of 1858, private secretary to President Lincoln and Secretary of State in the Cabinets of Presidents McKinley and Roosevelt.

VIENNA, Jan. 17 -- Several of Hungary's neighbors are likely to follow her example, declaring their partial or complete inability to meet their foreign obligations, including $600,000,000 in American money invested in Central Europe outside Germany, it is indicated by Premier Mouchanoff's hint a few days ago that Bulgaria would have to declare a moratorium unless she received early foreign aid.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- The American Olympic bobsleigh teams will be selected tomorrow at a meeting of the Olympic Bobsleigh Committee in New York City. The entries must be filed by Jan. 21, and it will be impossible to hold elimination trials because of the absence of snow here.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. F. Lament Belin are at the Ambassador from Washington.
The New York A.C. defeated the New Haven Indians of the New England Amateur Hockey League, 2 to 1, in a game at the New York Coliseum yesterday before 2,500 spectators.

On view at the Palace this week is another of those revue-like vaudeville bills which, when they are as entertaining as this newcomer, usually achieve a vogue at the Forty-seventh Street music hall. Surely it is unnecessary to recall the long-run Lou Holtz-William Gaxton show of last Summer and the even longer run Eddie Cantor-George Jessel entertainment of recent weeks.

Higher, not lower, wages are the remedy for the depression, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, asserted yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York City local of the International Photo Engravers' Union in the Elks Club, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

The Committee on Interamerican Relations, which, is composed of representatives of all factors of commerce, including finance, transportation and communications from every part of the United States, is providing for a continuing study of Latin-American commercial, investment and public credits, according to an announcement by General Palmer E. Pierce of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, chairman.
The scenic beauty of Switzerland was described and illustrated with colorful, moving pictures by Burton Holmes last evening at Carnegie Hall in the second of his course of travel lectures.

The novel and very stirring feature of the concert given by Bruno Walter and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was the performance of the Berlioz Fantastic Symphony. The earlier part of the program, Handel's "Concerto grosso," and the Haydn Symphony, had been heard earlier in the week.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A Mexican tomb just uncovered near the city of Oaxaca is declared by Alfonso Caso, the excavator, to rival Historically and intrinsically the tomb of King Tut-ankh-Amen in Egypt. The excavators produced more valuable relics, he said, than similar work in the Mayan ruins in Yucatan.

There may be joy in Heaven over one sinner that repenteth, but not in Tammany. Borough President HARVEY was hugged to the bosom of his colleagues on the Board of Estimate when he suggested, not so many months ago, that they all deserved a handsome increase in salary.

A statute to bar Communist literature from the malls and from interstate commerce will be urged upon Congress, with other measures designed to check the activity of radical organizations in the United States, it was announced last night at the second annual anti-Communist convention, held at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Last year's British production of steel and iron was only half that of 1929. The year's total production of pig iron was 3,758,100 tons, as against 6,192,400 in 1930; of steel 5,175,600 tons, against 7,325,700. The monthly average output was 855,000 tons of pig iron and 638,600 tons of steel.
Between 300 and 500 students living at the International House, 500 Riverside Drive, participated early yesterday afternoon in a disarmament demonstration in the shadow of Grant's Tomb.

Those arch-rivals in Eastern amateur hockey, Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, Brooklyn, and the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, yesterday battled to a tie in Madison Square Garden for the second successive Sunday afternoon. The score was 2 to 2, and the fact that the Gulls gained both their goals before the Half-Mooners had any made the uphill battle of the Brooklyn sextet a thrilling enterprise.

PARIS, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Capitalism "has degenerated into a form of servitude of the peoples to an insignificant minority," Grand Duke Cyril Vladimirovich, self-styled heir to the Russian throne, said in a New Year greeting today. [The Orthodox Russian New Year begins on Jan. 14].

Following his arrest after a holdup in Ozone Park, Queens, Joseph Fontaine, 17 years old, of 133-07 Ninety-sixth Street, Richmond Hill, was said to have made a confession yesterday accusing his 20-year-old sweetheart of having planned each of the six store robberies with which he has been charged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Despite reports of a growing estrangement between Governor Roosevelt and former Governor Smith of New York Mr. Roosevelt's supporters here have seen no indication that Mr. Smith intends to enter a primary fight in any State for delegates to the Democratic National Convention.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17 (AP) -- An effort to rally the nation's unemployed back of a Presidential boom for the Rev. James R. Cox was launched by friends of the Pittsburgh, clergyman tonight.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- My reply to Chancellor Bruening's appeal to the National Socialist party to endorse an undertaking to prolong President von Hindenburg's term in office was delivered to the Chancellor last night. I disclose my answer here:
DETROIT, Jan. 17 -- The New York Rangers, their squad reduced by injuries, were defeated, 4 to 2, by the Detroit Falcons in a fast National League hockey match tonight before 8,500 spectators.

Although it was easy for the Jewish people to retain their religion while living in the ghetto, it is harder to do so in a wider world saturated with materialism, the Rev. Dr. Abram Simon of Washington, D.C., declared yesterday in a sermon at the Temple Emanu-El, Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

William McFee, author of "The Harbourmaster" (Doubleday, Doran), the Literary Guild choice for January, thinks it strange that his recent comparison of women and automobiles attracted so much attention. He says there are nearly as many kinds of women as cars and "many of the former might be described as products of 'General Motives, A Design for Every Bankroll,' while the twin-six mentality has, seen for years a problem for husbands with limited resources."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17 -- For four successive weeks steel ingot production has been estimated at 18, 20, 22 and 24 per cent of theoretical capacity, respectively. The 24 per cent average for last week is made up of 20 per cent for the Chicago district, representing no increase; 22 per cent for the Pittsburgh district, representing a small improvement, and relatively high rates, with gains, in other and smaller districts.

A new appeal to the Navy Department to aid Merchant Marine officers holding Naval Reserve commissions by assigning them to active duty on short training cruises with pay and subsistence, has just been made by the Neptune Association whose members include 3,000 American shipmasters and deck officers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Secretary Stimson's decision as to whether he will submit to the Senate Finance Committee correspondence of the State Department relative to loans to Colombia and the Barco oil concession probably will be announced by him before the committee Wednesday morning.

There was not a vacant seat in the Town Hall last night, where Paul Robeson returned in triumph for his recital here after his recent tour abroad. The Negro baritone held his audience spellbound in a program mostly of spirituals, several of which were greeted with such enthusiastic applause that the singer repeated them.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Northwestern and Ohio State tonight were the only unbeaten teams remaining in the Western Conference basketball title campaign.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Trade of the United States with the Far East in November amounted in value to $84,180,000, as compared with $82,563,000 in October. The increase was due to a rise in exports.

From the pulpit of St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Father John Corbett, associate editor of The Messenger of The Sacred Heart, challenged yesterday the reply made last week to the Pope's recent encyclical by the Rev. James De Wolf Perry, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Jewish leaders representing various shades of opinion in the movement for the rebuilding of Palestine united yesterday in opening a $2,500,000 drive for the continuation of the work in 1932, voicing faith in the ultimate success of the project and paying tribute to the late Julius Rosenwald.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Coast Guard destroyer Herndon, with pumps working continuously to keep her forward compartments dry and with a great hole in her port side, rested safely at the destroyer pier today after, being in collision at sea with the collier Lemuel Burrows and being towed here stern-first early yesterday.

Indications point to greater activity in the securities markets as a temporary result of the easy money policy of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, but the acceleration will be erratic, according to the annual review and forecast number of The Annalist, now out.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 17 -- Frank L. Stanton Jr. of Atlanta, son of the late Poet Laureate of Georgia, who wrote "Mighty Lak a Rose" in honor of his infant child, was killed with his wife early today when their automobile struck a concrete bridge between Perry and Clinchfield.

LONDON. Jan. 15. -- The advance in stocks which has occurred this week at London, along with the change in tone on the New York and Paris markets, is taken here to indicate that financial markets are ignoring altogether news of international politics, even the reported threat of the Bank of Frarce to withhold renewal of its credit to the Reichsbank.
GREENUP, Ky., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Four persons were killed at a grade crossing here this afternoon when a Chesapeake Ohio passenger train struck an automobile. A fifth was critically injured.
HAVANA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Bedwell campaigner Vacillate captured the Marianao Handicap, feature attraction of the card at Oriental Park, today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Final passage of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation bill, the administrations major measure designed to bring the country out of the business depression, is expected this week. The parliamentary tangle of which Senator Blaine of Wisconsin took advantage Saturday to delay action will be settled in the Senate tomorrow, when the Senate will amend the House bill by substituting its bill after the enacting clause.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 17 -- Mrs. William Seward Webb entertained with a luncheon today at the Gulf Stream Club. On Tuesday she will be hostess at a large tea and recital by the New York String Quartet at Mirador, her villa. Mr. and Mrs. George Luke Mesker have issued invitations to a tea and recital by the quartet for Thursday.

MADRID, Jan. 17 -- Miguel Unamuno, recognized as the greatest living philosopher among the world's hundred million Spanish-speaking people, stated today that "all Europe is playing a sly game of diplomacy, as before the World War." "There is the same maintenance of armaments, and there are the same mutual fears that made war before," he declared.

A voice now familiar to millions rises above the multitude of appeals. It is the voice of WALTER DAMROSCH asking the people of New York to give heed to the distress of unemployed musicians. Although skilled and capable, they are steadily, by hundreds, being forced toward destitution.

Verdi's "Siinone Boccanegra" will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday evening, Jan. 28, in what is announced by the management as the first performance of the opera in North America. This is the season's fourth and final novelty for the Metropolitan, the other three having been Jaromir Weinberger's "Schwanda, der Dudelsackpfeifer," Montemezzi's "La Notte di Zoraima" and Franz von Suppe's "Donna Juanita."

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 17. -- The weakness of European markets was reflected in Argentine grain prices last week, wheat closing at 5.90 pesos per quintal and flaxseed at 8.95 against 6.25 and 9.65 pesos the previous week. The flaxseed figure is equivalent to a fall of 8 cents a bushel.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- The American Olympic speed skating team was picked today without trials because of the lack of ice throughout the State. The Olympic Skating Committee named thirteen skaters.

BERLIN, Jan 15. -- In business circles the Chancellor's failure to insure prolongation of Hindenburg's Presidency by a direct Reichstag vote was taken calmly. Even the Boerse continued firm. It was a matter of favorable comment in financial circles during the week that whereas the German Nationals had shown a strong desire to compel Bruening's resignation, nevertheless Hitler, whose party constitutes, the main body of the so-called "National opposition," behaved very temperately.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- A sudden and unexpected change from pessimism to optimism came to the wheat market on the Board of Trade here in the last hour on Saturday, upsetting all bearish theories and creating a belief that conditions had changed for the better and that the markets were in good position to respond to further constructive influences.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 17 -- Moslems throughout Palestine are highly indignant over the mysterious disappearance of one of the thirty manuscript volumes comprising the entire Koran in the museum of the Mosque El Aksa.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Montreal Maroons and Chicago Black Hawks fought tonight through seventy minutes of a National League hockey game at the Chicago Stadium before a crowd of 9,000 fans to a 3-to-3 tie.

Harry May, a seaman, and a recently discharged prisoner from Welfare Island, was announced yesterday to be the winning author among 500 or more inmates of that institution who had taken part in the first essay contest held there. A second awards was given to Miss Perry Perkins serving four months for disorderly conduct, and a third to Peter Curtis, serving an indeterminate sentence as a "repeater."

PARIS, Jan. 15. -- The trend of the Paris Bourse changed completely this week. No further attention appeared to be paid to the questions which hitherto had caused so great anxiety. The market was equally indifferent to news from Germany and to discussion of difficulties which the Lausanne conference will have to face.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Bishop James Cannon Jr. was eulogized as "a great champion of freedom of conscience and intellect" and "a sacrificing worker in the cause of prohibition" in a resolution adopted yesterday by the directors of the Anti-Saloon League and made public today.

Clarence Hitchcock, 31 years old, of 23 Grove Street, a chemist, died in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday of a bullet wound in the neck. He was shot Nov. 28 by John L. Tilker, 24, of 1,976 Belmont Avenue, the Bronx during rehearsal of an amateur play at 106 Bedford Street, in Greenwich Village.

Details of a confidential report on economic conditions in Germany just received by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, were made public yesterday at the headquarters of that organization, 342 Madison Avenue.

The National Geographic Society states in a current bulletin: "Though the South Pole, has been reached thrice and the coastline skirted, of the interior only the pie-shaped sector leading inland from the shore of the Ross Sea has been explored."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 17 -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., 18-year-old son of Bud Goodwin, former aquatic star of the New York Athletic Club, won the annual Miami-Biltmore invitation tournament today over the course of the Miami-Biltmore Country Club, defeating Howard A. Tryon, 21-year-old rival from Elmira, N.Y., by 7 up and 6 to play.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 17. -- State regulation of the production and transportation of natural gas in New York State is recommended by the Public Service Commission in a report made public today following an exhaustive investigation of the industry.

Mention of Judge CAEDOZO as an eminently fit successor to Mr. Justice HOLMES on the bench of the Supreme Court of the United States has been of a sort quite without precedent in the case of a judicial vacancy. From all parts of the country have come expressions of hope that President HOOVER might add another New York judge to the two from this State already in the Supreme Court.

Samuel Seabury has initiated ouster proceedings against another Tammany officeholder, it became known yesterday as the Hofstadter Committee prepared to ask the Legislature for longer life and additional funds for its investigation of New York City Government.

Protection of material dealers and subcontractors through a payment insurance plan is suggested in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports by Charles L. Eidlitz, builder and managing director of the Credit Association of the Building Trades of New York.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 17 -- With everything ready for A. Harry Moore's return to the Governorship on Tuesday, it became known today that he plans to start an economy drive on three more fronts.
MUKDEN, Jan. 17 -- Japanese suppressive measures continue throughout Manchuria. The week's toll in lives is more than fifty Japanese and 300 Chinese, labeled "bandits."
THIS probably comes under the head of Kicking a straw man around the premises, but at this time of year almost any kind of exercise is beneficial. And so, lay on, Macduff!

BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- Alfred Lansburgh, editor of Die Bank, criticizes the proceedings of the American Senate Finance Committee's inquiry into foreign loans. His view is that the committee hopelessly failed to understand the real nature and origin of American lending to Europe and that the bankers whom the committee questioned did nothing to enlighten it.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 17 -- "The discussion of limitation or reduction of armaments is a distraction from the real problem of making war an impossibility," Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan declared today before an audience of more than 1,000 persons in the high school auditorium here.

The seventy-nine relief stations of the Home Relief Bureau of the Department of Public Welfare, closed Jan. 6 because of lack of funds, will be reopened today with an expected registration of at least 5,000 applicants. More than 30,000 had registered with the bureau before it closed and the work of investigating these applicants, together with listing thousands of others, will be resumed this morning.

Declaring that the present election laws place the independent candidate or ticket at a distinct disadvantage in the competition for recognition at the polls, the Citizens Union asked yesterday for a revision of those laws. Its communication was addressed to the Hofstadter legislative investigating committee, with the suggestion that the reforms be recommended by the committee in its report to the Legislature.

To the Editor of The New York Times: William D. Guthrie, a leading authority on constitutional law, sets forth in THE NEW YORK TIMES a proposed amendment of Article XVIII of the amendments to the Constitution, which he believes, apparently, will solve all difficulties in the present prohibition situation, and which he "prepared for submission to Congress."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- Failure of world peace agencies to intervene effectively and the fact that American and European nations are too concerned with their own troubles will result in force being the decisive factor in the Manchurian crisis, according to Dr. Lucius Chapin Porter, Professor of Philosophy at Yenching University, Peiping, China, who is visiting Scarsdale Congressional Church here until Wednesday.
MUKDEN, Jan. 17 -- Japanese suppressive measures continue throughout Manchuria. The week's toll in lives is more than fifty Japanese and 300 Chinese, labeled "bandits."
THIS probably comes under the head of Kicking a straw man around the premises, but at this time of year almost any kind of exercise is beneficial. And so, lay on, Macduff!

BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- Alfred Lansburgh, editor of Die Bank, criticizes the proceedings of the American Senate Finance Committee's inquiry into foreign loans. His view is that the committee hopelessly failed to understand the real nature and origin of American lending to Europe and that the bankers whom the committee questioned did nothing to enlighten it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: William D. Guthrie, a leading authority on constitutional law, sets forth in THE NEW YORK TIMES a proposed amendment of Article XVIII of the amendments to the Constitution, which he believes, apparently, will solve all difficulties in the present prohibition situation, and which he "prepared for submission to Congress."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- Failure of world peace agencies to intervene effectively and the fact that American and European nations are too concerned with their own troubles will result in force being the decisive factor in the Manchurian crisis, according to Dr. Lucius Chapin Porter, Professor of Philosophy at Yenching University, Peiping, China, who is visiting Scarsdale Congressional Church here until Wednesday.

The need for increased faith in God and the means of attaining such faith were discussed by Bishop William T. Manning in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church, 340 Alexander Avenue, the Bronx.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 17. -- Although trading in the cotton contract market here was not particularly active last week, there was a generally better undertone and prices gradually strengthened. The upward slant of values was caused principally by firmness in the stock markets, and the better feeling in both stocks and commodities was attributed to the certainty of enactment into law of the reconstruction finance bill by Congress.

Below is a list of Home Relief Bureau stations in the respective police precincts to be reopened today. Persons in need of food, clothing, shelter and medical aid may apply to these stations. Those living in the precinct given in the first column should apply at the public school listed in the parallel column. The relief stations are not intended as offices for application for work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Nearly three years of the most severe criticism and personal abuse that any President of the United States has ever had heaped upon him, plus a flood of the toughest breaks possible in any natural course of events, have done things to Herbert Hoover.

Paul De Bruyn, national marathon champion of Germany, whose athletic activities in this country have been studded with sparkling performances, established a new course record in capturing the prize for the best time in the weekly handicap road run conducted by the Manhattan Athletic League on Riverside Drive yesterday.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 17 -- The New Bedford soccer team eliminated Boston from the National Cup competition today, winning by 5 to 1.

Prohibition is here and will not be repealed, according to the general belief expressed at meetings yesterday afternoon and evening in the John Golden Theatre, 202 West Fifty-eighth Street, under the auspices of the Allied Forces for Prohibition.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- In orders just issued by Major Gen. W.R. Smith, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy here, ninety-two cadets have been awarded letters, monograms or numerals for athletic prowess last Fall as members of the army football, soccer and cross-country teams.
National Thrift Week began yesterday, commemorating the birth of Benjamin Franklin, "patron saint of thrift," with the urging from many pulpits to spend, but to spend wisely.

LAKE ELSINORE, Cal., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Martin C. Martin of Hollywood, Cal., and Miss Loretta Turnbull of Monrovia, shared major honors as five world records were set today in the finale to the two-day meet of the Southern California Motorboat Association.

Individual scoring leaders in the P.S.A.L. and C.H.S.A.A. hockey tournaments remained in the first place in the races for honors in their respective leagues, despite the fact that they did not increase their totals during the past week.

A Mexican ballet called "H.P.," by the Mexican composer Carlos Chavez, will receive a world premiere by the Philadelphia Grand Opera Company in that city on March 31, with Leopold Stokowski conducting, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. William C. Hammer, director and general manager of the company.

Secretary STIMSON is quite right in refusing to make public confidential reports to the State Department. In them many things appear which were never intended to see the light, and which, if they were given to the Senate and perhaps printed in the Congressional Record, would make it impossible for agents of the United States to obtain useful information.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Party harmony in Ohio Democratic ranks, threatened by a fight to pledge Ohio's convention delegates to Newton D. Baker, has been bulwarked by Baker himself.

Despite the fact that his team met its first defeat of the season when Princeton bowed to Dartmouth at Hanover last Saturday night, John E. Siebert, crack Tiger forward, retained his place at the top of the individual scorers in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race.

GLENDORA, Miss., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Evacuation of the inhabitants of Tippo Basin, which went forward on a large scale for thirty-six hours, had virtually ceased tonight except in the haphazard use of boats. Five fissures which are steadily widening have appeared in the basin levees.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler told a meeting of Berlin "Nazi" students tonight that unless the nation's "dissident elements" became united and put an end to "Jewish bolshevism and internationalism" Germany within the next forty years would become a "nation of language teachers and museum guides."
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- A crossing of the Antarctic Continent from the Weddell Sea to the Ross Ice Barrier will be attempted by a British expedition, which plans to reach the frozen South next Winter.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- With the legislative leaders intent upon final adjournment as early as possible in March, it is expected that Senate and Assembly committees will start work in earnest this week. Senator Fearon and Speaker McGinnies, Republican chiefs, have told committee chairmen to lose no time in reporting bills so that calendars can be prepared and both houses get down to work.

The malfeasance indictments against former General Sessions Judge Francis X. Mancuso and other directors of the defunct City. Trust Company were dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Bleakley, who then granted the request of Hiram C. Todd, the special prosecutor, to resubmit evidence to the extraordinary grand jury now sitting in the County Court House.

Miss Marion Lloyd of the Salle d'Armes Vince, holder of the women's national championship, making her first appearance of the season here, captured the Alice Wendt Voorhees gold medal in the tournament last night at the Fencers Club. Miss Lloyd gained the medal after defeating Miss Dorothy Locke, her clubmate, and runner-up for the national crown in a fence-off, 5 -- 4. Miss Locke won the silver medal for placing second.

The country is face to face with a problem of reconstruction comparable with that which followed the World War, and the Young Men's Christian Association should take a prominent part in solving it, 500 men and women attending the eightieth annual dinner of the Y.M.C.A. of the City of New York were told last night by Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

A petition bearing the signatures of 500,000 American citizens who want peace will be presented to the United Statse delegation to the Disarmament Conference just before it sails on the liner President Harding tomorrow afternoon by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.
PARIS, Tuesday, Jan. 19 (AP) -- France wants the Lausanne reparations conference postponed and the moratorium on reparations and war debts extended until next year, it became known today.
The Giants lost some ground on one front but made a substantial gain on another yesterday in their spirited drive to bring their players into the fold for the 1932 season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- An important step toward support of the world Zionist movement was taken at a dinner here last night when an American Palestine committee of persons well known in public life was formed to further the restoration of Palestine as the Jewish national homeland and to disseminate accurate information as to the progress of the upbuilding work in the Holy Land.

To delay ratification of the World Court protocols beyond the present session of Congress might be disastrous, the Rev. Dr. Sidney L. Gulick, secretary of the Commission on International Justice and Goodwill of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, said yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Sterling lost ground In the foreign exchange market today, the New York rate dropping to $3.47 1/4. British Government funds were lower in sympathy, the conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan falling to L75 1/3 and the war loan to L97 11-16.

Thomas L. Chadbourne, author or the Chadbourne plan for stabilization of the world's sugar industry, will arrive in Cuba today to confer with President Machado in a final effort to save his plan. He sailed on Friday, two days after having returned from the adjourned international sugar conference in Paris.

In the annual report of his office, issued yesterday, District Attorney Charles B. McLaughlin of the Bronx characterized the acquittal in the Vivian Gordon murder case as "a gross miscarriage of justice," demanded two more county judges, and declared that the Bronx had less crime per capita than any community of its size in the country, although his statistics showed an increase in wrongdoing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Secretary Stimson said today there had been no change in the American attitude with respect to the intergovernmental debt problem and the decision not to send an American observer to the Lausanne conference on reparations.

Max Schmeling is ready -- eager, in fact -- to risk his heavyweight title against Jack Sharkey, whose foul in their bout two years ago, gave him the crown. The German made this known yesterday in the following statement:

TOKYO, Jan. 18 -- The status of Manchuria in the future is exercising many minds here, and many interesting ideas are being expressed. The following summary will show how the wind is blowing and may prove 50 per cent prophetic. No official authority is claimed, but every statement has been obtained from responsible persons or leading newspapers.
BELGRADE, Jan. 18 -- With great pomp King Alexander carried out the ceremonial opening of the new Parliament today, the Chamber and Senate meeting in joint session for that purpose.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- Miss Anne Dyer, 15-year-old player, featured the opening of the women's Pennsylvania squash racquets tournament at Merion today by being the first in the field of sixty-four to advance to the third round.

Commemoration by the W.C.T.U. of the twelfth anniversary of national prohibition took the rather curious, not to say ironical, form of a "victory luncheon." One misses the ardor and confidence of the days before "victory" or the days when "victory" was young.

In view of the proposed increase in the State income tax, certain legislators, according to a dispatch from Albany, are expressing the belief that "more lenient exemptions should be allowed." Any one but a politician would urge exactly the opposite.

Dan Totheroh, whose "Wild Birds" left a deep impression upon those who saw it six years ago, still has a touch of magic in his writing. His "Distant Drums," which drew Pauline Lord into the Belasco last evening, tumbles away into fragments in the last act, just as you have prepared yourself for some strange and haunting conclusion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Premier Laval of France has taken diplomatic, steps to determine the American Government's attitude toward possible European extension of the moratorium on inter-governmental debts.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- The American Embassy issued a statement to the French press today calling its attention to a declaration by President Hoover on Jan. 9, not previously published here, in which the President asserted that the budget of the United States would be balanced for the year beginning July 1.

Rochester, N.Y. New financing by the city of Rochester, N.Y., in the amount of $5,652,000 was announced yesterday for Jan. 26. On that date the city will open bids on an issue of various improvement bonds, maturing on March 1, 1934 to 1962.

Stricter laws against perjury were demanded by Police Commissioner Mulrooney last night in an address before Branch 184 of the Holy Name Society of the Archdiocese of New York, meeting in the auditorium of the Roman Catholic Church of the Good Shepherd at Cooper and Isham Streets.

Sixty-six couturiers, manufacturers and fabric houses participated in the exhibition of 110 style creations at the promenade of feminine fashions for Spring of the Garment Retailers of America in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

Former Supreme Court Justice Frank S. Gannon Jr., who was appointed to the bench of the Second Judicial District to serve the remainder of two unexpired terms, died of pneumonia last night at 8:30 o'clock at St. Vincent's Hospital, West New Brighton, S.I.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 18 -- The House of Assembly of the New Jersey Legislature, controlled by the Democrats for the first time in seventeen years, called from committee tonight a Republican measure to repeal the State's prohibition enforcement act and passed it by a vote of 42 to 15.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Premier Laval will present his new Cabinet to Parliament tomorrow and read his declaration of policy. It will be concerned almost entirely with foreign affairs and is expected to be brief, as are always M. Laval's declarations. In it he will set forth the French viewpoint regarding what should be done at Lausanne and the stand which France will take at the Geneva armaments conference.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 18 -- The Nanking Government today informed Shanghai bankers it was not contemplating a moratorium on domestic bond payments, following the bankers' assurance that they would provide financial assistance to enable the government to continue until after the Chinese New Year's Day, Feb. 6.
The second Coffee Dance of the season was held last night in the assembly room of the Cosmopolitan Club. Many dinners were given before it. Among the hosts and hostesses were:

"That every woman can do housework "is declared a fiction by Dr. HAZEL KYRK of the Home Economics Department of Chicago University. She has an article in The American Federationist in which she bewails the condition of household workers and advocates a change based on the establishment of various standards.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Great Britain is to send a team to the United States in the Walker Cup contest this year after all. A cordial invitation, it was announced tonight, had been sent by H.H. Ramsay, president of the United States Golf Association, to the Royal and Ancient Club and had been accepted.

Benjamin of Toddington, an English-bred dog, a red sable not yet 3 years old, last night was named best in show at the thirtieth annual specialty show of the Pekingese Club of America, in the grand ball room at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- David Burnet, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, testifying today at a Senate subcommittee's hearing on Senator Bingham's proposal for 4 per cent beer, conceded that the measure might result in a "substantial increase" in Federal revenue, but declined to estimate the possibility of an increase in the consumption of beer, saying that he had "no crystal ball in which to gaze."

BUCHAREST, Jan. 18 -- The Rumanian political police believe the arrest yesterday of a group of Russian Communists who arrived at Constanza aboard the Greek steamship Philomena to be of the greatest importance in view of the large sum of money, reported by the newspapers at between $2,000,000 and $5,000,000, found in their possession.

HONOLULU, Jan. 18 -- The special session of the Hawaiian Territorial Legislature, intended primarily to rehabilitate the forces of law and order, began this morning at Iolani Palace with every member of the Senate and House attending.

A memorial exhibition or paintings by the famous British artist, Sir William Orpen, who died Sept. 29, 1931, opened yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries, to remain until Jan. 30. These twenty-seven canvases, portraits for the most part, occupy all but one of the rooms on the main floor.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The golden music of "Carmen" and Conchita Supervia, one of the most famous singers of "Carmen" in Europe, as guest-artist to sing its principal role made a more than commonly attractive offering at the Civic Opera House tonight.

The De Witt Clinton High School basketball team scored its seventh victory in eight starts this season when it triumphed over the Samuel J. Tilden quintet of Brooklyn, 29 -- 22, yesterday on the Clinton court. The winners led at half-time, 17 -- 7.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 18 -- The Capitol and hundreds of business houses and dwellings in the downtown section of the city were decorated today with flags and hunting in preparation for the inauguration here at noon tomorrow of Governorelect A. Harry Moore, a Democrat of Jersey City.
Herbert E. Winlock, curator of Egyptian art at the Metropolitan Museum, was chosen director of the museum at a meeting of the board of trustees yesterday. He succeeds the late Edward Robinson.
