The discoveries in the pre-Aztec ruins of Monte Alban, overlooking the ancient city of Oaxaca, Mexico, announced in dispatches from Mexico City published yesterday, were characterized by archaeologists and anthropologists here yesterday as of the greatest scientific importance.

Women are assuming a more dominant role in world affairs, according to the Baroness von Hindenburg, niece of the German President; Professor Harry Overstreet of the College of the City of New York and other speakers at a meeting of Wo- man's Unity, world-wide cultural organization, held last night at the Roerich Museum Auditorium.

Deploring the tendency of minorities to acquiesce In the "prejudiced estimate" of them held by majorities which regard them as inferior, Professor Albert Einstein, in a message to American Negroes appearing in the February Crisis, commends them for seeking an "emancipation of the soul" through closer union and "conscious educational enlightenment."

Driven by necessity to choose the American bobsleigh teams because the thaw of the past week-end had canceled the tryouts, the American Olympic bobsleigh committee yesterday named seven combinations as eligible for the honor of bearing the United States shield at Lake Placid in the international games next month.
PEIPING, Jan. 18 -- Signs are rapidly multiplying to indicate that this year will be no exception to what has become the habitual annual Chinese outbreak, an early Spring civil war.

Possible applications of the insurance principle to payment for medical care are being studied by the Committee on the Costs of Medical Care, it was disclosed yesterday at a meeting of the executive committee of the organization. It was explained that the application of the principles to other emergencies had led the committee to these considerations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The United States delegation to the general disarmament conference at Geneva will exercise a quiet but firm role to facilitate an agreement among the nations which, if not productive of arms reduction, will lead to a treaty limiting armaments and paving the way for greater steps at a future conference.

Maud von Rosen, who has the distinction of being the only student ever accepted for individual instruction by the noted sculptor Carl Milles, opens her first American show at the Arden Gallery today. Yesterday the exhibition was opened privately with a tea given at the gallery by Mrs. E.H. Manville.

Radical changes in the city's methods of acquiring land for public purposes by condemnation, recommended in the report of Leonard M. Wallstein, Special Corporation Counsel, will save large sums for the city and help to stabilize the disturbed condition of its finances, it was revealed yesterday.

In less than thirty minutes after a syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company offered a new issue of $4,200,000 City of Baltimore (Md.) bonds yesterday afternoon the syndicate books were closed, the issue having been oversubscribed. It was the first time in many weeks that a municipal issue of comparable size had been disposed of so quickly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Senator Glass of Virginia, who with Senator Bulklsy of Ohio, resisted efforts to include in the Senate reconstruction finance corporation bill a proposal to permit rediscount of the securities of the $2,000,000,000 corporation by Federal Reserve banks, tonight forecast that this provision, embodied in the House bill, will be eliminated in conference.

BOMBAY, Jan. 18 -- Men and women affiliated with, unlawful Nationalist organizations extended their activities in Bombay today, picketing the mint and manufacturing contraband salt. A number of arrests were made.

General business activity in December declined below the November level, resuming the downward trend which was interrupted somewhat in the previous month, according to the monthly report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry, operating under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

A woman, destitute and hungry, and who, it is alleged, attempted twice to take her own life and those of her two small sons by gas, was held without bail for a hearing in Homicide Court when arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Goldstein in West Side Court.

A detailed survey of consumer buying habits, preferences and prejudices is being made in New York City coincidentally with the canvass for the new city directory under the sponsorship of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, it was disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Passage of a bill to set up a banking board of nine members was held up in the Assembly tonight because of the desire of Governor Roosevelt to confer on revision proposed for the measure.

Although under the election law the circulation of petitions nominating delegates for the two national conventions from this State can be begun today, none of the preliminary steps, such as the printing of the petition blanks, has even been begun.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- As a means of checking the tendency of depositors to take their money from smaller banks up-State, Senator Frederick J. Slater of Monroe tonight introduced a bill providing for the creation of an emergency financial council to administer a $10,000,000 fund for the relief of the institutions.
"Whistling in the Dark." a play by Laurence Gross and Edward Childs Carpenter, of which Ernest Truex will be the star, will open tonight at the Barrymore Theatre.

Formation of the Greater New York Real Estate Bondholders' Committee to assist the holders of realty securities in protecting their interests was hailed yesterday by many property owners and realty men as a constructive step in promoting real estate stability and in offsetting the effects of "fear and uncertainty which have warped the judgment of many persons regarding the value of intrinsically sound investments in this field."

Because of the refusal of many brokerage houses to lend the stock needed by speculators to cover short commitments, United States Steel common became so scarce yesterday in the stock-loan market that the premium was raised at one time to 1/2 point, or $50 for the use of 100 shares for twenty-four hours.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- British hopes of engaging in a projected transatlantic flying boat service at an early date received a setback tonight when it was announced that work had been stopped on the giant sixengined thirty-five-ton commercial ship which was being built to the order of the civil department of the Air Ministry at the Supermarine works of Vickers, Ltd., Southampton.
Vidal Gregorio, Spanish featherweight, and Johnny Pena of the Bronx slugged their way through ten rounds to a draw last night in the feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena before a crowd of 2,000.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Federal Judge John P. Nields today appointed Henry P. Scott of Wilmington, Edgar H. Stone of New York and Winfred B. Holton of Pelham, N.T., as receivers for the Spreckels Sugar Corporation of New York.

THE reference here is not to Robert Louis Stevenson but to Maxwell Stevenson, chairman of the board of stewards of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, No. 6 in the Columbia crew of 1901, former miner in Nevada, polo player and golfer at Meadow Brook, fight fan of old days and a man who knows where to buy the most luscious eating pineapples in the world.

A nation-wide campaign, with this city as the centre, was begun yesterday by the American Legion to obtain jobs for 1,000,000 unemployed as a step to general economic recovery. Backing the campaign and cooperating with the Legion are the American Federation of Labor, the Association of National Advertisers and hundreds of business organizations throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today to review the conviction of John Borum, John Logan and Milton Guy of murdering Lamar W. York, a prohibition agent, in Washington. The jury after reporting each of them separately not guilty of firing the fatal shot, convicted them collectively of the murder.

If short prayers find their way to heaven, those with which the sessions of Congress are opened should reach that desired destination. Brief petitions by the chaplains through a period of years should recite every special need and invite every particular blessing.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Negotiations between the railroad presidents' committee of nine and the chiefs of the twenty-one standard railway unions made progress today, an agreement being reached on the unions' proposal for establishment of regional employment bureaus to replace the present more or less haphazard method of returning laid off men to jobs.

The annual Charity Ball, probably the oldest philanthropic entertainment in New York, will be held tonight in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. It will be the seventy-fifth ball in a series that had its inception before the Civil War, from which time it has benefited each year the New York Nursery and Childs Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A few more workers lost jobs in manufacturing industries during December than were taken on. The ratio of those losing jobs to every 100 on the payroll was 3.43, compared with a ratio of 3.29 for those who obtained work during the month, according to the labor turnover table for December issued today by the Labor Department.

The upward movement under way last week on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday, advancing prices 15 points at one time on the largest volume of business in several weeks. After selling above 7 cents for May contracts, the market ran into more cotton from spot quarters but closed 5 to 10 points higher than on Saturday.

Chief Justice Edward B. LaFetra announced yesterday that he had summoned his associates on the City Court bench to meet in special session next Monday to consider Samuel Seabury's charges against Harry C. Perry, chief clerk of the court.

MADRID, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The appointment of Juan Cardenas as the Spanish Ambassador to Washington was ratified in a decree signed today by President Alcala Zamora. The President also signed formal letters apprising the Pope and the heads of thirty nations of his elevation to office.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18 -- Five New York entrants qualified today for the Glenn H. Curtiss Trophy tournament, match play, which starts Thursday on the municipal golf course at Miami Springs.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The discovery of a fortune in gold and precious stones in an ancient tomb of early Mexican chieftains lifted the hopes of archaeologists today that further vast treasures might be found buried in Northern Oaxaca.

Torn from her mother's grasp when a closing subway train door caught her overcoat, Katherine McDonald, 7 years old, was dragged along the platform and then onto the tracks of the I.R.T. station at Broadway and 231st Street last evening and almost instantly killed.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 18 -- Williams scored its most impressive victory of the season at Lasell Gymnasium tonight, defeating Columbia by 40 to 34 in an overtime contest.

Approximately 10,000 employes of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad have offered voluntarily to accept a 10 per cent cut in wages, but the management of the road has declined the offer pending the outcome of the wage conference between railroad labor and management now in progress in Chicago.

While sterling and the exchanges linked to it reacted yesterday after the improvement of last week, French, Belgian, Swiss and Dutch exchanges continued to advance against the dollar. The franc added one-eighth to its recent rise, closing at 3.93 5/8 cents, which is above the export gold point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Radio tubes, accessories and parts are included in the French Government's decree establishing drastic quotas on imports of foreign radio sets, by which shipments from the United States are considerably curtailed, the Department of Commerce was advised today in a cable from Allport Fayette, the United States Commercial Attache at Paris.

WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 18 -- Max and Louis Levand, publishers of The Wichita Beacon, today telegraphed to Arthur Brisbane, urging him, as "the world's most famous editorial writer, thinker, student, one of the country's most successful business men -- a man of unwavering honesty," to run for President.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- With three more speeches and numerous interviews added to his long record of public utterances, William H. (Alfalfa Bill) Murray, Governor of Oklahoma, who awaits convincing to become a candidate for President on the "bread and butter and bacon and eggs" ticket, tonight approached the end of a visit to the capital city.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Miss Elizabeth Eliot, daughter of the Hon. Montague Eliot and Mrs. Eliot, and Thomas James, son of the late Lieut. Col., the Hon. Cuthbert James and Mrs. James, has been announced.

Weakness in the utility stock leaders brought declines throughout the list on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, with domestic and foreign bonds sharing in the selling. German bond issues were particularly depressed, including German Municipals 6s and 7s, Commerz-und-Privat Bank 5 1/3s, Central Bank for German State and Municipal Banks 6s, Saxon Public Works 5s and United Industries 6 1/2s.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 18 -- To reach her 16-months-old son, Richard, after he had fallen from a fourstory window this afternoon, Mrs. Rose Meyers of 263 Broadway ran down two flights of steps to the second floor and then leaped out of a hall window fifteen feet to the ground.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Arthur Thurnblad of Chicago opened the defense of his world three-cushion billiard title tonight by defeating Bud Westhus of St. Louis, Southern sectional champion, 50 to 32, in sixtyfiv'e innings. The champion had a high run of seven, to four for Westhus.

MUKDEN, Jan. 18 -- The independence movement in Manchuria, judged from conversations with Chinese and from the local press, is gaining impetus and is now gradually including one or more of the three districts roughly described as Inner Mongolia.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Profit-taking by professionals on the basis of last week's rapid advances affected the stock market today at the start, and when a reaction failed to overcome these sales, general selling swept the market. Failure of the international negotiations to reach any accord on reparations was one of the chief causes to which the pessimism was attributed, for until today Bourse circles had been hopeful that some early solution would be obtained.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 18 -- Dr. Harold G. Wilcox, aged 42, descendant of an old and prominent family here, was found dead in his garage last night. He had been asphyxiated by carbon monoxide gas. Dr. John A. Clarke, medical examiner, pronounced his death an accident.

WARSAW, Jan. 18 -- For some time it has been persistently rumored that the Polish Government is embarking on a new policy toward the Ukrainians, and that far-reaching concessions will be granted to achieve permanent and loyal Polish-Ukrainian cooperation in East Galicia.

With savage and just contempt does Senator SMOOT characterize the swollen appendix of the Congressional Record, which thereby belies its title and becomes an omnium gatherum, an endless mishmash of exterior irrelevancies. Members of Congress "extend" their remarks.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 -- Government quarters today ignored Adolf Hitler's memorial to Chancellor Bruening explaining his refusal to support the prolongation of President von Hindenburg's term by act of the Reichstag.

Competition in railway freight container service, which has already caused patent litigation between the systems used by the New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads, has brought two more rival systems into the field. These systems are backed respectively by Thomas A. Bradley, president of the Acme Fast Freight Service, Inc., and by Elihu Church, former transportation engineer of the Port of New York Authority.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Revocation of a permit under which the Westchester Lighting Company is constructing an overhead high tension power line through Westchester County for the Niagara Hudson Power Company until the Public Service Commission has decided whether such a line should be built was urged upon the Department of Public Works today by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors.

LAKE PLACID, Jan. 18 -- "Rain, rain, go away," which had become more of a prayer than a nursery rhyme in the minds of residents and Olympic athletes here, was answered today by a promising snowstorm and a lowering temperature.

Why is a large majority of the student youth of Germany lined up behind ADOLF HITLER? There are a number of explanations, but the principal answer is to be found in a single phrase from HITLER'S speech of last Sunday before the Fascist student organizations.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 18 -- The first 1932 racing venture of Mrs. R. Pollard's Uluniu resulted in a surprising victory in the feature six-furlong Tallahassee Claiming Handicap at Hialeah, Park today. The 6-year-old gelding was the outsider in a field of four, but won easily by three lengths at 9 to 1.

Copyright, 1932. NANA, Inc. HONOLULU, Jan. 18 -- When a stranger on these shores strives to gain enlightenment concerning Honolulu's present situation, he soon becomes aware that he is an offislander. A clannish mystery, a courteous wall of silence and reserve, lies between him and the old-time residents.

MUKDEN, Jan. 18 -- The Japanese headquarters today announced an increased number of engagements with Chinese irregulars over the week-end, indicative of the Japanese determination to eliminate the irregulars at the earliest possible date with methods consistent to that end.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A complete list of the bank stock holdings which Andrew W. Mellon sold prior to becoming Secretary of the Treasury was requested today by the House Judiciary Committee which is hearing impeachment charges made by Representative Patman of Texas.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 18 -- Initiating its ninth season, the Society of Arts of Palm Beach will give its first and only open concert of the Winter on the evening of Feb. 1 at the Paramount Theatre. Heretofore, two open and three closed musicales have been the schedule.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Wheat traders ignored bearish news today and bought as though there never would be another chance to get grain so cheaply as at present. At no time today were prices on the Board of Trade here as low as at the finish on Saturday, persistent buying by commission houses in small lots sufficing to keep the pit situation tight most of the time.

MADRID, Jan. 18 -- Socialists and Communists of Bilbao presented a united front today as they stormed the jail to free three Communists who had been held in connection with yesterday's battle in which four Socialists and republicans were killed by Catholic Nationalist Basques.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Although the date has not yet been definitely fixed for the Lausanne conference and there is a possibility it may not be held at all, the British delegates are basing their plans for their departure to Switzerland on the assumption that the sessions will begin on Jan. 25.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted.

Butter. Receipts, 6.979 packages. The market held unchanged on all grades at the opening yesterday but the tone gained firmness towart the close and the market wound up with a much more confident feeling in evidence. Offerings were less liberal and trade was taking hold in better shape.
Arrangements have been made for the sale of the membership of Robert Plaut in the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange to Walter D. Stuart for $4,000.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 18 (AP) -- The 100-year old Hudson River Navigation Corporation, operating an Albany-New York night line, whose steamers have been popular for many generations, filed a petition in bankruptcy today in Federal Court at Utica.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Opposition to the application of the Niagara Falls Power Company, a Niagara-Hudson subsidiary, to amend its license for use of water from the Niagara River to develop electric power was expressed today by Governor Roosevelt in a letter to the Federal Power Commission, read at an open hearing.

Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and restoration of the government tax on liquor would yield a return, of $1,500,000,000 yearly and would permit abolition of the present personal income tax together with a substantial reduction of State and local taxes, Professor Edwin R.A. Seligman of Columbia University said in a speech last night.

Three Negroes, each suspected of being George Crawford, the chauffeur sought by the authorities of Loudoun County, Va., for the murders of Mrs. Agnes Boeing Ilsley, wealthy sportswoman, and her maid, at Middleburg, Va., five days ago, were picked up by the police in or near New York yesterday.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Revelation of a widespread conspiracy to collect automobile insurance on accidents that existed only in police reports, by an asserted conspirator who told the police he had been mutilated to provide evidence of injury and confessed because he feared further mutilation, resulted in a roundup here tonight that netted at the outset one woman and seven men, one a physician.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Greater New York's milk supply is an important necessity, and yet the Board of Health and the other authorities are allowing the source of supply to be strangled out of existence by the competition of dealers, who pass the cut in price to dairymen, who are producing the milk at a loss.

The Yale Club's squash tennis team captured the Group A title in Class C of the Metropolitan. League championship series last night through its 4-3 victory over the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club players on the latter's courts. The Eli players completed their schedule with a total of nine victories and only a single defeat, Crescent finishing second with seven victories and three defeats.

The story of a plot to "plant" narcotics on a crippled man, to discredit him Friday at the trial of his $100,000 damage suit in Supreme Court, was told in West Side Court yesterday at the arraignment of John L. Rice of Springfield Gardens, Queens, a private detective, on a charge of conspiracy.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius will sail Thursday on the Monarch of Bermuda and will be at her home in Bermuda for the rest of the Winter. She will be accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. William C. Stettinius of Baltimore.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Police Chief Andrew Coleman obtained a warrant today for the arrest of Maxwell A. Cox, missing former vice president of the Irvington Trust Company, revealing that a shortage of more than $10,000 of the bank's funds had been discovered.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 18 -- "Taxes must come down, the burden of governmental costs must be lightened and budgets must be balanced," said E.C. Grace, president of Bethlehem Steel Corporation, at the opening of the three-day annual sales meeting of all the Bethlehem companies here today.

Deems Taylor's opera after Du Maurier and Constance Collier, "Peter Ibbetson," was given its eleventh performance by the Metropolitan Opera Company, its seventeenth performance on any stage, and its first performance this season last night in the lyric theatre on Broadway.

Money market was without feature so far as variations in quotations and business volume were concerned. All sections resumed trading at quotations which ruled at the close of last week. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent, and this figure prevailed in the Street trading, while Federal funds were 1 34 a 2.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- A Polish inventor named Dunikowski, who claims the ability to make gold from sand, today was the centre of violent legal debates in the Ecole Centrale, where the inventor was preparing for a demonstration of his mysterious machine.
Winning six of the eight events, the Fordham swimming team scored a 45-to-26 victory over Manhattan in the Fordham pool yesterday. The visitors won the fancy dive and the 200-yard relay.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick Marsh Gordon, executive secretary of the Brooklyn Federation of Churches, died suddenly last night in the Brooklyn Methodist Hospital, where he had undergone an operation for a stomach ailment on Sunday. His death occurred on the eleventh anniversary of his election to the federation's board at its organisation in 1921.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Two important steps were taken in Congress today to expedite measures aimed to strengthen the credit structure. At the same time a Senate subcommittee was approving a bill calling for an outlay of $375,000,000 to provide Federal assistance to the unemployed through the States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Continuing their slashing reduction program inaugurated with the first deficiency bill, which cut about $14,000,000 from the budget estimate of $139,000,000, the House Appropriations Committee today reported the agricultural bill for 1933 with $10,799,591 lopped from the estimated requirement of $186,243,405.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- Coast Guards scored heavily against rum runners again early today in a series of brushes in Boston and vicinity which resulted in the seizure of two rum running speed boats, the capture of three men and confiscation of liquor valued at close to $225,000.

An increase from the previous year in net income from investments and sales of securities is reported by the General Public Service Corporation for the year ended on Dec. 31. The net, after interest, amortization and all other charges, and including $337,027 profit on sales of securities, was $322,580, against $196,316 in 1930, including $104,225 profit on sales of securities.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Dick Morris, a 4-year-old from the Knebelkamp and Morris Stable, and C.V. Whitney's Angry shared honors at Jefferson Park today.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- The hockey squad which will represent the United States in the Winter Olympic competition at Lake Placid next month was selected today. Fourteen players, members of the New YorkBoston team that defeated Yale and the University of Minnesota in the elimination series, were named.

Indecision on the Stock Exchange yesterday reflected the prevailing uncertainty in Wall Street. Trading was slower than on Friday, the last five-hour day, and it was evident that reactionary influences were at work. This was particularly true of the last hour, when the results of a mid-day rally were lost and losses substituted in many sections of the list.

The musical comedy which arrived at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre last night flying the Shubert house flag possesses three or four good tunes, an abundance of dancing and the valuable presence of Queenie Smith, for more than two years a stranger to the Manhattan footlights.

Both the foreign and domestic bond groups were irregularly lower on the Stock Exchange yesterday, and trading continued to slow up on the decline. Transactions amounted so $14,335,000, or more than $1,100,000 under Friday's total. United States Government bonds, however, resisted the decline better than the other groups.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Amateur boxing would be exempted, once and for all, from the provisions of the State boxing law under a bill introduced tonight in the Legislature by Assemblyman Joseph T. Higgins, New York, Democrat, and former Intercollegiate champion middle-distance runner.

Across our political stage several fantastic or freakish, public characters are marching. They are always to be looked for in times like these. Father Cox of Pittsburgh is the type corresponding to "General" COXEY of forty years ago. What this priest, who led an orderly cavalcade of the unemployed to Washington last week, now proposes, or threatens, is the formation of a Party of the Jobless," of which be may himself be the Presidential candidate.

Robert Gleckler, who recently appeared in "Louder, Please!" has joined the cast of the Ziegfeld show featuring Bert Lahr, which is now in rehearsal. Besides Mr. Lahr and Mr. Gleckler, the company will include Charles (Buddy) Rogers, Lynne Overman, Conchita Montenegro, Marjorie White, June McCloy, June Knight, Jack Holland, Tony and Rene DeMarco, the G Sisters, the Hernandez Trio and Tito Coral.

The expected reaction in prices for stocks and bonds, not having occurred at the week-end, put in its appearance yesterday. It was not of large dimensions in either branch of the market, and occasioned little comment. The grain markets attracted more attention; for the upward movement, which made some considerable progress on Saturday, was carried further yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The report gained currency in London's underworld tonight that Eddie Guerin, famous for his escape from Devil's Island, had died here over the weekend. Officers of Scotland Yard heard the rumor and set a number of inquiries afoot, but at an early hour had been unable to locate Guerin in any of his usual haunts or obtain definite reports of his death from his former associates.

The National Council of American Shipbuilders favors a policy of Federal aid to shipping, spread over a period in a manner that would encourage ship operators to build up their fleets according to a definite system rather than on a hit-or-miss schedule, according to H. Gerrish Smith, president.

Archbishop Pietro Fumasoni-Biondi of Washington, Apostolic Delegate from Vatican City in the United States, said last evening at a reception, in the Hotel Plaza given for him by the National Catholic Converts League of New York, that it seemed to him men were showing more energy and resourcefulness in dealing with the depression.

The admirable conduct of the people of Honolulu during the last ten days is a model for any community of mixed races under a threat of peril. The steps being taken to reform the police administration seem adequate to prevent a recurrence of the lax methods on which the assassination of the native in the Massie case is blamed.

Birds in This January Ornithologists are taking note of the large number of Purple grackles that have so far spent the Winter in this vicinity. According to FRANK M. CHAPMAN, this grackle migrates late, but is gone, as a rule, before December is far advanced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Possibility of the appointment of Benjamin N. Cardozo, Chief Judge of the New York Court of Appeals, to succeed Oliver Wendell Holmes as Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court was seen here today because of the seeming difficulty of obtaining confirmation by the Senate of any appointee not known to have liberal views.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 18 -- Sam Parker of Kalamazoo, Mich., and W.H. Fawcett of Breezy Point, Minn., Class B gunners, each tallied 196 to lead the scoring in the introductory shoot of 200 targets at sixteen yards today, the opening competition in the twenty-fifth annual midwinter tournament of the Pinehurst Gun Club.

Nathan Milstein, violinist; Benno Moiseiwitsch, pianist, and the English Singers were the artists at the fourth concert of the Beethoven Association in the Town Hall last night. Mr. Milatein and Mr. Moiseiwitsch played Beethoven's Sonata in G, Opus 30, No. 3, and the Cesar Franck Sonata, while the singers presented two characteristic groups, the first including madrigals, a ballet and a canzonet and the second made up of folksongs.

Major German De Freest Larner, securities salesman and sportsman, won an enviable reputation as an American ace in the World War as a member of the Lafayette Escadrille and the United States Air Service. He enlisted while a student at Columbia University.

Seven, charities were named among the beneficiaries of the will of Alfretta H. Gardner of 230 Central Park West, who died on Dec. 25. The will was filed for probate in the Surrogate's court yesterday.

Retail Problems Before Convention. The opening session of the twenty-first annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania Feb. 1 to 5, will be devoted to a broad view of the major problems now confronting retailers.

BILBAO, Spain, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Three thousand Communists began a general strike today by storming the jail In an attempt to lynch forty-one Catholic prisoners. Artillerymen and police held them at bay. Other demonstrators attempted to destroy the Sacred Heart of Jesus monument, but were prevented by police.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Forty-nine one-pound shells and 500 machine-gun bullets fired from a Coast Guard patrol boat, stopped the flight of the forty-five-foot power boat Imp in Delaware Bay near Ship John Light early today and intercepted a liquor cargo valued at $25,000, which was being taken up the bay.

Charging that some real estate bonds distributed to small investors were based on over-optimistic and unsound ideas of values, George E. Roosevelt of Roosevelt Son, a member of the recently formed Greater New York Real Estate Bondholders Committee, said yesterday the result had been the collapse of some of the houses of issue, such as G.L. Miller Co., the American Bond and Mortgage Company, and the K.H. Smith Company.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The Bourse was Irregular today, tendencies alternating throughout an animated session. Closing figures registered declines, but in no case were they equal to those which occurred yesterday. Shares of the Bank of France were down 85 francs, Suez Canal 120 and Rio Tinto Copper 65.

Selection of June 20 for the annual regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association at Poughkeepsie and a major change in the lanes for the racing were the most important matters transacted yesterday at the annual meeting in this city of the board of stewards of the association.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19 -- Pravda confirms today the reports which have been circulating to the effect that a shortage of metals and other materials in Soviet factories, caused by non-delivery by plants where they were ordered, has been seriously hampering production and in some cases stopping work altogether at intervals.

A new plan under which the Patino Mines and Enterprises, Consolidated, would acquire not less than 90 per cent of the stock, or in lieu thereof all the assets of the Sociedad Empresa de Estano de Araca, will be presented to Patino's stockholders at their annual meeting on April 12.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- With the resolution to continue the Hofstadter committee for another year pushed through the Senate at a turbulent session, final approval by the Legislature within a week appeared today to be assured.

A widespread desire among the people of the United States for the substitution of law for war has been expressed by many who have written or telegraphed their sentiments to Dr. Mary E. Woolley, president of Mount Holyoke College, since her appointment by President Hoover as delegate to the Geneva disarmament conference.

Merchandise to suit the wants of consumers as to quality and fashion, honestly advertised and priced at levels which customers can afford to pay, will get results in 1932. Dr. Paul H. Nystrom. Professor of Marketing, Columbia University, told executives of member stores attending the Spring, 1932, fashion forecast session of the Mutual Buying Syndicate at 11 West Forty-second Street, yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Cornell's basketball team, beaten eight times in its ten previous starts, scored a surprising 28-to-26 victory over a strong Syracuse five tonight. The Ithacans forced the pace throughout the game.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- A sweeping legislative investigation of the milk situation throughout the State was recommended by Governor Roosevelt's special agricultural advisory commission after it had listened to scores of producers and distributers voice their complaints and protests at a public hearing in the Executive Chamber.

For the first time since 1923, more than three figures were found necessary to determine the batting championship of the International League for the 1931 season, according to the official averages which were released yesterday and which gave the honors to Ike Boone of the Newark Bears.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19 -- Mike Brady of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Jim Noonan of Chicago were defeated, 3 and 2, today, by Jim Dante of Madison, N.J., and Eddie Schultz of Troy, N.Y., in the first round of the professional four-ball tournament on the Miami Country Club course.

A passenger whose name was not on the list of the Lloyd Sabaudo liner Conte Biancamano when that vessel arrived yesterday from Mediterranean ports, was her Highness the Maharani Sharmishthabi Holkar, who was Miss Nancy Miller of Seattle before her marriage four.

Instead of solving a crime, the writer of detective stories is compelled to plan a crime in "Whistling in the Dark," which was played at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre last evening. With Ernest Truex appearing as the master mind of a mob of gunmen, the result is a cheerful evening of well-planned fooling before the footlights.

The election of Francis S. Harmon, Mississippi newspaper editor and lawyer, as general secretary of the International Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association, was announced last night at a meeting of the committee in the Union League Club. Mr. Harmon succeeds Dr. John R. Mott, who resigned last Summer after seventeen years of service.
VIENNA, Jan. 19 -- Archduke Leopold Salvator was the innocent cause of a series of challenges to duels last night arising from an incident in Charly's Bar, Vienna's latest fashionable night resort.
Two more jewel robberies in the Park Avenue district were revealed yesterday by the police, bringing the number within the last month to four.

If the recommendations made by Governor MOORE in his inaugural address yesterday are followed by the New Jersey Legislature, the words "Jersey economy" may come to rank with "Jersey justice" as symbolizing something rapid and efficient.

A vigorous attack upon the proposed consolidation into four or five trunk line systems of the railroads serving New York from the South and the Northwest was made yesterday by Professor T.W. Van Metre of Columbia University and C.J. Fagg, traffic manager of the Newark Chamber of Commerce.

Retailers were the only group to show a decline in bankruptcies for the week ended Jan. 14, the total for which increased 3.6-per cent over the previous week, Bradstreet's reported yesterday. Store insolvencies totaled 535, as compared with 547 in the previous week.

Scoring a clean sweep over the visiting University Club, the Yale Club Class B squash racquets team took undisputed possession of second place in the New York group of the Metropolitan League last night, breaking the deadlock with Harvard, which was idle.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, Miss Amey Aldrich and Miss Elizabeth Morrow have gone to Boca Grande, Fla., to remain a few weeks.

Dudley Field Malone, recently named general counsel and governing director of the Association of Dress Manufacturers, Inc., put forward a proposal last night for a general lockout by contractors, if necessary, as a means of stabilizing the garment industry.
The Canadians of Montreal flashed the hockey style which enabled them earn the world's championship for the past two years in defeating the New York Rangers last night.

Lucrezia Bori, Spanish prima donna of the Metropolitan, and Goeta Ljungberg, the Swedish soprano, who will make her American debut with the company this evening, were announced last night as having placed their activities outside of opera in the care of the Columbia Concerts Corporation for a term of years.

TOKYO, Jan. 19 -- United States Ambassador W. Cameron Forbes will leave Japan in six weeks. The prospect of his being succeeded by Joseph C. Grew, a career diplomat who may be expected to stay for a reasonably long term, is welcomed by Americans here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No group of people feels more keenly the death of Julius Rosenwald than the Negro. Since 1910, when Booker T. Washington became his friend, some of Mr. Rosenwald's most notable gifts were made to raise the status of the American Negro.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We, the members of the Women's Welsh Club, feel keenly the loss of our chaplain, Mrs. Susannah E. Pech, and would like to express our appreciation of a rare character. Her remarkable career began at an early age in Wales.
The city's financial straits were temporarily eased yesterday by a $12,500,000 bank loan at 6 per cent maturing on Feb. 1.

William H. Truesdale has retired as chairman of the board of managers of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad. The board acted formally on his retirement toward the close of the year, but this did not become generally known at the time.

Joe Jacobs, manager of Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight champion, announced yesterday he expected to appear before the State Athletic Commission on Friday with signed contracts for a fifteen-round bout between Schmeling and Jack Sharkey, to be held at the Yankee Stadium under the direction of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, probably on June 16.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- Premier Laval's speech in the French Chamber, reiterating his views of reparations and the peace treaties, has caused considerable irritation in German political circles, where it is felt that neither the world depression nor the report of the Basic experts has been able to bring about a change in the traditional tenor of French governmental statements.

A protest against the employments of Diego Rivera, Mexican artist, and Jose Maria "Sert, Spanish artist, to paint murals for buildings in Radio City will be made to John D. Rockefeller Jr. by a class of fifty art students in the New School for Social Research.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A nonpartisan program for tax increases, embodying measures suggested by Republicans and Democrats alike, worked out on the general framework of the recommendations of Secretary Mellon, was disclosed today to be the aim of the Ways and Means Committee, which is holding Hearings on the new revenue bill.

Buyers in the Market Increases Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday, although showing an increase over the figures for the previous week, remained well behind the total reached in the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Wheat at no time today went as high as Monday's finish. Scattered commission house and local selling at the start on the Board of Trade here disclosed a lack of the aggressive Eastern buying of the two previous days and the price dropped 1 cent a bushel before support was encountered.

HELSINGFORS, Jan. 19 -- The Finnish Diet met in special session today to act on the bill repealing prohibition, drawn up by the Cabinet since the announcement of the complete count two weeks ago showed an overwhelming victory for the wets in the consultative referendum.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Eight men and a woman, whose operations were described by Assistant Prosecutor Nicholas O. Beery as "one of the most monstrous attempts to defraud insurance companies ever perpetrated in New Jersey," were held by Judge Frederick B. Conant in police court today.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The advisability of cuts in governmental salaries in the interest of a lower budget was discussed at length at a meeting of the executive committee of the Republican State Committee today, held to discuss a legislative program, but the committee failed to act on the question, partly because an impression prevailed that President Hoover was opposed to such re-, ductions.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I feel that the article by Edouard Herriot which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 16 should not be left without a reply.

Choosing Kenlon's Successor. After considerable delay, a new Fire Chief is about to be selected to succeed JOHN KENLON. There are twenty-four applicants for the position, which is one of the most important in the city to be filled by civil service examination.

The death of magazines, the starvation thinness of those surviving and the uncertainty of book sales have for most writers changed what was the business of writing into a too expensive luxury, Mrs. Inez Haynes Irwin, president of the Authors' League of America, said yesterday at the twelfth annual luncheon of the National Association, of Book Publishers.

Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter Committee, sent new charges against Sheriff Thomas M. Farley to Governor Roosevelt yesterday, after the Appellate Division in Brooklyn had decided that State Senator John A.. Hastings had no legal excuse for refusing to obey a subpoena of the committee.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 -- Excavations on the ancient site of the city of Jericho have resulted in the discovery of a number of dated tombs containing an unparalleled quantity of fine pottery and other objects.
Mrs. Alice Huntington Marshall, wife of Charles H. Marshall of this city, and sister of Mrs. Vincent Astor, has been in Reno several days.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Liquidation of hogs continues and the run in the West today was heavier than had been expected. Continued unfavorable weather is reducing the consumption of pork and affecting the market. The market early today was steady to 10 cents lower than yesterday, but the finish was heavy, with prices 10 to 15 cents lower.

Union Settlement Group Takes Over Performance of "Berlin." Several dinners will be given before the performance in the George M. Cohan Theatre of "Berlin" tonight. The show has been taken over by members of the Women's Auxiliary of Union Settlement in aid of the organization.

After a visit to the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, one was almost inclined to rush home and unpack one's golf clubs, for a ball room of the hotel was filled with lawn mowers, tractors, shredders, fairway rollers, sprinklers and all the other implements that are in use when the playing season is in full sway.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- Replying to the statement of the President's Committee of Nine that the financial plight of the railroads requires the $250,000,000 proposed wage reduction, spokesmen for the twenty-one standard railway unions today asked the carriers to explain simply and clearly why the employes should grant such a request.

The bankers have agreed to help the city meet its immediate needs, leaving the rest to further discussion. That sufficient progress should have been made in the negotiations of the past few days to bring about this result is an outcome for which the entire community has good reason to be grateful.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Opposition to a proposal to prohibit short selling on the cotton and grain exchanges was voiced to the House Committee on Agriculture today by representatives of the traders and the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, speaking for more than 2,500 business organizations.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Having taken a birdseye view of Asia, Will Rogers reached Paris tonight by air; "And believe me," he said, "a birdseye view is all one wants to take of most of Asia."

Capacity to pay, whether as conception or phrase, used to occur solely in connection with Germany's ability to pay reparations. We now encounter the idea and the words with reference to the ability of the allied governments to pay war debts. For Germany the meaning of "capacity" has changed considerably since HITLER substituted won't pay for can't pay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President and Mrs. Hoover were guests of honor at dinner tonight of the Secretary of State and Mrs. Stimson, who entertained at Woodley, their home in Cathedral Avenue, a distinguished company including the Chief Justice and Mrs. Charles Evans Hughes, Theodore Roosevelt, newly appointed Governor General of the Philippines, and Mrs. Roosevelt, and Robert Woods Bliss, Ambassador to Argentina, and Mrs. Bliss.

An "All Star Benefit Performance," directed by S.L. Rothafel, (Roxy) for American, British and Canadian men in this country who served with the British forces in the World War, will be held on Tuesday evening, Feb. 2, at the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of the Canadian Club of New York, according to an announcement yesterday.

Mr. GIBSON'S words to the men of the Y.M.C.A. suggest a need of something to supplement what mere relief can give to those who for the first time in their lives find it impossible to get a job -- or who, having had that experience last year, find their spirit failing in the dread of another period of idleness.

Members of the Association to Promote Proper Housing for Girls, at their annual conference yesterday at the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, were told that President Hoover's home-building program should focus on "largescale congregate housing" as well as single-family houses; that college dormitories for girls are used as "laboratories for developing social techniques," and that girls in the association's clubhouses in some cases "cannot afford to eat" this year.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- The German export surplus for December dropped to about $59,000,000, against $95,000,000 in the record month of October. Imports increased and exports declined in December, compared with November, filling business circles with apprehension that the development of Germany's foreign trade in 1932 will not justify the hopes of foreign creditors who seek to liquidate their credits with money accruing from German exports.

Had the Brooklyn Museum called its large exhibition, which opened yesterday, "Paintings by American Impressionists," and let it go at that, consternation on the part of the public might well have run up a fever. By adding "and other artists of the period, 1880 -- 1900," this calamitous result was forestalled.

William A. Prendergast, former chairman of the Public Service Commission and a former Controller of the City of New York, returned yesterday from a six weeks' holiday in Spain on board the Conte Biancamano of the Lloyd Sabaudo Line. He found Spain politically quiet on the surface, and thought the people were very intelligent and polite to strangers.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 19 -- Winning all eight classes of competition, the Harvard varsity, wrestling team defeated Brown, 28 to 0, tonight.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Thirteen Progressive members of the State Senate bolted the sessions today and announced that they would return "whenever the Stalwart majority is ready to enact a relief bill for any reasonable amount of money, provided it imposes the burden where it belongs."

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 19 -- The 1932 golf season here was inaugurated today when Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., turned, in a par 72 on St. Augustine links to win the qualifying medal in the annual Florida East Coast championship, leading the field by a margin of six strokes.

The right of Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator, to seize the fixtures and furnishings of a speakeasy the moment he raids it was upheld yesterday by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson, in a ruling on a petition filed Dec. 22 by the raided Stork Club of 132 West Fiftyeighth Street for an injunction to prevent such seizure.

To the Editor of The New York Times. After reading, with pleasure and pride, Dr. Hibben's account of his twenty years' stewardship as president of Princeton, I turned to the appendix. This records the "Faculty Publications" of one short but stirring year.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19 -- Pearls as big as dove's eggs and perfectly formed; bracelets, studded with jade, turquoise and emeralds; a crown and breast-plates of gold, exquisitely worked, and other priceless objects found in the fifteenth century tomb at Monte Alban, constitute the greatest archaeological treasure ever discovered on the American Continent, in the opinion of Alfonso X. Caso, Mexican archaeologist, who directed the work.
SENATE. Passed urgent deficiency bill. Senator Borah introduced bill to cut Federal salaries.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- American importers of radio apparatus and interested French dealers have been making intense but vain efforts for the last few days to obtain modification or even further clarification of the French decree limiting imports of American sets to a small quota far below the present figures.

Paul Kochanski gave his only New York recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. His program began with Bach's concerto in A minor, the Concerto, Opus 35, by Szymanowski, who, like Mr. Kochanski, is Polish; and two groups of shorter pieces by Pergolesi-Stravinsky, Scriabine, Ravel, DeFalla, Desplanes, Boccherini and Paganini.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19 -- The Camfire colt Arras, a double "winner at Tropical Park, again carried the colors of Mrs. H. De True to victory when he won a bitter duel from Hibala in the feature Shenandoah purse today at Hialeah Park.

Behind the accurate shooting of Grady, who tallied nineteen points, the Horace Mann School basketball team shaded the Trinity School five, 33 to 32, yesterday on the Trinity court in an overtime contest.

Twelve cases containing rifles, machine guns, pistols and ammunition seized from insurgents in the battle of Gibari, in Cuba last October, arrived yesterday at the Federal Building, where George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, is investigating an alleged attempt by revolutionists to ship arms to Cuba.

The Charity Ball, an annual event in society for seven and a half decades was held last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. It was the seventy-fifth ball and like its predecessors in the series that began in the old Academy of Music before the Civil "War, it was given for the benefit of the New York Nursery and Child's Hospital.

Advocates of a proposal to change the zoning of the residential district of Murray Hill, about which a fight has been waged for a generation, received support yesterday from Commissioner John F. Sullivan of the Department of City Planning. Commissioner Sullivan sent a petition to the Board of Estimate recommending that Lexington Avenue between Thirty-fourth and Thirty-eighth Streets be changed from a residential to a retail business zone.

After having fallen four stories, broken through a skylight and landed on a pile of books in the rear of a bookshop at 15 Ann Street, shortly before noon yesterday, Julius Diamond, 37 years old, a painter, was treated by an ambulance surgeon for contusions of the leg and sent home without any further injury.

Following are the items, totaling $14,233,157, deferred to specified dates on the Committee of the Whole calendar. Those receiving favorable reports, it is expected, will eventually go to the suspense calendar.

PARIS, Jan. 19 -- In very definite terms, despite their envelopment in somewhat obscure language, Premier Laval set forth today in his Ministerial declaration the policy of his reconstructed Cabinet before the Chamber of Deputies on what France wants with regard to reparations, cancellation of war debts and arms limitation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Charging the Walker Administration with dangerous extravagance, Senator Samuel H; Hofstadter and Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat, Republicans, of New York City, offered companion bills in the Legislature today to authorize reopening of the city budget to permit a sharp downward revision.

What Alabama did for Senator UNDERWOOD in the Democratic National Convention of 1924, Ohio is not to do for her Governor in 1932. Alabama's chairman kept calling "Twenty-four votes for OSCAR W. UNDERWOOD" until the cows -- or JOHN W. DAVIS -- came home.

Baseball, in the opinion, of the experts who feel and minister to the nation's sporting pulse, still ranks as the No. 1 American game, despite the obvious inroads on its popularity by the rapid development of football and golf.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Seeking to establish a basis of factual information for probable future legislation on transportation and communication, the House today ordered a sweeping investigation by the Interstate Commerce Committee into the ownership and control of all utilities except the railroads.

Preservation, of Stratford Hall, birthplace of General Robert K. Lee in Virginia, as a national shrine and historical museum was assured yesterday with the announcement that the remaining $115,000 mortgage on the 1,100-acre estate had been paid off by the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Outlining his plan for a drastic reorganization of the State Government inhis inaugural message today, Governor A. Harry Moore advocated the abolition of more than thirty-five commissions and the consolidation of more than one hundred departments, commissions and bureaus into twelve departments.

The money market was quiet and firm throughout. Virtually little business was transacted in any section, demand being poor in all sections. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 2 1/2 per cent, which also prevailed outside. Time money ranged 3 1/2 @ 3 1/2 per cent. Commercial paper and acceptances were at a standstill.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,193,450 barrels, compared with 2,234,200 in the previous week, a decrease of 40,750 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production east of California averaged 1,684,450 barrels daily, against 1,728,600 barrels.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Sterling weakened further in the foreign exchange market today, the New York rate falling to $3.44 3/4, which caused British Government funds to continue dull.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 19(AP) -- The Argentine Government imposed emergency taxes on incomes, property and business today in one of the most drastic steps of Argentina's financial history. The taxes were imposed to balance the country's budget, put its finances on a permanently sound basis and silence talk of a moratorium.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19 -- The first of a series of recitais was given this afternoon at Mirador, the home of Mrs. William Seward Webb, by the New York String Quartet, which appears in programs of chamber music each season at the homes of prominent colonists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Members of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee who oppose the provisions of the House bill dealing with the bonds and debentures of the $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation, believe that these securities will find a ready market under ordinary conditions and that the treasury will not be called upon, as provided in the Senate bill, to support the issues except in unusual situations.
LIMA, Peru, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A strong earthquake shook Lima tonight, terrorizing the inhabitants, cracking the walls of buildings and plunging the city into darkness.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 (AP) -- O. K. Allen, running for Governor with the backing of Huey P. Long, incumbent, was 40,000 votes ahead of the opposition field on unofficial and incomplete returns at midnight in today's Democratic primary election.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- General Charles Gates Dawes, former Vice President, first director of the Federal budget, author of the Dawes Plan for German reparations payments and Chicago banker, will be president of the $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation, President Hoover announced today.

MANILA. Jan. 19 -- President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Senate issued his first statement today concerning the appointment of Theodore Roosevelt as Governor of the Philippines, pledging support and cooperation "in everything that will promote the welfare and happiness of the Fllipino people."

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- For the first time in the history of the automobile, the per capita death rate in motor accidents declined during 1931 in the United States, the National Safety Council said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Otto Re selt of Philadelphia defeated J.N. Bozeman of Vallejo, Cal., 50 to 42 in his first start in the world's championship three-cushion billiard tour nament today. The match laste fifty-six innings.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 19 -- A. Harry Moore, Democrat, was inaugurated Governor of New Jersey here today, six years after his previous induction as the State's chief executive. It was the first time in forty-two years that a former Governor had been inaugurated for a second time, and more than 50,000 jubilant Democrats from all over the State took part in the ceremonies.

The Bronx Zoo is one institution in the city that has not suffered from the depression. The Aquarium has, a little. The figures for the year just passed show that 2,937,373 persons went to look at the animals, and 2,453,806 paid a visit to the fish. The one is a record breaker, being an increase over 1930 by 14,181; the other is a decline of about 69,000.

The annual dinner dance of the Kentuckians in New York will be givan, on Friday night in the ballroom of the Plaza. The guests of honor will be Albert Benjamin Chandler, Lieutenant Governor of Kentucky; Miss Susan Davis Buckner, George Gordon Battle, Dr. Fielding Lewis Taylor and Fred T. Bonham.

The Dungaree Club went out of existence last night when detectives from the West 152d Street Precinct raided its headquarters, a shabby ten-by-twelve-foot but of rough boards, under the Cascade Swimming Pool in 131st Street between Riverside Drive and Broadway.

The United States and International Securities Corporation has become the owner of 110,000 shares of the United Light and Power Company's class B voting stock, obtaining a voting interest of about 10.3 per cent in the $600,000,000 utility system.

HONOLULU, Jan. 19 -- Montgomery Winn, counsel for the four defendants accused of the murder of Joe Kahahawaii following an attack on Mrs. Thomas H. Massie, said today that unless the prosecution moved to obtain an indictment when the grand jury meets tomorrow he would invoke habeas corpus proceedings to obtain their release.

Aside from an occasional rally in the railway shares, there was little in yesterday's stock market to interest Wall Street. Business on the Stock Exchange was at low ebb, approximating 1,100,000 shares, and the trading was colorless. There was less tension in the stock-loan market, but this did not encourage speculation for the fall.

Prices moved in. a narrow range on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, large number of the leading issues closing unchanged on the day. Trading was at a low ebb, with no dealings in some issues which are usually active.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 19 -- John D. Cosgrove, a contractor, was elected first vice president of the First National Bank of Glen Cove at the organization meeting this afternoon to fill the vacancy made by the resignation of Mayor James E. Burns.

The Cathedral Boys' High School quintet, undefeated pace-setters in the Manhattan division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball tourney, gained its sixth consecutive triumph by vanquishing All Hallows Institute, 18 to 11, yesterday at the East Fifty-fourth Street gymnasium.

The Board of Higher Education at a meeting last night virtually stripped itself of administrative control over the city's three institutions of higher learning -- the College of the City of New York and Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Retroactive repeal of the recapture provisions of the interstate commerce act, under which more than $300,000,000 in excess railroad earnings is due the government, was urged by Commissioner Joseph B. Eastman today, with a view to relieving the credit predicament of the railroads.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- On the heels of a statement in the House this afternoon that President Hoover is not opposed to Federal salary reductions, movements began in both houses of Congress to cut salaries in every branch of the government service.

A British tariif, Iower than the present anti-dumping duties imposed on manufactured imports, which would tend to stimulate the exchange of goods with other nations and restore the balance of trade, was forecast yesterday by Gerald Campbell, British Consul General, in greeting more than 100 business men, public officials and journalists as his guests at a luncheon in the Canadian Club at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Both spot and future commodities were lower yesterday, particular, weakness being shown in eggs, and rubber, both of which dropped to new low prices for the year to date. Losses elsewhere included the grains, lard, tin, cotton and silk in the cash line, while reaction in futures was found in coffee, rubber, hides and silk.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 19 -- A massive gate tower, dating from the Early Iron Age, built partly of limestone and bearing a strong resemblance to the Israelitish masonry recently revealed at Samaria, was among the finds resulting from the four months of excavations on the site of the ancient city of Beth Shan.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- A victim of two automobile accidents on New Year's Day in New Rochelle which caused injuries at first believed trivial, Mrs. Madeleine de Sylvia Holden, civic leader in Mamaroneck and wife of Henry D. Holden, police justice of that village, died today in United Hospital, to which she had been removed Jan. 6.

Eleven years ago Mr. FREDERICK E. MURPHY, a successful farmer just become publisher of The Minneapolis Tribune, came to his office resolved to put into practice certain ideas which had grown up in his mind from a three years' vacation on a grain farm.

The two indictments against Samuel S. Leibowitz, Brooklyn lawyer, which arose out of the police vice squad trials last Summer, were dismissed yesterday by County Judge Martin in Brooklyn for lack of proper corroboration. The indictments charged subornation of perjury, which is a felony, and conspiracy to obstruct justice, a misdemeanor.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 -- Once the world's fastest human runner, Charley Paddock, who has been training for several months in hopes of staging a comeback by landing a place on the American Olympic team, today found himself barred from amateur competition.
MADRID, Jan. 19 -- The closing of Jesuit institutions throughout Spain, together with the seizure of all churches, schools and other property of the order is expected hourly.

The Bank of France has arranged to repatriate $125,000,000 of gold which it holds under earmark in the vaults of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The transfer, which is to be made in ten shipments of about $12,500,000 each, will not involve any increase in the gold holdings of the French central bank nor any decrease in the monetary gold stocks of this country, which amounted on last Wednesday to $4,457,000,000.

The newly refurbished Recital Theatre in West Sixty-third Street opened its doors last night with dance recital by Grace Cornell in which she exhibited eight dances composed by Rudolph von Laban the first work of von Laban to be seen in this country.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange continued irregularly lower yesterday on a turnover of only $10,571,500, which was the smallest full day's business for the year to date. The bonds of no single group moved in unison. Only one of the isssues of the United States Government list showed a gain for the day, this amounting to 4-32 point.

Blame for the present economic plight of the United States, in so far as the blame can be determined, rests upon all Americans and not upon any particular person or group, Calvin Coolidge declares in an article to be published today in the American Magazine.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 19 -- Harvard defeated Brown 44 to 27, in the dual varsity swimming meet in the Crimson gym tonight. The Crimson captain. Benton S. Wood of Honolulu, was shifted to the 300-yard free style and he defeated William Lewis of Brown by a shade to feature the meeting.

Disturbed by "persistent and widespread" reports that the $20,000,000 voted by the city for unemployment relief may be reduced as part of the general retrenchment program to cope with the city's financial difficulties, a group of leaders of major welfare agencies addressed a statement yesterday to Mayor Walker, the Board of Estimate and the citizens of New York protesting against such reduction.

In seeking to further two causes near his heart, President HOOVER has changed the personal plans of two men. General DAWES is not to go as chairman of the American delegation at the Disarmament Conference. This is because of his selection as head of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- General agreement on a bill to establish a State banking board seemed probable tonight as changes were being drafted to meet criticism of the measure in the form in which it passed the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Increases in employment of 0.7 per cent and in payrolls totals 0.3 per cent in fifteen industrial groups during December over November, 1931, were shown in the monthly employment report issued today by the Labor Department, based on returns by 49,841 establishments, which employed 4,572,588 workers in December, with combined earnings in one week of $101,655,164.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Fearing heavy demands on the depleted State treasury for special emergency projects, the Republican leaders made known today that they were making definite efforts toward final adjournment of the Legislature by March 10. They are demanding quick action on all bills and calling for steady committee work.

NANKING, China, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Severance of diplomatic relations with Japan is imminent as a result of the Japanese occupation of Manchuria, the official Chinese news agency, Kuomin, announced tonight.

The general trend of the markets was reactionary yesterday, but the changes were not of great importance. The stock market, in fact, gave some early signs of resuming the recent rise, and even the later downward movement did not cancel all of the preceding gains. In the bond market, prices generally went lower, but with great irregularity and with the usual meaningless distribution of declines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Administration financial experts informed the Republican conferees on the Reconstruction Finance Corporation bill, as Senate and House conferees began their sessions this afternoon, that President Hoover was opposed to making the bonds of the corporation eligible for rediscount by the Federal Reserve Banks.
TORONTO, Jan. 19 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs routed the New York Americans tonight and hung up a new National Hockey League record for the season thus far by scoring 11 goals to the Americans' 3.

Four police horses and their riders, the radical squad and forty patrolmen on foot balked an attempt by 200 Communists, or "left wing," fur workers at 5:30 P.M. yesterday to break up a meeting of right-wing fur workers in Bryant Hall, in Sixth Avenue between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets.
Leaving their training ground in the snow-covered Alps thousands of miles behind, the members of the Italian Olympic team arrived yesterday to participate in the Winter games at Lake Placid.

An airplane, guided by a pilot enclosed in a darkened cockpit, landed safely yesterday afternoon at Newark Airport under oral directions from another pilot who sat beside a set of dual emergency controls in the regular pilot's seat.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 19 -- A brilliant exhibition of shooting by Robert O'Connell in the second half enabled the Yale quintet to defeat Penn tonight. 23 to 22, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game.

The business of bringing the New York Giants into the fold for the 1932 season, which threatened to be quite a task about a week ago, continued to move briskly yesterday, with Secretary Jim Tierney announcing that the signed contracts of two more players had been received.

Sir WILLIAM ROTHENSTEIN, principal of the Royal College of Art, artist, author and educator, made the presidential address at the twentieth annual conference of educational associations in London. In his speech, as reported by The London Times, he said that "it was a deadly "thing that all the talents should "be drawn to London and that Lon"don should be so attractive in con"sequence."

Having advanced more than $2 a bale within a week, prices on the Cotton Exchange developed a slightly easier tendency yesterday and closed with losses of 4 to 6 points. Buying for trade and speculative account was less active, while the higher price level attracted scattered selling from producing sections.

The success of the recent efforts of Canadian Provinces and municipalities in marketing new bond issues in the home market was emphasized yesterday by the announcement of the Dominion Securities Corporation, as head of the Canadian syndicate that offered on Jan. 6 $5,062,000 of New Brunswick 5 1/2 per cent debentures, due Nov. 1, 1952, that the issue had been oversubscribed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A cabled denial from President Enrique Olaya Herrera of Colombia that he had ever discussed with Secretary Mellon the Barco oil concession, which has figured in the last four days in the impeachment hearings brought before the House Judiciary Committee by Representative Patman of Texas, was read to the committee this morning by Alexander W. Gregg, counsel for Mr. Mellon.

GENEVA, Jan. 19 -- The economic committee of the League of Nations ended its regular session here today with a report in which it announced its despair of trade sanity until the financial crisis is solved.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 19 -- The discovery by the United States of the necessity for government supervision of foreign loans comes too late, according to El Tiempo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Walter E. Edge, American Ambassador in Paris, was authorized by the State Department today to tell Premier Laval that the initiative with respect to intergovernmental debts should be taken by Europe, and the United States intends to make no move in the situation, at least not before Europe has taken some step.

On the application of George Eilperin, attorney for Morris Grossman, suspended Chief of Police of Long Beach, Judge Clarence G. Galston in the Federal court in Brooklyn dismissed yesterday the indictment charging Grossman with conspiracy to violate the national prohibition law through the landing of cargoes of liquor at the seaside resort.

THE bankers of this country from time to time have been called into conference and have given information or advice on international debt problems, the balancing of the national budget and the arranging of municipal loans. But a great financial field has been totally neglected.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The approaching disarmament conference will have too many complicated problems to reach quick results, in the opinion of Professor Gilbert Murray of Oxford University, one of the leaders of the disarmament movement in Britain.

Mischa Elman has refused to appear as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next Sunday and Jan. 31 as agreed in a contract made with his managers, the Metropolitan Musical Bureau, it became known yesterday.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A 4,000-pound whale-shark, rare deep sea fish, has been harpooned and towed to dock here.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Fearing "riots and disorders" might result, Frederick Von Nieda, chairman of the Citizens Protest League, canceled today a taxpayers' march on City Hall called for tomorrow, when the City Commission will consider the 1932 budget, to protest against a tax rate increase it would impose.

Andy Cohen, who came to the Giants in 1928 to replace Rogers Hornsby in John McGraw's infield only to drift back to the minors after a couple of seasons because a leg injury slowed him up perceptibly, was the leading second baseman in fielding in the International League for the season of 1931, according to the official averages released yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Red tape was cut and machinery set in motion today on a scale for which there is no recent precedent in the annals of the Legislature to bring financial aid to New York City through the enactment of a bill enabling the city to engage in short-term borrowing to the amount of $200,000,000.

PEIPING, Jan. 20 -- Even the Peiping-Tientsin area today affords striking evidence of the degree to which the Kuomintang party has lost the confidence of the people. Students, labor unions and other elements are openly denunciatory of the Kuomintang in Peiping and Tientsin, while in Shansi Province students have established a "People's Tribunal," which now is presuming to try Kuomintang officials for alleged misdemeanors.

Speaking at the annual meeting of the British Empire Chamber of Commerce, at which he was re-elected president, R.R. Appleby said there is "unquestionably a more hopeful feeling in trade circles in England," citing the business sites being purchased by foreign concerns.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Still holding a faint hope that the Assembly will not follow the lead of the Senate in approving continuance of the Hofstadter committee for another year, the Democratic legislative leaders fired a new broadside at the inquiry today.

Sidney R. Kent, for many years vice president and general distribution manager for the ParamountFamous Players-Lasky Corporation, has resigned, it was announced officially yesterday. No reason was given. There had been rumors for some time that he would take this step.

When Premier LAVAL assured the Chamber of Deputies, "We shall not "permit the right of reparations to "be taken, away," it was seemingly another instance of that rigid French legelism which outsiders find puzzling and irritating. What good does it do to insist on a "right" which has been rendered obsolete by events?

Two convicts who escaped from a Federal prison van on the Brooklyn Bridge, jumped over a railing into William Street, twenty feet below, and were on their way to Williamsburg in a taxicab were captured by the police late yesterday afternoon before the deputy marshals in charge of the van were aware of the escape.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial published in your edi- tion of Monday, Jan. 18, under the title "Colombia and Oil," compels me to request the publication of a brief statement.

In a curtain speech last night at the John Golden Theatre, Billy Bryant, impresario and leading actor of Billy Bryant's Show Boat Troupe, which for some thirty years has been plying up and down the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers, was nothing if not frank.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- New Jersey manufacturing industries in 1929 operated 8,388 establishments and because of the high rate of activity that year had a total output valued at $3,937,156,775, according to the biennial census of manufactures for that State issued today by the Department of Commerce.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Prices of hogs dropped 10 to 25 cents today to a new low since 1899, the general average being down to $3.85 a hundred-weight, compared with $4 yesterday. Pigs again led the decline and were quoted 25 to 50 cents lower, although the poor quality had something to do with the drastic decline.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 20 (AP) -- James N. Crofton, president of the Agua Caliente Jockey Club announced today the posting of a $10,000 purse for a match race here Feb. 21 among Phar Lap, Australian wonder horse; Marine, Canadian champion; Dr. Freeland and possibly Plucky Play, two of the best in the United States, for "the international championship."
