More than 4,000 persons who use the two trolley lines crossing the Williamsburg Bridge will be forced to use other means of travel this morning because of an order issued by the Transit Commission yesterday discontinuing the service of the lines at midnight last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- A belief that by evading the application of the States' rights idea to the Eighteenth Amendment the Democratic party might win the Presidential campaign this year, but would "lose both elections and respect thereafter," was expressed today by John M. Hemphill, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania in 1930, at a victory campaign committee dinner here tonight attended by nearly 500 Pennsylvania party leaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The charge that certain railways waste money by their practice of buying supplies chiefly from concerns which favor them in shipping was made today by William P. Bartel and J.L. Rogers, examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission, in a report to the commission.

Nine men and three women were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of homicide growing out of two slayings there last year. Three of the men and one woman were accused of participating in a speakeasy shooting in which a man was slain for $4, and the others were charged with the slaying of a grocery manager during a hold-up in which nothing was realized.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A reduction in the Federal payroll, with members of Congress leading the way by slashing their own salaries, is confidently predicted by some members of Congress, although the White House has served notice that President Hoover will make no specific recommendations for a blanket decrease.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not out of order to call upon the business men and various organizations to actively discourage any indiscriminate effort to remove married women from business, on the flimsy plea that such women are taking the places of more deserving single women.

Miguel Covarrubias, whose satire has brought him considerable fame, reveals at the Valentine Gallery his recent discoveries in Bali, one of the enchanted islands of the East Indian group. These paintings no doubt contain elements of satire, but Covarrubias seems to have been principally interested in plastic problems, spiced with tropical manners.

A campaign for the removal of surface cars on Madison and Fourth Avenues and the substitution of bus service was started yesterday at a luncheon of interested property owners, civic leaders and merchants held in the Hotel Roosevelt under the auspices of the Fifth Avenue Association.

Juvenile delinquents under the age of 16 are decreasing in number in this city, according to figures made public yesterday by Presiding Justice Franklin G. Hoyt of the Children's Court. It also was shown by the report that despite the depression and consequent suffering, only a few more cases of neglect of children had been reported than in more prosperous years.

Negotiations for the resumption of interest payments on equipment trust certificates of the Wabash Railway were disclosed yesterday by Evans, Stillman Co., security dealers and members of the New York Stock Exchange. They announced that they would seek to prevent the payment of $350,000 interest due on Feb. 1 on the road's second mortgage 5 per cent bonds if interest due on the equipment trust certificates was not met.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20 -- Without recommendation for mercy, Euel Lee, 60-year-old Negro, was convicted of the murder of Green K. Davis today after the jury had deliberated thirty-four minutes. The trial had aroused much public interest.

OAXACA CITY, Mexico, Jan. 20 -- The Monte Alban tomb in which priceless treasure and the remains of six Mixtec warriors were discovered recently is now closed, everything of archaeological value having been removed.

Increased selling pressure caused a further drop yesterday of 10 points or more in prices on the Cotton Exchange. This setback, making in all a decline of a quarter cent from the high levels of the week, steadied the market and limited the losses at the close to 4 to 7 points.

William J. Flynn, Public Works Commissioner of the Bronx, was accused in an injunction suit yesterday of exerting the influence of his office to get a $100,000 contract on the new $7,000,000 county building for his political friends, Sheriff Robert L. Moran of the Bronx and Edward J. Chapman, formerly an assistant district attorney, who are partners in the United Sand and Gravel Co., 349 East 149th Street.
Training for Blind Flight. Growing emphasis, both here and abroad, is laid on ability to fly airplanes "blind," or by instruments alone. This way lies the conquest of fog and poor visibility.

BOMBAY, Jan. 20 (AP) -- A hundred thousand persons are expected to assemble illegally tomorrow to voice their protests at the arrest of Mahatma Gandhi and Great Britain's stifling of the civil disobedience movement.

China finds it difficult to break off relations with Japan over Manchuria because of two principal factors in the situation. First, China permitted herself to become entangled in a web of world politics. Secondly, Japan, by treaty, is in possession of concessions, leased territories, railway zones and other rights and advantages which cannot effectively be revoked by the mere severance of diplomatic relations.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Taxpayers here marched on City Hall this afternoon to demand a $175,000 reduction in the $1,063,850 budget, already reduced by $25,568 below the original estimate. To accommodate the clamoring citizens, the City Commissioners were forced to move their meeting to larger quarters in the municipal pier.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 -- Establishment by every local real estate board in the nation of a housing committee to put into effect the recommendations of President Hoover's Conference on Home Building and Home Ownership was urged today by Edward A. MacDougall, president of the Queensboro Corporation of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- More than fifty lawyers have been recommended to President Hoover as qualified to succeed to the place on the bench of the Supreme Court of the United States vacated by the retirement of Associate Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes.

Several thousand peace workers, representing virtually all of the organizations whose major objective is to end war and many others that include peace work among their aims, took part yesterday in observing the departure for Geneva of Dr. Mary E. Woolley and United States Senator Claude A. Swanson of the United States delegation to the disarmament conference.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 20 -- The police of the International Settlement here was mobilized tonight as a precautionary measure following a Japanese attack upon a Chinese towel factory as an act of revenge against an attack by Chinese factory workers upon five Japanese monks a few days ago.

George Gershwin's Second Rhapsody will be played for the first time anywhere by the Boston Symphony Orchestra on Jan. 29 and 30, with Serge Koussevitzky conducting, and will be performed for the first time in New York by the same orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Feb. 5.

A 32-year-old Russian refugee, Mrs. Tatiana Kouteynikoff, who escaped into Istanbul with some of the straggling remnants of the White Army after the Russian revolution, and who was reputedly the daughter of a Russian Consul General to Turkey, was mysteriously killed by a shot last night in her five-room, apartment at 68 Lenox Avenue.

The undefeated Barnard School for Boys basketball team vanquished Woodycrest School, 28 to 17, for its fourth victory in the Barnard gymnasium yesterday. At the half, Barnard led, 19 to 3. Maurice O'Brien of Barnard made 16 points.

Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes, president of the directors of the Lots for Little Shop, reported at a recent meeting that owing to a successful year the organization had been able to contribute substantially to the Cardinal Gibbons Institute in Ridge, Md.; the Society of Catholic Medical Missionaries, the Helpers of the Holy Souls and the Barat Settlement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I take the liberty of writing you about a matter of public concern, since I know that you and your paper are the medium of fair and fearless expression of public opinion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read William D. Guthrie's argument in THE New YORK TIMES of Jan. 10, in which he proposes a substitute for the Eighteenth Amendment. Section 1 of his proposal reads: " * * * and any such shipment or transportation of intoxicating liquors into a State in violation of its laws, whether by the postal service or otherwise, is prohibited."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20 -- So far as horse racing in Maryland is concerned, the depression is over, because nine more 3-year-old thoroughbreds and eight additional owners are represented in the nominations for the 1932 renewal of the $50,000 Preakness Stakes, which will be run on May 14 at Pimlico, the home of the Maryland Jockey Club.

Even though this may serve only to intensify the points of argument among the country's sports experts, the fact is they have voted golf as the sport requiring the most skill as well as involving the most luck. Baseball is next on each count.
The Manhattan five overwhelmed Cathedral College, 39 -- 24, at the Manhattan gymnasium last night. It was the seventh victory of the season for the Jaspers.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 20 -- Maryland University, Southern Conference basketball champions, fittingly observed the dedication of the $200,000 Ritchie Coliseum at College Park tonight, defeating the Navy's quintet, 26 -- 15, before a crowd of 4,500 that jammed the big structure to the doors.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- An enormous disarmament petition, bearing 2,123,629 British signatures, was bundled into an express van today on the first stage of its journey to Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Income tax collections for the first six months of the current fiscal year were only $615,307,000, a decrease of $492,005,000 as compared with the collections for the same period in the previous year. Of the grand total the corporation income tax was $378,660,000, a decrease of $225,584,000, and the individual income tax $236,647,000, a drop of $266,420,000.

Jack Seaman and Harold Seiler of the Trinity Club, a seeded pair, survived the second round in the Metropolitan A.A.U. one-wall handball doubles championship at the Downtown A.C. last night. They defeated George Cahn and Frank Neubert, Twenty-third Street Y.M.C.A.

BOGOTA, Jan. 17 -- The term "rustic nationalism" is applied in an editorial in El Tiempo to the proposal of the Municipal Council of Medellin, capital of the State of Antioquia, to double the tax on sound film in any language other than Spanish.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Wholesale prices declined nearly 3 per cent in December under November and were 15 per cent less than for December, 1930, according to a survey made public today by the Labor Department covering 550 commodities.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20 (AP) -- After failing to win a race since 1930, Ironsides, a 7-year-old son of Man o' War from the Sophia Lee Stable, finally found a field he could beat when he led a band of sprinters home in the feature Clem McCarthy Purse today.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Francis CrowJey will die in the electric chair in Sing Sing prison late tomorrow night. Warden Lawes, who has been confined to his house with an injured wrist caused by a fall, is not expected to witness the execution, but will probably be present in the prison, officials said.

Although the Erasmus Hall High School hockey team was held to a scoreless tie by New Utrecht, the former gained a deadlock with Jamaica for the P.S.A.L. leadership at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. In the other contest, Brooklyn Tech upset Boys High, 1 to 0.

Pleas for world peace through resistance to war and by cooperation to assure a successful outcome of the Geneva disarmament conference, as well as recommendations for the alleviation of distress caused by present economic conditions, were made in addresses and reports heard yesterday by more than 1,000 women at the twelfth annual convention of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, Inc., in the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Samuel Insull Jr., chairman of the executive committee of Middle West Utilities Company, said tonight that the company earned approximately 90 cents a share on the common stock in 1931. He did not release the company's formal report for the year, but based on the 15,704,966 shares outstanding in December, the indicated net profit for the year available for the common stock was $14,134,069.

Reciprocity in tariff matters among the nations of the world is necessary to the expansion of the foreign trade of all nations, R. Grimm-Provence, Trade Commissioner of the French Embassy, declared last night in an address before the Foreign Commerce Club of New York at the Hotel Astor.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Investigation by Nicholas O. Berry, assistant prosecutor, and the Passaic police into the widespread conspiracy to defraud insurance companies on spurious accident claims spread today to Bergen County and resulted in four additional arrests, pressed by protests from agencies and motorists over announced increases in casualty insurance rates.

Butter. Receipts, 15,904 packages. Top grades held steady yesterday, with asking prices fully sustained in spite of only fair trading. After the call extras were difficult to find at 23 1/2 c, with most lines of full 92 score held at 1/4 @ 1/2 c premium. Buyers were not taking hold freely, however, and supplies were liberal.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- An intensive merchandising and advertising campaign in 1932 can cause a strong resumption of buying by the 40,000,000 gainfully employed in this country, was urged today by Gilbert T. Hodges, president of the Advertising Federation of America, in an address before the advertising council of the Association of Commerce.

The need for additional hospital facilities on the west aide of Manhattan to keep pace with the business and residential growth of that area was emphasized yesterday by physicians and others who addressed the luncheon club of the West Side Association of Commerce at the Hotel New Yorker.

The same controversies which led to the disruption of the intercoastal shipping conference a year ago marked a public hearing on the Johnson bill yesterday in the assembly rooms of the Merchants Association under the auspices of the Maritime and Transportation Committees of that body.

A nation which came through the difficult year 1931 with a favorable balance of trade amounting to $706,000,000 might seem to be in a fortunate position. In Germany's case, however, there are several factors which detract from the significance of this figure, reported in the dispatches from Berlin.

With the renewed conviction that the old game of whist will never die, members of the Atlantic Whist Association opened their thirty-fourth annual session with a duplicate whist game last night at the Sherman Square Hotel, Broadway and Seventy-first Street.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Will Rogers flew to London, today from Paris and this evening went to Southampton to meet Mrs. Rogers, who is aboard the liner Bremen, arriving tomorrow morning. Inquiries about his plans seemed premature today.

War between the United States and Japan is inevitable, in the belief of the Japanese, with the result that they are bending every effort to make ready for it, according to an article in this week's issue of Liberty magazine by General William Mitchcll.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Governor A. Harry Moore warned today that if the Republican majority in the Senate sought to block his tax relief program he would "campaign in every town and hamlet in New Jersey and tell the electorate what politicians are interfering and why."

A drive on the part of officials in all Federal departments to enforce the prohibition law in New York as it has seldom been enforced was planned here yesterday following the decision on Tuesday of Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson permitting Federal agents to seize and remove all furnishings and equipments used in connection with the sale of liquor.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight champion, faces the possibility of losing the title without throwing a glove.

BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- Professor Ernst Wagemann, head of the Federal Bureau of Statistics, has surprised gov- ernmental and financial circles with the publication of a program for a comprehensive reform of the German currency and credit system along Anglo-American lines.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- The Campbell bill, which writes off earnings for last year in determining railroad bonds as legal investments for savings banks, was passed today in the Assembly without a dissenting vote, after being amended to make it apply specifically to 1931.

Branch Cabell, who as James Cabell reported fires and police news in Harlem and the Bronx twenty-five years ago, and as James Branch Cabell wrote his many-volumed work about Poictesme, writes that James Branch Cabell never mado either of the widely publicized statements that "The Way of Ecben," published in 1929.

Charles (Vannie) Higgins, self-styled lobster fisherman, of 7,420 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, and eleven other defendants, all that remained of the eighteen persons named in the indictment, were acquitted yesterday by a jury before Judge Clarence G. Galston in United States District Court in Brooklyn of conspiracy to violate the national prohibition law.

The Musicians' Emergency Aid, of which Walter Damrosch is chairman, will begin today active solicitation of contributions for relief of unemployment distress in the world of music. A fund of $300,000 is sought. More than 200 men and women prominent in musical and society circles will serve as canvassers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Secretary Stimson declined today to permit a public review of the Barco oil concession by the Senate Finance Committee, reiterating the State Department's stand in one verbal and two written communications.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The railroad presidents' committee of nine tomorrow will present their complete case for a 10 per cent wage reduction for one year to the committee of the brotherhoods with whom they have been negotiating since Friday.

A campaign to raise $150,000 to provide jobs for the unemployed of Westchester County, chiefly the "white collar" type of workers, will be started immediately by the emergency employment committee of the Westchester County Children's Association, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon of the committee at the Uptown Club, 60 East Forty-second Street.

The holdout situation in the ranks of the Giants became relieved considerably yesterday. Secretary Jim Tierney announced he had received the signed contract of Freddy Lindsttrom, brilliant infielder and outfielder, who only a few days ago had declared himself dissatisfied with the terms that had been offered to him.

A.E. Fitkin, for many years well known as a public utility operator in Eastern and Western States, acquired yesterday control of the $70,000,000 American Gas and Power Company from the receivers for the American Commonwealths Power Corporation. The purchased company owns gas companies serving Minneapolis, Birmingham, Bangor, Jacksonville, St. Augustine and other important cities.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 20 -- A complete slate pledged to Alfred E. Smith for the Democratic Presidential nomination is to be filed with the Secretary of State within a short time, it was learned today. As the result of conferences with friends of Mr. Smith, steps have been taken to list a strong group of candidates who would support him at the national convention.

The Columbia University Club Class A squash tennis team, unbeaten this season in the Metropolitan League, had some very uncomfortable moments in its match with the Princeton Club last night on the former's courts, in spite of the fact that the latter was turned back 4 to 1.

The circus is fading from the American scene, said Signor Pompeo Luigi Coppini, the sculptor, as he brushed away a tear yesterday in an alcove dining room at the Hotel Roosevelt, where the Circus Fans of America were munching goobers after a hearty luncheon.

HONOLULU, Jan. 20 -- The bill creating a chief of police in Honolulu on Feb. 1 as a means of police reform to combat the crime wave passed the final reading in the House of Representatives and first reading in the Senate today.

Several trust companies and title companies held their annual meetings of stockholders yesterday and announced changes in personnel or took action on other matters. Among the former companies were the Guaranty Trust, the Irving Trust, the Chemical Bank and Trust and the Fulton Trust.

Bishop William T. Manning, speaking yesterday afternoon at the dedication of the new $185,000 Seabury Hall of the General Theological Seminary, called upon all the churches in the city to rally to the support of Samuel Seabury, counsel for the Hofstadter legislative committee.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Fahnestock, who were at the Savoy-Plaza, have gone to St. Augustine, Fla., to remain for three months.

A late rally wiped out most of the earlier losses on the New York Curb Exchange's stock list yesterday, and many leading issues closed with gains. The volume of trading, which agged during the greater part of the day, picked up perceptibly, with the day's total somewhat better than on Tuesday.

MADRID, Jan. 20 -- While the government remained reticent today about its plans for liquidation of the Jesuit order in Spain, charges of murder and violent epithets were hurled back and forth by Socialist and Catholic Deputies in the Cortes.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20 -- Favored to sweep through the Canadian covered courts tennis championship to his fourth straight title, George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago, America's second ranking player, almost caught a tartar today in a second-round match with William Thompson of Portland, Ore.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The beginning of economic recovery in this country next Spring was forecast tonight by Silas Strawn, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in an address over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Attorneys representing more than 1,800 residents of this village, among them owners of historic sites and writers and others with esttaes here, prepared today to file twenty-five suits for injunction to restrain the village trustees from advertising their properties for tax sales in a move o break a "tax strike" waged by the villagers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade here was dull and declining today until about fifteen minutes before the close. Then early sellers found little grain offered when they tried to cover, and prices rushed up 1 1/8 to 1 1/2 cents from the lows.

A number of debutantes active in the arrangements for the forthcoming supper dance for the benefit of the Blue Ridge Industrial School of Virginia, which will take place on Jan. 29 at the Plaza, will meet tomorrow afternoon at the home of Miss Betty Page to complete plans for a ping-pong tournament, one of the divertissements of the benefit.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Arrows tonight jumped into third place in the Canadian-American Hockey League by defeating the Bronx Tigers, 4 to 2.

While crossing Amsterdam Avenue midway between 105th and 106th Streets late last night, an unidentified woman about 55 years old stepped from behind an automobile into the path of a south-bound taxicab and was killed.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Eleven ski experts, only one of whom represented the United States in a previous Olympic Winter Carnival, were named today to carry the Stars and Stripes in the international snow-time sports here Feb. 4 to 13.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Susan Glaspell, author of last year's Pulitzer Prize play, Alison's House," received a tribute as one of America's outstanding women writers at a reception given in her honor at the American Woman's Club here this afternoon.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 20 Clarkson Tech captured tonight's hockey game from Yale, 4 to 3, through a spirited second-period rally which netted four swiftly scored goals, after the visitors had been held scoreless through an opening stanza in which the Elis scored twice.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 20 -- Reorganization of the University of Wisconsin's athletic department took concrete form today as the board of regents made changes in personnel and the State Legislature set forth its views on athletic policies.
PARIS, Jan. 20 -- What cannot be described as otherwise than a grave situation has been created in Paris by developments today in the situation affecting reparations and war debts.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 20 -- A baffled Police Department tonight continued its search for Benjamin P. Bower, baking company executive, kidnapped last night by two slim, sallow-faced men who are holding him for $50,000 ransom.

DETROIT, Jan. 20 -- Harold Fontaine, accused of supplying pistols and dynamite to the convicts who revolted at Leavenworth Federal prison in December, surrendered to the Windsor (Ont.) police today on another charge. Three convicts were killed and Warden Thomas B. White was seriously wounded in the outbreak.

Revival of interest in Italian art of the seventeenth century was made manifest in the Hartford Athena- eum's 1930 exhibition of "Southern Baroque Art." Now we have, newly opened, another splendid show of Italian art of the same period, at the Durlacher Gallery, 670 Fifth Avenue.

Dr. Jose Manuel Puig Casauranc, Ambassador of Mexico to the United States, speaking yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor by the Pan American Society at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, warned against "blind economic exploitation," declaring that it was high time to apply the principles of social ethics in economic intercourse.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- After yesterday's Cabinet declaration and the unanimity of the Chamber of Deputies in supporting Premier Laval's insistence on reparations, the Bourse tone improved considerably today. There were increased exchanges at the opening and brisk trading at the close, so that the gains in most instances counter-balanced all of yesterday's losses and part of the declines which occurred on Monday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- There has been no further mention in the Soviet press or in official circles of the proposed non-aggression pact with Japan since the announcement or the proposal last Saturday.

The majority of economists of New York State think prohibition is economically unsound and believe repeal would be beneficial, Dr. Lewis H. Haney, head of the Bureau of Business Research of New York University, declared yesterday afternoon before the Anti-Prohibition Institute of the New York State Division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform at the Hotel Commodore.

The increase in unrealized depreciation in the portfolio of the Sterling Securities Corporation during 1931 was restricted to $1,036,931, or from $13,528,630 at the end of 1930 to $14,565,561 at the end of 1931, according to the annual report made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Criticism of President Hoover's action in announcing the appointment of General Charles G. Dawes as president of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and Eugene Meyer as chairman of the board in advance of passage of the bill creating the corporation was expressed today by Democratic Senators, who professed to see a political motive in appointing two Republicans as executive heads of the $2,000,000,000 corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Ways and Means Committee by unanimous vote refused today to give the administration's recommendation for an increase in the postal rates a place in the non-partisan program of upward revision of taxes.

The city's safe emergence from its financial troubles became a matter of only a few hours yesterday when thirty-four leading banks agreed, on the strength of a Board of Estimate commitment of the Walker Administration to a strict economy and retrenchment policy, to make available during the year a total of $350,000,000, if necessary, for the financing of the city's outstanding obligations and the carrying out of its revised administrative program.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 21 -- Preferring the hazards of an election to a session wherein he would come under heavy fire on an issue appealing to the sentimental patriotism of the Japanese, Premier Inukai, it is believed, will dissolve the Diet today as soon as the chief government speeches have been made and before the Opposition has been heard.

An arrangement whereby the savings banks of the State will assist one another by taking over mortgages of any bank upon which unusual demands are made, is described by Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank, in his annual report to trustees of that institution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Hawaiian controversy was again brought to the floor of the Senate today when Senator Copeland of New York read into the record a petition from an American Legion post urging the correction of gangster and other bad conditions alleged to exist in the city of Honolulu.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 20 -- Yale defeated Wesleyan in swimming tonight, 53 to 18, and created three intercollegiate records in meter measurements, in the 200 and 500 free-style distances and 100-meters breast-stroke events never run off before in intercollegiate meets.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted.

THE boys on skates say that Cecil Dillon of the Rangers is the flashiest first-year man since Howie Morenz, the flying Frenchman, came darting over the frozen horizon. The thin youngster with the rapid-fire shinny stick enjoys another distinction. He is one of the few big league hockey players born this side of the border.

Led by Dotzauer, right forward, who registered fourteen points on five floor goals and four penalty shots, the Poly Prep basketball team vanquished the Marquand School five, 22 -- 16, yesterday on the Poly Prep floor. The victory was the fifth in seven games for the winners.
WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Federal Judge J.P. Nields appointed today William A. Laner of New York and A.F. Crichton of Wilmington receivers for the Hamilton Gas Corporation of New York.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 20 -- More than 300 prominent Palm Beach colonists attended the dinner dance with which the Colony Club opened its season tonight. Dancing took place in the patio, around which tables, adorned with flowers, were placed for dinner.

What, no music? No dancing? All the other ingredients for a hokum musical show are present or accounted for in John McDermott's "Adam Had Two Sons," which lasted about two hours at the Alvin last evening. Down on the torrid Canal Zone the squalls of passion are the prevailing winds.

A handicap of Alaska has been what a former Governor called "climatic fallacies." There still obtains a belief that the Territory is too remote to be visited by people of the continental United States, that the country is savage and the inhabitants are crude and unlettered.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- The full text of the Dunnigan-Steingut bill follows:

MUKDEN, Jan. 20 -- As a result of the ruthless campaign against Chinese irregulars, taking a toll in recent weeks of almost a thousand lives, the Japanese army headquarters here reports it is receiving tentative overtures of "cooperation" from leaders of the irregulars.

Mayor WALKER has perceived that he cannot ignore the tides, or sweep back the seas with a broom. The resolution adopted at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate brings the City Administration, for the first time, face to face with realities.

The Anglers Club of the city of New York met last evening to eat chicken a la Maryland and to discuss the state of the fish that got away. There were eighty-seven members present in the grill room of the Hotel Plaza, but the number did not include Mr. Calvin Coolidge of Northampton.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding fell $28,245,355 in December and amounted at the close of last year to $974,059,350, which was not only the smallest volume for any month's end in the year but the lowest reported figure since August, 1928.

Mayor Walker is expected to offer a vigorous defense of his administration, especially with regard to the city's present financial difficulties, tonight at Tammany Hall's annual victory dinner, in the Hotel Commodore. The dinner, which will be attended by more than 1,500, has been arranged by the Tammany Speakers Bureau.

A brilliant victory by Ernest Drosdick of the Newark A.C. in the National A.A.U. junior 100-yard free style swimming championship, and excellent performances by Raymond Ruddy of the New York A.C. and Robert West of Princeton University in invitation events, featured the monthly open water carnival in the 25-yard Mercury Foot pool last night.

OAXACA CITY, Mexico, Jan. 20 -- For days we had been excavating at Monte Alban, the ancient fortress-city, now a mountain of ruins, near his city in Southern Mexico. At last our picks and shovels uncovered the entrance to the ancient Mixtec Indian tomb that was to prove so interesting and rich in treasure and archaeological evidences.

MADISON, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Colonel William Aiken Starrett, builder of skyscrapers and president of Starrett Brothers Eken, Inc., general contractors, of New York, was dangerously ill today at his Midwood Terrace home here.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- All-round strength prevailed on the Stock Exchange today. British Government funds, encouraged by the flood of income-tax payments, made substantial gains, the war loan advancing 5/8 to u98 1/4 and the funding loan rising 3/4 to u86 5/8.

The Winter issue of The Bridge, literary publication of Evander Childs High School, the Bronx, has just been published. There are a number of articles, essays and stories in the magazine, which is entered in the Columbia Scholastic Press Association's annual competition.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- Peculier cabalistic marks, carved on the scalp of Norman R. Bechtel, an insurance accountant and Mennonite church worker, 31 years old, who was found dying on a Germantown estate early today led the police tonight to believe his murderer was a homicidal maniac.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Three Federal judges today heard argument in the district court here on a question involving the value of property of hundreds of settlers who went into the northwestern district of Colorado on an alleged understanding that a railroad would be constructed through their territory.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- A new and long air-train route was inaugurated today when a giant Imperial Airways machine took off from Croydon on an 8,000-mile flight to Cape Town, carrying three passengers, 20,000 letters and 150 parcels.

After giving a perfunctory performance in the first three or four hours of trading, the stock market came to life with such suddenness in the late dealings yesterday as to lift Wall Street out of its lethargy. There were spirited advances in leading issues on the Stock Exchange, including particularly American Telephone, United States Steel, Santa Fe, Auburn, Union Pacific, Southern Pacific, J.I. Case, Eastman, New York Central and a number of others.

The new set of by-laws which were adopted by the Board of Higher Education Tuesday night will relieve the board as a whole of much of the administrative detail in connection with the city's three institutions of higher learning -- the College of the City of New York and Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges -- but will not curtail the powers of the board in any way, educational leaders said yesterday in commenting on the change.

Luigi Raffa was convicted last evening before Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn in the Bronx of murder in the first degree in the arson-death of Earl Spencer Fox of Syracuse, N.Y., whose murder was described by the authorities as one of the most cunning and atrocious crimes in the criminal history of the city.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Flashing the same form that carried him to ten titles, Johnny Layton of Sedalia. Mo., conquered J.N. Bozeman of Vallejo, Cal., 50 to 41 in the world's three-cushion billiard championship today for his second triumph.
BOSTON, Jan. 20 -- After winning six straight games, the Harvard varsity sextet was beaten for the third time this season, losing to the Boston Hockey Club by 6 -- 3 tonight.

We know all about "sales resistance." It was fully explained by innumerable lecturers and "go-getters" to enthusiastic classes of young bond salesmen two and three years ago. Elaborate and ingenious devices to overcome it were added to their equipment in approaching "prospects," or victims.

A large percentage of the ever-increasing number of disabled persons can find gainful employment if employers can be educated to the fact that the disabled person generally makes a safer and more dependable worker than the normal person. Frederic G. Elton, district director of the rehabilitation bureau of the New York State Educational Department, told the annual meeting of the Shut-In Society yesterday at the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 - Dr. James T. Shotwell of New York declared today that the Kellogg Pact must be reconsidered, revised and completed, and the work of harmonizing it with the League of Nations Covenant in the Pact of Paris must be accomplished in order to form a real, world-wide organization of peace" and afford all nations a "sure alternative for armaments."

The electrical industry in the United States received an income in excess of $613,052,000 from the sale of appliances in 1931 and served 20,441,249 wired homes, according to the report of a market survey by Electrical Merchandising. Substantial gains were made last year in sales of electric refrigerators and clocks.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Five American and five Canadian aviators who came to China expecting to receive jobs at $1,000 a month piloting Chinese military planes found themselves stranded here today.

The National Biscuit Company reported yesterday for last year a net income of $19,739,491, after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.86 a share on 6,286,238 shares of common stock. This compares with a net income of $22,879,898, or $3.40 a share, on 6,206,787 shares of stock in 1930.

Harry Licht, 43 years old, of 1,174 Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn, who was president of H. Licht, Inc., furrier, at 259 West Thirtieth Street, when it and five subsidiaries failed for a total of $1,500,000 in May, 1929, was sentenced to the penitentiary yesterday by Judge Levine in General Sessions for not more than three years.

The executive committee for the charity carnival of next May gave a large supper dance last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for members of the debutante and junior committees and their friends. The guests were received by Mrs. Edward F. Hutton, Mrs. Eagene W. Ong and Mrs. Arthur B. Claflin.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- A storm of controversy, in which wives and husbands and even judges differ, has arisen here over a court interpretation of the rights of wives.

A standard vertical clearance of 175 feet as a maximum for bridges, and restriction of the height of funnela and masts of ocean-going vessels in conformity with that standard, were recommended at the seventy-ninth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers, which opened yesterday at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Waging the closest battle it has experienced this season and assured of victory only in the final ten seconds of play, the Fordham University basketball quintet scored a 20-18 triumph over Rider College of Trenton, N.J., before 1,000 spectators in the Maroon gymnasium last night.

Formation of a committee to invite deposits of first-mortgage bonds of the Long Bell Lumber Company, which was suggested recently by R. A. Long, chairman of the company, has been completed by Halsey, Stuart Co., it was announced yesterday.

The performance of "Die Walkure" last night by the Metropolitan Opera Company was distinguished by the American debut of Goeta Ljungberg, the young Swedish soprano of whom glowing reports had reached these shores before her arrival. There are good reasons for Miss Ljungberg's fame, and in the general sense of the word her first appearance was a brilliant success.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- Charges that Germany was secretly preparing a powerful army and a vast supply of war materials, in defiance of the restrictions of the treaty of Versailles, caused a considerable sensation at today's meeting of the Senate Foreign Affairs Commission.

While asserting that improvement in the steel business is "more in the promise than in the performance," Iron Age emphasizes that operations increased in the last week to an average of 28 per cent for the industry as a whole from a little more than 25 per cent in the preceding week.
GENEVA, Jan. 20 -- Delighted that Secretary Stimson is coming to the arms conference, League officials consider its chances are distinctly improved and the atmosphere generally made more bracing.
Twenty-three deputy fire chiefs assembled yesterday at the Municipal Building to take the civil service examination that will determine a successor to Fire Chief John Kenlon, who resigned last year.

Hugh Ross, displaying his customary enterprise, arranged a program of exceptional character and value for the concert given last night by the Schola Cantorum in Carnegie. Nothing on this program was more impressive or of greater musical value than the "Organum Quadruplum" of Perotinus of the twelfth century, a work edited by Rudolf Ficker and given, in this instance, its first performance in America.
"The Well of the Saints," J.M. Synge's play, will be presented tonight at the Irish Theatre in the Barbizon (Lexington Avenue at Sixty-third Street), with Augustin Duncan as the guest star.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday granted State Senator John A. Hastings permission to appeal from its own unanimous decision that he must answer a subpoena of the Hofstadter committee which he has been fighting since Jan. 4.

The United States must take a leading part in international reconstruction if the world, including the United States, is to be saved from a cataclysm, Sir Henry Thornton, president of the Canadian National Railways, told alumni of Brown University at the annual dinner of the Brown University Club, at the Hotel Brevoort last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Nearly 1,000,000 jobless persons migrated to fifty-two cities throughout the country in 1931 from agricultural sections and towns east of the Mississippi where small plants were idle, according to a survey made public today by Edward C. Hybicki, director of the Free Employment Agency of the Department of Public Welfare of New York City.

Gold in the amount of $19,393,100 was withdrawn from the Federal Reserve Bank yesterday for shipment to Europe, the amount including the second $12,000,000 shipment by the Bank of France in connection with its repatriation of its holdings of earmarked gold here.

HAVANA, Jan. 20 -- The first of a series of annual international tennis tournaments for which Harry F. Guggenheim, United States Ambassador in Cuba, has donated a silver cup to be awarded to the winner, will begin on Feb. 19 at the Vedado Tennis Club in Havana.

More than 50,000 persons have registered with the Home Relief Bureau since its opening, it was announced last night following completion of yesterday's registration at the seventy-nine relief stations maintained by the bureau in the five boroughs of the city.

Advances in United States Government securities and a resumption of the forward movement in domestic bonds marked trading in the bond market of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Foreign issues were erratic. Several groups made strong gains, however, including Argentine, Australian and Austrian series.

Pointing out that the daily crude oil production of the United States had declined 236,850 barrels from Dec. 19 to Jan. 16, Amos L. Beaty, president of the American Petroleum Institute, in a statement issued yesterday expressed hope that the oil industry in the United States would find itself "fairly well in balance" by April 1.

During the last ten years the Anti-Saloon League has spoken positively for the Drys in both political parties. They did what it said. They voted as the League dictated. If things have changed, and the power of the Anti-Saloon League has waned, its officials, meeting at Washington, are unaware of it.

Judge Donnellan reserved decision in General Sessions yesterday on the motion of Martin Conboy, counsel for Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, for a bill of particulars on the first of the four misdemeanor indictments on which his client is to be placed on trial on Feb. 1, accusing him of official negligence in the failure of the Bank of United States.

Jordan L. Mott, former president of the J.L. Mott Iron Works, who died of a heart attack in Nelson Harbor, Bahamas, on Jan. 7 while on a cruise, left the bulk of his estate to his grandson, Jordan L. Mott 3d, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 20 -- New York entrants dominated the play in the first round of the Florida East Coast championship on St. Augustine links today, with Tommy Goodwin of Monroe taking the lead with a victory by 7 and 6 over H.A. Somerville of Charlottesville, Va.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 20 -- Providence College proved too fast for Harvard's varsity basketball team on the Crimson court tonight, the Rhode Islanders handing Harvard its fourth straight defeat of the season by a 37 -- 25 count.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The British Foreign Office tonight issued the following communique on reparations:

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- A program of aid for New York State farmers, by inference applicable to those of the nation, through the establishment of rural credit corporations and farm-to-market roads, was set forth today by Governor Roosevelt.

Retail Trade Still Disappointing. No particular gain has developed in retail trade and weather conditions have turned the development of business for the late January period into more or less of a riddle, retail execu- tives here said yesterday. Apparel volume has dropped much below what was anticipated, and this recession is expected to exert a major influence in the reduction of dollar volume for the month.

BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- The German Government today definitely rejected the British-French proposal for a year's extension of the reparations moratorium granted to Germany under the Hoover holiday year and will insist that a definite adjustment of reparations be undertaken by the creditor powers before July 1.

NICE, France, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Reports were current in the American colony today that Mrs. Walter S. Davidson, mother of Marian Snowden, the American society girl who was married to Prince Girolamo Rospigliosi last November, was seeking to prevent a remarriage of the couple in the United States.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 20 -- Local opinion on yesterday's decree for sharply increased taxation appeared mainly favorable today. Such a step is regarded as preferable to an emission of currency, which President-elect Agustin P. Justo asserts his new government will not allow.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 20 -- The Englewood Field Club increased its lead in the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets League when it scored a clean sweep over the Plainfield Country Club, 5 -- 0, at Plainfield today.

A raid on the penthouse on top of the Columbia Broadcasting Company's building at 485 Madison Avenue was staged early this morning by plain-clothes policemen of the headquarters staff. The penthouse, which is occupied by a recently formed organization known as the Club Internationale, was said by the police to have been fitted up as a combined night club, speakeasy and gambling place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Five points, summarizing the position of the United States with reference to intergovernmental debts, are contained in the debt memorandum given by Secretary Stimson to Paul Claudel, the French Ambassador, last month.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Winnie Ruth Judd, once-confessed slayer, will begin in earnest tomorrow the battle for her life, with a phantom codefendant awaiting possible materialization when witnesses begin a parade to the witness stand.
The first or three sessions of the sale of early American antiques from Charles Woolsey Lyon, Inc., held yesterday at the Rains Auction Rooms, brought $17,285.50.

Painters, organized in 1899, is holding its thirty-third annual exhibition, to last through Jan. 30, at the Grand Central Galleries. About 150 miniatures are shown, including two memorial groups containing, respectively, work by Lucy M. Stanton of Athens, Ga., and Julie Kahle of New York, both of whom died in 1931.

"JIM" WATSON has got into The Atlantic Monthly. It was right that a classic example of the "glad-hand" statesman should be exhibited in that Boston gallery, now so much more tolerant and comprehensive than in its earlier years. Mr. FRANK R. KENT is the artist.

General Shigeru Honjo, commander of the Japanese forces in Manchuria, assured the American people that Japan aims for lasting world peace just as every other nation does, in a radio address from his general headquarter near Mukden, which was received here at 7:15 o'clock last night, New York time.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 20 -- John Ineson, 70, walked into the South Freeport postoffice today, purchased two stamps from the wife of Postmaster E.B. Butler and affixed them to letters. Then he entered his waiting automobile, a small coupe, in which his wife, Henrietta, 69, was waiting, and started it downhill toward the South Freeport boat landing.

A proposal to take the power of nominating judges from the political parties, vesting it instead in a special nominating council and the public, is being considered by groups interested in court reform, Charles C. Burlingham, former president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 20 -- An agreement to maintain published minimum passenger fares for cruises from United States ports to the West Indies and Central and South America during the period from Jan. 15 to March 31, entered into by thirteen steamship companies, was approved by the Shipping Board today.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 -- One of the most surprising upsets of the Winter season took place at Hialeah Park today in the featured Boynton Handicap when Mrs. Payne Whitney's Comstockery, a former steeplechaser, and held at about 59 to 1, defeated William M. Moore's Vander Pool, odds-on choice in a four-horse race.

MANILA, Jan. 20 -- The Philippines are stirred by a newly discovered provision in the revised penal code, which was passed by the last Legislature and became effective Jan. 1, whereby newspapers are held criminally liable for the publication of any court testimony regarded as damaging to the reputation, honor or private morals of any individual.
The first or three sessions of the sale of early American antiques from Charles Woolsey Lyon, Inc., held yesterday at the Rains Auction Rooms, brought $17,285.50.

Painters, organized in 1899, is holding its thirty-third annual exhibition, to last through Jan. 30, at the Grand Central Galleries. About 150 miniatures are shown, including two memorial groups containing, respectively, work by Lucy M. Stanton of Athens, Ga., and Julie Kahle of New York, both of whom died in 1931.

"JIM" WATSON has got into The Atlantic Monthly. It was right that a classic example of the "glad-hand" statesman should be exhibited in that Boston gallery, now so much more tolerant and comprehensive than in its earlier years. Mr. FRANK R. KENT is the artist.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The controller of the Currency reported today that gross earnings of the 6,805 national banks in existence on June 30, 1931, amounted to $1,308,764,000, which was a return of slightly less than 35 per cent on the capital, surplus and undivided profits invested.

HAVAN, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Scatter a 5-year-old son of Sir Gallahad III carried the Canadian owned silks of J.E. Smallman to victory in the five and one-half furlong feature at Oriental Park today. The victory was the third of the meeting for Scatter.
Plans for the expansion of the Columbia School of Engineering which would entail the expenditure of from $20,000,000 to $25,000,000 were revealed last night by Dean Joseph W. Barker.

The Automobile Club of America, the oldest organization of motorists in the country, whose thousands of members included many notables in society, business, politics and the professions, has received its death blow from the economic depression.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 -- A three months' cruise of the South Seas combining pleasure and scientific study is planned by Vincent Astor, according to Milton W. Holden of New York and Palm Beach, who will depart Sunday to join Mr. Astor at Miami.

Mme, Sigrid Onegin, noted Swedish mezzo-soprano, was the principal guest artist yesterday at the third musicale this season of the Harlem Philharmonic Society at the Waldorf-Astoria. More than 1,300 members and guests of the society were present.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Charles Aubrey Cartwright gave a luncheon yesterday in the Georgian Room of the Pierre. Among her guests were Grand Duchess Marie of Russia, Mrs. William May Wright, Mrs. George Rose, Mrs. Scoville Treadwell, Mrs. Aksel C.P. Wichfeld and Mrs. Ayres Starr.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Names of those who passed the recent dental examination were announced today by the State Board of Registration and Examination in Dentistry. Ninety-four persons took the examination. The successful ones included:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Increased cooperation of the United States with the League of Nations and revision of war debts were declared today by the Conference on the Cause and Cure of War to be among the chief objectives of that organization for this year.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- In an effort to keep State expenditures at a minimum, Governor Roosevelt is working to keep his supplemental budget at the smallest figure in some years.

Both the bench and the bar were blamed for the law's delays by speakers at the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association yesterday afternoon at the Bar Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street. The association, which will be in session today and tomorrow, received the report of its nominating committee, placing former Judge Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee, in nomination for president of the association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have been operated during December at 79.8 per rent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 85.8 per cent in November. It was 76.1 per cent in December, 1930, and 88.2 per cent in December, 1929.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 21 -- Crazed by fear of the flames and smoke in her bedroom, Mrs. Delphine Larro, 104 years old, resisted all efforts at rescue and was burned fatally today in a fire in a house in Summer Avenue, Minotola, near here, where she lived with her son.

Joe Crosson, operations manager for Alaskan Airways, arrived in New York yesterday after four years of adventurous flying in Alaska. It was Crosspn who, when Lieutenant Carl Ben Eielson crashed off the coast of Siberia in November, 1930, discovered the wrecked plane and Eielson's body.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Eastern wheat bulls tried to advance prices early today on the Board of Trade here and managed to bring about an upturn of about 3/4 cent from the previous close, but the local element is not inclined to buy when the May delivery here is selling at almost 5 cents above the same future in Liverpool.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21 -- John W. Leigh, vice president and treasurer of the Princeton Bank and Trust Company, was found shot to death this afternoon in the basement of his home, 182 Nassau Street, oy his sister-in-law, Miss Caroline S. Leigh, who made her home with Mr. and Mrs. Leigh.

LONDON, Jan. 21:-Disarmament as a "moral issue" was uppermost among the subjects discussed by the Bishops of the Church of England today at a meeting of the Convocatin of Canterbury. Following the example of their Archbishop, Dr. Cosmo Gordon Lang, the Bishops voted to offer prayers in all their churches during the Geneva disarmament conference.

The current economy drive of the city administration would be aided if the municipal hospitals followed the lead of the Beekman Street Hospital in raising its rates to insurance companies for workmen's compensation cases to a point more nearly covering the cost of their care, it was suggested at the annual luncheon meeting of the board of directors of the Beekman Street Hospital yesterday at the Recess Club, 60 Broadway.

The memorable feature of the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra given last night in Carnegie Hall came last on the program. It consisted in a superb performance, with Ossip Gabrilowitsch as pianist, of Brahms's B-flat piano concerto.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Jan. 21 -- Student rebellion flared up at the Patchogue High School today as the result of disciplinary rules announced by Principal Percy Proctor.

Declaring that the disarmament conference, opening Feb. 2 at Geneva, marks a "world crisis," Philip C. Nash, national director of the League of Nations Association, urged yesterday that the American delegation make public immediately its position upon five major questions.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Her eyes flashing, Winnie Ruth Judd, confessed slayer, drove a prosecution psychiatrist from the court room under a tirade today as testimony was started in her trial for the slaying of Agnes Anne LeRoi.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Prompt opposition to one of President Hoover's nominees arose today and meanwhile the Chief Executive delved among possibilities for filling a half-dozen vacancies still confronting him.

Further economies by the Board of Education are contemplated in a plan presented yesterday to Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the board, whereby the number of classes would be increased in the various groups under the control of principals and teachers.

LYTTON STRACHEY should have died hereafter, not in his prime. A great source of curious entertainment has gone. To a world cursed with long, solemn, jejune Official Lives and Letters and Public Services he brought the "new" biography that was in essence the old.

Contributions totaling $24,126 were announced yesterday by the Musicians Emergency Aid at the official opening of a three weeks' campaign for funds to help needy musicians. The campaign started with luncheons at the homes of Mrs. Vincent Astor, chairman of the campaign, and Mrs. Efrem Zimbalist.

The Attorney General's Investigation of the stock-selling activities of Town Topics and The Tatler and American Sketch, society gossip publications, was ended yesterday when the publishers of Town Topics, following the example set a week ago by their competitor, consented to an injunction permanently restraining them from further sales of stock in the publishing company.

For several hours yesterday the magistrates of this city ceased condemning and advising those accused of wrongdoing and gave the wrongdoers a chance to suggest "desirable" reforms in the attitude of magistrates toward prisoners. For the first time in the city's history the magistrates as a group toured the penltentiary at Welfare Island, where they talked with the prisoners about such matters as meals, personal comfort, overcrowding, unemployment and the causes of crime.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 -- The Diet was dissolved by imperial order this afternoon immediately after Korekiyo Takahashi, Finance Minister, had finished his defense of the government's financial policy. No Opposition member had an opportunity to speak in the lower house, but Junnosuke Inouye, former Finance Minister, spoke in defense of the late government's financial measures in the House of Peers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the New York Central Railroad to borrow not to exceed $75,000,000 on short-term promissory notes.

Cancellation, in whole or in part, of foreign debts would be preferable to any reduction in present tariff rate schedules, W.L. Munro, re-elected yesterday to the presidency of the American Tariff League, told members of that organization. In his annual message to the group Mr. Munro pointed out that settlement of international debts by payment in goods has been suggested, and if carried through would "lead to economic chaos and possibly social revolution."

Patrolman John Walsh of Traffic C, a veteran of twenty-eight years in the Police Department, was shot and killed last night when he announced his identity to two young bandits who attempted to hold up a speakeasy at 206 Bast Eighty-eighth Street.

School authorities who had failed to make extensive use of motion pictures as aids in education, especially in vocational training, were criticized as being "backward" in the opening address yesterday by Dr. Louis I. Harris, former city Health Commissioner, before a meeting of the National Board of Review of motion pictures.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 21 (AP) -- A heavy snowfall blanketed the mountain slopes about this Adirondack resort today and gave the Olympic ski teams their first opportunity for ski running and jumping practice in several weeks.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 21 -- Striking reforms in intercollegiate athletics, chiefly football, were recommended today to the Association of American Colleges in a report read by Dr. Thomas S. Gates, president of the University of Pennsylvania and chairman of the association's commission on college athletics.

The taunt that their turn may come next, directed at the holier than thous" who are now investigating the city administration, was flung last night by Mayor Walker, when, speaking before an audience of 2,000 members of Tammany, he reaffirmed his allegiance to the organization and its leader, John F. Curry.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 21 -- The first Argentine legislative session since the revolution of 1930, established itself in the long-quiet legislative halls today and began by launching a bitter oratorical attack upon the de facto government of President Uriburu, which has held the power since the revolution.

A new two-lane roadway with a capacity of 20,000 vehicles a day will be constructed within the next year or so on the eighteen-foot section of the Williamsburg Bridge now occupied by the tracks of the postoffice and Grand Street-Brooklyn trolley lines, according to plans of the Department of Plant and Structures disclosed yesterday by Commissioner Albert Goldman.

Brisk advances yesterday in the stocks and bonds of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, the Manhattan Railway Company and the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit Corporation were attributed by some investors to hopes for a general solution of New York City transit difficulties rather than to specific action relating to fares.

Gates W. McGarrah, president of the Bank for International Settlements, will return from Europe today on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Others on the Europa include Sir Robert Johnson, governor of the London mint; Mme. Elizabeth Rethberg, Michael Bohnen and Lauritz Melchior of the Metropolitan Opera, and a German toboggan team, coming here for the Olympic Games.

OAXACA CITY, Mexico, Jan. 21 -- The ruins at Monte Alban, where jewels and precious ornaments worth a king's ransom were unearthed recently by government archaeologists, hummed with excitement today. While officials were completing the exploration of the first chamber in the most recently excavated tomb scores of workmen were clearing away the debris from the ruins of what appears to have been an ancient temple.

Ninety cents a word for the several thousand words of a series of magazine articles was recently paid to former Governor Alfred E. Smith, automatically raising him into that company of writers who are better paid for a paragraph than Shakespeare was for some of his plays.

If Mayor Walker had had his way, John Ringling, the circus man, would have been Park Commissioner of New York "so that the kiddies could see his zoo," but if Mayor Frank Hague could have had his way Mr. Ringling would have taken up residence in Jersey City so that Jersey City could add to its fame by being the home of the Ringling Museum.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- After a day of upsets, four veterans were tied tonight for the lead in the world's three-cushion billiard championship tournament.

Ten men, including three officials of the Joseph Frankel Company, toy and novelty importers, were arrested and held for arraignment yesterday charged with conspiracy to defraud the government of customs tariffs. The men were arrested in three simultaneous raids by seven customs agents and two police detectives, who had been working on the case for several months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- In an effort to effect a more efficient administration of the immigration laws, including a general strengthening of land borders against alien smuggling, Secretary Doak has ordered numerous changes and transfers in the staff of immigration officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Anticipating passage of the $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation bill by Congress late tomorrow, President Hoover today submitted an estimate of $500,000,000 for its capitalization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The recent statement attributed to Secretary of Agriculture Hyde that the Wilson Administration made war loans to European countries after the armistice "without legal right" was denounced today in the Senate by Senator Carter Glass as "false in spirit and in text."

Stocks moved within a narrow range in quiet trading on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday. Opening prices were at or near their previous close, although a few of the preferred shares, particularly in the utility list, showed fairly large losses from the start.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Following is the memorandun filed by the president's committee of nine with the union leaders:
PARIS, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

Nicholas Somma, 25 years old, known as a small-time gangster in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, was slain and his companion, Michael Annunzio, 23, received forty-six stab wounds late last night when the two were trapped in the home of a friend whom they were visiting at 105-28 Seventy-seventh Street, Ozone Park, by four unidentified men, who apparently were grimly intent on their mission.
BERLIN, Jan. 21 -- Negotiations were inaugurated among the various Reichstag groups today for the proclamation of a year of political truce to be dedicated to rebuilding the fatherland.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Susan Glaspell, the American playwright and novelist, awaits a final decision by the Home Office upon her application to play next week at the People's National Theatre. She is scheduled to appear in the same role which she took in the original Provincetown production of her play "Trifles."

BUCHAREST, Jan. 21 -- Considerable light is thrown on the secret warfare of the G.P.U. against its enemies in half a dozen capitals by a Rumanian police statement concerning the eighteen Soviet agents arrested early this week on a ship at Constanza.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Hugh Whitefield Martin, also known as Riccardo Martin, who was one of the principal tenors of the Metropolitan Opera Company in New York for several years, today married Miss Allis Merrian Beaumont of Cleveland, Ohio, at the Henrietta Street Register Office.
The birth control movement is steadily gaining in public favor, speakers declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Birth Control League at the Hotel McAlpin.
Realty trading in Manhattan was featured yesterday by the sale of a large residence in the Murray Hill section to Frederick Brown, operator.

Speed, mobility, safety and economy will be combined in making a borough-wide survey of the public schools of Queens in an effort to expedite recognition and study of the incipient stages of tuberculosis, according to plans revealed yesterday at a meeting of the Institute on CaseFinding, held in the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the National Tuberculosis Association.

Negotiations for the purchase of the Hotel Brevoort, a lower Fifth Avenue landmark which has sheltered queens, princes and other famous personages since it was built 87 years ago and which is leased by Raymond Orteig, donor of the $25,000 prize for Lindbergh's flight to Paris, are being conducted by the Knott Hotels Corporation, it was learned last night from David H. Knott, head of the corporation.

It was only a coincidence that the presence of ex-Governor SMITH'S friend Mr. CURTIN in his home State of New Hampshire synchronized with an announcement that a complete slate of pro-Smith delegates is to be filed for the primaries there. The ex-Governor's friend denies that he had anything to do with it, or that he had any authority from Mr. SMITH to initiate moves for delegates.

With 200 exhibits, ranging from fifty-foot cruisers to tiny sailboats and from bulky oil-burning engines to "featherweight" outboard motors, the twenty-seventh annual National Motor Boat Show will open at 7 o'clock tonight in Grand Central Palace.

Manufactured commodities valued at more than $1,000,000,000 and agricultural products worth more than $4,000,000,000 were sold last year under some plan of guaranteeing quality to purchasers, according to a report of the American Standards Association made public yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 21 -- The task of studying on the spot and recommending how to settle the gravest conflict that has yet confronted the League of Nations was turned over without ceremony here today to its commission of inquiry into Sino-Japanese relations.

Jobbers Expand Dry Goods Orders. With a decided increase in the lumber of jobbers arriving in the local markets during the week, buying volume in the primary dry goods market showed a substantial expanion, in line with seasonal expectaions.

DENVER, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The griefstricken wife of Benjamin P. Bower, 62-year-old baking company executive who was kidnapped from his home last Tuesday night, offered today to pay "any reasonable sum" for his safe return.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my letter dealing with Chancellor Bruening's announcement I called attention to Annex 1 of the agreement with Germany of Jan. 20, 1930, and asked: "Was the declaration in Annex 1 another scrap of paper?"

Three more signed contracts were received by the New York Giants yesterday, it was announced by Secretary Jim Tierney, and though only one of these was from an active player it nevertheless revealed steady progress in the matter of bringing the athletes into the fold.

In the face of a rise in security prices, the total of brokers' loans declined $32,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $531,000,000, according to the report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Teams from the Salle d'Armes Vince, New York Athletic Club and the Fencers Club reached the final round, in the national junior epee team championship tournament last night at the Fencers Club.

While the revision of the by-laws of the Board of Higher Education seemed to divest it of its chief administrative functions, it is stated by Mr. TUTTLE that the board could not lawfully surrender either control or power over the three collegiate units.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 21 -- Operations of iron and steel companics in the Youngstown area continue to gain. The Carnegie Steel Company here is producing steel ingots close to 50 per cent of capacity to meet the requirements of its bar, strip, skelp and sheet mills.

Average daily electric power output, seasonally adjusted, is down to a new low for the present depression, the figure for the week ended Jan. 16 being 220,500,000 kilowatt-hours, as against 223,900,000 kilowatt-hours for the preceding week and 236,300,000 kilowatt-hours for the corresponding week last year.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Although sterling exchange was lower today, the New York rate declining to 53.45 1/2, British Government funds again were in demand from the Continent. France was said to be a big buyer in the early dealings. The 5 per cent conversion loan gained sharply to L101 and the war loan advanced to u98 1/2.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 21 -- Japanese consular and naval authorities in Shanghai today demanded a cessation of the Chinese boycott against Japanese goods and of general anti-Japanese activities by Chinese.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 21 -- The creation of a new type of college, to be called the general college, to minister to the needs of many students who do not plan to enter a profession was recommended today by Dr. Ernest H. Wilkins, president of Oberlin College and president of the Association of American Colleges, in his presidential address.

Poland's Olympic standard-bearers arrived in New York yesterday on the S.S. France en route to the Winter Olympic Games at Lake Placid with their hopes centred not so much on victory but rather on gaining international experience. Eighteen were in the party, hockey players and skiers, and they made up one of the youngest teams to reach here for the international carnival.

LA PAZ, Jan. 21 -- It is disclosed here that Juan Jose Soler and Cesar A. Vasconcellos, who had been chosen as the Paraguayan delegates to a conference in Washington for a Bolivian-Paraguayan pact of nonaggression, have resigned because of discord at Asuncion.

CANTON, S.D., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Three members of South Dakota's Sioux Valley Ski Club and three ski riders from Chicago, Estes. Park, Col., and Iona Island, N.Y., will represent the United States in the third Winter Olympic Games in February, in addition to the eleven named at Lake Placid yesterday.

Richard Whitney, a member of the Jockey Club and president of the New York Stock Exchange, was elected chairman of the hunts committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association at a meeting of the committee held here yesterday.
Bryson Burroughs is not only curator of painting at the Metropolitan Museum; he is also a painter. His latest canvases are now on view at the Montross Gallery, to remain until Jan. 30.

In sympathy with a stronger stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange made a further recovery yesterday and closed with gains of 2 to 3 points. Following the setback early this week of a quarter-cent from the high levels of Monday, foreign and domestic mills fixed prices more freely, which had a steadying effect.

Champion Idahurst Belle II, a brown and white parti-colored cocker spaniel, last night was crowned best in show over a field of 167 other spaniels at the fifteenth annual exhibition of the American Spaniel Club in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt.

MADRID, Friday, Jan. 22 -- The red flag was raised in town after town for fifty miles up the Liobregat and Cardenas Valleys of Catalonia yesterday by Syndicalists and Communists who proclaimed that a "Soviet Republic of Spain" had been established.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- In its first direct vote on the wet and dry issue since prohibition began twelve years ago the Senate today rejected, 55 to 15, a resolution by Senator Bingham suggesting to Governors of the States that they recommend to their Legislatures referenda on repeal and modification of prohibition.

Commodity markets generally were firm. Price changes were slight and found in but few articles, the majority showing a firm undertone and steadiness in value. In the cash group, the grains were soft following the decline in the contract grades. In futures, coffee, rubber and silk were higher, while cocoa and hides were lower.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 21 -- After defeating S.A. McGee of Elmsford, N.Y., by 10 up and 8 to play, Tommy Goodwin, 18-year-old star from Monroe, N.Y., went through the semi-final round in the Florida East Coast men's championship on the St. Augustine links today, eliminating Van Culver of Port Jervis, N.Y., by 5 up and 3 to play.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 21 -- John D'Agrostlno, 35 years old, of 126 Clinton Place here, who, with his older brother, Anthony, was reputed a year or two ago to hold a position in Northern New Jersey analgous to Al Capone in Chicago, was shot to death tonight by three unidentified assassins, who entered the office of his cooperage plant, adjoining his home, armed with pistols and a shotgun.

The net income of the United Founders Corporation from investments, exclusive of the results of security transactions, was substantially larger in the year ended Nov. 30 than in the preceding year. Net income, applicable to 8,977,354 shares of United Founders stock, after eliminating all portions applicable to subsidiaries, was $1,172,277, or 13 cents a share.

Details of measures taken by the receivers of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation to liquidate its indebtedness and prepare for reorganization were said yesterday to indicate that the loss of any constituent property by the system might be avoided and that, by a strict policy of conservation over a moderate period, the capital cost of reorganization would be limited to a minimum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The amusement industry of the nation, represented by spokesmen for nearly every branch of entertainment, protested to the Ways and Means Committee today against the treasury's suggestion that tax exemptions on admission tickets be lowered to raise additional Federal revenue.

MONTREAL, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Trying desperately to score the tying goal, the Toronto Maple Leafs took Goalie Lorne Chabot out of his cage and put six forwards on the ice with twelve seconds to go in their National Hockey League struggle with the Montreal Canadiens tonight, but the Canadiens scored a 3-to-1 victory.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 21 -- Over two negative votes, a resolution was adopted by the Republican State Central Committee today emphatically endorsing President Hoover for reelection.

Life insurance sales in December not only exceeded those of the same month of the preceding year for the first time since June, 1930, but were the largest for any single month in that period. The total of new business was $1,117,187,000, against $1,112,173,000 in December, 1930, again of 0.5 per cent.

Mr. COOLIDGE diagnoses a bad case of national swelled head when he curtly reports "we have found that "we were not so big as we thought "we were." It is now easy enough to see in how many ways we failed to show ourselves really big. We let success go to our heads.
