WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Construction corporations or other concerns holding government building contracts must pay the prevailing rate of wages or lose their contracts under the terms of an Executive order issued by President Hoover today.

Billy Petrolle the sturdy Fargo Express, will attempt to wreck the string of successes recently compiled by Eddie Ran, hard-hitting Polish welterweight, tonight. The boxers will clash in a ten-roun bout which will feature the card at Madison Square Garden, and a large crowd is expected to see the battle.

The Roman Catholic Church does not worship the Virgin Mary, and the fathers of the church, including St. Jerome and St. Augustine, did believe that there should be a Pope, Cardinal Hayes declares in a pastoral letter he issued last night on the eve of his sailing for the Bahama Islands today to install the Rev. Bernard Kevenhoerster as the first Prefect Apostolic of the islands.

A dozen prohibition agents, acting under a decision of the Federal court which permits them to remove furnishings and fixtures of raided night clubs and speakeasies, drew a crowd of more than 1,000 persons yesterday when they began the work of dismantling the Stork Club, at 132 West Fifty-eighth Street.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Francis Crowley, 20 years old, who murdered Patrolman Frederick Hirsch near North Merrick, L.I., on the night of May 5 last, was put to death in the electric chair in Sing Sing prison tonight. He entered the death chamber at 11:02 and was pronounced dead at 11:07.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A two-years' truce in the prosecution of the anti-trust laws as an emergency reconstruction measure for the relief of industry during the depression was proposed to President Hoover this morning by Charles F. Abbott, executive director of the American Institute of Steel Construction of New York.

Deputy Sheriff Joseph A. Lanman, who has had seventeen, years of service, including the handling of attachments, orders of arrest and replevin actions involving many millions of dollars and prominent persons, had the new experience of being arrested in the performance of his duties on Wednesday, it became known yesterday.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 21 -- First prize in the heavy car category in the European motor endurance contest was awarded to a Frenchman, M. Vasselle, in a Hotchkiss car, with 261,691 points. Last year's winner, D.M. Heley, was second in his Invicta, with 258,317 points.

Fluctuations in the share market on the Stock Exchange yesterday were narrow and the net results unimportant, but there was a fair-sized advance in bonds. Trading was again slow in both markets; in stocks the total volume was only slightly heavier than on the previous day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A copy of the British statement on the postponement of the Lausanne conference was received by the State Department today from the American embassy in London and was viewed as leaving the door open to the selection of a later date for the meeting.

The first anniversary of the affiliation between Joe Leblang's Central Ticket Office and Postal Telegraph was informally celebrated yesterday afternoon in the private office of Mrs. Tillie Leblang, widow of Joe Leblang, at 1,482 Broadway. Frank C. Page, vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation; R.G. McLaughlin, head of Postal Telegraph's New York division, and a group of newspaper men were among those present to hear Mrs. Leblang's report.

It is easily possible that the decision to postpone the Lausanne conference about reparations was hastened by Secretary STIMSON'S note to the French Government. This set forth the certainty that our Congress would oppose even an extension of the moratorium, much more a cancellation of the war debts.

It will be necessary to enlarge the accommodations for the experts of the nation's press at the Olympic stadium this Summer if the desire of the majority to "cover" the 1932 international games is fulfilled.
Gimcracks and Spizzerinktums. Public business these days is arduous, and its details are perplexing. But love of beauty is not entirely cast out of the minds and hearts of our lawmakers.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 21 -- A dramatic story of an escape from the French penal colony at Devil's Isle and a twenty-seven mile struggle to freedom by boat and swimming through a shark-infested sea was related to the British Guiana police by a salt-encrusted, sunburned, tattooed man who staggered ashore near New Amsterdam and begged for food and water.

The management of the New York Opera Comique has formulated a cooperative plan which is expected to enable the company to complete its season of six productions, it was announced last night by Kendall K. Mussey, general director. The Opera Comique has suffered from decreased income this season, and a special program is necessary to present the three operas that remain to be given.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The long-awaited bill by Senator Glass of Virginia, to revise the Federal Reserve and national banking laws, was reported this afternoon by the subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee and introduced in the Senate in advance of inspection by the full committee.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 -- An important social event of today was the recital by the New York String Quartet at La Fontana, the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Luke Mesker. White lilies formed the decoration for the music room and loggias for the table from which tea was served preceding the program.

MONTREAL, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Three United States players, headed by George Lott, advanced to the semifinal round of the Canadian covered courts tennis championship today along with a lone Canadian, Marcel Rainville of Montreal.

Five men arrested early yesterday in a duplex penthouse apartment on top of the building occupied by the Columbia Broadcasting System at 485 Madison Avenue were freed later in the day when police who made the raid were unable to explain to Magistrate Anthony F. Burke just what the prisoners were doing before they were arrested.

The proceeds of the Bale of a diamond ring twelve years ago and legacy of $951.20 were among the fifteen contributions totaling $1,887.23 which increased the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to $295,373.11, within $50,417.54 of last year's total.

Silent facts rather than laud words are needed now in the water power question, it was said yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers by Dr. George Otis Smith, chairman of the Federal Power Commission.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, pleaded with the spokesman for 1,500,000 railroad workers today to save many of the roads from the bankruptcy which, he said, threatens because of their inability to pay their fixed charges or to meet the obligations coming due for payment.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 21 -- At least twenty prominent New Hampshire Democrats are anxious to become delegates to the Democratic National Convention pledged to Alfred E. Smith.

The "Roosevelt for President" dinner, arranged by the Empire State Committee of Democratic and Progressive Women, will be held at the Hotel Commodore on Saturday night, March 5, it was learned yesterday. The dinner, originally scheduled for last Dec. 21, was postponed at the request of friends of Governor Roosevelt because at that time he had not announced his candidacy.
The demand for business space which has been gaining in momentum since the first of the year attained large proportions yesterday as shown by reports of brokers.

The effect of depreciated foreign currency upon the import trade of the United States and the advisability of meeting this situation through existing or new tariff legislation was discussed at a meeting of the foreign commerce department committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 21 -- Denouncing efforts at "browbeating" the State Supreme Court by sympathizers of the eight Negroes who were sentenced in Scottsboro to die for an attack in March on two white girls. Chief Justice John C. Anderson declared today, in opening the hearing on appeal, that the court would not be influenced in this way.

Modest gains were made yesterday by most groups of bonds on the Stock Exchange in trading that ruled slightly heavier than on Wednesday. Domestic bonds, particularly rails, rose more than did foreign loans. United States Government loans were steady to firm in quiet trading, with final prices 10/32 point higher to 5/32 lower.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Daily Mail said today that messages from a source in Moscow said Leon Trotsky would be permitted to leave hit exile in Turkey and reside in Germany. Negotiations bad been the progress for some time between the former colleague of Lenin and Social Democratic leaders in Germany, the paper said.
"Mr. Papavert." a new version by H.S. Kraft of the play recently presented at the Vanderbilt Theatre, will open there tonight. Edward Colebrook is a late addition to the cast.

ABOARD STEAMSHIP PRESIDENT HARDING, Jan. 21 -- "If the disarmament conference fails to accomplish anything we will not have to wait long for the next European war." That prediction was made tonight by Senator Claude A. Swanson, one of the two United States delegates en route to the Geneva disarmament conference who are aboard this ship.
LONDON, Jan. 21 -- An awkward situation which may reach crisis proportions developed today in the British Cabinet over the proposed tariff legislation.

A recommendation that the Board of Education carry liability insurance for protection in case of suits for negligence on the part of its employes was referred yesterday to the Board of Superintendents with the suggestion that the matter be taken up with the Corporation Counsel.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Willie Macfarlane of Tuckahoe, N.Y., former national open champion, and Charles Fairman of Kokomo, Ind., won in an uphill struggle today, defeating Bill Melhorn of Pensacola, Fla., and Walter Bourne, Princeton, N.J., by 1 up in twenty-one holes in the semi-final round of the professional four-ball tournament over the Miami Country Club course.

"Norma" will open the thirteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season next Monday evening with Mmes. Ponselle and Swarthout and Messrs. Jagel and Pasero in the cast and Mr. Serafin conducting. Next week, which marks the beginning of the second half of the season, will also include the North American premiere of Verdi's "Simone Boccanegra" and the first appearances of the season for Lauritz Melchior and Michael Bohnen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Consolidation of the Army and Navy administration in a Department of National Defense was urged today by Representative Byrns of Tennessee, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, who told the Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments that this would save $100,000,000 a year.

American shipping interests have slight reason to expect a reduction of toll on tonnage using the Panama Canal, Colonel Harry Burgess, Governor General of the Canal Zone, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Propeller Club at 54 Broad Street. The government is planning improvements to cost $100,000,000, he said, to double the capacity of the canal, and this outlay renders impracticable any change of toll system that would lower the income from American ships.

Directors of the Railroad Credit Corporation met yesterday and discussed details of a plan by which railroads sharing in the revenue pool that the corporation will administer may obtain funds in advance of their receipt in the pool. The corporation was established under the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission, awarding increases in specified rates if they were pooled for the benefit of weaker railroads.

Bloodstains led neighbors and the police yesterday to the second-floor apartment of Henry Fehrmann, 56 years old, at 30 Sunnyside Court, in the Arlington section of Brooklyn, where they found that he had murdered his wife and committed suicide.
PARIS, Jan. 21 -- Despite a continued campaign in the Paris press, French financial and banking circles are displaying full confidence in American finances generally and the dollar in particular.

Julia Vardo, an American soprano, who has been studying in France and Italy for the last few years, made her first public appearance in a song recital here last night at Town Hall. She sang a program including groups of German, French and Italian songs and two songs dedicated to the singer by McClure Stitt and Henry Hadley.

Having no place to lay its head, the Irish Theatre has tucked Synge's "The Well of the Saints" into a luxuriously appointed assembly-room at the Barbizon, where Augustin Duncan and a company appeared last evening. No setting could be more hostile to a richly poetic comedy of a lonely mountainous district in Ireland.

ANTWERP, Brussels, Jan. 21 -- The sixth International Merchant Marine Officers' Congress today adopted a resolution protesting against recent modifications of the international code of signals for merchant ships without previous consultation with representatives of the various international officers' organizations.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- The Bourse session today was irregular, with the greater part of the stock list showing losses at the close. At the same time heavy offerings were readily absorbed by both local and foreign orders. The external political situation, with Dr. Bruening's new declaration refusing a moratorium prolongation, was the chief disrupting factor.

THE so-called "dreadnaughts," the balloon-type fighters put in a class by themselves by Commissioner Muldoon, are apparently out of the picture. The Garden officials have quietly spread word that among the spectators at the Billy Petrolle-Eddie Ran debate this evening there will be Herr Max Schmeling, Squire, Jack Sharkey, Steve Hamas, Max Baer, King Levinsky, Stanley Poreda, Salvatore Ruggirello and Ernie Schaaf.

HONOLULU, Jan. 21 -- Members of the Honolulu Police Department today began an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding an attack and robbery late last night near the John Rodgers Airport in which Takeo Horimoto and Mrs. Taka Okazaki, both Japanese, were victims.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The floating supply of common stock of the United States Steel Corporation on Dec. 31, 1931, as indicated by stock in brokers' names was 1,156,845 shares, or 13.29 per cent of the total issue of 8,703.252 shares outstanding. This is an increase of 11.482 shares since Sept. 30, 1931, when the supply was 1,145,363 shares, or 13.6 per cent of the total shares outstanding.

James J. McCormick, deputy city clerk, whose banking of $299,000 in six years had been invesigated by the Hofstadter committee, said yesterday that he had heard the grand jury had indicted him for accepting gratuities from persons married in the municipal chapel.

The Manual Training High School basketball team lost by 27 -- 17 to the Bushwick High School five yester- day on the Manual floor. The victors tied at 11-all at the end of the first half, took the lead, 16 -- 14, at the start of the second period and retained the advantage to the end.

In a statement issued yesterday, H.L. Lurie, director of the Bureau of Jewish Social Research, who resigned last week as executive director of the Emergency Work Commission appointed by Mayor Walker to supervise the expenditure of the $15,000,000 appropriation voted by the city for emergency work for the unemployed, assailed the postponement and curtailment of public works projects as means of reducing expenditures to meet the financial difficulties of the city.

Mount Taurus, one of the noblest bastions that make the scenery of the lower Hudson River so impressive, will soon be defaced by quarrying if it does not become a State park by action of the Legislature. A plan to raise the fund to buy the threatened property has failed.

A reduction of $27,000,000 in the volume of Reserve Bank credit outstanding, a drop of $7,000,000 in the monetary gold stocks of the country and a less than seasonal decline of $6,000,000 in the amount of money in circulation were the principal items of interest in the weekly reports of the 'Federal Reserve System as of Wednesday, published yesterday.

The prompt action of Congress in considering and agreeing upon the Administration's bill for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is of the highest importance. This is not only because it puts into operation an essential expedient for meeting our present economic complexities, but because of the attitude which it shows that Congress, including the opposition House majority, is taking toward the larger problems of the day.

HAVANA, Jan. 21 -- Cuban cane planters and sugar producers are greatly alarmed over reports here that Thomas L. Chadbourne, negotiator of the Chadbourne plan for stabilization of the world sugar market, who is now in Havana, will recommend to President Machado a further drastic reduction in the crop now being harvested and ground.

Three hold-up men, apparently amateurs, stole $349,000 in jewels in the home of Harry Glemby yesterday morning. Mr. Glemby, who made a fortune in the manufacture of hair goods, was tied up on the floor of his apartment at 22 East Sixty-seventh Street and the robbers knocked out the butler after having gained admittance by using the open sesame of prohibition -- a confidential "some stuff here ordered by Mr. Glemby."

Quick sale is expected today of the issue of $100,000,000 New York City 6 per cent special corporate stock notes which will be marketed by a syndicate of nearly fifty banks and banking houses. This was indicated by the deluge of advance orders by telephone and telegraph which poured into Wall Street yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 20, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,838,000,000, a decline of $49,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $774,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

Interest in the railway shares was largely responsible for the modest gains on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The final prices were well below the best levels of the day, but there was nevertheless an appreciable net gain in the averages.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 -- John B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., medalist and the victor in 1931, eliminated Albert R. Hakes of Dunkirk, N.Y., by 2 up and 1 to play in the opening round of match play for the Glenn H. Curtiss trophy over the municipal course at Miami Springs today.

MADRID, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Troops and airplanes were rushed today into the Province of Catalonia and a naval destroyer was ordered to Barcelona, the principal Catalonian city, to combat revolutionary strikers who launched what Premier Azana declared an "anarchist movement."

The Seamen's Bank for Savings filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday to forclose on four consolidated mortgages, on which $450,000 is due, covering the property beginning on the north side of Eighty-eighth Street, 99 feet 10 inches from the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street, and extending westerly on the street 39 feet and northerly parallel with Madison Avenue for 100 feet 8 inches.

The national fervor, or a vigorous people, which, when translated into booms, speculation and "expansion orgies," probably helped to bring on the economic depression, will very likely help the United States to recover more quickly than any other nation, Dr. Julius Klein, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, said last night at a dinner of the Silk Association of America at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The annual Beaux-Arts Ball, generally regarded as the climaxing entertainment of each Winter season in New York, will be held tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. As "A Pageant of Old New York and the First Inaugural Ball of the United States of America" the event is expected to be one of the most brilliant and historically accurate functions yet arranged by its sponsors, the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects.

Seven members of the America Fore group of insurance companies issued yesterday their balance sheets as of Jan. 1, all carrying their investments under the emergency plan approved by the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners, which provided that quotations of June 30 were to be considered as representing a fairer, truer valuation of securities than those on any subsequent particular day.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21 -- Street Singer, the Friar Rock colt from Sweet Music, which used to race for W.R. Coe but which now bears the colors of the well-known trainer, Jack Howard, won the Palm Island Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today. Under 112 pounds the colt got up in the last sixteenth to win by three-quarters of a length from Dancing Mack, with Martis third, a length and a half further back.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The bursar of New York University gathered up some old bank-notes and wondered whether they were savings from a family sock. They had been received as payment of student fees. He also reflected on the unusual number of gold pieces that had come to his office.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Chairman O'Connor of the Shipping Board told the House Merchant Marine Committee today he believed that American lines "run bars" out at sea.

PARIS, Jan. 22. -- Trading slackened on the Bourse here today, but after an irregular period stocks strengthened and toward the close most of them were steady. The debate in the Chamber of Deputies and uncertainty about the internatlon financial situation acted to restrain transactions.

The Bronx Hospital, Fulton Avenue and 169th Street, the Bronx, will be forced to close its doors within thirty days unless outside financial aid is received at once, Alexander Selkin, its president, reported yesterday to Homer Wickenden, general director of the United Hospital Fund of New York, 122 East Twenty-second Street.

The National Credit Corporation has issued a call for payment on next Monday of the third instalment of 10 per cent, or approximately $50,000,000, on subscriptions to its gold notes. The previous calls were for similar amounts. All are payable at the Federal Reserve Bank in each district.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- Marcus Nakkanen, Finnish Olympic contender, and Mrs. Edith C. Secord, who holds the American national waltzing title with Ferrier T. Martin, won the senior waltzing trophy in the twelfth annual Lake Placid Club figure skating contest today.

In a vehement attack on all forms of censorship, Morris L. Ernst of the American Civil Liberties Union declared yecterdsy before the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures that the Commissioner of Licenses of this city was "becoming a Mr. Casey of Boston" by threatening to revoke the licenses of "impecunious newsdealers" here if they continued to sell so-called objectionable magazines.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Jan. 22.-William Hohenzollern, once Emperor of Germany in a letter to a member of the faculty of the University of Missouri, declares that the United States and the Allies are now being punished by world-wide depression for the war and the treaty of Versailles.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 22. -- Charles R. Smith of this city, who for two years has been vice president of the Middlesex Title Guarantee and Trust Company, was elected president today by the directors.

It is a pity that Mayor WALKER exposed himself to the temptations of a Tammany "Victory dinner." His mercurial temperament could not withstand the loud acclaim accorded him, and he was betrayed into saying many foolish things, and some defiant ones, which may yet cause him regret.

Benno Moiseiwitsch devoted his considerable gifts to Chopin in his recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The program took in all four scherzi, three impromptus, the twenty-four preludes that make up Opus 28, two waltzes and a nocturne. There were encores, also by Chopin.

Hanns T. Scheidacker, an artist who was trained in Munich but has spent most of his mature life in this country, is having an exhibition at the Fifteen Gallery until Jan. 30. An exceedingly accomplished artist, he uses full color and much paint, but his pictures have strength and integrity.

The early morning rattle of milk bottle in transit from wagon to doorstep, the clumping of the milk man's heels and the rumble of the approaching and departing milk wagon itself are features that are to be eliminated gradually from its delivery service, the Borden's Farm Products Company announced yesterday.

Bond prices moved downward in comparatively quiet trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Pressure against railroad issues, although not particularly insistent, resulted in lower quotations, as a whole. Foreign loans showed considerable irregularity and United States Government bonds were off slightly for the day.

The Cullum Geographical Medal, one of the highest honors conferred in the United States in recognition of outstanding geographical discoveries, was awarded last night to Bertram Thomas, the English explorer, who last Winter made the first recorded crossing of the great southern desert of Arabia.

Miss Yvonnn Bouche, 32 year old, who taught French in the Finch School, was shot and killed late last night in her apartment on the fifth floor of 175 Claremont Avenue by her suiter, Mauro Fallist, who then ended his own Life by jumping from a window of the apartment to an adjoining vacant lot.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 22. -- A protest against an order issued yesterday by President Hoover ruling that contractors on Federal public works pay the wages prevailing locally was telegraphed to the President today by the executive committee of the Associated General Contractors of America, in convention here.

DENVER, Jan. 22 (AP). -- While police questioned a suspect in belief that the kidnapping of Benjamin P. Bower, a bakery manager, might be a result of labor trouble, Lewis N. Scherf, head of the Colorado State Law Enforcement Department, today blamed the abduction on professional extortionists.

Max Schmeling of Germany, world's heavyweight boxing champion, and Jack Sharkey, American, contender, last night signed contracts at the Madison Square Garden Club to meet in a fifteen-round fight in the Yankee Stadium under the auspices of the Madison Square Garden Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The decision of the City Planning Commissioner to petition the Board of Estimate to change from a residential to a business zone the four blocks of Lexington Avenue from Thirty-fourth to Thirty-eighth Street is indicative of the danger to the city's future in proceeding much longer without a master plan.

The R.S.R.L. Realty Corporation filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against the 708 West 177th Street Corporation, Jacob R. Schiff and others, to foreclose a balance due of $27,750 on mortgage for $117,000 on the property there given by Elizabeth Schindler in 1924.

Plans for the exploration of the wreck of the Lusitania, including the proposed raising of jewels, the taking of still and motion pictures and the recovery of certain historical objects, were described last night by Captain H.H. Railey, leader of the Lake-Railey Lusitania Expedition, in a radio address broadcast from the WABC studios of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The trouble with business is there is too much big business and not enough small. If big business ultimately absorbs small business, it will relegate those participating in small business to the laboring class. Big business therefore deceives its economic purpose and suffers beneath its own weight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Attorney General Mitchell was requested today in a resolution offered by Senator Blaine and adopted by the Senate to withhold action on the suit in Delaware against the Radio Corporation of America and others until the Senate Judiciary Committee could obtain the facts in the case.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Tammany Democrats in the House are organizing opposition to the proposal for a reduction in salaries in every branch of the Federal Government.

MR. PAPAVERT, a play in three acts, by H.S. Kraft, adapted from a novel by George Froeschel. Settings by Herbert Ward; staged by Mr. Kraft and Max Figman; second version produced by Joe Zelli. At the Vanderbilt Theatre.

New offerings of bonds and notes this week reached $107,401,000, the largest total since the week ended on June 26, 1931, when the aggregate was $188,141,000. Interest in new financing this week centred in the offering yesterday of a new issue of $100,000,000 New York City 6 per cent special corporate stock notes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Humanity may benefit from the philanthropies of Julius Rosenwald for generations to come, but the actual expenditure of his millions will be ended in fifteen years, ten less than the maximum he specified in opposing the "dead hand in philosophy."

Representatives of three more nations landed on American shores yesterday en route for the third Winter Olympic Games at Lake Placid, thus adding twenty-four athletes to the ever-increasing number of contestants.

MADRID, Jan. 22. -- The Red flag fell swiftly down from over town halls in Catalonia and the Spanish tricolor floated up again into the breeze as fast advancing cavalry, infantry and artillery pressed on today against the Red revolt which had swept up two river valleys for fifty miles, threatening to set all Catalonia aflame.

A total of $11,179,916 of new municipal issues, representing the requirements of twenty-nine communities, will come up for award next week, compared with this week's revised total of $11,253,777. The weekly average for the year to date stands at $13,833,981.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Bud Westhus, St. Louis, turned in the major upset of the world's three-cushion billiard championship tournament today by defeating Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., 50 to 46 in eighty-two innings. Layton has held the title ten times and was rated as the one man to beat this year.

Three team races between the Victory class racing yachts and the Class S boats of Oyster Bay will be arranged for next Summer. That was announced last night at the Victory class dinner held in the Hotel Brevoort. It is doubtful if the Victory boats will race the Inter-Clubs or Atlantics again, having beaten them both decisively.

George S. Van Schaick, State Insurance Commissioner, in a warning yesterday to casualty and surety companies doing business in this State, said that unless they file pledges before Feb. 15 with the Insurance Department that they will comply with the rules made by themselves as to business acquisition costs, he will recommend legislative action to control that phase of the insurance business.

Those who like to peer behind the scenes, hoping to catch a fleeting glimpse of the comedies and tragedies of workaday life, the foundations of business and domestic relations of men and women who yet yearn for romance and occasional adventure -- these are wont to scan with a certain vicarious relish the notices in the Personal Column of The London Times.

Acute weakness cropped out in the last hour of trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday and, with the modest losses of the early afternoon included, the market at the close snowed the widest net decline in several weeks. The selling started in the railway shares and spread to other sections of the list, so that the whole market felt the pressure to some extent before trading ended.

The one hundredth anniversary of the founding of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society will be celebrated with a special service tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Bishop Manning, who is the president, will preach the sermon.

Columbia University, in planning a great engineering centre comparable to the Medical Centre and costing $20,000,000 or more, is carrying out the ideal it has had for years of developing engineering scholars, not merely practitioners, Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia, said yesterday.

The discriminating and dominating influence of women has kept alive the New York stage at a time when it is severely depressed by hard times, Basil Rathbone, formerly a star of the talking pictures and now back on the legitimate stage, told 1,500 women at a meeting yesterday afternoon of the Theatre Assembly at the Astor.

Increasing optimism, indicated in trade reports from fifty-five leading cities, appears to be based mainly upon enlarged activity in some of the heavy industries and upon an increased volume of business amon wholesalers, according to the weekly review of Bradstreet's.

Book Club selections for February include "These Restless Heads' by Branch Cabell, chosen by the Book of the Month Club; "Mary's Neck," by Booth Tarkington, the Literary Guild selection, and "Life and Andrew Otway," by Neil Bell, selected by the Book League of America.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 22. -- A direct image television camera, said to be the most modern development in radio and which had just been completed after years of research, was destroyed today in a fire which swept the experimental laboratories and television broadcasting station of the de Forest Radio Company at 2 Brighton Avenue here.

Duncan MacInnes, who has been considered for many years by every city administration the highest authority on the intricacies of the city's financial affairs, will remain in his position as chief accountant of the Department of Finance, despite the fact that on Jan. 6 he passed the statutory age limit for retirement of 70 years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- A committee speaking for some of the major automobile manufacturers of the nation today visited President Hoover to ask that he intervene to prevent imposition of a 5 per cent sales tax on automobiles, while representatives of the tobacco industry were appearing before the Ways and Means Committee to protest a further levy on their product.
SAN SALVADOR, Salvador, Jan. 22. -- Towns in Guatemala near Antigua are reported to have suffered greatly from volcanic eruptions and earthquakes accompanying them in the last two days.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 22. -- Theodore H. Boss, 28 years old, and Aaron Heller, 30, law partners, surrendered to Police Captain Owen J. Cunningham late this morning and were charged with conspiring to defraud the American Insurance Company of New York. Judge Frederick Conant fixed their bail at $10,000 after they had pleaded not guilty.
Billy Petrolle, the old Fargo Express, is still crashing at high speed along the road of one of the most remarkable comeback campaigns in modern ring history.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 22. -- Though the inquiry into Chilean finances conducted through diplomatic channels by Secretary Stimson was considered a new departure here, the filing of Chile's reply at Washington is regarded with satisfaction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- President Hoover signed at six o'clock tonight the Reconstruction Finance Corporation bill to create a $2,000,000,000 fiscal agency to relieve the credit stringency and, in his own words, "to stop deflation in agriculture and industry, and thus to increase employment by the restoration of men to their normal jobs."
BOMBAY, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Since the beginning of the Nationalist campaign and the enactment of laws to control it, 798 persons, including many women, have been imprisoned in the United Provinces.

A complete reversal of the attitude of present laws dealing with vagrancy, drunkenness and other petty offenses, to "something other than punitive," was urged yesterday by George W. Kirchwey, former dean of the Columbia Law School and warden of Sing Sing prison, in an address before the Regional Conference on Social Hygiene at the Hotel New Yorker.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler - s communism "reactionary, destructive and despotic" and declares that he "last way to seek for prosperity a through isolation," in the introduction to his new book, "Looking Forward," published yesterday by Charles Scribner's Sons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Undismayed by the overwhelming defeat in the Senate of his proposed State prohibition referendum resolution, Senator Bingham announced today that he would press for a Senate vote on his 4 per cent beer bill.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 22. -- Three men were killed tonight and two others injured seriously when the light sedan in which they were riding on the Brunswick Pike four miles north of here crashed head-on with a heavy truck. The men, all residents of Philadelphia, were furniture executives and salesmen returning from a convention in New York.

BOSTON, Jan. 22. -- A crowd of 8,000 watched tonight's double-header at the Garden between the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League and the United States Olympic team and the Polish Olympic team and the Boston hockey club.

Ill-feeling against the police, landlords and city marshals that had grown more intense daily for two months burst into violence yesterday when a mob of 500, encouraged by the shouts of almost 4.000 others, battled with the entire police reserve force of the Bronx in an effort to prevent the eviction of seventeen families at 2,802 Olinville Avenue, in the Communist quarter, where a rent strike had been in progress.

PARIS, Jan. 22. -- For France's often reiterated policy that there can be no reduction of her reparations claims unless there is corresponding reduction in her debts and that there can be no large measure of disarmament without the conclusion of a pact of mutual assistance, Premier Laval today, in the Chamber of Deputies, obtained a majority of fifty-one.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP). -- Overpowering five employes as they came to work, two men robbed the Springfield Atlantic Bank today of between $12,000 and $15,000 and escaped.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Efforts of Dr. Paul N. Cyr to oust Huey P. Long from the Governor's seat met another judicial barrier today. The State Supreme Court dismissed litigation aimed at removing the Chief Executive on the ground that he has been elected to the United States Senate and therefore cannot retain the Governorship.

If the builders of Radio City hold themselves to strict neutrality between Americans and foreigners in the selection of artists to paint murals for the new development, art will be best served, in the opinion of Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 22. -- The Board of Education for the city of New Brunswick approved today the school fiscal budget for the 1932-33 school year permitting a decrease in the appropriations of $72,404 and $60,016 in the amount to be raised by direct taxation.

American universities have "ten times as much money for scientific research as is good for them" and need specialization much more than they need endowments, Dr. E.E. Free, editor of This Week's Science and science lecturer at New York University, told delegates yesterday to the American College Publicity Association conference, second district, at the Washington Square Centre of New York University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Addison E. Southard, American Minister Resident to Abyssinia, who was attacked on Sunday in Addis Abeba by a traffic officer and civilians after an automobile accident, was instructed by the State Department today to state personally to Emperor Haile Selassie that the American Government expected prompt steps would be taken to punish adequately the assailants and that full publicity would be given to the action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Antiprohibitionists in the House today predicted two prohibition test votes this session and said the Senate's rejection of the Bingham proposal favoring State referenda was without significance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- A prohibition referendum plank which is supposed to reflect the view of Governor Roosevelt on what should be the Democratic party's national declaration on prohibition is scheduled to be adopted by the Washington State Democratic Convention, it was learned here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- Hogs were in fairly good demand today and from 5 to 10 cents higher than yesterday, with some held off the market at the last in expectation of higher prices tomorrow. While the receipts were in excess of a week ago, they were about normal for this season of the year.

The personnel of the Health Department's Bureau of Food and Drugs was shaken up yesterday. About seventy-five men, from supervising inspectors down, were moved to different stations about the city. It was, according to officials of the department, "for the good of the service."

Gold to the amount of $20,474,000 left this country yesterday for France, including $12,000,200 which had been held under earmark here by the Bank of France. The remainder, $8,473,800, was bullion shipped as an exchange transaction, the franc having risen above the gold-export point.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am one of the mute millions who practically are never heard from in matters of great moment. Nevertheless, I wish I were able to contribute something helpful to world peace and reconstruction. We are in a bad mess.

The motor boat fleet of 1932 came into port at the Grand Central Palace last night for the opening of the twenty-seventh annual National Motor Boat Show. Yachts, cruisers, runabouts and outboards, in addition to thousands of all kinds of nautical accessories, make up the display which occupies four floors of the building.

The season's third performance of Verdi's "Forza del Destine" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was the occasion for the introduction of another newcomer to this country. He is Armando Borgioli, Italian baritone, and he sang the role of Don Carlos of Vargas, sang it in a manner that brought from the large audience sustained applause and some cheers several times during the evening.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, who will play his only regular recital here this season at Carnegie Hall this afternoon, will give a special recital for the benefit of unemployed musicians at Madison Square Garden Monday evening, Feb. 8, his manager, George Engles, announced yesterday.

An easier tone in call loans in the outside market, where 2 1/4 per cent prevailed, was the only feature of an otherwise quiet and steady money market. On the Stock Exchange the rate held at 2 1/2, as previously. Time money continued at 3 1/2@3 3/4 per cent, but business was along small lines.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Market's are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public. Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted.

It takes a case for trial by jury thirteen months to be reached in the Municipal Court, a year and a half in the Supreme Court, and three years in the City Court. Agitation for relieving congestion and eliminating delay has been frequent but futile.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Following is the text of the new Finance Reconstruction Act:

One hour after the case had had been placed in its hands by Judge Nott yesterday, a jury in General Sessions returned a verdict of acquittal in the misdemeanor trial of Henry R. Swanson, John S. Wallis and John Erter, engineers, on an indictment charging they disclosed confidential information obtained a few years ago in the course of their employment by the Foster Wheeler Corporation at 165 Broadway.

Henry Suydam Satterlee Jr. of 108 East Eighty-second Street is slowly recovering in the Doctors Hospital from a fractured skull he suffered a week ago yesterday when he was struck over the head with a wrench by one of two men who had attempted to steal his overcoat from his car, it was learned last night.

A late addition to next week's list of Broadway openings is Vincent Youman's musical version of Jane Cowl's play, "Smilin' Through," which, as "Through the Years," will open next Thursday evening, Jan. 28, at the Manhattan Theatre. Under the title of "Love Is All" the show will conclude a week's engagement in Washington tonight.

HONOLULU, Jan. 22. -- A situation unparalleled in Hawaiian jurisprudence occurred this afternoon when the grand jury which had been investigating the murder charge against Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, her son-in-law, and two navy enlisted men adjourned to Tuesday morning without making an announcement of the reasons for the interruption of its inquiry.

The directors of the Railroad Credit Corporation adjourned a two-day meeting yesterday without taking definite action on a proposal by which needy railroads could obtain the use of funds in advance of their receipt by the corporation through the discounting of loan certificates issued by the corporation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- One of the major demands of the unemployment program of the twenty-one standard railway unions, that of employment stabilization, was considered as satisfactorily settled today but another chief issue, the 10 per cent wage deduction for a year remains undecided before the conference of the unions' leaders and the railway presidents' committee.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- Governor Roosevelt was formally notified today of his election as a member of the Academie Diplomatique Internationale of France, to succeed the late Hugh C. Wallace, who served as Ambassador to France during the Wilson Administration.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- A suggestion that if the reparations conference can eventually be arranged the Prime Ministers of France and Britain should foregather half way between London and Paris has been made, it is understood here, to Premier Laval.

Prices sagged in stocks and bonds the New York Curb Exchange yesterday in line with the Stock Exchange and other security markets, th Aluminum of America, Ameriin Gas and Electric, A.O. Smith, ead Johnson, Tampa Electric and utilities Power and Light B among the weaker issues.

ADDIS ABEBA, Abyssinia, Jan. 22 (AP). -- The Foreign Minister and three other Cabinet members and the Mayor called today on Addison E. Southard, the American Minister, and apologized for an assault on him by a traffic policeman last Sunday.

Deputy City Clerk J. J. McCormich was indicted yesterday on two felony and two misdemeanor charges. He was the first Tammany district leader to be accused formally of a crime as a result of the investigation by the Hofstadter committee.
After displaying strenth for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved lower in sympathy with the stock markets and ended with losses of 5 to 6 points on the day.

With volume continuing on a small scale in over-the-counter trading yesterday few important price changes developed. Bank and insurance stocks sagged late after opening at about the closing levels of Thursday and holding steady in the early dealings. Other groups were also weak at the end.

Gates W. McGarrah, chairman of the Bank for International Settlements, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for a brief visit, but declined to comment upon reparations or other international questions. He declared that he was opposed to the issuing of more government bonds and in favor of increased taxation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- President Hoover's program for economic recovery, embracing the $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation, headed by General Charles G. Dawes, was hailed tonight as the "strongest and most far-reaching" ever sent to Congress by any President, by Secretary Hurley, in an address before the Commercial Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Plans to report the Glass bill to revise the Federal Reserve and national banking laws in virtually the identical form, in which it was completed by the subcommittee yesterday and introduced in the Senate were made today by members of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

GENEVA, Jan. 22 (AP).- Liberian natives who testified before the League of Nations commission which inquired into reports of slavery and economic conditions in the Negro republic have been visited by severe reprisals, representatives of humanitarian organizations reported today.

The Newhouse Gallery, formerly at 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, opens today its attractive new quarters at 578 Madison Avenue with an exhibition called "From Van Dyck to Lawrence." It was assembled to show the development of English portrait painting during the "great" period.

BERLIN, Jan. 22. -- Official circles, while regarding it settled that the Lausanne reparations conference will not meet on the date originally scheduled, in 1st on only a brief postponement, with a meeting in February. They stress that the Basle experts' report urged immediate action.
Sales of apartment houses in Yorkville, the Washington Heights section, Harlem and lower Manhattan were announced yesterday. Investors were active in the day's trading.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 22. -- In compliment to their house guests, the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Henry Darlington of New York, Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. entertained today with a luncheon at Casa del Pastor. Their other guests were Bishop and Mrs. Nathaniel Seymour Thomas, Mrs. William Guy Noll, Mrs. H. Ashton Henry, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Homer, Miss Katherine Homer, Miss Madeleine Henry, Miss Nellie Cluett and Dr. Clement Cleveland.

Counting from last Fall, a twelve-month will be marked by appeals to the people in most of the leading nations. Great Britain had her general election at the end of October. Our own Presidential election is moving on apace. The French elections are due in Spring.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- The British National Cabinet saved itself from disruption today by abandoning the ancient tradition that all members must act as a unit in support of any policy adopted by the government. It was the imposition of a 10 or 15 per cent tariff on manufactures that threatened a rift.
Into the fold came another member of the New York Giants yesterday when Frank Hogan, ponderous catcher of the McGraw forces, affixed his signature to a 1932 contract.
SHANGHAI, China, Jan. 22. -- Danger of a conflict between Japanese naval forces and foreign troops of the International Settlement surcharged the atmosphere with foreboding tonight.

Mr. MacInnes Stays On. DUNCAN MACINNES was 70 years old on Jan. 6. In the ordinary course of events, that would have meant his retirement, under the age limit, from the post which he has held for so many years that Controllers have come to regard him as a fixture -- chief accountant of the Department of Finance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- A step aimed at facilitating the conference between the railway unions and executives at Chicago was taken today in the passage by the Senate of a concurrent resolution authorizing a study of the six-hour day for rail workers by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP). -- A "leap year" proposal setting forth ten qualifications for her appointment to the Supreme Court to take the place of Oliver Wendell Holmes has been received by the Senate Judiciary Committee from Rose Palmer, who describes herself as a New York attorney.

The program which Vladimir Horowitz presented for his piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall was devoted to Bach, Beethoven and Brahms. Bach was represented by the C major Toccata and the Prelude and Fugue in F minor from the second book of the "Well-Tempered Clavichord;" Beethoven by the C minor Variations, Brahms by two intermezzi from opus 118 and 119, the Waltzes, opus 39, and the Variations on the theme of Paganini.
Lieutenant Francis X. Kelly, Army Air Corps Reserve, and his younger brother Edward were killed instantly yesterday when their plane spun, nose first, into Bowery Bay off Rikers Island.

For no visible reason, so far as Wall Street could see, the stock market turned sharply about in the late dealings yesterday and closed with substantial losses in many parts of the list. Trading on the Stock Exchange was not active, but the turnover was somewhat heavier than on the day before.

LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP). -- The lower house of the Convocation of Canterbury voted unanimously today to concur with the resolution adopted by the upper house Wednesday, calling for establishment of intercommunion between the Church of England and the Old Catholic churches of Europe.

LYNN, Mass., Jan. 22. -- By producing electrically a "mosquito hum" like the mating song of the female mosquito, thus luring the males, it may he possible through the newly reported discovery of Professor Elihu Thomson of the General Electric Company for mankind to overcome the mosquito post.

The net income of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for 1931 was $1,532,080, against $4,588,383 in 1930, according to the annual statement of the institution published yesterday by George L. Harrison, governor. This income was insufficient to meet the dividends of $3,891,598 paid by the bank in the year to member banks at the rate of 6 per cent, making necessary charges of $2,359,518 against surplus.
Many dinners were given in advance of the Beaux-Arts Ball last night. At virtually all of these previous entertainments the guests wore the costumes in which they attended the ball.

As the New York Central Railroad completed yesterday the presentation of additional evidence in support of its plea for a 40 per cent increase in commutation rates, Transit Commissioner Leon G. Godley questioned the reasonableness of certain proposed family ticket charges within New York City.

John Morley, veteran greenkeeper at the Youngstown Country Club, was re-elected president of the National Association of Greenkeepers of America yesterday at the annual meeting held at the Hotel Pennsylvania. It was Morley's sixth term as head of the organization.

Jersey City, N.J. Jersey City, N.J., scheduled yesterday a new issue of $5,500,000 tax revenue bonds for award on Feb. 3. The issue will be dated Feb. 1, 1932, and will mature on Aug. 1, 1935. Bidders are asked to stipulate the rate of interest and to name prices of not less than par.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Click, a consistent winner over the smaller tracks last year, made his initial start of the Winter at Jefferson Park today and won the Charlie Trimble purse of six furlongs for the Carleton stable. It was Click's first race since failing to win at Laurel following a successful season at Thistle Down Park and Bainbridge Park.
Dr. Charles Brancati, the Italian physician who walked from his Throgs Neck mansion one morning more than three years ago and has never been seen since, is officially dead.

New York is the largest manufacturing city in the world -- sufficient reason why it should have the twenty-five-million-dollar Engineering Centre proposed by Dean BARKER of Columbia and approved by President BUTLER. Ideas rather than endowments make educational institutions.

MADRID, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Convinced that the Catalonian movement has been crushed, the Spanish Government directed its attention tonight to Andalusia, Galicia and this city, where extremist propaganda apparently was spreading.

MOSCOW, Jan. 22. -- The first outlines of the hew Five-Year Plan were presented to the Soviet public today in the form of "directives" for discussion by the coming communist party conference. These outlines are detailed statements that are to be made about the plan by Premier Vyacheslaf Motoloff and V.V. Quibesheff, chairman of the State Planning Commission.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- Manhattan Prep's basketball team defeated Iona School, 15-12, today in a Manhattan division C.H.S.A.A. game. Manhattan Prep led, 9 -- 6, at the half.
NANKING, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Former President Chiang Kai-shek, who resigned in disgrace five weeks ago, returned in triumph today to help save the Chinese Government from financial disaster.

A new scientific tool for probing further into the inner mysteries of matter which, its discoverers hope, will furnish the first direct experimental evidence of the motion of electrons within the atoms of metals and other solids at the terrific speeds postulated by Bohr, propounder of the orbital theory of the electron on only indirect evidence, is described in the current issue of The Physical Review, official organ of the American Physical Society.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Shorter working hours as a means of taking up slack in unemployment will receive a thorough study at the hands of a House committee.

Ohio's Republican State Committee has the honor of being the first State machine to offer renomination to Mr. HOOVER. There were but two dissenting votes, one and perhaps both of them survivals of the grudges left by the defeat of the late Senator WILLIS as an aspirant to the Presidency in 1928.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 22 (AP). -- William H. Jones Jr., former Adjutant General of the Kentucky National Guard, and two former Captains in the Guard were indicted by a grand Jury today. Two true bills charging embezzlement of Guard funds were returned against Jones and one each against C.L. Gullett of Salt Lick and Albert E. Ely of Glasgow.

School teachers throughout the city will be asked to increase their contributions to the School Relief Fund to aid the needy school children, according to plans discussed yesterday at a meeting of 100 representatives of teachers' organizations with Superintendent William J. O'Shea and other school officials.

THE Americans were in their dressing room in the Garden, donning their harness for the recent debate with the Chicago Black Hawks. Big Vernon Ayres, draping over his shoulders a set of harness that would have dismayed a fire horse, loomed as large as Primo Camera. Bill Burch was looking for a bit of tape. Red Dutton was testing a couple of sticks. Normie Himes was hauling a sweater over his head.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Not a single complete copy of the voluminous report of the Wickersham Commission on Law Observance and Enforcement has been sold.
MANRESA, Spain, Jan. 22. -- The government's punitive force was hunting Reds in the mountains near Figols tonight.

The Jamaica High School hockey team annexed the P.S.A.L. championship for the sixth time in seven years by repulsing Manual Training, 3 to 0, before a capacity crowd of more than 900 persons at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The victory enabled Jamaica to finish its season undefeated with five victories and two ties.

GUATEMALA CITY, Jan. 22 (AP). -- A series of more than three-score earthquake shocks which sent a part of the Republic of Guatemala into a shiver yesterday damaged communications, and it was feared today considerable damage might have been wrought in the sections around the two volcanoes Fuego and Acatenango, which began to erupt after the shocks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22. -- All of Yale's crew races with its traditional rivals, Harvard, Princeton, Columbia, Pennsylvania and Cornell, will be rowed away from home the coming season, according to the schedule announced tonight by the Yale Athletic Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Not a single complete copy of the voluminous report of the Wickersham Commission on Law Observance and Enforcement has been sold.
MANRESA, Spain, Jan. 22. -- The government's punitive force was hunting Reds in the mountains near Figols tonight.

The Jamaica High School hockey team annexed the P.S.A.L. championship for the sixth time in seven years by repulsing Manual Training, 3 to 0, before a capacity crowd of more than 900 persons at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. The victory enabled Jamaica to finish its season undefeated with five victories and two ties.

GUATEMALA CITY, Jan. 22 (AP). -- A series of more than three-score earthquake shocks which sent a part of the Republic of Guatemala into a shiver yesterday damaged communications, and it was feared today considerable damage might have been wrought in the sections around the two volcanoes Fuego and Acatenango, which began to erupt after the shocks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22. -- All of Yale's crew races with its traditional rivals, Harvard, Princeton, Columbia, Pennsylvania and Cornell, will be rowed away from home the coming season, according to the schedule announced tonight by the Yale Athletic Association.

The Japanese Room of the St. Regis was thronged last night for the Yankee Doodle Ball, an event arranged for the benefit of the Stony Wold Sanitarium by its Auxiliary No. 6, of which Mrs. Alfred L. White is honorary chairman and Mrs. Abel I. Smith, chairman.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 22. -- Vice Chancellor Robert H. Ingersoll confirmed today the agreement made by contestants under the will of the late Samuel Braunstein, wealthy merchant, whereby his wife, Mrs. Bertha H. Braunstein, and a grandchild, Doris Adele Braunstein, would receive $4,800 and $2,500 a year, respectively.

Although showing a slight improvement over recent reports, bank clearances in the week ended on Thursday were still substantially below those of the same week last year. The total for twenty-two leading centres was $5,781,983,000, a decline of 23.7 per cent from a year before, according to Dun's Review.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa sailed last night for the Channel ports with 950 passengers and 6,000 sacks of mail. In her fifteen hours in port the vessel, employing 150 longshoremen, discharged 1,000 tons of special express freight and took on board the same quantity, in addition to 6,000 tons of oil fuel and 5,000 tons of fresh water; also 750 passengers who landed and 3,800 bags of mail were unloaded.

Passaic High School's unbeaten quintet rallied in the last five minutes to defeat Xavier High, 29 to 28, yesterday in the Xavier gymnasium before about 1,000 spectators. The triumph was the tenth for the Jersey team.

LIVERPOOL, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British clocks 902.000 bales, against 883,000 a week ago, 913,000 two weeks ago, 921,000 three weeks ago and 1,081,000 a year ago; of which American 428,000 bales, against 411,000 a week ago, 422,000 two weeks ago, 425,000 three weeks ago and 592,000 a, year ago.

The costumes worn last night at the Beaux-Arts ball were gorgeous and in some cases defied description. Rare silks, satins, brocades, metal cloth and velvets, richly embroidered and lace trimmed, furnished the materials. For years some of the costumes have been on exhibition in museums, lent by their present owners, descendants of the original wearers.

At a meeting attended by legislative leaders of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and a commission that has studied the problems of harbor pollution in New York for the last year, a compact was drafted yesterday afternoon linking the three States in a fight against waterway pollution through creation of an interstate sanitation district and a permanent commission and the setting up of standards of purity for the district.

District Attorney Charles B. McLaughlin of the Bronx is slated to succeed the late George V. Mullan on the Supreme Court bench by appointment of Governor Roosevelt, it was reported yesterday. Mr. McLaughlin's appointment, if it goes through, will settle the controversy over the place which has been going on quietly since shortly after Justice Mullan's death.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 22 (AP). -- "Rock of Ages" and "Nearer My God to Thee" will live on in the hymnal of the Methodist churches.

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- Governor Roosevelt announced today that he had forwarded to Sheriff Thomas M. Farley for an answer the additional charge made by Samuel Seabury, counsel for the Hofstadter Investigating Committee.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club definitely clinched the honors in the first group of Class B in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League last night when it scored a clean sweep on its own courts over the Park Avenue Squash Club to win its seventh successive victory since the start of the season.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- Tabulation of the contestants in the third Winter Olympics to be held here Feb. 4-13, entries for which closed at midnight Thursday, showed today that seventeen nations, represented by 354 athletes, will participate in the international competition.

With, an entry exceeding that of the splendid exhibition of a year ago and bringing out quality that had never before been approached in this country, the annual Riding Club Hound Show yesterday attracted sportsmen and sportswomen from the hunting centres all over the country to the spacious ring of the Riding Club at 7 West Sixty-sixth Street.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 22. -- A 6-year-old daughter of the Kentucky Derby winner, Meridian, won the Suwanee River Claiming Handicap, feature at Hialeah Park today, when C.H. Miller's Meridian Queen landed the major share of the $1,500 purse. Meridian Queen was made the 6-to-5 favorite in a field of seven and won by half a length from J.P. White's John F.

PARIS, Jan. 22. -- "I shall buy a little boat with a white sail and go sailing in the sunshine on the blue Mediterranean Sea," Aristide Briand replied today to his questioners as what he intended to do now that he has laid down the seals of his office.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT HARDING AT SEA, Jan. 22. -- The belief in the United States that the American delegation "will have practically a deciding voice" at the disarmament conference in Geneva is deplored by Dr. Mary E. Woolley. She and Senator Swanson, the other official American delegate aboard this ship, conferred today with the State Department's technical advisers accompanying them to Geneva.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 22 (AP). -- The propriety of the conduct of the trial of eight Negroes who were convicted and condemned to death at Scottsboro for assaults on two white girls was argued in the Alabama Supreme Court today under the watchful eyes of prison guards posted to thwart any attempt at demonstrations.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- Sterling exchange was weaker today, the New York rate falling to $3.44 3/4. The stock markets generally were dull, although there was some activity in British Government funds, the war loan rising to u98 3/4 before reacting to u98 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Concern was expressed tonight over possible developments at Shanghai, where a Japanese naval demonstration is threatened due to rioting and the pressure of the economic boycott against Japan by the Chinese as a result of the Manchurian crisis.

Two robbers who dug a tnnnel to get around burglar alarms were caught yesterday in the act of stealing $15,000 worth of cigars and cigarettes. They had held captive for ten hours both the watchman and the engineer of an adjoining building, and it was that fact that betrayed them, for the patrolman on the beat is accustomed to talk to the employes, and when they were not around he suspected that something was wrong.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The Government of Chile, in a reply to a questionnaire from the Senate Finance Committee, made public today at the Chilean Embassy, officially denied that favors given to Cosach, the $300,000,000 nitrate syndicate orNational partly with the aid of the Nacional City Company and Guggenheim Co., had contributed to sus pensions of payments on its foreigin obligations.
LONDON, Jan. 22. -- A dispatch to The Times, London, from Shanghai tonight says:

COURT HOUSE, Phoenix, Ariz., Jan. 22 (AP). -- Winnie Ruth Judd's trial for murder reached a crucial phase today with defense counsel battling unsuccesfully against the admissibility of the State's physical evidence.

The city's new $100,000,000 issue of special corporate stock notes, bearing interest at 6 per cent and maturing in three, four and five years, was heavily oversubscribed yesterday within a few hours of the opening of the books of the banking syndicate.

Members of the New York State Bar Association expressed themselves as overwhelmingly in favor of retaining the jury system in a discussion of trial by jury at yesterday afternoon's session of the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the association at the Bar Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- Weakness in the stock marker, todny incressed pressure on wheat on the Board of Trade here, but the selling was mainly local. Houses with eastern connections absorbed the surplus in the pit at 59 1/2 cents a bushel and less for the May on scale order and toward the last short covering caused a moderate rally from the inside figures.

Senator BINGHAM'S resolution for a State prohibition poll was ill-judged, ill-timed and inconclusive. Its overwhelming defeat in the Senate, 55 to 15, was merited. Wet Senators who felt obliged to vote for it lest they be considered backsliders must have said things under their breath.

Professor SAMUEL A. BALDWIN, who gives his last Great Hall concert as organist of the City College next Monday night, has won the title of "Organist to the City of New York." In the course of the twenty-four years of his semi-weekly public concerts he has been to this city what in other ages and countries great musicians have been to monarchs.

PARIS, Jan. 22. -- Although the dollar almost touched the gold-import point today at 25.395, there was decided easing of press criticisms of American stability, while the Temps even printed a highly reassuring front-page editorial. The general opinion here is that the nervous flurry which began early in the week is over, and while the dollar may temporarily drop below the goldshipping point, it will not be for long nor will gold withdrawals be heavy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Reports that kidnappers were plotting to seize General Charles G. Dawes, president of the $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation, were circulated here today, but they left the General unperturbed. Puffing away at his underslung pipe, he went about his business at the capital as usual and chuckled over the tale.

DIE WALKUERE," the second act of which will be broadcast from the Metropolitan Opera house on Saturday at 3 P.M. over a coast-to-coast network affiliated with WEAF, is the second of the four operas forming Richard Wagner's great series of music-dramas, "Der Ring des Nibelungen."

BERLIN, Jan. 21 -- The necessity of offsetting paralyzing effects of the runs on German banks and the gold reserves of the Reichsbank in 1931 has led in recent months to numerous projects demanding a strict deflationary or moderate inflationary policy, or pleading for the creation of a new internal currency or the reduction of the foreign value of the mark by changing its relation to gold.

UNDER the auspices of the Canadian Club of New York in conjunction with the English Speaking Union of the United States an entertainment will be given on the night of Feb. 2 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the British Great War Veterans of America.

HONOLULU, Jan. 23 -- With Hawaii's new chief of police bill acquiring the status of law after five days before the territorial Legislature, the members of the Senate today turned all their attention to the matter of a public prosecutor to supplant the existing City and County attorney on the island of Oahu.

LOOKING back over the thirty-nine years I have spent in the motor-boat industry. I find there has been no brighter spot for the expansion and growth of the trade and sport than is offered in the present year and those to follow.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 23 -- Governor Huey P. Long left here tonight in a special car for Washington where he expects to assume his duties as junior Senator from Louisiana. He made a brief statement asserting that "within a few minutes Lieut. Gov. Alvin O. King will become Governor."

Details of a lease of the Hotels Brevoort and Lafayette are shown in an instrument just recorded in the Register's Office. Last Friday it was announced that the Brevoort would become part of the chain operated by Ex-Sheriff David H. Knott, but that Raymond Orteig would continue to operate the Lafayette.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Villanova College proved too speedy for the Montclair A.C. tonight on the club basketball court and won, 29 to 20.

To the Editor of The New York Times: 'When one reads such utterances as that of Father John Corbett, summarized in THE TIMES, one tends to become convinced that the time is not yet ripe for the reunion of Christendom which the Pope, in common with other men of good-will, so strongly desires, because the good-will is not sufficiently widespread in any part of Christendom for the problem to be approached in the right spirit.

CAIRO, Jan. 22 -- During the present Moslem month of Ramadan, when the Mohammedans fast for thirty days from sunrise to sunset, the Arab countries of the Near and Middle East are experiencing a period of calm. During the month no Mohammedan, will make an important political move which may result in any sort of disturbance.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 23 -- Manitoba, latest of Canada's Provinces to come forward in the mining industry, appears now to have made in 1931 an increase of almost 100 per cent in output over the preceding year, and indications are that the progress will be maintained.

DETROIT. AS an interesting commentary on the mysterious relationships of seemingly unrelated circumstances, the stream of smoke pouring from motor-car factory chimneys in Detroit is thinner these days, all because a group of men are meeting in Washington.

Brooklyn Prep's hockey team retained its lead in the Catholic High School Athletic Association tournament by blanking Loughlin High, 2 to 0 at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. In other games La Salle Military Academy routed St. James. 7 to 1, and St. Michael's defeated Holy Trinity, 1 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A belief that consolidation of the army and navy into a Department of National Defense would greatly increase the cost of national defense instead of reducing it $100,000,009, as had been contended, was expressed by Representative Charles H. Martin, a member of the House Committee on Expenditures in the Executives Department, in testifying today before that committee.

Welfare leaders continued yesterday to urge upon the city the necessity of making available for unemployment relief the $20,000,000 appropriated for the purpose, asserting that the sum voted was at best a minimum requirement and actually would not even meet the minimum needs.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 -- There are promising signs in Southern California that the corner around which better times are said to be lurking is not as far out in the suburbs as it has been. The situation in Los Angeles is difficult to diagnose.

MANY works have been written during the past ten years dealing with the problems that beset mankind of the present day -- the problem of disarmament, the problem of social relationship and the problems arising from economic disorder.

RADIO found it easy in the beginning to inject novelty into broadcasting. Today the microphone showmen are crying for more of the circus element, and they are reaching to far away places to attract attention. They have sent microphones down in submarine and broadcast from the bottom of Long Island Sound.

The air-mail postage stamp collection of John Aspinwall, a retired banker of Newburgh, which is said to be the largest and most valuable of its kind in the world, will be taken to London this week by Joseph Hoffman, advisory philatelic agent for Mr. Aspinwall, and placed in the custody of Frank Godden, one of the leading stamp dealers in Europe.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The Board of Parole announced today that investigation had failed to reveal evidence on which to declare Owen (Owney) Madden, alleged racketeer, a parole violator and return him to prison.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Pennsylvania's five ended its losing streak and at the same time broke Army's winning streak by beating the Cadets at the Palestra tonight, 22 to 18. The West Pointers had won four in a row before coming here.

HENRY McBRIDE'S "Palette Knife'' in the January issue of Creative Art contains, among other items, an incisive commentary on Picasso's "Metamorphoses." Fitzroy Carringrton revives the "Fifteenth Century Florentine Love Story" of Lorenzo di Medici and Lucrezia Donati, through the medium of some Otto prints; Dr. M.F. Agha, art director of the Conde Nast publications, writes an appreciation of the photography of Ralph Steiner, and Walter Rendell Storey discusses "Modern German Church Art."

MADRID. SOME one once called democracy the most splendid dream the mind of man has yet conceived. But a castle in Spain is an older, simpler, more closely cherished dream -- a dream with roots that go back to one's childhood, a dream that has about it all toe dear excitements of knights in armor and dragons breathing fire, of jousts and tourneys and ladies languishing in high towers.

The supply of Southern and Western vegetables in local markets during the past week was quite plentiful with price fluctuations generally small, especially on attractive quality products, George G. Royce, acting director of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, reported yesterday in his weekly consumers' review.

IN the Spring the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey will begin a comprehensive geodetic control survey of Long Island and the Connecticut shores. Reconnoissance headquarters at Sag Harbor, in the eastern part of Long Island, have already been established after a connection was selected for the new survey with the main survey of the country in Southeastern Massahusetts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond had reduced its rediscount rate from 4 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent on all classes of paper, effective on Monday.

THE hundredth anniversary of James Clerk Maxwell's birth was celebrated in October last at Cambridge, where he was the first director of the Cavendish Laboratory, by appropriate ceremonies in which some of the foremost physicists of our time piously participated.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 23 -- A field goal by Fuchs one minute be fore the end of the gamp, enabled American University to defeat the Naval Academy basketball team today, 22 to 20. The winning goal was made following six minutes of scoreless play with the score a 20-20 deadlock and both aides missing attempts at foul goals.

RICHMOND, Jan. 21 -- One of the liveliest controversies of recent months, a controversy in which H.L. Mencken and The Baltimore Evening Sun have been arrayed against the citizenry and press of the eastern shore of Maryland and Virginia, is gradually simmering down, with all hands apparently tired of dipping their pens in vitriol, after some weeks devoted to hurling epithets back and forth across the Chesapeake.

ROME, Jan. 7 -- When Pius XI was raised to the supreme dignity of Pontiff he had been occupied only five years in diplomatic missions. In 1917 he had been sent as Apostolic Visitator to Poland and then, in quick succession, was promoted to be Apostolic Nuncio to the same country, then Archbishop of Milan and finally Cardinal.

THE literary highlight of the week in Hollywood is the announcement that the Warners have acquired the services of Paul Green, young Professor of Phiosophy at the University of North Carolina, winner of the Pulitzer Prize with his play of several seasons ago, "In Abraham's Bosom," and represented in the first months of the current season with the drama, "The House of Connelly."
