ATER opening last Friday evening in the Grand Central Palace, the twenty-seventh annual National Motor Boat Show will resume tomorrow and continue through the week from 10:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. The exhibition occupies the first four floors of the building.

AGAIN, at the Great Wall of China, a vivid chapter of world history is being written, to the accompaniment of the clash of arms and the tumult of nations. Before it now stand the troops of Japan, after overrunning most of Manchuria -- a new invader at the gates of China.

With several plans under way to improve conditions in the cotton poods industry, through curtailment of production, a firmer attitude on prices and the clarification of distributive methods, leaders in the industry are hopeful that the current year may eliminate to some extent many of the abuses prevalent since the war, a canvass of opinions has disclosed.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 13 -- Almost every month sees some distinguished visitor in Buenos Aires absorbing his or her first impressions of Argentina's capital, and at the same time telling the world how its atmosphere reacts on the artistic or professional temperament.
Athletic letters for Fall sports were given to fifty-nine boys at Morris High School. Twenty-three were honored in football, a similar number in soccer and thirteen in cross-country.

WEIMAR, Germany, Jan. 22 -- The State of Thuringia may have to release $1,500,000 worth of real estate which, with another $5,500,000 worth, passed into the State's possession when, in June, 1919, claims of the ducal house that ruled Sachsen-Altenburg -- with a lot of other small principalities consolidated in the State of Thuringia after the revolution -- were settled by compromise.

George H. Moses, President protem of the United States Senate, speaking at the weekly non-partisan discussion yesterday afternoon in the National Republican Club, Inc., 54 West Fortieth Street, opposed cancellation of foreign debts to this country.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 22 -- Industrial operations are recovering slowly from the year-end inventory period. Steel ingot output was up about five points over last week, and holding around 25 per cent. The bulk of the new business is in small orders. No marked increase in buying from farm implement or rallroad sources is expected soon.

NEW YORK is now being canvassed by a thousand persons who are gathering information to be incorporated in a new city directory, the first since 1925. New York's first city di- rrctory, published in 1786, contained eighty-two pages and 821 names, and weighed approximately nine ounces.

THE Walt Kuhn exhibition at Marie Harriman's Gallery, originally scheduled to close Jan. 23, has met with such gratifying attendance that it has been extended an additional week and will not close until Saturday, Jan. 30.

DOCTOR KERKHOVEN." with its six hundred-odd pages, would seem a truly formidable piece of work were it not for the fact that actually two novels are here bound together as one. They are related stories, the Doctor Kerkhoven being the central character of each, the first story dealing with his early life, the second with his latter years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The landing of Japanese forces at Shanghai today caused apprehension here because of the added complication it might produce in the Sino-Japanese controversy over the Manchurian situation and the possibility that it might lead to difficulties with other powers through untoward incidents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Hoover today signed the bill providing $125,000,000 additional capital for Federal Land banks, thereby enacting what he termed "the third of our reconstruction measures."

SUGGESTIVE of the present-day tendency to incorporate folk art into contemporary interiors is the Swedish-Finnish exhibition of arts and crafts now at the Home Making Centre, Grand Central Palace. Here, in striking contrast, the visitor may see ancient peasant chairs and tables, contemporary pieces inspired by those of other times, and antique rugs and hangings that have furnished motifs for modern weaving.

BEING an uncommonly allusive stylist, Philip Barry presents something of a problem for the hard-pressed morning reviewer. The beauty of his plays lies in their deft, buoyant manner. They are not expositions of ideas: they are distillations of mood and spirit.

A GOOD story of New Zealand written by some one who knows it and has a real feeling for that country of wind and sky, rapid rivers and endless plains stretching away to unexplored mountain ranges. For the hero, Bobbie Cornish, the country itself and the thousands of sheep pastured on its plains have a boundless fascination.

The Rev. Clifford S. Gregg, who last Summer celebrated his twenty-fifth anniversary as rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, at 166th Street and Trinity Avenue, died in St. Luke's Hospital, Manhattan, yesterday in his sixty-second year, after an illness of two years.

The daily programs for broadcasting the Winter Olympics at Lake Placid over the nation-wide chains of the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System have been completed. Each system has arranged to give accounts of high lights on the Olympic schedule and resumes of events after the contests are completed.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 21 -- Possibilities that ex-Governor Walter M. Pierce and his wife, Cornelia Marvin Pierce, may enter the May primaries for nomination as Representatives in Congress from the Second District in opposing parties has created a situation not without interest and amusement to the voters of the State.

Economic planning, through self-control and self-regulation of industry, as exemplified by the functions that the New York clearing houses performed for member banks, was urged yesterday by Paul P. Gourrich, economist, as necessary to prevent dictatorship for business and to preserve individual efforts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The interest that had been supporting wheat of late on the Board of Trade here stepped aside today, apparently not Siking the action of stocks, and with the disappearance of the aggressive buying on scale orders that had been evident earlier in the week, prices dropped 1 7/8 cents from yesterday's finish before the decline was checked.

IMPORTANT developments have lettered the week red. Both the Metropolitan Museum and the Museum of Modern Art turned corners, almost simultaneously, entering new phases alive with auguries for the future. The question of mural embellishment for Radio City was brought smartly on to the carpet through the instrumentality of a combined protest and plea drawn up and signed by some fifty students in one of Ralph Pearson's classes at the New School for Social Research.

Orders were more plentiful in the wholesale markets during the week, with, the large contingent of visiting buyers making substantial purchases of ready-to-wear, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the Independent Merchandising Bureau, Inc., formerly Standard Store Service Company.

This is not the first time in American history when calls for a New York Governor to the Presidency came strongest from the South and the West. There has been no official party expression in New York, thus far, concerning the known aspirations of FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT. But the Democrats of Georgia, Alabama, Maine, Washington, the Dakotas and other States have been urging his candidacy.

COUNT D'HARNONCOURT tells us that "life in the Mexican hills and small towns is romantic but not sentimental." And he ought to know, having spent much time in the more remote districts studying Mexico's native art heritage and collecting material for the Carnegie Foundation.

CHIEF CONSTABLE SIR CLINTON DRIFFIELD, who has appeared in more than one of J.J. Connington's detective stories, is the man who gets to the bottom of the mystery surrounding the deaths of several members of a syndicate which holds a winning ticket in a sweepstakes.

ESCAPE from the tragic situation in which Mr. Dreiser finds America today must be sought, he thinks, along the road to freedom now building in Soviet Russia. To be sure, this means embarking on a great adventure, but "who is so mean as to fear adventure."

THE probable answer to the puzzle as to why stock boat sales kept up as well as they did last year is that the modern, moderate-size cruiser is stepping out of the luxury class and becoming more and more regarded as a Summer home, or a substitute for resort hotel bills and Summer cottage rentals.

Governor Roosevelt's announcement of his candidacy comes at a time when a survey of the strength of the Roosevelt boom in the various States, made by his friends, shows him to be within a hundred votes of the number necessary to nominate him on the first ballot at the Chicago convention on June 27.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Taking the lead at the outset, the Rider College swimmers had little trouble humbling Manhattan College at the Central Y.M.C.A. pool today. The final score was 37 to 22.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Six of the eight seeded players in the New Jersey squash tennis championship advanced as the tournament opened at the Short Hills Club today. The two others, including Harry F. Wolf of Montclair, the national champion, drew byes and will see action tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Myrtle Tanner Blacklidge celebrates the first anniversary of the disclosure of a $50,000 faro swindle by filing suit for $150,000 against Edward H. Litsinger, from whom she borrowed the $50,000.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 23 -- Navy's aggressive and well-balanced 1932 wrestling team made its debut here this afternoon by defeating the Eastern intercollegiate championship team of Lehigh University, 5 bouts to 3, for a point tally of 23 to 13.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Chicago and the rest of Illinois are experiencing one of the gravest financial crises in recent years.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 23 (AP) -- President Olaya Herrera announced today that his government had agreed to pay in scrip the interest on foreign debts of various departments and municipalities. The bonds affected are held principally in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Adopting a special rule by the vote of 153 to 24, the House today amended the agricultural appropriation bill, carrying $175,443,814, to prohibit salary increases in grade in the department during the remainder of 1932 and the fiscal year 1933.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Leo Tissean of Paris came here today to make housing arrangements for French athletes who will compete in the third Winter Olympics at this resort Feb. 4-13.

TURIN, Jan. 8, 1932. A FEW miles to the north of Cremona lies a small town the name of which, for the most part unknown, frequently recurs in the biographies of Vincenzo Bellini. This town is called Casalbuttano.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Although nothing has yet been definitely arranged, it is expected here that an interview between Prime Minister MacDonald of Britain and Premier Laval will take place toward the end of the coming week and that it will be held in Paris.

THE traditional units of rural local government, essentially unchanged since the days of Edward III, have in two short decades been almost entirely demoded. The town or township, legitimate descendant of the Germanic tun, the most primitive cell of our political life, if moribund.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- New York artists made nearly a clean sweep of the prizes for both painting and sculpture announced tonight as the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts opened its 127th annual exhibition with a private view. The show will be open to the public from tomorrow to March 13.

There are some important things about caring for babies that are not taught in the physiologies and pathologies. * * * Parent education * * * must bring about changed attitudes toward children, and, by the same process, changed attitudes toward human beings in general.

The National Oratorical Contest on the Constitution, which is conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES in the metropolitan area, will open for its ninth consecutive year on Feb. 1. Last year more than 82,000 students in this region took part in the competition and this year an even larger participation is expected.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 23 -- An assurance that if Pope Pius XI will appoint a commission of Roman Catholics, an equal number of Protestants "foremost in scholarship and friendly attitudes" will be appointed by the Christian Unity League "to confer over the points that divide us" is on its way to the Vatican from the Rev. Dr. Peter Ainslie of this city.

Staging a sensational rally in the second half after trailing by 19 -- 4 at the close of the first period, Manhattan's quintet triumphed over St. John's. 29 -- 27, at the 102d Engineers' Armory last night.

THE numerous attractions of a cruise to the West Indies are being offered as inducement to those who would leave the hustle of city life in the late Winter and at the same time bring assistance to a worthy philanthropy -- the Frontier Nursing Service.

CONTRARY to the estimates of pessimists, there were more motor boats registered in 1931 than in 1930, proving that even in depression times more people are turning to boating. What the reaction to the industry will be when the tide of prosperity turns, it Is not difficult to gauge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Senator Borah, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, declared today against extension of the Hoover holi- day year on intergovernmental debts under present circumstances in a public statement in which he placed upon France the responsibility for leadership in Europe at a time when he fears disaster may be impending.

Beatrice Jacobs of Brooklyn purchased the four-story brick apartment house on a plot 100 by 34 feet at 882-888 Pavonia Avenue, northwest corner of Van Wagenen Avenue, Jersey City, assessed at $86,400, from Boyarsky, Feder Denson, Inc.

Goeta Ljungberg sang Wagner's Elsa for the first time here -- looked the character, as well as sang it -- in the Metropolitan's third performance of "Lohengrin" at the opera last night. There was a large attendance of German opera devotees, drawn by reports of the new Swedish soprano in consequence of her debut as Sieglinde in "Die Walkuere" three nights before.

UNSEASONAL weather continued to take its toll of retail trade during the week and, combined with other adverse circumstances, held down sales, to the low level which has so far characterized the month's operations. With very indifferent results for the most part on the usual apparel promotions, the stores have given more attention to home furnishings and report fair activity on such lines.

WASHINGTON. IN the days at the suffrage parades, when "Votes for Women" was a battle cry that stirred some people to wild enthusiasm and made others tremble for the future of the Republic, the startling prediction that a woman would some day sit in the United States Senate would have called up a very definite image.

ONE of the so-called added inducements Chicago offered in bidding for the national political conventions was that the conclaves could be televised, enabling "people within a 500-mile radius of the Chicago Stadium to see as well as hear the conventions."

Scoring as bad advice such statements to consumers as "put in circulation all the money you can" and "speed up the pace of buying all around," Professor F.W. Taussig of Harvard University, the economist, declared over the radio last night that "a sudden burst of all-around spending is not the remedy for the present distresses."

MR. FORD'S chief interests in writing have been style and accuracy. He has written about each to excess, not always clearly, and has often enough shown himself singularly deficient in both. Those who read him for an accurate survey of the immediate past are about to endure confusion and recurrent vexation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Vigorous opposition was expressed to the Ways and Means Committee today by automobile manufacturers and dealers against the proposal of the administration for an excise levy of 5 per cent on passenger vehicles, 3 per cent on trucks and 2.5 per cent on repair parts.

With a total business 100,000 shares larger than on the previous Saturday, trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday attracted only passing interest. Wall Street, it appeared, is finding it difficult to simulate enthusiasm for a market that is entirely professional.

LONDON. LEWIS CARROLL sleeps beneath the yews and cypresses in the steep hillside cemetery at Guildford, but Mrs. Alice Hargreaves is happily still with us. Years and years ago Mrs. Hargreaves was Miss Alice Liddell -- the Alice of "Alice in Wonderland" and "Through the Looking Glass."

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Trading on the Bourse today was restricted to a very small volume, with prices irregular during most of the session. There was a slight rally just before the close, but a good proportion of the list sustained losses on the day. Some foreign leaders weakened because of the unfavorable situation reported from other markets.

To the Art Editor: AFTER reading Albert Sterner's letter in the Readers' Forum on American art, I am moved to write just a few words of appreciation for the lucid and understandable way in which he takes his stand.

THE Federal Radio Commission, having thrown down the bars with regard to announcements of phonograph records and electrical transcriptions as such, effective Feb. 15, the listening public, beginning at that time, is apt to hear "some fancy camouflaging," according to observers in Washington.
BARCELONA, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Extremist workers today put on a prelude to the nation-wide general strike called for next Monday. They succeeded in crippling activities of all sorts in Barcelona.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Kv Laffoon, Denver professional, stroked his way into a tie for the lead with Ralph Guldahl, professional from Detroit, at the halfway mark of the Arizona open golf tournament today. They ended the thirty-six holes with scores of 141, three under par.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 23 (AP). -- The $10,000,000 suit brought by depositors of the closed Peoples State Bank of South Carolina against the Chemical Bank and Trust Company of New York and Jerre L. Dowling will be dropped, it was announced here today by Thomas, Lumpkin Cain, Columbia attorneys, and N. Baxter Jackson, vice president of the Chemical Bank, alter conferences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The beginning of 1932 brought a more optimistic business outlook in some American markets abroad, but the general level of business activity continued low, according to the weekly survey of foreign trade by the Department of Commerce.
PARIS, Jan. 9. OF the two most remarkable productions of the week, one has been given not by a French company but by a Belgian, and the play is a French translation of a work by a German author.
EVENTS of the past week revealed that the tangled problem of reparations and war debts which has been harrying the world for more than a decade is entering upon a new and difficult phase.

MADRID, Jan. 23 -- The Jesuit Order will be dissolved throughout Spain under terms of a decree signed today by President Alcala Zamora, to be published tomorrow. Within ten days the Company of Jesus, born in the little town of Manresa, where Ignatius Loyola wrote his spiritual exercises centuries ago, will cease to exist legally.

THE day has been fair, perhaps a trine warm, but not unpleasantly so. Then, in what seems no more than an instant, huge banks of black clouds roll up, ominous-looking thunderheads; there is a heavy swift downpour, and the storm is over almost as quickly as it began.

The Newest in Hobbles. RESEARCH in hobbies is amassing a diversified record. Every day adds something spectacular. No effort has been made at subclassifications, such as fads and idiosyncracies; all curious caprices, extravagances and whimsical pursuits are piling up unassorted.

VICENTE ESCUDERO is what may be termed the fifth European "sensation" to be imported into the local dance field in five years. First came Kreutzberg; then La Argentina; then Argentinita; and, last season, Wigman.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Jan. 23 -- Lieutenant R.C. (Bim) Wilson, attached to the Army Air Corps here, is the author of a number of poems, some of which have been published, it was learned here today, although he prefers drawing cartoons and belittles his poetic work.

ATTACK aviation, that branch of the Air Corps which devotes its attention almost exclusively to ''ground strafeing" and the harasssing of ground troops and communications behind the enemy lines, will undergo the most extensive change in tactics since the World War during the coming year, if experiments now being conducted at the Advanced Flying School at Kelly Field are adopted.

MADRID, Jan. 21 -- The government's announcement that it will not present a land reform bill in the Cortes at present, coming on the heels of class troubles in the north and east of Spain, has set ahead indefinitely one of the two most difficult hurdles the new regime will have to take.

The World Disarmament Conference which is to meet in Geneva on Feb. 2 will assemble at a propitious time, says Lindsay Rogers, Professor of Public Law at Columbia University, in February Current History.
NEW YORK. Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland is at the Ambassador.

BALBOA, Jan. 23 -- The Special Service Squadron destroyers Wickes and Phillips sailed at 8 P.M. today, carrying marines, with Corinto, Nicaragua, as their destination and temporary base. The movement was ordered from Washington, according to local naval authorities, so the vessels would be close to Salvador in case they were needed in connection with the reported threatened Communist movement against the present revolutionary government.

An analysis of abuses under existing laws and suggestions for remedial legislation will be included in Samuel Seabury's preliminary report as chief counsel to the Hofstadter Committee, now nearing the end of its first year of activity.

THE PEOPLE OF THE LEAVES," which bears no relation to the recent "Men of the Trees," is a book on primitive types that seems to be the work of a writer whose primary purpose is not literary. Mr. Meik's book lacks dramatic qualities, but there are compensations.
BABE RUTH does a bending exercise twenty-five times each morning before he sits down to his porridge.

THERE is a mad inconsistency about the advance Spring fashions that makes them very provocative. You will hear certain details ascribed to innumerable sources -- all the way from Colonial belles to the "Pink Lady" of 1908 -- but it seems to us that Park Avenue doormen and West Point cadets ought to get some of the credit, too.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Mrs. Blanche Wendel Hoffman, 58-year-old wife of Deputy Sheriff John W. Hoffman of 25 Hunter Street, this village, laid claim today to a share of the $100,000,000 fortune of the Wendel family. She would not name a prominent law firm in New York City to which she had gone with her alleged documentary proof.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Upsala College scored its ninth consecutive victory, without a defeat to mar its record, when it defeated the Trenton State Teachers College basketball team tonight, 26 -- 21.

After all the baseball bats, golf clubs, tennis racquets and boxing gloves have been counted or placed end-to-end, the simple fact, government endorsed, remains that there are some 13,000,000 inhabitants of these United States who enjoy the pastime of hunting and fishing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Although President Hoover postponed until Monday the appointment of the three Democratic directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, all official agencies in Washington cooperated today to make it possible for the $2,000,000,000 corporation to begin to function by making its first extension of credits within ten days or two weeks.

Recommendations for increasing the city's revenue by at least $15,000,000 a year by means of bridge tolls, tuition fees in City, Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges, higher hack license fees and other means were submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate by Ignaz Reich, president of the Greater New York Taxpayers' Association.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 28 -- Now comes far Northwestern Szechuan province asking to be listed among the candidates for the distinction of having been the "Cradle of Mankind."

Our "Unproud" Women. Just when does our childhood contempt for a "copycat" change to admiration for those energetic emulators society paradoxically calls its leaders? * * * Most women passively accept expert advice in every field and thus attain a sordid, secondhand perfection.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 -- Luck Tom, stout 3-year-old colt, showed his heels all the way to a string of contenders in the feature $5,000 added Jefferson Derby today. It was the last day of regular racing at Jefferson Park. A welfare card will be run at the track tomorrow.

Air transportation is opening vast areas of potential wealth in the Canadian Far North, and air liner to Europe and Asia eventually will cross Canadian territory, William D. Herridge, Canadian Minister to the United States, declared last night at a dinner of the Canadian Society of New York at the Hotel Biltmore.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The slogan "Abolish war and reduce taxes" is both true and forceful, but, if the American people are ever to attain a wise conception of international relations and reach a rational and sound agreement on our foreign policy, it is of vital importance that the so-called militarist and isolationist and the alleged pacifist and internationalist should stop their foolish recriminations and develop an atmosphere of mutual respect.

SEATED well forward on the orchestra floor of the Ethel Barrymore Theatre last Tuesday at the premiere of Ernest Truex's new play, "Whistling in the Dark," was a gentleman just arrived from Milwaukee, Laurence Gross by name.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Jan. 23 -- Penn State won its first wrestling meet of the season here tonight, defeating Chicago, 24 to 8. The Lions took three bouts by falls and three by decisions.

The status of securities of traction companies in New York City which will mature this year will depend entirely on progress made in shaping a unification plan or in adopting some other program intended to solve the protracted transit difficulties, according to the opinion of large holders of the securities.

THIS is the third volume of Olav Duun's six-volume saga. "The People of Juvik," to appear here in translation. The remaining three are promised for the future. Unlike "The Trough of the Wave," which told the story of the early generations, and "The Blind Man," which spanned a lifetime, "The Big Wedding" covers only a few months of the history of the Juvikings.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- Dr. Eugene Chellis Glover, less than four years out of Harvard Medical School, but already considered one of the leading cancer research specialists of the East, died in the Thorndike Memorial Laboratory of the Boston City Hospital from poison contracted in experiments which, he believed, had led him to the threshold of an important discovery in the successful treatment of cancer.

Prince and Princess Rospigliosi Gioeni arrived yesterday on the motorship Vulcanla of toe Cosulich Line from Italy and were admitted to the United States without delay. The Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island on Friday had instructed the inspectors who were going to board the Vulcania at Quarantine, that there were no grounds upon which the Prince could be detained.

Disclosure by Joseph B. Eastman of the Interstate Commerce Commission that the commission favored repeal of the law providing that the government may recapture earnings of a railroad in excess of a given limit came as the culmination of years of controversy over this provision.
HAVANA, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Jack Collins, speedy 4-year-old, outclassed a smart field to win the mile-and-one-sixteenth feature at Oriental Park today.

THE centenary of the birth of Lewis Carroll is really the celebration of the birth of Alice in Wonderland, the imaginary child being much more imaginable than the real one. Both perhaps exhibited the primness of their period, in both perhaps the primness was more formal than real.

IT is my deliberate opinion that mankind has changed or evolved more rapidly in the last three centuries than at any former period of the world's history. I shall speak of the nature and the extent of these evolutionary changes presently, but meantime let me explain how it has come about that professional anthropologists have remained so blind to racial alterations which have been taking place under their eyes.

DOWN in Philadelphia a Mr. Manley is saying something harsh about the radio, its heirs and assign, in a play entitled "Wild Waves," which opened at the Garrick Theatre there last Monday night and will remain another week before chancing Broadway.

A DIMINUTIVE microphone, no larger than a half dollar, to be attached to the speaker's coat lapel, is the latest vogue for lecturer, preacher or political spellbinder. This tiny instrument, which may be concealed in the coat pocket if desired, is expected to prove a boon to orators whose style of address depends largely on freedom of gesture and movement in scoring points on the public platform.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Two Hoosiers of clay-court fame, Johnny Hennessey of Indianapolis and Miss Catherine Wolf of Elkhart, today were named rulers of the Western tennis world.

A bequest of $21,450 to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine for the erection of an altar and a memorial window in the chapel of the bay of the medical profession in the nave of the Cathedral was revealed yesterday when the will of Mrs. Ruth young Starr, widow of the Rev. Reginald Heber Starr, was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.
BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- Following is the official summary of the more important points in the agreement on credits reached here today, as given by the credit committee:

BERLIN, Jan. 6. FRITZI MASSARY is the won- der of the German stage. Over here she holds somewhat the position that Ethel Barrymore or Mrs. Fiske has in the hearts of our citizens. But in a way Massary is an even more extraordinary figure, for at the end of her career she has shifted to an entirely new field of theatrical endeavor.

HERE is the account of Martin and Osa Johnson's last safari into the depths of Africa, undertaken for the purpose of studying and making pictures of the pygmies of the Itura Forest country and the gorillas in Pare National Albert and in the region of the Alumbongo Mountains.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Led by Bantu, which brought $3,500, seventeen 2-year-olds from the famous Hamburg Place Racing Stables were auctioned off today for a total of $11,250 at Hialeah Park.

FULLY cognizant of the advanced and increasing interest in motor boating, followers of the sport will again seek the enactment of effective Federal legislation. during the present session of Congress, for the promotion of safety on the water.

FOUR weeks ago "Hay Fever" opened at the Avon Theatre. The night before it opened I added up and found that my bank balance was $37. The second week of the "Hay Fever" engagement showed a profit of $1,400. Pretty dice!

The week-end market for stocks and bonds came virtually to a halt. No initiative in either direction was visible. Inasmuch, however, as the trend of prices in the stock market bad been downward throughout the week, and since this receding movement had been in progress while the Reconstruction finance law and the New York City loan were providing outwardly plausible ground for cheerfulness, Wall Street drew its usual more or less confused conclusions.

In the belief that the Baumes laws have decreased crime in this State, the District Attorneys Association of the State of New York voted at its annual meeting at the Bar Association Building yesterday to support the present statutes and to oppose any modification of them.

BACK of the glttering panorama of cruisers, outboards, runabouts, racing craft, engines and equipment on exhibition at the Motor Boat Show there is something that the casual visitor to the Palace will not see. It is the spirit that animates approximately 5,000,000 followers of the sport of boating.

PHOENIX-KIND" is an unusual first novel, marked by the distinguished quality of its style and the perfection with which the subject is fused with the manner of its telling. The slight plot deals with the relationship between two brothers, and their unspoken and almost unrecognized rivalry over the girl whom the younger had introduced into their lives.

A high record for volume of business was set last year by the Fidelity Investment Association, which is devoted exclusively to the sale of annuities. Sales aggregated $54,252,000 against $47,884,000 in the preceding year, an increase of $6,368,000, or 13.3 per cent.

GEORG BRANDES spoke of him as "an intellectual aristocrat and social democrat"; Bernard Shaw called him "the cleverest man of the nineteenth century"; Bismarck played a game of political cat and mouse with him; George Meredith made him the hero of a novel.

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- The negotiations for the prolongation of Germany's "frozen" short-term, credits amounting approximately to $1,500,000,000 were concluded today with the signing of an agreement providing for their prolongation for one year.

MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- This week the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics honored the memory of Nicolai Lenin, who died Jan. 21, 1924, although, curiously enough, the anniversary holiday occurs here on Jan. 22. It is a holiday -- that is, a non-working day.

Berlin's effort to have the Young Plan canceled and discarded in February, 1932, has failed, as Chancellor Bruening probably knew it would when he launched his famous defi two weeks ago. It has failed because the largest recipient of reparations, France, has taken the position that an international contract cannot be destroyed by a unilateral declaration.

DURING the World War Bernard Shaw was bitterly attacked for such articles as "Common Sense About the War." "Nonsense About Neutrality." "The Humors of Patriotic Indignation" and, perhaps, most of all for his ironic Christmas message, beginning: "There were certain poor soldiers abiding in the field, keeping watch over their wire entanglements by night."

Independent surveys and researches have convinced many bankers and large investors that many of the leading chain store companies have placed themselves in a position to make relatively excellent showings this year.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review Dear Sir: -- As a direct descendant of Commodore James Barren. I must protest your most unfair estimate of him as given in your review of "Decatur" by Irving Anthony on page 8, BOOK REVIEW Section, your Sunday edition of Dec. 13. last.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Augi Kieckhefer, Chicago's southpaw cud star, and Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia, both former holders of the world's three-cushion billiards title tonight were tied for first place in the 1932 championship tournament.
HAVANA -- With a constant influx of visitors, added to the regular Winter colony, the season is developing with a full schedule of activities.

INCLUDING in their scope the years of the great war, these two handsome volumes of British horse-racing lore have an added interest for miscellaneously curious persons, though they are principally intended for those to whom the racing calendar is the most serious thing in life.

The New Tork and Chicago creditors committees of Pynchon Co., a New York Stock Exchange firm that failed on April 24 last, have approved a plan of composition under which payment of dividends on certain large claims would be deferred until after payments of from 25 to 35 per cent to other general creditors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Hoover will not give his approval to any proposition involving action by this session of Congress for an increase of the navy.

GENEVA, Jan. 23 -- There are reports here from excellent sources that Sir Eric Drummond on Monday will hand to the Council of the League of Nations his resignation as Secretary General of the League, to take effect in March, next year. No confirmation of this is obtainable from him, however, it being stated that he had no statement to make on the subject.

A field of thirty-one gunners competed in the rain at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The best work was done by S.B. Masten, who won the High Scratch Cup by breaking 97 out of a possible 100 targets.

The Michael Laura Club, an important Italian-American Democratic unit recently torn by factional strife, was raided yesterday by Federal prohibition agents, who seized a quantity of liquor and arrested four men, one of whom was said to be a brother of Magistrate Sylvester Sabbatino.

POLA NEGRI came out of Hollywood and the shadows of her recent illness last week. There was the old magic in her appearance as she received visitors at the Ambassador, but her languor was no dramatic pose and the vivid, radiant vitality that is a part of one of the screen's major artistic temperaments was missing.

CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 21 -- Fifteen months after the crash of the Rogers Caldwell brokerage firm and associate banks, together with the loss of $6,000,000 to the treasury of the State of Tennessee, nothing substantial has been accomplished toward the conviction or acquittal of those who are accused of being criminally at fault in the crash, or to bring about restoration of the vanished funds.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP). -- The English Football Association cup competition advanced through the fourth round today. The winners were Watford, Grimsby Town, Leicester City, Manchester City, Huddersfield Town, The Wednesday. Bradford, Bury, Arsenal, Preston North End, Derby County, Liverpool and Chelsea.

BECAUSE Ernst Lubitsch is celebrated for his shafts of wit in his pictures one is apt to think that he has neglected serious subjects, but this is not so; for although the great majority of his productions have been comedies of a higher order, he made several dramas before turning out "The Man I Killed," which was launched last week at the Criterion.

London, according to the dispatches, may lift its prevailing ban on tall buildings. It is hardly a question yet of making the sky the limit, as it is with us sometimes; all that the County Council is considering is an increase in permissible heights from 80 or 100 feet to 120 or 150.

Few more impressive racing records have been made than that of the Australian champion, Phar Lap, now in this country in preparation for the $50,000 guaranteed Agua Caliente Handicap to be run on March 20. The compilation, recently made and announced by the Agua Caliente Jockey Club, shows that in fifty starts the "down under" star has won thirty-six times, placed second three times, third twice, and was nine times unplaced.
A slight mistake in the choice of doors probably will cause Louis Passalaequa to be deported.

The symposium on "The American Now in the Making," which began in last Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES and which is continued in today's issue by Sir ARTHUR KEITH in his article" America: The Greatest Race Experiment," does not and can not tell us what an American is racially nor in what direction he is developing.

LAKE PLACID -- Pre-Olympic events have drawn many spectators during the past week, and plans are being completed for the North American bob-sleigh championship races next Friday and Saturday on the mile-and-a-half run which winds down the precipitous slope of Mount Van Hoevenberg.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 23 -- As Japanese naval reinforcements from the Kure naval base steamed up the Whangpoo River into Shanghai Harbor and landed 400 marines to strengthen the present Japanese forces, the likelihood of trouble over the Japanese demands upon Shanghai authorities increased.

Despite the rain, thousands of boating enthusiasts visited the National Motor Boat Show in Grand Central Palace yesterday, inspecting the great variety of motor boats and sailboats on exhibition. The management announced that attendance during the first night and day of the show, which opened Friday night, had been running approximately 20 per cent greater than at last year's display.

THE opera's thirteenth week ushers in the Metropolitan season's second half, with Jeritza singing thrice, Ponselle repeating a role that waited a hundred years -- and was worth it -- and bilingual Lily Pons in an Italian benefit for the French Hospital.

CHARLES II, one of the most interesting monarchs who ever ruled over England -- indeed, it would be little exaggeration to call him the last monarch who ruled over England -- has already been made the subject of several popular biographies.

Many of New York City's scholastic basketball teams will be idle this week because of the Regents examinations. but activities among the city's schoolboy quintets will be resumed in full force next week, which also will mark the opening of competition in the Manhattan and Bronx divisions of the annual city P.S. A.L. senior high school championship basketball tournament.

The famed Millrose A.A. girls' relay team, which has long been preeminent in its specialty on the cinder tracks and the pine boards, is preparing for a return to activity in this indoor campaign -- but in a new form.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 -- A new mile track record of 1:36 2-5 was set at Hialeah Park today when Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer's Repentance won the Miami Beach Handicap by three lengths and returned $65.70 for $2.

LONDON. THE extraordinary tributes paid to the memory of C.P. Scott -- tributes of a quality without precedent on the death of any English newspaper editor -- have neturally laid most stress on his distinction as a publicist.
VERDI'S opera in three acts "Simone Boccanegra," will be produced this week by the Metropolitan Opera Company for the first time in America.

THE old Colossus of Rhodes was ranked as one of the seven wonders of the ancient world. But this statue, about which men have spoken with awe, was small in comparison with the effigy of Lenin which, it is reported, will be set above one of the dams in the port of Leningrad.

"Social Service Sunday" and "Child Labor Sunday" will be observed today by several Protestant denominations. In the Bronx a "Church Loyalty and Home Visitation Evangelism" campaign will be inaugurated. Several Protestant Episcopal pulpits will be occupied by Bishops.

Last week was noteworthy principally for the consummation of measures intended to strengthen credit structures here and abroad and for the precipitation of the reparations problem into a more acute stage than had been expected. Business trends remained slow and cautious, seasonal factors causing increased optimism.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The director of the National Bank said today that withdrawals of Belgian gold from depositories in the United States were in pursuance of a policy determined last September.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- George W. Miller, attorney for the American League for twenty-five years and former Assistant Corporation Counsel of Chicago, died suddenly last night just after he had informed friends he was on the high road of health. He was 63 years old.

IT is a surprise to learn that Pirandello's short stories, most of which date from before the better-known plays, have never before been offered in English translation. For his stories, almost all of them, are intense and delicate bits of artistry unhampered by the lugubrious dressing of philosophy in which his plays are often made to appear.

Weakness in the grain and security markets failed to depress prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Quotations held within the narrowest range so far this season and closed with net losses of only 1 to 2 points.

JUDGING by the large number of boxes and seats that have been purchased for the special performance of "Peter Ibbetson," with Mme. Lucrezia Bori, Edward JohnSon and Lawrence Tibbett in the leading roles, to be given on Friday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Southern Woman's Educational Alliance, there is every indication that the funds of that organization will be greatly augmented.

OMAHA, Jan. 21 -- Returning to the corn belt after an absence of a few years, a native son was recently impressed by the unusual sight of "the home-killed hog dangling in the cooling farmyard breeze." It was a bit of scenery that has not been common hereabout for a long, long time.

Tests are being made by public utility corporations and others of a new type of device, employing gun-powder for energy, for splicing electrical cables, fixing bolts in steel plates, riveting structural steel and for many other uses in industry, it became known yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While engaged in a perfectly innocent session of our national game of bridge at my home the other evening we were suddenly startled by a violent attack by a man named Fish against Communists and Socialists. The attack came over the radio, which had died down in the course of the evening and then came on again with a loud burst.

MARIA NEMETH and Alfred Piccaver have carried out their threats to quit the National Opera Company in Vienna rather than accept a guarantee of only six performances per month at $144 each, under the new salary scale made necessary by drastic economies in the national budget.
AIKEN -- With January fast fading, the Aiken season is becoming livelier. Each day brings new arrivals and the Winter homes will practically all soon be opened.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 23 -- Williams won from Wesleyan at basketball tonight by 33 to 30. Markoski played a fine game for the Purple, shooting seven field baskets and one foul. Fowle and Good also played well for the visitors. For Wesleyan Schlums and Striebinger were the stars.

HELSINGFORS, Jan. 23 -- The initialing of the Russo-Finnish non-agression pact here on Thursday is regarded as an important international action and is accepted as proving that neither Finland nor Russia, contrary to sporadic alarming rumors, harbors hostile aspirations against the other.

The economic depression is restoring the strength of the family, speakers declared yesterday at the concluding sessions of the Regional Conference on Social Hygiene at the Hotel New Yorker, sponsored by nine welfare and health agencies. The creation of experimental advice stations to deal with marital difficulties was also advocated.

When the storm is behind and the sea wind dies away above the high stacks, passengers on incoming liners may breathe in relief and bother themselves with final packing, with perfunctory farewells to companions who seemed so essential in mid-ocean, and with the always unsatisfactory business of rewarding stewards with gratuities.

DALLAS, Jan. 21 -- Supporters of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for the Democratic Presidential nomination are stumped in Texas right now. The movement in behalf of Speaker John N. Garner has taken them by surprise and has left them slightly bewildered, although the leaders are aware of the obvious and almost the only political course to take.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- A departure in the Westchester County Recreation Commission's conduct of the Westcheater County Centre here and an added feature to the centre's provision for community entertainment will take place Monday evening, at 7:30 o'clock, when the doors of the centre will be thrown open for the first of the commission's weekly "play nights" without admission charge.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Freight rates on grain from the great Western farming States will be restored within two weeks to the higher level of July.

A NEW dance club known as the Imperial, admission to which is by invitation only, will inaugurate a series of Monday night supper dances with a Black and Gold Dance on Feb. 8 in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. This date has been changed from Feb. 1 as originally planned.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23 -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club hockey team, led by the brilliant Russell Blinco, conquered Yale's sextet in an overtime battle at the arena tonight, 4 to 3. A crowd of 1,500 saw the thrilling contest.

Wall Street, government, and our modern scientific and industrial gods having failed for the moment to lead us out of the wilderness of the depression, many voices are now suggesting that education may be the new Joshua to bring us to a more stable social order.

"Seeing" with their ten fingers, their faces wreathed in smiles, a group of nine blind members of the social welfare staff of The Light House, which is maintained by the New York Association for the Blind, acclaimed a new experiment in group education yesterday morning as they were taken through the Museum of Science and Industry at 220 East Forty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The consulate at Toronto has been raised to a consulate general and Emil Sauer of Doss. Texas, the consul there, has been promoted to consul general.

American delegates to the Disarmament Conference -- all except Secretary STIMSON, who is to go later -- sailed last week. It cannot fee said that they embarked like assured conquerors. Some of them spoke and bore themselves like men going on a fruitless quest. And few of their fellow-citizens on shore could think of them as surely starting on an auspicious voyage.

The United States was likened to Czarist Russia by Professor Jerome Davis of Yale University, in an address last night before the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Conference of the Unitarian and other liberal churces at the Pythian Temple. Professor Davis spoke on "Present Day Business Ethics -- What Is the Way Out?"

HAROLD G. HOFFMAN, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles of New Jersey, has announced that there will be a compulsory test of automobiles in the interest of highway safety this year. Under the law, Governor A. Harry Moore must issue a proclamation designating the period of the safety campaign.

Japan does not discriminate between treaties entered into by nations of equal strength and treaties enforced by a stronger nation on a weaker, for the reason that international law does not recognize any difference, Dr. Roy H. Akagi, visiting lecturer on Japanese affairs at Columbia University, said yesterday.

Competition in the second annual city P.S.A.L. senior high schools championship fencing tournament will open on Saturday morning, Feb. 13, at Washington Irving High School, and will close on Saturday. June 4, according to the revised schedule for the tournament announced by John J. McHugh, inspector of athletics of the P.S.A.L.

Henry Miller, 66 years old, who has spent nearly seventeen years in jail since 1890 and has been arrested twenty-two times, emerged from his latest adventure yesterday in Flatbush Court by pleading guilty to vagrancy, the charge having been reduced from petit larceny.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The proposal in the new Democratic tariff bill to have the President call an international economlo conference was attacked today at a hearing before the Senate Finance Committee by Ogden L. Mills, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, as futile and only a gesture, unless Congress informed the President of its attitude on the tariff.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Exactly why men stop growing when they have reached what we call maturity scientists cannot tell us. Some not understood law says thus far and no further. It is true that cells sometimes become outlaws and produce "unlawful growths" like tumors or cancers, but these exceptions are rare and always harmful.

MONTREAL, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Three goals in the last eight minutes of the third period gave the Montreal Maroons a 3 -- 3 tie with the Chicago Blackhawks in a National Hockey League game tonight. It was the third straight draw the two teams have played.

LUXOR, Egypt, Jan. 23 -- Reports of the illness of the Marquess of Reading have been exaggerated. He caught a cold during a visit to Palestine and tried to fight it off, but was forced to bed on his arrival at his hotel here.

BECAUSE of the depression many thousands of American families are forced to live on drastically reduced incomes -- sometimes on next to no income at all. In these circumstances many housewives are faced with the pressing problems of providing their families with wholesome food, of rearing their babies and of caring for the sick.

Walter Spence of the New York A.C. scored an unexpectedly decisive victory in defending his title of metropolitan A.A.U. senior 100-yard free style swimming champion at a water carnival in the seventy-five-foot pool of the Brooklyn Central Y. M.C.A. last night.

Hack Wilson, dynamic outfielder and erstwhile home-run monarch of the National League, received another official change of address yesterday when President Frank B. York announced that the former stormy petrel of the Chicago Cubs had been purchased by the Brooklyn club from the St. Louis Cardinals.

A BETTER subject for a travel book than the Caucasus would be hard to find. So far, astonishingly little has been written either in America or Europe about this Asiatic country -- one of the most beautiful, fascinating and romantic countries in the world.

Reverent students of our protective tariff system must be puzzled, perhaps pained, by the wrath which European adaptations and imitations of "the American system" stir in celestial bosoms at Washington. Why is there not rejoicing at the wide European extension of this illustrious American "institution"?

IN these columns last Sunday there was printed a map of the Old Spanish Trail route from Florida to Houston, together with, the principal feeders to this highway. The westward extensions for this highway are now presented for the benefit of those who wish to motor on to California during the next several months.

BERGENFIELD, N.J., Jan. 23 -- The censorship committee of the borough library here laid down a ban today on the spending of borough money for books which in the opinion of the committee "parade sex, score the Christian religion or defame American heroes and traditions," according to Mrs. P. Guernsey, its chairman.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith called for a clear, straightforward statement of the Democratic platform, with militant national unity of his party, to defeat the Republican organization in the Presidential campaign next November, in another vigorous "victory speech" before 1,300 district leaders and captains at a dinner yesterday at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, Grand Concourse and 161st Street, the Bronx.

Present attempts by Congress to enact legislation equalizing exchange differences in valuing goods imported from countries having depreciated currencies were termed moves undertaken to obstruct foreign trade by James B. Herzog, vice president of S. Stern, Stiner Co., customs brokers, yesterday.

WHEN Thomas Burke's "Limehouse Nights" first appeared some years ago people opened wide their noses. Some also placed cotton in eyes and tilted their very genteel their ears. Did such squalor exist? Were there dregs of humanity such as slid in and out of those bizarre and dimly lit pages?

The circumstances under which a tenant will be held to his lease when the apartment house in which he is living is put into foreslosure are described in a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the case of Jacob Reich, Inc., against Morris Fordon on an agreed statement of facts.

PART of a floor at the show is given over to exhibits of sail boats. One of these is a Red Wing sloop designed for racing and day sailing and built by the Luders Marine Construction Corporation. These little boats are 15 feet 9 inches in length and 5 feet in beam and have a sail area of 150 square feet.

To the Dramatic Editor: The controversy existing in some quarters relative to the attitude of critics toward the theatre of today and its offerings recalls through the help of my scrapbook that the amusement purveyors of some sixty-odd years ago were the recipients of criticism far more severe than that handed out at present.

Our Magazine Section today gives leading place to Alice of Wonderland and the Looking Glass and to her only begetter, LEWIS CARROLL. The hundredth anniversary of his birth is next Wednesday. The fact that Alice should he judged still worthy of so much prominence is a reaffirmation of faith in her immortality.

THE phrases, dissolution of the Imperial Reich and establishment of the Republican Reich, are distinctions without historical differences. Although Dr. Rosenberg's narrative ends with the fall of the empire and the abdication of the dynasty and has naught to say of the immediate conditions which produced the Welmar Constitution his title connotes the constructive rather than the destructive forces at work, although his material deals largely with the latter.

LOUISVILLE, Jan. 21 -- A. Scott Bullitt, Democrat, of Seattle, Wash., who failed by 15,000 votes to unhorse Senator Wesley L. Jones, Republican, in 1926, and who is going to essay the same task next Fall with a much better chance of success, unless all signs fail, addressed the Kentucky branch of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform and guests at the Pendennis Club here this week.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23 -- A jury before Judge Daniel J. Brennan in Quarter Sessions Court here tonight acquitted Deputy Sheriff Charles F. Hummel and George Washington Davis, Republican politician, of a charge of conspiracy to extort $5,000 from the promoters of a dance marathon at Dreamland Park here last Fall.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The text of the reply of the railroad unions to the Railway Presidents' Committee of Nine is as follows:

As a result of the widespread unemployment in German industrial centres, a "derationalization" movement is going on, sending people back to the land, according to Dr. Oskar Eckstein, economic adviser of the Potash Syndicate of Germany, who arrived here on Friday.

BROOKLYN MUSEUM -- Exhibition of paintings by American impressionists and other artists of the period, 1880-1900. "Impressionists," observes the catalogue foreword, is perhaps a misnomer, in view of the fact that the ideas of most of our artists who returned from France full of enthusiasm over the scientific theories of Monet and other French Impressionists "were modified by the change to home surroundings."

More than 500 persons including descendants of the first Huguenots to locate in America and representatives of historical, patriotic and civic organizations observed yesterday the two hundred and seventy-first anniversary of the first Huguenot settlement on Staten Island.

PARIS. A NOTED psychologist of Paris, Dr. Pierre Vachet, has devised a method of treating patients in groups, by means of phonograph records. Two modern inventions have long been used in medical work, the radio, with individual ear pieces, to distract and amuse hospital patients, and the motion picture in teaching medicine and surgery, but this is the first appearance of the phonograph record for curative purposes.

VIENNA, Jan. 12 -- The Viennese are subjected to a new horror of modern civilization -- the "taxi-telephone." A small basic sum has to be paid whether the telephone is used or not. Then by an ingenious -- or as public opinion declares a devilish -- device, every second employed in speaking is recorded against the subscriber.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Cornell's rejuvenated basketball team defeated Yale, 37 -- 21, tonight, scoring its first victory in three Eastern. Intercollegiate Basketball League games.

The 110-foot oil tanker Captain Matt, bound for Hart's Island with a cargo of 16,000 gallons of oil, was rammed by the steamship Robert E. Lee in the dense fog that blanketed Long Island Sound last evening. The collision occurred about three-quarters of a mile off Belden Point.

The world's heavyweight championship ring encounter between Max Schmeling, the German lad who holds the crown, and Jack Sharkey, America's foremost challenger, to be held in the Yankee Stadium on June 16, will be one of two titular matches on the calendar for local boxing followers, if present plans materialize.

On the eve of the opening of the Y.M.C.A. drive to raise $330,849 for relief work and its regular program, Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt telegraphed that organization yesterday congratulating it on the completion of eighty years of helpful service and extending his best wishes "for even greater success."

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 21 -- The naming by President Hoover of James R. Beverley as Governor to succeed Theodore Roosevelt is the nearest Porto Rico has so far come to choosing its chief executive. It is assumed that the Senate will confirm the appointment.

That large reserves were set up last year by banks in this district to take care of depreciation of investments and to care for future contingencies was illustrated in a comparative table of banks and trust companies in the metropolitan area which was published last week in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SOON after Dr. Lee de Forest invented the audion, or vacuum tube, as it is popularly known, he began to direct his attention to broadcasting of voices and music. That was in 1906. He believed that the magic glass bulb would do the trick, so he began to experiment.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Chiefs of the twenty-one standard railway unions, representing 1,500,000 employes on more than 200 Class 1 roads, in a tactfully worded document of about 2,000 words, told the presidents' committee of nine today that "as a matter of pure right and justice" the railway employes should not be asked to "contribute 10 per cent of their meager earnings for the benefit of other interests in the railroad industry."

GUAYAQUIL. ECUADOR'S recently inaugurated air mail service from Quito to outlying towns is probably the world's highest and only non-stop service, since the take-off is more than 10,000 feet above sea level and the planes return to their point of departure without landing.

Who would have thought that in all this broad land it would be so hard to find anybody willing to accept a position as President of the United States? To be sure, the hours are long and the work is rather confining. But on the other hand, the pay is quite good, particularly under present conditions, and there are other advantages.

THROUGHOUT the week private pilots have been dropping in to perfect landings at the local airports, returning from the Winter cruise of the United States Amateur Air Pilots Association. The manner in which these fliers, many of whom have had less than 100 hours experience, have come through despite delays from bad weather has brought praise from leaders in the aircraft industry.

More than half of the $100,000,000 special corporate stock note loan, floated by a syndicate of nearly fifty banks, will be earmarked for use to meet the city's outstanding corporate stock note obligations and will be unavailable for any other purpose, it was disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Despite the official sanction of the Home Office, Miss Susan Glaspell, the American playwright and novelist, will not act in her own play, "Trifles," here after all.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Jan. 19 were less than both the preceding week and the same week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.
BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- Expansion in demand for cotton goods has occurred

The fifty-sixth exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club is expected to eclipse all previous ones. More imported dogs than ever before are awaiting the call of the judges for this show, which will be held in Madison. Square Garden on Feb. 11, 12 and 13, many fanciers having gone abroad and paid high prices for animals that will make their debut in the Garden.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- A dinner and bridge was held tonight at the Sea Horse Yacht Club, Milton Point, Rye. Among those who entertained were:

SIR NORMAN ANGELL, British economist now visiting in New York, has been invited by WABC's program director to discuss "The Money Mystery" at 10:30 o'clock this morning. Next Sunday at the same time he will speak on "The Money Game."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Bill Carr of Pine Eluff. Ark., today established a new University of Pennsylvania record for the quarter-mile on the board track at Franklin Field by stepping the distance in 0:50.4 in the first of the mid-winter handicap meets. Rain fell during the events.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The establishment of retirement annuity programs by corporations on their own initiative was recommended in a report made public today of a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. The report took no stand on unemployment insurance, dealing solely with retirement.

LONDON, Jan. 9. A PLAY by Jose Lopez Rubio and Eduardo Ugarte, which won a competition and was, I understand, a success in Spain, has lately appeared at the Vaudeville in an English adaptation by Cecil Madden called "Max and Mr. Max."

The Philadelphia Arrows moved into second place in the Canadian-American League race by defeating the Bronx Tigers at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 2,500 saw the Quaker sextet break through in the final session to hang up a 1-0 triumph.

The national amateur pocket billiard championship will start tomorrow tonight at the New York Lodge of Elks, 108 West Forty-third Street, with J. Howard Shoemaker defending his laurels in a field of six players. The tournament will be conducted under the auspices of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players.

Graphs and charts maintained by students in a course on business cycles at Columbia University show that payrolls and employment in factories in the United States are increasing slightly, Frederick E. Croxton, Professor of Statistics at Columbia, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- The self-elimination of Governor Emmerson from the field of Republican candidates for Governor has clarified the political situation in Illinois. Many believe that Representative Michael Igoe, Democratic house leader at Springfield, has, unintentionally, eliminated himself no less effectively, if not as a candidate for nomination at least as one with reasonable hope.

SOUTHERNERS in New York are showing much interest in the annual Blue Ridge ball, which takes place on Friday at the Plaza, and from which many children in the mountains of "Virginia will benefit. This ball in aid of the Blue Ridge Industrial School of Greene County, Va., has been an annual outstanding event in New York for more than twenty years.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- One sign that Bermuda is having a flourishing season this year has been in evidence lately in the presence of the largest organized group of tourists ever to land at one time. They were the 350 guests of Rex Cole, distributer of electrical equipment in New York, who arrived on Monday on the new Monarch of Bermuda.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Chicago's race tracks will offer 157 days of racing in 1932. The Illinois Turf Association adopted its schedule today, opening the season on May 2 and closing on Oct. 31. Chicagoans will get their first glimpse of the thoroughbreds at Aurora, and the season will close there unless the Aurora dates are transferred to one of the other courses in the Chicago district, as was done last year.

VIENNA, Jan. 21 -- The tightening up in the last few weeks of governmental exchange and other restrictions has forcibly directed public attention to one of the most striking by-products of the world's confused currency situation -- the almost complete disappearance of private rights and personal liberty in Eastern Europe.

OCCASIONALLY one finds an individual whose life falls with almost unbelievable precision into the time-worn plot of the poor but honest boy who, after struggling with manifold misfortunes, achieves his life's goal. Just such a picturesque tale lies behind one of the most romantic collections in the world -- the Schwadron autograph and photograph collection of Jewish notables in the library of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

MONTREAL -- The event of this week for Montreal society is the annual Charity Ball, which is to be held on Friday evening in the Mount Royal Hotel. The Governor General and the Countess of Bessborough will arrive here from Ottawa on that day and will be present at the ball.

No one is likely to be disquieted by the news that the Bank of France is about to transfer $125,000,000 gold from New York to Paris. This gold is already the property of the Bank of France. For several months the Federal Reserve Bank, which holds it in trust, has "earmarked " it as thus owned.

LONDON. BRITISH production plans for the current year are on an ambitious scale, so far at least as quantity is concerned. There is no evidence yet to hand to show that in regard to quality any particular effort will be made to do more than play for safety.

SARA MARITZA, latest in the exodus of Continental actresses to Hollywood, will begin her American film career in a Paramount transcription of a European comedy, "The Man Who Had No Private Life." The work of Otto Furth, it relates the adventures of a young manicurist who becomes involved in the life of a reformer.

WHEN all is said and done there is in this year of 1931 little to be said that is new about woman. Psychologists, psychoanalysts, industrialists, biologists, anthropologists and educators have had their say over and over again, and to repeat the story in 569 pages seems more than a little tedious.

It is "grossly unfair" to expect a man to retire at the age of 65 years, or to bar an individual from a new position because he is past 40, Dr. Carney Landis of the New York State Psychiatric Institute, Columbia University Medical Centre, declared last night over the radio.

While it is not expected that the newly created Reconstruction Finance Corporation will deliver the country out of its economic difficulties immediately, Wall Street is confident that it will do much to hasten the recovery and that its usefulness will be demonstrated first in a graduai restoration of confidence.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Joe Boley, veteran shortstop of the Philadelphia Athletics, has been purchased by the Cleveland Indians to bolster their infield, it was announced today by Billy Evans, general manager of the Tribe.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Prominent amateur golfers are here to start tomorrow in two principal events, one for men and the other for women, which are introductory to the usual golf events here in February and March.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The twenty-eighth annual St. Valentine's golf tournament for men players at the Pinehurst Country Club heads a sports bill next week that will comprise also a race meeting, three polo games, a golf tournament of the Silver Foils, an archery tournament, a putting tournament for women at the Pinehurst Country Club, a fox hunt, and bridle trail parties every day.

ABOUT a year ago Edward Van Every presented "The Sins of New York," compiled from Tbe Police Gazette, to a generation which had grown up to regard the spirit of tabloidia as something horribly indigenous to our own calamitous epoch.

MR. BEACH has not proceeded far in his narrative before the reader who loves outdoor adventure is following close on his trail, loath to miss a line. The Alaska Range and its foothills comprise the least known adventure region in United States territory, if not in all North America.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23 -- The judges of the six district courts in Mexico City unanimously resolved today that the applications lodged by Catholic priests and other Catholics would be refused on the main ground that the recent legislation limiting the number of priests officiating in the Federal district to one for every 50,000 inhabitants does not impair the liberty of Catholics in their faith.

That German reparations and American war loans are two wholly separate questions, bearing no proper relation to one another, has been an official doctrine of the United States for more than ten years. As early as 1920 President WILSON stated in a letter to the Prime Minister of England that the American Government "cannot consent to connect "the reparation question with, that of "intergovernmental indebtedness."

TO Harry Moses, who almost became an active producer this season with the Germanic play called "Tempest in a Teapot," have gone the rights to "The Warrior's Husband," the Julian Thompson comedy which Mr. Hopkins (Arthur) once planned to utilize as a vehicle for Hope Williams.

The exchange of the liner Republic for the army transports Somme and Cambral, effected last October between the United States Lines and the War Department, acting through the United States Shipping Board, has worked out well for both parties, the first few months of operation indicate.

Trapped by smoke and flames in an apartment on the first floor of 205 Sumpter Street, Brooklyn, Mrs. Irene White, 40 years old, widowed mother of four children, was found dead early yesterday morning by members of a Fire Department rescue squad.

IN the January number of Prints, a magazine devoted exclusively to the arts of the point, a notice is given to the development of the print department of the Grand Central Art Galleries. This department was inaugurated in the Fall of 1930 and was so successful that the space of four rooms was presently set aside for it.

AFTER weeks of counter agitation in the form of pleas for international peace, economy programs and naval disarmament, hearings are being held in Congress on the Vinson bill which calls for a full "treaty navy."

DAVID WARFIELD, 65 years old, in retirement seven years from the theatre and appearing uncommonly well, answered the question directly, like an honest man and a trouper. He said, no, there were no actors today whom he would call really great -- no one, that is, to compare with Irving, Booth, Terry or Duse, but they might he coming along some time, any time, soon.

AS the range and variety of her training flights grow, the efficiency of the Akron as a cruiser of the air becomes ever more apparent. The navy's huge dirigible has faced the most strenuous Winter conditions that Commander Rosendahl could find and come through them smiling.

ROME, Jan. 22 -- The number of unemployed, in Italy, which at the end of December totaled 980,000, now exceeds 1,000,000, by far the highest in Italian history. Only about one-quarter of the unemployed draw the very limited unemployment insurance benefits provided by Italian law, with the result that there are about 750,000 who must be cared for in other ways.

A four-goal handicap proved too much for Governors Island to give Pennsylvania Military College in the Class A metropolitan indoor polo circuit game that featured the program at the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, last night, and the collegians triumphed, 9 1/2 to 8.

The need in education for curriculum reconstruction, whereby "the irrational reverence for points, credits, units and teachers' marks may be somewhat diverted," was emphasized yesterday by educators at a meeting of the Educational Records Bureau in the Hotel St. Regis.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. THIS has been "Ziegfeld Week" in the theatrical life of the town, and his friends, admirers and followers, whose name is legion hereabout, are somewhat feverish with excitement. His latest frolic, bearing the label of "Follies of 1931," opened at the Illinois Theatre Monday night with the traditional eclat.

Several good business leases, a fair amount of dealing on the east side and upper west side areas and the purchase of a plot in Union City, Hudson County, N.J., on which a large improvement for a mail order firm is said to be contemplated, characterized the realty features of the week.

Chief Judge Benjamin N. Cardozo of the Court of Appeals was formally endorsed for associate justice of the United States Supreme Court to fill the seat recently vacated by Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes at the closing session of the annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association at the Hotel Astor last night.

Fordham Prep will compete in the Manhattan division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association baseball tournament this Spring for the first time, according to the schedule announced by Brother Joannes of St. Ann's Academy, president of the C.H.S.A.A.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 22 -- Prince Lennart who incurred the wrath of his grandfather, King Gustave, by becoming engaged to Miss Karin Nissvandt, a commoner, is now staying at his castle at Mainau, Germany, with his fiance and her mother.

VATICAN CITY, Jan. 23 -- Fears for the collapse of other portions of the building which houses the Vatican library were felt today when Vatican engineers found that the cracks in the structure, which appeared after the collapse of the Sistine Hall two days before Christmas, had widened considerably.

The Cunard Line has announced definitely that the Aquitania will make two thirty day cruises to the Mediterranean starting on Feb. 3 and March 5. Harold P. Borer, the general passenger manager in the United States, said yesterday that the bookings for both cruises were satisfactory.

To the Dramatic Editor: I am one of those poor deluded individuals who had a good time at the opening of "Jewel Robbery" the other night. The following morning I awoke to discover that I had no critical faculties at all.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation bill represents an extraordinary effort to meet an extraordinary emergency in an extraordinary way.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Touching on the interesting article by Mr. Olin Downes in the Sunday TIMES of Jan. 10 respecting applause at symphony concerts, I would suggest that much of the trouble lies in the fact that applause with the greater portion of an audience is nothing but a habit, and is used without discrimination on all occasions.

A family should not attempt to buy a home until it is able to pay immediately at least 25 per cent of the total cost, Frederick H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and head of the finance committee of President Hoover's conference on home building and ownership, says in the current Review of Reviews.

ELIMINATION of grade crossings on Long Island, first agitated by civic organizations in 1927, found 1931 a banner year in the furtherance of this type of highway improvement. So successful have been ventures in this field of improvement that crossing eliminations, have become recognized as a standard equipment in connection with the design and construction of the highways of Long Island.
FOND DU LAC, Wis., Jan. 23 -- Governor Roosevelt of New York was endorsed as Presidential candidate by the Wisconsin Democratic conference here today.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 23 -- Noble L. Mitchell, formerly Speaker of the House of Delegates of Maryland and a leading attorney, died early today at the age of 77. He became ill on Tuesday at his home in Bel Air and was sent to a hospital here on Wednesday. He was operated on at once, but never recovered.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Pennsylvania gained its second straight varsity swimming victory today by beating Lafayette College in the Hutchinson pool, 51 to 20.

Bond prices continued irregularly lower on the Stock Exchange in yesterday's brief trading period, rail- road bonds again leading the decline.
