Aside from infrequently traded issues, losses of 1 to 4 points about covered the principal setbacks in the rail issues, which were recorded on comparatively quiet trading.

One of the most important matters Confronting the American people at present is the proper distribution of Workers among various occupations. The wages in any given field depend to a large extent upon the number of people in it in relation to the number needed.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The baillie [local magistrate] of the Clydebank area of Glasgow gave a thrill of short-lived hope to thousands of unemployed shipyard workers today, when he said that at the end of next week an important announcement would be made regarding resumption of work on the giant new Cunarder.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- Many sports events are on the calendar here for early February. Golf will probably lead in the field of outdoor sports, with the midseason match plays scheduled at the Southern Pines Country Club for Feb. 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6.

A novelty at once literary, economic and social is the appearance of American Taxpayers' Quarterly. No. 1, Vol. 1, has recently issued from the press. The title is not adopted, as one might callously suppose, on the theory that the taxpayer ought to have a quarterly because he is so often hanged, drawn and quartered.

More than $2,700 was contributed in the last week for the Neediest Cases; thus there is renewed hope that, before the books of the 1931 fund are closed, the $300,000 mark will have been passed. The total is now $295,660.28, which is $50,130.37 short of the 1930 fund.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 -- Old-school Republicans here are bewildered. It is not simply because two national third-party movements have been threatened from the district; at this stage of a Presidential campaign such activities may represent merely strategy designed to influence the old parties toward the adoption of certain policies.

A young tree surgeon, who turned hold-up man, was pursued by the police after a $150 hat shop robbery yesterday. He dashed into a flower store on the north side of Fifty-ninth Street between Lexington and Third Avenues. Cornered there, he shot himself through the head rather than face the disgrace he knew must follow his capture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A Communist revolutionary movement of serious proportions in El Salvador led today to the dispatch of United States, British and Canadian vessels to the scene for the protection of the lives of foreign residents.

Sixty-eight members of Fall sports teams at James Monroe High School received athletic insignia recently. The awards were presented to the football, soccer, cross-country and golf team members by the respective coaches of the sports, Joseph Weldman, Joseph Salta, Paul Courtois and Arthur Freund.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Jan. 16, an editorial supports the contention that a thirteen-month calendar of 364 days, with the practical elimination of one day in each normal year -- the discarded day to be called "Yearday" -- would be preferable to our present calendar.

TOKYO, Jan. 3 -- "The object of our five-year plan -- which, unlike the Soviet scheme, aims at strengthening the existing economic structure and not at attacking it -- is to to raise the standard of living of the 70,000,000 Japanese people by increasing the production of the country."

The net asset value of common stock of the Adams Express Company, an investment trust, was $1.31 a share on Dec. 31 after allowing for debentures at $1,000 and preferred stock at $100 a share, according to the annual report issued yesterday. This compares with $16.40 a share at the end of 1930.

AT THE end of his story of medicine Dr. Victor Robinson quotes Dr. Charles H. Mayo, the surgeon, as saying: "Every other hospital bed in the United States is now occupied by the mentally afflicted, insane, idiotic, feeble-minded and senile.

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- After keeping silent for almost a week before responding, Chancellor Bruening replied today to Adolf Hitler's memorial explaining his refusal to support the proposal to prolong President von Hindenburg's term by act of the Reichstag.

TOMORROW evening, a little less than twenty-four years after the date of his first publio organ recital in the Great Hall of the College of the City of New York, Professor Samuel A. Baldwin will celebrate his seventieth birthday by presenting another recital there, the last of a series that has been heard by more than a million auditors.

Delightful Lily Pons drew the season's largest matinee throng at the opera yesterday, when the Metropolitan's young French colorature soprano was heard as Rosina for the first time since her more extensive triumphs in this role last Summer in Argentina and Brazil.
Brooklyn Prep will not compete in the Brooklyn division C.H.S.A.A. baseball tournament this year, according to the schedule arranged by George Bahlman, athletic director at Brooklyn Prep.

PARIS we owe at least one debt of gratitude to the late, but not lamented, Eugenie mode for having ushered in an era of millinery individuality. First Spring hats offer us a wide variety of shapes and trimmings, and though it's more than probable that later in the season women of all ages will be wearing the same hat, it will be of their own free will and no fault of the Paris modistes.

Hundreds of legitimate business loans, delayed by small banks which must maintain a maximum of liquid assets, should be freed when the Reconstruction Finance Corporation starts to function, a prominent banker said here yesterday. The release of funds represented by such loans, he added, will be the most tangible benefit accruing to the average manufacturer and business man from the creation of the corporation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP). -- Experiments started fifty years ago by Prolessor A.A. Michelson to measure the speed of light are expected to be completed this Summer under the direction of his assistant, Fred Pearson, the University of Chicago has announced.

Liberalization of banking procedure is essential to encourage domestic manufacturers to expand foreign sales activities, F.G. Roehm, executive of the American Foreign Credit Underwriters, Inc., told THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. Some change which would leave the producer here free to solicit export orders, and grant moderate credit terms without encroaching upon the credit allowance necessary to conduct his domestic business, is advocated by Mr. Roehm.

THE cell is immortal," declared the famous German biologist Weismann decades ago. So it seems. Last "week a piece of heart tissue from a checken celebrated an anniversary in the Rockefeller Institute. For twenty years Dr. Alexis Carrel.

THE Chicago Civic Opera Company has had increased patronage of late, according to Edward Moore of The Chicago Tribune, who wrote last Sunday this was fairly obvious, although he had access to no figures. His remarks follow in part:

Reduction in the salaries of the higher paid city and county officials and employes, including judges and school teachers, and a 10-cent fare on the sub-ways, "if necessary," were advocated as a means of reducing city expenses and balancing the budget by George S. Horton, president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, at the annual dinner of the organization last night at the Brooklyn Elks Club, Boerum Place and Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- Harvard's varsity polo team extended its winning streak to three straight in defense of its Boston Indoor League polo crown by handing the Westwood trio a 13 1/2 -to-5 defeat at the Commonwealth Armory tonight.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23 -- The Yale fencers today defeated the Penn Athletic Club, 18 to 9, taking seven foils contests to two for the visitors and winning the epee competition, 8 to 1, but losing with the saber, 6 -- 3.

THE format of Bernard Sobel's "Burleycue" -- an underground history of burlesque which does not run very deep -- has as much avoirdupois as one or the heroines the author toasts and, unfortunately, the writing itself has not much more intellectual substance.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT HARDING, AT SEA, Jan. 23 -- In as-much as the United States already has the smallest standing army, in proportion to her territory, population and wealth, of any country in the world, Senator Claude A. Swanson and Dr. Mary Emma Woolley conferred today with the War Department's technical advisers on this matter.

GRAND FORKS, N.D., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Petitions will be circulated at once to enter Governor Roosevelt as a Presidential candidate in North Dakota. F.W. McLean, Democratic State Central Committee secretary, said tonight.

ISTANBUL, Jan. 22 -- Following the example set by other countries, Turkey has put in force recently measures restricting imports, thereby setting a higher premium upon contraband. The task of overcoming this evil is proving formidable.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- The destiny of the New England railroads remains undetermined. The transportation act, with its consolidation provisions, was passed more than ten years ago. No section of the country has studied the question of the disposition of its own roads so assiduously as has New England.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 23 -- Two prominent local Democrats who supported Alfred E. Smith in 1928 came out for Governor Roosevelt today in announcing as candidates for delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

IN the cemetery at Guildford in Surrey there is a cross of white marble bearing the name Charles Lutwidge Dodgson, and below it a second name, more modestly displayed. The second name is Lrewis Carroll. The strange man who there sleeps was born on Jan. 27, 1832, just a hundred years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Reflecting the generally lower level of prices for practically all commodities, the cost of living in the United States declined 9.3 per cent during 1931 and was 3 per cent lower in December than in June, the Labor Department announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The British Cabinet's "balance of trade committee" has finished the tentative formulation of the new economic policy for this country, which the whole Cabinet will consider in the coming week in preparation for something to say to Parliament when it reconvenes on Feb. 2.

GENEVA, Jan. 23 -- W.W. Yen, the new Chinese delegate to the Council of the League of Nations put on its record today the recent note of the United States which informed Japan and China that the Washington Government would not recognize any settlement reached through the violation of treaties, together with the Chinese reply.

"Super-bankers" were denounced as trying to rob Americans of their traditional freedom by United States Senator Royal S. Copeland yesterday afternoon at the first of a series of discussions of public affairs at the National Democratic Club, Madisor Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 23 -- Joseph deV. Keefe and K.C. Kennedy of the Merion Cricket Club led the field into the semi-final round of the second annual Greenwich invitation squash racquets doubles tournament today as play got under way at the Greenwick Country Club, the Field Club and the private court of Percy Rockefeller.

Three Diverse Exhibitions. Three rather diverse exhibitions are current at the Art Centre. These will continue until Jan. 30. Robert Tittle McKee shows flower studies and landscapes (done, mostly, in the Balearic Isles'). In the large gallery are oils by Carlos Crozco Romero, a protege of Carlos Merida, whose work is as reminiscent as his name.

BERLIN. THE flood of incoming books demands concentration upon a few. Discussion must be limited to those authors whose merit is more or less established, room being left for the introduction of a few newcomers.

REMARKABLE as is the record of achievement of the family founded by John August Roebling, who came to the United States from Germany in 1831, quite as exceptional in the annals of American industry is the fact that that record of accomplishment is one of steady advancement through the lives of three generations of one family.

The coming week's auction offerings include sculptures of the eighteenth century by Houdon, Clodion, Pajou and others and seventeenth and eighteenth century English furniture from the Great Neck and New York homes of S. Vernon Mann; also early American furniture and decorations collected by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Randolph Adams of Darien, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP). -- Rosemary Ryan, daughter of Justice J.T. Ryan of the New York City court, was painfully injured today when she was thrown from a horse at the Ride and Hunt Club.

WHEN a traveler in Paris, London or Shanghai finds himself afflicted with a toothache his first move usually is to seek an American dentist. American dentistry has justly become known the world over for its skill and efficiency.

MONTREAL, Jan. 23 -- A smashing service and spectacular play gave J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., a straight-set victory over Berkeley Bell of New York today, enabling the New Jersey stylist to regain the Canadian covered court tennis singles title he held in 1929.

Legislation in Washington last week adding $125,000,000 to the capital of the Federal Land Bank system, which strengthened considerably the position of bonds of those banks, was somewhat obscured by the creation of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Sterling continued to weaken today in the foreign exchange market because of the latest political developments. The New York rate was down at one time to $3.42 1/2 but recovered to $3.43. Leading Continental currencies also continued to move against the pound.

Support for the three bills introduced by Senator Gerald P. Nye in the early part of this month to strengthen the anti-trust laws and to assist small merchants in competition with chain stores is rapidly growing, it was disclosed here yesterday.

SERIOUS historical works, written chiefly in Russian and French, bearing on Emperor Alexander I of Russia and on his time are numerous. But American and English biographers so far have almost entirely overlooked him as a subject for works of popular interest.

HOLLYWOOD, CAL. THE cinema has gone literary. One by one talented and recognized authors have been signed to compose lyrical sentences and coherent plots, which may, in one form or another, reach the screen.

Extension of imperial preference within the British Empire, which never has appeared more likely than at the present time, will have far-reaching effects upon the foreign trade of other countries, especially the United States, according to the Index published by the New York Trust Company.
WASHINGTON. WILL what appeared to be the leadership and the courage of the automobile industry in creating the great value that is the 1932 automobile prove to be a blunder of industrial management?

THE new motor boats of 1932 show continued progress in many aspects calculated to delight alike the expert and the novice. While some of the new features are mechanical, others architectural and still others in equipment, all tend to make motor boats more comfortable and desirable than ever before in their history.

LESS than eighty years have passed since Japan entered the family of nations, not of her own accord, but forced into international intercourse by the United States. In 1854 she signed away her right to remain a hermit nation. Fourteen years later direct imperial authority was restored after 700 years of shogunate rule, and in 1889 the Emperor granted a Constitution.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Leutze's famous painting, "Washington Crossing the Delaware," in the Metropolitan Museum is again the subject of controversy, and no one knows what to do with it. Among many suggestions offered is that it be enclosed in a marble shrine.

AROYAL tomb discovered re- cently at the Zapotec ruins of Monte Alban, in Southern Mexico, has yielded jewels and golden objects of high crafts- manship and great beauty, and has brought us into contact with the symbols of an early American civilisation.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 23 -- With two national champions and Olympic three-weapon stars, Nunes and Huffman, the New York Athletic Club defeated the Naval Academy fencing team today in the latter's first meet of the season, 11 to 6.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Senator Fess of Ohio, national Republican chairman, forecast tonight a victory for President Hoover in November, saying that prohibition would be subordinated to economic issues. He declared that the Republican campaign would be based on the record of the Hoover Administration in business and industrial recovery.
Thrift Week. THERE was a rich city, and she had a great sorrow, For she had no money, no money could she borrow. She moaned and she murmured, and at last said she,

MANILA, Dec. 20 -- The official attitude toward recent subversive movements in the Philippines and the threat of uprising seems more gravely concerned with the possible effects of unfavorable publicity due to these movements than with the dangers of the uprisings themselves.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Driving toward completion of evidence by which the prosecution is endeavoring to hang Winnie Ruth Judd, County Attorney Lloyd J. Andrews approached today the unmasking of the alleged motive for the defendant's confessed slaying of her two women victims.

GENEVA, Jan. 23 -- With the Council's session on Monday begins a series of international meetings on three big questions -- Manchuria, political debts and disarmament. Each will be treated formally as if in watertight compartments. However, each will be understood better, perhaps, if some relationships among them are kept in mind.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- The manuscript of a plan of strategy against the British troops, worked out by General Washington at his camp near Dobbs Ferry on July 13, 1781, but never put into effect because of the timely arrival of the Count De Grasse with a powerful French fleet at Chesapeake Bay, was sold at auction here this week for $1,950.

Excessive competition in gasoline marketing is costing the industry more than $455,000,000 annually, without any compensating benefit to the motoring public, according to statistics compiled by Glen B. Winship, who has been active in the petroleum industry for fifteen years and for two years has been making a special analysis of gasoline marketing conditions throughout the country.

The decline in the consumption of cigarettes in recent months has not been offset by a proportionate increase in sales of other forms of tobacco, according to a memorandum in opposition to the proposed increase in taxes on tobacco products filed with the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives by the Tobacco Merchants Association of the United States.

PALM BEACH -- Gathering momentum from earlier weeks -- during which sports comprised preliminary play on the various golf courses, informal matches at the Palm Beach Tennis Club on the Poinciana grounds and practice polo play three days a week at the Phipps Fields at Gulf Stream -- Palm Beach this week inaugurates its real season of tournaments.

An Unemployed Boom. WHAT'S become of ambition? Here it is the end of January, the Jackson Day Dinner has come and gone, and yet there is a pathetically small number of Presidential booms in full swing.

THE single current American avocation -- or pastime -- that seems to be unaffected by the depression is the assembly-hall pursuit of culture. The theatres have suffered great losses, football stadia have shown empty seats in inverse ratio to the price of steel and even the movies have cut expenses and the publicity about actors' salaries.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 -- John B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., medalist and defending champion, lost today by 2 and 1 to Winfield S. Day, 16-year-old Chicago star, in the semi-final matches for the Glenn H. Curtiss Trophy on the municipal course at Miami Springs.

TORONTO. CANADA'S great air force concentration camp at Borden in Simcoe County is gradually being transferred to Trenton, east of Toronto, where there will be accommodation for land planes as well as sea planes.

WE live in very strange times, and at a great pace. Weeks are now days, and months weeks, and we cramp into the experience of one week all that we used to get in a whole year. We fly through the country, seeing nothing, and we listen to music all day on the wireless, hearing nothing.

The third and last concert this season of the New York Sinfonietta, with Quinto Maganini conducting, was held yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. A large audience applauded a program including the Schubert Fifth Symphony and selections from contemporary American composers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Standing on the steps of the Capitol today, Senator Walsh of Massachusetts accepted a petition, said to be signed by more than 5,000,000 voters, asking modification of the Volstead act.

DURING periods of depression when business is slack, more development work is done than in seasons when every shop is rushed to its limit to fill orders. In accordance with this general principle, much that was new in marine motors appeared during 1931 and more is promised for 1932.

Oxford began practice for its boat, race on March 19 with Cambridge University a day later this year than last year, although the candidates for the crew were not in residence until ten days afterward. Conditions on the Isis were not good and the practice finished in a steady down- pour of rain.

The weekly index of business activity has dropped back to 63.0 (preliminary) for the week ended Jan. 16 from 64.1 for the preceding week, although it is still above the low point of 62.3 for the week ended Dec. 26. There was a general recession in all types of activity represented in the combined index, with the exception of steel operations, which increased by slightly more than the usual seasonal amount.

DURING the lifetime of Sheridan a social revolution took place. The theatre reacted to the changed social point of view and gave the public what it wanted. Sheridan was the last of a dynasty; he had no successors on the stage.

BORN in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, in 1810, Jonathan Messersmith Foltz received his M. D. degree from the Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia when he was 20 and at once determined to enter the Medical Corps of the navy.

IN headlong New York City a restaurant flourished and was famous through all the years between the war that saved the Union and the war that saved the world for the depression and America for prohibition. Indeed, the career of that restaurant lapped over both wars -- went back to the 1850s and forward to 1920.

WHENEVER the labored question of duplications comes up ror discussion it is always to be expected that the more passionate the individual protest against the latest case of old wine in new bottles, the more insistent is the demand for a fresh recording of one or two items.

THE Do-X, now poised for flight at the Glenn H. Curtiss Airport. North Beach, Queens, is to lose its unique position as the world's largest airplane. Although its designer, Dr. Claude Dornier, maintains the attitude that his machine is nothing but a huge experiment, in Holland plans and specifications have been drawn for a plane twice the size if not with twice the load capacity of the German flying boat.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- From a cemetery in Medyhm, Egypt, which belonged to the Ptolemaic era, ten mummies dating from 250 B.C. have been discovered by an archaeological expedition headed by Alan Rowe from the University of Pennsylvania Museum Director Horace H.F. Jayne, stated today.

In face of difficulties caused by the economic depression, public education in 1931 produced a "really remarkable record of achievement," according to the tenth annual "rollcall" report, based on a survey of the year's academic developments throughout the United States and its dependencies, just published by the National Education Association.

PALM BEACH. Fla., Jan. 23 -- The Sportsman's Ball was given tonight at the Palm Beach Anglers' Club on the lake trail. Proceeds will go to augment a fund to prevent illegal netting of fish in Lake Worth. Mrs. John Charles Thomas gave a dinner at the home of her mother, Mrs. George A. Dobyne.

MARIE DRESSLER'S new picture, "Emma," which is sched- uled to come next week to the Capitol Theatre, is her first film following an illness of several months which kept her from any activity at the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studios. Miss Dressier has now recovered her health, and before the end of January expects to start work in "Prosperity."

Announcements of the retirement of parts of two issues of warrants and local improvement bonds in the remaining days of January featured the additions made last week to the list of bonds called for redemption before their maturity dates. The total for this month is now $70,631,000, compared with $22,164,500 in December and with $57,899,000 in January, 1931, at corresponding dates.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Governor Roosevelt formally announced today that he is a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President.

WHEN an author proposes to trace "amorous insubordination" through English poetry, and to observe the poetical expression of attitudes opposed to the usual devoted submissiveness, his book, be it ever so scholarly (and Mr. Salomon's study is scholarly even to the footnotes and the bibliography), is likely to prove fascinating reading.

IN these days when so many poets write from a meager and overly civilized background the verses of Lew Sarett are a relief. He is in the best sense of the word, a folk-poet, employing American Indian legends, lumberjack tales, lore of the backwoods and pioneer folk for his materials.

BOMBAY, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Seventy thousand "untouchables" [depressed caste Hindus], members of a textile workers' Union at Ahmedabad, organized and headed by Mahatma Gandhi, went on strike today in protest against the arrest of their secretary under the emergency ordinances forbidding Nationalist activity.

LONDON. A MONG European countries Denmark has the most radio auditors in proportion to population, according to the International Broadcasting Union, which has published a chart showing the ratio of radio licensee to population in many nations.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 23 -- The site upon which the new Adrian H. Joline Memorial Dormitory is to be erected on the campus of Princeton University is now being cleared and excavation will be undertaken shortly. The erection of this building, actual construction of which will be started early in the Spring, was authorized recently by the board of trustees in an effort to relieve unemployment conditions in Princeton.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 13 -- The new Argentine tax on business trans- actions, which has been collectable as of Jan. 1, is yielding results equal if not superior to the first estimates, a sum equivalent to $212,300 at current rates of exchange, having been collected between Jan. 1 and 11.
J. Edward Jones, in a report on the oil industry, blames the United States Department of the Interior for demoralized conditions in the petroleum business.

SEVERAL young women, alumnae of Vassar College, are assisting in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor," with Mme. Lily Pons, Martinelli and De Luca in the leading roles, which, will be given on the afternoon of Feb. 5 at the Metropolitan Opera House in aid of the scholarship fund of the Vassar Club of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. HOLLYWOOD is okay. Edgar Wallace, prolific writer of English best sellers, set the seal of approval on that famous Los Angeles subdivision when the question was popped to him at his Beverly Hills home, whence he fled from an exclusive hotel because ho couldn't get tea after 9 P.M. or before 6 A.M.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 -- A physician who, as a young interne years ago worked out many of the methods of applying the X-ray by means of a borrowed coil and tube, will be buried here tomorrow. He was Dr. Verner Simpson Gaggin, 62 years old, who died in his home here on Wednesday.

READING, Pa., Jan. 23 -- Shooting in a driving rainstorm, which aided the flyers and handicapped the gunners, Eugene B. Springer, New York Athletic Club, with Hardy D. Wilbank, Pennsylvania amateur champion, at nineteen out of twenty flyers from a 30-yard rise, to divide high gun honors in the mid-Winter amateur classic, featuring today's events over the Pleasant Hill traps.

WILLYS-OVERLAND, INC., announced last week reductions of $100 each in the list prices of all new 1932 six and eight cylinder Willys-Overland cars and the Willys-Knight six models. Prices for the Willys-Overland six start at $415 and range to $595 for the four-door sedan.

MADRID, Jan. 23 -- Precautionary measures were taken throughout Spain today to prevent disorders in connection with the general strike, scheduled to begin Monday and aimed at the establishment of a proletarian dictatorship. Communists, Anarchists and Syndicalists have covered all Spain with pamphlets calling on the masses to arise and seize power.

Because he resented getting eggs for dinner, William Jander, 70 years old, a retired railroad man, shot and wounded his sister and brother-in-law last night and killed himself with a bullet through the brain. Neither the sister, Mrs. Isabel Jansen, 64, nor her husband, George, 65, was seriously hurt.

Small declines in leading stocks and recoveries in the more active domestic and foreign bonds featured trading on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday in a moderate volume of transactions lacking in noteworthy price changes.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 23 -- Morgan memorial park, the 30-acre shore-front recreational centre and bathing beach that J.P. Morgan is developing as a memorial to his wife, the late Jane Norton Grew Morgan, for the residents of Glen Cove and Locust Valley, is within about six months of completion.

CARD parties in aid of the charitable enterprises of various philanthropic organizations will take place in the near future. A bridge party for the benefit of the Walter Scott Industrial School for Crippled Children and the Lulu Thorley Lyons Home for Delicate Children will be given on the afternoon of Feb. 1 in the Japanese Room of the St. Regis, under the auspices of the Junior League of the school.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 -- The Harvard Whites vanquished the Red varsity team in the feature squash racquets match in the State League competition today. The score of this Class A event was 4 to 1.
Yale's indoor polo team made an impressive metropolitan debut at Squadron A Armory last night against the twelve-goal team of the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Faced with a constant tide of liquor flowing into the United States over all its borders, the Coast Guard and forces of the Bureau of Customs are seizing boats and vessels at the rate of about 600 a year, the average in the latter half of the 1930-31 fiscal period, and are confiscating liquor valued at millions of dollars.

No President leads a life of ease. But Mr. Hoover has been busier than most of his predecessors, particularly lately. He is at work, with Congress, with, the Cabinet and with representative citizens on measures designed to revive trade, balance the government budget and stabilize the financial situation.

Controller Charles W. Berry's annual digest of the city's financial affairs issued yesterday shows that during 1931 the city received $1,413,867,997,23 from all sources and paid out a total of $1,446,399,616,99.The gross financial turnover for the year was $2,860,267,614,22.

The sun smiled gently on the Bronx yesterday, and the clear air carried a wistful song of cheer. Gone was the gloom of the last week and the sadness that had been almost despair. For right in the centre of the zoo, warm and well fed, sat Secundus, the City's Official Groundhog.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 22 -- The Dutch money markets and stock markets are being judged more favorably, and the belief seems to be winning ground that bottom level has at least been reached. At Amsterdam several specialties, notably in the sugar, oil and tobacco industries, are meeting increased demand from investors.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 24 -- Trading in cotton contracts here last week was rather moderate but prices were rather steady, showing no tendency to improve according to the firmness in the stock market. Early in the week the market developed an improving tendency in anticipation of the passage of the Reconstruction Finance measure by Congress.

BULLET JOE SIMPSON was in town recently. Bulllet Joe used to dash up and down the Garden ice in the uniform of the star-spangled Americans. Now he manages the American "ice farm" in New Haven. He was with the Forty-third Battalion, Cameron Highlanders, in the World War and has plenty of scars to show for his service.

TSINAN, China, Jan. 24 -- Shantung province, always a pivotal area in any Chinese civil war north of the Yangtse River, today presents the spectacle of preparedness and apprehension that is to be found here every Spring. The politicians, militarists and various factions are bidding for the support of the Provincial Governor, who this year is General Han Fu-chu.

The Weinsteins -- Aaron and his wife and their eight children, Isidor, 19; Hyman, 17; Fanny, 15; Sam, 12; Hilda, 8; William, 6; Pearl, 4, and Solomon, 2 -- looked upon life yesterday and found it good.

When the scientists get through with us, nothing "indefinable" will be left in the world. Their perseverance has brought to light mighty discoveries and revealed by infallible inference forces too slight ever to register on the human senses. Like hounds on a fresh track, they keep on over the thorniest obstacles.

OCONOMOWOC, Wis., Jan. 24. -- The two-day national amateur speed skating championship meet, held on a millpond near here, closed today. James Webster, St. Paul, won the title in the senior men's division, formerly held by Frank Stack, Canadian, and Miss Helen Bina, Chicago, was awarded the championship in the women's division, formerly held by Miss Loretta Neitzel, Detroit.
SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Martial law was declared throughout El Salvador today in a determination to put down Communist risings.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- The currency reform plan published this week by Director Wagemann of the Bureau of Statistics is not very seriously considered. The Reichsbank law could not be amended, as Wagemann suggests, without the consent of the reparation creditor countries.

Two incidents of the past week were of a character to cause interesting and not uninstructive reminiscence. With each the nature of the occurrence and the circumstances which occasioned it revived in a peculiar way the memory of other chapters of hard times.

Paul Moritz Warburg, chairman of the boards of The Manhattan Company and the International Acceptance Bank of New York, and member of a prominent family of bankers, died at 6:30 o'clock last night at his home, 17 East Eightieth Street. He was in his sixty-fourth year.

Governor ROOSEVELT'S written consent to have his name entered in the North Dakota primary as a Democratic candidate for the Presidency can surprise no one. His candidacy has been an obvious fact for more than a year. It long ceased to be an unknown quantity in our political algebra.
VATICAN CITY, Jan. 24. -- Pope Pius, in addressing the ecclesiastics today, glorified the disbanded Jesuits of Spain as "martyrs of the Papacy, martyrs of the Pope, martyrs of the Vicar of Christ."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Plans for an immediate start of the $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation were discussed today with President Hoover at a conference in the White House, in which Charles G. Dawes, president; Eugene Meyer, chairman of the board; Andrew W. Mellon, Secretary of the Treasury; Under-Secretary Ogden L. Mills, Paul Bestor, Farm Loan Commissioner, and George L. Harrison, Governor of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, participated.

The wrongdoing of public officials, which Samuel Seabury charged in his report was part of a Tammany system of graft and corruption, is but "an incident in the administration of all governments," Assemblyman Louis Cuvlllier, a member of the Tammany minority on the Hofstadter committee, declared in a "dissenting report" made public last night.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- In the rubber market here today plantation grades were quiet but steady. Smoked sheet spot sold at 3d a pound sellers, February from 215-16d to 3d sellers. March at 3d sellers, April-June at 3 1/8d sellers, July-September at 3 3-16d to 3 5-16d sellers, October-December at 3d to 3 7-16d sellers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Unusually mild weather has checked the demand for fresh dressed beef and lambs as well as for fresh cuts of hogs. Supplies of the latter were liberal here last week, and prices declined to the lowest since 1899. Best selection, which brought $4.35 a hundred pounds at the start of the week, declined to $4.10, with the close at $4.20.

Controller BERRY'S annual statement of what the city receives and what it spends, prepared with admirable lucidity by DUNCAN MACINNES, chief accountant, comes with special timeliness this year. The totals for 1931 are as impressive as ever, with receipts of $650,000,000 and expenditures in proportion.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag. president of the Young Men's Hebrew Association, reading his annual report at the fifty-eighth annual meeting of the association last night, reported an increase of 1.200 members during 1931. bringing the total membership to 5,677.

The first appeal of a racing decision carried to the North American Yacht Racing Union, governing body of yachting in this country and Canada, has heen decided by that organization's executive committee, headed by Clifford D. Mallory. The decision upholds the committee of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club in disqualifying the yachts Italia and Stranger in a race sailed last June at Toronto.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The legality of "nearly two billion" of postarmistice cash loans by the United States to European governments was questioned again today by Arthur M. Hyde, Secretary of Agriculture.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 24 -- Sixty-five men and women, managers, ticket-sellers, operators and ushers, were arrested here today when the four Plainfield motion picture theatres opened for Sunday performances in defiance of the State "blue law" of 1798, local custom, the opinion of part of the public and a "ban" imposed by the city administration.

HAVANA, Jan. 24 (AP). -- The $2,500 added Turismo Cup Handicap was the feature offering of the program at Oriental Park today and the winner turned up in P.B. Codd's Menelek, brown son of General Thatcher.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During a short speech to the Advertising Club the other day Mr. Murphy, the president, suggested that the word "depression" be omitted from our vocabularies. This seemed to me a splendid suggestion. But omitting the word is not going to do much good when people dwell upon the results of depression without looking ahead and finding a ray of hope.

Declaring that Bishop James De Wolf Perry had misquoted two passages from the books of St. Jerome and St. Athanasius, the Rev. John Corbett, speaking yesterday from the pulpit of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, renewed his attack upon the Bishop's reply to the Pope's recent encyclical urging all sects to return to the Roman Catholic Church.

A flock of Philadelphia lawyers will soon be required to differentiate among the plans of the Democratic chieftains for State referendums on prohibition. The plank which the Washington State convention, dominated by friends of Governor ROOSEVELT, probably will adopt was published in THE TIMES Saturday.

The Vicki Baums and Lion Feuchtwangers of Germany are less representative of modern German literature than of a body of "popular writing" that is cosmopolitan in spirit, George N. Shuster writes in his book, "The Germans," published today by Lincoln Mac Veagh, The Dial Press.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The United States cruiser Rochester and the destroyers Philip and Wickes, speeding from Panama to Salvador, carry 115 Marines, who probably will be landed and rushed to San Salvador, the capital.

Harry M. Daugherty's promised revelations concerning the Presidential Administration of Warren G. Harding, marked by the Teapot Dome oil scandals while Mr. Daugherty was was Attorney General, are about to be released to booksellers under the title "The Inside Story of the Harding Tragedy," it was disclosed yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24. -- Winfield S. Day, 16-year-old Chicago star, won his first tournament of the Florida season today, defeating John Brown of Portland, Me., by 4 and 2 for the Glenn H. Curtiss Trophy over the municipal course at Miami Springs.

Clarence D. Chamberlin landed his Packard-Diesel motored Lockheed monoplane yesterday afternoon at Floyd Bennett Field after art hour's climb through the clouds above Brooklyn to a new altitude record for Diesel engines of 22,000 to 25,000 feet.

Lord ROSEBERY once said that England always assumed a kind of "European censorship" which impels her to "administer exhortation "and rebuke to the States of the "Continent." If she has dropped it, America has taken it up in the person of Senator BORAH, who often comes forward as our Chief Censor of Europe.

VIENNA, Jan. 24. -- Austria spent another uneasy week-end in expectation of the materialization of the long-feared Heimwehr "putsch." Although it appeared that precautions taken by the Socialists probably had caused a postponement of the attempt believed to be set for tomorrow, nevertheless the situation in Austria remained as critical politically as it has been for some time financially.

The New York Rangers cut the Detroit Falcons' string of successes short last night by subduing the Michigan sextet in a hard National Hockey League match at Madison Square Garden. Opposing a stubborn, unyielding aggregation, the New Yorkers were taxed to the limit to win, but win they did, by the score of 4 to 3.

Appearing before the House Committee on Naval Affairs on April 17, 1930, Rear Admiral George H. Rock, Chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair of the Navy Department, said that American battleships were "in the Grand Fleet, but whether they were in the Battle of Jutland, I do not remember.'

The qualities that make Sigrid Onegin's art great were in high relief once more at her recital in the Town Hall last night. Her voice, her understanding of a variety of songs and their people and her personality had the large audience captivated from beginning to end, and the end was only after many encores.

Shanghai consists of three parts -- the International Settlement, the French Concession and the Native City. The Native City is further subdivided into three boroughs -- Chapei, Nantao and Pootung, across the Whangpo River.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- Izvestia, the official mouthpiece of the Soviet Government, publishes today a long editorial on the Far Eastern situation and the Soviet attitude regarding it. The article is couched in terms of great moderation, but does not attempt to evade the facts and really is a solemn warning to Japan.

Ross E. Young, 56 years old, a stock broker with offices at 15 Broad Street, killed himself yesterday in a room on the fourteenth floor of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by shooting himself in the right temple. It was the first suicide in the new hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (Canadian Press Cable) -- Sir Alfred Yarrow in 1861. when he was 19, and a young companion constructed a steam automobile, in which they would dash along the highway at fully twenty-five miles an hour. One night, as they roared down the road with smoke and flames belching from the stack of their vehicle, they encountered a mounted policeman whose horse threw him and broke his leg.

The Rev. Dr. Francis P. Duffy, chaplain of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, preaching yesterday morning in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, Forty-second Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, of which he is the pastor, announced that by special permission of Pope Pius XI a mass for late night workers, especially newspaper men and printers, in the Times Square district, would be celebrated at 2:15 A.M. beginning next Sunday.

No city money will be spent by the New York City commission that is arranging the George Washington bicentennial observance here, Grover A. Whalen, the chairman, announced yesterday. On the contrary, it is hoped that some features of the program will provide additional funds for New York's unemployed.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- Returning a card of 79-14-65, James B. Black gained the first low net laurels in the seventh weekly qualifying round of the annual Snowbirds' golf tournament held by the members of the Siwanoy Country Club today. Of the twenty-five players who took part, eighteen turned in scores.

BOGOTA, Jan. 24. -- Apparently the continued agitation for a complete moratorium on all foreign debt services led President Enrique Olaya Herrera to give the press his statement yesterday explaining the present situation and position of the government.

Louise Le Gal, assisted by Howard Blair, appeared in a program of "Cantomimes," of songs, dancing and pantomime, last night at the Booth Theatre. The program was in the form of a series of sketches including an incident in the life of Chopin, a scene in an Egyptian tomb in 1500 B.C., and character scenes from other countries, including Africa, Spain, England, France and Japan.
Abandonment of the gold standard in this country either voluntarily or involuntarily is inconceivable, the Guaranty Trust Company says in its current issue of The Guaranty Surey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Of the total collection of $1,914,054,600 the internal revenue receipts in 1931, the six New York districts accounted for $502,321,600, or about 26 per cent, the bureau announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Developments in the grain trade of late have demonstrated clearly, according to men in it, that more constructive influences are necessary to increase speculative buying and to prevent wheat prices from declining. Supplies are too large, they say, for consumptive demand the world over to have any material effect at present.

Yehudi Menuhin. no longer a child of phenomenal gifts and an unpredictable future, but a well-grown boy, gave his first New York recital of the season yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. In other words, Menuhin is no longer of the class of infant prodigies.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Sir William Jowitt, the only member of Prime Minister MacDonald's original National Cabinet to lose his seat in last October's election, has resigned as Attorney General. His decision was announced tonight after persistent but unavailing efforts to find a seat for him.
Tributes to the late Paul M. Warburg were paid yesterday by leaders in government, finance and Judaism. Their statements follow:

BERLIN, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Paul Warburg, who died in New York today was a member of a famous banking dynasty founded in Hamburg, Germany. After studying at German universities he entered the banking house of M.M. Warburg. His younger brother, Felix, preceded him to New York in 1894, while two brothers, Max and Fritz, remained in Hamburg to take over the family's bank.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Jan. 24 -- Mrs. Robert Weeks de Forest of New York, widow of the former president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has chosen the Pennsylvania Museum of Art as the recipient of her collection of more than 5,000 pieces of folk pottery, gathered by herself, her husband and their agents from forty countries during a quarter century.

The award to Dr. Charles H. Herty of New York of the medal of the American Institute of Chemists "for noteworthy and outstanding service to the science and profession of chemistry in America" will be announced today by Frederick E. Breithut, president, from the institute's office at 233 Broadway.

BERLIN, Jan. 24. -- It was learned today that the creditor bankers who yesterday concluded an agreement for a year's prolongation of Germany's $1,500,000,000 of private short-term foreign credits estimate that there is now about $250,000,000 hoarded in bank notes in the country and declare in their report that with reviving confidence the German money market will receive substantial relief from this source.

Changes in the structure of the New York City Government and in the manner of selecting its officials are needed to loosen the grip by which Tammany Hall foists a system of graft and corruption upon the people, Samuel Seabury informed the Legislature yesterday in his intermediate report as chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- The temperature dropped to 10 above zero today and improved conditions for the Olympic athletes, who had feared last night the snow would vanish again as a drizzle set in.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 24 -- Tonight 1,400 Japanese marines were ashore in Shanghai and all Japanese warships in the harbor had their guns stripped for action, while foreign defense forces and the police in the foreign area were held in readiness to meet any emergency.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- During the ceremonies last night incident to installing a new president and board of governors, several hundred members of the National Press Club paused to pay tribute to Richard V. Oulahan, late chief of the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and Graham B. Nichol, a charter member of the club, and in recent years Public Relations Counselor of the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 24 -- Asserting that the Yale undergraduate is "one of the most pampered individuals in the world," an article in the midwinter number of The Harkness Hoot by Richard M. Bissell Jr. of Farmington, Conn., a senior, declares that college students are not living up to the obligations laid upon them by the endowment of education.

Less than three weeks ago the Diphtheria Prevention Commission reporting upon the three-year intensive campaign, stated that the effectiveness of the toxin-antitoxin treatment had been amply demonstrated. There had been a reduction from 11,000 to 4,000 cases, and it was estimated that no less than 1,400 deaths had been prevented.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- Olympic skaters of Japan, Norway, Sweden, England and the United States displayed their speed and skill before a crowd of several thousand at an exhibition meet staged at Turtle Pond Club today.

MADRID, Jan. 24 (AP). -- A policeman was killed and five merry makers wounded in Barcelona as the government massed military and police forces today to cope with a threatened general strike tomorrow intended to establish a proletarian Dictatorship.

Miss Nelly Callahan spelled down a Supreme Court justice, a State Senior, a producer, two reporters and flock of actors last night at a spelling bee held by the Catholic Actors Guild of America, of which she is Social secretary. The contest took place in the guild headquarters at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The new tax bill to be reported to the House by the Ways and Means Committee in early February will not put burdensome taxes on industry and will avoid numerous "nuisance taxes" by imposing widely distributed consumptive taxes, according to leading members of the committee.

Paul De Bruyn, national marathon champion of Germany and holder of the New York County cross-country title, established a new course record in registering the best time in the weekly four-mile handicap road race conducted by the Manhattan League under the auspices of the Paulist A.C. in Central Park yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- Final action by the twenty-one standard railway unions on the demand of the presidents' committee of nine for a 10 per cent wage reduction for one year is likely to be taken tomorrow night or Tuesday unless unforeseen obstacles arise tomorrow, according to reports current tonight in the camps of employers and employes.

With the hope of early achievement of a general rapid transit unification plan fading rapidly into the background because of the city's financial condition and the general weakness of the securities market, the Board of Transportation will accelerate its program for getting the new Eighth Avenue subway into operation as a separate unit, it was disclosed yesterday.

PRINCETOWN, England, Jan. 24 -- Between 200 and 300 convicts of the 450 held in the lonely Dartmoor penal settlement here mutinied today and battled guards for several hours. Eighty convicts and twelve prison officials were injured, but no convict escaped.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Governor Roosevelt's announcement of his candidacy for the Presidency was received with interest here today but more attention was paid to the claim of his supporters that his first ballot strength in the Democratic National Convention would be not fewer than 678 out of 1,154 delegates.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- Uncertainty over the fate of the Lausanne conference has had unfavorable effect on business sentiment here; on Thursday it caused distinct reaction in stocks. Although all public utterances endorse the Chancellor's policy of immediate cancellation, business circles, which from the first foresaw that this policy would fail through French opposition, would have been satisfied with a long moratorium.

Declaring that the world needed to place greater emphasis upon the service rendered by its churches, the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner, pastor of the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, at 174th Street, said in his sermon last evening that it was enlightening to contrast church attendance in New York with attendance at theatres.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 24 (AP).-- Ralph Guldahl, tall, youthful professional from Detroit, shot a round of 68, three under par, on the final eighteen holes to win the $600 first prize in the $2,500 Arizona open golf tournament today.

Reduction of salaries of State employes and other retrenchment bofore new revenues are sought for the State will be urged upon the Legislature by the Merchants' Association of New York, it was announced yesterday by the association in making public its approval of two reports of its committee on taxation and public revenue, dealing with the budget and taxation, program of Governor Roosevelt.
ATLANTA, Jan. 24 -- Huey Long of Louisiana passed through Atlanta today en route to Washington to take over his Senate seat.
The National Motor Boat Show at the Grand Central Palace, which was closed yesterday, will continue today from 10:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. This has teen designated as "New England Day."

The Bronx Hockey Club scored its second victory in the Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League yesterday, defeating the St. Nicholas sextet by a score of 2 to 1 at the New York Coliseum before 3,000 spectators. A sizzling second period, in which all three goals were made, the winning marker coming with only fifteen seconds of playing time left, decided the battle.
Leases of space in Manhattan buildings announced over the week-end indicated a demand for good business Stations.
Local commodity markets were more or less unsettled last week, and sugar, coffee, cocoa, hides, rubber and silver futures closed with varying degrees of losses.

The Great Wall of Peru is a relic dating to the time of the early Christian era and was probably a frontier defense of the ancient Chimus, predecessors of the Incas, according to the consensus of a group of leading Andean Archaeologists obtained by the American Geographical Society and made public yesterday.

Scoring in all three periods and presenting a spectacular defense, especially by Goalie Byron Knapp, the New York Athletic Club hockey team defeated the Boston Hockey Club, 5 to 0, in the second game of the double-header staged at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Metropolitan Association A.A.U.

ATLANTA, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Tidings of encouraging developments in the business and governmental affairs of the South were brought to Atlanta today by newspaper executives attending the midwinter meeting of the directors of the Southern Newspaper Publishers' Association.
The Junior Newman Club of the Washington Irving Evening High School will give a midwinter dance at the Hotel Gotham on the evening of Jan. 30.

An editorial accusation that freedom of speech over the radio is being denied to American clergymen will appear in this week's issue of The Christian Century, an undenominational religious journal. Three instances in which freedom of utterance is said to have been either denied or imperiled are cited.

Five Norwegian skaters, one the Olympic 5,000-meter champion, arrived in New York yesterday on the S.S. Bergensfjord after a twelve-day transatlantic crossing to join their compatriots at Lake Placid for the Winter Olympic games, the main body having reached here almost a fortnight ago.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 24 -- Millions of American citizens are demanding a vote on national prohibition, Henry H. Curran, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, declared tonight in a letter to members of the House and Senate, insisting that sentiment was now strong enough to justify Congress in supporting a resolution for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- An eyewitness of today's battle in the Dartmoor prison courtyard gave the following description to The Sunday Dispatch:
Breaking 97 out of a possible 100 targets, J.H. Wantling led a field of thirty-five at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Tiff Denton, Kansas City veteran, tonight scored his first victory in the world's three-cushion billiard championship, defeating Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., 50 to 46, in fifty-seven innings.

The governmental heads of the three Scandinavian countries, Premier Thorvald Stauning of Denmark, Foreign Minister Birger Braadland of Norway (acting Prime Minister during the illness of Premier Peder Kolstad) and Premier Gustav Ekman of Sweden, spoke yesterday from their respective capitals to the people of North America over the WABC-Columbia network.

Paul M. Warburg was among those who made banking reform possible in the United States. Coming to this country as a young man, he entered the American banking field with the idea of returning in a few years to Germany, where members of his family had been bankers for generations.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan., 24. -- Plays today are better works of art and are "both better acted and better staged" than those of a generation or two ago, Mrs. Beatrice Forbes-Robertson Hale, former actress, told the Ethical Culture Society here today.

A mad war romance, known as "Cock of the Air," which has something of the moods of "The Last Flight" and "Private Lives," is now sojourning at the Rialto. In one of its many strange Interludes Lilli de Rosseau, a French actress, whom Lieutenant Roger Craig, of the American flying force, knows only as Whatever, expresses a longing for a champagne cocktail at the Ritz bar in Paris.

The New York Public Service Commission will announce today that it will revoke in many cases the unexercised authority previously granted to various public utility companies in the State to issue securities for various purposes.

With forty years of service and something like 1,000,000 miles of travel all over the waters of New York Bay behind him, Captain John J. Hammel, veteran skipper of the Staten Island Municipal Ferry Service, bade his crew good-bye and walked ashore from the ferryboat Dongan Hills at St. George yesterday afternoon a retired man.

Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee, will go before the Supreme Court today to ask for an order requiring State Senator John. Hastings to show cause why he should not be adjudged in contempt for having ignored a subpoena to appear before the Legislative Invesgating Committee.

HONOLULU, Jan. 24 (AP). -- This city's new police commission, created as a step toward solution of a so-called crime wave, today notified all members of the police force they would be reappointed for a probationary period of one year, starting Feb. 1, when the commission takes office.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- The "Spanish prisoner" swindle, hoary with years, during which it was successfully worked to separate the credulous from their money, is recalled by a letter from Surrogate James A. Foley of New York County to Governor Roosevelt, which the Governor made public here today with a request that it receive nation-wide publicity.

Moe Kushman, representing the home club, took first place in the weekly handicap road run conducted under the auspices of the St. Anselm's A.C. in the Bronx yesterday. The victor, who had an allowance of 4:30, was timed in 26:16 for the four and one-half mile event.

Persons interested in the work of the Riverside Day Nursery have arranged for a St. Valentine supper dance on Feb. 13 at the St. Regris. The proceeds will be used in the maintenance of the institution, which is at 149 West Sixty-third Street.

GENEVA, Jan. 24 -- The commission supervising the finances of the League of Nations has voted, 3 to 2, to economize by suspending temporarily the construction of the new Assembly building. The Norwegian member made the motion and was backed by his British and Hungarian colleagues, with the French and Czechoslovak members against the proposal.

The Park Association of New York City offered its services to the city administration yesterday in evolving a plan to make possible the purchase of 126 3/4 acres of park and playground areas at cost of $1,687,350. The offer was made in a letter sent out over the signature of the association's president, Nathan Straus Jr., to every member of the Park Association.

Despite a drop of more than thirty-two billion dollars in the national wealth and fourteen billion dollars in national incomes from 1929 to 1930, every family in the United States would have $10,961 of capital and an annual income of $2,366 if the national wealth and income for 1930 could be divided equally among all the families of the country, according to a compilation made by the National Industrial Conference Board, Inc.

National traits continue to run true to form among the peoples of Europe. The German Government on reparations has a good case but has not shown itself to be a marvel of tact in presenting it. The French continue to stage demonstrations of remorseless logic at a time when several good-sized conflagrations are under way in the world.

A bracelet of diamonds and emeralds was lost last Tuesday by Mrs. Muriel Vanderbilt Church Phelps, it was disclosed yesterday. Over the telephone last night from her present residence at Newport, R.I., Mrs. Phelps said that she did not know the exact value of the piece, but guessed at "not more than $5,000."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Secretary Mellon announced today an offering of two issues of certificates of indebtedness to obtain about $350,000,000.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 24 -- In compliment to Mrs. Samuel D. Riddle, Mrs. Alexander A. McKay entertained today with a small luncheon at her residence. Mr. and Mrs. Lorenzo Mitchell-Henry, her house guests; Mrs. George Messervy and Mrs. LeRoy McKay, were among those present.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 24. -- The student riots which have aroused such attention in the past week are the result of the extraordinary political conditions created by the severity of the dictatorship and the disunity of the old political parties, leaving only the students to voice the widespread discontent in Yugoslavia.

Praising Cardinal Hayea as "a dear saint of God" whose church has "all the splendor of the Latin Mass," the Rev, Dr. Robert Norwood, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, declared in his sermon there yesterday morning that despite the exterior distinctions between the Protestant and the Catholic Church there was underneath much in common.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24. -- Ernie Nevers carried too much power for Frank Carideo's All-Stars and the former Stanford fullback's National Collegians crashed their way to a 26-to-14 victory in the Knights of Columbus charity football game today before 40,000 spectators.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 -- Estimates of steel production last week range from 25 to 28 per cent of capacity, the lowest calculation representing an increase of about one-fourth in tonnage from the latter half of December while the higher rate is fully equal to that officially reported for last October.

LARCHMONT, N.T., Jan. 24. -- Old North Wind, worn ragged in fiction and fact, came to the fore for the regatta of the Frostbite Yacht Club today. It served to waft some seventy hardy sailors and sailorettes through Mine sailing dinghy races held under the auspices of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Beekman Street Hospital. Commissioner WYNNE, on occasion of the tenth anniversary of Beekman Street Hospital last week, congratulated that institution on its excellent record. Situated in a part of the city where hospitals are few and far apart, it ministers to a large daytime population of office-workers, and to a nucleus of men and women who dwell as well as work downtown.

It is possible to find a reference in the Bible to every physical science from astronomy to zoology that is known today, Dr. Harry Rimmer, president of the Science Research Bureau of Los Angeles, declared in a sermon on the "Harmony of Science and the Bible" at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fiftyseventh Street, yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Chicagoans are beginning to realize that with half a million unemployed and homeless people facing starvation within a week unless relief funds are forthcoming the city is now in as precarious a situation as it was after the devastating fire of 1871.

Edwin P. Farley, chairman of the American Hawaiian Steamship Company, Trill lead a delegation of intercoastal shipping men to Washington this week to support the proposal for Federal regulation of intercoastal shipping before a subcommittee of the Senate Commerce Committee.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24, (AP). -- A special program for unemployment relief in New Orleans attracted 5,000 spectators to Jefferson Park today. The regular racing season at Jefferson Park ended yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 24. -- For the second successive year Roy Coffin and Neil Sullivan of the Germantown Cricket Club won the invitation Greenwich squash racquets doubles tournament today at the Greenwich Country Club.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Northwestern tonight had reached the halfway mark of its campaign, for a second straight Western Conference basketball title undefeated and in the lead.

GENEVA, Jan. 24. -- In an atmosphere of pessimism, the Council of the League of Nations will open its sixty-sixth session here tomorrow. It will meet while various economic, financial and political experts are warning the world that it is headed for even greater troubles and are demanding international action as the only means of salvation.

The intermediate report of Samuel Seabury as counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, which has been investigating the New York City Administration, is released for publication this morning. The document fills 176 pages and the addition of various exhibits, mostly dealing with the bank accounts of persons examined, brings the total to 198 pages.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Paul N. Cyr, claimant to Louisiana's governorship, rattled his sword tonight from his home in Jearnerette and said "a few funerals in this State would help out a lot."

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 24. -- The quarter-final round was reached in the New Jersey State squash tennis championship at the Short Hills Club today, with one casualty among the eight seeded players. In a third-round match. Pat Cohalan of the New York A.C. triumphed over Gavin Brackenridge of the Princeton Club, 15-8, 15-2.

DENVER, Jan. 24 (AP). -- After five days of captivity during which, he was kept bound and blindfolded in a mountain cabin, Benjamin P. Bower, kidnapped Denver bakery official, was released from an automobile in West Denver today.

Admitting that there have been superstitious prayers, just as there have been superstitious sciences, the Rev. Dr. George Arthur Butterick, preaching at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventythird Street, declared yesterday that prayer was nevertheless not an anachronism in the modern world.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 24 -- Shipment's of all grains last week were at heavier prices. Corn and wheat were unaltered, weak. Flaxseed, at 9.50 pesos, was firmer. Peso exchange was weak, due to export bills not being offered, thus handicapping remitters abroad, who were unable to obtain cover.

One work new to the programs of the week's series of concerts by the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra was presented yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, Bruno Walter conducting. This was the Schumann 'cello concerto in A minor, with Gregor Piatigorsky as soloist.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- The export surplus of 2,967 million marks reported this week for Germany's foreign trade in 1931 means an increase of the favorable trade balance, as compared with 1927, amounting to nearly 6 1/2 billion marks; 1927 having produced an import surplus of 3,500 million marks.

MADRID, Jan. 24. -- The Reds are going to make a final bid for power in the general strike called for tomorrow, and thus hope to counter the government's systematic arrests, which are paralyzing the revolutionary movement. They plan to "go the limit," but the government is taking all precautions to meet the situation.

The city manager form of municipal government, indicated by Samuel Seabury as counsel for the legislative investigation in his intermediate report as a possible corrective for evils discovered in New York City, has been adopted by 427 cities in the United States, Canada and the Irish Free State since 1908, and thirteen more have adopted and rejected it.
NEW YORK. Mrs. John Lewis Hay will give a luncheon at the Plaza Feb. 3 for Miss Elizabeth Heller, whose marriage to George D. Smith will take place on Feb. 12.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, Jan. 13. -- Construction work on the new Zeppelin LZ-129, which is to be the world's largest lighter-than-air craft, is now well under way in the plants of the Luftschiffbau and the affiliated Maybach Motor Works. The dirigible is being built for regular transatlantic service to the United States and will be the first airship to be equipped with powerful crude oil motors.
Under the caption, "The Need for Constructive Legislation," Mr. Seabury presents his conclusions on the city inquiry thus far, as follows:

Support of the disarmament movement was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. George Maychin Stockdale, pastor of St. James Methodist Church, Madison Avenue and 126th Street and the Rev. Dr. Sidney E. Goldstein of the Free Synagogue and the Jewish Institute of Religions.
BOMBAY, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Despite jail terms of unprecedented severity, Mahatma Gandhi's army of Nationalist rebels showed no sign of penitence tonight.

A theatrical producer, an actor, two playwrights and an inveterate first-night playgoer met on neutral ground before 460 guests at the "Broadway dinner" of the Town Hall Club last night and uttered what presumably were their innermost thoughts about their profession.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Suggestions for saving as much as $500,000,000 annually in Federal expenditures are made in a report by a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. Matthew S. Sloan, president of the New York Edison Company, is chairman of the committee.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The news that collections of income tax and surtax aggregated u65,000,000 in the first sixteen days of January strengthened confidence in the markets, even though this amount represents only about 27 per cent of the total due by the end of March.

Former Alderman Patrick S. Dowd, for several years the centre of Democratic political controversies in the Thirteenth Assembly District, was killed shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday morning when he stumbled over a low wall and fell ten feet, landing on his head, in the areaway in front of 512 West 134th Street.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Jan. 23 -- Rear Admiral F.C. Billard, commandant of the United States Coast Guard, admitted that in view of the constant efforts at "intimidation and insidious propaganda" he knows "of no arrangements that can be made that will prevent occasional attempts of bribery" of Coast Guardsmen, in a letter made public today by the Rev.

Despite the fact that Princeton's basketball team was idle last week, John Siebert, crack Tiger forward, retained his position as pace-setter among the individual scorers in the Eastern Intercollegiate League competition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An editorial article in THE TIMES of Dec. 31, 1931, makes reference to an erroneous inference that very probably would be drawn from certain published statements regarding our cancellation of French obligations in the debt-funding agreements.

ALBANY. Jan. 24 -- With Governor Roosevelt an avowed candidate for the nomination for President, the drive to win delegates for him at the Democratic National Convention at Chicago in June will gain added impetus.

Joe De Lorenzo, Jamaica centre, with six goals, captured the individual scoring honors among the players in the P.S.A.L. hockey tournament and John Pons, La Salle M.A. wing, moved into first place in the race for the laurels among the C.H.S.A.A. players as the result of games played last week.

The Republican Committee of One Hundred will give its annual card party in aid of its charitable activities tomorrow afternoon in the Japanese Room of the St. Regis. There will be tables for backgammon for those who do not care for bridge.

A delegation representing the 6,000 Staten Island commuters who use the municipal ferry boats between St. George and Manhattan will attend tomorrow's meeting of the Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate to protest against Commissioner Albert Goldman's recommendation that the city rescind commutation tickets on the ferry.

PAUL M. WARBURG will always be identified with the establishment of the present banking and currency system in the United States. His contribution to the vital reform of sixteen years ago, and to the successful inauguration of the Federal Reserve System, was far greater than most of his fellow-citizens have been aware.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- The foreign trade statement of France for the full year 1931 shows that imports, at 42,190 million francs, decreased 10,312 million from the preceding year, while exports, at 30,421 million, decreased 12,414 million. Import of foodstuffs increased 2,177 million, raw materials decreased 10,287 million and manufactures decreased 2,201 million.

What has for some time been heralded as a Yiddish "Street Scene" was mounted at the Folks Theatre Saturday night. It is called "In a Tenement House" and was written by H. Kalmanowich. Although, like its better-known prototype, this play begins and ends on a stoop and depends on a fund of sound observation to gloss over bare melodrama, it is not imitative and has the authenticity of its details to give it merit.

More than $25,000 was bequathed to charity by Mrs. Alice Cotton Crowell, member of an old Brooklyn family, who died Jan. 10. Her will was filed in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn yesterday disposing of an estate of more than $100,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The District of Columbia Court of Appeals today ruled that $37,000 advanced by the late Alexander Britton, former president of the Chevy Chase Club, to his royal son-in-law, Prince Alfred Hohenlohe Schillingfurst, of Austria, was not properly deductible from his 1921 income tax return as a bad debt.

One of the greatest social revolutions in history has resulted from the depression, evolving a new and finer ideal and conception of life, Joseph V. McKee, president of the Board of Aldermen, declared yesterday at a luncheon, of nearly 200 Y. M.C.A. executives at the Commodore Hotel, officially opening the annual appeal of the association for funds.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT HARDING, at Sea, Jan. 25 -- The knotty naval parity problems of Great Britain, the United States, Japan, France and Italy were explained today to Senator Claude A. Swanson and Dr. Mary E. Woolley, the American delegates to the disarmament conference, by the Navy Department's technical advisers accompanying them to Geneva.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is marvelous what one man or a set of men, may accomplish when a great need arises. It is likewise astonishing how an intelligent, progressive community will allow gross evils to flourish in its midst without taking concerted action for self-protection.

MONTREAL, Jan. 25 (Canadian Press) -- The unusual incident of an entire forward line being tied for point-making leadership is presented in the National Hockey League scoring and penalty records, issued tonight from the office of Frank Calder, president of the National Hockey League.

Unlike most other appeals for economy at Washington, the report prepared by a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States offers specific suggestions. It cites eight places where it believes expenses can be reduced substantially.

PASADENA, Cal., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Declaring that the basis of European-American civilization is "critically shaken," Dr. Albert E. Einstein touched tonight on what he deemed to be the causes of this condition.

Miss Lillian Wald, founder and head of the Henry Street Settlement and Visiting Nurse Service, who is internationally known for her humanitarian work in many fields of social service, was the guest of honor last night at the annual dinner of the Society of the Genesee at the Hotel Commodore.
GENEVA, Jan. 25 -- Sir Eric Drummond, Secretary General of the League of Nations, notified the League Council at a secret meeting today of his intention to resign his post early in 1933.

The gross income of the Port of New York Authority from tunnel and bridge operations in 1931 was $7,550,405, according to an annual financial statement issued yesterday. The large revenue from projects completed late in the year, notably the George Washington Bridge over the Hudson River, will cause the gross income for 1932 to exceed that of 1931 by about $4,649,595, it was estimated.

A systematic investigation of the electric-light rates of the New York Edison Company and affiliated companies serving this city is demanded in a brief filed with the Public Service Commission yesterday by the Washington Heights Taxpayers' Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The situation in El Salvador produced by the attempted revolution by Communists is still considered serious by the State Department, although re-

Several moves were made yesterday by the American Power Boat Association's Racing Commission to cut the cost of competition this year. When the commissioners met, in connection with the Motor Boat Show, they agreed that it would be advisable to start an economy wave, and to reduce the price of motors in some of the racing classes.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25 -- Spanish Play, last year winner of the Louisiana and Latonia Derbies, and second to Mate in the Arlington Classic, staged one of the hardest races of his career today to win by a head from the Greentree Stable's Surf Board in the Inaugural Handicap, opening-day feature at the Fair Grounds.
