ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- At a conference of Republican Assemblymen, strong sentiment developed for material cuts in the Governor's executive budget. The opinion was voiced that, with the cooperation of the Governor, a reduction of $25,000,000 or possibly more might be made.

The banking syndicate headed by J.P. Morgan Co., the National City Bank and the Chase National Bank placed at the city's disposal yesterday the proceeds of the $100,000,000 issue of special corporate stock notes and set up a revolving credit fund of $151,000,000 for the city's use to float tax anticipation paper.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 25 -- A festive spirit prevailed at the Hebrew University on Mount Scopus today when thirteen students, including one girl, received Master of Arts degrees at the first graduation exercises held since the university was established in 1925 by the late Earl of Balfour -- the world's only university where Hebrew is the language of instruction.

The newly organized women's advisory committee of the Sanitation Department agreed at its first meeting yesterday to ask the Mayor's Unemployment Committee to assign 200 "white collar" workers to make a sanitary survey of the city streets.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The remainder of the huge credit of the $250,000,000 which the Bank of England arranged in the United States and France and spent in a futile attempt to save the pound last August is to be repaid Mondey, without the intention of renewal or depletion of the Bank's gold reserves, it was announced tonight.

The first eight railroads to report earnings for December showed a net operating income of $3,500,000, against $6,776,000 in December, 1930, a drop of 48.3 per cent, and against $9,918,000 in December, 1929, a drop of 64.7 per cent. Their net operating income in November was about $4,199,000, a drop of 50.6 per cent from the $8,513,000 earned in November, 1930.

THE Ancient Mariner has a bitter grievance. He read last week that a vote was taken on the game that required the most skill on the part of the contestants and the clerk of the polls, with no election districts missing, tabulated the vote as follows:

Backed by private interests, two engineers have been working for months in developing a new principie of flight and behind locked doors in a loft at Broadway and 110th Street have constructed a flying machine which is to be tested at Floyd Bennett or Roosevelt Field within the next month, it became known yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Eugene Lentilhon, American resident of Paris, died after an operation here today. The funeral will be held tomorrow at the American Cathedral.

Andreas Wendel and Richard Wendel Sturm arrived in the Surrogates' Court here yesterday from Bremen to represent the Wendels whom John Gottlob Mathias Wendel left behind him in Germany three generations ago when he came to America to begin the accumulation of the $75,000,000 of New York real estate which was left to divinity schools, hospitals and charity when his granddaughter, Ella Virginia von Echtzel Wendel, died on March 12 of last year.
Formation of a committee to protect the interests of holders of $30,000,000 of 6 per cent convertible debentures of General Theatres Equipment, Inc., was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- General lack of interest characterized today's stock markets, and business was very quiet again. British Government funds were fractionally lower.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. James Noyes Wallace of Gulf Stream were hosts at a small dinner at their home this evening. Dr. and Mrs. Edmund LeRoy Dow entertained twelve persons with a dinner at their residence, and John B. Irwin gave an informal dinner at La Chaumiere.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 25 -- Problems of unemployment and rehabilitation of the coal mining industry are expected to dominate the discussion of about 1,100 coal miners, representing twenty States of the Union and Canada, at the constitutional convention of the United Mine Workers of America which opens here tomorrow.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 25 -- Angelo Paino, sewer contractor of Brooklyn, who was indicted and later cleared on a charge of attempted bribery after former Borough President Maurice Connolly had been tried on charges of conspiracy to defraud the city in connection with the sewer scandal in Queens County, paid $204,105.81 to the State Tax Commission today as his income tax for the years in which his concern had the sewer contracts for Queens County.

H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Ship-builders, was elected chairman of the executive board of the American Marine Standards Committee at its annual meeting yesterday. Captain R. D. Gatewood, formerly manager of the Shipping Board bureau of maintenance and repair, and A.V. Bullion of the Division of Simplified Practice of the Department of Commerce were re-elected vice chairman and secretary, respectively.

Frederick S. Fales, vice president of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, was elected yesterday president of the Standard Oil Company of New York, Inc., to succeed Charles F. Meyer, who will remain a director. Mr. Meyer also retired as director and chairman of the executive comnittee of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Plans of the Southern Pacific Company to acquire control of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway by purchase of its capital stock were approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission today, adding nearly 2,000 miles of main-line track between St. Louis and Northern Texas to the transcontinental Southern Pacific System.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 25 -- Remonetization of silver at a ratio of 16 to 1 compared with gold was asked by Senator Wheeler of Montana today in a speech on the floor, in which he said maintenance of the gold standard in the United, States has increased the debts of producers of raw materials and commodities "by at least one-third."

Bankers of the United States were asked last night by Ogden L. Mills, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, to check their widely adopted policy of liquidity, to halt their selling of securities and their calling of loans, and to embark in the contrary direction of credit expansion.

MADRID, Jan. 25 -- Communistic and anarchistic attempts to overthrow the republic today through a general strike were instigated and supported by Royalists, who were using the Reds as catspaws, according to the Ministry of the Interior.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Seven of the eleven railroad employes charged with negligence in the wreck that took sixty-eight lives near here three weeks ago were sentenced to prison for varying terms early today after a trial that lasted one week.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 25 -- Airplane travelers from El Salvador said today they had heard that revolutionaries in the rising there had executed twenty-six minor officials and sympathizers of the Provisional Government.

The unusual scene of a defendant insisting on pleading guilty to a first degree murder charge, bringing a mandatory death sentence, and his lawyer, assigned by the court, insisting the plea be recorded as not guilty took place in Judge Donnellan's Court of General Sessions yesterday at the arraignment of William J. Turner, 21 years old, in the killing of a West Fifty-seventh Street speakeasy owner last year in a hold-up.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Oliver Wendell Holmes's last judicial opinion was the basis of a Supreme Court ruling today upholding a sentence of death upon three Negroes.

HOUSTON, Texas, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Jesse H. Jones, appointed today by President Hoover to be one of the Democratic directors of the nation's $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will not be frightened by the job or the amount of money involved.

Miss Georgette K. McClellan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Robert McClellan of 755 Park Avenue, has selected Feb. 12 as the date for her marriage to Edward Bridge Austin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Edwards Austin of 1,125 Park Avenue and Bellport, L.I., formerly of Brooklyn. The ceremony will be performed at Sherry's by the Rev. E.J. Leary and will be followed by a reception.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A proposal to tax the profits of bootleggers and short-sellers in the securities market was made before the Ways and Means Committee today by Dr. Joseph J. Klein, associate professor of taxation of the College of the City of New York.
"East of Broadway," described as "a comedy of Jewish life in New York," will open tonight at the Belmont Theatre. James R. Waters and Alfred Corn will be featured in the cast.

Hugh Herndon Jr., who flew around the world and was detained in Japan with Clyde Pangborn because they flew over fortifications there, returned yesterday with Mrs. Herndon on the Holland-America liner Statendam from Nassau.
Six Rumanian Army officers, all aviators, arrived in New York yesterday on the S.S. American Shipper for the bobsleigh competition in the forthcoming Olympic Winter Games.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- President Samuel Insull announced, after a meeting of the Chicago Civic Opera Company's trustees today, that no contracts for next season would be made until a guaranty fund of $500,000 had been obtained.

Joseph M. Price, chairman of the trustees of the City Club, endorsed yesterday the proposal for a nonpartisan city administrator, proportional representation and general charter revision suggested in Samuel Seabury's intermediate report to the Hofstadter committee.

GENEVA, Jan. 25 -- At the "urgent" request of China, made at the opening of its routine meeting this morning, the Council of the league of Nations resumed consideration of the Sino-Japanese conflict this evening instead of tomorrow as planned.

Recent improvement in conditions in the textile trade brought yesterday a steady demand for contracts from mill sources on the Cotton Exchange, and prices closed 4 to 7 points higher than on Saturday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Six inches of snow having fallen during the past twenty-four hours and with the whirling flakes still descending in a way to gladden the whole village, ski teams took merrily to practice today for the Winter Olympics Feb. 4 to 13.

With one directorship yet to fill, President HOOVER is already assured of strong and capable management of the affairs of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. At his request, the board will elect Mr. EUGENE MEYER as Chairman and General DAWES as President.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Democratic politics here came to a focus today with Governor Roosevelt's declaration of his candidacy and his entrance into the North Dakota primary. This move, his supporters said, had strengthened his cause, and had the effect of weakening any "stop Roosevelt movement."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- Inclusion of a clear statement on the prohibition issue in both the Republican and Democratic party platforms was urged by Governor Ritchie of Maryland, aspirant for the Democratic Presidential nomination, in an address today before the Democratic Women's Luncheon Club.

Yesterday's markets continued to indicate little except absence of initiative; the day's unimportant movement of prices up or down suggesting the not unfamiliar pause, in Stock Exchange activities, which is apt to follow an emphatic general advance and the subsequent usual "profit-taking recession."

What prohibition, has done to temperance would be one way of summing up the story of Finland's experience as told in THE TIMES of last Sunday by the Finnish Minister in this country. At the beginning of the nineteenth century, says Mr. ASTROM, his countrymen were among the heaviest drinkers in the world.

A new issue of $7,500,000 Kansas Power and Light Company first and refunding mortgage 6 per cent bonds, Series C, due on Feb. 1, 1947, will be placed on the market today by a banking group headed by the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and including Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; Arthur Perry Co., Inc., and the N.W. Harris Company, Inc.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Gorilla Jones of Memphis succeeded Mickey Walker as middleweight champion of the world tonight by decisively defeating Oddone Piazza of Milan, Italy. He won by a technical knockout in the sixth round of a scheduled ten-round contest.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The discovery of the tombs of the Kings of Jericho by Professor John Garstang, director of the Marston archaeological expedition, has revealed that Hatasu was probably the name of Pharaoh's daughter who found the infant Moses in the bullrushes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The War Department today assigned seventy-three officers to the Army War College for the course which begins next September and continues for a year. The list by branches, giving present stations, follows:

Vaino Korhonen, one of the younger stars in the billiard field, overcame a lead of 119 to 93 to defeat the defending champion, J. Howard Shoemaker of the New York Athletic Club, 125 to 122, in twenty-six innings, in the opening match of the national amateur pocket billiard championship which began last night at the New York Elks Club.

Rolls-Royce Company of America, Inc., has cash, and liquid assets far in excess of current obligations and it is not only solvent, but financially unembarrassed, says a bill filed yes- terday by Kenneth M. Mackenzie, attorney, asking the Federal court to dismiss the petition for an equity receiver entered recently by Marks Hurewitz, a bondholder.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 25 (AP) -- A soiled and torn letter, which the State said was a confession to the slaying of Hedvig Samuelson and Agnes Anne Leroi, was introduced today in Winnie Ruth Judd's trial for murder.

Enzo Fiermonte, Italian middleweight, won the decision from Charley (Trader) Horn of Ridgewood, N.J., last night in the main ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena without adding any to his prestige.
The world's wrestling crown remains in the possession of Jim Londos today, but not because he threw his youthful challenger, Sam Stein, in Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Huey Long, former Governor of Louisiana, entered upon his duties as junior Senator from that State today, but before he was sworn in he displayed some of his eccentric qualities to newspaper men who visited him at his hotel, appearing in lavender pajamas and discussing personalities and policies in short and snappy phrases.

HONOLULU, Jan. 25 -- Kenneth B. Barnes, president of the Chamber of Commerce, announced that Eugene H. Beebe, a prominent attorney, had been retained to assist the City Attorney and County Attorney in the prosecution of the Massie assault case, and that Barry S. Ulrich had been retained to assist in the prosecution of the Kawahawai murder case.

The last Russian Ambassador to the United States, Dr. Boris A. Bakhmeteff, who represented the Kerensky regime of 1917, yesterday described the Soviet Government's five-year plan as a setback rather than a forward movement. He addressed the school of politics of the Women's National Republican Club and presented data to show that in the last thirty years before the World War Russia had been in a process of economic and political transformation.
Followin in full is the address delivered last evening by Ogden L. Mills, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, before the American Acceptance Council at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:

American publishers brought out more new books last year than in any previous year, but the increase over 1930 was largely in the field of miscellaneous publications, of which the general sale normally is small, while fiction showed a marked falling off and biography a lesser one, Publishers' Weekly reports in its annual summary number, out today.

Woman authors wrote seven of the ten best selling novels of 1931. The Publishers Weekly notes in its recording of books of the month's best seller list for the year, a list topped by Pearl S. Buck's "The Good Earth." A woman also heads the list of best selling non-fiction with "The Education of a Princess."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The grav- ity with which the United States Gov- ernment views the situation at Shanghai was indicated today when Secre- tary Stimson summoned Secretary of the Navy Adams and Admiral Pratt, Chief of Naval Operations, to his office for an hour's conference and then conferred with President Hoover.

Antonio Scotti, who is in his thirty-third season with the Metropolitan Opera, observed his sixty-fifth birthday yesterday by seeing newspaper men and photographers for three hours at his Hotel Vanderbilt apartment and by attending a dinner in his honor in the evening.
DENVER, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Fearful of another raid on the home of Benjamin P. Bower, bakery manager who was released yesterday by kidnappers, police tonight guarded the residence.

More rigid control of the many private hospitals and sanatoriums scattered throughout the city, in order to protect the public against needless operations and unscrupulous doctors, was urged last night by Dr. David J. Kaliski, newly elected president of the New York County Medical Society, in his inaugural address at the Academy of Medicine.

Deposits in the mutual savings banks of the country amounted on Jan. 1 to $10,030,014,385, a high record and a gain of $565,281,893 for 1931, according to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. Total assets of these banks also reached a record on the first of the year at $11,206,875,737, which left $1,123,253,973 of reserve to assure the safety of deposits.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Two offices of men claiming the Governorship were opened in Louisiana today, one officially in the Governor's mansion at Baton Rouge and the other in a dentist's room at Jeanerette.

Trading in the listed bond market yesterday was the slowest since Nov. 25, amounting to only $9,493,000. On Friday, the last full trading period, total sales of bonds on the Stock Exchange aggregated $12,350,500. Prices drifted irregularly lower, although not much lower on the average.

There is a certain surplusage in the report to the Legislature drawn up by Judge SEABURY. He was required to do it under the terms of the resolution authorizing the city investigation. By way of disguising their real purpose, Republicans in the Legislature directed an inquiry into the structure of our Municipal Government.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 25 (AP) -- In naming Harvey Couch of Arkansas a director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, President Hoover has chosen a man with about as much respect for red tape as has Charles G. Dawea, head of the new government agency.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 -- Scientists and newspaper representatives today witnessed a demonstration of a 42-centimeter-wave radio beam of sufficient power to be heard from a loudspeaker and, it was said, to penetrate the atmosphere and a distance of 30,000,000 miles beyond.

Three electric subsidiaries of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York have applied to the New York Public Service Commission for au- thority to issue $75,000,000 in 5 per cent bonds, or $25,000,000 for each company, of which $50,000,000 is to be sold to the public.

No one who is in a hurry need linger over the dramatic news this morning. "The House of Doom," which was put on at the Masque Forty-fifth Street Theatre last evening, is one of those childish pranks that shake one's confidence in the art of the drama.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Now that Governor Roosevelt has formally presented himself to the country as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, his friends and supporters are preparing to do everything within their power to induce Alfred E. Smith to come out in the open and make known his position with regard to the Presidency.

Supreme Court Justice Richard P. Lydon yesterda granted permission to David Finkle to sue Sheriff Thomas M. Farley on the letter's official bond for recovery of two judgments which Tinkle said were obtained by him. Finkle charged that the Sheriff levied on the property of the judgment-debtor in the case and, while the levy was still in force, permitted the latter to remove and conceal the property levied against.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 25 -- The Viceroy of India, the Earl of Willingdon, opened the Legislative Assembly today with a speech defending his suppression of the All-India National Congress movement, and at the same time expressing pride that, toward the end of his public life, he was "leading India to her promised position as an absolutely equal partner with the other Dominions under the crown."

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Troops with machine guns were rushed to Dartmoor prison late tonight upon a warning from the civil authorities that friends of the 300 convicts who mutinied yesterday were planning to attack from the outside.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 -- A broken electrical timing device late today halted until tomorrow Gar Wood's assault upon the world's speed-boat record after he had attained a top speed of 111.14 miles an hour on a one-way run.

Feeling secure in the belief that a couple of signers a day will keep trouble away, Secretary Jim Tierney announced yesterday that two more members of the New York Giants had come into the fold. These were Francis Healey, second-string catcher, and Gilbert English, recruit infielder.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 25 -- Joseph J. Mutnick, counsel for three of the four local theatres whose sixty-five employes were arrested yesterday when they opened for Sunday performances in defiance of the State "blue law" of 1798, declared war to the finish today on the advocates of the ancient code.

In the Senate at Last. No longer will newspapers, to save space and avoid a title as long as a cat's tail, be required to refer as plain HUEY P. LONG to the man who was for many months Governor-Senator-elect HUEY P. LONG of Louisiana.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 -- T. Philip Perkins of New York, former British amateur champion, led a field of 121 linksmen to win the qualifying medal with 36, 40 -- 76 in the Miami Beach championship over the La Gorce Golf Club course today.
HAVANA, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Monday racing was resumed at Oriental Park today, with the major honors going to Mrs. Emil Denemark's Hogan's Dance, winner of the mile-and-one-sixteenth feature.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- After opening irregular, trading rallied on the Paris Bourse today and a majority of the list joined in the recovery. At the opening Rio Tinto Copper sustained a sharp decline, but when the general tone began to improve this stock staged a partial recovery.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- The first of the Summer collections at the fashion salons point to the straight silhou- ette and slightly shorter day skirts with their fullness very low or no fullness at all. Higher waistlines are indicated, rising to real Empire for evening.

CHICAGO, Tuesday, Jan. 26 -- Edward A. Stinson, 38 years old, dean of American aviation pilots and chief civilian instructor of army pilots during the World War, died here early today from injuries received last evening when a plane which he was testing in the dusk struck a tall flagpole in Jackson Park and crashed to the ground.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Jan. 20 shows decreases for the week of $235,000,000 in loans and investments, $167,000,000 in net demand deposits, $25,000,000 in time deposits, $12,000,000 in government deposits and $12,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 25 -- General Wu Te-chen, Mayor of Shanghai, will not be permitted to wait a week or longer before replying to the Japanese demands concerning the cessation of anti-Japanese activities.

CHICAGO, Tuesday, Jan. 26 -- After a day-and-night debate in which the "final reply" of the railroads on the 10 per cent wage cut proposal was bitterly denounced, ten of the twenty-one standard railway unions early today had reached a decision and the others, continuing in session, were expected to report to a meeting of the leaders scheduled for noon.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 25 -- Arthur A. Stearns, 73 years old, attorney and president of the Cleveland Public Library Board, died last night after an illness of several months with heart disease.

OAXACA CITY, Mexico, Jan. 23 -- Buried atop a sprawling mountain in tropical Mexico which overlooks the earthquake-scarred city of Oaxaca lies the clue to the obliterated Mexican civilizations that science and history have sought to uncover for a century.

Estimated automobile production declined last week, although the nor- mal seasonal movement is a continuous rise until the first week of May. In consequence, the adjusted index of automobile production shows a further decline to 42.1 from 46.9 for the preceding week and from 64.7 for the corresponding week of 1931.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 25 -- Mrs. H.D. Sterrett of Hutchinson, Kan., former women's Western champion, won the medal in the qualifying round of the Miami-Biltmore championship over the course of the Miami-Biltmore Country Club today with a card of 41, 48 -- 89.

Chicago's world's fair in 1933 is to have a section devoted to industrial art, according to a recent decision by the directors, who have appointed Ely Jacques Kahn, architect, to take charge of the new department.

The committee of stockholders seeking a change in the management of the Standard Oil Company of Kansas has sent out a reply to the recent letter issued by A.S. Hopkins, president, defending the management. Mr. Hopkins's letter, the committee says, "fails to give you a fair picture of what has happened to your company during the past ten years."

Support of the five-day week and the belief that its general adoption in the future is certain was expressed yesterday by representatives of twenty-five leading industries at a conference with Frances Perkins, State Industrial Commissioner, in the State Building.

Money market was quiet and firm all day. On the Stock Exchange 2 1/2 per cent continued for call loans, while 2 1/4 prevailed in the Street trading. Federal funds were 2 1/4 @ 2 1/2. Money was in good supply, but demand was light. Time money was unchanged at 3 1/2 @ 3 3/4 per cent, with business small.

The possibility of a general strike of dress workers in the metropolitan area within the next few weeks was indicated yesterday in the report of Benjamin Schlesinger, president of the Internitional Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, to the members of the executive board attending the quarterly meeting of the organization, held in the Hotel Taft.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 25 -- Henry C. Fownes 2d of Pittsburgh, member of the Oakmont Country Club, today won the qualifying medal in the twenty-eighth annual St. Valentine's golf tournament for amateurs, turning in a card of 76 at the Pinehurst Country Club.

HAVANA, Jan, 25 -- The failure of the Javanese producers to submit definite figures concerning crop restriction today, in conformity with a reported agreement made at a meeting of the International Sugar Conference in Paris early this month, has raised the hopes of Cuban sugar producers that the present crop here will be limited only to the 3,500,000 tons stipulated in the international agreement.

The National Motor Boat Show, now in its twenty-seventh annual session at the Grand Central Palace, again attracted a considerable number of visitors yesterday to view the 120-odd power craft and sailboats on display.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Walton Goelet are arriving on the He de France and will be at the Ritz-Carlton.

POONA, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Mahatma Gandhi is to have his reward for proving a model prisoner. Once a week one person, a relative or nonpolitical associate, may visit him. The prison superintendent and jailer will be present to see nothing political is discussed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Serious consideration is being given by the subcommittee in charge of the War Department appropriation bill in the House to a plan to abandon the citizens' military training camps for at least a year, thereby saving the government $2,603,624.

An analysis of the budget and the administration's fiscal policy at an early public hearing of the Hofstadter committee will be Samuel Seabury's answer to the charge that his investigation has impaired the city's credit, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Exports of finished manufactured products in 1931 were valued at $1,119,556,000 and were 47.1 per cent of the total, as compared with 1930 shipments valued at $1,808,089,000, comprising 50.2 per cent of all exports.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 -- George D. Widener's Panetian made it two in a row at Hialeah Park today when tie captured the feature Alhambra Claiming Handicap by half a length in a driving finish with French Lass, 6-year-old mare which races for H. C. Hatch.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Substantial increases in employment in the automobile industry in December, slight increases in several other major industries and seasonal gains in some major cities are reported by the employment service of the Department of Labor in the current Industrial Employment Information Bulletin.

Contributions from school teachers amounting to 5 per cent of their salaries are necessary to meet the needs of school children and others aided by the School Relief Fund, Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday in an appeal for additional contributions at a meeting of district superintendents, none of whom dissented from Dr. O'Shea's opinion.

BERLIN, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The German Government draws special satisfaction from the acknowledgment of her private creditors in the new prolongation agreement that the borrowed moneys were carefully soliciten and spent, Dr. Karl Ritter of the Foreign Office told the press tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The names of two Democrats from the Southwest, Harvey C. Couch of Arkansas and Jesse H. Jones of Texas, to become directors of the new $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation, were sent to the Senate today by President Hoover.

A new electrical-recording instrument, so sensitive that it detects errors of one-millionth of an inch, and could measure the thickness of an ordinary sheet of paper if it were cut edgewise into a thousand parts, was described yesterday before the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at the opening of its five-day annual Winter convention.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was the smallest in Volume since Sept. 1 of last year. The day's turnover approximated 800,000 shares, against 1,562,000 shares on Friday, the last full five-hour day of the week before. The extreme dullness was due largely to the timidity of speculators at the beginning of a week which may witness important developments.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The appointment of Howard G.E. Smith of Buffalo as a member of the State Civil Service Commission was transmitted tonight to the Senate by Governor Roosevelt. It was referred to the Finance Committee and confirmation is not expected before next week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President and Mrs. Hoover entertained at dinner tonight for Agnace Jan Paderewski, who arrived today and is their guest at the White House. Official, diplomatic and resident society, headed by Mrs. Hoover, attended later in the evening a concert given in Constitution Hall by the Polish pianist and statesman for the benefit of the Unemployment Fund of the American Red Cross.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- The new and heavier golf ball is making so many successful assaults on par during the Winter tournaments in the West and the South that Albert R. Gates, administrator of the Professional Golfers' Association of America, is hopeful that it ultimately will tee recognized as the international sphere.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The House Naval Affairs Committee will begin hearings tomorrow on the McClintic resolution to investigate the construction, performance and cost of the navy's giant airship Akron, with representatives of labor engaged in its construction as the first witnesses.

Defying the special efforts of the police to put an end to the steadily growing series of jewel robberies in homes of the wealthy in the Park Avenue district, a sneak thief stole five valuable pieces of jewelry yesterday from the home of Mrs. Francis K. Stevens, member of a socially prominent family, at 61 East Ninety-second Street, two doors from Park Avenue.

Stock prices moved yesterday in a narrow range in unusually dull trading on the New York Curb Exchange. Closing prices revealed that several key issues were unchanged, while the remainder showed about an equal division of fractional gains and losses.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 -- Setting a record for the revised Palm Beach Golf Club course, Albert R. Hakes of Dunkirk, N.Y., returned a card of 34, 31 -- 65 to win the medal in the qualifying round of the annual Lakeworth, tournament today. Hakes went out in one stroke under par and on the incoming nine was three shots under regulation figures.
Supreme Court Justice James C. Cropsey unanimously was re-elected president of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club at the forty-sixth annual meeting held at the clubhouse in Brooklyn last night.

VATICAN CITY, Jan. 25 -- The stability of the Vatican Library was further weakened today when the cracks which appeared Saturday widened and spread over the entire face of the building. They now extend from ground to roof, indicating that the ancient walls have entirely rotted and stand in urgent need of radical strengthening measures.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Prime Minister MacDonald today defended his Cabinet's agreement to disagree on tariffs, an expedient which is finding increasing support from all but the Labor and high tariff sections of British opinion.

Earl Carroll, it was announced yesterday, has begun work on three productions, the first of which, a musical show, will open out of town in February and come here late in March. The authorship and entertainers were not disclosed by Mr. Carroll's office.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 25 -- New Jersey went on record tonight calling upon Congress to cal la Constitutional Convention to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment and return to the States control of liquor.

Four additional contributions received by THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Funds over the week-end totaled $40. The 1931 fund now amounts to $295,700.28, within $50,090.37 of the sum received the previous year. The number of individual contributors is now 11,350, as against 11,742 in 1930.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 -- Abnormal cold early today in Southern California was reported to have done much damage to the citrus fruit crop.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Nine governments, Great Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Belgium, Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands and Sweden, have protested to the State Department against the bill of Senator King of Utah to deport alien seamen who desert in American ports.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest the special dispatch in the Jan. 21 issue of THE TIMES which estimates that there are 1,000,000 rural idle in fifty-two cities throughout the nation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- The wheat trade has generally adopted a policy of watchful waiting, and trade in the pit of the Board of Trade here was light most of today, although sufficient commission-house buying developed in the July to advance the new crop future 3/8 cent compared with the May, the two deliveries selling at the same price according to the blackboard.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- The Japanese threats against Shanghai are prominently featured in the Soviet press, but without comment, and it is significant that, although the news of the Japanese "ultimatum" to the Chinese authorities at Shanghai was published here yesterday, there was no allusion to the subect in an editorial in the newspaper Izvestia on the Far Eastern situation.
RENO, Nev., Jan. 25 -- Mrs. Edith Gould Wainwright, daughter of the late George Gould, received a divorce today from Carroll Livingston Wainwright, and a few hours later was married to Hector McNeal.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- A pre- diction that healthful financial days will return sooner than is now thought possible was made by Gilbert T. Hodges of New York City, president of the Advertising Federa- tion of America, at the annual dinner of the Advertising Club of Syracuse tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The House Committee on Naval Affairs, two members not voting, endorsed the Vinson $616,000,000 naval replacement bill today. At the same time the committee, taking into consideration the "abnormal economic situation," decided to postpone reporting the bill to the House until the success or failure of the Geneva Disarmament Conference is definitely indicated.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Augie Kieckhefer of Chicago was tumbled from the lead in the world's three-cushion billiard championship tourney tonight, losing to Jay Bozeman of Vallejo, Cal., 50 to 48, in fifty-four bitterly fought innings.
MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- Russia claims to have solved her rubber problem, and within ten years this country expects to be one of the great rubber producers of the world.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Governor Roosevelt called upon Sheriff Thomas M. Farley today to file within the ensuing week a reply to the charges made against him by Samuel Seabury, counsel for the Hofstadter Committee.

The drive to rid the city's news stands of obscene and objectionable magazines was taken before Police Commissioner Mulrooney yesterday by members of the recently organized Committee for Civic Decency, and it was indicated after the conference that action will be taken soon against certain publications.

Young women in society, members of the debutante and junior dance committees for the Century Ball, which will be given on Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria, held a meeting yesterday morning at the hotel to complete arrangements. The ball, which will be for the benefit of the Leake and Watts Orphan House, will be in celebration of the institution's 100th anniversary.

The Mercantile Library, founded in 1820, will continue its slow progress northward to a new home at 17 East Forty-seventh Street, opposite the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Purchase of a site for an eight-story structure at that address was announced yesterday.

The board of governors of the League of New York Theatres will hold a meeting on Tuesday or Wednesday of next week to discuss the recent appearance of the league's delegation in Washington before the Ways and Means Committee of the House in opposition to Secretary Mellon's proposed tax on theatre admissions.

After an inaugural address that called for reorganization of the State Government in the interests of thrift and efficiency, Governor MOORE of New Jersey finds himself confronted by a Republican Senate which seems to have scant sympathy with his reform policies.

The late ELWOOD HENDRICK in defining the chemists of the future could have found in the present an excellent precedent in the person and achievement of Dr. CHARLES H. HERTY, who has just been awarded the medal of the American Institute of Chemists for noteworthy and outstanding service to the science and profession of chemistry.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Jan. 25 -- A great increase in geologic precision in the locating of oil wells, and establishment of a new basis for correlating the study of the ages and origins of rock strata throughout the world were reported today to have resulted from studies of fossilized fish teeth made by geologists of the University of Missouri.

COLOGNE, Jan. 25 -- Disarmament, cancellation of reparations and war debts and an understanding between France and Germany in accord with Great Britain were declared pivotal points for "obviating the greatest perils threatening the peace of the world and overcoming the most formidable obstacles to the world's economic recovery" in a resolution adopted by the executive bureau of the Socialist International session here today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 26. -- Among the several small dinners of this evening was that with which Captain and Mrs. R. Amcotts Wilson entertained at their villa in Vita Serena, inviting ten guests in compliment to their house guest, Mrs. Julien Alien of New York.

Fire early this morning swept through the seven stories of the old Union League clubhouse, a famous Fifth Avenue landmark at the northeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, in the Fifth Avenue shopping district and directly across the street from the Wendel home, another landmark.

Mate and Equipoise, rivals in the Spring of last year for 3-year-old honors, until the latter went wrong on the morning of the Kentucky Derby; have been nominated for the forthcoming running of the Dixie Handicap, which will be renewed on May 7 at Pimlico, it became known, yesterday.

The proposal to save $2,603,624 by abandoning the citizens' military training camps shows ignorance of their value. There is no resemblance between them and compulsory training. Attendance is voluntary, and 38,546 young men presented themselves for instruction last year.

An urgent appeal for financial aid in "the war against hunger and starvation" among school children was made yesterday by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, before 800 district superintendents, principals and other directors of school departments assembled in the Washington Irving High School.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 26. -- At the opening session of the State Agricultural Convention in the Assembly Chamber at the State House today, Governor Moore offered every possible aid in the solution of the farm problems and urged the farmers to cooperate.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Baseball, coal mining, transportation, the motion picture industry, ranching and hotels were numbered among the enterprises developed by William Wrigley.

The most varied delegation of Winter sports stars to reach New York to date disembarked yesterday from the Ile de France and the Majestic as nineteen, luminaries from six different countries arrived for the Olympic games at Lake Placid.

OMAHA, Jan. 26. -- Herbert Hoover is the issue in the approaching political campaign and his re-election is more to be desired than any other one thing in the campaign, Mrs. Dolly Gann, sister of Vice President Curtis, declared here today at a State-wide meeting of Republicans sponsored by the Omaha Women's Republican Club.
PITTSBURGH, Pa., Jan. 26. -- Youth, of today is living extremely too fast, according to Dr. Philip H. Kruescher, Chicago surgeon, who is here for the American College of Surgeons Convention.

The immediate need of $150,000 by the Museum of Natural History to avert serious curtailment of its program, with the possible necessity of laying off a number of its employes, was set forth yesterday in a letter which Cleveland E. Dodge, chairman of the Executive Committee, sent to the museum's members.

An organized campaign to rid the building industry in New York of dishonest and irresponsible promoters and builders, said to have taken millions of dollars from, investors, bankers and workers, was started yesterday with the presentation to the District Attorney's office of data on the first of a large number of cases for possible criminal prosecution.

It was the fancy, open wide to argument, of Arthur William Row, whose "Afternoon Theatre" has been quiescent these several seasons, to make another bid for the special matinee trade yesterday afternoon with Oscar Wilde's bejeweled comedy. "Lady Windermere's Fan."

After maintaining an advance for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange met increased selling pressure in the last hour and closed at the bottom with losses of 2 to 6 points. A steady demand from trade sources in most of the session absorbed the limited supply of contracts, but hedging wiped out the improvement.

Stocks continued to mark time yesterday in advance of the dividend meeting of the United States Steel Corporation, and Wall Street was content to let the market drift. The total volume on the Stock Exchange was uncommonly small -- 760,000 shares, compared with 798,000 on the day before.

ALBANY, N. T., Jan. 26. -- The Senate voted today to confirm Governor Roosevelt's appointees to the State Power Authority, but only after a sharp debate in which Frank P. Walsh, the chairman, was bitterly assailed and all but three Republicans went on record as against him.

Nothing of much importance to the hilarity of nations has been accomplished by the production of "East of Broadway," which was acted at the Belmont last evening. It is a pointless little comedy of Jewish life, written by T. Reginald Arkell and Charles Wagenheim.
Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Barret gave the second in a series of dinners with dancing last night in the Regency Rooms of the Carlyle. Their guests were:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- A proposal to discard the administration's plans for various "nuisance" taxes and substitute consumptive taxes on some basic necessities was receiving serious consideration today by Democratic leaders interested in revenue legislation.

EDMONTON, Alta., Jan. 26 (Canadian Press). -- Return of Inspector A. N. Eames's party to Aklavik marks the third failure to capture Albert Johnson, since Constables A.W. King and R.G. McDowell attempted to arrest the trapper Dec. 31. The policemen were acting on complaints of Indians that Johnson had been seen in the act of hanging traps on trees.

A marked increase in the number of animals cared for by the New York Women's League for Animals because of the depression was shown yesterday in the report for 1931, which was read at the home of Mrs. Orme Wilson, 3 East Sixty-fourth Street, where the annual meeting was held.

About sixty restaurant and hotel operators banded together yesterday to fight for modification of the Volstead act so as to permit light wine and beer, all of them complaining that their business was being destroyed by speakeasy eating places.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 26 (AP). -- Two persons were killed early today by terrorists who "planted" time bombs in a dance restaurant within sight of the State Capitol buildings. The victims were Henry E. Hungerford, 73 years old, and his wife, Elizabeth, 70, who occupied an apartment over the cabaret, known as the Italian Villa.

Newton D. Baker issued a statement yesterday, just before he sailed for a. brief vacation in Mexico City, in which he declared that the League of Nations was not a political issue, that it should not be opposed or advocated in the political platform of either major party, and that if he had the power he would not take the United States into the League unless an enlightened majority of the people favored the step.
NEW YORK. The Baron Ashfield of London has returned from Canada and is at the Plaza to remain until he sails for England on Friday night.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 26. -- T. Philip Perkins of New York, medalist and former holder of the British amateur title, led the field today in the first-round matches of the Miami Beach championship over the course of the La Gorce Golf Club, defeating H.B. Money of Wilmington, Del., by 3 and 2.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 26. -- Favorites had easy victories today in the quarter-final round of match play in the St. Valentine's golf tournament for amateurs, with Henry C. Fownes 2d of Pittsburgh, the medalist, eliminating Francis T. Keating of New York by 6 and 5.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (AP). -- R. A. Fairbirn's Glastonbury, 4-year-old son of Sir Gallahad III and Bignonia, won the $1,200 Delgado Purse, feature of the racing program at the Fair Grounds today.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The riot at Dartmoor over sugarless porridge recalls the remark of Professor Kirchwey's that he believes almost every prison riot is due at bottom to the food.

Five positions in the city that were stricken out of the 1932 budget by Budget Director Charles L. Kohler were restored yesterday by the Board of Aldermen, which approved special revenue bond appropriations totaling $96,560.50, despite the efforts of the Board of Estimate to economize in City Government.

Blame for the mounting cost of government in the United States rests almost entirely upon State and local governments rather than upon the Federal Administration, Ogden L. Mills, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, declared last night at a dinner of the New York Credit Men's Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP). -- The Stock Exchange committee has repealed as from today its emergency regulation prohibiting the transaction of new continuation business -- that is, puttine off of payment from one account to the next. This restriction was imposed when Great Britain suspended the gold standard.

Roy Chapman Andrews told the New York Wells College Club yesterday that its members could be sure that any modern explorer who brough back tales of great hardships and miraculous escapes from death was either a "rotten" explorer or could not have had a serious object in view, since modern equipment for exploration minimizes the possibilities of such adventures.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Bat Battalino, featherweight champion, scheduled to meet Freddie Miller, Cincinnati, in a ten-round bout tomorrow, today said he had no intention of losing his National Boxing Association title on the scales. If he is dethroned it will be in the ring.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 26. -- Great satisfaction was expressed in the Arab Greek Orthodox community here today as the result of a judgment rendered in the High Court this morning by Chief Justice MacDonald and Justice Baker granting a stay in the election of the Orthodox Patriarch, which had been scheduled for Thursday.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Some State officials were pictured as living in "palatial" homes provided by the State, with their wives on the State payrolls as "housekeepers," in the report of the reclassification civil service committee filed today with the Legislature.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 26 (Canadian Press). -- The last half of the present cereal year ending on July 31 next, will be a period of rapidly diminishing stocks of wheat, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics predicted today, as import requirements must be filled from existing stocks in exporting countries.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Jan. 26. -- A University of Alabama freshman, who was interested in what the "hereafter" held for him and who could "wait no longer to find out," was in a critical condition at a hospital here today after having shot himself near the heart.

An opportunity to compare the relative merits of European and American hockey will be afforded metropolitan followers of the sport tonight when the Polish Olympic sextet clashes with the Crescent AthleticHamilton Club at Madison Square Garden.

Net earnings of the General Motors Corporation in 1931 amounted to $96,858,701, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $2.01 a share on the common stock, according to a preliminary statement issued yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president. This compares with net earnings of $153,766,247, or $3.32 a share in 1930.

The salary the Brooklyn club is to pay Hack Wilson, the former slugging champion of the Chicago Cubs, who came to the Robins Saturday by way of the St. Louis Cardinals, is to be determined next week, it was revealed yesterday. The stocky outfielder will arrive in New York on Sunday.

Buyer Total Above Year Ago. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a drop in number as compared with the figures for the preceding week. This total, however, was greater than for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

HONOLULU, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Another step toward prosecution of Mrs. Granville Fortesque and her co-defendants was taken yesterday when the Honolulu Chamber of Commerce retained Barry S. Ulrich prominent attorney, as special prosecutor to assist James F. Gilliland, City and County Attorney.

Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee, it became known yesterday, in about to enter upon a new phase of the city-wide investigation with the borough governments and the city budget as the essential features.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The application of the American Diamond Lines, Inc., a Delaware corporation, for loans aggregating $724,142 from the Construction Loan Fund was approved today by the Shipping Board. The loan is to be used in aid of the reconditioning, remodeling and improving of the vessels Saco, Sac City, Tomalva, City of Alton, Coahoma County and Sacandaga.

Miss Marion Lloyd, women's national fencing champion, made a clean sweep in the annual tourney at the Salle d'Armes Vince last night and won the gold medal for first place. Miss Lloyd is a leading candidate for the U.S. Olympic team, and is a veteran of the 1928 team which went to Amsterdam.

Fritz Reiner, as guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, directed performances of Schumann's "Overture, Scherzo and Finale," Brahms's Second Serenade, Smetana's symphonic poem, "The Moldau," and Richard Strauss's "also sprach Zarathustra," last night in Carnegie Hall.

Edward Robinson, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for more than twenty years, left an estate appraised at $585,327 after the payment of expenses and debts, according to the transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday. The gross estate was valued at $604,788.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- Viscount Cecil of Chelwood will not be a member of the British delegation to the disarmament conference at Geneva. The omission of his name from the list is far more significant and interesting than the inclusion of those of any of the British delegates who will attend.

Nathan L. (Nigger Nate) Raymond, 38 years old, who won $219,000, which he never collected, from Arnold Rothstein in a stud poker game five weeks before Rothstein was shot and killed in November, 1928, was sentenced to serve from, five to ten years in prison yesterday by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions.

TOKYO, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Thirteen additional Japanese warships were ordered by the Navy Office today to proceed immediately to Shanghai from the Sasebo naval base. Eleven Japanese warships previously were reported lined up in the Whangpo River, opposite the Chinese city, awaiting the outcome of the Japanese demand that Chinese officials suppress the anti-Japanese societies alleged to be supporting the boycott against Japanese goods.

Despite the depression and the prevailing rates of exchange, the various European countries will send their best athletes to participate in this year's Olympic Games in the United States, according to Count Henri Baillet-Latour of Brussels, president of the International Olympic Committee.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Economy has become a watch-word with the spokesmen for the two parties represented on Capitol Hill. Where only a few days ago the Republican leaders appeared well satisfied with a policy contemplating only perfunctory cuts in the Governor's budget, which might have saved $2,000,000, there is talk now of a major operation.

PARIS, Jan. 26. -- A deadlock between Great Britain and France regarding the next step to be taken in dealing with the reparations situation appears to have been created by yesterday's rejection by Premier Laval and Finance Minister Flandin of the British proposal for a year's continuance of the Hoover moratorium.

The difficulties that have hampered financing of the city's unemployment relief program were finally ironed out yesterday when the Board of Estimate took steps to provide $10,500,000, assuring continuance of relief work until the middle of May or June 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Governor Roosevelt has asked the support of New York Democratic members of Congress to prevent a proposed reduction in Federal appropriations for National Guard armory drills and field service. Representatives O'Connor and Black, making public the Governor's letter today, promised to fight against cutting appropriations for the training sections of the Guard.

The most recent figures for the trade between China and Japan show a radical decrease for the year 1931 as a result of the anti-Japanese boycott. The total export of goods to China from Japan for 1931 amounted to 258,000,000 yen, providing an excess of exports over imports of 21,000,000 yen.

New York State came to Wall Street yesterday for a loan of $25,000,000 until May 1 and paid at the annual rate of 4% per cent. This was the first time since 1915 that the State, confronted with decreasing income, had to borrow in anticipation of taxes and revenues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.-- Many features of the Glass banking bill are objectionable to treasury and Federal Reserve officials and to some members of Congress familiar with banking laws, with, the result, it was declared today, that the bill will have a difficult time in Congress and will have to be radically remodeled before it is approved.

Brooklyn Prep's basketball team went into first place in the Brooklyn division C.H.S.A.A. race by upsetting St. James High, defending Brooklyn division and city C.H. S.A.A. champion, 23 to 22, yesterday in the St. James gymnasium. The defeat was the second C.H.S. A.A. setback for St. James and jolted the champions out of the lead in the divisional race.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That a moratorium in itself having no solution is quite evident. But the underlying idea of a moratorium is merely to afford time for the tangled state of things to become coordinated, for the political confusion to clarify itself.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 26. -- Taking only twelve putts during the match, Miss Beatrice Gottlieb of New York defeated Mrs. Samuel R. Freeth of Hempstead, L.I., by 10 and 8 in the first round of the women's Miami-Biltmore championship today.

VATICAN CITY, Jan. 26. -- Renewed alarm over the stability of the Vatican Library caused engineers to make another examination of the building today to determine the causes of the recent collapse. Their conclusions, confirming a report to Pope Pius more than a month ago, attribute the disaster to the hurried manner in which the edifice was erected and its great age.

Taking the upper hand in the fourteenth inning with his high run of 48, Robert Cole, former national amateur champion, last night defeated Edwin Apfelbaum of the Newark Elks, 125 to 79, in thirty-seven innings, in the second night's play of the national amateur pocket billiard championship at the New York Elks Club.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 26 (AP). -- Winnie Ruth Judd accompanied the opening of her insanity-self-defense plea by a startling outburst against Sheriff J.R. McFadden today, after the State had advanced jealousy as the motive for the confessed slaying of her two women friends.

Lily Pons, coloratura soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, receives a salary from the Metropolitan of $445 a week and has earned $130,000 by her singing here and elsewhere since March 8, 1930, according to her testimony yesterday at an examination by the attorney for Maria Gay and her husband, Giovanni Zenatello, who are suing her for $315,000 for alleged breach of her contract with them as her former managers.

Ignace Jan Paderewski revealed here yesterday how the economic condition of the world appears to a great musician. He has long evaded interviews lest he be involved in the politics which he left by his dramatic resignation twelve years ago as Premier of Poland, to return to his piano.

Mrs. Charlotte M. Werner Paris, a typist employed for the last five years in the criminal division of the United States Attorney's office, and Thomas J.Todarelli, Assistant United States Attorney, who has prosecuted hundreds of criminal cases, are under Federal inquiry as a result of financial transactions each is said to have had with persons accused of mulcting the public of $50,000 in the last year through use of the mails.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Mass production of legislation by States and Congress set a record in 1931, according to an analytical report to the Industrial Council of the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday at the Carlton Hotel by M.J. Hickey, secretary of the council.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Newton D. Baker's admirable statement before sailing for Mexico today, opposing making the question of membership in the League of Nations a partisan political issue in the coming campaign, makes it permissible to refer to other comments by him upon the same subject in recent correspondence.

A new issue of $5,652,000 city of Rochester (N.Y.) bonds, due on Feb. 1, 1934 to 1962, the largest piece of municipal financing this year except New York City and New York State issues, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate headed by the Guaranty Company of New York.

Victor LeGloahec, a French chemical engineer, arrived here yesterday on the French liner Ile de France en route to San Diego, Cal., where he and two business associates plan to erect a factory to supply algin to American paper, textile, cement and leather concerns.

One of the noted paintings from the collection of the late Robert H. Benson of London has entered an American museum. It is the fifteenth century Florentine picture by Plero di Cosimo, "Hylas and the Nymphs," which has just been purchased by the trustees of the Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford, Conn., through the generosity of Frank C. Sumner.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 26. -- Arthur W. (Ducky) Yates of Rochester, N.Y., defending titleholder, scored an impressive victory in the first round of match play in the annual Lake Worth tournament today.
An invalid for the last seven years, Dennis Keating, 69 years old, was burned to death yesterday afternoon when his home at 330 Bement Avenue, West New Brighton, S.I., was partly destroyed by fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- President Hoover's economic rehabilitation program does not constitute inflation, as seemingly Is the belief in some foreign countries, it was said today at the White House, with the explanation that the interpretation placed on the President's policies abroad had been so erroneous as to warrant official correction.

HONOLULU, Jan. 26. -- Mrs. Granville Fortescue, Lieut. Thomas H. Massie, U. S. N., her son-in-law, and two naval enlisted men, Edward J. Lord and Albert O. Jones, were indicted here today for second-degree murder.

Recent concentration of public interest on the Reconstruction Finance bill has no doubt diverted attention from other pending proposals. Among these is the bill for amendment of the Federal Reserve law, sponsored by Senator GLASS and officially described by the short title of the Banking Act of 1932.

Three representatives of the Fencers Club were among the ten stars to qualify at the New York A.C. last night to represent the New York district in the national junior foils championship, which will be staged at the Winged Foot clubhouse on Feb. 26.
MADRID, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Spain's revolutionary strikes apparently dwindled today, but disorders continued, with three persons reported killed and three wounded.

Lieutenant John W. Kenna, former Supervisor of Patrol in the Third Division, and his mother, Mrs. Anna Kenna, brought suit for $500,000 damages in Supreme Court yesterday against Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee, and three of his aides, charging that in the conduct of the investigation of the magistrates' courts the defendants conspired to slander the good name of Lieutenant Kenna and his mother.

Irregularly lower prices, for domestic corporation, bonds, a brisk recovery in United States Government issues and a few notable rallies in foreign loans characterized dealings yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Trading was somewhat more active than on the previous day, the turnover being $10,869,000, compared with 59,493,000.

The architects of the Empire State Building, Richard H. Shreve, William F. Lamb and Arthur Loomis Harmon, last night received the medal of honor for 1931 from the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects at the chapter's annual dinner in the Architectural League Building, 115 East Fortieth Street.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 26. -- After extended conferences with executives of State agencies throughout the day, Governor A. Harry Moore announced tonight that three agencies had acceded to his demand that all public work be held up until the Legislature acts on his economy program for the return of $16,500,000 to the taxpayers.

At the annual meeting of the Regatta Circuit Riders Club, held yesterday in connection with the Motor Boat Show, it was suggested that this year's race for outboards on the Hudson River from Albany to New York be held on Sunday, May 15, instead of Saturday, May 14, as planned.

ATLANTA, Jan. 25. -- Dr. Dumas Malone, editor of the Dictionary of American Biography, tonight called upon universities of the future to "invest heavily in good government," in an address before members of the Atlanta Chapter of the Emory University Alumni Association.

The present electric light rates in the Washington Heights area are an improvement over previous rates, the New York Edison Company and affiliated companies declared through their counsel, William L. Ransom, in a brief filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission in the complaint brought by the Washington Heights Taxpayers Association against a schedule of rates approved last June.

Successful photographing for the first time of the tracks of the proton of hydrogen, the nucleus of the hydrogen atom, is revealed in a preliminary report in The Physical Review, published by the American Physical Society.

GENEVA, Jan. 26. -- A warrant was issued at Lucerne today for the arrest of John Wesley De Kay, 58 years old, who was born at Ashburn, Va., on a charge of swindling the Stieler Bank of Lucerne, obtaining 160,000 Swiss francs [about $32,000].

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 26. -- A photoplay in which the heroine, falsely convicted of murder, narrowly escaped the gallows, may save Mrs. Olga Ziegler, 38 years old, of Park Ridge, who was being tried for the murder last Sept. 15 of her husband, Otto, a silk manufacturer, from further efforts by the prosecution to send her to the electric chair.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT HARDING, AT SEA, Jan. 26. -- The two official American, delegates to the disarmament conference conferred today and disagreed with ten unofficial women delegates, representing various peace societies, about what the policy and activities of the United States should be at Geneva.
BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 26 (AP). -- Formal demand to vacate the Governor's ofice was made on Alvin O. King today by Dr. Paul N. Cyr, who declares he is legally Governor of Louisiana.

The shattered aspirations of veteran metropolitan virtuosi as well as the dreams of untried musical tyros were described yesterday by such authorities as Dr. Walter Damrosch, Dr. John Erskine and W.J. Henderson, music critic for The Sun, at a musical forum at the home of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, 2 East Ninety-first Street.

Recent developments in methods of protection of electrical power lines against damage from lightning and the comparative merits of steam and electricity as auxiliary equipment in power stations were the subjects of two symposiums yesterday at the annual "Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,161,500 barreis, compared with 2,193,450 in the previous week, a decrease of 31,950 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production east of California averaged 1,652,900 barrels daily, against 1,684,450, a decline of 31,550.
TOKYO, Jan. 26. -- Officials here state that Japan will avoid interference with the jurisdiction of the International Settlement of Shanghai or any action causing inconvenience to foreigners.

Bachelor of Arts degrees will be conferred upon 394 students this morning at mid-term graduation exercises in Hunter College Chapel. Eighty-six of the graduating class are from Manhattan, 134 from the Bronx, 143 from Brooklyn, twentyfive from Long Island, and six from Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Rolling along in the shadow of the Great Wall in China's "wild West," the Haardt-Citroen trans-Asia expedition is penetrating further into China proper after crossing the Himalayas and traversing the deserts of Eastern Turkestan.

Three men walked west on Broome Street shortly after 5 P. M. yesterday, arguing hotly. They crossed Elizabeth Street and approached the corner of Mott Street, only two short blocks from Police Headquarters. Half way down the block, in full view of passers-by, two of them tried to push the third into an automobile parked on the north side of the street.

The money market was listless, as nothing new in the way of increased business or rate changes developed to distinguish the session from its predecessors. While funds appeared in good supply, there was a very light demand, and the quotation for call loans on the Stock Exchange and in the counter market holding at 2 1/2 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- Play in the national racquets doubles championship tournament will start Thursday at the Racquet Club. Eight teams are entered, with four from New York and the same number representing Philadelphia. For the first time in many years there will be no teams from Boston or Chicago.

A fourth call for payment of 10 per cent of the subscriptions to the notes of the National Credit Corporation is expected soon in view of the disclosure by Ogden L. Mills, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, speaking before the American Acceptance Council on Monday night, that the corporation's loans exceed by a small margin the 30 per cent of its subscribed funds thus far called for payment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Contributions to the Democrats' $1,500,000 victory fund were urged by Jouett Shouse, national executive chairman, in a radio speech here tonight, broadcast over the Columbia network. The fund is designed to pay the deficit remaining from the 1928 campaign, the expenses of the national committee since that time and to provide a $500,000 fund for beginning the campaign this year.

GENEVA, Jan. 26. -- The committee of the League of Nations Council which is dealing with Liberia, acting on the republic's request for aid in maintaining the abolition of slavery, overcame Lberia's desire today to postpone the consideration of the experts' report on how to give this aid.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- With, sixteen unions definitely pledged to make an agreement with the railway presidents and with five "on the fence," indications appeared today that by tomorrow or Thursday the issue facing the conferees would be settled.

In Shanghai the Japanese demand and secure suppression of a Chinese newspaper preaching anti-Japanese doctrine, and in Peiping insist on the same treatment for an English-language newspaper guilty of the same offense. In Nanking the Nationalist Minister of Foreign Affairs, EUGENE CHEN, resigns and accuses the former President, CHIANG KAI-SHEK, of selling out to the Japanese.
STORRS, Conn., Jan. 26. -- Springfield College's basketball team defeated the Connecticut Aggies tonight, 52 to 32. Springfield led at half time by 33 to 12.

MR. DANIEL J. FERRIS was just about to buckle on his skates and head for Lake Placid when he was halted and subjected to a running fire of questions. Or better still, he was subjected to a fire of running questions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Should the affairs of the Federal Farm Board be liquidated at this time, the government would stand to lose $250,000,000 of the $500,000,000 appropriated as the revolving fund, James C. Stone, chairman of the board, told the National Cooperative Council, central organ of farm cooperative agencies, at a meeting today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- United action by business interests of the city and State against the movement to restrict security and commodity exchange trading in this country was urged in resolutions adopted by more than 300 members of the Philadelphia Commercial Exchange today.

SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 26 (AP) . -- Salvador's allegedly communistic rising has taken an uncounted number of lives, the government indicated today, but a British request for the landing of British marines brought reassurances of public safety.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (AP). -- The nonaggression pacts which are being negotiated by Soviet Russia with other countries are a means of achieving peace, Maxim Litvinoff, Commissar for Foreign Affairs, declared today in a statement issued just before his departure for the Geneva disarmament conference.

Tonnage of ships constructed throughout the world last year showed a decrease from the total of the preceding year, according to a report published yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping. The decline is reported the first in five years. The shipyards of the world completed 1,617,115 tons, a loss of 1,272,357 from the total of 2,889,472 built during 1930.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The granting of the Barco oil concession to the Gulf Oil Company and the Carib Development Corporation, the former controlled by the Mellon interests, in 1931, coincident with the granting of a National City Company credit to Colombia, drew sharp criticism today from Senator Capper, Republican, of Kansas, in an address on political developments over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26 (AP). -- The police said this afternoon that they had traced the kidnapped baby of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Aguilar to a point 100 miles southeast of Puebla and hoped to recover her soon.

SOUTH ORANGE. N.J., Jan. 26. -- The Montclair High basketball team, undefeated in three years, registered its twenty-sixth consecutive victory today, defeating Columbia High, 48 to 20. Columbia led. 13 to 12, at half time.

Spotting their rivals a two-goal lead early in the first period, New York's courageous Americans rallied brilliantly to turn back the world's champion Canadiens of Montreal, 3 to 2, in a stirring National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

A 2-year-old boy, playing in front of his home at 889 Belmont Avenue, Brooklyn, was wounded in the right side of the chest yesterday while detectives of the gun squad were pursuing Martin (Buggsey) Goldstein, an East New York gangster, and two companions.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26. --The initialing of a non-aggression pact with Poland was announced without comment today In the Soviet press, which also published an interview with Maxim Litvinoff, Commissar for Foreign Affairs, on the non-aggression treaties. It is now possible to make a brief review of the subject to elucidate the attitude of the Soviet Government.

In announcing yesterday a reduction in the quarterly dividend rate on common stock from $1 to 50 cents, the United States Steel Corporation made public its income report for the fourth quarter of 1931 showing a deficit of $15,033,414 after all dividend requirements and a total deficit of $49,236,881 for the full year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- Alfred S. Austrain, for twenty-five years a leader of the Chicago bar, died early today of a gastric ailment. He had been in failing health since he underwent an operation at Passavant Hospital in September. 1930. His age was 61.

Dr. Claymor H. Magna Jr., super- intendent of the Kings County Hospital, considered one of the most brilliant young hospital executives in the city, has been missing since 3 P. M. Monday, it was disclosed last night when a special police alarm spurred officials of the hospital and Police Departments into starting an inten- sive search for him.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 26. -- The conviction is deepening in foreign and Chinese circles here that the Japanese will take drastic action, regardless of the tenor of the reply of the Chinese authorities to their demands.

A strike fund of $450,000 is to be raised by 30,000 members of the New York Cloakmakers' Union, it was reported yesterday by David Dubinsky, secretary-treasurer of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, to the members of the executive board at the quarterly meeting now in session at the Hotel Taft.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26. -- To Fred Morrison, professional from Culver City, Cal., goes the honor of taking the top place among the money golfers at the end of the Far Western Winter tournament season.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 26. -- Josephus Daniels, Secretary of the Navy under Woodrow Wilson, asserted here today that "the nomination of a progressive figure, such as Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York, will insure a Democratic victory beyond all question."

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- There still is trouble in Dartmoor prison. An attempt this afternoon to exercise the convicts in batches of fourteen was not altogether successful and some had to be returned immediately to their cells.

C. Franklin Edminster, head of the architectural department of Pratt Institute for the last forty-three years and the oldest member of the faculty in point of service, died on Monday at his Summer home in Sayville, L. I. Mr. Edminster, who was in his sixty-seventh year, suffered a compound fracture of the pelvic bone in a motorcar accident near Bayville, L.I., last August.

Complaints against two burlesque theatres, the Centred, 1,567 Broadway, and the Republic, 209 West Forty-second Street, for giving Sunday performances were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein in West Side Court. Six employes who had received summonses were discharged.

New Drivers in City Cabs. People who use taxicabs frequently must have noticed that the drivers are often men of a type different from that of a year or so ago. There are now many who are courteous to their fares, helping women with bundles, saying "Thank you" for tips and driving with the traffic lights instead of deliberately getting blocked at every possible corner.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Arthur Thurnblad of Chicago, the defending champion, went into a tie with Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia for first place in the world's three-cushion billiard tournament tonight by defeating Tiff Denton. Thurnblad, scoring his fourth victory in five starts, beat the Kansas City player by 50 to 32 in fifty-one innings.

MADRID, Jan. 26. -- Several hundred Jesuits at Loyola College near San Sebastian, almost all Spaniards by birth, were busy taking leave of their relatives today before definitely establishing themselves abroad. They will go to Tournai, Belgium.

Policyholders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company will receive this year dividends aggregating $102,400,764, an increase of $8,000,000 over a year ago and the largest annual declaration ever made by a life insurance company, passing the $100,000,000 mark for the first time in history, it was announced yesterday by Frederick H. Ecker, president.
BERLIN, Jan. 26 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of Jan. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- The wheat trade is inclined to the bear side of the market as it becomes more familiar with the disparity between prices in this country and elsewhere, and today it commented freely on the wide differences that exist. New low levels since the crop was harvested were made in the Buenos Aires market today, March sellingbelow 40 cents for the first time, and closing 1/2 cent lower at 40 3/8 cents.

The twelfth annual track and field games of the Newark A.C. will be staged at the Newark Armory tonight with the national interscholastic championship meet held in conjunction with the open A.A.U. events. Ray Conger of the Illinois A.C., now a teacher at Carleton College in Minnesota, will make his indoor debut as will Ralph Sickel of the Kansas City A.C., former Big Six sprint champion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Newton D.
