Baker's statement that he did not favor a League of Nations plank in the Democratic national platform and that it would be a great mistake to make this a partisan issue was interpreted here today as indicating that he was at least a receptive candidate for the Democratic nomination.

Following an Investigation lasting six weeks, during which more than fifty witnesses were questioned privately, State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced yesterday he would conduct a public inquiry into the business methods and operations of the laundry industry in Greater New York.

The chances of rescue of the crew of the British submarine M-2, sunk in 102 feet of water off the south coast of England are much greater, due to recent inventions, than they would have been a decade ago.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 26 (AP). -- A petition for the appointment of receivers for the American Equities Company, a holding company of New York, was filed today in the United States District Court by Emil Mautner of Essex County, N.J., owner of 1,500 shares of the company's capital stock.

MANILA, Jan. 26. -- The action of the independent group of Filipinos, including Emilio Aguinaldo, in sending a message endorsing the move of the present mission to reach a compromise basis, and the subsequent letter by Manuel Quezon praising their position, urging that they join the present independent drive, is interpreted by The Tribune, leading Pilipino daily, as indicating the likelihood of a political coalition in the Philippines to end the long-standing feud.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26. -- Mrs. H. De True's Arras, the 4-year-old Campfire colt from Embroidery, won his fourth victory in six Florida starts when he captured the Leap Year Handicap at Hialeah Park today. Arras won by a neck in a driving finish from My Dandy with Royal Ruffin a length and a half away in third place.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Governor Roosevelt, speaking: tonight at a dinner given to American Legion men in the Legislature by tha State Division of the Legion, told of his plea to Congress members to oppose budget cuts which "may handicap the National Guard."

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- The British Cabinet, unhampered by the old rule that it must be unanimous on legislative programs, finished today details of the tariff bill to be presented to Parliament next week for enactment into law. Its early passage by Commons is a foregone conclusion.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 (AP). -- J.E. Smallman's Bess Cloi, a 4-year-old bay filly by Cloister-Bess Welch, easily accounted for the fifth race, the feature of the Oriental Park program devoted exclusively to claiming platers today.

Perhaps awaiting the Steel Corporation's statement, which was not given out until after the market's close, business in stocks fell yesterday to the smallest full-day figure of the year to date and the lowest since the beginning of last September. Indeed, except for Sept. 1 and half a dozen of the August dog-days, this was lighter trading than in any fivehour day of 1931.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Winter Olympic practice was in full swing today for the first time since Jan. 2.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- For the first time during the current fiscal year the treasury deficit on Saturday passed the one and a half billion dollar mark.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- A service "to thank God for imagination and' laughter" will be held in Liverpool Cathedral tomorrow in memory of Lewis Carroll, the author of "Alice in Wonderland," and Edward Lear, author of the "Nonsense Books" and reputed inventor of the limerick.

No outstanding changes in business conditions characterized the opening month of this year, according to the January report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. The monthly summary, made public yesterday, reports general commercial activity as on a par with December levels.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 26. -- J. D. Mead, member of a well known pioneer family of Lansing, apparently in a fit of insanity, entered the Capital National Bank just before closing time today, opened fire with a pistol and wounded five persons, one fatally Then, struck three times by a guard's bullets, he killed himself.

Railroads in different regions issued yesterday preliminary income accounts for 1931, all showing the effect in earnings on shares of the reduced traffic in that year. Among the roads reporting were the New Haven, the Illinois Central, the Norfolk Western, the Frisco and the Virginian.

There was a mixed trend in commodity prices yesterday. In the cash division, losses were registered in the grains, lard, cotton, butter and zinc, the last two named establishing new lows for the year. Rubber and tin were higher. In futures, coffee, cocoa and silk declined, while sugar, rubber and hides improved.

Mayor WALKER took Mr. DELANEY with him to his recent conference with the bankers. Mr. DELANEY is not only chairman of the Board of Transportation but author of the much-discussed plan for financing two-thirds of the cost of the new subways out of the proceeds of shortterm loans.

The British submarine M-2 was one of four submarine monitors authorized under a 1916 war emergency program. These vessels formerly were designated as the K-type, and the M-2 was once the K-19, which was launched at the Vickers shipyard In October, 1918.
SRINIGAR, Jan. 26 (AP). -- The Maharajah of Kashmir, once known as the mysterious "Mr. A." of a blackmail case, was again threatened tonight with the loss of his throne.

PARIS, Jan. 26. -- Germany, France's old enemy, is getting higher quotas than the United States on Imports permitted by France, and also is being allowed to send products to France on the account of reparations in kind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- A wider inquiry into the construction of the navy's dirigible Akron was ordered today by the House Naval Committee after a hearing at which Admiral William A. Moffett, chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics, had declared she is "the best airship in the world."

The second in the series of the Yorkville dances in aid of the Yorkville Community Association took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton and drew a throng. Joe Moss conducted a Meyer Davis orchestra for dancing.

The eight-year controversy between Bishop William T. Manning and the Rev. William Norman Guthrie over the ritualistic dances and pantomines which the latter insisted on including in the services at St. Mark'sin the Bouwerie, of which he is rector, has come to an amicable understanding, at least temporarily, it was learned last night.

Senator MOSES, in an address to New York Republicans, dug up a Yankee phrase as a sure guide for America's foreign policy today. "There was once a man in Maine "who got rich by minding his own "business." Excellent. But what was his own business? Neither Maine nor the rest of New England stuck to narrow confines.

Fewer than thirteen States would vote dry in a referendum, on prohibition, Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, declared yesterday, answering the recent statement of a dry leader that the prohibition forces controlled more than the number of States necessary to keep the Eighteenth Amendment in the Constitution.

PARIS, Jan. 26. -- Although there was only scattering trading today, the Bourse maintained its favorable tone throughout practically the whole of the session. Some selling toward the close did not greatly affect the gains made earlier in the day.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Licenses of four radio amateurs in Brooklyn were revoked today by the Radio Commission for infractions of its rules and one other Brooklyn amateur was warned.
Yesterday's session of the National Motor Boat Show at the Grand Central Palace was dedicated especially to yachtsmen. Today will be "naval day" and tomorrow "regatta day."

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Administration proposals for amendment to the socalled banking board bill to prevent its control by bankers were set forth today at a hearing before the Assembly Banking Committee by Lieut. Gov. Lehman.

The nineteenth annual exhibition of the Allied A lists of America opened with a reception last evening in the galleries of the Fine Arts Building. It contains 360 pictures and twenty-one pieces of sculpture. The following prizes and awards in the department of painting were announced yesterday:

ALBANT, Jan. 26. -- The possibility of an extraordinary session of the Legislature next Autumn to devise a further program of unemployment relief for another hard Winter, was put forward today by Governor Roosevelt.

In his statement yesterday, before embarking for a holiday cruise, Mr. NEWTON D. BAKER clarified his attitude with respect to the question whether and when the United States should join the League of Nations. If the step had been taken when President WILSON urged it, or even several years thereafter, he would have considered it wise and constructive.

The first official list of the jewelry taken by the three thieves who held up Mr. and Mrs. Harry Glemby and three servants in their apartment at 22 East Sixty-seventh Street last Thursday was given out yesterday by the police.

Sixty gentlemen of the old school met last night at the Manhattan Club to play dominos against bogey and a sprinkling of Supreme Court justices. It was the beginning of the annual tournament for the President's Cup, and a player has to win two legs in order to gain permanent possession.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city.

A jury that had deliberated twentysix hours and fifteen minutes returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree yesterday afternoon against Leon Blechersky, 35 years old, who was tried under the alias of George Harris, for killing Patrolman Patrick Mitchell at Amsterdam Avenue and 126th Street June 20, 1930, while Blechersky was trying to escape from the scene of a $7 hold-up in a commandeered taxicab.
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 27. -- The big British submarine plane carrier M-2, with four officers and fifty enlisted men aboard, made a dive yesterday morning from which it failed to rise.

For nearly twenty years ALLEN TREADWAY has been the Representative in Congress of those choice bits of Western Massachusetts that make up the First District. He knows the political ropes, if anybody does. He was educated in the Legislature. He was president of the State Senate, that mile-stone on the road to political promotion.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Rebels have succeeded in seizing four towns in the Republic of El Salvador and were attacking two others, dispatches from San Salvador said tonight.
BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- Claude N. Holwill, Commissioner of Maritime Customs at Amoy, China, died there on Friday of pneumonia after a brief illness. His age was 49.

Shares of a new general-management investment trust which, if all its stock is sold at current prices, will have assets of about $77,500,000, will be offered today by Calvin Bullock. The trust will be known as the Bullock Fund, Ltd. Incorporated in Maryland, it has an initial authorized capital of 5,000,000 shares, all one class and all voting.

It every community In the country would adopt the work plan now operating in Rochester, N. Y., about $2,000,000,000 would be placed in circulation, it was declared yesterday by L. M. Todd, Rochester manufacturer and one of the originators of the plan, and would aid in ending the depression.

Facing boldly the problem of economic rehabilitation, Australia has overcome financial difficulties and, to balance the national budget, has successfully converted an unfavorable into a favorable trade balance under an emergency tariff act, David M. Dow, official secretary for Australia in the United States, said yesterday before a gathering of the British Luncheon Club here in celebration of Australia Day.
PARIS, Jan. 26. -- Very considerable importance is attached in France to the treaty of non-aggression initialed in Moscow last night between Soviet Russia and Poland.

The Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation and its subsidiaries on the Pacific Coast effected an aggregate reduction in total obligations, consisting of notes payable and commitments, of $24,525,442 in the year ended on Dec. 31, according to the annual report sent to stockholders yesterday.
BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- Claude N. Holwill, Commissioner of Maritime Customs at Amoy, China, died there on Friday of pneumonia after a brief illness. His age was 49.

Shares of a new general-management investment trust which, if all its stock is sold at current prices, will have assets of about $77,500,000, will be offered today by Calvin Bullock. The trust will be known as the Bullock Fund, Ltd. Incorporated in Maryland, it has an initial authorized capital of 5,000,000 shares, all one class and all voting.

It every community In the country would adopt the work plan now operating in Rochester, N. Y., about $2,000,000,000 would be placed in circulation, it was declared yesterday by L. M. Todd, Rochester manufacturer and one of the originators of the plan, and would aid in ending the depression.

Piqued at the suggestion that 10 per cent of his salary be placed in the city's "conscience fund," Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens said yesterday that neither he nor his aides would make the contribution they promised about ten days ago.
PARIS, Jan. 26. -- Very considerable importance is attached in France to the treaty of non-aggression initialed in Moscow last night between Soviet Russia and Poland.

The Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation and its subsidiaries on the Pacific Coast effected an aggregate reduction in total obligations, consisting of notes payable and commitments, of $24,525,442 in the year ended on Dec. 31, according to the annual report sent to stockholders yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Special Prosecutor George P. Losche began an investigation today of the circumstances which led to a mistrial in the prosecution of Mrs. Olga Ziegler of Park Ridge for the murder of her husband.

K. Horinouchi, Japan Consul General in New York, speaking yesterday at a luncheon of the executive committee of the Japan Society at the India House, Hanover Square, declared that the American and Japanese relationship of the past has been the most important alloy in constructing the strong edifice of peace and progress on the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Charging that two former inspectors on the construction of the airship Akron had been discharged for calling attention to inferior materials used, E.C. Davidson, secretary and treasurer of the International Association of Machinists, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today that it appeared that the Navy Department had "broken faith with him" and revealed their identity to the Goodyear Zeppelin Corporation.

Steel Towers in Westchester. Steel has been highly honored of late. There are architects who think of it as not only useful but, on occasion, ornamental. No widespread protest greeted the tentative decision of the Port Authority to leave the piers of the new bridge over the Hudson naked.

With the issuance of invitations to forty-two member colleges to compete in its eleventh annual indoor track and field games, the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. announced yesterday that it would move the meet from the 102d Engineers Armory to the 258th Field Artillery Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, on March 5.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Declaring that all other agencies had failed to cope with the unemployment situation. William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, urged the Federal Government today to come to the relief of the unemployed, who, he said, numbered about 8,300,000 on Jan. 1.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 27 -- Fist fights and general disorder temporarily broke up the convention of the United Mine "Workers of America late this afternoon.

The request of public school authorities for 5 per cent salary contributions from teachers to aid on "the war against hunger and starvation" among school children met opposition yesterday from the Teachers' Union and the Kindergarten-6B Teachers' Association.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- At the annual meetings of stockholders here today, J. Irving Fowler of this place was elected to succeed the late Louis M. Brown as director of the Glens Falls Insurance Company, the Glens Falls Indemnity Company, the Commerce Insurance Company, the Commerce Casualty Company and the Glens Falls Investing Corporation.

The agreement under which the fifty-four banks and banking houses which floated the recent $100,000,000 issue of special city corporate stock notes are to finance a $151,000,000 revolving credit fund to handle city revenue bills will take care of this type of indebtedness up to April 30, 1933, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Atlantic Refining Company, one of the five American oil companies originally interested in the vast international oil development in the Kingdom of Iraq, has sold its interest to the other members of the United States group, which now are the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, the Socony-Vacuum Corporation and the Gulf Oil Corporation.

By a party vote in the Legislature, the Hofstadter committee is to proceed for another year with its investigation of New York's City Government. While in some respects the inquiry has not produced what political-minded Republicans expected of it, the results thus far have confirmed the belief that Tammany officials and those in the allied borough machines make a practice of selling favors for cash.

Obscene books falsely called realism have been flowing from the presses for the past ten years, Thomas Dixon, co-author of "The Inside Story of the Harding Tragedy," which he wrote with former Attorney General Harry M. Daugherty, said last night at the monthly meeting of the Booksellers' League at the Brevoort Hotel.

VIENNA, Jan. 27 -- The Austrian political situation, tense since Saturday, reached a sudden denouement this afternoon when Chancellor Karl Buresch called on President Wilhelm Miklas and handed him the resignation of the entire Cabinet. The President, after formally requesting Dr. Buresch to continue to conduct affairs, entrusted him with the task of forming a new Ministry.

Plans for the erection of a 47-story commercial building at Thirty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue on the site occupied until a year ago by the Union League Club were abandoned two months ago, it was disclosed yesterday, while firemen were still pouring water into the smoldering old clubhouse which was severely damaged by fire early yesterday morning.

The Board of Transportation surrendered to the borough presidents of Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday, at a meeting of the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund, new city street areas valued at about $10,000,000. The land was acquired by the Board of Transportation in condemnation as part of the right of way for construction of the new city subway system.

BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- The prospects that President von Hindenburg will accept an extension of his term of office as a non-partisan candidate were brighter today as a result of negotiations between political leaders and the heads of civic and industrial organizations, which are now being mobilized to give the old Field Marshal's renomination a wider popular appeal.

The appointment of Howard G. Cann as head football coach at New York University was announced yesterday by Professor Philip O. Badger, chairman of the university's board of athletic control. Cann also was named director of physical education with the rank of assistant professor.

It must be highly flattering to the movies to be blamed for so many events -- even for the mutiny in Dartmoor prison. Some people have such a prejudice against them that they would lay a volcanic eruption at their door if they had just seen one on the screen.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Search for the missing British submarine M-2 was being made in the wrong place, nearly six miles from where it disappeared, Captain Howard of the steamer Tynesider told the Gravelines correspondent of The Daily Mail today.

Westchester County residents will get lower electric light rates and have assurance of an adequate power supply at all times by the projected hightension transmission line which the Niagara Hudson Power Company proposes to build through the county, witnesses for the power company testified yesterday during the third day of hearings before the Public Service Commission in the State Building, 80 Centre Street.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- There is growing sympathy here with Japan in the Far Eastern situation, an increasing belief that China with virtual anarchy instead of effective government and with her armies dissolving into bandits and its bandits suddenly turning into armies, has becoms the pest nation of the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Apparently unperturbed by plans of the Democratic leaders to sidetrack the prohibition issue until relief legislation is out of the way, anti-prohibitionists of the House moved today to perfect the program upon which they will demand a roll-call vote before this session ends.

Twenty-four members of the Columbia class of 1892 gathered last eight at the Columbia Faculty Club, 117th Street and Morningside Drive, for their seventy-ninth semiannual reunion and dinner. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, spoke of the days of forty years ago and of his own class of 1882, while deans of colleges joined with the alumni in recalling the time when Columbia College was at Fortyninth Street and Madison Avenue.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 27 -- Mgr. Pascual Diaz, Archbishop of Mexico, issued a statement this morning declaring that Mgr. Francisco Orozcoy Jimenez, Archbishop of the State of Jalisco, who was mysteriously spirited from the city of Guadalajara several days ago, had been deported.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Firmness of British Government funds was the outstanding feature of the Stock Exchange today, these securities being helped by encouraging revenue returns. The conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan rose to L76 and the war loan to L99 5-16.

The Tikytt Psalter, a treasure of early English art, penned and illuminated, about 1310, brought $61,000 last night at the opening session of the auction of the library of the Marquess of Lothian, at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

AURORA, Ill., Jan. 27 -- This city today ended its five-day business holiday with a celebration in which several thousand sightseers from nearly all of its 50,000 citizens and near-by cities participated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Newton D. Baker's statement that adhesion to the League of Nations should not be a political issue in this year's Presidential campaign was approved today by Democratic Senators. Belief grew that Mr. Baker, by his declaration that he would not favor our entrance into the League unless a majority of the people favored it, had set up a rod in case the Presidential lightning might strike him.

The disbanding of the Society of the Friends of Music two months ago because of lack of financial support resulted yesterday in the filing in Supreme Court of a suit for $21,500 against the society, Winslow, Lanier Co., and sixty-three individual members of the society.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- William Francis Hopkinson, great-grandson of Francis Hopkinson, signer of the Declaration of Independence, and member of a family linked with important events in the city's history, died of heart disease today in a private hospital in West Philadelphia.

Although much more active than on the day before, the stock market continued yesterday to show the effects of the repression from which it has suffered for nearly a week, or since the United States Steel meeting became a subject of absorbing in- terest.

Commander Edward Ellsberg, who supervised the raising of the sunken United States submarines S-4 and S-51, expressed the opinion last night that every one aboard the sunken British submarine M-2 is dead.

Temporary suspension of registration for help in the seventy-nine stations of the Home Relief Bureau, effective at once, was announced by Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare, last night, when the registration, reached a total of more than 75,000 applicants.

An amendment to the treasury regulations governing the deposit of public moneys, which liberalizes the provisions concerning classes of collateral security eligible to be tendered as security against such deposits, has been put into effect, according to an announcement by Secretary of the Treasury Mellon, transmitted to banks in this district by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

To celebrate his one-hundredth birthday, Louis Maurer, believed to be America's oldest living artist, is going to have a one-man show. Mr. Maurer is the last surviving artist of the firm of Currier Ives, printmakers to the American people. The lithographs of horses that this firm made from his paintings will form the basis of his coming exhibition.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 27 -- The Most Rev. John Gregory Mlirray, recently named as successor to the late Archbishop Austin Dowling, was installed as Archbishop of the St. Paul Diocese in ceremonies held today in the St. Paul Cathedral.

Public interest in the new models of cruisers, runabouts, sailboats and marine engines on display at the National Motor Boat Show in Grand Central Palace continued unabated yesterday. During the day and evening large numbers of visitors thronged the aisles between the exhibits, thousands crossing the gangplanks for more detailed inspection of the craft on exhibition.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Jan. 27 -- Ruth Hoyt Knowles, star of vaudeville a generation back, has been sued for divorce by her midget husband, Howard A. Knowles, former stage performer and more recently wealthy real estate owner of this section.

How soon will Senator LONG set at Washington the pace that brought him fame, fortune and excitement in Louisiana? In speaking to the reporters he described himself as a minnow in his new environment, whatever title he might have to be regarded as a kingfish in his native State.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 27 -- The Vermont Democratic State Committee, in session here today, was practically unanimous in voting to endorse the candidacy of Governor Roosevelt of New York for the Democratic nomination for President.

Newton D. Baker's declaration that the League of Nations is not a political issue and that it should have no part in the coming Presidential campaign, a statement generally conceded to have removed the chief obstacle to his eligibility for the Democratic Presidential nomination, met yesterday with wide acclaim.

BOMBAY, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Two dozen important commercial organizations in India agreed today to suspend all business for a week in protest against further work by the Round Table Conference committees without Mahatma Gandhi's participation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What is one to do with passes, identification cards and the like, when printers and engravers persist in producing them in the old size and the new wallets are made to fit the new, small-sized currency?

A plan of reorganization for the Fisk Rubber Company, involving the exchange of preferred and common stock for the $7,870,000 of first sinking-fund gold 8 per cent bonds, due in 1941, and the $8,199,500 of 5 1/2 per cent gold notes, was announced last night.

A campaign to enlist the support of insurance companies for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, on the ground that the companies are sustaining a serious loss traceable to prohibition, has been started in New York, it became,known yesterday.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Lawrenceville School overwhelmed the St. Paul's School basketball team of Garden City, L.I., today, 46 -- 14, leading at the end of the first half, 30 -- 1. Captain Vreeland and Sauter scored 12 and 11 points, respectively.

Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee, which has been assured of another year of life, will renew his efforts today to have State Senator John A. Hastings held in contempt for refusing to obey a subpoena of the committee.

Insisting that relations between manufacturers and wholesalers must "savor less and less of the old-time horse-trade," with increasing interdependence between the two, H.W. Prentis Jr., vice president of the Armstrong Cork Company, called upon the producers last night to "maintain a proper potential profit level" for their wholesale distributors.

All the oldest inhabitants swear that "Robin Hood," which was revived at Erlanger's last evening, is forty-two years old, or will be on the ninth of June. At any rate, Harry B. Smith, who wrote the libretto, did not deny it last evening when Mr. Aborn asked him to show himself in his box, and surely a librettist's silence gives consent.

No voice was heard in opposition to Superintendent O'SHEA'S appeal at the meeting of district superintendents, principals and directors for contribution by the teachers of 5 per cent of their salaries to the relief of school children. Yet the Teachers' Union has written to President RYAN in strong protest against "the assumption of authority and responsibility" involved in the effort to make what is looked upon by them as a "levy."
HAVANA, Cuba, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Joseph Obregon, son-in-law of President Machado, said today he was "clear" in the Senatorial investigation of loans to Cuba.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 27 -- The scheduled ten-round fight between Bat Battalino, erstwhile featherweight champion, and Freddie Miller, Cincinnati southpaw, was declared no contest in the third round tonight when Battalino went down under what Referee Lou Bauman declared to be a "light" blow.

The first annual dinner of the Jewish Conciliation Court of America, which has sought for almost twelve years to settle difficulties of an intimately Jewish nature, was held last night at the Hotel Astor. Speakers praised the work of the court, reviewed its increasing scope and said it was in many ways an example for the civil courts.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- The American Chamber of Commerce here began today the first organized effort to seek to induce the French Government to modify its present policy of imposing quotas on importations, which are seriously affecting American business with France.
NEW YORK. The Baron and Baronne de Baubigny have left the Sherry-Netherland for California, where they will remain some time before returning to their home in Paris.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 27 -- The Ways and Means Committee came to the end of the general hearings on tax revision today, hearing at the close a plea by the independent oil producers for a tax on oil imports to act not only as a money raising device but also as a tariff against foreign producers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Augie Kieckhefer of Chicago went into a three-way tie for the lead with Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia and Arthur Thurnblad of Chicago in the world's three-cushion billiard championship struggle tonight by defeating Allen Hall of Chicago, 50 to 39, in forty-two innings.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 27 -- The Princeton Board of Education had cut its budget for 1932-33 to such an extent that it had been possible to save taxpayers $28,127.97, it was announced today. The budget totals $313,958.12, with $187,145.62 to be raised by taxes.

Maurice W. Levy, retired Kansas banker and politician and former associate of Jay Gould, left an estate of $1,022,827, which was reduced by debts of $276,436 and other reductions to $688,945 net, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The British Government's imposition of a general tariff, coming within a fortnight, will be followed by a bold and farreaching attempt to bring down the tariff walls against British goods all over the world.

In anticipation of the celebration next Spring by Columbia University of the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of Charles Dodgson, better known as Lewis Carroll, author of "Alice in Wonderland," the centennary yesterday passed without formal observance in the city.

MADRID, Jan. 27 -- Elias Tormo, former Minister of Justice, today presented a demand for an injunction to the Supreme Court on behalf of the Jesuits. He stated that the law under which the order was being constitutionally ejected did not apply to the Jesuits since they only took the oath to the Pope during the ante-reformist movement in the early days of Protestantism.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27 -- T. Philip Perkins of New York, former British amateur champion, shot subpar golf for a victory over Gus Novotny of La Grange, Ill., in the Miami Beach championship over the La Gorce course today, his 4-and-2 margin advancing him to the semi-finals.

Dr. Michael I. Pupin, who came here as an immigrant boy from Yugoslavia and attained fame and fortune as the inventor of important devices for the radio and telephone, last night received the John Fritz Gold Medal, the highest honor bestowed by the engineering profession in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A duty of five cents a pound on copper imports was asked in a resolution introduced today by Representative Douglas, Democrat of Arizona.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 28 -- A circle of warships playing search lights over an area of tumbling water off Portland Bill kept watch last night for any trace of oil or bubbles which might mark the position of the ill-fated submarine airplane carrier M-2.

The Building Trades Employers' Association in New York City plans to put into effect on May 1 wage reductions averaging 25 per cent, it was announced yesterday at the opening sessions of the thirty-sixth annual convention of the New York State Association of Builders at 2 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- George M. Reynolds, chairman of the $500,000,000 National Credit Corporation, today explained the policy of the bankers' credit pool as affected by the Federal Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Plans are being made tonight for the Railway Labor Executives Association to begin as soon as possible, probably tomorrow, the final stage in their negotiations with the railroad presidents' committee of nine.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 27 -- Conditions in the administration of justice in the large cities are "strong testimony to the impossibility of adequate conduct of judicial institutions without a high level of practitioners," Dean Roscoe Pound of the Harvard Law School declared in his annual report to President Lowell today.

The demand for well-located business sites continued in Manhattan yesterday when reports of new contracts by brokers indicated another busy day for renting and managing agents. Millinery, ribbon and knit-goods firms took space in the garment centre, while store renting was spread out over a wider area.

The first thirty railroads to report for December showed a net operating income of $16,421,000, against $30,426,000 in December, 1930, a drop of 46 per cent, and against $38,146,000 in December, 1929, a decrease of 56.9 per cent. Their November net was $19.188,000, against $33,803,000 in November, 1930, a decline of 43.2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The House passed today without record vote the bill appropriating $175,408,814 for the Department of Agriculture for the fiscal year 1933.

A widening of the rift between Java and Cuba on sugar-crop restriction was disclosed in a cable message that was made public here yesterday at the offices of Thomas L. Chadbourne, who is in Havana in an effort to save the sugar stabilization plan that bears his name.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Army defeated the U.S. Coast Guard Academy basketball team of New London, Conn., today in a fast and hard-fought game by 36 to 25.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "For and Against" offered a bright spot in these dark days of reading recriminations by the apparently desperate forces of prohibition against those enlightened people who sincerely desire the abolition of this oppressive, obsolete, un-American legislation.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Texas Knight, an appropriately named son of Sir Gallahad III, owned by the Texas-owned Three D's Stock Farm, made a successful debut as a 3-year-old today, winning the Aspirant purse over six furlongs at the Fair Grounds.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- While Tammany was making its last stand at the all-day session in the Assembly today against prolonging the life of the Hofstadter investigating committee for another year, Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, leader of the Democratic minority in the lower house, made public a "minority report" in which, point by point, he assailed the recent intermediate report to the committee by Samuel Seabury its counsel.

From the Public Printer at Washington comes news heartening to all who hope and work for the advancement of high thought and sound literature, for the popular diffusion of statistics, raw and cooked, eloquence and poesy and anthologies of elegant extracts.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27 -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., advanced to the semi-final round of the annual Lake Worth golf tournament today, defeating Arthur W. (Ducky) Yates of Rochester, N.Y., by 2 and 1. Yates, the defending titleholder, was 3 down at the turn.

An attempt to blackmail the office of the United States Attorney in an effort to prevent Federal authorities from continuing their investigation of the activities of Sidney Paris, husband of Charlotte M. Werner Paris, typist, who was suspended from that office last Wednesday, was charged yesterday by Thomas E. Dewey, Acting United States Attorney.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Two measures of prime importance to labor, to restrict the use of injunctions and to bring about an investigation of the six-hour day for railway employes, moved forward with rapid strides today in Congress.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 27 -- Forty-eight hours after he was reported missing at the State Prison. Leroy Trueblood, a prisoner serving five to seven years for passing bad checks, was discovered biding in a woodpile in the prison chair factory tonight.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 -- Though the dispatching of one cruiser and twelve destroyers, which had been waiting at Sasebo since Jan. 22, suggests warlike measures, official statements here give the impression that the Japanese Government does not expect to proceed to extremes at Shanghai.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Governor Roosevelt today sent a special message to the Legislature recommending a $150,000 reduction in his original budget request for $200,000 for draftsmen and engineers in the Department of Public Works. His action was interpreted as indicative of the growing sentiment for slashing the schedule of appropriations laid down early in the session.

A new issue of $25,000,000 New York Edison Company first lien and refunding mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds, series C, due on Oct. 1, 1951, will be offered today by the National City Company, subject to the approval of the Public Service Commission of New York, at a price of 97 and interest, to yield about 5.25 per cent.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Following a conference this afternoon with the Clearing House committee of Newark bankers, Mayor Jerome T. Congleton announced that the bankers of the city had undertaken to renew all expiring temporary notes of the city which they held and to do all in their power to have those in New York renewed.

Edward Fagan of the Engineers Club became the first player to score three victories in the national amateur pocket billiard championship tournament in progress at the New York Lodge of Elks by winning his matches yesterday afternoon and last night.

The New York State Committee for Billboard Legislation held its final organization meeting yesterday in the hall of the New York State Chamber of Commerce in Liberty Street. Pierrepont E. Twitchell, who was chosen permanent chairman, emphasized the need for funds to carry on the fight in the Legislature for the Zimmerman bill to regulate outdoor advertising, which Mr. Twitchell said was introduced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The results of counting atoms in the sun, 92,000,000 miles away, recently achieved by scientists, were summarized by Dr. Henry Norris Russell, Professor of Astronomy at Princeton University, tonight in delivering the first Arthur Lecture under the auspices of the Smithsonian Institution.
The Yale Club Class B squash racquets team went into second place in the New York group of the Metropolitan League last night by administering a 4-to-1 defeat to the Harvard Club on the Yale courts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Walter Kennedy, Elmslord building contractor, who pleaded guilty and received a suspended sentence on a charge of bigamy about three years ago in connection with his marriage to Mary Agnes Thompson, then a 17-year-old servant in his home, was revealed today as the innocent figure in his marital tangle.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club hockey team turned back Poland's Olympic sextet at Madison Square Garden last night by the score of 5 to 1. While a crowd of 5,000 persons looked on the Brooklyn stick-swingers, led by the irrepressible Blinco brothers, Lloyd and Russell, swept through the Polish players to hand them their second successive defeat in the United States.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Ray Conger's initial indoor effort in a drive for Olympic honors was crushed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The exclusion from the French market of substantial exports of radios from the United States by import quotas is held by the State Department to be unfair to the American radio industry, and it has advised Ambassador Edge to take up the matter with the French authorities.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 27 -- Henry C. Fownes 2d of Pittsburgh, the medalist, was eliminated in the semi-final round in the championship division of the St. Valentine's golf tournament today by Donald Parson of Youngstown, Ohio, in a close battle that ended on the home green, the score being 1 up.

Chief Magistrate James E. McDonald, after an examination of the records yesterday, said there would be no official investigation of the action of Magistrate Edward Weil in sentencing Walter Carpenter, 20 years old, of 325 West Forty-second Street, to six months in the workhouse following his conviction of disorderly conduct in the Night Court last Saturday night.

The adjustment of the eight-year controversy between Bishop William D. Manning and the Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie, announced Tuesday, was achieved through a disposition of both men to regard church unity in a time of economic distress as of more importance than ritual, it was said yesterday; but it was evident that neither disputant had abandoned his convictions as to what can go on during a church service with propriety.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published a letter from Joseph M. Smith, who stated that the International Relations Club of Lynchburg College, Virginia, favors the postponement of consideration of the Vinson naval replacement bill until the conclusion of the disarmament conference at Geneva shall have furnished evidence whether national armament or international agreements will be the instruments for guaranteeing the security of nations in the future.

Alleging an annual deficit in excess of $200,000 in the operation of trolley service over the Williamsburg Bridge at a 2-cent fare, W.S. Menden, president of the Brooklyn and Queens Rapid Transit Corporation, has requested the city to permit an increased fare before Feb. 15.

One of the "Evenings Abroad" in aid of the Visiting Nurse Service of the Henry Street Settlement took place last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis. It was called "A Night in Scotland," to celebrate the 173d anniversary of the birth of Robert Burns, which occurred on Monday.

HARBIN, Manchuria, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Eighteen persons were dead and fourteen were missing tonight after a day of terror in which soldiers of the army of Ting Chao plundered the homes of wealthy Japanese citizens, dragged Koreans off buses and killed them, and wrecked Japanese-owned buildings.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 27 -- Sunday "blue-law" fines of $25 each, totaling $425, were imposed upon four motion picture theatre managers and thirteen projection-machine operators, all of whom participated in presenting motion-picture performances here last Sunday, by City Court Judge William G. De Meza today.

"Russia of Today" is the title of an exhibition of paintings by Frank Horowitz currently on view at the Ehrich Gallery. There is very little that is distinctively Russian, however, and the canvas labeled "Blue Mountains, Pennsylvania," does not look out of place.

Another slight increase in steel operations is reported in the midweek review by The Iron Age, which estimates that the rate of the entire industry is 29 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 28 per cent in the week before. The publication says that business is "making very slow headway against adverse influences," and continues in part, as follows:

Bill Regan's goal in the last four minutes grave the Bronx Tigers a 3-2 victory over the Springfield Indians in a Canadian-American Hockey League game at the New York Coliseum last night before 2,500.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Jose Emilio Obregon y Blanco, son-inlaw of President Machado of Cuba, was an employe and then a joint manager of the Cuban branch of the Chase National Bank while the bank and its affiliates arranged $80,000,000 in loans and credits for Cuba, the Senate Finance Committee was told today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Glass bill to revise the Federal Reserve and national banking laws will be held back by the subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, which originally framed it, until it has been thoroughly rewritten, members of the subcommittee said this afternoon.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city.

Butter. Receipts, 13.565 packages. Decided weakness was still apparent at the opening yesterday and values fell a full 3/4 c during the early trading. Extras hit 21c before buyers would take hold, a level which has not been touched before here in January since 1901. No lower January price baa been recorded since 1899.
TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 28 -- Two Japanese battalions, 1,000 troops in all, were sent to Harbin last night from Changchun after an outbreak of looting and killing by Chinese soldiers.

Dr. Clamor H. Magna Jr., 36-yearold superintendent of Kings County Hospital, who had been mysteriously missing since Monday afternoon, was found dead in a room of the Hotel Rockingham at Portsmouth, N.H., yesterday with both wrists slashed. Dr. Magna was considered one of the city's most brilliant young hospital executives and had been devoted to his work.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. George Alexander McKinlock entertained with a dinner this evening at Casa Alejandro, their villa, honoring their house guest, Mrs. Joseph T. Ryerson of Chicago. Eighteen guests were present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The movement to give American producers the preference in purchases of supplies and materials by Federal departments gained headway today, following the receipt of a letter by Speaker Garner from President Hoover requesting appropriate legislation.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Gloom, among the Olympic athletes, caused by rain early today, was dispelled by a snowstorm of blizzardlike proportions tonight. However, the rain caused Jay O'Brien, chairman of the Olympic bobsleigh committee, to announce the postponement of the North American A.A.U. bobsleigh championships from Friday and Saturday to Saturday and Sunday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 -- A pair of Western thoroughbreds took the first two places from a duo of speedy Easterners in the Dade County Handicap, feature at Hialeah Park today. After six furlongs, which were run in the fast time of 1:11, R.W. Collins's colt Don Leon was the winner by a length over Brown Wisdom, which bore the colors of the Reichert Brothers.

A statement urging a policy on the part of the United States for a period of years in its relationship to the Virgin Islands was issued yesterday by Paul M. Pearson, Governor of the islands, after he had accepted a check for $500 for the island's undernourished school children from the Golden Rule Foundation.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Resumption of construction work on the giant Cunard liner, 534, depends mainly upon, whether the Government will extend to the company loan facilities similar to those under which the Lusitania and Mauretania were built before the war, it is apparent from a statement by the directors issued tonight.

The New York Life Insurance Company invested an average of $633,000 on each business day in 1931, or a total of $190,000,000, according to the eighty-seventh annual report for the year. New paid-for business aggregated $673,123,000 for the year, bringing the total of insurance in force to $7,657,373,158 on Dec. 31.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 27 -- Howard A. Woolverton, a prominent manufacturer of 52, who was kidnapped early this morning, walked unheralded into his home here just before midnight while members of his family were ostensibly waiting further instructions from his abductors, who had demanded $50,000 ransom.

It ought not to have been necessary for the White House to explain that the Reconstruction Finance program and kindred measures adopted are not "inflation." But something was needful in order to dispel foolish ideas in and out of our own financial circles, along with rather widespread ignorance in Europe regarding the nature of these plans.

CALCUTTA, Jan. 27 -- Wearing red saris [sashes] and with their hair adorned with lotus flowers, Miss Santi Ghose and Miss Sunity Chowduri, Bengali schoolgirls, were sentenced today to "transportation for life" for the murder of Magistrate C.G.B. Stevens last month.

Wall Street was interested mainly yesterday in the stock market's response to United States Steel's dividend reduction and its unsatisfactory income report for the fourth quarter of 1931. Steel common broke sharply, which caused no surprise, but it did not cause any acute unsettlement in the main body of stocks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- But for the insistence of Judge A.M. Cristy of the Circuit Court of Honolulu, it is believed here, the grand jury before which was produced the evidence in the case of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, her son-in-law, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, U.S.N., E. J. Lord and Albert L. Jones, the last two naval enlisted men, would have failed to indict and Mrs. Fortescue and her co-defendants would now be free.
"Literature is civilization," the German critic, Ernst Robert Curtius, repeats after Victor Hugo, in his study of "The Civilization of France" just published by the Macmillan Company.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Trading was almost at a standstill on the Bourse today, although just before the close there was a brief selling period. Prices finished at the day's lowest levels, although the variations did not in any case equal yesterday's gains.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Jan. 28 -- Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Minister to China, said on leaving Tokyo for Shanghai yesterday (Wednesday) that there was "no other means left on the part of the Japanese Government but to take the necessary drastic action'' at Shanghai to end anti-Japanese agitation and the boycott against Japanese goods.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 27 -- Preparations are well advanced for holding a Pan-Arab congress soon in some country adjoining Palestine, either Iraq, Transjordania or the Hedjaz.

A committee to protect the interests of holders of five-year 7 per cent convertible debentures of the Splitdorf-Bethlehem Electrical Company has been formed, it was announced yesterday. It said the business and financial prospects of the Splitdorf Electrical Company, formerly the Splitdorf-Bethlehem Electrical Company, were such that the company probably would be unable to pay interest due on March 1 on the Splitdorf-Bethlehem debentures, which will mature on Sept. 1.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27 -- Gar Wood shot his Miss America IX along the Indian Creek course at 110.785 miles an hour for a world's speed-boat record today to reclaim supremacy on the water for America.

The John Wesley Picture Foundation has been organized to produce talking motion pictures on religious themes for use in the Protestant churches throughout the country, it was announced yesterday when offcers of the new organization were elected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Believing that the most direct way to cordial commercial relations between this country and others is through reciprocal trade treaties made on the basis of mutual tariff concessions, the Democrats in the Senate started today an effort to reincorporate in the new tariff bill authority for President Hoover to negotiate such treaties.

HONOLULU, Jan. 27 -- Counsel for Mrs. Granville R. Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and two navy enlisted men, all charged with the murder of Joseph Kahahawai, moved today to quash the second-de-gree murder indictments returned yesterday by a grand jury on the ground that they were obtained by "judicial coercion."

C.A. Leon and Eduard D. Mathey, executors of the estate of John L. Mathey, sold to the Hudson Union Company the five-story brick store building and the two-story brick store building at 200-02 Washington Street, northwest corner of Second Street, and the two three-story brick flats with stores at 201-03 Bloomfield Street, northeast corner of Second Street, Hoboken, assessed at $120,300.

HONOLULU, Jan. 27 -- Counsel for Mrs. Granville R. Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and two navy enlisted men, all charged with the murder of Joseph Kahahawai, moved today to quash the second-de-gree murder indictments returned yesterday by a grand jury on the ground that they were obtained by "judicial coercion."

C.A. Leon and Eduard D. Mathey, executors of the estate of John L. Mathey, sold to the Hudson Union Company the five-story brick store building and the two-story brick store building at 200-02 Washington Street, northwest corner of Second Street, and the two three-story brick flats with stores at 201-03 Bloomfield Street, northeast corner of Second Street, Hoboken, assessed at $120,300.

A stiff northwest gale whipped this city and its environs yesterday, buffeting shipping in the harbor; tearing down, signs, trees and telephone poles and shattering windows; killing a 70-year-old woman in Bayonne, N.J.; and injuring more than a score of persons throughout the metropolitan area.

Net earnings of the F.W. Woolworth Company for 1931, including profits from sales of securities, were $41,348,795, the largest in the history of the company, it was announced yesterday. Equivalent to $4.24 a share on 9,750,000 shares of stock, they compare with 34,736,249, or $3.56 a share in 1930, and with the previous record of $35,664,253, established in 1929.

Declines were shown in most of the Market leaders on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, except in the foreign bond section, where the tone improved. Stocks which rallied against the trend included American Gas and Electric, Tampa Electric and some less active issues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The definiteness with which the administration has opposed suggestions for inflation of the currency as a method of meeting the depression, already, evidenced in information from the White House, received emphasis today when Senator Walsh of Massachusetts made public a letter from Secretary Mellon rejecting a proposal which would permit the issue of an additional $1,000,000,000 in national bank notes.

With only two matches remaining on the schedule, the unbeaten Columbia University Club Class A squash-tennis team maintained its place at the top of the Metropolitan League standing last night by winning its tenth consecutive victory.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Continuance of the Hofstadter Committee inquiry in New York City was assured today when the Assembly by a strictly party vote of 76 to 70, approved the resolution prolonging the life of the committee another year.

Frank Sheridan revealed in his piano recital at the Town Hall last night that he is continuing to make forward strides in his art. There is no longer any question of his talents for the piano: his technic is resourceful and his interpretative approach is sincere and musicianly.

Slow Retail Pace Continues. Retail trade continues to maintain a rather slow pace, with consumer response still of an indifferent nature. But three selling days remain before the close of the month and retail executives agreed yesterday there seems no reason to revise previous estimates that dollar volume for the period will be off about 15 per cent as compared with a year ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- County Treasurer Charles M. Miller delivered today $1,059,190 in certificates of indebtedness to the Chase National Bank and Salomon Brothers Hutzler of New York City. The certificates, due in June, when they will be refunded with bonds, were sold at an interest rate of 5.85.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Additional fashion openings continue the mode of a straight and narrow silhouette, and a slightly shorter day skirt.
"Through the Years," the Vincent Youmans musical play with a libretto based on "Smilin" Through," will open tonight at the Manhattan Theatre.

Governor ROOSEVELT has filled the vacancy on the State Civil Service Commission by appointing HOWARD G.E. SMITH, a Buffalo lawyer and business man. He is described by the correspondent of The Courier Express as "head of the Erie "County arm of the Democratic "Union, dedicated to the White "House cause of the Governor."

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Prince of Wales made a striking appeal for service tonight to the youth of his country. Ten thousand boys and girls at a meting in Albert Hall organized by the National Council of Social Service cheered the Prince, who also was heard over the radio in many homes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- General John J. Pershing told an audience of 200 at a luncheon given in his honor today at the Press Club that the American people will free themselves from the financial crisis. He admonished his listeners to harken back to the time of the war when they were called upon to exert their full strength, and urged that they summon the same courage and spirit in fighting the depression.

Net income of the Kreuger Toll Company for 1931 is officially estimated at $2.19 for every American certificate representing participating debentures of 20 kronor each, against $3.04 earned in 1930. Net earnings were about $23,500,000, and after interest on secured debentures a balance of about $21,000,000 remains, compared with $32,789,279 in 1930.

Considering the enormous vogue that Jean Jacques Henner once enjoyed (and not so long ago), it does seem strange that his name isn't so much as mentioned in Elie Faure's "History of Modern Art." It is not mentioned in Mr. Wilenski'a newly published "History of French Art."
JERUSALEM, Jan. 28 -- The Greek-born clergy of Palestine intend to appeal to the Archbishop of Canterbury to intervene in their present dispute with the native Arab Orthodox community.
Two large west side apartment hotels were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday.
With plans outlined for the most active outboard motor boat racing year, the National Outboard Association held its annual meeting yesterday in connection with the Motor Boat Show.

Recent water-colors by William Zorach are being exhibited at the Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street. "Maine in Winter," the show is called, and certainly there is in these landscapes, little evidence of the Gulf Stream's reputed proximity.

The "Olive Branch" petition sent by the Second Continental Congress to King George III in 1775 in a vain effort to avoid the American Revolution brought $53,000 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. It was bought by Gabriel Wells.

SHANGHAI, China, Friday, Jan. 29 -- Japanese marines fought the Chinese defenders of Shanghai today in a series of bloody battles in the narrow cobbled streets and precipitated the most critical international complications of the Sino-Japanese conflict by occupying the native city.
LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club of Brooklyn gained its third straight victory in the Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League by beating the Penn A.C. tonight, 38 to 21. It was the twelfth triumph for the Crescents in fourteen starts.

HAVANA, Jan. 28 -- An explosion which destroyed an entire building in the Santo Suarez district of Havana this afternoon killed two members of the secret police, Lieutenants Arturo Betancourt and Labrador Vaquero, when they were searching the house for arms and explosives reported to have been stored there by enemies of the government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A charge that taking of government plans caused the discharge of one of two men whose allegations of defects in the airship Akron led to the investigation now being conducted by the House Naval Committee was made before the committee today by Paul W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear-Zeppelin Company, builder of the craft.
Prices moved in a narrow range on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday as the apathy of the trading public continued to keep sales low. At the close the losses were about counteracted by the gains.

Reporting a deficit of $3,421,938 for the fourth quarter of 1931, after dividends on preferred stock, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it had omitted the 50-cent dividend payment on the common shares. The usual quarterly dividend of $1.75 a share on preferred stock was declared.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- New York City's special franchise valuations for 1932 show an increase of $46,350,855 over last year, according to tabulations made public today by the State Tax Commission, which sent out detailed figures on all public service corporations to municipal bodies.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- The national racquets doubles champions, Clarence C. Pell and Stanley G. Mortimer, were eliminated in the start of the present championship tourney at the Racquet Club today.
PORTLAND, England, Jan. 28 -- The British Admiralty announced that the possibility of saving any lives of men on the M-2 was "almost beyond hope."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 28 -- A spectacular second half rally, which closed with scoring shots by Captain George Seewagen, Olmstead and Crutch, in the final minute gave Springfield College a 28-to-24 victory over Yale tonight. Yale led by 24 to 22 as the last minute opened.

A call for a nation-wide "Day of Prayer" on Sunday for the success of the World Disarmament Conference, which opens next week in Geneva, was issued yesterday by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, with headquarters at 105 East Twenty-second Stret.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President and Mrs. Hoover entertained at dinner tonight in honor of the Chief Justices and Associates Justices of the United States Supreme Court.

Sales of department stores in the New York Federal Reserve district December were 8.7 per cent below those of the previous December, while for the entire year 1931 they were about 8 per cent smaller than 1930, the Feb. 1 review of credit and business published by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York will ay.

HENCE, loathed Melancholy! The fight game has been conducted in too solemn a manner. Now there is to be an "allegro" interlude. Max of the California Bounding Baers is due to clash in the ring with Harry Levinsky, called the Kingfish of Chicago. Here are the heavyweights who bring with them what John Milton once ordered up in one of his rare moments of cheerfulness:

LAKEHURST, N.J., Jan. 28 -- Lieutenant George C. Calnan, former international fencing champion and an officer in the construction corps of the navy, was gassed until he lost consciousness on the last cruise of the Los Angeles, it was revealed here today.

One tear-gas cartridge, the sound of an accidentally fired shot and many threats effectively resulted in the capture of Arthur Becker, Connecticut ex-convict and gunman, who was besieged by the New York and Connecticut police yesterday in his room on the eight floor of the Knights of Columbus Club Hotel, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Doris Doe, American contralto, will make her first appearance at the Metropolitan next week as Brangane in the production of "Tristan und Isolde" on Wednesday evening, when Gota Ljungberg will be Isolde here for the first time. Others in the "Tristan" cast will be Messrs.
PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 28 -- Halbert J. Blue of Aberdeen, N.C., won the St. Valentine's golf tournament here today after a sensational finish in his match with Donald Parson of Youngstown, Ohio.

A canvass yesterday among exhibitors at the National Motor Boat Show at the Grand Central Palace revealed that public sales of motor boats, sailboats and accessories had "exceeded all expectation," according to officials of the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers, under whose auspices the exhibition is being held.

Prices on yesterday's financial markets generally drifted lower, but with no emphatic movement, either in stocks or bonds. Railway shares gave seemingly no response to the indications, in the day's news, that agreement on the wage-reduction question would be reached; but Wall Street may have taken the view that such a result had been "discounted" in advance.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 28 -- Prime Minister J.B. Hertzog surprised the House of Assembly again today when moving for a select committee to inquire into the gold standard, he announced that the government still was determined to stay on the gold basis.

HONOLULU, Jan. 28 -- Montgomery Winn, associate counsel in the defense of Mrs. Granville R. Fortescue and three navy men accured of killing Joseph Kahahawai, suspected attacker of M Fortescue's daughter, filed a supplementary motion today to quash the second degree murder indictment against the four prisoners and also sought to have them admitted to bail.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Secretary Stimson has taken under consideration the apology by Abyssinia, but has declined to state whether the measures of redress taken are satisfactory and close the incident.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Not in years has President Hoover been so physically fit as he is today. He Is a vastly different Herbert Hoover from the man who entered the White House on March 4, 1929. Then he weighed more than 210 pounds, he was overfat and, like many other men prone to embonpoint, he favored the double breasted sack suits, which, worn buttoned-up, made a plump man appear somewhat slenderer.

Two men who posed as representatives of large corporations in defrauding women of more than $100,000 through bogus transactions were sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Alien in General Sessions, while some of their victims looked on and applauded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Four American destroyers are being sent from Manila to the Yangtse River to protect American lives and property in the expectation that the Japanese occupation of Shanghai will be extended up the river to Nanking and Hankow.

HAVANA, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Eather, winner of one of two Cuban starts and second in the other won the $2,500 Jose Marti. Handicap at Oriental Park today. The race was named for a Cuban hero of the Spanish-American war.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Jake Schaefer's bid for the world's three-cushion billiard championship suffered a setback today when he failed to get by Johnny Layton, the Sedalia (Mo.) star.

Through the personality and career of a young Russian lawyer who presented himself before the Holy Synod, demanded to be made a Bishop and became an Archbishop, Vladimir Brenner attempts to show in his new novel, "Russia in the Name of God," the spiritual strength and material weakness of the orthodox church.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 28 -- Requisition on the State contorller has been made by the trustees of the State teachers pension fund for $4,161,566 under the existing law requiring payment from the tax on first class railroad property. The annual sum is determined on an actuarial basis.

Price trend in commodities was lower yesterday, grains, lard, tin, silk and rubber losing ground in the cash section, while coffee, cocoa, rubber and hides reacted in futures trading. There was slight improvement in butter and silk.

Winston Churchill, the British statesman, defended last night the conception of a United States of Europe, but asserted that as European solidarity increased there should be a corresponding growth of solidarity and a closer communion of interests among English-speaking peoples.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Miss Linda Watkins, film actress, and Gabriel L. Hess of New York were married at the Blackstone here today. The ceremony was performed by Superior Judge Denis Normoyle.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 28 -- A revision of the American Standard Bible will be published in 1941, according to Dean Luther A. Weigle of Yale Divinity School, chairman of the American Standard Bible Committee of the International Council of Religious Education.

Brokers' loans, as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank yesterday, dropped $18,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday. The decline was the twenty-first in succession, which is a record for uninterrupted liquidation of brokers' loans, and carried the total to $513,000,000, the lowest recorded amount since Feb. 1, 1918, when $510,179,000 of brokers' loans was outstanding.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A Marine Corps officer who won a reputation fighting bandits in the West Indies is the commanding officer of the Fourth Regiment, United States Marines, in Shanghai.

DETROIT, Jan. 28 -- Although he had his Miss America IX streaking over the waters of Indian Creek, Miami Beach, Fla., yesterday faster than any human ever had piloted a hydroplane. Gar Wood appears to have failed of a new world's record by about two turns of his craft's propeller blades.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Secretary Hurley told the House Committee on Expenditures today that consolidation of the War and Navy Departments into a department of national defense would add to the cost of government and result in inefficiency.

The statement that Samuel Seabury was under investigation by the Bar Association was made yesterday by Frank P. Walsh, as counsel for State Senator John A. Hastings in a heated exchange before Supreme Court Justice Hatting, where he opposed Mr. Seabury's motion that Hastings be sentenced for contempt for failure to answer a subpoena of the Hofstadter legislative committee.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Charges made by Dr. E.H. Josephson of New York City that the New York Academy of Medicine had conducted a "racket" in the sale of serum for the treatment of infantile paralysis, were declared today by Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., State Health Commissioner, to be without foundation.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 28 -- Yale will play twenty-four baseball games this Spring, possibly twenty-six, in the event of ties in the series with Princeton and Harvard, it was announced today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The internal plight of the United States might well be likened to a group of men on a scaffold who had, with disregard, hoisted themselves to a precarious height. The realization of this position caused one of the men to lower his end in an attempt to reach the ground before he fell.

The eighth volume of the Dictionary of American Biography presents another cross-section of American life. It includes the biographies of seven signers of the Declaration, four Presidents of the United States, two Vice Presidents, ALEXANDER HAMILTON, NATHAN HALE, JOHN HAY, NATHANIEL HAWTHORNE and JOSEPH HENRY.

Butter. Receipts, 13,311 packages. The market staged a sharp recovery yesterday from Wednesday's low point and it would seem that the bottom has been reached in the recent steady declining tendency for the moment at least. Buying took on marked activity at yesterday's basis of 21c for extras with heavy chain store purchases featuring the situation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Opponents of proposed legislation to permit 4 per cent beer today began the presentation of their case before a Senate manufacturers subcommittee, headed by Senator Bingham.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- The little village of Lake Placid came into its own today as six inches of snow fell in the valley of the Adirondack Mountains to gladden the hearts of 200 athletes waiting for the opening of the Olympic Games Feb. 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Leaders of the Democratic and Republican organizations in the House agreed today to drop the administration's plan to make the proposed increases in taxes "retroactive" to cover incomes for the calendar year 1931, and each side turned to the other with a bid for cooperation in framing a revenue bill to balance the budget.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The round-by-round detail of the Fields-Brouillard title fight follows:

So long as the Japanese remain in Chapei, the landing or troops is a question between China and Japan. Should the Japanese enter the International Settlement without discussing the question with the other nations which join them in the government of the Settlement they will become involved in serious difficulties.

Before the Hennepin County Republican Club of Minneapolis last night Governor PINCHOT appeared as guardian of the orphan and emancipator of the serf. He repeated his favorite saying when he weeps for rural consumption that the farmer is "the orphan child of American politics."

A plan to use commercial paper instead of checks in paying for supplies, as a means of increasing the volume of credit outstanding and arresting the deflation, is under consideration by leading industrialists of the country, according to reports circulated here and in Washington yesterday.

Matthew S. Sloan resigned yesterday as president of the New York Edison Company and from all official positions and memberships on boards of trustees and directors of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York and its subsidiaries.

HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 28 (AP) -- City Treasurer Charles J. West, a World War veteran, was sentenced today to four to ten years' imprisonment in Clinton prison at Dannemora, N. Y., for grand larceny while in public office.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Will Rogers let a large cat out of the bag today, inadvertently creating quite a stir in diplomatic and journalistic circles. In the course of an after-dinner speech at the American Club's weekly affair he innocently remarked:

Sascha Gorodnitzki gave a piano recital in Carnegie Hall last night, his program including Scarlatti's Sonata in B minor, the Scarlatti-Tausig Sonata in C, Beethoven's Sonata in G, Opus 14, No. 2; Schumann's "Carnaval," two etudes and a nocturne by Chopin, Prokofieff's "Suggestions Diabolique" and Gavotte in F sharp minor and Liszt's Polonaise in E.

Patrolman Thomas Quales Jr., departmental chauffeur to Second Deputy Commissioner Felix Muldoon, shot and killed a fleeing man last night and, aided by his father, a court attendant, captured a second just after the fugitives are said to have killed a man near the Quales home in the Bronx.

Bicentennial Items Sought. A fair degree of activity has developed in merchandise showing the inspiration of the forthcoming Washington bicentennial celebration, it was reported here yesterday. Retailers are watching consumer reaction and the view was expressed that the more conservative patterns and effects will meet the biggest turnover.

GENEVA, Jan. 28 -- Hope of dissuading Sir Eric Drummond from resigning as Secretary-General of the League of Nations virtually faded at a private meeting of the Council today, although that body refused to make a definite decision now.

In an address last night before the Bar Association of the City of New York, at its headquarters, 42 West fourty-fourth Street, Judge Frederick Crane of the State Court of Appeals declared that our system of gal administration is being challanged.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 28 (AP) -- President John L. Lewis, in a dramatic speech before the biennial convention of the United Mine Workers today, proclaimed that he was against wage reductions.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 28 -- We American citizens now in Shanghai, engaged chiefly in commerce, are maintaining a strict neutrality of attitude between the Japanese and Chinese over the local situation. But we insist that the foreign concessions, chiefly the International Settlement and the French Concession, be maintained as strictly neutral zones and that the fort of Shanghai be kept entirely free for foreign trade.

Net income of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and wholly owned subsidiaries in 1931 amounted to $53,190,059, equal, after dividends on debenture stock, to $4.29 a share on 11,008,512 shares of common stock. This compares with $55,962,009, or $4.67 a share on the common in 1930.

In an open letter to Mayor Walker yesterday, the City Affairs Committee declared that the suspension of registration of unemployed by the Home Relief Bureau had created a "tragic emergency which the city government must meet "with new emergency measures" and demanded that the city administration take steps to provide additional unemployment relief for 107,000 needy families for whom no provision has been made.

After trailing Robert Cole, former amateur champion, by forty-nine points at one stage of the match, Vaino Korhonen won by 125 to 99 with an unfinished run of twenty-seven in the thirty-fourth inning last night to score his third victory in as many starts in the national amateur pocket billiard championship in progress at the New York Lodge of Elks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Senator Johnson introduced in the Senate today two bills to control the sale of foreign securities in this country.

GENEVA, Jan. 28 -- Japan and China will be reminded of their obligations under the first sentence of Article X, which Woodrow Wilson called the heart of the League Covenant, in a solemn declaration by the president of the Council at a public meeting Saturday on behalf of the other twelve members of the Council, these decided at a secret meeting today.

Although prices on the New York Cotton Exchange, influenced by weakness in securities, lost ground at one time yesterday, active trade buying on the recession caused a recovery that left the list a point lower to a point higher than on Wednesday.

Terms of the proposed reorganization of the Fisk Rubber Company provide for the exchange of $3,409,000 of new 7 per cent preferred and 228,600 shares of no-par common stock of the new company for the $7,620,000 first mortgage bonds of the present company, it was announced yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is something gruesome about the proposal of Representative Collins of Mississippi to cut down the R.O.T.C. and to abandon the Citizens' Military Training Camps. The very suggestion of such a suicidal move should fill every good American with wrath, but it is beginning to seem evident that there are very few real Americans left.
