An opera by Verdi, seventy-five years after its first performance and fifty-one years after the final revision of libretto and music, was given a North American premiere, and received with enthusiasm, last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. This opera was Verdi's "Simone Boccanegra," in the form in which it was mounted at La Scala in 1881.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Treasury certificates in the amount of $373,000,000 will be issued Feb. 1 to provide first financing for the President's reconstruction program and to meet a maturity of slightly under $61,000,000 in bills, Secretary Mellon announced tonight.

"The splendid record of the Democratic party in the present Congress is a forerunner of what the people may expect in the event of a Democatic victory in November, Jouett Shouse, Democratic national executive chairman, declared yesterday at a meeting of "victory campaign" workers held in the offices of the campaign in the Empire State Building.

SHANGHAI, 1 P.M., Friday, Jan. 29 -- The Japanese Navy, starting at midnight with a joint air and land attack, attempted today to rush the Chapei district of Shanghai, outside the International Settlement. The effort has resulted in an astonishing failure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Bank failures for the year numbered 2,290 with deposits of $1,759,484,000, the largest on record, according to a review made public today by the Federal Reserve Board. In December 353 banks with deposits of $319,289,000 closed their doors, the highest number for any month, with the exception of October, when 522 banks with deposits of $479,831,000 suspended.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 29 -- The departure of Japanese troops from Changchun for Harbin was delayed until last night by the refusal of the Chinese Eastern Railway officials to furnish trains. Eventually the Japanese themselves commandeered and manned three trains and left between 8 and 9 P.M.

Plans for the establishment of a chamber music foundation that will serve for music the same purpose that a public library does for literature, that will support free public concerts, and encourage and instruct musical talent, were announced last night at a testimonial concert for Adolph Lewisohn in the auditorium of Hunter College.

Leslie Banks has been engaged to stage the new Bernard Shaw play, "Too True to Be Good," which the Theatre Guild will soon produce, with Beatrice Lillie and Hope Williams in leading roles. The direction of the play will not interfere with Mr. Banks's current appearances in "Springtime for Henry."

The best safety device is a careful person." Travelers in Public Service buses in New Jersey may see this statement posted as a warning. Drivers and pedestrians alike would be more circumspect if they read the text and diagrams of the Travelers Insurance Company's report of motor vehicle accidents in 1931.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 28 -- This city spent a day of turmoil and fearful expectancy today and this evening, preceding the Japanese attack at Chapei, as raiding soldiers roamed over sections of the Native City while in the International Settlement foreign soldiers and members of the Settlement Defense Corps took up positions to guard against strife in that area.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Shooting under par on four holes of the first nine, which he played in 31, T. Philip Perkins of New York, former British amateur champion, submerged H.F. Bowbeer of La Grange, Ill., in the Miami Beach championship semi-final round today, winning by 8 up and 7 to play.
PARIS, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
ROME, Jan. 28 -- Premier Mussolini has called on Italy's physicians to discourage the desire of women for a thin figure, charging that it weakens the race.

DETROIT, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Detroit Falcons defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 2, tonight in a National Hockey League game featured by a match penalty, a double major, a major, and sixteen other penalties, along with some fist fights and a protested goal.
NEW YORK. Princess de Poix of Paris and her son, the Duc de Mouchy, who have been at the Ritz-Carlton, will sail tonight on the Ile de France.
BOMBAY, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Militant Nationalists defied the police here tonight with, fire, stones and shouts, while the government resorted to whipping to check the activities of juvenile rebels.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- A letter from Governor Roosevelt of New York brought joy today to Miss Frances McGaan, the nurse who won a dramatic fight for life in the Drinker respirator more than a year ago following an attack of infantile paralysis.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- A credit extension of only one month instead of three was granted by the council of regents of the Bank of France to Germany today when the question of renewing the $100,000,000 credit granted through the Bank for International Settlements last June was discussed and voted on.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Governor Roosevelt, speaking at the annual dinner of the Albany Chamber of Commerce this evening, said he was willing to cooperate with the Republicans in reducing his budgt to the tune of $20,000,000, if a way could be found. He took a firm stand against reduction in the salaries of State employes, of which there has been some discussion.

Between 300 and 500 patrolmen and detectives who have been engaged in what is known as "detail" work, characterized by some of their more active colleagues as "soft jobs," are due to go out on patrol work, it was indicated yesterday at Police Headquarters.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was slightly less active yesterday than on the day before, but there was only a moderate decline in prices. Wall Street waited impatiently for news of a decision at the railway wage conference in Chicago, but was still without definite information when the market closed.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 28 -- The City Commission will confer tomorrow morning with the Newark Board of Education to discuss the possibilities of further cuts in the school board's budget, Mayor Jerome T. Congleton announced today. No confirmation could be obtained of published reports that the commission would take up the question of having the teachers, policemen and firemen of the city, whose salaries are protected by law, accept a voluntary pay cut.

The annual reports of five general-management investment trusts in the group beaded by the Shenandoah Corporation and the Central States Electric Corporation, and including the Blue Ridge, American Cities Power and Light and Electric Shareholdings Corporations, showed shrinkages in values of net assets similar to those detailed in the last year by most corporations with their principal equities in securities.

Market was featureless, rates in all sections continuing without change. Business was on a small scale. Stock Exchange call loans were 2 1/2 per cent, with street trades at the same figure. Time money ranged 3 1/2@3 3/4 per cent. Commercial paper and acceptances were quiet.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Jan. 28 -- Edward H.B. Alien, well known in society and as an amateur horseman, was indicted today by the Montgomery County grand jury for the murder of his sister's sweetheart, Francis A. Donaldson 3d. This action, taken after two hours of consideration, means Alien will go on trial Monday.

MANILA, Jan. 28 -- The preliminary report for 1931 of E.D. Hester, United States Trade Commissioner, has been submitted to acting Governor George C. Butte. It is based on complete returns for the first eleven months of last year, plus commercial estimates.

In spite of financial difficulties and the effects of the depression, the railroads of the nation have got along better recently than the industries, and their securities will continue to be the "backbone" of insurance company, bank and savings funds, General W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said last night at the dinner of the annual Eastern Regional Savings Conference at the Hotel Roosevelt.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Jan. 28 -- Spring surged too early this year in the breast of Minnie, one of the two cub bears of Gardner Murdock, sportsman and hunter of Brook-haven, and posses are beating through the underbrush of the game preserve looking for her.

W. Stapley Wonham of the Round Hill Club of Greenwich and Junius A. Richards of the Rockaway Hunting Club reached the semi-final round of the metropolitan squash racquets championship doubles last night at the University Club.

Everybody harked back last night at the annual reunion of the pupils of old Public School 28, in the Hotel Astor. Gray-haired men remembered their schoolday pranks of half a century ago, "when New York was New York," and white-haired teachers smiled down on them and remembered when they were good boys.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., 18-year-old winner of the Florida east coast championship at St. Augustine, was defeated by 1 up by William B. Langford of Chicago in the semi-final round of the annual Lake Worth tournament today at the Palm Beach Golf Club.

BUDAPEST, Jan. 28 -- Nicholas Roosevelt, United States Minister to Budapest, and Count Ladislaus Szechenyi, Hungarian Minister to Washington, who is now in Budapest, were elected last night honorary presidents of a committee formed to arrange a bicentennial celebration of Washington Birthday here on Feb. 22.

The Chesapeake Corporation's balance sheet for Dec. 31 shows that the company substantially reduced obligations senior to common stock. The Alleghany Corporation controls the Chesapeake Corporation which in turn controls the Chesapeake Ohio Railway.

ABOARD THE SCHOONER CROWN OF DENMARK, Off Portland, England, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Captain John Hunt, master of this schooner, told naval officers today about a series of mysterious flares and rocking explosions which he saw from his ship on the night of Tuesday, the day the submarine M-2 went down.

Building labor union officials were engaged yestsrday in a study of the proposal of the Building Trades Employers' Association in New York City to reduce wages in the industry 25 per cent upon expiration of present contracts on April 30.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the special performance of "Peter Ibbetson," with Miss Lucrezia Bori, Lawrence Tibbett and Edward Johnson in the leading roles, which will be sung this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Southern Woman's Education Alliance.

Fausta Vittoria Mengarini, sculptor, is described in the foreword to the catalogue as "an artist of the old school, with the cultural background of Rome." She is the daughter of the scientist, Senator Guglielmo Mengarini and the niece of Max Lieberman, celebrated German artist.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- On the eve of a Gubernatorial and Presidential campaign, Republicans in the Legislature are confronted with another fight over prohibition. Having demonstrated in 1930 their ability to divert nearly 200,000 votes from the party in the State, the drys are lining up for another fight and have selected the Legislature for preliminary skirmishing.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- The Bourse strengthened today, some covering purchases helping this tendency which resulted generally in gains, although the volume of transactions increased only slightly. The fact that Wall Street did not appear to be seriously affected by the United States Steel Corporation's dividend reduction was considered here as an indication that the action by the corporation had already been discounted in New York.

Publication yesterday of the notes which Secretary STIMSON sent to and received from Japan in the course of the last six months, while the Manchurian imbroglio was passing into its successive phases, serves to illustrate a difference in method between our State Department and the British Foreign Office.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- With the accession of the Trainmen's Brother hood, making a solid front of twenty railroad unions agreed upon the issue of a wage "deduction," the labor chiefs decided today to resume joint negotiations with the railroad presidents' committee of nine tomorrow morning.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 28 -- The shoe industry in New Hampshire, which is fourth in shoe production among the States, is now operating at about 70 per cent of capacity as against 25 per cent three months ago, when the low point in output for 1931 was reached.

PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Acting on instructions from Washington, Ambassador Edge and other officials of the American Embassy visited Louis Rollin, the Minister of Commerce, this evening to enter the protest of the United States against the situation arising from the imposition of quotas on radios and radio lamps and tubes, which have virtually put an end to imports of those commodities from the United States.

The skyline of New York is the true expression of its life, not just an accidental organization of material, according to Eugene G. Steinhof, professor at the National School of Decorative Art of Vienna.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Minister, plans to leave tomorrow afternoon for Geneva to attend the disarmament conference, but will continue to keep in touch with conversations in Washington concerning the Shanghai situation. These conversations are strictly between Washington and London without any participation by Japan.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- A bill designed to prevent gerrymandering in the reapportionment of Congressional districts today was introduced in the Legislature by Assemblyman Streit, New York Democrat.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city.

Books should be chosen for publication largely on the basis of theme and authority, yet they should be written so simply that they can catch and hold an audience "among the millions of adults with seventh grade minds, with the mental age of 12," according to O.H. Cheney, retired banker who recently completed an economic survey of the book industry.

The fourth of the Sert Supper-Dances was held last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Many dinners preceded the event, which was one of a series arranged to raise funds for the charity patients of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

GUAYAQUIL, Jan. 28 -- President Baquerizo sums up the situation in regard to the exhaustion of Ecuador's gold reserves in a letter to President Cueva of the Central Bank, in which he expresses concern over the conversion of sucres into foreign exchange. He says the bank upholds the gold standard by strictly considering on their merits all discounts, but that it exercises no such censorship on drafts sold.

Contributions totaling $74,891.11 in the campaign of the Musicians' Emergency Aid to raise $300.000 for the relief of needy musicians were reported yesterday at the first luncheon meeting of about one hundred leaders and workers at the St. Regis Hotel.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 28 -- Frank H. Smith, New Jersey Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, defended his conduct of the liquidation of the Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken, closed by him seven months ago, in replying today to recent charges that the costs of liquidation were excessive.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Were a competition arranged for the most notable exhibit in the showwindows of Manhattan, I would confidently enter for first choice this time, even among such wide and costly variety -- just a fish.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 28 (AP) -- My Sweets, a four-year-old filly which has finished out of the money only twice in her twelve Winter races, and Crystal Prince, a non-winner over the Winter turf, divided honors in the twin feature events at the Fair Grounds today.

The aviation industry has weathered two of its most critical years and enters 1932 considerably stronger than it has been because of the adjustments that have taken place during 1930 and 1931, declared Charles L. Lawrance, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, in his report to the chamber yesterday at its yearly meeting hore.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 28 (AP) -- The forty-two-foot gasoline boat Quest, bearing five members of the Pennsylvania Pan-American Expedition on a tropical scientific survey, blew up tonight on the Baton Rouge riverfront.

ADDIS ABEBA, Abyssinia, Jan. 28 -- In an elaborate ceremonial the Abyssinian Government tendered a formal apology today to United States Minister Addison E. Southard for the attack made on him by native policemen about ten days ago.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Landing in Europe today, the American delegates to the Geneva conference made no attempt to conceal the fact that they expected to face obstacles in dealing with France.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 28 -- A $5,000 fine and indefinite suspension were imposed today by the Cincinnati Boxing Commission on Christopher (Bat) Battalino, Hartford, Conn., featherweight, for his "no contest" match with Freddie Miller, Cincinnati southpaw, last night.

In pursuance of his economy pledge, Mayor WALKER has promised to call on department " key men" for suggestions how to secure added revenue as well as to cut down expenses. A few have already been advanced, such as bridge tolls, a filing charge on plans for new buildings, and the assessment of the cost of fighting certain types of fires against the property affected.

Capitalism and radicalism had it out last night from the same dais at a round-table conference dinner of the Association for Better Citizenship at the Biltmore. A disturbance occurred when Israel Amter, speaking for the Communist party, prolonged his remarks so far that George W. Wickersham, the final speaker, had only four minutes on the air, the program being broadcast by WOR, compared to Mr. Amter's twenty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Democratic tariff bill which passed the House with ease more than two weeks ago struck a snag in the Senate today in the form of an unfavorable report by the Finance Committee.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Feodor Chaliapin, the famous Russian opera singer, so well known to music-loving Americans, appeared here last night in what is admittedly his greatest role. Boris Godunov, at the Royal Municipal Theatre under the auspices of the Wagner Society.

Japanese bonds were under pressure on the Stock Exchange yesterday, losses amounting to 1 to 5 3/4 points in trading that was somewhat heavier than it had been in the preceding few days. The bond market as a whole was lower, with the notable exception of United States Government securities, which rose briskly 1-32 to 30-32d point with the exception of the Liberty 3 1/2s which held unchanged.

The Boston Bruins finally made their way back into the victory column by defeating the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The rugged Massachusetts skaters, who are in last place in the American Division of the National Hockey League for the first time in six years, rose against the home six and registered a 4-to-1 triumph.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Important changes in the gold holdings of principal countries took place during 1931, although during the closing weeks of the year there were relatively small changes, according to the Federal Reserve Board's monthly bulletin.

Hanns Jelinek of Vienna, young modern composer, has been awarded the $500 prize offered by the New York Association of Music School Settlements for a work suitable for educational uses, Miss Marion Rous, chairman of the competition, announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Jan. 28 -- W. Cameron Forbes, United States Ambassador, saw Foreign Minister Yoshizawa this evening on instructions from Secretary of State Stimson to emphasize to the Japanese Government the seriousness of any action involving danger to foreign interests at Shanghai and also directing attention to newspaper reports that the Japanese intend to occupy the American radio station at Shanghai.

Peggy Wood will sail for London tonight in the Majestic to return to the scene of her triumph in "Bitter Sweet." The British Ministry of Labor, according to word received here yesterday, will offer no objection when she joins the cast of "The Cat and the Fiddle." to be produced at the Palace Theatre.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 29 -- The search for the M-2 moved today to a new area seven miles west of Portland Bill, about half a mile in extent, where the captains of two vessels reported they had seen strange happenings Tuesday, although at different times.

CAIRO, Jan. 28 -- The archaeological department of the Egyptian University, under the direction of Professor Selim Hassan, is continuing work this season on the excavations at the Giza pyramids, mainly on the clearance of a new part of the necropolis near the "Little Pyramid," whose attribution is still unknown.

Business of all kinds will read with relief the decision of the Democratic leaders in the House of Representatives to ban retroactive taxation and to balance the budget with a non-partisan levy. This announcement, made after a Ways and Means meeting yesterday, attended also by Speaker GARNER, tends to confirm the growing impression that the House majority is conservative, responsible and wise.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Jackie Fields, 26-year-old Chicagoan, now making his home in Los Angeles, tonight regained the world's welterweight championship he lost to Young Jack Thompson two years ago by defeating Lou Brouillard, rugged French-Canadian youth of Worcester, Mass., in a savage ten-round battle in the Chicago Stadium.

Novel features in the design of huge electrical transformers that have enabled them to withstand surges of artificial lightning three times more explosive and destructive than that of any natural lightning recorded so far, were described yesterday before the annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

Expressing general agreement only on the point that there are more ills in the book business than the common one of lack of cash customers, 1,417 readers of the Saturday Review of Literature have answered a questionnaire and written comments to tell what they consider wrong.

An estate of $6,511,971, after payment of debts and expenses, was left by George F. Morgan, president of Enoch Morgan's Sons Company, manufacturer of Sapolio, it was shown in the appraisal of his estate filed yesterday with the State Tax Commission.

Further steps toward a strike of 35,000 workers in the garment Industry of this area were taken yesterday with the announcement by union officials of a referendum to be taken at a mass meeting of workers next Thursday at Mecca Temple. This matter was presented to the members of the executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union at their quarterly meeting in the Hotel Taft.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 -- A recital of Negro exaltations and folksongs of the Kentucky Mountains was given this afternoon at the Everglades Club by Marion Kerby and John Jacob Niles before a gathering of prominent colonists.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Selling of July wheat by houses with Eastern connections failed today to have a last-minute effect on new-crop deliveries on the Board of Trade here, and the distant future went to a premium on the May for the first time this season, while the September was 1 7/8 cents above the May at the last.

J.P. Kell of Topeka, Kan., owner of 2,700 shares of capital stock of the Prairie Pipe Line Company, has sent a letter to several hundred of the company's largest stockholders suggesting the formation of a stockholders' committee to protest the terms arranged for the merger of that concern with the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Hoover today took another major step in his reconstruction program by bringing about an agreement to speed up alterations of the banking law and relief for the depositors in closed banks. The development was described as "an effort to bring two schools of thought together."

The business of bringing baseball players into the fold for the 1932 season moved along at a brisk pace yesterday when the three local major league clubs announced that five signed contracts had been received.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Mrs. Arthur Millea of Amawalk, N.Y., defeated Miss Bea Gottieb of New York City, runner-up in the qualifying round, by 4 and 3 in the semi-final round of the Miami-Biltmore women's championship over the Miami-Biltmore Country Club course today.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- In the recent report of the special advisory committee appointed by the Bank for International Settlements in accordance with the Young Plan there occur these solemn and arresting sentences:

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Before the announcement today that there would be no change in the bank rate there was some selling of British Government funds on the Stock Exchange. A better tendency developed in the afternoon, although closing prices were lower on the day, with conversion 3 1/2 per cent at u76 and of the war loan at u99 1/8.
Trading reported yesterday in the New Jersey metropolitan area was confined almost exclusively to housing properties.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 28 -- A serious political duel, not without its amusing side, is being conducted in the press concerning the situation in Rumania. Since King Carol's return the newspaper Indreptarea, the organ of King Carol's old supporter, General Averescue, contained yesterday an article known to have been written by General Averescu himself.

From the treacly and decidedly moonstruck play, "Smilin' Through," which Jane Cowl, author, wrote considerably more than ten years ago for the uses of Jane Cowl, actress, Vincent Youmans has fashioned another of his Broadway baby-operas.
Names of three members of the Stock Exchange who proposed recently to sell their memberships at prices ranging from $132,000 to $150,000 were announced yesterday by the Exchange.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 29 -- Dealing with reports from Harbin, Manchuria, where it was reported Japanese troops had been sent from Changchun because of fighting between Chinese factions, a Rengo (Japanese) news agency dispatch from Changchun today reported that Chinese had burned a section of the Sungari River bridge south of Harbin.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The citizens and taxpayers of New York should appreciate the service which Controller Berry has rendered in his presentation of a six-year summary of the city finances, tax-rates and assessed valuations. This makes available to us less than a month after the close of the year a complete picture of the city's operations during 1931.

The geographical social centre of New York City for 1932 has been determined by the Social Register Association at a point between Seventy-first and Seventy-second Streets and Madison and Park Avenues, it was announced yesterday.
The building at 589-91 Fulton Street at the junction of Flatbush Avenue Extension, has been leased by the Du Flon Estate to the Atlantic Nut Products, Inc. Rice Hill were the brokers.

Albert Edward Ransome, the young Canadian tenor, remembered as a romantic and commanding figure at his debut in a Metropolitan "Trovatore" a season or two ago, and recently heard again with the opera stars in a Sunday concert program, gave an interesting and enjoyable recital last evening at the Town Hall.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Lady Broadcast, the 6-year-old daughter of Messenger and Couscous, which was a top flight performer in stake company last year, proved an easy winner of the Pan-American Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today. She bore the colors of Herbert M. Woolf who recently purchased her at the dispersal of the Rogers Caldwell string.

Not a Sucess. Two Americans temporarily in Jamaica write to THE TIMES enclosing the same editorial from The Daily Gleaner of Kingston, the issue being that of Jan. 19. One of our correspondents writes that as "a patriotic American citizen it makes my blood boil when such slander against us is indulged in by the oldest and only daily printed in this colony."

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 28 -- M. Paul Claudel, the French poet who is Ambassador to the United States, has written a book which he describes as "a poetic drama of human destiny and spiritual salvation," entitled "The Satin Slipper," publication of which was announced today by the Yale University Press.

An effort is being made to bring Phar Lap, the Australian champion, now on the Pacific Coast, to New York. This became known yesterday when Henry C. Pebler, racing secretary at Aqueduct, stated that he had taken steps with a view of getting Phar Lap as a competitor in the Brooklyn Handicap.

Two hundred pier workers who left their positions at Pier 33, in Brooklyn, on Tuesday night when the Grace Line announced that they must accept a wage reduction of 15 cents an hour remained away from their posts yesterday. At the offices of the International Longshoremen's Association, 265 West Fourteenth Street, Joseph P. Ryan, chairman, kept in touch with the situation through union agents stationed at the pier.

The weekly Federal Reserve report, published yesterday, showed a continuance of the trend of recent weeks. There was a further contraction of $9,000,000 in the amount of Reserve Bank credit outstanding, despite the invitation to member banks to avail themselves more freely of central bank credit facilities: money in circulation again showed a less than seasonal decline and monetary gold stocks of the country dropped $24,000,000 to a total of $4,426,000,000.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 28 -- The eleventh annual Texas open golf tournament took on an Oriental flavor today as Tomeskichi Miyamoto, open champion of Japan, and Tom Rue, San Antonio amateur, won the amateur-pro event with a low best ball of 32 -- 32 -- 64.

Figures for December and the twelve months of 1931 continued to reflect the decline in railroad income. The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific and the St. Louis Southwestern reported net losses after taxes and charges for 1931. The Central of Georgia reported an operating deficit in December, and substantial reductions in net operating income for the month were reported by other companies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me the privilege of a tribute to Charles Kittredge Crane, whose sudden death at his home in Los Angeles is a source of personal sorrow to me. It is a fact within my own knowledge that he was the best-informed person in the United States on the subject of the international traffic in narcotic drugs.

The College of the City of New York will offer two courses for teachers and others interested in the instruction of adult foreign-born in the public evening schools. Sessions will he held in the Commerce Building. Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street, beginning Feb. 4. The Instructor for both courses will be Samuel J. Brown, principal of Evening School 32. Manhattan.

A large volume or leasing for business purposes yesterday approached record proportions. Brokers and renting agents continued to close contracts for space in Manhattan business buildings at an even faster pace than that set earlier in the week.

The eighth volume of the Dictionary of American Biography is published today, including the lives of the influential men and women of every occupation in the making of the United States in the alphabetical bracket between the names of Frederick Grinnell, inventor of the automatic fire sprinkler, and Freeborn Garretson Hibbard, Methodist minister and author.

Chairman STONE estimates that the Government would lose "not in excess of $250,000,000" if the affairs of the Federal Farm Board should now be liquidated. Is there any good reason why they should not be? The Farm Board's efforts to "stabilize " prices with funds provided by the taxpayer are a demonstrated failure.

HARBIN, Friday, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Japanese troops were imminently expected in Harbin today and it was understood that after their arrival the branch line of the Chinese Eastern Railway running to Changchun would be operated by Japanese train crews.

The Public Service Commission of New York approved yesterday the petitions of the New York Edison Company, the Brooklyn Edison Company and the United Electric Light and Power Company for permission to issue $25,000,000 each of twenty-year 5 per cent gold mortgage bonds, of which $50,000,000 are for public sale.

R.D. Elwell, Norman Cohn, Tracy Jaeckel, Lieutenant G. Heiss and Hugo Alessandroni of the Fencers Club brought distinction to that organization last night by winning half of the places in the preliminary qualifying round of the New York division for the national junior epee championship held at the New York Athletic Club.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The government received a new hint from British business leaders today that in making tariff agreements with the dominions it must not forget Britain's customers outside the empire.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Authorities of the International Settlement lodged a protest with United States Consul General Cunningham this afternoon in which they charged Japanese naval officials with violating the neutrality of the International Settlement "continuously."

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Jan. 30. -- Japanese military authorities announced at 9 o'clock this morning that Chinese reinforcements had made it necessary for them to execute a partial withdrawal movement to the east toward the North Szechuan Road, which is the base of Japanese operations outside the International Settlement.

Israel Lewis, who holds a mortgage for $11,900 on 138 West Sixty-third Street, has agreed with the fee owner, the Etcar Realty Corporation, that in consideration of the latter conveying this property to the Narem Realty Corporation the mortgage will be so modified that the Etcar Realty Corporation will be released from any personal liability thereunder, and no deficiency Judgment will be entered against it.

The net asset value of common stock of the Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland, after deducting required coverage for bonds and preferred stock, was $4.45 a share, comparing with $9.75 at the end of the preceding year, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Otto Jochman, 44 years old, of 4,282 Park Avenue, the Bronx, was found guilty at midnight last night of manslaughter in the first degree by a jury in Justice Albert Cohn's part of the Supreme Court. He had been on trial for murder in the first degree in the fatal shooting of his friend, Louis Jensen, 26, of Hoboken, N.J., whose body was found in a trunk in Jochman's room.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 29. -- The estate of Mrs. Emily Lefferts Jones of Manhattan and Huntington has been appraised at $1.830,860 gross and $1,644,169 net. Bequests are made to ten grandchildren, other relatives, three sons-in-law and employes.

BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- Japan's attack on Shanghai on the eve of the Geneva disarmament conference is greatly agitating German political opinion, which fears that unless the League of Nations now acts at once and with the greatest vigor the conference is doomed, and, in any case, already damaged, since everywhere the argument for a nation's arming as its sole protection against violence will draw support.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 30. -- A Japanese armored train proceeding to Harbin, Manchuria, with troops was derailed at 8 o'clock last night in marshy ground, where the engine and a car containing guns are sinking. The remainder of the train, including the coach in which General Hasebe was traveling, is safe.

PARIS, Jan. 29. -- The Lucile Paray fashion offerings show a strong Directoire influence in high waistlines, in upper puff sleeves on long light undersleeves, in epaulette evening sleeves and are in general slim cut and fit. Sixteenth century Renaissance influence also is seen in padded tuke or twist sleeve mountings and in jackets which are like buttoned jerkins.

College teams again feature the indoor polo play in metropolitan armories tonight. At Squadron A Armory in Manhattan the brilliant Yale trio will meet Los Kanduces, led by Gerard S. Smith, the nine-goal Brooklyn star, and at Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, the Pennsylvania Military College will engage the Squadron C trio.
SAN DIEGO, Cal., Jan. 29 (AP). -- Perfecting of a forty-pound radio which is capable of receiving and broadcasting the human voice has given ears and voice to the speedy little army pursuit planes.

The adaptation, of modern architecture to the housing problem of persons of moderate means was illustrated in two models shown privately yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art, 730 Fifth Avenue, to a group interested in better city living conditions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The nominations of Robert L. O'Brien of Massachusetts to be chairman of the Tariff Commission and of Ira M. Ornburn of Connecticut as a members of the board were favorably reported to the Senate today by its Finance Committee.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- It's a far cry from the "belly-flops" of boyhood days, on a home-made sled down the nearest hill, to the grown-up pastime of bob-sledding. But the men who go in for it, Winter Olympic athletes of eight nations, swear it is the ultimate in thrills.

Supreme Court Justice Peter A. Hatting adjudged State Senator John A. Hastings in contempt of the Hofstadter committee yesterday after noon and sentenced him to thirty days' imprisonment in the county jail.

James Monroe Hewlett, past president of the Architectural League of New York, was the guest of honor at a dinner given by the league last night to mark his recent appointment as resident director of the American Academy in Rome.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- District Attorney Frank H. Coyne assigned today his first assistant, Walter A. Ferris, to investigate the absence of $20,000 from the town accounts of Mamaroneck and the reported disappearance of George Johnson, 32 years old, of 165 Harmon Drive, deputy receiver of taxes.

Premier Laval's visit to the United States and the presence of illustrious Frenchmen at the Yorktown celebrations were events of great importance in cementing Franco-American friendship, Ambassador Paul Claudel declared yesterday at the annual luncheon of the French Chamber of Commerce at the Hotel Delmonico.

On the theory that the Radio City development is an American project and that "opportunity to decorate the wall space of these buildings should be given to American artists," the board of control of the Art Students' League of New York issued a protest yesterday against the reported plan to employ foreign artists for this decorative work.

SAN PEDRO, Cal., Jan. 29 (AP). -- The United States fleet, sailing just after midnight Sunday for Hawaii for manoeuvres, will be "fully prepared for any contingency," Admiral Richard H. Leigh, battle force commander, said today in denying the situation resulting from the Japanese attack on Shanghai would alter naval plans.

Extra policemen were assigned to the neighborhood of Pier 33, Brooklyn yesterday to act in any emergency caused by the walk-out of union pier workers who left the employ of the Grace Steamship Lines rather than accept a wage reduction of fifteen cents an hour.

Engineering awards throughout the country during the week ended yesterday total $22,573,000, as compared to $16,959,000 for the preceding week, Engineering News-Record reports. The past week's total compares with a valuation of $37,035,000 for contracts awarded in the seven-day period ended Jan. 29, 1931.

In settings reminiscent of the old regime the annual Russian Students' Ball was held last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the Russian Students Christian Association. The net proceeds will aid unemployed students and graduates of American universities.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- Sears, Roebuck Co., mail-order and chainstore organization, earned its dividend during 1931, the second year of depression, according to the annual report issued today by General R.E. Wood, president of the company.

PARIS. Jan. 29. -- Events in Shanghai failed to produce any serious impression on the Bourse here today. although the market relapsed into almost complete inactivity. Some of the French industrials maintained their positions, but the majority of the leaders closed with moderate losses.

Butter. Receipts, 12,145 packages. The market ruled easy yesterday, and with prices no more than barely sustained the immediate outlook is uncertain. Trading slackened sharply at Thursday morning's advance, and most holders are following a free selling policy In the effort to effect as good a clearance as possible.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP). -- The song of the riveter was heard in Symphony Hall today and a distinguished audience applauded in general delight, for it was the premiere of George Gershwin's Second Rhapsody.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 29. -- Governmental activity relating to balanced budgets was discussed at the opening session of the annual meeting of the board of governors of the Investment Bankers' Association of America here tonight.

Except for a short interval of ease in the outside market, where 2 1/4 per cent was made on call loans, against 2 1/2 on the Stock Exchange, there was no other feature to the market. Both bank and house money in good volume accounted for the concession in the Street trading.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Marion Sims Wyeth entertained tonight with a dinner and bridge at Trefontane, their villa in Singer Place. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Peter H.B. Frelinghuysen, Mr. and Mrs. George A. McKinlock, their house guest, Mrs. Joseph T. Ryerson and Paul Moore.

The forces of the Curtis Institute of Music came from Philadelphia to give a concert at Carnegie Hall last night. Fritz Reiner, who was here earlier in the week with the Philadelphia Orchestra, conducted the Curtis Symphony Orchestra of about 100 players in the first half of the program that included Weber's "Oberon" overture, Brahms's Fourth symphony and the first movement of Tchaikovsky's B-flat minor concerto with Jorge Bolet as piano soloist.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial calling attention to the different type of driver noticed at the wheels of New York taxicabs tells only half the story. While some credit should be given to the unemployment situation, which has provided a wider range of selection for the taxicab operating companies, the larger part of the result was brought about by the management of the companies themselves.

Dewey Albinson, formerly head of the painting department at the St. Paul School of Art in Minneapolis, has been spending several years in Italy and returns to show, at the Delphic Studios, some of the work he has recently done, for the most part in Abruzzi and along the Adriatic.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 29 (AP). -- A resolution seeking to curb "the evil of the use of injunctions" and asking the Illinois miners to obtain a dissolution of an injunction restraining the international officers from interfering with District 12 was debated at length today at the biennial convention of the United Mine Workers.

The Treasury Department's monthly report of the general stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of Jan. 1 shows the following principal changes during December. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added:

Large economies in cost and time will be effected for shippers or less-than-carload freight when the Inland Freight Terminal at Eighth Avenue and Sixteenth Street is completed, officials of the Port of New York Authority told the workers on that building during the craftsmanship exercises held there yesterday under the auspices of the New York Building Congress.
While former Governor Alfred E. Smith sat in Homicide Court yesterday morning a charge of homicide against his 22-year-old son, Walter J. Smith, was dismissed.

Plans have been completed by the Junior League Committee of the Charity Organization Society for a benefit dinner dance to be given on the night of Feb. 5 in the ballroom of the New York Junior League. The net proceeds will be used to aid in the relief work of that society.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- Governor Roosevelt Issued a proclamation today calling upon needy persons of the State to take advantage of unemployment relief. In effect, the Governor urged that pride should not be allowed to stand In the way of application for help.

Frances Mann, pianist, who has played several recitals here this season, appeared again last night at Steinway Hall in a program which she played in a sure and sympathetic style. She was warmly applauded by an audience that filled the small hall.

Carl Fischer, Inc., and Leo Feist, Inc., music-publishing companies which were taken over two years ago by the Radio Music Company, a subsidiary of the National Broadcasting Company, have repurchased their stock holdings in the radio organization and will again function on an independent basis, according to an announcement yesterday.

The time has passed when the United States can do anything about Japan's intentions in Manchuria, according to Charles K. Moser, chief of the Far Eastern section, division of regional information, United States Department of Agriculture. He expressed that view in an address on Manchuria yesterday at a luncheon of the Eastern Regional Savings Conference sponsored by the savings division of the American Bankers' Association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Judge Donnellan of General Sessions handed down a decision yesterday denying the motion of Martin Conboy, as counsel for Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, for a bill of particulars on the misdemeanor indictment accusing Mr. Broderick of having failed to enforce the State banking laws in connection with the collapse of the Bank of United States.

A suit for $200,000 damages against the New York Academy of Medicine and Dr. Sidney D. Leader was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by attorneys for Mrs. Diana Zanger of 1,025 Gerard Avenue, the Bronx. Mrs. Zanger charged that improper diagnosis and improper administration of the infantile paralysis "immune serum" were responsible for the death of her son, Marvin Zanger, on Aug. 26.

Encouraged by the returns of almost $75,000 toward the Musicians' Emergency Aid fund of $300,000, the members of the campaign committees continued their efforts yesterday through the headquarters of the organization at 113 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29. -- Albert R. Hakes, schoolboy star of Dunkirk, N.Y., lost to William B. Langford, Chicago veteran, in the final of the annual Lake Worth tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club course today. Hakes led by 1 up at the end of the morning round, but putted badly throughout the day, Langford finally taking the match by 2 up.
Manhattan's rejuvenated quintet easily defeated the Rensselaer Poly Institute five of Troy, N.Y., 32 -- 17 at the Manhattan gymnasium, last night.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Jan. 29. -- An investigation has been ordered by Governor James R. Beverley into a letter, photastatic copies of which have been widely circulated by the nationalist elements here, in which Dr. Cornelius P. Rboads, an associate of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, is alleged to have admitted that he had killed eight Porto Ricans and had infected others with cancer.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29. -- Colonel Charles F.H. Johnson, president of the Botany Worsted Mills at Passaic, N.J., told the Philadelphia Wool and Textile Association today that the anti-trust laws strengthened already powerful buyers and prevented sellers from effecting essential organization.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 29. -- Joe Kirkwood, Philadelphia golf professional, neglected his celebrated trick shots today long enough to shoot six birdies for a 34, 36-70, one under par. The score was good enough to lead the $2,500 Texas open field at the end of the first eighteen holes of the seventy-two-hole tourney.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 29. -- The Nassau County Bar Association adopted tonight a resolution offered by Frederic R. Coudert of Oyster Bay, affirming "its belief in the necessity for the prompt adherence of the United States to the Permanent Court of International Justice" and urging upon the Senate "the prompt ratification of the protocol submitted by the President to that end."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The heavy weight of ninety years which finally forced Oliver Wendell Holmes from the bench has not succeeded in diminishing his keen, if philosophical interest in life.

Senator Seabury C. Mastick, chairman of the New York State Commission for the Revision of Tax Laws, told members of the "Women's National Republican Club yesterday that he expected to present his report to the Legislature on Monday evening.

It comes as a surprise at first that the national wealth of the United States at the end of 1930, as estimated by the Industrial Conference Board, was less than 9 per cent down from the preceding year. The slump as measured on the Stock Exchange was obviously much sharper than that.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some of the opponents of war as m instrument of national policy, including those whose opposition is based on extreme pacifist principles, have been lightly suggesting the use of the boycott enforced by governmental action, as If it were a weapon to which no objection could be made on pacifist grounds.

Many native Southerners, now residents of New York, were in the throng that attended the annual Blue Ridge Ball last night in the ballroom suite of the Plaza. It was for the benefit of the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Green County, Va., which gives training to mountaineer children and which is situated near the Summer camp of President Hoover at Rapidan.

ALBANY. Jan. 29. -- Mayor Curley of Boston spent two Hours here today in conference with Governor Roosevelt and afterwards announced that the Governor had authorized the entry of his name in the Presidential primaries in Massachusetts on April 28.

Twelve miles north-by-east of Columbus lies that Ohio town of power and magic, the capital of prohibition, the master once of American destinies. That man has an anesthetic zone whose heart doesn't beat faster at the name of Westerville. There were forged the thunders of the Anti-Saloon League that scared Congress and the Legislatures into the Eighteenth Amendment.

Public offerings of new bond issues this week aggregated $42,518,130, compared with $107,401,000 last week when the $100,000,000 New York City 6 per cent three to five-year special corporate stock notes were marketed. This week's total does not include the $25,000,000 of 4% per cent notes, due on May 1, which New York State sold to a group of fifteen banking houses and banks and was not reoffered to the public.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 29. -- After differences of opinion developed today at the special meeting of the Republican State Committee to determine the party's position at the Presidential convention and to consider candidates for delegates, action was deferred until Feb. 26.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Jan. 29. -- Seventy-seven men were graduated from the Army Signal School short-term courses at the post here this morning in the War Department Theatre.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 29 (AP). -- The hope "that I'll be able to do a good Job," was Wilson McCarthy's response today to information that he had been named as a director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

MORRISTOWN. N.J., Jan. 29. -- Princeton University la the chief j beneficiary under the will of Paul Guenther, hosiery manufacturer of Dover, which was filed today. After making specific bequests of about $1,000,000 to other individuals and institutions, the will bequeaths the residue to the university.

Mayor Walker signed yesterday the local law creating a Board of Taxicab Control with broad regulatory powers. His action was taken just within the legal limit of thirty days after the public hearing over which he presided on Dec. 30.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. G. Harlan Miller, who had been at Whimsy Farm, their country place in Arlington, Vt., are at the Pierre until they sail for their home in Paris.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- American foreign trade by grand divisions last year was as follows:

MOSCOW, Jan. 29. -- Pravda's "flying brigade" continues its sharpshooting against the huge new agricultural machinery factory, Rostof, whose shortcomings the brigade began to expose a fortnight ago. Today's report states that production at the plant during the second ten days in January averaged only 20 per cent of the program because of failure to receive necessary parts.

HONOLULU, Jan. 29. -- Pending the receipt of official word from Washington concerning the stipulations made by Circuit Judge A.M. Cristy on the bail of Mrs. Granville Fortesque. Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and two seamen, E.J. Lord and Albert O. Jones, the four prisoners were temporarily turned over to the custody of the Honolulu police after their arraignment this morning.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29. -- The five-yrear-old gelding Pop Gaffney, a inaiden up to the end of last year, seems headed for an unusual 1932 career, for he now has won his three starts this year, the third coming in the McKinley Claiming Handicap, Hialeah Park feature this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Political developments this week have convinced President Hoover's supporters that whatever slight possibility for serious opposition to his renomination may have existed previously has now disappeared.

A last-minute move by labor union officials to compose the differences between their organization and the Building Trades Employers' Association over proposed wage reductions appeared likely yesterday.

Political gossip from Pennsylvania -- by no means verified-is that two of the three leaders in Democratic circles of that State may unite for Governor ROOSEVELT. In that event he would have more than half the delegation in the national convention.
To the Editor of The Kew York Times: The British movie critic quoted in THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial is far from being a pioneer in his thinking, however meritorious his place may be.
Commercial paper. Yesterday -- 31/4 to 4 per cent for the beat names.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 29. -- Members of his family, friends and neighbors of Gov. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt gathered tonight in the auditorium of the high school here to wish him Godspeed on the journey to the Philippine Islands which he will begin with Mrs. Roosevelt on Monday.

ROME, Jan. 29. -- Porto Danzio, on the coast, forty miles southwest of Rome, is again the scene of the recovery of a precious art work of archaeological interest. A short time ago a remarkably fine statuary group of the Roman period was found there.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 29. -- Onlookers thronged the roof tops of the sky-scrapers and other buildings in Shanghai's business section through-out the day to watch the Chapel area, over which Japanese airplanes roared every twenty minutes, releasing bombs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- Bullish sentiment was in the ascendancy on the Board of Trade here today as the result of reports of temperatures below zero in parts of Kansas and fears that the cold weather would work into the States east of the Mississippi, where the growth of Winter wheat has been unusually advanced for this season.
MEMPHIS, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Flood victims in Arkansas, Mississippi and Louisiana encountered a new hardship tonight -- cold weather.
The Fordharn Prep basketball team triumphed over Brooklyn Prep, 27 to 13, on the loser's court in Brooklyn yesterday. McNally led both teams in scoring with ten points.

PARIS, Jan. 29. -- Severe criticism was launched today in the Chamber of Deputies against the condition of French military and civil aviation, in which it was charged by several speakers that France was ill-prepared to meet sudden aggression from the air.

The 106th anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York, held at the Hotel Commodore last night, was replete with military pomp in features commemorating the George Washington bicentennial. Leading the midnight parade, which was viewed for the first time in 1826 in this city by Governor De Witt Clinton and Mayor William Paulding as well as veterans of the War of 1812, was a color guard dressed in Continental uniform.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Cleveland's wheels of industry were turning faster today than at any time in this district since the holidays.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The international situation at Shanghai was considered much improved today after Great Britain had promised to cooperate with the United States Government for the safeguarding of international rights in the International Settlement.
TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 30. -- The government is not yet officially informed that the League Council had decided to act under Article XV of the covenant.

The Committee on Civic Affairs of the New York Congregational Church Association will present a report on what it considers the duty of the churches to be, in the light of the Seabury report, to try to reform the government of the city at the annual dinner of the association Tuesday evening in the Hotel McAlpin.

TOPEKA, Ran., Jan. 29. -- The Kansas Republican Central Committee today endorsed the administration of President Hoover and Vice President Curtis and pledged its support for their renomination and re-election.

The war for gold, for political power through wealth, that followed the World War brought on the "economic calamity" of the present, Paul Einzig, British authority on world finance, writes in his new book, "Behind the Scenes of International Finance."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Federal Power Commission today announced its decision denying an application by the city of Lockport, N.Y., to divert 275 cubic feet of water a second from the Niagara River for experiments in developing hydroelectric power.

Stocks were depressed rather sharply in the first three or four hours of trading yesterday, but they reversed their course abruptly in mid-afternoon and retraced a good part of the ground which they had lost in the morning. Except for a dozen or so issues which lagged in the partial recovery, the net declines were less than a point on the average.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 29. -- In a spectacular game, the Polish Olympic hockey team bowed to the Walbrook Club of Baltimore, 4 to 3, tonight. Aleksander Kowalski and Albert Mauer were forced from the contert with injuries. It is feared that Kowalski may not be able to play in the Olympic Games.

Price movement in commodities was higher yesterday, the advance in contract grains in the Chicago market lifting cash positions here up sharply. Eggs and cotton in the spot market, and coffee, sugar and cocoa all moved higher. Slight losses were recorded in copper, tin, rubber and hides. Silk was firm.
Jim McNally's field goal in a three-minute extra period enabled La Salle Academy's basketball team to defeat Cathedral Boys High by 21 -- 19 at Goddard gymnasium yesterday.
AREPORT of sights and sounds on the Ranger bench while the bruising Bruins were hammering home four goals and skating off with a victory over Lester Patrick's platoon on Thursday night at the Garden:

VINELAND, N.J., Jan. 29. -- The Dias Clothing Factory in the centre of the business district here at Seventh and Quince Streets was held up today by two masked gunmen who escaped with the weekly payroll of $2,181.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Gus Copulos of Eugene, Ore., shot his way into the running for the world's three-cushion billiard championship today, racking up his fifth straight victory, while Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., ten-time holder of the title, was virtually eliminated from championship consideration.

J. Howard Shoemaker of the New York Athletic Club, defending champion, and Robert Cole, former champion, won the two matches played yesterday in the national amateur pocket billiard championship tournament in progress at the New York Lodge of Elks under the auspices of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 29. -- A committee of six, appointed by the Nassau County Clearing House Association, will begin a survey next week of all funds In county, State and national financial Institutions as a means of promoting stability among the member banks of the association.

Chief Magistrate McDonald announced yesterday the shifting of sixty-one assistant court clerks and court attendants in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. It was the third shift of that magnitude he had directed since he took office last April 28.

To the Editor of The New York Times: All of the New York papers have for months been carrying reports of the Seabury investigation of New York City government and so-called Tammany rule. I am not calling into question the propriety of such an investigation, nor am I disposed to impeach the sincerity of the motives underlying the inception of the Hofstadter committee.

Henry L. Stevens Jr., National Commander of the American Legion, declared last night at a military review of the old Thirteenth Regiment of Brooklyn that the National Guard was now the first line of defense and that the regular army had been reduced to a group of "highly trained technicians."

The flurry of business leasing that kept real estate brokers busy since Monday failed yesterday to maintain the pace it set earlier in the week. There was a corresponding dullness in other branches of trading during the day, which provided a few transactions.

OTTAWA, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's adverse balance of trade, from which the country emerged a few months ago, "was alone caused by the tariff policy of the United States," Harry H. Stevens, Minister of Trade and Commerce, said today.

Receipts of crude and refined oils from California at Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports in 1931 amounted to 17,836,000 barrels, a daily average of 49,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compares with 25,643,000 barrels, a daily average of 70,000 barrels in 1930.

Commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Leake and Watts Orphan House and as a benefit for that institution, a large supper dance and entertainment called the Century Ball was held last night in the ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. Under the sponsorship of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the Governor, and a large group of patrons and patronesses, the event enlisted many younger members of society who had been active for weeks in preparations.

Interest in this country in broadcasts of literary criticism must be slight compared to the enthusiasm on the subject in England. A certain amount of time on the air is here devoted to talks about books, often by competent critics with wide experience in writing for newspapers and magazines.
The National Motor Boat Show will close its twenty-seventh annual session at the Grand Central Palace tonight. The hours will be from 10:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. today, "national review day."

A group of musical compositions, books and copyrights owned by the late Albert Teres, which his executors valued at $100,000, was claimed after his death by a man who said he bought them for $250, it was disclosed yesterday in a decision handed down by Surrogate Wingate in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 29. -- The first application to borrow money from the Railroad Credit Corporation under the marshaling and distributing plan was filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway Company.

Max Baer, California heavyweight, battered his way to a decision over King Levinsky, hard-swinging Chicagoan, in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night with an exhibition of strong and steady rib punching. A crowd of 11,000 attended, receipts being estimated at $31,000.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- The suspension of eight bobsleighers, including the chairman of the American Olympic Bobsleigh Committee and four other members of the United States squad, caused a stir of excitement in this quiet little village today.

Although various reasons were assigned for the late rally yesterday on the Stock Exchange, the most likely explanation, it seemed to Wall Street, was that stocks responded to the demonstration of strength in grain. The share market made only a partial recovery, but it managed to shake off the reactionary influences that had governed it earlier in the day.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29. -- The Foreign Office tonight Issued a communique about the interview of Japanese Ambassador Kokl Hirota with Vice Commissar Karakhan, which established the following three points:

"Tree sparrow" is a thankless name to fob off on so genial a bird. Like "ground sparrow" and "house sparrow," it is almost a term of opprobrium, especially for a bird that is not much given to perching in trees. The tree sparrow deserves our gratitude.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- The British and United States Governments are much closer together tonight in the matter of Shanghai than they were wenty-four hours ago. Perhaps it is no exaggeration to say they now are in complete accord.

GENEVA, Jan. 29. -- Declaring her dispute with Japan was now likely to lead to a rupture, China took the grave step today of forcing the Council of the League of Nations to act under some of the obligatory provisions of the covenant in addition to the conciliatory procedure which hitherto has confined It to action to which both parties consented.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP). -- The House Judiciary Committee set Feb. 15 today for the consideration of legislation to regulate short selling and invited Richard S. Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, to testify.

Men holding emergency jobs with the Emergency Work Commission received assurance of payment for February when the Board of Estimate approved at a special meeting yesterday the allotment of $2,326,849 requested by the commission from the $8,000,000 appropriation voted by the Board of Estimate earlier in the week for emergency work.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 30. -- After watching the Shanghai battle from a roof top, from which he was dislodged by machine gun bullets, the correspondent of The Daily Express telegraphs:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- In an effort to block trafficking in radio facilities, the Federal Radio Commission adopted today a new general order requiring that all applications for assignment of broadcasting station licenses be accompanied by a sworn statement containing detailed information concerning the assets which are to be transferred and the actual cost of replacements.

Dates for the Eastern and national outboard motor boat championships were set and many new rules were adopted yesterday at a meeting of the racing commission of the National Outboard Association, held in connection with the Motor Boat Show.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- A bill to impose a 1 per cent sales tax on luxuries was introduced today by Senator Thomas F. Burchill, Democrat, of New York, who declared it would not only increase the State's revenue but would lighten the "growing burden of taxation on real estate."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Prince Farthing, a promising son of Dunlin, which disappointed often as a 2-year-old last year, scored his first 3-year-old victory today when he carried the silks of Joseph Leiter home first in the Crystal Springs Purse at the Fair Grounds.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 29. -- "Japan's next war will be for the mastery of the Pacific, which means war against America," according to Eugene Chen, three times China's Foreign Minister. Even as he spoke, in the drawing room of his house in the French concession, Japanese planes droned overhead and Japanese and Chinese forces battled for Chapei, a few miles away.

Between 1,400 and 1,800 members of Van Drivers and Packers' Local 814, with headquarters at 265 West Fourteenth Street, were locked out yesterday by the Van Owners' Association of Greater New York, with offices at 144 Columbus Avenue, as the result of a dispute over a 10 per cent wage reduction.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29. -- Faltering on only one hole, when he hooked a drive off the fairway in the afternoon round, T. Philip Ferkins of New York, former British amateur champion, defeated Winfield S. Day of Chicago, by 7 to 5 in the final of the Miami Beach tournament over the course of the La Gorce Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- How the Japanese movements in Shanghai led to battle was described In a series of official dispatches to the Navy Department today from Colonel Richard S. Hooker, who is in command of the Fourth Regiment of Marines at Shanghai.

PASADENA, Cal., Jan. 29. -- Proof that space is curved and that the universe is expanding and contracting in cycles must await additional observations by Mount Wilson Observatory astronomers of the apparent relationship of the velocity and distance of remote nebulae, Dr. Albert Einstein indicated tonight in "teaching" a class of more than 100 astromoners, physicists and mathematicians at the California Institute of Technology.

BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- In reply to the contention that a Germany without the burden of reparations would be economically stronger than other European nations, owing to its small internal indebtedness, the govern merit issued a statement tonight enumerating the reasons for the low internal debt of the Reich.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- General paresis, an organic disease of the brain which only a few years ago was regarded by the medical profession as a uniformly fatal malady, is now being arrested or cured in 90 per cent of the cases treated in St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Dr. William A. White, superintendent, reported today to Secretary Wilbur, under whose jurisdiction the hospital is operated.
Stocks were weaker yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange, but rallied in the last hour from the day's lows, closing moderately lower. Domestic bonds were easy and foreign bonds mixed.

Only two issues of more than $1,000,000 each are included in next week's schedule of State and municipal loans to be awarded. The total is only $12,261,882, compared with this week's revised total of $14,729,916 and with the average weekly total for the year to date of $14,057,962.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- After a two-and-a-half-hour joint session tonight devoted to considering a proposed compromise on the 10 per cent railway wage "deduction," the railroad presidents' committee of nine and the leaders of twenty standard unions adjourned until 10 o'clock tomorrow morning with matters "going along to a satisfactory conclusion."

Precision clocks and methods of time-measurement that can split the second into one hundred billion parts were described yesterday during the closing session of the annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers.

George Jean Nathan's book, "Some Friends of Mine," which Knopf had listed for publication this Spring, has been temporarily withdrawn from publication for rewriting and expansion. Mr. Nathan said yesterday that it probably would be published in the Fall as a 90,000-word book, its length at present being only 25,000 words.
ELMA, Manitoba, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Under cover of darkness an assassin moved through the farm home of Martin Sitar early today, dealing death to the farmer, his wife and seven of their children.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The tension of the present situation at Shanghai has served to create interest among munitions experts here in the large purchases by Japan of raw cotton in the United States, by which she has become the world's largest cotton buyer.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Governor Ritchie of Maryland tonight told the Ohio Bar Association that lawyers were the guardians of America's priceless liberty.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Rose Allen will be a neutral witness at the trial of her brother, Edward, for the killing of Francis A. Donaldson 3d, her close friend, she said today. She said through her attorney:

In a broadside attack on the authenticity of about 700 paintings in Europe and America attributed to Rembrandt, Dr. Frank Jewett Mather Jr., director of the Museum of Princeton University, Marquand Professor of Art and Archaeology in that institution and one of the country's leading art scholars, asserts in the current issue of Creative Art that "like any other heavily watered paper issue, the Rembrandt list will eventually shrink of itself to just proportions."
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Saving a Half Billion" is of more than passing interest, but why not pursue the thought further?

TOKYO, Jan. 29. -- The question of sending an expeditionary force to Shanghai, which was discussed by high officials of the General Staff today, remains in suspense pending the developments of the next twenty-four hours.

The most charitable theory of what happened at Shanghai is that the Japanese military command blundered sadly. The intention could not have been from the first to bomb a civil population in an unfortified city, and to leave burning houses and slaughtered natives as a kind of testimony to what the Chinese will call a burst of Japanese savagery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Suggestions on the part of naval officials to sell the airship Los Angeles, useless under the Versailles treaty as an instrument of War, were revealed today before the House Naval Committee, which is investigating charges that the airship Akron contains faulty materials.

Twenty submarines have foundered since 1904, not counting those sunk in war. None disappeared more mysteriously than the M-2. She was seen to slip stern first below the waves. After that -- silence. No men equipped with breathing masks floated to the surface, as a few did from the Poseidon, lost in the Yellow Sea.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 29. -- The Gettysburg five defeated Drexel's quintet tonight, 44 to 31.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The doubling of import duties by Sweden on importations of foreign motor cars will affect shipments of such vehicles from the United States to one of its foremost markets abroad. Exports to Sweden of American automobiles and trucks during the first eleven months of 1931 were valued at $5,649,882, of which passenger cars accounted for $3,902,753 and trucks $1,747,124.

Last Spring a group of architects sailed to pay an alumni visit to the Ecole des Beaux Arts in Paris. They chartered the liner American Farmer for the purpose. On the way home in June the conversation turned one day to the question of the Gulf Stream.

Domestic corporation bonds weakened on the Stock Exchange yesterday; foreign loans, particularly Japanese, were irregularly lower, but United States Government issues continued their upward trend. Although a long list of railroad bonds lost a point or more, public utility bonds made the poorest showing in the domestic group, more than a score of them moving into new low ground for the year.

About 600 shouting, angry persons gathered yesterday in front of 665 Allerton Avenue, in the Communist quarter of the Bronx, where a rent strike is in effect, and for a time it seemed as if there would be a repetition of last Friday's rioting, but three scheduled evictions were postponed until Monday because of the rain, and the crowd departed.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- Dr. Henry Spahlinger, who claims to have spent $500,000 in the discovery of a method of vaccination against tuberculosis, presented his long-held secret to a number of his financial supporters here today. Details of the formula, which were not given to newspaper men who attended the handing-over ceremony in Lady Seaforth's drawing room here tonight, were later sent to the Ministry of Health and leading medical and scientific bodies.

Insurance Company Is to Build $1,500,000 Offices on John St. Plans were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings for a twenty-five-story and penthouse office building at 91 to 101 John Street, 28 Gold Street and 1 to 13 Cliff Street at an estimated cost of $1,500,000.
A slight fog which blew in over the harbor about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon and gradually became denser, hampered port traffic and delayed the sailing of ocean liners.

HARBIN, Manchuria, Jan. 29 (AP). -- The possibility that Japan and Russia might come to grips over the operation of the Chinese Eastern Railway was envisaged tonight in view of the conflict between rival Chinese armies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Administration opposition to the decision of Democratic and Republican leaders in the House to abandon the retroactive feature of the proposed tax increases was voiced personally to Speaker Garner today by Ogden L. Mills, Under Secretary of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Fred A. Bradley will not run for re-election as Republican county chairman if he is confirmed for reappointment as customs collector at Buffalo, he has informed the Senate Finance Committee.
HAVANA, Jan. 29 (AP). -- After finishing fifth in each of his three starts here, the Pine Tree Stable's Honey Grove came back today to win the mile and one-sixteenth feature at Oriental Park.

The University Fencers Club placed three of the six men who qualified last night in the preliminary competition held at the New York A.C. for the metropolitan junior saber championship. The six came through from among twenty men who represented eight organizations.

George Washington's reputation rests upon his character rather than upon his skill as a General, Major Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, declared in an address last night at a Washington bicentennial celebration of the Third Masonic District Association of Manhattan, held at the Masonic Hall, 46 West Twenty-fourth Street.

Orders for seventy-four elevators, said to be the largest number ever planned for a single office building, have been placed by the Rockefeller interests for the central seventy-story unit in the midtown business and amusement centre popularly known as Radio City, the Metropolitan Square Corporation announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Europe bought more from the United States last year than did any of the other grand divisions, according to figures made public today by the Department of Commerce.

No "Serum Racket." The New York Academy of Medicine serves as a clearing house for information concerning public health matters. Municipal authorities, civic agencies, the medical profession and the public generally have come to look to it for advice and guidance.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, winner in the New York group of Class B in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League championship, completed its schedule last night with its eighth successive victory.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- Sterling was lower today in the leading foreign exchanges, which resulted in a setback in British Government funds. The New York rate was down to $3.46. The conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan fell to u75 1/2 and the war loan to u98 5/8.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 20 (AP). -- South Africa and Australia began their fourth-test cricket match today with the Springboks, scoring 265 runs for seven wickets when stumps were drawn for the day. Australia won the first three tests.
ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- The executive committee of the Governors' Conference will meet here on Feb. 6 to form a program for the annual meeting of State Executives in Richmond, Va., on April 25.

Despite a slightly better feeling In Industry and business generally, there are still few actual indications of any real improvement, according to the weekly reviews of business. They note a slight improvement in the employment situation, which, however, was limited chiefly to small Industrial plants.
