The News Syndicate Company, owner of the thirty-sixth-story News Building at 220 East Forty-second Street, announced yesterday that a system of ownership management supervised by Robert L. Parker will become effective next Monday. The building is reported to be 90 per cent occupied.

Little improvement was recorded in the bank clearings of the country last week over the preceding week and the loss compared with a year ago continues to be sharp, according to Dun's review. The total in twenty-two cities for the week was $4,684,750,000, or 37.1 per cent below the corresponding period in 1931.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 29. -- The City Commission placed before the policemen and firemen today a request that they accept a voluntary salary cut of 10 per cent, with a warning that hankers had advised that unless a cut of $2,000,000 were made in Newark's 1932 budget, the city might find it impossible to market its bonds and city employes might be paid in scrip.

The annual report of the Pennsylvania Water and Power Company for 1931 shows a net income, after taxes, charges and depreciation, amounting to $2,056,141, equal to $4.78 a share earned on 429,848 no par shares of capital stock, compared with $1,957,797, or $4.55 a share, in 1930, including $370,000 transferred from equalization reserve in that year.
STEUBENVILLE, O., Jan. 29 (AP). George Lindsey, 23 years old, killed Miss Winfred Bradford, 19, a senior in the high school at Mount Pleasant today in the presence of fellow students.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Miss Anne Washington of New York, niece of Dr. Walker Washington of Staten Island, a direct descendant of Augustine Washington, half-brother of George Washington, has arrived here to design the costumes for the George Washington Bicentennial Ball to be held Feb. 22 and the first presentation on the preceding night in Constitution Hall of the masque "Wakefield," written for the bicentennial celebration by Percy Mac-Kaye.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 29. -- Crew practice at Haivard will get under way Feb. 8, when the varsity, house and 350-pound varsity candidates report to Coaches Charles Whiteside, Ed Brown and Fred Sullivan at the Newell boat house.

John Golden, who has already made three Broadway productions this season, has engaged Frank Craven and Thomas Mitchell to appear in an as yet untitled play by Daniel N. Rubin. Rehearsals are scheduled to begin on Monday and the play is expected to open in New York late next month.

The first fifty-five railroads to report earnings for December showed net operating incomes of $21,123,000, against $40,231,000 in December, 1930, a drop of 47.4 per cent, and against $51,434,000 in December, 1929, a drop of 58.9 per cent. In November their net income was $23,600,000, against $44,214,000 in November, 1930, a decline of 46.6 per cent.

December dollar sales of reporting chain-store organizations in the New York Federal Reserve District averaged about 6 1/2 per cent smaller than in 1930, the Feb. 1 review of the Fedtral Reserve Bank of New York will say. Sales for 1931 declined 3 1/2 per cent from 1930.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- President Hoover today named Wilson McCarthy of Salt Lake City as the third Democratic director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, completing the board.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- An estate of at least $22,250,000 is disposed of in the will of William Wrigley Jr., which was filed in Probate Court today. Mr. Wrigley died Tuesday in Phoenix, Ariz. The bulk of the estate goes to the immediate family, with bequests and annuities for other relatives and business associates.

SHANGHAI, 11 A.M., Saturday, Jan. 30. -- A burst of Chinese shellfire at 6:45 this morning put an end to the truce arranged last night as the Chinese began firing into the Japanese end of the International Settlement.

BOSTON, Jan. 29. IN the Boston theatres the future outbids the present. That present consists, first, of "The Band Wagon," through two weeks filling the Colonial at every performance: second, of "The Good Companions," mistakenly continued at the Shubert for an additional week: third, of three of "those things" that depend upon contented customers telling their next friends all about it.

The American Federation of Labor made public yesterday a letter sent by William Green, its president, and other members of its legislative committee to Representative James W. Collier, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the House, in which they suggested that no reductions in exemptions or rate increases in the lower brackets be made in the income tax.

This much is certain in China: The Chinese people are back to 1896, back to the battle for concession, back before John Hay enunciated the open door policy. All the benefits of the revolution of 1911, or Sun Yat Senism, of the popular movements between 1919 and 1927, are wiped out.

OSLO, Jan. 10. IN his new play, "A Journey in the Night" ("En Reise i Natten"), the Norwegian dramatist Sigurd Christiansen, who writes only during leisure hours and continues to serve as a postal official in the little town of Drammen, has been remarkably successful in projecting and visualizing the tense inner drama of thoughts and feelings.

EDGAR WALLACE, who always has time for one more venture, took a few minutes off from his duties at the RKO studios and turned out an impression of Hollywood. The piece appeared in The London Daily Mail for Dec. 28, under the heading, "On the Spot in Hollywood."
MONTREAL, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadiens took a tighter hold on second place in the National Hockey League's international division tonight by defeating the Detroit Falcons, 4 to 3.

BOSTON, Jan. 30. -- Gene Venzke of the New York A.C. featured the annual Knights of Columbus meet at the Garden tonight when he won the Knights of Columbus mile in the sizzling time of 4:15 1-5, breaking the track record.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 30. -- Checking a determined second-half rally by the Providence College basketball team, the St. John's quintet of Brooklyn scored a spectacular 30-26 triumph tonight in a wellplayed game.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Arthur Thurnblad of Chicago, seeking his second world's three-cushion billiard championship, strengthened his title chances with a decisive triumph today.

NICE, Jan. 29. -- The French Riviera, that favorite playground of titled and wealthy folk, after its excellent Summer season, finds itself this Winter in a sorry plight for want of visitors. Two disasters, the so-called Wall Street collapse and the fall of the British pound, are held responsible for the fact that few Americans and English have visited the Azure Coast this year.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is no fairy godmother and has no cure-all for financial ills, but it will inevitably lift vast burdens from private finance and revive many a crippled business enterprise, according to an analysis of the new emergency organization by Louis B. Wehle, former general counsel of the War Finance Corporation, upon which the new relief agency is patterned.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28. -- What impresses foreigners most that come to the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics today, whether as visitors, as resident diplomats or engineers, is the fact that the Soviet leaders know precisely what they want and are doing it in sharp contrast to the rest of the world where leadership seems to be a lost art.

DETROIT. SIR DENNISTOUK BURNEY'S rear-engined car provided a field day for American automotive engineers assembled here for the annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers. Not a single feature of its design failed to prove of interest to those engineers who believe that this type of car is destined for development in this country.

CHICAGO., Jan. 30. -- Drastic write-offs and the setting up of reserves for possible losses are shown in the annual report issued today by Montgomery Ward Co., mail-order and chain-store merchandisers. Measured in dollars, sales declined last year with commodity prices, being $198,118,920, but they were exceeded only in the boom years, 1928 and 1929, and in 1930, when the total was $249,097,223.

An 11-year-old girl of Portuguese descent, who bears a striking resemblance to Lily Pons, won first place yesterday in the final contest for child voices at Ampico Hall, at which prominent members of the Metropolitan Opera Company were the judges.

THE central problem before the World Conference on Armaments, opening on Tuesday, will be the question of "security." The subsidiary problems turn upon the different methods of limitation which can be used to curtail land, air and naval forces in case the nations of the world are able to solve or to surmount this fundamental question.

ALTHOUGH the advantage of fire departments having apparatus and central stations equipped with radio are obvious, firemen have been slow to take it up. More than sixty cities have installed police radio, with the result that these organizations are more highly efficient than ever before.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 30. -- With the galleries packed with supporters of all parties who voiced constant interruptions, former President Bautista Saavedra read his defense in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday against charges of illegal acts during his administration, which began in 1921.

HAMBURG, Jan. 28 -- The necessity of trying to save international commercial intercourse in the face of irrational and regressive trade barriers being erected everywhere was emphasized at the recent annual meeting of the Hamburg Exporters' Association.

Steady buying was maintained in the wholesale markets throughout the week, and while buying allotments have shrunk, retailers are planning their stocks more cautiously, with the idea of making continuous purchases throughout the season, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

MONTREAL -- The snowshoe marathon starts from Quebec this morning with Montreal as its objective, a distance of 200 miles. The prizes total $4,000 and the race extends over the whole of this week, with the finish at La Fontaine Park in Montreal next Sunday.

A FEARSOME little book is this, and full of tales more marvelous than travelers have ever brought back from far countries or folk imaginations have ever conjured into dragon shapes or eerie wraiths. If one is squeamish there are places in it at which one may balk. But doubtless it will be very good for the reader to persevere until he has read the book through carefully enough to have mastered its contents.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Jan. 31. -- Efforts to arrange a truce between the Japanese and Chinese forces were ended today without definite result in the face of a battle between snipers and Japanese machine gunners across a near-by creek at the edge of the International Settlement.

With the usual avenues for obtaining funds closed by the condition of the security markets, many first-class railroads have been compelled to raise money by pledging senior securities with banks. The sums thus obtained amount to at least $350,000,000, all of which must eventually be refunded through the sale of securities to the public.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The race meeting of the Pinehurst Matinee Club next Friday will form one of the principal sports attractions of the week here. The matinee club has one of the fastest half mile tracks in the country, and, with the Spring advancing and the horses racing here approaching their best condition, attempts will be made to lower some of the records set here last season.

The lease of 45 East Forty-ninth Street, which is held by A.N. Gitterman, as tenant, from the Ruthen Realty Corporation, has been modified so that the annual rental will be reduced to $1,500 for the period from Jan. 1, 1932, to Dec. 31, 1946. It is stipulated that the tenant may cancel this lease on giving six months' notice.

Ever since Detective Sergeant Timothy Connell burst through the door of a Bronx speakeasy in 1924 to meet death in a fail of bullets from the guns of three hold-up men the police had been looking for Francis Little. Yesterday they found him, quite inadvertently, and he was locked up in the Bronx to answer a John Doe indictment for the murder of Connell.

OTTAWA. BISON AMERICANS is doing well in Canada. Rescued from what seemed certain annihilation, watched and guarded and encouraged by the government, its progeny now are so numerous that it became necessary recently to slaughter 1,500 of them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The United States and Great Britain moved jointly today in ordering units of their Asiatic fleets to Shanghai and up the Yangtse River to protect their nationals and interests as the Sino-Japanese conflict assumed an ominous aspect with Nanking considering a declaration of war and Tokyo deliberating on sending an army expeditionary force to Shanghai.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 30. -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club held its first invitation shoot at its new traps today, the visitors being the representatives of the Bergen Beach Gun Club of Brooklyn. Instead of an interclub competition, the New Mooners offered a high-over-all scratch prize, and handicap prizes for both the visiting and the home gunners.

Suggestions for a nation-wide commemoration in Presbyterian churches of the 200th anniversary of the birth of George Washington were issued yesterday by Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge, Moderator of the Presbyterian General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Popular faith in the groundhog on Feb. 2 as prophet of the weather is without foundation and the most reliable prediction can be found in a little box in the upper corner of one's daily newspaper, according to Arthur H. Howell, biologist of the Department of Agriculture.
HELSINGFORS, Jan. 30. -- Parliament passed the prohibition repeal bill on third reading today by 120 votes against 45, with thirty-four members absent.

PREPARATIONS to do honor to the memory of George Washington in connection with the 200th anniversary of his birth next month are by no means confined to this country. From Germany comes the news that Walter Bloem, prominent novelist and playwright, has written a Washington drama called "Held seines Landes" ("Hero of His Country").

PARIS, Jan. 28. -- Seldom has there been such a complete deadlock in international affairs as there is just now on the eve of the conference for the limitation, of armaments by international agreement. And with that deadlock has come a very great deal of international recrimination.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an address at the National Republican Club Senator Moses is reported as defending a policy of isolation for this country and saying our present difficulties "have come upon us because we crossed the ocean to dabble into the troubles of other nations."

The Grace liner Santa Maria sailed from her Brooklyn pier yesterday without any cargo. Loading of the ship was blocked by a strike brought about by the International Longshoremen's Association, which refused to recognize a wage reduction suggested by officials of the company.

Dr. Walter Damrosch was deluged with hundreds of congratulatory messages from all parts of the country and Europe on the celebration of his seventieth birthday yesterday. The occasion was enlivened by a surprise breakfast arranged for the noted conductor by a group of about twenty-five friends, relatives and associates in the National Broadcasting Company at his home, 133 East Eightieth Street.

AT precisely the moment, 1807, when Napoleon had paralyzed or conquered every Continental opponent and was in effect Emperor of Europe; at the climax of his fame, though it then seemed as if the conquest of Europe were merely the preface to undreamable further glories; just at that moment his fall began.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 30. -- The 1932 Dartmouth Winter carnival will start Friday with the arrival of 500 guests and a large group of Winter sports stars in Hanover.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- Shelly Bay, Bermuda's picturesque old race course, which for years has been the scene of all the racing activities in the island, win soon go into the discard if the recommendations of Lieut. Col. W.D. Kenny, English turf expert, are followed out.

THE sphinx, for centuries the riddle of the Nile, still reelines with outstretched paws in the Valley of Giza, but its granite features, carved by the scourged slaves of Khafre, have surrendered much of their mystery since the excavation of Tell Halaf, an ancient city of Upper Mesopotamia.

A thorough reform of the methods and administration of the New York Parental School for incorrigible truants, begun two months ago, has worked a complete transformation in the life of the 225 boys now living there by modernizing and "de-institutionalizing" the school, it was declared yesterday.

MUKDEN, Jan. 3. -- Japanese Army circles in Manchuria arc divided between shocked amazement and incredulous amusement over the Chinese Army practice of insisting upon being offered large cash rewards before they will fight. A conspicuous example of this system was contained in a mandate issued from Peiping by Marshal Chang Hsueh-liang just a few days before his armies began their retreat from the city of Chinchow.

Our jovial old friend, M. LEON DAUDET, rejoices prematurely in the illusions of hope about the United States. He sees the American people preparing to throw away prohibition, "that dangerous school of banditry." He salutes "the return of "that great nation to good sense and "good wine."

The New York Civic Opera Club, Inc., has postponed tonight's announced performance of "Cavalleria" and "Pagliacci" at Mecca Temple until next Sunday, when the tickets for this evening will hold good. The club has been invited to continue its productions thereafter at the City College Hall.

Although the present-day aircraft engine has reached a new standard in efficiency and performance, there are still some defects that must be remedied; one of these is that of the overheating of cylinders and pistons. Engineers, after much experimenting, have found that in many cases a great part of this overheating is due to the employment of fuels having unsuitable detonation characteristics for the compression ratios and heat characteristics of the modern aircraft engines.

When the ancients had super-tasks to perform they put them at the hands of a mythological hero endowed with great strength. He cleaned the Augean stables, destroyed the Stymphalian birds, slaughtered the water serpent Hydra, overthrew the Cretan bull and strangled the Nemean lion with his bare hands -- feats with engineering implications of the overcoming of natural forces hostile to mankind.

Emergency employment at the rate of 66,455 days of work a week is now being provided by the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau, it was reported yesterday to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee at 29 Broadway by Raymond W. Houston, assistant director.

VlENNA. ARCHDUKE OTTO, the youthful pretender to the throne of Hungary, periodically engages the imagination of Europe. Since early childhood, as the top step in a flight of seven handsome brothers and sisters, he had successfully held the romantic sympathies of old ladies, the dreams of young ones and the hopes of royalists.

EMBARKED upon a twenty-year program for the reorganization of production and consumption in the Southeast, the Southeastern Economic Council, composed of business leaders in that section is directing its attention today to immediate aims which comprehend:

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- Mainbocher offers the most completely wearable collection yet shown, with a variety of skirt and coat lengths. Day frocks are fourteen and fifteen inches off the floor and very straight, with wide shoulders and high waists.

STILL handicapped by unseasonal and rainy weather, retail trade was unable to improve on the subnormal business which has been its portion since the beginning of the year. In a final effort to push up volume for the closing week of the fiscal year and to move merchandise which has been selling only slowly, the stores launched clearances at greatly reduced prices.

THE play by Manuel Seff and Forrest Wilson entitled "Blessed Event," which has been hovering expectantly on the edges of theatrical conversation for some weeks, turned up at last in Newark on Monday night. This, as all must know, is the document about a tabloid columnist who, portrayed by Roger Pryor, rockets through the following story, as described by The Newark Evening News:

ON more than one occasion within the memory of the present generation the weakness of China has caused international complications of the most serious kind. One major war has been fought and others have threatened because of China's inability either to resist foreign pressure or to put her own house in order.

AT AN age and hour when most children are whisked off to bed to the tune of a maternal lullaby or, heaven save them, a Peter Rabbit story, Tom and Betty Wonder were polishing off their dance routines in a small town somewhat vaguely identified as Havre, Mont.

PROFESSOR R.W. KELSEY of Haverford College has a scheme for putting intercollegiate football on a handicap basis and points out that the handicap system is used to balance the competition in other sports, such as track, tennis, golf, polo, billiards, and so on. That's true, but in championship competition there are no handicaps in these sports and players or teams start from scratch.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 30. -- No airship superior to the Akron has ever been built, her commander, Lieut. Commander Charles E. Rosendahl. told the House Naval Committee today at its closing hearing into charges that the dirigible had been built of defective metals and that poor workmanship had been overlooked by inspectors, with the result that the huge craft was unsafe for actual flights.

Several encouraging features characterized the realty situation in the metropolitan area last week, Of chief importance, as it is so closely associated with the future stability of realty holdings in general, was the decision of the Building Trades Employers' Association to reduce wages in the building industry up to an average of 25 per cent on May 1.

A man 35 years old who is capable of earning $6,000 to $7,000 or more annually at his peak should have reserves in the form of savings or insurance of $7,633 and should be saving at least $8.97 a week, according to the American Provident Society. The figures are given in a report of a study of the means to financial independence in the society's new volume, "Are You as Old Financially as in Years?"

Following a month in which the total was the smallest in years, there has been greater activity in January in the redeeming of bonds before their maturity dates. A total of $70,718,000 has been retired, compared with only $22,164,500 in December, and with $57,899,000 in January a year ago.

LONDON. IT would be unfair and misleading to pretend that Great Britain experts great results from the Geneva conference on armament reduction -- results that would be immediate and so concrete that an untechnical public would be able to recognize them as a tangible move toward peace.

AIRSHIP builders are stubborn people. While the Naval Affairs Committee of Congress, stirred up by reports that the U.S.S. Akron was "not up to expectations," was hearing testimony last week of her splendid performance from Lieutenant Commander Charles E. Rosendahl and others thoroughly conversant with airships, the Luftschiffbau Zeppelin at Friedrichshafen made public the work that is going forward on an airship 600,000 cubic feet larger than the Akron.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Declaring that, real estate owners are being "put on the spot" as to taxation burden, the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards warned today that the owners must organize on a State and national basis "if home ownership is to increase and real estate is to continue to be one of the safest and most attractive investments."

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Jan. 31. -- The Japanese last night (Saturday) effected the seizure and military occupation of virtually all parts of the International Settlement eastward of and down the river from Soochow Creek, which area includes the postoffice, the Astor House Hotel, the buildings of the Japanese, German and Russian consulates and the city's main wharves and docks.

BRITISH veterans of the World War in the United States will be the beneficiaries of an unusual entertainment which will take place on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of the Canadian Club of New York and the English Speaking Union of the United States.

RAYMOND RECOULY'S "Joffre," like his book on Foch, is a defense of an outstanding military man against his detractors (the other military men) and his enemies (the politicians). Foch, a highly vocal soldier, told his own story and struck out boldly against all detractors and enemies.

Norman Henderson, senior partner and a founder of the banking firm of Henderson Co., at 40 Wall Street, died of heart disease yesterday at his home at 770 Park Avenue. Mr. Henderson was in his seventieth year and had been ill for about a month.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- The Franco-British negotiations for a reparations settlement to succeed the Hoover moratorium, which have been deadlocked, have entered a new phase, it is understood here tonight, and another compromise proposal is now under discussion between the French Treasury experts and British diplomatic representatives.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30. -- One of the four great centres of the ancient world, Antioch, will be excavated by archaeologists of Princeton University working in collaboration with the Musees Nationaux of France, the Baltimore Museum of Art and the Worcester Art Museum.

SCIENCE is combining its knowledge in several related fields to bring about improvement in health and comfort for the individual -- be he home owner or apartment dweller. The appreciation of the value of air conditioning is spreading rapidly and the nation's leading scientists and engineers in the heating, ventilating and refrigeration fields have banded together during the week just past in a series of technical sessions held in Cleveland.

THE CIRCUS: FROM ROME TO RINGLING" is the comprehensive title of a book by Earl Chapin May which Duffield Green announce for publication on March 28. Mr. May is well qualified to write such a book, for he is the son of a circus man and was brought up under the shadow of the big top.

WITH Albert Coates guiding the orchestra at the Bolshoy Theatre, and Leonid V. Baratof, after a trip to the United States, guiding the art destiny of the Affiliated Bolshoy Theatre; with Nicholas V. Smolitch, Leningrad director, pouring new vitality into the Bolshoy.

BUFFALO, Jan. 28. -- As the originator of the man-a-block system of unemployment relief, Buffalo has received the sincere flattery of imitation by several municipalities and earnest inquiries from a good many more. The subject becomes in some respects more interesting as the advance of midwinter shows how it works out.

DARTMOOR PRISON, the scene of a recent outbreak of prisoners, is one of Britain's notable penal institutions -- a grim pile of buildings standing on a lonely moor in Devonshire. Many novelists have celebrated the bleak and forbidding Dartmoor country in their books, among them Conan Doyle, whose "Hound of the Baskervilles" bayed across the foggy moors, Eden Phillpotts and John Galsworthy, in whose play "Escape" the prison figures.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 31. -- Japan's attitude toward the proposed application of Article XV of the League of Nations covenant, though not yet officially formulated, can be stated thus: She welcomes an impartial inquiry covering the conditions of China's relations with Japan but objects to an inquiry being connected with the charge that she intends to make war on China or filch Chinese territory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- With the preliminary details for operating the $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation arranged, the directors today marked time until next week, when formal organization will be effected and the oaths administered to those in charge of the undertaking.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Duranty's Moscow dispatch to THE TIMES regarding Russian rubber will receive a great deal of well-merited attention. Perhaps the following additional data will be of interest:

SEVERAL times during recent years the American public has been horrified by accounts in newspapers, magazines and books of the antiquated and inhuman methods employed by the State of Georgia in the management of convicted criminals.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Agreement was reached tonight by the chiefs of the twenty standard railway unions to grant the railroads a 10 per cent wage "deduction," amounting to $210,000,000, for one year.

THE week brought forth two large group shows, that of the Allied Artists of America which opened to the public last Wednesday in the Fine Arts Building, and the 127th exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, which opened last Sunday in Philadelphia.

Stocks were weak on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, but activity was light and few issues declined more than a small fraction. Leaders to show losses for the day were Gulf Oil and Electric Bond and Share. Aluminum of America was slightly stronger.

INCIDENTS, situations, characters and the general spirit of this novel place it in historical perspective in Russia's new era -- at the beginning of that nascent civilization whose lusty cries and indecent behavior are causing such perturbation among elderly civilizations (forgetful of their own unmoral infancies).

BOSTON, Jan. 28. -- Governor Ely's special message asking the general court for emergency legislation to pledge the credit of Massachusetts in behalf of the cities and towns does not by any manner of means imply that these municipalities are tottering toward bankruptcy.

LONDON. IN my biography, "The Architect," written a few years ago, I was at great pains to be honestly analytical and there wrote myself down as an architect pure and simple with few, if any, interests not more or less directly connected with my chosen profession.

VIENNA, Jan. 29. -- Recent events in Central Southeastern Europe have shown that the supreme factor here, as in Western Europe, is the Franco-German conflict. Behind the resignation of the Vienna Cabinet, Count Bethlen's mysterious journeys, the flotation and refusal of loans by various countries, permutations and combinations connected with the projected Danubian Federation, looms always the shadow which produced the greatest conflicts since medieval times -- the wars of 1870 and 1914.

Business conditions were slightly improved in the United States last week, but the gains were hardly up to normal seasonal expectations. Some of the increased activity was due to order for Spring moods, particularly in textile and shoe manufacturing.

BERLIN, Jan. 28. -- The German credit agreement of 1932 implicitly lends support to the German contention that to treat reparations and German private debts abroad as distinct and separate is a mere bookkeeping technicality, since payment in either case must come from the same source and be transferred to a creditor country in the same way.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The light of the sun at noon is 120,000,000 times brighter than that of all the stars on the clearest night, and 465,000 times brighter than that of the full moon at its zenith.

HAVANA. -- Announcement of the tournament for the amateur golf championship of Cuba, which will be played on the links of the Country Club of Havana, beginning Feb. 15, has aroused a great deal of interest among golfers here. This tournament may be entered by amateurs of any nation and many entries have already been received.
IN a recent talk with a representative of THE TIMES, Bruno Walter, the present conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, discussed world conditions in music and America's relation to them.

WHERE the actors meet these nights to dine in West Forty-eighth Street it is all very friendly and candle-lighted, and the talk consists -- as it would have to do, by an ancient statute -- of the good old theatre's incessantly frantic odds and ends.

"Don't Tread on Me." THE legislative architect of the Federal Reserve System, Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, is the indirect means of encouraging railway travel to Washington. He has drawn up a bill which would revise Federal Reserve and national banking laws, with the result that almost every train, so it seems, is bringing bankers clamorous to discuss its provisions before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

The story of Herman Dworman is a chronicle of patience rewarded, of ambition realized. After years of effort and frustrated hopes he finally has won a handball singles title. That was the mark he was aiming at while he was steadily gaining fame in national competition, but always as a doubles player.

The blond and Nordic Goeta Ljungberg -- admirably blond and most becomingly Nordic -- made her third appearance with the Metropolitan Opera Company yesterday afternoon as Brunnhilde in "Walkure." She had made her Metropolitan debut in the same opera as Sieglinde.

COCOS ISLAND is again calling to the treasure hunters. Now, as in centuries past, its very name suggests adventure, mystery and remoteness. It has been a fabled Eldorado since the days of the Conquistadores, when, legend has it, the rich loot from a Lima cathedral was hidden there by a bold buccaneer.

Radio has already proved itself an efficient schoolmistress closely heeded by youthful ears and followed by the youthful mind. Experiments in dozens of little red schoolhouses and our vast city palaces of learning alike have proved its pedagogic power.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- A pre-Lenten, soiree was given a few nights ago by the Italian Ambassador and his wife, Count and Countess Manzoni, whose receptions are always attended by Americans. The guest of honor was the former Queen of Spain, who now goes by the name of the Duchess of Madrid.

Plans for the sixth annual Eastern championship auction and contract bridge tournament, to be held at the Hotel Roosevelt Feb, 22-26 inclusive, were announced yesterday by George Reith, chairman of the card committee of the Knickerbocker Whist Club and of the tournament committee.

An exhibition of work by students of the Fountainebleau School at Fontainebleau, France, is being held at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, to stay until Feb. 6. This institution is sponsored by the French Government for the benefit of American artists, and has regular Summer sessions.

WHEN a dramatist has accomplished as much as Dan Totheroh has in "Distant Drums" it seems extraordinarily ungrateful to dwell upon his efficiencies. He has tried one of the most difficult feats in the drama. Waiting of a covered-wagon journey of 1818, he has attempted to lift his able into the region of supernatural things, and for the most part he has succeeded.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- Army, in a sensational second-half rally, defeated Georgetown at basketball today, 24 to 20. Georgetown presented a tight defense, but Army was able to break through it in the second half when Stecker, Epler and Besson all bombarded the Georgetown basket with success.

FOR the second time the United States Senate has passed a bill providing for the establishment of a national park in the Everglades region of Florida. Last year a measure for the same purpose passed the Senate, but because it was not acted on by the House before the end of the session, it failed to become a law.

The twenty-seventh National Motor Boat Show closed in the Grand Central Palace last night, leaving its sponsors and exhibitors optimistic and confident. While final figures were not available, it was said that attendance had exceeded last year's by a wide margin and that sales in many instances had surpassed those at any other exhibition.

ELKINS, W.Va., Jan. 28. -- Native sons and favorite sons as well as sons of New York bask in the political limelight in West Virginia as the primary campaign in which a decision will be reached on May 10 gets under way.

A quiet, informal canvass of sentiment among Republican leaders in the State has shown no serious feeling on the part of influential Republicans against sending a solid delegation for President Hoover to the Republican National Convention on June 17, it was disclosed yesterday.

FOR more than a century and a half the part played by the beautiful, fascinating, young Peggy Shippen Arnold in the treason of her husband, General Benedict Arnold, has been a subject of speculation among historians and biographers.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. THE cinema industry has become, almost overnight, a shrinking violet, scorning publicity, and feeling that the less attention paid to it by the public, the better off Hollywood will be. This applies, of course, only to the family circle and to matters ordinarily discussed at the breakfast table or by the evening fireside.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 30. -- Dr. John Brown Herreshoff, one of the leading metallurgical chemists of the United States, died at his home here today after an illness of three weeks. He was 81 years old.

The city's present financial condition and its need for large additional revenues from sources other than real estate taxes were cited by the Lower Manhattan Industrial Association yesterday as arguments for placing rapid transit on a self-supporting basis.

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- The German delegation to the Geneva disarmament conference, which is to decide on Germany's relative military strength for the future, will be one of the smallest delegations present. Including the secretarial staff, it will have only about twenty-four members.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Professor Daniel Gregory Mason's book, "Tune in, America" (see article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Jan. 17), profoundly touches one of the most serious questions of American musical culture. I beg to differ with the author's assertion that the indifference of our audiences to American art is due to Jack of "musical patriotism."

If WALTER DAMROSCH had lived in Greece in its golden age he would have been called Synchronos. No one has synchronized or synthesized or symphonized more vibrations of American atmosphere into melodies and harmonies during the last half century than has he in making this ennobling and refining use of our environing medium, he has performed a highest public service-patriotic and unselfish.

Mr. WINSTON CHURCHILL, on his return, to New York from Nassau, gave to the reporters some thoughts of his about the outlook for democracy in the world today. He believes in it, though he considers it just now at a rather low ebb. One of its defects, according to Mr. CHURCHILL, is that it has too little respect for eminence, and does not seem to be bringing forth great men.

THERE is no more impressive way to enter China than over the foreign-owned railroad leading from Tonkin into Yunnan, by means of which France keeps a watchful eye on her Chinese neighbor. The railroad starts from Hanoi, seat of the Governor of French Indo-China, and winds up through the rugged mountains along the Tonkinese border to Yunnanfu, capital of Yunnan Province.

FASHION, having experimented blithely with Algerian and Persian and Second Empire themes in the past few seams, has' picked out a definitely American motif to play with this oring. The George Washington Bintennial Celebration which starts on is responsible for many of the stume colors and details you'll be eing.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 28. -- The pinch of imposed economy is being felt by all State departments and institutions in Missouri, and it is the hope of Governor Henry S. Caulfield that the end of 1932 will find the State in a financial condition that will at least not embarrass its credit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Gold shipments by Japan to the United States since the abandonment of the gold standard in that country on Dec. 13 have totaled $44,500,000, according to a cablegram received at the Department of Commerce today from the American Commercial Attache at Tokyo.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Everton hung grimly to its small lead in the English League first division soccer championship race today by defeating Liverpool, 2 to 1. Sheffield United, runner-up, won from Birmingham, 1 to 0.

TO the long list of treaties providing for peaceful settlement of international disputes there have been added two more. Russia and Finland recently announced that they had agreed on a non-aggression treaty under which each promises not to attack the other, and a few days later Russia initialed a similar treaty with Poland.

Julius Seligson, former national intercollegiate titleholder, started in quest of the metropolitan indoor tennis championship yesterday by defeating Bernard Schein of Newark, N.J., 6-0, 6-0, at the 106th Regiment Armory, Brooklyn.

New materials and processes, now in development stage, will start industry on the road to recovery and result in greater progress, provided a saner and more balanced code of business ethics is invoked, Melvin W. Cassmore, research expert and specialist in power utilization and metallurgy, said here yesterday.
NANKING, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Goaded by the Japanese invasion of Shanghai, the Chinese National Government decided today to declare war on Japan.

THE "short-writer the Judge fotched in'' for one of his terms on the bench in Morehead, county seat of Rowan County, Ky., happened to be a young woman, Jean Thomas, with a deeper interest in balladry than in court reporting. Or, if she did not come to Morehead with balladry first in mind, her attention was soon aroused by an old fiddler, playing and singing beneath a tree, a group of mountain folk around him.

PARIS, Jan. 16. PARIS has its fashions in playwrights as in hats, and the latest of them is Jacques Deval. Any manager would be glad to have a play from him, and all his plays are successes. He can do no wrong.

Expressing alarm over the increasing number of boys and girls charged with serious crimes, the Kings County January grand jury handed up a presentment to County Judge McLaughlin in Brooklyn yesterday asking whether the church had not lost its influence on youth.

Ethel Haven, an American girl who has studied in Paris (also, in this country, with Walt Kuhn), is having an exhibition of decorative screens at the Brownell-Lambertson Gallery until Feb. 13. Miss Haven has many manners, varying from a severely modernistic design of blue flowers to a bouquet reminiscent of a Redoute water-color.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Declaring that the proposed consolidation of the Army and Navy Departments into a Department of National Defense was contrary to all military precedent, Secretary Adams told the House Committee on Expenditures today that it would create a job too big for any man to handle and would open the way for a political machine that would create a power against the principle of good government.

Louis Burns, rangy Bryant Hill School sophomore, last night ran the fastest schoolboy half-mile race of the current board floor season in annexing the honors of the 880-yard run closed to public and private high and preparatory schools at the 102d Engineers Regiment Armory.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Australia and South Africa continued their fourth test cricket match today before a crowd of 30,000 with the Spingboks running their first innings total to 308 but Australia, in its reply, tallying 302 for only four wickets at the close of play for the day.

Denunciation of "short-sighted politicians who would cut the very heart right out of the American military establishment, ase certain Congressmen are doing at present," was voiced yesterday afternoon by Henry L. Stevens, national commander of the American Legion, speaking at a mass meeting of Bronx legionaires at the Morris High School Auditorium.

THE Group Theatre, which left New York after the failure of "1931" to take Mr. Green's "House of Connelly" on tour, is, while it travels, making ready a new and as yet untitled play by Maxwell Anderson. According to the author, the time of the play is 100 years ago, and it deals with the struggle between Americans and Spaniards for the possession of New Mexico.

Stocks in yesterday's week-end market ended a fraction lower, after the lightest business had been done of any Saturday since midsummer of 1931. In bonds there was little uniformity of movement; the prevalent trend was downward, although the day's declines were as a rule only slight.

LONDON, Jan. 6, 1932. THE prospects for the new year are far from promising. London music suffered a heavy loss when Lionell Powell and Mrs. S. Courtauld died within a day of each other. Powell was responsible for the Sunday afternoon concerts at the Albert Hall, which this year, thanks to the engagement of Sir Thomas Beecham and the London Symphony Orchestra, rose to artistic value and importance.
We are glad to print in these columns communications from readers, urging, however, that letters be made as brief as possible.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- A total of 1,023,375 persons are serving the government in its executive and military departments and the total payroll of all government employes, including the executive, military, legislative and judiciary departments and the independent offices, is about $1,500,000,000.

ALLIED Artists of America -- This group is holding its nineteenth annual exhibition in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. It remains until Feb. 11. Prizes and honorable mentions were announced Jan. 27, when the exhibition was reviewed.

Reis-Allwood Homes, Inc., sold the six-room house in Allwood, which its sales and executive offices have occupied for about a year and a half. The company will move on March 1 to a remodeled Dutch-type farmhouse said to be more than 150 years old.

For months the newspapers will be full of tabulations based on the Democratic National Convention. A week ago Governor ROOSEVELT'S managers issued the first of them. The figures would seem to indicate that later tables, or those from rival sources, will be mere surplusage, because this one assigned to Mr. ROOSEVELT on the first ballot 678 votes, or 92 short of the required two-thirds majority.

To the Art Editor: NO lasting work can come from a lowering of standards or from the arbitrary raising of standards such as the fashionable dicta that to be truly great a work must represent American subject-matter, machinery, Alas! Poor Cezanne! whose life was dedicated to the dogma of the freedom of the artist to determine his own subject-matter and insistence upon the importance of the philosophic elements of form and composition.

LELAND STANFORD, whose story the director emeritus of the Stanford University library tells in this biography was in many ways a typical product of the gilded age. The son of a farmer and innkeeper, he was born in 1824 near Albany, N.Y.
TORONTO, Jan. 30. -- Fighting an up-hill battle all the way, the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight defeated the New York Rangers, 6-3, in a thrilling overtime battle.

PARIS. TO come from the films of America to those of Paris is to go from one world to another, but though the differences are startling nothing could be more unjust than to say that one is better than another. "Chacun a son gout" is as applicable in this case as in any other.

Drastic revision of the Martin act, designed to place all dealers in securities in the State under the supervision of the Attorney General's office, is embodied in a proposed amendment to the law to be introduced tomorrow in the Legislature on behalf of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d and Joseph E. Widener entertained tonight with a dinner at their home. Their guests were:

The enrolment of more than a million young men and women in business courses is evidence of some of the outstanding educational, occupational and social trends of the twentieth century. The number enrolled in business courses exceeds the number in any field of vocational training chiefly because of the multitude of opportunities in business and because of the mobility within business organizations.

AFTER having made one picture from Earl Derr Biggers's story, "Behind That Curtain," in which the wise Charlie Chan was almost overlooked, the Fox company turned out another film from the same book and called it "Charlie Chan's Chance."

WHEN two aviation squadrons of the New York Naval Militia were recently disbanded by order of Governor Roosevelt, it was reported that the entire organization might be dissolved. The squadrons were given up, it is stated, because of complications arising from the fact that the naval militia is under control of both State and Federal Governments.

The world's amateur 18.2 balkline billiard championship has been assigned to the New York Lodge of Elks, 108 West Forty-third Street, and has been tentatively scheduled to start on March 23, the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players announced yesterday.

Modern industry, with its demands for highly specialized qualities in workers, has produced a condition among them akin to the "shell-shock" suffered by soldiers during the World War, Dr. Floyd H. Allport of Syracuse University declared last night in a radio talk under the auspices of the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education, which was broadcast over a nation-wide hook-up of the National Broadcasting Company.
It has been noted of Japanese demands on China that if the demands are rejected the Japanese attack, and if the demands are accepted the Japanese open fire.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, who is to go on trial tomorrow on an indictment charging him with failing to enforce the banking laws in connection with the failure of the Bank of United States, received a vote of confidence last night by the Westchester County Bankers Association.

DESPITE the intimation above that this department is reserved to matters musical, it is presumed that a digression into other departments of recording is not only permissible but, judging from questions received, welcome in some quarters.

YESTERDAY Walter Damrosch celebrated his seventieth birthday. Born in Breslau, Jan. 30, 1862, he came to America with his father, Leopold Damrosch, in 1871. His career since those days has been an adventure and an Odyssey, and of incalculable value to music in America.

IT was interesting to find a number of physicians agreeing, in their talks before the Medical Association of Greater New York the other night, on the importance of safeguarding not only the physical health but the peace of mind as well of fliers.

As the result of an anonymous telephone call Thursday night to the Central Park Casino warning that robbers were plannng to hold up Mrs. Alfred C. Blumenthal, whose husband is a broker in theatrical enterprises and a close friend of Mayor Walker, the Police Department has provided a twenty-four-hour-a-day detective guard for Mrs. Blumenthal, it was divulged last night by police of the East Fifty-first Street Station.

The city manager form of government, indicated by Samuel Seabury in his report to the Legislature last Sunday as a possible corrective for local evils, was vigorously endorsed for this city yesterday by Richard S. Childs, president of the City Club and chairman of the council of the National Municipal League.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- There was no change in the level of business activity in a majority of the American foreign markets for the second week in January apart from a feeling of optimism for the coming year, according to the weekly survey of the Department of Commerce, which follows in brief.

Suit was brought in the Supreme Court yesterday by the Continental Bank and Trust Company to collect $1,486,000 from Irwin S. and Henry I. Chanin through foreclosure proceedings on a bond issue which totaled $7,500,000 when authorized in 1926.

GENEVA, Jan. 28. -- With the first World Disarmament Conference only a few days off, every train now brings more delegations to join those whom the Council sessions already have assembled here, and more proof that Europeans still look for salvation in almost everything to the United States of America instead of to the united action of Europe.

NEW ORLEA1CS, Jan. 30. -- The favorite, Jimmy Moran, from the stable of Mose Goldblatt, won the Pontchartrain Handicap, $3,000 added, from a high-class field at the Fair Grounds track today in a chilly wind.

United States Government bonds were again the strongest spot yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. During the two-hour trading period they advanced 1-32 to 23-32 point, while domestic corporation bonds and foreign issues were irregularly lower.

OUT of the depths of its vast and varied populations, an unfamiliar scientific India seems to be rising into prominence simultaneously with the now familiar political India. World-famous Indian scientists like Sir C.V. Raman, Sir J.C. Bose and Sir P. C. Ray are evoking by their examples a revival of that almost forgotten devotion to the sciences which once distinguished the more intellectual of India's races.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The United States Asiatic Fleet, under command of Admiral M.M. Taylor, is widely separated. Fourteen units, including the new 10,000-ton cruiser Houston, are at Manila, and the others are in Chinese waters.

IN a period when the extreme interest in the fluctuations of the human heart and the frequently inexplicable divagations of the individual has made biography secondary only to the novel in popular favor, it is a decided pleasure to welcome any astonishingly worthwhile addition to this literary form.

TWO typical days spent with Governor Roosevelt, one at Albany and the other in his home at Hyde Park, reveal a moving picture -- needless to say, it is emphatically a talkie -- of the life of the New York Executive.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 30. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in leading cities for the week ending Jan. 27, aggregated $7,037,000,000, or 15 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 29 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

As railway wage readjustments prepare to march off the stage the revision of wages in the building trades comes on at the other end. The railroads occupy the more strategic position in our business life because they are interwoven with every phase of it. They are in a figurative as well as in a literal sense the lines of communication in our economic system.

District Attorney Crain took his first step yesterday in the campaign he had promised to a committee of clergymen and laymen to prevent the publication and sale of alleged objectionable magazines. He ordered Charles Pilatsky, Assistant District Attorney, to obtain summonses for four news stand owners under Section 1,141 of the penal law, which includes as an offense the display of indecent posters or magazines in public places.

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company, the Safe Harbor Water Power Corporation and the Pennsylvania Water and Power Company entered into a forty-eight year contract last year, under which power purchases among the companies take the form of annual sums independent of the amount of output, according to the annual report to stockholders of the Pennsylvania company.

With banks throughout the country, large and small, reluctant to increase their holdings of bonds materially at this time, the bond market was unable to make much headway in the month just completed. One of the prime reasons why the banks have not "taken hold" in the bond market is the loss of deposits.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 30. -- Many of the Democratic leaders in New Hampshire who, in 1928, supported Governor Alfred E. Smith for the Presidency have now turned to Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt. Two have come out for Smith, however, and some others are said to be waiting for him to declare himself in the race.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Jan. 23 increased slightly over the preceding week, but were lower than a year ago, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me, as an American who was present at the recent International Conference on Calendar Reform at Geneva, to correct a misleading statement about this meeting in a letter from V.M. Elmore of Montgomery, Ala., published in THE TIMES.

THE latest work on Jean Sibelius has been issued by the Oxford University Press. It is Cecil Gray's "Sibelius." The book does not profess encyclopedic completeness of data, either about the compositions or the personality of Sibelius.

The Commonwealth Fund, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, disbursed in 1931 $2,232,261.91, the largest sum in any year since the fund's establishment in 1918 by the late Mrs. Stephen V. Harkness, according to its thirteenth annual report, made public yesterday.

The weekly index of business activity is practically unchanged at about the average level of the last nine weeks. The preliminary index for the week ended Jan. 23 is 62.9, as against 63.0 for the preceding week. Freight car loadings, adjusted for seasonal variation, display a continued tendency to sag, following the sharp rise recorded in the first week of the new year.
MIAMI -- Events to aid charity, which as usual will feature the activities of February in the Miami area, are in their entirety of much more interest socially than in any recent season.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Arlington Park, playground of Chicago millionaires, will offer the richest race program in America this season, giving away nearly $700,000 in purses for its thirty-day meeting.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- Governor Roosevelt celebrated his fiftieth birthday today among his friends and neighbors of Dutchess County, cradle of the political career which has placed him before the country as an aspirant for the Presidency.

ALVIN SIMMONS has seen many a radio star rise, shine, twinkle and disappear. Few have known more radio entertainers. They call him Al, and they win that right because he has always been on the job since WJZ opened its doors in Newark back in 1921.

WASHINGTON. THE traditional policy of the United States is to meet with the other nations of the world and to offer its cooperation in an endeavor which has in view the reduction of the huge burdens resulting from unnecessarily heavy and costly armaments.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 30. -- Petitions from thirty counties were filed at the State Elections Bureau today by Joseph F. Guffey, former Democratic National Committeeman, placing the name of Governor Roosevelt upon the primary ballot as a Democratic candidate for President.
Columbia University's many branches and contacts for gathering and spreading learning are pictured in the following list which President Butler gave in his recent annual report:

Brooklyn Prep, defending champion in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association hockey tournament, remained in first place in the league's fourth annual competition by defeating St. John's, 2 to 1, in one of the three games played last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.

New York was criticized by Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, Secretary of the Interior and former dean of the Medical School of Leland Stanford University, as "a disappointment in the medical field" because of its small provision for post-graduate medical training, at the fiftieth anniversary dinner of the Faculty Association of the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital at the Hotel Biltmore last night.

Shortly after Sonia Stokowski, 8-year-old daughter of Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, had made a radio appeal for funds for needy musicians yesterday morning at the children's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society at Carnegie Hall, Ernest Schelling, conductor of the concerts, announced the formation of a "children's crusade," to collect funds for the drive of the Musicians' Emergency Aid.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30. -- With the fear held that the pilot and seven passengers, three of them women, of a Century-Pacific airliner may be lying injured and freezing in the mountains between Los Angeles and Bakersfield, preparations for the greatest air hunt staged in the West were being planned here tonight.

Interest in the silver market began to revive last week as the movement for an international stabilization conference gathered momentum and as reports reached Wall Street of the threatend closing of large silver mines in Mexico. Trading in silver futures increased sharply on the National Metal Exchange.

With business on the Stock Exchange at the lowest level for a Saturday since the end of last August, Wall Street made little pretense of interest in yesterday's market. Stocks fluctuated within narrow limits and closed with unimportant net changes.

Brain Sharpeners. CROSSWORD puzzles are not sufficiently perplexing for British readers. Several dailies and weeklies are devising or reviving problems of an older fashion. This one is called a cure for brain-fag:

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- Since Governor Clifford and his American wife arrived here three weeks ago they have been widely entertained by the American tourist colony. Among those who have figured in all of these parties are Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Munson, Miss Sulley, Bertram Taylor and Miss Taylor, Dr. and Mrs. Charles Dolley and Mr. and Mr. Lewis Young.

TWENTY-TWO years ago a comparatively young man produced one of the few great political works of modern times. "The Great Illusion," which proceeded to demonstrate with Euclidean exactitude that war was economically outdated -- it did not pay. Four years later the world produced the great war and proceeded to prove Norman Angell's theorem true.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 30. -- More British troops have been ordered into Kashmir, where the situation seems to be going from bad to worse. This morning, at the urgent request of the Kashmir Durban (government), a column set off from Jhelum for Poonch, a small feudatory State of the Maharajah of Kashmir, up in the mountains whose capital is a small mud walled town on the banks of the swiftly flowing Tawi River.

Three hundred and forty-four high schools and academies in the metropolitan area have enrolled in the National Oratorical Contest on the Constitution which opens tomorrow. The contest is conducted annually by THE NEW YORK TIMES in this region, which comprises New York City, Long Island, Westchester and Putnam Counties and Northern New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Administration opposition to drastic reduction of the army personnel as proposed in the recommendations for War Department appropriations for 1933, made by a House subcommittee, was foretold today when Secretary Hurley made a personal call on Speaker Garner at the Capitol.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- Trading on the Stock Exchange was extremely restricted today, but the tendency was better in some sections. Sterling weakened further in foreign exchange, the New York rate falling to $3.45 1/2. This, however, did not affect British Government funds, which recovered slightly; the conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan to u75 5/8 and the war loan to u98 3/4.

MALONE, N.Y., Jan. 30 (AP). -- A milk producers association, composed of all the dairyman in the New York milk "shed," was proposed in a resolution adopted by an emergency milk committee of farmers of Franklin, Jefferson, Clinton and Lewis Counties.

February will be a particularly active month in the dog world. Beginning on Friday, when the Maryland Kennel Club opens its nineteenth annual exhibition in Baltimore, there will be a continuous round of shows in the eastern section of the country that will hold the attention of the fanciers through four weeks.

The final, session yesterday of the sale at the American Art Association-Andersoa Galleries, Inc., of the collection of S. Vernon Mann of Great Neck, L.I. and New York, brought $104,640. Yesterday's session amounted to $71,112.50 and Friday's to $33,527.50.

MARY PICKFORD has finally located a suitable story for her next picture, and she will begin preparations within a few weeks for production in the late Spring. The story is from the typewriter of Francis Marion, the scenario writer, and is called "Happy Ending."

Baseball's off season, which has slipped along rather quietly this Winter save for a couple of strident holdout blasts and the interesting manoeuvrings in the proprietorship of Hack Wilson, will enter upon its closing scenes this week with the staging of the annual dinner, frolic and minstrel show of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association, of America, followed by the annual schedule meetings of the National and American Leagues.

CONNECTICUT licenses win expire at the end of February and must be renewed by March 1, it is announced by the State Department of Motor Vehicles. There are 418,633 persons operating cars in Connecticut at present. Applications by mail will be received only at the main office, State Office Building, Hartford.

Immediate cash payment of adjusted service compensation certificates was demanded by 1,500 Veterans of Foreign Wars at a rally last night at Stuyvesant High School, Fifteenth Street and First Avenue. Speakers said such payment would cause no deficit to the treasury, that it was due in view of the service rendered during the World War and that soldiers should receive at least as much recognition as international bankers.

The charitable activities of the Police Department were praised by Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney in an address last night at the eighteenth annual entertainment, reception and ball of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association at Madison Square Garden.

ONE of the relics of our Colonial past which the anti-quarian has popularized is the Franklin stove. Examples are being sought for country houses, and modern reproductions of many of the old models may be had which, after a little use, can hardly be distinguished from their proto-types of more than a century and a half ago.

The activities of the Federal Government in merchant shipping held the attention of shipping men from many parts of the country and drew the fire of prop nents of privately operated transport systems at the annual sessions of the National Conference on the Merchant Marine, held last week in Washington.

AT last Harry M. Daugherty, Harding's political manager and Attorney General, has broken silence about his affairs and his written the book he promised. It has been a promise of several years' standing. At many breathing spells during the rough-and-tumble controversies, investigations and criminal prosecutions to which he has been subjected during the last eleven years, Mr. Daugherty has declared that "at the proper time" he would tell his story.

Governor Pinchot of Pennsylvania criticized the regional sales plan formulated by the National Coal Association in a statement yesterday before sailing on the liner Monarch of Bermuda. He also made a plea for cooperation among New York dairy men in an address broadcast over the country.

WHILE Newark and adjacent municipalities have been disputing about the respective merits of Park Avenue and Verona Avenue for Route 10, the New Jersey State Highway Commission has been forging three links in the highway chain that is to stretch from Jersey City to Ledgewood.

SEVERAL card parties, in conjunction with teas, musicales and dancing, have been arranged by persons interested in augmenting the funds of various philanthropic organizations. Members of the New York Branch of the Mary Hillard Society, which is comprised of alumnae of the Westover School, will give a bridge party on Tuesday afternoon on board the Conte Grande at Pier 95, North River, for the benefit of their Summer camp.

IN thousands of rural and semirural communities throughout the United States the pioneer's practice of trading farm produce for merchandise is again entering into everyday business. Current economic conditions, with glutted farm markets, increase in marginal farms and decrease in marginal cash, provide an immediate motive for this reversion to an older school of commerce.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- Boston University's hockey team triumphed over the Army sextet by 8 to 3 tonight, Weafer and Elem excelling on the attack.

Supported by the poor retail results experienced during the month Just closing, which are not traceable entirely to weather conditions, the view has steadily gained ground that steps must be taken to correct the adverse situation which has developed from the long-continued emphasis on cheapness, according to comment in well-informed retail circles here during the week.

Breaking 99 out of a possible 100 targets, B.M. Higginson annexed the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. It was the best score in a field of fifty-four gunners.

IN connection with the celebration this year of the bicentenary of the birth of George Washington, the National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York will display an interesting collection of Washingtonia at the society's headquarters, 215 East Seventy-first Street.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 30. -- Using three complete teams during the game, the Naval Academy basketball squad defeated Western Maryland today, 49 to 19.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney announced yesterday that he would go to Albany on Tuesday to appear before the Legislature in behalf of the so-called public enemy law. The statute, which makes it possible for the courts to jail those who associate with known criminals, went into effect on Sept. 22, 1931, and would expire on March 1.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, Canal Zone, Jan. 28. -- The temporary reduction by 10 per cent of toll charges through the Suez Canal, to be effective July 1, will establish the lowest rates in the history of that waterway, and yet the tolls on laden ships will still be higher than the present rate at the Panama Canal.

THE normal life of a city of seven millions is best studied in the small-scale model. That at least is the safest method for the layman, who really is not competent to handle seven million people. It is different with the expert in such matters. He is not unduly disconcerted to learn that in New York City, at any time, there may be operating perhaps 200 cocaine peddlers.
Developments in the Far East brought more activity in trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and an advance left prices 4 to 7 point, higher than on Friday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES printed a dispatch from Indianapolis stating that the United Mine Workers may recommend a thirty-hour week as a cure for the evils that now beset the mining industry. The railroad workers seem to have a similar plan as a cure for their troubles.

Resolutions protesting any further reduction of the armed forces of the United States, and especially, in view of the Sino-Japanese situation, of the Marine Corps, were adopted yesterday at a meeting of the Eastern Seaboard Division of the Marine Corps League, in the Towers, Brooklyn, and copies of them were ordered sent to President Hoover, every Senator and Representative and to the chairman of the House Naval Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Senator William E. Borah, the chairman, and leading members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee expressed themselves today as strongly opposed to an economic boycott against Japan or the placing of an embargo on the shipment of arms to the Orient.

PALM BEACH. -- Although few sports events of major interest are especially notable on the week's calendar, the days will be filled with social and cultural affairs, two of these latter inaugurating series which are highlights of each successive season.

HONOLULU, Jan. 30. -- At liberty for the first time since Jan. 8, the day on which Joseph Kahahawai met his death, the four defendants in that case were enjoying themselves this afternoon at Pearl Harbor, having been released there in custody of Captain W.K. Wortman, U.S.N., shortly before noon.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30. -- "The imperialist war has already broken out in the Far East. It is impossible to regard what is now happening there except as a real war, and the situation is further complicated by capitalist rivalries in China, where the conflict of interests between the United States and Japan is especially noticeable."

The School Relief Fund, ministering to the needs of thousands of school children for food, warm clothing and shoes and carrying emergency relief to the families of many of these children, is faced with a sharp increase in the calls for aid and, with its reserves dwindling rapidly, has sought additional contributions from school employes to continue its work during the new term and the Summer months.

Japan's excuse for high-handed measures in China has heen that the Chinese Government was able neither to make war nor to maintain peace. But now the returned CHIANG KAI-SHEK at Nanking has issued a tentative declaration of war upon Japan. This is doubtless prompted by the outrages committed by the Japanese in Shanghai.

FROM first hand information obtained during the past three weeks by the writer and a staff of assistants, it is apparent that the interests of the automobile industry and the interests of the motoring public are more closely interlocked at this time than at any period in the past.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 30. -- Producing figures to support his prediction of a substantial increase in gold mining in 1932, Charles McCrea, Provincial Minister of Mines, addressing the Empire Club, urged the men of Ontario "not to be afraid to risk a dollar in finding new mines."

THE cost of the World War is an unfinished story. It will be fourteen years before disability awards to American soldiers reach their probable maximum. It will be forty-four years before the budget of the Veterans' Bureau can reasonably be expected to drop below one hundred million dollars.

A DEPARTURE from the usual system in arranging philanthropic entertainments has been made in the formation of a Monday evening dancing club to be called The Imperial, which will conduct a series of dances for the benefit of the Social Service Bureau of Bellevue Hospital.

PALM BEACH. ALTHOUGH at a casual glance fashions in Palm Beach seem not radically changed from those of last year, a second look discovers new aspects, mainly those of color and material. The only note repeated is that white, for the second consecutive season, has assumed the leading role for evening and daytime frocks, sports apparel and hats.

A MOVE is being made by members of the French Parliament to have performances of the Opera and the Opera Comique broadcast, but the artists are said to receive the proposal with disfavor. Deputies representing the provinces declare they are interested in having one act of an opera broadcast.

Security owners are hearing some plain talk on the subject of dividends. First the United States Steel Corporation, largest industrial enterprise in the world, serves notice, in effect, that no further payments on common stock need be expected unless business improves, accompanying this gloomy reminder with the sorriest income report in its history.

Riding and hitting hard, the young Los Nanduces indoor polo team scored an upset over the highly favored Yale University trio at Squadron A Armory last night, winning a close, well-played game, 11 1/2 to 8 1/2.

The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange in January was the smallest of any month since last August. Transactions fell below a million shares a day on both Jan. 25 and 26. This was the slowest pace since last September. Sales this month have totaled 34,342,456 shares, compared with 50,190,478 in December, and with 42,543,435 shares in January of last year.

Sheriff Thomas M. Farley's answer to the charges filed against him by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter committee, will be in Governor Roosevelt's hands tomorrow night, it became definite yesterday as arrangements were made for printing the bulky document.

NEW YORK. General and Mrs. Ivor Thord-Gray will give a reception with dancing this afternoon in the Japanese Room of the St. Regis for their daughter. Miss Francis Thord-Gray, who was introduced to society during the Winter.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 30. -- Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club, defending champion, was eliminated in the New Jersey squash tennis championship by Edward Largian of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in a close five-game semi-final match at the Short Hills Club by 7 -- 15, 15 -- 10, 17 -- 15, 2 -- 15, 15 -- 7.

Reports of increasing activity in the East in behalf of Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland have been received by the Roosevelt camp here during the past few days without alarm. The friends of Governor Roosevelt are confident, it is understood, that they will have no trouble holding the Eastern delegates they now claim against any drive for Ritchie.

LISTENERS seem to be none too sure that they like the way Deems Taylor narrates the Metropolitan Opera. The voice interrupts the music, and some suggest that he broadcast the story in the beginning and stay off the air while the opera is on.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30. -- In one of the closest guarding games seen here in years, Pennsylvania defeated Yale tonight in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest, 19 to 16. A crowd of 3,000 saw the game.
Loew's new theatre, at Seventy-second Street and Third Avenue, is rapidly nearing completion and is scheduled to open its doors to the public about Feb. 20.

THE Winter season, much shorter than usual -- with Asn "Wednesday falling on Feb. 10 -- is nearing its end, and there is a rush of weddings before the beginning of Lent. Two marriages have been, arranged for Saturday, that of Miss Marie Iselin to Thomas Sergeant La Farge, and Miss Dorothy D. Pratt to Samuel Croft Register 2d; and on Shrove Tuesday, Miss Eilean Burden will become the bride of "Walter Maynard.

Playing spectacularly throughout the entire second half, the Seton Hall College quintet of South Orange, N.J., scored a 29-to-20 triumph over the Fordham University five in the Fordham gymnasium last night before a crowd of 1,800 spectators.

DEBTS which under existing conditions cannot be paid an occupying the attention of every financial centre and capital city in the world today. One committee of experts has just ended its sessions in Berlin on the problem of Germany's short-term debts, while another, meeting at Basle, has pronounced Germany unable to meet her reparation bill of $475,000,000 a year.

Miss Adelaide Nutting, professor emeritus at Teachers College, Columbia University, will receive a portrait of herself at a reception at Teachers College on Feb. 10, it was announced yesterday. The portrait is the work of Stanislav Rembski.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As soon as I had read the comment on my sermon of Jan. 17, made by the Rev. John Cole McKim, D.D., in a letter to THE TIMES, I sent to him the fuller version, which appeared on Jan. 23 in The Catholic News, and have received this morning a gracious letter of thanks.

Will the power issue figure prominently in the Presidential campaign? That question has been argued lately in almost as lively fashion as the power issue itself. The latest to enter the debate is HAROLD E. WEST, chairman of the Maryland Public Service Commission.
