THE feat of the waterspout which, according to press dispatches, recently scattered fish in the streets of Bordeaux is not without precedent. A few years ago a waterspout picked up hundreds of fish from Boca Ciega Bay, Fla., and showered them over a near-by golf links.
Commodities were generally steady yesterday so far as their price trend was concerned. In only a few instances were there any variations and these for the most part were small and unimportant.

Two minutes after a man was seen darting out of a rooming house at 45 Halsey Street, in the Bedford residential district of Brooklyn, a bomb exploded last night in the vestibule of the house with a roar that was heard nearly a mile away, tearing a hole a foot wide in the floor, shattering all the windows in the house and many in near-by residences and spreading fright throughout the neighborhood.

AS Lowell lecturer, Professor Elliott of Harvard offered last year an objective yet sympathetic study of a formidable theme. On the British Empire as a major uncertainty of a transitional period, he mobilized information derived from documents, enriched by travel and mellowed by contact with statesmen and officials who see the situation from the inside.

JUDGING by their numbers and the numbers of those who visit them, exhibitions of modern art and interest in it seem to be increasing in this country, but it is far too large and various an American place to estimate its tastes and standards as a whole.

MEMBERS of the Junior League are now actively engaged in raising funds to support the league's main, charity, the Baby Shelter, which occupies the fifth floor of the clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street.

DELEGATES from sixty nations will meet at Geneva on Tuesday to open a world conference on armaments, which has been planned ever since the League of Nations was founded. They will endeavor to reach an agreement limiting the size of armies, navies and air forces -- a gigantic project for which the groundwork has been laid by the League's Preparatory Commission.

Moving down the harbor through a heavy fog at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, the Roma of the Italia Line, outward bound on a Mediterranean cruise, crashed into the President Roosevelt of the United States Lines, which lay at anchor off Quarantine. The Roma suffered only slight damage to her forepost and put to sea last night after temporary repairs had been made.

THE composition of "Towards a Better Life," to judge from Kenneth Burke's detached preface, has bad a checkered but finally triumphant history. On three separate occasions the author sat down and commenced work on Chapter One of an objective, realistic novel.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Jan. 30. -- Penn State won its third game on the home floor tonight, defeating Syracuse, 41 to 33, in a spirited second half rally which was featured by the play of Norris McFarlane, sophomore substitute forward.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 30. -- St. Benedict's Prep School of Newark, Kearny High School and Westfield High School won championships in their respective divisions in the North Jersey interscholastic indoor track and field games at the Newark Armory tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30. -- The St. James filly Evening, which races for George D. Widener, captured the second running of the $2,500 added Hialeah Highweight Handicap, feature at Hialeah Park today, and flashed such a sparkling performance that she equaled the seven-furlong track record of 1:23 2-5, which was set yesterday by Scotch Gold.

Led by Jack Klunk, brilliant New York University swimming star, the Violet natators triumphed over Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 41 to 30, in the seventy-five-foot London Terrace pool yesterday. The N.Y.U. swimmers annexed six of the eight events.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not fair to India to let go unchallenged the statement which appeared in a press dispatch that India "is a country where women occupy a position inferior to men."

A growing tendency to seek medical advice and treatment for mental disorders at the appearance of the earliest symptoms was reported yesterday by the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, after a nationwide survey of the existing facilities for the study and management of these conditions outside of institutions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Newton D. Baker's remark that Americans should study the purport of the League of Nations, and overcome some of their unwarranted prejudices against it, is very timely now, as in the past.

TOKYO, Sunday Jan. 31. -- As the Japanese neared Harbin yesterday, the Chinese prepared to retreat northward toward Hulan. The Japanese will not enter the city until today, giving the Kirin troops hostile to General Hsi Hsia, installed as Governor of Kirin by the Japanese, time to get away.

Among the art offerings during the coming week will be the sale of seven rare and valuable musical instruments owned by John Hudson Bennett at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries Friday evening.

SINCE the introduction of slots at the leading edge of airplane wings by Handley Page in Great Britain, the aircraft industry has been interested in studying the effect of these devices, of the interceptor device and of flaps at the trailing edge which followed them on landing speeds and lateral control.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23. -- With forty-four delegates to throw into the scales of the Democratic National Convention the party organization in California is acutely conscious of the possibilities of its power in naming the candidate, even though it has little hope of delivering the State's electoral vote.

BOSTON, Jan. 30. -- Senator Walsh and Governor Ely today pledged anew their allegiance to Alfred E. Smith as candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency until he definitely eliminates himself from the race. Their statements followed a plea made by Mayor Curley yesterday at Albany that Mr. Smith join him in supporting Governor Roosevelt and predicting a Massachusetts delegation instructed for the former.

POEMS by "H.D." are eagerly awaited as the flowers of Spring, or the Spring songs of birds and their effect, when they do appear, in just as rejuvenating and magical. A rare lyric genius is that of "H.D." Her work is sculptured with all the care of the worker in marble.

ALFALFA BILL has been visiting Washington. With Prince Albert coat and light brown sombrero, with a gold and diamond Masonic ring sparkling on a knotty finger, with a large turquoise stickpin in his dark tie, the picturesque Governor of Oklahoma placidly consumed two pots of coffee while testifying before the Ways and Means Committee.

Irma Duncan and her American group of Isadora Duncan Dancers gave their first performance of the season yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall before a large and enthusiastic audience. Indeed, there seemed ample reason for cordiality, for Miss Duncan appeared at her best and her young group had made enormous strides since last season.

The recent confirmation of the falling of the walls of Jericho would have been on the front page in the news of the fifteenth century B.C. According to the chronology in the editions of the Bible of fifty years ago, the Exodus was as long B.C. as the discovery of America was A.D.

The American-owned public service companies in the International Settlement at Shanghai had thus far escaped damage at the hands of either Japanese or Chinese forces, according to dispatches received yesterday at the New York headquarters of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The terror of fire, bombs and bullets in the Chapei section of Shanghai ceased for a time this afternoon and a flight of the Chinese population began immediately. By thousands they thronged into the haven of the International Settlement, a bloodsmeared, terror-stricken, cringing crowd, and threw themselves on the ground or into corners of safety.

Acting on the "call" sent out over the country by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America that today should be observed as a nation-wide "Day of Prayer" for success of the Geneva conference the great majority of pastors will devote a sermon or a part of a sermon today to disarmament.

FOR a picture of social life fifty years ago I can only draw upon a limited experience, first as a girl before 1880 and as a young married woman after that date. I can, in short, only give the youthful feminine point of view.

KNOXVILLE, Term., Jan. 28. -- For the first time in its long history Knoxville finds itself with a handful of Communists in its midst. They hail from New York, but they came here from the mine war zone in Southeastern Kentucky, where the authorities have been making it hot for them.

PARIS, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Dr. Leopold von Hoesch, the German Ambassador, told Premier Laval today that Germany was unwilling to sign any new reparations agreement which, by, implication, would put Germany in the position of acknowledging the validity of payments under the Young Plan.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30. -- Temple's basketball team played its most brilliant game of the season tonight in registering a 48-26 victory over New York University in Mitten Hall. It was the eighth straight triumph at home for the Owls.

BERLIN. THE German delegation to the disarmament conference will he instructed by its government to demand that an end be put to competitive arming and that, an incisive reduction of existing armaments be undertamen without further delay.

The Consolidated Gas Company of New York is planning further to unify, within their respective spheres, the group of gas and electric companies which it controls. The plans entail the merging of some companies and the dissolution of others, over a period of years, and the immediate centralization of gas operations and electric operations throughout the system under the authority of the executive committee.

DR. WALTER DAMROSCH crossed the threescore-and-ten mark yesterday and celebrated his seventieth birthday by working and rehearsing for his regular Sunday symphonic broadcast. And the National Broadcasting Company reported to the veteran conductor that the audience in tune with his music appreciation lectures on Fridays now totals more than 6,500,000 listeners.

Squadron C gained a noteworthy, metropolitan indoor polo circuit victory at the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, last night, when it defeated Pennsylvania Military College, 15 to 10 1/2. The game was played on the flat.

TOKYO. MO-GA and Mo-bo-the names are coined from "modern girl" and "modern boy" -- are Japan's younger generation. Or, at least, they are its more conspicuous members. That differences should arise between generations is inevitable, unless a race remains tucked away in some remote and inaccessible pocket of the earth where social patterns, slowly molded, are never chipped and broken by rude contacts with the outside world.

VATICAN CITY, Jan. 28. -- The suppression of the Jesuit order in Spain and the confiscation of all its properties there has been a heavy blow to the Vatican and one of the things which have saddened the Pope most in the last few years which on the whole have not been happy ones for the Catholic Church.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- The British Government's ban on foreign actors and musicians, whereof the latest victime are Evelyn Herbert and Robert Halliday, American stars of "Waltzes From Vienna," instead of being supported by the theatrical world and press, now is vigorously denounced by all who have the welfare of the English stage at heart.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- The trap shooting range has been one of the popular sporting places throughout the early season here. A 100-bird skeet tournament will be held tomorrow at the Gun Club. Among those who are to take part will be Ben Ames Williams, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ballard of Boston, Mr. and Mrs. Jordan W. Lambert and Mrs. John W. Hession of Hastingson-Hudson.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 29. -- One of the most important domestic problems inherited from Chiang Kai-shek's Government by the Canton faction, which has just come into power, is that of the recrudescence of Communist activities in Kiangsi Province.

ANOTHER chapter has been written in the career of the statue of Eros, which was recently returned, after a long absence, to its place in London's Piccadilly Circus. For seven years "the centre of the British Empire," as Piccadilly Circus is called, was forced to do without its famous statue while a subway was being constructed.

WHAT did I think "of the sight" when I was on the top of the Empire State Building? Frankly, I was so entranced "seeing" that I did not think about the sight. If there was a subconscious thought of it, it was in the nature of gratitude to God for having given the blind seeing minds.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- A cold wave originating in the frozen Canadian regions gripped the Middle West today with temperatures in some areas as low as 31 below zero. Chicago, which has not had zero weather in two years, shivered early this morning while the thermometer read 4.2 above, and a prediction of 5 below was made by the Weather Bureau.

THE annual carnival and MardiGras celebration at New Orleans is one of the most unique and colorful festivities on thi American, continent. For several weeks each Winter this remarkable old city plays host to thousands of visitors from all parts of the country who go there primarily for the occasion.

MADRID, Jaan. 28. -- The Communists are using the same tactics in Spain as they did in Russia during the revolution. Strikes here, riots there, continual turmoil everywhere give the feeling that something is going to happen as the masses are encouraged by these apparent symbols of success.

The poor average stock turn ratio of 1.4 per cent and losses ranging from 2 to 11.7 per cent of net sales are shown for 1930 and 1929 in the report on china and glassware sections in department stores which has just been completed by the controllers' congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The Arms Conference, about to open in Geneva, will show that among the casualties in the Far Kastern imbroglio, the Covenant of the League of Nations, the Kellogg Pact and the Nine-Power Pacific treaty should be listed as seriously wounded.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Dismissal of a $500,000 suit by one W.B. Foshay enterprise receiver against receivers of two others was recommended by a special master in chancery today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 30 (AP). -- Decision on an offer to purchase The Brooklyn Daily Eagle will be made by the Gannett interests prior to a meeting or stockholders Tuesday, it was announced today by Frank E. Tripp, vice president and general manager of the Gannett Company, Inc., which operates a group of dailies in New York, New Jersey and New England.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- "Pelham Manners of 1932" was presented tonight by the junior section, of the Manor Club of Pelham Manor. Miss Carolyn Rodgers of Pelham Manor wrote the music and arranged the revue. Special music was composed by Mrs. Otis H. Trowbridge, chairman of the junior section; A.H. Stevens Jr., Revell Chapman and Paul Sterrett of New York.

The eve of the celebration of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's thirtieth anniversary as president of Columbia University, to be held on Feb. 11, finds the university planning a $20,000,000 Engineering Centre which will be the climax of three decades of material and educational expansion.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 30. -- Yale's fencing team scored another easy victory here this afternoon defeating the Sanford Saltus Fencing Club of New York, 14 to 8. The Eli swordsmen won the foils competition, 5 to 4, the epee, 3 to 1, and the sabre duels, 6 to 3.

ONE of the most striking shifts in contemporary taste is the rise to favor, within the last few years, of the art that followed the close of the High Renaissance in Italy. During the first decades of the twentieth century, critics and historians of art were wont to damn such painters as Caravaggio, Guido Reni and the Caracci with the ignominious epithet "baroque," supported by slighting references to "Counter-Reformation rhetoric," and "brown soup."

EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 30. -- Michigan State College made it two straight over Colgate University tonight by defeating the Maroons, 29 to 28, in a game that was decided in the first overtime period.

NO man," declare the biographers, "ever looked more the circus barker and less the artist" than did Frank Harris. Certainly not the literary artist, one must agree, and least of all the author of "The Man Shakespeare."

"Souls of poets dead and gone. What Elysium have ye known, Happy field or mossy cavern, Choicer than the Mermaid Tavern?" -- Keats. THE Mermaid Tavern is no more. But Its ghosts have children and grandchildren and great-grandchildren that have lived long and traveled far. And the spiritual heritage of the secluded retreat of Ben Jonson, Shakespeare, Kit Marlowe and Beaumont and Fletcher is still theirs.

The first sixty-eight railroads to report for December showed net operating income of about $26,836,000, against $52,597,000 in December, 1930, a drop of 48.9 per cent, and against $68,708,000 in December, 1929, a fall of 60.9 per cent. In November their net was $32,611,000, against $57,616,000 in November, 1930, a decrease of 43.3 per cent.

BERLIN. IN a discussion of young German women who write, the first name which comes to mind is that of Grete von Urbanitzky. Indubitably this Viennese girl has talent of an extraordinary quality, though her great novel, "Eine Frau erlebt die Welt" (Paul Zolnay, Vienna-Berlin) does not give unalloyed delight.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- Etched against the white background of Lake Placid's snow-covered streets, the varicolored flags of seventeen nations flapped lazily in the breeze today and high on the central masthead in the stadium waved the Olympic banner with its five interlocking circles.

PARIS. FRANCE regards the disarmament problem differently from almost every other nation. To a very great extent the idea of arms limitation by international agreement was French in inception. It is one of those ideas which naturally suggests itself to the French mind, which likes to have life systematized, balanced and controlled.

THE rural population of the United States is gradually becoming accustomed to the throb of the night mail planes running along scheduled routes. Country dwellers are developing city ears and no longer awaken at these sounds in the hours just before the dawn.

BERLIN, Jan. 22. -- To European athletes the Olympic Games at Los Angeles mean the chance of a lifetime, the coveted chance of a visit to the United States. This fact alone guarantees that there will be as many contestants from Europe at the Tenth Olympiad as can possibly get there.

One of the outstanding individual scorers in New York City's scholastic basketball ranks is Vinnie McCormack, who occupies one of the guard positions on the St. Peter's High School quintet of Staten Island. McCormack captained the team last year.

Virtually all the important commodity future markets displayed a slightly easier tone last week. Early in the week the sugar market was considerably lower on reports of disagreements on the restriction program, but toward the close it recovered a large part of its loss.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Secretary Mellon announced today the detailed allotment of $372,003,000 of certificates of indebtedness recently offered "by the treasury. The funds obtained will be used to finance the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and to retire an issue of $61,000,000 in treasury bills due Monday.

There was heard last week, even above the clamor of Presidential politics, a pleasant sound in the land. It was the grinding of the mills of economic readjustment. People seemed to feel that at last the government and industry of the country were beginning to rebuild on the foundations that exist today -- even though these foundations may be the ruins of the bull market.

A WELL-WRITTEN life," Carlyle said, in one of his infrequent lighter moments "is almost as rare as a well-spent one." He was of the clan of writers of Lives, but that was nearly a hundred years ago. Times and biographies are changed.

MAN has long talked about signaling to Mars, 35,000,000 miles away. That planet is selected because its "canals" and indications of vegetation have encouraged astronomers to believe the red-hued sphere to be inhabited.

STOCKHOLM. SOME nature films of outstanding interest and educational value have recently been shown in Stockholm. The brothers Utterstrom, the Swedish ski champions, one of whom will represent his country at the Lake Placid international contests, are hunters by occupation, and part of their booty on their return from the Canadian wilds is a story in pictures and entertaining captions of brown bears and deer and elks and other wild life of the American north.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Representative James W. Collier, Democrat, of Mississippi, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, collapsed while sitting at his desk in the Capitol Building today. He was taken immediately to Prospect Hospital, where his condition was pronounced as "not serious."

THE Air Travel League of America, with headquarters in Pittsburgh, has been organized by a group of men from aviation, professional and business circles to meet an indicated need for an interpretation of air transportation in this country.

Emil Carlsen, noted Danish artist who died on Jan. 2 at his home, 43 East Fifty-ninth Street, at the age of 78, left his estate, which was valued at "more than $10,000." to his widow, Luella May Ruby Carlsen, it became known yesterday when his will was offered for probate in the Surrogates' Court.

J. Howard Shoemaker of the New York Athletic Club, defending champion, defeated Robert Cole, former titleholder, 125 to 97, in 30 innings, last night in the national amateur pocket billiard tournament in progress at the New York Lodge of Elks, under the auspices of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players.

Moscow. THE Soviet attitude toward world disarmament may be summed up in the homely phrase, "There ain't no sech animal." Far from entertaining hope of satisfactory results at the Geneva conference, Soviet leaders and the official press have made no secret of their opinion that the whole business is a low political shuffle aimed at bamboozling the peoples of the world.

BERLIN, Jan. 10, 1932. THE latest to follow the example of Richard Strauss and Erich Korngold in enriching the private repertory of Paul Wittgenstein, the pianist who lost his right arm during the war and who then proceeded to develop a most astonishing virtuosity with his left, is Maurice Ravel.

Public pinion must force drastic revision of the penal laws and the code of criminal procedure if organized crime with its racketeers and gunmen is to be successfully combated, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. said yesterday at the weekly forum of the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue.

MADRID, Jan. 28. -- Alarmed by the number of unemployed in the rural districts, estimated at 500,000, President Zamora has signed a decree to force landowners to hire laborers on "undermanned" properties under penalty of losing their land.

MUKDEN, Dec. 20. -- The last three months have witnessed a new and an amazing extension of what the Japanese call their "sphere of interest," and sometimes even their "sphere of influence" in what is loosely called the Manchurian area.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Paul P. Gourrich was quoted in THE TIMES as asserting the necessity for economic planning for industry to prevent dictatorship for business and to preserve individual effort. He stated that schools of economic thought were how broadly divided into two camps, planned versus free economy, and that advocates of the latter doctrine based their assumptions on an economy which was largely the echo of an outlived era.

ANOTHER attempt to end slavery in Liberia is in progress at Geneva, where an international conference is considering the status of natives of the African Republic held in servitude and the steps that are necessary to abolish the practice. About a year and a half ago the results of an international investigation into slave conditions in Liberia were made public, and such a flood of protest followed that Liberia promised to end the traffic.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- With the proposal to prolong the life of the Hofstadter committee, investigating the government of the city of New York, for another year having received the necessary legislative sanction, several measures which will serve at the same time as retaliation and as a test of Republican sincerity and good faith are either in course of preparation or already pending before the Senate and Assembly.

LONDON. THAT the volume just issued under the title "The Year Book of Education, 1932" (Evans) is the first of its kind is somewhat surprising in view of the vast extent of the educational literature previously existing.

The reports of earnings of the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for 1931, which showed for the former a deficit of $49,236,881, and for the latter, one of $13,179,255, after dividend payments, have stimulated the suggestion by brokers that these companies and many other industrial units might show improved earnings in the future, by writing down the value of their fixed assets, thus decreasing depreciation charges.

The Giants yesterday brought their complete string of catchers into the fold with the announcement by Secretary Jim Tierney that the signed contract of Bob O'Farrell, the veteran backstop, has been received. As there are only three catchers on the Giant roster, this completes the list, Frank Hogan and Francis Healey having signed some time ago.

The radio will carry daily reports of the progress of the Olympic Winter games from Lake Placid to every corner of the United States. Two chains, the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System, will make accounts of the activities of the world's great athletes engaged in the contests available to innumerable followers of Winter sports.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- A variety of events featuring numerous sport and social activities will usher in the week at Southern Pines. The program begins today with a benefit exhibition golf match at the Southern Pines Country Club. The midseason tournament will start Tuesday at the Country Club and continue through the week.

AT a recent meeting of the Metropolitan Gasoline Dealers Association at the association's offices, 233 West Forty-second Street, Gregory L. Halley, president, announced that a concentrated fight would be made against the proposed gas tax increase.

The addition of three teams to the annual P.S.A.L. senior high school championship dual meet swimming series since the original schedule for the annual competition was issued on Jan. 7 has caused a complete revision of the schedule. John Adams High, Far Rockaway High and Townsend Harris Hall High have been added, making the total number of teams entered twenty-seven.

The intelligence and general culture of college sophomores throughout the country will be measured this Spring by a aeries of tests to be given simultaneously as part of a research project being developed by the cooperative test service under the auspices of the American Council on Education, it was announced yesterday at Columbia University.

IF some American rivers of song have undergone spectacular changes since the melodies associated with them arose, what has happened to European streams which are known better through phrases of poets and composers than from descriptions of geographers?

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 30. -- Carnegie Institution of Washington announces receipt of a telegram from Dr. Sylvanus G. Morley of its archaeological staff that discovery has just been made at Chichen Itza, Yucatan, of a beautifully sculptured and painted Maya platform, the best of its type thus far uncovered at this place.

THE Russians have never made any secret of their need of rubber. Before we ever heard of the Five-Year Plan the Soviet Union offered a first prize of $50,000 and a second of $25,000 for a commercial synthetic rubber process, the contest to close early in 1928.

MINEOLA, L.I. Jan. 30 -- In findings of fact handed down today by Supreme Court Justice Burt Jay Humphrey to counsel in the litigation over title to Seaman's Gore, a strip of land of about 1,000 acres between the Atlantic Ocean and the mainland near Seaford, L.I., the court holds that title to the property vests in the State of New York.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The British press is thoroughly aroused tonight over the actual and potential seriousness of the events in Shanghai. All except the Rothermere and Beoverbrook newspapers demande swift and effective action by Britain in conjunction, with the United States and other powers to localize the conflict and then end it altogether.

DETROIT, Jan. 28. -- The latest step of the anti-prohibition forces in Michigan is the recent concerted action of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, the Michigan Moderation League and the Crusaders in circulating "red, white and blue" petitions to place on the ballot in the November election, the following amendment to the existing prohibition amendment to the Michigan Constitution:

LONDON, Jan. 14. THE speeches made by dramatists at the fall of the curtain are generally brief and formal, which is well, for if the play has been good, we do not want its illusion to be frittered away in personalities, and if the play has been bad, the author's gratitude is embarrassing.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30. -- Aspirants for the honor of representing America in Olympic rowing are now bobbing between the freighter lanes on the muddy water of the Oakland Estuary.

RENO, Nev., Jan 30 (AP). -- Mrs. Lucy Cotton Hann, publisher of the New York Morning Telegraph and a former stage star, filed suit today to divorce Charles Hann Jr., former Deputy Attorney General of New York and Harvard football star. Mrs. Hann charged extreme cruelty.

WITH the sinking of the British M-2 the number of submarines that have met disaster since 1904 now totals twenty. Russia, the United States, France, England, Germany, Japan, Italy -- no great naval power has been spared.

GENEVA, Jan. 30. -- Sir Eric Drummond, acting under authority which Article XV gives him as Secretary General of the League of Nations, formed today, from diplomats present in Shanghai when the Japanese landed, a committee to inform the Council of what had happened and is happening there.

LAKE PLACID. -- With the opening date of the Olympic Winter Games on Thursday, Lake Placid has already donned its holiday dress. The streets are a kaleidoscope of color at night as the varicolored lights shine through the miles of evergreen roping which decorate hotels, private homes and shops.

The younger set of women fencers come in for their share of attention this week with the staging at the Fencers Club on Tuesday evening of the preliminary round for New York entries in the national junior championship.

WARSAW, Jan. 28. -- It will be impossible for the disarmament conference to push aside the security problem or to disregard its importance, according to the semi-official Gazetta Polska, which says in an editorial that not all countries are island or continents well guarded by natural frontiers.

Plans are being made for a celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on March 17, and a committee of leaders on the Exchange has been formed. The Exchange was opened for trading as the New York Coffee Exchange on March 7, 1882.

Ship lines have developed a technique in loading automobiles aboard ship in the last few years which is held largely responsible for the fact that in 1931 the decrease of motor cars carried overseas for travelers was only 25 per cent from the total for 1930, whereas the decrease in passengers traffic ranged from 30 to 40 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Fliers who established new air marks last year received National Aeronautical Association certificates at a reception here tonight. Senator Hiram Bingham, president of the association, presented the certificates and the Washington Aero Club acted as hosts.

HAVANA, Jan. 30 (AP). -- A six-furlong sprint for four-year-olds and up featured a mediocre card at Oriental Park today, the winner turning up in C. Troutt's My Beauty, a six-year-old bay mare by Porte Drapeau-Trade Mark.

When Eva Hoanig sold to Benjamin Horwitz the three-story dwelling at 530 West 142d Street she took hack a purchase-money mortgage for $7.500. due in five years at 6 per cent and subject to a first mortgage for $9.000.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The Hon. Averill Furness, daughter of Lord Furness, shipping financier, by his first wife, was married to Andrew Rattray, noted East African hunter in charge of the Furness shooting party, it was reported here today. The ceremony was quietly performed at the office of the district commissioner at Nairobi.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 30. -- Ray Mangrum of Los Angeles, and Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., professionals, led the field today at the end of the first thirty-six holes of the $2,500 Texas open golf tournament. Each had a card of 143.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Bullish enthusiasm was rampant early today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here and prices rushed up around 1 1/2 cents to a new high mark since Nov. 21 on the July, while the September sold at a best top for the season.

The outcome of the disarmament conference depends on the people. It is becoming appallingly evident that this oftrepeated declaration is not mere evangelistic rhetoric. In fact, there seems to be increasing reason for believing that the fate of the conference is in the hands of the people of the United States -- or of the United States and Great Britain.

Modification of the anti-trust laws so as to sanction combinations not inimical to public welfare was advocated by speakers who discussed "anti-trust laws and the attitude of the government toward business" yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the National Republican Club.

The Old Order Changreth. TO many people, one of the most depressing things about the depression is the closing of the Automobile Club of America. It was not just another automobile club. It was an institution intimately and essentially involved with the development of motoring in this country.

SPECTACULAR strikes and gunplay in the sort-coal fields of Kentucky present an illusion of being the main drama. In reality they are incidental, as the struggles of trapped animals in a clearing are incidental to the devastation of a forest fire.

MUKDEN, Jan. 4. -- Though Japanese authorities in Mukden, both civil and military, are extremely eager to give a courteous hearing to all the criticisms which foreigners have to offer on their policies in Manchuria, and though they freely admit that many blunders and mistakes have been made, they stanchly defend the fact that they have put many Chinese ex-bandits into high positions.

THE "Small Town" of Bradda Field's novel is not one of those Middle Western ones of the United States about which so much has been written, but is located in Ontario, Canada. For general dreariness, there would seem to be nothing to choose between Canada and our Middle West, although the Canadian town is here presented as being, if anything, the narrower in its interests, the more circumscribed in its horizon.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30. -- Dr. Herbert Adams Gibbons, writer and traveler and former member of the Princeton University politics department, defended tonight the Japanese policy in China as the manner in which all great nations have acted and are acting in questions of national life and preservation, and said he did not see any cause for alarm by the foreign residents of Shanghai.

PAU, France. Jan. 30. -- In the presence of a distinguished gathering of American and French officials and airmen an imposing monument was dedicated this morning to the memory of Wilbur Wright at the field of Pontlong, five miles from here, where the American pioneer aviator set up the first flying school in the world nearly a quarter century ago.

THE effort which is becoming more and more habitual with those who make our dance recitals, to make them more and more entertaining by bringing them closer to the practices of the theatre, was brought up once more for critical consideration last week when Grace Cornell presented a program of "theatre dances" composed especially for her by the eminent German dance theorist and pedagogue, Rudolph von Laban.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 30 (AP). -- Two dozen penalties were called and two fist fights developed tonight as Springfield and the Bronx Tigers played a 2-2 tie in a Canadian-American Hockey League game that brought the uncommon sight of a goalie being penalized.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Whitney Young of New York City, Consul at Yokohama, has been assigned as Consul at Colombo, Ceylon. Other changes in the foreign service the past week were announced by the State Department today as follows:

THE only library engaged in the publication of a complete general catalogue of books relating to America is the John Carter Brown Library, in Brown University, Providence, R.I. The significance of this record may be grasped when it is understood that the list will include approximately 30,000 titles, with full descriptions, of works on the discovery, exploration and settlement of North, South and Central America before the year 1801.

ROME. ITALY must perhaps be considered the latest arrival among the nations which have ranged themselves firmly in favor of disarmament, but she has embraced this cause with all the fervor of the neophyte.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Lieut. Commander S.G. Moore of Paris, Texas, commander of the United States destroyer Truxton, in a dispatch to the Navy Department today reviewed events immediately preceding and following the truce which was to have become effective yesterday between the Japanese and Chinese.

IN its scope and maturity. Ward Greene's third novel represents a considerable advance over his two earlier books. "Cora Potts" and "Ride the Nightmare" were simple chronicle novels and each related the adventures of a single character.

Pronouncing himself fit to step up and start pounding out homers for Brooklyn, Hack Wilson, king of the four-base hitters two years ago, had a conference with his new boss, Max Carey, yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

Eight new ring champions will be crowned in the New York State amateur boxing tournament which gets under way tonight in Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the Metropolitan A.A.U. The program of preliminaries is scheduled to start at 7:45 o'clock.

HAVANA, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Jockey R. Martin, who has been riding well, took over the spotlight at Oriental Park today by piloting two winners. He triumphed on Robert Robertson's Morning Beams in the second race and followed this by riding J.J. Keith's Fairyman home an easy winner in the fourth, feature event for 4-year-olds and upward, at six furlongs.

When the current news relates to industrial activities or corporation earnings, it is unpleasant enough; it presents a cheerful aspect mostly when it reflects the industrial state of mind and the measures taken to alleviate existing difficulties. In that category the agreement on wage reduction by the railway unions with the rail-way managers must be placed.
VERA CRUZ, Mexico, Jan. 31. -- Newton D. Baker, former United States Secretary of War, and his wife, arrived here this evening aboard the Ward liner Siboney on a vacation trip, their first to Mexico.

With formal ratification of the 25 per cent wage cut in the building trades set for Wednesday at a meeting of the thirty trade groups comprising the Building Trades Employers' Association of New York, there was some talk over the week-end in building circles of a counter-proposal by organized employes, according to Alien E. Beals in the current Dow Service Reports.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Gus Copulos of Eugene, Ore., one of the four players favored to win the title, was defeated by Len Kenney, Chicago, 50 to 32, in forty-seven innings, in the world's championship three-cushion billiard tournament tonight. The loss, his third in eight games, dropped Copulos from a tie for third in the standings to fourth place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- J.P. Morgan Co. made a net profit of $10,071,903.05 on sales in the United States of foreign bonds of a total face value of $1,875,578,000 between Jan. 1, 1920, and Dec. 15, 1931.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 31. -- China, the world's greatest geographic national entity, occupying an eighth of the world's land surface and in-habited by a fourth of the world's population, tonight presents the most tragic aspect known to mankind since the cessation of the European war thirteen years ago.

BROINTXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 31. -- Despite a howling wind and the penetrating cold, twenty-two members of the Siwanoy Country Club competed today in the eighth and final qualifying round of the annual Snow-birds golf tournament. Eleven of them returned cards.

Although reduced buying budgets served to lower volume, a steady degree of purchasing featured the week in the wholesale markets here. Initial reorders on suits came through from Southern stores and confidence in the sales possibilities of these garments during the coming season was strengthened.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 31. -- Continuing their crusade against the State "blue laws" of 1798, three of the four Plainfield motion-picture theatres again attempted to open today for Sunday performances. But scarcely were the doors thrown wide and the cashiers' windows raised when determined policemen made three arrests and personally supervised the closing of the houses.

The Rev. Dr. Francis P. Duffy, veteran chaplain, inaugurated at 2:15 A.M. yesterday a mass for night workers at his church, the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, Forty-second Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31. -- Woman's plane in the new Russia theoretically is equal to man's -- in voting and all other rights of citizenship. With regard to wages, women generally get the same as men of equivalent capacity in industry, business and office administrations, although there are individual complaints, especially in the teaching profession, that women sometimes receive a lower scale.

The Thirty-first United States Infantry, which was ordered from Manila to the International Settlement in Shanghai as additional protection for the Americans there, is the crack outfit of the Philippine Division. It is familiarly called "The Polar Bear Regiment," as a tribute to an earlier life, and it has the distinction of being an organization that, as such, never served on the American, continent.

A three-goal lead proved immensely valuable to the New York Americans in their National Hockey League game with the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night, for the rugged visitors from the North, refusing to surrender, hacked away at the New York advantage and threatened to tie before a last-period goal by Normie Himes blasted their chances and gave the Americans the victory by 4 to 2.

The preliminary report of the United Gas Improvement Company for 1931 shows total income from dividends, interest and miscellaneous sources amounting to $37,914,977, compared with $36,204,055 in 1930, an increase of $1,710,922, or 4.7 per cent. After provision for expenses, interest and taxes, net income available for dividends amounted to $34,750.114, an increase of 5.9 per cent over $32,810,744 reported in 1930.

Christian marriage is the hope of the family and the State, Dr. Caleb R. Stetson, rector of Trinity Church, said in his sermon yesterday morning. It is the duty of Christian people, he said, to "stand firmly for the ideals of Christian marriage and to let it be known that we are faithful to our Lord."

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- The report in London that ex-Governor Lowden was slated to succeed General Dawes at St. James's gained credence in political circles here tonight following Mr. Lowden's refusal to either deny or affirm it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Ignoring the recent adverse vote in the Senate on a resolution offered by Senator Bingham for a referendum on prohibition, Senator Wagner of New York will introduce tomorrow a joint resolution to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment.

The new headquarters of the Kips Bay Day Nursery at 454 East 122d Street will be dedicated on the afternoon of Feb. 25. During the ceremonies a plaque will be unveiled to the memory of the late Mrs. Arthur Murray Dodge, whose generous gifts have aided the nursery.
PARIS, Jan. 31. -- The French delegation to the arms conference, headed by former Premier Tardieu boarded a train tonight for Geneva.

DONNACONA, Que., Jan. 31 (Canadian Press). -- Racing the thirty miles in the record-breaking time of 4 hours 27 minutes, John Jokela, noted Finnish runner who makes his home in Toronto, today won the first lap of the Quebec to Montreal snowshoe marathon.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 31. -- (AP) -- William R. Castle Jr., Under-Secretary of State, speaking here tonight, expressed the hope that the Sino-Japanese situation would accentuate the need of disarmament and facilitate the work of the impending conference at Geneva.

EDMONTON, Alta., Jan. 31 (Canadian Press). -- Murder balked Canada's "Mounties" today in their month-long quest for Albert Johnson, mad trapper of the Rat River country inside the Arctic Circle. Constable E. Millen, a member of a mounted police force seeking Johnson for wounding another constable, was shot when the first attempt was made to capture him Saturday by the two-gun hermit.
SHANGHAI (Monday), Feb. 1. -- Pour American destroyers steamed into Shanghai's harbor today to lift the anxiety of foreigners frightened by fighting between forces of China and Japan.

Securities admitted to the two local stock exchanges in January were comparatively few, and were mostly additions to issues already listed. The total of admissions to the list of the New York Stock Exchange was $112,021,307, of which $32,800,000 was new bonds, $50,645,000 additional bonds, $2,013,429 new stock, and $26,562,878 additional stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Consul General Edwin S. Cunningham, in a report to the State Department from Shanghai today, stated that he was making representations to Consul General Mural of Japan for damage done to American property in the International Settlement by Japanese vigilantes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- A group of tired but happy presidents of railroads and union leaders affixed their signatures at 11.40 o'clock tonight to an agreement under which 1,500,000 railroad workers will permit a 10 per cent deduction from their pay for one year.

At this time of unrest what the world needs is the steadfast mind, said Dr. J.V. Moldenhawer, minister of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and West Eleventh Street, in his sermon on 'Christianity and the Steadfast Mind."

Participation by officials and representatives of public utility companies in the annual conventions of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners was condemned yesterday as injurious to utility regulation and destructive of public confidence in regulatory bodies, in a letter sent to all members of the association by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the New York Public Service Commission, acting jointly with the full membership of the California and Wisconsin regulatory boards.

A proposal for a social and economic "general staff" as a means to avert depressions and to alleviate them if they come was advanced yesterday by Otto H. Kahn, international banker and philanthropist, in an address at the annual breakfast of the House of Artists and Writers, 244 West Tenth Street.
LONDON, Jan. 31. -- Great Britain ordered a warship from Hongkong today with a battalion of infantry and a battery of artillery to Shanghai to reinforce the ships and troops already there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Seeking the highest and driest accessible spot in the Eastern Hemisphere, the Smithsonian Institution is considering the establishment of a solar observatory in the Sinai Peninsula where, according to the Old Testament record, Moses received the Ten Commandments.

A.C. Blumenthal has been elected a director of the Roxy Theatres Corporation. He was placed on a subcommittee to arrange for a new financial set-up for the company, and to study its operating methods.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 31. -- A problem which for many years has occupied leaders in Jewish religious and cultural thought, that of the non-categorized or un-churched, was discussed here today at the closing sessions of the two-day semi-annual meeting of the executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

Edwin Apfelbaum of the Newark Elks defeated Vaino Korhonen, unattached, 125 to 64 in forty-four innings yesterday in the national amateur pocket billiard championship in progress at the New York Lodge of Elks under the auspices of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was with a sense of a great personal loss, even of personal failure, that I read in THE TIMES today the news "British Drop Cecil as Arms Delegate." Viscount Cecil of Chelwood has become a familiar name to me through the reading of big farsighted, thoughtful and brilliant articles on disarmament which hava been published in THE TIMES Magazine from time to time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The output of motor vehicles in the United States in 1931 totaled 2,389,730 units, as compared with 3,355,986 in 1930 and 5,358,420 in 1929, when the record was established, a survey by the Department of Commerce shows.

The regular Sunday afternoon lecture audience at the workhouse on Welfare Island sat rapt yesterday while M.H. Aylesworth, president of the National Broadcasting Company, sketched the history of radio, offered opinions as to its future, and settled at least one matter that seemed to be in the mind of every one present.

From the Foreign Office at Tokyo came a statement echoing the one made to the Council of the League of Nations by the Japanese delegate. He said, and so did the Foreign Office, that the League would assume "a terrible responsibility" if it sought to ascertain the rights and wrong's of the action of Japanese Marines in Shanghai.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Appeals to liberals to back. a third party movement were made here today in statements issued by Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader, and the League for Independent Political Action, headed by Professor John Dewey.

A foretaste of what the local Weather Bureau described as the beginning here of the cold wave now gripping the Middle and Far West was afforded residents in this city and surrounding regions yesterday as a west wind of gale proportions blew the temperature down to its seasonably freezing level and dispelled those flickering glimpses of Spring fondly suspected by some to be just around the corner.

Grover Cleveland, the Democratic Governor of New York, who fought Tammany and became President, is presented in Denis Tilden Lynch's new biography. "Grover Cleveland: a Man Four-Square," as a hard-drinking, fist-fighting politician who made saloons his clubs and found many of his early friends among the habitues of these clubs.

A determined effort is being made by the automotive and related interests to defeat Governor Roosevelt's proposal for an increase in the tax on gasoline from 2 to 4 cents a gallon, according to the Petroleum Industries Committee, recently organized by the oil companies operating in New York State to handle their part in the campaign.

Detailed plans of the American Diamond Lines for increasing the speed of their six vessals from ten to fourteen knots under an agreement with the United States Shipping Board were announced yesterday by J.E. Dockendorff, president of the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation, owners of the lines.
GENEVA, Jan. 31. -- The arms conference will open Tuesday as scheduled, although there were rumors here most of today that it might be postponed because of the Sino-Japanese situation.

GENEVA, Jan. 31. -- Samuel Reber Jr., representing the United States Government on the Liberian committee of the Council of the League of Nations, has handed in a memorandum giving a report on serious repressive measures taken by the Liberian Government against natives, particularly the Kru coast tribes.

Further overtures to former Governor Alfred E. Smith by friends of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt are likely to be made in the near future, it was reported yesterday, in the interest of obtaining more than an outward show of harmony between the State's Chief Executive and his predecessor.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Within a short time are opening two major international conferences, whose aim is to solve, if possible, two of the most outstanding of the knotty problems vexing the world today; namely, the problems of disarmament and of the war debts.

Sweeping changes in the city's methods of acquiring land by condemnation for public use are recommended in the first section of the report sent yesterday to Corporation Counsel Arthur J. W. Hilly by Leonard M. Wallstein, Special Assistant Corporation Counsel.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 31. -- Dinghy sailors and sailorettes of the Frostbite Yacht Club today had a taste of real Winter in the form of a forty-mile northwest gale that swept Manhasset Bay on Long Island Sound from sand dune to clam flat and knocked the mercury down to the freezing point.

A.C. Bostwick's Mate, twice conqueror of the champion, Twenty Grand last year, is placed at the top of the list with a 128-pound impost in the weights for the Metropolitan Handicap, announced yesterday by Walter Vosburgh, Jockey Club handicapper.

Baseball men from far and wide arrived in town yesterday, and while the pretense was urgent business, in connection with the American and National League schedule meetings today and tomorrow, none overlooked the opportunity of attending the ninth annual dinner of the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association of America, which drew more than 800 guests to the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore last night.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- Sentiment in the London financial market has undergone this week a decided change for the better. First came news of the successful conclusion of negotiations regarding extension of the German short-term debt, under the stand-still agreement.

LOS ANGELES, Monday, Feb. 1. -- Sixty-five ships of the battle force began moving out of the San Pedro-San Diego area at one minute after midnight and by this afternoon Admiral Richard H. Leigh will have his powerful attacking squadron all assembled at sea to begin the greatest peacetime manoeuvres ever attempted by any naval force.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 31. -- The football teams of Navy and Columbia will meet on Farragut Field here Nov. 5 and not on the Baltimore Stadium gridiron, as had been reported, it was learned at the Naval Academy today.

A "Wagnerian Welcome and Frolic in Valhalla" was held last night at the Harmonie Club in celebration of the seventieth birthday of Walter Damrosch. The "Heroes of Valhalla" who greeted their honor guest with a brief verse set to Siegfried's Call were sixty of his friends, including many of his prominent colleagues in the world of music.

ROME, Jan. 31. -- Foreign Minister Dino Grandi, accompanied by a few officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, left for Geneva this evening to attend the disarmament conference. Part of the Italian delegation already is in Geneva and part left with Signor Grandi today; the remainder, including the Ministers of War, Navy and Air, leave tomorrow.
The thirty-four chairmen who will supervise committees under the jurisdiction of the Amateur Athletic Union this year were named yesterday by President Avery Brundage.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31. -- Fog, sleet and snow handicapped the search today for the Century-Pacific air liner missing between Bakers Field and Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Farmers were advised today by the Department of Agriculture in its outlook statement for 1932 to look to increased activity in the automobile, iron and steel and constructive industries for first signs of general improvement in the domestic demand for farm products.

Samuel Seabury, who as chief counsel to the Hofstadter Committee has attacked the political "deal" that led to the creation of twelve new places on the Supreme Court bench in the Second Department, took a step yesterday toward divorcing the judiciary from politics in his capacity as president of the State Bar Association.
A party of German athletes, one of the last delegations coming for the third Olympic Winter Games, arrived yesterday morning aboard the liner Hamburg.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 31. -- Blinded by the swirling flakes of a heavy snowstorm, Captain Werner Zahn, at the helm of the German four-man bobsleigh, Fram II, climbed the icy hank of the tricky Zigzag turn on the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic run this morning while traveling at a mile-a-minute speed and the sleigh was precipitated 110 feet down the wooded mountainside.

After a protracted conference Which often seemed to be faced with failure, representatives of 1,500,000 railway employes have agreed in Chicago to accept a cut of 10 per cent in wages. Since this will remain in force only for twelve months, it is described as a " deduction" rath or than a " reduction."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The movement to block Governor Roosevelt, at present the leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, is expected to gain impetus within the next week or ten days, when Alfred E. Smith will issue a statement defining his position.

Mayor CURLEY'S "whirlwind" trip to Albany must have given a good deal more satisfaction to himself than to Governor ROOSEVELT. The other day Governor ELY, visiting former Governor SMITH in New York, told the reporters that Massachusetts would be "solid" for SMITH or the candidate he picked.

The tragic psychological effects wrought by unemployment in the lives of families and individuals, as observed by some 900 social workers who have made close to 750,000 visits to the homes of the poor In this city, are described in a report to be submitted today by the Welfare Council to its membership.

PARIS, Jan. 31. -- Jean Patou, despite announcing that he has raised waistlines, is the rare fashion creator who is clinging to normalcy except in in a few evening gowns. Most suits are worn with bodices just below the waist and belted at the natural level. The new sweaters have pointed and fitted fronts like peasants' bodices and sunburn backs.

Midway in a Metropolitan Sunday concert that hung up the "standing room only" sign on Broadway last night and earned $4,000 profit for the work of Young Judaea as beneficiary of the evening, Grischa Goluboff, a 9-ycar-old violinist, who has made public appearances in a modest way hitherto, played Mendelssohn's concerto with the opera orchestra and received an ovation from both sides of the footlights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The United States and Great Britain are answering the Japanese challenge to their rights in the International Settlement at Shanghai by sending warships, marines and troops to the danger point in the determination to give the fullest protection possible to those rights and to their nationals in the Settlement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The Costigan-La Follette bill to appropriate $375,000,000 for the relief of the unemployed, and which is opposed by the administration because of its semi-dole features, will occupy the attention of the Senate tomorrow and probably produce a prolonged fight and a bitter partisan debate.

PARIS, Jan. 31. -- France has instructed her Ambassador at Tokyo to make the same representations in regard to Shanghai that the United States and Great Britain have made, it was announced today, and has given orders for her concession at Shanghai to be "defended energetically."

An ambitious revival of "Julius Caesar," with eight stars in the cast, will soon be presented in London at His Majesty's Theatre, according to word received here yesterday. The company, which will be employed on a cooperative basis, will hold such well-known players of the English stage as Godfrey Tearle, Lyn Harding, Oscar Asche.
Marking the start of the disarmament conference at Geneva, bells and carillons in churches throughout the metropolitan area will be rung tomorrow morning between 11 o'clock and noon.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 31. -- An investigation into the financial affairs of John W. Leigh, Princeton banker and civic leader, who committed suicide here Jan. 21, has failed to locate an endowment fund belonging to the Second Presbyterian Church of Princeton totaling $52,000, which had been entrusted to Mr. Leigh, it was revealed here today.
NEWSREELS, a compilation or Movietone and Metrotone newsreels, shown continuously at the Embassy Theatre.

Paul Muni, the Rev. Walter E. Bentley and Gerald Griffin, president of the Catholic Actors' Guild were the principal speakers at an open meeting of the Jewish Theatrical Guild yesterday afternoon in the Morosco Theatre. Mr. Muni, who is now appearing in "Counsellor-at-Law," reminisced in a humorous vein of his stage and screen roles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Despite the generally depressed condition of business there was a comparatively small reduction in the output of tobacco products during 1931, as compared with the previous year, according to figures issued today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.
HONOLULU, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Daniel Lyman, murderer, whose escape from Oahu prison a month ago terrorized Honolulu householders, was captured today at John Rodgers Airport, five miles, from Honolulu.

Dr. E. Gordon Crichlow, 34 years old, a Negro physician, was found dead in his apartment on the ground floor of 139 West 143d Street at 9:15 o'clock yesterday morning, his skull crushed and the ring finger of his left hand badly lacerated. A gas range burner, believed to have been the death instrument, was on the bed.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 31. -- Selection of the Eastern group which will meet a similar Western group in an official demonstration of American football in connection with the Olympic Games at Los Angeles next Summer was announced today by T. A.D. Jones of this city, former Yale bead coach and graduate advisory football committee chairman, representing the Tenth Olympiad Committee.
NEW YORK. William T.P. Hollingsworth and Miss Jacqueline Hollingsworth, who have been living in Paris, are returning from California today and will be at the Savoy-Plaza.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31. -- A sea adventure began today with the arrival of the liner Mariposa on her maiden trip from New York to enter the San Francisco-Australia service of the Matson Line.

Declaring that the present war-like activities in the Far East and the general unrest among other nations were evidences of a need for world cooperation, the Rev. Dr. Hugh Black, professor at the Union Theological Seminary, charged American political leaders yesterday morning in his sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, with "playing politics" and the Republican Administration with breaking a promise to the people to allow them to vote on the League of Nations.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 1. -- The Foreign Office spokesman said this morning that Japan would not send troops to Shanghai unless they were requested by foreign powers or the municipality or unless the Japanese marines' position became desperate. The latter eventuality would menace the International Settlement, it is believed, and the municipality or foreign powers would then have no choice but to invite the Japanese to rush troops.

Dividend declarations in January indicated no change in the downward revision of payments. Reduced and omitted disbursements to shareholders were numerous and included lowered payments by some of the leading corporations. The total or dividends declared by 939 corporations was $234,875,617, compared with 5363,572,932 for 1,730 corporations in December and with $349,571,195 for 1,183 corporations in January, 1931.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Minnesota looms as the chief threat to North-western's drive for a second straight Western Conference basketball title. North-western is at the head of the standing with six victories in as many starts, and with the hardest part of its schedule ahead.

TOKYO, Jan. 31. -- The Japanese Government received information today that Chiang Kai-shek had ordered the Nineteenth and Third Divisions of his guards to concentrate near Shanghai in addition to the 30,000 troops already there and had ordered military aircraft from Honan Province to support the infantry.

Article I of the State Constitution contains the clause "nor shall private property be taken for public use without just compensation." It goes on to describe various methods by which that compensation is to be determined. In application they have not proved altogether satisfactory.

The Sino-Japanese situation was referred to by many ministers here in their sermons yesterday. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, radio minister of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, praised the recent notes sent by Secretary of State Stimson, condemned the bombing of Chinese civilians in Shanghai and declared that "this is not the end for Japan."

Large withdrawals or gold by European countries featured the movements of the metal through the Port of New York in January, exports aggregating $107,638,600, against $22,960,400 in imports. $1,900,000 of which came from Canada by way of Chicago, compared with $17,611.000 imported and $32,945,200 exported in December.

Controller Charles W. Berry wrote yesterday to eight banking houses and bankers that took part in the recent conference with city officials on the city's financial condition and expressed his thanks for their assistance in improving it. His letter read:

SAN ANTONIO, Texas. Jan. 31. Clarence Clark, professional from Blopmfield, N. J., won the Texas open golf tournament today when he shot a scintillating last-round 69 for a seventy-two-hole score of 287. He succeeded Abe Espinosa of Chicago as champion.

A squad of thirty-three players, comprising fourteen pitchers, three catchers, nine infielders and seven outfielders, will report to Manager John McGraw in Los Angeles late this month when the Giants open their training for the 1932 pennant campaign, according to the official roster distributed yesterday by Secretary Jim Tierney.

Irwin S. Chanin, head of the Chanin Construction Company, explained yesterday that neither he, his brother, Henry I. Chanin, nor any Chanin corporation was interested in the ownership of the properties named in the suit brought in the Supreme Court on Saturday by the Continental Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, to foreclose mortgages on the Majestic, Masque and Royale Theatres, in Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets near Eighth Avenue.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Plain steers selling largely at $5 to $7.50 a hundred pounds were picked up fairly well last week. Prices ranged low, although a fair grain was made at the close. The week's average of all steers was $6.65, or 20 cents higher than in the previous week.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- The New York Rangers tonight added two points to their lead in the American group of the National Hockey League by walloping the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 0, in the Chicago Stadium, before a crowd of 12,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Tribute to Woodrow Wilson as a champion of world peace was paid today at the Washington Cathedral by Canon Anson Phelps Stokes in an address wherein he expressed the hope that "the efforts of our President and his fine delegation to the Geneva conference shall not be later thwarted by political partisanship or a narrow nationalism.''

The first of two programs in a "Folk Festival of the Homelands" was given at the Guild Theatre last night under the auspices of the Folk Festival Council of New York, which is affiliated with the Foreign Language Information Service. Groups representing eleven nations presented songs and dances of their own tradition before an audience that filled the theatre to capacity and remained enthusiastic throughout the long program.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with a great deal of interest THE TIMES dispatch, "Soviet Develops Vast New Rubber Source; Root of Plant Said to Produce 40 Per Cent Latex."

Describing a religion devoid of the supernatural element as little more than a "devitalized set of maxims," the Rev. John Carter Smyth urged yesterday a fuller acceptance of the supernatural, principles which St. Paul taught.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- With an inciplent crop scare in the, Winter wheat country, the clash between China and Japan, the strained political situation and the bearish statistical position of the world's wheat markets, there is an abundance of material for the trade to work on, with the result that nervous markets are expected for a considerable period.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31. -- The fourth and final appearance this season of the New York string quartette was given this afternoon at the home of Mrs. W. Seward Webb on Dunbar Road.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 1. -- A battle in which artillery and machine guns are being used is under way this morning on the borders of the Hongkew area, seized by the Japanese Saturday night. The fighting follows failure of Chinese and Japanese authorities to reach an agreement yesterday (Sunday) afternoon to end hostilities.

The "Surrealisme" show at the Julien Levy Gallery, 602 Madison Avenue, about which there has been so much discussion, has come and gone, and the gallery has now opened a much less taxing exhibition of modern photography by Walker Evans and George Lynes.

Mischa Elman made his first appearance of the season in recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. His program included Handel's sonata in A, Mozart's sonata in B flat, No. 15; Glazunoff's concerto in A minor, a group of abort pieces by Gluck-Ries, Beethoven-Elman, Chopin-Wilhelmj and Brahms-Joachim and Vieuxtemps's "Ballade et Polonaise."

Cooperation in Government, Inc., an organization to encourage pupils to become leaders in school activities and to develop responsibility, will present 200 awards at forty-one of the high school graduations which are being held this week.
STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Cal., Jan. 31 (AP). -- An end to the age of metals is foreseen by Professor Theodore J. Hoover, dean of the Stanford School of Engineering and brother of President Hoover.

Toscha Seidel, noted violinist, played a concert last night in the auditorium of the Young Men's Hebr Association, Lexington Avenue at Ninety-second Street, before a large invited audience. The concert was sponsored by the department of music of the association in commemoration of the birthday anniversary of Theresa L. Kaufman, to whose memory the auditorium was dedicated.

A garage, a storage warehouse, a poultry market and a frame house were burned to the ground and six other buildings were partially damaged in Jersey City yesterday morning in one of the largest fires there in recent years. The flames spread unchecked for more than three hours as every available piece of fire apparatus in the city was called out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Payments for the operation and maintenance of the general departments of Montclair, N.J., in 1930, were $2,416,775 or $57.13 per capita, according to a survey made public by the Bureau of the Census today. Operation of public service enterprises (waterworks) cost $242,051.

MANILA, Monday, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Three destroyers steamed out of Manila Harbor soon after 9 A.M. today (8 P.M. Sunday in New York), as the advance guard of nine ships of the Asiatic Fleet ordered to Shanghai to protect American lives and property.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 31. -- The Elizabeth Town and Country Club defeated the Montclair A.C-, 5 to 0, today in a Class B New Jersey group match of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League tournament.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 31. -- The Japanese forces holding the International Settlement area east of Soochow Creek continued today to evict literally tens of thousands of Chinese from their homes and humble places of business, and an enormous stream of distraught humanity continued pouring into the heart of the Settlement from across Soochow Creek bridges.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- Action on budget cuts and clarification of negotiations for an additional tax program appeared probable for the coming week of the Legislature as the members began to arrive at the Capitol for tomorrow night's session.

The Museum of Modern Art, 730 Fifth Avenue, which has just closed an exhibition of the work of Diego Rivera, Mexican mural painter, will offer an invited list of American mural painters an opportunity to show their work in the museum, according to announcement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Adoption of a permanent and uniform policy respecting military pensions and veterans' benefits, as a part of the program to cut Federal expenditures, was recommended today by a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, headed by Matthew S. Sloan of New York.

The Hakoah All-Stars and New Bedford of the American Soccer League staged a return exhibition match at Commercial Field, Brooklyn, yesterday for the benefit of the World Maccabee Association games to be played in Palestine in March. When the two teams met for the same purpose in December, Hakoah won, and the local team emerged the victor again yesterday, 2 to 1.

PARIS, Jan. 29. -- The influx of gold into France, the considerable magnitude of which was indicated in Thursday's bank statement, is considered likely to continue. The reason assigned is that the movement reflects a general lack of confidence, justified by existing economic troubles; that international credits are becoming narrower, and that banks in every country are seeking to call in "unfrozen" foreign credits.

Six railroad crossing watchmen, employed by the Long Island Railroad at crossings in the Rockaway Beach division of the line were arrested early yesterday morning on charges of leaving their posts of duty. Two of them were accused also of grand larceny in connection with the looting of telephone coin boxes and slot machines in the stations along the division.

HERE it is February and G.H. Ruth is getting ready to head far Florida. Just a few weeks and the boys will be tossing the ball around in the training camps. It's almost time to take stock of the veterans on hand and check up on the newcomers who will be getting their first whirl on the big circuit.

There are many reasons why the layman finds himself troubled In the presence of the new physical sciences. They are expressed in a language of supermathematics which few specialists even are able to employ or understand. Then the new discoveries apparently violate the basic rules of logic or common sense.

Undaunted by the experiences of Dr. FILCHNER and Sir ERNEST SHACKLETON in the Weddell Sea, Mr. H.G. WATKINS, leader of the British air-route expedition to Greenland, proposes to land an exploring party, survey the Antarctic coast line between Luitpold Land and Graham.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- In the rubber market here today plantation grades were quiet and easier. Smoked sheet spot and February sold at 2 15-16d to 2 3/8d a pound buyers, March from 3d to 2 7/8d to 2 15-16d value, April-June at 3 1/4d to 3 1/8 buyers, July-September at 3 1/4d to 3 1/8d to 3 3-16d sellers, October-December at 3 1/4d to 3 1/8d to 3 5-16d sellers.

Charges that George O. Barnes, a representative of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States, has been seeking $15 annual memberships in that organization from Queens storekeepers with the implication that if they joined their Sunday closing hours would not be subjected to scrutiny by the league any longer are under investigation by the police.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 31. -- While trading in the cotton contract market here last week was a little more active than in the preceding week, the range of prices was narrow and values ruled quite steady, considering the weakness that developed in the stock market, the unfavorable situation in the Far East and the less promising outlook for the desired reduction in the acreage to be devoted to cotton this year.

The final result of the recent $5,138,000 campaign of the New York Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, to provide the 1932 budgets of ninety-one affiliated organizations, was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the federation in the Community House of Temple Emanu-EI by Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the federation.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 1 -- (AP) -- L. M. Karakhan, Soviet Russia's acting Commissar for foreign Affairs, informed Japanese Ambassador Hirota today that Russia might be compelled to protest against the entry of Japanese troops into Harbin, Manchuria, the Ambassador informed the Foreign Office today.
Prayers for world peace and sermons expressing hope for the success of the forthcoming disarmament conference at Geneva were heard in the city's pulpits yesterday.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Jan. 31. -- Edward H.B. Allen will go on trial tomorrow on a first degree murder indictment growing out of the slaying last Nov. 9 of Francis A. Donaldron 3d, socially prominent suitor of the defendant's sister. Miss Rose E. W. Alien.
Heal estate investors in the metropolitan area showed a preference for housing properties, according to deals announced over the week-end.

After having made methodical arrangements for his cremation and burial, William C.M. Smith, 55 years old, of 602 West 190th Street a retired automobile salesman, committed suicide last Saturday night in the Hargrave Hotel, 112 West Seventy-second Street, by drinking a mixture of two poisons.
CHICAGO. Jan. 31. -- The agreement signed tonight by representatives of the railroads and the railway unions carried the following terms on the demands of the men:

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club and the St. Nicholas Hockey Club were the winners in the amateur double-header held under the auspices of the Bronx County post of the Veterans of Foreign Wars at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The Crescents triumphed over the New York A.C. sextet by 3 to 0, while the St. Nicholas skaters downed the Lake Katonah Hockey Club, 4 to 0.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- The feature of the speeches made at the annual London bank meetings by the chairmen this month, is their unanimity concerning the causes which forced Great Britain off the gold standard. The speeches agree that external circumstances played the largest part in that crisis, but all admit frankly that our own internal economic conditions also contributed in no small degree to the catastrophe.

Dr. Gustav Bucky, inventor of the Grenz ray for the treatment of skin diseases and director of the X-ray department of the Virchow Hospital, Berlin, arrived yesterday from Germany on the Hamburg of the Hamburg-American Line, accompanied by Mrs. Bucky, to study the new developments in high-tension X-ray apparatus.

One Thing Left In. Efforts to take several public questions "out of politics" are still making, and with a certain promise of success. It is confidently said that ex-Secretary BAKER'S statement about the League of Nations will cause It to cease to be an issue between parties.
