Paul de Bruyn, national marathon champion of Germany and holder of the New York County cross-country title, captured first place in the handicap road race held by the Manhattan. Athletic League under the auspices of the Greek-American A. C. in Manhattan yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- In order to meet a maturity of $75,173,000 in treasury bills Feb. 8, Secretary Mellon announced today that a new issue of about $75,000,000 would be made at that time.

Interest rates on call loans In January eased, after the first week, from levels approximating those of the closing days of December to 2 1/2 per cent for the remainder of the month, resulting in an average for renewals that equaled December's.

The Bronx zoo bore itself with a commendable calmness yesterday, at least in comparison with certain other Sunday afternoons. Part of its resident population was too much interested in tomorrow's matters to consider anything else. It is then that the zoo will stake all on a new groundhog, one almost without practice in shadow visibility.

GENEVA, Jan. 21. -- The Secretariat of the League of Nations received word today that Robert Haas, the Frenchman who is director of its transit section, had reached Shanghai last night by boat, after the train in which he started from Nanking had been stopped, and was trying to organize the League's investigating committee on the Shanghai affair as fast as he could amid the fire and fighting.

ATTLEBORO, Mass., Jan. 31. -- Six men put in two hours of work burglarizing the Horton-Angell Company jewelry factory early this morning and escaped with $60,000 worth of gold wire, rolled gold plate and bullion.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 31. -- Emphasizing that rigid economy in government and not the creation of public debt through the building of improvements is the path to prosperity, the board of governors of the Investment Bankers of America ended their meeting at the Seaview Golf Club at Absecon today.

Jones Wilder Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, announced yesterday that the board intended backing to the limit the bill introduced in the Legislature by Senator Hofstadter permitting the city to reopen its budget and slash from it items of expense whose elimination is deemed essential to municipal economy.

Despite the fact that Princeton was idle again last week, John Siebert, crack Tiger forward, remained entrenched at the top of the individual scorers in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race.

TRENTON. N.J., Jan. 31. -- Howard R. Stewart, 55 years old, a real estate dealer of White Plains, N.Y., was found dead tonight of a bullet wound in the mouth and his wife, Lisa, 50 years old, critically wounded in a sedan on the Yardville-Allentown road outside of here.

BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- The final arrangement reached on the "credit-freezing agreement" for Germany's short-term indebtedness is favorably regarded in financial circles here. This is particularly true of quarters where anxiety had been felt concerning the Reichsbank's reserves and the mark's stability.

Three definite steps toward world peace should be taken by the disarmament conference opening tomorrow at Geneva, Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, veteran worker for international good-will, said yesterday during a radio broadcast which linked Switzerland and the United States.

It required much credulity to believe that any formidable group of anti-Hoover delegates would go to the Chicago convention, or that the President's renomination was seriously threatened. Nevertheless, for several months Washington has produced a small crop of stareyed oracles who believe just that.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31. -- The week's shipments of all grains were heavier except corn. The estimated exportable surpluses for this date follow: Wheat, 148,194,754 bushels; corn, 20,248,463 bushels; flaxseed, 81,605,040 bushels. The wool market showed improved demand in all classes and prices were higher.

New securities offered to the public last month made the smallest total for any January in the last six years, and one issue, that of the city of New York, accounted for more than half of the amount. No industrial, railroad or foreign bonds were marketed.

The first month of the year has brought a seasonal upturn in some of the chief industries, but nothing in the way of vigorous general trade and industrial recovery is yet evident, the National City Bank says in its current bulletin.

Different views concerning modern writers were expressed in New York City pulpits yesterday. Two members of the clergy held that the modern school of writers wearied the present generation with overemphasis on what is base and vulgar in life.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Super-intendent of Banks, goes to trial this morning before Judge George L. Donnellan, in General Sessions, on indictments charging conspiracy and neglect of duty in connection with, the closing of the Bank of United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Application of the principle governing workmen's compensation for the payment of automobile accident damages was recommended today in a report by a committee which has been studying the subject under the auspices of the Columbia University Council for Research in the Social Sciences.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 1. -- What constitutes the equivalent of a functioning government for China while Marshal Chiang Kai-shek, Wang Ching-wei, and the major portion of the Nanking regime were moving to safety at Loyang [Honanfu], in distant Honan Province, was formed at Shanghai last night.
Copyright, 1932. by H.A.N.A., Inc. On all sides there is growing impatience with the increase of public expenditures and complaint against the heavy burden of taxation.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 1 -- When the investigation of charges against Dr. Cornelius P. Rhoads of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research was resumed today patients who had been treated by Dr. Rhoads appeared as volunteer witnesses and testified "Dr. Rhoads saved my life" and "he kept me from dying."
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Stanley Montague today faced the possibility of life imprisonment as a result of aiding his brother's escape from the county jail.

Rosa Ponselle fell victim to the cold wave two hours before she was to sing "La Gioconda" at the Metropolitan last evening. A large audience found printed slips in the programs announcing the prima donna's indisposition and the reappearance of Leonora Corona in her place.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Edward T. Stotesbury, president, and George A. McKinlock, vice president, were re-elected, as were members of the board of governors, at the annual meeitng of the Palm Beach Taxpayers' Association held this morning.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- After a nervous and irregular opening prices on the Bourse became steadier today and closed generally higher. The monthend liquidations were accomplished under favorable circumstances. The Bank of France shares closed 90 francs higher.

GENEVA, Feb. 1 -- On Sept. 18 of last year Japan began the invasion of China without any declaration of war, giving as an excuse that a section of the South Manchurian Railway, altogether two yards in length, which was carefully guarded by Japanese railway guards, had been destroyed by Chinese soldiers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- With the Speaker's gavel falling with machine-like rapidity today, the House went through the consent calendar in a three-hour session, passing thirty-seven bills and postponing or rejecting action on the remainder.
FRANKLIN, Texas, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Texas law to curtail cotton planting was held "unconstitutional, null and void" in a ruling by District Judge W.C. Davis today.

MANILA, Tuesday, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Amid scenes reminiscent of World War days, the naval transport Chaumont sailed for stricken Shanghai at 2:45 A.M. today (1:45 P.M. Monday in New York) with 1,056 officers and enlisted men of the Thirty-first United States Infantry Regiment aboard.

The summary of the National Education Association's report on the educational state of the nation for 1931 is that, "although here and "there the line has bent back, there "has been solid achievement." We recently mentioned France's wonderful maintenance of her schools in wartime -- the "scholastic front," as M. VIVIANI called it, having followed the military front never more than a few kilometers distant.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 1 -- A Federal survey to determine which of the States have failed to handle their relief problems and to decide what form of aid should be offered by the Federal Government was proposed today by Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland in an address before the General Assembly of Kentucky.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Feb. 1 -- A perfect bridge hand -- thirteen spades -- was dealt to Mrs. G. Comyns Thomas Jr. of Elizabeth at an informal contract bridge game at the Baltrusol Golf Club here, it became known today. Mrs. Thomas received the hand while playing after dinner on Saturday evening, when she and other friends were guests of Colonel and Mrs. Carroll Badeau of Elizabeth.

GENEVA, Feb. 1 -- The present situation in the Far East is a source of deep regret not only to Japan and China, but to all the nations of the world. Every effort has been made to reach an amicable settlement, and it is to be hoped that by a continuance of these endeavors it will be possible to remove a situation which is causing such universal concern.

Efforts to arrest last month the downward trend in stock prices, following the making of a new bear-market low on Jan. 5, were unsuccessful, and an enhancement in values that had appeared in the first half of the period was erased by a decline which held until the end of the term.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 1 -- Federal agents from New York raided tonight a modern, newly equipped distillery, valued at $250,000 by Special Agent Joseph A. Frayne, at 102 Vesey Street, here, and connected by a double-belted electric conveyor through a tunnel under the street to a block-long garage across the street.

The American League champion-{ ship season for 1932 will get away in two sections, according to the official schedule released for publication today, with the Senators and Red Sox staging an inaugural all by themselves in Washington on April 11 and the rest of the field swinging into action on the following day.

An early advance on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried prices to the highest level of the last two weeks, but selling in the final hour wiped out the improvement and left quotations a point higher to 2 points lower than on Saturday. Developments in the Far East continued to be the factor, but did not inspire sufficient buying power to change the general character of the situation.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1 -- New Jersey municipalities would be permitted to sell their bonds over the counter this year if they could not get suitable bids by advertising the issue under a bill, already approved by the Assembly, that was passed by the Senate at tonight's legislative session here.

John. N. Willys, chairman of the Willys-Overland Company, has sent a letter to holders of first mortgage twenty-year 8 per cent sinking fund gold bonds and five-year 5 1/2 per cent sinking fund gold notes of the Fisk Rubber Company stating that he is definitely opposed to the plan of reorganization of that company which has just been promulgated by a committee of which Orrin G. Wood is chairman.

Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok, winner of the metropolitan indoor tennis championship in 1928, put in his first appearance in the current revival of the tournament at the 106th Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, yesterday and advanced two rounds without the loss of a set.

The application of the Westchester Electric Railroad Company for a franchise to operate motor buses, in substitution for trolley cars, from Dyre Avenue, the Bronx, to South Fifth Street, Mount Vernon, was opposed by residents of the Bronx yesterday at a public hearing before the Board of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Japan in preparing an Asiatic Monroe Doctrine, patterned after the American Monroe Doctrine, and seeks to become "master director of the affairs of Asia," Senator James Hamilton Lewis, Democrat of Illinois, declared tonight in a radio speech in which he dealt boldly and at length with the Sino-Japanese situation over a national network or the National Broadcasting Company.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Hoping that the Republican majority in the Legislature will play "smart politics" and "put the Governor in a hole," the drys will do their utmost for the passage at the present session of the State dry law enforcement bill introduced last week by Assemblyman Jenks.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen arrived yesterday from the Channel ports with her decks covered with ice and frozen snow, after encountering a blizzard on Sunday 300 miles east of Nantucket Lightship that caused her speed to be reduced to ten knots for fourteen hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Laurence Olivier and his wife, Jill Esmond, English actors, who have played in recent R.K.O. moving pictures, must leave the United States, their permits to remain in this country having expired.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Action was taken today by Democratic leaders of the House to delay consideration of the army appropriation bill and the pending proposals to make heavy reductions in the personnel of the army as a means of economy. Reports were quick to start that the delay was due to the crisis in the Far East.

All missionaries in China are safe thus far, according to information received by the foreign mission bureaus of various denominations in New York, but the situation of the Chinese in Shanghai is appalling. A cablegram received yesterday afternoon by the Methodist Episcopal Church Board of Foreign Missions said that 1,000,000 persons were homeless.

During the past two or three years the work of the Travelers Aid Society has developed in unexpected ways. Originally started nearly fifty years ago for the protection of young girls and children compelled to travel alone, it has widened its scope to include all persons temporarily stranded, alone and without money, in this city.

The fifth annual invitation tennis tournament under the auspices of De Witt Clinton High School opened yesterday at the 369th Regiment Armory, Lenox Avenue and 143d Street, with a field of forty-nine entries, the largest in the event's history.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Utica Curling Club's rink skipped by J.W. Clader gained the final of the W. Fred Allen Memorial Medal curling competition today and will clash tomorrow with a rink from the Country Club of Brookline, Mass., for possession of the medal and the right to represent the United States in the Olympic games curling demonstration Thursday at Lake Placid.

The receivers for the Wabash Railway announced yesterday that the company would defer payment of principal and interest due yesterday on equipment trust certificates and that the receivers had made no provision for the payment of the interest that was also due yesterday on refunding and general mortgage bonds.

ALBANY Feb. 1 -- Governor Roosevelt received late tonight the reply of Sheriff Thomas M. Farley to the charges made against him by Samuel Seabury, counsel for the Hofstadter committee, seeking his removal from office. The reply arrived at the Executive Mansion only a short time before the dead line established by the Governor.

Business in money in the new week was of the same pattern as that which marked the course of trading last week. Turnover remained upon a small scale, with quotations in all sections unchanged. On the Stock Exchange day loans ruled at 2 1/2 per cent, while a concession to 2 prevailed in the counter market.

About this time in a Presidential year troubles begin to multiply for the leading candidate. His friends do foolish things in their effort to help him. Living as he must in the glare of the political spotlight, his every move is in public view. He is connected as if by a microphone with the ears of the nation; and every word he says is audible to all and is weighed critically.

An attitude on the Presidency and on international affairs that Franklin D. Roosevelt expressed to S.J. Woolf, artist and interviewer, more than three years ago when Governor Roosevelt was Governor-elect, is brought back into the news through inclusion in Mr. Woolf's "Drawn From Life," a volume of forty-three sketches and interviews published today by Whittlesey House, McGrawHill.

Militarists should be removed from their high places among the nations and the Golden Rule should be the guiding factor in all deliberations on international questions, the Rev. Dr. Charles E. Jefferson, honorary minister of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, said yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 1 -- William S. Vare, leader of the Philadelphia Republican organization, said here today that if he were elected a delegate-at-large to the party's national convention in Chicago, he would go with an "open mind" on a Presidential candidate.

The decline in January in money rates may be attributed partly to the continued reduction in member-bank credit and partly to the retirement of currency from circulation, which, however, was less rapid than usual for the time of year, according to the Feb. 1 review of credit and business conditions by the New York Federal Reserve Bank.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 1 -- Unless the proposed school tax bill introduced by Assemblyman Edwin Wallace becomes a law immediately, Nassau County will be forced to close all county departments before March 1. H. Stewart McKnight, County Attorney, declared today at a meeting of the Board of Supervisors.

Foreign trade moving through New York during 1931 decreased because of the depression, but the relative strength of the port was improved as the share of the nation's foreign commerce moving through the city was increased, according to a bulletin issued yesterday by the Bureau of Commerce of the Port of New York Authority.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Too late to do him any good in the battle for the three-cushion billiard championship of the world, Young Jake Schaefer of San Francisco today regained his form, playing sensationally to defeat Alien Hail of Chicago.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Sentences aggregating fifty-three years in the State penitentiary at Raiford were imposed here today on fourteen persons, including two women, convicted in connection, with Communist demonstrations here in November during a celebration of the anniversary of the founding of Soviet Russia.

Earl Carroll, producer, and Dorothy Knapp, star for a time of his musical comedy, "Fioretta," went on the witness stand yesterday at the opening of the trial before Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer of Miss Knapp's $500,000 suit against Mrs. Anne Penfield, widow of Frederic C. Penfield, former Ambassador to Austria-Hungary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Styles in depression relief change from season to season. Last Fall, at the time of the special legislative session called by Governor Roosevelt, the style was all for spending as much money as possible to relieve unemployment.

Controller Charles W. Berry's attempt yesterday to assuage the wounded feelings of Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens over the contribution of 10 per cent of the latter's salary to the city's general fund brought the response that Mr. Harvey and his aides would contribute the percentage only upon condition that other city officials earning more than $5,000 a year did likewise.

HONOLULU, Feb. 1 -- The pleas of Mrs. Granville R. Fortescue, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie and two navy enlisted men, charged with murder in the second degree, were postponed today until Friday at 1:30 P.M. upon representation of defense counsel that they had not had time enough to study the indictments.

The course which Japan has chosen to pursue during the last few days would make any appeal to her Government's sense of international obligation appear grotesque just now. Its military operations in China are inexplicable on any sound theory of national conduct.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Senate today approved the $125,000,000 appropriation for increasing the capitalization of the Federal Land Banks.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Haitian National Guard today took over the Military Department of the West, replacing two United States Marine officers with Major Fernand M. La Fontante, a Haitian who rose from the rank of private.
TORONTO, Feb. 1 -- The National Hockey League decided today there would be no change in the playing rules to penalize defensive tactics.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 1 -- In order to clear any confusion in the minds of Americans at home concerning Shanghai it is necessary first to explain the political composition of the city, which has three main divisons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Navy Department has been asked to set a price on the airship Los Angeles by Howard Hughes, producer of aerial motion pictures, who telegraphed Rear Admiral William A. Moffett this afternoon that he wanted to bid on the dirigible.
It is a wraith-like message that comes to us from Waslov Nijinsky, once famous dancer, now in a sanitarium in Switzerland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Speed vs. Safety," stating that last year about 35,000 were killed in motor vehicle accidents in this country, refers only to the principal feature of the ghastly toll the automobile exacts.

The New York State Amateur Boxing Tournament opened at Madison Square Garden last night when preliminary bouts in the annual chase for titles were held. A crowd of 6,000 persons witnessed the battles, which were productive of considerable action.
NANKING, Tuesday, Feb. 2 -- Japanese bluejackets were landed from warships here today and concentrated at the Japanese wharf.

Feodor Chaliapin, who has not been heard in this country for three years, will come here in October and appear both in concert and opera, F.C. Coppicus of the Metropolitan Musical Bureau, a division of the Columbia Concerts Corporation, announced last night.

Brisk rallies in the principal utility stocks imparted a firmer tone to trading on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, numerous foreign and domestic bonds also showing strength, including the Nippon Electric Power 6 1/2 s, which were active and higher on the day.
Mayor Walker has been ordered to remain indoors and rest as much as possible because he is suffering from a bronchial cold, low blood pressure and low pulse, it became known yesterday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Protests of seven foreign nations on the use of the Olympic bobsleigh run today resulted in the supervision being removed from the local authorities and transferred to Erwin Hackmann of Germany and Albert Mayer of Switzerland, members of the international bobsleigh committee.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- George Brinton McLellan, American-born theatrical manager of London, and director of the Wernher group of eight West End playhouses, died suddenly today at the age of 65.

MONROE, La., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Appeals to Federal agencies to contribute aid in the fight that is being waged to protect Monroe from flood waters of the Ouachita River were wired tonight to Washington by Alvin O. King, Acting Governor.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Justice Ralph W.E. Donges of the Supreme Court declined today to hear an application by Samuel P. Morris, Atlantic City attorney, for a writ to test the right of Mayor Harry Bacharach of Atlantic City to retain his membership on the Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- Seven of the eight seeded players in the women's national squash racquets championship that started today at the Harvard, Club were victors in straight games, but Mrs. Ralph Holman of Boston, women's State champion, met stern opposition before eliminating Mrs. H. Stuart Green of New York, 18 -- 17, 15 -- 12, 10 -- 15, 18 -- 15.

Professor William Heckler looked thoughtful last night in his study at 228 West Forty-second Street, headquarters of the Flea Circus, and told how his natural inclination for natural history had led him into the business.

A devastating attack brought Young Terry of Trenton, N.J., a victory last night over Marty Sampson, Harlem middleweight, in a torrid ten-round battle before about 2,500 fans at the St. Nicholas Arena.

John Hilfers wanted to paint portraits, flowers and landscapes. For twenty-five years he worked at his home-made easel in the parlor of the five-room apartment on the fourth floor at 1,608 Third Avenue.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 1 -- A statement, signed by forty-two prominent residents of Nassau County, protesting against the appointment of Frank Tappen as deputy chief of the County Police Department, was presented this morning to the Board of Supervisors by William D. Guthrie of Locust Valley, attorney, a Democrat.

Frank E. Tripp, vice president and general manager of the Gannett Company, Inc., announced yesterday that his company had relinquished controlling interest in The Brooklyn Daily Eagle to a group headed by M. Preston Goodfellow and Harris M. Grist, publisher and managing editor respectively of The Eagle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Progressives of the Senate today began a fight for direct financial relief for the unemployed. Senator La Follette of Wisconsin, in a three-hour speech, urged the adoption of the La FolletteCostigan bill, which would provide $375,000,000 to be distributed through State and local relief agencies.
U.S.S. CALIFORNIA, At Sea, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Admiral Richard H. Heigh, commander of the battle forces, led the Blue Fleet to sea today to attempt the "capture" of the Hawaiian Islands.

A vote of confidence in retailing for 1932 was cast last night on behalf of the National Retail Dry Goods Association by Major Benjamin H. Namm of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, who presided at the opening session of the association's twenty-first annual convention, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The serious crisis in the Far East had echoes today in both houses of Congress and in connection with pending proposals for economizing in appropriations for the two military services, the army and the navy.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Lee Shubert, New York theatrical producer, tonight paid tribute to his one-time London partner, George B. McLellan, who died today, as one of the best versed men in theatrical affairs in the world.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- Gerhart Hauptmann, Nobel prize winner of 1912 and one of Germany's most distinguished writers, will sail for the United States on the Europa on Feb. 19. He will be received at the Academy of Arts and Letters on Feb. 27 and later at Columbia University, and he will attend the opening of the Hauptmann exhibition, which has been organized by Professor Frederick Heuser.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Feb. 1 -- Revolutionists captured Tulcan, the capital of the Province of Carchi, 100 miles from Quito yesterday by a surprise assault on the police Station and later the practically deserted barracks of the Manabai battalion, according to a special edition of El Telegrafo today.

WARSAW, Feb. 1 -- An 8 per cent reduction of wages in the Polish coal industry came into force today, and a strike of the miners was called off pending the results of a ballot to be taken by the union this week.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Feb. 2 -- Chinese troops, believed to number 50,000, poured into the area surrounding the International Settlement of Shanghai yesterday (Monday) and engaged in feverish activity in erecting defenses. Wild rumors began to spread about the city that the Chinese intended to make an attack.

Edward Fagan of the Engineers' Club advanced to within one step of the national amateur pocket billiard title last night by defeating Robert Cole, former champion, 125 to 97, in 53 innings, in the next to last match on the schedule of the championship tournament in progress at the New York Lodge of Elks, under the auspices of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players.
JUDGE KENESAW MOUNTAIN LANDIS was taking his ease in his inn. He lolled back in a deep chair that practically engulfed him. What about baseball? What were his thoughts and plans on the subject?

Mrs. Ida C. Cook, divorced wife of the late William Wilson Cook, former counsel general for the Mackay Companies and an authority on corporation law, settled her claim against the estate of her husband for $160,000, it was revealed yesterday when Surrogate James A. Foley signed an order sanctioning the settlement.
LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Dr. S. Tartakower of Poland was the only winner in the first round of the international chess tournament which opened at the Central Hall, Westminster, today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposed banking board bill has received a great deal of attention, and rightly so. There seems to be a consensus of opinion that the Superintendent of Banks of the State of New York has been expected to bear burden which is too great for any man.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 1 (AP) -- With Don Bradman scoring a double century, Australia today completed its first innings in the fourth test cricket match with South Africa, with 513 runs as compared to the 308 the Spring Boks registered in their first.

Francis X. Mancuso, former judge of General Sessions, was charged with perjury, and Isidore Siegeltuch. a director of the defunct City Trust Company, with abstracting and misapplying funds of the company, in new indictments made public yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William F. Blcaklcy, sitting in the special term of the criminal division of the court ordered by Governor Roosevelt to inquire into the insolvency of the bank.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- A non-partisan "Hindenburg for President" committee, consisting of eminent personalities in all walks of life, under the leadership of Dr. Heinrich Sahm, Chief Mayor of Berlin, opened a campaign for the re-election of the Field Marshal tonight by issuing anappeal proposing President von Hindenburg as "the candidate of the German, people."

Brisk rallies in railroad bonds co-incident with the gains made in rail stocks as a result of the agreement reached in the railway wage meeting in Chicago, featured dealings yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange. A long list of the rail issues rebounded 1 to more than 6 points in the heaviest trading seen in several days.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- "One against another and all against China," runs a Pravda headline today about the position of the "imperialist powers" in regard to Chinese affairs, with the adjoining double heading, "Concentration of naval and military forces in Chinese waters."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 -- The Howe Stable's Lullaby II sprang a surprise today when she captured the Coral Reefs Purse, feature on the day's card at Hialeah Park, by a good two lengths, while Mabla, the odds-on favorite at 3 to 4, was driving hard to land second, a length in front of Jaffa.

Amid all the pomp and ceremony Usually associated only with the signing of a world's heavyweight championship fight, Hack Wilson, outfielder and former home run champion of the National League, affixed his signature to a 1932 contract in the club offices at Ebbets Field yesterday to become officially a member of the Brooklyn Robins.

Both the stock market and the bond market were governed yesterday by the conclusion, over Sunday, of the railway wage agreement. In each of these markets the effect was presumably more emphatic from the fact that prices in each had been moving slowly downward during the three preceding business days, on the theory of a deadlock in the conference.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors named a committee today to act jointly with a committee of the Lower Hudson River Association to confer with the Port of New York Authority and urge speed in the construction of the proposed $35,000,000 Riverside Drive extension into Northern Westchester as a toll highway.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Charles W. Wallace, District Attorney, announced today that the Schenectady County Grand Jury had failed to find sufficient evidence upon which to indict John De Braccio, who is being held in jail for the torch murder of Albert Renier two months ago.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Far Eastern news had a disturbing effect today on the London stock markets, which were generally dull. Japanese bonds fell several points, with declines in Chinese bonds smaller. Sterling was weaker in foreign exchange, the New York rate opening lower at $3.44 1/2, recovering later to $3.45.
NEW YORK. The Countess of Moray and Mrs. L. Stuyvesant Chanler Jr., daughters of Mr. and Mrs. J. Archibald Murray, are arriving today on the Aquitania.

The ultimate aim of Japan, alter having dominated Manchuria, is to dominate China, Dr. W.W. Ten, Chinese Ambassador to Washington and China's chief delegate to the Geneva disarmament conference, declared last night in a radio interview broadcast from Geneva.

MONTREAL, Feb. 1 (Canadian Press) -- R.J. (Hooley) Smith, Montreal Maroons' centre, has again forged into leadership for point-making honors, according to figures issued tonight from the office of Frank Calder, president of the National Hockey League.

The Merchants' Association has written to President HOOVER opposing his plan for the development of the St. Lawrence waterway, now under negotiation with Canada. There is nothing surprising about this attitude. New York's commercial interests have looked askance at the northern waterway, for fear lest it divert freight from this port.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Further reduction at this time in the armed forces of the United States was opposed by Henry L. Stevens Jr., commander of the American Legion, and Mrs. Frederick C. Williams, national president of the Legion auxiliary, in addresses tonight at the opening session of the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Al Rossi, hard-hitting Newarker, knocked out Billie Hood of England in the seventh round of a scheduled eight-round bout tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Indications that the Federal taxing basis will be broadened by the addition of new sources of revenue were given by the House Ways and Means Committee today when, before beginning plans for drafting a tax revision measure, it asked Ogden L. Mills, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, to submit estimates on the new levies that have been discussed in the last few weeks.

Britain's Enemy and Friend. While memorial services were being held ashore at Portland on Sunday for the men lost in the M-2, the flotilla continued its "forlorn" but determined search for the sunken craft.

Asserting that it was "a fundamental of taxation" that when a tax was too high it defeated its own purpose and became uncollectable, the Petroleum Industries Committee of 230 Park Avenue announced yesterday that all the organizations of the 2,300,000 motorists in this State were uniting in an effort to defeat Governor Roosevelt's proposal to increase the tax on gasoline from 2 to 4 cents a gallon.

Scientific knowledge about infantile paralysis has grown so rapidly in recent years that there is now hope of controlling the disease by immunization, Dr. Simon Flexner, director of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, said yesterday in an address at the Hotel Biltmore before the annual meeting of the Evelyn Goldsmith Home for Crippled Children, Inc.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1 -- Joseph F. Guffey, chief backer in Pennsylvania of Governor Roosevelt, invited friends of other Democratic candidates today to enter their names on the State primary ballot in April. The former national committeeman headed a group of Roosevelt supporters who filed petitions in Harrisburg Saturday to place the New Yorker in the primary race.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 1 -- Charles Sheldon Hastings, professor emeritus of Yale University, an authority on optics and optical instruments, died In Greenwich, Conn., on Saturday.

Michael Kramer, owner of a jewelry store at 1,361 Sixth Avenue, at Fifty-fifth Street, was reading a letter yesterday morning about 9 o'clock, just after he and his brothers had opened the vault and prepared the shop for work.

The market for stocks will, on the whole, be narrower than the market for bonds when the deflation has passed, F.J. Lissman, investment banker, said yesterday. He discussed the future of the securities market and financial advertising at a luncheon of the financial advertising group of the Advertising Club, of New York at the organization's clubhouse, 23 Park Avenue.

Urges Volume Cut to Hit Returns. A reduction of 20 per cent in dress volume, through the elimination of accounts which are unjust returners of merchandise, was urged yesterday in a communication to members by M.D. Mosessohn, executive chairman of the Associated Dress Industries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Chinese situation was brought to the front in the House of Representatives this afternoon when Representative Thomas I. Blanton of Texas declared he was unwilling to do anything "to protect a few Chinese merchants."

PANAMA CITY, Jan. 17 -- The present government of Salvador under General Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez has been recognized only by Mexico, and, apparently hoping that help toward recognition might result, the Minister of Foreign Relations, Miguel Angel Arujo, has asked international lawyers of various Central American countries for opinions as to the constitutionality of the Martinez administration and as to recognition under the Central American treaties.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Setting the pace for a record field of contestants, T. Philip Perkins of New York, former British amateur golf king and the defending titleholder in the tournament, and Jack Toomer, 22-year-old star of Jacksonville, tied for the qualifying medal today in the fifth national championship of club champions, on the St. Augustine links.

Additional contributions of $26,500 have raised the total collected by the United Hospital Fund to provide free hospital service for the sick poor to $530,971, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of the executive committee of the fund at 122 East Twenty-second Street.

Albert H. Wiggin, chairman of the governing board of the Chase National Bank, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen from Berlin, where he had been for the past two months as the chairman and chief American delegate to the Foreign Creditors' Committee.

Dr. Olga Knopf, a Viennese gynecologist, who for seven years was one of the principal disciples of the School of Individual Psychology advanced by Dr. Alfred Adler, says that men and women differ only slightly physiologically, and not at all psychologically, in her book, "The Art of Being a Woman," published today by Little, Brown.

News that an agreement had been signed providing for a 10 per cent reduction in railway wages was greeted yesterday with a demonstration of strength on the Stock Exchange. The market also was stimulated by the bidding-up of stocks which, presumably, would be benefited by the placing of "war orders" in this country.

ATTLEBORO, Mass., Feb. 1 -- The Catholic Church of St. John the Evangelist, built in 1885 on North Main Street, was destroyed by fire today with a loss of $75,000. Burning embers set fire to the new parish church under construction, but this building was saved.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- Prices of foods and commodities, such as kerosene and soap, suddenly were raised from 10 to 35 per cent in Moscow today in State stores and cooperatives serving the Soviet public and "closed" stores used by foreign diplomats, technicians and others.

GENEVA, Feb. 1 -- It is without any illusions as to the difficulty of their task that the delegates of fiftyfour nations are assembling here for the opening tomorrow of the World Conference on Limitation and Reduction of Armaments. Even the outline program has required six years of active work.

Violence broke out again yesterday when three families were evictee from their homes at 5 Allerton Avenue, in the Communist neighborhood of the Bronx, where many of the residents are striking for a 15-per cent reduction in their rents. A mob attacked policemen and a city marshal's crew, but the police soon subdued the fighters and eight of nine persons arrested, including five women, were jailed.
MANILA, Tuesday, Feb. 2 -- The bulk of the United States Asiatic Fleet sailed for Shanghai yesterday afternoon, headed by the flagship Houston, with Rear Admiral Montgomery M. Taylor aboard.

A new straw vote on prohibition, in which 20,000,000 persons will be solicited for their opinions in advance of the national party conventions, is being conducted by The Literary Digest, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William Seaver Woods, editor-in-chief of the magazine.

The committee on securities of the New York Stock Exchange, having been notified that the interest due yesterday on State of New South Wales (Australia) external 30-year 5 per cent sinking fund gold bonds, due in 1957, was not being paid, ruled that beginning yesterday and until further notice the bonds shall be dealt in "flat" and that to be a delivery must carry the Feb. 1, 1932, and subsequent coupons.

The protective committees representing holders of the majority of the $16,000,000 principal amount of general and improvement bonds outstanding of the City of West Palm Beach, Fla., announced yesterday that a plan for refinancing the city had been decided upon.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Feb. 1 -- Edward H.B. Allen, steeplechase rider and prominent in society, stood before Judge Knight in the County Court here today and pleaded not guilty to an indictment charging him with the murder of Francis A. Donaldson 3d, suitor of his sister, Rose E.W. Allen.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Dropping down into a claiming class after performing successfully in the handicap division last year, Mrs. M.B. Price's Silverdale today won the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- In an exhibition contest tonight, the Winnipeg hockey team, which will represent Canada in the Third Olympic Games, vanquished the Cataracts of Niagara Falls, Ont., and the Sailors of Port Colborne, Ont.

Samuel Dushkin, who signalized his return to New York by a brilliant performance earlier in the season of Stravinsky's violin concerto with orchestra, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall, playing the Vitali "Ciaccona;" a "Sicilienne" of Paradise; the rarely heard Variations on a Norwegian theme by Weber; the Bach Partita in E major for violin alone, and smaller pieces by Sarasate, Paganini-Kreisler, Prokofieff, Ravel, Fairchild, Mussorgsky and the Wieniawski "Carnaval Russe."

H. Alexander Hathaway, a nationally known poultry fancier and early authority on the cultivation of birds by the incubator method, died late Sunday night in the Paul Kimball Hospital in Lakewood, N.J., after suffering a paralytic stroke last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Organization of the board of directors of the $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation will be completed tomorrow, when oaths will be administered and the board will adopt rules for the extension of credit to banks, railroads and other business.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade here was as strong today as it was weak Saturday. War talk, strength in foreign grain markets, an upturn in securities in New York and a better export demand caused sentiment to veer to the bull side.

A marked difference of opinion as to whether a reproduction of Mount Vernon should be erected in this city as part of the George Washington bicentennial observance developed yesterday at a meeting of the New York City commission for the celebration.

COURT HOUSE, PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Opening volleys in the battle of psychiatrists were fired by the defense today in the Winnie Ruth Judd murder trial after Dr. W.C. Judd had described his wife as a frustrated woman who "dwelt on thoughts of a child."

Continued anxiety over the fate of the Chadbourne plan for stabilization of the world's sugar industry was reflected yesterday in a sharp break in raw sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Closing prices were 5 to 7 points below the prices at Saturday's close.

Mate, A.C. Bostwick's smart son of Prince Pal and Killashandra, for the second time in two days heads one of the country's great handicaps. Frank J. Bryan, handicapper for the Maryland Jockey Club, yesterday announced his weights, which show Mate top weight in the Dixie Handicap, just as he was in the Metropolitan Handicap weights issued by Walter Vosburgh, Jockey Club handicapper.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- The official trade figures furnished by the Foreign Trade Commissariat for the first nine months of last year, which are all that are yet available, show the following exports and imports in the Soviet Union's trade:

THE appointment of Howard G. Cann, who yesterday took office as football coach and director of Physical education at New York University, can be construed in no other way than as a testimonial to the qualifications of the man for leadership of youth.

Howard G. (Jake) Cann took up his duties as head coach of football and director of physical training at New York University yesterday. The action was the first official step that N.T.U. has taken to put into effect its new athletic policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The governments of the United States and Great Britain late today transmitted new and vigorous protests to Tokyo in connection with incidents at Shanghai involving the International Settlement. This action was taken after Secretary Stimson conferred today with Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, and had talked over the transatlantic telephone with Premier Ramsay MacDonald.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The question of direct Federal relief to the unemployed was brought up in the House today when Representative Huddleston of Alabama sought approval by a labor subcommittee of his bill to put $100,000,000 at the disposal of the President for relief work.

An estate of $207,873 gross and $201,893 net was left by Mrs. Charlotte L. Crittenden, widow of Walter S. Crittenden, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mrs. Crittenden died on Feb. 17, 1931. A total of $103,127 from her estate goes to charitable and public organizations, this sum being bequeathed out of the estate of $170,127 which she received from her husband, who died on Nov. 7, 1929.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Johnson of California will be invited to enter the Presidential preferential primary in Ohio in May, it was learned here tonight.

The reply of Sheriff Thomas M. Parley to the charges of Samuel Seabury that he had demonstrated his unfitness for public office at public hearings of the Hofstadter committee was received by Governor Roosevelt at the Executive Mansion in Albany a few minutes before midnight last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- There are 165 American residents in Nanking and most of them are missionaries, according to the best information available to the State Department. Exact figures on the extent of American interests in, the Nanking area were not procurable, but were said by officials to be relatively small.

In his supplementary report, entitled "Illustrative Condemnation Cases" which was made public yesterday, Special Assistant Corporation Counsel Leonard M. Wallstein described how many politicians and their satellites have been able to earn handsome profits under the condemnation system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A report on the shelling of Nanking was received by the Navy Department from Lieut. Commander P.W. Rutledge, commander of the destroyer Simpson, stationed at that city. Officers here believed that the Japanese had attempted to block off Chinese reinforcements who were proceeding toward Shanghai.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Feb. 1 -- After 113,000 miles of speed flying, Captain Frank M. Hawks had a narrow escape when his left tire blew out on landing here this afternoon. The flier, who averted a ground loop by applying the right rudder strongly, said it was the first blowout he had had.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 1 -- W.D. Kyser, president of the Memphis Power and Light Company, Memphis Street Railway Company and Memphis Natural Gas Company, died suddenly of heart disease today at his home here. Mr. Kyser would have been 50 years old next July 17.

Canon William Sheafe Chase, for more than a quarter of a century rector of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, former leader of the New York Civic League and for several years a superintendent of the International Reform Federation, made public yesterday his resignation as rector.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Despite a fresh crop of reports about his being transferred from Paris to London, Ambassador Walter E. Edge insisted today on his return from Pau, where he dedicated the Wright monument, that there was nothing now to be said.

GENEVA, Feb. 1 -- The possibility of the League of Nations Council having to discuss the Sino-Japanese "undeclared war" tomorrow, despite efforts to reserve the day for the opening ceremonies of the first world disarmament conference, was being considered reluctantly late tonight.

The railroads of the country began yesterday compiling data for putting into effect the voluntary 10 per cent deduction in wages which became effective yesterday as a result of the agreement reached at the Chicago conference of the managements and the unions.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Japanese bombardment of Nanking tonight confronted the British Government with an even graver emergency than that at Shanghai last week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Cold weather over the West resulted today in a marked curtailment in the movement of hogs. Prices here moved up 10 to 20 cents, with choice kinds showing the most strength. Lights sold at equal to the best figure since Jan. 7, the top being 20 cents higher at $4.35.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Glass told the Senate today that bankers were engaged in propaganda against his banking bill, similar to that which arose when the Federal Reserve legislation was before Congress.

TOKYO, Feb. 1 -- The United States, British and French Ambassadors again called on Foreign Minister Kenkichi Yoshizawa today. Japanese newspapers connect the visits with the proposal of Brig. Gen. G.E.E. Fleming, in charge of the British troops at Shanghai, that the Japanese entrust the defense of their 25,000 nationals in that city to neutral troops.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The Senate tonight passed twelve bills under a speed program inaugurated by Senator Fearon, the majority leader, the bills were of local application for the most part. The Assembly passed one minor bill and adjourned.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A statement issued at Nanking by the National Government before the Japanese launched their attack there was made public here today. It said:

Impatient drivers and careless pedestrians are responsible for a large percentage of the traffic accidents in New York, Police Commissioner Mulrooney said yesterday as he opened a safety school for drivers at the Police College.

Germany's Olympic hockey team made a thrilling debut at the New York Coliseum last night, scoring four goals in the last period to gain a 4-all tie with the Bronx Hockey Club after it appeared that the visitors had been hopelessly beaten.

A move to help foreign buyers whose governments are opposed to shipment of gold to the United States to obtain credit here was begun yesterday by the board of trustees of the American Manufacturers' Foreign Credit Insurance Exchange at its annual meeting at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The State Department will instruct a representative in Shanghai to cooperate with the international committee of foreign officials which the League of Nations plans to have report to Geneva upon conditions incident to the Japanese occupation, but the United States Government, it announced today, does not feel warranted in appointing an official as a member of the committee, since that organization would be acting under the League Covenant.

Art is long, but artists are often "short." Depression cuts from many budgets the item for the products or services of painters, sculptors and musicians. It is futile today to hope for a Maecenas. New plans must be worked out by artists and by their friends.

The likelihood that Governor Roosevelt and Lieut. Gov, Lehman would be called as witnesses in defense of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, was clearly indicated yesterday by counsel for Mr. Broderick at the close of the first day of his trial on charges of neglect of duty in failing to close the defunct Bank of United States before he finally did so on Dec. 11, 1930.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Senator Glass told the Senate today that bankers were engaged in propaganda against his banking bill, similar to that which arose when the Federal Reserve legislation was before Congress.
LAKE PLACID, N.T., Feb. 2. -- Mounting the perpendicular wall of the Shady Corner turn on the Olympic bob run at a 65-mile-anhour clip, a German bobsleigh went hurtling into space today.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 2 (AP). -- Whitney thoroughbreds dominated the program at the Fair Grounds today as they finished one, two in the Bayou St. John Purse and second in the Pompom Purse.

Great Britain and the United States, with the approval of France and Italy, are not forcing their view or imposing their will upon Japan and China. As set forth in the statement by Secretary STIMSON yesterday, they are responding to a joint request for their good offices.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange broke sharply yesterday under the heaviest selling movement in several weeks and closed with net losses of 17 to 19 points. Brokers usually operating for Japanese interests were active sellers from the start, and reports from the Southwest that freight and insurance rates to the Orient had been advanced several hundred per cent closed the list at the bottom.
Mr. WILLIAM S. VARE, master of the Philadelphia machine, declaring his purpose to be a candidate for delegate-at-large, makes this modest observation:

NAIROBI, British East Africa, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The secret jungle romance of the Hon. Averill Furness, daughter of Viscount Furness and stepdaughter of a wealthy American woman, had an unpleasant aftermath today after Lord Furness had learned of her marriage on Jan. 24 to Andrew Rattray, famous Kenya hunter.
OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 2. -- The Imperial Economic Conference will convene in Ottawa on July 18, Premier Bennett, announced today.

Movements on the Stock Exchange yesterday were as uncertain and inconclusive as they have been during most other recent days. In stocks, which as a rule went slightly lower for the active shares, there were reasonably evident traces of surface "turns" by professional speculators; no intelligent trend was indicated.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 2. -- Athletic awards for participation in Fall sports at Princeton University were announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 2 (Canadian Press). -- The Sydney Morning Herald declared today that Premier J.T. Lang of New South Wales had instructed the State's Agent General in London to negotiate with bondholders for a one-year suspension of all interest payments due on New South Wales bonds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Led by Mrs. Lowell Fletcher Hobart, president general of the Daughters of the American Revolution, 400 women, delegates from forty-two organizations to the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense, held possession of the House side of the Capitol for more than half an hour today while they searched for leaders to whom they might state their support of a "treaty navy" and protest the proposed cuts in the army.

Failure of the disarmament conference, now in session at Geneva, because of "the most inauspicious circumstances" under which it was convened and of "the intransigeant attitude of France" was foreseen yesterday by Dr. Richard von Kuhlmann, former Foreign Minister of Germany, who has just arrived in this country to lecture on the international situation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- The wheat market today lacked the snap that had characterized it for a few days and prices on the Board of Trade here held within a range of around a cent. A fractional rally followed an early dip, but the more peaceable news from the Far East started a minor selling movement which disclosed a lack of aggressive support.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 3 (AP). -- A Foreign Office spokesman indicated today that the first four proposals in the Anglo-American peace plan for China and Japan probably would be acceptable to Japan, hut said the fifth was "absolutely unacceptable."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Senate leaders of both major parties expressed the opinion today that some form of direct Federal relief for the needy may pass the Senate as a result of increasing demands from various sections.

Leading stocks on the New York Curb Exchange closed irregularly lower in quiet trading yesterday. Marked strength was evidenced in the foreign bond section, while the more active domestic bonds also showed improvement.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Augie Kieckhefer of Chicago defeated Jake Schaefer of San Francisco today, 50-36, in forty-eight innings, in one of the best exhibitions of the world's three-cushion billiards tournament, to strengthen his hold on second place.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- Before diplomatic representatives of all countries represented in the play, the draw for the Davis Cup tennis matches was made today in the Elysee Palace. President Doumer of France officially opened the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Albert B. Fall, Secretary of the Interior in the Cabinet of President Harding, now serving a sentence of a year and a day in ,the New Mexico Penitentiary at Santa Fe for having accepted a bribe of $100,000 from Edward L. Doneny, Los Angeles oil operator, must serve out his full term.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 2. -- The Japanese officially gave out here this afternoon their version of last night's bombardment of Nanking, charging that the Chinese were solely responsible and declaring that the Chinese fortress at Lion Hill had bombarded the Japanese warships three times and simultaneously Chinese troops attacked a floating dock which was guarded by Japanese troops.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Except for four destroyers which are being exchanged for vessels of a later type, the British squadron at the China station is now at full normal strength.

Governor Roosevelt, it was disclosed yesterday, has been seriously considering the appointment of William R. Willcox, Chairman of the Republican National Committee in the 1916 Presidential campaign, as a member of the State Transit Commission to succeed Justice Charles C. Lockwood.

The November, 1928, grand jury, which had been held in readiness for more than three years for any new development in the murder of Arnold Rothstein, the gambler, was discharged yesterday by Judge Levine in General Sessions at the suggestion of District Attorney Crain.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 2. -- The Canton regime, which a week ago was virtually independent and rebellious against Nankins, today declared in favor of the removal of the national capital to Loyang and urged Sun Fo and Eugene Chen to proceed to Can- ton to strengthen the personnel of the South, which is intent solely on supporting the central government to the limit of its resources.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Alteration of the call of the Democratic National Committee for the election of delegates to the national convention was suggested today by James Francis Burke, general counsel of the Republican National Committee, to meet the situation in Massachusetts, where the Republican call provides for the election of delegates under the new apportionment of Congressional districts and the Democratic call under the old law.

The Federal grand jury in Brooklyn handed to Judge Clarence G. Galston, in the United States District Court yesterday, two indictments charging sixty-five persons with conspiracy, and with transporting and possessing intoxicating liquors.

Edward Ellis, now appearing in support of Pauline Lord in "Distant Drums," at the Belasco Theatre, is announced by A.H. Woods for an important role in "The Inside Story," which Mr. Woods will present at the National Theatre the week of Feb. 15.

As time goes on, and ALFRED E. SMITH continues to keep silence in several languages, some of the effects become apparent. His reticence has by no means prevented movements in various States to elect delegates to the National Convention instructed to vote for him.

With the Board of Transportation announcing salary cuts for 196 designing engineers and impending lay- offs for ninety-eight designers and draftsmen, and Borough President Harvey of Queens giving leaves of absence without pay to 154 engineers and announcing that twice that num- her would meet the same fate at the end of the month, the city's pro- gram of retrenchment and economy pledged by Mayor Walker began to hit home yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 2. -- Governor A. Harry Moore, the first incoming executive to prepare a fiscal budget, announced today he had cut $8,000,000 so far from budgetary requests. "I intend to cut more than the $8,000,000 from the budget," he declared.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Interest payments on bonds of the State of New South Wales, due in London and New York, will be met by the Commonwealth Government, Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons announced today. In turn the Commonwealth Government will take measures to recover the amount from the State Government.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2. -- The initial performance at the Palm Beach Playhouse of "June Moon," this week's offering, took place this evening before a large audience of subscribers. In the leading roles were Zamah Cunningham, Emily Ross, Howard Bailey and Allan Towers.

J.H. Thomas, Secretary for the Dominions and acting head of the British delegation to the International Disarmament Conference in Geneva, spoke to America by radio last night and declared that the "United States is marching side by side, united with the great European powers represented on the Council of the League of Nations, to preserve the peace of the world."

YOKOHAMA, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Prices on the Yokohama Raw Silk Exchange, the principal source of supply for the United States, dropped almost 20 per cent during the morning session today and the Exchange suspended operations at noon.

Net profit of the Caterpillar Tractor Company for 1931 amounted to $1,361,200 after cost of sales, depreciation, charges and Federal taxes, equal to 72 cents a share earned on the capital stock, comparing with $8,714,801, or $4.63 a share, earned in 1930.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 3. -- Six Japanese destroyers bombarded the Woosung forts, sixteen miles down the Whangpoo River from Shanghai, today to cover a landing party sent to occupy the Chinese fortifications.

The plans to start a dry newspaper in New York City have been suspended because of business conditions, it was announced yesterday by Stanley High, former editor of The Christian Herald, and one of the leaders in the plan. Mr. High did not know whether the project would ever be revived.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Prices of hogs dropped today, although receipts were smaller than had been expected. The eleven Western markets have received 90,000 head, or 28 per cent less than during the same part of last week. The market here at the start today was 5 to 10 cents lower than yesterday and at the last was quoted as 15 to 25 cents lower.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 3 (11.45 A.M.) -- Divided into four squadrons of three planes each Japanese airmen are now intensively bombarding the Chinese forces in the Chapei and adjacent districts of Shanghai.

Led by Julius Seligson, former intercollegiate titleholder, eight players advanced to the quarter-final round of the Metropolitan indoor tennis championship yesterday at the 106th Regiment Armory, Brooklyn.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Feb. 2 (AP). -- James M. Dixon, 58, a former director of the American Tobacco Company and ex-president of the Tobacco Products Corporation, was found dead in his office here today, a victim of a suicide bullet.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 2. -- In the first day's play of the first contract bridge tournament ever held at Yale twenty-two pairs competed, everyone playing ten hands of duplicate bridge, with the scoring under the Mitchell system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The joint proposals by the United States, Great Britain, France and Italy for the cessation of hostilities and for negotiations to settle all controversies between China and Japan in the spirit of the Briand-Kellogg pact and the Dec. 9 resolution of the League of Nations was announced by Secretary of State Stimson today as follows:

A prophecy that the United States would eventually discard the gold standard of exchange was voiced by Lieut. Commander Joseph Montague Kenworthy, former British Laborite M.P. and a retired naval officer, at the annual dinner of the Greater New York Federation of Churches held last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

With Governor Roosevelt weighing the fitness of Sheriff Thomas M. Farley to continue in public office yesterday, the additional grand jury, which has been investigating criminal charges against him, was reported to be almost ready to report its findings.

Moving hurriedly through odds and ends of legislative matters as if in haste to be on their way and give the game back to the players, the club owners of the National and International Leagues, conducting separate meetings at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, officially rang down the curtain on another season of so-called Winter baseball.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- Governor Roosevelt issued a denial today of published statements that he had been responsible for the dismissal of ninety-one members of the engineering and landscaping staff of the Westchester County Engineer, Jay Downer.

WASHINGTON, Wdnesday, Feb. 3. -- Although a large number of vessels of the United States Scouting Fleet are at Guantanamo, only thirty-five miles from Santiago, no word of the reported earthquake there had been received by the Navy Department here at 4 o'clock this morning.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,170,800 barrels, compared with 2,161,500 in the preceding week, an increase of 9,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Daily average production east of California was 1,667,700 barrels against 1,652,900, a rise of 14,800.

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- The stock markets were steadier today except British Government funds, which declined. Sterling showed a better tendency, the New York rate rising from $3.45 to $3.46, later reacting to $3.45 3/8. There was a further sharp decline in Spanish pesetas to 44 1/8, the weakness being attributed in banking circles of Barcelona to the easing of control measures and the expectation of a budget deficit.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the publicity given to certain persons who have seen fit to anesthetize and to operate upon themselves in public, or to smilingly suffer operation under spinal anesthesia, reducing as it were the procedure to the simple terms of a mechanical act, it would seem wise to reflect upon the method exercised by the ethical surgeon in the choice of anesthetic agents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The board of directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which will make loans up to the amount of S2,000,000,000 to banks, railroads, busines corporations and agricultural associations, organized today, electing General Charles G. Dawes as president and Kugene Meyer, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board, as chairman.

Discovery yesterday afternoon that two automobiles were used by the gangsters who killed two men and a woman Monday night at 1,216 Commonwealth Avenue, the Bronx, gave the police a definite hope of tracing the murderers.

The thrifty heroes of Horatio Alger Jr., who kept tin cash boxes and married their employers' daughter, are not only unknown to most of the bootblacks and newsboys of the present, but are disapproved of by many of those who do know of them.

Inadequate demand for copper at prevailing levels and the anxiety of certain sellers to move the metal resulted yesterday in the export price of copper declining to 6 7/8 cents a pound, the lowest quotation at which the metal ever has been sold for shipment abroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Americans and other foreigners in Nanking are "safe for the present," Lieut. Commander P.W. Rutledge, commanding the destroyer Simpson, radioed to the Navy Department today. The Simpson is standing by at Nanking ready to evacuate American nationals in the event such action becomes necessary.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Governor's budget bill was reported today by the Senate Finance Committee and the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, with its total reduced by $21,455,751, to about $301,000,000, the largest slash of the kind on record.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Feb. 2. -- Frederic S. Pepper Jr., who lived for many years as a virtual recluse, provided in his will, probated today, for a lasting memorial to himself in the form of a $2,500,000 hospital for the "free care and treatment of sick and 'injured persons."

"Some meteorologists," states Professor ALEXANDER MCADIE of the Blue Hill Observatory, "hold that "the circulation of air 3,000 to "5,000 meters above the ground "controls the path and perhaps the "intensity of storms. It is therefore "important to know something of "the flow at high levels if we would "improve the forecasts."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- President Hoover today issued a proclamation calling attention to the 200th anniversary of the birth of George Washington and inviting the people of the country to organize themselves in their respective communities to do honor to the memory of the first President during the period from Feb. 22 to Thanksgiving Day.
The purchase by an operator of an office building in lower Broadway and the sale of church property in the midtown area were the outstanding realty transactions announced in Manhattan yesterday.

A large audience attended the performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night under the auspices of the Canadian Club of New York for the benefit of disabled American, British and Canadian soldiers who served with the British forces in the World War.

Endorsement of the proposed plan to license builders in New York State was voiced by A. Pearson Hoover, head of the Investing and Contracting Builders' Association, at a conference held yesterday in the Hotel Commodore under the auspices of the Lien Law Revision and Enforcement Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- A joint resolution authorizing the President to reorganize the independent executive agencies of the government was reported favorably by the Senate Finance Committee today following an executive session at which only one Democrat, Senator George, author of the resolution, was present.

MANILA, Feb. 2. -- The U.S.S. Black Hawk, mother ship of the destroyer squadron, will leave for Shanghai at noon tomorrow, while the Jason and the Pecos, supply ships, are under twenty-four-hour orders.

Bryant Park as an appropriate setting for a reproduction of Mount Vernon as part of the George Washington bicentennial observance here was upheld pesterday by Charles K. Bryant, architect, of Richmond, Va., who carried out the same reproduction at the French International Colonial Expedition last year and also reproduced Washington's home at the San Francisco exposition.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Feb. 2. -- A jury of ten men and two women was completed this afternoon to try Edward H.B. Allen for the slaying of his sister's suitor. Assistant District Attorney Groshens in outlining the Commonwealth's case said:
BERLIN, Feb. 2. (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 30 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Cancellation of German reparations and interallied war debts was advocated by Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain, when Parliament reassembled today, as the most effective means of setting the world's financial problems.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 3 -- Wu Te-chen, Slayor of the Chinese municipality at Greater Shanghai, today emphatically denied that any regular Chinese forces disguised as civilians were engaged in sniping in- side or outside of the International Settlement and branded such sniping as exists as the work of organized Communists and other secret societies interested in the downfall of the Chinese National Government in order to serve their own purposes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The story of a second oath of office secretly administered to President Coolidge, two weeks after his father swore him as successor to President Harding, was related today by Former Justice A.A. Hoehling of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia.

Arthur Henderson's opening address as chairman of the Geneva disarmament conference was heard in this country over the network of the National Broadcasting Company as a part of an international hook-up.

Henry Ford does not owe any of his success to Shakespeare, it appears from an anecdote related in a volume of essays about rare books, book collecting and authors, entitled "These Three," by Gabriel Wells, which has just been published.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 2. -- Declaring that the Federal budget must be balanced or "economic chaos will follow," Representative Crisp, acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, today told that body that "many excise taxes" will have to be levied by the present Congress.
BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- Russian orders in Germany last year amounted to $220,000,000, a record figure, representing an increase of 62 per cent over 1930.

PLATO fixed the maximum, active population of a city-State at 5,040. Even with our multiplied and improved means of communication, it is hard for people to be neighborly in much larger groups than would be represented by five thousand male citizens.

HIGHBRIDGE, N.J., Feb. 2. -- Dr. Frederick C. Low, 60-year-old family physician, who has been practicing in this town of 2,000 persons for thirty-five years, killed his wife Alice, the daughter of the late As- semblyman John J. Mathews; their 10-year-old daughter Mary and ended his own life by poisonous injections, officials of Hunterdon County determined here today.

Prices showed considerable irregularity in the listed bond market yesterday. Advances and declines in the domestic corporation list were about evenly balanced, foreign loans were irregularly lower, with many notable exceptions, and United States Government bonds displayed a lack of trend.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- Activity was resumed on the Paris Bourse today and nearly the whole list participated in a well-defined movement toward recovery. The market was favorably impressed by Wall Street's reaction to the railway wage cut, but aside from this factor it seemed to be little influenced by the international situation.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 2. -- Japan's only "price of peace" in the Shanghai area, according to her Minister here Mamoru Shigemitsu, is that the Chi nese troops withdraw to a distance from which it would be impossible for their artillery to shell the Japanese defense lines at the International Settlement.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Roosevelt tonight took his stand firmly and beyond equivocation against American participation in the League of Nations. The League, he declared, had strayed far from the purposes that Woodrow Wilson, its founder, had in mind, until it had become not an organization for the general promotion of world peace, but a vehicle for straightening out national and political difficulties strictly confined to the European scene.

American Chicle Company -- Year ended Dec. 31: Net profit after Federal taxes and other charges, $2,089,121, equivalent to $4.18 a share on common stock, against $2,210,044, or $4.42 a share, in 1930. Quarter ended Dec. 31: Net profit, $452,198, against $512,633 a year before; current assets, $5,169,467, against $4,875,958; current liabilities, $699,570, against $622,022.

New York Clearing House banks have agreed informally that in the future they will not act as agents in shipments of United States gold coin abroad when they have knowledge that the metal is to be used for hoarding. The decision, which was reached by the Clearing House committee last week, will make uniform a policy that has been pursued for some time by several of the larger banks.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Anent the present situation in the Far East, we shall profoundly appreciate some small space for our words.

Colonel William J. Donovan has accepted the chairmanship of a special committee to start a new feature in the work of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, it was announced yesterday by Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the committee. The plan is to create opportunities for the thousands of unemployed in New York City to spend their idle time usefully.

BOSTON, Feb. 2. -- The Boston Bruins came from behind to tie the New York Americans in a National Hockey League game tonight with a determined third period rally, but, in pressing for the winning score, left a wide opening that enabled Billy Burch to cage the tally that won for the visitors, 4 -- 3.

The Cathedral Boys High School quintet, which is setting the pace in the Manhattan Division of the Catholic High Schools' Athletic Association, gained its eighth association triumph in nine starts by beating De La Salle Institute, 15 -- 13, in an overtime contest yesterday on the losers' floor.

Demand for store and loft space, particularly for garment firms, was evidenced in a long list of business leases announced by brokers yesterday. Four reported for the building at 222 West Thirty-seventh Street gave 100 per cent occupancy for this structure above the store floor.

The text of the new standstill agreement between German banks and their foreign creditor banks, concluded recently in Berlin, was received in Wall Street yesterday, having been brought back by Albert H. Wiggin, chairman of the governing board of the Chase National Bank, who negotiated the agreement on behalf of American bankers.

Butter. Receipts, 22,810 packages. The market opened steady to firm yesterday but with Chicago prices suffering a sharp decline a rather unsettled tone developed toward the close. Some of the larger buyers were inclined to hold off and the immediate outlook is quite uncertain.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The legislative leaders decided today to hold in abeyance any action on the report of the Mastick Tax Commission recommending sweeping revisions in taxation, until after the current budget had been disposed of.

Tears streamed from the eyes of Dorothy Knapp, stage beauty once advertised by Earl Carroll as the "most beautiful girl in the world," as she denied before Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer in Supreme Court yes- terday that she had received any pay after her dismissal from a star part in Mr. Carroll's "Fioretta."
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 3 -- Japan's reply to the proposals of the United States, Britain and France for a truce in China is expected to be on the following lines:

LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The second round of the international chess tournament was contested today at Central Hall, Westminster. Dr. A. Alekhine of Paris and P.S. Milner-Barry of Oxford were the winners. Four adjourned games of the first round also were played.
