Selection of the jury which will determine whether Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, was guilty of neglect of duty in not closing earlier the defunct Bank of United States was completed yesterday.

Democratic State Chairman James A. Farley, manager of the Presidential boom of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, conferred on Monday with former Governor Alfred E. Smith, according to information yes- terday from usually well-informed sources.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- A boom for Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies of the Assembly as the Republican candi- date for Governor next Fall will be started at a dinner to be held in the State capital on Feb. 17, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Peace proposals were submitted concurrently to the Japanese and Chinese Governments today by the United States. Great Britain, France and Italy in an effort to terminate hostilities at Shanghai, and elsewhere in China.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The government's deficit on Jan. 31 reached a new high mark, $1,512,532,500; a year ago it was $242,843,500.
Multi-family structures in various towns provided the bulk of realty trading in the New Jersey metropolitan area reported yesterday.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Feb. 2 AP -- General Jiro Tamon, the Jap- anese leader who captured Tsitsihar and Kowpangtze, moved his troops from Changchun toward Harbin today. The movement was started in weather 30 degrees below zero Fahrenheit, and there was a blinding snowstorm, but despite these conditions 2,000 Japanese residents of Changchun cheered the departing soldiers.

GENEVA, Feb. 2 -- Two hundred and thirty-two men and women, representing nearly sixty nations With different traditions, different cultures and different creeds at all ends of the earth, sat facing the presidential tribune when Arthur Henderson this afternoon opened the proceedings of the first world conference on disarmament.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From the viewpoint of the railroads, 1931 has been characterized by appalling decreases in operating revenues, rapidly depleted surpluses and apologetic statements to stockholders taking the place of dividend checks.

Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and chairman of the committee of nine railroad presidents that arranged at Chicago a 10 per cent reduction in railway wages, will report on the negotiations at a special meeting here tomorrow of the Eastern Presidents' Conference.

The Elshuco Trio, giving its third concert of the season last night in Engineering Societies Hall, counted itself among the few musical organizations of this city which have seen fit to observe the death of Vincent d'Indy by performance of his music. The d'Indy piano quintet in G minor, op. 81, had the place of honor on the program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Legaliza- tion of 4 per cent beer, as proposed in the Bingham bill, might mean a return of the saloon in some form, Colonel Amos W. Woodcock, Director of Prohibition, today informed a Senate judiciary subcommittee.

Under the terms of an offer made yesterday by the finance committee of the United States Steel Corporation employes will be permitted to subscribe for common stock at $40 a share, the lowest figure ever fixed since the stock subscription plan was adopted.

PEIPING, Feb. 2. -- Spurred by the news of the Japanese assault upon the Chinese area at Shanghai, the Japanese campaign to capture Harbin and last night's bombarding of Nanking, the Northern Chinese leaders are now exerting every effort to sink their differences and unite their forces to avert invasion of this region.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with great interest the letter to THE TIMES, "What's the Matter With France?"

A father of two grown children, who, the police insist, has been arrested fourteen times for grand larceny, was seized last evening outside the Long Island Railroad station at Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, after an exciting chase from the I.R.T. subway station, charged with the theft of $7.

John C. Parker was elected president of the Brooklyn Edison Company and Harry L. Snyder was elected president of the New York Queens Electric Light and Power Company at a meeting of the board trustees of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, yesterday, to fill vacancies caused by the resignation of Matthew S. Sloan from the presidency of the two companies.

"It's a fine day, let's go out and kill something." One is reminded of that fabled English saying by the attitude of a few people in this city toward public parks. "Here is a "fine park, let's go and stick some"thing in it that doesn't belong "there and will spoil it."

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 2. -- A three-hour conference today between county officials and New York bankers in an effort to borow funds to meet Nassau County's financial situation "brought no results," H. Stewart McKnight, County Attorney, revealed tonight at a mass meeting here.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- Lucien Lelong fight dress standardization with a beautiful collection of style, featuring a variety of ideas and colors. He abandons pajamas and cotton, except for tennis frocks. Soft canvas and woolens are used instead. The only period influence is discernible in a few long renaissance evening coats.

SANTIAGO, Cuba, Wednesday, Feb. 3. -- Two severe earth shocks, one at 4:30 P.M., yesterday, the second at 1:15 o'clock this morning, laid at least one third of Santiago in ruins and resulted in a casualty list of probably 1,500 dead and injured.

The Canadians of Montreal made good use of an early lead to defeat the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Springing to the attack in the first period when they scored two goals, and continuing their aggressiveness to tally two more counters in the final chapter, the world's champions decisively conquered their New York rivals by the score of 4 to 1.

Professor PUPIN led the American Woman's Association up Mount Pisgah and showed the Promised Land of electricity. Physicist and engineer must agree with him that we achieved our dynamos, electric lights and electric labor-saving devices in spite of our ignorance.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 2. -- Starting match play in defense of his title, T. Philip Perkins of New York, former British amateur titleholder, was carried to the eighteenth green today to win his first-round encounter in the fifth national championship of golf club champions on the St. Augustine links.

The city's official groundhog lurked last night in the corner of a warm glass cage in the Bronx Zoo. He rested a little, but he did not sleep. He was shivering and was haunted by spectres. Shadows played upon the walls of the Small Mammal House, and they were shadows that mocked him and laughed at his distress.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- At the wool auction sales today, the closing of the first series, 11,008 bales were offered, of which 9,367 were sold. Today's session was well attended and competition was keen throughout. An excellent selection of merinos and crossbreds was offered and fine sorts closed 5 to 7 1/2 per cent higher, while others were at par.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2. -- Headlines in the Soviet newspapers today show a dual view of the Chinese situation, as outlined in yesterday's dispatch. Thus the army organ Red Star runs a four-column heading, "Imperialist Plot Against China," where Izvestia features "Japanese Refuse to Withdraw Troops and Cease Bombardment of Chapei," and in heavy black letters, "Second Protest of the United States against the action of Japan," with a subhead.

Holders of certificates of deposit representing more than 99 per cent of the outstanding bonds of the Erco Realty Corporation have approved the plan drawn up by the Bondholders' Committee constituted under the Erco Hall Apartment Building Bondholders' Deposit Agreement, it was announced yesterday by S.W. Straus Co., Inc.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Premier Ramsay MacDonald must relinquish active leadership of the British Government for at least a fortnight beginning tomorrow, when he is to go to a nursing home for a delicate but not dangerous operation on his left eye. The trouble is glaucoma, a disease affecting the drainage duct behind the eye.

Pressing its campaign of retrenchment again yesterday, the Board of Estimate, sitting in Committee of the Whole, attacked a calendar listing proposed appropriations aggregating $19,150,566. Of that total the board approved only allotments of $37,725. It deferred action for a varying period of weeks on proposed appropriations amounting to $18,829,833, relegated to the suspense calendar $72,462 and referred back to various city departments for further consideration items amounting to $210,545.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 2. -- The State League of Municipalities went on record today, at a conference here, for suspension of the old-age relief law for a year and for increased fees for motor vehicles.

Steamship agents throughout the country are engaged in a rate war for bookings on Winter cruise ships operated by the transatlantic lines, a survey by the Cunard Line shows. The lines have agreed on minimum rates for their cruises, but apart from that detail the cruise trade is reported torn by a campaign of bidding by agents for passengers with offers of lower rates than the printed tariffs and selection of better class accommodations.

Books for the Unemployed. It is not within the province of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee to supply reading matter to the unemployed, yet that is one want of the needy which should be somehow met.

Representative John J. Boylan of Tammany Leader John F. Curry's district received $153,964 between 1926 and 1930 for his testimony in condemnation cases as a real estate expert for the city, according to the third section of the condemnation report issued yesterday by Leonard M. Wallstein, Special Assistant Corporation Counsel.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2. -- Pravda features a cabled summary today of articles from the Berlin press admitting that the Soviet's first fiveyear plan is on the highroad to success and expressing respect or alarm -- in accordance with the particular German newspaper's political views -- about the second five-year program.

HAVANA, Wednesday, Feb. 3. -- Santiago, second city of Cuba, has been laid waste by a severe earthquake which took a toll of lives estimated in fragmentary reports reaching here early this morning at 1,500.

Handicap adjustments, which will hold for the national championships, and the setting of tentative dates for these title games occupied the executive committee of the Indoor Polo Association of America during its midwinter meeting at The Riding Club yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's address tonight before the New York State Grange follows:
NANKING, Wednesday -- Feb. 3 -- (AP). -- Martial law was declared here at 10 A.M. today.

During next week foreclosure auction sales will be held affecting 107 parcels of real estate in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens, with an aggregate assessed valuation of more than $6,500,000, according to figures compiled by the Foreclosure Service Company.

Formation of a Protestant foundation to administer gifts and bequests was announced last night by Edwin L. Garvin, former Federal district judge, at the first annual dinner of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Inc., at the Pierre Hotel. It will operate similarly to Catholic and Jewish agencies already in existence and is supervised by the federation, which includes sixty-seven Protestant welfare agencies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The British policy in favor of a general cancellation of reparations and war debts, as proclaimed by Chancellor of the Exchequer Chamberlain today in the British House of Commons, was received with interest here but created no apparent disposition to change the prevalent official and legislative viewpoint in opposition to cancellation.
BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- At a Cabinet meeting tonight the government decided upon independent diplomatic intervention in the Sino-Japanese conflict.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- American concerns representing virtually all phases of international trade and finance have central offices in Shanghai, where about 65 per cent of all direct investments by Americans in China are concentrated.

Lewis E. Gensler's production of "Collision," a comedy adapted by John Anderson from the German of Rudolf Lothar and Erno Sebesi. will open at the Gaiety Theatre on Tuesday evening, Feb. 16. Before its New York premiere the play will have a single performance in Great Neck on Saturday evening, Feb. 13.

Controller Berry announced yester- day that the city had reached an informal agreement with the representatives of about 100 State and national banks on the refund of a part of the $26,000,000 collected from them by the city under a law recently declared unconstitutional.

HAVANA, Feb. 2. -- A national militia, to be composed of all members of the national police and volunteers and to be recruited in the six provinces of the island, was created by a Presidential decree signed today by President Machado.

Down in Macdougal Street the old Provincetown Playhouse is still giving sanctuary to homeless plays. Last evening another Negro play appeared on that miniature platform, "The Marriage of Cana," by Julian L. Macdonald, Mr. Macdonald has managed to write a Negro play without a lynching or a witches' caldron, which is something of an achievement in this brimstone season.
The High School of Commerce basketball team defeated Seward Park High, 18 to 12, yesterday at the Commerce gymnasium in the opening Manhattan division P.S.A. L. game for both fives.

By defeating Vaino Korhonen, unattached, 125 to 82, in forty-three innings, last night at the New York Lodge of Elks, Edward Fagan, of the Engineers' Club, completed his tournament schedule undefeated, and in decisive fashion captured the national amateur pocket billiard championship with victories over all of the other five entries.

Two years ago the Legislature authorized a temporary commission to suggest changes in the State tax system which should "distribute the "tax burden as widely and evenly "as possible and thereby relieve "those present sources of revenue, "particularly real estate, which now "bear a disproportionate part of the "whole tax burden of the State."

One of the most difficult sched- ules ever arranged for a Columbia football team was announced yes- terday by Manager Harry Gross. The Blue and White will play nine games, eight of which will be at Baker Field.

The danger of overemphasis on cheap merchandising, involving possibly the alienation of customers, was pointed out by more than one speaker at sessions yesterday of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, continuing its twenty-first annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

GENEVA, Feb. 2 -- United action by the world to prevent actual war delayed the opening of the world disarmament conference for just one hour here today. In that brief hour the Council of the League of Nations, hastily convoked by Britain, moved with a punch it bad not shown before to stop Japan's undeclared war with China.

W. Bernard Vause, former Kings County judge, who was convicted of mail fraud more than a year ago and sentenced to serve six years in jail for the part he played in swindling investors in stock of the defunct Columbia Finance Corporation, is finally on a train bound for Atlanta Penitentiary.

The Southern New England Telephone Company reports for 1931 a net income of $3,529,454, after depreciation, charges and takes, equal to $8.82 a share earned on 400,000 shares of stock, comparing with $3,411,331, or $9.41 a share earned on 362,500 average shares outstanding in 1930, or $8.53 a share on 400,000 shares outstanding at the year end.

The lessons of the infantile paralysis epidemic last Summer were laid before the Public Health Officers' Association of the City of New York at a meeting last night by Dr. William H. Park, Professor of Bacteriology at New York University and director of the Bureau of Laboratories of the Health Department.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 2. -- The sixhour day, the five-day week and employment insurance were voted into the constitution of the United Mine Workers of America at their biennial convention today. By the vote these principles now become "objects of the union."
NEW YORK. Mrs. Rutherfurd Stuyvesant will give a dance Saturday night at the River Club for her niece, Miss Alice Morton Rutherfurd.

BOSTON, Feb. 2. -- Three quarterfinal brackets were filled today in the women's national squash racquets championship tournament at the Harvard Club, with all eight of the seeded players still remaining in quest of the title which is being defended by Miss Ruth Hall of Philadelphia.

SAMARANG, Java, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The 1932 Java sugar crop, it was learned today, will be reduced by 50 per cent. As a result an area of 90,000 hectares [222,390 acres] will not be planted and more than fifty factories will be closed.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- In widely sep- arated plane crashes, a mail pilot and an army mechanic are dead, another mail flier is badly hurt and three others are missing tonight. Meantime searches for two missing airliners, one carrying eight persons and the other five, have been fruitless.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 2. -- (AP) -- Slow bowling of Clarence Grimmett proved too much for South Africa today and Australia won the fourth test cricket match from the Spring Boks by ten wickets, to make a clean sweep thus far in the five-game series.
BOMBAY, Feb. 2 -- (AP). -- The government struck two swift blows at Mahatma Gandhi's civil disobedience campaign today through the arrest of the leader's youngest son and a legislative victory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am also a great lover and admirer of this highly civilized and beautiful country named France, and I want to answer a few words to this other friend who is wondering why Aristide Briand, the great apostle of peace, goes peacefully fishing instead of attending the Geneva conference.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 2. -- While the Sangchow Railway continues to handle an enormous number of panicky refugees, all river craft from junks to large modern steamers, loaded to the danger point, are departing from Shanghai and river steamers today carried more than 20,000 Chinese.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2. -- The 7-year-old gelding Brown Wisdom, one of the best sons of Brown Prince II, and now bearing the colors of W.C. and E.W. Reichert, won the Sunny Isle purse, feature at Hialeah Park this afternoon, and defeated the smart sprinter Vander Pool after a thrilling stretch drive.

Comment in commission-house circles yesterday seemed to indicate that the downward movement on the Stock Exchange, after an early burst of strength, had some relation to the proposal to restore peace between Japan and China. This reasoning, which was disputed in other quarters, was based upon the notion that the previous day's advance had its inspiration in the exploitation of stocks expected to benefit from "war orders."

TWIN MOUNTAIN, N.H., Feb. 2. -- Two youths who braved blizzard-swept Mount Washington Sunday perished on the mountainside, their companion, Donald Higgins, 23, of Winchester, Mass., reported at noon today when he staggered into the base station of the Mount Washing- ton Railroad.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Demand for hogs was less active today and the market gradually declined and closed 10 to 20 cents lower in the face of prospects of reduced arrivals. The average price dropped 10 cents to $3.80, equaling the inside figure since June, 1899, while the top was 15 cents lower at $4.10.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 3 -- Although reserves played nearly half the game, the Navy basketball team easily defeated Randolph-Macon College of Ashland, Va., today, 48 to 22. Bedell, star guard, led the winner's attack with fourteen points.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The installation of John H. O'Brien of Water-town as Grand High Priest of the Grand Chapter of the State of New York, Royal Arch Masons, today marked the closing of the 135th annual convocation of the chapter.

AURORA, Ill., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Mayor Conrad Bjorseth today announced himself as satisfied with the results of the five-day "business moratorium" which he proclaimed to quiet public nerves unsettled by several bank closings in near-by towns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The United States naval force under Admiral Montgomery M. Taylor's command at Stanghai and at points along the Yangtse River tonight numbered twenty-six vessels, with four others en route from Manila to Shanghai.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- "Face the Music," a musical comedy revue by Irving Berlin and Moss Hart, based upon exposures of the Seabury investigation in New York, was produced for the first time tonight. Staged by Hassard Short, with dialogue directed by George S. Kaufman, the piece, in two acts of twenty scenes, was greeted hilariously by an audience at the Shubert Theatre here.

DALLAS, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Magnolia Petroleum Company announced today that its wells in the East Texas oil field would be limited to seventy-five barrels a well daily six days a week, and that purchases would be made on the same basis.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- An unemployed mother of two children, who came to America in 1914 as a 14-year-old "picture bride," was informed today that an uncle in Italy had bequeathed $1,000,000 to her.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 -- The first in a course of six talks under the auspices of the current events' lecture series took place this afternoon at Lagomar, the home of Mrs. Henry R. Rea of the Ocean Boulevard. Shaw Desmond of London, author and lecturer, spoke on "The Old Europe Passes" before a large gathering of members.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- Some doubt was expressed tonight as to whether Senator Davis's announcement of his candidacy for renomination was as "wringing wet" as several chieftains of the Philadelphia Republican organization had been predicting, but it was believed that it would satisfy the organization.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- As a result of the confessions of two conscience-stricken officials in the Thuringian Ministry of State, it was charged today that Adolf Hitler had secretly acquired German citizenship in the Summer of 1930 by virtue of a sham appointment to the post of Police Commissioner in the town of Hildburgshausen, Thuringia.

VIENNA, Feb. 3 -- The report of the Vienna Press Union, the organization representing all the Viennese newspaper men and most of the foreign ones in this city, on the alleged acceptance by journalists of some $45,000 to conceal the facts regarding the collapse of the Creditanstalt was published tonight.
Two more Tammany district leaders were Indicted yesterday, bringing the total to four in little more than a year. They were Sheriff Thomas M. Farley and his predecessor in office, Charles W. Culkin.

PEIPING, Feb. 3 -- The Japanese Residents' Association, fearing the "spread of the consequences of the Shanghai situation to Peiping," petitioned the Japanese Legation today to cable to Tokyo urging the necessity of reinforcing the legation garrison.

James Branch Cabell in an interview yesterday afternoon discussed writing style, his methods of work and his early life as a reporter on a New York newspaper, praised the work of two young autnors and said that the rye whisky being distilled in the South today was superior to the old-fashioned corn whisky.
The second seeded players in both the men's and the women's singles were eliminated from the Metropolitan indoor tennis championships yesterday at the 106th Regiment Armory, Brooklyn.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The Rutgers varsity basketball team broke a losing streak of four games by repulsing Fordham, 26-23, in the college gymnasium tonight. The reverse leaves the Fordham record at four victories and five defeats.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- Republican leaders in the Legislature have virtually decided to postpone consideration of the revolutionary changes in the State tax program recommended by the Mastick commission until next year. An agreement has been reached to continue the life of the commission for another year with an additional appropriation of $25,000 to enable it to continue its survey of taxation.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- We are driven to ask whether, in case war breaks out between China and Japan, Great Britain wil be drawn in, and if we are drawn in would not America also be involved? And what of Russia?

Because the dividend meeting of the General Motors Corporation was "hanging over the market" traders moved cautiously yesterday and the turnover on the Stock Exchange was only slightly more than 800,000 shares, compared with 1,119,000 shares on the day before.

Completion of the city's three west side piers on the North River waterfront between West Forty-seventh and Fifty-second Streets, will be delayed two months and the plans of the Department of Docks to build two more piers just north of these structures will be temporarily abandoned, according to A.J. Duggan, resident engineer.

Steel producers are hopeful that the recent agreement to reduce railway wages by 10 per cent will result in an increased demand for steel on the part of the carriers, according to the weekly review of Iron Age. This publication expresses the belief, however, that while "some rails and repair material probably will be bought," major programs are likely "to be postponed until the last half of the year."

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 3 (AP). -- Although Mendelian laws of heredity were cited as being opposed to his diagnosis of the mental condition of Winnie Ruth Judd, Dr. Paul E. Bowers, State psychiatrist, declined to agree today to the defense contention that the accused slayer of Agnes Anne Leroi and Hedvig Samuelson is insane.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Senator Davis of Pennsylvania, former Secretary of Labor, came out today for return of the control of the liquor traffic to the States and modification of the Volstead act to permit the legalized use of light wines and beer.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- While the four German bobsledders, injured in yesterday's crash, were in the General Hospital with practically no improvement noted, the Olympic bob run barely missed taking toll of another foreign team today. The Swiss cousins, Rene and Gustave Fonjallaz, spilled on the Whiteface Curve and were tossed into the trough.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Governor Roosevelt said tonight that he had received many messages from different parts of the country commending his stand in opposition to American entry into the League of Nations and the remission of war debts, defined in his address last night before the New York State Grange.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 (AP). -- The investment of 150,000,000,000 rubles (nominally $75,000,000,000) in the second Five-Year Plan was outlined today by Premier Molotov in an address at the Ail-Union party conference.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 3 (AP). -- The indictment of Sheriff Thomas M. Farley by a New York grand jury today is expected to have no effect upon Governor Roosevelt's consideration of Samuel Seabury's demand that Parley be ousted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The motor-vehicle industry, through T.R. Dahl, vice president of the White Motor Truck Company and an official of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, today opposed Federal regulation of interstate truck traffic.

MADRAS, India, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Declearing scenes he had witnessed "disgrace British justice, law and order," Peter Freeman. former member of the British Parliament. today cabled Premier Ramsay MacDonald, asking an official inquiry into the campaign against civil disobedience.

In strict harmony with the intercalary proprieties, twenty-nine Republican members of the Legislature are to give a dinner to Speaker MCGINNIES at Albany on Feb. 17. It is to be an " all-Republican" feast. All Republicans in the Legislature are bidden and will be glad to go, but politicians are a superstitious race; and so the number of the dinner committee is, as " JOE " would put it, " strictly embolismical."

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The enlarged reforestation program approved by the voters of New York State at the last election was formally started when Governor Roosevelt signed a measure putting the machinery in operation for a start on the project.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- A proposal for a constitutional amendment to establish a system of pari-mutuel betting at the New York State tracks was introduced in the Assembly today by William Breitenbach, Brooklyn Democrat. Similar proposals have been introduced in past years, but have failed to win much backing.
A description of the Santiago quake and the devastation caused by it was broadcast by the Columbia network yesterday afternoon.

Widely varying estimates of the casualties caused by the Cuban earthquake were received here yesterday from representatives of American firms in Santiago, but all reports agreed that the damage had been extensive and a large portion of the city destroyed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- News that the President had asked Secretary Mellon to be Ambassador to Great Britain surprised most members of the Senate and House today. Senator Reed, the Secretary's intimate friend, was one of the three or four in on the secret in advance.

Gota Ljungberg's Isolde was the feature of the Metropolitan Opera Company's performance last night of Wagner's opera of love and fate. The announcement of her appearance attracted an audience larger than any that had gathered for a performance of "Tristan" during Mr. Gatti-Casazza's regime.

PLATO reasoned well, but it can't be said that Governor ROOSEVELT does in explaining why he has given up his former ardent advocacy of the League of Nations. A public man is entitled to change his mind. He may announce that he has done so and let it go at that. But if he attempts to argue the case, his reasoning ought to hold water.

SHANGHAI. Feb. 3 -- The continuing arrival of foreigners into the central district of the International Settlement from the eastern areas, which has been raked for many days by shells and machine-gun and rifle fire, is bringing to light astonishing tales concerning the Japanese from reputable witneses.

INDIANAPOLIS. Feb. 3 (AP) -- In keeping with sentiment for no wage reductions, the biennial convention of the United Mine Workers of America today voted against any decreases in the salaries of its international officers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There was an editorial in THE TIMES to the effect that the delegates to the Disarmament Conference started on their mission with some doubt in their minds, apparently, as to what they could accomplish.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens yesterday wrote to Controller Berry requesting that the 1932 city budget be reopened and recommending ten ways to make material reductions. Mr. Harvey, in his letter, called on the Controller to work with him to bring about a reopening of the budget for reconsideration of each item with a view to eliminating all non-essentials.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company brought suit in Supreme Court yesterday against the 1931 Holding Corporation and thirty-six other defendants for foreclosure of a $1,400,000 mortgage on premises at 220 to 230 Madison Avenue and 16 and 18 East Thirty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A protest against an excise tax on electric power and fuel gas was carried to the Ways and Means Committee today by public utilities interests, but questions asked of their representatives by committeemen indicated that proposals for such a consumer's tax would be closely studied when the drafting of the new revenue measure begins in a few days.

The United States Appraiser's Stores at 201 Varick Street are the scene this week of the government's annual tea party which is a serious business, though it resembles nothing so much as a group of seven men with nothing to do but sit around and drink tea.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 -- My Dandy, racing for W.C. and E.W. Reichert, captured the Musa Isle Handicap at Hialeah Park today and gave the Westerners their second feature victory at this course in two days. Yesterday Brown Wisdom won the Sunny Isle purse for the same owners.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- After an irregular opening a few orders sufficed to turn the Bourse toward recovery today and the whole list strengthened during the latter part of the session. At the same time the volume of business remained low. Suez Canal was the only leading issue which suffered any important loss at the close.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 3 -- The elimination of two former winners of the Walter J. Travis Trophy featured the second round of match play today in the fifth national championship of club champions on the St. Augustine links.

An order directing certain alleged "left-wing" fur workers to show cause why they should not be restrained from interfering with the work of the International Fur Workers' Union, an American Federation of Labor organization, and from using the title "Fur Workers' Joint Council of New York of the International Fur Workers' Union Affiliated With the American Federation of Labor" was filed yesterday in Supreme Court.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 3 -- Although Yale tonight used a reserve six for part of the game, the St. Nicks in their annual hockey visit here were beaten by 4 to 1. Johnny Jones, former Princeton forward, scored the visitors' goal in the final period in the most brilliant attacking effort of the St. Nicks.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 3 (AP) -- An affidavit made in Paris by Robert W. Sanborn asserting that his mother had confessed to him she had sponsored the forging of her father's will was filed in Superior Court today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 3 -- Insurgent delegates to the convention of the United Mine Workers of America lost their fight today for amendment of the union's constitution to Include "home rule" provisions and curtail the powers of the international officers. Each resolution on these subjects was voted down.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Use of the trade name "Yankee Line" by the American Hampton Roads Line for their service between Philadelphia, Boston and Portland, Me., and Hamburg and Bremen, was authorized by the Shipping Board today.

HIGH BRIDGE, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The nature of the poison used by Dr. Frederick C. Low, family phy- sician of High Bridge, to kill his wife and 10-year-old daughter Saturday night and to take his own life remained unknown today. No autopsies have been performed but a small quantity of a substance found in a bottle in the furnace of the Low home will be analyzed.

GENEVA, Feb. 3 -- How to divide two and one-half hours justly among the representatives of the many scores of private pence organizations which have sent petitions to the disarmament conference was the mathematical problem, which was most greatly disturbing Geneva tonight.

Patrolman Francis Hackett, a member of the vice squad, shot and killed an unidentified Negro last night in the hallway of a tenement at 73 West 118th Street after the man, mistaking the detective for a visitor on a tour 'of Harlem's night life, had lured him there and tried to rob him.

Great Britain is looking toward the United States for new markets, according to Gerald Campbell, British Consul General here, who spoke yesterday at the National Retail Dry Goods Association's annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Loans instead of gifts for relief of unemployment were proposed in the Senate today by Democratic leaders, who offered a bill to appropriate $375,000,000 for this purpose and $375,000,000 for road building, as a substitute for the La Follette-Costigan measure to provide $375,000,000 for donations.
HAVANA, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Malolo, a 6-year-old son of Dis Donc, racing under the colors of the Blue Star Stable, captured the six-furlong handicap purse, which featured the card at Oriental Park today.

LONDON. Feb. 3 -- British Government funds rose on the Stock Exchange today in anticipation of renewed buying. The conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan sold at u76 and the war loan at u99 1-16. Sterling was somewhat easier, although movements were small.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 3 -- Yale and Harvard rowing officials, together with executives of the New Haven Railroad system, today settled details for the seventieth rowing race between the oldest athletic rivals in the United States. The rowing schedule for June 24 will include the three events which have been listed for a quarter century.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Hun School continued its winning streak today, defeating Fennington, 18 to 13.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 3 -- The Japanese bluejackets are being withdrawn at midnight from the border lanes adjoining the American and British lines along the northernmost projection of the International Settlement area. They also will be withdrawn from the factories and cotton mills just behind these lines and behind the lines held by the American marines.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Elimination of the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen acting as the Municipal Assembly of New York City in amendments to the existing charter or the drafting of a new one under the provisions of the home rule act is the aim of a bill introduced today by Senator Hofstadter, chairman of the New York City investigating committee.

EDMONTON, Alta., Feb. 3 (Canadian Press) -- A wartime flier took off into the twilight of the north today to aid Royal Canadian mounted police in capturing, dead or alive. Albert Johnson, insane trapper, who has killed one policeman and wounded another in evading arrest in the Arctic Circle barrens eighty miles south of Aklavik.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- An invitation to send representatives to an international economic conference at Geneva or some other city "centrally located" was declined today by the American Federation of Labor on the ground that the time was inopportune for such a gathering.
HAVANA, Feb. 3 (AP). -- You could not see much damage from the air in Santiago, but before I left about 6 o'clock this morning for Havana in my plane I drove through the streets in an automobile.
GENEVA, Feb. 3 -- The disarmament parley is receiving little attention in the Soviet press, whose foreign news pages are devoted Instead to the strife in China.

Jersey City, N.J. Jersey City failed yesterday to receive any bids on its issue of $5,500,000 tax revenue bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1932. and due on Aug. 1, 1935. Bidders were permitted to name the rate of interest to the legal maximum of 6 per cent, but were required to name prices of at least par.

NAIROBI, British East Africa, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Andrew Rattray, noted hunter, and his bride, the former Miss Averill Furness, who were secretly married in the African jungles, said today that they intended to start their honeymoon within a few days on a safari.

BASLE, Switzerland, Feb. 3 -- At almost the eleventh hour the danger of Germany losing the $100,000,000 credit which now forms a major part of her gold reserve was definitely removed today, but only for one month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The decision of the Philippine Democrata party to dissolve has caused complications in the insular Legislative Commission which may lead to withdrawal of the two minority party leaders from the independence delegation here.

Back to the Old Ownership. This community and the journalistic craft in general will welcome the repurchase of The Brooklyn Eagle by its former owners. Under the editorship of Dr. MCKELWAY and the Gunnison-Hester management It became one of America's outstanding newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- An attack upon the petitions for disarmament, signed by 600,000 American women and taken to Geneva by the American delegation to the arms conference, was made today by the Women's Patriotic Conference of National Defense.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Investigation of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company's stock-selling activities has been completed by Federal postal inspectors and the Federal Attorney's office, it was stated today, and is awaiting approval by the Attorney General before the case is presented to the grand jury.

Photographs by Walker Evans and George Lynes, young American artists, will be on view at the Julien Levy Gallery, 602 Madison Avenue, until Feb. 19. Mr. Evans is a sort of New York Atget. He photographs a heap of junked sheet-iron, an electric sign in process of installation, a face on a bill-board grotesquely pock-marked by wind and rain; photographs them without sentiment and with only the faintest undercurrent of satire.

Lea Luboshutz, violinist, appeared in a recital last night at Carnegie Hall before a moderate sized audience. Her program included the Brahms sonata in G. major, Chaconne for violin alone by Bach, a group of short pieces and the Wieniawski concerto in D minor.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Assembly Committee on Banks decided today to report the Campbell bank supervision bill without amendments which Governor Roosevelt has strongly urged, and thereby brought about every prospect of a battle between the Governor and the Republicancontrolled Legislature.

Buying Activity Gaining Slowly. Actual buying activity in the wholesale markets here this week has not shown a gain proportionate to the increase in the number of buyers here, manufacturers reported yesterday. From the standpoint of units, as well as dollar volume, orders for Spring apparel are tending to run about two weeks behind the corresponding period a year ago, despite an earlier Easter.

Richard Nicolai Belling, 26 years old, of 305 West Seventy-first Street, asked help yesterday in his attempt to learn whether he is "countryless," as the State Department contends, whether he is a Chinese subject or whether he is a citizen of the United States.

SANTIAGO, Cuba, Feb. 3 -- At least twelve persons were killed and 300 injured in a series of earthquakes that leveled a fifth of the buildings in Santiago and damaged another two-fifths. Two babies and a mother were killed in a maternity hospital when its walls fell.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Throughout this broad land of ours are hundreds of thousands of person who concede to THE NEW YORK TIMES the honor of being "America's outstanding newspaper." Your editorial force, your news gathering corps, your facilities to get and print and distribute the important, worthwhile news events, entitle your Journal to take this position.
With a revamped team, the New York Athletic Club played a 3-3 tie with the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club last night in a Metropolitan Hockey League game at the New York Coliseum.

Graduation exercises of the School of Nursing of Mount Sinai Hospital were held last night in the hospital auditorium. Fifth Avenue and 100th Street. The 118 members of the forty-ninth graduating class were addressed by Miss Lillian D. Wald, founder of the Henry Street Settlement.

The All Hallows Institute basketball team downed Mount St. Michael's High, 27 to 25, yesterday in the latter's gymnasium in an overtime game. At half time, the losers led, 15 to 8, and at the close of the regular time, the score was tied at 23-all.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Sweeping amendments to broaden and strengthen many laws, including the Martin anti-stock fraud statute and the Donnelly anti-trust act, were recommended by Attorney General Bennett today in his annual report to the Legislature.

Butter. Receipts, 12,822 packages. The market held steady on fine butter at the opening yesterday. Enough support was in evidence early to hold prices unchanged, but trading was by no means active up to noontime and receivers in general were free sellers with liberal supplies of fancy stock on hand.
A conference on public expenditures in this State has been called for 9:30 A.M. today at the Bar Association, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, by the New York State Economic Council. The call declares:
HOUSTON, Texas. Feb. 3 (AP). -- An unidentified woman burned to death today in a fire that swept the Evangelistic Temple at which Raymond T. Richey presides. Two other persons were reported missing.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 3 -- The ancient Papal Palace, with its priceless treasures, was pictured today by the former chief engineer of Pope Pius XI to be moving slowly westward under the impact of an earthslide in Vatican City.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Hoover tonight announced the appointment of Andrew W. Mellon, Secretary of the Treasury to be Ambassador to Great Britain, and Mr. Mellon's acceptance of the post.

Nine gangs of twenty-three men each were busy yesterday and last night at Pier 33, Brooklyn, unloading freight from the Grace liners Santa Ana and Santa Olivia, while representatives of the striking pier workers who quit work last Wednesday rather than accept a reduction of wages picketed the immediate neighborhood in an attempt to divert union truckmen from the pier.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The names of half the students at Princeton Seminary, as well as several members of the faculty, are signed to a petition sent tonight to President Hoover, requesting that the United States take action to "mitigate the conflagration" in the Far East.

With the declaration, yesterday of a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on common stock, directors of the General Motors Corporation reduced the annual rate from $3 to $2. The company had been paying regular dividends of 75 cents quarterly since March, 1929, shortly before which time the common shares were split on a basis of two-and-a-half for one.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday, when Tuesday's heavy selling was not renewed, and a recovery left the list 1 to 4 points higher on the day.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- With the temperature hovering around the freezing mark and slategray skies overhead, this bustling village today awaited the Third Olympic "Winter Games, which open tomorrow. A steady fall of snow was a welcome portent of favorable weather conditions to the 335 athletes from seventeen countries, although a slight rain at noon proved alarming for a time.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 4. -- Some aspects of the four proposals of the powers which Japan substantially accepts require careful examination but they appear to offer a practical framework on which peace in Shanghai can be built, provided always that unpredictable developments do not alter the existing situation.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Finance Ministry today made public the probable 1932 fiscal revenues of Argentina, indicating the grand total would reach $235,463,000.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 4 -- Foreign Minister Kenkichi Yoshizawa discussed Japan's reply to the peace proposals of the United States, Britain and France with General Sadao Araka, Minister of War, in a final series of conferences today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Charged with accepting bribes and permitting the landing of liquor on the New Jersey coast, L. Tracey Truex, chief boatswain's mate, and Leon E. Daniels, boatswain's mate at the Manasquan Beach Coast Guard station, have been dishonorably discharged and sentenced to a year's imprisonment in the naval prison at Portsmouth, it was made known here today.

MONTREAL, Beb. 3 (Canadian Press). -- Settlement of the wage dispute between the railways and running trades is understood to be imminent. A new agreement is in the process of being drafted and, it is expected, may besigned within the next twenty-four hours.
Columbia University has received gifts aggregating $64,426.49, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler.

News that Secretary MELLON has accepted appointment as Ambassador to England will give a first impression to most readers that it is something quite out of the ordinary. There has been a long and fine tradition about American representation at the Court of St. James's.

The State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration began yesterday a drive to double the number of persons now holding jobs provided by the ninety-two work bureaus throughout the State that operate under the supervision of the relief administration.

BOSTON, Feb. 3 -- The quarterfinal brackets in the women's national squash racquets championship were completed today on the Harvard Club courts, with one of the eight seeded players failing to get into the fourth round of play.
"If Booth Had Missed," the Arthur Goodman play which won the National Long Play Tournament last Spring, will have its Broadway premiere tonight at Maxine Elliott's Theatre.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Caught between love and duty, Devi Das, youngest son of the Mahatma Gandhi, has chosen duty in preference to a beautiful 19-year-old bride.

SHANGHAI. Thursday, Feb. 4 -- The heaviest guns that have been used so far by the Japanese in Shanghai went into action at dawn today while the Chinese replied with smaller pieces. As a drizzling rain was falling no Japanese airplanes had appeared to assist in the battle up to 8:30 A.M.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I, an Englishman born in India and long: connected with it, thank you for the broad way in which you have treated the British-Indian question?

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Awaiting completion of selections by the Republican Senate, the Democratic Assembly and the State League of Municipalities for his non-partisan committee of fifteen to aid in formulating legislative relief for distressed municipalities, Governor A. Harry Moore revealed today details of his plan to reduce taxes by direct return.

Relief of realty from excess taxation requires a State constitutional amendment reducing the maximum tax-rate limit from 2 per cent to 1.75, or 1.5 per cent, according to Stewart Browne, president of the United Real Estate Owners Association. Mr. Browne also advocates that assessed valuations be kept down to actual values based upon net income on improved property and a site assessed value on non-improved property.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A wholesale price index of 67.6 for the week ending Jan. 23, a decrease of 0.4 per cent from the index number 67.9 for the week ending Jan. 16, was announced by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- The retreat from the League of Nations issue of Democratic Presidential possibilities brought a scolding and some endorsement today from Senators of that party and much fun-poking from the Republican foes of the League.
U.S.S. CALIFORNIA AT SEA, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Quiet has settled over the radio on this, the third day of the sixty-craft "Blue" fleet's advance westward from California's coast.

A decision in favor of the Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and the Duplex Motion Picture Industries, Inc., was handed down yesterday in Brooklyn Federal court by Judge Marcus B. Campbell in an equity patent infringement suit brought by Cinema Patents Company, Inc.

B.C. Schram, receiver of the National Bank of North Hudson, sold the three-story brick flat, with store, on a plot 28 by 106 feet, at 513 Central Avenue, southwest corner of North Street, Jersey City, to Antonio and Angialina Riccinto for $12,500.

TWIN MOUNTAIN, N.H., Feb. 3 (AP) -- The bodies of two young mountain climbers were found today by searchers high on the snowcovered side of Mount Washington within a short distance of the summit shelter which they had become exhausted in trying to reach in a climb on Sunday.

Representatives of thirty trade groups in the Building Trades Employers' Association of New York City formally ratified a new wage schedule effecting cuts of 25 to 30 per cent to go into force May 1, when existing agreements expire.

NANKING, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Thirty-six American women and children were evacuated from Nanking today aboard the British river steamer Woosung, which will take them to Shanghai. A number of British women and children also were aboard.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 3 -- One result of the invasion of China proper by Japan, has been to weld the Chinese people closer than ever before in a national unity.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 3 -- Firing by Japanese warships upon the Chinese Woosung forts, at the mouth of the Whangpoo River. twenty miles below Shanghai, began at 11:30 A.M. today, according to the Japanese Consulate, which charges that guns of the forts opened fire first, bombarding passing Japanese warships.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- At the request of Governor Moore, representatives of the Pennsylvania and Reading Railroad Companies agreed today to call upon arbitrators named some time ago to complete within a month plans for consolidation of the two systems in South Jersey.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 3 -- Business men are watching with interest the preparations for the approaching conference between the representatives of the Guggenheims, Medley G. B. Whelpley and Paul Mayer and the Chilean Government to draw up definite alterations in the structure of the Cosach nitrate combine.

Although the death rate did not reach a new low, the health record during 1931 for millions of insured wage earners was the "most remarkable of all time," according to a statement yesterday in the statistical bulletin of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

New York City borrowed $15,000,000 in Wall Street yesterday under the $151,000,000 revolving-credit agreement entered into last month by the city and a banking group headed by J.P. Morgan Co., the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank in connection with the latter's purchase and public offering of $100,000,000 6 per cent special corporate stock notes.

Net earnings for 1931 of $14,542,319, equivalent, after preferred dividends and special deductions, to $1.08 a share on 12,644,313 shares of common stock, were reported yesterday by Standard Brands, Inc., holding company for several food units. This compares with $16,402,253 net, or $1.22 a share on 12,644,002 snares in 1930.

Price reaction was general in commodities yesterday. Particular weakness was registered in rubber futures, which broke 7 to 15 points, with the February contract selling at 4 cents, a new low for all time. Spot rubber was quoted at 4.10 cents, also a record low. Losses were also found in sugar, in futures trading, and corn, oats, lard and printcloths in the cash section. Coffee, cocoa and silk were steady.

Admitted assets of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York increased $54,039,556 in 1931 to $1,106,236,049. Income for the year was $234,925,900, while disbursements were $183,272,515, leaving an excess of income of $51,653,385.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Admiral Montgomery M. Taylor, Commander-in-Chief of the United States Asiatic fleet, was directed by the Navy Department this afternoon to assure the other neutral naval and military authorities at Shanghai "one hundred per cent naval and military cooperation" by the United States Navy in maintaining the neutrality and the safety of the International Settlement at Shanghai.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 3 (AP) -- Captain Clarence Starn, veteran Inlet skipper, was arrested here in August with several other captains of the local yachting fleet in connection with an alleged plot to smuggle Cuban, revolutionists from this coast to Cuba.

Trucking interests of the city protested yesterday against increases in the registration fees of motor trucks as recommended in a report made Monday to the State Legislature by the State Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Investments made by Americans in foreign securities during 1931, including State, government, municipal and private issues, amounted to $507,354,150, which was 67 per cent less than in 1930, when they amounted to $1,550,056,000, according to an estimate by Max Winkler made public today by the Foreign Policy Association.
ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- With the Legislative machinery moving well, Republican leaders insisted today that they would be able to achieve their objective of a final adjournment in early March.
SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 4. -- The large Chinese foreign-style, as well as small native banks, all of which had been closed since the afternoon of Jan. 28, reopened this afternoon.

John J. Dundon, assistant general manager of the wiring bureau of the Brooklyn Edison Company, was acquitted in Special Sessions Court of Kings County yesterday of a charge of assault in connection with the beating of the Rev. Eliot White near the Edison Company's pay office at Rockwell Place and De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, on last Dec. 2.

Thirteen American artists are completing a series of fourteen large mural paintings to decorate the National Gallery in Washington for the bicentennial celebration of the birth of the first President. The project was announced yesterday by Ernest Peixotto, president of the Mural Painters' Society, which sponsors it.

LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of France, world's champion; Isaac Kashdan, United States; Dr. S. Tartakower, Poland, and Sultan Khan, India, were returned winners in the third round of the international chess masters tournament in progress at Central Hall, Westminster, today.

SANTIAGO, Cuba, Feb. 3 -- Shortly after 5 P.M. yesterday a strong tremor shook the earth in and about this city, disturbing its usual tranquillity. This, however, gave no anxiety to the people of Santiago, for they already have become familiar with these seismic phenomena.

Despite pleas for leniency made by Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney; by Rabbi Moses Hyamson and by Hyman Reit, former magistrate, Joseph. F. Cohen, woolen jobber, of 838 West End Avenue, was sentenced yesterday to serve a year and a day in Atlanta Penitentiary.

So far as yesterday's stock market was concerned, prices drifted uncertainly within a narrow range and with no uniformity of trend. Railway shares moved in different directions, indicating again the dodging in and out of professional speculators with no particular view of things.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- Sol Kaplan, a pianist prodigy, 12 years old, appeared as soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra at a children's concert in the Academy of Music this afternoon.

LONDON, Feb. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The government's new import duties bill will certainly be passed before Easter, Stanley Baldwin, acting government leader, said in the House of Commons today. All other government business will be shelved to permit passage of the bill as quickly as possible.

GLEN COVE. L.I., Feb. 3 --The Nassau Country Club squash racquets team won its fourth Metropolitan League Class B match. 4 to 1, here tonight, defeating the Rockaway Hunt Club team. 4 to 1. The victory gave Nassau undisputed hold on fifth place for which it formerly was tied.

Escape out of our present difficulties by the third-party route is urged by the League for Independent Political Action, of which Professor DEWEY is the head, and by NORMAN THOMAS, speaking for the Socialist party. The league manifesto concerns itself with a body of principles around which minority parties and independent groups may rally.

A series of concerts in high school auditoriums with orchestras recruited from unemployed musicians is being arranged by the Musicians Emergency Aid in cooperation with the Musicians Union and the MacDowell Club of this city, Walter Damrosch, chairman of the, organization, announced yesterday.

Widespread solicitation by attorneys eager to represent property owners in condemnation proceedings brought by the city was disclosed yesterday in the fourth section of the condemnation report prepared by Leonard M. Wallstein, Special Assistant Corporation Counsel.

SOMERVILLE. Mass., Feb. 3 (AP). -- The Somerville Institution for Savings was closed today. The closing coincided with the expiration of a ninety-day period during which depositors could not withdraw their funds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Testifying before a House committee on the La Follette-Costigan bill, Karl de Schvreinitz, executive secretary of the Philadelphia Community Council, said:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- In his appeal today to the public to end hoarding, President Hoover said:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Columbia defeated the Army quintet today, 32 to 24. The Blue and White players were better all the way, although once an Army spurt carried the cadets to the front for a second in the second half. The defeat was the first the cadets have suffered on their home court this season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Senator Barbour of New Jersey today pledged himself to support President Hoover for renomination.

To the Editor of The New York Times. Every one will of course concede the premise of Jerome D. Greene that economic coercion is coercion; but, certainly for those of us who are seeking for light over the troubled waters of the Pacific. Mr. Greene seems rather to have befogged than clarified one of the dominant issues involved.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Resolved Williams will give a dinner tomorrow night at the Pierre for their debutante daughter, Miss Barbara Williams, and afterward will take their guests to the final Junior Assembly at the Ritz-Carlton.

Senator Claude A. Swanson of Virginia, the only member of Congress In the United States delegation to the disarmament conference in Geneva, gave his impressions of the opening of the conference in a speech from Geneva broadcast here last evening through the facilities of the Columbia System.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Stripped of power two years ago for his "right wing" leadership, Nikolai Bukharin, once known as one of the foremost Soviet theoreticians, today took part in a Communist party conclave for the first time since his demotion.

GENEVA, Feb. 3. -- The contents of Tokyo's reply to the peace proposals of the United States and Great Britain were communicated orally to Sir Eric Drummond, Secretary General of the League of Nations, this afternoon by Ambassadors Matsudaira and Sato, Japan's envoys to London and Paris, respectively.

Important among various business leases announced yesterday was one by the Jersey Silk Mills, Inc., which has joined the rapidly growing silk centre just east of Times Square and leased space in the forty-two-story Continental Building, at the southeast corner of Broadway and Forty-first Street, where several other large silk and textile firms have located since the completion of the structure by Louis Adler last Fall.

After learning that the New York Telephone Company had charged a charity donation it had made to operating expenses instead of to surplus, the Public Service Commission, by a vote of 3 to 1, ordered yesterday an investigation into this practice. A public hearing will be held in the commission's offices at 80 Centre Street next Wednesday morning.

The Columbia University Class A squash tennis team is assured of at least a tie for the Metropolitan League championship as the result of a 5-to-0 victory yesterday over the Fraternity team. Columbia, with one more match to play, has won eleven and lost none.

Magistrate Harris, after a hearing in Jefferson Market Court yesterday, reserved decision on charges of violation of the Sunday performance law brought against the owners of the side show at 228 West Forty-second Street and against the managers of a burlesque show given last Sunday at the Eltinge Theatre.

NEW ORLEANS. Feb. 8 (AP) -- E. R. Bradley won his second feature race in as many days when Bert John, which ran third in his three previous starts as a 3-year-old, captured the Frigate Old Ironsides Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 -- Mrs. J.J. Lawlor of New Rochelle, N.Y., was overwhelmed by Mrs. H.D. Sterrett of Hutchinson, Kan., defending titleholder, in the second round of match play for the women's Miami Beach championship over the Bay Shore golf course today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Hoover seems to be in sympathy with the construction of a ship canal from the Great Lakes via the St. Lawrence River to the Atlantic Ocean, thereby making Montreal the metropolis of the Western Hemisphere in place of the city of New York. The cost of the St. Lawrence project will be in the neighborhood of $999,000,000, to be apportioned between the United States and Canada.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Thursday, Feb. 4 -- Four terrific explosions aboard the Sun Oil Company's motorship Bidwell, tied up at the Sinclair company's wharf at Marcus Hook, twenty miles below hero early this morning, killed at least six persons and sent a score of others to hospitals with burns and serious injuries.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 4 (AP). Chinese and Japanese forces broke out again this morning with the use of machine guns and fields guns over a wide front. The firing was distinctly audible in the northern sections of the city and it was believed to extend along the Shanghai-Woosung Railway, in which area the major scene of operations has been transferred from the native city of Chapei.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 3 -- The official list of entries for the Dartmouth Winter carnival, which will be held on Friday and Saturday, announced today, shows fifty-eight competitors, representing twelve American and Canadian colleges and universities.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- The American Chamber of Commerce delivered today to Louis Rollin, Minister of Commerce, one of the most vigorous protests ever made by an authorized American trade body to the French Government.

Ernest Koslan of Evander Childs High School and Joseph Abrams of De Witt Clinton yesterday gained the final round of the fifth annual De Witt Clinton High School inter-scholastic indoor tennis singles tournament at the 369th Regiment Armory.

While Governor ROOSEVELT was studying Sheriff FARLEY'S reply to the charges and demand for removal filed by Judge SEABURY, the grand jury gave its opinion of the validity of one part of the case. By indicting Mr. FARLEY and his predecessor, Mr. CULKIN, presumably on the urging of the District Attorney's office, the grand jury has offered Albany a collateral opinion which is necessarily of great significance in the premises.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- The wheat market today was disappointing to many traders on the Board of Trade here. Despite plenty of bullish news, with war talk, another cold wave over the main belt, an active foreign demand, good buying of futures here for European account and higher cables, the market was again unable to absorb all the May that seemed to be for sale at 60 cents and above.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Bud Westhus of St. Louis shoved the veteran Tiff Denton of Kansas City deeper in the cellar of tbe world's three-cushion billiard championship tournament today by defeating him, 50 to 34, in sixty innings. It was Westhus's fourth victory in eleven matches and the ninth defeat in eleven games for Denton.

HONOLULU, Feb. 3 -- Hawaii's "Black" army settled down today in its field positions to await the onslaught of the "Blue" force, which is steaming somewhere in the Pacific, en route for its attempted conquest of these islands. Defense arrangements have been completed in every sector and installations have been inspected from the air by a staff of officers and reported satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Ninety per cent of the whisky prescriptions issued by doctors are for beverage and not medicinal purposes, Dr. Arthur D. Bevan, ex-president of the American Medical Association, testified today at the Senate Manufactures subcommittee hearing on the Bingham beer bill which Dr. Bevan opposed.

Money market continued at a standstill. Virtually little new business was reported, most of that arranged being in the nature of routine requirements. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 2 1/2 per cent with outside funds at 2 1/4 and Federal money at 3 to 3 1/4 per cent.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 3 -- City Judge William G. De Meza fined two men $25 each and suspended the sentence of a third in connection with the effort being made to prevent Sunday movies here. The defendants were charged with violation of the city ordinance pertaining to manual labor on Sundays.

More than $5,000,000 and valuable art treasures were disposed of in the will of Lewis Cass Ledyard, a leader of the bar in this country and former personal counsel to the elder J. Pierpont Morgan and the New York Stock Exchange. The largest bequest was one of $2,000,000 to the New York Public Library, of which Mr. Ledyard was a former president.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- The Saranac Lake High School team regained the New York State High School speed skating championship on the Pontiac rink today before a crowd of nearly 2,000.

Loans of members of the New York Stock Exchange on security collateral declined further by $75,141,871 in January, comparing with a decrease of $142,992,095 in December, 1931, reducing the volume of such loans contracted for and carried in New York at the close of business on Jan. 30 to $512,017,942, the lowest figure on record.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Willys R. Peck, American Consul General in Nanking, informed the State Department today that more than thirty American women and children were being evacuated. These are practically all Americans resident in the capital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Hoover appealed to the country tonight to cease the hoarding of currency, as a patriotic move toward loosening credits and restoring economic stability. Hoarded funds were estimated by the President at $1,300,000,000, every dollar of which, he reasoned, meant the destruction of from $5 to $10 of credit.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The British Government had received no reply tonight either from Tokyo or from Nanking to five proposals for restoring peace sent yesterday to the Japanese and Chinese Governments from London and Washington. But Sir John Simon told the House of Commons this afternoon there were grounds for hope that these proposals were having a good result."

MONTREAL, Que., Feb. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Permission to postpone the interest payable on 5 per cent first mortgage debenture stock and bonds of Algoma Central Terminals, Ltd., will be sought at a special meeting of holders of these bonds to be held in London, England, on Feb. 22, according to a circular letter issued by R. Home Smith, president of the Algoma Central Hudson Bay Railway and of Algoma Central Terminals.

GENEVA, Feb. 3 -- The question of guaranteeing the security of nations as a preliminary to disarmament began today to occupy a prominent place in the preoccupations of the disarmament conference, although the conference is still only in its embryonic stage and not yet organized.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Arthur Thurnblad of Chicago defeated Jake Schaefer of San Francisco tonight to retain his slender chance of winning the world's three-cushion billiard title a second straight time.
BERLIN, Feb. 4 (AP). -- The contention that real whisky cannot be made anywhere outside the British Isles was made in a Berlin court today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 4 (AP). -- Quarrels over men and the purported "strange intimacies" between Agnes Anne Leroi and Hedvig Samuelson, trunk murder victims, broke up the friendship between the two young women and Winnie Ruth Judd, who is on trial for the slayings, it was testified today.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 4. -- "Two days more of bombing and bombardment and Shanghai will be through with the horrors of war."

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 4. -- In a speech before the assembled members of the American colony at Churubusco Country Club at a luncheon tendered by the American Legion, the University Club, the American Club and the American Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in the Wilson Administration, made a strong plea for International agreement and sacrifice as a means to protect mankind from a recurrence of the great war.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 4. -- The Alleghany Corporation, which controls the Chesapeake Corporation and the Chesapeake Ohio, the Missouri Pacific and other railroads, has retired in part its current loans and accounts payable and arranged a four-year loan for the balance.

TOYKO, Feb. 4. -- Ambassador Troyanovsky of Russia visited Foreign Minister Yoshizawa today to protest against the use of the main line of the Chinese Eastern Railway by Japanese troops advancing toward Harbin from Tsitsihar. Assistant Foreign Commissioner Karakhan warned Ambassador Hirota of Japan at Moscow to expect a protest if the Japanese entered Harbin, but it is plain the Japanese believe those protests are matters of form.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 4 (AP). -- Canada defeated the United States today, 2-1, and Germany conquered Poland by the same score, but so close and hard fought were the games that the hockey scheme for the Winter Olympics had to be changed summarily.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Immediate passage of the La Follette-Costigan bill to appropriate $375,000,000 for direct unemployment relief was asked of the Senate in a statement tonight by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, on behalf of the executive council of the federation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The Norris anti-injunction bill, which would restrain Federal courts from issuing injunctions against strikers, during labor disputes, was finally laid before the Senate today with a favorable report from the Judiciary Committee.

Net income of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company in 1931 amounted to $8,464,158, equal to $7.03 a share earned on 1,203,952 capital shares, compared with $7,911,893, or $7.88 a share earned on 1,003,952 shares, in 1930, according to the annual report. After the payment of dividends, however, there was a deficit of $367,458, comparing with a deficit of $119,723 in 1930.

The illness of Armand Tokatyan tenor, with the grip has necessitated several changes in next week's bill at the Metropolitan Opera House. Alfio Tedesco will replace him as Count Almaviva in "The Barber of Seville," which opens the fifteenth week of the season on Monday night, and on Thursday night Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffman" will be presented instead of the originally planned "Mignon."
THE HAGUE, Feb. 4. -- The World Court delivered an advisory opinion today on the Poland-Danzig controversy over the treatment of Poles in Danzig territory.

Approval of the proposed merger of the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation, the Prairie Oil and Gas Company and the Prairie Pipe Line. Company was believed yesterday to be virtually assured when it became known that the Rockefeller interests had sent in their proxies to be voted in favor of the consolidation.

The New York Central Railroad resumed its fight for a 40 per cent increase in commutation rates yeaterday by presenting to the Public Service Commission a list of figures showing, according to counsel for the railroad, that the company is operating its commutation service throughout Westchester County at a monthly loss of about $437,000.

There is no more excuse today for indicting and trying a person in a criminal court than there is for hanging him for being ill or insane," Clarence Darrow writes in his autobiography, "The Story of My Life," published today by Scribner. Constantly through the long book runs the theme of hatred for all criminal court proceedings, despair at the present methods of treating crime.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 4. -- All fire apparatus in this town turned out at noon today In answer to a general alarm from Washington's Headquarters in Morris Avenue here, now a public museum of Revolutionary War relics. As word spread through the community that the historic building was afire, hundreds of residents hurried to the old frame structure to save what they could of the many valuable antiques kept there.

Some people like to read short stories as they come out in the magazines, while others prefer to wait for them to be collected in a volume. For one reason or another the short story is a favorite with many. It gives a brief diversion, does not require much time or concentration, and offers endless variety of material and method.

Plans for the foundation of the new Federal court house to be erected in the Civic Centre at a cost of about $10,700,000, have been submitted to the Treasury Department by Cass Gilbert, architect. It is understood that if the clans are approved bids will be advertised for at once.
BOSTON, Feb. 4. -- Another break through the seeding list was recorded today as the women's national squash racquets championship tournament advanced into the semi-final round at the Harvard Club.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 4 (Canadian Press). -- Today his Excellency the Earl of Bessborough, Governor General of Canada, performed the ceremonies which started the seventeenth Parliament on its third session.

Cornered by policemen whom he threatened to shoot if they tried to arrest him, Arthur Anton, 26 years old, of 206 East Eighty-seventh Street, who had wounded two men in the same building an hour earlier was killed by detectives yesterday at 140 East Third Street.

The Folk Festival, celebrated in two opening programs, the second of which is to be given next Sunday night, suggests how varied a heritage of beauty and of skill has been brought to us from other lands -- and how little we have availed of it. FRANKLIN K. LANE, former Secreretary of the Interior, described these gifts in a glowing catalogue which ought to be inscribed on a welcoming column at our port.

A frantic neighborhood search for 5-year-old Florence McDonnell of 287 Chauncey Street, Brooklyn, missing since Wednesday afternoon, ended in the finding of the girl's body just before noon yesterday in a cellar at 232A Ralph Avenue, around the corner and within seventy-five feet of her home.

The Pennsylvania Railroad will apply to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for loans which it was estimated would reach $5,000,000 monthly for an unstated period, it was announced yesterday by W.W. Atterbury, president. The loan would be used to continue electrification of the road's main lines, the initial cost of which will be $100,000,000, and for terminal improvements.

The New York A.C. fencing trio, composed of Leo Nunes, Dr. John R. Huffman and Nicholas Muray, last night successfully defended the national senior saber team championship by defeating the Fencers Club and New York University representatives in the final round without losing a bout.
Resales of foreclosed properties factory deals and apartment house transfers were among the variety of New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 5. -- Three Japanese aviators were killed today when their bombing plane was shot down within 100 yards of Chinese military headquarters, five miles northwest of Shanghai.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- His belief in independence for the Philippines is reiterated by Senator Harry B. Hawes, Democrat, of Missouri, in his book, "Philippine Uncertainty; an American Problem," which was published today. Senator William E. Borah, Republican, of Idaho, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, in a foreword agrees with Senator Hawes's view.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 4. -- Harvard University authorities today appealed to the police to search for Floyd J. Stewart, 23 years old, of Garden City, Kan., and Nathaniel E. Jones, 23, of Billerica, Mass., students at the Business School, who have been missing since they vanished Sunday in Jones's small automobile.

In the seeming rejection by the Japanese Government of the peace proposals made by Great Britain and the United States, with the approval of France and Italy, there Is still a certain ground, for hope along with surprise and disappointment. There is force in the contention of Japan that her treaty rights in Manchuria cannot be included among the "pending questions" which the projected peace conference is to discuss.

HONOLULU, Feb. 4. -- Seth W. Richardson, Assistant United States Attorney General, arrived today to begin his inquiry into the Hawaii crime wave. In a prepared statement to the press he said he hoped to conclude his work at the earliest possible date.
