BRANFORD, Conn., Feb. 4. -- Sergeant Victor MacDonald of the Army Medical Corps, stationed at Fort Jay was killed and nine passengers of a Greyhound Line bus headed from Boston to New York were severely injured when it skidded and side-swiped an eastbound truck owned by the Affleck Moving Company of Providence on the Boston Post Road just before daybreak this morning.

The February financing for the Federal Intermediate Credit Banks system, comprising an issue of $15,000,000 of 5 per cent collateral-trust debentures, due in four months, will be done next week, according to an announcement made yesterday by Charles R. Dunn. fiscal agent for the banks.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the beat names. Wednesday -- 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names. The Quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Bondholders of the city of Asheville, of Buncombe County, N.C., and of its various political subdivisions, who have received no interest on their investments since 1930, will receive "substantial" checks in a few days from the bondholders' protective committee headed by Henry W. George, treasurer of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, covering part of the past-due interest.

Net profit of the Transamerica Corporation and its holding companies in 1931, as shown in the annual report of the company published yesterday, was $6,245,837, or 26 cents a share. Net assets of the corporation on Dec. 31 amounted to $131,121,778, equal to $5.54 a share on the 23,659,368 shares of capital stock outstanding.

By way of demonstrating that the alleged holdout situation is far from being as seriously out of hand as it is feared in some quarters, the New York Yankees, through Secretary Ed Barrow, announced yesterday the receipt of seven new signed contracts to bring the total of players now in the fold up to fifteen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The time is soon coming when it will be necessary to consolidate the air forces of the army and navy with one directing head, but such a movement now would be premature, Major Gen. Benjamin D. Foulois, chief of the Army Air Corps, told the House Committee on Expenditures today.

The city of Newark, N.J., plans to do its annual long-term financing in the amount of $5,000,000 on Feb. 20, subject to final approval of the Board of Commissioners, which is expected to be given at a meeting to be held on Wednesday. The new financing will take the form of an issue of bonds, due variously in from one to forty years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- Selling of May Wheat at 60 cents a bushel and higher was renewed today on the Board of Trade here, and the speculative interest was not sufficiently large to absorb it. The result was that the market turned weak after an early advance and closed 5/8 to 7/8 cent net lower.

BASLE, Feb. 4. -- The decline in the funds of the Bank for International Settlements that has been going on since the Hoover plan suspended the reparations account appears now to be almost stopped. The monthly statement issued tonight shows the World Bank's resources on Jan. 31 totaled about $207,000,000, or only $700,000 less than at the end of December.

Two plays were added yesterday to the list of productions scheduled to open next week in the Broadway theatres. They are "Zombie," a play by Kenneth Webb, which, under the management of George Sherwood, will come to the Biltmore Theatre on Wednesday night, with Pauline Starke in the leading role, and "Monkey," which will be presented next Friday evening at the Mansfield Theatre by Robert Sparks, recently represented on Broadway by "Never No More."

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 4. -- A fine swirling snow from a low, leaden sky fell on Hanover tonight, bringing joy to the Dartmouth Outing Club on the eve of the twenty-second annual Dartmouth Winter carnival. Until the past few days there had been grave doubt that the carnival could be held, because of the absence of Winter weather.

Money market passed through another session properly classified as stagnant. While funds appeared in fair volume, little of it was employed in any section -- day loans, maturity funds or business paper. Stock Exchange call money was 2 1/2 per cent, which also ruled in the counter market, with Federal funds at 2 3/4@3.

Stock compositions of the German repertory, which formed half the program of the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Bruno Walter conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall, were contrasted with two works played for the first time in America; Krenek's suite from music to Goethe's "De Triumph der Empfindsamkeit," in which the orchestra was assisted by Jeannette Vreeland, soprano, and Franz Schmidt's "Variations on a Hussar's Song" for orchestra.

TOKYO, Feb. 4. -- We think we owe the world an explanation of our activlties at Shanghai, in view of the misunderstandings and to avoid the result of misinformation concerning the present conditions there.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- Thomas J. O'Neill, attorney for Mrs. Jane L. Bianchi of Yonkers in her suit for $100,000 against the New York Telephone Company and Charles J. Haverty, one of its employes, moved that a verdict of $25,000 brought in today by a jury in Justice Bleakley's part of Supreme Court here be set aside as "grossly inadequate."
VIENNA, Feb. 4. -- The coverage of the Austrian note issue in gold and foreign exchange, it was admitted today, has sunk from the legal minimum, of 24 to 23.1 per cent.
The number of workers at the Brooklyn Navy Yard will have dropped from 4,105 employed on Jan. 31 to about 3,600 shortly after Feb. 12, when the new treaty cruiser Salt Lake City will leave the yard.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 4 (AP). -- The biennial convention of the United Mine Workers of America voted today to maintain for the International Union the present per capita tax of 50 cents a month. A recommendation for a reduction was shelved when it was referred to a committee.

A decrease of 3.55 per cent In funds raised in 1931 for ministerial support by churches of the Methodist Episcopal denomination was revealed yesterday in an editorial comment by The Christian Advocate discussing the annual statistical report to be published in the Methodist Year Book for 1932.

Unless the city finds some way to prevent further evictions of the families of the unemployed, the Unemployed Councils of New York will use force to "fight off the hired thugs of the landlords," Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen, was told yesterday by a committee of the Communist organization that headed a large and enthusiastic unemployment demonstration in a march from Union Square to City Hall.
DETROIT, Feb. 4. -- New York and Chicago bankers have refused to loan the city $5,000,000 unless their ultimatum to cut another $6,000,000 off the expense list is obeyed.
PARIS, Feb. 4 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

DUBLIN, Feb. 4. -- Neville Chamberlain, British Chancellor of the Ex-chequer, scored a bullseye for President Cosgrave of the Irish Free State today. His move for tariffs in the House of Commons will not Improve Eamon de Valera's changes of gaining a majority in the Irish Free State elections on Feb. 16.

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- Twenty-five days hence Great Britain will become a general tariff country after ninety years of free trade. A resolution providing for this drastic change in fiscal policy was introduced in the House of Commons this afternoon by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer.
TOKYO, Feb. 4 (AP). -- The Japanese Government today ordered a full division of the army to Shanghai to relieve the 5,000 bluejackets who have been fighting it out with the Chinese for a week.

"The Soul of Mexico," a motion picture produced and financed by Mrs. Juliet Barrett Rublee, was presented for a single showing at the Roerich Museum last night before a gathering that included Jose Manuel Puig Casauranc, Mexican Ambassador to the United States; Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow and representatives of the motion picture industry.

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- Trading was light on the Stock Exchange today, although the tone was cheerful. Sterling on New York opened cheaper at $3.44 1/2 in anticipation of a redaction in the bank rate, but after it was announced that there would be no change it recovered to the overnight level of $3.45 1/4.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The dally average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 3, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,830,000,000, an increase of $17,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $863,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Two girls and an inspector in the Forestry Bureau were mysteriously shot from a speeding automobile in the north-western part of the capital tonight. The police cent out an alarm indicating a belief that the shootings were the work of a maniac.

The proposal of the Republican majority in the Legislature to eliminate the entire $46,400 appropriation for the State Board of Housing as part of its program to slash the State budget by $21,455,751, was met here yesterday by a concerted protest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Public pressure resulting from developments in the Far East prompted Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Affairs Committee to revive efforts today for action at this session on his $616,000,000 warship authorization program, designed to build the fleet up to the London treaty limits.

Figures on capital outlay and maintenance costs for operation by the city of the Whitestone spur of the Long Island Railroad as a part of the rapid transit system submitted to Aldermanic President McKee's special committee yesterday by Robert Ridgway.

Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, who two months ago persuaded the Eastern President's Conference to appoint a committee to negotiate with the railway labor unions on wage reduction, made to the conference yesterday his official report stating that the brotherhoods had accepted a 10 per cent deduction in wages for one year.

Soviet Russia's new Five-Year Plan, as outlined by Premier MOLOTOV, is not in line with forecasts published only a few weeks ago, apparently on the highest authority. The burden of the news out of Moscow around the turn of the year was that the second Five-Year Plan would lay chief stress on production of commodities, and not a development of industrial plant.

Now that the Building Trades Employers' Association of this city has formally ratified the new wage scale, cutting rates from 25 to 30 per cent under the existing schedules, the next move is for the unions to make. Will they accept the new system, or call their men out on May 1 when it goes into effect, or perhaps try to effect a compromise ?

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4. -- Although trailing by two points at the half time, the Princeton varsity basketball team came back in the second half with a sustained offensive drive which gave the Tigers a 46-to-32 victory over a powerful Gettysburg team here tonight.

More than 5,000 workers, representing 30,000 dress makers in this city, met in Mecca Temple, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street, last night and approved a resolution presented by their leaders to call a general strike in the dress industry. The time when the strike is to go into effect was left to the discretion of the New York Dress Joint Board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- With his obvious pleasure over his appointment as Ambassador to Great Britain tempered by regret over the coming break in his Washington associations, Andrew W. Mellon, retiring Secretary of the Treasury, told newspaper men today that he expected no difficulty in the performance of his new duties in the leading diplomatic post in the gift of the President.

The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company has sold the property at 34 Union Square, southeast corner of Sixteenth Street, it was announced yesterday. The property, which consists of a six-story building on a lot 26 by 100 feet, has been bought by the Bell-Fourth Avenue Corporation, Mark A. Freeman, vice president.
MARCUS HOOK, Pa., Feb. 4 (AP). -- The lives of at least seventeen men were snuffed out in explosions which wrecked the oil tanker Bidwell early today as she lay at a Delaware River pier here.

"Leaks" on the locations of parcels of land which the city sought to acquire by private purchase and the profits resulting to "insiders" from the advance knowledge were disclosed yesterday In the final section of the 600-page report on condemnation procedure compiled toy Leonard M. Wallstein, Special Assistant Corporation Counsel.

Making capital of his service and volleying beautifully, Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Yonkers defeated Julius Seligson of the Bronx yesterday to gain the final round of the metropolitan indoor tennis championship at the 106th Regiment Armory, Brooklyn.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 4. -- "Japan's attack on Shanghai is bringing the amazingly healthy result of inaugurating a new historical period in China's attitude toward foreigners other than Japanese, a more realistic and less impatient attitude toward extraterritoriality and a new cordial disposition to teamwork with other foreigners in the International Settlement."

Discussion by the new wage schedule adopted by the Building Trades Employers' Association, cutting 25 to 30 per cent from the rates in the existing agreements, will feature the regular meeting of the Building Trades Council next Tuesday morning in the union headquarters, 154 Third Avenue.

Although bank clearings in the week ended on. Wednesday were 838,013,000 greater than those in the preceding week, the increase was not so great as had been expected, in view of the fact that heavy bank settlements are made at the beginning of the month.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Feb. 4. -- Private P.P. Butcher, 21 years old, of the Sixty-first Service Squadron, narrowly escaped being dragged into the air by the leg from an airplane moving at 115 miles an hour here today. About 700 feet of one-half inch steel cable trailing behind the plane, which was 500 feet up, snaked across the field, gashed Butcher's leg, missed six other privates and cut into a steel hangar door.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4. -- A new sixfurlong track record was set at Hialeah Park today, when George D. Widener's fleet sprinter Panetian dashed six furlongs in 1:10 2-5 to lower the old mark by a fifth of a second. The gelded son of Galetian and Pan Maid flashed his performance in the Long Key Handicap and defeated Don Leon by three lengths.

Sino-Japanese Developments. SHANGHAI -- The Japanese, after landing more men and big guns, began their biggest offensive in Chapei today. Admiral Shiozawa announced he would drive the Chinese back five or six miles. Eighteen Chinese airplanes arrived for the battle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Two be seeking to end "unfair competition of foreign transatlantic lines arisi from "cruises to nowhere" and prevent placing large foreign oce liners in the West Indies service we introduced in the House and Sena today.

The long-awaited declaration by former Governor Alfred E. Smith as to whether he will be a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in opposition to Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt is scheduled for tomorrow, it was indicated yesterday.

Arthur Goodman has chosen an extraordinarily difficult subject in "If Booth Had Missed," which was played at Maxine Elliott's last evening. He has turned it into an extraordinarily fine play. If Booth had missed when he fired at the Civil War President in Ford's Theatre on that fatal nigrht.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Three bins by Senator Borah seeking to reduce salaries of members of Congress, Cabinet officers and others in Federal service who receive more than $5,000 annually, were referred today to the Civil Service Committee, with the prospect that they will reach the Senate floor for discussion tomorrow.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Feb. 4. -- The "unwritten law" was brought into the murder trial of Edward H.B. Alien today for the first time when, after strenuous opposition by the State, the defense won the right to have read to the jury his statement to the police Immediately after he had killed Francis A. Donaldson 3d, his sister's fiance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Under-Secretary Ogden L. Mills of New York will become Secretary of the Treasury when Andrew W. Mellon resigns that post to become Ambassador to Great Britain, the White House announced informally today.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4. -- The appointment of Edwin J. Loeb, Los Angeles corporation lawyer, to be arbiter over the Western activities of the motion picture business was announced today; it was regarded as a significant development in the internal reorganization of the industry.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 4. -- Three Northern players and one Southern representative survived the quarter finals today in the fifth national championship of club champions on the St. Augustine links.
Leading truck owners and operators pressed their fight yesterday against increased registration fees, which, they contend, will play havoc with the transportation business here.

Seal hunting in Long Island Sound, two hours from Times Square, is the favorite pastime of R. Snowden Andrews, member of the New York Stock Exchange. He was back in his office at 71 Broadway yesterday after a five-day hunt at Goose Island, off Guilford, Conn.

IT may be all for the best but it was a trifle careless of Paulino Upsidedown to be strolling around with a broken rib. His explanation is that he didn't notice it. That's just like Paulino. The fight program may be a little livelier with the battered Basque on the sideline, but the discovery of the broken rib has prevented what would have been a vivid clash in style -- of hats.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 5. -- The Japanese launched a large-scale offensive against the Chinese troops in the Chapei area of Shanghai this morning after having landed ten big guns and at least 1,000 fresh men during the night.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4. -- The seared and crumpled wreckage of the trimotored Century - Pacific airliner which vanished a week ago between Bakersfield and this city with three women and five men aboard, was found today atop the snow-laden ridge route, four miles north-west of Lebec.

The Boston Bruins struck back at the New York Americans with a vengeance last night when they routed the star-spangled sextet in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. Smarting under a 4-to-3 defeat handed them by the New Yorkers in their last game at Boston on Tuesday, the visiting skaters registered a 5-to-0 triumph before a crowd of 9,000 persons.
AUBURN, Ala., Feb. 4. -- The newest addition to the list of the elements, No. 85, has peeped out of hiding by making its first appearance in concentrated form.

Brokers' loans, as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, declined in the week ended on Wednesday for the twenty-second consecutive time. The drop, amounting to $8,000,000, reduced the total to $505,000,000, the smallest on record with the exception of the $473,438,000 reported on Jan. 25, 1918.

BASLE, Feb. 4. -- Following is the balance statement of the Bank for International Settlements, giving its condition as of Jan. 31, as made public here today. Figures are in Swiss gold francs at par 19.3 cents:

HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 4. -- Charles Cardenas, Cuban skipper, captured the first race of the international Star Class series for the historic Bacardi Cup off the Malecon today. Cardenas, who is defending the trophy, served notice on the other skippers, American and Cuban, that he will be a formidable rival once more.
NANKING, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Nanking, which was evacuated by British and American women and children yesterday after a bombardment by Japanese warships, was returning to normal today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4. -- Twenty-three members of the colony were guests today of Mrs. Loring Quincy White at luncheon followed by contract at the Semlnole Club.

A distribution of $7,862,459 in cash and securities is being made by the General Motors Corporation to 30,222 of its employes who invested in its savings and investment fund of 1926, which matured on last Dec. 31, it was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president.

MONTREAL, Que., Feb. 4 (Canadian Press). -- The 26,000 members of the running trades, locomotive engineers and firemen, trainmen, conductors, yardmen and railway telegraphers employed by the Canadian National and Canadian Pacific Railways today accepted a 10 per cent wage cut for one year and two months dating from Dec. 1, 1931, and an agreement to that effect was signed here early this evening.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Banishment of care for six days was proclaimed tonight as New Orleans, draped in purple, gold and green, hailed Momus in the first glittering street pageant of the feast of Mardi Gras, the carnival season, observed for more than 100 years.

RAGUE, Feb. 4. -- Dr. Voitetch ka, the Slovak leader and professor of the University of Bratislava, o was sentenced three years ago imprisonment for fifteen years high treason by a Czech court, threatened with total blindness.
PARIS, Feb. 4. -- French Senators in the midst of their solemn deliberations today were startled by the screams of a woman who declared she was chained in the visitors' gallery.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 4 (Canadian Press). -- To show the trend of Canadian trade, a summary of the business of the country during 1931 was today issued by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. It indicates progress toward elimination of the adverse balance of trade with foreign countries and a well-maintained favorable balance of trade with the British Empire nations.

"WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- President and Mrs. Hoover tonight held the fifth of the Winter's State receptions at the White House, entertaining for the officials of the Treasury, Postoffice, Interior, Agriculture, Commerce and Labor Departments. The sixth and last reception, that in honor of the army and navy, will be held Monday night, Feb. 8.

J. Stewart Baker was elected yesterday chairman of the board of the Manhattan Company, succeeding the late Paul M. Warburg, while James P. Warburg, son of the banker, was elected vice chairman of the board to succeed Mr. Baker.
LONDON, Feb. 4. -- Japan's reply to the Anglo-American peace proposals did not arrive at Downing Street today, but the summaries cabled from Tokyo produced keen disappointment.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- Two bills were introduced today by Senator Horton providing for reductions in the salaries of all State officials and employes above $1,000 and caused a good deal of comment amog civil service workers and others on Capitol Hill.

The names of two prospective purchasers of Stock Exchange seats, at $135,000 each, were revealed yesterday by the Exchange. The names of two applicants for membership through transfers of rights were also announced.

Tariff-law provisions excluding obscene books from this country are not meant to respect either person or the literary merits of a volume, the United States Customs Court declared yesterday in affirming the action of customs officials who excluded in 1929 a first edition of George Moore's "A Story-Teller's Holiday" imported by Paul Hyde Bonner, silk man and book collector.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP). -- With the Ways and Means Committee closing its month of searching at public hearings for fresh and substantial sources of revenue, only a few concrete suggestions for the new tax bill had been cleaned from the 300 witnesses heard.

The recovery in prices continued yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and the list closed with gains of 3 to 7 points. The lowest quotations were at the opening on scattered selling and the tone strengthened as trade interests took contracts from the market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- President Hoover's call yesterday for a nationwide drive to restore economic stability and his plea to the country to put hoarded dollars to work has met with enthusiastic support from the public, if the telegrams and other messages received by him today reflected the sentiment of the communities from which they came.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Governor Roosevelt of New York and Newton D. Baker, both possibilities for the Democratic nomination for President, were the targets for criticism from Joseph P. Tumulty today for "running away from the peace ideals of Woodrow Wilson" and the League of Nations.

NEW YORK. The final Junior Assembly of this season will take place tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Among those who will give dinners in advance are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Resolved Williams, Mrs. Gilbert E. Jones and the Misses Julia and Mary Willets.

With all possibility of operation of the new Eighth Avenue subway by April 1 removed, an examination of the reasons why the line from Fulton Street to 207th Street has not been opened has been undertaken by Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, and will be made the subject of a public hearing, it was announced yesterday.

Five men were arrested last night following a raid by gangsters on a room above the Abbazia Restaurant, at Second Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, which, police say, was being used as a race track bookmaker's establishment. Two men are known to have been wounded in the attack, one critically; and police believe at least three others were shot and spirited away.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad in a preliminary report showed a net loss of $2,261,045 in 1931, against a net income of 52,523,271, or $2,07 a share on its $50 par common stock, in 1930. The earnings follow:

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 5. -- This morning's Chinese newspapers said that a company of peasant women had taken over the job of guarding the Shanghai Road in the vicinity of Woosung, where there has been considerable artillery activity during the last few days.

A definite Improvement in credit from the standpoint of collections was reported yesterday to the National Retail Dry Goods Association, holding its annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania, by A.B. Buckeridge, executive manager of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc.

Raw sugar was sold yesterday at the equivalent of 1 cent a pound, or the lowest price in the history of the trade, as the market continued in a highly nervous state over the difficulties between Cuba and Java and the possible collapse of the Chadbourne plan for international sugar stabilization.

Yesterday's stock market came virtually to a halt. The day's changes in prices were mostly small fractions, and no trend was indicated. This reflects nothing but professional Wall Street's inability to make up its mind. In old-time markets, Wall Street used to say that an outright halt, after a reasonably long swing in one direction, meant that the force of that particular movement had been spent and that it was likely to be reversed.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

GENEVA, Feb. 4. -- Although the chronic disagreements of outlook which characterize the relations of certain groups of European peoples may imperil this disarmament conference, it is at least starting with fair good humor and a reasonable display of mutual concession.

Simon Lake, pioneer inventor of undersea craft, described here last night a new escape buoy which he said might have permitted the saving of some of the sixty members of the British submarine M-2's crew when she sank last month in the English Channel.

HAVANA, Feb. 4. -- The Cuban Government and Santiago local officials began energetically today the herculean task of clearing away debris, caring for the wounded and feeding and housing the homeless while the nervous populace continues to leave the city in fear of a reptition of the severe earth tremor that wrecked the city early yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 4. -- After a strong opening on the Bourse today the movement toward recovery gave way to a selling wave, and a large part of yesterday's gains was lost. Trading was irregular and some of the leaders managed to resist the downward trend.

By any standard of measurement, yesterday's stock market was one of the dullest in the last five or six years. In point of volume trading was the slowest since Sept. 1 of last year. The turnover was about 674,000 shares, compared with 809,000 on the day before.

ABOARD U.S.S. CALIFORNIA, Somewhere at Sea, Feb. 4 (AP). -- There is little of war, even of makebelieve war, to be seen from the bridge of Admiral Richard Leigh's flagship, the battleship California, on this the fourth day of the 1932 manoeuvres.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 4 (Canadian Press). -- The Royal Bank of Canada said in its news letter today that credit expansion and improved price levels were bound to ensue from such a return of confidence as would restore to activity money now hoarded in the United States.

For almost a month admirers of Pennsylvania's junior Senator have been distressed by contradictory rumors. He was the same old Dry. He was a brand-new Wet. He was astride the fence. Last week the chiefs of the machine said that he would soon renounce prohibition.

The annual contract bridge tournament between the Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Columbia Clubs of New York had its first session last night when twenty-two hands were played in the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty-fourth Street. The scoring was on a cumulative basis, with Harvard competing with Columbia, playing North and South, and Princeton with Yale, playing East and West.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- With a last plea by independent oil producers for an import tax on petroleum and a suggestion from a member of Congress for a higher estate levy, the Ways and Means Committee today closed its hearings on an upward revision of taxes.

Butter. Receipts. 15,510 packages. The market ruled unsettled on top grades yesterday and prices were only barely sustained after some shading on extras during the progress of the call. Supplies of fancy goods on hand an well in excess of the demand which continues slack and the immediate outlook is most uncertain.

TOKYO, Feb. 4. -- Besides rejecting the fifth point of the powers' proposals for peace in Shanghai, as anticipated, the Japanese reply handed to the Ambassadors tonight turns down the second point, which would have prohibited an increase of forces, and declines to renounce mobilization or preparation for hostilities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The demoralization of business activity throughout Shanghai as a result of the continuing hostilities there was described in a report to the Department of Commerce today from the United States Commercial Attache, Julean Arnold.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 4. -- Nassau County's unemployment demonstration, sponsored by the Unemployment Council of Long Island and tinged with the red of communism, was washed out by yesterday's rain. The few orators who braved the weather abandoned their soap boxes under verbal, vegetable and sometimes manual heckling by their audiences.

Conflicting statements by the Grace Line and 200 pier workers who refused to accept a wage reduction of 15 cents an hour were made yesterday by spokesmen of the line and of the International Longshoremen's Association. Substitute workmen who unloaded part of the cargoes of the liners Santa Ana and Santa Olivia left the Grace Line pier at Hamilton Street, Brooklyn, about 3 A.M. yesterday and returned later in the day.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- The gaunt pine shaft that stands silhouetted against the white background of the snow-covered Adirondack countryside twice bore the American flag today in the age-old custom that is the symbol of Olympic victory.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 4. -- Notwithstanding the government's firm stand in support of the gold standard at the rates of 6 pence to the Chilean peso, business men here generally are inclined to believe the situation will not continue for a long period, considering the prolonged pressure from the adverse trade balance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Representations to purchasers that the State Department vouched for the value of foreign bonds might lay the bankers and bond houses concerned open to legal action, Secretary Stimson informed Senator Walsh of Montana in a letter read to the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Ogden L. Mills will bring to the treasury portfolio sound experience and personal ability at a time when the administration is throwing the full weight of its recovery program against the depression. The new Secretary has been a key man in formulating this program.

The application of business principles to government and immediate action by the Federal Reconstruction Finance Corporation to relieve banks in the West were advocated yesterday by Governor Julius L. Meier of Oregon at a luncheon in his honor at the Bankers Club.

The Emergency Work Commission announced yesterday through John A. Stephens, chairman of its operating committee, that it would give employment to 30,570 men during February and that about the same number would continue to receive relief until May 30.

BERLIN, Feb. 4. -- An indictment charging malfeasance in office threatens Dr. Wilhelm Frick, former Minister of Culture and the Interior of Thuringia, as the result of the plot to make Adolf Hitler a German citizen through a fake appointment to the post of a town police commissioner in Thuringia in July, 1930.

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- The proposal to divide Palestine into two strictly autonomous provinces -- one Arab and one Jewish -- now has been made and accepted with reservations by the Arab leaders in Palestine.
One man was shot and another struck over the head with the cover of an ash can yesterday when striking teamsters attacked a van owner and three non-union workers in East Eighth Street.

Fire in a haberdashery store on the ground floor of a four-story building at 1,188 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, caused a stampede last night in a dance hall on the second floor where 200 persons, mostly young women, became panic stricken when clouds of black smoke seeped up through the dance floor.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 5. -- The announcement that Andrew W. Mellon is to succeed General Charles G. Dawes as Ambassador to the Court of St. James's is enthusiastically received here by the press and public alike.

Electric power production continues to show little change after adjustment for normal seasonal fluctuations. The seasonally adjusted daily average for the week ended Jan. 30 is 220,800,000-kilowatt hours, as against 221,000,000-kilowatt hours for the preceding week and 234,400,000-kilowatt hours for the corresponding week last year.
SANTIAGO, Cuba, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Relief agencies intensified their work today to alleviate suffering and repair damage in the earthquake-wrecked city of Santiago.

The New York State Bankers' Association made public yesterday a resolution adopted on Oct. 28 by its council of administration attesting to its faith in the honesty, integrity and ability of Joseph A. Broderick. State Superintendent of Banks, who is now on trial charged with neglect of duty in connection with the failure of the Bank of United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Japan responded to the overtures of the powers for peace in China today with a note which was regarded by officials as falling far short of acceptance of the five-point international peace program, and at the same time, according to advices received here, landed army detachments at the rail head near the Woosung forts outside of Shanghai and dispatched other troops for China.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- An expected increase in the movement of hops failed today to materialize, and with light-weight pork loins firmer there was a rush of smaller buyers to obtain supplies, with the result that prices were lifted 10 to 20 cents from Wednesday.

The balance sheet of the S.S. Kresge Company, as of Dec. 31, 1931, which was issued yesterday, shows that the company acquired $8,951,286 of its common stock last year, thus reducing its cash holdings from $11,154,533 at the end of 1930 to $3,849,954 at the end of last year.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4. -- Rejecting the proposal of the City Commission that the Newark employes accept 10 per cent reductions in salaries. Harry V. Osborne, former Common Pleas judge, counsel for teachers, policemen and other civil service employes, denounced today the bankers who advised a $2,000,000 budget cut as "seeking to exact their pound of flesh to increase their dividends" in an attempt to make capital of the present economic depression.

Mme. Jeritza drew a large audience last evening for the Metropolitan's most cheerful spectacle, "Donna Juanita." The operetta was sung here for the fifth time in five weeks. Von Suppe's dancing conquerors of sunny Spain thus tied a midseason record with "Schwanda," among recent novelties, and "Pagliacel," on the standard opera list.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP). -- Two groups, one from Ohio and another from North Carolina, today presented their credit problems to the Reconstruction Corporation, without, however, obtaining definite action or commitments.
To the Editor of The New York Times : I have read with interest and approval your editorials on the Sino-Japanese situation.

A Neglected Building. Under the taking caption, "Another Eminent Victorian," The Manchester Guardian writes of the complaint of the trustees of the Crystal Palace in London that it is little known or used by the public.

MADRID, Feb. 4. -- Overwhelming the Catholic opposition tonight, the Spanish Cortes approved a motion supported by a majority of the political parties giving parliamentary sanction to the government's method of enforcing Article XXVI of the Constitution, under which the Jesuit order has been dissolved.
HARBIN, Manchuria, Friday, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Japanese troops entered Harbin today after smashing through the Chinese forces.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is to be regretted that Senator Glass sees fit to combine an anti-speculation measure with a sane bill for the strengthening of the national banking system. The Senator from Virginia is expert at banking legislation, but his attempts to combat the evils that attend security speculation seem ill-advised; they are certainly out of place in the proposed amendment to the Federal Reserve act.

James Monroe High School's basketball team, runner-up to De Witt Clinton for the Bronx P.S.A.L. title last year, defeated Morris High, 39 to 13, yesterday in the James Monroe gymnasium in the opening game of the Bronx division P.S.A.L. tournament.
"The Marriage of Cana" was withdrawn last night from the Province-town Playhouse, where it opened Tuesday evening.

Despite the financial difficulties in Hungary, the Hungarian National Bank has declared a dividend of 12 per cent for 1931 and the Hungarian Commercial Bank one of 10 per cent, according to advices received here yesterday by Carl Marks Co., Inc. The First National Savings Bank of Pest and the Hungarian Discount and Exchange Bank, it is added, will pay dividends of 8 per cent each.

LOYANG, China, Feb. 4 (By military wire to Nanking and via telephone to Shanghai). -- On the railway journey from Nanking to Loyang my mind was full of memories of America, its charming Southland, the marvelous Wellesley campus and my many friends and former classmates.

The many ways and means recently devised by science to make the tiny electron, smallest particle of matter, perform its modern miracles were described last night before the American Institute of the City of New York, oldest scientific organization in this State, at a "march of science meeting" held at the American Museum of Natural History.

The Glass bill to revise the Federal Reserve and national banking aws was opposed yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in a resolution declaring that passage of the bill "would inquestionably bring disaster to the banking and business interests of the country," and "would intensify the very evils with which the business world is now contending."

Brief speeches by authors and critics were broadcast by the Columbia system yesterday afternoon from the Hotel Chatham, where Robert M. McBride and the Literary Guild gave a party in joint celebration of the publication of James Branch Cabell's new book, "These Restless Heads," and the Guild's fifth anniversary.

PARIS, Feb. 4. -- In Bruyere's youthful collections the day skirt's length is unchanged and evening wear is ankle length. The silhouette is straight, but the skirts are made more ample than elsewhere by a circular cut or goring. The waistlines mostly are normal.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4. -- The Autogiro Company of America announced here today it had received word that Captain Lewis Yancey had made a successful landing in an autogiro on a terrace of the ruins of Chichen-Itza in Yucatan, Mexico.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- When the Republican economists in the Legislature proceeded to revise Governor Roosevelt's executive budget bill their hands fell more heavily on the State Housing Board than on any other agency of the State Government.
Henry J. Gaisman, chairman of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, has bought the A.P. Theobald residence adjoining the Gaisman estate in Hartsdale. George Howe, Inc., was the broker.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- The four teams that will represent the United States in the Olympic bobsleigh races next week were chosen, tonight.

The Harvard Club players last night clinched the metropolitan Class A squash racquets championship by defeating the Racquet and Tennis Club five, 3 to 2, in a match on the Harvard Club courts. The new title-holders have played out their schedule and, although other clubs have postponed engagements, the outcome of these cannot affect the Harvard Club standing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Pre-war Germany is partly responsible for the training of Japanese and some of the Chinese troops who now are expected to face each other in operations in China proper.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Two Democratic members of the House. Percy E. Quin of Mississippi and Samuel Rutherford of Georgia, died suddenly of heart disease within an hour of each other today.

Selection or Mr. OGDEN MILLS as Secretary MELLON'S successor was expected, and will meet with general approval. Since this month in 1927, Mr. MILLS has been Under-Secretary, an office created in 1921, distinct from the Assistant Secretaries of the Treasury, in charge of particular branches of the department's work.
Altorfer Brothers Company -- Year ended Dec. 31: Net loss after charges and taxes, $236,103, against net profit of $459,938, equivalent to $2,46 a share on 150,283 common shares, in 1930

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Word has been received from Vatican City that the Right Rev. John J. Mitty, Bishop of Salt Lake City, has been appointed Coadjutor Bishop to the See of San Francisco, with the right of succession to Archbishop Hanna. Bishop Mitty is also promoted to the rank of Archbishop of the titular Sea of Egina.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Things are going fairly smoothly in Great Britain, but quite a ripple on political waters has been caused by the announcement that the government are not all entirely agreed on the tariff question. There are four Ministers who are opposed to tariffs, but they are apparently to be allowed to speak and vote against the proposal.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- In opening the third Olympic Winter Games here today, Governor Roosevelt made a plea for world peace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- A decline of $6,139,141,856 in the gross value of farm products of the United States between 1919 and 1929 is shown in a report by the Census Bureau, the gross value in 1929 amounting to $11,775,236,064, as compared with $17,914,377,920 in 1919.

Finding a definite increase in optimism regarding the outlook for the bond market as a result of a questionnaire sent to most of the investment banking houses throughout the country, Lawrence Stern Co. of Chicago have announced that 60 per cent of their replies reported the outlook as fair to good.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- Frank J. Loesch, 79-year-old president of the Chicago Crime Commission, today advocated the establishment of an interstate secret organization to combat kidnappers.

"Paris and Its People" is the title of an exhibition that has opened at the Maurel Gallery, 689 Madison Avenue, to remain until Feb. 28. About two-thirds of the work shown is by contemporary artists, the remainder ranging in point of time all the way back to Watteau (1684-1721), whose "Une Elegante de Paris" is included.

De La Salle Institute upset St. Ann's Academy, 16 to 15, yesterday in a Manhattan Division C.H.S. A.A. game in the East Fifty-fourth Street gymnasium. The victors led throughout and held a 14-to-8 advantage at half-time.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- Miss Ruth Hall of Philadelphia, defending champion, and Mrs. William F. Howe Jr. of Boston, 1929 titleholder, gained the final round of the women's national squash racquets championship at the Harvard Club today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Two former trustees and two former appointees of the Sanitary District were found guilty on "graft" charges involving $6,500,000 today in the Criminal Court. Sentences of one to five years in the penitentiary were imposed on the trustees, Timothy J. Crowe, Democratic president of the district during 1927-28, and Frank J. Link, leader of the Republican faction headed by former Senator Deneen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The French proposals for the establishment of an international police force to guarantee the security of the world, as presented formally to the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva today by Andre Tardieu, chief of the French delegation, aroused lively interest here and were received with an open mind by the State Department, although the reaction in Congressional circles was not favorable.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Feb. 5 (AP). -- An automobile accident today threatened to disarrange plans for the society wedding tomorrow afternoon of Miss Marian Bennett of New Britain and Eugene V. Homans of Englewood, N.J., both prominent golfers.

Although the influence of outside markets was unfavorable yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange remained steady and fluctuations were the smallest of the year, the list closing unchanged to a point higher than on Thursday. Southern spot circles reported a slightly easier basis at some points, but few hedges came on the market and July held within a 2-point range.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- The Philadelphia Record will call tomorrow upon Alfred E. Smith of New York to clarify "by an immediate statement" reports linking his name with the Democratic Presidential Campaign. The Record supported Mr. Smith in 1928.

My companions and I are leaving the bustle of New York and the lamentations of depression pessimists for a region which many, many years ago was trodden by armor-clad conquistadores. We are not out to battle with "dangerous natives," nor do we anticipate any tremendous "jungle perils."

The Rev. Dr. Harry Rimmer, evangelist and Presbyterian clergyman, of Los Angeles, who is holding a series of meetings at the Calvary Baptist Church, announced yesterday that he would defend a civil suit brought against him here by Colonel Ode C. Nichols, a. Los Angeles freethinker, and that he hoped the action would result in a ruling by the New York courts upholding the "truth and scientific accuracy" of the Bible.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 5 -- The heaviest snowstorm in twelve years, striking New England with little warning, passed out to sea today, leaving the entire region buried under a snow blanket ranging from six inches to two feet after causing two deaths, three minor train derailments, crippling power, light and communication lines and marooning hundreds of motorists.

In an effort to apply emergency measures to correct the serious situation in municipal financing which investment bankers say is rapidly growing worse and, if allowed to continue, can only provoke further defaults, the heads of several municipal bond houses and municipal bond attorneys discussed informally yesterday a plan of action intended to change completely the present methods of handling new issues of municipal securities.

Foreign and domestic bonds drifted irregularly lower yesterday in extremely dull trading on the Stock Exchange. Railroad bonds were the weakest of the domestic corporation group, though as usual the infrequently traded issues in all groups showed the greatest declines.

A precise statement of the city's current assets and liabilities has been needed ever since the Administration began negotiations with the bankers. Controller BERRY has now made a report to the Board of Estimate, giving the figures in detail. They show that even with the bankers' aid the city cannot finance its present public improvement program.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Coast Guard cutters were searching the waters near the Delaware Break-water for the bodies of seven men, comprising the captain and crew of the tug Lonnie B. Shaw, which is believed to have sunk in a heavy gale last night three miles east of McCrea Shoal while towing the lumber-laden barge Ruth Shaw toward New York from Sturgeon Point, Va.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Coincident with the news that Senator Barbour favors incorporation of a wet plank in the Republican national platform, former Governor Edward C. Stokes, in a signed article in The Trenton State Gazette today suggested a plank advocating manufacture and sale of light wines and beer in order, he said, to give employment and provide taxes for Federal and municipal governments.

Interest in the municipal bond market next week will centre in three high-grade issues which will come up for award through competitive bidding, aggregating $7,912,000 of the total of $11,379,944 of new issues on the week's calendar. This week's total was $12,561,882, but most of the issues failed to sell.

Committees in more than 7,000 cities will go into action Feb. 15, representing the American Legion, the American Federation of Labor and the Association of National Advertisers, backed by welfare, church, civic and business organizations, in what is described as the greatest mass campaign since the World War, to obtain jobs for 1,000,000 unemployed.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Arthur Thurnblad, Chicago, "was dethroned as world's three-cushion billiard champion, tonight when he lost to Augie Kieckhaefer, 50 to 33, in forty innings. The defeat was Thurnblad's fourth in ten matches, leaving him only one to play, while the victory boosted Kieckhefer into a tie for first place with Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia, at seven games won and two lost.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Japan is contemplating sending a division of troops to Shanghai, Ambassador Katsuji Debuchi informed Under-Secretary of State William R. Castle Jr. today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Armed and mounted patrols cruised tonight through the northern section of Washington to prevent further shootings by the gunmen who last Bight wounded three persons and attempted to fire upon another.
ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Up-State New York presented a Winter scene today, with a good snow blanket over most of the countryside.

Juan Gris was one of the first of the cubists. Such labels are, however, becoming more and more troublesome, owing, perhaps, to the complicated ramifications and subdivisions that have crept into modern art. You never know precisely what an "ism" really is any more.

Arturo Toscanini will not resume his post as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra during the week of Feb. 29, as scheduled, it was announced yesterday by the directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society. Mr. Toscanini has notified the directors that his decision was prompted by the advice of his physician.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The nomination of Andrew W. Mellon for Ambassador to Great Britain was confirmed by the Senate this afternoon less than three hours after the Foreign Relations Committee had unanimously approved the appointment.

The provisional figures for 1931, just published by che Registrar General, indicate that Great Britain's birth-rate is the lowest on record. This is but a continuation of what has taken place since 1922. Unless the death-rate falls, the birth-rate for 1931 is just enough to maintain the existing- total.

George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, filed suit for $500,000 in Supreme Court yesterday against sixty-eight former officers and directors of the Union Mutual Casualty Insurance Corporation, which he took over by order of the court on May 26, 1931, and of which he is the liquidator.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Between $15,000,000 and $20,000,000 in State funds will be needed for poor relief for the year beginning June 1, according to statements in a letter dispatched today by the State Emergency Relief Administration to Governor Moore and legislative leaders and made public here.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Gar Wood coaxed an average speed of 111.712 statute miles an hour out of his Miss America IX on a two-way run over the Indian Creek water course today and claimed a new world's speedboat record for America.

The loan made to the Alleghany Corporation to further its most recent adjustment was backed by the Guaranty Company interests, it was ascertained yesterday. While the amount of the loan was not disclosed officially, it was estimated at $10,000.000.

While business circles apparently have "a feeling that definite progress is being made in, the process of adjustment and that the results of such steps as the rail wage cut and the formation of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will be shown in the near future," Bradstreet's week-end review says, information from fifty-five leading cities indicates little actual quickening "beyond the limited seasonal activity in certain lines."

Thirty members of the Society of Woman Geographers -- women who go places and do things -- and about fifty men. and women guests had dinner last night in the Daniel Giraud Elliott Hall in the American Museum of Natural History. It was the society's first dinner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The annual international ice patrol of the North Atlantic shipping lanes will start March 15 with the cutters Pontchartrain and Modoc on duty. Coast Guard headquarters announced today. The United States patrols the shipping lanes under a treaty negotiated in London in 1914, two years after the Titanic on its maiden voyage went down after hitting an iceberg.

The earth awakens, shakes herself, assumes a more comfortable posture and drops off to sleep again. Such is the geological process of slightly readjusting her strata. In consequence Santiago lies in ruins, lights candles and gives thanks that there was no heavy loss of life.

MANILA, Feb. 5 -- A change in Filipino opinion toward gaining independence under the present disturbed world conditions was sharply indicated by an editorial this morning in The Tribune, a leading Filipino daily.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A plea that postal field employes be excluded from legislation restricting promotions and filling of vacancies during the fiscal year 1933, was made today to Chairman Byrns of the House Appropriations Committee by Thomas F. Flaherty, secretary-treasurer of the National Federation of Postoffice Clerks, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.
LONDON, Feb. 5. -- Beaumont Pease, chairman of Lloyds Bank, paid a tribute to the "patriotic sanity and common sense restraint" of the Britsih people at the bank's annual meeting today.

No new offerings of bonds and notes were made this week, marking the first week since the final one in December that the market went into such a state of inactivity. Prior to that the week ended Oct. 13, 1931, was blank as to bond offerings, while in the two weeks immediately following only one issue a week was put out.
SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 6. -- Japanese naval officials denied today that Japanese troops had been landed at Woosung to occupy the Chinese forts there.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- It is stated here that the British Government, acting in harmony with Washington, sent an added protest to Tokyo today against the Japanese use of the International Settlement as a base for attack against the Chinese. This protest was sent verbally through Sir Francis Lindley, the British Ambassador to Japan.

Decision on the motion of attorneys for Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, to dismiss the indictment charging neglect of duty on which he is being tried, was reserved yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan, in General Sessions, after opposing counsel had presented argument for nearly three hours.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a request of Cornelius N. Eliss, chairman of the Emergency Work Commission, to transfer $2,000,000 from the $8,000,000 appropriation voted by the city for emergency work for unemployed to the Home Relief Bureau, thus making the total appropriation for direct home relief $4,500,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Crude petroleum production in December amounted to 73,174,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,360,000 barrels, or 68,000 less than in November, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The New York University swimming team scored its first victory over Fordham in five years by vanquishing the Maroon contingent, 43 to 28, in the Fordham pool last night. The meet marked the close of the 1931-32 season for the home swimmers, who concluded their campaign with a record of two triumphs and two defeats.

Unless the city can raise the additional funds by long-term or serial bond financing, to supplement the $251,000,000 recently made available by leading banking houses and the $100,000,000 potentially available by a second issue of special corporate stock notes, it faces a deficit of about $43,700,000 for 1932, Controller Charles W. Berry declared yesterday in a report to the Board of Estimate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You have given considerable space to the subject of cosmic rays, which seems to have aroused general attention to an unusual degree. Inasmuch as I discovered this wonderful phenomenon and investigated it long before others began their researches your readers may perhaps be interested in my own findings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Examiner Aaron J. Hughes told the Federal Trade Commission today that the National Public Service Corporation and its subsidiary holding company, the Municipal Service Company, recorded profits of $2,740.904 from appreciations of securities transferred from one subsidiary to another.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Samuel Seabury, counsel for the Hofstadter committee, called upon Governor Roosevelt today to discuss the removal charges against Thomas M. Farley, Sheriff of New York County.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city.

HONOLULU, Feb. 5. -- After a conference with Governor Judd today United States Assistant Attorney General Richardson announced that none of the hearings he and his party will hold inquiring into conditions in Hawaii will be opened to the public and that nothing concerning the information gathered will be disclosed until after he has reported to the Attorney General and Congress.

Charitable organizations will receive almost $150,000 of the estate of John J. Bannan, appraised at $210,695 after the payment of debts and expenses, in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday with the State Tax Commission. Mr. Bannan died on Feb. 19, 1929.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- The Bourse opened firm after yesterday's slump, and despite an interval when trading languished, the tone continued steadily to improve. All the leading stocks advanced and buying by Parisian and provincial investors was in evidence. Toward the close there was one period of animated trading.

Recreation for the Unemployed. It is being impressed more forcibly on workers in close contact with relief for the unemployed that some provision must be made for their enforced leisure. The League for Industrial Democracy is trying to open fifteen or twenty reading and recreation centres in those parts of the city where people out of work will be most helped by them.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 5 -- The Yale Swimming team defeated City College of New York tonight, 38 to 33. The Elis also won at water polo, 43 to 27.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Russia's "first lady," the wife of Michael Kalinin, President of the Soviet Union, plays her part in building socialism in Russia not as the country's official hostess but as the active manager of a big state grain farm in Siberia.

A slight upturn in the production of steel ingots in January brought the operating rate of the industry to an average of 26.54 per cent of capacity, compared with 23.58 per cent in December and 42.86 per cent in January, 1931, according to the monthly compilation of the American Iron and Steel Institute, issued yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 -- Edwin J. Loeb, corporation lawyer, who has been chosen arbiter for motion picture interests on the West Coast, declared today that "the additional responsibilities which have been assigned to me by Will H. Hays constitute what is hardly more than an amplification of the work my law firm has been doing for the producers for years."

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 5. -- Renewing its recommendation for a national conference of coal mine operators and miners to stabilize the industry, the United Mine Workers of America again urged today that president Hoover call the two forces together.

The fact that I have lived a little longer than most men is no "cause for a lot of pomp," JOHN R. VOORHIS used to say when, at the age of 90, he wag arranging for his funeral. Though he was a public official in this city for fifty-eight years, the fact that he lived into his 103d year grave the public its greatest interest in him.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 5. -- "We, too, know how to die when we have to,' said Finance Minister T.V. Soong, who arrived this afternoon to try to stabilize Shanghai's finances as part of the herculean task of restoring order in the government's financial chaos.

HAVANA, Feb. 5 -- President Machado issued a proclamation today to the people of Oriente Province expressing the sympathy felt by the entire nation for the victims of the earthquake at Santiago and assuring them that the government and he personally would labor indefatigably to restore the city.
GENEVA, Feb. 5. -- Following is the text of the French proposals laid before the disarmament conference today:

After adopting resolutions calling for "sound, real and effective retrenchment of government expenses," opposing the Capper-Kelly price-fixing bill, approving the new Vestal design copyright bill subject to modification, and adopting an advertising and selling code, the National Retail Dry Goods Association ended its annual convention with a fashion show yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday ..3 8/4 to 4 per cent for the best names Thursday ..3 8/4 to 4 per cent for the best names The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, speaking last night over the Columbia Broadcasting System, declared that there "exists a civic responsibility to promote the health and welfare of the citizens of every community by guarding against sickness that is bound to flow from undernourishment and lack of medical care in times of financial stress."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Paul M. Linebarger, describing himself as a legal adviser to the Chinese Nationalist Government, was prevented from testifying as such when he appealed today to the House Insular Committee in behalf of the 55,000 Chinese residents in the Philippines.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- The new British tariff impresses political opinion in Germany as an epochal event whose importance for the world cannot be overestimated, for the reversal of the traditional British free trade policy is not regarded here as merely an emergency measure.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Feb. 5 -- After courts-martial which resulted from the recent investigation by Federal authorities into charges that Coast Guardsmen were accepting huge bribes, three officers who had been in charge of the Blue Point, Bellport and Georgica Coast Guard stations on Long Island are now serving sentences in the Portsmouth (N.H.) naval prison, District Commander Eugene Osborne revealed today.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Secretary of War under President Taft, Governor of New York, Governor-General of the Philippines, Secretary of State -- few Americans have had wider executive experience of high office than Henry L. Stimson.

A tentative general program for New York's observance of the George Washington bicentennial was drawn up yesterday at a meeting in the Commodore. The plans are to be submitted to civic, patriotic and other groups for approval before further action at a meeting next Wednesday.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- While an impressive burial service was being conducted over the spot where the M-2 is lying off Portland Bill today, divers a hundred feet below made two important discoveries which may explain the disaster and indicate that death, at least for a majority of the crew of sixty-one, was mercifully quick.

In the Great Hall of the Junior League clubhouse last night a large dinner dance was held under the auspices of the Junior League committee of the Charity Organization Society. The net proceeds will be used to aid the relief work of the society.
SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 6 -- Japanese troops were being landed last night from transports off Woosung and Liuho, ships in the vicinity reported to this city by wireless.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Direct Federal relief for the unemployed was opposed today by James A. Emery, counsel for the National Association of Manufacturers, as a blow at the freedom of States.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 5. -- Day by day in brief intervals of cessations in the Japanese bombardments and air raids, Shanghai is absorbed by the spectacle of the impressive naval pageant as the warships of many nationals steam up and down the Whangpoo River.

Deems Taylor's "Peter Ibbetson" was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera House before a regular Friday evening subscription audience, which gave the opera and the leading performers enthusiastic receptions. Lucrezia Bori was again Mary, Duchess of Towers; Edward Johnson was in the name part, Lawrence Tibbett was Colonel Ibbetson and Gladys Swarthout was Mrs. Deane.
TOKYO, Feb. 5 -- Japan's economic condition, seemingly as sound as that of any European nation, apparently has withstood the pinch of the country's military adventures in China.

John R. Voorhis. the Grand Sachem of Tammany Hall and one of the city's most colorful figures, died early yesterday morning at the age of 102. The end came in the small red brick house on Greenwich Street, which -- just after the Civil War--he had helped to build and where he had since made his home.

A counterfeiting plant which had already issued more than $25,000 in five-dollar notes was seized yesterday in Flushing by Federal agents and New York police, together with $25,000 in finished counterfeits and a supply of paper cut to the five-dollar size, ready to be made into $1,000,000 in additional bank-notes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The wise man who said, "You can't fool all the people all of the time" did not have the American farmer in mind. For a hundred years or so the farmer has been the toad under the tariff harrow that was to make us all rich by cultivating our infant industries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Until uncertainties that obscure the situation at home and abroad have ended, Agricultural Department experts will make no predictions concerning demand and supply or prices of farm produces, although continuing to forecast prospects on the basis of estimates of production and acreage and the plans of farmers to plant crops and breed cattle.

ON the office wall opposite the desk of President John A. Heydler of the National League there hangs a picture of a baseball park with the players on the field and the stands crowded. Across the bottom of the picture is written: "Forbes Field, June 30, 1909. Attendance, 30,338."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- After a month's slumber in a House committee pigeonhole, a proposal for distributing 40,000,000 bushels of Farm Board wheat to the unemployed awakened suddenly today, and final committee action on Monday was assured.

"WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Secretary Lament and authorities on banking will testify before the Watson subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on Feb. 15 on the administration's Federal home loan bank proposal.

SEATTLE, Wash., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Reports from Squaw Harbor, 150 miles east of Unimak Island in the Aleutian chain, tell of the violent eruption of the volcano Shishaldin, one of the highest peaks in the chain.

The proposal of an Everglades National Park in Florida was taken up by the Seventieth Congress, which passed a bill directing the Secretary of the Interior to ascertain whether it would be practicable. In his report on Dec. 3, 1930, Secretary WILBUR stated that "the park, if established under authority of Congress, would measure up to national park standards."
GENEVA, Feb. 5. -- Andre Tardieu. French Minister of War and head of the French delegation, laid France's proposals on the table at the World Disarmament Conference here today.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 5 -- Favored by ideal weather which produced a day of bright sunshine and air with just enought of the bite of Winter in it, the twenty-second annual Dartmouth Winter Carnival opened today with hundreds of guests and competitors on hand for the skating and skiing events of the first of the two-day program.

Ernie Schaaf, who now makes his home in Boston, knocked out Salvatore Ruggirello, Italian heavyweight, in the fourth round of a one-sided battle scheduled for fifteen sessions last night at Madison Square Garden, without being seriously extended at any stage of the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Senator Barbour of New Jersey will work for the incorporation of a wet plank in the Republican national platform next Summer, it became known today when the Senator, who recently announced his support of the renomination of President Hoover, made public a letter to Edgar A. Knapp of Red Bank, N.J., who had inquired what stand on prohibition Mr. Barbour would take in view of his espousal of the Hoover movement.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Scoring four goals, Malcolm McAlpin led the Princeton Varsity hockey sextet to its fifth consecutive victory here tonight, the Tigers routing the Boston University team, 8 to 1, in the Hobey Baker Memorial Rink.

The "absurd little differences" in use of words and manners that Americans note in our English visitors, and that the English note in visiting Americans, do "more to unange the hands across the sea into lists' than do the major issues on Which statesmen disagree, John Langdon-Davies, English author and educator, said yesterday afternoon at a reception and tea given him by the English-Speaking Union, 19 West Forty-fourth Street.

EVANSTON, Ill., Feb. 5 (AP). -- Four professors of Northwestern University, two football stars and a dozen other university men won a foot race and a fist fight in City Hall today in behalf of a Negro scholar's candidacy for Alderman.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 -- George D. Widener's Evening, the St. James-Crepuscule filly, gave further evidence of being a formidable candidate for the Florida Derby when she dashed a mile in 1:36 3-5 at Hialeah Park today and captured the Builders' Handicap with ease.

It is apparently the belief of party leaders in both the Senate and the House that legislation has been proceeding at too rapid a rate. This is a sort of reflex of the complacent feeling that Congress has deserved well of the country thus far by being so hard working and expeditious.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Robbers broke into the office of the Loose Wiles Biscuit Company on Market Street here last night, blasted the doors off the safe, and escaped with about $100 in cash. The blast awakened residents of the neighborhood.

The demands of the union pier workers who quit the employ of the Grace Line last week were placed before the Shipping Board and Department of Labor at a conference last night at the Hotel McAlpin attended by T.V. O'Connor, chairman of the Shipping Board; Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, and investigators of the Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Bills providing for punishment of rape in Hawaii with death or life imprisonment and for appointment of the prosecuting officer of Honolulu by the Hawaiian Supreme Court were introduced in the Senate today by Senator McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, at the request of Mrs. Harry Kluegel, chairman of the Honolulu Citizens' Organisation for Good Government.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 5 (AP). -- The text of the decree specifying that the children of marriages between Catholics and non-Catholics must be reared in the Catholic faith, under pain of annulment of the marriage, reads as follows:

The fifty-first anniversary of the United Society of Christian Endeavor will be celebrated tomorrow after-noon and evening at meetings of branch organizations in many Protestant churches of the city. A rally under the auspices of the New York City Christian Endeavor Union will be held at 3:15 P.M. at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West Seventy-third Street.

AUBURN, Ala., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Discovery on land and sea of many new sources of Element 87, one of the two most recently found chemical elements, was announced today by Dr. Fred Allison of Alabama Polytechnic Institute.

The ninety-second charity ball of the Emerald Association last night at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of Roman Catholic orphan asylums of Brooklyn was attended by more than 5,000 persons, including State and city officials and others prominent in the social and cultural life of Brooklyn.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 5 (AP). -- Sheriff's deputies rescued Gordon H. Sawyer, prominent banker, kidnapped for $60,000 ransom, after a revolver fight with three men and a woman today.

The Newtown High School five, defending city P.S.A.L. champions, got off to an auspicious start in quest of another title by crushing the John Adams High quintet, 52 -- 12, yesterday as both teams launched their Queens Division P.S.A.L. campaigns.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- An undercurrent of dissatisfaction-so serious that at one time Canada threatened to withdraw its teams -- over the rules under which the speed skating races have been held thus far in the Third Olympic Winter Games broke sharply into the open tonight.

Pressure against the stock market was renewed yesterday, and with such vigor that the lazy drift of the day before was replaced by a rather brisk decline. Trading on the Stock Exchange was much more active; the turnover was slightly less than 1,100,000 shares, compared with 674,000 shares on the day before.

The complaint of the public, booksellers and the Cheney report that books too often are allowed to "die like populai songs," that publishers push dozens of unwanted titles into the markets every season, advertise them with exclamatory adjectives and then let them sink into "stock remainders." will he answered this Spring by the offering of fewer titles and by what is designed as "more helpful advertising."

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 5 -- The necessity of taking immediate radical steps to insure the safety of Vatican buildings was again brought out today when wide cracks were discovered at two other points of the imposing buildings which surround the Belvedere courtyard.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 5. -- The United States Circuit Court here today canceled the $12,000,000 Kern County Naval Oil Reserve leases to the Pan-American Petroleum Company, an Edward L. Doheny concern, and, in a decision written by Judge Sawtelle, imputed the leases to a $100,000 bribe given in 1921 to Albert B. Fall, former Secretary of the Interior.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Because of the depression infants are surrounded by conditions "more serious than any ever faced before in the United States," according to Dr. Josephine S. Baker, first director of child health work in New York City, who spoke before a Senate commerce subcommittee.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Sandwrack, coupled with Quando as the J.F. O'Neil entry, won the fifth and feature race at the Fair Grounds today. The evens was a $1,000 allowance affair named the Algiers Purse.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 5 (AP). -- Wang Ching-wei, President of the Executive Yuan of the Chinese National Government and chairman of the Central Political Council of the National party, issued a statement from the new capital at Loyang today in which he declared China would never sign treaties prejudicial to her territorial and administrative sovereignty and would continue to resist Japanese aggression.

TOKYO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Japanese press dispatches from Manchuria today said Edward Hunter, American resident of Peiping, China, and acting as correspondent in Manchuria for the International News Service, was captured by Chinese troops somewhere between Changchun and Harbin and has been missing since then.

The War Department has collected and classified data on 12,000 industrial plants that could be used to make munitions in an emergency, Frederick H. Payne, Assistant Secretary of War, disclosed last night in an address before the New York Post of the Army Ordnance Association at the Army and Navy Club, 30 West Forty-fourth Street.
GENEVA, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Explaining his motives for introducing the French disarmament proposals when he did, Andre Tardieu today told correspondents:

The final session of the sale of oil paintings that belonged to Eugene H. Block, Mrs. J.E. Spiegelberg, the estate of a New York collector and others was held last night at the American Art Association-Andersen Galleries, Inc., and totaled $19,530. The grand total was $36,895.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Governor Roosevelt today defined his present stand on prohibition as to be that of 1930 when he came out in opposition to the Eighteenth Amendment and in favor of the substitution of an amendment which would insure "home rule" to the several States, leaving to the Federal Government the function of protecting Dry States against the importation from wet territory of beverages with an alcoholic content proscribed within their boundaries.

Although still retaining its professional flavor, the stock market showed signs of increasing animation yesterday. At the same time the tendency toward downward reaction became more pronounced and the issues upon which selling converged made a generally unsatisfactory showing on the Stock Exchange.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Feb. 6 -- As one contribution to the Presidential candidacy of Governor Roosevelt, Mrs. Mildred Edwards Whitmire, a reporter on the staff of The Greenville Piedmont, has warned him against mispronouncing the words "initiative" and "associates."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- The long-awaited attitude of Secretary Wilbur on an oil tariff was expressed by himself today as favorable, but his approval was conditional upon several parallel steps to bring order in the disturbed industry.

The United States has weakened the peace effort of the world by staying out of the League of Nations, and this country's aloofness is more dangerous to itself than to any one else, Clarence K.
