Streit, staff correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES at Geneva, said last night in a radio interview carried across the Atlantic by short wave and rebroadcast in America by the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- William S. Vare passed through Washington today on his way to his Winter home in Florida and talked a little about politics, but no new name to add to what is so far a one-man list of Republican Presidential prospects.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 5 -- While the police of Northern New Jersey were searching tonight for the blond young woman and her four confederates who staged six hold-ups in Passaic County within the last twenty-four hours, she and two of her aides robbed the Roxy Beauty Parlor at 186 Main Street here tonight.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 5. -- Thomas Aguilar, an official of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation here and a native of Los Angeles, and his wife Hazel May Pugh Aguilar, a native of St. Joseph, Mo., this morning recovered their eleven-month-old daughter, who was kidnapped eleven days ago.

The last for this season of the Junior Assemblies took place last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton in a setting of Spring blossoms. Baskets of forsythia and daisy plants were arranged in the foyer, while there were groups of cybotium ferns in the corners of the ballroom, the walls of which were festooned with Southern smilax.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Woodrow Wilson was right! The United States made a big mistake in turning down its greatest statesman and following the advice of a small coterie of narrow-minded, revengeful and political Senators by staying out of the League of Nations.
ALBANY, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The New York State Grange expressed opposition today to further use of Federal funds to stabilize farm prices.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5. -- In honor of their, house guests, Sir Humphrey de Trafford and Lady de Trafford and Major T. Bouch of London, who arrived last night, Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener and Joseph E. Widener entertained today with a luncheon at Mr. Widener's residence in South Ocean Boulevard.

A curtailment of expenditures by the State for social service, and by industry and the State for workmen's compensation, would disrupt the present organized system of vocational rehabilitation, disorganize relief for the needy and in the end cost the public more than it is spending now in preventing distress and maladjustment.

Butter. Receipts, 10,572 packages. The market still presents a very unusual appearance. Supplies of fancy butter are still too liberal to clear as a result of the slack trading recently prevailing, and while street stocks are moderate and receipts somewhat lighter the weight of the excess stocks on hand is inducing a nervous and unsettled tone.

While the police were straining Thursday night to solve the murder of 5-year-old Florence McDonnell in a cellar at 232A Ralph Avenue, Brooklyn, another girl of the same age was attacked near City Island, the Bronx police reported yesterday.

Street fatalities continued to decline, here last year, although 1,116 persons were killed by motor vehicles, it was reported yesterday by the Police Department. There were forty-seven fewer fatalities than in 1930 and 104 fewer than in 1929.

PARIS, Feb. 5. -- The Schlaparelli collection is one of the Paris fashion season's high spots. He uses the Directoire waistline just below the bust to make a youthful and completely modern silhouette with very square shoulders and sleeves larger at the top, but not puffed.

Richard T. Beckman, a pioneer flier of Germany who has been building aviation engines since 1909, gave a private demonstration yesterday afternoon of an airplane engine which has been operating for more than 500 hours and runs under an entirely new principle.

Soon after Lily Pons had concluded her "mad scene'' in "Lucia di Lammermoor," which was presented by the Metropolitan Opera Company yesterday afternoon for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Vassar Club of New York, a group of young girls went to the star's dressing room and informed her of the organization of the Lily Pons Fans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The problem of selection of judges has stimulated a number of people to suggest several methods, most of which involve an assumption that, to my mind, is not warranted by experience. It is assumed that were the electorate given the facts, they would act intelligently at the ballot box.

Representatives of 381 clubs, including 767 registered delegates and several hundred other women, attended the eighty-seventh convention of the New York City Federation of "Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Swiftly developing plans for a nation-wide drive to combat hoarding and restore the country's hidden wealth to circulation brought from President Hoover on the eve of a White House conference of civic organization leaders tomorrow an announcement that Colonel Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News, has been called upon to head a national organization which will direct the campaign.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William C. Breed will sail next Tuesday for Bermuda.

Money market remained at a standstill so far as business and rate changes were concerned. Day loans on the Stock Exchange and in the counter trading continued at 2 1/2 per cent, with Federal funds 2 3/4 @ 3 Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were all quiet and unchanged in quotation.

Great spirits yet on earth are sojourning. Naturally, the greatest are Oklahomans. Representative SWANK and Senator ELMER THOMAS, representing presumably the best agricultural thought and supported in principle by chiefs of important organizations of farmers, propose to put the all-derided Farm Board out of business and centre Government control of farm prices in the fount of bureaucratic wisdom, the Secretary of Agriculture.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 6 -- Members of the Thirty-first United States Infantry, 1,168 of them, came into Shanghai today to the strains of martial music from a Filipino band, led by picturesque Sikhs on white horses and Shanghai motorcycle police.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Feb. 5. -- Applause, laughter and hisses filled the county court room this afternoon as Edward H.B. Alien, 23-year-old steeplechase rider, told how and why be killed Francis A. Donaldson 3d. his sister's suitor, on the night of Nov. 9.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 5 -- Louis Greenspan, Jamaica, L.I., lawyer, was convicted today of subornation of perjury by a jury in the Supreme Court here. Denying the motion to set aside the verdict, Justice George H. Furman declared "there is no question but that the defendant obtained divorces on false testimony and that he conducted a divorce mill."

Government spokesmen at Tokyo are anxious to have the world take note of a vital distinction between Manchuria and Shanghai. The Japanese reply to the peace suggestions declares bluntly that it is a settled policy not to accept neutral intervention in Manchurian questions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Secretary Hurley sent to the House today a draft of proposed legislation to authorize the War Department to exchange lands near the military academy at West Point, with the State of New York, and to exchange or sell for military purposes other government lands.

The steamship Jean Jadot rammed and sunk the fishing schooner Eleanor Nickerson of Boston, with a reported loss of twenty-one lives, about eighty miles off Cape Sable in a blinding snowstorm yesterday. The Jean Jadot of the Lloyd Royal Belge Line was expected to put in at Quarantine tonight with the six survivors of the Nickerson's crew.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 5 -- General Tsai Ting-kai, the poet and scholar who is commanding the Chinese force about Shanghai, said today that he intended to go on fighting until he did not have a man left.

The volume of trading increased as prices sagged on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, but the greater part of the list remained inactive while a few favorite issues showed increasing attention from speculators and investors. Losses occurred in American Gas and Electric, Cord Corporation, Electric Bond and Share, Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line, Deere Co., United Light and Power A, Middle West Utilities and Prudential Investors.

Baseball's old guard suffered another loss to its rapidly thinning ranks yesterday when Barney Dreyfuss, owner of the Pittsburgh Pirates, vice president of the National League and dean of major-league magnates, died at Mount Sinai Hospital, where he had been a patient since Dec. 14.

TOKYO, Feb. 5. -- The Japanese Cabinet has successfully weathered serious differences which threatened to scrap plans for dispatching army units to Shanghai and probably would have caused the downfall of the government, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Professional operators were on both sides of the wheat market on a fair scale on the Board of Trade here today. One set sold rather freely at the start, the weakness in the stock market and more favorable weather over the Winter wheat belt creating bearish sentiment sufficient to cause a break of about 1 cent from yesterday's finish.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- Nobody will henceforth be barred from military service in the German Army for having been or being a member of the National Socialist party, as a result of a decree which General Groener, Minister of Defense, issued today.

The foreclosure of a mortgage originally $1,500,000, but now with interest close to 32,000,000, against the New York Queens County Railway Company was forecast yesterday by the announcement of Justice Charles J. Dodd in special term of the Supreme Court, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The effect on American exports to Great Britain of the protectionist tariff proposed to become effective in that country on March 1 will be to impose a 10 per cent ad valorem duty on 46 per cent of British annual purchases in this country, which heretofore have entered duty free, the Department of Commerce announced today.
The Appellate Division, with one dissenting vote, upheld yesterday the decision of Supreme Court Justice Hatting that Senator John A. Hastings of Brooklyn was in contempt of the Hofstadter committee.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin of Boston will say of the wool market tomorrow: "The market is a bit slower this week than it was in January. Fine and half blood wools have been in chief demand, with the latter grade most keenly sought.

VAN NUYS, Cal., Feb. 5 (AP). -- A daredevil who had faced the dangers of film flying stunts for fifteen years spun to the ground and instant death today before movie cameras. He was Leo Nomis, aged 38, as famous in the air as Douglas Fairbanks is on the ground.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP). -- British approved of Andrew Mellon as Ambassador became unanimous today when formal diplomatic approval was conveyed from the Foreign Office to the American Embassy. Universal satisfaction had been previously expressed.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The government's tariff proposals were subject to much discussion on the Stock Exchange today, but failed to bring more business, although there was moderate buying of industrials, which were generally firm. Cessation of Continental buying and week-end profit-taking resulted in British Government funds losing ground, the conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan falling to u75 7/8 and the war loan to u98 7/8.

FIVE years ago an Englishman went to India with high hopes of fortune and renown. To him had been given the job of broadcasting for 350,000,000 people. Money was provided for the erection of stations in the three great cities of Bombay, Calcutta and Madras.

The repute of Senator GLASS, on account of his work in the enactment of the Federal Reserve law, is deservedly so high that his judgment of its needed amendment is entitled to respect. We must confess regret, however, at the position which he appears to have taken in regard to the bill which he has laid before the Senate Banking Committee.

ASSEMBLED here are the spokesmen for 1,700,000,000 people. There is no human being, whether he is engaged in industry and commerce, in the desert or Africa, in the jungles of the East or amid the ice of the Arctic region, who has not some one here to speak in his name. * * *

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Fernand Jacopozzi, a pioneer in the modern art of electrical illumination and flood-lighting, died in his Paris home early today at the age of 54. M. Jacopozzi, who was born in Florence, Italy, made a reputation as an electrician. His creations first came to world notice with his illumination of the Eiffel Tower.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Members of the Bronxville Riding Club held a dinner and hunt ball tonight at the Siwanoy Country Club. The committee in charge included Mrs. R.T. Wilken, Mrs. Gerald Clokey and Frank Howard. Dinner hosts were Dr. and Mrs. Henry E. McGarvey, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Reid.

TOPEKA, Feb. 4 -- In forty years the complexion and characteristics of party politics have not changed very much in Kansas. The annual meeting of the Republican Kansas Day Club which has just been held, and at which the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the organization was fittingly celebrated, proved that political problems, like prosperity and depression cycles, occur with fairly consistent regularity.

SEATTLE, Wash., Feb. 6 -- Riding the swells of the Pacific like a ghost ship, her prow headed for home although there was no hand at her helm, a deserted Japanese freighter was sighted 400 miles off the Japanese coast by the crew of the Shidzuoka Maru, which arrived in Seattle today.

WAVELAND, Ind., Feb. 6 -- Roused from their beds early today by a telephone operator, vigilantes of this little town, pitting rifle volleys against machine-gun fire in an hour's battle in the dark, routed a gang of seven robbers trying to blow up and loot the State Bank of Waveland.

THAT a keenly critical mind, a nimble wit and a mildly caustic pen were lost to America with the death of Stuart P. Sherman is now proved anew with the issuing of a third collection culled from Mr. Sherman's writings.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 25. -- The report on the administration of the Belgian Congo in 1930, just placed before the Belgian Chamber, shows that the native population numbers 9,584,936, while there are 25,179 Europeans, of whom 17,432 are Belgians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Resolutions asking President Hoover to instruct the United States delegation to the Geneva, disarmament conference to demand universal disarmament were presented to President Hoover today. They were adopted on Feb. 2, the opening day of the conference, at meetings sponsored by the Women's International Leagues in 100 cities in thirty States.

SIX hundred and seventy-two airplanes; fighters, light And heavy bombers roared over Manhattan's canyons, soared up and down the Atlantic and dispersed to their home stations without a single serious accident last Summer. Millions of persons were thrilled at Uncle Sam's fighting air fleet, in close formation.

IT is characteristic at Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler that only a few months before his seventieth birthday he should publish a book entitled "Looking Forward." His life has been an active one and laden with honors and achievements requiring more than a full column of "Who's Who" to list.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 6. -- In a typical second-half surge, the Dartmouth basketball team outscored Yale tonight, 37-24, before 2,000 spectators. Dartmouth trailed at half-time 11-8, but the combination of Jake Edwards and Ben Burch proved too much for the Elis after the first period.

Batter. Receipts, 8,925 packages. The market closed easy with prices barely sustained on all grades of butter. Supplies of fancy stock accumulated from current receipts are relaclosed easy with prices barely sustained on demand and, with Chicago showing weakness, the outlook seems uncertain for the first of the week.

SOMERVILLE, Mass., Feb. 6 (AP). -- Leslie Morrissey of Somerville, brother of the captain, of the Boston fishing schooner Eleanor Nickerson, rammed and sunk by the steamer Jean Jadot, today made public a list of those who he believed had been aboard.

FEBRUARY, 1917." is a book on the Russian revolution. Although it is a large, thick volume, it covers only the very first period, from the downfall of the old regime to the days following upon the first -- and unsuccessful -- Bolshevist rising -- against the Provisional Government.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Feb. 6 -- Penn State's wrestling team defeated Syracuse today, 20 to 6, taking six of the eight bouts.

Raising the limit on individual deposits in the Postal Savings Banks from $2,500 to $5,000 was urged by Representative Emanuel Celler in an open letter to President Hoover made public last night as the most effective way of coaxing hoarded money back into useful channels.
Our weather all week was obviously the result of a mix-up between the groundhog and St. Swithin.

BUFFALO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A fur-buying racket through which trappers and hunters in widely separated parts of Canada and the United States were swindled out of thousands of dollars was believed by police to have been broken today with the arrest in New York City of Samuel Stineburg, 35 years old, accused of being the head of the system.

Dorotny Gordon gave a program of folksongs of all nations in costume yesterday afternoon at Town Hall before a large audience including many children. With slight changes of her costume, made while she explained the origin and characteristics of each song, tne singer quickly took her audience from the British Isles on a musical tour through Europe, returning at the end of her program to a group of folksongs from various parts of this country.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Repeating "Oh, I'm not a candidate," Mrs. Dolly Curtis Gann bowed away today from a suggestion she should run for Governor of Kansas, her home State.

HONOLULU. AN invention designed to improve the life-saving equipment of the Army Air Corps in cases where pilots are forced down in water has been tested at Wheeler and Luke Fields here. Conceived by Lieutenant George G. Tourtellot, wartime aviator, the device consists of a metal container for the rubber raft carried on many aircraft flying over the sea.

Preliminary work of partitioning off a section of the Bell Telephone Laboratories Building at Bethune and Washington Streets has been completed in preparation for the unusual feat of piercing the eleven story structure with elevated double tracks as part of the New York Central Railroad's west side improvement plan.

STATISTICS of record-breaking weather are the despair of the writer on meteorology. There can never be any assurance of finality in such statements as, for example, that the place having the heaviest Known yearly rainfall in the world is so and so, or that such and such an air temperature is the highest ever registered in the United States.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Trading for the most part was quiet on the Bourse today, but because of a short period of active exchanges the session was considered exceptionally favorable for a Saturday. A rise in the Bank of France shares stimulated all bank stocks.

WHILE the radio audience is listening to Sousa's Band, to the antics of Amos 'n' Andy or to the Rise of the Goldbergs, another exciting drama is taking place in the air these days, but the listening public misses it. If only their tuners were designed to dip into the short-wave lengths they could eavesdrop on a coastwise sketch that might be listed in the program as "Radio and Rum."

Repairs and improvements to the 10,000-ton treaty cruiser. Salt Lake City, which was commissioned as the first of her type more than two years ago, are being completed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard at a cost of about $200,000. The cost of welding a cracked stern post, discovered after the ship was placed in drydock is included in the repair bill.

Although my vote was not cast for him, it seems that not sufficient credit has been awarded to President Wilson for the outstanding event in his administration that during the exceptional conditions of the World War the gold standard was maintained throughout, and apparently no suggestion was ever made to depart from it.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- Reiteration of the demand for election of a Governor for a four-year term in non-Presidential years was made today by Senator John J. Dunnigan, Democratic leader of the upper house.

A major mystery, more baffling and certainly more irritating to the academic mind than many a detective thriller, has emerged at the University of Chicago. For years it has been an axiom that the college graduate is far better prepared for later professional training than the boy who rushes into law or medical school without a preliminary degree.

A total of 2,350 dogs, representing an entry of 3,006, will occupy the benches in the exhibition hall of Madison Square Garden when the fifty-sixth annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club opens at 9 o'clock next Thursday morning.

Samuel E. Macmillen, brothefr of Francis Macmillen, the violinist, died on Friday. Mr. Macmillen, who at various times was active in newspaper work in New York and Chicago, was also prominent in the musical world of the United States, having been manager of the National Symphony Orchestra of New York and later of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra.

THIS ia the story of dramatic criticism at sea. For it so happened that this correspondent, always in search of the truth, recently put to sea while Broadway was drifting in the doldrums. Being preoccupied with urgent matters, the managing editor had agreed.

The progress in 1931 of the General, Motors Corporation's profit-sharing plans for executives and workers, despite the slump in business which reduced the company's earnings from $151,098,992 in 1930 to $96,858,701 last year, is shown in the annual report of its savings and investment plan for employes and in the income account for last year on which the bonus for executives is computed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A pledge to assist President Hoover in his efforts to restore hoarded wealth to circulation and a decision to organize for the movement every community in the nation were the results today of a conference between the President and business, industrial and civic leaders representing organizations with a membership of more than 20,000,000.

The steady decline into new low ground last week of prices of sugar, copper, zinc and other commodities and major foodstuffs was followed closely by economic observers. It was noted that two of these staples, sugar and copper, continued to sink in spite of world stabilization plans to support them.

MARIE DRESSLER is at the Capitol in her first screen appearance since she won the medal of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for the best performance by an actress last year. "Emma" is a drama of the little comedies and tragedies which fill the average American family life.
TOKYO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Russian and Japanese authorities alike ridiculed reports published abroad today that Russian troops have been concentrated at Vladivostok.

THE reader may, if he has a taste for novels with wide implications, discover in Sylvia Thompson's latest romance a kind of allegorical statement of the conflict in contemporary England between the old social order and the new.

The Citizens Union, in recommendations submitted yesterday to the Westall legislative committee investigating the administration of justice in the State, urged establishment of a State judicial council, with broad supervisory powers over the courts in the State.

The racing interests in the State are understood to be planning another attempt to obtain legalization here of pari-mutuel betting at the race tracks. The move is entirely apart from the bill presented in the legislature yearly by Assemblyman William Breitenbach of Brooklyn, on which the racing interests look with disfavor.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- Democrats of Pennsylvania, far from united in purpose as the Presidential campaign approaches, watched with mixed emotions these last few months as Joseph F. Guffey of Pittsburgh, their former national committeeman, whom may of them had not taken too seriously in late years, grasped his opportunity, leaped upon the Roosevelt band wagon and seized the driver's whip and reins to direct its progress after it crossed the State's border.

TOKYO, Feb. 6. -- The situation tonight seems more hopeful here. The greatest need is breathing space to allow the present excitement to subside and permanent factors of policy to come into play. The violence of the situation has temporarily obscured those factors, but cooler heads here know that Japan cannot afford to stir up an international hornets' nest at Shanghai.

HONOLULU, Feb. 6. -- The storm of "hostilities" has not yet broken over Oahu Island, although the zero hour for the commencement of the war game between the "Blue" attackers and "Black" defenders of Hawali passed at 5 o'clock this morning.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 6 -- T. Philip Perkins of New York, former British amateur golf champion, successfully defended his title in the national championship of club champions at St. Augustine today when he won the thirty-six-hole final for the Walter J. Travis Memorial Trophy from C. Bayard Mitchell 2d of Woodbury, N.J., 4 and 3.

AIKEN -- Activities here are taking on added interest as the resort season nears the middle of February and as daily arrivals of Winter home owners, their guests and visitors at the hotels swell the colony. Some of the most important seasonal events will soon be held, opening with the annual Aiken hunter trials some time the latter part of this month.

PARIS THE cinema world of Paris has spent most of the month of January taking stock of the accomplishments of 1931 and looking forward with mingled hope and apprchension to 1932. For the talking picture is even newer to France than to the United States, and it has been, no less revolutionary, artistically and financially.

IN all ages he who poses as laudator temporis acti is ineffective. In none does he find a smaller congregation than in 1932. The freedom of this generation from old trammels is welcomed not as a victory in a long-time struggle but as the natural birth of a new era.

More inhabitants of the United States now own shares in leading industrial, railroad and public utility corporations than at any previous time in history and are in a position to profit by the recovery of business. Instead of having discouraged the average man from owning common stocks, the depression has resulted in a wider distribution of these securities than ever before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The text of the statement issued by the Japanese Government today on the Japanese policy toward China, and the Japanese troop movements to China was received by the Japanese Embassy tonight from Tokyo, and was made public as follows:

BIRMINGHAM, Feb. 4 -- Impetus to every agricultural, industrial and commercial process they know, and more besides, is being promised Alabamians and Tennesseeans now by protagonists of the Muscle Shoals plan which President Hoover's Interstate Commission has approved.

ROME, Feb. 5 -- That ancient Rome was destroyed not by barbarians, as has been believed hitherto, but by a catastrophic earthquake is the conclusion reached by archaeologists after a careful examination of the remains of the Trajan Forum just brought to light by excavations ordered by Premier Mussolini.
ALL along the Riviera thousands of men and women are always busily engaged in making the many perfumes for which France is celebrated.

Announcement by the Pennsylvania Railroad that it would apply to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan to finance electrification of part of its system and to improve terminals caused conjecture last week whether such a purpose would be within the scope of the corporation.

Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Hewlett Cornell fave a dinner dance last night in the Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Asoria for their debutante daughter. Miss Ruth Keen Cornell, who is a student at the Sarah Lawrence College, Bronxville. The debutante, who insisted her mother in receiving, wore a gown of chartreuse green taffeta, embellished with a sash of flame-colored satin.

MATRIMONIAL bonds may now be severed in one day in Mexico, according to a law which went into effect recently in the State of Chihuahua. This speed record for the dissolution of the marriage vow carries with it the further privilege of obtaining the final decree by mail, thus setting a new signpost on the highway of easy divorce.

AWITTYand thought-provoking comedy with tragic implications, this novel tells the story of a family which, the author holds, is symbolic of England as a whole -- a family which will not realize that the old order of life has passed.

Although puzzled by the enigma of current economic conditions, large and small retailers took away from the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, held here last week, the practical lesson that in large measure the achievement of profitable operation lies in their own hands, according to a canvass of merchants' views made by a reporter for THE TIMES.

Fire of unknown, origin virtually destroyed the Eden Musee, one of Coney Island's best known attractions, along with most of its wax figures yesterday morning, leaving in the charred ruins badly battered effigies of famous or notorious characters.

Stock issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $316,188,718 in market value in January, according to the exchange's monthly report, issued yesterday. The change was the smallest for any month since last August, when the market value increased $164,000,000.

A LIVELY and graphic tale of the experiences of a British officer during the Peninsular Wars, Carola Oman's new novel has an exciting plot and an exceptionally likable hero. Major Colquhoun Grant is an intelligence officer in the army commanded by Lord Wellington, one who, in his commander's own words, is "worth a brigade."

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 6. -- That the government of Ontario understands the future of low-grade gold production and recognizes it as probably the hope of the Province in the coming years if the Province's position is to be maintained, was the message this week from Charles McCrea, Minister of Mines, to a large gathering of mining men here.

COLONEL REEVES'S book belongs in the now-it-can-be-told class -- and he has a lot to tell. As Prohibition Administrator of New Jersey during a part of 1926 and 1927 he had, evidently, a very edifying job, and he passes on to his readers the disillusioning information with which it swamped, submerged and paralyzed him and after several months made the resigning of the office the only way to preserve his self-respect.

Alfredo Gandolfi, called at the last moment to sing Scarpia in "Tosca" when the veteran Antonio Scotti could not appear at the Metropolitan last evening, met an emergency for which the younger italian baritone had waited during his four years in opera here, not only fully prepared but with at least one demonstration, made in another city, of his ability to do so.
VATICAN CITY, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Pope Pius celebrated today the tenth anniversary of his election to the throne of St. Peter.

TlHE Chevrolet Motor Company last week introduced a new line of commercial vehicles, said to be the most extensive it has ever produced. At the same time prices were reduced in some cases as much as $65 a model. The range is now $355 for the half-ton chassis to $1,020 for the one-and-a-half-ton van panel model.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 6 -- The Naval Academy gymnasium team opened its season today by defeating New York University by a score of 42 to 12, capturing five first places out of six events.

RETAIL sales improved a little last week, but continued to run substantially under the level of a year ago. Some gain was remarked in the ready-to-wear departments. On the other hand, seasonal promotions of home wares did not meet with the expected response. But it is indeed questionable whether higher mark-ups are advisable.

Great Britain has been forced to abandon her historic policy. She will shortly have a general tariff of 10 per cent on imports, with a few raw materials and foods excepted; while wheat is to be taken care of by a quota system. The decline in sterling hasn't made the exporter so happy as was expected.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Mrs. William Louis Koehnejsntertained today at Cocoanut Grove, honoring her guests, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Koehne of Chicago and Mrs. James Woody of Buffalo. Miss Eleanor Tevander, visiting Mr. and Mrs. O.N. Tevander, was also honor guest.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- The president of the council of the autonomous territory of Memel was arrested today by the Lithuanian Governor of the territory, allegedly upon orders from Kovno. A "Council of Greater Lithuania" was appointed to take over the government.

HISTORIES of art contain many omissions, but apparently there is not to be omission of the American pre-Raphaelites from the program covering our "middle years." Steps already have been taken to hunt down their scattered works and to restore them to the modest place they filled by the side of the ambitious Hudson River School, or, to speak more precisely, facing that dignified school with the obvious intention and expectation of supplanting it.

Support of the disarmament conference at Geneva and the avoidance of armed intervention by the military forces of this country in the Sino-Japanese conflict were urged yesterday by speakers and by means of banners at a peace rally under the auspices of the Socialist party at the Eternal Light monument in Madison Square Park.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Solitaire is the convalescent's boon, and I found it so during a rather prolonged recovery period; but one day laying out the cards the thought came that perhaps the procedure was rather childish, since there must be many repetitions of the same game.

Wall Street found little that was diverting in yesterday's dull trading on the Stock Exchange. Aside from a sharp break in Auburn, the price movements were narrow, limited to fractional declines in most of the active issues. Even the 10-point drop in Auburn excited little comment, since spectacular swings in this stock have come to be commonplace occurrences.

With Wall Street wishing him the best of luck and offering sympathetic cooperation, President Hoover launches an aggressive campaign to end hoarding. The financial community's reaction to the undertaking, as indicated by the fragments of opinion picked up at the close of a dull week, is that hoarding is more of a symptom than a cause of current financial ills.

MANY a mongrel has a better prize-winning temperament than the pedigree show-dog, and to take your high-prized, long-pedigreed prize canine into the show ring does not necessarily mean that he will be a winner of prizes.

WITH the annual Wagner cycle heralding Spring, the fifteenth week of opera brings also the return of Elizabeth Rethberg and George Thill in a "Faust" matinee. Other stars depart on concert tours at this season.

Debutantes of recent years and many young men thronged the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night for the second Knickerbocker Assembly of the season. Younger married couples, who have attended the assemblies in the past, had not been invited.

Japanese Goods. I am heartily in sympathy with T.H.P. Sailer's suggestion, of an individual boycott of Japanese goods. After all, few of the articles exported to this country by Japan are necessities of life. Japanese silk could be replaced by silks from other countries, or, better still, by American rayon and American cotton goods -- GEORGE RAYMOND, Paterson, N. J.
BROADCASTING is destined for an evolution that will lead it into television, according to a manufacturer who predicts speeding up in television activity within the next ninety days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Railroad employment suffered a further loss in November when there were 56,192 fewer workers than in the preceding month and their total compensation was $16,157,859 under that of October.

Today. 11:30 A.M. -- Noted music ensembles of America and Europe will be heard in the Library of Congress Musicale series to be inaugurated over the WJZ network today. The Musical Art String Quartet will be the group heard in the opening concert.

IT is a strange and significant fact that Abraham Lincoln is the only American President whose personal appearance has been a cause of controversy. Friends and enemies alike have generally been content to accept the looks of other Presidents as God made them.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 4 -- A pre-convention controversy has developed in Minnesota which is interesting as it reflects the judgement of some competent observers on the political position of President Hoover throughout the Northwest. A movement has arisen to send an uninstructed delegation to the Republican convention at Chicago.

Foreign loans held their ground much better than did domestic corporation issues on the Stock Exchange yesterday in the dullest trading of any Saturday this year. In the home issues, railroad bonds especially were under pressure, with a sizable list losing 1 to 4 points.

The first exhibition of Robert Lawson, a young American etcher, is on at the Kleeman-Thorman Gallery, Madison Avenue near Fifty-seventh Street, to close on Feb. 29. This artist is not afraid to be literary. Leprechauns, cluricauns, mermen, merrows and kirkegrims people his fantastic plates.

LONDON. THE past, present and future of the novel appear to be subjects on which our literary critics never tire of expatiating. J.B. Priestley has been predicting that in 1932 we shall see more of the strong sense of character and the mingling of humorous and romantic elements which have been the splendid tradition of the English novel.

Disclosing an increase of 758,193 shares in the short account in January, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the total on Feb. 1 was 3,600,265 shares, compared with 2,842,072 shares a month before. Detailed figures showing the short interest in individual issues were not given out, as they were in December.

A hitch-hiking trip from the Bronx to Roosevelt Field, L. I., with a mild foraging raid in Forest Hills and a dive into Flushing Creek as unexpected interludes, brought two 13-year-old boys to the Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica last night suffering from submersion and exposure.

OMAHA, Feb. 4 -- If there ever was any disposition in the corn belt to accept the doctrine that an agricultural surplus constituted an economic misdemeanor the results of the last harvest have given it a setback. With farm animals starving in one section for want of the feed with which granaries in another section are filled because there is no market, the farmer is inclined to laugh bitterly every time Secretary Hyde mentions overproduction.

INTERNATIONALISM is apparently to be the keynote of next Summer's dance activities in Europe, with the two largest events scheduled for Paris and for Buxton, England. Germany is not to occupy such a conspicuous place in the field of assemblages and conferences as in the recent past, presumably for financial reasons; and the fourth of the biennial German congresses, which was to take place this Summer, has not been undertaken.

There is a very apparent reaction on the part of retailers against the low price levels which now pervade the wholesale markets, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. "Many buyers," the report says, "are coming in with instructions not to purchase at the new low levels which are being created at the expense of quality.

NOW that its "Grand Hotel" company is well into the task of translating Vicki Baum's play to the screen, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is preparing to do "Strange Interlude." The leads have already been assigned to Norma Shearer and Clark Gable, but further than that the production is still in the tentative stage.

A difference of opinion was reported yesterday to have arisen between Governor Roosevelt and Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, on legal aspects of the charges against Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, Tammany district leader.
CHARLES LUTWIDGE DODGSON had abundance of leisure; he had few duties involving peremptory claims upon his time. I do not suppose he was ever idle; but I doubt whether he read many books.
An eighteen - family apartment house at 417 Teaneck Road, Ridgefield Park, was sold by De Witt, Smith Batsle, Inc., to the United States Agency, subject to a $65,000 first mortgage.

Senate bill No. 1 was signed by Governor ROOSEVELT last week with more than the usual ceremony. Introduced by Senator HEWITT, it gives force to the constitutional amendment bearing his name, adopted by an overwhelming vote last Fall, committing the State to a broad program of reforestation.

Presiding Justice Edward Finch of the Appellate Division, speaking yesterday afternoon at a non-partisan forum in the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue, advocated changes in legal practice and procedure in the courts to meet changing social requirements.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The ancient Greeks told the story of the giant who could not be defeated because, when thrown to the ground, he regained all his strength from the contact with mother earth and returned to the fight with fresh vigor. There is a resemblance with this son of nature in Ramsay MacDonald.

AFTER a period of quiescence, Arthur Hopkins has once more turned his attention to play production. He is starting work on a piece by David Boehm, co-author with Murdock Pemberton of "Sing High, Sing Low," a piece which, at present, bears the curious title of "Love Life of the Tiffy."

A DELIBERATELY realistic style which falls to make the book convincing is the chief characteristic of Mr. Stringer's new novel. One need only recount the plot of "The Mud Lark" to reveal the heavy odds against the author and the necessity for careful handling of material.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6. -- Columbia, Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball champions for the last two years, swung back into league competition tonight and easily defeated Penn at the Palestra, 39 to 23.

THE quite remarkable response to the recent review of the Parlophone "Two Thousand Years of Music," including very specific requests for further information as to sets or particular records along the same line, seems to indicate that a note on the subject of "The Columbia History of Music" would not be amiss.

Facilities for community functions as well as new ideas in educational equipment have been incorporated in the plans for the new Washington Junior High School plant at Mount Vernon, N. Y., which when completed will represent an investment of about $1,200,000 exclusive of land value, according to a description of the project by the architects yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the general heading of "They Say" in Sunday's issue, THE TIMES prints an extract from an address by William D. Guthrie at a meeting of State presidents of federations of the bar, in which the speaker referred to the fact that there is no constitutional prohibition against the appointment of laymen to the Supreme Court of the United States.

Forty-four members of the New York Stock Exchange still hold rights to one-fourth of an additional membership, which have not been exercised, according to an announcement issued yesterday by the Exchange. Under a resolution adopted by the members last Autumn, the disposal of these rights will be in the hands of a special committee during the next year.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- Governor Roosevelt and four other members of the executive committee of the Governors' Conference gathered today at the Executive Mansion to prepare an agenda for the annual meeting of the State Executives in Richmond, Va. on April 25.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 7. -- After a comparatively quiet evening, heavy Japanese field guns in the Hongkew area opened up a violent bombardment just before midnight, augmenting the briskest machine-gun fire that has been heard in the last twenty-four hours.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Trading in Twheat today on the Board of Trade here was mainly in evening up by operators who feared untoward developments over the week-end, although nothing in the news suggested this other than that a new cold wave may appear.

FREQUENT rehearsals are being held for the elaborate pageant, "Honor to Washington," which will be given on the night of Feb. 24 in the Town Hall. These rehearsals have grown out of a series of meetings held at the Colony Club and in the homes of several individuals interested in the production, which is the fifth in a series to aid the endowment fund of the Town Hall.

HOW safe is air transport? That question can be answered by comparisons of one sort or another which are frequently deceiving. When it was put to Anthony H.G. Fokker after a lecture one night he answered:

GOOD TIMES" is the obvious product of a will to write a cheerful but timely story which while admitting the existence of the depression, shows just what gay things can happen in the lives of the unemployed. It is the chronicle of the adventures of four young New Yorkers who are without jobs and who decide, perhaps a little tardily, to take Horace Greeley's advice.

At the second concert of the week in New York by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, its conductor, Mr. Koussevitzky, had arranged a program which consisted in the repetition of George Gershwin's "Second Rhapsody," played for the first time Friday evening; a suite by Corelli, Nikolai Tcherepnin's "Eight Miniatures" (after a Russian illustrated alphabet), and, for the final performance, Tchaikovsky's "Symphonic Pathetique."

Predictions made twelve months ago of a construction year in the United States in 1931 equal to that of 1930 failed to materialize, in spite of a heavy increase in public works and rapidly decreasing building costs, according to a survey just completed by The Engineering News Record.

VERY little worth while is being written for the violin any more. People haven't any feeling any more for this instrument, for its charm, its loveliness, its intonation, its wealth of possibilities in variegation. Beethoven wrote things held impossible of execution by his contemporaries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- In memory of Stephen Tyng Mather, founder and former director of the National Park Service, who died two years ago, the first of the bronze plaques designed by Bryant Baker of New York for The Stephen T. Mather Appreciation, of which John Hays Hammond is chairman, will be unveiled in Mount Rainier National Park on July 4, Mr. Mather's sixty-fifth birthday anniversary.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Feb. 6. -- A new physics laboratory was opened informally here this afternoon and was inspected by members of the annual graduate council of the alumnae association which is holding a week-end session here, and by the faculty.

Criticism of the five-cent subway fare as "a purely political issue" and a demand that early unification of all rapid transit lines be effected on a self-sustaining fare basis were expressed by Louis B. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, at the thirty-sixth annual dinner of that organization held last night at the Hotel Commodore.

HISPANIC SOCIETY OF AMERICA -- An exhibition of paintings by Cesareo Bernaldo de Quiros of Argentina, Twenty-five canvases, several of them very large, in which, a catalogue observes, this artist "has done for the gaucho of half a century ago, about to disappear, what Gauguin succeeded in doing for the Maoris and what Paul Elie Dubois did for the Tauregs of Hoggar."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Little hope can be held for world peace under present international conditions, Senator Shipstead, Farmer-Laborite, of Minnesota, said tonight in a radio speech dealing principally with the Sino-Japanese dispute. He spoke over the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 4 -- A special human-relief session of the Ohio Legislature such as New York, Pennsylvania and other States have had seems certain now, with all the large cities of the State resorting to temporizing and quasi-desperate methods of carrying their unemployed through this Winter.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 6 -- In commemoration of the 200th anniversary of the birth of George Washington, the program of the annual alumni week-end at Princeton University, which would be held here on Feb. 20, 21 and 22, would be dedicated to the Revolutionary leader.

HAVANA, Feb. 6. -- Cuba's 1932 sugar crop will be restricted to 3,061,000 tons, according to a decision by the Cuban Sugar Stabilization Institute, which tonight so advised President Beaudouin of the International Sugar Council in Brussels.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Harry R. Lydecker, 62 years old, of 102 Pershing Avenue, an attorney who for twenty-six years was calender clerk of the Appellate Division, Second Department of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, was found dead of illuminating gas poisoning this afternoon in the kitchen of his home.

EXPERIENCE reveals that it is a difficult thing to sit down and create a radio sketch with paper and pencil. The Rise of the Goldbergs, Amos 'n' Andy, Gene and Glenn and othsrs in the popular ranks have grown naturally and often over a period of months or years before gaining recognition.

WHEN Grandpa took Grandma out buggy riding on the Sunday afternoons of long, long ago, they would amble along the familiar country roads. And when they would reach the old red depot at the crossing, Grandpa would pull out his watch, and apply the reins to Dobbin.

Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Yonkers reaped the reward of the most consistently fine tennis he has played in many seasons by carrying off the metropolitan indoor championship yesterday at the 106th Regiment Armory, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- An upward tendency in British trade in January is virtually the only sign of improved business conditions abroad in recent weeks, according to the weekly survey of foreign commercial activity made public by the Department of Commerce.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Augusta Bernard makes a new outline attractive by joining the skirt to the bodice at a high level and marking a low natural waist with wide crossed belts of the fabric attached in different ways.

THE life of a foreigner in a treaty port of China is normally an approach to paradise -- particularly for the women of the foreign communities. Plenty of servants -- boys, cooks, amahs, a fish coolie to look after the gold fish, a dog coolie to air the Airedale, a servant for almost every whim and mood.

BOOKS about toys should be written as children play, in a spirit of thorough enjoyment and genuine interest. It is safe to say that all children at some stage love toys, but few adults can retain or recapture the joy that toys, simple or elaborate, once brought them.

MITCHEL FIELD, L. I., Feb. 6. -- As soon as orders are received from the War Department in Washington, probably within the next week, the Ninety-ninth Squadron, the first of three squadrons consisting of fifty-four airplanes representing part of the Ninth Observation Group of the Army Air Corps, will leave here for Chapman Field in Miami, Fla., where they will have one month's gunnery practice, it was made known here today.

New York University's basketball team set a whirlwind pace as the game was drawing to its close and upset St. John's College, 29 to 24, at the 102d Engineers Armory last night. Field goals by Joe Hugret, Violet star, at critical moments were decisive factors in the N.Y.U. victory.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Today's short session of the Stock Exchange was one of the least active since the resumption of Saturday trading, with few price changes and the tone inclined to dullness. In foreign exchange the New York rate dropped slightly to $3.451/4 and leading Continental rates followed suit.
SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 7 -- The riddled Chapei sector of Shanghai, once the home of 200,000 persons, was a city of the dead today.
NORRISTOWN, Pa., Feb. 6 -- Edward H.B. Alien, steeplechase rider and prominent in society, was acquitted tonight of the murder of Francis A. Donaldson 3d, his sister's suitor.

Pacifists should heed the advice of George Washington that the United States must maintain an adequate army if it is not to lose, through a world-wide reputation for weakness, the rank which is its due, said Brig. Gen. Lucius R. Holbrook yesterday at a reception of the Long Island Historical Society, Pierrepont and Clinton Streets, Brooklyn.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 6 -- Marceline Torti, 12 years old, was killed instantly tonight when she was struck by the Long Island Railroad's Cannonball Flier at the Post Avenue crossing here. Her body was carried 100 yards on the locomotive's cowcatcher before the engineer, Frank Smith of Greenport, could bring the train to a stop.

In his book about the Germans George N. Shuster rises to the level of Andre Siegfried at his best and leaves the reader wondering whether his claim is not strong enough to make him a contender for the honors of a master of nation portrayal. Mr. Shuster is consistently informative without ever striking a professorial pose, delightful without pandering to popular taste, and profound without lapsing into spells of obscurity.

New announcements made last week of bonds called for redemption in February before their maturity date consisted of several small lots of municipal issugs and parts of issues of two industrial corporations. The total for the month is now $36,041,000, compared with $70,336,000 in January and $54,129,000 in February, 1931, at corresponding dates.

PALM BEACH -- Golf enthusiasts will divide their interest this week between three events of major importance. The fifth annual artists and writers' tournament will be played at the Palm Beach Golf Club and the South Florida championship will be held on the Royal Poinciana links, both beginning tomorrow and closing on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Warning to coal operators that they must either obtain legislation to permit organization of regional sales agencies such as they plan or face litigation to test their legality was given today by the Department of Justice.

PREVIOUS articles in these columns have shown motorist from the Eastern States how to reach Southern California in midwinter over good roads and with maximum comfort. Now it remains to call attention to what may be seen when one gets there.
THE greatest picture in the world today -- and we can't get it." So was Samuel L. Rothafel, Roxy, quoted by Russian newspaper men during his visit to Moscow.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 6 -- Butler University alumni, faculty members and students, with friends and representatives from more than 150 other educational institutions, took part today in the inauguration of Dr. Walter Scott Athearn, formerly of Boston University, as president of Butler.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- The one man who has more influence on the political situation in Massachusetts than any other person is not a citizen of the State. His name is Alfred Emanuel Smith. His intentions are the unsolved enigma which all the forecasters and harmonizers and adjusters are trying to read.
BOSTON, Feb. 6 -- The favored Exeter hockey team turned back the Andover sextet, 2 to 1, in the seventeenth annual game today before 2,000 spectators in the Arena.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 6. -- President Ortiz Rubio and Senora Ortiz Rubio received a courtesy visit tonight from Mr. and Mrs. Newton D. Baker at the executive residence, Chapultepec Castle.

IT seems highly probable that not many today read the poetry of Robert Browning. That Victorian's works are, of course, treated in college courses, sometimes at considerable length and with studious care. But it may be questioned whether many of those who read Browning in college turn to him in later years, and it is open to question whether many laymen turn to that poet of their own accord.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Admiral William V. Pratt, Chief of Naval Operations, told the House Expenditures Committee today that Japan has the most efficient war machine the world has ever seen.

PICTURESQUE and prominent as were most of the personages whom the King of England honored on New Year's Day with orders and ribands and titles, none was more colorful than Salote Tubou, native Qneen of the seldom-visited Tonga or Friendly Islands.

Of Service to Motorists. IN the regrets expressed here last Sunday concerning the closing of the historic and, until recently, robust Automobile Club of America, it was explained that because of economic conditions the club had lost members until its expenses far exceeded its income.

SINCE the opening performance of the Soviet dialogue film, "Road to Life," which is concerned with the redemption of the besprizorni, or the wild waifs of Moscow and other cities, unprecedented throngs have jammed the little Cameo.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Another discordant note was sounded in the Olympic Stadium today and the apparently amicable settlement of the 10,000-meter speed skating controversy at the international meeting last night nearly went for naught.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 6 -- A strong Navy wrestling team defeated Princeton today, 25 to 3. Captain Don Hooker scored the only Princeton points when he gained a time advantage over Coleman after the latter almost had thrown the Tiger leader.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The House Rules Committee today set the stage for consideration Friday of the Rutherford "lame duck" resolution for amending the Constitution to change the dates of the inauguration of the President and the meeting of Congress.

LONDON. A Geneva the representatives of sixty nations have assembled for the conference on disarmament. They have not come gladly, because their minds are full of the economic problems of the world crisis, and they really have had little time to prepare for the reduction of armaments.

Japanese bonds, which were by far the most active group in the foreign loans traded on the Stock Exchange last week, made new low marks for the year on Monday or Tuesday in all issues, some of them reaching the lowest levels touched since they were issued.

DENVER. If a troubled arena in which Governors and Federal mediators have sought in vain to bring about good-will between employer and employe a young woman has achieved notable success -- by winning the zealous cooperation of the workers in meeting the competition of rival companies.
EXETER, N. H., Feb. 6. -- Placing first in seven of the nine events, the Huntington School track team defeated Exeter today, 50 to 27. Three Exeter indoor records were broken.

WEST POINT, N.T., Feb. 6 -- Army boxers won from the University of New Hampshire today by a score of 5 1/2 to 1 1/2. Two Cadet victories were scored on technical knockouts, Cleveland excelling MeCaughney in the 125-pound bout, while Hagan stopped Brooks in the 145-pound event.

YOUNG women of society will take part in a performance of "Romeo and Juliet," which will be given under the auspices of the Junior Branch of the New York Women's League for Animals on the night of Feb. 27 at the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street for the benefit of the league.

ONE looks in vain in the advertising pages of the literary publications for any mention of the country's largest publisher, though his activities, are frequently referred to in newspapers and in periodicals devoted to general information.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A group of 117 men, women and children, arrested by Japanese blue-jackets in their drive on Chinese snipers, were turned over to the International Settlement authorities today, many of them marked with wounds, presumably from bayonets.

The Hoover Medical Group, an organization of doctors, has leased for a term of years the five-story dwelling at 315 West Seventy-fourth Street which was occupied for many years by the Beardsley family. The lessees already have taken over the building, which has been remodeled into doctors' offices.

KURT WEILL'S new opera, "Die Burgschaft" ("The Pledge"), which the Stadtische Oper has taken upon itself to produce in March, is casting its shadows before. The score has already been published by the Universal Edition. The book this time is not by Weill's old associate, Bert Brecht, but by Caspar Neher, who paints modernistic scenery and who made the settings for the Weill-Brecht "Mahagonny" in Berlin and elsewhere.
The swimming team of Johns Hopkins University defeated the Manhattan College tankmen, 30 -- 29, in an exciting meet at the Manhattan pool yesterday.
CAPE TOWN. BOY!" One bears the call echoing through a hundred camps and trading shacks, water-front bungalows and outposts -- the real call of Africa.
A SECOND Daniel come to judgment!"

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 6 -- Holding to its pace of the opening day, Dartmouth's Winter sports team captured the championship in the twenty-second annual Winter carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A stiff warning was given to members of Congress today that they are overworking, and must take better care of their health.

CAIRO, Feb. 5 -- That the arts of painting and sculpture were highly developed in ancient Egypt is shown by the most recent discoveries at Tel El Amarna. A caricature of the King with a scrubby beard, before he had been shaved was among the sculptors' trial pieces found.

DETROIT. THE Chicago automobile show, just closed, has left motor company executives more than ever convinced that 1932 is destined to be a year of recovery -- unless the situation is changed by the imposition of a special excise tax on motor vehicles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report of recommendations of some members of Congress advocating the acquisition of the British West Indies and the French possessions in the Caribbean in part payment of the money due the United States resulting from certain credits set aside for co-belligerents under an act of Congress, August, 1917, should not distress the British and French or cause embarrassment to Americans.

GOOD as Storm Jameson's work has been up to this point, her latest novel, "That Was Yesterday," is far and away the best book she has yet written. Her memorable trilogy -- never published under a single title -- which dealt with the career of Mary Hervey and covered eighty years of the changing national life of England, was a rich and thoughtful work.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 6 -- Winning five of the eight first places in swimming and holding a decided edge in water polo, the Naval Academy natators registered a double victory over Rutgers College this afternoon, in an Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet, winning the swimming 49 to 22, and the water polo 70 to 33.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Attorney General Mitchell said today that the government was without reliable figures on the cost of prohibition enforcement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of local election results in Germany during the last year it is rather surprising to note that the vast majority of the German, workers is not favoring the Communists and the National Socialists. According to figures recently published by the leading German workers' union, fewer than 4 per cent of the workers are "radicals."
NANKING, Feb. 6 (AP) -- While Nanking was expecting an attack by the Japanese today, eighty-six Americans were evacuated, making a total of 109 of the 180 American residents who have left the city.
NEW YORK. Lady Harrington, accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. James T. McMillan, sailed on the Virginia yesterday for California.

IN conjunction with the annual drive in the interests of its Baby Shelter, the Junior League is engaged also in several other under-takings, which are enlisting many of its younger members. One of these functions is the annual concert toy the league's glee club, now in its tenth year of existence.

The Hebrew Orphan Asylum of 1,560 Amsterdam Avenue receives $5,000 and five other Jewish institutions $1,000 each in the will of William I. Spiegelberg, retired commission merchant and secretary of Temple Emmanu-El and vice president of the congregation, who died in Paris on Jan. 18, it was revealed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in the Surrogate's Court.

GENEVA, Feb. 6 -- Plans for a possible blockade action should Japan defy the great powers in the present efforts to settle the Far Eastern conflict peacefully have been considered in detail, particularly in London, it is understood here. Apparently no decision has been taken and the great powers are manifestly extremely reluctant to resort to any of the measures thus far suggested.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 -- Without money to meet its payrolls Feb. 15, Detroit faced the necessity today of making a final drastic slash in its expenses if it is to avoid insolvency.
WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 6 -- Worcester Academy rushed to the front in the closing minutes of a hard-fought basketball game with Andover today to win, 40 to 33.

BERLIN, Jan. 25, 1932. IN 1857 a certain Albert Emil Brachvogel wrote a gigantic piece of sentimental fiction about Wilhelm Friedemann Bach, the favorite son of All-Father Johann Sebastian, a wayward genius but also a notorious and dissolute scrapegrace, whose negligence the world has to thank for the loss of a heart-breaking number of Bach manuscripts.

THE Senate Finance Committee has been investigating the sale of foreign securities in this country. This inquiry seems to have been prompted by the belief that the "international bankers" have misdirected the savings of the American people into speculative investments abroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- Hermann Herzog, landscape painter, who celebrated his 100th birthday on Nov. 16, died at his home in West Philadelphia today. Although he had not been strong enough in recent years to carry his easel to his landscape subjects, his memory was so retentive that he painted from memory many scenes of Holland and France seen long ago.

SINCE there are a number of angles in this business, most of them dissecting each other at the first opportunity, some general meeting place must be found for all of them, and by common consent this would be that little wicket-covered centre of the Broadway universe, the theatre box-office.

Stringent bank credit is threatening the survival of some of the real creators in the women's apparel field, according to reports in the trade here. While possessing recognized ability as style creators, a number of producers, not being able to furnish the kind of balance sheet and demonstrated earnings required by the banks, are finding it very hard to obtain funds to make their piece goods purchases and cover other needs.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 6. -- Adoption of bimetalism as a means of taking "from the international bankers control of the value and volume of money" was urged today by John A. Simpson, president of the National Farmers' Union, in testifying before the Senate Finance Committee in favor of Senator Wheeler's bill to establish a double system of currency.

The indications point to an expense ratio of about 35 per cent in the annual Harvard report on department store operations for 1931, according to Professor Malcolm P. McNair, director of the bureau of business research of the Harvard Business School.

A consideration of patient psychology is more important than climatic conditions in the treatment of tuberculosis today, declared Dr. Berthold S. Pollak, speaking at the opening session of the seventh annual convention of the Deborah Consumptive Relief Society held last night at the Hotel Astor.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6 -- Tennis rankings as chosen by the selection committee were confirmed today at the annual convention of the United States Lawn Tennis Association after representatives of the Eastern Association had been defeated in their attempt to have Frank Shields placed below John Van Ryn and John Doeg.

The annual ball of the First Reserve Aero Squadron Association, Inc., was held last night at the Ambassador for the benefit of the Dug Out, an institution for disabled exservice men. It was preceded by a dinner at the hotel in honor of General Benjamin D. Foulois, chief of the United States Army Air Corps, who came by plane from Washington for the event.

VIENNA, Feb. 4. -- The chief argument which will be urged at Geneva, in favor of disarmament of the great powers will be the fact that armaments are a provocation to war and that their decrease will help preserve peace.

Schools entered in the National Oratorical Contest on the Constitution here increased to 352 last week, setting a new record for the local region. These 352 schools are thirteen more than have ever been recorded from New York City, Long Island, Westchester and Northern New Jersey in any of the seven years during which THE NEW YORK TIMES has acted as the local sponsor.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 6. -- With less than a fortnight remaining in which candidacies for delegates may be declared, the New Hampshire Democracy is in a growing turmoil over the alignment of those pledged to Presidential nominees.

NEIL BELL, or, under his real name, Stephen Southwold, is an old hand at tales for children. Now in his forties, he has settled down to the serious business of writing novels for grown-ups. He has changed his name, but not his habit of venturing into the land of make-believe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: News has just reached New York of the recent death in London of Poldowski, the composer -- Irene Dean Paul in private life. She was the daughter of Henri Wieniawski, the celebrated Polish violinist, born a posthumous child in Brussels several months after her father's illness and sudden death in St. Petersburg.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Putting into effect a policy of naval reinforcement, the Navy Department has ordered the armored cruiser Rochester from Central American waters to Manila to serve in the Asiatic Fleet under Admiral Taylor, commanding American naval forces in the Far East.

The hope of improving public taste in this country lies in the education of children and of the sales forces of stores, William Sloane Coffin, President of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, asserted yesterday in an address at a luncheon of the Municipal Art Society of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 6. -- Army defeated Colgate at basketball today, 30 to 20. The game was hard fought, Colgate getting a late start but coming back strongly toward the end.

Perplexing as the curved space and finite universe of relativity may be, they are at least logical developments of four-dimensional geometry. Grant the premises and the conclusions are inevitable to a mathematician. Not so with the atom. There is nothing: deterministic about it, nothing logical about the willful leapings of its electrons.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. (AP) -- Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., closed his schedule in the world's three-cushion billiard tournament tonight by defeating Augie Kieckhefer of Chicago, 50 to 38, in forty-nine innings. The defeat left Kieckhefer tied for first place with Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia.

IT is with a mingled feeling of enrichment and regret that one closes this little book of collected articles on the appreciation of art by the former editor of The International Studio. We are enriched by the white light it sheds on art and by the emotional experience we have lived through its pages, the while we regret the untimely and tragic death by drowning in 1928 of its brilliant young author.

THE present increasing popularity of Verdi, as remarked by Francis Toye in "Gluseppe Verdi: His Life and His "Works," is due in part to "reaction against Wagner, reaction against mere complexity." This Verdi boom, of which the recent production of "Simone Boccanegra" at the Metropolitan and the revival two seasons age at the same theatre of "Luisa Miller" were symptoms, has been particularly striking in Germany.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- The Illinois Manufacturers' Association, comprising 3,000 concerns with 700,000 employes, and having an annual industrial output of $5,000,000,000, today telegraphed to President Hoover a pledge of its support of the national movement to restore $1,300,000,000 hoarded currency to circulation.

WASHINGTON. A SMALL portable "airport traffic control projector" which can be carried around under the arm, and through which airplanes may be warned to come in for landings or remain in the air until further orders are received, has been perfected and publicly tested by the aeronautics branch of the Department of Commerce.

WITH the approach of LentAsh Wednesday falling on Feb. 10 -- members of society are turning their attention to philanthropic endeavors, chief among these being the Lenten sewing classes, always a feature of the penitential period.

EXPERT skaters from nine countries, winners in the Olympic Games and of the World Championships of 1932, will take part in an International Skating Carnival which will be held on the night of Feb. 24 at the Madison Square Garden, to augment the funds of the convalescent relief division of Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau.

Tributes will be paid to the memory of Abraham Lincoln in some of the churches of the city today. In others sermons will be preached on the meaning of Lent, heralding the approach of Ash Wednesday, which falls on Feb. 10. Five Bishops will preach.

The Japanese Navy Inspector's Office in New York was notified yesterday afternoon by the Naval Attache to the Japanese Embassy in Washington that it had received the following official message from the Department of Navy of Japan.

OTTAWA, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Earl of Bessborough, Governor General of Canada, this afternoon unveiled a marble group in the Hall of Fame in the Parliament Building, placed there through the contributions of Canadian residents in the United States.

WITH the local exhibition season now at its height (more than thirty new shows opened on the first two Bays of the week, followed by others) gallery visitors who like to be thorough are sure to find their time fully occupied.

CONCHITA SUPERVIA, Spanish colorature mezzo-soprano, who made her debut in Chicago with the Civic Opera Company in the role of Carmen, appeared in the same part in Boston last Tuesday night on her visit with the company in that city.

CLOSELY following Count Sforza's "European Dictatorships," "The Terror in Europe," while dealing with the same theme of postwar autocracies and having, necessarily, many points in common with its predecessor, is a valuable further contribution to the literature of recent political evolution.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Daniel Rice Weller, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company of Louisiana and a former director of the Standard Oil Company of NewJersey, committed suicide this morning by firing a bullet through his brain when in the home of his brother.

The fastest, greatest mile race ever run in American athletic history was clicked off last night in Madison Square Garden by Gene Venzke, rangy local lad, at the Millrose A. A.'s twenty-fifth annual indoor athletic meet.

Five gunners tied for the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterlay. They were D.L. Taylor, J.H. Wantling, T.H. Lewis, S.B. Masten ind Z.G. Simmons Jr. Each carded 95.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 6 -- Sailing about Manhasset Bay until darkness closed down on them, the Long Island skippers of the Frostbite Tacht Club held a canvased dinghy competition all their own today. The Westehester sailors were not on hand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The comprehensive program for disarmament, laid before the general disarmament conference at Geneva today by Viscount Cecil of Chelwood as president of the International Federation of League of Nations Societies, aroused interest here today, but there was no official comment, pending a report from the American delegation.

EARLY this January the Paris Opera mounted the new lyric drama of Franz Werfel and Darius Milhaud, "Maximilian." The libretto was adapted by MM. Hoffmann and Lunel from the Franz Werfel drama, "Juarez and Maximilian," which has been played here recently by the Theatre Guild.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 -- A rather unprecedented situation in Sino-Japanese war risks cropped up here today with the sailing of several vessels from this coast for Shanghai. While vessels in or near the war zone have been covered by the 2 per cent war risk, virtually every vessel being loaded on this coast to sail for Shanghai will go out without any war insurance.

A STOUT-HEARTED FOX. COULD he have gazed into some prophetic crystal forty years ago, would Premier Inukal of Japan have sought so stead-fastly the official post he now holds? Upon his government rest the most momentous decisions which have confronted modern Japan -- decisions not only of critical importance to his own country but of interest wherever bugles and bo'suns' pipes are blown.

Brooklyn Prop. La Salls Military. Academy and St. John's High triumphed in the final three games of the fourth annual Catholic High Schools' Athlstic Association hockey tournament at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

LOUIS BROMFIELD'S forthcoming novel, "A Modern Hero," which Frederick A. Stokes Company has announced for publication on April 28, is the first of his novels in which a man is the central figure. It is the story of the rise and fall of a financial adventurer who begins life in a circus and makes a great fortune.
The Bronx Tigers improved their standing in the Canadian-American Hockey League last night, defeating the New Haven Eagles at the New York Coliseum, 1 -- 0.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Feb. 6 -- A design for an Edison memorial museum and eternal light at Menlo Park has been approved by the Edison Parkway Commission of Perth Amboy and will be presented by its chairman, Joseph F. Deegan, to the Edison Pioneers at their annual dinner on Thursday in the Hotel Astor, New York.

For American higher education the most important single development in college athletics during the past six months is the further fall in football gate receipts and profits therefrom. Next to this development, and perhaps somewhat related to it, stands the growing appreciation of the principle that the control of college sport is a part of the function of college or university officers in fact as well as in theory.

THE financial situation of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra is precarious again. To quote The Pacific Coast Musician, "the orchestra is standing on a mountain of deficit and wildly waving its hands for financial rescue.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 3. -- No sooner had James R. Beverley delivered his inaugural address as Governor than he faced the writing of hiS first message to the Legislature which opens on Monday. Presumably his inaugural gave the key to his legislative message.

The long-awaited statement from former Governor Alfred E. Smith as to whether or not he will again be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency will be released to the press of the nation for publication in the newspapers tomorrow morning.

PARIS, Feb. 5. -- The outstanding social event of the Paris pre-Lenten season was the big charity ball for the Petits Lits Blancs [little white beds], which was given at the Opera Wednesday night. The annual affair is always brilliant and this year was no exception despite the depression.
