WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Three bills carrying more than $110,000,000 for aid to the farmers were approved today by the Senate Agriculture Committee and meanwhile the Senate prepared to resume its battle over legislation to help the unemployed.

The popular conception of an artist is that he is not a financial wizard turning one dollar into two by his magic touch. In the last three years, however, while thousands of bankers and business men have guessed wrong, a group of artists of the National Academy of Design has succeeded in developing a $250,000 trust fund into nearly $400,000.

THE story of Mrs. Juliet Barrett Rublee and her motion picture, "The Soul of Mexico," is the story of a great enthusiasm. Like Stuart Chase, she found herself wanting to take the world by the buttonhole and describe the beauty and wonder that she had discovered in the land below the Rio Grande.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Miss Marian Bennett of New Britain and Engene V. Homans of Englewood, N.J., nationally known golfers, were married here this afternoon in the presence of 500 guests in the First Church of Christ.

PARIS. AT the age of 60 Andre Giae remains one of our youngest writers. Several years ago he surprised-even his most fervent admirers by revivifying the French novel with his imperfect, yet remarkable "The Counterfeiters."

GENEVA, Feb. 5. -- If the Genevese who are a solid, industrious people little given to speculative introspection, think about it at all, they must have reached the conclusion that there is a special providence caring for their city. For, in a period of unprecedented depression throughout the Winter resorts of Europe, Geneva, which never before was a particular Mecca for foreign visitors in February, is booming.

IN SPITE of rapid strides on the part of air transport and the general improvement of performance figures in both commercial and military aircraft, the engine, regarded as the pulse of the aeronautical industry, continues to beat the pace for advancement.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 6. -- The question of the Nassau County Republican leadership is resolving itsel into a situation presaging a primary fight this Fall, political observers declared here today, with the elected leader asserting the leadership and the acknowledged leader declining it.

The senior class at Manhattan College, which made public yesterday its composite attitude toward persons and things, found in former Governor Alfred E. Smith "the greatest living American" and the favorite Presidential candidate. As the most representative American, however, the class chose Charles G. Dawes, while Pope Pius XI was designated the greatest living man.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Postal receipts at fifty offices in the United States in January were $3,860,085 less than in the same month last year, the total being $25,312,009.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Five of the six games in the sixth round of the international chess tournament in progress at Central Hall, Westminster, were, decided today. Four of the matches were, drawn, Sultan Khan of India being the only winner, defeating Winter of England.

AS Stuart Walker sees it, the legitimate theatre to which he belonged actively for twenty-one years is in a parlous state, or even in a dilemma, if you choose to call it that, and Mr. Walker does. Though you can scarcely see Times Square these days for the experts who throng through it, willing and oven delighted to stop you and say.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES article reviewing a volume of essays entitled "These Three," by Gabriel Wells, cites an anecdote concerning Mrs. Henry Ford's failure to possess herself of a first folio edition of Shakespeare because of her husband's off-hand remark that "he had never got anything out of Shakespeare."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Jan. 30 were less than during the previous week and the corresponding week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- There has been much plain speaking and facing of facts at the Communist party conference this week, but also some discreet evasion. Thus M. Ordjonikidse declared that copper production totaled 12,000 tons in 1925 and 48,000 tons in 1931, but omitted to state it was 47,000 tons in 1930 or that last year's program called for 100,000 tons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your very creditable article in today's TIMES there appears a quotation from Mr. Cecil Gray's monograph in which he says that Sibelius "is predominantly, even overwhelmingly, Swedish, not Finnish."

IN a letter to his publishers Branch Cabell (lately James Branch Cabell) informed them that though "These Restless Heads" would probably have to be described as a book of essays, it really should be described as "a frame of mind."

THE suggestion that Frederick Stock, conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, may be induced to come East to take command of an orchestra in this part of the country was voiced by Edward, Moore of The Chicago Tribune, last Sunday. To quote Mr. Moore:

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Two track records were lowered at Hialeah Park today, one in the $2,500 added feature Hialeah Park Handicap when Mrs. John Hay Whitney's Lightning Bolt won by a length and a half. He was timed in 1:50 3-5 for the mile and an eighth, lowering by two-fifths of a second the mark set by Impish last week.

PARIS, Feb. 5. -- It is curious to note in these momentous days of tension and stress over the events at Shanghai and the disarmament conference at Geneva with what calmness, bordering on complacency, France is taking matters. It is not that things are ideal for her, but certain of her interests are being well served by the present state of affairs.

Herman Melville's copy of a book which he used as a source for his best-known work, "Moby Dick," is to be sold at auction in a collection of books, autographs and manuscripts from the libraries of Mrs. Frederick A. De Peyster of this city, James M. Kennedy of Garden City and others on Tuesday afternoon at the American Art Association, Anderson Galleries, Inc.

THE architecture usually called "Modern" has reached a stage where it must be treated at least as a present phenomenon. By its votaries it is described as the first definite style since the Gothic to be "created on the basis of a new type of construction."

President Hoover's appeal to the country last week to end the hoarding of currency and thus to make a patriotic effort to assist financial recovery focused attention upon a problem that has been causing grave concern among banking authorities for several weeks.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- "Sub-Editing," a book written for newcomers to Fleet Street, by F.J. Mansfield of the editorial staff of The London Times, published here by Pitman, devotes considerable space to the consideration of American journalism

PARIS. FORD of France boasts a production for 1931 of a little more than 13,000 passenger cars and trucks, which compares with assemblies in 1930 of 12,900 units. Net profit for the past year is likely, in turn, to be just a bit higher than for the previous year, or about 36,000,000 francs against 35,200,000 in 1930 and 34,536,000 in 1929.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- An opinion that Japan probably had its eyes on the Philippine Islands as a source for war materials and future expansion was expressed before the Insular Affairs Committee today by John H. Pardee of New York, president of the Manila Electric Company, which operates a number of public utilities on the island.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney whose chief joy in life as a "kid" was playing baseball on the streets of Hell's Kitchen, his home district, upheld the national sport yesterday as the most wholesome activity for boys and said he hoped the youth of the city was not growing "soft" by giving up the old game in favor of golf.

DUBLIN, JAN. 15 FOLLOWING the usual fortnight of inactivity preceding Christmas, the Gate and the Abbey Theatres reopened on St. Stephen's (Boxing Day) with new plays. World premieres are now becoming the rule and not the exception in Dublin.

WASHINGTON. NOTHING in the outward scene has altered much since the bright beginning of the Hoover era. People are short-cutting as usual through the President's front yard and pausing to peer in at the wideopen door of the White House

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Feb. 6 (AP). -- After the acquittal of Edward H.B. Allen tonight, men and women crowded around the court house, shouting for joy. Giant firecrackers were set off and it seemed as though the horn of every automobile was blowing at once.

ROME, Feb. 6 -- From Vatican sources it is semi-officially confirmed that within a week the last act of the Italo-Vatican conciliations will be played with a visit by Premier Mussolini in his official capacity to Pope Pius XI.

Business failures will continue at their present unusually high rate for at least another three months, even though a trade upturn may be initiated during that period, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, told THE TIMES yesterday in commenting on the record-breaking total of bankruptcies during January.

GENEVA, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, president of the International Federation of League of Nations Societies and known as the "grand old man of disarmament," laid before the disarmament conference today a definite program of proposals, included in which was a 25 per cent reduction of world armament expenses.

Gradual but persistent slackening in basic activity is indicated by a further decline in the weekly business index, which on the basis of preliminary figures is now, by the margin of a tenth of a point, at a new low for the depression to date. The preliminary index for the week ended Jan. 30 is 62.2, as against 62.8 for the preceding week and 77.5 for the corresponding week last year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Immigration Bureau today announced that 46,217 more aliens left the United States during 1931 than arrived.

The greatly improved Squadron C polo trio marked up another metropolitan indoor polo circuit victory in theSquadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night when it halted Governors Island, 13 1/2 to 9 1/2. The winners received four goals by handicap.

Many of the leading philatelists of this and other cities will attend the annual dinner of the Collectors' Club next Saturday night at the Hotel Astor. Invitations have been extended to officials of the American Philatelic Society and other stamp organizations and representatives from some of the Canadian clubs are expected.

PARIS. AN outstanding textile fact based on selections made by couturiers is the supremacy of wool for Summer as well as Spring. Not that there will be more wool than anything else, but there will be a great deal of it.
Uninfluenced by the action of most other markets yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward and closed with gains of 7 to 8 points.

PANAMA, Feb. 2. -- If it can be accomplished by legal enactment, Panama's election next June will be calm and peaceful. A decree to that effect has just been issued by Secretary of Government and Justice Guellermo Andreve. All that remains now is to enforce it.

Lightning, in the form of Federal prohibition agents, struck twice at the Mansion House at 15 East Sixty-first Street. Raided last October by dry agents, the club had reopened and was preparing for its usual nightly guests when the raiders called again yesterday afternoon.

A DECREE signed recently by President Alcala Zamora of Spain dissolved the Jesuit Order in that country. Jesuit institutions of learning in Spain are to be used for lay education; churches and religious objects of the order will be turned over to parish priests.

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- The film record of the British Himalayan expedition's ascent of Mount Kamet, 25,447 feet, the highest summit reached by man, has been rejected for lack of a plot and "love interest."

THE tremor that hook Santiago de Cuba last week draws attention to a region of the earth nearly as unstable as Japan. A seismological world survey has shown that quakes are associated with the deeper parts of the oceans or with land regions that were once the bottoms of deep seas.

IN behalf of the Lots for Little Shop the directors of the organization, of which Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes is president, will hold a reception tomorrow afternoon at the Empire State Club at 350 Fifth Avenue. During the afternoon the Rev. John La Farge, S.J., will speak on the philanthropic work which has been accomplished by the shop.

LAKE PLACID -- For the first time in the history of the Olympic Games, sled-dog racing has been included in the schedule of demonstration events at the third Olympic Winter Games, which are now well under way at Lake Placid. Canada and the United States are competing in this picturesque sport, entering five and eight teams, respectively.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During recent broadcast it was interesting to listen to Senator Robert B. Howell of Nebraska attempt to answer Senator James E. Beck's appeal for a referendum on the Eighteenth Amendment.

The strike of longshoremen on the pier of the Grace Line, which has disrupted the sailing schedule involving several of the company's liners in the last week, was maintained without change yesterday and the two Grace ships now in port were delayed further in sailing because the cargo brought from Southern ports could not be unloaded in time.

MEMBERS of the board of managers of the Kips Bay Day Nursery will open formally the new headquarters of the organization at 454 East 122d Street on the afternoon of Feb. 25. In the dedication ceremonies a plaque in memory of the late Mrs. Arthur Murray Dodge will be unveiled.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6 -- Professor Willielm Kohler, director of the Weimar State Art Collection, will come to Harvard in September for the academic year as Kuno Francke Professor of German Art and Culture.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 6 -- A field goal in the final minute of play by Ken Fairman, Princeton forward, gave the Tigers a thrilling 25-to-24 victory over La Salle College tonight.
One of the three ten-goal players in polo, Captain C. T. I. (Pat) Roark, assigns the major share of the credit for the fame he has won in a brilliant mallet-swinging career to the pony.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 -- Having fewer cares to put aside than most other cities, New Orleans approaches Mardi Gras, the climax of its world-famed carnival, with the gorgeous splendor of other years scarcely dimmed. So far as visitors will be able to see, the pageant will be as brilliant as in the past.

At a luncheon meeting yesterday in Cavanagh's Restaurant, members of the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York subscribed $61,000 to a general fund which will be used in a drive against proposed State measures to increase license fees on motor trucks and, the gasoline tax.

Four outstanding points in the "aid to export" provisions of the law creating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation are outlined by United States Senator Duncan U. Fletcher of Florida, in a special statement received yesterday by the American Manufacturers' Export Association.

MADRID, Feb. 5 -- The republic is neither ours nor the people's," said Ramon Franco, the Spanish flier, before leaving here by plane. "We propose by the force of opinion and the legality of our design to govern the Spanish people."

ABOARD U.S.S. CALIFORNIA, Somewhere at Sea, Feb. 6 (AP). -- The joint army and navy exercise officially begins today. With the passing of the zero hour at 5 A.M., Honolulu time, each side is free to push ahead with its plans, the "Blue" to determine the effectiveness of the air, surface and land attacks against Hawali, and the "Black," the defending force, to test its air, surface, subsurface and land defenses.

ONE of its English critics has remarked that Miss Ferguson's novel takes the reader into the midst of a "sustained Family Joke." But tastes in jokes differ, and long sustained family ones often seem tedious to the outsider, who may even fail to find them funny.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Two United States mission houses in Shanghai were attacked this afternoon while a fleet of airplane bombers roared overhead, battering for the second time today the flattened sector of Chapei.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The damages to the business community arising out of the Sino-Japanese hostilities at Shanghai are estimated at about $12,500,000, the Department of Commerce was advised today in a cable from its Commercial Attache at the Chinese port.

ALTHOUGH the present depression has brought out its share of prominent pessimists, men in high, places whose statements seem to indicate they have little hope for the future -- among them H.G. Wells, Bertrand Russell, Dean Inge and Governor Murray of Oklahoma -- it has proved no different from other "hard times" in this respect.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6 -- The Montreal Maroons crept closer to a chance for a play-off berth in the international section of the National Hockey Leagrue tonight by defeating the New York Americans, 3 to 1, before a crowd of 11,000.
WASHINGTON, FORD'S THEATRE where, almost sixty-seven years ago. Abraham Lincoln was assassinated, will be opened to the public as a national museum on Friday, the 123d anniversary of Lincoln's birth.
LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Alice Wilson Fox in a letter published recently in The London Times tells an amusing anecdote of herself and Lewis Carroll.

HE called her darling and she called him darling. If I ever fall in love again I'll call my girl fishface or a term that will mean something." Miss Bishop's story deals entirely with people who move in that lighthearted stratum of society where "darling" is a convenient substitute for any name you may not have heard -- and it manages to be distinctly more entertaining than most such stories.

HAVANA, Feb. 6. -- An appropriation of a million dollars to repair the streets of Santiago, damaged by an earthquake, which almost destroyed that city on Feb. 3, is recommended today by the Secretary of Public Works, Mr. Onetti, who estimates this amount will be required to make the thoroughfares safe for traffic.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- A circuit of some of the German universities and a close-up view of the domestic economy of their teaching force discloses a state of high thinking and plain living in which the plainness is of such character that one begins to wonder how long such loftineses of thought can be sustained on it.

The power of taxation held by the Federal Government today was not intended by the makers of the Constitution, is a danger to our form of government and may lead to its being supplanted by State socialism, Representative James M. Beck of Pennsylvania, former Solicitor General of the United States, said yesterday at a luncheon discussion on taxation at the National Republican Club.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 6 -- The offensive strength of the Princeton varsity hockey reserves enabled the Tigers to score their sixth successive victory and to maintain an undefeated home record by defeating the Army sextet today, 7 to 1. Art Lane, star sophomore reserve wing, led the scoring with three goals, one in each period.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Secretary Mellon, whose nomination as Ambassador to Great Britain was confirmed by the Senate yesterday, probably will take the oath of office as Ambassador on Tuesday in a ceremony at the Treasury Department to be attended by many high officials.

HAVANA -- The fifth annual international star class yacht regatta is now on, holding first place in the interest of both residents and visitors in Havana. Races are being held off the famous Malecon, Havana's beautiful waterfront drive, which is crowded daily to watch the craft battle for the Cuban trophy.

Realty trading assumed a more diversified aspect last week than has recently been the case, and the announcement of some large home building developments and sales projects added a note of encouragement for future activity.

PINEHURST -- Two major golf tournaments of the Pinehurst Country Club and golf tournaments of the Silver Foils and Tin Whistles organizations are on the links' schedule of this resort for the coming week. Stars will compete in all these events, and some colorful golf is in prospect.

BROWNELL-Lambertson Gallery -- Paintings by Henri Burkhard the Franco-American artist, who has evolved a decorative variant of the Cezanne manner. Opened Feb. 1, closes Feb. 13. Reviewed yesterday. Also pleasant decorative screens by Ethel Haven, an American artist.

Eleven specialty clubs will hold shows in this city next Wednesday, the day before the opening of Westminster's great exhibition. In the Grand Central Palace the Associated Terrier Clubs will hold forth, nine organizations having combined forces to present the most notable gathering of terriers that has been brought together in this country in a similar event.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 6 -- Rear Admiral Toma Uematsu arrived in Shanghai today and is taking over the command of all the Japanese naval landing forces from Captain Baron Semejima, who becomes second in command. Admiral Uematsu issued an extraordinary declaration on his arrival, saying he was amazed to learn of the divergence of views with the United States, Great Britain and other nations.

ARTHUR PRYOR, the bandmaster, is the author of more than 300 compositions, including three light operas and more than fifty marches. Now he leads his radio band across the WEAF network every Saturday night at 9 o'clock.
Twenty-one games are listed for this week in the city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship basketball tourney and seven of the contests will mark the start of the league season for twelve teams.

Pleas for a more sympathetic attitude towards France were made at the 154th annual luncheon of the France America Society at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. The speakers ware William D. Guthrie, the president; Count Charles de Fontnouvelle, consul General here; Jules Henry, counsellor of the French Embassy at Washington; and Louis Wiley.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- With the Presidential and Gubernatorial campaigns in mind and being convinced that prohibition is bound to become an issue in both contests unless the two major parties find a way to keep it out, Republican leaders in the Legislature have declared a moratorium against both wet and dry legislation at the present session.

F.A. Sieverman, New York Athletic Club, and Robert H. Reutter, Columbia University Club, two of the four seeded players in the national veterans' squash tennis championship tournament in progress at the Princeton Club, advanced to the third round by winning their matches yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- When Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, sounded the death-knell of free trade in Britain last night he was announcing at the same time a revolution in the British industries, most of all in shipping.

The body of John R. Voorhis, Grand Sachem of the Tammany Society, was moved yesterday afternoon from the old red brick house in Greenwich Street where he had lived for more than half of his 102 years and where he died early Friday morning, to the lounge of the Great Wigwam on the third floor of Tammany Hall's new building at Union Square East and Seventeenth Street.

NEXT Saturday evening Broadway will witness the spectacle, all but unprecedented, of an actress shutting shop arbitrarily while playgoers are being turned away from the box-office unable to purchase tickets. For this is what will happen, when Katharine Cornell says farewell to the Empire Theatre and takes "The Barretts of Wimpole Street" to Boston to begin a tour.

One thousand members of the Associated Unions of the Printing Trades, Lithographers and Engravers heard pleas for the complete unionization of the trades to eliminate unemployment at a mass meeting last night in DeWitt Clinton High School, Mosholu Parkway and Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- H.B. Lees-Smith, former British Postmaster General, who has just returned from a visit to the United States, in an interview here contrasted British and American telephone services.

GENEVA, Feb. 6 -- All the world took part today in this conference for the reduction of armaments. Through the voices of nine speakers, in hundreds of telegrams and letters and in many scores of petitions signed by nearly 10,000,000 men and women of all classes in all nations declared their will for peace and their demand that this conference take concrete action for the prevention of war.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- It is difficult tonight to find any Englishman, official or unofficial, who regards the French proposals at Geneva as a serious or wholly sincere effort to achieve the reduction of armaments. Almost the only good point that British editors find in the scheme is the proposal to forbid the use of poison gas and bacteria warfare, a suggestion which tonight's Star urges that all nations should accept immediately.

MANILA, Jan. 2. -- The recent action of Wisconsin in putting a direct levy upon the manufacture and use of olemargarine, coupled with repeated surveys of outspoken American editorial opinion, has brought about an increasing conviction in the Philippines that the dairy States group has become the most important of factions in the United States which are demanding Philippine independence.

VIENNA, Feb. 6. -- Victor Kienboeck, former Finance Minister, was appointed president of the Austrian National Bank today to succeed Dr. Richard Reisch, who resigned two days ago as a result of general dissatisfaction over his conduct of that institution.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- The Olympic bob run was the scene of unsurpassed speed today as both course records were broken, and it also was the scene of another accident, the fifth of the week. A Belgian team suffered a spill on the Whiteface curve and a German team shattered Henry Homburger's world's record of 1:52 for four-man bobs as the boblet mark was beaten four times.

Women athletes in the metropolitan district continue to devote much attention to the movement to boom lacrosse, with the number actively interested in organizing a New York team, having grown to fifty since the first practice was staged a few weeks ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Over an excellently cooked dinner of rice, curry, chapatties and firni I have been trying to analyze the feeling of mental discomfort which came to me in reading a sentence in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Dec. 13, which has just reached me.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After the Jackson banquet at Washington, Senator Carter Glass asked former Governor Cox of Ohio, "Why don't you send your political ecclesiastics in Ohio back to the pulpits?" May I supply the answer which circumstances doubtless did not permit Mr. Cox to give?

The French proposal for an international police force to safeguard the security of the world, presented Friday to the World Disarmament Conference by Andre Tardieu, was the subject of considerable criticism by the four speakers who addressed the Foreign Policy Association at that organization's semi-monthly luncheon meeting yesterday at the Astor.

THE Print Collector's Quarterly for Winter contains quarterly notes by the editor, a critique of Rowlandson's prints by Victor Rienaecker, "Two Documents on Stefano Della Bella" by Augusto Calabi, "The Line Engraving of Stephen Gooden" by Forrest Reid and "The Prints of Camille Pissarro, a Supplement to the Catalogue by Loys Delteil," by Jean Cailac.

A cablegram from Shanghai announcing that "all missionaries are safe" was received yesterday by the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., at its headquarters at 156 Fifth Avenue.
Careless handling of a small calibre rifle by the 14-year-old son of a policeman resulted yesterday in the wounding of the boy's chum, and may possibly cost him his life.

The amount of claims for personal accidents involving automobiles received by the Aetna Life Insurance Company in 1931 increased 21.1 per cent over the total in 1930, to $1,217,373. This increase is regarded as an indication of what reports from the insurance companies of the country generally will show.

THE demand for sophisticated beauty in Old World furnishings has brought to the fore many small types of chairs, tables and sofas of the great French periods and emphasized the intimate air of the small drawing room, sitting room and dining room of the less formal eighteenth-century Parisian life.

There was a fair demand for new potatoes last week in the New York Wholesale market and the very finest sold on the basis of $3 a bushel. George G. Royce of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, writes in his consumer's weekly review of local wholesale markets.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 6 -- Robert P. Simpson, a vice president of the Baltimore Trust Company, died today at his home in Roland Park at the age of 77.

Indoor track prospects at New York University this Winter are exceedingly bright. A careful campaign has been mapped out with the hope of bringing the large squad along gradually so that by March 5 all the stars will be in top form for the national intercollegiates.

In a breath-taking game that left the outcome in doubt until the last second, the Yale polo trio scored a superb victory over the Pennsylvania Military College team at Squadron Armory last night before a large and enthusiastic audience.
SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 7 -- Three days of bombing and shelling have caused terrible havoc in the Woosung forts. But the red, blue and white flag of China still waves over their torn walls.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 6 -- As a climax to the Maryland Kennel Club show for the benefit of the unemployed of Baltimore, Dr. A.A. Mitten's great English setter, Champion Blue Dan of Happy Valley, was named best in show tonight. The award was made by Dr. John E. de Mund, president of the American Kennel Club.

BABYLON, L.I., Feb. 6 -- The establishment of a central coast guard station at Gilgo Beach State Park has been decided upon by the United States Government in accordance with a plan evolved by the Long Island State Park Commission which calls for the removal of three frame service stations between Fire Island inlet and Jones inlet.

Any method which lends itself best to the most radical reduction of armaments and their most effective limitation will be acceptable to the Italian delegation at the Geneva Disarmament Conference, Dino Grandi, Italian Foreign Minister and head of his country's delegation, said last night in a radio address rebroadcast in this country by the National Broadcasting Company.

In a breath-taking game that left the outcome in doubt until the last second, the Yale polo trio scored a superb victory over the Pennsylvania Military College team at Squadron Armory last night before a large and enthusiastic audience.

English, French and Italian antique furniture and fine Georgian silver, Sheffield plate, tapestries, textiles and Oriental rugs owned by Mrs. James E. Spiegelberg and Mrs. Clara Borger of New York, and Oscar Dane of St. Louis and from the collection of Mrs. John Stewart Kennedy will be sold at auction on Friday and Saturday at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

ROME. THE inclusion of G.F. Malipiero's string quartet, "Cantari alla Madrigalesca" (literally: Canti in Madrigal Style), in the program of the I.S.C.M. festival at Vienna next June, gives added interest to the first Italian hearings of this latest work of the Venetian composer during the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge concerts recently held in various cities of the peninsula.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The question of State Department supervision of foreign loans is once more in the headlines. Since the Winter of 1927-28, when Senator Carter Glass questioned the constitutionality of this policy, it has received occasional attention by the Senate and the public.

Any method which lends itself best to the most radical reduction of armaments and their most effective limitation will be acceptable to the Italian delegation at the Geneva Disarmament Conference, Dino Grandi, Italian Foreign Minister and head of his country's delegation, said last night in a radio address rebroadcast in this country by the National Broadcasting Company.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- No office in Cook County, except possibly that of Mayor of Chicago, is regarded as being of so great public and political importance as the State's Attorney. Bitter battles have been waged in the past for nomination and election to the post of Chief County Prosecutor, and there are signs that the approaching contest, which enters its primary phase next April and must be determined in November, will maintain the record.

Southern cotton growers should reduce their acreage at this time, but they should improve the vacated land with fertilizers and the planting of other forms of farm products to bring a halt to the declining fertility of the soil, according to Alston H. Garside, economist of the New York Cotton Exchange.

MEXZCO CITY. MONTE ALBAN -- latest of the treasure-houses of preconqnest Mexico to be discovered -- lifts frowning battlements along the mountain crest to the west of Oaxaca City. For miles, silhouetted against the clear tropic sky.

Tariff increases amounting to as much as 111 per cent on the cost of items purchased by importers will be added if the Hawley bill, suggesting compensatory duties on imports from countries where currencies have depreciated, is enacted into law, C. T. Riotte, secretary of the National Council of American Importers and Trader's, Inc., said here yesterday.

Professor Charles Heinroth, for nearly twenty-five years municipal organist of Pittsburgh, who will give this afternoon the first of a new series of public organ recitals in the Great Hall of the City College, will then begin his term as successor to Professor Samuel A. Baldwin, whose retirement last week ended a series of concerts that had been heard by more than 1,000,000 persons since 1908.

JANET GAYNOR, that vivacious screen, heroine whose years from the extra-girl days to stardom under the Fox cachet were less than most, returned from a tour of Europe this week on the Lloyd Sabaudo liner Conte Grande, and glad she was to set her foot again on shore after an unusually severe Winter crossing on the southern track.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Treachery, by some one on the prison staff was officially established today as one of the immediate causes of the Dartmoor prison mutiny a fortnight ago, when 300 convicts tried to escape and set one of the prison buildings afire.

TRAGI-COMEDY, as distinguished from satirical tragedy. is quite one of the hardest things to do well. Miss Anne Parrish has shown before how well she can succeed with this form, and "Loads of Love" is no exception to her previous work.

CHINA, to the Western trading countries as well as Japan, is a market for the investment of surplus capital, for the sale of goods and for the purchase of raw materials. This was true in 1839 when Great Britain fought the Opium War to force the Imperial Chinese Government to permit foreigners to trade in China as they pleased.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- Friends who wagered $2,000 with William R. Crissey, young Philadelphia broker, that he could not dine with President Hoover, play golf with Bobby Jones and John D. Rockefeller, Sr., and motor or play golf with the Prince of Wales, all within a year, are satisfied that their money is safe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- American wheat bins are overflowing with 304,000,000 bushels available for export, about 75,000,000 more than last year, the Agriculture Department estimated today. At the same time it placed the surplus available for export and varry-over at 429,000,000 bushels, against 355,000,000 at this time last year.

Leo Sexton of the New York Athletic Club and Phil Bernstein of the Millrose A.A. scored victories in the two field events which inaugurated the Metropolitan Association A.A. U. indoor senior track and field championship program on intramural field at New York University yesterday.

The week ended yesterday, on the financial markets, with hardly a flicker of life in any quarter. It was one of those days on which, so far as any fresh appraisement of values was concerned, practically all the markets might as well have been observing a holiday.

Secretary STIMSON recently declared in an official communication that the United States would view with "displeasure" anything like a united front in Europe in its dealings with this country. He was referring primarily to the question of reparations and war debts. But the scope of his protest would extend to tariff matters undoubtedly.
LONDON. AN EPOCH in radio history was marked by the rebroadcast in England for the first time of a full hour's program by American artists entertaining from New York studios.

COLON, R. P., Feb. 2. -- While the British Navy was searching vainly last week for the Submarine M-2, which was lost with its crew of fifty-four officers and men, volunteers at the Coco Solo submarine base here were being rescued from the U. S. S-S-4, in which forty officers and men were drowned in December, 1927, when the craft was rammed by a destroyer off Provincetown, Mass., and sunk in 102 feet of water.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. WITH some of the largest theatre chains in the country either being turned back to their former owners or sold to independent operators on a nothing-down-pay-me-some-time basis, Hollywood is viewing the disintegration of one of the most spectacular creations of the boom-day orgy with something akin to satisfaction.

Farm communities normally consume over one-third of the totsal lumber cut or over one-half of that used in building construction, according to a special lumber survey committee of the Timber Conservation Board. The year 1931, although a reasonably productive season, was marked by another staggering decline in prices of farm products.

Four members of the Jamaica High School hockey squad, which last month won the city P.S.A.L. championship for the sixth time in seven seasons, were among the large number of New York City's scholastic athletic stars who were graduated from the high schools during the past week.

NO contemporary writer is better equipped than Mr. Bercovici to write a novel of gypsy life, for he is a Rumanian who, having learned in childhood the Romany legends, language and customs, traveled in a gypsy caravan all over Europe as a young man.

Russia is not and never will be Utopia -- George Bernard Shaw to the contrary notwithstanding. We cannot, however, ignore Russia's challenge to youth, which is nothing less than the ageless impulse behind social progress, the grim determination that all men shall have a better chance in life.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- In an intercollegiate fencing match, fought with fails, epee and saber, Army swordsmen won from Columbia today by a score of 9 to 8. The Cadets took the foils bouts, 5 to 4, won all four of the epee bouts, but Columbia made a clean sweep with the saber, 4 to 0.

HEAVY firing broke out again yesterday morning in the International Settlement at Lake Placid. There may be a call for the U. S. Marines along the frozen front. It is understood that the War Department has completed plans for evacuating the helpless civilians in that stricken area.

MONTREAL, EAST, Que., Feb. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Frank Hoey, Montreal, increased his lead in the 200-mile Quebec-to-Montreat snowshoe marathon by covering the seventh lap today from L'Assomption to Montreal East, a distance of sixteen miles in 2 hours 9 minutes 12 seconds and placing third in the lap.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press) -- In the destruction of the Commercial Press and the Oriental Library at Shanghai, the Chinese people and the world at large have suffered an irreparable cultural loss, Professor Kiang Kang-hu. director of Chinese studies at McGill University, declared yesterday.

SAO PAULO, Jan. 19. -- The inclusion in the 1932 budget of a provision extending the 2 per cent gold tax on imports to all ports in Brazil has become a source of bitter political agitation in the State of Sao Paulo, as it is argued that the extension of this tax to Santos would put that port in an inferior position.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Princeton defeated Army in the swimming tank today by a score of 49 to 22. It was the Cadets' first defeat of the season.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 6 -- The Yale junior varsity indoor polo team today conquered Farmington Valley, 13 1/2 to 9 1/2, scoring four times in the final period. The visitors led during the first two periods, Johnny Enders leading their attack with six goals.

The American Society of Painters, Sculptors and Gravers opened its exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art with a reception last evening. From today and until Feb. 28, the show will be open to the public.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- Chancellor Bruening started for Geneva tonight to plead Germany's case before the disarmament conference. While he left behind no intimation as to his line of argument, he is fully conscious that German popular opinion, regardless of partisan affilations, is a compact unit in its expectations that the leader of the German delegation will demand speedy fulfillment of Germany's rights under the Treaty of Versailles.

PARIS, Feb. 6 -- Having gotten over the first flush of elation at having given the Geneva conference a carefully prepared scheme for "disarmament with security," France today began to take stock of the farreaching internal political consequences of the move.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 -- California is face to face with one of the most interesting political situations in its history. A situation which involves issues and men, sectional obsessions, petty jealousies and party quarrel. It centres first about the Presidential primary, and second in the choice of a candidate for United States Senator to succeed Samuel Shortridge, and the ability or desire of the senior Senator.

After a legislative convulsion lasting nine weeks, Governor LA FOLLETTE'S unemployment relief program appears through the haze, hacked but recognizable. In Wisconsin all must be leaders, and the goal is reached by many paths. Governor LA FOLLETTE controlled the Assembly, but in the Senate he lacked a single vote, and in the end had to deal with an independent among independents such as only Wisconsin could produce.

A NUMBER of prominent women who are Interested in the construction of the Marie Reparatrix Home for Business Girls at 10 East Twenty-ninth Street have arranged a supper dance for tomorrow ranged a the Biltmore in aid of the project. The proposed building will be supervised by the Order of Marie Reparatrix, which was founded in 1856 by the Baroness d'Hooghvorst, The home will provide shelter for young business women at modest rates.

The bodies of three of the seven men believed to have been lost when the tug Lonnie B. Shaw foundered early Friday off Cape May, N. J., while towing the lumber-laden barge Ruth Shaw, were recpvered yesterday by the Coast Guard.

In a game that was marked by brilliant play, the Fordham University basketball team vanquished the Temple University five of Philadelphia, 30 to 23, in the Fordham Gymnasium last night. A crowd of 3,000, the largest to attend a Maroon basketball contest this season, watched the game.

FARADAY'S discovery of electromagnetic induction, a hundred years ago, is the closing event of a great epoch, in the history of physical science and engineering. It is the epoch in which the power age was born. "Watt's invention of the modern steam engine in the early days of the American Revolution marks the beginning of this epoch.

CASTLE HARBOUR, Bermuda, Feb. 6 -- A number of distinguished guests and visitors at the Castle Harbour Hotel were entertained tonight at a gala dinner at which Helen Knott and Chester Towne, dancers, appeared, having come from New York for the occasion.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6 -- E.R. Bradley's colt, Broad Meadows, won the mile race, known as the Louisiana-Mississippi Chambers of Commerce Purse, at the Fair Grounds today, by a length and a half from Silverdale which led to the home stretch.

A NUMBER of prominent women who are Interested in the construction of the Marie Reparatrix Home for Business Girls at 10 East Twenty-ninth Street have arranged a supper dance for tomorrow ranged a the Biltmore in aid of the project. The proposed building will be supervised by the Order of Marie Reparatrix, which was founded in 1856 by the Baroness d'Hooghvorst, The home will provide shelter for young business women at modest rates.

The bodies of three of the seven men believed to have been lost when the tug Lonnie B. Shaw foundered early Friday off Cape May, N. J., while towing the lumber-laden barge Ruth Shaw, were recpvered yesterday by the Coast Guard.

It is the epoch in which the power age was born. "Watt's invention of the modern steam engine in the early days of the American Revolution marks the beginning of this epoch.

CASTLE HARBOUR, Bermuda, Feb. 6 -- A number of distinguished guests and visitors at the Castle Harbour Hotel were entertained tonight at a gala dinner at which Helen Knott and Chester Towne, dancers, appeared, having come from New York for the occasion.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 6 -- The Yale junior varsity indoor polo team today conquered Farmington Valley, 13 1/2 to 9 1/2, scoring four times in the final period. The visitors led during the first two periods, Johnny Enders leading their attack with six goals.

The American Society of Painters, Sculptors and Gravers opened its exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art with a reception last evening. From today and until Feb. 28, the show will be open to the public.

BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- Chancellor Bruening started for Geneva tonight to plead Germany's case before the disarmament conference. While he left behind no intimation as to his line of argument, he is fully conscious that German popular opinion, regardless of partisan affilations, is a compact unit in its expectations that the leader of the German delegation will demand speedy fulfillment of Germany's rights under the Treaty of Versailles.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 -- California is face to face with one of the most interesting political situations in its history. A situation which involves issues and men, sectional obsessions, petty jealousies and party quarrel. It centres first about the Presidential primary, and second in the choice of a candidate for United States Senator to succeed Samuel Shortridge, and the ability or desire of the senior Senator.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee has paid out or made payable appropriations of $9,790,732.66, or more than half of the $18,000,000 contributed by the public, it was announced yesterday. The funds paid for unemployment relief had totaled $8,286,541.08, in addition to appropriations of $1,504,191.58.

Patriotic and civic organizations joined yesterday afternoon with the Tammany Society in paying tribute to the memory of John R. Voorhis, for more than twenty years Grand Sachem of the society, who died Friday at the age of 102.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- In the rubber market here today plantation grades were steadier, but trading was quiet. Smoked sheet spot sold at 2 7/8d a pound value, February at 2 13-16d to 2 7/8d sellers, March at 2 7/3d buyers, April-June at 2 15-16d to 3d sellers, July-September at 3 1/8d value, October-December from 3 1/4d to 3 5-16d to 3 1/4d value, crepe spot 3 3/8d to 3 7-16d value.

The new wage schedule adopted last week by organized employers for the building trades in New York City and vicinity will have a stabilizing effect on the construction industry here, according to expressions of opinion carried in the current Dow Service daily building reports.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Bishop James Cannon Jr. of the Methodist Episcopal Church South, who bitterly opposed Governor Smith in the Presidential campaign of 1928 and was active in carrying Virginia for the Republicans, declared tonight that Mr. Smith's statement of his position had made prohibition the outstanding issue in 1932.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- German medical circles regard the conviction of Professor George Deycke and Dr. Ernst Alatadt at Lubeck partly with sympathy for them -- especially for Deycke because of his attainments and advanced age -- but in general concur with the court in attributing the deaths of the children to defective laboratory equipment and procedure which condition was brought out in all the expert testimony.

Art is to play an appropriately important role in the celebration this month of the Washington bicentennial. Many exhibitions have been arranged. One of the most interesting of these is certain to be the Washington show that opens Feb. 15 in the American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum.

PARIS, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Minister Emilio Fortes Gil, former President of Mexico, has presented his resignation, it became known today, in order to become a candidate for the Governorship of his home State of Tamaulipas.

Conchita Supervia, the Spanish mezzo-soprano who is now a member of the Chicago Civic Opera Company, made her first appearance in New York in recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Preliminary announcements had retailed many of the facts of Mme. Supervia's career, as her beginning in opera at the age of 14 at the Colon Theatre in Buenos Ayres, and her singing Carmen at the age of 15 in Italy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- An army of 1,121,050 wage earners, salaried officers and others were employed in the manufacturing establishments of the New York industrial area in 1929.

Lent should be regarded as a "spiritual training season" rather than a time of penance, and as such approached with joy instead of reluctance, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared at high mass there yesterday.

GENEVA, Feb. 7. -- Andre Tardieu, French Minister of War, who on Friday laid before the World Disarmament Conference the French plan for a world police force to keep the peace, tonight made an address to the people of the United States over the radio.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- Enthusiasm over the displays of automobiles at the shows in the East and in Chicago has given the trade a boost, according to opinion here. It is said that dealers made large purchases on expectation of a satisfactory demand from the public.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- Too adept in their stick-handling, too fast in their skating and much, too experienced, the United States and Canada, top-ranking teams in the Olympic hockey tournament, scored decisive victories today. The Americans turned back the German sextet by 7 to 0, in the Arena tonight, while the Maple Leaf six registered any easy triumph over Poland, 9 to 0, in the afternoon for its third straight success.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- The Republican proposal to pass in unamended form the bill to set up a banking board of nine members may bring the threat of veto by Governor Roosevelt, it was indicated here today.

The disarmament conference at Geneva against the background of trouble in the Far East was the subject of sermons in four churches yesterday, with the Rev. Dr. George Maychin Stockdale of the St. James Methodist Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 126th Street, proposing that the existing armaments of nations be cut to one tenth of their present force and the remainder amalgamated into an international peace force.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Through the Washington legation, Dr. Lo Wen-ken, Chinese Minister of Foreign Affairs, today renewed his plea for intervention in China by Western powers.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- Chanel retains the low waistline just above the hipbones, often defined on day coats and dresses by narrow suede or fabric belts. Coats are loose or belted and achieve a straight simplicity by intricate smooth goring or seaming. Long or short sleeves also conform to the straight and narrow modern line.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP). -- President Hoover will be the chief speaker, by radio, at dinners to be held throughout the country on Friday commemorating the 123d anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.

The sun beat down upon the Bronx yesterday, turning mere atone apartment houses into golden castles, and the segment of woods to the east into a vast jungle. It looked down upon the bison in the zoo as they contemplated the future oblivion of the race, and the sea lions worrying already about today's supper.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 8. -- Japanese naval officers said that the big push in the Woosung area would occur today, with the Japanese using virtually all branches of the armed services to dislodge the Chinese from their positions.

The exploits of the American Second Division at Soissons and Chateau Thierry were described yesterday by its former commander, Major Gen. James G. Harbord, retired, in an illustrated lecture before an audience of 1,000 men and women at the Welfare Island workhouse.

Declaring that religion is now at its "lowest ebb" in history, Bishop William T. Manning called for a renaissance of religious faith and a renewed interest in prayer as means of combating the present world crisis, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial entitled "What Might Happen" you refer to the possibility that the Republican State of Pennsylvania, with its seventysix votes in Democratic National Conventions, might provide the additional strength required either to give Franklin D. Roosevelt his twothirds majority next June or to enable his opponents to hold him short of that necessary fraction.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 6. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 64.2, which compares with 64.5 a week ago, 65.2 two weeks ago, 65.2 three weeks ago and 65.3 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; this week's is the lowest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Feb. 7. -- Alfred E. Smith's terse announcement of his willingness to run for President again threatens to split California Democratic ranks wide open and today sent leaders of the party into a hurried political huddle here.

In a letter to the Board of Estimate, made public yesterday, leading business and civic organizations in Manhattan urged prompt action to grant bus franchise to the New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, in accordance with contract forms already approved by Mayor Walker and John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

The New York Giants soccer team overcame another hurdle in its march toward a second United States championship by defeating the Newark Americans, 6 to 1, at the Polo Grounds yesterday in the semi-finals of the National Challenge Cup competition.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 7. -- All grain shipments have been heavy for the past week. Wheat and corn prices are firm, flaxseed dull, because of cessation of demand from the United States. The low level of cattle prices continues, the cut in profit for producers reacting on the pastoral land value, estimated at 40 per cent under those of 1928.

Vincent Coll, who in the brief space of a few months had attained nationwide notoriety as the most ruthless of New York's killers, was riddled with machine gun bullets and instantly killed early this morning when he was trapped by his enemies in a telephone booth in a drug store at 314 West Twenty-third Street, west of Eighth Avenue.

The National Yacht Club hockey team ot Toronto, more commonly known as the Toronto Sea Fleas, made an impressive New York debut yesterday by defeatine the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club stick wielders at Madison Square Garden, by the score of 4 to 1.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Republican chieftains, headed by W. Kingsland Macy, State chairman, will meet here on Tuesday to frame a course on reapportionment of the State's representation in Congress. With the Court of Appeals scheduled to hand down on that day a ruling on the status of the reallotment resolution adopted by the legislative majority last year, the leaders will determine their future policy on the basis of the court decision.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Continuing a practice which he started last year, President Hoover, accompanied by Mrs. Hoover, attended services today in the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church and sat in the pew which President Lincoln used while a worshipper there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Directors of the $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Corporation after a long plan-drafting session today, announced that seventeen regional loan agencies would be set up in its program of reviving the credit energy of the country.

Failure to coordinate the prodigious amount of knowledge developed by isolated groups is largely responsible for inefficiency in dealing with the world's problems, Young B. Smith, dean of the Columbia University School of Law, declared in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, made public yesterday.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Feb. 7. -- Miss Joan Keller of 333 Mosholu Parkway, New York City, is one of four successful candidates out of 154 girls from twenty-two States, the District of Columbia, Hawaii and Chile, who applied for scholarships to Swarthmore College for next year.

The Senate's confirmation of Secretary MELLON as Ambassador to the Court of St. James's brings to a close a career in our public service exceptional in several regards. Even in consecutive service at the head of the Treasury, Mr. MELLON has a record never but once exceeded.

Increases in truck registration fees, ranging from 860 per cent to 5,150 per cent, will result if the proposals of the Mastick tax commission are enacted into law, according to figures compiled and made public yesterday by the cost committee of the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Charles G. Dawes, wife of the former Ambassador to the Court of St. James's, with her nephew, Henry Dawes, is returning tomorrow on the Berengaria.

Harold Kramer, C.C.N.Y. swimming captain and metropolitan 440yard free-style champion, is showing the way in the race for scoring honcrs in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association, the Lavender leader in three meets having amassed a total of 35 points.

The largest representation of buyers seen here this season shopped through wholesale apparel markets last week placing orders for Spring merchandise. Individual purchases were smaller than those of the corresponding period last year, but frequent re-orders through the coming weeks are expected to bring the total volume to a point equal with the 1931 season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Tokyo Government's statement in explanation of its reasons for sending Japanese troops to Shanghai for the relief of Japanese sailors who have borne the brunt of the fighting there during the past fortnight is regarded in informed official quarters in Washington tonight as giving the situation a more favorable aspect.

PHOENIX, Ariz, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The twelve men on the jury trying Winnie Ruth Judd in the "trunk" slaying of Agnes Anne Leroi have only to hear the summing up of evidence, and the charge of Superior Judge Howard C. Speakman, and are expected to retire late tomorrow for deliberations.

About 100 etchings, including sevaral by James McNeil Whistler, and approximately 200 Japanese prints were stolen Saturday night from the Walpole Galleries, 13 West Fortyeighth Street, by thieves who jimmled the door, nailed it shut behind them to prevent interruption, and then selected their loot with the care of connoisseurs.

Rosa Ponselle sang to a brilliant audience at the Metropolitan last evening, departing from her more familiar opera repertory and presenting new and untried music, to the delight of the artist's admirers. Her selections included airs from "Tote Stadt" and "Carmen" and an address to Aphrodite from Romani's "Fedra," conducted by the composer.

The cornerstone of the new $1,250,000 All Souls' Unitarian Church at Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, which will house the congregation of the oldest church of that denomination in the city, was laid yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, the pastor, in the presence of more than 300 parishioners.

A stockholders' committee opposing the reorganization plan announced by bond and note holders' committees of the Fisk Rubber Company has asked stockholders to contribute 5 cents for every share held to finance its work. Andrew J. Miller, of Hallgarten Co., is chairman of this committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The action of the British Government in moving for a 10 per cent tariff was described in a statement tonight by Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democrat, of Kentucky, as a development in "the foolish train of international events which we set in motion when the Hoover-Grundy tariff law was enacted in 1930."

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Feb. 7. -- Mgr. Bernard was installed as Prefect-Apostolic of the Bahamas by Cardinal Hayes of New York this morning in a brilliant outdoor ceremony in which Cardinal O'Connell of Boston also participated.

It should not be news, as Governor ROOSEVELT suggested to the Albany reporters, that he has not changed his stand on prohibition since he stated it in a letter to Senator WAGNER in 1930. Nevertheless, because Mr. ROOSEVELT is a leading Presidential aspirant and only recently announced a change of views about the League of Nations, his reaffirmation of the Wagner letter comes as a matter of national importance.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7. -- While Edward H.B. Allen, young society man, enjoyed a reunion with his father, sister and two brothers today, the jury verdict which acquitted him last night of the murder of Francis A. Donaldson 3d was assailed by the slain youth's father as one prompted by "emotion", following "prejudiced opinion."

Clear, sunlit paintings of New York streets by Nicolal Cikovsky, pencil studies of "the depression" by Raphael Soyer and paintings by L. Ribak and M. Solataroff are on view at the John Reed Club until Feb. 16. The gallery is open from 10 to 6 daily, and evenings from 8 to 10.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7. -- Captain and Mrs. R. Amcotts Wilson entertained tonight with a dinner at their Vita Serena villa, honoring their house guests, Mrs. George A. Dixon Jr. and Mrs. William Randolph Hearst. Among the guests were Joseph E. Widener, Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener, Mr. and Mrs. George D. Widener and their house guests, Sir Humphrey E. De Trafford and Lady De Trafford and Major Thomas Bouch.

The Countess Margit Bethlen was ordained yesterday an elder at the morning services in the Magyar Presbyterian Church, 233 East 116th Street. She is the third woman upon whom the Presbytery of New York has bestowed this office, but the first of Hungarian nationality.

Phillips H. Lord, known to thousands of radio addicts as Seth Parker, and his company yesterday foregathered on the stage of the Cort to provide Broadway with an afternoon of the kind of sweetness and light and rustic humor that they contribute regularly over the wireless and recently have been contributing in a tour of road theatres and auditoriums.

AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 7. -- One Texas Democratic leader expressed doubt today that Alfred E. Smith would be a candidate for the nomination, and another predicted a divided party if Mr. Smith should run for the Presidency.

To the Editor at The New York Times: The question why three-quarters of the people in the United States are not receiving dental care, raised by the American Dental Association in THE NEW YORK TIMES, is obviously vital to the publlo health. The number of dentists and the ratio of their number to the total population are factors emphasized in the article.

While walking along an empty corridor on the sixth floor of Post Graduate Hospital yesterday afternoon, Rose D'Agostino, 23 years old, of 2,081 Wallace Avenue, the Bronx, was set upon by an unemployed seanan who sprang at her from a vacant room, made a fruitless effort to snatch her hand bag as he hit her a glancing blow on the head with a blackjack, and then fled when her screams attracted attendants.

There is one interesting scene in "Under One Roof." a Yiddish play by Ray Field and Meyer Schwartz which was put on at the Second Avenue Theatre Saturday night, but it does not occur until two and a half exceedingly bungling and tedious acts have passed.

A Japanese and Chinese discussed the present Sino-Japanese situation urging world-wide cooperation for international amity at an anti-war demonstration under the auspices of the Socialist Party of Greater New York at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Life insurance in force throughout the world at the close of 1929 aggregated $147,000,000,000 and incomplete data for 1930 indicate a "substantial increase" in that year, according to a survey by A.S. Christenson, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- Unsatisfactory conditions surround the cattle interests. There was no particular demand last week except for a few choice to fancy steers which commanded the best prices, ranging up to $9.65 a hundredweight at the opening of the week, with the best offered at the last, bringing only $7.50, a loss of 75 cents to $1 on the week.

The second concert of the League of Composers at the French Institute was devoted yesterday afternoon to a group of young Europeans: Mario Bruschettini of Turin, Egon Wellesz, Paul Pisk and Joachim Stutschevsky of Vienna, Erwin Schulhoff of Prague and Alexandre Mossolov of Moscow.

Employing printers of the largest printing and book establishments in New York City, with an annual payroll of $25,000,000, have requested six printing unions with a total membership of 15,000 to confer this week on the employers' proposal for a wage reduction of 20 per cent in two unions and 30 per cent in four -- to go into effect on March 1.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7. -- While thousands stood with bared heads, Barney Dreyfuss, owner of the Pittsburgh Pirates and father of the world's, series idea, was burled today in West View Cemetery.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The Hurricane Poloists, a New York aggregation including the international stars, Captain C.T.I. (Pat) Roark, G.H. (Pete) Bostwick and Stephen (Laddie) Sanford, defeated the Midwick Country Club four in a sensational extra period match, 8 to 7, today.

TOKYO, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The Japanese Consul General at Vladivostok, Siberia, reporting to his government today that the Siberian seaport had taken on "an atmosphere which may be described as like that of wartime," indicated that the military activities of the Soviets were merely precautionary.
ABOARD U.S.S. CALIFORNIA, Off Hawaii, Feb. 7 (AP). -- "The airplanes are attacking."

Doubt over the acceptance by the Amateur Athletic Union of the world's record jump of 6 feet 7 3/8 inches made by George Spitz Jr., New York University sopohomore, at the Millrose A.A. games in Madison Square Garden last Saturday night, was dispelled yesterday.

Ex-Governor SMITH desires and seeks another nomination for the Presidency. No other conclusion can be drawn from his statement made public this morning. For him to say that he leaves everything to the Democratic National Convention is a mere form of words.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- What is regarded here as a possible sign of an upward trend in business was revealed today in the monthly report of the corporation bureau of the Secretary of State's office, made public today by Secretary Edward J. Flynn. In January more new companies were formed than in any month in two years, with a single exception.

Rapid transit lines, street railways and bus companies reporting to the Transit Commission carried 40,946,000 fewer passengers in the quarter ended Sept. 30, 1931, than they did in the same three months of 1930, according to a report issued by the commission yesterday.

A great deal of the modern defense of loose morals comes from persons who are seeking to justify their own actions, and therefore does not prove that the real standards of conduct have changed, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Riverside Baptist Church.
LONDON, Monday, Feb. 8 (AP). -- A Vienna dispatch to The Daily Express said today it was feared that seventy passengers had been frozen to death in a snowbound train near Bodok, Rumania.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 7. -- Thirty foreign telephone operators, including a few Americans, were still carrying on today at North Exchange, just inside the Settlement boundaries in West Hongkew.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- Lithuanian troops are patrolling the streets and frontier of the autonomous territory of Memel, whose governing council was supplanted yesterday by a Lithuanian directorate. Otto Boettcher, the German President of the territory, who was arrested by two Lithuanian officers, is being held at the army barracks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is seldom that one sees so much misinformation in so small a space as is visible in Mr. Cuvillier's letter on the so-called All-American Ship Canal. Arguing against the St. Lawrence ship canal, he puts the cost of the latter at $999,000,000.

The death rate in New York City during the last three months has been the lowest known here for that period of the year since the consolidation of the five boroughs in 1898, according to figures made public yesterday by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Commissioner of Health. Dr. Wynne attributes the decrease in fatal illnesses to the mild Winter.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- Formation of a $100,000,000 State Public Credit Association along the lines of the Federal Reconstruction Finance Corporation to assist New York municipalities in financing will be proposed in a bill to be introduced in the Legislature at Albany this week by Monroe County Representatives.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- Owing to the marked improvement in the Reichsbank's status, and a decline in credits taken through the new acceptance and guaranty bank, the possibility of another cut in the bank rate has again been discussed. The last reduction was to 7 per cent on Dec. 10; the recent high record was 15 per cent in last midsummer's panic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The evacuation of American women and children from Nanking was urged, Nelson T. Johnson, American Minister to China, today informed the State Department because an extension of present military activities would make it difficult to remove them if the city was attacked.

HONOLULU, Feb. 7. -- The port of Hilo on the island of Hawaii was "captured" today by the "Blues," who seek to retake the Hawaiian Islands from the "Black" enemy, supposed to have captured them from the United States in the annual army and navy war games.

FARMINGTON, Mo., Feb. 7 (AP). -- Virgil Red Frazier, one of the five men who escaped from the St. Francis County jail last night, after tearing a hole in the jail wall by a nitroglycerin blast, was recaptured tonight at his home at Donne Terre, eighteen miles north of Farmington.

The New York County Lawyers' Association announced yesterday that it had approved a report of its committee on Legislation urging the passing of one measure that is now before the State Legislature and the defeat of six others.

Contrary to public opinion, outside its borders, China is equipped with a small but excellent fleet of reconnoissance and fighting airplanes manned by some 150 pilots trained in the latest tactics of aerial warfare in the United States, Great Britain and other countries, it was explained yesterday by a high official of the United Aircraft Export Corporation who has just returned from Shanghai.

The seventy-nine precinct stations of the Home Relief Bureau, which interrupted registration of applicants on Jan. 27, will resume registration Wednesday with a greatly expanded program of assistance for the many thousands of unemployed in distress in this city, it was announced yesterday by Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare in charge of the bureau.

HOUSTON, Texas, Feb. 7. -- Clarence Clark, Bloomfield, N.J., professional, continued a lucrative Southern campaign today by winning the Colonial Country Club's fifty-four-hole open golf tournament and the first prize of $500, with a score of 220.

HONOLULU, Feb. 7. -- Since the murder of Joseph Kahahawai, which has so upset these smiling islands, the four persons accused of murder, including Mrs. Grace Fortescue and her son-in-law, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, U.S.N., have been kept in seclusion in the Pearl Harbor Navy Yard.

More than 2,700 social workers associated with the Family Welfare Association of America, whose 238 member agencies assisted approximately 4,000,000 individuals during the last year, issued a joint statement through the association yesterday asserting that relief work is not enough to deal with the unemployment problem and urging a program of careful economic planning along national lines.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 7. -- Under the protection of an order issued yesterday by Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church in Newark, the Faramount, Oxford and Strand motion picture theatres, all owned and opirated by the Publix-New Jersey theatre Company, Inc., and associated with the Paramount group, opened their doors this afternoon and continued performances uninterruptedly until closing time.

After setting the pace for the individual scorers in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race since the start of the season, John Siebert, Princeton forward, dropped from the leadership as the result of two circuit games played last Saturday night.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- Stirred by former Governor Smith's announcement, the forces backing Governor Roosevelt prepared today to gird themselves for a stiff fight for the Democratic nomination for President.

Both playwright and actor-director, Messrs. Lenz and Sterni, were at their mirth-provoking, satirical best at the Little Theatre last evening. Mr. Lenz has a fascinating way of extracting certain well-worn garments from the property room of comedy and brushing them up to look like new with many a deft alteration in style so that they are quite a la mode.

Rochester announces through its Mayor that it is proud of a campaign it is now waging to improve business. Two pages in the March Ladies' Home Journal give an account of the plan, with emphasis laid on the part played by organized women.

The report of the Jewel Tea Company, Inc., for the year ended on Jan. 2 describes adjustments made to the decline in prices which illustrates the process many companies had to follow in the period. Net profit of the company in 1931 was 81,363,780, or $4.87 a share, against $1,705,293, or $6.09 a share, in 1930.

More than 100 of the crack yacht racing skippers of Long Island Sound, and ten times as many spectators, gathered at George Ratsey's sail loft pier in City Island yesterday for the contests of the Frostbite Yacht Club.

The Capitol at Albany will present the appearance tomorrow, at least to the mind's eye, of a beleaguered castle. Hosts will march up the hill in protest against the various proposals for new or increased taxes, on which a hearing is to be held.

Sweeping changes in organization and administration of vocational schools in the city as well as in their cooperation with industry, are recommended in the first report of the Vocational Survey Commission, to be made public today. Separate reports on each of the major industries in the city and on special phases of the educational program will be made later.

For the second time since he became chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee Samuel Seabury is to appear before the Court of Appeals in Albany today to seek its aid in forcing balky witnesses to testify.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Senator William E. Borah of Idaho, chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, asserted tonight that the latest suggestion from Paris for a new world organization to enforce peace was "inherently objectionable."

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 8 (AP). -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that Japanese diplomats abroad had been instructed to seek favorable opportunities to broach a scheme for the international demilitarization of zones surrounding the principal commercial centres of China.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Washington comment on the statement of Alfred E. Smith follows:
PRESIDENT JOHN A. HEYDLER of the National League was shuffling some papers on his desk. Had he any views on the holdout situation?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Asserting that Federal efforts to enforce the prohibition laws have cost at least $370,000,000 between January, 1920, and June 30, 1931, and that $10,984,000,000 had been lost in revenue, Henry H. Curran, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, sent letters today to all members of the Senate and House, asking that Congress submit to the nation the question of repealing the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Secretary Mellon announced today that bids on a tender of $75,000,000 in ninety-threeday treasury bills, to be dated Feb. 15, would be received at the Federal Reserve Banks and branches up to 2 P.M. Eastern Standard Time, Thursday, Feb. 11.
HAVANA, Feb. 7 (AP). -- J.E. Smallman's Blue Day won the Jockey Club Handicap, $2,500 added, at Oriental Park today, beating A. Snider's Sultry in a hard drive. W.F. Axton's Monkey Shine was third.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Enactment by Congress of the Federal home loan bank bill, one of the administration relief proposals, may not be pressed by President Hoover, some Republican leaders said tonight, if the Reconstruction Finance Corporation gives material aid to distressed mortgage holders and those provisions of the Glass banking bill under which paper is eligible for rediscount at the Federal Reserve banks are revised to permit additional aid.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Feb. 7 (AP). -- Philadelphia newspapers received so many telephone calls while the Allen jury was out that their employes found, it almost impossible to use the telephone for outgoing calls. Swithboard operators compared the situation to that in world series baseball games and Presidential elections.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- Rounds of applause followed the closing appeal of Winston Churchill in Orchestra Hall this afternoon for a closer union of the English-speaking peoples against "communism and the disintegrating forces of a disunited Europe."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Alfred E. Smith's statement that he will accept a call from the Democratic National Convention to run again for President, which was regarded as making him in fact if not in form an active candidate, was received here today with elation by the Republicans and generally with disfavor by the Democrats.

Percy Grainger, composer and pianist, has been appointed head of the music department of the New York University College of Fine Arts, it was announced yesterday by Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown. Mr. Grainger will succeed Albert Stoessel, who is now head of the opera department of the Juilliard Graduate School.

A London dramatic critic has just made some arresting remarks on the theatre in the United States and in his own country. In a visit to New York he attended fiftythree plays, and he doubts whether more than ten of them would have passed the British censor.

PARIS, Feb. 5. -- The increase of 936,000,000 francs shown by the weekly statement of the Bank of France was for the most part counterbalanced and explained by the decrease of 747,000,000 francs in the bank's foreign balances.
