With this addition to the bank's gold the reserve cover rose from 63.10 per cent to 63.39.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 7. -- Watchful waiting seemed to be the dominating influence last week in the cotton market, and as a result the volume of trading was comparatively small. Although there was a downward trend in the stock markets, the prices for cotton were fairly well maintained, the extreme range of fluctuations being less than $1 a bale and the figures at the week-end showing virtually no net change for the period.

Setting a new national record for the distance, Paul De Bruyn, German marathon champion, won the fifteen-mile run conducted yesterday by the Metropolitan A.A.U. athletes development committee under the auspices of the James J. Tappen Post, American Legion, at the Silver Lake course, Staten Island.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- In offering her plan at Geneva for an international force to insure peace, France intended very seriously to make it possible for the United States to join, it was said today in official quarters.

Perhaps the falling of the last week's stock market into all but motionless apathy indicated, as well as anything else could do, the condition of the financial mind. There had not been the uninterrupted advance since New Year's Day that occurred in the corresponding period of 1931 and 1930, but the early "January rise" had been considerably larger than in either of those two years, and was therefore sooner spent.
GENEVA, Feb. 7. -- With the impetus of world opinion behind it, the Geneva disarmament conference will get well under way tomorrow.

Lotte Lehmann's second concert here within two months gave convincing evidence last night of the truth, of the tradition that there are no bad seasons for great artists. The largest audience that the Town Hall has had this season filled every available seat in the hall and on the stage and included the maximum number of standees permitted by the law.

A Domestic Danger. British, diplomacy seemed at first to be reluctant to go along with American in trying to check Japanese aggression in China. Latterly it has changed into an attitude of cordial cooperation with the United States in this matter.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- War reports and weather conditions are attracting increased attention the Board of Trade here. Most of the speculative traders in wheat fear that a war between China and Japan might involve other nations, especially Russia, and that there would be no foretelling of the final results.

Friends of Mayor Walker and prominent members of Tammany Hall, who last Fall formed the opinion that Controller Charles W. Berry would be a candidate for Mayor in 1933, are more than ever convinced by recent developments that their belief is justified, it was revealed yesterday.

The first dance of The Imperial, a recently formed Monday night dancing club, will be held tonight in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The net proceeds from the series of entertainments will be given to the Social Service Bureau of Bellevue Hospital.
The Virginians of New York will give a reception and supper dance tomorrow night in the small ballroom of the Plaza.

After thirty years of effort to convince the world that war is stupid, that a nation's trade cannot be won by force of arms, and that a province or even half a continent won in war is a poor bargain for the cost, Sir Norman Angell will end a lecture tour of this country on Feb. 18 when he will be guest of honor at an "All-Nations" dinner at the WaldorfAstoria.

A school is to be established in Radio City where talented students may live and receive, either free or at a nominal cost, instruction in dancing, acting and make-up, Samuel L. Rothafel (Roxy) declared yesterday afternoon in a talk at the Dancers' Club, 24 West Fifty-fourth Street.

After conferences that started Saturday afternoon and extended at intervals until last night, attended by officials of the Grace Lines, Chairman T.V. O'Connor of the United States Shipping Board, agents of the Department of Labor and Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, the strike of union workers on the Grace Line pier in Brooklyn was said last night to be virtually settled.

GENEVA, Feb. 7. -- There is some uneasiness here over the disturbance at Memel, not so much on its own account as because it might seem to indicate a growing tendency in a world already upset by events in the Far East.

Danny Hicks, Brooklyn Prep wing, captured, the individual scoring honors among the C.H.S.A.A. players in the fourth annual tournament, the regular schedule of which was brought to a close on Saturday night.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 7. -- C. Lawrence Gregorio, a Camden attorney, has an appointment to go before Governor George E. White of Ohio Tuesday morning to plead for a pardon for Lament Signer, former school board member of Pine Hill Borough, who escaped from an Ohio prison farm sixteen years ago and who, hundreds of petitioners declare, has lived an exemplary life since.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- The memorandum for disarmament which Andre Tardieu has conjured up in Geneva is universally rejected by Germany. An echo from the United States and other countries that do not hold the French theory that might makes right also condemns the plans.

Members of the executive committee of the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop of which Mrs. Samuel Adams Clark is president, will meet this morning at the home of Mrs. Clark, 655 Park Avenue, to make special plans in behalf of the organization. The shop was organized by the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop Association, comprised of auxiliaries of various cancer hospitals in the city, for the benefit of needy patients.

In aid of the Fort Valley School in Georgia, Miss Leslie Frick, mezzosoprano, will give a recital tomorrow afternoon at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street. The assisting artist will be Mrs. John Bates, harpist. The artists are donating their services.

After conferences that started Saturday afternoon and extended at intervals until last night, attended by officials of the Grace Lines, Chairman T.V. O'Connor of the United States Shipping Board, agents of the Department of Labor and Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, the strike of union workers on the Grace Line pier in Brooklyn was said last night to be virtually settled.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- The Racquet and Swimming Club defeated the Field Club of Greenwich, 4 to 1, today in a Class B match in the Westchester group of the Metropolitan League squash racquets tournament.

Thomas Hamilton MacRae, Chicago publisher, died suddenly last night in a small restaurant on the second floor of 34 West Forty-sixth Street. His death was caused by a heart attack believed to have been brought on by the exertion of climbing the steep flight of steps leading to the restaurant.

Alfred E. Smith, standard bearer of the Democratic party in 1928, announced yesterday his willingness to assume that role again in the 1932 campaign. In expressing that willingness he threw open the doors for a nation-wide fight for delegates pledged to him, in opposition to Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Only the industries that reported an output value of $25,000,000 or more are included in the summary.

T.H. Lawrence broke 99 targets to capture high scratch honors at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. A. Happel Jr., who returned a full card in the regular event, annexed the Handicap Trophy in a shoot-off.
The New York Rangers manifested their superiority over the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night by defeating the puck-chasers from the Windy City for the third time this season.

TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 7. -- Shouting to own proposals to demand repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, the Washington Democratic convention today was on record as favoring a referendum on prohibition by the States in what is regarded as a platform plank, favored by Governor Roosevelt of New York.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Augie Kieckhefer of Chicago and Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia will fight it out for the world's three-cushion billiard championship tomorrow night. A prize of $10,000 will be at stake.
Editorial comment on ex-Governor Smith's announcement, as assembled by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press, follows:

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- The financial markets have recovered well during the past few days from their first unfavorable reaction to the ChinoJapanese dispute. While that situation still causes anxiety, financial London now feels that the Far Eastern problem will be solved without seriously Involving other nations.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 7. -- With the investigation into the Dec. 11 break of seven convicts from Leavenworth Penitentiary now substantially completed, Sanford Bates, Superintendent of Federal Prisons, announced here today the appointment of F.G. Zerbst as warden in place of Thomas B. White.

Three benefit performances drew large audiences last night to the Globe, Manhattan and Sari Carroll Theatres. Entertainers from the dramatic and musical stages, the night clubs and the radio studios contributed their services to shows under the sponsorship of the Catholic Actors' Guild, the Columbia broadcasting system and the Broadway-Saranac Relief Fund, respectively.

Greenbacks, half-dollars, quarters, dimes and nickels rained down from the open windows in narrow Mott Street yesterday, the second day of the year 4885 of the Chinese calendar, while the dragon danced in the crowded gutter.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 8. -- Sunday was a disappointing day for the Japanese forces. They made no advances in the Chapei area and although army reinforcements were landed in the Woosung area the Chinese hold upon the Woosung forts was unshaken.

HONOLULU, Feb. 7 (AP). -- A vast fighting force of the air rose out of the horizon at dawn today, delivered a smashing attack on the defenders of the island of Oahu and then wheeled around and disappeared over the bend of the sea toward its floating base in the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Consideration of the Democratic tariff bill, which has been unfavorably reported by the Senate Finance Committee, and of the resolution submitted by Senator Reed, Republican, of Pennsylvania, under which the United States Tariff Commission would investigate the relationship to American tariff rates of the abandonment of the gold standard by several foreign countries, is scheduled to come before the Senate this week.

Famous for its soprano "Bell Song" and pictorially also evoking the Far East, the three-act opera "Lakme", by Leo Delibes, composer of the ballets of "Coppelia" and "Sylvia" and the familiar "Naila" waltz, is announced at the Metropolitan as the last but one of this season's opera revivals.

In a letter to stockholders of the City Stores Company, Dr. Paul H. Saunders, president, announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached regarding the contract recently proposed effecting revisions in the management and indebtedness of the company.

BOMBAY, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The attempted shooting of Sir Stanley Jackson, Governor of Bengal, by a 17-year-old girl has drawn the attention of British authorities to the increasing part women are taking in the struggle against the British [Raj] authority.

The story of the sinking of the Boston fishing schooner Eleanor Nickerson last Friday morning in a blizzard off Le Havre Banks, N.S., and the drowning of twenty-one members of her crew was related by the six survivors who arrived here yesterday on the Belgian steamship Jean Jadot, the vessel that cut their craft in two.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7. -- Views were expressed in the steel trade last October that the long decline in the demand for steel had ended, that Octo- ber would be left behind as the low month of the depression and that any changes henceforth would be for the better.
HAVANA, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The summaries of the second international Star Class yacht race for the Cuba cup follow:

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Feb. 7. -- The declaration by former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York that he was willing to accept the Democratic nomination for the Presidency was accepted by the leaders of the party in this State as presaging a fight for the control of the seventysix delegates to be elected at the primaries in April.

The statement by former Governor Smith left all the Democratic State and city leaders silent last night, but the Republicans were frankly certain that it woud "cause a commotion in the ranks of the other side."

The Welfare Council of New York City, financed entirely by private gifts but devoting itself to coordinating relief on every front, has put forth a summary of what is being done by the various public and private special funds for relief of the families of the unemployed.

Henry Hadley and the Manhattan Symphony Orchestra offered an unusual opportunity for three guest artists assisting at their concert last evening in the ballroom of the new Waldorf-Astoria. Elsa Hilger. 'cellist, was introduced in a concerto by Haydn, and Edna White, trumpet soloist, in one of modern and striking character by Guy Ropartz.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 7. -- A united front and a common policy, even preferably international intervention in China by the great powers, were strongly advocated tonight by Admiral Kiochi Shiozawa in his first discussion of the political significance of the present situation in an interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Washington dispatches describing the first unfavorable reactions of American officialdom to Japan's proposals to demilitarize Chinese ports were received with expressions of surprise and disappointment in Foreign Office circles here today.

Congress leaders have vowed to reduce every appropriation bill submitted to them. At Albany Governor ROOSEVELT succeeded in paring the State budget well below the previous year's total, only to have the Republicans announce that they intended to cut it still further, to the tune of $20,000,000 or more.

Business men, realty interests and financial groups, it was revealed yesterday, are predicting that the heaviest drive in years for a rapid transit fare rise will be well under way within a few months. Their belief is predicated upon the city's present financial condition, under which all public works projects have been curtailed and every effort is being exerted to find new sources of revenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Feb. 3 shows decreases for the week of $13,000,000 in loans and investments. $287,000,000 in net demand deposits and $25,000,000 in time deposits, and an increase of $215,000,000 in government deposits and of $25,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- An investigation by Charles S. Wilson, the United States Minister at Bucharest, was asked today following reports that a former resident of Wilkinsburg, Pa., had been murdered while on a visit to Rumania.
Details of business and residential leaseholds in Manhattan are given in several instruments just recorded in the Register's office.

Amid settings decorated in black and gold, the first dance of The Imperial, a recently formed dancing club, was held last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Subsequent dances will be held there every Monday night. The net proceeds will aid the Social Service Bureau of Bellevue Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A resolution calling on the Department of Justice for an itemized statement of amounts spent each year in the enforcement of prohibition was introduced in the House today by Representative Major of Illinois.

Revival of business is being retarded seriously by extravagance in government expenditures and by the "staggering" burdens of taxation upon industry which result from such extravagance, according to the board of directors of the Broadway Association, which called upon Governor Roosevelt yesterday to assume leadership in placing government on a "sane, economic basis" by making drastic cuts in the proposed budget for New York State.

Passenger traffic to the West Indies on steamships ordinarily operated in the transatlantic service has nearly doubled thus far this season despite cancellations of several cruises. Figures compiled by the North Atlantic Passenger Conference for the period from Dec. 2, 1931, to Jan. 2, show that 10,375 passengers have sailed on thirty-four cruise ships, an increase of 4,415 over the total of 5,960 passengers on twenty-one ships reported for a similar period one year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Direct Federal relief for the unemployed will be asked by organized labor, following a meeting of national and international officers of various unions here tomorrow, according to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.
Ash Wednesday services, marking the first day of Lent, will be held throughout the city tomorrow.
NEW YORK. Mrs. John R. Fell Jr. gave a luncheon yesterday at the St. Regis for Mrs. George Trowbridge Elliman and Miss Winifred Lee.

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- Vionnet closes the season here with a beautiful collection, approving high waist lines and big sleeves. Day skirt lengths are unchanged. For evening wear they are slightly trailing or floor length.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Feb. 9. -- Foreigners and Chinese refugees in the International Settlement were wounded today by badly directed artillery fire both from Chinese and Japanese guns in the battle of Chapei.

The performance of "Face the Music," a new musical comedy by Irving Berlin and Moss Hart, on the night of March 2 at the New Amsterdam Theatre has been taken over for the benefit of the Boys' Club of New York. The net proceeds will be used in the maintenance of that organization, which provides a recreational and educational program for boys.

In an interview that followed on the heels of a conference between Alfred E. Smith and Governor Roosevelt here yesterday the former Governor disavowed any intention of pursuing a "rule or ruin" policy in respect to the Democratic nomination for the Presidency.

A plan, whereby the interallied war debts to the United States might he liquidated in the lateral sense, and through which the citizens of this country might obtain a potable supply of alcoholic beverages, is contained in a "public announcement," published today over the signatures of thirty-three men prominent in financial and industrial life.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Ex-Governor Smith's statement regarding the Presidential nomination caused some sharpshooting in the House today after Representative Blanton, Democrat, of Texas, had told Republicans that they need not be so joyous and that the former Governor had put himself "out of the running before it gets started."

TOKYO, Feb. 8. -- The only proposal Japan intends to make for the settlement of the Shanghai affair, a Foreign Office spokesman said tonight, is the establishment of an internationally guaranteed neutral zone around the city. Rumors that Japan is intriguing with local Chinese to set up a puppet government are described as entirely false.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad had current assets of $8,361,785 and current liabilities of $9,900,049 on Dec. 31, according to a balance sheet filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. A year previously current assets were $11,087,000 and current liabilities $12,263,216.

One of the first results of ex-Governor SMITH'S leap into the Presidential arena is to put a terrible strain upon the great thinkers in Tammany Hall. Thus far they have been silent, communing with, their own hearts. They have no opinions to express about a political event which has started everybody else all over this State and throughout the country to talking and taking sides.

SEATTLE, Wash., Feb. 8 -- Victor Aloysius Meyers shifted his cigar to the other side of his mouth, put a twist in his thin waxed mustache, tilted his silk top-hat a little further back on his black plastered-down hair, shouted a couple of okay's at passing friends, adjusted his bulky overcoat and settled himself down for an interview.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8. -- Celebrities in the world of arts and letters teed off at the Palm Beach Country Club today when the fifth annual tournament of the Artists and Writers Golf Association got under way. Jefferson Machamer of New York leading the qualifying field with a card of 44, 39 -- 83.

The money market displayed no evidence at the resumption of trading in the new week of departing from the quiet and narrow groove within which it has moved during the last month. Business was small and confined to routine requirements, with quotations in all sections developing no change from last week.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read in THE TIMES with interest the letters of Herbert Pell and D. Thauvron, protesting against the views held by many relative to the French nation.

Arrangements to unite the commercial paper business of Hathaway Co. with that of Goldman, Sachs Co. under the name of the latter firm, creating what was reported to be the largest commercial paper business in the country, were announced yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Creation of the proposed North Jersey Metropolitan Regional District, including eight counties and with a borrowing power of $80,000,000, which would finance an elaborate public works program and give work to thousands, thereby relieving unemployment, was recommended today by the State Regional Planning Commission, in its annual report to the Governor and Legislature.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Both in praise of Sir John Simon's Geneva speech and in criticism of the French plan submitted last week by Andre Tardieu, The London Times will say editorially tomorrow that "the conference has now been given a lead which, if followed, will enable it to accomplish practical work of Immense value to the world.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- The French treasury is far from being in the flourishing condition it was in a few years ago, declares Deputy Lucien Lamoureux in the Chamber Finance Commission's report on the budget bill, which will be presented to Parliament tomorrow.

Too much domestic happiness, "too pleasantly softened lives in a too tender world," is marring the quality of the work of some of England's young women novelists, Sylvia Thompson, who at 27 is the author of three popular novels and the mother of two children, said last night in an interview at the Hotel Elysee, 56 West Fifty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- R.K. Smith, Commissioner of the Shipping Board, testified before the House Merchant Marine Committee today that on foreign-flag ship "trips, to nowhere" Americans can get all they want to drink.

GENEVA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Secretary, in an address before the World Disarmament Conference today, attacked the proposal made last week by the French War Minister, Andre Tardieu, calling for the arming of the League of Nations.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8. -- Equaling the course mark established in the recent Lake "Worth tournament, Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N. Y., turned in a brilliant 32, 33 -- 65 today, leading the qualifying test in the twentieth, annual South Florida championship on the Palm Beach Golf Club course.

NANKING, Feb. 8 (AP). -- Chang Fakwel. the noted commander of the equally celebrated Chinese regiment known as "The Ironsides," is reported to be directing the defense operations at the Woosung forts.

WASHINGTON', Feb. 8. -- Information, for banks and other financial Institutions desiring to apply for loans under the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, act was issued today by the corporation in "Circular Number One," which read:

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The first of a group of writers, artists and editors arrived here today from New York to distribute food to destitute miners at Lafollette, Tenn., and Pineville and Harlan, Ky.
DUBLIN, Feb. 8. -- The nominations for the Irish Free State general election resulted today in 240 candidates being named for the 152 seats.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 8. -- A stirring call to arms has been made by the Loyang Government's newly created Military Affairs Committee bearing the signatures of Chiang Kai-shek, "Wang Ching-wei, Feng Yu-hsiang. Chang Hsiao-liang, Ten Hsi-shan and eight others.

Accused of improper conduct in thirty-three cases, David Zirinsky, a Brooklyn lawyer, was ordered disbarred by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday. The court confirmed a report by Official Referee James C. Van Siclen finding that Zirinsky had made a practice of charging property owners excessive amounts for the redemption of tax liens he had bought from the city.

Oscar Straus's "The Chocolate Soldier," so melodiously tailored after Shaw's "Arms and the Man" that its tunes, as whistled in New York streets, drowned the author's protest twenty-odd years ago, was revived last night for this season's fourth visit of the youthful Opera Comique Company at the Heckscher Theatre on upper Fifth Avenue.

An incident in "the wild and merry life" that Abraham Lincoln's law partner William H. Herndon, said Mary Todd Lincoln led her husband, is told in Dale Carnegie's "Lincoln the Unknown," published today by Century. A short time after their marriage, Mr. Carnegie relates, the Lincolns were having breakfast at a boarding house in Springfield, when Lincoln did something, no one remembers what, that Mrs. Lincoln objected to.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Feb. 9 -- For the fourth consecutive day Japanese naval and military plans and prophecies were astonishingly upset by the tenacity of the Chinese defense. Monday night found the Woosung situation still unsolved, while the Japanese lines on the Chapei and Hongkew front were not materially changed, despite a furious battle with an enormous expenditure of munitions.

TRENTON. N.J.. Feb. 8. -- Federal Judge William Clark today ordered Lewis J. Tutt, Deputy Prohibition Administrator for this district, to explain tomorrow why the government agents do not arrest the "higher-ups" in cases of liquor-law violations.

A grave problem is presented by real estate bonds which, in the past few years, have been so widely distributed to small investors throughout the country and which are now exposed to racketeering reorganization, according to Francis K. Stevens, vice president of Brown.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- France announced a new quota today on canned peas, string beans, carrots and tomatoes, restricting importations for the first quarter of 1932. American importations into France of those products are unimportant.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 8 -- About 130 candidates reported to the Harvard crew coaches at Newell boathouse as the first official practice was held today.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 -- The Democrats in the Boston City Council broke sharply with Mayor Curley today and unanimously endorsed the Presidential candidacy of Alfred E. Smith, in the face of the Mayor's support of Governor Roosevelt.

HONOLULU, Feb. 8 -- The "struggle for the recovery of the Hawaiian Islands for the United States" in the annual army and navy war games continued today to be tense, with both the "Black" defenders and "Blue" attackers sparring cautiously for an opening which would bring into play the full forces of both sides.

Plans to beautify Claremont Park, to make this city-owned tract a fit neighbor for Riverside Church, Grant's Tomb and International House, have been completed and will be carried out at the expense of John D. Rockefeller Jr., it was learned yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 8 (AP). -- Everywhere in this city are soldiers and refugees -- in the cabarets, the clubs, the public buildings, even in the apartment houses.

The question of whether a city magistrate is also a public censor was raised yesterday in Yorkville Court when Harris Mace, who runs a a news stand in Forty-second Street near the main entrance to the Grand Central Terminal was arraigned on a charge of selling indecent literature.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Can we not apply a few general principles to that confused and rapidly moving series of events at Shanghai and thus organize our thinking with respect to them?

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Hoover's anti-hoarding drive is too reminiscent of some previous campaigns to suggest the probability of much direct success, but at the same time it stimulates an interesting line of thought.

Upon retirement of C. C. Nobles, president of the Winged Foot Golf Club at Mamaroneck for the last ten years, members of the famous Westchester Club, scene of the 1929 national open championship, elected Rudolph O. Haubold head of the organization at the annual meeting, it was announced yesterday by Robert J. Murray, secretary.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Feb. 9 -- A nine-point program for the limitation and reduction of armaments was presented on behalf of the United States today to the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva by Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson in his opening speech to the conference as acting chairman of the American delegation.

Ideals of patriotism would be emphasized and preserved better by combining many of the societies whose activities are devoted to that end, General Louis W. Stotesbury told members of the New York City Society of the Dames of the Loyal Legion yesterday at the society's silver anniversary meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Governor Roosevelt returned to Albany this evening, fresh from his talk with former Governor Smith. He appeared to be in great good humor when he received the newspaper correspondents an hour later. But he declined to shed any light on what had been discussed in the conversation in his New York City home.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- It was Mark Twain who once remarked that "people often complain about the weather, but no one ever does anything about it." In like fashion the Europeans have been complaining about the American style of speed skating, but no one has offered a real solution.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange here was generally steady in undertone again yesterday. Prices receded early under a little Southern selling and liquidation, but offerings were absorbed by a continuance ot trade buying or covering and prices fluctuated within a range of 4 or 5 points.

Announcement that $100,000 was "in sight," in gifts of $1,000 each, to support the American Legion's "million jobs in sixty days" campaign, was made yesterday afternoon by Henry L. Stevens Jr., national commander, after a meeting of the National Employment Commission of the Legion at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Twelve families and their house hold effects were moved into the street yesterday from their apartments at 665 Allerton Avenue, the Bronx, an arbitration committee having failed to settle a strike for a 15 per cent reduction in rent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP). -- Two United States destroyers have been ordered from Shanghai up the Yangtse River, one to augment forces at Nanking and the other to be stationed at Chingkiang.

A single agency in Washington the Veterans' Administration, spends more than one-fourth of all the funds used by the Federal Government. In the estimates submitted to Congress by the President this bureau is allotted $1,072,064,527 for the fiscal year which begins next June, out of a total of approximately $4,000,000,000 in the budget.

Plans of the American International Corporation to acquire control of the Reliance International Corporation through an exchange of stock have not materialized as expected because of a failure of stockholders of the latter company to deposit the required amount of stock.

BERLIN, Feb. 8. -- A popular referendum to decide the future political status of Memel Territory is demanded by the Memel Landbund. the organization of the German population of Memel, in a letter to President von Hindenburg.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Feb. 9 -- The text of Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson's opening speech, delivered before the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva this morning, follows:
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 8 -- Winnie Ruth Judd was convicted by a jury tonight of the murder of Agnes Anne Leroi. The penalty is death by hanging. Feb. 23 was set as the date for sentence.

Supporters of prohibition were likened to the Pharisees of the New Testament by the Rev. Dr. Robert Norwood, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, in an address at the second annual victory luncheon of the New York State Division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.
Unlisted security prices wavered in the early trading yesterday, but later recovered, with minor losses on the day.

The demand of the Printers' League for a 20 per cent wage reduction is "simply preposterous" and "will not be considered by Typographical Union No. 6" was the answer made yesterday by Austin Hewson, president of the union, to the employing printers.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The prospect of David Lloyd George, former Liberal chief, as leader of a crusade against the British Government's new tariff policy was presented to members of Parliament tonight.

Probably it is unfortunate that daily financial reports have to give so prominent a place on all occasions to the movement of stocks and bonds. There are times when one or the other or both of those markets are the significant part of the financial picture, and indicate what is presumably happening elsewhere.

Working on a lead which they refused to make known, detectives left Police Headquarters yesterday to search out of town for the machine gunner who, in the early morning, left the riddled body of Vincent Coll "on the spot" in a West Twenty-third Street drug store.

The New York State Pharmaceutical Association, meeting yesterday in the Commodore, adopted a resolution favoring the passage of the Capper-Kelly fair trade bill now before Congress. The measure would permit manufacturers of trade-mark articles to make contracts with wholesalers and retailers specifying minimum prices to be charged by retailers.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 8 -- Harvard's varsity swimmers won their fourth straight dual meet of the season tonight from the combined Megill-Toronto University teams by 54 to 17.

Sales of cars of the General Motors Corporation to consumers in the United States in January totaled 47,942 units, against 61,566 in the corresponding month of last year and 53,588 in December, it was announced yesterday. Normally, sales in January are above those in the preceding month.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Governor A. Harry Moore and his fellow members of the newly reorganized State House Commission ordered an Investigation today when they discovered that New Jersey has a $6,000 a year superintendent with no institution to operate, and an appropriation of $2,000 for food with no inmates to feed.

An eleven-day strike of union longshoremen at the Grace Line pier, in Brooklyn, was settled yesterday morning at a conference of steamship officials and the International Longshoremen's Association at the offices of the line, 10 Hanover Square.

Stockholders in the closed Bank of United States have until Feb. 27 to subscribe to stock of the corporation that is to be organized under the so-called Untermyer plan for the liquidation of the assets of the bank, according to an announcement yesterday at the law office of Samuel Untermyer, 30 Pine Street.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The stock markets again were extremely quiet today and the general tone was dull. Foreign exchange was quiet. After opening at $3.45 1/4, sterling on New York fell back to $3.45. In British Government funds the war loan dropped to u98 1/4.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Dispatches from Nanking today disclosed that the government, temporarily functioning at Loyang, had succeeded in uniting the several political factions in the face of Japan's activities here. The country has been divided into four military zones, with Chiang Kai-shek coordinating all commands.

Hisses and boos mingled with cheers and applause last night at Carnegie Hall, when pacifism and militarism, came to grips before a capacity audience under the auspices of the New History Society. When it was all over, with wars refought and history revised, the listeners took the subject unto themselves and went away arguing.

GENEVA, Feb. 8 -- The fixing of maximum limits on armaments beyond which the assembled nations would bind themselves not to go and the exclusion by international agreement of certain instruments and methods of warfare were put forward today by Sir John Simon, Great Britain's spokesman, as the two chief objectives of the World Disarmament Conference.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 8 -- In his report to the Governor and the New Jersey Legislature, made public here today, Chester I. Barnard, State director of emergency relief, estimates the total personal aid required at this time to meet conditions due to depression at $250,000,000 per annum.

MANILA, Feb. 8 -- Responsible political leaders are extremely skeptical over a cable displayed by the Philippine Civic Union, the most active independence society, purporting to come from the delegates at Washington.

In honor of the imminent bicentenary of the birth of George Washington, the Macy Art Gallery has assembled what it believes to be "the most comprehensive sales exhibition of prints of Washington portraiture ever held in New York City." Nearly 500 items are on view, including prints after all but a few of the forty-five portraits for which Washington sat during his life.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Bearish statistics on the world's wheat situation, which were credited to the Department of Agriculture, more than offset today everything of a strengthening character in the market for that grain on the Board of Trade here and resulted in net losses of 3/8 to 5/8 cents a bushel.

BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- The speech of Andre Tardieu at Geneva impresses German newspapers as a most complete and unequivocal enumeration of all the arguments which have been presented by French statesmen in the course of years and which up to now are held to have made disarmament impossible.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 8. -- One of the enigmas of the present situation is: What has become of the student movement?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Bus traffic over the Camden-Philadelphia highway bridge was cited by a large New Jersey delegation here today as an illustration of the need for Federal regulation of interstate passenger bus transportation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Secretary Hurley will give his views on Philippine independence, based on his recent visit to the islands, at an open hearing of the Senate Committee on Territories and Insular Affairs on Thursday morning.

CALDWELL, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Under the feeble beams of hastily procured flashlights, Dr. E.C. Butler continued an emergency operation on Mrs. Benjamin Pfitzenmayer of Central Avenue, West Caldwell, after the electric lights in his private hospital at 249 Bloomfield Avenue had gone out just as he had made the first incision.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 8 (AP) -- William J. Ruof, former vice president of the First Central Trust Company of Akron, pleaded guilty today to embezzlements stated to have run as high as $400,000. He was sentenced to sixteen years' imprisonment and fined $24,000 by Federal Judge Samuel H. West.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Gill Robb Wilson, State Director of Aviation, declared today he did not construe the opinion of Common Pleas Judge Hartshorne of Newark as relating to other than the powers of the commission to make laws. The primary function of the commission, he pointed out, was to develop aviation and promote safety.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The House authorized today by a practically unanimous vote a broad investigation of all factors in the depression of silver, including a survey of the monetary systems of the world.

Candidates must not only walk but talk warily amid the pitfalls of radio and newsreel. Governor ROOSEVELT has been kindly reproached by a North Carolina woman reporter who has detected him, or thinks she has, in two mispronunciations. He is accused of putting the accent on the penult of "initiative," a mystic ritual word like "referendum," and of being false to the true quantity of ultimate "a" in the noun "associates."

GENEVA, Feb. 8. -- Just a week after the Council of the League of Nations assembled urgently at the demand of Great Britain it heard the British spokesman state that it was "impossible that the present position in the Far East be allowed to continue" and that Britain and the United States were therefore taking formal measures to end it.

In this instance the orders are for an advance along the entire national front in a united attack on "depression" by the American Legion and the Federation of Labor, with auxiliary forces. The objective is to find a million new jobs within thirty days for a million wage earners now unemployed.

The city of Detroit, faced with $7,500,000 of notes maturing a week from today and in need of $5,900,000 additional for current expenses, has just five business days in which to satisfy bankers here and in Chicago that it has been able to balance its budget if it is to obtain the full amount by the time set.

Madison Square Garden saw a unique spectacle last night. It was neither a boxing nor a wrestling match, although one of these events had been bought off for the occasion. The match was between a pianist and a piano, with the pianist victorious.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Coincident with the statement of Alfred E. Smith that he was a receptive candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, two definite moves developed today to prevent Governor Roosevelt of New York from getting the nomination and to deadlock the convention, at least for several ballots.

During the Spring term of the public schools, which started yesterday, pupils are scheduled to participate in many of the exercises to be held in connection with the Washington bicentennial. School children will provide entertainment one hour each school day at the exhibition in the Arnold Constable Building, Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street, beginning on Feb. 22 and continuing through Feb. 25.

Bond prices sagged again on the Stock Exchange yesterday in the slowest trading for a full five-hour day since Nov. 11. Yesterday's turnover amounted to only $8,010,800, compared with $8,002,000 on Nov. 11. The only group to run counter to the general market was United States Government bonds which were bid up 2-32 to 14-32 points with the exception of one issue, the Treasury 4 1/4s.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Leo Lermond, America's mile champion, who ran a 4:12 mile in following the footsteps of the record-shattering Gene Venzke, came hack to the track tonight at the golden anniversary games of the New Jersey Chapter, Knights of Columbus, in the 113th Infantry Regiment Armory, to capture the one-mile invitation run for the Charles P. Gillen Trophy, which was one of the features of the meet.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Dr. Hamilton Holt, president of Rollins College, spoke this afternoon on "Our Adventure in Common-Sense Education" before a large audience of invited guests at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Seligman. Dr. Holt explained the conference plan of instruction, which he introduced at Rollins six years ago when he assumed the presidency, as opposed to the generally used lecture system.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- The Bourse session was quiet today without important price variations. The Bank of France and a few other leaders were stronger, while Rio Tinto Copper weakened. Trading did not at any time become active.
No transactions were recorded yesterday on the Real Estate Securities Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Dr. Daniel A. Poling, chairman of the Allied Campaigners for Prohibition, said today that he held " a downright belief that a majority of the voters are with us for the Eighteenth Amendment," but he added that "tens of thousands -- I myself -- won't vote solely on the issue."

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The British National Government brushed aside a motion of censure tonight by a vote in the House of Commons of 438 against 39. There were 138 absentees. After this interlude Parliament will resume tomorrow the debate on the tariff resolution, which the government is bound to carry by a vote of similar proportions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Secretary Stimson, in a message today to Lord Lytton of Great Britain, chairman of the League of Nations Far Eastern Commission of Inquiry, which will arrive in New York on the steamer Paris tomorrow en route to the Orient, extended cordial greetings to the delegation.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Both houses of the Legislature moved swiftly tonight under the high-speed program of the current session.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Beams of sunlight broke through black, low-hanging clouds this after noon and struck an American flag as it rose for the fourth time to the top of the central mast of the Stadium in token of Olympic victory. Irving Jaffee of New York had just scored a stirring triumph in the 10,000-meter final, giving the United States a clean sweep of the Olympic speed Skating championships.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Receivers were appointed today by Federal Judge George A. Carpenter for Mills Sons, promoters of Westwood and building developers. Laurence H. Mills, secretary of the company, and William W. Wheelock, an attorney, were named by the court.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Augie Kieckhefer of Chicago won the world's three-cushion billiard championship tonight by defeating Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia, 60 to 27, in 40 innings.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Henri Matisse, one of France's greatest living painters, is just finishing in his studio at Nice a mural fourteen by forty feet which he expects to be recognized as his greatest canvas.

A Salvation Army chaplain, according to the police, yesterday identified Fred Hicks, Negro-Indian halfbreed who is being held in connection with the strangling of Florence McDonnell, 5 years old, as the "dark man" he saw last Wednesday afternoon talking to a little girl on the steps of the house at 232A Ralph Avenue, Brooklyn, in the cellar of which Florence's body was found last Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President and Mrs. Hoover entertained tonight in honor of the army and navy at the last state reception of the season.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 8 -- At the annual luncheon here today of the New Jersey Press Association, the yearly scholarship prize of $100 went to Henry W. Bagley of Catskill, N. Y., as the senior in the journalism class at Rutgers University giving the greatest promise of usefulness.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- "Julius Caesar," which was presented magnificently tonight, after the fashion of Sir Herbert Beerbohm Tree, in His Majesty's Theatre, with realistic scenic effects, was hailed as a triumph. Oscar Asche, Lily Brayton, Godfrey Tearle, Baliol Holloway, Basil Gill and Lyn Harding were included in the cast but not Sir Harry Armstrong, who withdrew owing to the pressure of private work.

If Japan's activities in Manchuria and Shanghai were not so poignantly real it would be allowable to speak of a fantastic atmosphere encompassing the whole adventure. Unexpected military moves are followed by bewildering explanations and breath-taking proposals.

A psychiatrist, a lawyer and a historian appraised Abraham Lincoln last night, and offered the opinions that the former President was "an incurable legal romanticist," "downright lazy," and "incapable of limpid, straightforward thinking." They spoke at the 403rd regular meeting of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103rd Street.

A change in the Industrial list of stocks, carried in THE NEW YORK TIMES averages, was deemed advisable. American Smelting and Refining, General Motors and Union Carbide and Carbon stocks, heretofore multiplied, have been dropped, and Detroit Edison, General Motors and Peoples Gas of Chicago stocks, without any multiplication, have been substituted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The depression problem of the United States cannot be solved from Washington, according to Colonel Frank Knox of Chicago, who arrived today to direct President Hoover's campaign to get hoarded money back into circulation.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 8 -- All the spiritual forces of the church must be mobilized to bring the comforts of faith, religion and hope to the multitudes of all countries who are suffering terrible hardships in the present hard times, said Pope Pius, speaking today to Lenten preachers.

The pamphlet report of the Hartford Electric Light Company for 1931 shows a net income of $2,621,466, after taxes, charges and depreciation, equal to $3.12 a share earned on 840,000 capital shares, comparing with $2,674,600, or $3.18 a share earned in 1930.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- The body of Dorothy Lutz, 7 years old, who disappeared last Wednesday, was found today in an upstairs bedroom of a vacant dwelling seven doors from her own home at 1,007 North American Street here. She had been assaulted and strangled to death.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Special committees were named tonight by the Senate and Assembly to cooperate with one named by the New Jersey League of Municipalities in a nonpartisan effort to further Governor Moore's plans to relieve municipal financial stress and the burden of taxpayers by direct return of $16,500,000 of road funds and other means.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Renewed weakness today in the securities of the Insull companies has again centred attention on the position and outlook of the various operating and investment concerns in that group. The selling spread today to shares of the Insull operating companies, which are not affected directly by the problems of the two investment trusts, Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- A new low mark for hogs since June, 1899, was established today, when the average dropped 5 cents from Saturday's price to $3.75 a hundredweight. The top of $4.10 for the day equaled the previous low point for the season. Receipts, while somewhat below the average for this season of the year, were 30,000 larger than a week ago.

In the hardest fought match of the tournament to date Edwin Muller of the Princeton Club defeated W. Murray Lee of the Columbia University Club last night in the second round of the national veterans' squash tennis championship at the Princeton Club.

BASLE, Switzerland, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Board of the Bank for International Settlements voted today to help South American central banks maintain the gold standard, and instructed President Gates W. McGarrah to prepare a plan extending its services to the South American continent.

Any movement which would rid New York City of corruption such as has been revealed by the Seabury investigation must recruit its leaders from the dominant political party, according to Charles P, Taft 2d, son of the late President.

Dr. George W. Stoner of 84 Norwood Avenue, Stapleton, S.I., retired senior surgeon of the United States Public Health Service, died on Sunday at the United States Marine Hospital in Baltimore. He was 77 years old.

DeWitt Clinton High won its first Bronx P.S.A.L. basketball game yesterday, defeating Evander Childs High on the Evander court, 20 -- 19. Clinton staged its main scoring attack just before half-time, holding a 16-to-10 lead at the close of the second period.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A rehearing of the issues involved in the proposed acquisition by the Southern Pacific Company of the St. Louis-Southwestern Railroad or Cotton Belt was requested in a petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Missouri Pacific and the Texas Pacific roads.

Greensboro, N.C. The city of Greensboro, N.C., has arranged for a renewal until Sept. 1 of slightly less than $1,000,000 of its 6 per cent notes, which will mature on Monday. It is part of a total issue of $3,310,000 of bond-anticipation notes issued last October to take care of maturing paper.

BOGOTA, Feb. 8 -- A contract whereby all Colombian States and cities carrying foreign loans, except Barranquilla, agree with the National Government for the government to issue 6 per cent scrip exchangeable for maturing interest coupons of the cities' and States' foreign bonds, was approved by a Presidential decree on Feb. 4, according to the text partly published in tonight's press.

The city's hurrying throngs were startled yesterday noon to have thrust into their hands copies of a newspaper. A cursory glance showed that it called itself the "Herald Times," and just below the name was an eight-column streamer reporting "Hoover Demands Prohibition Repeal."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The circular issued by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, giving information for railroads and receivers thereof desiring to apply for loans under the act, reads as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- With the machinery for making loans from its $2,000,000,000 fund already in operation, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today began sending circulars to all institutions and companies eligible for loans under the law, instructing them as to the procedure to be followed in applying for financial assistance.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 8 -- The Walsh bill, introduced recently in Congress, "is a most constructive step toward the matter of revising our anti-trust laws," H.W. Davis of the University of Pennsylvania told members of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers in the annual convention here today.

In the feature bout of six rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night, Milton Krompier of the Bronx, 133 1/4 pounds, defeated Frankie McKenna of the west side, 134. The decision was well received by the crowd of 2,000.

Fifty years of service in the New York postoffice by William T. Gutgsell, 70-year-old superintendent of the Inquiry Section, will be celebrated at a dinner in his honor by Mr. Gutgsell's associates, headed by Postmaster John J. Kiely, on Thursday evening at the Cornish Arms Hotel, 311 West Twenty-third Street, it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Andre Tardieu, French Minister of War, warned the World Disarmament Conference today that until the League of Nations was armed there would be no assured peace in the world. M. Tardieu spoke following Sir John Simon, head of the British delegation, who attacked the French plan for arming the League.
''The Fatal Alibi," starring Charles Laughton, will open tonight at the Booth Theatre. At the same time Maurice Chevalier, French stage and screen star, will begin an engagement at the Fulton.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city.

HAVANA, Feb. 8 -- Dave Atwater's yacht, Moonshine, of the Narragansett Bay fleet, captured the Bacardi Cup today, finishing the three-race Star class series with a point score of 47 out of a possible 48.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- To help put the virtually bankrupt producers of French talking pictures on their feet again, American, and German manufacturers of sound film recording equipment have agreed after a tenday meeting here to a reduction in royalties of at least 25 per cent and in some cases even more.

Four additional justices for the Municipal Court and three additional judges for the City Court in the Bronx were demanded yesterday by the November, 1931, term of the Bronx grand jury in a presentment to Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan which asserted there was a complete breakdown in the administration of justice in these courts because of delays in reaching trials.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The seventh round of the international chess tournament was contested today at the rooms of the Empire Social Chess Club. The winners were Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of France, world's champion, and Mir Sultan Khan of India.

MONTREAL, Feb. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Steadily adding to his assists records, R.J. (Hooley) Smith of the Montreal Maroons continues to dominate the point-makers of the National Hockey League, according to averages issued tonight from the office of President Frank Calder.

To the Editor of The New York Times: All along I have been a Roosevelt advocate for the Democratic nomination in June -- until I read his pronouncement on the League of Nations. Mr. Roosevelt followed Senator Morrow in advocating the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The expenditures of Federal, State and local government should be cut sufficiently to reduce taxes 20 to 35 per cent as speedily as may be legislatively possible. Senator Corell Hull, Democrat, of Tennessee, asserted in a Senate speech today.
Teams from the University of California and Columbia, meeting in the John Jay Social Room at Columbia, debated the question: "Resolved, That President Hoover should be returned to the White House."

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 8 -- A measure which would set up a "credit board" of twelve members headed by the State Banking Commissioner, and assure the permanent liquidity of the assets of Building and Loan Associations by a pool of reserve funds, was introduced in the Assembly tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Avowing that responsibility for mounting tax burdens must be placed upon the local governments, Governor Roosevelt said tonight in a radio address broadcast by WGY that he was taking a firm stand against further State contributions to localities until they had effected necessary economies in their own field.

HONOLULU, Feb. 8. -- Mrs. Thotnas H. Massie will remain here to testify at the retrial of four men of mixed blood accused ou attacking her, she said today in her first public statement since the alleged attack last September.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 8 -- First returns from a State-wide poll which is being conducted by The Des Moines Register and Tribune put President Hoover in the lead by only a narrow margin. He is being strongly pushed by Governor Murray of Oklahoma, while Governor Roosevelt of New York is a good third.

The exhibition of modern architecture opens to museum members today and to the public tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art in the Heckscher Building. The material, which consists of models and photographs, will remain on view until March 23.

Manhattan. BROPHY. KATHERINE (Feb. 2). Estate, more than $20,000. To the Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent De Paul, Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson, and Missionary Society of St. Paul the Apostle, 415 West Fifty-ninth Street, $25,000 each; Catholic Foreign Missionary Society of America, Ossining, N.Y.; Dominican Sisters of the Poor, 140 East Sixty-first Street; House of Good Sheperd.

Five small boys living on the lower East Side discovered late yesterday that one may enter a theatre without being in it, and that the easiest way to get out of a tight spot is not to get in it, In the first place.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8 -- The consistent Jaz Age, which races for J. Pannalee, gained his fourth victory in six Florida starts, when he captured the Ocala Claiming Handicap, feature at Hialeah Park today, under a vigorous ride by Jockey Buddy Hanford.

Four members of the commission appointed by the League of Nations to report on the dispute" between China and Japan over Manchuria arrive here tonight in the French liner Paris en route to the Far East.

Spring Lines Gaining Headway. Orders for early Spring merchandise received in the market here yesterday gained in volume as compared with a week ago, with the ready-to-wear lines meeting more definite buying interest as the fashion trends crystallize, both manufacturers and buyers here reported yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Five officers of the American Bond Mortgage Company of New York and Chicago went on trial in Federal Court today on charges of misusing the mails. They are accused of making false representations in the sale of second mortgage bonds of the Mayflower Hotel Company of Washington.

Whatever their personal feelings about Mr. HOOVER, Eastern Republican leaders have never seriously considered any other course than sending to the Chicago Convention delegations instructed for the President. There has been occasional talk, and perhaps secret hope, of miracles performed in the names of COOLIDGE, or DAWES. But one by one these and others have been eliminated from the nomination picture.

Price movements on the Stock Exchange yesterday conformed to the pattern of last week and Wall Street displayed just about the same amount of interest. Transactions ran up to 1,150,000 shares, compared with 1,082,000 on Friday, the last five-hour day of the previous week.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Samuel Seabury asked the Court of Appeals today to send Dr. William F. Doyle and State Senator John A. Hastings to jail for contempt of the Hofstadter committee. The court reserved decision.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Japan's suggestion for revising the Nine-Power Treaty of 1922 concerning China by eliminating Manchuria from its scope and for demilitarizing under neutral supervision the chief ports of China will be promptly rejected if it is ever formally presented to the United States Government, according to all indications given today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Not since the break between Taft and Roosevelt in 1912 has the estrangement of two men in public life, formerly close friends, so interested "Washington as the breach between Alfred E. Smith and Governor Roosevelt, now apparently widened irremediably by Mr. Smith's statement announcing his receptive candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President.

Joint action by the United States and Great Britain to overcome the international economic depression was urged last night by Winston Churchill, former British Chancellor of the Exchequer, in an address before the Economic Club at the Hotel Astor, when Mr. Churchill outlined a program of economic and financial cooperation between the two nations as an essential step toward world rehabilitation.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb., 8. (AP). -- Waite C. Hoyt, veteran pitcher and shining star of many an American League and world's series battle, today was unconditionally released by the Philadelphia Athletics.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8 (AP) -- J.J. Robinson's string of successes at the Fair Grounds was lengthened today with the victory of Flying Don in the Lake Maurepas Purse.

Plans for making the debenture issues of the Federal Intermediate Credit Banks system eligible collateral for fifteen-day loans by the Federal Reserve Banks to member banks, and for authorizing the former system to accept notes, drafts and bills of exchange drawn by farmers' cooperative marketing associations, were announced yesterday by Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent for the system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The nomination of Ogden L. Mills to be Secretary of the Treasury, in succession to Andrew W. Mellon, who has been appointed Ambassador to Great Britain, and of Arthur A. Baliantine to replace Mr. Mills as Under-Secretary of the Treasury, were transmitted to the Senate today by President Hoover.
One More Unfortunate. The hotels and restaurants of a city, although they are commercial enterprises, become after many years as representative and identifying as the parks and the museums.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 8 -- Newton D. Baker and Mrs. Baker left Mexico City this evening by train for Vera Cruz, where they will embark in the morning on the Ward liner Orizaba for Havana. They will go direct from there to New York.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8. -- The Soviet belief that events in China will lead to joint action by the great powers to suppress revolutionary or even nationalist movements was further illustrated today by an article from the London correspondent in Red Star, the army newspaper.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Funds to continue the work of the State Housing Board would be reincluded in the budget before its adoption this week, it was understood here today.

The Yale Club Class C squash tennis team qualified for the final round play-off for the championship of this division last night when it defeated the Bayside Tennis Club in the semi-finals on the courts of the Columbia University Club, 5 to 2. The proteges of Frank Lafforgue will meet the Elizabeth Town and Country Club for the title Monday evening at a club to be decided upon.
The sharpest decline in employment since 1921 is indicated in figures compiled by the State Department of Labor and made public here yesterday by Frances Perkins, Industrial Commissioner.

HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Bess Cloi, a 4-year-old filly owned by J. E. Smallman of London, Ont., carried off the major honors of an all-claiming program at Oriental Park today, winning a six-furlong sprint for 3-year-olds and up.

Sergei Rachmaninoff's recital at the Town Hall last night was the third in the endowment series. The program included Mozart's Sonata 14, an old French gavotte and a gavotte by Gluck arranged by Pauer; a ballade, a nocturne, a rondo and a scherzo by Chopin; two preludes by the pianist, Liszt's "Valse oubliee" and "Voices of the Wood" and the Strauss-Tausig valse-caprice, "One Lives but Once."

The trial of Sheriff Thomas M. Farley on an indictment charging grand larceny growing out of his conversion to his own bank account of interest on funds held by him pending litigation was set for Feb. 23 by Judge Otto A. Rosalsky in General Sessions Court yesterday.

Filippo Ricci yesterday sold the two-story brick garage on a plot 50 by 95 feet at 343-45 Newark Avenue, southeast corner of Merseles Street, Jersey City, assessed at $24,600, to Domenico A. and Maria M. Mustillo.

Stocks on the New York Curb Exchange were subjected yesterday to slow but persistent selling pressure. Trading was dull, however, and final quotations disclosed only a few losses of striking size. On the average, the net declines were only moderate.

Sections of the new union inland freight terminal that the Port of New York Authority is building on the block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets will be ready for use by the railroads late this Summer for the handling of less-than-carload freight, according to an announcement yesterday.

TOKYO, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Junnosuke Inouye, eminent financier, liberal statesman and leader of the Minseito (opposition) party's campaign for the general election Feb. 20, was assassinated tonight by a youth who is, at least, indirectly connected with the reactionary "patriotic" elements responsible for most of the political murders that have blackened Japan's recent history.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 9. -- At the close of the twelfth day of the indecisive Sino-Japanese hostilities, Shanghai's 3,000,000 population, except for the nerve-shattered, hysterical, shell-shocked cases, are regarding the state of warfare along the borders of the International Settlement with equanimity.

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- Spirited debate today marked the reception by the Chamber of Deputies of the 1932 budget which according to the reporter of the committee, Deputy Lucien Lamoureux, will probably be in deficit by 4,000,000,000 francs [$160,000,000].

Following several conferences with real estate owners, William F. Deegan, Tenement House Commissioner, announced last night that a bill had been introduced in both branches of the Legislature to amend the multiple dwelling law so that the time limit provided for the completion of expensive alterations to existing buildings would be moved forward to April, 1933.

Out of the excavations which will help to transform the site of old Fort Tryon into a spacious park have come relics of the time when that Washington Heights territory was torn with the Colonies' struggle for independence.

An organized effort to improve traffic conditions in Bark Avenue, with a view particularly of lessening the danger to pedestrians, has been started by property owners and busiess men of the district under the leadership of the Fifth Avenue Assoiation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Because of the extraordinary demands upon his time in the campaign to restore business and industry, President Hoover announced this afternoon that for the next few months he will not participate in formal White House receptions.

Captain Sir Malcolm Campbell, bolder of the world's speed automobile record, arrived yesterday from England on the Cunarder Berengaria on his way to Daytona Beach, Fla., to try to break his former record in his car Bluebird, which arrived a week ago.

It is announced that the international exhibition in Venice (a biennial) will open April 28, remaining until Nov. 4. Nations participating are the United States, Great Britain, France, Russia, Austria, Japan, Spain, Belgium, Holland, Denmark, Czechoslovakia, Switzerland, Poland, Hungary and Italy.
LONDON, Feb. 9. -- General resolutions assuring the adoption of a general 10 per cent tariff by Great Britain, effective March 1, passed the House of Commons tonight by a vote of 452 to 76.

Art and antique dealers of this country were urged to maintain the highest ethical standards by William Sloane Coffin, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in an address last night in the Hotel St. Regis at a dinner of the Antique and Decorative Arts League, Inc., which includes among its members some of the leading art and antique dealers in this country.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- Proof of the existence of an Anglo-American alliance "unrecorded by document or signature -- an indestructible alliance of temperament, of language and of inevitability," as The Daily Express will say editorially tomorrow, is held to have been given by Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson at Geneva today when he revealed that the United States's view on disarmament is "practically identical with that of Great Britain."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- A formal appeal for Federal aid to the unemployed, including the enactment of the Costigan-La Follette bill appropriating $375,000,000 for relief purposes, was presented to President Hoover this afternoon by more than 100 leaders of organized labor on behalf of 5,000,000 union members, following an all-day conference at the American Federation of Labor headquarters, where the program, was drafted.

LONDON, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press). -- The Parliament of Canada has the right to regulate and control radio communication in the Dominion, the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council decided today in dismissing the appeal of the Attorney General of Quebec from the decision of the Supreme Court of Canada.

LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- In the eighth round of the international chess tournament at the Empire Social Chess Club today Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of France, leader in the competition and world's champion, drew with Maroczy of Hungary. In an adjourned game from the fifth round Alekhine defeated Buerger of England.

The executive committee of the Building Trades Council of Greater New York, Long Island and Vicinity, on behalf of about 115,000 building trades mechanics and their assistants, voted yesterday to reject "absolutely and unqualifiedly" the proposal of the Building Trades Employers' Association that the workers take a wage reduction of 25 to 30 per cent beginning May 1, when the present contract will expire.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noted with interest the article on the front page of THE NEW YORK TIMES entitled "Artist Financiers Got $250,000 in 1929, Turn It Into $400,000 Despite Depression."

The revival of Leo Delibes's "Lakme" with Lily Pons in the leading role and the season's first appearance of Clarence Whitehill will mark the sixteenth week of the current Metropolitan Opera season next week. Mr. Whitehill has been personating George Washington recently in the filming of episodes of "Washington's life in connection with the bicentennial celebration now under way.

Stocks fluctuated slightly yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange, transactions in most groups resulting in fractional declines. Domestic lends were mixed, while the more active of the foreign issues showed a small improvement.

The time for regulation or commercial motor vehicle operation is now, J.J. Pelley, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, said yesterday in an interview in the offices of the company here. Railroad companies could not be expected to plan new large capital investments until they knew when unregulated or subsidized competition would cease, he added.

Cupid, about whom poets have sung since the first wandering minstrel strummed his lyre, will trip in dots and dashes over the singing telegraph wires this week-end, and many a sweet young simplex operator will discover what is this thing called love -- all because Western Union has again merged with St. Valentine.

HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Quorum, 4-year-old son of St. James, which once raced for George D. Widener, carried the silks of S.S. Friedlein to a clever victory in the Shrine Purse at Oriental Park today.

The daily average gross crude-oil production in the United States last week was 2,152,700 barrels, a decrease of 18,100 barrels compared with the output in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The daily average east of California was 1,653,000 barrels, compared with 1,637,700 barrels in the preceding week, a decrease of 14,700 barrels.

Process servers seeking William J. Flynn, Bronx Commissioner of Public Works, reported to Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee, late yesterday afternoon that they were unable to find him.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 9 (AP). -- Two officers of the Democratic State Committee today accused Sedgwick Kistler. National Committeeman, and John R. Collins, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, with lending themselves to a movement to "stop Roosevelt" in Pennsylvania.

Hovsep Pushman, not a frequent exhibitor, opened at the Grand Central Galleries yesterday a show that remains until Feb. 20. Included are new canvases and some that are older. Old and new, however, are peculiarly relative terms as applied to this exquisite art.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 9. -- Osservatore Romano, a newspaper which often speaks for the Vatican, prints today another strong protest against religious persecution in Mexico, specifically attacking the application "in a fashion hostile to honor to God and to the welfare of souls," of Article CXXX of the Mexican Constitution.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 9. -- Japan's twelve-day and twelve-night battle against the Chinese Nineteenth Route Army for possession of Chapel, and five-day and four-night battle for the Woosung forts at the mouth of the Whangpoo River, both were admittedly unsuccessful when dark descended this evening.

The resolution proposed by Bishop William T. Manning and unanimously adopted on Saturday at the annual luncheon of the France-America Society, protesting against a gibe at France's attitude toward international debts, in the current musical show "Of Thee I Sing," resulted yesterday in a letter from William D. Guthrie, president of the society, asking the producer and authors to delete the gibe.

The recommendation that judges of the Court of Appeals and justices of the Supreme Court be appointed by the Governor with the assistance of the Senate was made last night in a report to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York by its committee on the judiciary, of which Samuel H. Ordway is chairman.

HONOLULU, Feb. 9 (AP). -- A new prosecutor was assured for the murder case against Mrs. Granville Fortescue, society matron, and her three naval co-defendants today, as defense attorneys contemplated seeking a change of venue.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- In the face of a threatened veto by Governor Roosevelt, the Assembly Banking Committee reported favorably today in unamended form the bill to set up a banking board of nine members. The bill has already passed the Senate in its present form.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- A suggestion that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation issue for public subscription a given amount of its government guaranteed debentures of small denominations with the double purpose of providing the corporation with funds and bringing hoarded money out of hiding, is being considered by the administration and government fiscal officers.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 9. -- The annual meeting of the football rules committee will take place at Dartmouth College this week-end at which time the ten members will look into the game exhaustively, seeking possible changes in the code.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The Congressional reapportionment plan which was put through the Legislature last year by the Republicans in a concurrent resolution was invalidated by the Court of Appeals today.

Plans for a widespread organization of relief on a permanent basis hitherto never before attempted, with a view not only to assist the needy unemployed this Winter but to cope with a possible emergency next Winter, were made public yesterday in a preliminary statement of the Block Community Organization, an activity of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

Presidents and executive officers of forty-four of the civio trade associations in the city will meet tomorrow in the Hotel New Yorker at a luncheon conference which is reported to have for its chief purpose the formation of a city-wide citizens' organization to work for sharp reductions in municipal expenditures and a consequent decrease in taxation.

Floyd Bennett Field, the city airport on Barren Island, at the far end of Flatbush Avenue, may be the first American airport to have a fashionable restaurant like those on some of the leading European flying fields, it became known yesterday when it was announced that negotiations for a franchise to establish such a restaurant were in progress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Reports that Ecuador had forsaken the gold standard, although unconfirmed through governmental sources, caused no surprise in official quarters here today as Ecuador already had been listed among those countries that technically have forsaken the gold standard for the "gold exchange standard."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Railroad earnings between 1920 and 1930 in excess of the legal 6 per cent return and liable to recapture by the government were estimated today at $361,465,815 by Interstate Commerce Commissioner Joseph B. Eastman.
SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 10. -- The sun shone today for the first time this week through the lifting fog. Immediately the battles of Chapei and Woosung flared up again.

LONDON, Feb. 9. -- Business on the Stock Exchange again was light today, prices in most sections declining because of lack of support. British Government funds opened firm, but developed weakness after a little selling. The conversion 3 1/2 per cent loan dropped to u75 3/5 and the War Loan to u98.

Pressure against the stock market was not relaxed yesterday, but the decline in prices was narrower than on the day before. The more stubborn, resistance gave rise to the hope in Wall Street that the selling movement might be near exhaustion. However, many stocks went into new low ground, among them some of the high-priced issues which have put up a brave front for weeks.

The prospect of increased school budgets in the smaller communities brought out a large number of voters and created many close contests last night in municipalities in all parts of New Jersey where school board elections were held. In several towns a record number of candidates ran for vacant positions on the school boards and candidates for re-election faced opposition for the first time in several years.
