PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Despite the phenomenal basket shooting of Earl Nikkel, Yale forward, who scored sixteen points, the Princeton varsity basketball players staged a last-half drive which gave them a 35-to-28 victory over the Elis tonight.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Led by Whitehead, who scored nine points, the Princeton freshman basketball team defeated the Hun School five here tonight by a 28-to-19 score. The yearlings led at the half-time, 12 to 11.

Contract bridge, which once was confined almost wholly to a few of the more exclusive London bridge clubs, has attained nation-wide popularity in England in the last few months, Colonel B.M. Beasley, president of the Crockfords Club in London, said yesterday upon his arrival here on the Berengaria.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Three electrical workers were seriously burned and one is expected to die, as the result of a short circuit in an electrical structure on which they were working in the power substation of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company at Broad and Miller Streets late this afternoon.

Strengthened by an enlarged force of supervisors and investigators and a volunteer corps of shoppers, the Emergency Home Relief Bureau will reopen its seventy-nine precinct stations today after a shutdown of several weeks and will resume registration of applications for relief, it was announced yesterday by Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare.

Messages assuring their continued support of Governor Roosevelt in the face of Alfred E. Smith's declaration of willingness to accept the Democratic Presidential nomination, were received at Roosevelt headquarters here yesterday from Democratic leaders in many States.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Twenty-two aviators, locked out by the Century Air Lines in the first organized labor dispute on record in American aviation, mapped a strike program tonight at a meeting in their Chicago headquarters.

With, more than 550 individual specimens on the bench, including some of the most noted winners in the rings of the United States and England and embracing nine different breeds, the exhibition of the Associated Terrier Clubs will open at 9 o'clock this morning in the exhibition hall of the Grand Central Palace, Forty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Judge Irving Lehman scathingly denounced police use of the "third degree" as the Court ol Appeals, in a four-to-three decision, today reversed the conviction of Vincent Mummiani for the murder of Dominick Buoncore in New York and granted a new trial.

Walter E. Edge, Ambassador to France, arrived on the North German Lloyd liner Europa yesterday for a six-day visit, and the first thing he did on reaching New York was to deny rumors in New Jersey that he had returned to become the Republican party's "man on a horse" to take the lead for President Hoover in the State primaries.

Heavy liquidation of raw sugar was resumed yesterday after a respite of several days, and the March contract went to the low level of 0.88 cent a pound, 3 points below the previous bottom mark, established last week. This price contrasts with the high record of 23.35 cents, reached in 1920.

The decline in commodities continued unchecked yesterday, new lows for the year to date freely interspersing the subjoined list of cash articles. These were corn, oats, lard, pork, beef, copper and rubber. In futures, a decline of 5 to 6 points in sugar carried the March contract to 0.88, a record low. Losses were also reported in coffee, silk, hides and rubber. Cocoa turned up slightly.

Absence of Southern selling in any appreciable volume and a continued moderate trade demand were reflected by a fairly steady undertone on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, although a somewhat easier feeling developed in the last hour under increased offerings promoted by the action of the stock and grain markets.

Camden County, N.J. Camden County, N.J., plans to enter the market on Feb. 24 with a new issue of $1,000,000 general improvement bonds, due on March 1, 1934 to 1967. The proceeds are required for road, bridge and institutional construction.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- The House Judiciary Committee rejected today proposals to make permanent the district judgeship in Southern New York held by Francis A. Winslow, resigned.

SAN PEDRO, Cal., Feb. 9 (AP). -- The auxiliary yacht Invader, chartered by Douglas Fairbanks, sailed today for the South Seas, to be joined by the motion picture star when it reaches Papeete, Tahiti. Mr. Fairbanks said he would sail from San Francisco for Papeete on Feb. 17, and that, cruising the far South Seas, he would shoot at least 100,000 feet of film for a picture tentatively entitled "Tropical Night."

Margaret Ayer Barnes, who won the 1931 Pulitzer prize last Spring for her novel, "Years of Grace," told yesterday at a luncheon of the New York League of Advertising Women at the Hotel Pennsylvania of the steps that led her to the award and to a headline "Writing Mother Wins to Glory," which she termed "this odd apotheosis of a middle-aged mother of three adolescent children."

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- The stock market weakened sharply today, with leading issues taking considerable losses. Trading on the Bourse was unusually slow, probably because of the MardiGras holiday. The Bank of France shares fell 325 francs, Suez Canal 175, and other leaders in proportion.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9. -- Mrs. Lillian Hoggarth of Lorain, Ohio, the medalist, won by a margin of 3 and 1 from Mrs. Lawrence Schwab of Great Neck, L.I., in the initial round of match play for the women's Miami golf championship today.

John. N. Willys, chairman of the Willys -- Overland Company, who announced last week his opposition to the plan of reorganization of the Fisk Rubber Company that had been promulgated by a committee headed by Orrin G. Wood, attacked the plan yesterday on the ground that a change in the company's structure now would affect its operations.

Trial of the suit filed eleven months ago by the Department of Justice for the dissolution of the Sugar Institute, made up of the nation's largest sugar refiners, began yesterday before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 9. -- With eighteen candidates for the places on New Hampshire's delegation to the National Democratic Convention now in the field and favorable to nomination of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt for President, Robert Jackson, secretary of the national committee and its member from New Hampshire, has summoned them to conference tomorrow in an effort to smooth the Roosevelt path.

The Gorlin Construction Company, Aaron Gorlin, president, sold Palace Court, a four-story brick apartment house, on a plot 60 by 108 feet, at 2,267-69 Boulevard, northwest corner of Boyd Avenue, Jersey City, assessed at $112,000, to Dave Sundell.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- A Democratic National Convention unpledged in advance to any candidate is favored by Jouett Shouse, chairman of the party's executive committee.
That the demand for commercial space in high-class structures in the midtown zone is assuming continually increasing proportions is shown by the volume of contracts closed during the last ten days.

In the death of Junnosuke Inouye, thrice Minister of Finance in Japanese cabinets, Japan has lost not only her foremost banker and one of her leading financiers, but a national leader, who had the esteem of his own people and of friends in many nations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The text of the appeal to the federal Government for economic and legislative relief submitted today by the American Federation of Labor and its affiliates follows:

The bond market on the Stock Exchange was on the defensive again yesterday and closing prices showed further losses from the advances made by many issues in January. Several issues touched the lowest levels since December, particularly domestic corporation bonds.
NEW YORK. Walter E. Edge, American Ambassador to France, is at the Ambassador.

En route to the battlefronts of the Orient, the European members of the League of Nations commission which will inquire into the Sino-Japanese conflict reached New York yesterday on the French liner Paris.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9. -- That Japan has now embarked on a regular war of conquest against China is the view gradually forcing itself upon Moscow's conviction. Opinions vary about the reasons that have prompted Japan to engage in a gigantic adventure which entails grave risks of friction with the other great powers, but that she intends to take all the risks is no longer doubted here.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 9. -- Winning the first golf competition in which she ever took part, Mrs. Johnny Farrell, wife of the former national open champion, teamed with E, Terence MacGovern of Great Barrington, Mass., to lead the field today in a mixed foursome handicap tournament.

Reactionary influences were again at work on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The share market continued its indolent decline, the main body of stocks losing from a fraction to 2 points. Bonds extended their recent losses, but only moderately. The commodity markets also moved lower.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- With doors locked and galleries cleared in the first secret session since June 14, 1929, the Senate today debated the appointment of Ira M. Ornburn of Connecticut as a Democratic member of the Tariff Commission, and then confirmed him by a vote of 70 to 9.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9. -- Stroking the incoming nine boles in 33, Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., who won the medal yesterday with a brilliant 65, defeated Ora L. Brailey of Toledo, Ohio, by 2 up in the opening round of match play of the twentieth annual South Florida championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

Noiseless electric welding could be employed with safety and economy in the construction of buildings of the dimensions of the Empire State Building, it was said last night by F.T. Llewellyn, member of the structural steel welding committee of the American Bureau of Welding, during a joint meeting of the Metropolitan Section of the American Society of Civil Engineers and the American Welding Society at the Engineering Auditorium, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

GENEVA, Feb. 9. -- To this open court of the world's nations, met to consider and decide how armaments should be limited and reduced, the United States and Germany today brought their proposals. They harmonized and complemented each other.

John Toth, 52 years old, who said he was an insurance salesman and lived at 29 Stuyvesant Place, was convicted in Special Sessions yesterday of defrauding a man of $18 under pretext of obtaining a job for him. Carl Hoffman of 511 East Twelfth Street was the complainant.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on Governor Smith's Presidential pronunciamento is rather a remarkable document. You are frankly fair. You point out that Mr. Smith merits no reproach for his understandable desire to lead his party once again.

The four top seeded players in the national veterans' squash tennis championship, headed by Dr. Harold R. Mixsell, the defending titleholder, came through to the semi-finals last night at the Princeton Club.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press). -- The Commonwealth Government has decided to pay to all holders of bonds of New South Wales the interest payments defaulted by that State as soon as possible.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Less wheat is on hand in the world than a year ago, according to data prepared by Nat C. Murray, grain statistician of Clement Curtis Co. Commenting on a report that the government estimated surplus wheat stocks in the United States, Canada, Australia and Argentina on Jan. 1 as 970,000,000 bushels, against 961,000,000 a year earlier, he said:

Guarded by six detectives, six uniformed policemen and a squad of private operatives, all the cash in the vaults of the old branch offices of the Manufacturers Trust Company at 139 Broadway was transferred at 6 o'clock last night to the offices of the Chatham Phenix National Bank and Trust Company at 149 Broadway, on the opposite corner of Liberty Street and Broadway.

Bronx landlords were warned last night to be guard against a group of "racketeers" who have been organizing rent strikes for dissatisfied tenants on condition that they receive 50 per cent of whatever rent reductions may be granted.

TOKYO, Feb. 9. -- Discussing some of the objections cabled from Washington to Japan's tentative plan for neutralizing treaty ports, a Foreign Office spokesman today said a plan for a neutral zone five miles wide around Shanghai had been proposed by the United States Minister in 1927.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Feb. 9. -- "Pay as we go" was the rule laid down for Porto Rico by Governor James R. Beverley in his first message to the Legislature now in annual sixty-day session. "The government must live within its income," he said.

Intercoastal steamship lines which have engaged in a rate war during the past year as a result of the dissolution of the United States Intercoastal Conference have reached a settlement and will come together in a new conference on March 1, it became known yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Federal Judge William Clark, who once held the Eighteenth Amendment invalid, ruled today that bartenders and other speakeasy employes could not be charged with maintaining a nuisance. Only the proprietor or owner of a place selling liquor illegally could be indicted and prosecuted under this section of the Volstead act, he decided.

GENEVA, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Chancellor Heinrich Bruening at Germany, addressing the world disarmament conference today, pledged Germany, "with all emphasis," to advocate "general disarmament -- disarmament of an unmistakable nature, such as the League of Nations covenant envisaged."

The Railroad Credit Corporation's directors will meet here on next Wednesday to consider plans for extending funds to railroads in advance of their receipt from the national revenue pool approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission and to consider applications for loans.

Thus far the Disarmament Conference, in addition to the draft plan submitted by the Preparatory Commission, has had before it the proposals of Great Britain, France, Germany and the United States. All profess a common aim. All agree that the differences in their preliminary statements ought to be patiently discussed, without being too much overborne by technical arguments, in the hope of arriving at a definite and universal agreement.

Egon Petri gave his second New York recital last night in Town Hall. He played the Italian Concerto and the "St. Anne" organ prelude and fugue of Bach, the latter in the arrangement of Busoni; six Liszt transscriptions of Schubert songs, and the whole of the second set of the Chopin Studies.

Henry Miro, Harlem's "Policy King," was arrested yesterday by detectives of Chief Inspector John O'Brien's staff following raids on an automobile accessory store at 1,941 Seventh Avenue and an apartment at 157 West 117th Street, in which twenty-three Negroes, three of them women, were arrested.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Vice Admiral Nomura, the new Japanese naval commander at Shanghai, expressed his readiness today to enter into a truce with the Chinese under which the Japanese would withdraw to Hongkew in the Shanghai area if the Chinese would retire to an area twenty miles beyond Chapei, the Navy Department was informed this afternoon by Admiral Taylor, commander of the Asiatic Fleet, who is at Shanghai.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- The first open rift within the Democratic majority of the Assembly blocked enactment today of the measure which would have enabled municipalities to take advantage of Governor Moore's proposal for the return of $16,500,000 of road funds in relieving them of the necessity of adopting their 1932 budgets today, by extending the period for twenty days.

Will Rogers, America's homely philosopher, returned yesterday from a foreign tour that lasted long enough for him to "settle" differences between China and Japan, to appear at the Arms Conference in Geneva, to get it started off right, and to thrust his square-Jawed face into any number of other world centres to make the serious appear humorous and the humorous takes on an expect of solemnity.
LONDON, Feb. 9. -- A new wave of depression, swept England today, weakening the stock markets, particularly industrial and railway shares, and causing sterling to react on all foreign exchanges.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- A better undertone was apparent today in the market for hogs, and while light weights were barely steady, medium and weighty butchers were strong to 5 cents higher than yesterday. Decreased receipts and expectations of a small run tomorrow had some effect.

Even the most illustrious of the French detectives finds it difficult to discover the murderer of Sir Roger Ackroyd in "The Fatal Alibi," which was staged at the Booth last evening. Who are we that we should consider ourselves superior to a French detective?
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Feb. 9. -- Pittsfield, in the heart at the wealthy colonoy of Berkshire estates, went "broke" today for the first time in its history.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Walter Runciman in the House of Commons today asserted there were some people who thought sterling would not slide down, but he himself was not so conlident.

The report of the Commonwealth Edison Company for 1931 shows net income of $16,322,541 after depreciation, taxes and charges, equal to $10.40 a share on 1,569,420 shares of stock outstanding at the end of the year, compared with $16,402,588, or $11.51 a share earned on 1,425,100 in 1930.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9 (AP). -- John L. Smith, receiver for the Mayflower Hotel Company and Mayflower Hotels Corporation of Washington, testified today as a government witness in the trial of five officers of the American Bond and Mortgage Company charged with misusing the mails.

Harold Samuel, pianist, was the soloist yesterday at the fifth concert of the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conducting, at Carnegie Hall. The program included the first performance in this city of "Divertimento," a suite in four movements by Bernard Wagenaar, an instructor in composition and theory at the Juilliard School of Music.

BOSTON, Feb. 9. -- The Boston Bruins were in top form tonight and they humbled the New York Rangers by 2 to 1 in one of the most exciting games of the National Hockey League season in the Boston Garden.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- Chancellor Bruening's Geneva address pleases German political opinion of every shade by its unequivocal enunciation of equality of rights and security as a fundamental to Germany's position toward disarmament. However, it incurs criticism for the Omissions Commissions, such criticism more or less reflecting party bias.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 9. -- A temporary injunction restraining labor unions and officials from interfering with the Rust Engineering Company of Pittsburgh in its work on a bridge over the Lehigh Valley Railroad in Weequahic Park for the Essex County Park Commission, and on a bridge over Route 29 for the Lehigh Valley Railroad, was obtained from Vice Chancellor M.L. Berry today by counsel for the engineering company.

The case of the countryside vs. billboards will probably be argued at length at this session of the Legislature. Civic organizations by the score are lined up in support of legislation to bring the objectionable signs under some measure of control.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The Democratic Presidential situation, complicated by the rival candidacies of Governor Roosevelt and former Governor Smith of New York, received an entirely new slant today in a suggestion that Tammany, in the event of a deadlock in the national convention, might turn from Roosevelt and Smith and put forward Mayor Walker as a candidate for the nomination for Vice President.

HONOLULU, Feb. 9. -- "Blue" submarines, cruisers, destroyers and plane carriers, seeking to "recapture the Hawaiian Islands for the United States" in the annual army and navy war games, slowly circled the Island, of Oahu on patrol and succeeded today in driving the "Black" defenders back to within twenty-five miles of the coast lines, restricting considerably the activity of the Black air forces.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9. -- After five unsuccessful efforts in Florida this season, Jack Howard's 6-year-old Islam at last broke the ice at Hialeah Park today when he got up to win the Fort Pierce Claiming Handicap in what was one of the closest finishes of the meeting.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 9. -- Announcing that negotiations for the prolongation of the $40,000,000 worth of American short-term credits, which were broken off because the American creditors were dissatisfied with the terms Hungary was willing to offer, had been renewed, Finance Minister Koranyi appealed tonight in a Parliamentary speech to all Hungary's creditors to show consideration of the difficulties of her position.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I want to congratulate THE TIMES for its editorial "The Governor and the League," which calls to the bar of public opinion a leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, the present Governor of New York, Franklin D. Roosevelt.
The State Athletic Commission yesterday announced the reinstatement of Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight champion; his manager, Joe Jacobs, and the latter's business partner, Billy McCarney.

The same gang that killed two of Vincent Coll's gunmen and a woman in Commonwealth Avenue, the Bronx, last week and got away in two automobiles bearing license plates stolen in shipment from Auburn Prison to this city, used two more stolen cars and two more of the plates from that shipment when they killed Coll last Monday morning in West Twenty-third Street.

The radio invention called the micro-wave, now in the experimental stage, is destined to play a wide role as a medium of popular education in world affairs, declared Professor Walter Pitkin of the Pulitzer School of Journalism of Columbia University in an address last night at a dinner of the Women's City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The nominations of Ogden L. Mills to be Secretary of the Treasury and Arthur A. Ballantine to be Under-secretary were reported to the Senate today by the Finance Committee, but plans to waive the rules, under a unanimous consent agreement, and vote to confirm them immediately were blocked by objection of Senator Norris, which forced a delay of twenty-four hours.

A donkey named Jimmie was entered at the 12th annual pet show of the Madison Square Boys' Club at 312 East Thirtieth Street last night, and being the only donkey in his class won a cash prize of $1 and a blue rosette for his exhibitor, four-year-old Eddie Gannon.

VIENNA, Feb. 9. -- Franz Lehar, composer of "The Merry Widow" and a score of other tuneful operettas, announced today he was taking legal steps to protect his works from alteration or adaptation after his death.

It is not uncommon for readers of books and theatregoers, when confronted by a puzzling new opus from the hand of a favorite writer, to remark that they don't quite catch what Smith is driving at, but it is unquestionably the best thing he has ever done.

The importance of teaching children the necessity of orderly and planned saving, not only from the individual but from the social standpoint, was stressed by Professor Harold F. Clark of Teachers College, Columbia University, one of the speakers at a symposium held yesterday afternoon by the Child Study Association of America at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- A constant flow of protests from opponents to the proposed heavy new taxes on motor trucks and buses at a joint hearing before the fiscal committees of the Legislature this afternoon was brought to a standstill by a charge that the Republicans were trying to "pass the buck" to Governor Roosevelt in connection with the proposed measures for new revenues.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Governor Roosevelt was called a "liar" by a Republican Senator from the floor of the upper House today for the Governor's inclusion of Ulster County in his "roll of shame" for counties which had failed to take advantage of tax relief.

HAVANA, Feb. 9. -- The American yacht Winsome of Peconic Bay, sailed by H. Edwards, skipper, and G. Goodwin, captured the Cuba Trophy today in the international regatta for Star Class yachts when she added 6 points in the final race, making a total of 16 points for the three-race series.
TOKYO, Feb. 9. -- Junnosuke Inouye, former Finance Minister, was shot tonight as he was about to enter a political meeting in a suburb of Tokyo, and died ten minutes later.

In the belief that Bryant Park in its present condition constitutes "an eyesore" which gives persons visiting New York an unfavorable impression of the city's appearance, the Sixth Avenue Association is about to request the Department of Parks to beautify the grounds.

HAVANA, Feb. 9. -- The House of Representatives this afternoon unanimously approved legislation to exempt from payment the profits tax of 1 1/2 per cent of the gross sales tax during the period January to July of this year all merchants and industrialists of the city of Santiago which was almost destroyed by earthquake on Feb. 3.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, came to the Capitol today to protest against the proposed increase on stock transfer taxes from 2 to 4 cents. In a brief filed with the committees holding the hearing on the proposal, he asserted that security trading was already being driven out of New York by heavy levies and declared that the extra impost would accelerate this movement.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Bearish sentiment in wheat was, if anything, more pronounced today than yesterday on the Board of Trade here, and the market was on the down grade from the start. No effect was felt from Liverpool's closing at 1/8 to 1/4 cent a bushel higher, the May there selling within 1 1/2 cents of the same future in Chicago, compared with about 4 1/2 cents recently.

The charge that Controller Charles W. Berry was deliberately trying to destroy the 5-cent fare by his repeated efforts to bring about abandonment or modification of the present short-term financing of subway construction was made yesterday in the Board of Aldermen by Dennis J. Mahon, leader of the Democratic majority.

Confidence in the future of the railroads was expressed by F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central, in a message to employes published yesterday. Mr. Williamson said conditions under which the railroads operate are changing, but that the roads were adjusting themselves to these changes.

A resolution urging the commissioners of the Sinking Fund to discontinue city operation of the Twenty-third Street-East River ferry line was adopted yesterday by the directors of the First Avenue Association at the Hotel Roosevelt. J.J. Hackett Jr., secretary of the association, presented a report to show that the city had spent $281,000 to operate the ferry in 1931, while the total receipts were only $68,911.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 9. -- Edward Haughton's Wotan was a surprice winner of the Mardi Gras Handicap at the Fair Grounds today when he took the lead in the Stretch, galloped sway from a smart field and won at odds of more than 13 to 1.

By the Black-Walsh-Bulkley substitute for the La Follette-Costigan bill for direct Federal unemployment relief, $375,000,000 are to come straight from the Treasury to build public roads and $375,000,000 more to be lent to the States upon certificate of necessity by the Governor, with his promise to recommend to the Legislature and the people legislation to repay the loan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial on third parties maintains the pleasant fiction that the American voter today has a choice between two political policies and that therefore there is no need for presenting him with a third alternative.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Charges that the national capital is a sanctuary for liquor violation, with highclass bootleggers leading a "charmed life," were made to the Senate District of Columbia Committee today by Senator Howell, Republican, of Nebraska, in urging his bill designed to permit search of dwellings in the Federal city without warrants.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- The satisfactory development of the status of the Reichsbank during the first week in February was again offset by a loss of more than $4,000,000 in gold, which was taken from the earmarked reserves in New York and Paris.

MONTREAL, Que., Feb. 9. -- The financial statement of the Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada for 1931, presented at the sixty-first annual meeting of shareholders here today, reflects a year of progress and denied repeated rumors that the company was liquidating United States securities.

Norman Cohn, formerly national indoor and outdoor saber champion, paid off an old score last night and also won the national team three-weapon championship for the Fencers Club, of which he is a member, in the competition held at the Fencers Club.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- Under-Secretary of State von Buelow today presented to the Council of the League of Nations a note declaring that the Memel affair was too urgent to brook further delay and that unless the matter of the attendance of a Lithuanian plenipotentiary at the League's inquiry were immediately settled steps would be taken by Germany to initiate further action.

An ordinary postal card, addressed to the janitress of a tenement at 10 East 112th Street, and telling her that if she would look in a vacant apartment on the top floor she would find something surprising, led last night to the discovery of the body of a 13-year-old girl who had been assaulted and murdered.

Copyright, 1932, by NANA; Inc. WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Ambassador Grew attributes his first "break" in the foreign service to the fact President Roosevelt chanced to hear how he had shot a tiger between the eyes while lying on his back in a Malayan jungle.

A field goal by Nat Lazar as the whistle sounded in an extra period gave the St. John's College basketball team a 31-to-29 triumph over Loyola College of Baltimore at Arcadia Hall, Brooklyn, last night.

More than $500,000 which Jackson Barnett, Creek Indian, gave to the Baptist Home Mission Society in 1923 under a deed of trust, now held by the Chase National Bank as successor trustee to the Equitable Trust Company, was ordered returned yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

Led by a woman, a band of sixteen Communists set out yesterday morning to force a strike in the garment centre. They ended in jail because an employer whom they attempted to victimize was late in arriving at his shop.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Lamont Signor, Pine Hill (N.J.) school board member whose act of kindness led to his arrest and discovery that he was an escaped Ohio convict, received a full pardon today from Governor White.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Necessity for broadening the tax base far more than has heretofore been considered, possibly to the extent of imposing a general sales levy, presented itself to the Ways and Means Committee today when, on the basis of drastically revised estimates of the treasury, it became known that the new revenue bill must raise $1,241,000,000 in additional taxes to balance the budget in the fiscal year 1933.

Women are urged to spend money, and the great Paris dressmaking houses are throwing new clothes into the balance to make it easy for them. Almost daily reports of beautiful collections are coming over. The American woman with a lively imagination must see those slim girls parading back and forth before her mind's eye and long to rush out to buy a high-waisted dress with enormous sleeves and a fichu.

The Chicago Black Hawks trailed the New York Americans into the third period of their National Hockey League game in Madison Square Garden last night, then released a strong scoring burst which saw the star-spangled contingent forced back ruthlessly, to bow in defeat, 3 to 1.

HAVANA, Feb. 9. -- The sugar situation here became further complicated today upon the receipt by the National Sugar Institute of a cablegram signed by nine members of the International Sugar Council protesting against the figure of 3,061,000 tons decided upon by the institute as Cuba's 1932 crop and stating that the highest figure acceptable to them was 2,369,000 tons.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Amateur boxing matches having an admission fee need not be licensed and they are not unlawful, the Court of Appeals held in effect today.

The committee on State legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York announced yesterday its disapproval of fourteen bills pending in the Legislature and its approval of four. Copies of the report have been sent to members of the Legislature.

Peter J. Brancato, Assistant State Attorney General in charge of the New York City Bureau, will appear in the Supreme Court tomorrow to apply for an order to begin an action to annul the charters of three well-known night clubs. This is the second stage in the drive begun six weeks ago by the State authorities to close all night clubs operating illegally in New York City.

ORMOND, Fla., Feb. 9. -- John D. Rockefeller Sr. told The Associated Press today that there were indications that business conditions throughout the country were improving, and that he was greatly encouraged.

The fourteen-story and penthouse apartment at 1,269 Madison Avenue, southeast corner of Ninety-first Street, has been sold by the Niap Realty Corporation, William J. Spain, president, to a client of the Leonard S. Gans Company. The property has a frontage of 100 feet on Madison Avenue and was bought by Mr. Spain about three months ago subject to a $295,000 first mortgage at 5 per cent, held by the Central Savings Bank.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9. -- Jefferscfon Machamer of New York, who won the medal in yesterday's qualifying round, was put out today in the first round of match play in the fifth annual Artists and Writers' Golf Association tournament, David Roberts of New York eliminating his fellow-townsman by 6 and 5.

ROME, Feb. 9. -- Both the Vatican and the Italian Government today officially announced that Premier Mussolini in his official capacity as head of the government of Italy will visit Pope Pius XI in the Vatican at 11 o'clock in the morning of Feb. 11.

The Grace liner Santa Olivia sailed yesterday morning from Pier 33, Brooklyn, for South America, with a cargo including freight originally intended for the Santa Ana, which sailed on Sunday while the union longshoremen employed at the pier were on strike.

A considerable number, probably most, of the young girls and women sent to correctional institutions find such commitment no bar to romance and succeed in marrying happily, according to the superintendents of many of the nation's leading institutions of correction for women who gathered at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday for a two-day conference.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 8. -- A cabaret supper dance given tonight at the Art Association drew a capacity attendance. Owing to the party's success Mrs. Snowden A. Fahnestock, chairman of the committee, plans a similar one later in the Winter.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. (AP). -- Otto Reiselt, Philadelphia, defeated Arthur Thurnblad, Chicago, the 1931 title winner, 50 to 30, to win the second place play-off and a prize of $5,100 tonight in the world's three-cushion billiard tournament. The match lasted forty-four innings.

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- France has done her duty and will so continue, Premier Laval stated today in the Chamber of Deputies in reply to reproaches by Edouard Harriot and other Left deputies protesting against the government's inaction in the Sino-Japanese conflict.

The will of Paul M. Warburg, who largely influenced the establishment of the Federal Reserve System, not only entrusts his accumulated wealth entirely to his widow during her lifetime, and thereafter divides it equally between their son and daughter, but also leaves a set of rules for keeping it safely invested.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 9. -- Tokyo's proposal to create wide demilitarized zones around five of China's greatest ports was scornfully rejected this afternoon by Quo Tai-chi, the Loyang Government's Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, now residing in Shanghai.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- A couple of tiny airplanes, which were built in order to popularize flying in Germany, could be seen for the first time today rocking around in the Winter gales above Templehof Airport, where they were demonstrated to experts.

Colonel KNOX'S account of what was done in Aurora, Ill., to restore confidence in the banks suggests the "rosy-fingered" dawn of a better day. It is not as if the crowing of a chanticleer had brought it. It has come as a result of economic conditions.

HAVANA, Feb. 9. -- Characterizing the present tax system in Cuba as largely a heritage from Colonial Spanish days, Professor E.R.A. Seligman of Columbia University, who has been retained by the Cuban Government to make a study of Cuba's fiscal system with a view to placing taxation on a more equitable basis, presented today his voluminous report to the Department of the Treasury.
A "Social" Dialogue FRANK: Nice of you to come up with me, AL.

More than a majority of the five-year 6 per cent convertible gold notes has heen deposited with the reorganization committee of the Snider Packing Corporation and the time for deposit has been extended to March 1, with the privilege for a further extension.

Net earnings in 1931 of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, a finance company, amounted to $7,554,998, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $2.54 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding during the year. This compares with net earnings of $8,318,793 for 1930, equivalent to $2.75 on the average number of shares outstanding in that year.

"Damien of Molokai," a biography of Joseph Damien de Veuster, the Flemish peasant priest who spent sixteen years caring for lepers on the Hawaiian island of Molokai before he contracted the disease and died was published yesterday by Macmillan.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The full text of the Court of Appeals decision invalidating the Congressional reapportionment resolution adopted by the State Legislature last year follows:

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, Feb. 9. -- The decision of the Court of Appeals today holding that the Jarl Company has a cause of action in seeking to set aside its tax assessment on the ground that the land had been annexed to this village illegally marked another point won by the 1,800 residents of the annexed area in their "tax strike" against the annexation.

Textile High School's basketball team tallied its third triumph in as many Manhattan division P.S.A.L. games by defeating George Washington High, 30 to 8, at Textile yesterday. The winners led at the half, 15 to 7.
From the summit of the Empire State Building yesterday two men of politics exchanged views, or rather impressions of the views they saw below and before them from the world's tallest structure.

Sutton Studios, Inc., Harold Rosenbluth, president, gave to the Liberty Place Holding Corporation a mortgage for $15,000, payable Feb. 8, 1935, at 6 per cent, on 1,033-35 First Avenue, two five-story tenements with stores adjoining the southwest corner of Fifty-seventh Street. This lien is subject to a first mortgage for $100,000 at 5 1/2 per cent held by the Bank for Savings.

Two women armed with bricks held a burglar at bay in a Flushing residence yesterday until the police arrived and arrested him. The burglar was Paul Lamoureix of 174 Fort Green Place, Brooklyn. Twice in the last thirteen years, detectives say, his house-breaking activities have resulted in prison terms.

GENEVA Feb. 9. -- Once more tonight the Council of the League of Nations assembled in a special meeting at the call of China, listened to her renewed complaint against Japan's actions in the Far East and was urged to make haste in ending them.

Stocks moved up and down nervously yesterday in a slothful market dependent almost wholly upon hesitant professionals for its impulses. The day's business on the Stock Exchange was a trifle larger than on Tuesday but still far short of what would be considered a normal volume even in the dog-days of Summer.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- State and judicial conventions and the Fail primaries will be held two weeks earlier in September, if a bill passed today by the Assembly is concurred in by the Senate and aproved by the Governor.

Brokers' reports yesterday indicated an undiminished demand for business quarters in midtown Manhattan. New leases constituted a large part of the day's realty activity, and some of the contracts were for entire floors.

European withdrawals of gold amounting to $17,045,500 were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Imports of $1,070,200 from Canada and $575,000 from India were also announced, and an increase of $100,000 in gold earmarked for foreign accounts was shown.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 10. -- Chinese-operated businesses in Shanghai, suspended Jan. 29 as a protest against Japanese operations here, continued inactive here today under the vigilant picketing of members of the Chinese street unions.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 10. -- A Federal bond issue to provide relief for the unemployed was urged by Alfred E. Smith in an article which appeared in The Yale Daily News today.

Joseph H. Hoadley, 67 years old, a conspicuous figure off and on in the last thirty years in the financial district in engineering and industrial projects he promoted, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of passing a fraudulent check on a West Fifty-eighth Street restaurant owner in return for food and lodging.

A contest for deposits of the $30,000,000 General Theatres Equipment, Inc., 6 per cent defentures, on which the interest due on April 1 is not expected to be paid, became an established fact yesterday, when announcement was made of the formation of a second protective committee for the issue, in which the Chase Nationa Bank is represented.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York went on record at its monthly meeting yesterday as opposed to extension of the powers of the Interstate Commerce Commission over steamship and motor-truck transportation. Sections of the report of its legislative committee, which dealt with bills now before Congress designed to lessen the degree of independent action by water and motor lines, resulted in unfavorable action by the shippers.

When Sir Oliver Lodge first turned to psychical resarch he felt no enthusiasm for the subject, was conscious, "indeed, of an element of dislike," he writes in his autobiography, "Past Years," published by Scribner today. It was only gradually, he writes, that "my scepticism about such phenomena was overcome," but "I found a series of facts which were unpalatable and mainly neglected by scientific men, and I felt that they were worthy of attention."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The Ways and Means Committee in two executive sessions today considered possible tax sources which would yield $1,241,000,000 in new revenue for the fiscal year 1933. Afterward Acting Chairman Crisp stated that "nothing definite" had been done, adding that, because of the complexity of the problem, a tax bill could not be expected until after March 1.

The War Wepartment should withdraw the Reserve Officers' Training Corps from colleges throughout the country and limit its training activities to military work, the Columbia Spectator, student daily newspaper, declared yesterday in its leading editorial.

MADRID, Feb. 10. -- With the city under heavy military guard to prevent disorders the steamship Buenos Aires sailed from Barcelona at dawn today for Spanish Guinea bearing 109 Communist leaders to exile for their share in the recent revolt in Catalonia.

The Do-X, the world's largest airplane, will leave New York some time in May on the first leg of its flight back to Germany. This was announced definitely last night by the biplane's skipper, Captain Franz Christiansen, who, with his second in command, Captain Wilhelm Niemann, and all but two members of the crew sailed for home last night on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 11. Military observers here understand 20,000 Japanese soldiers will arrive in China today and tomorrow. This is the interpretation placed upon the engagement of sixteen Whangpoo River pilots by Admiral Nomura of Japan.
ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Governor Roosevelt's special message transmitted to the Senate and Assembly today read as follows:

JERUSALEM, Feb. 10. -- Disorderly scenes which threatened to develop into rioting necessitated the calling in of police and marred the inaugural lecture today in the Hebrew University of Norman Bentwich, former Attorney General of the Palestine Government and recently appointed to the Weizmann chair of international law and peace.

For failing to produce books and records as directed by a Supreme Court subpoena, Irving Levy, president of the Hydrox Laundry and Dry Cleaning Corporation in Brooklyn, was adjudged in contempt yesterday by Referee Nathan Friedman at the public hearing in the State Building into the business methods and operations of the laundry industry in this city.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 10. -- Mayor Walker and the Prince of Wales were the two living examples of Beau Brummel who have done mnre than any other individuals to influence the trend of men's clothing. Sylvan Kronheim of New York told the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at the annual Spring style meeting here today.

Park Avenue is one of the finest thoroughfares in the city. Like Fifth Avenue, it has even suffered from being too fine. People who live in the apartments that face it complain that they are experiencing increasing difficulty crossing the traffic stream, now augmented by hundreds of cars seeking to take advantage of the viaduct over the congested streets of the Grand Central district.

The committee in charge of arrangements for the strike of 30,000 dressmakers has decided to issue the strike call next week, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Schlesinger, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, who said the exact date would be withheld for the present.

Sluggish demand for copper resulted yesterday in a continuation of price cutting and the metal was offered by custom smelters at 6 cents a pound and by second hands at 5 3/4 cents, the lowest levels at which the metal has ever been sold for domestic delivery.

The Interim report of the Public Utility Holding Corporation of America and subsidiaries for the six months ended on Nov. 30, 1931, shows net income after all expenses, taxes, charges and underlying dividends and minority interests, of $981,626, equal after preferred dividend requirements, to about 16 1/2 cents a share on 3,633,494 shares of Class A and common stock outstanding at the end of the period.

The Dryden, a sixteen-story apartment hotel at 148-52 East Thirty-ninth Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues, was bid in yesterday by the United Cigar Stores Company as plaintiff in a foreclosure action against 148 East Thirty-ninth Street, Inc., and others.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10. -- Yale defeated Brown University tonight at swimming in the Carnegie pool, 47 to 24. The visitors finished first in only the 150-yard back-stroke race, which was won by Franklin White of Flushing, and the 200-yard relay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Development of a powerful financial machine based on revolutionary changes in the Federal Reserve System and designed to stimulate credit through a possible increase of $2,500,000,000 in the currency was decided upon at a non-partisan conference of Democratic and Republican leaders called at the White House today by President Hoover.

Last August the report of the Wickersham Commission on "Lawlessness and Law Enforcement" was made public. Instances of extreme brutality, mental and physical, used by the police to extort confessions were cited. The conclusion was reached that "the 'third degree' is widespread throughout the country."

The proposal of the Building Trades Employers Association that the nominal wage scales in the building industry be materially reduced has been approved by the board of governors of the Investing and Contracting Builders Association, Inc., according to a statement issued yesterday by Colonel A. Pearson, Hoover, president of the association.

Doors' will be opened in Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock this morning for the first session of the fifty-sixth annual bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which willl be continued through Saturday, with 2,350 dogs representing seventy-seven recognized breeds on the benches.

Faced with restricted purchases, the steel industry is not making much headway, according to The Iron Age, which finds that buying from automobile companies and builders is lagging, while the railroads are not making commitments in as great a volume as had been anticipated.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found, yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city.

Occasionally the death of a minor author does more to "eclipse the gayety of nations" than would that of a great writer. EDGAR WALLACE never pretended to be a literary genius. Yet he had certain remarkable gifts for the kind of work which he did.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- While the House Judiciary Committee was deciding, in a heated two-hour executive session, to discontinue the impeachment hearings and charges brought against Secretary of the Treasury Mellon by Representative Patman of Texas, the Senate today confirmed Ogden L. Mills and Arthur A. Ballantine, as Secretary and Under Secretary of the Treasury, respectively.

Two union organizations representing 10,000 workers in book and job printing plants in the city decided yesterday to reject the proposal of a voluntary 20 to 30 per cent cut in wages suggested by the Printers' League Section of the New York Employing Printers' Association.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- After opening irregular today the stock market recovered after a disturbed period. Copper shares fell sharply. The pound sterling opened considerably weaker, which was sufficient to start the session badly, but as the day progressed there was some timid buying which developed sufficiently to permit almost all stocks to close above the opening levels.

Governor ROOSEVELT has before called attention to mounting local taxes, but never more pointedly than in his radio address on Monday evening. State subventions and distributions of one kind and another, once hailed as a means of relief to real estate, have often proved merely an added burden.

The Compinsky Trio, Sara, pianist; Manual, violin; Alex, 'cello, played with admirable art last night in Carnegie Hall. A trio in which the two stringed instruments blend and fuse tone as they did last night, in which the string players are not forced to compete to see which can be heard above the din of the piano, is rarer than might be believed.

GENEVA, Feb. 10. -- League of Nations, British and American quarters here take a very serious view of the consequences to the League, to Britain and to the United States if a remedy is not found soon for the paralysis which yesterday's session of the League Council showed was afflicting their efforts to end the Far Eastern conflict.

The merger of the Chatham Phenix National Bank and Trust Company into the Manufacturers Trust Company became effective yesterday, when the combined organizations of the two institutions opened for business under the name of the Manufacturers Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- A charge that the State Department forced the Republic of Haiti to float an unnecessary foreign loan of $16,000,000 in 1923 in order to perpetuate American control over that island republic was made before the Senate Finance Committee today by Georges Leger, a lawyer of Port Au Prince and brother of the Foreign Minister of Haiti.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Late tonight the Republican majority in the Senate, with its steam roller crushing all opposition, adopted a concurrent resolution providing for a sweeping investigation of Governor Roosevelt's regime. The vote, 27 to 21, was on strict party lines.

Kentucky Colonels here greeted with varying enthusiasm yesterday the announcement in morning papers that the Legislature of the Blue Grass State was considering a bill to tax the 1,000 or more men and women holders of the honorary title $100 a year.

An Increase of more than $1,200,000 in net income is shown in the annual report of the P. Lorillard Company for 1931. The net was $4,846,373 after Federal taxes, Interest, depreciation and other charges, equivalent after preferred dividends to $2.12 a share on 1,909,212 common shares.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation declined 87,203 tons in January, or from 2,735,353 tons on Dec. 31 to 2,648,150 tons at the end of January. The reduction brought the corporation's unfinished business to the lowest in its history.

The National City Bank took a demand mortgage for $10,000 at 6 per cent from Attilio Foscolo on his property at 7 and 9 Carmine Street, subject to a first mortgage for $50,000 at 6 per cent held by the Italian Savings Bank.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- Herbert Gerlach, chairman of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, answered today the radio statement made by Governor Roosevelt on Monday in which the Governor had placed Westchester at the head of his "roll of shame."

Upon the wan faces of Republicans a broad smile has appeared. This phenomenon is quite unlike previous endeavors to force a smile. It is difficult to be joyous over the prospects of something called the Reconstruction Finance Corporation or "balancing the budget."

Accused of arson, Miss Catherine McDonnell, 34 years old, was arraigned yesterday in West Side Court and held in $10,000 bail by Magistrate Charles Brandt Jr. for a hearing today. Fire Marshall Brophy and detectives charged that she had set fire to a rooming-house which she leases at 68 West Ninety-seventh Street.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The stock markets continued depressed today. Sterling displayed renewed weakness in leading foreign currencies, the New York rate dropping to $3.24 3/4%. British Government funds were lower on the unfavorable trend in sterling, and Walter Runciman's speech yesterday offset good revenue returns.

The Container Corporation of America, Walter P. Paepcke, president, sold its North Bergen plant, a two-story brick building on a plot 250 by 378 feet at 1,723 Bergen Turnpike, near Thirty-eighth Street, North Bergen, to Gibraltar Corrugated Paper Company, Inc., of North Bergen.

New anesthetics made of synthetic perfumes, which will give the patient subconscious sensations of fragrance, were predicted last night by Professor Marston T. Bogert, head of the organic chemistry department of Columbia University, in a lecture on "Perfume Engineering" before the science forum of the New York Electrical Society at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

The Actors' Equity Association has granted the William Morris Agency, one of the best-known casting agencies in the vaudeville and motion-picture field, permits to represent its members. This action was taken after ample proof had been submitted to Equity's legal department that Paramount-Publix no longer had a financial interest in the agency.

NEW YORK. The Sert supper dances which have been held Thursday nights for several weeks in the Sert room of the Waldorf-Astoria have been discontinued. They will be resumed next January as a means to raise funds for the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

The word "block-aider" was coined yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith when he endorsed the Block Community Organization of the Gibson Unemployment Committee, which is headed by Wilton Lloyd-Smith. After being told of the plan to organize the city block by block to aid families in need, the former Governor said:

MOSCOW, Feb. 10. -- That Maxim Litvinoff proposes to play an important role at the Geneva disarmament conference was clearly foreshadowed by today's editorial in Izvestia entitled "The Land of Soviets Will Struggle for Peace."

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- After many weeks of intense effort by French and British experts and diplomats to come to an agreement regarding German reparations, they have virtually reached a point where they have agreed to disagree and within a few days are expected to issue a reassuring but vague announcement of accord, it was learned in authoritative quarters today.

What are the native drums saying? They are singing the death chant of the "Zombie" in a play of that title produced at the Biltmore last evening. Among the mountains of Haiti where voodooism fills the woods with terrors, the zombie is a sort of animated corpse who may be hypnotized out of his grave and made to perform unseeing labor under the direction of a ghoulish overseer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Concern was manifested in official circles today over possible danger to Americans and other foreigners in the International Settlement with a big battle in prospect between the Chinese and Japanese around Shanghai.

A proposal of the ship lines operating in the port of New York that the wage rates of longshoremen be reduced because of the heavy losses of traffic has been submitted to the International Longshoremen's Association by Frederick Toppin, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company and chairman of the committee of ship lines.
Old and New "Monkeying." Add to the list of famous sayings by famous men: "This is no time to monkey with the budget." -- Tammany Leader DENNIS J. MAHON, in the Board of Aldermen, Feb. 9, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- A periodometer, or "brass brain," capable of solving with more accuracy than human calculators the problems presented by the curves of natural processes in space and time has been invented by Dr. Charles G. Abbot, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution.

By administering the Princeton Club its first defeat of the season on the loser's courts, the Yale Club Class B squash racquets team last night took the lead in the New York group in the qualifying play of the metropolitan district, winning a close contest, 3-2.

Survivors of Lafayette Post, 140, Union Veterans of the Civil War, gathered last night at the Hotel Commodore with the sons and grandsons of veterans at a Lincoln's Birthday dinner meeting. James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, was the principal speaker.

The American Bankers Association in a statement issued yesterday outlined its position on important financial measures before Congress. The association opposes hasty action on the Glass banking bill; believes that action on the Federal Home Loan Bank bill should be deferred until the success of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in dealing with the problems involved can be determined, and takes an emphatic stand against the bill to increase to $5,000 the postal savings deposit limit.

The formation in 1927 of the Sugar Institute, Inc., defendant in an antitrust suit brought by the Department of Justice, was an act of public service, John C. Higgins of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell, attorneys for the institute, said yesterday, completing the opening of the defense before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack.
ROME, Feb. 10. -- Italy is preparing to celebrate the bicentenary of George Washington's birth, and the government has appointed a special committee to devise ways to honor him.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 11. -- Nelson T. Johnson, United States Minister to China, Sir Miles Lampson, the British Minister, and Henri A. Wilden, French Minister, were on the way from Nanking, reports said, for a conference here with Japanese and foreign officials regarding the situation.
Joe Zelli of Montmartre and the West Fifties left these United States last night more in sadness than in anger.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 10. -- The Princeton varsity hockey team defeated the Lake Katonah Club tonight in the Hobey Baker memorial rink by a 3-to-2 score for its seventh successive victory. Play was comparatively slow, with the visitors carrying the offensive throughout the final period only to fall short of tying the score.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- Belief in some quarters that price fluctuation would be stopped by suspension of the gold standard was termed "pure childishness" by Alexander D. Noyes, financial editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in an address before the Philadelphia Association of Security Salesmen at the Penn Athletic Club today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- An agreement between the Cosulich Line, Lloyd Sabaudo and the Navigaziono Generals Italian pooling earnings on passenger traffic was approved today by the Shipping Board.

BOULDER CITY, Nov., Feb. 10. -- Fed by a twenty-four-hour rain and a cloudburst, the Colorado River suddenly speeded up from an indolent five second-feet of water to 50,000 second-feet and charged down today upon the builders of Hoover Dam.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- As was to be expected, Ambassador Hugh S. Gibson's speech at Geneva yesterday was received coldly in official circles here and with open hostility by the press. Chancellor Bruening's address, of course, received no better welcome. The French feel thay have offered a feasible plan and since not only the American and German, but also the Italian views, given today, clash with those of France, comment is naturally unfavorable.

Nathaniel Davis, the author of this one, is said to be a Philadelphia actor with the means of finance his first work as a playwright. Mr. Davis may be air-minded -- his title would seem to indicate as much -- but he is certainly not theatre-minded. As disclosed at the Ritz last night his "dramatic comedy" was something that appeared to have strayed in out of the rain.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- The movement of hogs throughout the West today was materially smaller than a week ago and a year ago. Supplies here were below trade requirements and prices advanced 10 to 15 cents, although the demand was not particularly strong.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 10. -- Fielding H. Yost, athletic director at the University of Michigan, who has just completed an investigation into each of the forty-three deaths charged against football last Fall, disclosed today that only twenty-two of the fatalities actually resulted from playing the game.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- A resolution calling for immediate modification of the Volstead act to permit manufacture of beer of 2.75 per cent of alcoholic content by weight was sent to members of Congress today by the executive committee of the American Federation of Labor following an all-day session.

Unworried by Dress Strike Threat. Incoming buyers are displaying no apprehension regarding the threatened strike in the dress industry, in he belief an adjustment will be made without a prolonged cessation should a strike materialize, it was reported here yesterday in well-informed quarters.

GENEVA, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Foreign Minister Dino Grandi, chief of the Italian delegation, told the World Disarmament Conference today that Italy rejected the French theory of the necessity of security to precede disarmament and that his government was willing to abolish capital ships, submarines, aircraft carriers, heavy artillery, tanks, bombing aircraft and chemical warfare weapons, and to revise the laws of war to protect civilian populations.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 10. -- Apprehension is growing over the possibility of serious Communist disturbances inside the International Settlement in the next fortnight.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 10. -- Dr. George W. Knight, Professor Emeritus of History at Ohio State University in Columbus and former dean of its College of Education, died there today of pneumonia at the age of 73. During his career at the university he had taught 16,000 students.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Five Republican members of the California delegation in Congress sought the support of President Hoover today for a two-cents-a-gallon excise sales tax on imported crude oils, and of four cents a gallon on gasoline imports.

GENEVA, Feb. 10. -- All the great powers but one have now laid their cards on the disarmament conference table. Great Britain, France, the United States, Germany, Italy, Japan and Poland have stated their cases. The three latter spoke today. Tomorrow it will be the turn of Russia and Belgium.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Following is the text of Secretary Hurley's statement today before the House Insular Affairs Committee:

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10. -- Joseph Edwards's 8-year-old brown mare, Single Star turned in an excellent effort to win by a nose from J.D. Norris Jr.'s Tombereau in the six-furlong, dash which held the feature position on the card at Hialeah Park today.

The year 1931 was one of progress for the Hackensack Water Company, although the company was affected by conditions common to all industry, says Nicholas S. Hill Jr., president, in his annual letter to stockholders.

A refutation of attacks on President Hoover contained in recent books purporting to reveal sensational facts bearing upon his business and public career previous to his election is contained in an article appearing in the issue of Collier's Weekly, out today.

Prices on the Curb Exchange moved yesterday in a narrow range with the significant changes about evenly divided between gains and losses. The volume of transactions continued small. Domestic and foreign bonds were also mixed.

A total of $12,500 has been raised from all sources to date toward the amount needed to assure the payrolls for the remaining productions of the season of the New York Opera Comique, Kendall K. Mussey, director of the company, announced yesterday at the third meeting of the employment pledge campaign committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Declaring that the Geneva conference demonstrated that little can be expected in the way of further disarmament and the situation in China had shown what a determined armed power can do in the face of treaties, Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Affairs Committee announced today that he would push consideration of his naval building bill despite the opposition of the Hoover Administration and the Democratic leadership of the House.

Designs for the Palace of the Soviets, to be erected in Moscow, constitute the outstanding feature of Joseph Urban's exhibition, which opens this afternoon at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street -- a show that may be looked upon as an interesting supplement to the current exhibition of modern architecture in the "International Style" at the Museum of Modern Art.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 10. -- Both the Japanese and Chinese combed the Shanghai area today for whatever materials of war they could lay their hands on.

Vicente Escudero introduced three new dances at his sixth New York performance last night in Chanin's Forty-sixth Street Theatre. The "Jota de Navarra," with music by Granados, proved to be very much the twin of the previous jota; and since the earlier number was a good one.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10. -- In honor of Chester Harvey Rowell, who addressed the current events lecture subscribers this afternoon at the apartment of Addison Mizner, and of Dr. Hamilton Holt, president of Rollins College, Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Bryden gave a dinner tonight for twelve guests at their home.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 10. -- As Governor Moore's non-partisan committee for municipal tax relief, representing the Legislature, the State League of Municipalities and the State Association of Freeholders, was called today to meet at the Newark Athletic Club tomorrow and attack the tax problem, the Executive announced he would invite legislative leaders, bankers and bond brokers to a conference Monday at the State House.

A suit against J.J. Shubert, theatrical producer, by his former wife, Mrs. Catherine M. Shubert, to amend a divorce decree of 1917 and to require Mr. Shubert to provide "adequate support" for her was revealed in Supreme Court yesterday when Mr. Shubert's attorney, William Klein, argued before Justice Levy for dismissal of the action, Decision was reserved.

The prospect for definite accomplishment by the disarmament conference now in session at Geneva is improving daily, Sir John Simon, head of the British delegation there, said yesterday in a radio address heard in New York through Station WABC.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- Viscount Snowden, "the man without a party," as he described himself as he sat amid the ranks of the Conservative peers massed on the treasury benches, made his first speech in the House of Lords today when he delivered an attack on the tariff policy of the National Government, in which he is Lord Privy Seal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Extension of the candidacy of Speaker Garner for the Democratic nomination for President beyond the status of a "favorite son" was the outstanding development today in the situation caused by the receptive candidacy of Alfred E. Smith of New York and the statement of Jouett Shouse, national executive chairman, urging the election of uninstructed delegates to the national convention.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 11 (AP). -- A detachment of United States marines narrowly escaped death or injury when a Chinese cotton mill in which they were billeted was bombed by a Japanese airplane at noon today. Five Chinese were killed and fifteen wounded when one of the bombs exploded, building in which the marines were quartered was wrecked.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 10. -- Commenting on Senator Johnson's proposal to close the money markets of the United States to Latin-American countries which have failed to meet service on foreign debts, the conservative paper Diario Illustrado says today that this is another instance in which the mismanaged government of Chile preceding the military regime plunged the nation into the depth of discredit.

The council of the National Academy of Design announced yesterday a list of nine paintings by American artists which it had bought with income from the Henry W. Ranger fund during the last seven months. The paintings have been assigned to various museums and other institutions in this country.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney is considering having physical examinations of all prisoners accused of serious crimes made by physicians not connected with the Police Department, at the time of arraignment, in order to forestall accusations that third degree methods have heen used to obtain confessions, he disclosed yesterday.

Jazz and the radio are "refining influences" on musical taste in the United States according to Percy Grainger, newly appointed head of the music department of the New York University College of Fine Arts.

BABYLON, L.I., Feb. 10. -- Declaring that flower growers in Holland are using airplanes and four-day ocean, liners with special refrigerators to invade the New York market and flood it with surplus blooms that cannot be sold in England and France because of tariff barriers, the Long Island Bulb Growers Association moved today to obtain a Federal embargo on the importation of flowers.

An application for the listing of 153,672 shares of $40 par preferred stock and 153,672 shares of common stock of the National Distillers Products Corporation was approved yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The preferred stock is to be listed on official notice of issuance in exchange for shares of stock of the Medicinal Holding Corporation and the common is to be listed on official notice of conversion of the preferred shares.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- The directors of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., decided today to suspend payment of dividends on all classes of stock outstanding. The dividends omitted are the quarterly payments of $1.50 on the second preferred, $1.38 on the 5 1/2 per cent preferred and 1 1/2 per cent in stock on the common stocks, all due at this time.

In a ring surrounded by a crowd of Scottish terrier enthusiasts, Heather Aristocrat of Hitofa, owned by Frank Spiekerman of the Hill Top Farm Kennels of Greenwich, Conn., gained the highest honors in the breed yesterday at the specialty show of the Scottish Terrier Club of America in the combined exhibition of the Associated Terrier Clubs in the Grand Central Palace.

Opportunities for individuals to become increasingly active in affairs of State and in the solution of international problems were emphasized in Ash Wednesday sermons yesterday. Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York warned worshipers at Trinity Church in the financial district that they had a choice between Christ and chaos.

Saturday will be just another day. The sun will rise and set, and the moon, too. There will be business as usual, and in the evening the theatres will be filled. But there will be a void in a thousand homes and small shops of the land. For the pink sheets of the Police Gazette will not brighten them this week and possibly never again.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- Anthony Eden, Parliamentary Secretary for Foreign Affairs, assured the House of Commons today that the League of Nations Council had not considered imposing an economic boycott on Japan under the provisions of Article XVI of the covenant and that the question had not arisen.
PARIS, Feb. 10 (AP). A comprehensive analysis of German reparations payments, designed to refute German claims recently published here, was issued by the French Government tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Voicing the opinion of the Hoover Administration, Secretary Hurley told the House Insular Affairs Committee today that the time was not ripe to grant independence to the Philippine Islands.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- A February heat wave spread over the Middle West today, shattering all-time records in some cities.

For the first time since 1905 the directors of the Eastman Kodak Company voted yesterday to omit the payment of an extra dividend on the company's stock. Since 1925, the extra dividends have been $3 a year.

ROME, Feb. 10. -- Foreign Minister Dino Grandi's speech at the Geneva disarmament conference has been read with the greatest attention and interest in Rome, where it is regarded as one of the most notable contributions yet made to the solution of the problem of reduction of armaments.

A break between Samuel Seabury and Governor Roosevelt appeared to be imminent last night as reports reached here that the Governor had decided tentatively against summary removal of Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, a strong Tammany district leader.
"Monkey." a play by the late Sam Janney, will open this evening at the Mansfield Theatre.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Wheat today showed more resistance to pressure than of late on the Board of Trade here and rallied 1 to 1 3/8 cents after an early decline that carried the May 4 3/4 cents under the high of last week. Fairly aggressive commission-house buying on the early break absorbed the pit surplus, and continuation of the purchases started local shorts to cover.

Increased offerings attributed largely to liquidation of tired, long accounts depressed prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday. May contracts sold off to 6.63 cents a pound, their lowest price since the January rally to 7.03 cents. The market closed barely steady at the bottom at net declines of 10 to 12 points.

Fourteen articles on "The Christian Way Out of Our International and Economic Difficulties," to be published during Lent in The Witness, a Protestant Episcopal weekly periodical, were announced yesterday. Two articles are to be published each week, beginning Saturday.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 10. -- H.W. Watlington's Bermuda Waterworks will be formally opened tomorrow by Governor Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt and commercial service will begin immediately.
Ch. Yang Fu Tang, a chow, and Ch. Sealand Career, a pomeranian, were crowned best of breed at their respective specialty exhibitions yesterday in the Hotel McAlpin.

An area of about 1,000 square miles, with a population of 150,000, comprises the Memel region which has just been brought before the League of Nations by a military stroke reminiscent of the early post-Armistice years in Central Europe. The territory lies on the Baltic along the eastern border of the same East Prussia whose western frontier is the celebrated Polish Corridor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The announcement of Foreign Minister Yoshizawa in Tokyo today that Japan was considering sending envoys to the United States, Great Britain and France to explain and clarify the Japanese position on the Manchurian question was received with surprise here today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- The Public Service Company of Northern Illinois, the third of the big Insull operating companies to issue annual reports this week, made a relatively better showing for 1931 than either the Commonwealth Edison or the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Companies.

Eddie Flynn, New Orleans, national amateur welterweight champion, scored a victory in Madison Square Garden last night over Charles Crovatta, Pittsburgh, Allegheny Mountain champion, before a crowd of about 6,000.

HONOLULU, Feb. 10. -- The great airplane carrier Saratoga was "bombed out of commission" in the war games off Hawaii at dawn today by fifteen bombing planes of the "Black" forces defending Hawaii against attack.

TOKYO, Feb. 10. -- Proposals for demilitarized zones in China are now definitely connected with Japan's policy of sending troops to Shanghai. A Foreign Office spokesman today recalled that Japan had announced two objectives -- order and security in Manchuria and the suppression of the boycott in China.

NOW that the Olympic skaters have cooled out, a reasonable survey of the arguments involved may be taken. Primarily it was a clash between skating systems. The Europeans run speed-skating races one way. We run them another. They dislike our way. We dislike their way. There are some objections to both schemes.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- Petitions to put the name of former Governor Smith on the Democratic preferential primary ballot as a candidate for the Presidential nomination will be circulated in Pennsylvania by a group headed by George F. Douglas, a candidate two years ago for superior judge.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Alfred E. Smith could not withstand the factors that forced him to make a statement that he would take the nomination if tendered to him, for the following reasons:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- Seemingly beaten by the bob piloted by a mere slip of a boy, the gray-haired Stevens brothers came careening down the Mount Van Hoevenberg run today in two thrilling trips, shattered all records and virtually assured the Winter Olympic team championship for the United States.
The original deeds for the purchase of Wakefield, in Virginia, the birthplace of George Washington, which were thought for nearly a century to have been lost, have come to light.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 10 (AP). -- Angered at a question by a member of the Senate Finance Committee, General Charles P. Summerall told the committee today he would resign within six hours as president of the Citadel, the State military college.
LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The effect of Mahatma Gandhi's boycott on British trade in India is vividly shown in a report by T.M. Ainscough, the senior British Trade Commissioner in India, published today.
