The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives is preparing a tax bill for 1932-33. Leaders of both parties have declared that the proper goal is an attempt to balance the budget. Speaker GARNER believes that this should be done "not later than some time in 1933."

Winning by default from the Fraternity Club, which was unable to put a team on the courts owing to injuries suffered by three of its players, the New York A.C. drew within striking distance of the Columbia University Club last night in the Metropolitan Class A squash tennis championship.

The Trade and Commerce Bar Association, a new national organization which will provide for business interests information on legislation affecting the "freedom of industrial enterprise" and formulate proposals for industrial legislation, filed incorporation papers in Albany yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10. -- Yale's hockey team defeated Boston University tonight, 6 to 1, a goal by Clem midway in the third stanza, saving the visitors from a shut-out.

PINEVILLE, Ky., Feb. 10 (AP). -- Within less than an hour tonight, eleven New York writers, members of a committee for the relief of miners, were arrested in their hotel rooms, arraigned on changes of disorderly conduct, had the charges dismissed and were escorted to the State border after being advised never to return to Bell County.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Senators Fess of Ohio and Borah of Idaho, both Republicans, clashed today in a lively debate over the La Follette-Costigan bill for direct Federal aid for the unemployed. Crowded galleries applauded the speakers. Vote on the measure was delayed until tomorrow, when Republican leaders count on Democratic aid for its defeat.

Nearly $500,000 has been spent by the School Relief Fund since Oct. 1 to provide food, clothing and other aid for needy pupils and their families, according to a report made yesterday by Frederick D. Chambers, treasurer of the fund, at a meeting of the Board of Education.
BUCHAREST, Feb. 10. -- Your correspondent learns from exclusive sources of an important political development in Rumania, presaging the end of the semi-dictatorial regime of Professor Nicolas Jorga.

Resolutions that would have placed the New York Board of Trade on record as in favor of resale price maintenance and legislation to make it effective were referred back to the price maintenance committee at a meeting of the board, yesterday at the Hotel Prince George.

TOKYO, Feb. 10. -- Repeated questioning of Tadashi Konuma, held as the assassin, of former Finance Minister Junnosuke Inouye, has failed so far to elicit information definitely linking him with any political organization, though his methods suggest intelligent direction.

HAVANA, Feb. 10. -- The speedy Winsome, entry of the Peconic Bay fleet and skippered by Harkness Edwards, completed a string of triumphs in these waters by leading an American team of four star class yachts to a 23-to-12 victory today over a Cuban team in the concluding event of the six-day regatta here.

The Lawyers Mortgage Company, which acquired the five-story loft building at 391 Broadway last year, has sold the property to an investor. The building occupies a lot 25 by 100 feet between White and Walker Streets.

Just when Wall Street was steeling itself for another sharp extension of the recent decline, rallying tendencies developed on the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon and cancelled the greater part of the early losses. The market was breaking rather badly when the recovery unexpectedly got under way.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Roosevelt's anti-League stand, the Governor should know, was a grievous disappointment to many of his ardent supporters. The reasons for this should be clearly spelled out.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb 10. -- Japan is sending to San Francisco this week $18,500,000 in gold to strengthen her credit. Of this amount $13,500,000 is expected here early Saturday, according to United States customs officials, $5,000,000 having arrived last Sunday.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- Continuation of the quota system will virtually close the French market to American exports. This conclusion was reached today at a general meeting of the American Chamber of Commerce of Paris, whose members are gravely concerned over the contingent apportionment of French tariffs.

The vogue for gangster pictures glorifying criminals is having a harmful effect not only on boys but on girls as well, with the result that there is an increase in juvenile delinquency among young girls, according to the women superintendents of correctional institutions conferring here at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

One of the most important single additions ever made to the New York Public Library's collections was announced yesterday. It is the fourteenth century Tikytt Psalter, which brought $61,000, the highest price, at the auction of the library of the Marquess of Lothian on Jan. 27 and 28 at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.
LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 11. -- In large headlines today The Daily Express asks, "Has Japan a European Ally? -- A Secret Treaty?"

The governors of the New York Curb Exchange unanimously elected Howard C. Sykes president yesterday to succeed William S. Muller. Edwin Posner was chosen vice president, Mortimer Landsberg treasurer, Eugene R. Tappen secretary, and E.J. Muller assistant treasurer.

Lack of bids rather than heavy offerings forced prices lower yesterday in practically all departments of the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Domestic corporation issues were the weakest, with United States Government securities irregularly lower, while foreign loans, chiefly the higher-rated issues, showed the best resistance to the decline.
The Hamburg-American liner New York will arrive today from Hamburg and Channel ports. Those on board include:

SHANGHAI, Feb. 11 -- "We will attack any force which attacks us," declared Admiral Nomura, the Japanese naval commander, in an exclusive interview aboard his flagship at sunset tonight after he had carefully considered sixteen questions submitted in writing this morning.

The recovery in the securities markets yesterday was felt with full force on the New York Curb Exchange, where stocks rose 1 to 7 points on increased activity. Domestic bonds also closed with good gains, but foreign bonds were slow to catch the trend and finished irregular.

Butter. Receipts, 13,450 packages. The market held unchanged on fancy butter yesterday with prices only barely supported. Supplies are liberal and general demand for top grades was only moderately broad. Receivers ware following a free selling policy and plenty of fancy stock was available at quotations.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 11 -- Less than five hours after a Japanese airplane dropped two bombs into the Wingon Cotton Mill, a portion of which was occupied as billets by men or the Third Battalion of the Fourth Regiment of United States Marines, Admiral Nomura's Chief of Staff.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The officially amended Board of Trade figures for Great Britain's foreign trade in January are as follows: Exports of British products, u31,120,000; reexports, u5,230,000; total exports, u36,350,000; total imports, u62,260,000; excess of imports, u25,910,000.

The committee on criminal courts law and procedure of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, in its current bulletin, voices its disapproval of proposed legislation relating to the possession, use and licensing of firearms, on the ground that the suggested elimination of fingerprinting and photographing for permits, as well as other proposed changes, would tend to break down safeguards effected by present laws.

Wall Street's enthusiasm for the proposed bill to liberalize the rediscount privileges of the Federal Reserve Sysmtem was evidenced yesterday by a broad and vigorous upswing on the security exchanges that added $3,000,000,000 or more to open market values.

Bank clearings, as had been expected, were somewhat smaller in the week ended on Wednesday than in the preceding week, according to reports from centres received by Dun's Review. Clearings for the week amounted to $4,604,930,000, or 34.3 per cent less than in the same week last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Representatives of railroad security owners, electric railways, railway labor and industries supplying the carriers with materials and equipment, united today in opposition to further enforcement of the recapture provisions of the Interstate Commerce act, before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

Owen (Owney) Madden, convicted slayer and reputedly one of the city's biggest racketeers, and three other ex-convicts, mentioned with him in the Attorney General's investigation of the suspected "laundry racket," were being sought last night by detectives with warrants for their arrest as parole violators and for their immediate return to prison.

MANILA, Feb. 11 -- The Philippines Herald, a strong independence paper, carried a special story today signed by Marcial Lichauco, a member of the Philippine Mission, quoting Secretary Hurley as declaring the Filipinos to be incapable of governing themselves.

Although readjustments are continuing to be made in industry, little appreciable revival has materialized yet, according to the weekly reviews of trade and business. In some directions the trend of business is rising irregularly, but curtailed public buying power continues to hold up purchases of all lines except actual necessities.
LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

One must be patient with one's friends, but the continuous vocal efforts of Senator DILL, and Senator WHEELER must be a little trying to Governor ROOSEVELT. They are not patrons whose recommendations are likely to advance his fortunes in the East.

Letters and telegrams approving a world peace program proposed by The Ladies' Home Journal In an editorial letter addressed to Miss Mary E. Woolley were read yesterday at a luncheon given by Loring A. Schuler, editor of the magazine, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Homer S. Cummings of Stamford, Conn., former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, arrived here tonight for conferences with supporters of Governor Roosevelt. It was indicated that he would be the national manager of the Roosevelt campaign for the nomination for President.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Hoover and Will Rogers got together this afternoon in an effort to settle almost everything that is disturbing the world, particularly Manchuria, Shanghai, hoarding, Alfalfa Bill Murray and commission government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Several Senators agreed tonight to receive the New York writers reported mistreated and escorted from Pineville, Ky., by county officers while attempting to aid striking miners.

In a letter to stockholders of the Prairie Pipe Line Company urging approval of the proposed consolidation of that company with the Prairie oil and Gas Company and the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation, W.P. Gates, president of Prairie Pipe Line, said yesterday that liquiation of the company's assets was not possible and that the only choice available was between the continued operation of the company as a separate unit and the proposed merger.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 12 -- A four-hour truce allowed rescuers to enter the Chapei battle zone to bring out any civilians and wounded soldiers trapped there. They emerged at 11:30 A.M. and said their merciful errand had been completed as far as possible.

The renominatlon of John K. Fitch, class of '02, as president of the Alumni Federation of Columbia University was announced yesterday by Levering Tyson, '11, chairman of the alumni nominating committee.

A deficit in the taxable estate of Robert W. Chanler, artist, otherwise known as Sheriff Bob, was shown in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday, although two untaxable trust funds totaling $465,843 were also shown in the appraisal papers. The gross taxable estate of the artist was $163,146, but deductions for debts, mortgages, and other expenses totaled $199,571.

The drive by friends of former Governor Alfred E. Smith to win to his support as many delegates as possible in New England and the East in opposition to Governor Roosevelt begins, it was indicated here yesterday, in New Hampshire early next week.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 11 -- The Minneapolis Gas Light Company offered today, subject to approval of the City Council, to exchange its own stock, a second preferred 5 per cent issue, for approximately $2,500,000 of American Commonwealths Power Corporation stock which the public purchased from the Minneapolis Company or its officers or employes.

Arrangements were made yesterday for sales of four seats on the New York Stock Exchange through purchases of rights at a cost of $135,000 for each membership. The sales were the first steps taken by the special committee of the Exchange that has undertaken to dispose of the unexercised rights in the next year.

New dogs were in the rings and on the benches, new enthusiasts crowded about to watch the competitions, but it was the same great exhibition of thoroughbred dogs that the Westminster Kennel Club opened yesterday morning in Madison Square Garden.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 11 (AP) -- An invitation to the world to join him in prayer for the liberation of humanity will be issued by Pope Pius tomorrow when he broadcasts a message in connection with the tenth anniversary of his coronation.
COPENHAGEN, Feb. 11 -- The 1931 accounts of Denmark's largest private bank, the Danske Landmandsbank, were presented at a meeting of the directors today.

The battle between the two committees seeking deposits from holders of the $30,000,000 General Theatres Equipment, Inc., 6 per cent convertible debentures on which the interest is not expected to be paid on April 1, was opened in earnest yesterday, when the so-called independent committee, as opposed to the committee in which the Chase National Bank is interested, questioned the priority of the bank loans over the debentures.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Eleven years ago I made the prediction to some friends that some day Franklin Roosevelt would be nominated by the Democratic party and elected President of the United States. Of course, as yet no real certainty exists as to either of these things.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The Court of Appeals has upheld the right of teachers to compel the Teachers Retirement Board of New York City by mandamus to pay a retirement allowance. The opinion, written by Judge Irving Lehman, reversed the findings of the Appellate Division, First Department, in an action brought by Miss Jennie Erskine Murray, and reinstated the decision of the Special Term.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- At first the wheat trade today construed the talk of currency inflation as likely to be decidedly bullish, resulting in a wave of buying at the opening of the Board of Trade here that swept prices 1 to 2 cents a bushel above the finish of the previous day.

NEW YORK. W. Vinton King, accompanied by his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. C. Shelby Carter, will leave tonight for Havana. Later they will visit Mr. and Mrs. Salvador Rionda in Manati, and Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Doty in Tuinucu, Cuba.
The George Washington High School quintet vanquished the High School of Commerce, 20 to 15, in a Manhattan division P.S.A.L. game at the George Washington court yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 12 -- The Japanese high command determined today to reduce the stubborn Chinese forts at Woosung with 500-pound aerial bombs.

WARSAW, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Polish Commissioner of Danzig, H. Strasserburger, resigned today. The Polish Government announced that he had done so "because increased German 'Nazi' influence prevented efforts at cooperation between Danzig and Poland."

The Sev Realty Corporation gave to Sol Bloom a mortgage for $25,000. payable Jan. 18, 1935, on 334-342 East Twenty-seventh Street and 329-330 East Twenty-sixth Street, subject to prior existing mortgages aggregating $188,400.

A college emergency relief corporation to tide higher educational institutions through the depression without diminution of important activities was suggested last night by Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, at a dinner of the Stevens Alumni Association at the Hotel Astor.
Sixteenth Street, 104-06 East, 46 feet wide, and 32 Union Square, 26 by 125; Tea Realty Corporation to Third Holding Corporation, 342 Madison Avenue.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 12 -- Continued Japanese shelling of the Woosung area and occasional shelling and bombing of the Chapei district of Shanghai marked the fourteenth day of hostilities yesterday, the anniversary of the founding of the Japanese Empire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Ogden L. Mills will be sworn in as Secretary of the Treasury tomorrow morning, when the retiring Secretary, Andrew W. Mellon, will take the oath of office as Ambassador to Great Britain and Arthur A. Ballantine as Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

Bonds rallied briskly yesterday on the Stock Exchange in response to the plan to expand the credit base of the Federal Reserve System. Many domestic corporation issues were pushed up 1 to 5 points, the rails making the best recoveries, having suffered most during the recent decline.
VATICAN CITY, Feb. 11 -- The Pope today received Benito Mussolini not merely as Premier of Italy but as the chief of the Italian State.

Winter fog descended over the city yesterday and rose and fell intermittently all day until night, when it settled down in earnest, disrupting harbor traffic schedules and delaying several liners ready to sail. In brief spells when the fog lifted incoming ships managed to work their ways to dock, and a few of those sailing slipped out.

Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, an influential Tammany district leader, who Samuel Seabury has charged is unfit for public office, was notified yesterday that he must stand trial next Tuesday before Governor Roosevelt, from whose decision there is no appeal.

Two Columbia swimming records went crashing last night in the Morningside pool as the Lions defeated Dartmouth, 49 to 22. Parnell Callahan of Columbia, breast stroke star, established a new mark in his specialty and the Lions' 400-yard relay team bettered the record which they made a week ago.

All the important financial and commodity markets, with the exception of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange, will be closed today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. The security exchanges, including the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb, will reopen tomorrow, but some of the commodity markets will remain closed until Monday, The New York Cotton Exchange is among those that will be open tomorrow as usual.

Responsibility for any eventual failure on the part of the United States and other nations to cope with the Sino-Japanese crisis was placed squarely on the shoulders of isolationists in this country in a statement issued yesterday by the board of directors of the League of Nations Association, of which Charles H. Strong is chairman.

A proposal that the members of Typographical Union No. 6 employed in newspaper offices demand the five-day week and the six-hour day led the list of six propositions voted upon at a referendum of the union it was announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 10, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,807,000,000, a decrease of $23,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $859,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.
Trading on the Real Estate Securities Exchange yesterday resulted in the sale of one 301 East Thirtyeighth Street Building certificate for $21.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 11. -- One of the problems confronting the football rules committee, which meets here tomorrow, will be legislation regarding equipment, it was announced today. For this purpose a committee of six manufacturers of spoiling goods will sit with the rules committee.

Arnold Hoffmann, a Russian painter of the Roerich type, is having an exhibition of oils and lithographs at the Car-Delbo Gallery until Feb. 15. Like other members of the Russian "Travellers" group, he is preoccupied in contemplation of the occult. "Arnold Hoffmann is a visionary," writes Alton Gulkis in the catalogue foreward.
ALBANY. Feb. 11 -- Bills appropriating $250,000 to continue the work of the Hofstadter committee inquiry were introduced in the Legislature today.

The American college president, as Professor LASKI writes in the current Harper's, is "a unique institution," without a European analogue. "The Harvard of ELIOT, the Yale of "HADLEY, the Chicago of HARPER are "almost epochs in the intellectual "life of American civilization."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- With applications for loans being received daily by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Secretary Hyde issued today regulations under which farmers may borrow from the special fund of $50,000,000 for agricultural purposes.

Contracts for the exchange of Union City and Hackensack properties have been signed by Peter Leone, Inc., with the P.L.M. Holding Company. Under the trade the Leone company will convey the three-story frame flat with store at 200 Fortieth Street, northwest corner of Hudson Avenue, Union City.

Brokers' loans declined $19,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the current total of $486,000,000 being the lowest on record, with the exception of the $473,438,000 reported on Jan. 25, 1918, in war time.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- With the bob run turned from a ribbon of ice to a swift rivulet of melted snow, the Olympic program almost was halted completely today as rain end Spring-like weather returned. But the conditions could not halt the Norwegian ski-jumping stars, who enthralled a crowd of 7,000 with superb exhibitions of courage and skill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Vessels engaged in intercoastal commerce would be prohibited from carrying cargoes consisting of products "manufactured, mined or produced" by the owners or operators of the ships, under a shipping act introduced today by Senator Johnson of California at the request of the Shipping Board.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Lewis holds that Japan may ultimately "rule Asia" and "sees Russia as an ally." Senator Lewis failed to figure that Manchuria, and even "all of China" should Japan "attach" them, would not constitute all of Asia.

Secretary HURLEY'S opposition to the bill proposing to grant immediate independence to the Philippines is important in itself and also for what it represents. He expressed what must be the view of President HOOVER. It must also be the policy which the new Governor General of the Philippines, now on his way to his post, has agreed to carry out.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Since the "disillusionment" of the American people after the failure of the Hoover moratorium last June they have become "more isolationists than at any time since the rejection of the Treaty of Versailles," Walter Lippmann, New York editorial writer, today told the members of the American Club of Paris in an address at their weekly luncheon.

The autobiography of Sir Finders Petrie, whose researches into the past have led to much rewriting of the world's history, will be published today by Henry Holt under the title. "Seventy Years in Archaeology."

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 11 -- Guest of honor at a party here to mark his seventy-second birthday tonight, Colonel Isaac Schoenthal of Orange, a member of the Essex County Tax Board and former Surrogate of Essex County, was stricken with heart disease and died within a few minutes.

Expenditures for public health work should not be curtailed during this time of financial depression and unemployment, according to a resolution adopted by the State Public Health Council, made public yesterday by Dr. Simon Fiexner, its chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Edwin S. Cunningham, the United States counsel general at Shanghai, reported the bombing of the Wingon mill to the State Department today and Colonel Hooker of the Fourth Marines reported it to the Navy Department.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Spiritual phobias are the hardest things in life to conquer, because they are so deeply and fearfully rooted. So let us not be too hard on Protestants for carrying this idea of self-preservation all these years. Because so fine a politician as Alfred E. Smith is thus opposed, it is well that we know some of the reasons why.

No reasonable criticism can be made of Governor ROOSEVELT'S decision to hold a public hearing of the charges made against Sheriff FARLEY, with plaintiff, defendant and defendant's attorney present. Not only has the Governor broad powers in these matters; he has undisputed choice of methods of procedure.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 11 -- A statement issued last night by President Ortiz Rubio said that Luis Montes de Oca, former Minister of Finance, had been ordered during his stay in the United States to study the Federal Reserve System on behalf of the Mexican Government.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The text of the government's tariff bill, which was published tonight, reveals the free list is much greater than was indicated by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in his tariff speech a week ago.

Nearly 2,000 persons, including many leaders in statecraft, politics, education, jurisprudence and commerce, attended a dinner given at the Waldorf Astoria last night in honor of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, by the Alumni Federation of Columbia in cooperation with the trustees and faculty.
John Philip Sousa, composer and band leader, was guest of honor last night at a dinner given to him by the American Legion Post of the New York Athletic Club, in the club.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 11 -- Captain Lewis Yancey took off at 10:45 o'clock this morning for Tampico on his way to Cleveland. A large crowd, most of whom had never before seen a "windmill plane," witnessed the departure. Among them was a representative of President Ortiz Rubio.

A campaign for public housing construction was begun here yesterday by the Public Housing Conference of New York. Drafts of a State enabling act to permit cities to go into the housing business, and of a constitutional amendment to allow the States to extend credit to cities and to limited dividend corporations or cooperative associations for housing activities were presented to a representative group of social and civic workers.
TOKYO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Kigensetsu Japan's "Fourth of July,' was celebrated today by public demonstrations in which the Sino-Japanese conflict played a part.
HONOLULU, Feb. 11 -- The sixth day of the "Battle of Oahu" passed today with the "Blue invaders" still unable to attain their objective of a foothold on this island.

The ownership of five tenements in the Greenpoint district of Brooklyn, tenants of which denied knowing the landlord or having paid any rent in the last two years, was settled yesterday to the satisfaction of officials of the Tenement House Department after inspectors had searched for several days through Itligated city records.
LONDON, Feb. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Colonel MacKenzie - Rogan served in the army for fifty-three years. His great-grandfather fought under Marlborough and his father fought at the battle of Waterloo.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- It was learned here today that the negotiations leading to the Anglo-French "agreement" on reparations reported from Paris were so stormy that at one time Lord Tyrrell, the British Ambassador, threatened to resign in exasperation at the unyielding attitude of both the British and French negotiators.

An easy undertone continued in the market for Stock Exchange call loans, Street trades and Federal funds being made at a concession from the board rate, which held at 2 1/2 per cent, as previously. Time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were all quiet and unchanged in quotation.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 11 -- Resignations of two Roosevelt supporters as officials of the State Democratic Committee were forced today by John R. Collins, the chairman, on the ground that they were not Riving "impartial service to all the Democrats of Pennsyivania."

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Crystal Prince, 3-year-old gelding from P. C. Thompson's stable, won his second race of the Winter season when he carried off the honors in the feature Arcadian Purse, decided over six furlongs at the Fair Grounds today.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Two members of a group of New York writers, who went into the Kentucky coal fields to distribute food and clothes among needy miners, came here today with bruised heads and stories of beatings and deportation from the town of Pineville, but officials of that community discounted their reports.
PARIS. Feb. 11 -- Trading revived on the Bourse here today. Toward the close some irregularity developed, but the majority of the list finished higher. Copper, however, continued to lag.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Governor Roosevelt is understood to be prepared to submit on Monday his long-awaited list of appointments for New York City posts.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial regarding Al Smith's candidacy says: "if that abhorrent and un-American dragging of religion into politics were to be witnessed again."
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11. -- The Princeton Preparatory School quintet lost to the Princeton University Freshmen, 45 to 27, today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Eighteen graves containing the richly ornamented bodies of a people who lived nearly 5,000 years ago have just been discovered at Ur of the Chaldees by the joint expedition of the University of Pennsylvania Museum and the British Museum.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 -- Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Williams entertained tonight with a dinner at their villa. Their guests included:

All the class B shares of the Federal Water Service Corporation will he sold at auction by Adrian H. Muller Son at noon on Feb. 25, with other collateral securing loans advanced to the Tri-Utilities Corporation by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and the Chase National Bank.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Cottonseed crushed in the six-month period, ended Jan. 31 was announced today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 3,547,330 tons, compared with 3,730,660 tons for the same period a year ago, and cottonseed on hand at mills Jan. 31 was 1,179,210 tons, compared with 619,148 tons.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 11 -- Admiral William V. Pratt, speaking for the Navy Department, complained today of what he said was the misinterpretation placed on dispatches from Admiral Taylor, the American naval commander at Shanghai, by foreign newspapers.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, who is personally opposed to the prohibition law, instituted 2,188 padlock actions in the last year, or 25 per cent more than had been begun in any preceding year.

"I wrote three short stories in two days and sold them all," Elsie Janis writes in her autobiography, "So Far, So Good," published today by Dutton. "Imagine my elation! Having always wanted to be a writer, and already tired of the stage, it seemed to me providential that I had 'clicked' even in a small way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Navy Department order against the granting of shore leave to officers and enlisted men of the United States fleet while the ships are in Honolulu waters was modified today when, acting on the recommendation of Admiral Frank H. Schofield, Commander-in-Chief of the fleet, now at Pearl Harbor on his flagship, the Pennsylvania Admiral William V. Pratt.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The shooting of the Countess de Janze and Raymond Vincent de Trafford, brother of Sir Humphrey de Trafford, in a compartment of a London express train just before it pulled out of the Gare du Nord in Paris on March 26, 1927, was recalled today by a report in The Daily Express that they were to be married.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 11 -- The Woosung forts, at the junction of the Whangpoo and Yangtse Rivers, not only are still firmly held in Chinese hands but eight days of Japanese naval and aerial bombardment and four days of artillery fire have demolished only two of the twelve guns of the forts.

Dr. Harold R. Mixsell of the Princeton Club, national veterans' squash tennis champion since 1926, will defend his title against Frank A. Sieverman Jr. of the New York A.C. tomorrow in the final round of the eighth annual tournament at the Princeton Club.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the Hat below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 11 -- Mile upon mile of streets deserted, roadways and sidewalks gritty with broken glass, the entire area uninhabited except for occasional Japanese bluejacket guards, hungry dogs, homeless cats -- this was the spectacle found this morning when correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES toured North Szechuan Road in the Hongkew area of the International Settlement, armed with permits from Admiral Shiozawa and cameras.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Tumultuous scenes succeeded one another in the French Parliament this afternoon and tonight when a determined effort was made by the Opposition to reject the budget bill submitted by the committee because it was presented in deficit.

A stockholder's action seeking an accounting for $100,000,000 alleged to have been lost to the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation through improper management, and seeking the ultimate appointment of a receiver for the company, has been begun by Eddie Cantor, stage comedian, It was learned yesterday.

GENEVA, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Maxim Litvinoff, Commissar for Foreign Affairs for Soviet Russia, proposed total and universal disarmament to the World Disarmament Conference today as the only valid security against war.

GENEVA, Feb. 11 -- The circle of ideas within which this conference must find its solution of the world's armaments problem was completed and locked today when Maxim Litvinoff offered Soviet Russia's proposal that the only security against war was the abolition of all arms and armies.

Agreement was reached here yesterday between a local banking group and officials of the city of Detroit whereby the bankers will renew a loan of $7,500,000 to the city coming due on next Tuesday and will provide a credit of $5,900,000 to enable the city to meet current expenses.
Oils and water-colors by A. Everett Austin Jr., director of the Wadsworth Athenaeum at Hartford, Conn., will be on view at the Brummer Gallery until Feb. 29.

THE Football Rules Committee will hold a session today at Hanover with the esteemed E.K. Hall in the chair. Nothing revolutionary is expected to come out of Hanover. There have been countless suggestions for changes in the rules, regulations and equipment for gridiron warfare but it is doubtful that any but minor changes will be made or recommended.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11. -- Showing all the speed and racing ability that enabled him to remain undefeated for nearly two seasons, W. M. Moore's Vander Pool outgamed G. D. Widener's Panetian in a stirring stretch drive in the six furlongs of the featured Thomas A. Edison Handicap at Hialeah Park today to win by half a length.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Pennsylvania State College won the Pennsylvania intercollegiate glee club contest held under the auspices of the Philadelphia Forum tonight. The judges accorded the winning club 255 2/100 points out of a possible 300. West Chester State Teachers College was second with 246 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The possible trend of new national taxes was revealed today when it became known that the Ways and Means Committee had named subcommittees to study the proposal for a manufactures sales tax, also the plans for increased Imports on income taxes and gifts.

The plan of reorganization for the Tobacco Products Corporation has been declared operative by the banking committee in charge of the matter. Notice will be given later as to the date when debentures and stock of the new Tobacco Products Corporation will be available for exchange for the Class A and common shares of the present Tobacco Products Corporation of Virginia.

Marked ingenuity has been shown by and for the unemployed in devising means of using idle time with profit or pleasure. Most efforts of the kind, in the early days of depression, were directed toward finding or creating work or arranging classes for practical study.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 11 -- James G. Kimberley, president of the Neenah Paper Company and vice president of the Kimberley-Clark Company, announced today at his Winter home in Tryon, N.C., that he if moving his legal residence from Neenah, Wis., to Washington because of the increasing tendency of Wisconsin political leaders to penalize wealth by taxes.

Detailed plans for a west side rail terminal, office and residential centre over the Sixtieth Street yards of the New York Central Railroad, incorporating suggestions expanding the original proposals, were announced yesterday by the Regional Plan of New York and Environs.

The annual meeting of the Edison Pioneers was held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor. What once had been a gay reunion of men associated with the early days of the electric light and the phonograph became instead a sad memorial service.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 11 -- Premier Mussolini of Italy, accompanied by a small suite, including the Italian Ambassador to the Holy See, Senator de Vecchi; Minister of Justice Rocco, Under-Secretary of Foreign Affairs Fanl and Under-Secretary of the Presidency Guinta, was received in audience this morning by Pope Pius XI in his private library at the Vatican.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Legislation to open up huge, untapped reservoirs of credit to speed the return of normal business conditions was introduced today in Congress.

In setting forth the Soviet Government's views, LITVINOFF began by proposing total disarmament, but went on to state that he would be content with a good deal less. Signor GRANDI had proposed a drastic reduction in arms, but let it be known that worth-while results can be attained short of the ideal.

A very vigorous and broadly effective reading of Mahier's Fifth Symphony was given by Bruno Walter and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. This was Mr. Walter's contribution to the cause of Mahler, who has not been a generally popular figure on American orchestral programs.

Nominations to the number of 866 have been received for the eighteen fixtures which are to be staged during the Spring meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club at Jamaica, it was announced yesterday by Racing Secretary Henry Pebler. The meeting will run for twenty-two days beginning April 16.

Three men and two young women were arrested last night after an automobile chase through the streets of the Corona section of Queens, in which a number of shots were exchanged. One of the young women and a detective engaged in the chase were slightly wounded.

A group of paintings by American artists of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries is being shown at the Milch Galleries, to stay until March 5. Winslow Homer heads the list, as catalogued, with his "Eastern Point," a sea piece of rock and surf, from the collection of the Addison Gallery at Andover, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 --Purchase by the mint of silver mined in the United States at prevailing prices was proposed in a bill introduced today by Senator Pittman of Nevada. The limit would be 5,000,000 ounces a month.

HAMBURG, Feb. 11 -- Every Nazi (National Socialist) who dares to drink a drop of beer these days in Greater Hamburg will be thrown out of the party. This does not mean that the Hitlerites are going in for prohibition, but it is the most strik-which the Nazis and Communists are organizing to force the administration to reduce the beer tax.

Yesterday's vigorous and sustained recovery on the Stock Exchange was ascribed by Wall Street quite unanimously to the overnight proposals of the White House conference, regarding Federal Reserve facilities. It was recognized by bankers conversant with the facts that the proposed extension of rediscounting powers might be of substantial help to some sound member banks, in need of access to Reserve Bank credit.

Members of the New York Curb Exchange presented yesterday to William S. Muller, retiring president of the Exchange, a watch and chain and a diamond stickpin in recognition of his services to the organization during his four years as president.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Feb. 11 -- Nine hundred unemployed men today smashed their way into the Cabinet chamber where Prime Minister Squires was holding a party meeting. After upsetting tables, ripping telephones from the table and throwing ink wells about, they broke a picture over Sir Richard's head, the glass cutting his hands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A compromise plan for Federal unemployment relief without resort to a direct gift, as proposed by the Costigan-La Follette bill, or to Federal "loans" to States as contemplated in the Democratic substitute, was presented in a substitute offered today by Senator Wagner of New York.

The Republican State Committee is scheduled to meet on Feb. 27 to elect the delegates at large to the national convention in Chicago on June 14, it was announced yesterday. The formal call for the meeting will go out soon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The text of the Glass bill, introduced today, to improve the facilities of the Federal Reserve System, is as follows:

A gayly caparisoned production of "The Tales of Hoffmann," the first of the current season, was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Offenbach's amusing and often sentimental work, which continues to win popularity fifty-one years after its first performance in Paris, was presented last night with a cast that only the Metropolitan can lavish on an opera as light and unpretentious as this.

Lewis Carroll at Oxford. It Is hard to imagine the author of "Alice," Mr. CHARLES L. DODGSON, being a routine instructor at Oxford for many years. His branch was mathematics, and the Bishop of Oxford, writing in The London Times about the Lewis Carroll centenary, recounts some of his endeavors to make the students see how arithmetic is, after all, related to the facts of life.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 12 -- The truce agreed upon by Chinese and Japanese was established this morning, but was only partly observed, and instead of being confined solely to the removal of Chinese civilians from the shelled area of Chapel, it developed into a wild scramble on the part of Chinese attempting to rescue their belongings from North Szechuan Road and adjacent districts.

Abandonment of the gold standard would result in chaos throughout the world for an indefinite period, but such action is not conceivable either in the United States or throughout the world, Fred I. Kent has written in the American Bankers Association Journal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Fighting on a large scale between the Japanese and Chinese at the Woosung forts outside of Shanghai, in expert opinion here, must necessarily take on the character of trench and then open warfare, since the forts, which never were of much military value, have been rendered of little or no military value by the long Japanese bombardment.

Albert Tilt, secretary of the Manhattan Club and a silk merchant, won the great dominoes tournament put on by that institution. Out of the closed and smoke-darkened room where for the last fortnight mere merchants had been trying to defeat the judiciary, the officials finally brought the word early this morning.

The proposals for extending or modifying the Reserve law's provisions for rediscount and note issue, agreed on in principle at Wednesday's White House conference and about to be embodied in bills, have been widely misconstrued. This was perhaps inevitable, in view of the lately prevalent loose talk about "inflation."
HAVANA, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Meeting a large field of platers at a mile and a sixteenth, H. Lunsford's My Last Honey won her second race of the Oriental Park meeting today.

Shortly after contributions totaling $190,081 from 1,630 donors had been announced yesterday at the third weekly report luncheon at the St. Regis of the musicians' emergency aid campaign, Dr. Walter Damrosch, chairman of the organization, urged the 100 workers present to continue the drive for at least two weeks more.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 11 -- Financial figures of the New Jersey State Highway Commission were analyzed by State Senator Emerson L. Richards at the first meeting here today of the new joint legislative and municipal committee on financial relief for municipalities, to show that instead of being able to spare $16,500,000 which Governor Moore proposed to return to the municipalities, the highway commission, according to its own figures, has a deficit of $330,000.

Led by Frank T. Nordell, rangy sophomore, New York University last night retained the team title it captured last year in the annual metropolitan A.A.U. indoor track and field championships at the Fourteenth Infantry Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

Intimations of the complicity of the German Government in recent events in Memel which resulted in the deposing of Otto Boettcher, a German, from the presidency of the Executive Council, are contained in a note from the Lithuanian Government to the League of Nations, cabled to the Lithuanian Consulate General here yesterday.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names.

Since "Monkey," which was played at the Mansfield last evening, is not a good detective drama, everyone concerned has been courteous enough to ridicule it shamefully. Edward McNamara, the Hibernian flat-foot of "Strictly Dishonorable," appears in "Monkey" as a Hibernian flatfoot, and during the first act he rattles off as bare-faced a sequence of gags as an opening performance ever produced.

The North German Lloyd Line rompleted yesterday its tenth year of transatlantic operation after an extended period of war-time and postwar inactivity. On Feb. 11, 1922, the liner Seydlitz left Bremen for New York, the first ship of the line to head for this port since the United States entered the World War.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- As a prelude to a dinner at the Executive Mansion tonight Democratic chieftains of New York City met in conference with up-State leaders to discuss the candidacy of Governor Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for President.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Despite Republican protestations to the contrary, the proposed omnibus investigation of the administrative departments of the State, now under Democratic rule, is regarded by much of official Albany as an attempt on the part of Republican leaders to place the Democratic party in the State on the defensive, while the Hofstadter Committee is operating with the same objective in view where the Democratic Administration of New York City is concerned.

The Stuyvesant High School basketball team registered its fourth victory in as many Manhattan division P.S.A.L. games by defeating Haaren, 30 -- 15, yesterday at Stuyvesant. The losers led at the half, 11 -- 9.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- High government officials expressed the opinion today that there would be no opposition by the administration to the adoption by Congress of legislation which would temporarily waive features of the anti-trust laws to permit the adoption of a plan of bituminous coal operators for restriction of production with resultant price-fixing and regional sales agencies.
DETROIT, Feb. 11 -- "What's Henry Ford going to do?" is the question which the automobile world has been asking since the Spring of 1930.

SPRINGFIELD, 1ll., Feb. 11 -- Governor Pinchot of Pennsylvania, speaking before the Midday Luncheon Club at a Lincoln anniversary observance here tonight, charged that the basic cause of the depression in this country was the "greed" of a few persons who by concentrating the bulk of the nation's wealth in their own hands caused mass purchasing power to fall below production.

BERLIN, Feb. 11 -- A painting showing Jesus praying in the Garden of Gethsemane has been identified by Dr. Max Friedlaender of the Kaiser Friedrich Museum as a work of Lucas Cranach the Elder. The painting, which is about two by three feet, was discovered by the Rev. Martin Voelkel, pastor of a small church in Karlhorst, a Berlin suburb.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Feb. 11 -- A successful test of a new device to make flying safer was described at the Naval Air Station here today. The device is the sonic altimeter, perfected by engineers of the General Electric Company, and tried out in a flight of several hours' duration on Tuesday in the airship Los Angeles.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 -- It is known here that the Japanese have made overtures for the purchase of several vessels adapted to troop carrying, and that Washington has frowned on any such sales.

Word that The Police Gazette Is dying and will adorn the walls of the barber shops no more was heard with sadness yesterday in the city's tonsorial parlors. Strangely enough, the barber shops in the financial district were more sentimental about it than some of the less pretentious places on Second and Tenth Avenues.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The stock markets were active today and there was renewed demand for British Government funds. Sterling regained part of yesterday's losses, closing at $3.43 and sending the War Loan up 1/8 to u95 5/8 and the Funding Loan 1/8 to u86 1/8.
The 123d anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln will be celebrated throughout the nation today with dinners, luncheons, dances, radio addresses, military pageants and memorial exercises.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The return of Malta by a Parliamentary form of government by the restoration of the Constitution and general election at an early date are recommended in a report today of the royal commission sent to the island to investigate by Prime Minister MacDonald.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11. -- A preliminary report of a nation-wide investigation into football injuries was carried by Dr. Marvin A. Stevens, Yale head coach, to Hanover, N.H., today for submission to a meeting of the football rules committee.
Some good acreage deals and a variety of dwelling transactions were reported yesterday in the suburban areas. Increased activity was apparent in the several segments of the metropolitan zone.

GENEVA, Feb. 11 -- Tomorrow will mark the expiration of the fourteenday period in which the Chinese under Paragraph 9 of Article XV of the League of Nations covenant can force the convocation of an extraordinary League assembly to hear their case.

Cotton shared to the extent of about $1 a bale in the general market advances that followed yesterday's reports from Washington on emergency banking legislation. Despite the holiday tomorrow, commission house interest broadened and helped to raise prices from 6.44 to 6.66 cents for March contracts and from 7.02 to 7.25 cents for October, or 21 to 24 points above Wednesday's closing quotations.

The proposed changes in the Federal Reserve act, designed to broaden the lending powers of the Reserve Banks and to make effective the system's excess gold reserves, which have been agreed upon by Congressional leaders, were hailed with enthusiasm by Wall Street bankers yesterday as the "most constructive steps undertaken by the administration and Congress during the depression."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Denunciation by Secretary Hurley of the Hawes-Cutting bill to free the Philippines in five years as "cowardly" brought the Secretary into a verbal conflict with Senator Hawes which threatened to disrupt the meeting today of the Senate Committee on Territories and Insular Affairs.

First steps in the formation of a city-wide civic group designed to bring about "more efficient government in New York City, placing of all subways on a self-supporting basis and immediate operation of the Eighth Avenue subway" were taken at a conference yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker of representatives of more than forty trade and taxpayers' associations.

CHICAGO. Feb. 11 -- Tornadoes today swept over parts of Illinois and Oklahoma, destroying school houses and barns. Record high temperatures and a sixty-mile wind prevailed in the Chicago area, where fifteen buildings were damaged. Meanwhile a cold wave was reported moving down from Canada into the Northwestern States.

Chile Mapocho Acuna, former vice squad stool pigeon, whose testimony before Samuel Seabury as referee in the investigation of the magistrates' courts resulted in the indictment of more than a score of patrolmen as "framers," eluded his guard yesterday and hastily left for St. Petersburg, Fla.

The trade had varying opinions yesterday as to the public taste in valentines. Rudolph Frey of the Paper Novelty Manufacturing Company said that the old-time comic valentine is passe, as obsolete as the lace-fringed, hand-worked petticoat, but Harry Schmuckler of the Williamsburg Publishing Company said it is back stronger than ever because people "need a little bit of clean humor."

Senator FEARON disclaims ulterior motives for the committee the Republicans desire to have appointed by the Legislature to look into the conduct of the executive departments and bureaus at Albany. He and his Republican brethren hate to spend the Summer doing nothing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Less than ten days after his arrival in Athens to resume excavation on the site of the ancient agora, or public square, Dr. T. Leslie Shear, field director for the American School of Classical Studies, yesterday discovered four inscribed stelae and a marble figure from the beginning of the fourth century, B.C., according to word received here tonight.

Ambassador EDGE made his hurrled trip from Paris solely to look after his "personal affairs," but these seem to have included a little activity in New Jersey Republican politics. He is reported, along with the two Republican Senators from New Jersey, Messrs. KEAN and BARBOUB, to be urging the party organization in that State to make sure of a solid Hoover delegation at the Chicago convention.
GENEVA, Feb. 12 -- Lausanne as the place and June as the time have been chosen for the negotiation of a "durable solution of the problem of reparations," it was announced this evening.

SHAHGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 13 -- Heavy guns thundered through Shanghai at 8:05 A.M. today and a few moments later a squad of six Japanese airplanes rained down clusters of bombs on the Chinese positions in the ruins of Chapei.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 12 -- The immediate inauguration of a strike of all Chinese taxpayers in the International Settlement is sponsored by the Kuomintang Party headquarters in letters forwarded to the Chinese Ratepayers' Association, Shanghai, Citizens' Federation and the Chinese District Chamber of Commerce.

In case any one thinks that a Broadway columnist leads an uneventful existence, there is the instants of "Blessed Event," which was played boisterously at the Longacre last evening. It is the work of Manuel Seff and Forrest Wilson, and it is based on the fabulous career of Walter Winchell.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Nelson T. Johnson, the American Minister to China, in conferring at Shanghai with the British and French Ministers and in talking with Chinese merchants who desire his mediation for peace, is acting under general instructions to do what he can toward adjusting the Sino-Japanese controversy, the State Department said today.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 13 -- A heavy bombardment of the Chapei area by the Japanese during the night was evidence that peace had not resulted from the many conferences held here yesterday by the United States, British and French Ministers to China with the highest Chinese and Japanese officials in this city.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The troubles of President Hoover were likened to those that beset Abraharm Lincoln in speeches at the Lincoln Day dinner of the National Capital Republican Club tonight.

Steamship owners and agents indicated yesterday that they would oppose legislation. now before Congressional committees which would limit ship lines in coastal, intercoastal and cruise fields. The Johnson bill, introduced in the Senate Thursday at the request of the United States Shipping Board, is a substitute for a bill previously discarded as too sweeping, and will be opposed by intercoastal men.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The Royal Aero Club today awarded the Britannia Trophy for the year's most meritorious flying performance to the Australian airman, Bert Hinkler, for his New York to London flight.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Williams gave a small luncheon today at thein villa. The guests were Joseph E. Widener with his house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d, Mr. and Mrs. George D. Widener, Sir Humphrey De Trafford and Lady Trafford and Major Thomas Bouch, and Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas W. Paige and Mrs. J. Henry Alexandre.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report of the presentation to President Hoover by William Green, President of the Federation of Labor, which appeared in THE TIMES, induces me to address you. You have covered the situation admirably.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12 -- One of the largest weekday crowds of the season saw Jack Howard's consistent veteran Islam score his second successive victory to take the featured Darwin Purse by a length and a half from A.G. Weston's Dancing Mack at Hialeah Park today.
PARIS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Although the thirty-year battle for woman's suf-

With Jack Klunk and Irving Prank setting the pace with two victories apiece, New York University's swimming team last night defeated City College, 50-21, in the C.C.N.Y. pool, to remain undefeated in metropolitan tank circles.

England has one advantage over the other leading Powers in trying to think boldly and justly about the world crisis. She has tier general election behind her, while in this country, in France and perhaps in modified form in Germany the consultation of the people lies ahead.

Revivals of two Russian operas which were produced here last year by the Russian Opera Foundation were announced yesterday for performances the week of March 28 at Mecca Temple, at a meeting of members of the committee of the organization at the Chatham Hotel.

Patrolman Dudley P. Hanley, attached to the staff of Deputy Chief Inspector James S. Bolan, blundered into a hold-up while making a vice raid last night on an apartment at 113 West 114th Street and was shot and critically wounded toy one of the gunmen.

Dr. James M. Kieran, president of Hunter College, told the alumnae association of the college yesterday that the expansion program which was to see a new Hunter College centre in the Bronx within the next two years, may be delayed by the economy program adopted by the City Administration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Moving with the speed and dispatch that have marked the progress of other economic measures in Congress, the Banking Committee of the Senate and House voted favorable reports today on the Glass-Steagall bill designed to gear the machinery of the Federal Reserve System for greater service to the nation during the business emergency.

In a statement sent yesterday to the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives, William C. McTarnahan, vice president of the American Oil Burner Association, criticized the efforts of domestic oil producers to obtain a tariff or an embargo on petroleum and petroleum products.

General John F. O'Ryan, writing in the current issue of the quarterly The Air Law Review, the organ of the American Academy of Air Law, advocates the limiting of liability in airplane accidents to $5,000 for each person killed.

"Through the Years," Vincent Youmans's musical version of Jane Cowl's successful play, "Smilin' Through," will be withdrawn from the Manhattan Theatre tonight after a Broadway run of only two and a half weeks. The show opened here on Jan. 28 following a month's preliminary engagement out of town.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Ogden L. Mills of New York succeeded Andrew W. Mellon as Secretary of the Treasury at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon. Mr. Mellon took the oath as Ambassador to the Court of St. James, while Arthur A. Ballantine, Assistant Secretary, was sworn in as Under-Secretary to succeed Secretary Mills.

Under cross-examination yesterday at a special hearing of the Interstate Commerce Commission in Brooklyn, C.H. Dyson, fuel agent of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, admitted that the railroad had abandoned, at least temporarily, its paternalistic policy of purchasing coal at a price that would permit the coal operators and the mining industries to prosper.

HAVANA, Feb. 12 -- The Cuban Government received a ninety-day extension today from the Chase National Bank on its payment of $20,000,000 due on the short-term public works loan, and commission in the amount of $50,000 was turned over to the bank, according to a statement by its officials this afternoon.

Only $6,818,997 in new municipal financing is scheduled for award next week, one of the smallest weekly totals in recent years. This figure compares with this week's total of $11,979,944, most of which failed to attract any bids. The weekly average for the year to date is $13,462,281 but only a relatively small portion was actually awarded.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Feb. 12 The world disarmament conference bore its first fruit today with the resumption of direct negotiations between the French and Italian delegations to settle their naval differences. was firmly believed that the conferences now being held would lead to an extension of the London naval treaty of 1930 and provide a basis for further disarmament of all powers on the seas.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Twenty-five billion dollars -- that is about our stake in foreign finances. Estimates vary, but it is not far wrong to figure $8,000,000,000 as the present value of the governmental war debts, 18,000,000,000 in municipal and other public bonds, 18,000,000,000 in stocks and industrial bonds, and $1,000,000,000 in short-term credits.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Replying to Secretary Hurley's characterization of his Philippine independence bill as "a measure completely lacking in courage," Senator Hawes of Missouri asserted today that certain proposals of the War Secretary for dealing with the Philippines were "political immorality."

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- As a result of yesterday's recovery in Wall Street following the proposals in Washington regarding Federal Reserve facilities, the stock markets here were in good form today. Business showed no great expansion, but there was a more confident feeling among dealers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Shanghai has now become the capital as well as the storm centre of China, and negotiations for peace are proceeding there as the Japanese continue to shell the Chinese city and forts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When Mr. Mitchell of the National City Bank expressed his sympathy for the German youth's protest against being burdened with reparations for fifty-six more years to come. Senator Reed protested: "But why should America's future generations, which also had nothing to do with the war, be shouldered with the burden?"

George M. Weiss, prominent minor league baseball man and for the past three years associated with the Baltimore International League Club, became a member of the New York Yankees' general staff yesterday when Colonel Jacob Ruppert appointed him assistant secretary and general manager of the Yankees' minor league interests.

Business will be resumed in Wall Street this morning after the one-day suspension occasioned by Lincoln's Birthday. Some of the commodity markets will remain closed until Monday, but most of the Exchanges will reopen today for the two-hour trading period.

GENEVA, Feb. 12 -- China referred her conflict with Japan to the Assembly of the League of Nations today. It is the first time the Assembly ever has been called to deal with a question of peace and war.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- The emergency credit expansion bill in the United States is the topic of the day in German financial circles, some economists already sensing the dawn of a new boom and even the more conservative ones being inclined to see a chance for improvement throughout the world if the bill is adopted.

DESSAU, Germany, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Karl Hoeltermann, new leader of the Reichsbanner organization, launched a campaign of the Iront Front, the organization combining the various Republican groups, in the provinces here tonight in an address in which he charged that the Reichswehr and the Ministry of Defense were being conducted under pressure by Adolph Hitler.

The Providence Reds defeated the New York Tigers, 3 to 1, in a Canadian -American Hockey League game last night at the Coliseum. The victory increased the Reds' margin over the second-place New York sextet to six points.

Analyzing the city and suburban real estate market from the developer's point of view, W. Burke Harmon, president of the Harmon National Real Estate Corporation, yesterday expressed confidence in the ability of a construction program to arrest what economists call the present downward price tendency.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- Declaring that the question of taxation is the foremost political issue of the present, W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, in an address at the Grant Club's Lincoln Day dinner tonight, attacked the "extravagance" of Governor Roosevelt's administration and praised the Republicans in the Legislature for cutting expenditures.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- A grandson of Colonel W.H. Eves, who witnessed the assassination of Lincoln, will appear in a revival of John Drink-water's "Abraham Lincoln" at the "Old Vic" Theatre on Monday.
THE stories from Lake Placid have stirred up memories of ancient Winters. From, Los Gates, Cal., comes the following:

The Board of Transportation has completed the final draft of its proposed form of contract for independent operation of the new city subway system, including the Eighth Avenue line, and will make it available for publication tomorrow.

Leonardo Comes to America. Flying machines, submarines, diving suits, water - supply and drainage systems, machine tools, printing presses, textile machinery, artillery, fort-demolishers-there was scarcely a technical subject that LEONARDO DA VINCI did not touch.

An appeal for universal popular support of President Hoover's program to solve the country's economic problems was made yesterday by John W. Philp, Fourth Assistant Postmaster General, in addressing the thirty-second annual Lincoln luncheon of the New York State Women's Republican Club at the Hotel St. Moritz.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The indictment of Bishop James Cannon Jr. of the Methodist Episcopal Church South and Miss Ada L. Burroughs of Richmond, former treasurer of the Virginia Anti-Smith Committee, was declared invalid today by Justice James M. Proctor of the District Supreme Court, who sustained a demurrer against conspiracy charges growing out of a grand jury investigation of anti-Smith campaign funds in the 1928 Presidential campaign in Virginia.

After having been closed a week pending investigation of complaints that it had been the scene of "wild parties" and rowdy gatherings, the Columbia University chapter house of the Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity, at 608 West 113th Street, will be reopened on Monday, it was announced last night.
The 123d anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln was celebrated throughout the nation yesterday with more solemnity than in any other year since the World War.

The wax model of George Grey Barnard's latest work, a heroic statue called "The Builder," which the sculptor considers his best creations, will be moulded in plaster next Thursday and then cast in bronze, Mr. Barnard announced yesterday.

The Right Rev. Mgr. John Chidwick, pastor of St. Agnes's Roman Catholic Church, West Forty-third Street, who was chaplain of the Battleship Maine, will speak over radio station WLWL Monday night at 6 o'clock during a program commemorating the thirty-fourth anniversary of the sinking of the ship.

It has been a week of architecture. On Wednesday the exhibition of work in the "international style" opened at the Museum of Modern Art. On Thursday new architectural designs by Joseph Urban were brought forward at the Architectural League in East Fortieth Street.

Owen (Owney) Madden, former convict and reputedly one of the city's biggest racketeers, was arrested late last night by detectives who had been searching for him since the State Board of Parole on Thursday ordered his return to prison for violation of his parole.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 12 -- Employes and management delegates from the subsidiary companies of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation were assembled here today In the annual meeting of the board of trustees of the corporation's relief plan.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of France, world's chess champion, today won the international masters' tournament at the Empire Social Chess Club by drawing his game in the eleventh and final round against Sir George Thomas of England.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- Declaring conditions this year, economically and politically, were comparable in many ways to those in 1864, Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, told the Union League of Philadelphia at its Lincoln Day meeting tonight that the light of perspective would demonstrate "that the one great leadership of this era was supplied by Herbert Hoover."

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 12 -- A Roosevelt-for-President League was formed here today by Democratic County Chairmen and State Committeemen from thirty of the State's sixty-seven counties following the split in the State Committee over Alfred E. Smith and the ousting yesterday of two organization officials.

PASSAIC, N.J., Feb. 12 -- "Personally, I do not agree with the administration in all matters, but I can say, in all sincerity, that the program which the President has formulated to meet the present acute economic situation has my whole-hearted support," United States Senator W. Warren Barbour said tonight in a Lincoln's Birthday address at the annual dinner of the Passaic Republican Club in the Elks' Club here.
MANILA, Feb. 13 -- Attacks on Secretary Hurley's statements as to Philippine independence continued today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- An examiners' report to the Interstate Commerce Commission today upheld railroads under certain conditions In charging "extra fares" on trains superior in service and speed to others, but urged that extra-fare trains be limited to one-third of the total operated between any two points.

"I sincerely believe we will make good headway in our work," said Dino Grandi, Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs, when he spoke to a nationwide audience through the facilities of the Columbia Broadcasting System last night. He was introduced by Frederic William Wild, Columbia's commentator at the Geneva Disarmament Conference.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 12 -- Charles Francis Adams, Secretary of the Navy, in a speech before the Lincoln Club tonight, challenged the Democrats to produce a leader who could do more than President Hoover has in the crisis which has confronted the country.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- Snow that had been stored in a shed today saved the greatest exhibition that the Third Olympic Winter Games have furnished to date. The barren tower of the ski jump was blanketed with a new surface at daybreak so that the Olympic jumping tests could be held in the afternoon.

PEIPING, Feb. 12 -- Ending three years of preparation and ten months of actual journeying, the GeorgesMarie Haardt Expedition, under the joint auspices of Andre Citroen and the National Geographic Society, completed an 8,000-mile motor journey from Beirut to Peiping today.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- Favorably influenced by the reaction in the New York market to the Federal Reserve credit expansion bill, prices on the French Bourse advanced today. Gains of 5 to 10 per cent by leading stocks more than counter-balanced the losses recorded early this week.

CAIRO, Feb. 12 -- The theory of an ancient "merimde" race of the Egyptian delta distinctly different from the oldest neolithic race of Upper Egypt is now definitely confirmed as result of the discovery during excavations in the past season of a neolithic settlement near Beni-Salame, about thirty miles northwest of Cairo on the edge of the Libyan Desert.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Georgetown University came out of a ten-game losing streak tonight and defeated Pittsburgh, 33 to 30.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Federal Judge John Boyd Avis signed an order today to permit foreclosure of a mortgage held by the Central Hanvoer Bank and Trust Company of New York City against the Ambassador Hotel, Atlantic City.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Gene Sarazen turned his sharpshooting irons on Metairie Golf Club's hazards today to show the way in the first eighteen holes of the New Orleans $5,000 open with a 69, three under par for the heavily trapped course.

The Asthma and Hay Fever Club of New York met in Pythian Temple yesterday, in the Lincoln Room, for "Discussions and Exchange of Experiences," under the direction of P.F. Jerome, who has had hay fever more than thirty years.

"Tannhauser" was presented yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera, the first performance of the annual Wagner cycle, which also embraces this year the operas of the "Ring" and "Tristan und Isolde." One of the largest cycle audiences in a number of years occupied every seat and included hundreds of standees.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Witnesses favoring legalization of 4 per cent beer testified before a Senate committee today that arrests and deaths from alcoholism have mounted under prohibition and that loss in revenue and the expense of enforcement have cost the government $6,000,000,000.

Berkeley Bell of Texas, tenth ranking tennis star, gained the semi-final round of the annual Heights Casino invitation tournament in Brooklyn yesterday, but only after a hardfought match in which Edward T. Herndon, young home-club representative, pressed him much too hard for comfort.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 12 -- During the four-hour truce in the Chapei area this morning missionaries, members of the Red Cross and Red Swastika societies and members of the Shanghai Volunteers' Corps shepherded from the no-man's land of Chapei more than 2,000 Chinese civilians, including more than 300 who were wounded.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 12 -- That one irresistible accompaniment of the sea -- fog, which oft makes the hardiest mariners fidget -- faced the Winter-defying sailors of the Frostbite Yacht Club today. The wet blanket covered Manhasset Bay, where they were to sail the first races of a three-day program.

Many persons guilty of being old will regret to notice that their valued and respectable friend The Police Gazette is sick, it may be unto death. Conducting himself according to a conservative tradition, Puritan, Victorian, he has had to struggle for life against the franker, the all-revealing modern competitors.

BUCHAREST, Feb. 12 -- The news of the departure of Nicolas Titulescu from Geneva, where he has been representing Rumania at the Arms Conference for Bucharest, has turned out to be a bombshell in Rumanian politics.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Seventy-six men and women, all but four of them New Jersey residents, were graduated from the short courses given by the College of Agriculture, Rutgers University, at exercises held this morning in Kirkpatrick Chapel.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 13 -- Japanese airplanes bombed Chapel this morning as the Chinese waited impatiently for four squadrons of planes coming up from Canton to assist new units of infantry that were being thrown into the line in preparation for the impending Japanese push on Woosung and Chapei.

Boston terriers held first place on the program of the second day of the Westminster Kennel Club's fifty sixth annual dog show in Madison Square Garden yesterday. America's own breed of dogs this year has the largest entry of all in the greatest of all canine exhibitions in the country, 147 of the game and cocky little sportsmen being on the benches.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A group of New York writers whose expedition into the Harlan and Bell County coal fields of Kentucky to study mine strike conditions resulted in their being ejected into Tennessee Wednesday night laid their story before a group of Senators today and asked a Senatorial investigation of conditions in Kentucky.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- Once again the United States dollar comes in for wide comment in the Paris press today, but thus far on the whole the attitude is the reasonable one of wait and see. There is no denying, however, that in French financial circles the keen interest is somewhat mixed with nervousness over the Glass-Steagall emergency banking bill, now under discussion in Washington.

Newspapers were denounced for carrying news unfavorable to members of the Police Department by the Rev. John H. Healy of St. Vincent Ferrer's Church, Sixty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue, at a requiem mass for policemen there yesterday under the auspices of the departmental Holy Name Society.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A plea that the same assistance "be extended to women and children as has been given to banks and railroads" was made by Senator Johnson of California in a speech today supporting the amended Costigan-La Follette bill providing $375,000,000 for direct relief of unemployment and $375,000,000 for additional road-building.

A beer strike in Hamburg by Hitlerites and Communists provides an exhibit of old and new forces operating side by side. It used to be said before the war that the current price and quality of Munich beer determined the political mood of the Bavarian people.

Hundreds of graduates and former students of Columbia University returned to the Morningside Heights campus yesterday afternoon for the twenty-fifth annual alumni day celebration, which included meetings, luncheons, reunions, class-room demonstrations and "Around Columbia" tours.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 12 -- Marshal Chiang Kai-shek and the Generals and politicians affiliated with him in the maintenance of his "shadow" government at Loyang [Honanfu] have decided upon the early removal of their capital to Peiping, according to information regarded as authentic which reached foreign official circles in Shanghai tonight.

Four classes of yachts will compete in the regattas to be held at Los Angeles in connection with the Olympic Games in August, according to an announcement sent yesterday by Ernest Stavey, corresponding secretary of the North American Yacht Racing Union, to member associations.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Headed by John F. Curry, Tammany chieftain, a group of Democratic leaders from New York City and up-State, controlling more than fifty delegates, are understood to be in informal agreement to avoid pledges of support to any candidate for the Democratic nomination for President.
