SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 13 (AP) -- A group of 100 American residents of Shanghai cabled United States Senator William E. Borah at Washington today protesting against what they said was Japanese violence against non-combatant civilians and property in Shanghai.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 12 (AP) -- South Africa and Australia started their fifth and final test cricket match today in sensational fashion with the Springboks going out in their first innings for only 36 runs and Australia's wickets falling for only 153.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 12. -- An urgent appeal to all, not only Catholics but people of all religions, to pray to God that the world may be delivered from its present troubles was made by Pope Pius XI today in St. Peter's at the end of a mass celebrated there this morning in commemoration of the tenth anniversary of his coronation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- Governor Roosevelt conferred today with Samuel I. Rosenman, his counsel, regarding the procedure to be followed at the public hearing on Tuesday on the charges of Samuel Seabury against Sheriff Thomas M. Farley.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Senator Robert Wagner and Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader in New York, have all expressed their views on disarmament to the children of the Hessian Hills School here.

The George Washington Bicentennial Committee made public yesterday a proclamation by Mayor Walker, dated as of tomorrow, calling upon the people of the city to face the hardships of the present depression with the same spirit manifested by the country's pioneers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The contention was made here today that the new credit expansion bill before Congress does not take fullest advantage of opportunities to increase the nation's consumer credit.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- With a rider introduced at the last moment providing for woman's suffrage, the government's electoral reform bill was adopted by the Chamber of Deputies without a dissenting vote this afternoon after the members of the Radical-Socialist and Radical parties had left the hall in protest during the discussion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Substantial increases in income and corporation taxes and re-enactment of the Federal gift tax to prevent evasion of statutory levies on large estates were tentatively agreed upon today by the Ways and Means Committee In its quest for $1,241,000,000 in new taxes with which to balance the budget in the fiscal year 1933.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 13 (AP) -- When Lieut Gen. Kenkichi Uyeda, commander of the Japanese Army expedition to Shanghai, arrives in the field he will propose that the American, British and French commanders request the Chinese troops to withdraw and permit the establishment of a neutral zone fifteen to twenty miles in extent.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Believed to bo the victims of poison, Raymond Giberson, 29 years old, was found dead today and his wife, Vera, about 24, critically ill and unconscious in the bedroom of their home on Iroquois Road here.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 -- Thomas Milton Jones, 57, chief clerk of the Federal Reserve Bank here, leaped 150 feet to his death from a bridge in Schenley Park today. His wife said he had not been in his usual health since he suffered an automobile accident three years ago.

GENEVA, Feb. 12.--Every day the list of proposals of what arms should be abolished, what limitations made and what means should be used to insure reductions in armaments grows longer as orator after orator takes his place on the rostrum of the disarmament conference.
Passengers leaving today for London via Plymouth and Havre on the Cunarder Alaunia include:

With an additional allotment of $1,000,000 made yesterday by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration to New York City's work relief funds, the total of the city's receipts for this purpose from the State organization has reached $4,250,000.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP) -- George W. Turnham, a son of the man who is said to have loaned to Abraham Lincoln the only law book available to the future President when he was educating himself, told of that incident today and also told two other stories of Lincoln which have not been widely related.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Supporters of Governor Roosevelt of New York planned today to take an aggressive campaign for delegates to the Democratic National Convention in Answer to the candidacy of Alfred E. Smith, announced on Sunday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 12 -- The police sought tonight to obtain an explanation for the suicide of Miss Clorinda Holland, 35 years old, who plunged from a window of her room on the fifteenth floor of the Hotel Claridge early this morning. Her body was found by the engineer of the hotel on a terrace, forty feet above the street level.

The Democrats at the Chicago convention "must arise from prejudices, sectionalism and petty partisanship" to nominate a Presidential candidate who can be depended upon "to rebuild our economic structure," James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic State Committee, told members of the Women's Democratic Club at the Hotel Commodore last night.

Lou Bender, Columbia's basketball captain and all-league forward, went on a scoring rampage last night in the Morningside gym and led the Lions to a 38-20 victory over Pennsylvania in an Eastern Intercollegiate League encounter.

ATLANTA, Feb. 12. -- Governor Roosevelt authorized the secretary of the Georgia Democratic executive committee today to place his name on the ballot as a candidate for the Presidential nomination in the Georgia primary on March 23.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 12. -- Beautiful Grenada, the island often known as the Killarney of the Caribbean, is once more a scene of political discord.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Applications for authority to obtain loans under the interstate commerce act were filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Boston Maine, the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie, the Detroit Toledo Shore Line and Tavarea Gulf railroads.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- All grain exchanges in the United States were closed today for Lincoln's Birthday, but Winnipeg and Liverpool were open as usual.

The preliminary report of the New York Central Railroad for 1931 shows that, despite a net deficit of $2,312,561 in the last three months of the year, the company earned its interest charged by a small margin. The net income for the year was $2,430,101, or almost 50 cents a share on the $499,259,735 of capital stock outstanding, against $35,981,791, or $7.21 a share in 1930.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- The Foreign Office here and the British Embassy refused today to divulge the terms of the reparations agreement which has been submitted to the representatives of the various interested powers at Geneva today, but in authoritative quarters it was confirmed that its object is to postpone vital issues to the new conference.
NEW YORK. Harold S. Vanderbilt has come from Palm Beach to the Barclay.
BERLIN, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The beer strike called in protest against a price-cutting decree by Carl Goerdeler, the nation's price czar, spread considerably today.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Relatives of Elizabeth Barrett Cook, who died aboard a steamer between Naples and Gibraltar last week, said tonight they would engage detectives in an attempt to learn who sent the girl a cablegram falsely announcing the death of her fiance a few days before she died.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12 -- With the Northern cotton markets closed for the Lincoln holiday and the absence of the customary interchange between the trading centres, operations today on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange were quiet. Prices were sustained, however, by moderate trade buying and by the optimism resulting from the bulge in stocks of the previous day.

Franz Anton Mesmer, about whose name for more than a century have hung the words "swindler" and "charlatan," applied to him by the academicians who were his contemporaries, was in reality the precursor for the modern art of mental healing, Stefan Zweig, Austrian biographer and novelist, writes in his book "Mental Healers," published today by the Viking Press.

DETROIT., Mich., Feb. 12 -- With the beginning of production of the new Ford eight and four cylinder lines, employment will be increased by 30,000 to 35,000 Detroit workers still on the rolls and awaiting rehiring. The recall is likely to start within a week or ten days.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 12 -- About 200 Rutgers alumni returned today for the eighth annual alumni day. They were permitted to attend undergraduate class reunions and watched the Rutgers wrestling and basketball teams in action.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 12 -- The League of Nations committee of inquiry on Shanghai met again this evening and toiled over the framing of an additional report on the Shanghai crisis to be telegraphed to Geneva tomorrow night. It adjourned at 7:30 o'clock this evening.

A famous English schoolmaster, EDWARD BOWEN of Harrow, of whom Lord BRYCE wrote with more moving eloquence than of statesmen, prelates, scientists or historians, used to say to his boys: " Take the " bitter and the sweet as sweet and " bitter come and play the game."

Florence Austral, soprano, appeared in her only recital here this season, last night at Carnegie Hall. Her program included five lieder by Brahms, four by Strauss, and the aria Suicidio from "La Giaconda." John Amadio, flautist, also appeared on the program in several groups of flute solos.

Murray B. Kestin, an attorney, of 11 West Forty-second Street, who is representing certain minority stockholders of the Prairie Pipe Line Company, took issue yesterday with W.F. Gates, president of the company, who, in a statement the day before, advocated the merger of Prairie Pipe with the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation, and the Prairie Oil and Gas Company.

Two issues aggregating $17,122,000 composed this week's new offerings of bonds in the New York market, whereas last week no new financing was done publicly. During the corresponding week last year new issues totaling $74,784,000 were marketed. This week's financing consisted of $15,000,000 Federal Intermediate Credit Banks 5 per cent debentures, due on Feb. 15, 1936, and $2,122,000 State of Maryland 4 1/4s, due from 1935 to 1947.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 12 -- Comprehensive economic planning is impossible in a capitalistic or any other kind of democracy, Jacob Viner, Professor of Economics at the University of Chicago, told more than 200 delegates to the intercollegiate conference on capitalism and its alternatives at Williams College this afternoon.

All Northern markets of this country were closed yesterday, in observance of the Lincoln holiday. On the European markets, the day's most interesting incident was the advance in stocks on the Berlin curb, ascribed in the dispatches to "hope of revival under the stimulus of the new American credit plan."

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- New England supporters of Alfred E. Smith for the Democratic Presidential nomination gave evidence today of organizing zeal coincidental with the announcement that Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts will take to the stump for Smith in New Hampshire a week before the Presidential primary in that State.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Recent commercial developments in Paris connected with the matter of restricting importations brought up a question which keenly interested not only the various commercial attaches of foreign countries here but Ministers an Ambassadors themselves.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The reaction of British political opinion is unfavorable to the news from Geneva of a special meeting of the League of Nations Assembly, called upon the demand of the Chinese to consider the invasion of their country by Japan.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A biography of Abraham Lincoln that challenges in brevity the Emancipator's own Gettysburg Address, has been written by Carl Sandburg, poet and Lincolnian authority for the Keystone View Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Chinese Government, in a statement received by its legation here tonight, denounces Japan's acts in Manchuria and at Shanghai and declares China "will continue to resist in self-defense against Japan's attacks at all points and with all forces at its command."
GENEVA, Feb. 12 (AP) -- China took the last diplomatic step but one today to halt hostilities in Shanghai and the Council of the League of Nations sidestepped the issue until next week.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12. -- With an unusual daring and frankness Pravda's front page editorial reveals today the main springs of the Soviet foreign policy in general and the Soviet participation in the Geneva disarmament conference in particular.

WARSAW, Feb. 12.--News of the resignation of Dr. Henryk Strasburger as Polish High Commissioner of Danzig, which was announced this morning, had been held up for several days by the Polish Government to avoid the Impression that this change was in any way connected with the Lithuanian move against Memel's autonomy.

Spring Fur Orders Gaining. Business is now opening up on fur garments for Spring and at least one of the big resident buying offices here Is placing substantial orders for jackets. The trend is strongly toward galapins and lapins in black and nutria shades, to retail from $25 to $29.50 and $35.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 12 -- Business men are working now for the return of the Bank of Mexico to the status it held before recent legislation converted it into a central institution of credit.

New York City joined in the celebration of the 123d anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln yesterday. Civic, patriotic, religious, political, educational, welfare and other organizations held commemorative exercises throughout the day. Speakers at luncheons, dinners and patriotic gatherings discussed his life and work.

PINEVILLE, Ky., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Learning that a Congressional investigation of conditions in Kentucky mining districts would be sought, a group of citizens sent a telegram to several members of Congress today suggesting that the inquiry "begin with New York and the nest of Communists there."

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 12 -- On the courts of Trinity College, scene of the first national intercollegiate lawn tennis championship, representatives of Harvard,. Yale, Princeton, M.I.T. and Trinity gathered today for the first national intercollegiate squash, racquets championship.

Within the next few days the fate not only of the Japanese naval and military demonstrations in the Shanghai area but of all foreigners in China will probably be decided, according to Upton Close, student of Oriental affairs, who has spent many years in China, Japan and other parts of the Far East.

The increasing popularity of Reno divorces since the six weeks' residence law went into effect has led the Marriage License Bureau in Brooklyn to refuse licenses to holders of Reno decrees, it was disclosed yesterday by Assistant Corporation Counsel Joseph P. Reilly.

Samuel Seabury, the chief investigator of the City Government, is y to find himself under crossexamination by Governor Roosevelt on Tuesday's hearing in Albany on the charges he has filed against Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, it became known yesterday.

HONOLULU, Feb. 12 -- Constructive ground warfare was in progress late today in Waianae, a pocket on the northwest side of Oahu, where 1,500 "Blue" soldiers and marines landed this morning from "enemy" transports as the final phase of the struggle in the war games for possession of this island, drew to a close.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 12 -- Prince Lennart and his fiancee, Miss Karin Nissvandt, will go to London next week to be married there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Senator Smoot in the Senate today said the "buoyant courage and unwavering determination of Lincoln puts to shame those Americans who have surrendered to skepticism and despair because of the economic storm which is now sweeping over the world."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Quick action is necessary to save New York real estate. It is struggling under a burden too heavy to bear. Conservative action rather than destructive criticism is necessary. We must find other sources of income in order to fill up the looted treasury.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- The thirty-one building trades in Chicago, representing a membership of 150,000, today voluntarily accepted a 20 per cent wage reduction for one year.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 12. -- A bill presented to the Constituent Assembly and Chamber of Deputies calling for the authorization of the expropriation by the government of Frigorifico National, handing over the entire plant and equipment to the city councils of Lima and Callao, is at present holding attention in local political circles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Quite recently in the House of Representatives of a Western State the Reds protested against measures being adopted to weed out undesirable aliens or agitators and prevent them from entering this country. They appeared at a legislative hearing with a placard reading "Down With Fingerprints and Passports."

A "scale" which weighs the nuclear of atoms of masses less than a trillionth of a trillionth of an ounce has been built at the Bartol Research Foundation at Swarthmore, Pa., it was announced yesterday by Dr. Henry A. Barton, director of the American Institute of Physics.
The text of President Hoover's address by radio from Washington to the Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club in New York last night follows:

The Cunarder Berengaria sailed at 9:15 o'clock last night on her weekend cruise to Bermuda after a delay of twenty-four hours caused by fog and tide. The delay cost the steamship company 238 passengers who had paid about $15,000 that will be refunded to them when tickets are turned in to the office at 25 Broadway.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- An international rum ring which Federal agents say bore signs of Al Capone's guiding hand was revealed here today in 104 indictments handed down by a grand jury in United States District Court. The indictments, charging conspiracy to violate the tariff act and violation of the prohibition law, were based on evidence gathered by agents after months of work.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- After conferring today by telephone with Cornelius M. Bliss and Colonel Joseph Hartfield of the New York City Emergency Work Commission, Governor Roosevelt announced that they, with Jesse I. Straus, chairman of the State Relief Administration, would come hero on Feb. 23 for a conference with him on continuance of State aid for the jobless.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Predicting that the Geneva disarmament conference "can but end in a fizzle" and suggesting that Secretary Stimson recall the American delegates as quickly as possible, Representative Britten today urged that the United States bend her energies "toward the building of a navy that will insure our peace even if the balance of the world becomes enmeshed in the present unholy slaughter in Asia."
For the second time in the long history of the Westminster Kennel Club, a pointer captured the highest honors in the annual exhibition which came to a close in Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Supporters of Governor Roosevelt in the race for the Democratic nomination for President, were greatly encouraged today by reports from all sections of the country that the candidacy of Alfred E. Smith seemed to have made little or no headway west of Pennsylvania and that there was no indication of any weakening of the New York Executive's strength outside of New England.

THE north wind doth blow and we shall have snow. So runs the old nursery rhyme. It is singularly appropriate because, for some reason that the oldest philosopher has not been Able to explain, every child la "ex officio" an inspector of the Winter skies, a herald of the arriving snow.

THE heroine and narrator of this new Mary Roberts Rinehart story is a nurse who doubles in crime detection. Her name is Miss Adams, but Detective Inspector Patton, with whom the occasionally collaborates, calls her Miss Pinkerton whenever he is particularly pleased with the assistance she has given him.

ARCHITECTURE and painting divide the honors this week. The Museum of Modern Art presents -- as its last offering before the move into new quarters -- an admirable survey of architecture illustrating what has come to be known as the international style.

IN his "Saginaw Paul Bunyan" Mr. Stevens has moved his search for these legends to Michigan; these are the true tales of Paul in the State of the Great Lakes. Mr. Stevens's first collection of Paul Bunyan stories, published seven years ago.

THERE are seven good reasons for attending respectfully to the contents of this symposium on applied psychology: one for each of the contributors thereto. Under the auspices of the Psychological Corporation founded by Dr. James McKeen Cattell in 1921 for practical research in the problems of human behavior, a number of lectures were given by authorities in different fields, and it is these lectures which have now been assembled by the editor, Paul S. Achilles.

The International League's championship season for 1932. during which each of the eight clubs in the circuit will be called upon to play 168 games, will open on April 13 and close on Sept. 18, according to the official schedule released for publication today.
EVERY two years Ed Wynn descends upon Broadway looking for acts.

In the present struggle between China and Japan, "face" is playing an important role. The Chinese boycott of Japanese goods and the ridicule heaped upon Japanese residents at Shanghai constituted a loss of "face" which Tokyo would not tolerate.

To survey in a single book the history of sport in America from 1490 to 1890 is a tolerably large undertaking. Mr. Manchester has succeeded admirably in the task he set himself, and the result is a work rich in interest and, incidentally, a volume which is a beautiful example of the book-maker's art.

THE day and night with Abraham Lincoln of which I shall tell were the most important in his life and, in the tremendous consequences which ensued, the most important to the country at large. I refer to the 6th day of November, 1860, and to the night which followed it.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 17. -- Time may prove that credit flexibility can be achieved through a Reconstruction Finance Corporation in Washington, but whether or not a similar plan to release $100,000,000 in New York State can surmount the obstacles of the Commonwealth's Constitution is taxing the best legal minds here and in Albany while hundreds of financially straitened communities await the outcome.
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Feb. 11. -- Arkansas is providing a good laboratory in which to study the back-to-the-land move, a phenomenon of the depression era.

The lure of the "big city," which Ralph Nussbaum had felt ever since he was old enough to run away from his home, at 1,012 Clenton Avenue, Rochester, N.Y., was not strong, enough to offset, cold and hunger, and the boy, now 14 years old, gave himself up last night to the police.

THE first models of Packard's new line of Light Eights to arrive in New York reached the city last week and were placed on exhibition in the showrooms of the Packard Motor Car Company of New York at Broadway and Sixty-first Street.

To the Eidtor at The New York Times: The war debts, the present enigma facing the whole world, and blamed for the universal monetary crisis by financiers and economists of both continents, have been the cause of much discussion, but until now I believe there is only one point on which every one agrees -- that something must be done about it.

No material change occurred last week in the volume of bonds called for redemption in February before their maturity dates, the additions continuing to be few and consisting of parts of State and municipal issues. The total for the month is now $36,153,000, compared with $70,486,000 in January, and $54,179,000 in February, 1931, at corresponding dates.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- The British Foreign Office issued a communique today stating the postponed Lausanne reparations conference would be held in June. This decision was taken by agreement of the governments of Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and Great Britain.

There has been a rather curious digging into American history by English writers and publicists in recent weeks. The obvious intent is to convict this country of the atrocious crime of being inconsistent. It is the old argument of then and now contrasted. The thought seems to be that an arrow shot at the American eagle will be particularly effective when feathered from its own breast.

The recently-completed studies of the Regional Plan emphasizes the fact that badly planned neighborhoods, rather than cheap tenement houses, are responsible for the existence of slum districts, says Henry James, author, and a trustee of the Carnegie Corporation, in a review of the final reports of Thomas Adams on the work of the Regional Plan of New York and Its Environs and an explanation of its recommendations.

MANY New Yorkers were surprised to learn the other day that a sportsman had gone sealhunting in Long Island Sound, and that, moreover, he was merely following his annual custom. But seals are not strangers to the Sound or even to the harbor.

CHICAGO. ART, as it manifests itself in Chicago in the early thirties of the present century, is shown at its best in the thirty-sixth annual exhibition by artists of Chicago and vicinity at the Art Institute.

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- One of the most interesting angles of the arms question to the onlooker here in Paris is the recent press and political campaign charging Germany with having violated the terms of the Versailles Treaty regarding armaments. It has particular importance, since it has been timed just to precede and overlap the Geneva conference.

The vagrancy law against suspicious persons without visible means of support was invoked by the police yesterday to hold Serafin Rodriquez, 33 years old, as a suspect, pending further investigation of his possible connection with the murder of Maria Rosalez, the 13-year-old girl whose body was found in a vacant apartment at 10 East 112th Street last Tuesday.

IN all probability there will be as many differing opinions of this novel as there are individual readers. Its curious and rather prankish mixture of comedy and satire, romance and tragedy, all but defies classification. Readers who enjoyed the engaging light comedy of "The Selbys" will not be disappointed here; for, in the Malorys.

There is a vital need of closer relationship between banks and business men if many of the basic difficulties which have featured the current depression are to be avoided in the future, according to Benjamin L. Levinson, director of merchandise planning of the Independent Merchandising Bureau.

A STUDY, already monumental of the music of books of the Hebrew Pentateuch, has been made by Professor Salomo Rosowsky of the Palestine Institute for Musical Sciences, who has recently lectured upon his findings at Columbia University.

One of the highest honors in philately has just been conferred upon Dr. Carroll Chase one of the leading members of the Collectors' Club of this city, whose specialized studies on United States stamps particularly of the 3-cent 1851-57 issue have placed him in the ranks of the comparatively few serious students of philately in this country.

PARIS, Jan. 30. WE have had several new plays this week, and I have no space to tell you in detail about them all. I am not sure that it would be worth while, even if I had, for they certainly do not all merit a detailed analysis.

Condemning the speakeasy as "ten times more detrimental" than the saloon of former days, Representative William E. Hull of Illinois, in an address at the annual reunion luncheon of the Illinois College Alumni Association in New York at the Hotel Astor yesterday, urged a reconstruction of the liquor laws similar to the government-controlled system in Sweden.

Today. 11:30 A.M. -- The Elshuco Trio, guest artista on the Library of Congress musicale, will select from the trio works of Franz Schubert and Johannes Brahms for today's concert over WJZ's network. The trio consists of Karl Kraeuter, violinist; Willem Welleke, violoncellist, and Aurelio Ciorni, pianist.

Governor Roosevelt, in a proclamation made public yesterday, urged all citizens of New York State to take part in the Washington bicentennial exercises, which will begin on Feb. 22, the 200th anniversary of the birth of the first President, and continue until Thanksgiving Day, Nov. 24.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The United States Government, it is understood would not view with favor an arrangement for demilitarizing Shanghai, should that be one of the conditions suggested by Japan, which has demanded that the Japanese remain in the city and the Chinese forces retire for several miles.

SINCE the Spring of 1860 when J.L. Scripps, a reporter for The Chicago Tribune, journeyed to Springfield, Ill., to work up the first Whig campaign biography, there have been, according to the estimates of librarians, at least 4,000 books and pamphlets about Lincoln.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- Edward M. McMahon, a second vice president of the Chase National Bank, died in the Mount Vernon Hospital today after an operation. Mr. McMahon, whose home was in Pelham Manor, was formerly an official of the Equitable Trust Company in New York and when that company was merged with the Chase National he became a second vice president in the Chase bank.

THE air-transport world is watching intently a legal battle centred at Phoenix, Ariz. This battle, preliminary skirmishes of which are now going on, reaches its zero hour during the first week in March, when representatives of American Airways and Century Pacific will clash before the Arizona State Corporation Commission.

A valentine by one of America's most, famous poets which, research indicates, has never before been published and about the composition of which virtually nothing is known has been discovered by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- The Army boxing team won from Virginia Military Institute today by a score of 5 to 2. The bouts were all closely contested except in the 135-pound event where Cadet Coit won for the Army over Bain by a knockout in 1:45 of the second round.

MADRID, Feb. 13. -- Spain's anarchists will make a final concentrated effort to keep the black flag flying over the powerful National Workers Federation which Joaquln Maurin and other Red leaders have been trying to wrest from their grasp.

IN writing of the poetry of Wilfred Owen, Siegiried Sassoon makes the statement that "he was a man of absolute Integrity of mind," and it is this integrity that stands out on every page of this small collection of stern, uncompromising verse. Mr. Sassoon goes on to say -- with perhaps something unnecessarily ungracious in the implication -- that, unlike many of the war-poets, Owen never wrote as a personal gesture.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Through the swift sequence of recent events in the Orient, the disunity of the Western nations emerges as a challenge to curiosity. It is evident that there exists between the United States and the European powers some disturbing factor of major importance which has been preventing concerted action.
AROUND the world before the microphone is the unique record of Joseph R. Scherer of Los Angeles. He has broadcast in forty countries -- and in no less than six languages.

THE modern history of Europe has been conditioned to a large extent by events in the Balkana. Indeed, the author of this book observes, from 1856 to the World War most of the major crises in European politics were due to a possible or probable partition of Turkey, and he recounts the attitudes and plans of the various powers.'

WHEN the Arabs issued from the desert under the militant and irresistible early Caliphs, successors of Mohammed, they had the peculiar character of a civilized people without a material civilization. This is important to remember; and one of the drawbacks of the volume under review is that it falls to give sufficient emphasis to this consideration.

A collection of old American furniture, with silver, glassware and porcelain, and a group of eighteenth century English furniture, the furnishings of Mayflower Lodge, the home of H. Thomas Farrar at Westport, Conn., with a few additions, will go on sale Saturday at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. The exhibition began yesterday.

As its contribution to the Washington Bicentennial, the Metropolitan Museum has arranged an interesting exhibition of portraits in the Alexandria assembly room of the American wing. This exhibition opens with a private view tomorrow, and may be visited by the public from Tuesday until Nov. 27.

The Board of Transportation sent yesterday to the Board of Estimate its long-awaited draft of the proposed contract for independent operation of the city's new subway system on a five-cent fare basis. It submitted also a report outlining the contract terms and containing detailed estimates of operating revenues and expenses.

ARECENT American expedition into the jungles of Guatemala, where the enigmatic ruins of magnificent Maya temples have long puzzled archacologists, suggests a new theory to explain the strange riddle of why and how this entique American civilization declined.

Five hours a day of manual labor in addition to school work does not necessarily dampen the enthusiasm of youth for education, in the Far West at least, for this is a condition upon which students attend the Intermountain Institute at Weiser, Idaho.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 13. -- Former Mayor Frederic E. Small of Rochester, candidate for delegate at large to the Democratic National Convention, hitherto unpledged, formally pledged himself today to the Presidential candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
With the opening of crew racing two months away -- California will row Washington at Seattle, April 16 -- the practice season has started at all institutions which support crews.

Despite the gradual decrease in new bond financing since 1929 there has been a sharp increase in the amount of bonds called for redemption prior to maturity. Officers of several large corporations which have been active in calling their obligations explained yesterday that in-asmuch as the slackness of business had left corporations with large amounts of surplus funds, it had been decided to use these surpluses to call bonds and thus lower fixed charges.

The historic ground where the guns of old Fort Tryon once looked out over the Hudson to guard Manhattan against a British attack from the north is being transformed rapidly into one of the city's most picturesque playgrounds.

While the amendments to the Glass-Steagall bill may have chilled Wall Street's enthusiasm to some extent, the stock market community continues to accept the measure without reservation, after two days' reflection, as a likely way out of the depression.

PARIS, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Lucien Lamoureux, prominent financier and reporter for the Budget Committee in the Chamber of Deputies, today described the new American proposal to broaden the rediscount basis of the Federal Reserve System as "fruitful inflation."

After much sparring, the reparations conference has been called to meet in Lausanne the first week in June, and the official announcement yesterday said that the interested powers would undertake to go much further than a simple extension of the moratorium; they would seek a lasting settlement.

WILLIAM MCKINLEY was a happy man in politics. He had only one manager, MARK HANNA. From the time HANNA set out to make MCKINLEY President, the Clevelander was in sole control. He ran both the pre-convention campaign and the convention. He managed the campaign against BRYAN.

Throughout the East, from Constantinople of Tokyo, native peoples are demanding the right to conduct their affairs in their own way. In four previous articles Dr. Herbert Adams Gibbons, American author and scholar, has dealt with various aspects of the unrest, as he has found them during n two-year tour through Asia.

Georges Thill and Elisabeth Rethberg appeared for the first time this season with the Metropolitan Opera Company yesterday in a matinee perfarmance of Gounod's "Faust." There was a large audience and the singers were welcomed with applause at their first appearance on the stage.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- Army defeated Princeton at wrestling today, 22 to 8. The cadets took six of eight bouts, two of them by falls.

LAKE PLACID. -- Hundreds of devotees of the thrilling sport of bobsledding are remaining at Lake Placid over the week-end to witness the North American bobsleigh championships and the A.A.U. national bobsleigh championships, to be held on the Mount Van Hoevenberg bob-run on Monday and Tuesday.

Commodity values soared yesterday, all sections of the market registering substantial gains. In the cash section, sharply higher prices were noted in the grains, provisions, textiles and miscellaneous group, while in the futures market hides, rubber, silk and cocoa worked into new high ground for the week. The forward trend dovetailed with the rise in security values, a reflection of the change in sentiment which grew out of the pending financial legislation at Washington.

IN 1931 the air routes of the world the sky lanes of the fastest means of transportation man has ever known totaled in round figures 190,000 miles. Of this great network, invisible save for its airpot stations and its lengthening string of beacons by night, the United States had 51,000 miles and all of Europe some 83,000.

FAR below the lofty buildings of Columbia University on Morningside Heights is a stonewalled labyrinth extending its narrow arms to most of the campus structures and having, for all its comparative modernity, an air of antiquity and mellow tradition.

TASTE in poetry hue changed since the day when Petrarch wrote his sonnets to the divine Laura. The chill of classic personality has melted before the lyrical expression of individualism, and the rigidity which once restricted the poet's phraseology has relaxed, permitting a generous equipment of linguistic equivalents broad enough to cover every manner of description.

High winds were responsible for low scores at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. The best work was done by S. O.S. Graham, who took the high scratch cup with a card of 92. The high handicap cup went to P. Sieppy with 82-18, 100.

The New York-New Jersey high School regional champion who qualifies to represent this district at the national finals of the National Oratorical Contest in Washintgon on May 21 will be the sixth and last speaker on the program. Drawings for places were made there last week by Fleming Newbold, business manager of The Washington Star, on behalf of the sixty-six American newspaper sponsors.

Immediate steps to re-establish confidence among small but numerous stockholders were urged upon company executives and directors yesterday by Arthur Lazarus, consultant on financial problems and special lecturer on stockholder relationships at the College of the City of New York.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 13. -- A fighting Princeton hockey team tonight gained the first victory the Tigers have recorded against Yale since 1926, by defeating the Elis, 2 to 1.

HAVANA, Feb. 9. -- Cuba's first industrial technical school for girls, Rosalia Abreu, will be officially opened on Feb. 24 at General Machado, the model town founded by President Machado and where an industrial school for boys is already functioning.

All doubt as to the effect, on the Wall Street mind, of the government's finance proposals of last Thursday seemed to be removed by the action of yesterday's stock market. The advance in prices on the average has not been exceeded on any occasion since the rapid recovery which followed Mr. Hoover's original announcement of the Reconstruction Corporation plan, early last October.

IN a season of many varied activties, the Junior League is now completing final preparations for the annual concert of its glee club to be given on Wednesday night in the Great Hall of the clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street. Members of the club have been rehearsing for many weeks under the direction of Marshall Bartholomew and a program of unusual interest has been arranged.

The dream of the educational theorist in a democracy is an educational system that will adjust every boy and girl to the economic and social life of the civilization into which he is born. The hope and faith of every parent is that this dream may come true.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- The prospective Republican investigation of the administrative departments of the State, under a concurrent resolution sponsored by Chairman Hewitt of the Senate Finance Committee and adopted by the Senate after heated debate on Wednesday evening, was inspired from Washington, according to Senator Dunnigan, leader of the Democratic minority in the upper house.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 13. -- Fifty-six seniors and forty-four juniors at Dartmouth College are listed as taking honors work in various subjects. Standing sufficiently high in their courses, they are not bound to attend classes, but may devote their time to special concentration.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 13 (AP). -- As a blinding snowstorm swept over Woosung during the afternoon the Chinese immediately took advantage of the poor visibility to rebuild their defenses and to shift their troops, General Tsai Ting-kai, Chinese commander of the Nineteenth Route Army, said this evening.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Dramatic developments followed one upon the other today in the aftermath of the mystery-shrouded death of Miss Elizabeth Barrett Cook, 20 years old, on board a ship off Gibraltar.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- France seems at last to have capitulated to electric coffee percolaters and bread toasters. There are many of these appliances, which have long been common accessories of the American home but which, for some reason, the French housewife until now has not taken to, on display at the annual Housekeeping Arts Exposition in the Grand Palais.

TWO years ago last June the Ludington brothers, Nicholas and Townsend, of Philadelphia; Paul Collins, veteran air mail pilot and later operations executive on T. A.T., and Gene Vidal, army and commercial pilot, joined forces to start the New York, Philadelphia and Washington Airways.

Trading on the New York Curb Exchange, yesterday was marked by further short covering, which induced brisk rallies in all the leaders and resulted in the heaviest Saturday trading since Dec. 19 last, when 322.543 shares were dealt in. Transactions were 295.715 shares, comparing with 110,825 on the preceding Saturday.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 13. -- Beekman Pool of Harvard University won the first national intercollegiate squash racquets championship today.
We trust it is not unpatriotic to suggest that if George Washington had had this beastly muggy weather to contend with he would never have been able to cross the Delaware.

BOSTON, Feb. 13. -- George Spitz, sensational New York Universtiy high jumper, who competed unattached, tonight leaped over a deligately balanced cross bar at a height of 6 feet 8 1/2 inches, higher than any human has ever jumped before. The feat broke his own world's indoor record and also the outdoor record.

St. John's College scored its eighteenth basketball victory of the season by defeating the St. Thomas College five, 37 to 34, in the St. John's High School gymnasium last night. It was a nip and tuck battle all the way with St. John's leading at half time, 20 to 19.

DALLAS, Feb. 11. -- Big business has fought some major battles in Texas, but never before has it been so generally involved in court litigation as at present. It is interesting that this takes place when all over the country, and no less in Texas, the tendency has been to leave business alone.

IN its role as a military weapon of the first order, the airplane is very much in the limelight these days. In China the effectiveness of bombing attack on both military units and the civilian population has been made manifest, even though the Japanese Admiral was careful to state that thus far he had only used his "little" bombs.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 13 (AP). -- A widely but thinly spread sales tax for the products of hundreds of industries is being considered by the House Ways and Means Committee. Representative Rainey, chairman of the Ways and Means subcommittee, studying tax proposals, said today that the sales tax appeared to be the most feasible if it could be properly applied and collected.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 13 (AP). -- United States marines have materially strengthened the defenses they are guarding on the Settlement boundaries in view of the constant dropping of stray explosives into the American sector and the possibility of an increasing deluge of bombs and shells if the expected new Japanese offensive materializes.

RICHMOND, Feb. 11. -- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith's recent announcement of his position in the Presidential campaign has not altered the plans of the group in this and other States which recently launched a boom for ex-Governor Harry F. Byrd of Virginia.

WITH the Folk Festival Council starting auspiciously upon its five-year plan of promoting respect for the native arts of the various foreign-born elements in America, the appearance of the New Negro Art Theatre dance group in the stage show at the Roxy this week is timely.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 13. -- A gold mine will be operating at Amisk, or Beaver Lake, in Northern Saskatchewan, within a few months, according to current news that milling machinery for the Amisk Lake Gold Syndicate has been bought in England and will be shipped to Canada at once.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- Stanley G. Mortimer, who has the distinction of being the only player besides Clarence C. Pell to triumph in the Gold Racquet tournament since 1914, sustained a foot injury in his semi-final match today and was forced to default in the fourth game to Herbert N. Rawlins of New York.

THE custom of speaking of the "road" as a pestilential area made up of a succession of theatrical Tombstones, Tonopahs, Leadvilles and Virginia Cities is made mildly ridiculous these days, thanks to the astounding conduct of Billy Rose's "Crazy Quilt," the revue which loitered in these faubourgs for some ten weeks last Spring, and which, since mid-September, has been offering a foot-free challenge to certain theories of panic and depression.

BERLIN. WHEN the book effectively entitled "Volk ohne Raum" first appeared, in 1925, its name helped it make a deep impression on the German youth and on all those who used to work in our former colonies. For "a people without space" is the name of the malady that is destroying Germany.

The child will have to be taught the social aspects of saving, its importance in an interdependent credit economy, and the necessity foe orderly and planned saving, not only from the individual but from a social standpoint. This is a far different concept from the old conception of thrift.

IF any one supposes that religion and science are as the poles asunder, Mr. Langdon-Davies is here to disillusion him. Those two great protagonists have never been wholly independent of each other. Not only, according to this writer, are what he calls "the brute facts at orthodox morality" derived from science, from man's picture of the universe, but, what is worse, they are derived from an obsolete and exploded science.

ALBANY, Feb. 13. -- Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, whose Presidential aspirations now stand as the centre of a furiously developing Democratic controversy, said today that the rank and file of the party, and not a process of "trade and barter" by a handful of leaders, should determine who is to be the nominee.

Louis DeMaria, 33 years old, who was believed by the police to be a petty racketeer, was shot and killed early yesterday while on a "ride." His body was tossed out at a lonely spot in Johnson Avenue, 300 feet south of Kappock Street, the Bronx, where a bus driver spied it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP). -- A group of Western and Southern Senators agreed today to accept the invitation of members of the French Parliament for the formation of an informal inter-parliamentary association to study legislation to restore the purchasing power of silver money.

ROME. THE first fortnight of the current opera seasons in the leading theatres of Italy, inaugurated partly on Dec. 26 and partly on New Year's night, has proved distinctly above the average in interest, even without absolute novelties.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- A busy week of sports and social activities opens tomorrow with the match play in the annual seniors tournament of the Pinehurst Country Club, yesterday having witnessed the qualifying round. Among those competing is John D. Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., national senior champion.

AMSTERDAM. THERE is a saying here that when gem-cutting goes everything goes. In the Big Room in the diamond exchange on the Weesperplein it is as noisy as always, and loud-speakers high on the walls bray warnings across the din in tones like those of a frightened steamer wailing across a breaking surf, whenever an "unauthorized stranger" inadvertently wanders into this forbidden centre of the world's cut diamond trade.

Heavy buying in virtually every section of the listed bond market lifted prices of many issues 1 to 9 points with railroad bonds leading the recovery. Losses of many days were erased and a few issues went to new high ground for the year.

PANAMA, R.P., Feb. 11. -- The elections in Costa Rica Feb. 14, the day this dispatch, is printed, may not determine the successor to President Cleto Gonzales Viquez, since the law requires a clear majority for election, and with four candidates in the field, it is likely that a later choice will have to be made between the two receiving the largest number of votes.

The cost of converting the Whitestone spur of the Long Island Railroad into an extension of the city's rapid transit system would be either $65,300 or $40,080, depending upon the plan of connection adopted, and not $242,000 or $230,000 as estimated by Robert Ridgway.

WASHINGTON. GENERAL CHARLES GATES DAWES takes the field in the war against hard times. On the eve of his scheduled departure upon the more or less pacific assignment as head of the American delegation to the Geneva disarmament conference, he was suddenly recalled by Mr. Hoover and made president of the Federal Government's $2,000,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

A NEW contribution to the story of the American Indian will be found in "Black Elk Speaks: Being the Life Story of a Holy Man of the Ogalala Sloux," as told to John G. Neihardt. Black Elk was born in 1863 and has played an important part in the Indian's struggle for survival against white civilization.

TORONTO, Feb. 13. -- In a game that broke up in the wildest fight scene ever witnessed on local ice, the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight defeated the Montreal Maroons, 6 -- 0, in their scheduled National Hockey League fixture.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 7. -- The provisional budget for 1932 which will remain in force until the government can present a definite scheme for the consideration, of Congress estimates expenditures at 96,296,283 sols (about $38,518,675). This presupposes a revenue approximately 2,000,000 sols in excess of the estimate of 95,000,000 sols presented in the report of the Central Budget Committee some six months ago.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 13. -- Yale's polo trio gave Princeton a ten-goal handicap today, but despite this rode through to a sweeping 28-to-16 1/2 victory.

PARIS, Feb. 13. The week closed with the Paris Bouise's recovery well established. The improvement yesterday was continued throughout today's session, which was rather an animated one especially for a Saturday. The whole list advanced, with nearly all closing above the prices prevailing before the slumn at the beginning of the week.

THE revolution of 1688 ended Pepys'a official career in the British Admiralty. His remaining days were spent in retirement, in peace, except for a brief imprisonment on the charge of Jacobite intrigue in 1690. These last years were spent in friendly correspondence with Evelyn and Dryden and in arranging and completing his valuable library of which the Pepys Ballads were a part.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 14. -- In the most desperate fighting that has taken place since the hostilities between Japanese and Chinese broke out here Jan. 28, Japanese troops succeeded yesterday afternoon in crossing Wanchaopan Creek, a tributary of Woosung Creek, which separates the Chinese forts from the attackers.

A statement, signed by a dozen prominent educators, which declares that enlightened public opinion based on accurate information is essential if future wars are to be avoided, has been sent to more than 1,000 superintendents of schools and other educational leaders throughout the country, it was learned yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 13. -- Foreign diplomatic circles and foreign observers developed speculations today on Sino-Japanese relations and Chinese internal politics.

Frank Ward, City Athletic Club professional, winner of the world's open squash tennis championship on six previous occasions, scored a decisive first-round victory as play for the title began yesterday at the Hotel Shelton Squash Club, under the auspices of the National Squash Tennis Association and the United States Professional Squash Tennis Association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- Wheat surprised even its best friends today by advancing on the Board of Trade here to the best prices since Nov. 21 for the deferred deliveries. Speculative interest was the broadest in several weeks and buying was more general than it had been recently.

PALM BEACH Forecasting the rush of activities to mark the forthcoming six weeks until April 1 are the many important events on this week's program. Each year sees a more highly syschronized schedule of activities for the weeks between Feb. 15 and April 1. the time, before that being set to comparatively slow rhythm.

Captain Harry L. Bowdoin is one man whose boyhood dreams of seeking lost treasure will come true. In April he and his crew of searchers will sail on the ship Salvor for a point off the Virginia Capes where $4,000,000 in gold lies in the purser's office of a liner that went down more than a score of years ago.

The two-ton instrument that Dr. BAINBRIDGE has built for the Bartol Foundation to weigh atoms so small that several hundred thousand of them are barely visible under the most powerful microscope is nothing new to physicists. This "mass-spectrograph," as it is called, is identical in principle with that devised by Sir FREDERICK ASTON, greatest of authorities on isotopes, a name coined by SODDY to designate atoms which are chemically alike but slightly different in weight.

SWALLOWDALE," like its predecessor, "Swallows and Amazons," meets the test of a good book for children, for it can be read with pleasure by adults as well as boys and girls. There is something entirely convincing and satisfying in the businesslike way in which the author sets to work to describe the second Summer that Captain John, Mate Susan, Able Seaman Titty and Ship's Boy Roger spend camping on Wild Cat Island.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- The murder of Vera Page, the most revolting crime in London in many years, with its amazing chain of coincidences is now likely to be relegated to the list of unsolved mysteries. A squad of 200 picked London detectives in the last two months have taken more than one thousand statements hoping to trace the murderer.

WEST POINT, Feb. 13. -- Two new Military Academy tank records were set in the Army-Amherst swimming meet today, which was won by the cadets, 52 to 28. Banker made new time in the 200-yard breast-stroke event, clipping 2 seconds off the best mark.

WHEN Ronald Colman returns to the Goldwyn studios in March he will find a new assignment waiting for him, the role of Dmitri, eldest of the Russian brothers Karamazov in Dostoievsky's great novel. Because of restrictions limiting the release date of "Cynara," the play which Mr. Goldwyn acquired for his star earlier in the season, the English story will be held over as Mr. Colman's second picture of the season.

TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 14. -- The censorship on military movements in force since Feb. 2 was raised at 9 A.M. today, with the announcement that the Kanazawa Division had completed disembarkation early this morning at an arranged point in the vicinity of Shanghai, with General Uyeda in command.

Prices in the local commodity markets felt last week the full force of the Congressional efforts to relieve the credit strain, resulting in sharp rebounds from the low marks established earlier in the week. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, rubber and hides all responded, although sugar, coffee and silks were not traded yesterday.

UNDER the auspices of members of the junior branch of the New York Women's League for Animals a performance of "Romeo and Juliet" will be given on the night of Feb. 27 at the McDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street, to further the charitable enterprises of the league.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- Bowled over by a blast of the gale which swept across Long Island Sound, the new small racing yacht Albatross of the Snipe class was capsized off here today.

FEB. 22 always has been one of our most Important holidays, but this year it transcends all others because it marks the two hundredth anniversary of the birth of George Washington. Preparations for this bicentennial celebration will begin officially on Feb. 20 and 21 by commemorative services throughout the United States.

LONDON. ENGLAND'S newest Nelson museum has lately been opened in a strong room, whose steel walls have been painted and grained to resemble oak, in the basement of Lloyd's new building in Leadenhall Street.

Section 15A of the transportation act, hailed as the salvation of the railroads when the law was enacted in 1920 is drawing deprecation as the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce continues its hearings on bills H.R. 7,116 and H.R. 7,117.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 13. -- The United States Government was doing everything in its power to make the aviation industry thrive, F. Trubee Davison, Assistant Secretary of War in charge of aviation, told members of the Aviation Committee of the Long Island Chamber of Commerce at a luncheon held today in the Garden City Hotel.

BOSTON, Feb. 13. -- Harvard won the first game of its hockey series with Dartmouth. 5 to 2, at the Garden tonight, overcoming the Green's first period two-goal lead. Barry Wood, the Harvard leader, caged two of the first three Harvard goals.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 13. -- The Navy swimmers easily defeated Brown University today, 49 to 22. Navy was disqualified in the relay event after winning. Davis, Navy's second man, jumped too quickly.

ARTURO TOSCANINI has notified the directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, on the advice of his physician, that he cannot resume his post as conductor of the orchestra the week of Feb. 29, as scheduled. The question of whether he will be able to direct later in the season is left undecided.

HOW the automobile industry will fare this year depends, of course, to a very large extent upon general business conditions. For the last two years I have deliberately refrained from making any predictions. I think it is a good policy to adhere to now.

The team of Los Nanduces Up lifters and the New York A.C. were victorious last night in the only games played the first round of the sixth annual mid-Winter indoor polo tournament in the low goal division sponsored by the New York A.C. in the 105th Field Artillery Regiment Armory, the Bronx.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Arthur Ringwalt, United States Vice Consul, and a woman companion were attacked by Japanese civilian guards inside the Japanese occupied Hongkew section of the International Settlement three days ago, it was learned today.

MANY have already subscribed to the historical pageant, "Honor to Washington" which will be given in the Town Hall on the night of Feb. 27 under the auspices of the Town Hall historical committee. The event has aroused much interest here and in distant cities.

Baseball's off-season for the Winter of 1931-32 was today reduced to a matter of hours for with this week all three of Greater New York's major league clubs will set out for their respective training camps to begin the serious business of preparing for another championship pennant campaign.

WITH the completion of "Lost Squadron" and "Girl Crazy," R.K.O. has eight features ready for release during the next two months. Two of them, "Girl of the Rio" and "Panama Flo," have already hit Broadway in what the exhibitors call a pre-release engagement.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 13. One of the earliest known writings of George Washington and other memorabilia will form the nucleus of an exhibition of Washingtonia to he displayed by the Cornell University Library for the observance of the Washington bicentennial.

Alien Industries, Inc. -- Year ended Dec. 31: Net loss after charges and depreciation, $74,939, against net profit of $96,797 after same charges and Federal taxes, equivalent after preferred dividends, to 74 cents a share on 66,000 common shares in preceding year.

America's great array of track and field talent, which is now concentrating in the East to gain as much competition as possible in preparation for the Olympic struggles to come later in the year, will be seen in action again next Wednesday night when the New York A.C. will hold its annual indoor carnival in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- In a debate broadcast tonight over the Columbia System on the subject Should Our Federal Government Assist Our States by Granting Funds to Relieve Distress Due to Unemployment?" Senator Edward P. Costigan, Democrat, of Colorado, said that the answer was "Yes," while Senator Otis S. Olenn, Republican, of Illinois, insisted that States and communities could care for their local problems.

Charging violation of the Sherman anti-trust act, the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company, whose stock-selling activities have been under investigation by Federal postoffice inspectors, filed a summons yesterday in a suit for $75,000,000 begun in Federal court against Henry L. Doherty, Henry L. Doherty Co., the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the North American Light and Power Company.

The proposed amendment to the Federal Reserve act making United States Government securities eligible as collateral behind Federal Reserve notes to the extent that the notes are not backed by the minimum gold reserve of 40 per cent will increase the "free gold" of the system by $703,000,000 on the basis of last Wednesday's Reserve statement, or from $471,000,000 to $1,174,000,000.

Henri Deering was piano soloist at the students' concert of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra last evening, greeted by a subscription audience that filled Carnegie Hall. The American pianist, who recently returned from a tour of England, Germany, Holland and France, was heard in the Symphonic Variations of Cesar Franck with the orchestra under Bruno Walter.

TO understand the conflict of forces, the opposing factors, the myriad Influences that constitute the shifting world of radio values, it should be helpful to have stood at least once upon the threshhold of the milder forms of insanity. For the commercial radio world, paradoxically enough, is an impossible blend of forces that resist fusing.

THE information is scarcely worth digging after, but it would be interesting to know exactly when the last recording by the Flonzaley Quartet was released. Time was when its disks were regular fare, a period which stretched well back into the days of acoustical recording.

TWO questions now intrude themselves upon every American group. At dinner and on the street corner, in the club, at the factory door and in the office washroom they ask one another: "Can they stop Roosevelt?" and "Will they try to beat Hoover?"

MANY enthralling tales have been written about the more picturesque ships of the Far East, but one humble, unromantic group of boats has had less than its fair share of praise. It is the small interport vessels that ply along the China Coast.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent Sunday issue THE TIMES printed the two quotations following:

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, through its Work Bureau, is practically subsidizing a sociological study of the part played by heredity and environment in the making of gangsters that is expected to be of extreme importance as a scientific study of "the anatomy of society."

The Pennsylvania, the Reading and the Central of New Jersey railroads have applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission further to lower freight rates between Jersey City and Philadelphia to meet motor-truck competition, it was announced here yesterday.

THE little seaport of Memel, on the Baltic, is again a storm centre of European politics. The Lithuanians have arrested the Pro-German Mayor, Otto Boetscher, and charged him with high treason. Lithuanian troops are patrolling the streets and the German frontier.
ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 13. -- Andover outclassed Milton Academy at wrestling today, 24 1/2 to 6 1/2. Davis of Milton threw Walden, and Draper drew with Kennedy of Andover in overtime.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- Harnessing the air for generating electric power is advocated by Hermann Honnef, an engineer, whose perfected designs for that purpose are engrossing the attention of scientists and technicians and may revolutionize the German electric industry.

AMERICAN youth, in the opinion of Professor Shri Vishwanath Maharaj Keskar. Brahmin teacher and philosopher who recently visited this country to lecture, study and observe in colleges and universities, "want more than money can buy and in this they are more civilized than many or their parents."
Sales of small dwellings and multi-family structures comprised the bulk of realty trading in New Jersey yesterday. A few deals involving business properties also were announced.

AIKEN. -- A great deal of interest is centring in the polo match next Sunday between teams representing Aiken and Augusta. The match is to be played on Augusta's municipal field and is expected to draw thousands of spectators, as polo has been played in Augusta but a short time and because of Aiken's recognized supremacy in the game in the South.

ALTHOUGH many of the annual entertainments for long established institutions have passed Into history, there still are others to come, notably the St. Valentine's Kettledrum in aid of the Samaritan Home for the Aged. This entertainment, which appeals particularly to juveniles, is a fixture in society, and has been an annual event since 1873.

LOU HOLTZ'S VAUDEVILLEREVCE -- Tomorrow evening at the Hollywood Theatre. The first of the Palace's eight-week boys, a raconteur and master of ceremonies of note, arrives for an indefinite engagement with a popular-priced show which includes Clark and McCullough, Vincent Lopez and his orchestra, the Boswell Sisters, Lyda Robertl, Venita Gould, Jay Brennan, Harold Arlen, Coletta Ryan, Lorraine Manners, Earl (Snakehips) Tucker, Beaaie Dudley, "Throe Little Words," Benny Bakar and Dave Gould's dancing chorus.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP). -- A resolution calling for an investigation of conditions in the mining counties of Harlan and Bell, Ky., was prepared today by Senator Costigan, but Senator Borah said he did not believe the Senate had any jurisdiction.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- Cornell defeated Princeton in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game today, 35-30, before a Junior Week crowd.
BISMARCK, N.D., Feb. 13 (AP). -- Presidential candidates in the State preference primary of March 13 increased by two today, and supporters of others hurried to file them by tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Blame for most of the hoarding of money was put upon persons of comparative wealth by some treasury officials when the monthly statement of the Treasurer of the United States, given out today, showed a heavy increase in the issuance of bills of large denominations.

The organization of marine mortage banks as an important organ in the financing of merchant shipping is recommended by W.B Castonguay, head of the Bureau of Finance of the United States Shipping Board, who made a survey of the situation during the past year at the behest of the board.

For twenty-one years from Feb. 1, 1932, the land at 161 Second Street, twenty-four and a half feet wide, on which there is a five-story tenement, has been leased by Winthrop C. Rutherfurd to the Meyeson Holding Corporation, M. Rapaport, president, at a ground rental of $975 a year, in addition to all taxes and assessments.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 13. -- The Naval Academy water polo team received its first defeat in several years when it lost to the New York Athletic Club, 50 to 18, today.

Steel went up 5 3/8 points at the first opening of the market after the action to spread banking credits and ''free" more than a billion in gold was agreed upon at Washington. That was Thursday morning on the stock exchanges -- one of the pleasantest days the country has had for a long time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In one of Mr. Downes's recent articles on music in the Sunday edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES he discussed the question: "Should a symphony be applauded between movements, or should it not so be applauded?"

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent letter to THE TIMES, concerning the subject of calendar reform at Geneva, I mentioned that a committee of the League of Nations had "very definitely registered a disapproval" of the movement that sought to amend the present calendar by substituting therefore a thirteen-month calendar of 364 days and a "year day."

MUSEUM OF MODERN ART -- Exhibition of modern architecture in the "international style." Opened to the public last Wednesday. Closes March 23. Reviewed Feb. 9. Further comment on this page. Whitney Museum of American Art -- Exhibition of the American Society of Painters, Sculptors and Gravers. Opened Feb. 6. closes Feb. 28. Was reviewed in the news columns last Sunday. Further comment on this page.

WHILE the questionnaires propounded by theatrical press agents for the puzzlement of chorus girls contain nothing at all about the fourth dimension, relativity and other trivia on which the late Thomas A. Edison used to query his schoolboy admirers, they are formidable sheets, nevertheless, and require a deal of answering.

More than 1,300 entries, representing more than fifty schools, are expected for the Manual Training High School interscholastic track and field meet to be held in the 245th Coast Defense Armory, Brooklyn, on Saturday afternoon, starting at 1:30 o'clock.
The New York A.C. defeated the Bronx Hockey Club by a score of 3 -- 2 in a Metropolitan Amateur Hockey League game last night at the New York Coliseum, holding a lead through three fast periods.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 13. -- Economic planning is vital to the modern machine age, Norman Thomas said tonight in a debate with Professor Jacob Viner before the intercollegiate conference on capitalism and its alternatives assembled here.

DETROIT. THE hard and courageous work of getting the 1932 model motor cars to and through the metropolitan automobile shows is definitely over. Now comes the harder work of selling them, a task that has been tackled with zest by the automotive industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP). -- The business of being a Senator, as Mrs. Hattie W. Caraway looks at it, "is an all-day job." At 54 she has succeeded her late husband, Thaddeus H. Caraway, and is America's first duly elected feminine Senator. Her term lasts until March, 1933.

EVEN though its denouement is somewhat strained, the picturization of the mystery murder play, "The Silent Witness," which was at the Roxy, is nicely actod and unusually well staged, particularly a court room scene, which is quite a fair replica of one in London's Old Bailey.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- Apart from the plan which the Japanese Government is pursuing in its dealings with China at the present time, the mystery in the Far East is the attitude of Soviet Russia. For, contrary to general expectations, the Soviet Government does not show any inclination to place obstacles in the path of Japanese activities, however violent they may be.

MELBOURNE, Feb. 11. -- By its determination to allow New South Wales to default in the payment of interest to bondholders in New York and London, the Commonwealth government acted in the best interests of those bondholders.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 30. -- The members of the Jesuit Order in Spain began negotiating with the Belgian Government for hospitality as early as May, 1931, and the government appears to have extended the widest hospitality to the order, for the very good reason that Belgium is in need of intellectuals and it wants more secondary schools.

Heartening news comes from the Coast. Vic Williams has started training and track followers of the United States who are looking forward to the Olympic Games at Los Angeles are jubilant. Williams and Ben Eastman, who have engaged in stirring middle-distance duels, are this country's main hopes in the 400-meter run, the only individual track event won by an American at Amsterdam.

LONDON, Feb. 2. BEVERLEY NICHOLS is so accomplished a writer and, as I discovered long ago at Oxford, so entertaining and intelligent a conversationalist that he would seem to have been born to write good plays, and I think it highly probable that he will write them.

RECENTLY there has been a revival of interest in John Clare. A poet of peasant origin, he was a literary lion for a few years at the beginning of the romantic movement in England. He became a curiosity in 1820, when his first book passed through four editions.
GENEVA, Feb. 13. -- The Council of the League of Nations turned its attetion today to trying to put out what some regard as the first spark from the Far Eastern area to fall in Europe.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- A better-times Valentine in the form of rising market prices and a brighter outlook for a pronounced pickup of employment after the announcement of new Federal Reserve legislation heartened the Middle West today.
ROCHESTER, Feb. 13. -- In his address tonight Lieut. Gov. Lehman said:

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- The court has given its verdict in the Luebeck "Calmette case," but quite apart from the fact that the two convicted physicians, Professor George Deycke and Doctor Ernest Altstaedt, have appealed, the case is far from closed. The medical world is continuing to discuss the scientific intricacies that made this trial so unusual and the discussion is not likely to come to a quick end.

PREFACING his anthology with a dissertation on "The Tenth Muse," who was created and christened "Gasteria" by Brillat-Savarin, Thurston Macauley then proceeds to set before the reader the "feast" of prose and poetry dealing: "with the pleasures of "the festive board" that he has collected from the writings of many authors, chiefly British, but including also a few French and American.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11. -- Surprised comment frequently made in recent years by trained observers visiting San Francisco has concerned what seemed to be a lack of interest in Oriental affairs. Had these same observers been here since the Japanese descent on Shanghai they would have thought San Francisco had undergone a metamorphosis.

BOSTON, Feb. 12. THE re-form as the official word has it of Earl Carroll is touching every sympathetic heart. This week his "Vanities" is enanting the Colonial for eight performances only the "Vanities" of last season, with Herb Williams, Jack Benny and Chaz Chase.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- A crazily bounding disk that rolled past Goalie Frank Farrel of the United States team in the Arena today gave Canada the Olympic hockey championship as the Dominion sextet and the Americans played to a 2-2 tie.

THE city of New York's happy and heedless financial course has been abruptly halted. The first crisis is safely passed, but the city will have to exercise considerable caution throughout the year if it is to avoid more serious trouble.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- After it had overridden a decision of the chair to make such a proposition in order, the House today voted down a proposal to increase the term of its members from two to four years, offered by Representative Bankhead, Democrat, of Alabama, as an amendment to the so-called "lame duck" resolution.

The total demand for crude oil including natural gasoline and benzol during December was 79,441,000 barrels, compared with 80,962,000 barrels for the same month a year before, a decrease of 1.9 per cent, according to a compilation by William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist, from data of the United States Bureau of Mines.

RADIO'S gold rush began ten years ago. Time has flown. It is difficult to realize that WGY is old enough to stage a ten-year birthday party as it will on Saturday night. And WOR will cross the decade milestone on Washington's Birthday.

BOSTON, Feb. 11. -- Three recent events have reminded New England anew of its own lure in Winter. The Dartmouth Carnival is an established feature of the college year and almost a national institution. The snow trains operating out of the North Station in Boston are on their way to becoming a permanent fixture in the schedules of thousands of enthusiasts for Winter sports.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 13. -- The efforts of President Hoover to relieve depression were emphasized by two speakers at the meeting of the Nassau County Federation of Republican Women at Police Headquarters here this afternoon. The speakers were Ernest Lee Jahncke, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, and Herbert Feiss, economic adviser to the Department of State.

Companies financing the selling of products distributed on the deferred payment plan have proved their ability to ride out almost any kind of economic storm, contrary to the opinions of many who feared that a heavy deflation in prices might cause their downfall, according to A.E. Duncan, chairman of the board of the Commercial Credit Company.

RACKETY RAX" is the funniest book that can be read on Manhattan Island in this year of grace. In fact, it may cautiously be stated that it is probably the funniest book that has been published during the course of any of the more recent aeons.

The possibility of wide-spread local contests for posts as delegates to the Democratic National Convention, staged by followers of Alfred E. Smith, has been virtually eliminated by the decision of the five county leaders, and their up-State allies, to avoid definite commitment to any candidacy until after the delegates have been chosen, it was declared yesterday.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Feb. 13. -- The Westfield Polo Club trio tonight defeated the Squadron A team of New York, 15 to 11, after spotting the visitors a six-goal handicap, in a game played in the Westfield Armory.

LONDON. Feb. 13. The attendance was large at the Stock Exchange today and dealers put in the busiest forenoon since the resumption of Saturday trading. Sentiment was helped by the report of the Anglo-French agreement at Geneva regarding the reparations conference to be held at Lausanne in June.
