Formation of a council of industrialists and bankers for the purpose of combating the tendency toward hoarding by corporations and individuals, increasing the supply of eligible paper and exercising a liberalizing influence on banks was urged yesterday by Dr. Warren M. Persons, economist, in an interview with THE TIMES.

BARCELONA, Jan. 27. -- With an offensive against the Catalan autonomy statute in full swing, and the Cortes, after five months, still delaying the approval of the project which was ratified by 600,000 votes in a popular plebiscite last August, the Catalans are becoming convinced that the forces in control of the government have no intention of allowing them to rule themselves.

Methods of industrial management developed in the United States are not only innocent of the charge of having caused the depression but they have thoroughly demonstrated their worth in trying times, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, said yesterday.

For the next three weeks the New York Academy of Medicine at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street will be less exclusively a medical institution than it has been heretofore and will be again after March 5, for during the next three weeks the building will house an art exhibition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Alanson B. Houghton, former United States Ambassador to Great Britain, asserted in a recent speech in Brooklyn that the next constitutional problem confronting self-governing peoples will be the question whether the government or the people shall have the right to declare war or remain at peace.

Two minor explosions occurred yesterday in Brooklyn. The first, believed to have been caused by a small bomb hurled from a passing automobile, shattered two plate glass windows in the front of the drug store of Samuel Angerts at 908 Flatbush Avenue, opposite Erasmus Hall High School.

LISBON, Jan. 28. -- Directly west a few miles across the bay on which the British naval base of Hongkong is situated lies a bit of territory called Macao, not over five miles square, which was given to Portugal by a Chinese Emperor in appreciation of this country's help in fighting Chinese pirates and brigands when the Portuguese Navy was a power on the seas.

One of the strongest amateur balkline fields ever assembled will see action in the world's 18.2 tournament at the New York Lodge of Elks next month with Albert Poensgen of Germany defending his championship. Under the present arrangements, eight foreign players are scheduled to come here under sanction of the Union Internationale des Federations d'Amateurs de Billiard, which exercises world control over amateur billiards.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 13. -- The arrival from New York tomorrow of Alberto Pani, newly appointed Minister of Finance, and the attitude he will take toward the solution of financial and economic problems are matters of the greatest importance to Mexico at present.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 13. -- Yale's fencing team defeated New York University, 10 to 7, today in the closest dueling match the Elis have had this season. A sweeping 8-1 win in the foils alone saved Yale from defeat, as the Violet swordsmen won both the epee and saber matches, 3-1.

Governor Roosevelt, it was learned yesterday, gave his assurances to New York City leaders who have conferred with him during the last week that the long-deferred appointments to fill vacancies would be made tomorrow.

LAWRENCEVILLE. N.J., Feb. 13. -- With ten seconds of play remaining, Hilsman caged a basket to give Lawrenceville School a 29-28 victory over Blair Academy today. At half-time the score was deadlocked at 16 -- 16.

STUDIO electricians speak the most colorful vernacular to be found on a motion picture lot. The quaint argot they use is an outgrowth of the pet terms and words which the light manipulators have bestowed on the equipment with which they work.

ISTANBUL, Feb. 12. -- At the celebration of this Ramadan's Kadir Guedjessi (Night of Power) the Koran was read in the Turkish language for the first time in Turkey's most famous mosque, Santa Sofia, and it is almost certain that every mosque soon will follow suit, to the eventual exclusion of Arabic from all religious services in Turkey.

NEW BRUNSWICK. N.J., Feb. 13. -- A well-balanced Yale team defeated Rutgrers, 60 to 11, taking all first places except one and every second place, in an Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet in the Ballontine pool tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am about to indulge in near-swear words. It is my first attempt, and I believe it not only justified but imperatively demanded by the existing facts as I see them and the great interests of disarmament and world peace.

To the Dramatic Editor: After seeing the play I was greatly interested in Mr. Atkinson's consideration of "Distant Drums" in a recent Sunday TIMES. I cannot, however, agree with him in his estimate of the play's last act. To me it was the most stirring of the three, and I found Eunice's departure from the camp profoundly moving.

IN one of the Roundabout Papers that appeared in The Cornhill Magazine for December, 1862. Thackeray invents a delightful and whimsical story of a dream in which he met Laurence Sterne at the Hotel Dessein. Yorick has some choice and none too flattering observations to make concerning his contemporaries. He speaks of Goldsmith.

The old "matter of Barnes," the precedent often invoked by Democratic members of the Hofstadter committee and reluctant witnesses to support the contention that they need not testify about "private affairs," arose again yesterday to hamper Samuel Seabury's investigation into the awarding of City contracts.

THE useful floor screen is today acquiring new beauty and individuality at the hands of prominent artists, who are skillfully harmonizing it with modern interiors. Even in period interiors, where the traditional types of screen have always been an important feature, the modern painted screen has found a place.

THE Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives began last week to draft a tax bill which aims at a balanced budget. Its interest in this question rises above the routine duty of finding money with which to meet expenditures in an ordinary year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ended Feb. 6 increased over the preceding week, but were less than a year ago, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Berkeley Bell, erstwhile Texan, who was seeded No. 1 among the sixteen contestants, advanced to the final round in the annual Heights Casino invitation tournament yesterday afternoon and this afternoon will meet J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange for the honor which John Van Ryan, Davis Cup player, won last year.

Outplaying the Maroon by a wide margin all through the game, and combining a smart, fast-pass attack with a powerful defense which yielded only four goals, City College's varsity basketball team outscored Fordham, 37-13, at the C.C. N.Y. gymnasium last night.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. The colony here is now in the midst of a round robin tennis tournament which is being played on the counts of the Cloister Hotel with the finals in the mixed doubles and women's singles arranged for Tuesday afternoon.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- Sir Francis James Wylle, who with Lady Wylle is considered to be largely responsible for the success of the Rhodes Scholarships, has been appointed the honorary chancellor of Union College for this year by President Frank Parker Day, himself a Rhodes scholar from Canada in the class of 1905.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13.-- Authorities on finance and housing and business economists will testify in support of the home loan bank bill when hearings are resumed on Monday before the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, the National Association of Real Estate Boards announced today.

AT the risk of giving a wrong impression of the book as a whole, it would seem proper to say that any one who has read the various popular works of Jeans and Eddington should, as a needed corrective, read also this much-needed little volume by Professor Dingle, of the Imperial College of Science and Technology, and Honorable Secretary of the Royal Astronomical Society.

The Eastern Steamship Lines launched the liner Acadia yesterday at the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company and announced that construction work would be advanced to permit the ship to enter service between New York and Yarmouth, N.S., by June.

A nation-wide campaign to follow up the White House conference on child health and protection will start in Washington tomorrow, George Aubrey Hastings, administrative assistant to President Hoover, who will direct the campaign, announced yesterday.

EXCEPT for those who witnessed the very fine production by the Theatre Guild of "Volpone" a few years back, and those audiences at college theatres that may have seen one or another of his comedies, few have been fortunate enough to make visual acquaintance with the dramatic work of Ben Joason.

GENEVA. YOU have heard that people who live in glass houses should not throw stones. You have never seen people living in glass houses. It simply wasn't done. But now it is done. That proverbial glass house has just been built -- in Geneva.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 13. -- The Lapham Trophy, played for annually by squash racquets teams representing Canada and the United States, returns to this country tonight.

GREAT is the gulf between the life of woman in a Communist State and in a capitalist civilization. But, despite the Five-Year Plan and the New Order of Things and the rigors of the Soviet system, the Russian woman responds to the trimmings of life in precisely the same manner as her sister in Paris.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- Vestiges of an unknown religion which evidently combined the cult of the death with the idea of fecundity are being accumulated by the researches of the French mission in Northern Syria, it was declared by Professor F.A. Claude Schaeffer of the University of Strasbourg lecturing before the Societe Ernest Renan in Paris.

George Washington High School's team began the defense of its city P.S.A.L. fencing championship by defeating New Utrecht, 5 to 1, at Washington Irving High School yesterday as competition started in the second annual tournament for the title.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 13. -- The undefeated St. Paul's School hockey team beat the Harvard freshman six, 3 to 2, today, Pillsbury's goal in 9:15 of the overtime period giving the St. Paul's sextet the victory.

Governors of thirty States and Mayers of many important cities endorsed yesterday the war-against-depression campaign, which will open tomorrow under the auspices of the American Legion, American Federation of Labor, Association of National Advertisers, American Legion Auxiliary and other organizations.

TOKYO, Feb. 13. -- About a thousand guests, including twelve young imperial princes and princesses, accepted Ambassador Forbes's Invitation to attend the formal opening of the new American Embassy today.

MEMBERS of the Junior League in Washington, Baltimore, Syracuse and New York are cooperating with he active committees of the Frontier Nursing Service in twelve large Eastern cities in enlisting the patronage of Individuals for the West Indies cruise which has been arranged in behalf of the organization.

A gradual extension of the health courses and medical service available in the fifteen continuation schools for the 80,000 regular pupils to the more than 20,000 unemployed adults who are being trained for new trades and occupations is being effected by school officials, it was disclosed yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 13. -- Racing under restraint and holding his opposition safe all the way, Mrs. John Hay Whitney's crack 4-year-old Lightning Bolt scored an easy victory in the $3,000 added Jockey Club Handicap before a large crowd at Hialeah Park today.

THE second entertainment of the newly formed dancing club known as The Imperial will be given tomorrow night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. It will be a Valentine ball and its decorations will be characteiistic of St. Valentine's Day.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- Henry Harrison Blagden, a wealthy bachelor, of Haranac Lake, who is prominent socially and in sporting and hunting circles, has been missing from a cottage on the grounds of the Lake Placid Club since Thursday night and today Thomas Blagden Jr., his brother, received a letter from him asking $1,000 ransom for his release by kidnappers.
FREDERICK DELIUS, who is approaching his seventieth birthday, has written two new works, "Fantastic Dance," for full orchestra, and a setting for voice and piano of Paul Verlaine's poem, beginning:

EVERY reader of this amazing and amusing autobiography must echo the statement with which Rupert Hughes concludes his "Foreword," that of all the many biographies and autobiographies he has read there was "never one that touched life at more dangerous points more vividly."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- A record has been set in the number of investigations asked at this session of Congress, but only a few have been authorized by either branch.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 13. -- In a game featured by the fine defense of both sides, the Naval Academy basketball team defeated the University of Pittsburgh today, 29 to 22.
NEW YORK. Walter E. Edge, Ambassador to France, has returned from Washington and is at the Ambassador before sailing for France.

LONDON. IN the latest batch of sound pictures issued from British studios, by all odds the best is one which may be said to owe at least as much to America as to England, and perhaps a little more to Hollywood than it does to Elstres.

MONTREAL. -- This is the red-letter week in this season's Winter sports events in Montreal, as the world's figure skating championships are to be contested in this city on Wednesday and Thursday, for the first time in Canada and the second time on this continent.

A leasing transaction involving the removal from Fifth Avenue of the Gorham Company was closed yesterday by which that concern will concentrate on May 1 all of its whole sale business in the twelve-story building at 6-8 West Forty-eighth Street.

Buying activity declined in the wholesale apparel markets last week due to the departure of buyers who had completed initial purchases for Spring, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the Independent Merchandising Bureau, Inc.

FRANCIS YOUNGHUSBAND. in his introduction to "In the World's Attic," tells us that Mrs. Merrick has made no new exploration, "but what she has done is to go over old tracks in a new spirit." He regrets, and the reader may regret it too, that she did not spend more time in the Himalayas "to commune with the great mountains and the still solitudes."

A spirited second-half rally, which overcame an 11-7 deficiency at the intermission, enabled a fighting Manhattan quintet to upset the New York University five, 24 -- 19, before a crowd of 2,500 at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

Christian mission bodies in China and Japan protested against war activities in the Far East in cables received yesterday by the Rev. Dr. A.L. Warnshuis, secretary of the International Missionary Council, 419 Fourth Avenue.
HOLLYWOOD, Cal. REORGANIZATION is the order of the day, internally and externally. Motion-picture companies are dancing to the pulling of the purse strings and it's a strange experience.

IT will be remembered that MacKnight Black was the author of some very startling verse collected into a small volume under the title "Machinery." Since the publication of that book, Mr. Black has died, and the effect that he might have had upon American poetry can only be guessed at.

LONDON. PRINCESS ELIZABETH of England is a to have a house of her own. It is not a palace, but a miniature cottage with bedrooms on the second floor-miniature, and yet large enough for the little Princess to keep house in.

WHEN Goethe died on March 22, 1832, Thomas Carlyle, thinking of the forty volumes of the poet's collected works, wrote: "To measure and estimate all this, the time has not come; a century hence will be the fitter time."

The enthusiasm of bankers for the Glass-Steagall bill was tempered somewhat yesterday by the belief that the amendments to the measure proposed by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee will, if included in the final draft, detract from the effectiveness of the bill.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 13. -- With heavy rains and temperatures twenty degrees on the thawing side, followed by a jamming of ice at the knolis in Niskayuna, the Mohawk River has backed up all along the line. Alpaus Creek has overflowed its banks and the cellars of many near-by houses are flooded, while acres of vacant fields are under water there.

BERLIN, Feb. 1, 1932. MEYERBEER fares in Berlin approximately as he does in New York. The Stadtische Oper keeps "L'Africaine" on tap and turns it on from time to time. In recent years the same house has also sponsored a creditable performance of "Le Prophete," but two Meyerbeer operas under one rooftree are clearly an unwarranted extravagance in a day when the budgetary axes are working overtime.

GENEVA, Feb. 12. -- For the last four days Geneva and the Americans therein assembled to discuss the matter of world armaments have been afflicted by a "bise." The bise is the Swiss equivalent of an American Winter gale, but of worse disposition.

THERE are ninety-two kinds of matter known as elements, each with a definite place in what is known as the Periodic Table, and each with a weight of its own. Hydrogen is the lightest and uranium the heaviest element. Sir J.J. Thomson, dean of physicists, found that the rare element neon contains two kinds of atoms, the one differing from the other only in weight.

AND now, depression or no depression, the Sunday night benefit circuit is in full mid-winter swing, and what is laughingly called the actor's day of rest has succumbed in the name of charity, whose ways may be holy but often are trying.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 13. -- Lehigh easily defeated Yale in wrestling, 26 to 8, today, winning six bouts to two for the home team.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- So successful was the Colonial Exposition's small "cageless zoo" last Summer that plans are being considered for its enlargement and consolidation with the municipal zoological gardens now in the Jardin des Plantes. It is proposed to abolish the Jardin des Plantes zoo and move all its animals to the Parc de Vincennes, where the work of demolishing pavillions and removing other traces of the exposition is still going on.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The House today formally dropped impeachment charges against Andrew W. Mellon as Secretary of the Treasury. Without debate or a record vote, it adopted the judiciary committee's recommendation to discontinue further consideration of allegations that he had engaged in private business contrary to law during his eleven years in the Cabinet.

How the average exporter will benefit from the "aid to export" provisions contained in Section 5a of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation law depends entirely on the interpretation officials place on the words "American securities" used by Congress to define the type of collateral required before acceptance credits can be granted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Issuance of 1,671 warrants for raids on Washington speakeasies during 1931 was pointed to today by the Crusaders, an anti-prohibition organization, as evidence of "rebellion" in the nation's capital against the Eighteenth Amendment.

Writing on disarmament in the current number of the Nouvelle Revue de Hongrie of Budapest, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, says the governmental propagandists as well as publicists should emphasize the fact that in order to "make truly effective military and naval disarmament it should be preceded by moral disarmament."

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- Further fashion showings reveal that the Parts couturiers are agreed upon a general silhouette with wide shoulders and straight, slender lines relieved by bust emphasis, but are split on the question of waistline boundaries. Schiaparelli leads one school with her just below the waist lines, while Chanel and Molyneux push above the hipbone division. Lelong. Lanvin and Augustabernard offer waistline variety and Brueyere sponsors one slightly super-normal.

WASHINGTON. WHEN, a few days ago, Admiral William V. Pratt, who, as Chief of Operations, exercises the active command of the United States Navy, informed the House Expenditures Committee that the present Japanese war machine was the most efficient the world had ever seen, he was emphasizing efficiency, not power.

WHEN Samuel F.B. Morse boarded the packet ship Sully at Havre 100 years ago he was known as an American painter with an unusual talent for portraits. When he stepped oft the Sully at the foot of Rector Street, New York, six weeks later, he was the author of an idea that was to be epochal in the application of electricity to the needs of mankind.

Arthur M. Loew, motion picture producer, telegraphed yesterday from Miami, Fla., to his New York offices to deny reports from South America that several South American governments were imposing or were about to impose $10,000 fines against him and Hal Roach, also a film producer, for alleged violations of passport regulations.

MADRID, Feb. 13. -- The 101st successful trial of the Geneva lifesaving apparatus was made today by the Spanish submarine C-3 when a seaman descended 110 feet in the escape chamber, drank a glass of beer, and returned to the surface of Cartagena Bay.

Just a suggestion of typical March weather was in the air yesterday when, with the temperature comparatively mild and the blue sky fluffed with clouds, a gusty wind swept out of the northwest shortly after 2 P.M., rattling signs and fences in the city, blowing down telephone wires in the suburbs, and causing confusion and accidents to small boats which had ventured forth on the waters of Long Island Sound.

MIAMI. -- Public inspection of private gardens at so much per person is the means of raising money for a playground for juniors and a park for the elders adopted by the Riverside Garden Club of Miami. It has received the endorsement and cooperation of the owners of some of the private estates in Miami.

ONE could say nothing more flattering about any study of a community than that it deserves to be put on the shelf beside the "Middletown" of Robert S. and Helen Merrell Lynd, and one can honestly say this for Mr. Blumenthal's book. The comparison should not be pushed too far.

Former German Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. When President Hindenburg conferred the Chancellorship on the Centrist Deputy, Dr. Heinrich Bruening, on March 30, 1930, the public outside a quite narrow circle knew nothing of the new occupant of the highest office in the realm, to which still attach, from the time of Prince Bismarck, dignity and prestige.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12. -- One of the most interesting features of the Soviet economic position today is the effort toward economic independence, particularly regarding the production here of equipment and material hitherto imported. No small success has been attained already in this direction and the economic newspapers daily record fresh instances of the Soviet's ingenuity in "catching or surpassing foreigners" by home production.

BARCELONA, Feb. 13. -- This city, the Marseilles of Spain, with its turbulent sea-front districts and sullen industrial labor unions contrasting with fine boulevards and smart shops and the centre of the Red movement in Spain, has seen a new figure emerge menacingly from the ferment which has carried one faction after another to the top in internal fight for control of the national labor syndicates.

FILMING of "Grand Hotel" is practically completed at the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studios with a cast headed by Greta Garbo, John Barrymore, Joan Crawford, Wallace Beery, Lionel Barrymore, Lewis Stone and Jean Hersholt.

THE gifts of many prominent men and women have made possible the construction of the new headquarters of the Kips Bay Day Nursery at 454 East 122d Street, which will be opened formally on the afternoon of Feb. 25.

While the members of the Cruising Club of America, which fosters offshore racing, have delayed framing a much-needed rule for ocean contests, with the result that the Bermuda race next June will be sailed under the regulations of 1930, English yachtsmen have gone ahead with a view of developing fast and seagoing yachts.

OTTAWA, Feb. 10. -- The Parliament of Canada, having been opened with ancient and symbolic formalism, inherited from the Mother of Parliaments and in the shadow of traditional social splendor, has settled down to its serious business with rare diligence.

EVERY country has know revolution. It is the price of civilization. It is through revolution of one sort or another that progress, as judged by Western standards, has been won and China has certainly been no exception to this rule.

CAPE TOWN. AFRICA is likely to remain on the lion standard for a long time. In spite of the heavy export of skins. Lions are so plentiful and destructive in some parts of South Africa and Rhodesia that they have been classed as "vermin" and attacked by cattle farmers with guns and poison, like the rabbits of Australia.

A NEW type of radial engine was demonstrated late last week. Involving several new adaptations of principles formerly used in two and four cycle engines with the object of utilizing the most advantageous points and eliminating the faults of each the composite engine was declared a success by several technical men who witnessed the demonstration.

PIERRE LOTI'S "Le Mariage de Loti" according to the Victor Book of Operas, was the source of "Lakme" Leo Delibes's liberttists, Edmond Gondinet and Phillippe Gille. The opera was produced in Paris April 14, 1883. Marie Van Zandt, a native of New York, sang the title role.

MORE than 2,000,000 boys and girls are scheduled to be graduated from American schools and colleges in June, according to the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education, which will begin a series of eight vocational guidance programs this week over WABC and a network of seventy-nine stations.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- A curious byproduct of Great Britain's new aggressive nationalism is the almost complete break the government has made with the economists who hitherto had exerted a powerful influence behind the scenes.

Miss Helen Hicks, who has high hopes this year of scoring a grand slam in women's golf comparable to that of Bob Jones two years ago in men's links play, starts along the 1932 tournament trail at Palm Beach tomorrow. There she will compete in the Florida State event which is scheduled to continue through Friday.

Foreign exchanges rallied sharply against the dollar yesterday as European interests, whose belief that this country is headed toward inflation has been strengthened by the Glass-Steagall bill, sold United States exchange to carry home their dollar balances.

ONCE more a volcano in the Aleutian chain of islands has been reported in violent eruption This time it was Shishaldin on Unimak Island that recently belched forth clouds of smoke and showers of ashes and lit up the sky "like a huge torch."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13. -- In compliment to Miss Frances Hutchinson of Philadelphia, who, with her mother, Mrs. Sydney Emlen Hutchinson, arrived last night at El Mirasol to be the guest of the latter's father. Edward T. Stotesbury, for several days, James H.R. Cromwell entertained this afternoon with a tea at Malmaison, his villa on the Stotesbury estate.
DUBLIN, Feb. 11. -- The promise of the Ottawa conference of Dominion Premiers has altered, the whole trend of the Free State election campaign, which ends next Tuesday.

PARIS, Feb. 12. -- The social season at French Winter resorts this year is comparatively quiet. A few Americans always sojourn on the Riviera but neither the French nor the British are present in their usual numbers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13. -- Negotiable bonds said to be worth $41,000 were found in the room of a hotel occupied by Oscar Mohr of New York last night and, as he disclaimed ownership, the police today began inquiries to clear up the mystery as to who left them there.

EASTON, Pa., Feb. 13. -- The presentation of "The Contrast' by the Marquis players at Lafayette College on the evenings of Feb. 17, 18 and 19, will be the first event in the college's celebration of the bicentennial of George Washington. Another feature of the program will be a lecture on Feb. 23 by Bernard Fay, Professor of History in the University de Clermont-Ferrand, and author of "George Washington, Republican Aristocrat."

UP to the holiday retail trade showed very little improvement over the recent low level, but rose somewhat toward the close of the week. The special holiday offerings seemed to attract better response, due, perhaps, to the change in sentiment brought about by rise in the stock and commodity markets as a result of proposed banking legislation.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 13. -- Important recommendations for regulating trading on the Buenos Aires and Rosario Grain Exchanges were made today in a report by Julio Urien. Director of the National Statistical Department, who has just completed an investigation of grain futures trading in the two principal Argentine markets.

The sincerity of parties to mixed marriages between Roman Catholics, and non-Catholics in their promise to educate their children in the Catholic faith governs the validity of dispensations rather than whether or not such promises actually are carried out, the Rev Dr. Valentine G. Schaaf, of the department of canon law at the Catholic University of America in Washington, D.C., said yesterday, according to The Associated Press.
VIENNA, Feb. 11. -- A development of great importance to the banks of Southeastern Europe occurred during the past week.

MONTREAL, Feb. 13. -- The New York Rangers tonight found the Canadiens at the peak of their world's championship form and were forced to accept defeat in a National Hockey League match as Montreal swept in two goals in the first period and one in the second, to win, 3 to 1.

HAVANA, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Bob Up, a 3-year-old daughter of Upset, which also has raced at Jefferson Park this year, staged a great stretch drive to outgame a field of better grade claiming sprinters in the six-furlong feature at Oriental Park today.

HAVANA. All tennis enthusiasts will turn out this week to see the first international amateur championship tourney, which will start Friday at the Vedado Tennis Club, an event which has been created recently through the gift of a silver trophy by the Hon. Harry F. Guggenheim, United States Ambassador to Cuba.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13. -- Bernard H. Brodsky, president of the Philadelphia Wool and Hide Company, was abducted by three bandits today, forced to drive their automobile three blocks and then shoved from the car after being compelled to surrender a payroll of $2,650.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Attacks upon prohibition were tonight ascribed by Senator Brookhart to "high finance." In a radio speech over the National Broadcasting System, he denounced the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, the Association of Women for Prohibition Reform and the Crusaders, but asserted that the "fight is over now so far as the Constitution and the law are concerned."
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 13. -- Dartmouth's brilliant basketball team swept to another victory tonight, defeating Army by a 28-16 score.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- An unfavorable report on bills of Senator Borah to reduce salaries and mileage of members of Congress was ordered today by the Senate Civil Service Committee.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 12. -- Cincinnati, once again hailed as "the queen of the West," took stock recently and discovered that under six years of City Manager government, these were some of the things accomplished:

DETROIT, Feb. 11. -- A critical situation in the finances of Detroit was faced last week when the administration was told by Detroit banks that they had loaned their legal limit to the city, and New York bankers refused an accommodation of $5,000,000, a large part of which was needed to meet the Feb. 15 payroll.

GENEVA, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press). -- "Canada will wholeheartedly support any constructive proposal for the limitation and reduction of armaments," Sir George Perley, her chief delegate, told the world disarmament conference today. "And we believe that action toward this end should be taken and taken now.

McNally, a "real free economist," has undertaken to give your readers and myself a lesson in economics, history and sociology. The issue of "free versus planned economy" being of outstanding importance to the economic thought of today, I would like, with your permission, to make a few observations on Mr. McNally's letter.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. CALIFORNIA, off Oahu, Feb. 13. -- As the Hawaiian war games neared the end, the "Blue" attacking force was in a secure position ashore on the west coast of Oahu, in undisputed control of the sea and certain of the ultimate capture of Honolulu from the "Black" force.

A HUMAN DIVINING ROD. DID President Hoover select a newspaper man to head a nation-wide drive against hoarding because no newspaper man would, be suspected of that practice? The human divining rod who is called upon to discover and entice $1,300,000,000 worth of gold, silver and paper currency from hiding places in spare socks, mattresses, tin boxes and back yards is Colonel Frank Knox, who only five months ago bought The Chicago Daily News.
THE difficulties which many States are experiencing in balancing their budgets are causing legislators to look to motor tax funds as a means of relief.

RECRUDESCENCE is a long word and, if one takes the pains to trace it back to its origin, an unpleasant one, with a suggestion of raw and painful rounds. Therefore, although many have told us that we are experiencing a recrudescence of mural painting, we decline to cast the shadow of even a pedantic aspersion upon the lovely art of wall decoration.

YOUNGER members of the Spence Alumnae Society, comprising the organization known as The Spinsters, will give their annual supper dance on the night of March 4 in the ballroom of the Park Lane for the benefit of the Adoption Nursery, which is maintained by the Spence Alumnae Society.

Proper evaluation of consumer demand through more accurate indices and the adoption of corrective measures to stem a decline in demand at the source were suggested yesterday as aids to future business stabilization by T.M. McNieee, market analyst of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

GENEVA, Feb. 13. -- Sir John Simon's plea for delay in yesterday's secret meeting of the Council of Twelve of the League of Nations was put in a new light when it became known today that a little before that meeting Hugh R. Wilson, United States Ambassador to Switzerland, had officially informed Sir Erio Drummond, Secretary General, that Anglo-American negotiations with, the Japanese at Shanghai had completely broken down.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13. -- A high, cold wind today put a halt to the par-breaking performances of the leaders in the $5,000 New Orleans open golf tournament, and the end of the second eighteen holes found Gene Sarazen of Long Island, Harry Cooper of Chicago and Johnny Camet, youngster of Eldorado, Ark., bunched at the top with cards of 145.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 13 (AP). -- Cleveland voters will elect on Tuesday their first Mayor since 1925, choosing between Daniel E. Morgan, former City Manager and choice of the Republican organization, and Ray T. Miller, an aggressive candidate backed by the Democrats.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13. -- The development of the department of hygiene and physical education at Princeton University during the two decades of its existence was traced by Dr. Joseph E. Raycroft, its organizer and director, in a report made public today.

MONTREAL, Feb. 11. -- Some Canadian wheat will be shipped to the new seaport of Churchill this year and be conveyed to Europe by the Hudson Bay route, it was predicted in shipping circles here, as a result of the recent announcement by Dr. Manion, Dominion Minister of Railways and Canals, that Churchill "would be in a position this Summer to accept such commerce as was offered."

THE research departments in the various Hollywood studios have a professional pride of their own. Mr. RAMSAY MACDONALD opened the Institute of Geology and the Institute of Engineering, extensions of the University of Edinburgh, the other day. From geology and HUGH MILLER and the evolution of engineering he went to the University Women's Union. He gave the women an unco nieve-fu' of compliment.

The American Solvents and Chemical Corporation, a Delaware concern, with subsidiaries employing 700 men and women in plants throughout the United States in the manufacture of industrial alcohol, ethyl acetate solvents and other chemicals, was adjudged bankrupt yesterday, after a short hearing before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

To Wall Street the violent advance on the Stock Exchange yesterday, following that of Thursday, indicated that speculative interests had not altered their original judgment of the proposed amendment to the Federal Reserve act. A badly frightened bear party continued to cover its commitments at swiftly rising prices, while other speculators proceeded to buy stock for long account.

It was his Influence as the founder of a new school of biography that inspired so many of our leading Journals to supplement their obituaries by critical editorials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Senate and House leaders moved today for a vote Monday "or certainly early next week" on the Glass-Steagall bill, which provides a further release of the stored credit of the Federal Reserve System to help dispel the business depression.
DR. LEE DE FOREST traveled across the continent last week from his laboratory in California and released news that he has turned his inventive ability to television.

Fresh buying enthusiasm appeared in the securities markets yesterday, lifting stocks 2 to 14 points and bonds 1 to 9 points, with an aggregate increase of nearly $4,000,000,000 in quoted values. The spectacular movement in the stock market produced a virtual panic among bearish speculators.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 13. -- After suffering a collapse from heart disease in the pulpit while preaching, the Rev. Dr. Romilly F. Humphries, Protestant Episcopal Archdeacon of Baltimore, died late last night at his home here. When he was stricken on Ash Wednesday evening in the pulpit he was revived and insisted on finishing his sermon.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13. -- The price war between several chain food commodity stores in Beechview which has been waged intermittently for five weeks broke out in force again today, and patrons who crowded the stores laid in supplies at the lowest prices in thirty years.
LOUISVILLE, Feb. 11. -- Abolition of all bipartisan boards and emergency tax bills have taken up most of the time of the first six weeks of the biennial session of the Kentucky Legislature.

HONOLULU, Feb. 13. -- With the joint army and navy manoeuvres brought to an official close at dusk last night, the umpires and high ranking officers of both services settled down today to draw conclusions which would be of advantage in a time of actual hostilities.

ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S sketch of his own life is even briefer than CARL SANDBURG'S three-hundred-word biography, but it does not include the period of "greatest stress and strain," of which President HOOVER, in the figure of an engineer, spoke from the room where LINCOLN for five years toiled with "patience, understanding steadfastness, genius and "courage."

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has added recently to its classical collection and is showing for the first time, in its room of recent accessions, a rare Greek terra cotta relief of the middle of the fifth century B.C.

LONDAN. WHILE the rest of London waits gloomily on the course of events. Gordon Selfridge, the merchant-adventurer of Oxford Street, announces his intention of making his already considerable shop the largest in the world.

Squadron C, with its hard-riding trio of Miiton Kornblum, Gilbert Wilson and Warren Sackman, defeated a crack combination from the New York Riding Club which boasted of the services of the Hoppings and Tom Watson, by the score of 9 1/2 to 7 1/2, in the feature Class B polo match at Squadron C Armory last night.

MUSEUM of Science and Industry -- Four new murals by Howard McCormick, permanently installed in the foyer. They were shown for the first time last Monday. These murals, conventional in treatment, illustrate "the development of civilization through the use of tools."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Owing to the shortage of government funds the Bureau of Industrial Alcohol today discontinued supplying record books for physicians' prescriptions employed in the distribution of medicinal liquor. Dr. James M. Doran, chief of the Industrial Alcohol Bureau, said that in the future physicians would be required to obtain their record books from commercial printing establishments.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 14. -- Fresh Japanese soldiers poured into Shanghai today while rival guns on the Chapei battlefront boomed a salute to another Sunday and the sixteenth day of hostilities there between China and Japan.

PARIS, Feb. 2, 1932. RARELY has a work cost a composer as much pains as this piano concerto of Ravel. He worked at it continuously for more than two years, cloistering himself in his home at Montfort I'Amaury, refusing all invitations, and working ten and twelve hours a day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- Declaring that the regional sales plan proposed by the National Coal Association, even if held to be legal by the courts, would be ineffective, W. Jett Lauck, consulting economist of the United Mine Workers of America appealed today to the bituminous coal operators to support the coal-stabilization plan proposed in the David-Kelly bill now pending in Congress.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 13. -- While declining to fix any definite date when the Chinese armies will be beaten back beyond gun range of the International Settlement, Vice Admiral Nomura told THE NEW YORK TIMES exclusively tonight that the naval authorities, in full cooperation and agreement with the army authorities, had determined to end this period of hazardous conflict within the city very quickly.

The champion swimming team of George Washington High School decisively defeated James Monroe, 47 to 15, in the opening of the annual series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx senior high school title of the Public Schools Athletic League in the seventy-five-foot home pool yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- William Knightsmith, London's most famous toastmaster, died today at the age of 73.

It requires exceptional fortitude in present circumstances to maintain, as Mr. CALKINS does in The Rotarian Magazine, that "today all business, including "the business of government, needs the "courage, honesty and energy of youth "far more than it needs the caution, "experience and conservatism of age."

In the profusion of plans offered at Geneva, the American delegation has submitted one proposal which may ultimately prove to be the entering wedge for an agreement. This is its conditional acceptance of the principle of "budgetary limitation" of land armaments. France has been an advocate of this method since the Preparatory Commission began in 1926 to draft plans for the present conference.

PARIS, Feb. 13 (AP). -- The interests of American exporters to France of leather, machine tools, pencils, electric motors, tomato products and dried prunes, which, are hit or endangered by the new French quota system, are being protected by the American Chamber of Commerce, it was announced today.

Experience shows that a regular allowance can be made a very helpful means of acquainting the child with the significance of money in modern life, and its relation to value; and that it furnishes a basis for important educational experience and guidance.

WHAT is believed to be the most important of the missing works of Peter Warlock (Philip Heseltine), "A Chinese Ballet," has been found by The London Sunday Referee. Mr. Warlock, who died in December, 1930, wrote it in conjunction with Adrian Allinson in 1916.

BUTTE, Mon., Feb. 11. -- As nearly as anything can be certain in politics it already is a foregone conclusion that the Montana delegation to the Democratic National Convention will be for Franklin D. Roosevelt. Months ago Senator T.J. Walsh, Senator B K. Wheeler, National Committeeman J. Bruce Kremer and State Chairman W.W. McDowell declared themselves for the New York Governor All four in recent weeks have visited Mr. Roosevelt at least once.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 13. -- This city's financial problems were solved today, at least temporarily, with the announcement by Julius S. Rippel, banker, that a group of banks and insurance companies had agreed to buy $6,000,000 of the city's tax revenue bonds, bearing 6 per cent interest, and that Newark bankers had agreed to renew the $1,000,000 of temporary bonds falling due Monday and held partly here and partly in New York.

BERLIN, Feb. 13. -- The text of today's communique on the Lausanne reparations conference impresses Berlin political circles as showing that France has yielded on the chief point, as the question of whether the Young Plan shall be perpetuated at the conference has been left open.
GENEVA, Feb. 13. -- Four peoples from opposite ends of the earth laid their pleas for disarmament and peace before the World Disarmament Conference today. They were Canada, Latvia, Hungary and China.

THE American public has grown accustomed to scientific miracles in home management. Refrigerators without ice, furnaces without ashes and a hundred labor-saving conveniences ready at the pressure of a button have come to be accepted as a matter of course.

Visiting clergymen will be heard in many pulpits of the city today. The sermon topics will deal with war, economics, marriage and a need for new leadership in national and international affairs. Abraham Lincoln will be the central figure of many sermons.

Poly Prep is near its goal in the quest for permanent possession of the trophy placed in competition three years ago by the alumni associations of Poly and St. Paul's School of Garden City to promote athletics between the two schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced tonight that it had made its first loans under authorization granted by Congress.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13. -- Jumping into the lead at the rise of the carrier. Mrs. M.B. Price's Silverdale made every post a winning one to account for the $2,500 Edgewater Gulf Hotel Claiming Sweepstakes, decided won one and one-sixteenth miles at the Fair Grounds today.

LONDON, Feb. 3, 1932. AT the present moment economic pressure, points to a closing of frontiers -- economic and artistic. Even the harmless and economically desirable tourist has, in one country, to report to the police twenty-four hours after arrival and declare his mother-in-law's maiden name.

There came to this country from France recently a cloth-covered notebook nearly 200 years old, containing more than 100 drawings which have been classified by George S. Hellman, New York art connoisseur and writer, as early and supposedly lost work by the famous eighteenth century French artist Jean Honore Fragonard.

Two small strips of land in the heart of a Greenwich Village block were recently found to belong to the estate of Captain Richard Towning, who died in New York in 1843 after retiring from the West Indian slave trade.

THE American Institute of Graphic Arts has placed on exhibition at the New York Public Library its tenth annual selection of "Fifty Books of the Year" -- books chosen as notable examples of fine bookmaking from among more than 650 volumes submitted by 150 publishers, printers and designers throughout America.

A NEW book by Henry Neumann, for these many years leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, is always gratefully welcomed by those who take this business of living seriously and intelligently enough to want to meet It with wholesome and reasonable programs and methods.

THE sixteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season features the revival of Leo Delibes's "Lakme." with Lily Pons in the title role. The opera, which will be presented Friday evening, has been musically prepared and will be conducted by Louis Hasselmans, and the stage direction is in charge of Alexander Sanine.

Owen (Owney) Madden, convicted slayer and alleged racketeer, began a legal fight yesterday to prevent his return to Sing Sing for violation of his parole. Lawyers acting in his behalf obtained a writ of habeas corpus from Supreme Court Justice Peter J. Hatting, returnable at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning, when they will seek his release as well as the release of three other ex-convicts under arrest as parole violators.

By eventually bringing the world's goods under social control for the benefit of all we could solve the problem of the relation of physical possessions and Christianity, the Rev. Dr. J.V. Moldenhawer declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP). -- While the twenty-three former pilots of the Century Air Lines continued their passive resistance strike, officials of the company announced today that the required quota of fliers was nearly filled and that they expected to resume normal operations soon.
The open season on Yiddish dramatic recitals has begun, rather earlier than usual, with three taking place over the week-end.
DUBLIN, Feb. 14 -- The Cosgrave Government in Ireland is fighting with its back to the wall this weekend to keep the Free State on the path of peace and economic cooperation with the British Empire.

Last week's rapid advance in the markets may itself have meant much or little; the event will prove which. No doubt, it was inspired to a great extent by wholly erroneous ideas of what the week's new finance plan proposed to do. But on the other hand, it touched the imagination even of those who read its purposes correctly, and the psychology of the present situation is important.

Captain John F. Milliken, executive secretary of the Neptune Association, announced yesterday that he had filed a statement with the Merchant Marine Committee of the House of Representatives recommending elimination from the Volstead act and the Eighteenth Amendment of provisions that bar liquors from ships entering or leaving American ports.

The first in a series of lectures by Dom Urban Butler, O.S.B., of St. John's Priory, Bath, England, will take place on the night of Feb. 29 in the Astor Gallery of the WaldorfAstoria for the benefit of the fund for the establishment of a reception house of the Good Shepherd in New York.

BAKERSFIELD, Cal., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The sink of Death Valley, several hundred feet below sea level, where mirages of lakes and rivers often torment travelers crossing its burning expanse, has become a real lake.
Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in the Wilson administration, returned yesterday in the Orizaba of the Ward Line with Mrs. Baker from a three-weeks vacation in Mexico.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Although the operation on Prime Minister MacDonald's eye proved satisfactory, he has been ordered to take a further three weeks' complete rest.

Roland Hayes, returning from the Far West, gave his only recital in New York for this season yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. Heard at close quarters, the voice of one of the most famous tenors and finished artists of his race disclosed equally the subtle nuance of many a classic and the deep emotion in his singing of Negro spirituals.

ALBANY, Feb. 14, -- When the Legislature reassembles tomorrow night it will face a new "hurry-up" program, including, probably, bills for a revised motor vehicle tax, for setting up a banking board and for Congressional reapportionment, and a battle in the Assembly over the Senate resolution providing for an inquiry into all State departments.
A Secretary of Wrath. The head of the War Department at "Washington is not neceasarily a fighting man. "Under the American system we assert civilian control of the army.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 14 -- In the presence of one of the largest crowds that has enjoyed a dog show In New Jersey in recent years, Mallhawk Banker, the grand English setter owned by the Happy Valley Kennels of Dr. A.A. Mitten of Philadelphia, was judged the best in the show tonight at the nineteenth annual event of the Newark Kennel Club.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- The Western Conference basketball championship struggle tonight was a free-for-all, with Northwestern, Purdue, Minnesota and Michigan still in the drive for the title.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 14 -- Breaking all tradition, Dartmouth students heaped honors on an individual tonight and accorded a favorite son a noisy welcome which heretofore had been reserved only for victorious teams.

DUBLIN, Feb. 14 -- Patrick Reynolds, for five years a member of the Dail Elreann for Leitrim and Sligo and running as a government candidate in the present election, was assassinated today while canvassing in County Leitrim. The killing was believed to have had no political significance, but it created a tremendous sensation throughout Ireland on the eve of the elections.

The Garrick Theatre, time-honored playhouse in Thirty-fifth Street just east of Sixth Avenue, where many famous actors have appeared and where the first production of the fledgling Theatre Guild was shown in the Spring of 1919, was severely damaged by fire shortly before 3 o'clock yesterday morning.

Tomorrow there will be a hearing on the bill, Introduced by Assemblyman LANGDON POST, of which the purpose is to put responsibility on those who publish or distribute indecent books rather than on the retall dealers who are now held liable.

PASSAIC, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Herbert E. Parker, 55 years old, executive secretary of the Young Men's Christian Association here, committed sulside today in the boiler room of the institution by shooting hlmself in the head. Mr. Parker's health had been impaired by worry over the financial condition of his association, with which he had been connected for seventeen years, the police said.

One might expect to find at least a faint historical piety toward France in Missouri, a part of LA SALLE's immense gift of territory to Louis XIV and itself called Louisiana for the first few years after the purchase. MAKQUETTE, JOLIET, LA SALLE are names of, general honor.

While buying activity tapered off in the wholesale apparel markets during the week, a fairly steady flow of orders appeared on Spring merchandise. Retailers are now preparing for promotions of new Spring lines and a trend away from price merchandise of questionable quality is evident.

While police guarded the wreckage from hundreds of souvenir hunters, mechanics yesterday gathered the crumpled silk and twisted metalwork of the Goodyear blimp Columbia, which crashed with, the loss of one life Saturday near the city dump in Flushing.

To the Editor of The New York Times : It is just, I think, that a reply be made to the attacks upon Governor Roosevelt for his change of attitude upon our adherence to the League of Nations. These attacks began with your leading editorial, "Governor Roosevelt and the League," followed up to date by severe and unfair argument In letters of highly committed advocates of the League.

"There's Always Juliet," starring Edna Best and Herbert Marshall, will open tonight at the Empire Theatre. Lou Holtz's vaudeville revue, with himself, Clark and McCullough and Vincent Lopez and his orchestra among the chief entertainers, will begin an engagement this evening at the Hollywood Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Assertions that thirty-four Senators and 190 Representatives favored submission of a prohibition repeal proposal to the States and that "shrewd political observers," believed the next Congress would be ready to act affirmatively were made by Henry H. Curran, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, in his report for 1931, issued today.

Charles Weidman added appreciably to his stature as an all-around dance artist by his recital yesterday afternoon at the Guild Theatre, when he revived his ballet version of Max Beerbolim's "The Happy Hypocrite," and formally introduced his group of men dancers.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. MARYLAND AT LAHAINA, H.I., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The arrival here today of the U.S.S. Pennsylvania, flagship of Admiral Frank H. Schofield, Commander of the United States Fleet, completes the assemblage after the gigantic Hawaiian war game.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 12 -- In 1931 the foreign trade of Holland with England showed a favorable balance of 161 millions in this country's favor, but British trade with Holland is now declining. The decrease of u14,000,000 in total imports into Great Britain during January as compared with December was expected here owing to the continuous imposition of greater restrictions on British imports.

ROME, Feb. 14 -- It is understood that the Italian Government has purchased at a bargain price from Prince Alberto Giovanelli of Venice the famous painting by Giorgione entitled "The Tempest" and generally recognized as the most valuable privately owned canvas in the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Abusive treatment by Japanese volunteers at Shanghai of Arthur Rumney Ringwait, the United States vice consul there, and Mrs. L. Young, a Chinese woman of American nationality, whom he was accompanying in search of her missing daughter, was reported to the State Department today by Edwin S. Cunningham, the United States Consul General, who protested to the Japanese Consul General before reporting the incident.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Relatives of Harry H. Blagden tonight promised a statement tomorrow when, they said, everything would be cleared up. Previously they had promised a statement early tonight which was not forthcoming.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP). -- Dead dollars are responding to the government's drive against hoarding. Thousands of letters, radiating confidence and promising support, pour daily into the office of Frank Knox, chairman of President Hoover's antihoarding committee and publisher of The Chicago Daily News.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 14 -- Josephus Daniels, Secretary of the Navy in the Wilson administration, today declined to accede to the request of thousands of fellow citizens that he become a candidate for Governor because, he said, he could better serve the State as editor of The News and Observer.

Textile High School's basketball team is leading the city's P.S.A.L. quintets in scoring in P.S.A.L. competition, with a total of 134 points for its four games. Stuyvesant High School, which is tied for the leadership with Textile in the Manhattan division P.S.A.L. race, each with four victories and no defeats, is second in scoring with 104 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- With the administration and Congress working in harmony and committed to swift enactment of law for broadening the nation's banking credit facilities, another Federal organization designed to hasten business recovery advanced a step further today when the Reconstruction Finance Corporation appointed advisory committees for Its loan agencies throughout the country.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 15 -- Minister of War S. Araki in a statement 'to the press today declared that Japan intended to limit the affair at Shanghai and does not seek a quarrel with other Chinese armiea not now on the scene.

Throughout the two weeks of fighting in Shanghai the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America has quietly been trying to bring about peace, it was disclosed yesterday in a statement issued by Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary.

NEW ROCHELLE, Feb. 14 -- Two boats capsized during the Winter regatta of the Frostbite Yacht Club held today under the auspices of the New Rochelle Yacht Club, while before and after the racing two more capsized and one heeled over and filled.

Final attempts to block the abandonment of the Long Island Railroad's Whitestone branch, which has been ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission to become effective at midnight tonight, will be made today by counsel for the commuters.

The St. Nicholas Hockey Club staged a stirring rally in the final period to defeat the German Olympic hockey team at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Going into the final period on the short end of a 2 to 0 score, the St. Nicholas stickwielders flashed a dazzling offensive which netted them three goals in less than three minutes, giving them a 3-2 victory.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 14 -- After Attorney General Ramon Quinones had reported that his investigation had proved unfounded a charge circulated by nationalists that Dr. Cornelius P. Rhoads had sought to carry out a United States plot for the extermination of the Porto Rican race, Governor James R. Beverly announced today that the incident was closed.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 13 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 63.6, which compares with 64.2 a week ago, 64.5 two weeks ago, 65.2 three weeks ago and 65.2 four weeks ago. The present year's highest average to date was 66.3, in the first week of January; this week's is the lowest.

Taking advantage of his limit handicap of five minutes, William Hannon, veteran athlete of the St. Anselm's A.C., won first place in the weekly handicap road run staged by the St. Anselm's Club in the Bronx yesterday. The victor negotiated the distance of four and one-half miles in 27:05.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- Internal trade in Germany continues dull. Full estimates for 1931 make the retail turnover 13 per cent below 1930 and 20 per cent below 1929. In department stores last year's turnover was 14 3/4 per cent below 1930. At present industrial activity is still declining in raw materials and instruments of production, although in metal goods, textiles, clothing, shoes and paper there is slight and mostly localized improvement since December.

HAVANA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. F.J. Vollmer's General Court won the $3,000 added Cuban Mile Championship, Oriental Park's Feature today, in a hard drive from Blackstrap and Switch, running coupled as the entry of Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The opinion was held in some quarters that the Costigan-La Follette relief bill, which has the right of way in the Senate, may not be voted on tomorrow because of the many amendments pending and the stubborn opposition of the insurgent Republicans.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- For the thirteenth time Clarence C. Pell, the present national champion, carried off today the gold racquet symbolic of victory in the annual racquets classic held each season at the Tuxedo Club.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 14 -- Shanghai need not fear that the arrival of the Japanese army protends an immediate large-scale offensive, the army's mission here being to establish peace and remove unrest without the loss of a single man on either side, if possible.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Feb. 14 -- Erik Rylander, member of the Swedish Olympic team, won the United States Eastern ski championship at the meet held today under the auspices of the Greenfield Outing Club. His jumps of 157 and 159 feet for 217.9 points earned him the crown.
HONOLULU, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The feigned warfare of the annual army-navy manoeuvres, held this year around the Hawaiian Islands, is over, Referees will decide who won.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- The world's speed skating championships, scheduled for Friday and Saturday here as an aftermath of the Olympic Winter games, will have to get along without the presence of Irving Jaffee, newly crowned Olympic titleholder in both the 5,000 and 10,000 meter races, and probably without Jack Shea, local boy who completed the domination of United States by winning the 500 and 1,500 meter events.

With the rival teams in a scoreless deadlock up to within two minutes of the end and with an extra period looming, New Bedford, tallying as the direct result of a free kick allowed for a foul, defeated Hakoah, 1 to 0, at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

BISMARCK, N.D., Feb. 14 -- Because heavy snows blocked prairie roads, former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York will not be entered as a "Democratic Presidential candidate in North Dakota's primary.

As a major step in the endeavor to make the school the focal point of Jewish culture in the United States as well as the basis of a future nation-wide organization of all orthodox congregations, Yeshiva College, West 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, will become the centre of a new organization of more than 150 of the principal orthodox synagogues in the metropolitan area.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 15 -- "Foreign nations and foreign firms must reconcile themselves to the fact that Shanghai as a great international trading port, to all Intents and purposes, is dead if the Japanese are permitted to continue their attempts to eject the Chinese armies from a thirty-mile radius," declared a highly placed spokesman of the Central Government today.

One woman was burned to death, and two men and a woman were rescued early this morning In a fire in a five-story tenement house at 786 Columbus Avenue, between Ninetyeighth and Ninety-ninth Streets. Twenty families were driven from the building by the flames, and at least that many more were forced to abandon adjoining tenement houses by the dense smoke.

A spectacular exhibition of shooting in the Yale-Princeton game of last Tuesday by Earl Nikkel, elusive Eli forward, enabled him to take the lead in the race for individual scoring honors in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League.

The daily publication of all short sales of each stock listed on the New York Stock Exchange and "the abolition of false short sales," were recommended by George Brokaw Compton, lawyer and former New York inheritance tax appraiser, in the course of a debate over the radio yesterday afternoon with Ernest B. Cobb, a member of the New York State Board of Certified Public Accountant Examiners.

Cubic foot building cost compilations prepared for the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports by Alien E. Beals show that the net field cost of building in the metropolitan area of New York City touched the lowest levels in the last half of 1931 that may be expected for some years to come.

PASSAIC, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Shortly after he had taken a marble belonging to a chum, who chased him to recover the plaything, Omeras Emmanuel, 10 years old, was found dead today lying beside a building at Parker Avenue and Brinkerhoff Place.

HEIDELBERG, Feb. 14 -- The sixth congress of the Federation of European Sugar Beet Growers opened today under the chairmanship of M. Monmirel of France, with delegates from every sugar beet producing country in Europe. The economic importance of the interests represented is illustrated by the fact that the South German Growers' Association, with headquarters at Worms, alone has 53,000 members with 77,000 acres in beets.

ATLANTIC CITT, N.J., Feb. 14 -- The Steeplechase Amusement Pier on the Boardwalk here, famed for two generations throughout the country, was destroyed by fire tonight with a loss estimated at $500,000.

Owen (Owney) Madden, ex-convict and reputed racketeer, and the three other former Sing Sing inmates held in the Tombs as parole violators, expresaed confidence yesterday that they would be released this morning on the writs of habeas corpus obtained in the Supreme Court by their counsel.

GENEVA, Feb. 14 -- In all friendliness of honest difference of opinion it appears certain that the United States and France must take the leadership of the two main schools of opinion which are being formed in this disarmament conference. Their two conceptions were set forth very plainly in speeches delivered from the platform at conference assemblies early this past week.

The program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon was made up of Schumann's piano concerto in A minor, op. 54, and Mahler's Fifth symphony. Harold Bauer, appearing with the orchestra for the second Sunday in succession, was the piano soloist.

What is believed to be the only example in this country of marble sculpture by Luca Delia Robbia has just been purchased by the trustees of the Cleveland Museum of Art out of the fund established by its late president, Jeptha Homer Wade.

The Boston Bruins kept the New York Americans from breaking their tie with the Maroons for third place in the International Division of the National Hockey League by conquering the local campaigners, 3 to 1, at Madison Square Garden last night. The visitors ran up a lead of two goals in the initial session, and added another tally in the final minute of the final chapter, the Americans tallying in the middle chapter.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- Under the pressure of world events, especially in China, and as a result of developments at the Geneva disarmament conference, opinion here has hardened into certainty that two opposing policies now exist and are being actively pursued-the imperialist policy of war and the Soviet policy of peace.

Woodcuts by Timothy Cole, souvenirs of the time when wood engraving was the usual process for pictorial reproduction, will be on view in Room 316 of the New York Public Library until the end of March. Cole raised the craft of wood engraving after original paintings to the level of an independent art.

Paul De Bruyn, German marathon champion, repeated his victory of last week when he triumphed yesterday in the second of the series of long-distance runs conducted by the Metropolitan A.A.U. under the auspices of the James J. Tappen Post American Legion, at Silver Lake S.I.

Betrayed by an 11-year-old girl, who bad been their lookout, Richard Rogers and Charles Hanson, each 14 years old, were arrested just before 2 A.M. yesterday at their "cove," an abandoned sedan in an empty lot at Amsterdam Avenue and 181st Street, where they lived and had cached the loot of a Greenwich Village burglary.

The Rev. Dr. Fulton J. Sheen, member of the faculty of the Catholic University of America, Washington, D.C., preached the first of a series of Sunday Lenten sermons on "The Perennial Struggle" at high mass yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 14 -- The Paramount, Oxford and Strand chain theatres gave performances again here today despite the opposition of the City Administration to Sunday motion pictures and the decision of Vice Chancellor Church in Newark yesterday, in which he refused to enjoin the authorities here from interfering with Sunday shows.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- A request for information as to the need for a proposed constitutional amendment to permit development of additional recreational facilities in the forest preserve lands of the State was made today by Governor Roosevelt in a letter to Conservation Commissioner Henry Morgenthau Jr.

BARBOURVILLE, Ky., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Kentucky National Guardsmen and a force of special policemen, all fully armed, will prevent striking miners from entering the city tomorrow for a scheduled National Miners Union demonstration.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14 -- Anthony Doherty, 58, Louisiana State Senator and hardware merchant, and William Phillips Connell, 50, president of the Louisiana National Bank, here as tourists, died early this morning, each of a heart attack, according to the official statement by medical men after the autopsy required by Mexican law.

Thomas Taylor, 18-year-old star of the Long Island City Athletics, led home the field in the Manhattan Athletic League's weekly handicap road race conducted under the auspices of the Greek-American A.C. in Manhattan .yesterday. Taylor, who had an allowance of 3:30, was clocked in 24:27 for the four and one-quarter mile run.

Attention is called by publication today of a Life of JOHN HANSON to one whom WASHINGTON himself congratulated on hia appointment to fill the most important seat in the United States." The tima was November, 1781, the office referred to was that of " President of the United States in Congress assembled," and its first incumbent, elected unanimously on the first day of the session, was JOHN HANSON of Maryland.

The movement begun by the New York Employing Printers Association for a wage reduction in the book an job printing plants grained support yesterday from the board of directors of the National Association of Book Publishers. The book publishera informed the employing printers in a letter that they would back them if they decided to inaugural the "open shop."

Nobody grudgea to the Republicans their annual invocation of LINCOLN as the tuteiar saint of their party The piety of the later generations can but feebly atone for the malignancy of Republican leadera in his lifetime; and as the merits of the existing party grow thin or seem exhausted, the more they need the vicarious attribution of his.

To the Editor Of The New York Times: I was interested in the letter from Ellia E. Brown in that he forms his Judgment of the thrift of a great nation such as France from the writings of Balzac, Dumas and others. That would be amusing if it were not so absurd.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 14 -- Miss Ardath Schneider of Long Beach, Cal., riding H. Field's Altavar over a muddy six furlongs, won her third victory in four starts in the Coronado Town Plate, a race for women riders, today.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 15 -- American and British members of the International Settlement Volunteer Corps patrolling the northern boundaries of the Settlement received a baptism of fire today when a number of Japanese shells fell within their positions.

The Adirondack Summer School for Teachers announces a new development in teacher training in the formation of a study camp at Raquette Lake, N.Y., which will devote three hours daily to intensive study and the rest of each flay to sports and other diversions. The studies will cover the high-school curriculum. Dr. Gahriel Mason, principal of the Abraham Lincoln High School, will be the director of the school.

To the popping of photographers' flashlights and with a gallery of about fifty fans, trainmen, porters and depot employes, the first Spring training movement by a metropolitan baseball club began yesterday in Grand Central Terminal when secretary James J. Tierney of the Giants conducted a party of six players, one coach, and a platoon of newspapermen aboard the Lake Shore Limited for the first leg of the trip to Los Angeles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since 1916 all cities in the United States have increased the fares on their transit lines excepting New York. Practically every civic organization in the city passed resolutions favoring an increase here. Mayor Hylan refused to consent to any change, and no change has been made to this date.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 34 -- Henry Harrison Blagden, wealthy hunter and sportsman of Upper Saranac, is, so far as is known tonight, still in the hands of the man who, with, or without confederates, kidnapped him from a cottage of the Lake Placid Club Thursday night.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- St. George Arnold, fiance of Miss Elizabeth Barrett Cook, who died mysteriously on the steamship Chinese Prince in the Mediterranean after receiving a false cable message that he was dead, tonight asked the State Department to aid him in getting a copy of the fake dispatch, fearing it would be destroyed before the ship reached this port, to which she is on the way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Resuming sessions tomorrow after a three weeks' recess, the Supreme Court is expected to give a final answer to many questions asked in forty-one cases, among them the usual accumulation of State tax controversies.

The week at hand promises to be another of those unusually strenuous ones in the local galleries. Nearly thirty exhibitions are on the list of openings for today alone. These include the Washington bicentennial and Morse exhibitions that open privately today at the Metropolitan Museum and publicly tomorrow.

This has been the most disastrous quarter-century the world has experienced since the destruction of the Roman Empire, John Haynes Holmes said at the service commemorating his twenty-fifth anniversary as minister of the Community Church of New York, at Temple Beth-El, Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, yesterday morning.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14 -- Resumption of services in the twenty-five Catholic churches to be allowed to function in the capital proved impractical today, to the great regret of Catholics.

An entertainment in aid of the charitable enterprises of Haarlem House will be held tomorrow night at the Fulton Theatre. The artist will be Maurice Chevalier. Assisting him will be Jacques Fray and Morio Braggiotti at the piano.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Kenkichi Uyeda, commander of the Japanese land forces at Shanghai, was expected to present an ultimatum to the Chinese soon, demanding withdrawal. If this is refused, he is expected to launch an early renewal of the Japanese offensive.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Open conflict with the officials in charge of the event and unusually slow times caused by the snowdeadened course marked the Olympic four-man bobsled competition today.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 14 -- St. Peter's basilica had another bomb scare last night when attendants found a small, heavy package, tightly bound with string, concealed in the passage leading to the sacristy.

Bundled in clothing such as is worn by Arctic explorers, Miss Ruth Nichols flew a Lockheed monoplane powered with a 225-horsepower Packard Diesel motor to an altitude of 21,350 feet yesterday above Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn.

Samuel Insull Jr., vice chairman of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and of the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, in his annual reports to the stockholders of these companies, made public in Chicago yesterday, says that a merger of the two organizations is being considered.

In its report for 1931, transmitted yesterday to Governor Roosevelt and the Legislature, the Transit Commission lists among its chief accomplishments the promulgation of its tentative $474,500,000 plan for unification of the Interborough and B.M.T. under a board of transit control.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 -- The veteran Gene Sarazen stuck close to par on the final thirty-six holes of the New Orleans $5,000 open golf tourney today, and claimed first money of $1,000 with a seventy-two-hole total of 290.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Governor Roosevelt will consider only the charges against Sheriff Farley based on his conduct since assuming his present office in the removal proceedings which will culminate with a hearing before the Governor Tuesday afternoon, It is confidently expected, here.
The disarmament conference at Geneva and the movement for world peace were discussed in many pulpits of New York City yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 15 -- Preparations are going on in and around Shanghai for what promises to be a great battle, in which a large Chinese army will be opposed to the forces which have been brought from Japan.
