GENEVA, Feb. 14. -- The League of Nations called a secret meeting of its Council for tomorrow to consider the Chinese request for an emergency meeting of the full League Assembly. W.W. Yen, the Chinese delegate, said he was determined to go on with the appeal for a special meeting of the Assembly, filed Friday, if the Council decided it would not convene the meeting itself.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Plater gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 1,148 Fifth Avenue, for Miss Eleanore Leake, daughter of Mrs. Henry Sabin Leake, whose engagement to Richard C. Plater Jr. was announced last week.

BERLIN, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Germany's republicans, including the Social Democrats, who embrace most of the laboring class, indicated at a national conference today that President von Hindenburg would have their support if he agreed to become a candidate for re-election.

Part of the latest report of the Lawisohn Prison Commission discusses the injustice of certain provisions of the penal law affecting prison sentences. The present "fourth-offender" act has fallen into general disrepute. Only the most hard-boiled prosecutor or judge would uphold the doctrine that all persons who had committed a fourth felony, no matter what its nature or their background, should be committed to prison for life.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 -- While the cotton market bare was somewhat more active last week, notwithstanding the holidays, quotations fluctuated somewhat erratically until near the close, when the effect of the sharp upturn in securities gave prices a more decided upward slant.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- The text of the report of the Interstate Commission on Unemployment Insurance is as follows:

EVERY so often at some sports gathering there goes up the cry: "We won't play!" This is supposed to be formal notice that some of the contestants are about to pick up their marbles and go home. But how often do they go home under those circumstances? And what reception would they get if they did go home?

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- Raymond Pitcairn, chairman of the Republican Citizens' Committee Against National Prohibition, with headquarters here, sent a telegram today to Senator Simeon D. Fess at Washington warning the Republican national chairman that "substantial contributors" to the party's campaign funds were going to shift their gifts to the Democrats "for the wet cause,'' and particularly mentioning as one of them Arthur Curtis James of New York.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 14 -- A dragnet of fifty-one detectives placed around Weequahic and Clinton Hill, residential sections here, after residents had reported 400 burglaries in the last four months, yielded a 15-year-old schoolboy who regaled the police today with tales of his prowess as a "Raffles."

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Despite efforts of buyers of beef cattle to obtain supplies last week at previous low prices, the market slipped away from them to higher prices to a top of $9.25 a hundredweight on Wednesday, while a few choice to prime yearlings brought $9.50.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith, rival candidates for the Democratic nomination for President, both will be delegates-at-large from New York to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago on June 27, if the present plans of the party leaders remain unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Cotton merchants of the South welcome rather than fear an investigation of their activities, provided for in the Norris resolution calling for an investigation of the Farm Board and its subsidiaries, Dameron H. Williams of Gastonia, N.C., asserted here tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 (AP) -- John W. Considine Jr., son of one of the operators of the old Sullivan and Considine vaudeville circuit, and Carmen Pantagea, daughter of Alexander Pantages, for many years a business rival of the elder Considine, were married at the Ambassador Hotel here today.

The Board of Transportation will hold on March 2 the first of its public hearings on the form of its proposed contract for independent operation of the new city subway system at a five-cent fare. The contract draft, together with a report which stressed the necessity of preserving the short bond financing of new subway construction in order to preserve the present fare, was sent to the Board of Estimate on Saturday.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- A broad plan for the establishment of State systems of unemployment insurance is outlined in a report of a commission of experts named by the Governors of six large industrial States, made public here today.

The New York Chamber Music Society, of which Carolyn Beebe is president, founder and pianist, presented the fourth of its season of Sunday salons at the Hotel Plaza last night. The novelty of the evening was a second movement played from manuscript of Henry Hadley's theme and variations in B flat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Backers of Governor Roosevelt for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency who have been conferring here said today that strong efforts would be made to elect delegates for him in New Hampshire, which holds the first primary.

Despite the fact that he was inactive all week, Harold Kramer, C. C.N.Y. swimming captain, continues to hold the lead in the race for individual scoring honors in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association with a total of 35 points.

An attempt by robbers to make away with a safe from the offices of the Gulf Refining Company at 374 Maspeth Avenue, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, during which a 70-year-old watchman was badly beaten, was foiled last night by a Western Union messenger who went to the oil company's plant when the regular buzz from the watchman's clock failed to ring in the telegraph office at 9:20 P.M.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- The view now taken here is that the new 10 per cent British duties will not materially harm German exports. The real blow to German foreign trade came earlier, with the 50 per cent special duties, and still more as a result of British currency depreciation which had diminished the opportunity for German exports, particularly machinery, metal wares and certain kinds of textiles.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP). -- The Detroit Falcons downed Chicago's second-place Black Hawks, 3 to 1, tonight in a National Hockey League match featured more by roughness and fisticuffs than smooth hockey.

A "Grand Opera Surprise Party," for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Aid, which is conducting a drive for $300,000 to help needy musicians, will be given at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday evening, March 6, Dr. Walter Damrosch, chairman of the relief committee, announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 -- Strabo V. Claggett, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor In 1930 and a Presidential elector pledged to Alfred E. Smith in 1928, and Mayor John J. Murphy of Somerville announced today their support of Governor Roosevelt for President, but took divepgent views of Mr. Smith's recent statement.
SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 15 (AP) -- All's quiet on the western Shanghai front, but 3,500 British "Tommies" were on the job today or in reserve, prepared to meet any emergency in that sector.

John Hanson of Maryland was the first President of the United States, Seymour Wemyss Smith, financial writer and historian, declares in his book, "John Hanson, Our First President,", published today by Brewer, Warren Putnam.

Arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Michael A. Ford in Yorkville Court, on suspicion of planning a $20,000 jewel robbery in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Dominick Capizio, 36 years old, an unemployed salesman of 2,824 Westfield Avenue, Baltimore, was held without bail for Special Sessions, charged with violating the Sullivan law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A discovery that valuable minerals can be separated from worthless rock by steam explosive, which shatters the rock without the labor and expense of first pulverizing the entire ore, was announced here today by Chief Engineer R. S. Dean of the metallurgical division of the United States Bureau of Mines, and his coworker, John Gross.

Reversing the result of their meeting in the final of the Canadian indoor championship, Berkeley Bell of New York, formerly of Texas, defeated J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., yesterday to add his name to the distinguished list of players who have won the annual Invitation indoor tennis tournament of the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- The rise of 936 million francs in the gold reserve of the Bank of France during the week covered by Thursday's statement brings the ratio of cover against the | note issue to the high record figure of 65.06 per cent. It compares with 63.39 in the preceding week.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Life insurance companies, having passed through their most critical year, face a bright prospect because of sound investment practices, George S. Van Schaick, State Insurance Commissioner, declared today in his annual report. He urged legislation to extend to non-life insurance companies some investment limitations now placed on the life group.

With Lou Holtz and other arch competitors arriving elsewhere on Broadway tonight to lay siege to the favor of vaudeville-goers, that ancient stand of the two-a-day, the Palace, has assumed an aggressive and even a militant attitude, indicating plainly its intention to hold its own.

R. Stanley Dollar, president of the Dollar Line, will return today on the Ile de France from a round-the-world inspection tour of trade and shipping conditions. Mrs. Dollar is accompanying him. Andre-Louis Chevrillon, French author, and Sebastian Charlety, rector of the University of Paris; Vicomte Foy and Comtesse Augusto Gavicchia are on board.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14 -- The two days' holiday reduced all grain shipments, but the week closed with all prices higher by approximately 40 centavos a quintal. The expected United States finance measures stimulated demand for Argentine flaxseed, hides and wool.

Two arrests, made yesterday by detectivevs of the safe and loft squad, are said to have completed the round-up of a gang of alleged truck thieves responsible for the theft of $70,000 worth of merchandise in the last three months.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Feb. 14 -- A regional plan for the guidance of the Philadelphia Tri-State District during the next half century, evolved after years of work by more than 200 engineering officials and consulting architects in the 4,555-square-mile area embracing parts of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware, will be presented by the Regional Planning Federation following a dinner here on March 16.
ORMOND, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP) -- John D. Rockefeller Sr. went to church today for the first time in several weeks and found an overflow congregation on hand to greet him.

HAVANA, Feb. 14 -- Three persons were killed and four wounded early this morning in an explosion on the tug Manuela in Havana Harbor which set fire to the tug and two barges, endangering the Walter D. Munson, a 3,000-ton vessel of the Munson Line, lying alongside with about 130,000 gallons of gasoline aboard.

The Baxter Mile, one of the features on the program of the New York Athletic Club games at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night, promises to develop one of the most brilliant races of the Winter track season.

F.O. Williams led a field of thirty-five gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He took the High Scratch Cup by breaking 97 targets. P. Sleppy, P. Garino and C.W. Meyer each had a full card of 100 to tie for the High Handicap Cup.

Governor ROOSEVELT instantly perceived the significance, personal to himself, of the intention of Democratic leaders to send uninstructed delegates to the national convention at Chicago. The Chairman of the Democratic National Executive Committee, Mr. JOUETT SHOUSE, had announced the program: "It would be wiser not to instruct delegates to the convention in favor of any candidate save where such instruction is necessary under the primary laws.

Members of the Brooklyn Museum's Brazil Expedition are excavating a large burial ground at Marajo, largest of the Amazon delta islands, according to a letter just received at the New York headquarters of the expedition from Desmond Holdridge, the 24-year-old leader.

The New York County Lawyers Association, acting on the second report of its committee on legislation, has approved four measures introduced at the present session of the State Legislature and has disapproved four others, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The demands of Eastern railroads that they be permitted to consolidate all roads in that region into four systems instead of five are to meet new opposition tomorrow before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Sentiment has changed markedly in the grain trade. The legislation passed or being considered by Congress, combined with a material broadening in the European demand for cash grain, is regarded as having come at a psychological moment, and the action of the market at the close last week indicated that the trade wanted to advance prices if there was any basis for it.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 -- Months ago steel producers almost abandoned efforts to gauge the trends and prospects of steel demand, their interest being centred on what they were doing in actual shipments. The last couple of weeks appear to have justified their course.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Sentences imposed on first offenders are denounced as "inhuman" and the laws under which they are imposed are declared so severe as to defeat their own purpose, in an interim report to the Governor and the Legislature which will be filed tomorrow by the Commission to Investigate Prison Administration and Construction.

The nation-wide campaign to obtain jobs for 1,000,000 unemployed, which has been planned for the last six weeks by the American Legion in cooperation with the American Federation of Labor, the National Association of Advertisers and other organizations represented in the National Employment Commission, will begin today.

Word has reached Tammany Hall, it became known yesterday, that Governor Roosevelt intends to remove Sheriff Thomas M. Farley from office unless the Sheriff and his counsel can change the present aspect of the case, at the public hearing he has called for Tuesday afternoon In the Executive Chamber at the Capitol at Albany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Opposition to the passage of the Home Loan Bank bill, the fourth step in the program of President Hoover for economic relief, was voiced today by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America in a statement declaring that there Is already a surplus of homes in New York, Chicago and other cities which would be increased by enactment of the bill.

Doubt, cynicism, a reaction from a period of exultation, and the eternal conflict between magic and mysticism were the elements which formed the temptations during Christ's forty days in the wilderness, and they still plague the world according to the Rev. Dr. Joseph Fort Newton.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -- In compliment to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson, who arrived by private car today from New York and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Myers, also of New York, and as a farewell before leaving, tomorrow for New York to sail on Friday for England, Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney entertained tonight with a dinner at Louwana.

The American Woolen Company reported yesterday a net loss of $2,836,826 for 1931, against a net loss of $4,897,584 in 1930, and announced it would ask stockholders at the annual meeting on March 22 to change its 400,000 shares of $100 par common stock to capital stock with a stated value of $5 a share.

The best traditions of the Beethoven Association were served last night when Georges Enesco, violinist and composer; Carl Friedberg, planist; Felix Salmond, 'cellist, and Egon Kornstein, violist, took part in the performance of music by Brahms, Enesco and Faure.
The Ile de France of the French Line arrived yesterday from Havre and Plymouth, bringing among her passengers a lightning calculator, Dr. Salli Finkelstein of Warsaw.

A plan by which importers of raw sugar hoped to save more than $100,000,000 in duties annually by importing the product in syrup form collapsed yesterday under a decision of the Third Division United States Customs Court, which held the syrup dutiable as sugar and described the plan as an "artifice."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Legislation providing for consultation with engineers before bankers make foreign loans for public works abroad was suggested to the Senate Finance Committee today by the American Institute of Consulting Engineers of New York.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- With interest in official circles at the Capitol keyed to high tension and with Democrats throughout the nation absorbedly watching, Governor Roosevelt will sit tomorrow in judgment on Thomas M. Farley, Tammany district leader, one of the pillars of the Tammany organization and Sheriff of New York County.
The more important changes since 1906, when the game was opened up by the forward pass, as listed by Parke Davis in Spalding's Football Guide follow:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- An immediate loan of $1,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Missouri Pacific Railroad, out of a total of $23,250,000 applied for, was approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission today.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 -- Miss Helen Fitzgerald, 23-year-old flier of Binghamton, N.Y., who won highest honors for women at the Miami Air Meet, died of self-poisoning late last night.

Despite a decline of 7 per cent in sales last year, and of 6 per cent in the number of stores operated by the company, the Kroger Grocery and Baking Company reported yesterday that its net earnings were $2,731,128 for 1931, equivalent to $1.46 a share on the outstanding stock, compared with $2,168,247, or $1.15 a share in 1930.

Six applications for loans are expected to be considered by the board of the Railroad Credit Corporation at a meeting to be held tomorrow in the offices of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad here. The names of the applicants were not disclosed, although it was known recently that the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway had considered asking the corporation for aid.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Feb. 16 -- Japan withheld her big drive today, apparently determined to wait for still more guns and troops in order that there might be no repetition of the bitter experience at Chapei, where outnumbered Japanese bluejackets were repulsed by a suddenly bellicose Chinese army.

JOHN DELANEY has been talking and figuring and digging subways for so long that it would be hard to think of any other person as chairman of the Board of Transportation. He is a resolute person, but somewhat reserved, making no attempt to be always in the public prints.

Prices of cotton advanced yesterday at the opening of the Cotton Exchange, but reacted under realizing and from selling that was believed to be largely for Southern account. May contracts, after selling up to the 7-cent level, declined to 6.88 cents a pound, but continued trade and commission-house buying on the decline resulted in rallies of 4 to 5 points.

An extra period victory over the Squadron A No. 2 team brought Los Nanduces Uplifters into the semifinal round of the low-goal division of the New York A.C. indoor polo tournament at the 105th Field Artillery Armory last night.

Butter. Receipts, 6,868 packages. The market developed a firmer tone over the week-end and prices on top grades moved upward 1/2 c before the close of the call yesterday. Sentiment has lately been affected by increased demand from out-of-town sources and to some extent by the stock market rally of late last week and a generally more confident feeling was noticeable yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Feb. 16 -- Nanchang, the capital of Kiangsi Province, has been captured by Chinese Communists, which gives the Reds virtual mastery of the entire province except the Yangtse River port of Kiukiang and a small strip of railway southward to Nanchang.

George M. Carney, Assistant District Attorney, announced yesterday that a grand jury investigation into the recent slaying of Vincent Coll, gang leader, by a man with a machine gun in a West Twenty-third Street drug store would be resumed today with the calling of Walter Winchell, newspaper writer, as a witness.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Senator Fearon, Republican leader in the upper house of the Legislature, struck back tonight at Lieutenant Governor Lehman and other critics of the Republican program for a widespread inquiry into State departments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Upholding the constitutionality of the Walsh law, under which Harry M. Blackmer, self-exiled oil man, was fined $60,000 for contempt of court, the Supreme Court ruled today that Mr. Blackmer must pay the penalty.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Governor Roosevelt announced tonight the appointment of former County Judge Reuben L. Haskell of Brooklyn as a member of the Transit Commission to fill the vacancy created by the recent elevation of Charles C. Lockwood to the Supreme Court.

Mlle. Rosette Anday, contralto of the State Opera in Vienna, and Baron Egon Ernst von Ketschendorf went to the Municipal Building yesterday and obtained their marriage license. They stated that they would be married this morning on the chantry of St. Thomas Church.
DUBLIN, Feb. 15 -- Eamon de Valera stands nearer to power tonight than at any time in his checkered career as agitator and rebel.

Owen (Owney) Madden, convicted slayer, and three of his ex-convict associates obtained temporary freedom yesterday afternoon when Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy took under advisement writs of habeas corpus obtained Saturday in their behalf after they had been seized and ordered back to Sing Sing for violation of parole.
Announcement by the North American Yacht Racing Union that a new type of small boat -- the Monotype class -- has been added to the Olympic sailing program has aroused the interest of local yachtsmen.

Elihu Root, dean of America's "elder statesmen," spent his eighty-seventh birthday yesterday quietly at his apartment at 998 Fifth Avenue. There was no celebration of any kind, not even a birthday dinner. The former Senator and Secretary of State lunched at noon with his daughter, Mrs. U.S. Grant 3d, and her daughter, Miss Edith Grant.

The downward reaction to which the stock market and the grain markets were subjected yesterday caused no great surprise. The pace of advance on last week's two final business days had been exceptionally rapid; on a percentage basis, Saturday's "stock market averages" reached a figure 20 per cent above "Wednesday's closing, before the plan for enlarging Federal Reserve facilities had been promulgated.

Coming as an aftermath of the excited advances of Saturday and Thursday, the downward readjustment yesterday conformed to expectations. It was described in market circles as a "corrective reaction," which is the conventional explanation under the circumstances.

Football coaches and officials in all sections of the country were almost unanimous in endorsing the action of the National Football Rules Committee last night. All agreed that the game had been made safer for the player and improved for the coaches, officials and spectators.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Overriding every parliamentary obstacle in the interest of a measure designed to spur business recovery, the House today suspended its rules and passed by the overwhelming vote of 350 to 15 the Steagall-Glass bill providing for extension of the services of the Federal Reserve System.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Samuel Insull, public utility operator, faced today two meetings of 1,500 stockholders of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, and explained how those big investment companies had incurred a depreciation of around $333,000,000 in their assets as the result of investments in the Insull group of companies.

DENVER, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Men and sons of men who cheered William Jennings Bryan in 1896 returned to- day to cheer William Jennings Bryan Jr., as the son of the Great Commoner opened the Western States Silver Conference with a plea for bimetalism.

New York City's assessed valuations on real estate and personal property for tax purposes increased $814,580,301 over the total for last year, according to final figures made public yesterday by President James J. Sexton of the Department of Taxes and Assessments.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Chile Acuna, stool pigeon wanted in connection with New York's vice squad investigation, was on his way back there tonight by airplane.

SARANAC, N.Y., Tuesday, Feb. 16 -- A gang of at least fifteen men, who worked in relays in various cities and used several automobiles and a small truck, kidnapped Henry Harrison Blagden, according to the story he told by telephone from Cleveland to his brother, Augustus Blagden, early this morning.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Cutting $9,375,462 from departmental requests by the "ruthless" economy he urged in his inaugural address. Governor A. Harry Moore recommended expenditure of $27,189,702.94 to finance the State Government during the fiscal year beginning July 1 in his budget message presented tonight to the Legislature.

BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- Defying the reactionaries' demands for the head of Chancellor Heinrich Bruening as the price for their support for a second Presidential term, Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg today announced his candidacy.

The domestic pulp producer has been caught, at least temporarily, by severe competition aggravated by increasing exports of pulp from countries that have abandoned the gold standard, Charles W. Boyce, secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association, said yesterday at the opening of the association's fifty-fifth annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The appointment of Justice Cardozo was greeted on every hand with praise and satisfaction. Some of the comments were as follow:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Democratic measure authorizing the Federal Government to loan $375,000,000 to States for unemployment relief work and to spend $375,000,000 additional on road work during the next eighteen months was defeated in the Senate today by a vote of 48 to 31.
Once again Jim Londos successfully defended his wrestling title by defeating Jim McMillen of Illinois for the third time in Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 10,000 saw the bout.

ROME, Feb. 15 -- A mysterious message from America revealed the existence of a deadly bomb near the central altar of St. Peter's Cathedral in a supposed plot against Pope Pius XI or Premier Mussolini, who appeared there last week, it became known today.

Net income of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company in 1931 amounted to $5,665,802, an increase of $311,070 over net income of $5,354,732 earned in 1930, a gain of 5.79 per cent. The earnings were equal to $7.64 a share earned on 741,086 shares outstanding at the end of the year, against $7.23 a share earned on 740,186 shares at the end of 1930.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Secretary of State Stimson conferred on the Shanghai situation today with several foreign Ambassadors, after Edwin S. Cunningham, American Consul General at that city, had informed the State Department that he and the British Consul General had protested on Saturday to the Japanese Consul General against the landing of Jaoanese troops in the settlement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The dispute between A.P. Giannini, founder of the Transamerica Corporation, and Elisha Walker, who succeeded him as ruler of the giant bank-holding company, arose over abandonment of Mr. Giannini's policy of dominating banks through stock ownership by Transamerica.

Encouraged by the endorsement of President Hoover and of religious, social, business and fraternal organizations throughout the country, as well as Governors, Mayors and other public officials, the drive of the American Legion and affiliated organizations for 1,000,000 jobs began officially at 8 o'clock yesterday morning.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- As a result of conferences with W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, the legislative leaders of that party have decided to appeal to the United States Supreme Court the decision of the State Court of Appeals that the measure adopted by the Legislature last year reapportioning the State's representation in Congress is invalid.

The value of the estate of Thomas Fortune Ryan, financier, who died on Nov. 23, 1928, was set at $141,824,497 gross and $135,164,110 net by the appraisers for the State in the transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday by Deputy Tax Commissioner Maurice A. Stephenson.

Registration of the unemployed seeking aid from the Home Relief Bureau is approaching the 100,000 mark, it was revealed yesterday with the announcement that 95,486 persons had registered at the seventynine precinct stations of the bureau. The registration in the last two days alone was 4,578.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 15 -- As engineers extend their careful inspection of the walls of the Vatican to test their stability after the collapse of the Sistine Hall library, it is reveals that many parts which had hitherto appeared above suspicion stand in urgent need of repair.

MEDIA, Pa., Feb. 15 -- By a ruling in the Delaware County Orphans Court here today that Dr. John T. Dorrance, late president of the Campbell Soup Company, was a resident of New Jersey, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania lost the first step in its legal battle to collect about $17,600,000 in inheritance taxes from his $115,000,000 estate.

Patrolman James R. Goodwin of the Wadsworth Avenue station had two hours to spare before going on duty last midnight, so he dropped in at Louis Krasnow's drug store at Amsterdam Avenue and 169th Street. Krasnow and Goodwin had been close friends ever since the policeman surprised hold-up men in the drug store a year and a half ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The opinion that short selling as practiced on the New York Stock Exchange was illegal, that a group of twenty men dominated the activities of "bear raiders" and that recent bear drives "constituted the ruthless efforts of speculators to recoup fortunes lost in 1929" was expressed today by Harold G. Aron before the subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee at the hearing on bills to regulate short selling.

PANAMA CITY, Feb. 15 (AP) -- An aged Austrian physician, Dr. Hans von Tietdjke, a resident of San Andres, Colombia, who refused to divulge his past even to close friends, is said to have confessed on his deathbed his connection with the Mayerling mystery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Assurances that Governor Roosevelt would not enter the primaries in "favoriteson" States, but would earnestly seek second-choice support from their delegates after they cast complimentary votes for their respective candidates, were given today by Homer S. Cummings to friends of favorite sons in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES headlines "Sees an Anesthetic Made of Perfumes" imply that the use of perfumes in anesthetic is a new idea, and give the casual reader the impression that there is in view an anesthetic panacea by means of which he may be enabled to lose consciousness in an aroma of sweetness, awakening after all is over in an atmosphere permeated by delightful memories of his experience.

The listed bond market showed much more strength than did the stock market yesterday. United States Government bonds closed substantially higher, and a sizable list of domestic corporation bonds gained 1 to 6 points for the day. Foreign loans, as a group, did not do so well as the domestic issues, but some of the foreign bonds made gains of a point or more.

Four large mining concerns, three of which compose the Kennecott Copper group, omitted dividends on their common stock yesterday. The companies were the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., largest producer of nickel in the world; the Kennecott Copper Corporation, one of the two largest copper producers in the world, and two companies controlled by Kennecott -- Utah Copper and Nevada Consolidated Copper.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Feb. 16 -- This city today awaited with tense expectation the arrival of dawn tomorrow, believed to be the zero hour for the concerted Japanese drive on Woosung, Chapei and Kiangwan, facing the International Settlement on the north.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Governor Roosevelt sent a special message to the Legislature tonight calling for the passage of legislation to permit municipalities to buy "the cheap electrical power to be developed from the St. Lawrence," and also to allow municipalities to combine into utility districts for this purpose.

Lou Holtz, who helped introduce the vaudeville-revue type of entertainment at the Palace where he played for eight weeks through the past hot Summer, now has gone out on his own. He has assembled another of those shows which he presented last night before an overflowing and curious audience at the Hollywood Theatre, a highly decorated assembly hall heretofore devoted to cinematic products from the studios of the Brothers Warner.

A new orchestra, known as the New York Orchestra, Inc., was incorporated last week and will make its first appearance, according to the announcement, at the end of March or early in April in Carnegie Hall.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 15 -- Federal expenditures for the fiscal year 1932-33 are drastically reduced in the main estimates presented to the House of Commons today by the Minister of Finance. The total is $356,774,000, compared with $400,402,000 for the current fiscal year.

Further proof of his right to priority in the discovery of element 87 was offered yesterday by Professor Fred Allison of Alabama Polytechnic Institute before the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Excepting only prohibition, enforcement, the axe of economy was applied today by the House Appropriations Committee to the budget for the major activities of the State, Justice, Commerce and Labor Departments. The appropriation bill as reported to the House by the committee made a reduction of 55,070,318.77 from the amount asked for in the budget.

An estate of $1,132,804 gross and $980,219 net was left by Francis K. Pendleton, former Supreme Court Justice and former Corporation Counsel of New York City, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The bulk of the estate, $873,163, was in stocks and bonds, and $176,985 was in real estate.
That the shoe business is in the upward trend and expanding was indicated by two long-term leases for store space in the midtown section signed yesterday by two large shoe firms.

In a play-off on the Princeton Club courts last night the Yale Club team won the metropolitan Class C squash tennis championship by defeating the Elizabeth Town and Country Club, 6 matches to 1. The tournament play had been divided into three groups, from which the Yale and Elizabeth clubs emerged as the finalists.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Bullish factors in the wheat situation received little consideration today on the Board of Trade here, the decline in securities offsetting routine news and leading many local traders to go out of the lines they acquired last week.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES quoted Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals thus:

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Of 36,745 unemployed registered in Essex County as of Jan. 1, work has been found for 6,358, or slightly more than 17 per cent, D. Frederick Burnett, county director of the State Emergency Relief Administration, announced today.

Whether Staten Island's branch of the City Court, created by legislative enactment last year, will continue to be homeless, as it has been since last Jan. 1, or will avail itself of the discarded village hall in Lafayette Avenue, New Brighton, to try its calendar of nearly 500 cases, is expected to be decided in the next few weeks by the Sinking Fund Commission of the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The House Naval Committee voted today to recommend reduction of enlisted men who are fliers in naval service from 30 per cent of the total flying strength to 20 per cent.

Keeping at a Distance. We are all familiar with the old way of keeping Bibles "chained" so that they might not be stolen, but it is a new idea which Governor MURRAY of Oklahoma has applied in his executive office.

The legislative committees eliminated the item of $50,000 for the investigation of the schools of New York City, which was included in the Governor's budget at the instance of the Board of Education and upon the recommendation of the Director of the Budget.
Walter E. Edge, Ambassador to France, leaves tonight for Paris on the Ile de France of the French Line. He is returning to his post after a brief visit here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The right of a Legislature to reapportion Congress districts, regardless of the attitude of its Governor, a question in which New York State is deeply interested, will be reviewed by the Supreme Court of the United States under an order issued today.

Sino-Japanese Developments. SHANGHAI -- Seven more Japanese transports took troops to the war area yesterday and vast stores of munitions and many field guns also were unloaded in the Japanese part of the Settlement. Chinese guns shelled Japanese welcoming the troops.

The comments of leaders of the New York bar and of public opinion concerning the selection of Benjamin N. Cardozo yesterday to be associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, emphasized his learning, his lucidity and his special fitness to continue the "liberal" traditions of the retiring justice, Oliver Wendell Holmes.

YONKERS, Feb. 15 -- John E. Andrus, Yonkers capitalist, reputed to be one of the ten wealthies men in America, termed the present depression the worst in history and expressed sympathy for President Hoover, urging his re-election, in an interview tonight on the eve of his ninety-first birthday.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- The Third Olympic Winter Games ended today as they had started almost a fortnight ago -- with an American victory.

MADRID, Feb. 15 -- An anarchist general strike broke out in twenty-three Spanish cities and towns today in protest against the deportation of 109 anarchist leaders last week, but the net result was that one striker was killed, a score were wounded and the government, in the words of the Governor of Barcelona, "collected another boatload of them."
HAVANA, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Irving Jacobs of New York and Jockey Johnny Gilbert dominated the program at Oriental Park today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Alphonse Capone, the Chicago gangster, who is under sentence for evasion of income taxes, petitioned the Federal Board of Tax Appeals today for relief from a proposed additional assessment of $322,842 and from an assessment of $68,664 imposed by the Internal Revenue Bureau, or a total of $391,506 which the government seeks to collect.
James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, and not Homer S. Cummings of Connecticut, will direct the campaign to get Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt the Democratic nomination for President.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Senator Dunnigan and Assemblyman Steingut, leaders of the Democratic minorities in the two houses, introduced a concurrent resolution in the Legislature tonight, calling upon Congress to take steps for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 16 -- The heads of the three provisional provincial governments of Manchuria are now in Mukden for a preliminary constitutional conference. General Ma Chen-Shan, who, according to report is to be reinstated in his old position as Governor of Heilungkiang, is expected today.

The Hunter Bulletin, student publication at Hunter College, was out on the campus yesterday, but its masthead bore the legend, "Published by Student Council," instead of the names of the editorial staff, which quit last Thursday in a body.

Some judicial appointments or promotions at once evoke wondering inquiry how they ever came to be made. If Judge CARDOZO had not been named for the Supreme Court to succeed Justice HOLMES, the puzzled question would have been why he was not.

The intention of the Democratic organizations in the five boroughs to continue strictly non-committal to the Presidential aspirations of either Governor Roosevelt or former Governor Smith was further manifested yesterday when the Kings County Executive Committee selected its nominees for the posts of delegates and alternates to the Democratic National Convention.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, has in preparation a collection of personal reminiscences which Charles Scribner's Sons will publish under the title, "Across the Busy Years." He has set no date for the completion of the book, which probably will be lengthy as the mere list of Dr. Butler's attainments and activities occupies an almost record amount of space in books of reference.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Submitting its annual report to Governor Roosevelt and the Legislature tonight, the Public Service Commission asserted that during the past year it had saved to consumers of gas and electricity in the State more than $7,400,000 through negotiations with utility companies for rate reductions.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 -- Three putts on the last green proved costly to Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L. P., woman's national golf champion in today's qualifying round for the championship of Florida over the Palm Beach Country Club course, the medal honors going by one stroke to Miss Edith Quier of Reading, Pa., with 38, 39 -- 77.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Benjamin Nathan Cardozo, Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, was nominated by President Hoover today to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- The Westchester tax equalization table, determining what share of the 1932 county taxes is to be paid by each of the eighteen towns and four cities of the county, was presented to the Board of Supervisors today and made a special order of business for a meeting on Thursday.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 15 -- The full text of the statements of E.K. Hall, chairman, and W.S. Langford, secretary, of the Football Rules Committee, outlining the changes made in the code and the reasons therefor, follow:

The annual report of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company, a Canadian corporation, for 1931 shows a net income of $4,150,438 before income taxes, comparing with $5,770,670 earned in 1930. Gross revenue was $13,693,194, against $14,954,074, and operating income after expenses and depreciation was $8,060,113, against $9,221,477.

Stanley Dollar, president of the Dollar Line, returned on the French liner Ile de France yesterday from a tour around the world. He was accompanied by Mrs. Dollar and their two children, Stanley Jr. and Diana.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city.
Arthur Huttick, promising young west side light-heavyweight, plodded to victory over Bob Olin of Brooklyn in the main ten-round bout before a slim crowd at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

GIBRALTAR, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The mother of Elizabeth Barrett Cook arrived today on the Conte Biancamano in apparent ignorance of a fake telegram reporting the death of her daughter's fiance. The mother and a younger sister of Miss Cook are on the way back to the United States from Naples and their ship put into the harbor here for only a few minutes.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- A bill which would enable insolvent New Jersey banks to join in the benefits of the Federal Reconstruction Finance Corporation was passed tonight without opposition by the Senate. It was sent at once to the House. The bill authorizes the State Banking Commissioner or receivers for State banks to pledge the assets of the closed institutions, now prohibited by law, to obtain loans through the corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just read in THE TIMES the statement that "our debt to England after the Revolution was due to the assumption by our government, in the treaty of peace, of the private debts of British subjects in this country."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Emphatic support of the Home Loan Bank bill, which would provide $150,000,000 of Federal funds for rediscounting mortgages on houses, was voiced today by building and loan association spokesmen and real estate men before a subcommittee of a Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

With the departure today of the first fast steamshios to leave New York since the announcement of the proposed amendments to the Federal Reserve act, upward of $40,000,000 in gold is expected to be shipped to Europe.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 -- Before a large and enthusiastic audience John Charles Thomas appeared tonight in the first of a series of four recitals for members and guests to be given at the Everglades Club under the auspices of the Society of Arts.
GENEVA, Feb. 15 -- The Council of Twelve of the League of Nations will meet tomorrow morning at what its members regard as the crossroads of the Far Eastern situation.

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 15 -- The political situation in Panama became tense today, with police ready to forestall a rising following the delivery of a note from Minister of Justice Guillermo Andreve, representing President Alfaro, to the electoral jury, asking reversal of the jury's attitude regarding the issuance of voting permits to native sons of foreign parentage.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- News of the appointment of Benjamin N. Cardozo to the United States Supreme Court was received today with great satisfaction at the Capitol, where the choice was regarded as a fitting reward for the great services the New York jurist has rendered as presiding judge of the highest State tribunal.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15 -- The colors of F.H. Carpenter flashed to an easy victory in the St. Valentine's Claiming Handicap, feature on the card at Hialeah Park today, as the 6-year-old Double Heart breezed home five lengths ahead of his nearest opponent, C.V. Whitney's Pennate.

A strike call to 30,000 dressmakers will be effective at 10 A.M. today, according to an announcement made last nigrht at a meeting of the general strike committee of the Dressmakers Union at which William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, called upon the union to wage a fight to end sweatshops.

New York City has no intention of endeavoring to market "any kind of city securities under present market conditions," Controller Charles W. Berry wrote yesterday to H.C. Sylvester Jr., vice president of the National City Company, in response to an inquiry based on reports that the city might attempt to market about April 1 a part of the $100,000,000 of special corporate stock notes remaining of the authorized amount of $200,000,000.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names

The annual meeting of corporate members of the Girl Scout Federation of Greater New York, will be held today at the Cosmopolitan Club. Mrs. Robert G. Mead is chairman of the organization which was formed in 1930 to coordinate Girl Scout activities in the five boroughs.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 15 UP) -- On the treacherous Melbourne wicket South Africa made only 45 runs in its second innings today to lose to Australia by an innings and 72 runs in one of the most remarkable test cricket matches ever held.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Amadeo P. Giannini, former San Francisco fruit merchant who became a leader in banking circles of the country, won today his greatest triumph by displacing a powerful group of bankers from control of the Transamerica Corporation at its annual meeting.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Payne Whitney's Justinian spread-eagled his field and C.V. Whitney's Chimney Sweep ran second in the Tarpon Purse, which featured the program at the Fair Grounds today.

From his admission to the New York bar in 1891 to his selection yesterday to be Associate Justice of the Supreme Court at the age of 61, Benjamin Nathan Cardozo has steadily accumulated, without seeking it, the admiration of lawyers and laymen, conservatives and liberals, Republicans and Democrats, who have come to speak of him as one of the great legal scholars of his time.

A committee of shipping men will leave for Washington today to submit the terms of the newly created intercoastal steamship conference to the bureau of regulations of the United States Shipping Board. R. A. Nicol of the Dawnic Steamship Company, who was chairman of the committee that recently brought the lines into agreement after a controversy of more than a year, will head the committee.

An intensive study of the proposal to build a railroad tunnel between the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn and New Jersey will be undertaken by two committees consisting of representatives of the Port of New York Authority, the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Long Island Ten-Year Plan Committee, it was revealed yesterday.

The outcry raised during the season of 1931 against the mounting toll of gridiron casualties, the most violent excoriation football has been subjected to since 1905, brought forth yesterday the most far-reaching modifications adopted in the playing rules of the game in a quarter of a century.
BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- The curve of German foreign trade, under the pressure of protective measures throughout the world, swooped down in January to a point which was probably the lowest in this century.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The Sino-Japanese situation has become so dangerour, in the opinion of the British Government, that Sir John Simon made two calls today to discuss it with Prime Minister MacDonald in the nursing home where the Premier is confined as a result of his recent eye operation.

Price trend in commodities was mixed yesterday, advances and declines being distributed throughout the list. Grains, lard and rubber declined, while copper and silk improved in the cash section. In futures, coffee, sugar, cocoa and cotton turned higher, but the grains, silk, hides and rubber were easier.

"Collision," a comedy adapted by John Anderson from the German, will open tonight at the Gaiety Theatre with June Walker and Geoffrey Kerr featured in the cast. At the Forty-eighth Street Theatre "When the Bouph Breaks," a play by Jerome Sackheim, will have its premiere.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- A memorandum protesting the restrictions on foreign performers in British theatres has been sent to the Prime Minister, the Home Secretary, the Minister of Labor and Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw by the British Actors' Equity Association.

The last trains to pass over the tracks of the Whitestone branch of the Long Island Railroad were operated last night despite an unsuccessful attempt by Mayor Walker's aides to obtain a two-week respite from George Le Boutillier, president of the Long Island, before the abandonment of the line.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- Captain Ned Warren and Head Coach Joe Wood met fifty-five Yale varsity baseball candidates today in the Cox Memorial cage, where the athletes held their first practice of the season, consisting mainly of physical exercises and a brisk run.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 16 -- It is possible that more Japanese troops may be sent to Shanghai, it was revealed here today, although no definite decision has been made as yet.

Is Insurgent virtue wliting? The Progressives have conferred solemnly several times and talked about a third party, but have shown no intention of forming or leading one. They remember too well Senator LA FOLLETTE'S adventure in 1924. But surely somebody must stand up against Mr. HOOVER in the primaries.

The Ways and Means Committee of the House faces a dilemma as it begins to draft a new tax bill. It strongly desires to add enough revenue to enable the Government to balance its budget in 1932-33. Yet it wishes to avoid imposing retroactive taxes on income earned last year.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 15 (AP). -- Several new cracks were discovered today in the Vatican building which is occupied by Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State. One is in the ceiling under the Cardinal's office.
PARIS, Feb. 15 -- The Laval Government tomorrow will face a serious situation in the Senate in which internal politics have been thrown into the balance against the delicate international situation.

A gold medal for the best two-story house built in the United States during the years 1926-30 has been awarded to Dwight James Baum of Riverdale for the dwelling he designed for Francis Collins at Fieldston, part of the Riverdale community in the Bronx on the Hudson River.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Senator Wagner of New York said of the appointment of Justice Cardozo:

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Winging merrily on to what is fervently hoped will be a restoration of John McGraw's supremacy over all matters pertaining to baseball, the vanguard of the Giants which steamed out of New York yesterday arrived here today for a six-hour breathing spell before plunging on for the final long jaunt that will wind up in Los Angeles Thursday.

Of all the comedies of manners recently produced in this neighborhood, John Van Druten's ''There's Always Juliet" is incomparably the best. He is the same John Van Druten whose "Young Woodley" introduced us to him seven years ago, and whose "After All" was produced here a few weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Setting aside the opinion of the New York Transit Commission that there should be no increase in the charges to the Long Island Railroad for its use of the Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, the Interstate Commerce Commission approved today with some modifications a rental agreement between the Pennsylvania Railroad and its Long Island subsidiary.

A penitentiary term of not more than three years was imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on William Griffith, 34 years old, of 712 Ditmars Avenue, Brooklyn, who admitted that when employed as secretary to a department store executive last December he had stolen from the store's vaults 1,400 confessions signed by women who had been detected stealing articles but had been released without prosecution.
Additions to west side apartment houses holdings and an east side investment featured the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday.

Further activity in midtown leasing was apparent yesterday in an announcement that the Ahrens Publishing Company has taken for a long term space on the ninth floor of the News Building, 220 East Forty-second Street. The space repre- sents a consolidation and enlargement of the firm's present quarters in 40 East Forty-ninth Street and 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.

That the central tower in Radio City may contain a series of mural paintings 250 feet long was revealed yesterday by Raymond M. Hood, one of the architects of the new development, in an address at the Architectural League in connection with an exhibition of the work of Joseph Urban for the benefit of unemployed architects.

"As Applied Art Steps Out of Depression" was the subject of a lecture delivered at the Art Centre yesterday afternoon by Foster Gunnison of Cox, Nostrand Gunnison, Inc., lighting engineers. The address served formally to open the annual exhibition of Contemporary Decorative Arts assembled by the Art Alliance.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Week-end news from the United States caused London stock brokers to arrive at their offices earlier today, anticipating large orders. Many dealers reported that increased business began in some markets before the official hour.

The thwarting of the will of Kaiser Wilhelm by his Ministers led to the World War and Germany's defeat, according to a book which the former Kaiser helped to prepare. "Blind" and "carrying the Reichstag on their backs," the book declares, Chancellor Prince von Bulow and the "mysterious figure of the juggler-calculator Holstein" brought about the German ruin by frustrating all efforts of the Kaiser to assure friendship with England and Russia.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- A sharp conflict between Governor Roosevelt and the Republican-controlled joint legislative unemployment committee on establishment of a system of compulsory unemployment insurance was revealed tonight.

GENEVA, Feb. 15 -- Whatever positive results may be attained at this disarmament conference, it is the opinion of most of the delegates that at least a stabilization. If not a reduction, of armaments must result.

Three unofficial American observers at the International Disarmament Conference at Geneva, representing peace and religious organizations, speaking to the United States through facilities of the National Broadcasting Company last night, declared that public opinion, more than any ether factor, could bring success to the conference program.
NEW YORK. The Polish Ambassador, Tytus Filipowicz, who has been at the Ritz Tower, will leave tonight for Lake Placid.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Three bills designed to bring into the State treasury $104,000,000 in addition revenue by tax increases were passed in the Assembly today. Having already been approved in the Senate, they now go to the Governor.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- With Samuel Seabury repeatedly reminding him that standards in public life are set by the Executive with the power of removal. Governor Roosevelt took up the issue of Tammany corruption today at a public hearing in removal proceedings against Sheriff Thomas M. Farley.

Gold In the amount of $38,045,400 was withdrawn yesterday from this market for shipment to France, approximately $24,000,000 representing the tenth and eleventh transfers of earmarked gold made by the Bank of France and the remaining $14,000,000 exchange transactions made possible by the high level of the franc.

Frederick J. Leary, vice president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, and Ernest B. Tracy have resigned as directors of the Reliance Management Corporation and the Reliance International Corporation. Reports yesterday were that they had been unable to reconcile their views with those of the other directors who are identical in each company and who are arranging a deal to give the latter corporation control of the former, substantially reversing the present status.

The general business depression and the illness of William H. Todd, shipbuilder and veteran patron of volunteer firemen's associations, will result In the temporary dimming of one of the city's most colorful spectacles, the annual parade on Washington's Birthday of the Kings County Volunteer Firemen's Association.

An alliance between Great Britain and the United States, based on friendship rather than official formulae, was urged yesterday by Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York, at the Washington bicentennial luncheon of the Colonial Daughters of the Seventeenth Century in the Biltmore Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- Five foremen of a stevedoring firm, on their way to Chester to supervise the loading of a ship, were killed this morning and another was injured seriously when the motor truck in which they were riding was struck by a thirty-five-car Reading freight train at an unguarded crossing in southwest Philadelphia.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 16 -- H.J. Koehler, 57, is a veteran Labrador explorer. His son, Hans V. Koehler, said at his home this afternoon that although he and other members of his family were pleased to hear from his father and Connell, they had not been worried for their safety.

Several witnesses, testifying yesterday at the resumption of the public Inquiry by State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. into alleged racketeering in the laundry trade, declared they had been discriminated against by supply houses when they had failed to follow suggestions that they Join the Laundry Board of Trade.

Shaking off its lethargy in a last-hour rally, the stock market lifted itself yesterday into new high ground for the current movement. Net gains, most of them made in the last fifty minutes of trading on the Stock Exchange, ranged from 1 to 8 points for the leading issues.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- The Bourse opened irregular today, but despite uncertainty over the political situation, gradually strengthened until just before the close when quotations began to move lower. Final prices, while higher than the opening, were not the day's highest nor quite equal to yesterday's closing levels.

Riding hard from the opening to the close, the Allenhurst Polo Club team reached the semi-final round in the low-goal division of the New York Athletic Club indoor polo tournament at the 105th Field Artillery Armory last night with a one-sided victory over the New York Athletic Club, 12 1/2 to minus 1/2.

Exrept for the easier tone in the street market where day loans were arranged at 2 1/4 per cent, contrasted with 2 1/2, on the Stock Exchange, there was no feature to the business in money. Time loans, commercial paper and acceptance markets were all quiet and unchanged in quotation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The way was cleared in the Senate tonight for taking up the Glass-Steagall credit expansion bill tomorrow afternoon, but only after Senator Glass, co-author of this measure to stimulate business, had pleaded for its preference on the ground of the critical economic situation.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 16 -- A first-period rush in which Lane and Cook scored gave the Princeton varsity hockey sextet its ninth successive victory and a 2-to-1 verdict over the German Olympic hockey team tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The House today passed, by a vote of 335 to 56, the Norris-Rutherford "lame duck" resolution, proposing to do away with short sessions of Congress and to set the inauguration of the President and Vice President on the 24th of January following their election, instead of March 4.

An epidemic of horror pictures has been sweeping the cinema field. Perhaps the success of "Dracula" provoked the more recent shockers. "Frankenstein" has drawn protests from both English and American friends of children. One critic reported that there were few thrilling scenes in it, and that the laughter at some of the intended horrors and grotesqueries was not tinged with hysteria.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- After listening today to arguments wholly in support of the bill introduced by Assemblyman Langdon W. Post, Democrat of New York City, which provides for extension of the Governor's powers of investigation under the Sherman-Moreland act to municipal governmental units throughout the State, the Assembly Judiciary Committee killed the measure, although no one had appeared in opposition to it at the hearing.

LYNDHURST, N.J., Feb. 16 -- Extradition of four men under arrest in New York would be sought on the grounds they were members of a gang of five who had attempted to hold up a service station yesterday morning and had engaged in a pistol duel with policemen, local authorities informed the New York police today.

The second trial of the damage suits, totaling $125,000, brought by Mrs. Millie Delahoyde and George Connell, both of Richmond Hill, against the Sheffield Farms Company was begun yesterday before Justice Leander B. Faber and a jury in Queens Supreme Court, Long Island City.

That section of wall Street committed to the advance drew the inference from yesterday's late but emphatic rally on the Stock Exchange that the market had consolidated its gains of last week. This was not the unanimous judgment, but tapewatchers, at least, felt that the resumption of the advance so soon after the spectacular upturn of last Saturday and Thursday was a highly encouraging development.

Mayor Charles Heling of Lindenhurst, L.I., a supporter of Governor Roosevelt, has been selected by the Suffolk County Democratic Executive Committee as its candidate for delegate to the Democratic National Convention from the First New York Congressional District.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 17 -- Ambassador Debuchi has notified Foreign Minister Kenkichi Yoshizawa that Secretary of State Stimson is preparing a formal protest to Japan against the landing of troops in the International Settlement and warning Japan that if the Chinese make Japan's act a pretext for attacking the Settlement and any American lives are lost, the United States will hold Japan responsible.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Feb. 16 (Canadian Press) -- A message nearly five months old, carried over snowbound Labrador by Indians, dog-team mail and radio, has brought the first word from two adventurous Americans, Herman Koehler and Fred Connell, since they started their canoe trip into the barren Labrador-Quebec peninsula last July.

If the Marx Brothers were playing in "Collision," which was staged at the Gaiety last evening, no one who is in his right mind can tell exactly how funny it would be. It is a comic extravaganza adapted by our own John Anderson from the German of Rudolph Lothar and Erno Sebesi.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The letter sent by Secretary Mills to Chairman Crisp of the Ways and Means Committee read:

Copyright, 1932, by The Associated Press. ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Rising slowly from his seat and glancing quickly around the soft-lighted, brown-paneled chamber. Chief Judge Benjamin Nathan Cardoza gathered his black robes about him and stepped down today from the bench of the New York Court of Appeals after eighteen years of service to step up to the ambition of all lawyers, service in the Supreme Court of the United States.

The "War Against Depression," begun on Monday by the American Legion and affiliated organizations, resulted in the finding of 16,857 jobs up to noon yesterday, it was announced at the national headquarters at the Hotel Biltmore.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Costigan-La Follette bill to provide direct Federal relief for the unemployed was rejected in the Senate tonight by a vote of 48 to 35.

While Assistant Attorneys General John T. Cahill and Peter J. Brancato were preparing briefs yesterday to file with Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy to sustain their contentions that Owen (Owney) Madden, convicted slayer and his three convict associates should be returned to Sing Sing for violation of parole, it became known that Major William H. McMullen, chief parole officer, here had left the service of Parole Board.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Feb. 16 -- A suit asking $140,000 damages was iled today at Oshkosh against F.J. Sensenbrenner, president, and J.C. Kimberley, vice president of the Kimberley-Clark Company, by Edgar R. Thorn of Detroit, who charges that the paper company, executives concealed the true value of the company's stock to obtain 63 shares of preferred and 468 shares of common stock in the corporation Thorn inherited from his father.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The National Government forged ahead with its new 10 per cent tariff policy today, getting the contentious import duties bill through second reading in the House of Commons by 451 to 73 votes.

Alfred Stieglitz is celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of his career as a photographer. Not in eight years has he held an exhibition, but the display of photographs now on view at An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, was worth waiting for. It gives a comprehensive picture of the work Mr. Stieglitz has done since 1892, the latest prints being the New York series made last year.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 16 -- County Prosecutor Ray T. Miller, a Democrat, was elected Mayor of Cleveland at today's special election.

The glee club of the Junior League will give its annual concert tonight in the Great Hall of the clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street. A diversified program has been arranged and several of the numbers will have special obbligatos. Mrs. George Edgerton Ogilvie and Dr. Otto V. MacKenty Schmidt will play a double violin obbligato early in the program and later Mrs. Ogilvie will play a group of solos.

Hugh T. Cuff, a Democratic State committeeman and labor leader of Grant City, S.I., was one of twelve prosecution witnesses called yesterday in the trial of Edward Cooperstein, a real estate broker of St. George, S.I., in the Richmond County Supreme Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- Rayman Pitcairn, chairman of the Republican Citizens' Committee Against National Prohibition, replied tonight to Senator Brookhart of Iowa, who a few days ago spoke of a letter mailed by Mr. Pitcairn with copies of the imitation newspaper.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 17 -- After an almost continuous bombardment beginning at 8:30 o'clock last night and ending at 5:30 this morning, the expected Japanese advance on Chapei failed to develop and an unaccustomed quiet descended upon the front lines.

GENEVA, Feb. 18 -- It is with a growing consciousness that events in China are putting to a test the real value of all international agreements that the disarmament conference is continuing its work. Speaker after speaker is insisting that the present situation imperils public trust everywhere in the worth of such agreements and that it is contributing to just that distrust and suspicion which this conference is trying to remove.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The combined opposition of New England States, excepting Rhode Island, was leveled today against the four-system plan for rail consolidation of the major Eastern trunk lines, in testimony before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Beck-Linthicum resolution, proposing to modify Eighteenth Amendment so as the liquor question back to the States, was rejected today by the House Judiciary Committee by a vote of 14 to 9.

Expressing his gratification and that of Chairman E.K. Hall over the sympathetic reception generally accorded the changes made in the gridiron code for 1932, William S. Langford, secretary of the Intercollegiate Football Rules Committee, spent most of his day yesterday on the telephone accepting words of congratulation for the organization and furnishing answers to the few critical questions raised as to the feasibility of the modifications.

BOMBAY, Feb. 16 -- Miss Madeleine Slade, Mahatma Gandhi's English disciple, was ordered today to leave Bombay before tomorrow night and not to return without permisto oblige the police commissioner sion. Sir Patrick Kelly, commissione of police in Bombay, signed the order, issued under the emergency powers ordinance.

HAMBURG, Feb. 16 -- Hanseatic shipping circles believe the Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd Lines, which have found the 1930 pooling arrangement unsatisfactory, will consolidate soon to strengthen their position for weathering the business depression.

SOFIA, Feb. 16 -- To Judge by the statement of Premier Muchanoff to newspapermen today on his return from Geneva, a remarkable difference of opinion exists between the government and the League of Nations commissioners and foreign creditors regarding Bulgaria's ability to continue to discharge her foreign obligations.

PINEVILLE, KY., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Harold Hickerson, New York playwright, who has been held in jail on charges of criminal syndicalism since he came here last Wednesday with a group of New York writers, was freed today on his agreement to leave the State.

While Brooklyn civic organizations moved yesterday to have the reproduction of Mount Vernon which it is proposed to erect in this city as part of the George Washington bicentennial observance located in some Brooklyn park, Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., issued a statement against placing the structure "in any finished, landscaped park."

Scholastic athletes who transfer from a public high or private school in New York City to another public high school in the city will not be eligible to represent the latter school for twenty weeks, the equivalent of a full school term, according to a ruling passed at the February meeting of the high schools games committee of the P.S.A.L. at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

GENE VENZKE and George Spitz. These boys have come fast and high. Young George, who is formally listed as George B. Spitz Jr. on the student roll at N.Y.U., is the tall, thin, dark-haired boy who goes out evenings and leaps over a horizontal crossbar. The point about George is that the height of the bar apparently matters little to him. He goes over it just the same.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- Rejecting the Premier's plea for a brief delay to permit the conclusion of the preliminary debate at the Geneva arms limitation conference, the French Senate today overturned the Laval Cabinet.

The Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, which is controlled by the Transamerica Corporation through the ownership of 63 per cent of its capital stock, is expected to continue to do business as the securities affiliate of the holding company under its present title as a result of control of Transamerica obtained by the Giannini interests at the stockholders' meeting on Monday.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The British Board of Film Censors began today its first big offensive in its war against "sex" films.

Two-score of the most prominent yachtsmen of Long Island Sound met at 145 West Forty-fourth Street last night and formed the North American Dinghy Association, along the lines of the small boat organization of similar name in England, which for years has been in exceptionally popular faver.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 36. -- Passage at once of two municipal utility bills introduced in the Legislature as a part of Governor Roosevelt's utility program was urged by Delos M. Cosgrove of Watertown, vice chairman of the State Power Authority, at a dinner meeting tonight of Syracuse and Utica Chapters of the National Association of Cost Accountants.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Wheat sold up 2 1/2 to 3 1/4 cents a bushel today on the Board of Trade here after a dip at the opening and reached new high levels on the current movement for the May and the July, while the September went to the best mark since trading in that delivery started.

The influence of the Shipping Board was greatly strengthened, in the opinion of New York shipping men, by the decision of Justice Sutherland of the Federal Supreme Court in the action of the United States Navigation Company against the Cunard Steamship Company, fourteen other lines and two individuals, which was published yesterday.

Cathedral Boys High basketball team assured itself of at least a tie for the Manhattan division C.H.S. A.A. title by defeating the second place St. Ann's Academy quintet, 28 to 13, yesterday at the East Fifty-fourth Street gymnasium. At half time, Cathedral Boys High led, 17 to 2.

In an effort to bring to book several small communities in Florida whose obligations are in default, the Florida Municipal Bondholders' Protective Committee, organized under the sponsorship of the Municipal Securities Association of Jacksonville, Fla., has issued its first call for deposit of bonds in connection with plans worked out for eighteen municipalities.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 16 -- Escaping early today from kidnappers, Harry G. Blagden, 45 years old, sportsman who operates a boys' camp at Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y., smilingly told of hiS experiences later in the day as he lay in bed at the home of a friend, Claude J. Peck, recovering from shock.

Governor ROOSEVELT and Miss PERKINS, State Industrial Commissioner, are well within the facts when they say that the new plan of insurance against unemployment is not at all radical. It was worked out by a competent committee, representing the States of Ohio, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island and New York, to be laid before the Legislatures of those seven States.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- A deficit of $52,468.15 was reported today by Willis Wells, chairman of the finance committee of the Third Olympic Winter Games Committee, in the staging of the Winter Olympics here.

Within forty-eight hours, 753 first and second grade detectives must present full reports of their activities during the last six months to Assistant Chief Inspector John Sullivan, head of the detective bureau, It was disclosed yesterday at Police Headquarters.

Thirty sympathizers with the striking Kentucky coal miners assembled at Broad and Wall Streets yesterday noon bearing placards denouncing "kidnapping, starvation and terror" in the Kentucky coal fields. Policemen Informed them that they could not meet there because it would impede traffic, so they walked in single file, holding their placards high, through Wall, William, Nassau, Pine and other streets in the financial district.

Grover A. Whalen, former Police Commissioner and former Commissioner of Plant and Structures, was questioned by assistant counsel yesterday at the headquarters of the Hofstadter legislative inquiry, during the absence of Samuel Seabury in Albany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Recommendations for new taxes to provide $337,000,000 in addition to the administration's original program for increased revenue to balance the budget in the fiscal year 1933, were laid before the Ways and Means Committee today by Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury.

It is hard to believe that Governor ROOSEVELT has consented to be a candidate in the Massachusetts primary election in late April. Yet his son in Boston so believes. Mr. STRABO CLAGGETT, that Democrat of great name who wasn't elected Lieutenant Governor in 1930, has served notice on Governor ELY, his more fortunate companion on the ticket of that year.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 -- George Bernard Shaw's "Saint Joan," with Mrs. Elisha Dyer Hubbard in the title role, was presented tonight at the Palm Beach Playhouse. A capacity audience gave Mrs. Hubbard, founder and president of the playhouse, and the supporting company an enthusiastic ovation at the close of the play.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The assessed valuation of property in New York State subject to ad valorem taxation in 1930 was $27,034,695,261 and in New Jersey $6,829,018,324, according to financial statistics for these States for the fiscal year 1930 issued today by the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Unwillingness of J.P. Morgan Co. to cooperate with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in a plan enabling the Missouri Pacific Railroad to liquidate its indebtedness was cited in correspondence between an official of the road and the Interstate Commerce Commission, made public by that body today.

GIBRALTAR, Feb. 16 -- Mystery still surrounds the death of Elizabeth Barrett Cook, one of the strangest ever recorded at sea. Dr. A.G. Holborrow, city analyst, definitely established today the drug found with the ether cloth in the cabin of the dead girl as quadronol, a German drug with which he said he was unfamiliar.

The "bank relief bill" -- for extension, under certain circumstances, of the Reserve System's powers for note issue and rediscount -- passed the House by 350 to 15. The Senate will undoubtedly concur, though probably with amendments designed to limit the new credit facilities to banks which need them and to insure the use of them to smaller member banks.

In the absence of any report from Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee's committee on Whitestone transit relief, the Board of Estimate, sitting yesterday in Committee of the Whole, postponed until Friday any action on the abandonment of the Whitestone spur.
