To the Editor of The New York Times: Interest in the recent "marathon" contract bridge match was amazing. The play of many of the more interesting hands provoked and still provokes discussion and criticism both in this country and abroad.

Morris Ostfeld, head of the Star Turf Exchange, 198 Broadway, publishers of a racing form bulletin, was held in $2,000 bail yesterday by Francis A. O'Neill, United States Commissioner, following his arrest on a charge of using the mails to defraud in circulating "sure thing" tips for beating the races.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 16 -- Harvard's basketball team won its third game of the season and its second in succession by defeating Northeastern University tonight, 32 to 23. Twenty-seven points were scored from the foul line, Harvard accounting for fourteen.

After a brief exhibition of seemingly reactionary tendencies, yesterday's markets took on fresh strength, ending with substantial further gains. On the Stock Exchange, active shares declined 1 or 2 points in the early trading; then, resuming the advance, they scored advances from the earlier low quotations ranging, in many important stocks, from 3 to 7 points.

Gross crude oil production in the United States averaged 2,138,300 barrels a day in the week ended on Feb. 13. This compares with 2,152,700 barrels a day in the previous week, showing a daily decrease of 14,400 barrels. The figures were released yesterday toy the American Petroleum Institute.

The Republic of Uruguay was added yesterday to the list of South American nations unable to keep up sinking-fund payments on their external debts, retiring substantial amounts of bonds yearly. Jose Richling, Charge d'Affaires of the Uruguayan Government, issued a statement here notifying American bondholders of the inability of the government to continue the sinking funds in 1932 without depleting its gold reserves but that the interest on the bonds would continue to be paid.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 16 -- The Extra Dry Cafe, 1,110 Atlantic Avenue, frequented by distinguished visitors for more than a half century, was raided by Federal prohibition agents tonight.

NEW YORK Mrs. Charles Connfelt gave a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. Among her guests were Mrs. Lewis Gouverneur Morris, Mrs. John Aspegren, Mrs. Robert E. Todd, Mrs. Moses Taylor Campbell, Mrs. Everett Colby, Mrs. J. Russell Soley and Mrs. Ansel Phelps.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Evening, the fleet filly which races for G. D. Widener, kept up the excellent showing she has made this Winter by leading home a field of five in the Deland Handicap, feature at Hialeah Park today. Evening finished a length and a half in front of the Howe Stable's Sansarica, which took second by two lengths from the Wheatley Stable's Slambang.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Pilots engaged in Interstate transport service would be required to pass "blind flying" tests under an amendment to the air commerce regulations drafted by Assistant Secretary Young of the Commerce Department. In addition they would be required to have considerable night flying experience.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, spent an hour today at Buckingham Palace, where it may be safely assumed he informed the King of the Shanghai situation and outlined the negotiations which are proceeding daily between the British and United States Governments for the purpose of being in accord on their respective policies dealing with the Far East.

Discarding their skis yesterday to gain a foothold on the metallic steps of Manhattan's loftiest peak, the Empire State Building, five members of the Polish Olympic team, who also are expert mountain climbers, conquered the heights of the world's greatest skyscraper in twenty-one minutes.

Philip A. de Laszlo, British artist, who has painted portraits of well known Americans, including President and Mrs. Hoover, attacked modern art yesterday in an address at a reception in his honor given by the English-Speaking Union at 19 West Forty-fourth Street.

For several months the sword has been suspended over the head of the Laval Cabinet, and yesterday the blow fell. The hostile vote in the Senate came on the general policy of the Government, but the decisive clash seems to have been precipitated by M. LAVAL'S success in driving through the Chamber of Deputies last week his electoral reform bill.

Miss Muriel Guggolz of the Salle d'Armes Vince carried off the women's national junior foils championship in the competition staged last night at the Fencers Club. She captured four bouts in the final to triumph.

Real Estate Valuations. New York City has reason to be thankful to those who took measures to deal with the housing shortage after the war and chose 1932 as the date when tax exemption on new buildings should expire.

Four more Yankees, three of them in the veteran class, had their signed contracts delivered to Business Manager Ed Barrow's desk yesterday. Chief of the veterans is Earle Combs, the silver-haired Kentucky outfielder. The others are Charley (Red) Ruffing, right-handed pitcher, and Eddie (Doc) Farrell, once something of a sensation as an infielder with the Giants.

The pamphlet report of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company for 1931 shows a net loss of $774.142 after depreciation and a net profit of $149,505 before depreciation, but after write-offs, adjustments and charges. Operating earnings of $9,446,267 were $158,745 below operating expenses, but other income for the year, including $218,925 interest received on refunds of prior years' income taxes, amounted to $339,035.

AVALON, Santa Catalina Island, Cal., Feb. 16 -- Chicago's Cubs came to Avalon today in a downpour of rain, which failed to dampen their fire of determination to lay the Spring training foundation for a 1932 National League pennant. Rogers Hornsby, picking up the zest of his squad of eighteen players, mostly of the younger crop, wore an enthusiastic grin.

BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- The world premiere of Gerhart Hauptmann's "Before Sunset" proved an unquestioned success at the Deutsches Theater. The 70-year-old dramatist shows that he still is in the front line and able to build a watertight, vividly characterized play.

BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- With Germany's export balance destined to show a further slump, the question of the Reich's ability to meet service charges or her foreign indebtedness is becoming an acute problem. This is the opinion of some financial writers who pointed out that the Reichsbank's reserves will be indisputably imperiled if the hitherto favorable surplus is wiped out in the ratio reflected by figures for January.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange was strong yesterday, although trading was lighter than on the previous day. United States Government bonds were again sharply higher and railroad bonds led the advance in domestic corporation issues.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I not assure readers that the aim of prohibitionists and anti-prohibitionists is exactly the same? That is, to abolish forever the saloon, sometimes called speakeasy, with its lawlessness and vicious influence on the young people of the present day.

A State bond issue of $200,000,000 to provide funds for an extended program of public works and to make it possible to advance funds to cities where such programs have been curtailed because of financial stringency, was urged yesterday in a letter sent by Frank G. Taylor, Public Welfare Commissioner, to Commissioner Charles H. Johnson of the State Department of Social Welfare.

Through the formation of the Faraday Refrigerator Corporation the General Motors Corporation has entered the gas-refrigerator field with a view to supplementing its line of electric refrigerators produced by its wholly owned subsidiary, the Frigidaire Corporation.

To lose Mrs. FISKE is to lose an actress who kept the theatre at its high estate. To her it was no idle sensation. For sixty-four years she had trouped steadily across this broad country in classics, modern dramas and light-fingered comedies, playing the one-night stands as honestly as the largo cities and taking her lot with less practiced itinerants.

For thirty minutes yesterday Walter Winchell, newspaper writer, testified before the grand jury on the manner in which he obtained information connected with the recent slaying of Vincent Coll, gang leader, by a man with a machine gun in a West Twenty-third Street drug store.

At their third concert of the season the Musical Art Quartet presented Tansman's "Triptyque" for string orchestra for the first time as a quartet; the first performance anywhere of Efrem Zimbalist's Quartet in E. and Ravel's Quartet in F.

AKLAVIK, N.W.T., Feb. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Through blizzards and subzero weather of the sunless Yukon, Albert Johnson, mad trapper, footed it today in his dramatic race to Alaska -- outside the reach of the pursuing Royal Canadian Mounted Police, who want him for murder of one of their force.

John Hartigran, 25 years old, a taxicab chauffeur, of 77 Perry Street, at 6:30 o'clock last night was found guilty of manslaughter in the first degree by a jury in Judge Freschl's part of General Sessions. Hartigan was on trial for the slaying of 19-year-old Catherine Cronin In his home last Sept. 7.

Walter L. Clark is having an exhibition of portraits at the Grand Central Galleries, of which he is the president. Through most of his business career Mr. Clark followed the profession of mechanical engineer. During the early part of the World War he was with the firm of Morgan Co., and after that with the Westinghouse Electric Company.

The percentage of "in-and-out" short trading on the New York Stock Exchange during January was higher compared with total daily transactions than in any of the three months and few odd days during which reports have been compiled on transactions of this character, according to the Stock Exchange bulletin for February.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The action of the Council of the League of Nations today in instructing a drafting committee to frame an appeal to Japan urging the cessation of hostilities in the Far East and declaring that the League will not recognize any territorial changes which have occurred as a result of "Japanese occupation" was regarded with approval here.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 16 -- Joseph Fitz Randolph, retired lawyer, who was a member of the New York bar for sixty years, known especially for his expert knowledge of probate law, died today at his home in Elm Street at the age of 88. His wife, who was Harriet W. Talcott, a daughter of William H. Talcott of Jersey City, died in 1891.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Traveling at an average speed of forty-eight miles an hour, Henry Homburger drove his team of Saranac Red Devils to its second successive North American and A.A.U. four-man bob-sled championship this morning over the Mount Van Hoevenberg bob-run.

GENEVA, Feb. 16 -- The Council of Twelve of the League of Nations met at the crossroads today and took the road they thought dangerous but right. Ceasing to put China and Japan upon the same moral plane, they turned for the first time since the conflict began to Japan alone.

Two alleged racketeers, who refused to reduce their "protection" charges despite the pleas of one of their customers, were arrested last evening in Max Grumer's vest manufactory at 142 Henry Street. Detective Thesby Feltenstein made the arrests after, it was charged, they had accepted $50 in marked bills from Grumer.

An increase of $7,500,000 in the gross revenue during 1931 over the preceding year, derived by the National Broadcasting Company principally from furnishing facilities to backers of programs, was announced yesterday by M. H. Aylesworth, president, in his annual report to the company's advisory council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Dropping more than $50,000,000 from the previous month's level, American foreign trade in January totaled $286,000,000, a decline to the lowest point on exports since 1914 and on imports since 1915. January merchandise exports were $150,000,000 and imports from abroad, $136,000,000.

A shifting of assets which strengthens the Chesapeake Ohio Railway as the keystone in the Van Sweringen system and provides the Alleghany Corporation, a Van Sweringen holding organization, with about $6,000,000 in cash or the equivalent, was disclosed yesterday.

Jamming the sidewalks on Seventh Avenue from Twenty-third to Fortieth Street from curb to building line, the exodus of dressmakers who answered the strike call of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union yesterday turned the garment centre area into a sea of humanity that required the combined efforts of several hundred policemen to manage.

CAMDEN, N,J., Feb. 16 -- Approval of the proposed high speed rail line across the Delaware River between here and Philadelphia was given by Mayor J. Hampton Moore of Philadelphia in a speech before the Camden Chamber of Commerce and the Camden Rotary Club today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson said today testimony by George N. Leger that the American Government forced Haiti to accept a loan from an American banking concern was untrue.

Considerable Southern selling and realizing was absorbed on declines of 3 or 4 points in the early trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here. Then prices turned upward on an increase in demand influenced by advances in the grain and stock markets.

St. John's College chalked up its nineteenth basketball victory of the season when it beat a fighting Villanova College five, 27 to 18, before a crowd of 1,000 at Arcadia Hall, Brooklyn, last night. After a slow start in the first half, the Redmen got off on a scoring spurt early in the second half and won easily.

The Detroit Falcons held the New York Rangers to a tie in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. A goal scored by Frank Carson of the Michigan sextet late in the second period brought about a 2-to-2 deadlock which a full third period and a regulation ten-minute overtime session failed to dispel.

An estate of $1,743,187 net was left by Charles C. Brace of Tarrytown, N.Y., who died on Aug. 26, 1931, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The gross estate was appraised at $1,876,643, of which stocks and bonds made up $1,574,439.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A response made today by Jouett Shouse, chairman of the executive committee of the Democratic National Committee, to Frank A. Hampton of North Carolina was taken as a danger signal to the Roosevelt forces in their effort to win second choice position in those Eastern and Northern States where Mr. Roosevelt is not admittedly the leading candidate.

WARSAW, Feb. 16 -- The semi-official Gazeta Polska today emphatically repudiates all the sensational rumors of an alleged Polish plan to occupy Danzig by force, which circulated in Germany and elsewhere following the resignation of the Polish High Commissioner in the Free City, Dr. Henryk Strasburger.

The preliminary annual report of the Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., shows net Income amounting to $15,023,840 after all charges, taxes and depreciation, equal after preferred dividends to $2.53 a share earned on 3,099,574 common shares, the average number outstanding during the year, as compared with $16,079,310, or $3.25 a share earned on 2,807,819 common shares in 1930.

Persons prominent in the hotel business and in the city's political life attended the funeral of James B. Regan, former proprietor of the old Knickerbocker Hotel in Times square, who died of pneumonia on Saturday at the Park Lane Hotel after an illness of almost a month, at the age of 66.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Cornell defeated Dartmouth, 28 -- 27, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- General Gustave Ferrie, a pioneer in the development of wireless telegraphy for military purposes, died today at the age of 63 after an operation for appendicitis in which internal poisoning was involved. He was Inspector General of the French Army's telegraphic service.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Spanish Play, winner of the Latonia Derby and second to Mate in the Arlington Classic last year, won his second race of the Winter season when he got up in the final strides to defeat the Southland Stable's Playtime in the Airport Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

To the Editor of New York Times: It Japan should place its differences with China before the League and, if necessary, the World Court for conciliation, it would establish a precedent, valuable to Japan and to all nations, for peaceful methods in settling disputes.
MOSCOW, Feb. 16 -- What the welldressed Russian will wear. Soviet style, will be the subject of an exhibition soon to be opened in Moscow.

Textile High School's basketball team gained undisputed possession of first place in the Manhattan division P.S.A.L. race by defeating Stuyvesant, 27 to 15, yesterday in the Textile gymnasium. Previous to the game, the teams were tied for the leadership with four victories apiece in as many Manhattan P.S.A.L. contests.

The resignation on last Thursday of the staff of The Hunter Bulletin, student publication at Hunter College, was the chief subject of campus comment yesterday, and when the day session ended petitions calling for restoration of the staff were in circulation.

The verdict returned by the jury which heard the trial of suits for damages totaling $960,000 against the New York American League Baseball Club was set aside yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Gavegan after the jury, unable to agree, had found both the plaintiffs and the defendants guilty of negligence.

VIENNA, Feb. 16 -- The Austrian Government today addressed to the Ministers of Britain, France, Italy and Germany a note pointing out Austria's need for wider markets and deploring the impossibility of obtaining them by agreement with her neighbors.

A strong note of optimism ran through addresses yesterday at the second day's sessions of the American Paper and Pulp Association and affiliated organizations, holding their annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Trading was dull and prices lower on the Stock Exchange today, following the decline in Wall Street. British Government funds were easier in sympathy with a drop by sterling in the foreign exchange market to $3.44 3/4 on New York.
Five of the fleetest milers in America will face the starter tonight in the Baxter Mile, featured event of the sixty-fourth annual indoor games of the New York A.C. in Madison Square Garden.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 -- All the favorites, led by Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., women's national golf champion, and Miss Edith Quier of Reading, Pa., the medalist, came through by wide margins in the first-round matches of the championship of Florida tournament over the Palm Beach Country Club course today.

Means to bring railroad and trucking interests together on plans for legislation to regulate highway traffic will be discussed at a meeting called for tomorrow in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Agnew T. Dice, president of the Reading Company. Among the railroads that will be represented are the New York Central, Pennsylvania, Lehigh Valley, Delaware, Lackawanna Western, Baltimore Ohio and New York, New Haven Hartford.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 16 -- The Rev. Dr. Horatio Oliver Ladd, Episcopal clergyman and teacher and the oldest alumnus of both Bowdoin College and Yale Divinity School, died today at his home here.

WOODBURY, N.J., Feb. 16 -- Police Recorder Frank L. Johnson sentenced three schoolboys, charged with having broken the lock of a motion picture theatre's exit door to see the movie, to receive ten lashes each tonight, and then descended from the bench and administered the flogging himself with a borrowed strap.

MONTREAL, Feb. 16 -- The Montreal Maroons climbed out of the cellar in the International group of the National Hockey League by routing the New York Americans, 7 to 1, tonight. The setback forced New York into last place.

While James and Edward Monahan, 16-year-old twins of 1,359 Second Avenue, were being placed on a year's probation as wayward minors by Magistrate Harris in Yorkville court yesterday, their father, James Sr., was arraigned before Magistrate Brodsky in family court in the same building for being $154 in arrears in alimony payments to the boys' mother, Mrs. Margaret Monahan.
NEWTON, Kan., Feb. 16 -- "How is the old foot?"

Controller Charles W. Berry said yesterday that he would Issue a formal statement in a few days giving his estimate of the city tax rate for 1932, which must be set by the Board of Aldermen before March 3.

Peter J. Brancato, Assistant State Attorney General, who completed his first year yesterday as head of the New York City Bureau, Attorney General's office, was guest of honor at a dinner given by his associates at the Club Plaza, 111 Second Avenue.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 16 -- Dead-locked by partisan feeling, Governor Moore's special joint committee on municipal tax relief abandoned an attempt to reach a decision on his plan to rebate $16,500,000 of road funds to municipalities at two heated sessions here today.

The appointment of Rufus D. Smith, associate dean of the New York University Washington Square College, as dean of the college to succeed Dr. James Buell Munn, resigned, was announced yesterday by Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown.

Judge Donnellan of General Sessions, in a decision handed down yesterday, denied a motion for the dismissal of the misdemeanor indictment charging Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, with falling to perform his official duty in connection with the collapse of the Bank of United States.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Telegrams went flashing across the nation today to some 2,000 Chambers of Commerce in every State of the Union asking for their cooperation in the citizens' campaign to put idle money to work.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 17 -- The good political work done by the Japanese Army in the last two months is evidenced by the smoothness and speed with which the framework of a new State has been built at Mukden by Chinese leaders of a calibre not inferior to those displaced.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The hoarding tide has turned, President Hoover announced this afternoon.

One of the most notable financial results of the current depression is an increased tendency on the part of the public to fall back on trust companies, and to turn over to such organizations of specialists the conservation and management of their wealth, according to the reports that opened yesterday the annual three-day conference of the Trust Division of the American Bankers' Association in the Commodore Hotel.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 16 -- Fighting in the rebellion led by Manual Castro Quesada, defeated Presidential candidate, spread to the streets of the capital today and his followers began seizing provisions from grocery stores.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Heartly (Hunk) Anderson, head football coach at Notre Dame, sadly shook his head today over the new rule outlawing aggressive use of the hands on the defense.

BERLIN, Feb. 16 -- No intimations were forthcoming from Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's Nationalists or Adolf Hitler's National Socialists today as to the nature of their counter-attack against President von Hindenburg's acceptance of the non-partisan nomination for the Presidency as "the people's candidate."

Charles (Red) Boyette, Sixty-ninth Regiment, 179 pounds, retained his New York State National Guard heavyweight title when he knocked out Izzy Grove of the 212th Anti-Air-craft Regiment, 171, in the last round of their scheduled twelve-round bout at the Twentysecond Engineers Armory last night before a crowd of 5,000.

Stocks resumed their advance on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, with numerous active foreign and domestic bonds continuing uninterrupted gains in active transactions. Leaders improving included Electric Bond and Share, Cities Service, American Superpower and St. Regis Paper.

Forty-seven small packages of morphine, valued at about $7,000, were seized yesterday afternoon by customs officers in the locker of a dining-saloon steward aboard the French liner Ile de France, which was docked at Pier 57, North River.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad has bought or contracted for more than $19,000,000 worth of equipment, materials and supplies from Pittsburgh industries, Elisha Lee of Philadelphia, senior vice president of the railroad, told 400 business men, railroad executives and city officials at a Pittsburgh Chamber of Commerce luncheon today.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 16 -- The government announced today that it had nipped a leftist revolt which was to have broken out yesterday morning and that thirteen leaders of the Opposition, including Colonel Gustavo Jimenez, Minister of War under the Provisional Government of David Samenez Ocampo last year, had been seized and deported from Callao by steamer last night for Valparaiso, Chile.

An electromagnet so powerful that it will attract minerals and other substances popularly considered as non-magnetic, was described yesterday before the 141st meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

A reorganization plan for the American Solvents and Chemical Corporation has been adopted by the committee headed by Joseph P. Ripley, vice president of the National City Bank. New cash totaling about $1,650,000 will be realized through the sale of certain idle properties, and $731,500 more will be realized by the offering of 133,000 shares of common stock in the new company.

Anglo-American cooperation to preserve the structure erected for the settlement of international disputes is imperative if civilization is to survive, Karl A. Bickel, president of The United Press, told members of the British Empire Chamber of Commerce at a luncheon at the Downtown Athletic Club. 18 West Street, yesterday.
DUBLIN, Feb. 16 -- The rush to the polls that President William T. Cosgrave had hoped for failed to materialize in the Irish Free State election today.

The Initial report of the Vocational Survey Commission, appointed by the Board of Education, compels praise for clear presentation of existing conditions and soundness of the basic recommendations. Of the million children (approximately) in the public day schools of the city, 200,000 are in the day high schools.

Buffalo, N.Y. The city of Buffalo, N.Y., which failed on Feb. 10 to receive any bids on a new issue of $1,790,000 of bonds because bankers were unwilling to take $3,000,000 of the issue, which has a maturity of only three years, plans to reoffer the entire issue on Feb. 24.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The application of the American Scantic Line, Inc., for loans from the construction loan fund for use in reconditioning, remodeling and improving the Saguache, Minnequa, City of Fairbury and Bird City was today approved by the Shipping Board.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 16 -- The Japanese Consul General, Karamatsu Murai, published a statement today concerning the use of American, British and other flags by Chinese mischief-makers and observed that, unless effective control is improvised, "unfortunate possibilities" are likely to eventuate

To the Editor of The New York Times: In answer to Karl C. Narf's letter printed in THE TIMES, I should like to ask if he has ever studied American, German or French history. He started off correctly by stating that we should not judge a nation by what a few of its authors are wont to write.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 17 -- Two British bluejackets, members of a naval landing party guarding the British docks on the Whangpoo River, were injured today when a number of shells from the artillery duel between Chinese and Japanese forces fell on the wharves.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- The text of Governor Roosevelt's interrogation of Sheriff Parley follows:

ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 17 -- The Andover basketball team maintained its winning stride, defeating Massachusetts Institute of Technology freshmen today, 38 to 16, after leading at half time 14 to 9. Sweet and Barr led the winners' attack with 13 and 10 points, respectively.

John W. Gugliucci of 294 West Ninety-second Street, who is alleged to have taken in between $25,000 and $50,000 a year in the last nine years operating an advertising racket, was held yesterday in $5,000 bail by Francis A. O'Neill, United States Commissioner, on a charge of mail fraud.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- With Republican leaders, big and little, from all parts of the State for an audience, W. Kingsland Macy, the Republican State Chairman, and F. Trubee Davison, Assistant Secretary of War, speaking at a testimonial dinner for Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies of the Assembly this evening, sounded what generally was regarded as the keynote of the party's State and national campaigns.

A picture of three members of a socially prominent family several thousand miles from home, ill, tired and with nerves frayed was given yesterday by Miss Helen Fortescue, 18-year-old daughter of Mrs. Granville Fortescue, who with her son-in-law, Lieutenant Thomas H. Massie, U.S.N., and two enlisted men, is being held in Honolulu charged with the murder of a Hawaiian, Joseph Kahahawai.

GENEVA, Feb. 17 -- Andre Tardieu, with his colleagues, Paul Reynaud and Colonel Jean Fabry, left for Paris this evening. Although the disarmament conference will continue, even the momentary absence of France has taken from it much of its zest.
A variety of flats and dwellings, in addition to taxpayers and a theatre, yesterday were reported transferred in the New Jersey metropolitan area.

The forward movement in commodities was checked yesterday, moderate price reaction being reported in a number of cash and contract staples. Grains, coffee, hides, textiles and dairy products all lost ground. However, there was a slight firming up in copper, zinc and tin.

TOKYO, Feb. 17 -- Toshio Shiratori, director of the Bureau of Information of the Foreign Office, today met a deputation of American missionaries and Japanese Christians and answered numerous questions regarding the present dispute in China. The meeting originated in the concern which Christian bodies in the United States have been expressing to similar bodies here.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- Prince Oscar of Prussia, fifth son of the former Kaiser, is being quietly groomed as the Presidential candidate of Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's Nationalist party, it was reported tonight after the conclusion of an all-day conference devoted to search for a nominee to oppose President von Hindenburg.

John G. Jenkins, former president of the Jenkins Trust Company, who last Summer was credited with having completed payment of $706,000 in debts for which he had not been legally liable, is being held in Kings County civil prison in connection with a guardianship proceeding involving $4,000.

Vacancies in apartments in Manhattan have increased from 7.41 per cent in 1927 to 14.93 per cent in 1932, according to a survey completed yesterday under the direction of William F. Deegan. Tenement House Commissioner. Vacancies in "new law" tenements were found to be only 10.72 per cent, compared with 17.96 per cent in "old law" tenements.

"Trick for Trick," the mystery play which was to have opened last night, will have a postponed premiere this evening at the Sam H. Harris Theatre. The opening of "The Inside Story." originally scheduled for tonight at the National, has been deferred until Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Reflecting bank failures, voluntary liquidations, withdrawals from the national system and other results of the heavy reduction in business activity during 1931, resources of national banks totaling $24,662,286,000 on Dec. 31 were $4,137,398,000 lower than on the same date in 1930, the Controller of the Currency, J.W. Pole, announced today.

It is now potentially possible to harden virtually any metal or alloy so that the soft and weak metals like copper, lead, zinc, nickel, aluminum and tin can be made as strong as steel, it was declared yesterday at the 141st meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers by Dr. Paul D. Merica, vice president of the International Nickel Company, who delivered the annual lecture of the Institute of Metals Division.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The new State of Manchuria will be known as "Anku," "Land of Peace," and its national emblem will be the discarded Chinese five-barred flag emblazoned with the rising sun of Japan.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Royal Ruffin a gelded son of the Preakness winner Coventry, accounted for the Bahamas Purse, the feature at Hialeah Park today, after seven previous starts at this course in which he could get no better than second. Bearing the colors of Desha Breckinridge, Royal Ruffin charged on the leaders in the stretch and won going away by half a length.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Wheat traders operating on the bull side of the market were somewhat less confident of their position today. The failure of Liverpool to respond to yesterday's sharp upturn, the reactionary tendency in securities and disappointment because President Hoover's special message to Congress did not treat on prohibition led to profit taking and heavy selling by houses with Eastern connections.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The President, in a message today, asked Congress for authority to reduce the expenses of carrying on the Federal Government by coordinating its manifold activities.

The annual report of the Eastern States Power Corporation for 1931 shows a net income of $664,582, equal after preferred dividends to 32 cents a share earned oh 572,132 Class B common shares outstanding, comparing with $1,092,685, equal to 79 cents a common share, after preferred dividends, in 1930.

Publicity on relief activities has created the impression that all New York's needy are being fed, though this is true of less than half the city's hungry, and "even those receiving relief are forced to live on 7-cent meals," according to a statement issued yesterday by the City Affairs Committee in an analysis of relief expenditures.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 17 -- Archbishop Ruiz y Flores, the Papal Delegate to Mexico, warned Mexican Catholics today not to resort to violent protest against the laws limiting the number of priests, nor even to criticize the arrangement whereby the Catholic Church agrees to function under the laws.

Winston Guest and Lawrence Baldwin led the Optimists' rally in the last two periods of the featured Class A game in the Squadron C Armory last night to enable that team to defeat the all-Star Emus trio, 15 to 12 1/2, before a crowd of 2,000 who turned out to aid the Kings County American Legion welfare committee fund.
MONTREAL, Feb. 17 -- Fourteen charming girls faced the judges in the world's figure skating championship which started today at the Winter Club.

Restaurant men of New York, united with headwaiters, hotel and restaurant employes' associations representing many thousands, agreed yesterday to "make a march on Washington" for a direct appeal to President Hoover and Congress for the immediate modification of the prohibition laws.

American Legion Post 1025, which recruits its membership from the Grand Street Boys' Association, gave a dinner and entertainment last night at the clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street, to 350 disabled veterans of the World War. Buses brought the guests from government hospitals in the city.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- The movement of hogs in the West continues to be small and today's arrivals here were the second lightest for a Wednesday since Oct. 14 The price of fresh pork loins has not changed for several days. Prices of hogs today were steady to 10 cents higher than yesterday.

(The following story of the harrowing experiences of the crew of the Hudson's Bay Company trading ship Baychimo, marooned all Winter on the Alaskan Arctic coast, has been written for The Associated Press by Captain Sydney A. Cornwall, master of the vessel.)

Foiling two detectives who had been "planted" in an Atlantic Pacific chain store at 546 Second Avenue, between Thirtieth and Thirtyfirst Streets, two gunmen who had unsuccessfully attempted to rob the store shot it out with the plainclothes men about 6:30 o'clock last night and escaped in a waiting automobile.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The charge that Jack (Legs) Diamond, former New York gangster, was protected from the State and city police by Federal anti-narcotic agents was made to the House Rules Committee today by Representative Black, Democrat, of New York, in urging a favorable report on his resolution for an investigation of the enforcement of anti-drug laws.

Several former members of the New York Stock Exchange have repurchased seats in the belief, apparently, that a revival in market interest is in prospect. They will be revealed, probably today, among the recent purchasers of the remaining lot of forty-four "rights" attaching to Exchange memberships.

A fourteen months' quest by the police for Charles A. Levine, who gained attention in 1927 as the first passenger to accompany an aviator, Clarence Chamberlin, in a non-stop flight across the Atlantic, ended yesterday with Levine's arrest on a grand larceny charge in Harbor Sanitarium, at 667 Madison Avenue.

GENEVA, Jan. 17 -- The text of the note of the League of Nations Council to Japan, handed last night to the Japanese representative in Geneva, was made public here this noon, following its receipt in Tokyo. It follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Governor Roosevelt and Republican leaders are understood to have reached an agreement tonight on amendments to the bill to set up a banking board of nine members which will insure Executive approval, and the bill is scheduled for passage next week.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- His face whipped to a fiery red by stinging pellets of sleet, 19-year-old Reto Capadrutt of Switzerland piloted his rope-steered sled to the combined North American and A.A. U. boblet championship today down the Mount Van Hoevenberg slide.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- Believing that the trade policy of whatever new French Government replaces the fallen Laval Cabinet will be virtually the same as that of its predecessor, a delegation from the American Chamber of Commerce of Paris called today on Charles Duchemin, head of the Kuhlman Chemical Works, to press its case on the French import quotas.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 -- In the picturesque Orange Gardens of the Everglades Club, Mr. and Mrs. G. Horton Glover entertained tonight with a dinner for forty guests, honoring Mr. and Mrs. Henry Black of New York and Bar Harbor, who are visiting them.

Financial transactions directed by Paul Plunkett, prominent in financial circles and whose name is in the Social Register, caused two wellknown New York men, one a friend of President Hoover, to lose more than $1,300,000, it was charged yesterday by Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall of the State Bureau of Securities.

The Southern Pacific Company failed yesterday, for the first time since 1905, to declare a dividend when due. The company, which reduced its annual rate from $6 to $4 by the declaration of a quarterly dividend of $1 on Nov. 18, made the following announcement yesterday after the close of the stock market here:

Regular railroad service on the Whitestone branch of the Long Island Railroad will not be resumed, according to a telegram received yesterday afternoon by Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen, from George Le Boutillier, president of the Long Island.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Assailing Governor Roosevelt and Newton D. Baker, leading possibilities for the Democratic Presidential nomination, as candidates who have surrendered to "the devil of expediency" and become "Mr. Facing-Both-Ways" in their recent statements on the League of Nations, Joseph P. Tumulty, former secretary to Woodrow Wilson, declared today that they had without hesitation repudiated "the noblest thing" for which Wilson stood.

A long-term program of pier construction and a transportation system that would remove local freight from the piers and leave them exclusively to the service of the steamships were urged for New York by Billings Wilson, assistant general manager of the Port of New York Authority, in an address before the metropolitan section of the American Society of Civil Engineers last night at the Engineering Societies Building, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Just after Speaker GARNER and the House Democrats had announced their purpose to bring about a sweeping reorganization and economies in the Government service, the President sent a message to Congress demanding legislation for the same objects.

Predicting a Democratic victory in the Presidential election in November, John W. Davis, the nominee in 1924, declared last evening that the party had many men capable of solving the nation's problems and that he would welcome the announcement of new candidacies.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Samuel Seabury challenged Governor Roosevelt today to show his independence of Tammany Hall by removing Sheriff Thomas M. Farley and upholding the arm of the joint legislative investigating committee which a Republican Legislature created.
Eric H. Louw, Minister from the Union of South Africa to this country, issued in Washington yesterday the following statement discussing the maintenance of the gold standard in South Africa:

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Jan. 27 the tulips were coming through their cover of leaves. I was swinging in a hammock under the trees watching the chipmunks playing and the song sparrows hopping about. The garden mold was as soft and mellow as in May, and yet we are told the climate does not change on the average.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city.

While the Board of Estimate met in executive session yesterday in an effort to find funds for the completion of local improvements already authorized, seven Brooklyn local boards voted their approval of more than $1,600,000 in such improvements to be added to the already overburdened calendar.
MOSCOW, Feb. 17 -- Under the heading "Every One for Himself and All Against Disarmament," Izvestia today presents to its 1,500,000 readers the Kremlin's view of the Geneva arms conference.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- With the exception of some irregularities among rentes and a few domestic stocks, the Paris Bourse was unaffected by the governmental situation today. Trading was fairly good and was stimulated by important gains in copper stocks and by news of Wall Street's renewed strength yesterday.

A special panel of 150 talesmen, from which a jury will be chosen to try Sheriff Thomas M. Farley on the grand larceny indictment filed against him Feb. 3, was drawn yesterday at the Criminal Court Building. The trial was put off from Feb. 23 to Feb. 26 by Judge Otto A. Rosalsky to meet the legal requirements of the law and to permit notification of the talesmen.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Lloyd K. Garrison of New York has been selected to succeed the late Harry S. Richards as dean of the University of Wisconsin Law School, President Glenn Frank announced today.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 38 -- Japanese artillery, cavalry and infantry forces began a general movement into positions on the Chapei-Woosung front today, displacing the bluejackets from all but a small sector. A fleet of tanks also was moved out of the Hongkew district.

An amendment to the rules of racing has been proposed by A.H. Morris, one of the seven stewards of the Jockey Club, it became known at the Jockey Club yesterday, and will shortly be published so that other members and followers of the turf may give views upon it before any official vote is taken.

AKLAVIK, N.W.T., Feb. 17 (Canadian Press) -- When Albert Johnson came to the end of his trail today he had been battling cold, hunger and blizzards for weeks, now running through bleak hills, now standing at bay and shooting down his pursuers if they came within range of his deadly rifle.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Believing all the ill we hear of own hospitals and similar philanthrophy institutions, we must conclude that they are maintained not for the migation of human suffering but the purpose of adding to the age of mankind.

In December Governor-elect MOORE of New Jersey said that he was " determined to practice-rigid economy "in the management of State " affairs." The budget which he has now, as Governor, submitted to the Legislature conforms to that resolution.

E.W. Scripps founded the United Press and the Scripps-Howard News paper Alliance and achieved great wealth while violating all the copy book rules for success, "drinking a gallon of whisky every day for ten years" and carrying a lighted cigar in his mouth through every waking hour, according to Gilson Gardner for years Scripps's confidential assistant, who has written a biography ''Lusty Scripps," which is published today by Vanguard.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Formal legislative approval of an investigation of the State departments by an all-Republican joint committee was voted today, when the Assembly, balloting on party lines, adopted an enabling resolution already passed by the Senate.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 17 -- Ralph L. Fuller, manufacturer, former president of the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce, and Mayor of Euclid, Ohio, for two terms, died at his home today after, a long illness. His age was 66.

GENEVA, Feb. 17 -- The Council of Twelve of the League of Nations made public here today its note of yesterday to Japan and anxiously waited to see if its text would receive the same full publicity in Japan.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 17 -- President A. Lawrence Lowell of Harvard University, speaking for the first time from a radio studio, tonight urged the people of the United States to consider the necessity of joining with the League of Nations in an economic boycott against Japan.

John Christian Glaser Hupfel, who closed his large orewery with the advent of prohibition after sixty years in the brewing business in this city, died yesterday at the age of 88 in the house at 148 East Thirty-seventh Street where he had lived since he was 9 years old.

Trade Off 15% in First Half. Well-informed estimates here yesterday placed dollar volume of retail trade in the metropolitan area for the first half of the month at 15 per cent under the corresponding period a year ago. This approximates the decline for the first half of January.
Full Programs of Principal Stations for the Ensuing Week Are Published on Sunday

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 18 -- Japanese army and naval officers will meet Generals of the Chinese Nineteenth Route Army today to discuss terms for ending the fighting here, but since the Japanese are expected to demand that the Chinese withdraw twenty kilometers [12.4 miles] from Shanghai the outcome of the conversations is regarded as doubtful.

Raffaele Prisco, 56 years old, founder and president of the Prisco State Bank at 73 Mulberry Street, which was closed by the State Banking Department because of irregularities last July, was sentenced to an indeterminate term of not more than three years in the penitentiary by Judge Levine in General Sessions yesterday.

There was no great change in the money market from that which has characterized sessions of early week. Quotations in all sections remained firm, while business continued at a minimum. This applied to day loans on the Stock Exchange, time money, commercial paper and acceptances.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- Fortunes of this political crisis have again put Andre Tardieu in a key position, not necessarily for the Premiership but as being able to swing the needed Right votes to make a concentration Cabinet possible. Definite decision awaits his arrival here from Geneva tomorrow.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 17 -- The Princeton basketball team had little difficulty in defeating Pennsylvania tonight, 38 to 20, gaining undisputed possession of third place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League standing.
A National Voice. The Privy Council has given judgment on appeal that the control of radio communication in Canada lies within the jurisdiction of the Dominion Parliament, not that of the Provinces.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- R.C. Sherriff, author of "Journey's End," now a student at New College, Oxford, signed a contract here today with Universal to collaborate on new films with James Whale, producer of the film versions of famous war dramas.

State of Illinois. To satisfy legal requirements the State of Illinois has formally called for bids, to be opened tomorrow, on its new issue of $18,750,000 of 6 per cent revenue notes, dated Feb. 25, 1932, and callable by lot on fifteen days' notice on any date fixed by the Governor, the Auditor of Public Accounts and the State Treasurer, but no earlier than Dec. 1, 1932.

Flames darting from the stage of the Palace Theatre at Broadway and Forty-seventh Street drove the capacity audience of 1,900 persons in a pell-mell rush for the streets at 10:15 o'clock last night. Two persons were painfully burned and at least five others were injured, one seriously, in the mad scramble to get to the doors.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 17 -- Prime Minister Lyons announced at the opening of the new Australian Parliament today that the Federal Government would fulfill immediately its promise to pay interest due on the debts of New South Wales.

EASTON, Pa., Feb. 17 -- The Rutgers quintet nosed out Lafayette, 22 -- 20, tonight in a fast contest. Coming from behind after Rutgers had taken a 21-9 lead, Lafayette staged a rally that came within two points of tying the score.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- With only a short rest after he had concluded the trial of Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, Governor Roosevelt opened a hearing in five murder cases which continued until early evening.

The plan for relandscaping and beautifying Bryant Park which the Sixth Avenue Association intends to submit to Park Commissioner Walter R. Herrick is not approved by the Park Association of New York City, Inc. Nathan Straus Jr., president of the park association, said yesterday that while the proposal was a step in the right direction, the suggested design "seems to fall very far short of an ideal plan."

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 17 -- Colonel Thomas Lytle Walker, United States Collector of Customs for Kentucky, custodian of the Federal Building here and for many years a prominent Republican leader of the State, died in the Kentucky Baptist Hospital this afternoon from an infection which set in after he cut his finger a week ago on his estate at Harrods Creek.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Democratic House leaders, in commenting today on the recommendations made in President Hoover's special message proposing consolidation of government bureaus, expressed doubt that the changes suggested would result in much saving.

Nearly a quarter-million dollars was donated by the New York Telephone Company to charities and charged to operating expenses during the last three years, it was disclosed yesterday at a hearing by the Public Service Commission on the question of the propriety of this practice.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- A solution of the problem of the German banks, which have been virtually paralyzed since the crisis last Summer, will be attempted by means of sweeping relief action by the government, which is energetically pressing the matter and intends to decide this week upon the exact nature of the measures to be taken, so that a bill can be submitted to the Reichstag when it meets next Tuesday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with much interest your editorial headed "Unoccupied Hours." It may be of interest to know that there is an organization active in unemployment relief in the metropolitan area that not only provides relief for the physical needs of the unemployed but, in doing so, considers the necessity of mental help of which your editorial speaks.

A new architectural theory for the standardization of housing materials without standardizing the style of houses was discussed yesterday by Frederick J. Kiesler, Viennese architect, in an address at the Women's City Club, 22 Park Avenue, before about seventy-five members and guests.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- An indication that, another challenge for the America's Cup may be forthcoming from England soon was seen today in the adoption by the British Racing Union of a resolution touching on construction of cup boats.

PINEHURST, N.C., Feb. 17 -- Robert J. Breed of Danvers, Mass., defeated Thomas S. Jamison of Greensburg, the medalist, in the semi-final round of the first division in the annual seniors' golf tournament today, 1 up.

A further advance of about 6 to 8 points in prices early yesterday on the Cotton Exchange was followed by reactions. An active demand from the trade and some commission house buying seemed to be supplied by realizing and Southern selling at the early advance.

In ten years the city of Cleveland has treated itself to three charters. It has also had three styles of ballot. Whatever may be thought of the flinging-away of the city manager plan last Fall, the new ballot was simpler and easier than its predecessors.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 17 -- Princess Sibylle of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, who, reports say, will be the bride of Prince Gustaf Adolph, has arrived in Stockholm.

Characterizing the United Action for Business Recovery campaign as a patriotic endeavor as great as that which animated millions of men and women during the World War, leaders of the drive reported at a luncheon yesterday at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, that the first forty-eight hours had produced 29,404 jobs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Arrangements are being made for an authorized and complete edition of the letters of Grover Cleveland. Numerous letters by Mr. Cleveland are known to be in private hands throughout the country. We earnestly request all persons holding them to send either the originals or careful copies to the editor of the collection, Professor Allan Nevins, Columbia University, New York City.

Seven times in the last ten years the Senate has adopted the Norris resolution to change the date when Congress meets and thereby eliminate " lame duck " sessions. Six times the House has blocked the plan. Yesterday, however, it gave its approval by a vote of more than five to one.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Prime Minister MacDonald, wearing a patch over his left eye, was able to preside at a Cabinet meeting today for the first time since his operation a fortnight ago. Immediately after the session he went to Chequers, where he will rest several days.

Not being particularly parsimonious, the authors of "Face the Music," which was produced at the New Amsterdam last evening, have satirized not one subject, but three. Not only politics, but show business and the depression come under their musical comedy scalpel.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 17 -- President Enrique Olaya Herrera issued an executive decree today reducing interest rates for three years and protecting debtors against foreclosure. The decree may be extended for two years if considered necessary at the expiration of the three.

No word reached the New York Yacht Club last night from the Yacht Racing Association of Great Britain or the International Yacht Racing Union regarding a resolution to request a consideration of mast changes in Class J of racing yachts.
BERLIN, Feb 17 -- (AP) -- The Reichs-bank's statement as of Feb. 15 shows the following changes in reichs-marks:

Columbia's basketball team, champion of the Eastern Intercollegiate League for the past two campaigns, went into a tie for the leadership with Dartmouth last night by triumphing over an aggressive Yale five, 48 -- 23, in the Morningside gymnasium.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 17 -- A committee of cancer specialists at the University of Utrecht, after experiments lasting several months, announced today that the method of cancer research of Dr. S.G.T. Bendien, a Dutch physician, was without value in recognizing or fighting the disease.

The will of Miss Giulia P. Morosini, who died at her estate, Elmhurst, Riverdale-on-Hudson, on Feb. 4, was filed for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's Court of the Bronx. Relatives, employes, an old favorite horse, hospitals and several other institutions will benefit from the estate of the former horsewoman, who was believed to have inherited between $7,000,000 and $10,000,000 from her father, Giovanni P. Morosini, a banker and an associate of Jay Gould.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The apparent identification of the narcotics quadronal, reported found in the cabin of Miss Elizabeth Cook was the principal development here today as friends and relatives of the girl awaited the arrival of the steamer Chinese Prince, aboard which she died.

Details of life on a Western Pacific island whore every man is convinced that his wife is a witch and every woman that her husband is a sorcerer, where the major emotion is fear, are told by Dr. R.R. Fortune in "Sorcerers of Dobu: The Social Anthropology of the Dobu Islanders of the Western Pacific," published today by Dutton.

With Brig. Gen. Lucius R. Holbrook commanding the First Division as grand marshal, the George Washington Bicentennial parade Will march up Fifth Avenue next Monday afternoon, according to an announcement of plans for the military display given out yesterday at headquarters of the Second Corps Area on Governors Island.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- With his second premiere on consecutive nights, H. M. Harwood -- this time in collaboration with R. Gore Browne -- tonight at the London Playhouse got Miss Gladys Cooper into the headlines with what The Daily Mail describes as "a beautiful play," entitled "King, Queen and Knave."

What James Chapin did for the Marvin family Frederick Wight does for the people of Cape Cod. In a singularly fresh, unmannered and forthright style, Wight paints these seafaring men and duck hunters. His exhibition, at the Marie Sterner Gallery, has a good salt taang to it.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 17 -- A prediction that tomorrow's peace negotiations would almost certainly result in failure because the Nineteenth Route Army commanders would not agree to a withdrawal except with honor, which meant a complete Japanese withdrawal and the return of the army to Japan, wasvoiced tonight by Eugene Chen, former Chinese Foreign Minister, and Quo Tai-chl, former Vice Foreign Minister, after discussion of today's developments.

TORONTO, Feb. 17 (Canadian Press) -- The Ontario Liquor Control Board sold liquor and permits valued at 145,835,707 during the year ended Oct. 31, according to its annual report. Breweries and brewery warehouses sold $16,294,999, while the rest came from liquor commission stores.

Approval of four bills now pending in the Legislature for changes in the law and disapproval of ten others ware announced yesterday by the Committee on Criminal Courts Law and Procedure of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

Sino-Japanese Developments. SHANGHAI -- Japanese Army and Navy leaders yesterday arranged a peace conference with Chinese military leaders and promised that the great offensive would not begin today. Chinese leaders predicted the Japanese terms would not be accepted, largely because they would involve evacuation of the Woosung forts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- The financial plight of Chicago's local governments reached a stage today where Mayor Cermak threatened to close the City Hall, the schools and other essential departments unless the Legislature provided immediate relief.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 17 -- The Chinese are continuing to mass their forces and today, according to their own figures, they have about 120,000 soldiers in the immediate Shanghai area.

Bureaucracy in the Federal Government was attacked last night by Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland in a radio speech delivered over WJZ and a nation-wide hook-up of the National Broadcasting Company. Governor Ritchie is an announced candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 17 (AP) -- There are no thrills in shooting up the forts of Woosung, says Captain Jiro Saito of the Japanese Navy, like strolling along San Francisco's Barbary Coast twenty-odd years ago.

Dr. Sebastien Charlety, rector of the University of Paris and noted French historian, was invested with the honorary degree of Doctor of Literature yesterday afternoon by Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown of New York University at a private ceremony held in the council chamber of the university at Washington Square in the presence of members of the council, professors and university officers.

While union leaders announced that 3,000 additional dressmakers had joined the ranks of the 20,000 strikers on the second day of the walkout, the organized employers declared that the union was unjust in its treatment of their members and asserted they could not consider terms of a settlement until it was known what inroads the strike had made on the union shops.

Los Nanduces Uplifters and the Riding Club reached the final round of the high-goal division of the New York Athletic Club indoor polo tournament at the 105th Field Artillery Armory last night. The Riding Club defeated the First Division Polo Association, 9 1/2 to 8, in two extra periods.

With the Class A team championship of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League hanging in the balance, Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C., national amateur titleholder, and Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club, former wearer of the crown, met on the Winged Foot courts last night.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Victories by wide margins marked the second round of matches in the championship of Florida golf tournament today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note that the committee on criminal courts law and procedure of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York has aligned itself with those who are opposing modifications of the firearms law, which would make it easier for a citizen to procure and possess a pistol for the defense of his home and place of business.

It is important for an artist to have a style. Rudolph Ganz, pianist who played last night in Carnegie Hall, has a style. One listener may find it cold, unimaginative, lacking in nuance. He may say that this playing is objective and technical to the point of emotional impassivity.

OIL CITY, Pa., Feb. 17 -- Philip S. Tarbox, general manager of the Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation's independent plant, died suddenly today of heart disease. He had been confined to his home for a week with the grip.

Badminton, as played by professional champions, was introduced in the metropolitan area last night at the Heights Casino. The matches attracted a capacity crowd of more than 250 persons, and judging from the applause and keen interest evidenced by the gathering the sport gained many enthusiasts.

THE hockey race is going into the stretch now and the star-spangled Americans are down in the cellar of the International Group. It's a cold, cheerless place at this time of the year and Manager Eddie Gerard is naturally a trifle gloomy. He looked for better things.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- Mrs. Florence Kelley, distinguished welfare worker, who had been secretary of the National Consumers' League since 1899, died in the Germantown Hospital today in her seventy-third year.

"Bootlegging" of Bibles into the United States from European countries whose currency is depreciated threatens the existence of American publishers of Bibles, according to complaints made yesterday by some of them to the American Paper end Pulp Association, in session at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WOODBURY, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Police Recorder Frank L. Johnson, who sentenced three boys yesterday to be publicly whipped for disorder in a motion-picture theatre, a sentence which was forthwith executed in the court room, found himself the centre of a violent controversy today.

While the rate of operations for the steel industry at large was slightly lower in the last week than in the preceding week, "business sentiment" has improved as a result of "remedial measures now being taken in Washington and the announcement of the Ford Motor Company's plans for early resumption of volume production," according to the weekly review by The Iron Age.

United States Government bonds formed the strongest group in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday, all three issues of Treasury 3 3/8s, and the 3 1/8s and the 3s, making new highs for the year. Net gains in the government list ranged from 2-32 to 14-32 point.

Can it be that the engineers of the 25,000,000 passenger cars now in use are wrong? Sir DENNISTOUN BURNEY, designer of the British Zeppelin R-100, not only charges it, but proves it by producing a teardrop automobile in which a busy executive, traveling at eighty miles an hour, can read and write and eat and drink in perfect comfort.

Announcement was made yesterday of the formation of a new protective committee for shareholders of the Prairie Pipe Line Company and the Prairie Oil and Gas Company, with a view to blocking the proposed consolidation of those companies with the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Company on terms already approved by the managements of the companies.

The James Madison High School basketball team defeated Erasmus Hall in a Brooklyn Division, Group II, P.S.A.L. game on the former's court yesterday by the score of 32 to 31. Tarjesen tallied seventeen points for the winners. Despite the close score, Madison never trailed, leading at half time, 21 to 16.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Glass-Steagall credit expansion bill, centre of debate in the Senate today amid bipartisan efforts to hasten it to final passage, was advocated by Senator Glass as a measure which would accomplish the double purpose of inspiring American bankers with courage to assist business and place this nation in an impregnable defensive position against threatened gold raids from abroad.

The Continental Can Company's report for 1931 shows a net income of $5,670,699 after all charges and Federal taxes and after a deduction of $1,232,840 as a special reserve for receivable items. This income was equivalent to $3.27 a share on 1,732,985 no-par capital shares.

The executive committee of the Printers' League moved yesterday to confer with Major George L. Berry, president of the International Printing Pressmen's and Assistants Union of North America on a proposed wage reduction for Pressmen's Union 51, with 3,500 members.

Seventeen directors have retired from the board of the Sterling Securities Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Control of the trust was acquired by the Atlas Utilities Corporation last year and Melvin E. Sawin and John W. Donaldson, as representatives of that company, have been elected vice presidents, and O. L. Johnston has succeeded H. B. Brown as secretary.
NEW YORK. Sir Norman and Lady Watson of Reading, England, arrived on the Majestic and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.
DUBLIN, Thursday, Feb. 18 -- The Cosgrave and de Valera forces were running neck-and-neck this morning in the first returns of the Free State's general election.

At the present time there is no production of adequate housing for half the nation, according to Eugene H. Klaber of the American Institute of Architects, who suggests government aid to foster an increased buying power and to create renewed construction activity throughout the country.

"Those who think railroads have no future have not dug into the matter sufficiently," the trust division of the American Bankers Association was told yesterday by H.G. Parker, vice president of the Standard Statistics Company.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17 -- After exactly three months' stay at the Gaylord Farm Sanatorium in Wallingford, Albert J. (Albie) Booth, outstanding Yale athlete, today returned to Yale University.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The text of the President's message to Congress today on reorganization of the executive departments of the government was as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Roosevelt's address to the New York State Grange must be a profound disappointment to many Americans interested in our foreign policy. As a program, it contains no constructive suggestions. Instead, it expresses a negative attitude which would turn the clock back on advances already made by the United States in international cooperation.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Army, making an uphill fight from mid-time in the first half, overhauled the Penn State five today to win by 46-37.

The body of Harry Simms, 19-year-old miners' organizer, who was shot to death at Barbourville, Ky., last week, lay in state yesterday in an open coffin, half covered with a flaming red robe at the Workers' Centre, 35 East Twelfth Street. While honor guards of serious-faced Communist boys and girls, not yet in their teens, stood rigidly at attention throughout the afternoon, hundreds of sympathizers filed by the bier.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 17 -- The appearance of new cracks in the walls of the Lapidary Museum today reaulted in a hasty evacuation of that building, which was declared by engineers no longer fit to house its exhibits, which, being all of marble, represented a weight which the ancient structure was no longer able to bear.

Four players reached the second round in the world's open squash tennis championship tournament at the Shelton Club last night. Of the quartet who advanced, three went ahead on decisive victories, while the fourth gained the second round by virtue of a default.

So far as regards yesterday's stock market, it showed the footprints of professional speculators -- as indeed it has done, for the most part, ever since Wall Street's imagination was stirred by last Thursday's proposals at Washington. This time it was "profit-taking sales," which turned the course of prices downward after an early and brief advance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of THE TIMES dispatch telling of the death of Henry J. Raymond's grandson: THE NEW YORK TIMBS of Sept. 18, 1901, states that THE NEW YORK TIMES was founded by Henry Jarvis Raymond, George Jones and E.B. Wesley.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Describing hospitalization in New York City as a "big business" with an investment of $200,000,000 and a weekly expense bill of $1,100,000, Homer Wickenden, general director of the United Hospital Fund of New York, declared there was serious need of coordinated planning for the hospitals of the metropolis in an address before the Hospital Council of Essex County here today at St. Michael's Hospital.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Over Republican opposition, which brought out the declaration that the Federal Reconstruction Finance Corporation had agreed to finance the sale of the Camden-Philadelphia bridge and thus replace $6,500,000 of State funds diverted to unemployment relief, the Assembly passed today a bill which would turn over to the municipalities $13,000,000 of motor fuel tax funds for tax relief.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The stock market generally was firm today. Sterling was slightly lower in foreign exchange, the New York rate closing at $3.44 3/4 Revenue returns brought buyers of British Government funds, the war loan rising to u99.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Walter Spence and Norman Kramer took two first places each and swam in the 400-yard relay to give the Rutgers swimming team a 38-33 victory over N.Y.U. in the Ballantine Pool tonight.

With the ear-splitting din of a crowd of about 8,000 spectators ringing in his ears, Gene Venzke, Pottstown, Pa., schoolboy, last night ran the second fastest mile, indoor or outdoor, ever negotiated by a human being.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The State Department was disturbed today by unofficial reports that the Japanese reply to the Council of the League of Nations maintained Japan's position unchanged and, in addtion, was contending that if the Chinese forces withdraw from Shanghai she would undertake not to occupy Chinese soil indefinitely, nor seek monopolistic privileges.

Woodpulp converters, some of them having membership in the American Paper and Pulp Association, opened independent headquarters yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania, where the association is holding its fifty-fifth annual meeting, and announced that they were opposing the movement for woodpulp tariffs which many members of the association are supporting.

Mayor Walker conferred yesterday with William G. Fullen, chairman of the Transit Commission, and John J. Curtin, its special counsel, who are seeking active cooperation by the Board of Estimate in the public hearings to begin on March 1 on the commission's tentative $474,500,000 subway unification plan.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Governor Roosevelt's examination of Sheriff Thomas M. Farley as to the source of his income at the Albany hearing today follows:

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Sir Lindsay, famous steeplechaser and joint favorite with Grakle and Gregalach for the Grand National, was injured in a race at Newbury today and afterward it was declared his was a hopeless case and it was unlikely he ever would run again, according to The Express.

Jouett Shouse, chairman of the executive committee of the Democratic National Committee, quoted yesterday from a letter written by Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1920 to support his contention that it would be for the best interests of the party for State delegations to the national convention to go uninstructed so that the nomination for President might be kept open and the man regarded as best qualified at the time of the convention be named.

A report luncheon of the 200 volunteer workers engaged in raising funds for the Musicians' Emergency Aid will take place today at the St. Regis Hotel. Gifts totaling more than $190,000 from 1,600 contributors have already been received toward the $300,000 goal.
EDMONTON, Alta., Feb. 17 -- Albert Johnson, mad Arctic slayer, was cornered by a Royal Canadian Mounted Police posse today near Eagle River, Yukon, and killed in a gun battle.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Without explanation, State police have announced they intend to check "very carefully" Harry R. Blagden's story that he was kidnapped here last Thursday night.

One of the largest housing deals in Manhattan in some time was announced yesterday, when Dr. Theodorus Bailey, as president of the Bailiwick Realty Company, purchased the nineteen-story and penthouse building at the northeast corner of Broadway and Ninety-ninth Street for investment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Loans authorized by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation amounting to $500,056 were paid out of the treasury on Monday, it was disclosed by the treasury's daily statement made public today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 1, tonight, taking undisputed possession of first place in the International Division of the National Hockey League race.

Thirty-seven prizes were awarded yesterday in the competition for designs for small houses suitable for mass production, which was arranged by the Architects' Emergency Committee, 114 East Fortieth Street, for the benefit of unemployed architectural draftsmen in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Adoption by the Ways and Means Committee of a sales tax on manufactures as the backbone of the new levies was predicted today by Representative Rainey after the subcommittee, of which he is chairman, had spent the day in studying the proposal.

In a late decline yesterday, the stock market lost all of its gains of the previous day. Trading on the Stock Exchange was more or less colorless, so that Wall Street attached no great importance to the day's proceedings. The consensus seemed to be that the market, for the time being, is subject to the impulses which conflicting professional factions may be able to supply.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 17, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $1,795,000,000, a decrease of $12,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $855,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1931.

Nine-year-old John Elliott, son of an unemployed dock builder of 478 Forty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, stopped to romp with his brothers, Lawrence, 8, and Andrew, 5, on their way back to school yesterday afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 18. -- Blame for "creating" a new and "intelligent" class of criminals was put today on "general disregard for the law, especially the prohibition law," by Dr. Amos T. Baker, chief psychiatrist of Sing Sing prison.

A few scattered signs of improvement were observed in January, but business in general in that month declined under the level of activity in December, according to the fortysecond report, issued yesterday, of the Conference of Statisticians in Industry, operating under the auspices or the National Industrial Conference Board.

The speculative markets, which have lately elected to indulge in daily alternating hot fits and cold fits, presented signs of convalescence again yesterday. The advance in stocks, which followed as usual an early brief movement in the opposite direction, was itself followed by moderate advance in grain and cotton.

Like many unpretentious mystery plays, "Trick for Trick," which was acted at the Sam H. Harris last evening, has so much amusing hocuspocus here and there that you wish the whole thing were a little better. It is the story of a battle royal between two magicians -- the great La Tour, who boasts that he can explain every supernatural phenomenon according to natural laws, and his pupil, Azrah, who is his chief rival.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Java sugar producers tonight agreed to limit their 1933 quota to 1,350,000 tons providing Cuba consented to limit her 1932 quota to 2,350,000 tons. The agreement was reached at a conference over the Chadbourne Plan.

Approximately 51,000 pupils were graduated from the elementary and junior and senior high schools at the close of the Fall term recently, and while the girls showed a better average of success in the lower grades, they were outclassed by the boys in the high schools.

Many persons prominent in the civic, educational, political and cultural life of the State and nation gathered at the Waldorf-Astoria last night at a dinner in honor of Sir Norman Angell, British economist, author and legislator, and heard speakers from several countries agree that international cooperation is the surest way to peace.

Criticism of the Sanitation Department for doing little to improve the city's cleanliness is expressed in a letter sent to Mayor Walker yesterday by the committee of twenty on street and outdoor cleanliness of the Academy of Medicine, which listed a number of specific recommendations.

A first New York performance of Daniel Gregory Mason's Second symphony, memorable performances by Bruno Walter and his men of the Mozart E flat symphony and the orchestral part of the Brahms violin concerto and the thrilling interpretation of the latter work by Yehudi Menuhin made the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society given last night in Carnegie Hall.
