The separation of the Group Theatre from the Theatre Guild, under whose sponsorship the former organization this season produced "The House of Connelly" and "1931," became known, yesterday when it was learned that the Group Theatre's next offering, a play by Maxwell Anderson, would be presented independently.

Trading was erratic on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, some leaders advancing while others lost ground slightly. Recoveries occurred in the most active bonds as a rule, although some foreign issues declined again.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- Sir Charles Addis, director of the Bank of England, chairman of the Hongkong-Shanghai Bank, is one of the signers of a strong letter which appears in The London Times this morning urging the British Government to cooperate with the United States and the League of Nations.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The stock market received good stimulus today from the reduction in the bank rate from 6 to 5 per cent. Early irregularity quickly gave way to a generally firm tendency. The international group after opening dull gathered renewed strength.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- With the purpose of gathering into the treasury every possible return from the present income tax, the Ways and Means Committee today invited Secretary Mills to appear tomorrow to present his views on the proposed repeal or modification of the capital gains and losses law to prevent deduction from taxable incomes of large losses in the stock market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- No diplomatic action will be taken by the State Department at this time on the ultimatum delivered by the Japanese to the Chinese forces at Shanghai today. The situation was considered by Secretary Stimson and his advisers, and afterward it was said that the conclusion was reached that any new move at this time would be of no avail.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- An economy wave promising immediate slashes in personnel and budgets was started today by officials of Chicago's "bankrupt" local governments.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding decreased $12,992,948 in January to $961,066,402. This decline compared with drops of $28,000,000 in December and $37,000,000 in Novemher. It is interpreted by the American Acceptance Council, which compiles the figures, as indicating, apparently, that the low point for acceptance volume had been reached.

Increasing activity in the drive for delegates on behalf of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt has been exerted in the last few days in the hope of keeping to a minimum the number of delegates that Alfred E. Smith will control at the Democratic National Convention.
LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The British public tonight viewed the prospect of a de Valera government in Ireland with some curiosity but complete unconcern.

PARIS, Feb. 18 (AP). -- The Infanta Eulalia of Spain said tonight she believed she had located $1,000,000 worth of jewels which she had reported lost and which she said she planned to sell so that former King Alfonso's daughter, Princess Beatrice, and Prince Alvaro de Bourbon-Orleans might be married.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- Halting here to deliver two addresses as part of the celebration of "Farm Week," Governor Roosevelt today opened a swing through the western portion of tha State in which official business was mingled with solidification of strength in the area for the coming Presidential contest.

Arthur C. eKrwin, Board of Education inspector, was dismissed yesterday after the board had approved, by a vote of four to two, the report of a, special investigating committee sustaining charges of bribe-taking.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was considerably less active than on the day before, but the performance was much more satisfactory, from the Wall Street viewpoint. Colorless and dull up to 2 o'clock, the market swung upward rather sharply in the last hour and closed on the strongest note of the day.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 19. -- The Chinese will not accept the Japanese ultimatum presented yesterday, demanding that the Chinese permanently evacuate an area of 400 square kilometers in Shanghai and north and east of it, and both sides are busily preparing for the crucial clash.
MUKDEN, Feb. 18. -- The independence of Manchuria and Inner Mongolia was formally declared today by the new Northeastern Administrative Committee.

Government control of the oil industry, with legislation to prohibit production in excess of consumption or market demand was urged last night by Amos L. Beaty, president of the American Petroleum Institute, in an address at the annual dinner of the petroleum division of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, which marked the close of the institute's 141st meeting.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 18. -- After staging a mass meeting of thousands of its supporters last night, the government called for and won a vote of confidence in Congress today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18. -- Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., women's national golf champion, and Miss Maureen Orcutt of Haworth, N.J., Canadian titleholder, won their semi-final matches today in the Florida championship tourney.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- While no opposing voice was raised, the speeches of those advocating the Glass-Steagall credit expansion bill in the Senate today precluded a vote until tomorrow. During the debate a letter was introduced from Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, revealing that under the existing law the Federal Reserve Banks would be able to meet a demand for only $430,000,000 in new currency or release that amount of gold for export.

Replying to opponents of the proposed merger of the Prairie Pipe Line Company, the Prairie Oil and Gas Company and the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation, W.F. Gates, president of Prairie Pipe Line, sent yesterday a letter to stockholders of his company in which he announced that more than 71 per cent of the company's stock had approved the consolidation.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18. -- A band of jubilant Giant athletes, eager to get down to the important business of preparing for a pennant race, a lofty purpose which had brought them more than 3,000 miles across a continent, reached Los Angeles today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The action of the governing board of the New York Stock Exchange in restricting the lending of stocks from April 1 for an indefinite period was received in Congressional circles here as a constructive step. There was a difference of opinion, however, whether the decision would head off the consideration of legislation aimed at the regulation of sales on the Exchanges.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 19. -- The Foreign Office today corrected its statement of yesterday that the first draft of the note from the Council of Twelve of the League of Nations to Tokyo originated in Washington. Inquiries at Geneva have shown it was prepared there.

CAIRO, Feb. 18. -- A fourth pyramid at Gizeh has just been discovered and its ownership has been definitely established as that of Queen KhentKawes. The discovery was made by Professor Selim Hassan of the Egyptian University.

Samuel Untermyer, in a statement issued on his behalf here yesterday, endorsed the Delaney plan of subway financing as the one means, if any at all exists, of saving the 5-cent fare on the city's rapid-transit lines.
Within the next five years Soviet Russia will achieve a place equal to the United States in the amount of tonnage carried on her railways, according to Charles A. Gill of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad.

After a somewhat irregular start yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced on buying that appeared to be stimulated by the firmness of the late Liverpool market, combined with the strength of wheat and stocks. May contracts advanced to 7.08 cents a pound, and October to 7.49 cents, making new high marks for the present movement.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The directors of the Bank of England today gave concrete proof of their belief that the worst of Great Britain's financial and economic depression is over. To the immense relief of the financial community they reduced the bank rate from 6 per cent to 5 per cent.

A decision which may have an important effect on landlord-tenant litigation in the municipal courts was handed down by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, yesterday. The decision upholds the right of a defendant in a summary proceeding, such as an eviction action, to ask judgment in a counterclaim for amounts in excess of the $1,000 limit imposed in ordinary municipal court proceedings.
NEW YORK. The Cuban Ambassador, Orestes Ferrara, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

Charles M. Schwab, who at 18 was a grocer's clerk at $2.50 a week, at 35 was president of the Carnegie Steel Company and at 41 was beginning the upbuilding of his own Bethlehem company into a $700,00,000 industry, celebrated his seventieth birthday yesterday jovially among his friends, sentimentalizing about the steel business.

Contributions totaling $220,514 were announced yesterday at the fourth weekly report luncheon of the Musicians' Emergency Aid at the St. Regls Hotel. Speakers on the various committees urged the more than 100 voluntary workers present to make renewed efforts to complete the goal of $300,000 set by the relief organization at the beginning of the drive.
Money market carried over another day without change either in quotations or business. Rates in all sections continued firm on a turnover that represented routine requirements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Bishop James Cannon Jr. was challenged in the House today by Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts to arange an open court trial of the clergyman's $500,000 libel suit against him.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Feb. 19. -- The continuous flood of gold from Chinese abroad cabled to Shanghai as patriotic donations to support resistance against Japan serves enormously to hearten and encourage the Nineteenth Route Army and other troops engaged in this area.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 18. -- T. Philip Perkins of New York, former British amateur champion, and Howard A. Tryon of Detroit, routed A. P. Lawton of Providence, R.I., and H.B. Money of Wilmington, Del., by 11 and 9 in the first round of the Miami Biltmore 36-hole four-ball tournament at the Miami Biltmore Country Club today.

Bond prices continued their upward trend on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with United States Government issues again leading the list. Total transactions, however, fell below $11,000,000 for the first time in several days, altfiough government issues showed increasing activity, with the net result that eight issues of this group made new highs for the year.

President HOOVER'S report that his appeal of a fortnight ago has been followed by release of hoarded cash is interesting. He is apparently correct in saying that the recent increase of hoarding has been checked. It was not stated how he obtained his estimate of $34,000,000 returned to circulation since Feb. 4.

The New York Central Railroad is considering an application to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan of about $7,000,000 to provide for the completion of certain projects in its west side improvement plan. Application may be made within a few days.
LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The situation of G.W. Watson, outlined in his letter to THE TIMES, is typical of thousands of individuals, and, in view of all the circumstances, who can blame them for hoarding currency? They have seen their life savings shrink terrifically as the result of purchasing securities which for years were considered perfectly sound, and correspondingly there has been an alarming decline in their income.

DURANGO, Col., Feb. 18. -- An urgent appeal for assistance was received today by Durango officials from storm-bound Silverton, fifty-one miles west of this city, which has been isolated for nineteen days.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 18. -- Dazzling Providence College with, a brilliant attack, especially in the first half, the City College of New York quintet triumphed tonight, 37 to 20. Providence made only seven points in the opening half, while the New Yorkers, with Davidoff scoring eight points and Spahn nine, led at half time, 23 to 7.

The seven-story store and office building at 99-101 Beekman Street, corner of Pearl Street, has been sold by Henry Lehman to a client of the Rosenberg-Murray Company, broker in the deal. The property was sold for all cash above the first mortgage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Two New England Governors appeared before the Interstate Commerce Commission today in opposition to Eastern trunk line penetration of that territory as planned under the four-party alignment of railroad consolidation, while one testified in support of it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The World Court issue will probably be placed before the Senate within two weeks, after lying dormant in the Foreign Relations Committee for more than a year.

Resolutions protesting against the proposed Federal tax of 1 cent a gallon on gasoline and any increase of the gasoline tax by the States were adopted yesterday by the directors of the American Petroleum Institute. The resolution said that gasoline consumption was decreasing, and that any additional levies would accelerate the decline.

Terminating a sequence of twentythree declines which had continued from Sept. 2, brokers' loans advanced $13,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. The rise carried the total of loans to brokers and dealers reported by the Federal Reserve Bank yesterday to $499,000,000 which, except for the previous week's figure, was the lowest reported since Jan. 25, 1918, when brokers' loans were $473,438,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The administration's drive to end hoarding will centre around the issuance at an early date of low-denomination, bonds to "give the hoarding public something with which to replace the currency now cached in the tea pot or the safe deposit box."

The identities of eleven prospective purchasers of memberships in the New York Stock Exchange through transfer of rights at prices equivalent to $135,000 for each membership were revealed yesterday by the Exchange. The names of five men who proposed in the last week to purchase Stock Exchange memberships, exclusive of rights, at prices ranging from $134,000 to $175,000, were also disclosed.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18. -- The 4-year-old coit Don Leon, which has been performing so creditably for R.W. Collins, won again at Hialeah Park today, annexing the Palatka Handicap to the surprise of many observers. The son of Lee O. Cotner and Water Willows finished the six furlongs a half length before Panetian, which got second by three lengths over Vander Pool, the favorite.

Methods of combating the narcotic evil were discussed yesterday at the fifth annual conference of committees of the World Narcotic Defense Association and the International Narcotic Education Association at the McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Collections of internal revenue for the first seven months of the 1932 fiscal year totaled $944,636,000, a decrease of $529,286,000 from the same period of 1931, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

George W. Wickersham, as president of the New York State Economic Council, Inc., yesterday at- tacked the Republican legislative leaders for not having further reduced the budget submitted to them by Governor Roosevelt. He characterized as "mere cheese-paring" their reduction of $21,000,000.

The difference of opinion among members of the American Paper and Pulp Association concerning the methods that should be used in dealing with the dumping of chemical wood-pulp in the American market by European countries having depreciated currencies reached the breaking point yesterday.
GENEVA, Feb. 18. -- The knot in which the disarmament conference was certain to become entangled was tied and double hitched today when Ambassador Rudolph Nadolny laid Germany's proposals before it.
CASTLE HARBOR, Bermuda, Feb. 18. -- The weekly gala dinner dance at the Castle Harbor Hotel has been advanced from Saturday to Thursday. Among those attending this evening were:

DUBLIN, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Eamonn de Valera, the lanky Spanish-Irishman who once was under sentence of death for his unending battle against England, became a real possibility tonight as the next President of the Irish Free State Cabinet.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18. -- Led by the relay team, which shattered the national intercollegiate 400-yard record, Yale's swimmers turned back the Dartmouth squad, 48 to 23, in Carnegie pool tonight.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP). -- In a copyrighted story today The Boston Post says that Miss Elizabeth Barrett Cook, Brookline heiress, who met death at sea under strange circumstances on the freighter Chinese Prince, died a victim of her own hoax.

In the most drastic reform introduced since the country-wide controversy over short selling began, the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that, beginning April 1, its member firms would be required tc obtain the express consent of customers before their stock could be lent to protect commitments on the down side of the market.
The Manhattan College quintet easily beat the Baltimore University five, 32 -- 19, at the Manhattan gymnasium last night, easily overcoming the visitors' early lead.

The United Action Group for Employment, which began Monday a drive to find jobs for 1,000,000 persons, reported yesterday at its headquarters at the Hotel Biltmore that in the twenty-four hours ended at noon yesterday employment had been found for 11,195, bringing the total to date to 41,125.

A further expression of Dr. Oswald Spengler's conviction -- given earlier in "The Decline of the West"-- that Western civilization has reached its peak and must soon be destroyed, makes up his new book, "Man and Techniques -- a Contribution to a Philosophy of Life," published today by Knopf.

Mrs. Michael E. Paterno of this city and Irvington-on-Hudson gave a reception with music yesterday afternoon in the Jade and Basildon rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria. Palms, cybotium ferns, forsythia and Spring flowers were used in the decorations. An interesting feature of the entertainment, which took place in the Jade room, was the dancing by Vicente Escudero, Spanish dancer, and Carmita.
MONTREAL, Feb. 18. -- Twelve thousand enthralled spectators echoed their approval as Miss Sonja Henie, world's and Olympic figure skating champion, was acclaimed the 1932 world's titleholder tonight.

The first rocket experiment of the American Interplanetary Society will be carried out next month in open country at Red Hook, N.Y., G. Edward Pendray, vice president of the society, announced last night at a meeting of the organization at the American Museum of Natural History.

Dan Breen, who has been elected in Tepperary in the Irish election, is a 37-year-old veteran Irish revolutionary and a former commandant in the Irish Republican Army. He has not only been imprisoned, but has been wounded about twenty times since he began in 1914 to fight for Irish independence.
DUBLIN, Friday, Feb. 19. -- Eamon de Valera and his Republican party were maintaining' a narrow lead early this morning in the Irish Free State elaction Tuesday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 18. -- Judging of the ski jumping event in the Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, N.Y., was criticized today by Julius Blegen, coach of the United States team, who recommended that a protest be filed with the International Ski Federation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- While speculative interest in wheat on the Board of Trade was not large today, the undertone was distinctly firm. Prices, after dipping early, started upward and closed within a fraction of the top at net gains of 7/8 to 1 cent.

Divided We Stand One of the Liberal members of the MacDonald Government, Sir DONALD MACLEAN, recently undertook to explain the arrangement by which he and a few of his Cabinet colleagues were left free to oppose the government policy on tariffs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- The combined support of House Republican and Democratic anti-prohibitionists will be sought soon for a measure that would legalize 2.75 per cent beer and establish a tax of 3 cents a pint on the new beverage.

James Doolittle, speed flier, made the fastest flight on record between Cheyenne, Wyo., and Newark Airport yesterday when he covered the 1,650 miles in eight hours and thirty minutes. Using a Lockheed-Vega, Doolittle carried a cargo of still and motion pictures depicting the Japanese occupation of Shanghai.

WOODBURY, N.J., Feb. 18. -- In the interest of the good name of their community, parents of the three boys who were publicly flogged here last Tuesday in the court room of Police Recorder Frank L. Johnson, announced tonight that they would take no legal action against the recorder.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP). -- Willie Macfarlane, Tuckahoe (N.Y.) veteran, and Dick Metz, San Angelo (Texas) youngster, burned up the Palma Ceia golf course today to tie for medalist honors in the $4,000 Gasparilla open golf tournament with 36-hole scores of 136.
World Examining Works, store, basement, second and fourth floors in 344 West Thirty-eighth Street, from Rhinebeck Holding Corporation; Schuster, Fine Mayleas, brokers.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18. -- Mrs. Sydney Emlen Hutchinson who, with her daughter, Miss Frances Hutchinson, is a guest of her father, Edward T. Stotesbury, at El Mirasol, gave a small dinner there tonight. Mrs. Stotesbury is in Havana and is expected to return early next week.

FORT SCOTT, Kan., Feb. 18 (AP). -- A receivership for the Prairie Pipe Line Company, removal of its president and three directors and prevention of its proposed merger with the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation and the Prairie Gas and Oil Company were asked in a suit in equity filed today in Federal District Court here in the name of Lionel F. Straus of New York, holder of 1,000 shares of Prairie Pipe.

Louis Maurer, only surviving member of the illustrious firm of Currier Ives. "Printmakers to the American People," will be 100 years old next Sunday. By way of celebrating this centenary, the Old Print Shop at 150 Lexington Avenue has arranged an exhibition of some of Mr. Maurer's prints, many of them dating back to the middle of the nineteenth century.

Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is advocated in 84 per cent of the ballots received for the first tabulation by States in the nation-wide prohibition poll by The Literary Digest, it was announced yesterday.

KEARNY, N.J., Feb. 18. -- Norman Oldham, 20-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Oldham, was burned to death tonight in an effort to rescue his brother's three small children, who he believed had been trapped by fire that destroyed the Oldham house, at 294 Ivy Street here.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- A concurrent resolution proposing a constitutional amendment to provide a method of permanent registration of voters was passed without opposition in the Senate today. The proposal was sponsored by Senator Perley A. Pitcher, Republican.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The British Yacht Racing Association's decision to approach the New York Yacht Club concerning a revision of the weight rule of Class J yachts in no way indicates a possible British challenge for an America's Cup race, according to Major Brooke Heckstall-Smith, secretary of the association.

The unnamed but celebrated spokesman for the Tokyo Foreign Office, who long ago took his place among the masters of curt and candid prose, rises to new heights in his comment on the note addressed by the Council of the League of Nations to the Japanese Government.

Bank clearings continued their downward trend in the last week, despite various favorable business developments, including increased stock market activity, according to R.G. Dun Co. The total reported from twenty-two leading cities of the country was $4,763,567,000, a decrease of 40.9 per cent from the corresponding week last year.

The Rev. William S. Winans, former assistant pastor of the Central Congregational Church, Brooklyn, died on Wednesday night at the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. He suffered an attack of heart disease on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Warning that the strife in China showed "that size and population are in themselves no protection," Representative Vinson urged on the House of Representatives today speedy passage of his $616,000,000 naval building program, to give notice that this country intended to take its part in maintaining the peace of the world.

Assets of the Equitable Life Assurance Society increased from $1,284,286,000 at the end of 1930 to $1,400,232,748 at the end of 1931, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Thomas I. Parkinson, president, in the report makes a plea for more favorable treatment of mutual life insurance companies by those dictating the tax schedules of the various governmental agencies.

Modern civilization will never be safe, "no matter how many leagues and pacts and disarmament treaties we may create," until the five great Western powers have determined to understand each other, to support each other and to unite, in the opinion of Walter Lippmann, New York editorial writer, who spoke last night from Geneva in an international radio broadcast transmitted in this country.

FREIBURG, Baden, Feb. 18. -- Richard Hageman's opera, "Tragedy in Arezzo," or "Caponsacchi," which is based on "Caponsacchi," Arthur Goodrich's dramatic version of Robert Browning's "The Ring and the Book," was presented for the first hearing on any stage at the Freiburg Stadt Theatre tonight.

State of Nebraska. A movement to enable the State of Nebraska, which has no bonded debt, to Issue bonds for $30,000,000 for highway construction purposes has gained considerable impetus as the result of a resolution adopted by the directors of the Nebraska Good Roads Association calling for a vote in November on a proposal to amend the State's Constitution to permit the sale of the bonds.

Although Jewish farmers throughout the United States are feeling the effects of the economic depression, there are no indications that they are leaving their farms, according to the annual report of the Jewish Agricultural Society, issued yesterday by Gabriel Davidson, general manager.

Fifteen persons were hurt yesterday afternoon when a Fort Hamilton-Fiatbush bus crashed into an automobile at a busy Brooklyn intersection, hit a steel electric light pole and then, with its injured driver helpless, raced wildly for several blocks and ran head-on into three taxicabs parked at a stand in the centre of the street.

PARIS, Feb. 18. -- President Doumer called upon Paul Painleve this morning to form a new government and after twelve hours of interviewing and consultation France's scientist-politician was able to report to the President late tonight that he had high hopes of succeeding.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 18. -- Complete slates of Democratic National Convention delegates had been entered by both the Roosevelt and the Smith forces in New Hampshire when the filing of candidacies for the March 8 Presidential primary was closed today by the Secretary of State.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 18. -- Leaders of the Japanese adventure at Shanghai admit with dismay and bewilderment that Japan, in the five months since the Manchurian adventure was begun, has lost much of the world's sympathy and approval.
Several apartment houses were sold yesterday in the New Jersey metropolitan area. In addition there were scattered taxpayer and dwelling deals.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 18. -- English champion at 11 months, Heather Reveller of Sporran, noted Scottish terrier, owned by S.S. Van Dine of New York, completed his American championship today at the opening session of the annual dog show of the First Company Governor's Foot Guard Athletic Association held in the High Street Armory.

Governor ROOSEVELT may or may not remove Sheriff FARLEY from office. The certain thing is that on Wednesday he laid down a principle which not only would justify removal but would, if enforced, strike terror into the hearts of all Tammany officeholders and go far to break up the system under which they live and move and have their being.

Three creditors of the Dimon Steamship Corporation, 24 State Street, with claims totaling $9,249, filed a petition of bankruptcy against the company yesterday afternoon in the United States District Court. Efforts of the major creditors, who have attempted to keep the company out of receivership, were threatened by the action, causing Major Henry F. Holthusen, their counsel, to ask that the petition be denied.

Dr. Henry Illoway, former writer and professor at the Cincinnati Medical College, who died at his home, 1,113 Madison Avenue, on Jan. 15, bequeathed his large library of Hebrew works and a trust fund of $1,000 to the Jewish Theological Seminary of 531 West 123d Street, it was revealed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogates' court.
PARIS, Feb. 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

The extraordinary winning streak which has been run up by the New York University co-ed swimming team was continued last night with a victory over the Savage School team in the American Woman's Association Club pool. The N.Y.U. girls scored by 32 to 21 for their twenty-eighth consecutive triumph.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 18. -- A record - breaking performance by Bernie McCafferty, Holy Cross College star, in which he set a new armory track standard of 1:12.6 to win the special 600-yard Waldron Memorial Trophy race, was one of the outstanding features of the sixth annual Seton Hall College Athletic Association meet at the 113th Infantry Armory tonight.

Michael C. Clohessy, an electrician who has been in the employ of THE NEW YORK TIMES for seven years, was in a critical condition at the Coney Island Hospital last night whence he had been taken after an assault upon him by four men on Wednesday evening.

The Montreal Maroons strengthened their hold on third place in the international division of the National Hockey League by defeating the New York Americans, their bitter rivals for the play-off berth, at Madison Square Garden last night. Before a crowd of 5,000 persons, comprising the smallest gathering of the season, the rugged puck-chasers from the North tallied once in each period to win by 3 to 1.
TOKYO, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Japan's policy toward China-how firm or how mild -- is but one issue in the Japanese election Saturday.

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., Feb. 18 The body of Sister Lowell Bernard, 67-year-old nun of the Dominican Sisterhood, was found here today in the ashes of St. Hyacinth's Roman Catholic School, a forty-year-old, three-story frame structure, that burned to the ground last midnight with a loss estimated by Fire Commissioner Cox as between $50,000 and $75,000.

The world's visible supply of coffee on Feb. 1 was 37,259,510 bags, comparing with 37,245,599 bags on Jan. 1 and 32,134,234 bags at the beginning of February, 1930, according to statistics of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. This includes coffee stored in interior warehouses in Brazil and also that owned and controlled by the government of Sao Paulo.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 18 (AP). -- The Jamaica Colts defeated the touring English cricket team on the first innings score at the conclusion of a two-day match. The young Jamaicans today declared their first innings at 286 runs for the loss of ten wickets, one run more than the English Tennyson's team scored in its first innings yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- The round-by-round story of the Dempsey-Levinsky fight tonight follows:

Westchester County residents who have been fighting the plans of the Niagara Hudson Power Company to string high tension overhead wires through the county lost a point in the legal battle yesterday. The Public Service Commission adopted an opinion by its counsel, Colonel Charles G. Blakeslee, in which Colonel Blakeslee advised the commission not to go to court and seek an injunction against the building of the eighty-foot towers for the high tension lines.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I state some facts known to ma on the subject mentioned in your editorial "Memel and the Corridor"?

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date and the ratio of reserve at the New York bank to be at the highest. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.

With a burglar alarm siren sounding and patrolmen converging on foot and in squad cars upon them, four robbers, their pockets bulging with, jewelry valued at $30,000, slipped through the police net and escaped shortly before 10 o'clock last night after a daring robbery of H. Lekowitz's jewelry store at the corner of Grand and Eldridge Streets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- A bill authorizing the Secretary of War to proceed with improvement work along the New York State Barge Canal, recommended by the army engineers in 1930, at a cost of $50,000,000, was introduced in the house today by Representative Gavagan of New York.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- A blow is aimed at "racketereeing" in the condemnation of property wanted by New York City for public purposes, such as parks, docks, water supply or rapid transit lines, through a series of eight bills introduced today by Senator Dunnigan, Democratic leader.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 18. -- Simple ceremonies are planned for the transfer of government at 5:30 o'clock on Saturday evening, when General Agustin P. Justin and Julio A. Roca will take their oaths as President and Vice President respectively. Later they will receive the Ministers and greet foreign diplomats.

The greatest loss sustained in this country during the current depression has been "the public lack of confidence in our leaders, political, financial and business," Thomas C. Hennings, vice president of the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis, said last night.

In discussing plans for additional taxes some members of Congress seem to believe that $1,241,000,000 is the amount needed in new revenue if the Federal Government is to balance its budget during the fiscal year which begins next July. Unfortunately, this figure is too small.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18. -- William Gibbs McAdoo announced today a preference for John N. Garner of Texas for the Democratic Presidential nomination. The former Secretary of the Treasury, who was a candidate for the nomination in 1924, said that under the Speaker of the House all elements of the party should be able to unite, and in that case his election would be certain.

Control of James A. Hearn Son, Inc., Fourteenth Street department store, has passed into the hands of a group of bankers and cotton textile concerns headed by F.A. Powdrell, chain store and textile executive, it was disclosed yesterday. The new interests, whose identity was not disclosed, will place new capital ranging up to $1,000,000 in the business, according to Mr. Powdrell, who has been elected treasurer of the store, succeeding Clarkson Cowl.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 18 (AP). -- A confusion over names led the police into a renewed investigation today of the kidnapping of H.H. Blagden, New York State sportsman who disappeared last Thursday night and appeared here five days later.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Wholesale prices in the United States in January showed a further decline of 2 per cent below those of the previous month, reaching a level of 14 per cent below that for the same month last year, the Labor Department announced today.

The seventeenth week of the current Metropolitan Opera season next week will be marked by the season's first performances of "La Juive," "Romeo et Juliette" and "Das Rheingold," which will begin the annual matinee presentation of Wagner's "Ring" in its entirety, without cuts.

HAVANA, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Jockey Johnny Gilbert, the riding ace of the Cuban race meeting, again dominated the program at Oriental Park as he scored with three of his mounts today. He also placed second with May Agnes K. in the second race and third with Czarist in the sixth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- House Democrats' resentment against President Hoover's message urging a wide program of bureau consolidation was voiced today by Representative Byrns, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, who took the floor early to charge Mr. Hoover with insincerity.

Net income of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company for 1931 after depreciation, federal taxes and all other charges was $1,401,061, equivalent after preferred dividend requirements to $1.79 a share on 674,648 common shares. In the preceding year the net income was $4,011,578, or $5.56 a share, on 685,648 common shares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Additional credits of nearly $100,000 to Juan Leguia, son of the former President of Peru, from the National City Bank, the Chase National Bank and the Royal Bank of Canada were revealed today by the Senate Finance Committee.

IT wasn't the time alone -- 4:10 flat for a measured mile -- that caused the delirium in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night. It was the whole picture and the background and the way in which the feat was accomplished.

In 1924, after the investigation of the naval oil leases began, HARRY M. BLACKMER, former chairman of the Midwest Refining Company and official of the Continental Trading Company, fled to France. Other persons whose testimony was wanted in the famous cases that grew out of that investigation also skipped to foreign parts and laughed at the Government.

An investigation into the fire Wednesday night in the Palace Theatre which resulted in the injury of eight persons was started yesterday by Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy. After he had questioned nine wit- nesses he declared last night that the cause was still undetermined and that his efforts would continue.

Mrs. Jessie D. Hayden Wiggin, wife of Albert H. Wiggin, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, exhibited her first finished piece of sculpture yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Art Galleries.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No one doubts that every country has the right to recognize or not the governments of other countries. As regards American nations, the rule has been modified by the Pan-American principle which calls for good understanding, close relations and solidarity among all the countries of this continent.

PARIS, Feb. 18. -- Prices continued firm on the Bourse today, the market being uninfluenced by the Cabinet crisis. Toward the close a slump set in, but it affected the internationals for the most part, and even Wall Street's slackened activity left Paris indifferent.

PARIS, Feb. 18. -- Prices continued firm on the Bourse today, the market being uninfluenced by the Cabinet crisis. Toward the close a slump set in, but it affected the internationals for the most part, and even Wall Street's slackened activity left Paris indifferent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- In his speech on his bill Mr. Vinson said:

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 18. -- An order approving an application of the receivers of the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company to issue $15,000,000 in receivers' certificates in a refunding move designed to take care of the railroad's obligations for the next three years has been entered here by Judge Luther B. Way in United States District Court.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 18. -- The rumbling echoes of Japanese shells fired over Shanghai roofs tonight, coupled with the news of Japan's sweeping demands made upon China, finally convince even the most skeptical that a real first-class war exists in the Far East and that regardless of Tokyo protestations that the present conflict is merely a local affair the whole China coast will soon be subjected to assaults from Japan.

The Columbia rowing squad, consisting of eleven crews, made its season's debut yesterday on the Harlem River in a clear but frigid setting. It was the earliest outdoor start ever made by the Blue and White oarsmen, and Coach Richard J. Glendon expects to keep his pupils on the river each day unless a change of weather forces them back indoors.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- Jack Dempeey's pubilistic come-back ran into a stone wall tonight.

Advocating a uniform minimum prison sentence for first offenders, Dr. Walter N. Thayer, State Commissioner of Correction, listed yesterday "many glaring instances" of first offenders who are serving long sentences.

Sharp price advances were registered in a majority of commodities yesterday, particularly contract grains, which rose from a fraction to upward of a cent; cotton, which soared 11 to 14 points, with spot at a new high for the year. Other articles to improve were sugar, cocoa, hides and eggs. Slight losses were recorded in coffee, rubber and lard.

CAPE TOWN, Feb. 18. -- It was officially announced today that the De Beers diamond mines, the most famous in the world, were closing down. The Premier and Jagersfontein mines are certain to follow suit.

Sheriff Thomas M. Farley "was in great pain" from bruises received it a fall during the entire time he was trying to satisfy Governor Roosevelt's demand for an explanation of his bank deposits, his physician declared yesterday.

Adolph Feldblum, impartial chairman of the dress industry since last July, communicated with the three employers' associations and the dressmakers' unions yesterday, offering to mediate the issues in the strike, which will enter on its fourth day today with mass picketing by 15,000 men and women.

The advisory council of the Association of Railway Executives took steps at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to act on the suggestions for reductions in railway expenditures made by the Interstate Commerce Commission in its decision authorizing the freight rate surcharges put into effect in January.

American dollars at the rate of one million a day were poured into Latin America during the three years, 1926, 1927 and 1928, and little of the total has been put to productive use, Thomas F. Lee, banker and authority on Latin-American affairs, declares in his book, "Latin-American Problems -- Their Relation to Our Investors' Billions," published today by Brewer, Warren Putnam.

January Retail Collections Off. Retail collections during January dropped 3.46 per cent, according to figures based on an index of twenty local stores, it was announced yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The decrease compares with a drop of 1.23 per cent in December and was the largest for any month since last September.
In the first overtime game it has played in two years the Fordham University basketball team triumphed over Penn State, 38 to 37, in the Fordham gymnasium last night.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Ed Haughton's Wotan, which has jumped from a cheap claimer to a high-class performer in a few months, kept his consistent Winter turf record intact when he won the James Rowe Jr. Memorial Handicap over one and one-sixteenth miles at the Fair Grounds today.

Newspaper headlines used to refer to Mrs. FLORENCE KELLEY as a "woman radical." She was enough of a radical all her life long to get at the roots of things, and enough of a woman to ask, on one occasion, those who, in the name of sex equality, sought the repeal of the welfare laws which she cherished:

SHANGHAI, Feb. 18. -- The complete alienation tram China of all three of the Manchurian Provinces. Inner Mongolia and Jehol, and the establishment of an independent government in a separate new nation, will be an accomplished fact greeting the League of Nations commission when it reaches China early in March.

GENEVA, Feb. 18. -- The committee of six jurists of the Council of the League of Nations decided tonight to overrule the legal points raised by Japan against China's convocation of the League Assembly to consider the Far Eastern dispute.

TORONTO, Feb. 18. -- Ousted for a day from a deadlock for the leadership of the National Hockey League's international section, the Toronto Maple Leafs stepped back to a firstplace tie with the Montreal Canadiens when they defeated the New York Rangers, 5 to 3, tonight.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- With the exception of rentes, which, were irregular owing to the uncertainty over the Cabinet crisis, the slock market continued to improve today. There was some buying for investors and even provincial orders. The continued strength of the Bourse surprises professionals because of the small volume of business done and the little encouragement to be drawn from the political and economic situation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The reception, growingly hostile, which Congress has given to the President's plan for government economy was foreseen by his own party advisers. At least one effort was made to avoid it. On excellent authority it was reported today that Representative Snell of New York, Republican floor leader, asked Mr. Hoover not to send in the message of Wednesday outlining a plan immediately termed "idiotic and astounding" by Speaker Garner.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- King George praised the fortitude shown by his people in critical times and made a fervent plea for the success of the Geneva disarmament conference today.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Coach Bill (Kid) Gleason will be missing when the Athletics make their official departure tomorrow night for their training camp at Fort Myers, Fla.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent survey of students in the University of Chicago Law School which was discussed in THE NEW YORK TIMES, and according to which students with three years of college training seemed to succeed better in the professional school than four-year students, need not disturb the academic mind unduly.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The General who strode into the Argentine capital almost a year and a half ago, taking over the government by threat of arms, will stride out tomorrow in favor of a duly elected President.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 19 -- The peculiar attitude toward their parents of children who run away from home, steal or get into any sort of trouble with society was described by Dr. Horatio W. Newell of the Cleveland Mental Hygiene Clinic before the annual meeting of the American Orthopsychiatric Association.

The train bearing what was listed officially as the vanguard of the Robins left last night from Pennsylvania Station for the Spring training camp at Clearwater, Fla. Paradoxically, however, there was not a single Robin on the train. Furthermore, there was no club attache on board.

MANILA, Feb. 19 -- Some Filipino leaders here are turning strongly against Section 6 of the Hawes-Cutting bill, to which the mission in Washington has presumably acceded, setting a limitation on the amount of cocoanut-oil exports at 63 per cent of the copra imports of the previous year.

Thirty-seven communities throughout the country will be in the market next week with new bond issues aggregating $20,329,672. Banking interest will centre largely in the offering of $5,000,000 city of Newark (N.J.) various improvement bonds on Tuesday and the proffering of $4,790,000 city of Buffalo (N.Y.) bonds on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Chemicals and poison gas have been developed until they now constitute the most humane and effective instrument of war the world has ever known, Representative Collins of Mississippi told the House today.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 19 -- Governor William H. Murray is openly in the race for the Democratic nomination for President.

An exhibition of prints in various mediums by artists ranging from Delacroix through the moderns has just opened at the Keppel Galleries, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street. This may seem at first glance a rather long vista to be confined within the boundaries implied in the exhibition's title, "Masters of Modern Art."
BREMERHAVEN, Feb. 19 -- Just before the Europa sailed for New York today her two most distinguished passengers, Gerhart Hauptmann and Dr. Sven Hedin, met aboard for the first time in seven years.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Dr. Ira Solomon Wile of New York was elected president of the Orthopsychiatrists' Association.

Before one of the most enthusiastic crowds ever to pack the exhibition room at Jack Doyle's Billiard Academy, Walter Lindrum, 33-year-old Australian wizard, who holds the world's championship at English billiards, last night defeated Tom Newman, former holder of the title.

Lily Pons appeared for the first time in this city as Lakme last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. The pretty opera of Delibes was revived for her, and rightly, for the music is very suitable to her voice. Now "Lakme" is better adapted for a small theatre than the Metropolitan, but it charmed the audience.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Concern for the safety of foreigners in the International Settlement at Shanghai occupied the attention of government officials in viewing the Sino-Japanese crisis as the zero hour of the Japanese ultimatum arrived tonight.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 20.-- A few minutes after 7 o'clock this morning, five Japanese scout planes sped into the air and reconoitred over the Chinese positiOns in Chapel. It was a thick, foggy day, but the airmen could see enough to indicate that the Chinese front lines were in- tact -- that the Chinese army was defying the ultimatum, which expired at 7.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- An immediate favorable report on the nomination of Judge Benjamin N. Cardozo as an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States was approved unanimously today by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 19 -- The new Manchurian nation, while it will immediately establish its own customs service and institute a new tariff system applicable to Manchuria's needs, will not attempt to avoid payment of Manchuria's just proportion of China's foreign indebtedness secured by customs revenues.

ROME, Feb. 19 -- Two British aviators named Hamilton and Coupland reached Rome airport today on the second stage of an attempt to beat J.A. Mollison's flight record of nine days from England to Australia. They were expected at 9 o'clock last evening, arriving, more than fifteen hours behind schedule, through a mishap over the Gulf of Genoa which almost cost them their lives.

SAMARA, Russia, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A realistic drama of a well-organized band of forty modern thieves came to its climax here today with the sentencing of one of them to death and the mysterious murder of the Communist attorney appointed by the court to defend them.

Under a continuation of the buying movement, prices advanced yesterday in early trading on the Cotton Exchange, carrying the May up to 7.18 cents a pound, or 55 points above the low level of last week. After this demand had been supplied by realizing or Southern selling, the market reacted to about Thursday's closing quotations.

The controversy over the location of the reproduction of Mount Vernon for New York City's celebration of the bicentennial of George Washington's birth was settled yesterday with a decision to place it, in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, and to erect a reproduction of Federal Hall in Bryant Park, west of the New York Public Library, where some of the most important functions of the celebration will be held.
NEW YORK. Colonel and Mrs. Edward M. House are now in Charleston, S.C.

State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced yesterday that a preliminary investigation of companies that have been selling real estate bonds in this State discloses that 500,000 investors purchased more than $500,000,000 of these securities on which dividends are now in default.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- More than 100 members of the Garden Club of Palm Beach and representatives of similar organizations throughout the State were luncheon guests today of Mrs. Harry R. Rea, vice president, at Lagomar, her ocean front estate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- The decision handed down yesterday by the Public Service Commission with relation to the efforts of Westchester citizens to atop the construction of an overhead high-power tension line through the county was not a final decision, according to Supervisor Joshua M. Fiero Jr., counsel to the supervisor's special committee on power lines, who expressed confidence that the final decision would be more favorable.

PARIS, Saturday, Feb. 20 -- At 3:30 this morning Paul Painleve wearily gave up his intense efforts stretching over nearly forty-eight hours to form a new government to succeed Pierre Laval's. Just as everything seemed settled and he had decided definitely to form a Cabinet of the Left, taking a chance on squeezing through the Chamber of Deputies next week, something happened which upset all his plans.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 19 -- Hundreds of American residents who live in the most dangerous spots in Shanghai were advised by United States Consul General Edwin S. Cunningham today to evacuate these areas for points of greater safety either tonight or tomorrow morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- A group of railroad executives, bankers and manufacturers rode today over the Reading tracks between Wayne Junction and Bridgeport in a newly developed pneumatic-tired railroad car which, its sponsors hope, will enable railroads to recover shorthaul passenger traffic now lost to motor buses and save additional branch lines from abandonment.

Following advances of 1 to 7 points at the opening as frightened bears were driven to cover by the overnight announcement of additional restrictions on short-selling, the stock market turned sharply about yesterday afternoon and gave up the greater part of its early gains.
Commemoration of the bicentennial anniversary of the birth of George Washington by religious groups will begin this morning.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- British observers were confident tonight that Eamonn de Valera would be held in check by Labor and by the conservatism of Ireland's farmers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Declaring that "constitutional offi- cers are seeking new sources of taxation, and to nearly all of them is being brought home the forgotten fact that sources of taxation are not without limit and cannot with impunity be tapped simultaneously by every kind of government," Governor Roosevelt urged in The Yale Daily News today, a complete readjustment of Federal, State and local taxation systems.
HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Otto Matiesen and Duncan Renaldo left here several days ago on an automobile trip to the East.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 John D. Rockefeller Sr. and Sir Malcolm Campbell, British holder of the world's automobile speed record, exchanged felicitations on the golf course here today as the 93-year-old philanthropist finished his daily round.

Robbers escaped with a total of $2,420 yesterday in three hold-ups, two in the Bronx and one in Manhattan. In a fourth attempted robbery in Manhattan the "victim" punched a would-be bandit who quickly fled.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 -- A brilliant sun and a deep blue sky greeted the Giant on their second day of training this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Hoover in a statement today condemned short selling for speculative profit on the New York Stock Exchange and said that he and other administration officials had frequently expressed the view to managers of the Exchange that measures should be taken to protect investors from "artificial depression" of the prices of securities they hold.
Philosophy of Platitude. When THACKERAY came to this country he was asked: "What do they think in England of MARTIN TUPPER?" His reply was: "In England we don't think at all of MARTIN TUPPER."

While there is little evidence of positive improvement in business, sentiment remains optimistic and trade in most centres is holding its own, according to the weekly reviews of the mercantile agencies. Bradstreet's observations to this effect are based on information received from fifty-five leading cities.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The success of President Hoover's policy of "reflation" to prevent further deflation under compulsion of bank stringency and to undo some of the present extreme deflation depends much, according to the current issue of The Economist, on confidence in both the United States and Europe.

Those who have summered and wintered with Tammany for many years understand perfectly that its methods of political corruption are combined with human and neighborly qualities. This must never be forgotten when the effort is made to estimate the political power which Tammany wields.

At a foreclosure sale yesterday the Sherman Square studio apartments at 160 West Seventy-third Street were struck down on one bid of $500,000. The buyer was announced as Teresa Mahoney, said to be acting for a syndicate. Edwin J. McDonald was the auctioneer.

Gold to the value of $7,427,500 was dispatched to Europe yesterday and $2,167,100 of the metal was released from earmark. There were no imports here, but the Federal Reserve Bank received word that $129,000 had arrived at San Francisco from China.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 19 -- Bettors at the four major horse-racing tracks in Maryland sent more than $47,000,000 tumbling through the pari-mutuel machines during the 1931 meetings, according to the annual report of the Maryland Racing Commission just issued.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 19. -- "My impression is that the Chinese forces around Shanghai are not likely to accept Japan's ultimatum, but if they have not evacuated the front trenches by 7 o'clock tomorrow morning I'll take the necessary action," General Kehkichi Uyeda said at Japanese Army headquarters at 3 o'clock Friday afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The longer one lives with the peace problem, the more one is impressed with the fact that the progress of society depends upon finding the effective formula. Almost all constitutional, legislative and diplomatic action revolves around determining a form of words which will be at once acceptable to the interests concerned and which will define the condition to be met.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 20 -- Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, newly appointed Governor of the Philippines, who arrived here with his wife and their daughter Grace yesterday evening, had an audience with Emperor Hirohito at noon today.

John M. Grant, newly elected president of Transamerica Corporation, took charge yesterday of the New York offices or the organization, which have been without executive direction since last Monday, when the sweeping victory of A.P. Glannini in the proxy fight for control of the corporation resulted in the resignations of Elisha Walker, chairman; James A. Bacigalupi, president, and most other officers under the former management.

Robert Smalls, a 15-year-old Negro boy, confessed last night in the Ralph Avenue police station in Brooklyn that he had strangled Florence McDonnell, 5 years old, whose body was found in the cellar of a tenement at 232A Ralph Avenue on Feb. 4. The youth said he killed the little girl because she had "snitched" on him when he played truant from school.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Jimmy Walker has done much to advertise New York to the world, but not a bit more than "General" Jacob S. Coxey, as Mayor, is doing for his home city of Massillon. At least that is the opinion of the, "General."

SHANGHAI, Feb. 19 -- Chapel, from which hundreds of thousands of refugees have streamed into the International Settlement since the beginning of the hostilities twenty two days ago, was today again the source of a constant rush of frightened civilians, who by the tens of thousands crossed all the Soochow Creek bridges into the zone of comparative safety.

Definite indications of a cessation of the liquidation of municipal bonds which has disrupted the market for several months were reported here yesterday by municipal bankers and brokers. In recent weeks the dumping of sizable blocks of State and municipal bonds onto the market for what they would bring reached such proportions that new financing was virtually excluded.

TOKYO, Feb. 19 -- The dullest general election campaign Japan has known since manhood suffrage was granted will close tomorrow when 676 candidates contest 427 seats, thirty-nine candidates having been elected unopposed. Three hundred and twenty-six are Seiyukai party adherents, 288 Minseto and thirty-four Labor, divided among three groups.

The campaign against depression waged by the United Action Group for Employment restored 11,458 wage earners to jobs in the twenty-four hours ending at noon yesterday, it was announced last night at the national headquarters of the campaign at the Hotel Biltmore.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 19 -- The Rev. Dr. Stanislaus G. Bende, 39 years old, pastor of the St. Ladislaus Hungarian Roman Catholic Church of 215 Somerset Street, was burned to death in the rectory of the church when he was trapped in the hallway of the blazing structure early this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Glass-Steagall credit expansion bill was passed in the Senate late this afternoon without roll call. Only a few voices were heard in opposition. The bill was sent to conference with the House, which approved it in different form on Monday by the overwhelming vote of 350 to 15.

Articles to retail at 20 cents will be sold in stores of the F.W. Woolworth Company, marking a departure from the policy of handling only 5 and 10 cent lines maintained for fifty years, it was announced yesterday by H.T. Parson, president. Beginning March 1 new lines at the higher prices will be added in 100 stores of the 1,905 comprising the Woolworth chain throughout the country.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- While Clarence C. Pell, national titleholder, advanced to the second round as he started play in the national racquets championship today, two unexpected victories were scored by young Boston players.

A description of some of the original entertainment features which will make the Rockefeller midtown development a world-wide influence in music and theatrical fields" was given by S.L. Rothafel (Roxy) in a speech yesterday before the New York Building Congress in the Commodore.

John Theofel, Queens County Democratic leader, followed yesterday the lead of John H. McCooey, Brooklyn leader, by naming a strictly organization slate of delegates to the Democratic National Convention. Petitions bearing the names of the organization choices, to be voted on at the primary on April 5, were put in circulation yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 - Dewey Bentham's Martis, the five-year-old son of Sir Martin-Flying Jib, was the surprise winner of the Orange Blossom Handicap, feature at Hialeah Park today, when he got up the stretch and won by a head from Prince Tokalon, the favorite.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- The French Government today gave tangible evidence of its intention to carry on with its contingent system of restricting foreign imports by extending the quota established a few months ago on salted, smoked and canned fish.
An industrial deal and several housing transactions were reported yesterday in the New Jersey metropolitan area.

Believing that granting permission for increased height in buildings in East Forty-second Street would greatly increase traffic congestion in the Grand Central zone, the Board of Estimate denied yesterday an application for increased heights in the area bounded by Forty-second and Forty-seventh Streets, a line 100 feet east of Third Avenue and a line 100 feet east of Lexington Avenue.

GENEVA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Mexico will accept a reduction of armaments to a minimum compatible with internal security, its spokesman, Francisco Castillo Najera, told the world disarmament conference today.
It was a short fight and a merry one last night, the return ring engagement between Eddie Ran, Polish welterweight, and Billy Townsend, the rugged fighter from Vancouver.

An assemblage of travelers at the Forrest Theatre last night experienced a mid-Winter crossing from New York to Cherbourg in a farcecomdy of that name which was listed as the work of H.G. Buller. It was rough going, for the S.S. Oceanic, as the glimpses afforded by the stage settings indicated, was anything but a luxurious and sturdy ocean greyhound.

The full story of the two carefully concealed operations for cancer performed on President Grover Cleveland in 1893, shortly after his second inauguration, is told by Dr. James H. Tobey in his new book, "Cancer: What Every One Should Know About It," published by Knopf.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Charles C. Peterson of St. Louis gained four points to trail Isidro Ribas of Havana by only one point in their five-city fancy shot billiard match as a result of tonight's play.
The F.L. Realty Corporation gave a $4,000 demand mortgage, at 6 per cent, to Frank Garofalo on 309 East 110th Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Some Senators favoring Governor Roosevelt were jubilant today over former Secretary McAdoo's advocacy of Speaker Garner for the Democratic nomination for President, because they believed that it destroyed any idea that the quarrels of the 1924 convention would be duplicated through inheritance by the Governor of the Ku Klux Klan support.
LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- British farmers have demanded a 10 per cent tariff on meat and wool as well as on other non-empire imports covered by the government's new tariff measure.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Winning its first Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet of the season, Rutgers defeated C.C.N.Y., 46 to 25, in the Ballantyne pool today.

VIENNA, Feb. 19 -- After fourteen years without capital punishment, Austria is likely to see the reintroduction of the death penalty if Premier Karl Buresch can obtain Parliamentary support of his wishes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Cooperating in the President's anti-hoarding campaign, Secretary Mills announced today that a special certificate of one-year maturity, redeemable on sixty days' notice and carrying a low interest rate, would be made available for purchase through the banks of the country.

IT must have been bitter for Jack Dempsey, the old Manassa Mauler, to stand on weary legs in that Chicago ring and have a clown fighter like Kingfish Levinsky give him a contemptuous gesture to "come on an' fight."

Considering the overnight excitement occasioned by the Stock Exchange's decision to stop the indiscriminate lending of stocks to speculators for the decline, the eccentricities of yesterday's market caused no surprise. The sharp advance at the opening here was due mainly to urgent coverings by frightened shorts.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 20 -- The great array of military strength that Japan has been massing here during the last few weeks was flung against the Chinese positions along a sixteen-mile front from Shanghai to Woosung this morning in the great- est military action since the World War.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Mrs. Sanford Cresci, 39 years old, wife of a former borough official of Vineland, and her three young children were drowned today in Tumbling Dam Lake here after, the police believe, she hurled the children into the water and then leaped in with them.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A bill providing for transfer of the State Housing Board from the Public Works Department to the Department of State has been introduced in the Senate by Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter, who sponsored the multiple dwellings law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The treasury's views on suggested changes in the administrative provisions of the present revenue law were presented to the Ways and Means Committee today by Arthur A. Ballantine, Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

Joseph Rao, Harlem gang chief and ally of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, who was believed to have been the "target" for gang bullets that killed a child in 107th Street last July, was sent to jail yesterday for conspiracy to commit extortion. Four other members of his gang have been jailed on the same charge.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES printed a dispatch from London informing us that there will be no opera at Covent Garden next Summer; that instead the financial reserves will be used for the giving of opera in English next Autumn. The dispatch further states that this step will obviate the necessity of exporting capital, since no foreign artists will be engaged.

Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, from his bed in Flower Hospital told interviewers yesterday that he would not hold it against Governor Roosevelt if the latter removed him from office, but he intimated that he would like another opportunity to explain the sources of his bank deposits.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- To the accompaniment of high-class music and song in the Royal Albert Hall, for which 25 cents admission was charged, the British motoring public had the opportunity today of judging Henry Ford's new eight-horsepower automobile.

The report of Dr. FREDERICK KEPPEL as president of the Carnegie Corporation calls attention to the reaction against lavish grants by foundations of wide scope for general research programs and surveys, in favor of specific enterprises conducted by individuals of recognized ability.

The Marine Estates Corporation has sold four taxpayers at 6,324, 6,326-26a and 6,328 Avenue N, Brooklyn, held at $35,000. The plot is 60 by 100 feet. Ohnewald Denlinger, the brokers, also sold for Harry and Gertrude Senft a dwelling on a plot 40 by 105 feet at 1,078 East Thirty-first Street, near Avenue J, held at $14,000.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Rejecting a strong plea by Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Democratic National Executive Committee that uninstructed delegates be sent to the National Convention, the Florida Democratic Executive Committee at a meeting here today voted to hold a Presidential preferential primary on June 7, as suggested by friends of Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Cannot some concerted action be taken at this time to inflate the highest rated interest-bearing securities rather than inflate our currency and thereby deflate the dollar, which will ultimately have an adverse effect on bond prices?

The committee for the Third Leap Year Assembly to be held on Feb. 29 in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton announced yesterday that owing to the large number of early subscriptions received, the lists for the dance were closed about two weeks ago.

GENEVA, Feb. 19 -- The League Council sat tonight with all eyes and ears on the clock. The hands moved fast. As the Council sat the clock struck four successive hours. To the silent crowd of many tongues each tick said, "War is nearer, nearer, nearer."

Thomas F. Manville Jr., only son of the founder of the Johns-Manville Corporation, disclosed last night that he has been receiving threatening letters recently. Mr. Manville refused, however, to reveal any details about the letters. He explained that he had reported the matter to Police Headquarters and had been advised not to discuss the case with any one.

China is incapable of self-government and should be placed under international control until she learns to rule herself in peace, free from the domination of war lords who have divided the country, Herbert S. Houston, a member of the American committee of the International Chamber of Commerce, declared yesterday before the Woman's Forum at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Project and studies for decorations in fresco by Isabel Whitney, one of the few professional frescoists in the country, are on view at the Fifteen Gallery, through Feb. 27. Nearly all these delicate pencil and watercolor projects have been carried out in homes in the vicinity of New York.

This country must develop a "relational" society to replace the Individualism of the pioneer, which it has outgrown in life but retains in law, Dean Roscoe Pound of the Harvard Law School said yesterday in an address at the annual meeting of the City College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa at the Hotel Biltmore.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:

BALTIMORE, Feb. 19 -- "Debunking" of history in schools in so far as making clear the causes of war is concerned, will be urged in a resolution being prepared today for presentation tomorrow at the convention here of the Progressive Education Association.

In as spectacular a match as has been seen on a local squash tennis court in many seasons, Harry F. Wolf of the New York A.C., national amateur titleholder, defeated Leo Collins, coach at the Union League Squash Club, last night in the world's open championship at the Hotel Shelton.

To enable his friends to make a fight for delegates to the Democratic National Convention in California and Massachusetts on even terms with candidates pledged to Governor Roosevelt, former Governor Alfred E. Smith is being urged to broaden his candidacy for the nomination for President to the extent of filing formal consent to placing his name on the primary ballots in these States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- With both parties jockeying for position in the House today to carry out the recommendations of President Hoover for stricter economy in departmental management, the Democrats moved to report out an economy resolution with a view to cutting off a number of government offices.

More than 150 churches and synagogues, most of them in Brooklyn, have endorsed a petition in protest against the electric light rates charged by the Brooklyn Edison Company in its new rate schedule, placed in effect last July, which instead of reducing the old rate as promised, has increased the monthly charges more than 30 per cent, it was announced yesterday by E.F. Jeffe, engineer, representing the petitioners.

The listed bond market, as a whole, did little more yesterday than hold its ground. A scattering of individual issues, notably railroad loans, made sizable gains, while in many other groups early advances in sympathy with stocks failed to hold until the close of the market.

Members of the Glazed and Fancy Paper Association, holding their eighteenth annual meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, heard a statistical report showing that the total business of their industry in pounds in 1931 was only 1.12 per cent below the total for 1830.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Newton D. Baker, who was Secretary of War in President Wilson's Cabinet, joined today with President A. Lawrence Lowell of Harvard University and other college presidents and publicists in a petition urging President Hoover and Congress to signify to the League of Nations that the United States "will concur in economic measures it may take to restore peace" in the Far East.
The holiday exodus for George Washington's Birthday began last night with thousands quitting New York by rail, motor, air and bus.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Maurice Browne decided today to resume production of John Hastings Turner's "Punchinello," which recently was closed after a run of three days.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP) -- The first thread of a two-and-a-half-year-old Pennsylvania murder mystery was unraveled here today with the announcement by the police that Anthony Bell, 38 years old, former Fayette (Pa.) County detective chief, had confessed his part in the murder of John Donohoe near Masontown, Pa., in July, 1929.
Strength in the major commodities -- the grains and cotton, featured. Rubber WAS another to move higher. Irregularity was noted in sugar. coffee and hides.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Partially atoning for their setbacks in the Olympics, Norway's speed skaters swept through to victory in the first two races of the world's championships today.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 20 -- The Chinese Government rejected General Uyeda's ultimatum last night in a reply written by Wang Ching-wei, to whom the Chinese Government entrusted full power to cope with the crisis. He announced at Nanking the gist of his reply, which contained five points, as follows:

While more than 15,000 dress strikers paraded the garment district yesterday in what was said to be one of the largest picketing demonstrations ever arranged, several moves were made to shorten the strike, which began last Tuesday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Iron play which furnished some of the most brilliant golf of the season carried Miss Maureen Orcutt of Haworth. N.J., Canadian champion, to a victory of 1 up over Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L.I., women's national titleholder, in an extra-hole match for the Florida championship today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- There was one man in the boxing world tonight who was certain that Jack Dempsey still could come back. It was the old Manassa Mauler himself.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Curtailment of Chicago's police and fire protection was the chief recommendation in Mayor Cermak's economy program presented this afternoon to the Council as a result of the city's financial embarrassment and the prospect that no funds will be available to pay municipal workers for a long time to come.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (.P) -- Georgs L. Crooker of Providence, R.I., member of the New England Governors' Railroad Committee, told Chairman Porter of the Interstate Commerce Commisson today that he thought the Boston Maine Railroad should be unified with the Chesapeake Ohio.

The annual Dixie Dinner Dance of the New York Southern Society was held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event since its inception twenty-six years ago has attracted many Southerners now living in New York and has been marked by special features attendant upon George Washington's Birthday.

Appeals to President Hoover to urge the ratification by other nations of the Geneva narcotics convention of 1931 and to the Senate for speedy ratification by this country were among the resolutions adopted yesterday at the fifth annual conference of committees of the World Narcotic Defense Association and the International Narcotic Education Association at the Hotel McAlpin.
E.D. Gallaudet of the Yale Club, seeded No. 2, met an early disaster in the national Class C squash tennis championship tournament yesterday afternoon at the Park Avenue Squash Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 -- Chinese of this city have collected within the past few days and forwarded to China more than $1,000,000 gold to support the Chinese Army against Japan, Arthur G. Wong of the Bank of Canton here announced tonight. The collections are continuing.
The Cathedral Boys High basketball team clinched the Manhattan division C.H.S.A.A. championship by defeating lona School, 32 to 11, yesterday at the East Fifty-fourth Street gymnasium.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 19 -- With department chairmen of the American Legion and the auxiliary from eight States in attendance, the organization's fifth annual child welfare conference was opened in the Soldiers and Sailors War Memorial Building here today.

The spiritual emotions of children should be cultivated at the same time as their intellectual and physical growth, Dr. Leon W. Goldrich, director of the Bureau of Child Guidance of the Department of Education, told a group of social workers and teachers yesterday at the annual meeting of the Children's Welfare Federation of New York City, Inc., at 99 Park Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- Criticizing the policy followed by this country and its bankers in making foreign loans, John B. Stetson Jr., former Minister to Poland, said at the Wharton Alumni Institute of Business here today that it was only when loans were made "with strings to them" that they resulted in real benefit to the lending country.
