Philanthropic grants made by the Carnegie Corporation from the income of a $115,000,000 endowment fund left by Andrew Carnegie, totaled $3,279,000 during the year ended Sept. 30, 1931, according to the annual report of Frederick P. Keppel, president, made public today.

Nearly everything else having been satirized this season, the radio is now serving its turn in "Wild Waves," which was acted at the Times Square last evening. It is the work of William Ford Manley, who has practiced the radio profession personally, and as one of the chief actors it offers Osgood Perkins, who can make almost any play seem plausible.

Mrs. James J. Davis, wife of Senator Davis of Pennsylvania; Judge and Mrs. E.J. Henning, Mr. and Mrs. J.J. Pelley and Louis S. Levy, New York lawyer, are among the passengers booked to sail today for a cruise to the West Indies and Central America on the French liner France.

HALIFAX, N.S., Feb. 19. (Canadian Press). -- Their faces gaunt and haggard and covered with heavy beards, ten members of the crew of the rum-runner Whichone brought their crippled motor-vessel into Hallfax Harbor yesterday after a ninety-one-day voyage from St. Pierre.

Demand for furs has declined in this period of depression, but according to a bulletin of the Department of Agriculture, the "fur catch" has not been good for the past five years. The chief cause is "over-trapping in the face of reduced breeding areas."

Murdered by underworld enemies and their bodies crammed beneath the closed rumble seat of an automobile, William (Wolfy) Burke and Augrie Marine, known to the police as burglars, gunmen and extortionists, furnished detectives yesterday with another gangland mystery.

While some of the market leaders reacted under profit-taking on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, the undertone of most stocks was firmer and numerous gains appeared among inactive issues. The bond market also continued strong, except some German issues in the foreign group and a few of the highly active domestic issues.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP) -- E. F. Prichard's Weideleen, a 4-year-old daughter of Paul Weidel, won her second race of the Winter season when she accounted for the Orleander Purse, a six-furlong event for fillies and mares, at the Fair Grounds today.

Three men, two of them former convicts, were convicted by a jury in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions shortly after 6 o'clock last night in the kidnapping of Sidney Mann, owner of a meat market at 90 First Avenue, for a $1,000 ransom on the night of Oct. 13.
"WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Six weeks of bearings on a bill to legalize 4 per cent beer were closed today with about 280,000 words of direct testimony on both sides of the question in the record.
SHANGHAI, Saturday, Feb. 20 -- Shanghai is writhing this morning with the torch of war against her breast. The battle is irrevocably joined and now only force can decide the issue.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Premier Inukai called on Emperor Hirohito last night and was understood to have submitted grave decisions for his approval. His move came after an important Cabinet meeting at which Minister of War Araki warned that Marshal Chiang Kai-shek was reported to be leading heavy reinforcements into the Shanghai lines in defiance of the Japanese demands.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Heather Reveller of Sporran, the noted Scottish terrier owned by S.S. Van Dine of New York City, which completed his championship yesterday, tonight was judged best in show in the annual exhibition of the First Company Governor's Foot Guard Athletic Association, which came to a close in the Foot Guard Armory with a capacity crowd in attendance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "A Tax on Manufacturers" states regarding the 4 per cent Canadian manufacturers' tax that "Pyramiding of the tax is avoided by a system of licenses."

DUBLIN, Saturday, Feb. 20 -- Eamonn De Valera appeared fairly certain early this morning of forming a new government, becoming the second President of the Irish Free State Council. For years he was known as the "first President of the Irish Republic."
William Tilden, world's professional tennis champion, returns to Madison Square Garden tonight to engage Hans Nusslein of Germany in the fifth and deciding match of their title series.

The Juilliard School of Music, which presented the new American opera "Jack and the Beanstalk," by Louis Gruenberg and John Erskins, as the first of its productions in the new auditorium, went back two centuries and more for its second opera production of the season.

The $7,000,000 loan for which the New York Central Railroad contemplates applying to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation would be used for yard and right-of-way improvement on the west side. It is expected that application for approval of the loan will be made next week to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The slogan of Abraham Lincoln's second campaign, "Don't swap horses while crossing a stream," was recalled in a House speech today by Representative Wood of Indiana, chairman of the Republican National Congressional Committee, who was urging a second term for President Hoover.

On the basis of complete reports, to be made available within the next few days by Borough Presidents and city department heads, the Board of Estimate is prepared, it was disclosed yesterday, to carry out as far as possible the recent recommendation by Controller Charles W. Berry that some $213,509,000 of unencumbered balances of authorizations reserved against the debt limit be immediately rescinded.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Endorsement of both "wets and drys" was claimed in the House today for Speaker Garner as a Presidential possibility. Representative Blanton, an ardent dry, predicted that Speaker Garner would sweep the country because "the people believe there is something here besides the liquor question."

Net income of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company for 1931, after estimated income tax, all charges and depreciation, was $746,167, equal after preferred dividends to $17.03 a share earned on 40,000 common shares, compared with $713,321, or $16.21 a share, earned in 1930.

OTTAWA, Feb. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Hostilities between China and Japan had repercussions in the House of Commons today, eventually leading to the first vote of the session. Colonel J.L. Ralston, former Minister of National Defense, ran foul of parliamentary rules when he vainly endeavored to precipitate a discussion of the proposal of officers and men of the Royal Canadian Air Force to organize flying units for China.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The stock markets again were good today, dealers reporting an increase in the volume of business. British Government funds continued to rise following the reduction of the bank rate. The war loan touched L100 1-16 before closing at L100, the highest since the eve of the last general election.

If one can't be nominated, one can nominate. Mr. BRYAN was an industrious namer of candidates deserving the Democratic nomination for President. Is Mr. McADOO going to imitate that illustrious example? Mr. BRYAN liked to encourage obscure merit.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Two boys in a family of five brothers are dead today and the others, with their father, Samuel Patitucci, a cobbler, are seriously burned as the result of a fire in their home in Dragston last night following a kerosene lamp explosion.

Woosung and Chapel, the region where China and Japan are now preparing for a settlement of their quarrel, form a natural fortress. It is part of an alluvial plain, intersected in every direction by thousands of miles of canals and creeks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The text of the Glass-Steagall bill, as passed by the Senate, is as follows:

The directors of the Electric Bond and Share Company voted yesterday to call a special meeting of stockholders for March 22 to consider and act on a proposal to change the present common stock, which is without par value, into common stock with a par value of $5 a share on the basis of an exchange of three present shares for one new share.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard adjourned the hearing on a petition in bankruptcy brought by three creditors of the Dimon Steamship Corporation when counsel for an opposing group of creditors charged yesterday that the claims of the petitioners were untrue.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 19 -- John L. Stonebam, 42 years old, an attorney, with offices in Aatoria, L.I., was held without bail for the grand jury by Justice Walter R. Jones this morning on charges of subornation of perjury after Assistant District Attorney Martin W. Littleton Jr. declared that the lawyer had been operating a divorce mill, through which almost 1,000 fraudulent divorces had been obtained.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Governor Roosevelt replied today to Republican charges of extravagance in his administration. Asserting that the increase in governmental expenditures lay at the door of local units, he once more demanded that genuine economies be exercised.

Survey to Include Small Stores. For the first time, small stores having net sales of from $100,000 to $500,000 annually will be included in the survey of merchandising and operating statistics for 1931 now being undertaken by the controllers' congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday by H.I. Kleinhaus, manager.

Another boy violinist, Noah Bielski, made his first appearance in concert here at Carnegie Hall last night. This lad, a native and resident of Brooklyn, is said to be 10 years old, and looked even younger in what is becoming the recognized child prodigy regalia -- white shirt, open at the throat; knee-length velvet trousers, black slippers and black and white socks.

Harold T. Brown, manager of the Detroit Harbor Terminal, who testified last Thursday in Federal court that Louis Chinal, a detective employed by the Sugar Institute, had offered him a bribe of $50,000 to $100,000 for the records of W.A. Edgar Son, sugar brokers, was asked yesterday if he had not drugged Chinal with knockout drops and if he had not brandished a pistol while the two were in a Detroit speakeasy last May.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 19 (AP) -- J.E. Pearman of Bermuda, the defending champion, entered the final round of the Riddell's Bay Golf Club men's championship for the Warwick Vase today by defeating Col. J.L. Miller of the Chester Golf Club, Chester, N.S., 1 up in a close match.

The money market was listless. Notwithstanding the good supply of funds on offer the demand from Stock Exchange call funds was poor, and the rate of 2 1/2 per cent was maintained on the board, while 2 1/4 prevailed in the Street market. Time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were steady in tone.

Although the Manhattan swimming team captured four first places in seven events against New York University yesterday, the Violets triumphed over the Jaspers, 35 to 27, in the London Terrace seventy-five foot pool. It was N.Y.U.'s third victory over a metropolitan rival this season, the Violet having defeated Fordham and City College in previous meets.

Drug, Inc., reported yesterday net earnings for 1931 of $19,433,237 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes, minority interest and other charges, equivalent to $5.55 a share on 3,501,499 shares of no par capital stock. This compares with net earnings in 1930 of $21,123,430, or $6.03 a share, excluding the equity in $1,138,275 of undistributed earnings of affiliated companies.

America's oldest living artist, Louis Maurer, who will be 100 tomorrow, hopes to celebrate his birthday, not by painting a picture, for he gave up painting several years ago, but if all goes well he will on that occasion play for the first time two compositions for the flute dedicated to him by his last music teacher.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Demands that the transportation act be amended to bring the acquisition of railroads by holding companies within the jurisdiction of the Interstate Commerce Commission were reiterated today by Commissioner Joseph B. Eastman during testimony before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

Riverside Drive apartment houses were called "slums or potential slums" last night by Henry Wright, New York architect, in a symposium on modern architecture at the Museum of Modern Art, 730 Fifth Avenue. The discussion, which was attended by some of the city's leading architects, was held in connection with the museum's exhibition of recent developments in the so-called "international style" of architecture, which has aroused widespread interest.

C.R. Dewey, vice chairman of the board of the First Citizens Bank and Trust Company of Utica, was elected president of the Trust Companies Association of the State of New York at the annual meeting yesterday at the Lawyers Club. Merrel P. Callaway, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, and Edward K. Letchworth, vice president and general counsel of the Marine Trust Company of Buffalo, were elected vice presidents.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- Seton Hall defeated St. Joseph's College tonight, 40 to 34, in an extra-period basketball game. This was the first home defeat for the Crimson and Gray in more than two years.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- As the zero hour approached for the threatened Shanghai battle at 11 o'clock tonight, British time, the government took action.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP). -- T. Philip Perkins, former British amateur champion, and Howard Tryon, Detroit, strode far into the van of favorites today as they won their quarter-final match in the amateur four-ball matches here, 11 and 10, from J.B. Ryerson, Cooperstown, N.Y., and A.R. Hakes, Dunkirk, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The estimated cost of January building operations in the United States was $50,909,971, or 18.6 per cent below December and 66.6 per cent under January, 1931, the Labor Department announced today.

The Stock Exchange's new rule regulating facilities for "short selling" will be regarded by perhaps most readers of the news as a welcome restraint on a mischievous practice. Those who have believed, as some of the witnesses at the Congressional hearing on the subject seemed to do, that "bear selling" has been a primary cause both of the falling stock market and of our other economic troubles will presumably look for better times.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 -- Bill Terry's lengthy argument with the New York Giants over his pay envelope for 1932 ended amicably today when the big first-baseman emerged from a fifteen-minute afternoon conference with Manager John McGraw and admitted he had signed on the dotted line.

Irregular price movements in yesterday's share market apparently reflected little more than the confusion of speculative professionals who found it necessary to orient themselves in an awkward situation. By its unexpected action of Thursday in requiring its commission houses to refrain after April 1 from lending the stock of margin customers without their explicit authority, the Stock Exchange obviously has made short selling a more tedious and difficult process.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Big money campaigners of American golfdom, headed by Billy Burke, national open champion, were brushed aside today as match play in the $4,000 Gasparilla open tournament moved through the second round.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 19 -- Former General Jose San Martin, who was second in command to General Jose Escobar, leader of the ill-fated revolution of 1929, must stand retrial by the Supreme Military Tribunal here on a charge of rebellion against the constitutional government, because he was erroneously reported not guilty when court-martialed at Torreon in the State of Coahuila last week.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 20 -- Continuing with smoothness and celerity the process of State building, the Northeastern Executive Council today unanimously selected Henry Pu-yi as the first chief of the new State of Ankuo. His name, coupled with this announcement is now allowed to appear for the first time in the Japanese newspapers.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Mayor Congleto announced today that a syndicate of bankers in Newark and New York, arranged by the Fidelity Union Trust Company here, was renewing $4,100,000 of this city's temporary bonds due today and tomorrow.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 19 -- Yesterday's clash between gendarmes and tax collectors on the one band and the inhabitants of the village of Pacsa on the other, which produced another victim today, raising the number of farmers killed by the gendarmes to three, was the cause of a tumultuous scene tonight in Parliament.

School teachers and other employes of the Board of Education gave an average of 3 per cent of their January salaries to the School Belief Fund, more than doubling the average monthly total of contributions received before recent appeals were made for 5 per cent of their pay to care for increasing calls from needy school children.

An opening advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday was followed by reactions under Southern selling and pre-holiday realizing. May contracts sold off from 7.18 cents a pound to 7.12 and October, from 7.58 to 7.48 cents, making declines of about 6 to 10 points from the high prices touched at the start.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20 -- Princeton rallied brilliantly for three goals in the final period against the Yale hockey team tonight and converted a 3-to-l deficit into a 4-to-3 victory at the Hobey Baker Memorial rink.

FIRE, one of the farmer's worst enemies although not classed among serious agricultural problems, has come measurably nearer control in the last few years. Fire in the thinly populated rural districts has all too often wiped out the capital investment and the work of years for farmers who have been helpless to wage a battle against their unexpected foe and have often been handicaped by lack of water as well as equipment.

LONDON. ONE of the oldest pieces of insignia still used for its original purpose made one of its rare appearances recently. This is the diamond scepter that for one brief moment on the day of his induction into office the Lord Mayor of London holds in his hand to symbolize his rulership of the ancient City.

In Washington and Lee University, at Lexington, Va., the nation has a living symbol of Washington's interest in education. That university claims the unique distinction of having among its financial assets a $50,000 gift made by him. It yields the university an annual income of $3,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A fifteen-year program for Philippine independence was projected today by the Senate Committee on Territories and Insular Affairs, which on Wednesday will start drafting a bill embodying it.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 20 -- The individual minute droplets of which tog is composed have been measured and photographed for what is believed to be the first time at the research station of the Masachusetts Institute of Technology at Round Hill, Mass., it was announced today by Professor Edward L. Bowles, director of the station.

With the fixed investment trust field steadily narrowing to a comparatively few large groups, and with the number of "orphan" trusts -- those whose sponsoring organizations have gone out of existencesteadily increasing, there is an increasing need for organizations which specialize in transferring holders in these "orphans" into the stronger groups through exchanges of stock.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- Despite the protraction of the Cabinet crisis, the Bourse made further progress today. The improvement centred mainly In domestic bank shares, but extended also to the international stocks which were favorably affected by yesterday's advance on the New York Stock Exchange.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 -- Neither the "Goo Goes" nor the "Gang" is a political party, but both operate in ways that influence powerfully the politics of Boston, The "Goo Goos," short for Good Government Association, emphasize the avowed nonpartisan or bipartisan character of their organization.

THE New York Legislature has before it a measure designed to place radio broadcasters under the same responsibility for libel as newspapers. A bill amending the penal law to this effect has been introduced by Senator William J. Hickey and Assemblyman Howard Dickey, both of Buffalo.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 19 -- There is no longer a vestige of doubt about the intentions of Governor Alfalfa Bill Murray. He is a forthright candidate for the Democratic nomination for President. He has downtown, headquarters and multl-colored advertising matter in Oklahoma City, an office in Chicago and captains beating the bushes in North Dakota, Georgia, Iowa and Indiana.
NEW YORK. Princess Henry of Reuss, who has been in New York for the Winter, will sail Feb. 26 on the Europa for her home in Paris.

PARIS. PARIS Summer Fashion Shows open with a big cotton offensive. Cotton weaves of many varieties are being used to replace woolens and silks whenever possible, and this implies a whole style program: light naturel shades and girlish simplicity seem to be the order of the day.

EDINBURG, Texas, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The days of six-gun government along the Texas border were remembered tonight while sixteen citizens of the little town of Donna stood accused of planning to seize control there by a wholesale killing of Democratic officeholders.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 20 Westchester County, where George Washington campaigned as General of the army in the American Revolution, will pay homage to the first President of the nation on the occasion of the 200th anniversary of his birth, with a variety of festivities.

MONTRKAL. FOR more than thirty years the Right Rev. Arsene Turquetil ban ministered to the Eskimos of the Far North. living their rigorous life, teaching the children, succoring, the sick and braving the dangers of blizzardswept trails.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- This city has a new and less costly plan for covering over the railroad cut of the New York, New Haven Hartford, which bisects the city, and creating a civic centre.

ERNST TOCH, one of the leaders of the avant-garde of the German school of composition, arrived in New York last week, with a tour of principal cities of the United States before him. The electrical energy which characterizes the piano concerto of Toch which Jesus Sanroma played with the Boston Symphony Orchestra several seasons ago in this city does not betray itself in the bearing of its composer.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- A universe containing millions of worlds, some of them dead and others inhabited by beings as far superior to mankind as men are to single cells, is visioned by Dr. William D. MacMillan, professor of Mathematical Astronomy, in a new theory of cosmosgony announced by him today at the University of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Governor Roosevelt's open pronouncement at Buffalo in favor of returning liquor control to the States was discounted by Democratic political leaders, who could be reached tonight, as having no important bearing on his chances for the Presidential nomination.
NEW YORK is now levying a tribute of vast proportions upon other sections of this country, and even upon localities abroad, for building Radio City.

THE celebration of the two-hundredth anniversary of the birth of George Washington has brought to the fore many examples of the fabrics, furniture, ceramics and other decorative accessories created during the early days of the Republic.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Charles J. Marasco of New York won the qualifying medal in the second annual Winter golf tournament of the New York Athletic Club, which began today on St. Augustine links. The club party arrived this morning in a special train section.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Several dances were held tonight in Westchester County, in celebration of the bicentennial anniversary of the birth of George Washington.

WASHINGTON. PRESIDENT HOOVER has said that fighting depression is like fighting a great war. The weaknesses on the different fronts shift, the enemy strength at different points varies, and measures which must be taken to meet new and difficult situations must be shifted in the course of the campaign.
A LISTENER in Ohio submits several questions he would like to have answered.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1931 furnished radio program circuits measuring more than 44,000 miles, according to a report to the Federal Radio Commission. These circuits to twelve networks in the nation used about 90,000 miles of wire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Holding that the first concern of schools today should be "to bring to the younger generation a vision which will call forth their active loyalties and challenge them to creative and arduous labors," Dr. George S. Counts of Teachers College, Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today found reason to be cheerful with the repayment to it of a loan of about $1,000,000 made on Feb. 15 to a large banking organization. Interest for the five days was added to the remittance.

VIENNA, Feb. 20 -- Extensive prepreations have been made throughout Central Europe by American institutions and public bodies to celebrate the bicentenary of Washington. In Vienna the America-Austria Society, the American Medical Asociation and the American Women's Club will hold a joint reception in the Hofburg Monday, where speeches will be delivered by American Minister Stockton and members of the Austrian Government.

ADVOCATES of a unified department of national defense in Washington listened last week as they sought light on the roposed Byrns bill, to arguments or and against the measure. Representative McSwain, chairman of the Military Affairs Committee, heartily endorsed the bill although Secretary Hurley for the War Department and secretary Adams for the navy were ot so enthusiastic about it.

One of the most consistent winning relay teams in the city's scholastic ranks during the current indoor track season has been the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School quartet of Brooklyn. Thrice within the past two weeks Loughlin's team has taken the laufels in important schoolboy relay events at several big club and A.A.U. meets.

Dr. KIANG KANG-HU, Professor of Oriental Languages at McGill University, has urged learning Chinese, since one who cannot read its literature can "never "really understand the civilization of "China." He contends that the language is not difficult, since it has "no alphabet, no grammar and no punctuation."

An exhibition of water-colors and pen-and-ink drawings by John Ruskin is current at the North Book Shop, 537 Fifth Avenue, to stay until March 12. For a critic as dogmatic and assertive as Ruskin to take up the pen in emulation of the artists he had damned is courage indeed Four of his own favorites.

THIS essay reader who requires profundity of treatment or depth of thought will do well not to turn to the pages of E.V. Lucas. This author has a leaning toward the lighter, the frothier, the more ephemeral phases of life, and prefers to go skimming blithely over the surface of things rather than to sink his pickaxe into the bedrock.

LONDON. A FEW weeks ago, a distinguished visitor appeared in London, who would once have been regarded as nothing less stark and startling than a naked faku out of the desert. Be would have been far more of a monster, in the time of George Washington, than a red Indian suddenly appearing at the Cabinet Council of Lord North.

ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 20 -- The United States has been left "without one friendly nation in the world," Senator Lewis of Illinois, said here today in a Washington Memorial address at the closing session of the Georgia Press Institute.
Raw sugar, cocoa, hides, silver and wool tops advanced on local exchanges last week, while coffee, rubber and silk closed lower.

A BEAUTIFUL book this, one to delight and intrigue any reader who cares about the things it deals with. Any one, familiar with Professor Van Dyke's previous volumes concerned with the face of nature, "The Mountain," "The Desert," "The Opal Sea" and others, will know with what charm and interest he imbues his subject.

PREDICTIONS that the transport airlines would find cause for congratulation in statistics which they themselves established in 1931 have been fully justified by the figures issued last week by the Department of Commerce. Passengers carried on the domestic lines during the year reached a total of 457,340, as compared with 374,935 in 1930, and passenger miles increased to 104,018,022 from 84,015,572.

INTERNATIONALISM, which, if we count in accordance with the cycles of the past, has hardly begun, already comes in for editorial reproach in that most admirable of magazines The Atelier, published in London as The Studio. The editor, Mr. Geoffrey Holmes, is trying in the February number to discover what is wrong with modern painting, and his first article of a series to be devoted to this search deals with internationalism.

Because of favorable growing weather in the Southern States, strawberries from Louisiana and asparagrus from South Carolina, Alabama and Texas have arrived in the New York market several weeks earlier than last year, it was said yesterday by George C. Royce of the New York City office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

A total of 115 thoroughbreds has been nominated for the $50,000 Kentucky Derby, which will have its fifty-eighth running on Saturday, May 7, according to an announcement yesterday from Colonel Matt Winn, president of the American Turf Association and executive director at Churchill Downs, in Kentucky, where the famous test is held.

A SHORT ninety miles south of Key West lies Cuba -- land of almost perpetual sunshine and an ideal climax to a Southern motor trip. To most Americans Cuba is almost synonymous with Havana, its capital city. This arises from the fact that until quite recently the rest of the republic was practically unknown to tourists.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Willie Macfarlane, former national open champion, slipped into the final round of the $4,000 Gasparilla open golf tournament today by defeating Wild Bill Mehlhorn of New York, 1 up, in a thrilling eighteen-hole match.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- Paris will pay its tribute to George Washington in ceremonies tomorrow and Monday to commemorate his 200th birthday. Not only the American colony here but officials of France, led by President Doumer, will join in an elaborate program.

As one of its many plans for honoring the memory of the Father of his country, the George Washington Bicentennial Commission has set out to revive interest in Colonial gardens, and to encourage home owners to plant gardens of the Colonial type.

ELMER RICE soon will be bound for Russia, where he will find that performances of his play, "The Adding Machine," in the land of the Soviets have already made him something of a celebrity. He expects to arrive there in time for the May Day celebrations, and will not return until Broadway is simmering in the heat of August.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 21 -- Japanese tanks rumbled on Kiangwan under the defeaning roar of a major bombardment today in the great offensive against that crucial point in the Chinese lines, which still was stubbornly defended against the invaders.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 -- Gerhart Hauptmann. whose new play, "Before Sunset" -- his first, written in 1889, was Before Sunrise" -- has just had its first, performance here acclaimed by critics and the public, sails on the Europa tomorrow for New York, accompanied, by his wife and son, Benvenuto.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Lieutenant Charles Pugh of the First Pursuit Squadron, Boiling Field, was killed instantly today when his small pursuit plane dived from a height of 100 feet as he sought to land at the Hagerstown Airport.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- A fighting Amherst team gave Army a close call at basketball today, losing to the cadets in an extra period by 30 to 28.

The Florida State championship decided, with Miss Maureen Orcutt of New Jersey having repeated her triumph, of 1930, the women links stars now move on from Palm Beach to Ormond Beach, where the South Atlantic event will be contested, starting on Tuesday.

TO those who show signs of embarrassment or confusion whenever the word "poetry" is mentioned in casual conversation, Miss Bonaro Wilkinson's book will be a godsend. It is aimed at the person who has a guilty, surreptitious feeling that he likes "poetry" but doesn't know how or why.

Declaring that Congress must appropriate sufficient funds to insure national defense or change the defense act, Major Gen. George E. Leach, chief of the Militia Bureau in Washington, urged yesterday that it was "the paramount duty of Congress to carry on its own program."

WASHINGTON. PRESIDENT HOOVER hopes soon to put additional drain pipes under "the swamp of bad organization" in our government. Too much waste arises from that swamp, he has said, and he asked Congress in a special message last week, to permit him to deal with the situation along modern engineering lines, to the end that the Federal Government may eventually become a smoothly running business organization with no costly duplication of functions or authority.

ON the evening of April 11. 1796, President George Washington sat down at his desk in the Executive Mansion on High Street, in Philadelphia, and addressed the following letter to Gilbert Stuart, the portrait painter:

There are a total of nine handicap races ranging from 100 meters to 5,000 meters on the program of track events to be contested at the New York County American Legion track meet which will be held in the 102d Engineers Armory on March 7.
Transactions in gold here yesterday were confined to the shipment of $2,281,900 to Holland. In the foreign exchange market the dollar continued to improve, although francs and guilders were stronger.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Spanish Play, 4-year-old colt from the Knebelkamp and Morris Stable, with Jockey C. Landolt up, won the Jack L. Dempsey Handicap, today's feature race at the Fair Grounds. Wotan was second and Lucky Tom third.

Richmond Hill High School registered a 5 to 1 victory over George Washington High, defending city P. S.A.L. fencing team champion, in one of the eight matches in the second annual title tourney contested yesterday at the Washington Irving High School.

Despite passing of the peak of active buying and a reduction in the number of buyers in the market here, reorders and mail requisitions during the week continued steady and reflected a good demand, according to the market report especially prepared for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howeli, Inc.

To the Art Editor: THE belief that all that is necessary to establish a national school is to paint the native scene -- as seems to be the thought behind the manifestoes of some of these super-patriots -- is naive in the extreme. It is quite unworthy of intelligent consideration and leads one to suspect that it is mere pose and very little else.

YOUNGER members of society are looking forward with keen anticipation to the annual St. Valentine's Kettledrum in aid of the Samaritan Home for the Aged, which takes place on Friday in the ballroom of the Plaza. Since 1873 the Kettledrum has been a fixture in society and appeals particularly to juveniles, the attractions being arranged especially for their amusement.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- With an enthusiastically reviewed revival of John Drinkwater's play "Abraham Lincoln." at the Old Vic, and celebration of the 200th anniversary of Washington's birth, there comes to Americans living in England a welcome relief from news from home as it is given to them by the British press.

THOSE Who still stick to the fine old axiom that you cannot indict a nation will find backing in theae two booKs which have happened to appear at a most appropriate time, one written by a Japanese of humane and cosmopolitan culture, the other edited by him. Dr. Nitobe is no meek apologist for his nation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20 -- A large and enthusiastic gathering of Connecticut dog fanciers crowded the New Haven arena tonight for the final judging of the thirteenth annual exhibition of the Elm City Kennel Club, the concluding feature of which was the award of the title of best in show.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- George Richmond Fearing 3d became a semi-finalist in the national racquets championship at the Boston Tennis and Racquet Club today by defeating Philip Wharton in three love games. Fearing yesterday put out Palmer Dixon when within three points of elimination in the third game, and today Wharton offered little resistance to the young local star.

Season's records were bettered in five events at the weekly dual meets in the Manhattan-Bronx senior high school swimming championship competition of the Public Schools Athletic League in the 75-foot pool of George Washington High School yesterday.

To the excitement of 200 boys competing in songs at the Town Hall last night there was added the thrill of a sudden escape from danger by one of the nine groups competing. The youths of Storm King School, up the Hudson, dropped seven stories in an elevator as they set out for the hall from their neighboring hotel.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 20 -- Declaring that truancy from school in a child was a definite sign of maladjustment and that the parents should endeavor to gain the same relation to their children as that of the psychiatrist, Dr. Isra T. Broadwin of New York told the American Orthopsychiatric Association at its annual convention today of the study he had made of certain types of neurotic children in relation to truancy.

MIAMI -- Members of the Biscayne Bay Yacht Club are planning to hold their annual chowder party on Washington's Birthday. They have made a practice of taking their friends aboard their yachts on this holiday to a small island or key down Biscayne Bay, where chowder, cooked in true Southern style in great cauldrons over log fires, is prepared and eaten in the open.

BALTIMORE. Feb. 20 -- Administrators of American schools were urged to see that "the textbooks in history present truthfully and adequately the chief factors and Influences operating in world affairs and producing the problems of peace and war," in a resolution adopted by the Progressive Education Association in the closing sessions of its annual meeting here today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 20 -- The official Soviet attitude regarding the formation of the independent government in Manchuria is shrouded in complete silence, the government continuing the non-committal and non-interfering policy maintained throughout the recent Far Eastern events.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- The selection by the Democratic State Central Committee of Judge Henry Horner as candidate for Governor on its approved slate to be submitted to the voters in the April primary has stirred up down-State opposition in the party.

ONE never knows what a man so dynamic and so volatile as Alfredo Casella will be doing next: every sort of surprise is possible, and, indeed, in this possibility lies a great part of his worth as a man of intelligence, full of curiosity about every new experience, always ready to try a new road, to exemplify in his work the latest musical tendencies which seem likely to succeed in impressing themselves for some seasons.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 20 (AP). -- New York, Buffalo, Philadelphia and Harvard teams swept into the semi-finals of the National Squash Racquets tournament today, eliminating the other entries in more or less easy fashion.

THE experiment of elaborated travelogues like "Around the World in Eighty Minutes" has been pleasant enough financially to prompt Douglas Fairbanks into making another. At that, Mr. Fairbanks did not need much prompting.

RICHARD WHORF of Winthrop, Mass., who probably needs to be more fully identified as the Inspector Henderson of the detective comedy, "Monkey," at the Mansfield Theatre, is taking his third whack at Broadway after a four-year stay in New England.

Practically twenty per cent of the winners of the title "best of breed" at the fifty-fifth Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden were bred by their owners. In other words, out of seventy-seven recognized breeds on the benches, top honors in fifteen went to dogs that had been bred and raised by their owners.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- James H. Bridge, 73 years old, of Tuckahoe, former curator of the Frick art collection, filed suit for $250,000 damages, charging slander and libel, in Supreme Court here today against Miss Helen C. Frick, daughter of the later Henry Clay Frick, capitalist and founder of the Frick collection.

NOW come the gadgets -- don't shrug your shoulders. You can't ignore gadgets. They're apt to make a great difference between a reputation that goes. "Yes, she has enormous chic," and one that concedes. "Well, she looked rather smart today."

Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York, said yesterday that the use of a site in Prospect Park for the erection of a reproduction of George Washington's home in Mount V'ernon, as contemplated by the committee in charge of the riicentenriial celebration here, would, in his opinion, be a violation of the city charter.

Some of the details regarding the need among the unemployed were disclosed yesterday in a report of the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau, compiled from data gathered by 491 investigators who visited 6,304 urgent cases.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 -- The bicentenary of George Washington's birth will be observed more generally in Germany than anywhere else outside of the United States. Appreciative articles are multiplying in the German press and not only will there be ceremonial observances on Feb. 22 in the principal cities but public exercises have been planned to run until November which will make 1932 a Washington as well as a Goethe year in Germany.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 21 -- After a day of fierce fighting yesterday [Saturday] in which the losses on both sides were heavy, the Japanese had advanced, but had failed in their objectives. The Chinese at 11:30 o'clock last night admitted retreating from the Kiangwan racetrack area, but asserted the village of Kiangwan, chief objective of the Japanese and a central point on the front, was still held by Chinese forces after changing hands three times.

The future of the new Earl Carroll Theatre at Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street was revealed as uncertain last night when it was learned that Mr. Carroll had approached the Shuberts with a proposal to transfer his "Vanities" to a Shubert-controlled house a week from tomorrow night.

Two questions often asked concerning reparations are how much France has received from Germany since the Armistics and how far the amount has gone toward meeting the cost of reconstruction in the devastated areas. Figures published in Paris give the French answer to both questions.

The decision of the Treasury Department to further the Government's anti-hoarding campaign by issuing special Treasury certificates on or about March 7 in denominations of $50, $100 and $500, known popularly as "baby" bonds, is in a sense, merely a repetition of methods which have been used on various occasions.

George Weinsteln of N.Y.U., former P.S.A.L. sprint champion, took the measure of Ralph Sickel, former Missouri Valley Conference 100-yard titleholder, in the 100-meter final, one of the feature events of the Maccabee track and field meet at the 102d Regiment Armory last night.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- Two telegrams, both sent from Naples, preceded by a few hours the mysterious death at sea on Feb. 7 of Elizabeth Barrett Cook on the Steamship Chinese Prince between Naples and Gibraltar.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 19 -- In building the huge new Payne Whitney gymnasium, which is now nearing completion at a. prospective cost of nearly $5,000,000, Yale has sought to work out, according to Dr. William G. Anderson, the director, "the most complete program possible under existing conditions to prepare the student physically for the battle for existence."

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- A struggle for control of the aviation industry in the United States is seen by some observers behind the first wage dispute incolving pilots on commercial airline which broke out recently in Chicago and aroused such loud protests from the new pilots' union that the true significance of the event was lost.

THE death of Edgar Wallace was cause for consoling many thousands in this country who had enjoyed his melodramatic novels and the one melodramatic play he wrote that was produced here. But to no one who knew him only through his work was his death so shocking as to those who were acquainted with him personally.

SOUTH ORANGE, Feb. 20 -- A Colonial costume ball in celebration of the Washington bicentenary and of the leap year will be held at the Essex County Country Club, West Orange, next Saturday night. There will be old-fashioned dances. Prizes will be awarded for the best and most original burlesque costumes.

BANISHMENT to the penal colony of Spanish Guinea was the punishment recently meted out to 109 Spanish Communists who participated in the uprising in Catalonia a short time ago. Other countries also retain deportation as the sentence for certain political or criminal offenses.

An international program designed to stress the cooperation of France with the American Revolutionary forces will be held by New York University in its celebration of the Washington bicentennial tomorrow afternoon in the auditorium of the Gould Memorial Library at University Heights.

THROUGH the efforts of the Clothing Relief Committee, one of the major bodies of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, hundreds of distressed families in New York are being outfitted so that they can face the everyday exigencies of life with self-respect.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- France is warned against any additional armament expenditures by Germain Martin, ex-Minister of the Budget, writing in the newspaper Le Capital about the country's present monetary, economic and budgetary conditions. Taxes cannot be further increased.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Republican and Democratic parties enter the 1932 campaign with publicity organizations already wise in the ways of spreading partisan "gospel."

LONDON. WHAT is believed to be the largest collection of toy soldiers in existence -- certainly one of the moat comprehensive -- was formed during the later years of his life by an English physician, Dr. Vere Nicoll, who died recently.

Although Us three most heavily weighted components declined, the weekly index of business activity registers only a moderate loss for the week ended Feb. 13. The preliminary index for that week is 62.5, as against 62.8 for the preceding week and 77.8 for the corresponding week last year.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- When this city adopted the new city charter, two years ago, with the accompanying city manager provisions, supporters of the new form of government hoped it would take local government out of the hands of the politicians.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 -- Oil and water, natural enemies, are brothers under the skin. At least they are political bedfellows in California, whose destiny seems inextricably linked with the future of the aqueous and oleaginous fluids.

DUBLIN, Feb. 20 -- Virtually certain of becoming the Free State's next President, Eamon de Valera today insisted that he would carry out the campaign, promises which his allies of the Labor party are determined he shall not fulfill. New returns today made it clearer than ever that Mr. de Valera would not be able to form a government without the help of the Labor party.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 18 -- Of the utmost interest in national politics was the crash of things Republican in Cleveland's special Mayoralty election this week, when the Democratic organization headed by Newton D. Baker, Presidential dark horse, elected Prosecuting Attorney Ray T. Miller the first Democratic occupant of the Mayor's chair since 1915.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- More money is being spent in New York State each year for tobacco, soft drinks and cosmetics than for public education, according to an analysis of the report submitted to the Legislature by the Stale Commission for the Revision of the Tax Laws (Mastick commission) and of reports to the State Education Department by the New York State Teachers' Association made public today by President W. Howard Pillsbury.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- The world's record for the forty-five-yard high hurdles was equaled twice tonight in the Garden during the first annual New England intercollegiate track meet conducted by the University Club of Boston. The meet attracted a crowd of 5,000 fans.

THERE was published recently an account of the purchase by the New York State Grand Lodge of Masons of the historic De Windt house at Tappan, N.Y., which Genera George Washington used as bis headquarters during the Revolution and where he regretfully signed the death warrant of Major John Andre, British officer.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 20 -- Alfalfa Bill Murray's floppy campaign hat was thrown into the national ring here today. After Democratic leaders in a State rally had hailed the Governor as "Oklahoma's candidate for the Presidency," he replied to their plaudits with the declaration:

American currency is the medium on which all export orders are now based, according to information supplied the American Manufacturers' Export Association by members replying to a questionnaire sent out by the organization recently. Although returns are not complete, answers to date indicate that few exporters changed the length of credit granted foreign customers as a result of the Hoover moratorium plan announced June 20.

The outstanding realty transaction for the close of the week in Jersey City was the sale by the B. W. Realty Company (Georgfe P. Winter and Charles H. Blohm) of the Marble Court apartment house at 637-41 Bergen Avenue, northwest corner of Jewett Avenue, to the Robdon Realty Company.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 -- Owing to uncertainties in business, the Los Angeles Grand Opera Company has abandoned plans for next season's opera here. The decision was announced by David T. Babson, president. The cancellation is expected to be temporary, and the organization will not disband.

One is reminded by an Office of Education Bulletin on "The American Lyceum" of a nineteenth-century glory that has faded. Its history is sufficiently recorded in this pamphlet and the encyclopedias. It was the invention of a Connecticut man, JOSEPH HOLBROOK of Derby, a lecturer on the natural sciences.

GENEVA, Feb. 19 -- Many wise things have been said during the last two weeks in Geneva as day after day the Disarmament Conference has listened, to a very high level of oratory and sentiment. There has not been a single Minister or delegate who has not spoken with deep feeling of the popular demand all over the world for peace and disarmament, whether peace comes by disarmament or disarmament by peace.

ROME, Feb. 19. -- Of particular interest, now that efforts made by the world during the last ten years to oiganize international peace have resulted in the convocation of the Geneva Disarmament Conference, is the book which has just appeared in an Italian edition wherein Senator Carlo Schanzer reviews this complex, intricate subject from its inception to the present day with a completeness unpossessed by any previous work.

MEXICO CITY. Feb. 20 -- Dr. Gregorio Mendlzabal, dean of Mexican physicians and noted philanthropist, died yesterday after a long illness at the age of 86. He had practiced his profession for sixty-three years, a career which is unrivaled in the medical history of this republic.

MADRID, Feb. 19. -- A letter ostensibly written by Joseph Stalin and spread with double headlines over the front page of the leading Republican daily El Sol this week assails the Spanish Communists for breaking with Moscow.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 -- Measured in elapsed time, one week has passed since the Giants embarked on their 1932 training campaign, and while the signing of Bill Terry has been the only event of major importance, the decks have been thoroughly cleared for the action that awaits the athletes in the coming week.

TO the Editor of The New York Times: It is probably not clearly realized that an average of four persons commit suicide in Greater New York every day, according to recent returns. In the aggregate there are about 1,600 suicides a year, while the number of unsuccessful attempts at suicide is probably about the same, if not more.

CAMBRIDE, Mass., Feb. 20 -- The oldest map in the world, drawn more than 4,000 years ago on a clay tablet 3 by 2 5/8 inches, is the unique find of excavators for the Semitic and Fogg Museums of Harvard University, under the direction of R.F.S. Starr, Fellow of the Fogg Art Museum, at the site of ancient Nuzi, in Iraq, 200 miles north of Babylon.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- The East and the Middle West divided honors by capturing the two feature events of the seventeenth annual track meet of the Meadowbrook Club tonight In Convention Hall.

THE author of this unique book wants to see education vivified and children inspired by having a more intimate knowledge and a clearer appreciation of the fundamentals of the universe inoorporated into the training of their early years.

THE complete programs for the Munich and Salzburg Festivals have been made public. In Munich, at the Residence Theatre, there will be twelve performances of six Mozart operas during the period from July 21 to Aug. 19. At the Prince Regent Theatre, from July 18 to Aug. 21, eighteen performances of eight Wagner operas will be presented.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Ruins of a beautifully ornamented Persian palace of the Sasanian period, between 226 and 661 A.D., have been uncovered at Tepe Hissar near Dangham by a joint expedition of the Pennsylvania Museum of Art and the University of Pennsylvania Museum.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Mrs. Jessie Woodrow Sayre, daughter of Woodrow Wilson, suggests, in the current issue of the bulletin of the Women's National Democratic Club, six platform planks for the consideration of the Democratic National Convention at Chicago.

HAVANA, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Fortunate Youth, a successful campaigner over the Maryland and metropolitan turf last year, finally won a race at Oriental Park when he accounted for the feature National Handicap, decided over six furlongs, today.

OWING to a great demand for tickets for the historical pageant, "Honor to Washington," to be presented at the Town Hall Wednesday night, special arrangements have been made for an audience to witness the dress rehearsal in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A rearrangement of the mechanics of liquidating securities of closed national banks beld by receivers has been inaugurated by the Controller of the Currency, J.W. Pole. For a wide territory in the Eastern States securities of this type will be concentrated in New York for liquidation through the Federal Reserve Bank.

Backers of the Untermyer plan for liquidating the assets of the defunct Bank of United States with full payment to depositors within three years, yesterday sent to each of the 22,800 stockholders of the institution who had not yet subscribed to the $8,000,000 fund which must be raised before the plan can be made effective a letter warning them that subscriptions would not be accepted after Feb. 27.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Officials of the Far Eastern Division of the State Department said today they knew of no record and had no recollection of any evidence to support the contention of the Japanese Foreign office that President Roosevelt had approved in advance Japan's annexation of Korea.

PARIS -- In a swing around Central Europe one quickly discovers that all countries are preoccupied with "the crisis" and dictatorship. The crisis is composed of two different elements -- the economic circumstances and the reaction to them of the population. Thus considered, the crisis is regarded differently in each country.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20 -- In connection with the George Washington bicentennial celebration, Yale University will open tomorrow an extensive exhibition of its treasures in literature and the fine arts relating to the life of Washington and the history of the United States during his lifetime.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20 -- The exhibition of sixty pieces of early American church and domestic silver from the Mabel Brady Garvan collection in the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts is announced by President Angell. These items have nearly completed the collection, and are said to have placed it in the forefront of its kind.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 -- In compliment to Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, who arrived from Miami with Joseph E. Widener, Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. B. Widener 2d and Mr. Widener entertained tonight with a buffet supper for fifty-two guests at their residence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Henry P. Kiley of Bridgeport, clerk in the consulate at Geneva, Switzerland, has been appointed vice consul there. Other changes in the Foreign Service the past two weeks were announced today by the State Department as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Administration forces in Congress, it was Intimated tonight, will try in the conference committee to change the Glass-Steagall credit expansion bill so that all needy member banks of the Federal Reserve System will be able to borrow from Federal Reserve Banks, or, if that program fails, to remodel the bill's language so that banks with capitalization above $2,000,000, can borrow up to 6 per cent of their deposits.

There is a possibility that the "rabbit ball" discussion which featured big league baseball meetings during recent seasons may enter college baseball with the coming season. Harvard, either formally or informally, may take up the discussion with some of her rivals of bringing back to the college game the old slow type of baseball.

The Far Eastern situation is giving a full and fair play to the force of moral suasion as a preventive of war. It has supplied the occasion for calling to the attention of Japan and China their duties under the covenant of the League of Nations, under the Kellogg pact and under the Nine-Power Pacific treaty.
LONDON. THE success won by "Death Comes to the Archbishop" insured a welcome here for "Shadows on the Rock." According to The Manchester Guardian, while it has not the full charm of the former book.

PARIS. IN the Place d'lena in Paris stands an equestrian statue of Washington with his drawn sword pointing toward the sky. A little French girl passes there every morning with her English nurse, who considers that this is a good opportunity for a history lesson.

DUBLIN, Feb. 19. -- The Free State's military tribunal has just delivered a remarkable verdict of guilty against the publisher and editor of Eamon de Valera's new daily newspaper. The Irish Press, on the charge of seditious libel.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Far Eastern news caused some hesitancy in the stock markets today, dealers awaiting further developments, although the tone generally was firm. British Government funds were considerably quieter, although the war loan held to the overnight figure of u100.

SINCE Sept. 18, when Japanese troops went into action in Manchuria, China has invoked three separate articles of the League of Nations Covenant. Her invocation of Article XI resulted in the appointment of an international commission of inquiry, which is now en route to investigate and determine what should be done.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The House will be in session as usual on Monday, despite the 200th birthday anniversary of Washington on that day.
To the Editor of The New YorK Times: The present situation with respect to the world's two perplexing problems seems about as follows:

MAN has searched for many things during the long centuries that he has been a rationalizing force upon the face of the earth: the philosopher's stone, the fountain of youth, the secret of transmuting base metals into gold, the power to combat gravity and rise into the air upon wings, the cloak of invisibility and direct communication with supernatural forces.

Getting Killed Legally. SO far as this observer has been able to ascertain, all the organizations and individuals seeking to promote safety advise highway pedestrians to walk against motor-vehicle traffic. In other words, those on foot are warned to reverse for themselves the rule of always keeping to the right.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 20 -- T. Philip Perkins of New York, former holder of the British amateur title, and Howard A. Tryon of Detroit advanced today to the final in the Miami Biltmore thirty-six-hole four-ball tournament by defeating Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., and Celeste A. Durand of Long Beach, L.I., 6 and 5.

GENEVA, Feb. 20 -- Something a great deal more than the special Assembly of the League of Nations, it now appears, was convoked when the Council yesterday summoned all members to Geneva on March 3 to deal with the Far Eastern war.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Charles Briggs, after quoting at length from a recent speech of Alanson B. Houghton, suggests that the people should have the power to declare war. Is it to be inferred that the people, because they are citizens of a democratic country, are to have a direct voice in every executive act?

A LTHOUGH a book by a scholar. in a field usually reserved to scholars, N. Burton Paradise's history of an Elizabethan. "Thomas Lodge." is nevertheless an intensely Interesting bit of work. The Yale professor of English bases his book on an observation not before met with -- namely, that a period of great achievement can often be more profitably studied through its lesser figures than through Its outstanding men.

ENGLAND, like the United States, has been making an investigation of its liquor problem and has just issued a highly significant report. In distinction and authority the commission that has issued it is quite comparable to the Wickersham commission.

Through a rigid enforcement of the new football rules and the prope training and care of players it may ba possible next Fall to do away with 50 per cent of the injuries in the game as now played, it was declared yesterday by Professor Frank S. Lloyd of New York University.

TO be "Uncle Ernest" to 1,000 boys and girls -- or is it 10,000? -- is what it means to conduct the Children's Concerts and the Young People's Concerts that have grown to occupy so large a place in the musical life of several American cities.

Efforts to make education easily available for the unemployed In these times so as not only to keep up their morale but also to make them more available for new jobs as they become open are coming more to the fore this Winter, according to reports received from other cities.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 18 -- A large number of young American and Canadian aviators who thought the Sino-Japanese dispute would lead to open warfare in which they could participate on the side of China are in Shanghai, practically penniless, regretting that they paid heed to the anti-Japanese associations along the Pacific Coast which promised them big jobs if they ever landed in China.

Rules for regulation of motor truck operation were suggested recently by J.J. Pelley, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, in a speech advocating the establishment of a coordinated transportation system. He spoke before the American Fruit and Vegetable Shippers' Association.

ATLANTA, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Governor Roosevelt has engaged W.E. Page, a prominent Southern newspaper publisher of Columbus. Ga., as manager of his Presidential campaign in Georgia and he will open headquarters in Atlanta within a few days.
William Tilden, 39-year-old veteran of the tennis courts, retained his world's professional crown last night with one of the gamest exhibitions of his long career.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Army's hard-riding polo trio won an intercollegiate match from Princeton today by 11 to 8.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 20 -- Winning five of the eight first places, the navy plebe swimming team defeated the University of Pennsylvania freshmen, 40-30, today. The plebes also defeated the Penn Cubs at water polo, 68 to 0.

LISBON, Feb. 5. -- Portugal has so much wine that it has been decreed by the government that restaurants and hotels must serve it to their cuustomers free of charge on request. In fact wine is cheaper than water In some parts and much cheaper than kerosene everywhere.

STUDENTS of Thomas Carlyle have long been aware of the important services rendered that writer by Joseph Neuberg -- the translation into German of "Past and Present" and "Heroes and Hero-Worship," and help in preparing "Frederick the Great" -- but the letters which Mrs. Carlyle wrote to Neuberg have remained shut from public gaze until now.

BUFFALO, Feb. 18 -- The reappotntment of Fred A. Bradley as Collector of Customs for the Western District of New York appears to have come nearer to arousing a national issue than any other recent incident connected with the personnel of the administration.

The majority report of Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee's subcommittee appointed by the Board of Estimate to work out a solution to the transit problem caused by the abandonment by the Long Island Railroad of its Whitestone branch has caused a split among the members of the subcommittee that will result in the submission of two reports to the Committee of the Whole Tuesday, it was disclosed yesterday.

Two items in THE TIMES of last Thursday bear directly upon the popular tendency to interpret current economic difficulties into terms of permanent collapse. An official estimate of Great Britain's foreign receipts and payments in 1931 shows an adverse balance of u110,000,000.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- In 1914 1,779,000 Germans were members of gymnastic and sport organizations. In 1919 there were only 680,000, but by 1920 the total had increased to 2,244,000, and in 1931 the number organized in such associations alone had risen to 7,000,000.

The present opposition of the railroads to the use of valuation in determining railroad rates is a complete reversal of their former position, it was asserted in discussion of the hearings of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce on the proposed repeal of the recapture clause of the transportation act.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 20 -- Assuming the advantage in the second half, following a first-half tie, the Naval Academy basketball team closed its season today by defeating Harvard University, 33 to 27. The middies climaxed a successful season, in which they won all except three of their sixteen games.

Led by the Misses Marjorie Blick and Gladys Lutenberg, the New York University girls' basketball team triumphed over the Connecticut Agricultural College sextet, 33 to 23, at the N.Y.U. School of Education gym yesterday. It was the Violet team's initial appearance on its home court this season.

SADI writing in the twelfth century might have had some prescience of the desolation of the mighty pile that stands where Seraglio Point, Jutting out between the Sea of Marmora and the Golden Horn Into the Bosphorus, guards the Sublime Porte itself.

Ethel Cohn has Bold to Jacob Mircoff a lease of the five-story building with stores on the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street (20 1/2 by 80 feet), which runs to April 30, 1944, together with her interest in a sublease of these premises made to the Simash Realty Corporation.

Moscow. A DEFINITE task has been assigned to art in the all-embracing plan worked out by the Soviet on the basis of Marxian dialectic methods. Certainly not on the principle of art for art's sake, but also no longer along the line of purely propaganda art.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Does any one know when George Washington was born? I thought we knew. As a schoolboy I learned the date was Feb. 22, 1732, and that Betsy Ross cut the stars for the first American flag with one clip of the scissors.

If the images or films which DEMOCRITUS assumed, all objects were continually giving off from, themselves, maintaining their integrity though penetrated by the subtler images of the thoughts of men, were still moving in the atmosphere of the earth after two hundred years, they could not do more to make this nation conscious of WASHINGTON than the thousands of articles, portraits and illustrations appearing in these weeks.
Editor, The New York Times Book Review: Frequent recent instances of authors appropriating material from various of my books induce me to request the courtesy of your columns for a protest.

Twenty-four years ago in London Mel Sheppard carried the colors of the United States to victory in the 800 and 1,500 meter runs at the Olympic games. Since then, at Stockholm, Antwerp, Paris and Amsterdam, despite high hopes and valiant efforts, no American has been able to duplicate Sheppard's triumph in the 1,500-meter race.
That eerie stillness which has descended on the United States is due, of course, to so many people not lifting a finger to promote their own candidacies.
DUBLIN, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Eamon de Valera said tonight that his Fianna Fall party was the victor in the Free State general election and that "now or later Ireland will win her complete independence."

MRS. FISKE was to the American theatre what Rejane was to France, Ellen Terry to England and Duse to Italy. She was the very last of her school, and with her passing the last great woman disappears from the American stage.

IT was unfortunately characteristic of the congested seasons of the Dance Repertory Theatre that such a delightful work as Charles Weidman's ballet version of Max Beerbohm's "The Happy Hypocrite" had its first performance a year ago before an audience too fed up with new works to give it due consideration.
THERE is a film which you have seen and, I hope, approved, which is nobody's child.

The need for retrenchment and economy would make it impossible for the Board of Education to carry out the recent recommendations of the Vocational Survey Commission for an ambitious program of vocational education in the near future, school officials declared yesterday.

AS has been reported recently, the English Ford Company is preparing to produce a "midget" automobile in Great Britain for the European market. What is known as the saloon model of the line is pictured above, with the permission of Autocar, English motor magazine.
Leases of private homes featured the Westchester realty dealings reported by brokers yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Moved by the plea of Mayor Cermak and civic groups to help Chicago in her financial chaos, four leading banks in the "Loop" today paid $2,917,451 in 1930 personal property taxes.

WARSAW, Feb. 18. -- The Memel affair is not likely to have present and probably even future, repercussions in Danzig as far as the Poles are concerned, for it is widely felt that a disturbance in Danzig now would damage rather than advance Polish aspirations.

REPORTS placed retail trade at a little higher level for the week, due to more favorable weather conditions and the introduction of fresh designs in various lines of merchandise. Final clearances of men's wear brought a somewhat better response.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- A denial of rumor that the Federal Farm Board was to impound its wheat led to general selling at the opening of the Board of Trade today, and some stop-loss orders were uncovered. Outside buying increased on the break, however, which, with purchases against bids, absorbed the surplus in tbe pit around 61 cents a bushel for the May, and a rally followed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Bank debits outside New York City during the week ending Feb. 13 were less than during the preceding week and the corresponding week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 19 -- Recently restored to the post of Minister of Finance which he held years ago. Albert J. Pani is almost as much of a mystery to the public as if he had never held public office. The reason is that the problems he faces are so different that his previous record does not provide any gauge.

Z.G. Simmons Jr. and F.O. Williams tied for the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday, each returning a card of 97. In the first 25-target shoot-off, they again tied with 23 each. In the second, Simmons won by breaking 25 straight.

PANAMA, R.P., Feb. 15 -- Reports of political unrest in Colombia are not surprising, in view of the difficult financial situation of the government and the extent of the business depression there. Indeed, when the task that faced and still faces President Olaya Herrera is fully considered, that there is not more political unrest may be credited largely to his energy, courage and political skill.

Operating costs which automobile owners may deduct from gross income in filing the Federal Income tax return due on or before March 15 were listed yesterday by T.M. Hentges, vice president of the New York Automobile Club. Some of these deductions apply only when the car is used wholly or chiefly for business, while others may be made by all automobile owners.

DRASTIC provisions establishing the liability of operators of aircraft for damages caused on the ground are contained in a draft prepared after discussions over a period of several years by the Comlte International Technique d'Experts Juridiques Aeriens -- known for brevity as "Citeja," which is now being brought to the attention of thirty governments which formed the committee.

THE value of the cinema as a means of propaganda was evldent to the Soviet Government immediately after the revolution, for when the Commissariat of Education was reorganized, the Photo - Cinematographic Department was brought directly under its supervision.

All the financial and commodity markets as well as the banks will be closed tomorrow in observance of Washington's Birthday. Foreign markets will be open as usual. In the United States, business will be resumed on Tuesday.

Speculative excitement over the Stock Exchange's newly adopted rule which takes away some of the brokers' privileges in the lending, of stocks had entirely subsided yesterday and the share market moved in a sedate, orderly manner. Prices were lower -- strikingly so in some instances -- as the pressure of pre-holiday selling was felt.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Capturing the last two races on the program, Ivar Ballangrud won the world's speed skating championship for Norway today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- How to decline gracefully an invitation to go head-hunting is one of the more delicate social problems of South American jungle explorers. That situation was faced by Matthew W. Stirling, scientist of the Smithsonian Institution, who is leading an expedition in the wilds of Ecuador making sound movies of the Jivaro Indians, the institution announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- A reappraisal of America's contribution to culture was suggested as "a job urgently calling educated men and women" by Dr. Harry T. Collings, Professor of Commerce in the Wharton School of Commerce and Finance, in an address today to the mid-year graduating class of the University of Pennsylvania.

There has been increasing talk of "frightfulness" in future wars. Recently the disarmament conference in Geneva heard proposals for the abolition of certain weapons, notably the submarine and lethal gas; and for the protection of civilian populations from bombing planes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor reported today that returns from 49,251 establishments in fifteen major industrial groups, having in January 4,362,503 employes, whose combined earnings in one week were $93,573,892, showed a decline of 3.9 per cent in employment, as compared with the December total and a decrease of 7.5 per cent in payroll total.

THIS report might well have been entitled, "A Banker Looks at the Book Industry," for Mr. Cheney served his State more than twenty years ago as Superintendent of Banks and has been a banker of more than ordinary prominence in more recent years.

Morton H. Fry, president of both the Reliance International Corporation and the Reliance Management Corporation, has sent to the stockholders of each company the detailed plan under which the former proposes to acquire control of the latter. Meetings of both bodies of stockholders will be held on March 22 to consider the plan.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 20 -- Indictment of a Brooklyn man charged with having arranged the marriage of his wife to another man who set him up in business, gave him grants of land in return for the "favor" and let him board at his house in Roslyn in the guise of a cousin of the bride, was revealed today by Richard Brown, Assistant District Attorney of Nassau County.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Feb. 20 -- A new $125,000 hospital building, the most complete of its kind on any army post and which is a part of the government's $3,000,000 construction program to replace the wartime wood structures here with modern brick fireproof buildings, was occupied today by the medical detachment of the Ninth Observation Group.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A system of economy, like a machine, can endure a long time merely by patching and repairing. When overhauling is delayed, a crisis arises. Ultimately it becomes a question, of reconstruction or collapse.

GEORGE ARLISS is now to be seen at the Warner Theatre in a most pleasing screen version of Gouverneur Morris's story, "The Man Who Played God," which was dramatized by Jules Eckert Goodman in 1914 and called "The Silent Voice."

AMONG all the many ways by which the people of this country are preparing to celebrate the bicentennial of Washington's birth year this noble and handsome volume must rank among the most notable and the most useful. For its inherent importance is of such measure and quality and the need for its service is so manifest that its usefulness will continue through the years.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 21 -- In striking contrast with the manner in which the Japanese load aboard transports the bodies of their soldier and sailor dead after dark and the manner in which the hard-pressed Chinese armies bury their dead in shallow trenches was the impressive military funeral accorded here today to the two British bluejackets killed by a Chinese shell Wednesday morning.

LIMA, Feb. 20 -- Because of continual torrential rains, which are assuming alarming proportions, the main railroad line in Peru has been cut at thirty different places, principally on the Sierra division.

DETROIT. THAT the automobile industry will reach its production and sales peaks later this year than usual is a conviction that grows among observers in Detroit. Last year the high point of production came in April and was followed by a sharp curtailment.

ATLANTA, Feb. 18 -- The allied forces of prohibition, its cohorts led by Dr. Daniel Poling, Major Raymond Robins and Robert C. Roff, descended upon the Gate City Wednesday and lost no time in assailing everything wet. Their onslaught seemed to be perfectly timed, as Atlanta's wet Mayor, James L. Key, had just learned he must run the gantlet of a recall election.

BEFORE "Blessed Event" opened at the Longacre Theatre nine days ago most of us would have said that the centrifugal night-club play could no longer be a source of innocent merriment. Ever since "Broadway" was produced in 1926 the centrifugally directed play ahout the carnival life of Gotham nights has heen a familiar commodity.
