A youthful thug, one of three who had boasted they would "kill a cop," was shot dead yesterday morning in a pistol battle with a young detective and a young patrolman who had interrupted the robbers in a restaurant on Broadway near Eighty-first Street during their third hold-up in a night of swashbuckling crime.
THERE are traffic policemen who are artists. They take their work seriously. Their fellows on the force point to them with pride. And yet, to the driving public, they are natural enemies.

MANILA, Jan. 23 -- The effects of the improved standard of living upon the birth rate in the Philippines are again strikingly demonstrated in the report of Jacobo Fajardo, director of the Bureau of Health, for 1931. The figure for 1,000 population jumped 6.7 points during the year, to reach the extraordinarily high mark of 56.53 births in the metropolitan district.

TOKYO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- It was reported today that Henry Pu Yi had refused to assume office in the new State of Ankuo unless he was made king or emperor, insisting upon a restoration of the glory of the Manchu dynasty and the "Dragon Throne."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Tension over the safety of the International Settlement because of the battle at Shanghai was somewhat lessened here today with the Japanese advance to the Kiangwan area. Danger to the Settlement, however, has not been removed and might become serious if the Japanese break the centre of the Chinese line and swing to the west in "mopping up" operations.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Navy continued undefeated in Intercollegiate Swimming Association competition by downing Pennsylvania at Hutchinson pool today, 42 to 29, but was upset at water polo when a fighting Red and Blue team came through in the closing minutes to win. 39 -- 32.

IF Western civilization, setting predictions at defiance, should after all escape collapse, it will not be because the critics have softened their attacks with apology or tempered their predictions with cheer. Indeed, the critics, if they can be observed to change at all, appear to become only the more outspoken and uncompromising.
PINEHURST, N.C. -- Three outstanding sport events and several other competitions will make for a busy social time at this resort during the week.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 20 -- The Harvard hockey team scored four goals in the first period today, which was amply sufficient to defeat DartMouth, 6 -- 2, and sweep the season's series.

THE Lenten season has in preparation numerous musical entertainments for the diversion of members of society. One in the near future will be a performance of "Face the Music," the new musical comedy by Irving Berlin and Moss Hart, on the night of March 2 at the New Amsterdam Theatre.

With so much grist to grind these days, legislative mills apparently need more machinery. State Government, organ of the American Legislators' Association, reports a 50 per cent increase in interim committees and commission of one sort or another during the past two years.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- A great tennis week for Bermuda is scheduled to start on Tuesday on the newly constructed courts of the Bermuda Lawn Tennis Club just on the outskirts of Hamilton. In past years many of the world's leading players have been attracted here for this annual event, among them several former American national champions, but the field this year outstrips all others.

Tribute to the memory of George Washington and especially to the first President's work in establishing religious freedom in this country was paid yesterday in synagogues throughout the city. Special Washington bicentennial services were held in addition to the regular Jewish sabbath rites.

Although its views on the subject are expressed in undertones, Wall Street appears to be pleased by the fact that the sacrosanct character of the Federal Reserve act does not prevent its alteration to meet a national emergency. Speedy passage of the Glass-Steagall bill by both the House and the Senate was, from the Wall Street point of view, the overshadowing event of last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- James D. Preston, for thirty-four years superintendent of the press gallery, was "impeached" by its members today for having resigned in violation of an implied contract to remain for 100 years. An engraved silver service and a purse were presented to him after he was found "guilty of devotion, friendship and service far beyond the average known among your fellow-men."

GOVERNMENT should put its house in order, and balance the budget, and instead of eternally looking for new sources of revenue it should make a determined try at spending not more, not the same amount, but less of the earnings and savings of the American people.

WHEN Sir Oliver Lodge writes on the ether or the atom he fascinates his reader by his clearness, his literary skill, his allowance for the technical Ignorance of his readers. But when he writes about himself we miss the old freedom.

THE recent $2,000,000 bequest to the New York Public Library in the will of Lewis Cass Ledyard increases the principal funds, whose income supports the reference department of the institution, to around $40,000,000. It was the first large donation made to the library in several years.

PARIS, Feb. 20 -- With characteristic energy. Andre Tardieu, who was asked by President Doumer to form a Ministry late this afternoon, completed his consultations and announced his Cabinet before 12:30 tonight.

THESE two books, like others published in recent months, indicate a return of the pendulum in the treatment of Washington. A few years ago It was complained that men saw him through a golden haze of eulogy. We were told that panegyric should be brushed away and the "real" or "human" Washington revealed.

HENRI BARBUSSE, the celebrated French writer whose war novel "Le Feu" won world renown, declares in his admirable introduction to this important collection that the first duty of the modern Spanish writer is "to watch over the fidelity, the purity, and the thoroughness of the revolution of April," for the spirit behind this movement is the stuff of which literature is made.

RICHARD CAMERON BEER, brother of Thomas Beer, the author, announces that he will open on March 1 a gallery in which young American artists, particularly those handicapped by lack of funds, may exhibit their work. Mr. Beer proposes to conduct this enterprise along the lines of the Opportunity Gallery at the Art Centre, which has been inactive most of this season.

WERE the State Department of the United States to use some other term than "Latin -American Division" to indicate the branch which supervises our relations with the countries south of the Rio Grande, it would add greatly to its prestige in South America.

The charge that the Republican majority in the Legislature frequently rejects measures sponsored by Democrats for purely partisan, reasons and then puts through similar legislation in slightly different form was made yesterday by Senator John J. Dunnigan, majority leader, and Senator Thomas F. Burchill.

PARIS. THE year of 1932 will probably continue to be a year of economic crisis; but it will not be, in France, a year of literary crisis'. The season has already seen the publication of two fine novels, "Saint-Saturnin" and "Claire."

LOUISVILLE Ky., Feb. 20 -- Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight champion, will be impreased into Kentucky's army next week with the rank of Colonel. Governor Ruby Laffoon has the Kentucky Colonel commission ready to present to the boxer, perhaps as a reward for creating more excitement in Kentucky sporting circles than they have experienced in many a day -- with the exception of Derby days, of course.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20 -- To the Brookmeade Stable of Mrs. Isabelle Sloane went the distinction of winning the Nursery Stakes No. 1, feature at Hialeah Park today. The stake is for juvenile colts and geldings. Okapi, a son of Eternal from Oktibbena, was the winner under 122 pounds, and he equaled the three-furlong track record in his speedy dash to victory.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- The Syracuse University basketball team vanquished the University of Rochester tonight, 29 to 11. The losers were held to one field goal.

EVA LE GALLIENNE stepped off the Ile de France last Monday morning and by noon the drama was looking up again in West Fourteenth Street. By 4 P.M. it was by way of being in a furor, and by this morning her next Civic Repertory season -- the sixth -- must be all but blocked out.

JUDGE BENJAMIN NATHAN CARDOSO's elevation to the United States Supreme Court will add to that body a jurist who, like Justices Brandeis and Hughes and former Justice Holmes, may be described as liberal. But the adjective in any of these cases Is too vague.

IN "The Puritan" Liam O'Flaherty returns to the fast-paced technique and the general type of problem that made two of his earlier books, "The Informer" and "The Assassin," such superlatively exciting reading. Again he has written an ethical detective story -- or, as some one has described the genre, a "melodrama of the conscience.

Virtually all the prominent bridge players in the East and many more players in quest of fame have entered the sixth annual Eastern championship bridge tournament which opens tomorrow at the Hotel Roosevelt. Five events are scheduled, with the interest centring on the contract-pair and contract team-of-four championships.

RADIO is replete with "success" stories -- stories of people who came from comparative obscurity to national and almost overnight prominence. A list of such people would read like a Who's Who in Broadcasting. The ascent of Gertrude Berg has been even swifter than that of her fortuitous brain-child -- "The Rise of the Goldbergs."

Sermon themes today in the city's churches will largely deal with aspects of the life of George Washington. Masons will attend many of the services in groups. Special ceremonies will be conducted, particularly in the Protestant Episcopal churches.

RECOMMENDED routes in and out of Manhattan, the Bronx, Long Island, Westchester and Staten Island have been listed after a survey by Earnest Bearnarth, director of the travel bureau of the New York Automobile Club, and are given as follows:

Bonds called last week for redemption in the remaining days of February, before their maturity dates, consisted entirely of parts of municipal issues. Those called to date for retirement this month aggregate $36,170,000, compared with $70,631,000 In January and with, $54,481,000 in February, 1931, at corresponding dates.

TACOMA, Wash., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Professor Richard Pierce, architectural instructor at the University of Washington, was buried by a snow-slide which hurtled down from Mazama Ridge into Paradise Valley late today.

GENERAL RAFAEL DE NOGALES is that soldier of fortune whose memoirs of his fighting with the Turks in the great war came out under the title of "Four Years Beneath the Crescent." In another book the General has dealt with "The Looting of Nicaragua."

Property owners and architects interested in the development of the Riverside Drive section came to its defense yesterday with vigorous protests against the charge of Henry Wright, New York architect, that the neighborhood had been built up with apartment houses which were "slums or potential slums."

THE name of George Washington will re-echo round the globe tomorrow from morning until late at night when world leaders honor the memory of the first President in ceremonies ushering in the bicentennial of his birth.

METROPOLITAN MUSEUM -- Portraits of Washington, in the Alexandria Assembly Room of the American Wing, and paintings by Samuel F.B. Morse in Gallery D6. These opened to the public last Tuesday and were "reviewed Feb. 14 in the news columns.

IRVLNGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Attempting to rescue another skater who had crashed through the ice on Beltzhoover Pond on the estate of Benjamin S. Halsey near Harrlman Road, George Griffin, 17 years old, assistant Scoutmaster of a Dobbs Ferry boy Scout troop, lost his life today when the ice beneath him crumbled and he fell beneath the pond's frozen surface.

Formal regulations to govern the operation of the Police Department's new radio alarm system, which will flash reports of crimes of violence and other law infractions to 220 department automobiles cruising throughout the city, were sent yesterday by Commissioner Mulrooney to every precinct and detective office in the five boroughs.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The coming week will witness the beginning of campaign activities by the State Republicans. At the committee meeting in New York City on Friday preparations for the representation of the State at the Republican National Convention in June will be made by the election of a prearranged slate of delegates-at-large who regard the renomination of President Hoover as a foregone conclusion.

WHEN we at the disarmament conference demand equality and equal security, we there-by mean that this condition, the onesided disarmament of Germany and the insecurity of Germany resulting therefrom, must cease. President Wilson, who in the course of his fourteen points demanded disarmament and who tenaciously fought for this demand at the conclusion of peace, endeavored to secure universal and equal disarmament of all nations as a safeguard against future wars.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Intimations that the drys would enter a candidate in the State's Senatorial primary to oppose Senator James J. Davis were given here today by Governor Pinchot, who said he had been asked to "talk with certain gentlemen" on the subject of such an opponent.

R. Stanley Dollar, president of the Dollar Steamship Company, conferred several times during the last week with officers of the Roosevelt International Mercantile Marine Company on matters pertaining to the merger of their interests in the purchase of the United States Lines from Paul W. Chapman and his associates.

A BICENTENNIAL, two centenials and one milestone that might be designated mezzo-centennial, give the week festive look. As for "Washingtonia," you meet with examples in every other shop window, while, if you wish them in concentrated or top-notch form, there are plenty of exhibitions on or pending -- at Ehrich's, at the Art Centre, at the Old Print Shop at Macy's, at Arnold Constable's.

Playing spectacularly from the start to the close of the game, the Fordham University basketball team scored a 27-to-26 triumph over the strong New York University quintet in the Fordham gymnasium last night.

MOSCOW, Keb. 19 -- There is probably less popular interest in Russia regarding the events in the Far East than any other country in the world. At this time, when cables from Shanghai and Tokyo occupy the front pages of the English and American press, the Russian newspapers print only brief dispatches, more like those in tabloid papers.

Isamu Noguchi is having two exhibitions simultaneously in New York: sculpture at the John Becker Gallery and brush drawings at Demotte's. The young artist's cosmopolitan career is thus summarized in the Demotte catalogue:

SEVERAL card parties will take place in the near future to augment the funds of charitable enterprises. Members of the board of directors of the Catholic Young Women's Club will give their annual luncheon, followed by bridge, on the afternoon of March 8 at Sherry's in behalf of the philanthropic activities of the organization.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Cornell, the surprise team of the Eastern Intercollegiate League, defeated Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, 30 to 24.

IT would be misleading to interpret literally the subtitle of The Colophon. This delectable publication may be a "Book-Collectors' Quarterly" in intention, but an inquiry into its distribution, at the end of its second year of life, reveals that it does not always fulfill this function.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- An outspoken opinion of Great Britain's policy in Shanghai was uttered by General Sir lan Hamilton, presiding today at the annual British Legion conference in London. "In The Times of Feb. 18 six gentlemen of the League of Nations beat a war drum and called on the British to head a crusade against their old allies, the Japanese," he declared.

Approximately $60,000,000 due American companies is tied up in Latin-American countries because of exchange conditions, according to an estimate made by the Committee on Inter-American Relations in a summary of 1931 trade developments in South and Central American countries released yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20 -- A call for a special meeting of the Democratic State Central Committee, to be issued immediately, will be the opening gun in a State and national campaign which will be featured, as far as the State is concerned, with the election of a Senator, a Governor, six Representatives and the biennial General Assembly.

SINCE it would not be difficult to maintain the thesis that just now, in what is rapidly becoming the worst of all possible worlds, the sum total of mentality has sunk to the jungle level of darkness, savagery and ineptitude. Dr. Swift's book ought to have welcome, at least from those who still hope it may be possible to find a way out into the open and the sunlight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The nation's celebration of the 200th anniversary of the birth of George Washington will begin at noon Monday when President Hoover will pay tribute to the achievements of the first President before a joint session of the Congress. The exercises in the House of Representatives, where President Hoover will speak, will also he broadcast over nation-wide chains.

Realty brokers viewed with considerable satisfaction the results of the apartment house situation on Manhattan Island issued last week by Tenement House Commissioner William F. Deegan. In spite of the large number of vacancies, the east side Park Avenue area from Forty-sixth to Eighty-sixth Street, Fifth to Lexington Avenue, made the very creditable showing of vacancy percentage of only 7.68.

A change in the traditional method of handling retail expenses, featuring an indirect way of increasing markup which if generally adopted would improve the profit showing of stores, was outlined here yesterday by H.I. Kleinhaus, manager of the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Feb. 21 -- "We are making much more rapid progress than has been expected and the battle will soon be over and the danger to Shanghai past," said an official statement issued by the Japanese Legation this morning at 10:30.
Negotiations for a speedy termination of the strike of 23,000 dressmnkera which began last Tuesday will be held tomorrow by representatives of the union and the jobbers and "Inside" manufacturers.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Americans who have frequented the Hotel Drouot here, where old treasures are sold at auction, will see one of the celebrated show places near Paris, the chateau de Mereville, forty miles south, go under the hammer soon.

GIBRALTAR, Feb. 20 -- Because information from Berlin on the chemical composition of a drug believed to have been taken by Miss Cook failed to arrive, British authorities today failed to complete their analysis, as had been expected.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The intensive campaign of the Citizens' Reconstruction Organization to bring hoarded cash into circulation was set today for the period of March 7 to 15.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. THIS is a season when the critic holds his ear close to the ground listening hopefully for every suggestion of music. However distant it may be, he greets it with delight and enthusiasm. For this is a season when the theatre is in bitter discord, when it is fighting for its very existence.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 18 -- Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt, all thing's considered, would be expected to carry Wisconsin's delegation to the Democratic National Convention in the April election with no extra steam necessary to achieve that result. In general, his views square with those of the La Follette group which is in full political control hereabout.

I WAS convinced the dome I had Seen was one of the eggs. Lo, that bird alighted upon the dome and brooded over it with its wings, stretching out its legs upon the ground." Thus Sinbad the Sailor described the fabulous bird, "as big as a mountain," that "fed its young ones on elephants" and flew off across mountains and seas carrying Sinbad in its claws.

Profit-taking continued yesterday on the New York Curb Exchange, with renewed short selling also in evidence, resulting in moderate declines in most of the market leaders. Domestic bonds were weaker, and foreign issues mostly showed losses on the day.

AUGUSTA, Ga -- Devereux Milburn, internationally famous polo back, will play with the Augusta team against Aiken to dedicate the new $50,000 municipal polo field here. Preparations have been made for 50,000 spectators.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To those of us Americans who have the good fortune to be in Geneva during these historic days, at the opening of the World Disarmament Conference, the skyline of national and international, politics takes on a clearer aspect.

A controversy concerning the advisability of allowing corporations whose shares are listed on the New York Stock Exchange to buy their own stock In the open market has been stimulated among brokers in Wall Street by the annual reports recently issued by many companies, which show that such purchases reached a new high record last year.

WHAT is sauce for the goose, runs the old proverb, is sauce for the gander. And if a Romanoff Grand Ducheas has a tale to tell, why not a Grand Duke? As a matter of fact, these memoirs of Grand Duke Alexander, grandson of Czar Nicholas I and brother-in-law of the last Romanoff Emperor, have a greater historical interest than the reminiscences which the Grand Duchess Marie published as "The Education of a Princess."

TOKYO, Feb. 20 -- At an audience this morning Theodore Roosevelt had only a short formal conversation with Emperor Hirohito but at luncheon they had a long talk. The Emperor asked many questions regarding Mr. Roosevelt's hunting expedition in Indo-China and Tibet and also expressed appreciation of the late President Theodore Roosevelt's many acts of friendship toward Japan.

Charles C. Peterson of St. Louis, fancy shot billiard champion of the world, will defend his honors against Isidro Ribas of Spain in the fourth match of the five-city series at the New York Elks Club at 108 West Forty-third Street starting tomorrow night.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Feb. 20 -- With minor cuts and scratches to tell the tale, two Hicksville youths had a miraculous escape from death this afternoon when their automobile was rammed by an express train, traveling at 50 miles an hour, at the South Oyster Bay Road grade crossing, half a mile south of here.

More extensive commercial extploitation of the products and byproducts of industrial research in fields non-competitive with the one in which they were originated is a vital step in aiding business recovery, according to Maurice Holland, director of the division of engineering and industrial research of the National Research Council.

An extremely rare autograph letter by Izaak Walton, author of "The Compleat Angler," has been brought to America by Gabriel Wells. Few seventeenth century authors appear to have been more liberal than was Walton in presenting inscribed copies of their books and to have been more confirmed annotators of books in their own possession.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 20 -- Nate C. Brown of New York, former army aviator, landed at 5:10 this afternoon at the Portland Airport in his big, bright red plane in which he intends to attempt a long-distance flight from Old Orchard Beach, possibly tomorrow.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: Mr. R.A. Marr Jr., a direct descendant of Commodore James Barron, has disapproved of THE TIMES review of my new biography, "Decatur." He is much concerned to defend his ancestor, when nothing is less necessary.

OMAHA, Feb. 18 -- Political interest in the corn belt received considerable impetus from the statement of Alfred E. Smith announcing his passive receptivity and from that of Jouett Shouse, pleading for uninstructed delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

IT is difficult to classify this book because of the great amount of miscellaneous Information which It contains. The publishers are Justified In proclaiming It "a new and valuable survey of contemporary American music in the community, employing the findings of the nation-wide research of the National Recreation Association."

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 18 -- How to accelerate the Supreme Court's unhurried tempo without running the risk of a citation for contempt is a problem worrying many plaintiffs, defendants and lawyers in this State.

A subpoena has been sent to all banks and brokerage houses in the city, it became known yesterday, in connection with an investigation by tha Hofstadter Committee into the financial transactions of George S. Collins, executive secretary to Mayor Walker.

Record-breaking performances by Sid Bernstein of Alexander Hamilton and Louis Burns of Bryant featured the annual Manual Training high school interscholastlc track and field meet, in which the host school captured the team honors and a total of seven new meet records were created, at the 245th Coast Defense Armory in Brooklyn yesterday.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- Many prominent Northern visitors intend to take part in crowded programs of activities scheduled for the last week of February and early March here. Among the events of interest to the leading men golfers of the colony will be the Sand Pipers' medal tournament, set for Saturday, and the Spring Sweepstakes, scheduled for March 5.

An oath administered 2,000 years ago to the young men of Athens when they were inducted into citizenship was taken yesterday by 200 high school graduates who have been recognized by the Cooperation-in-Government movement as leaders in school activities and who are destined to set ideals of good citizenship in their individual walks of life.

BUFFALO, Feb. 20 -- Speaking to Erie County Democrats tonight Governor Roosevelt demanded repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and return of liquor control to the individual States as a means of meeting pressing problems in current governmental economics.

MADRID, Feb. 20 -- Spain today announced her first republican budget, balancing it on paper only by calling for an internal loan of 500,000,000 pesetas, which is about $40,000,000 at the present depreciated currency rate. Total expenditures are put at $305,000,000.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 20 -- A decline of $223,759 in gold production by Ontario gold mines in January, compared with the high record of December, has been announced by the Provincial Department of Mines. In December the output reached $3,906,467, while in January it was $3,682,708, which, however, was well ahead of January, 1931, when the value was $3,280,032.

IT is difficult to understand why yet another book should appear about the gold rush in Johannesburg, trekking across Central Africa, encounters with native tribes, wild animals and malaria, except that the author happens to have been a member of that famous company of Mounted Police that was organized by Cecil Rhodes "to explore and subdue a great section of Matabeleland and Mashonaland and create an empire out of the wilda."

THAT there were two Mathilde Wesendoncks and that the name of Wagner's "immortal beloved" was originally not Mathilde at all is a piece of news which the February issue of the Zeitschrift fur Musik gives for what it may be worth.

With parades, meetings, addresses, flag displays, religious services and radio observances, New York City and its environs, in common with the rest of the country and many other parts of the world, will celebrate today and tomorrow the 200th anniversary of the birth of George Washington.

WHAT appears to be one of the most intriguing avocations of present-day historians of the hypothetical is to erect a philosophical edifice for the "isms" of which they have made use in expounding their various historical theses.

MEASURED by small things, Georgre Washington's career was far from being an uninterrupted series of successes. He had none of the arrogance, none of the blind confidence in his "star" that characterizes an Alexander, a Frederick the Great or a Napoleon.

WHAT Is London's "Verge"? Probably few Londoners could answer the question, although at Buckingham Palace there is a special little court which deals with certain matters connected with it. The members of this court are known as the Justices of the Verge of the Palaces.

International exchange of teachers is valuable in promoting both education and world-wide amity, and legislation which hampers it should be abolished here, according to Miss Margaret Lambie, a member of the bar of New York State and the District of Columbia.

ONE of the best known plays for children, "Pinocchio," will be presented by the Junior League Players this week as the second offering this season in a series of children's plays. The performances will be given in the Great Hall of the clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street on Friday afternoon and Saturday morning and afternoon.
BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- Two pool records were broken as Dartmouth's varsity swimming team won a 59-18 victory over M.I.T. in the University Club pool today.

IT is generally supposed that opinion in France is united upon the subject of military policy and disarmament. We have been repeatedly told that France is committed to the policy of conscription, on the ground that it is both cheap and democratic; and that France will disarm only when her demands as to "security" are met.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Tactics used on the Western Front in the World War have been adopted by the Chinese and the Japanese in the battle of Shanghai, according to military experts here. They said today that upon the basis of the latest advices it was too early to estimate the prospect of Japanese success.

PALM BEACH -- Fairly overlapping on the week's program here are events any one of which would dominate an entire week earlier in the season. The first five days particularly are so full of varied activity that hours will have to be carefully planned for society at this resort to attend any considerable number of them.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 20 -- A passenger train bound from Mexico City to Jalapa, capital of the State of Vera Cruz, was held up near Pavon early this morning by a group of well-armed bandits.

DEBONAIR DEBUCHI. ANY time that Ambassador Katsuji Debuchi emerges from the Japanese Embassy in Washington these days and enters what all too often is written "a waiting automobile," the chauffeur must know by this time where he is going.

THE changing of the title of Ernst Lubitsch's film now at the Criterion from "The Man I Killed," a literal translation of the title of Maurice Rostand's play from which it was adapted, to "Broken Lullaby," recalls the many alterations names of books and plays have undergone when brought to the screen.

INDIA these days is proving a profitable market for out-of-atyle American shoes and second-band American clothes. Those Indians who wear cheap clothing are not accustomed to wearing trousers, so few are sold there. But cots, overcoats and vests find a ready sale.

MR. CUTHBERTSON has had years of experience on the Great Lakes. He has painted and sketched the ships and scenes which he describes and his book is generously illustrated with colorful reproductions of some excellent portraits and drawings.

The struggle for the Catholic High Schools' Athletic Association hockey championship remained deadlocked last night after the second clash between Brooklyn Prep and La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale, L.I. These two teams, which played a 4-4 draw last week, battled through another overtime tie game at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, 1 to 1.

THE Bureau of Part-Time Work, founded to utilize the abilities of trained women who desire to work on a short-hour schedule, has just completed ten years of usefulness, during which it has demonstrated that the short day is feasible in many fields of work.

UNION LEAGUE CLUB -- Exhibition of old and modern English and American sporting prints, arranged by Eugene V. Connett Jr. through the courtesy of Messrs. Arthur Ackermann Son, Inc. This is one of the largest and finest displays of sporting prints held in New York in many a day.

AUSTIN, Texas. Feb. 20 (AP) -- Discovery that no injunction was in effect at this time against military control of the East Texas oil field caused Governor Sterling to renew his seventy-five-barrel-per-well daily allowable order against all operators in the area today.

BRUNO WALTER, whose seven-week incumbency of the Philharmonic - Symphony conductorship has been productive of more solo appearances with the orchestra than is customary, will begin his final week of concerts on Thursday with himself as piano soloist in a Mozart concerto.
The City College basketball team compiled its biggest score of the season to conquer Lehigh University, 50 to 29, last night in the Lavender gym.
Six of the eight seeded players have survived the first two rounds of the national Class C squash tennis championship now in progress at the Park Avenue Squash Club.

BERLIN, Feb. 20 -- Three men sat at a luncheon table here today in the beat hotel in Europe, which, despite the war readjustment and depressions, is still in German possession. They discussed the German debts, political and private, and her willingness and capacity to pay them.

PLANS are already well advanced for the 3932 National Air Races at Cleveland. Clifford Henderson, general manager of the races, is now touring the country obtaining expert opinion from manufacturer, pilots and engine builders on the program which is to include no less than ten free-for-all events.

HOLLYWOOD. Cal. CONSIDERABLE interest is being evinced by the cinema industry in the outcome of Tom Mix's return to the screen in his first talking picture, now being filmed by Universal. The children, a problem to Hollywood as well as their parents, have not followed the theatre with as much avidity since the screen became garrulous as Was shown during the days of golden silence.

THOUGH some of the writings of soldiers have emerged as classics, few Generals, regrettably, understand the art of writing. Sir George MacMunn is not among the rare exceptions. Glorying, as he evidently does, in the fame and capacity of Gustavus Adolphus, he falls short of either sufficiently dramatizing the life of his hero or of choosing language incisive enough to set forth his deeds in memorable form.

DR. SALLI FINKELSTEIN of Warsaw, ready to have his powers as a lightning calculator tested, is given two numbers to multiply together, each consisting of three figures. The answer is noted on a piece of paper almost immediately.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Mrs. Mary Richmond Pressly of La Jolla, Cal. has recently presented to Wells College a number of documents relating to the early history of Aurora, New York.

LONDON, Feb. 5 EVER since John Palmer published his book on the contemporary French dramatists and the work of Lenormand and Jean-Jacques Bernard began to appear over here, there has been a certain sharpness in our controversies about the French stage.

Yale's swimming team, many times champion of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association, remained in the ranks of the undefeated last night by defeating Columbia, 47 -- 24, in the Morningside Heights pool.

Town Hall, having to prepare an hour's lecture on one subject, I discovered that I was present at a symposium and was expected to speak for but twelve minutes on the difficulty of obtaining theatre tickets, a matter which, at the moment, did not intrigue me.

THE Nash Motors Company will introduce its 1932 line of cars in New York and elsewhere throughout the country next Saturday, it is reported. The line will include five series, four eights and a six, and shipments of the cars to dealers and distributers are now going on.

MR. ZIEGFELD'S "Hot-Cha!" (and Mr. Brown's, Mr. Henderson's, Mr. Hellinger's and Mr. Lahr's, too, for that matter) took tryout steps last Monday night at the National Theatre in Washington, whence it moves tomorrow evening to Pittsburgh, then probably to Newark and finally, if all in well in an uncertain world, to the mansion at Sixth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street on March 8.

FRANKFURT AM MAIN, Feb. 8. -- Nothing will more astound the future historian of our period than the contrast between our helpless floundering in the morass of our economics, even though they are of our own making, and the purposefulness and precision with which our science masters one after another the hidden intricacies of nature, sometimes succeeding in imitating her, now and then even improving on her work.

Has teaching, like stenography, frequently In this country served merely as a first step out of the flannel-shirt into the white-collar class? Dr. Clarence Linton of Teachers College, Columbia University, implied last week in an address before the Child Study Association that a chief trouble with our schools lies in the calibre and origin of much of their teaching force.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 20 -- Columbia took undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by defeating Dartmouth, 42 -- 32, in a thrilling game.

As Congress has passed successive measures for aids to recovery, there has been the usual disposition to dispute over the question who deserves the credit for them. Various Democratic leaders have challenged the claims of the friends of the President that he is entitled to the palm.

While many of the richest Latin-American countries have been defaulting on their bonds in recent months, Nicaragua, one of the most restricted economically, has been steadily paying off on hers, it was revealed here last week with the departure of Irving A. Lindberg, collector general of customs and high commissioner, for his post at Managua after conferences with British and American bankers.

VIENNA, Feb. 18. -- Austria discovered this week that its principal bank, two-thirds of its industry, its State theatre and even the direction of its financial and economic policy are all under control of foreigners, and as a consequence Austria is feeling sad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Hoover will take steps soon to put his name before the voters of Ohio as a candidate for re-election. This was indicated today by Walter Brown. Postmaster General, who was just returned to Washington from Ohio, where he made a survey of the political situation.

THE characters and qualifications of the travelers who have contributed these three books to our knowledge of South America well illustrate the variety of the appeal that the southern continent now possesses to those of us in the English-speaking latitudes.

AT first glance this book would seem to be merely a literary stunt, but it turns out to be a really good mystery in spite of the unusual circumstances attending its writing. The authors are all members of the Detection Club, a private association of writers of detective fiction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Following the Republican charge that the Byrns bill consolidating the army and navy into a "Department of National Defense" was "railroaded" through the Committee on Expenditures, Chairman Cochran, after a stormy session this morning, gave up his plan to report it favorably today and allowed the measure to be sent to a subcommittee for redrafting.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 20 (Canedian Press) -- Canadian butter exports in the last two months were more than nine times what they were in the previous year. Last month the quantity sent abroad was 112.600 pounds, valued at $28,048, compared with 65,900 pounds at $23,459 in January, 1931.

DAYTONA BEACH. Fla., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Sir Malcolm Campbell made two practice runs over a bumpy beach in his record-holding Bluebird racing car today and afterward declared, "It was the worst drive I ever had in my life."

OTTAWA, Feb. 18 -- Nationalization of radio broadcasting in Canada has come a step closer through the decision of the Privy Council which establishes Federal jurisdiction over the industry from microphone to receiving set.

MANY reservations have been made in several large Eastern cities for the West Indies cruise on the Britannic which has been arranged in aid of the Frontier Nursing Service. The steamship will leave New York next Saturday for a sixteen days' trip to Southern ports at the height of the season in those places, and will return to New York March 13.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts denied today that he had pleaded Congressional immunity in responding to a libel suit filed by Bishop Cannon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The theory advanced in THE TIMES regarding the decline of the Mayan Empire in Guatemala and Mexico is extremely interesting. In considering not only the decline and end of that great empire, but its origin, may I submit a theory of mine, which possibly has occurred to others interested in the subject?

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- Paris during any Ministerial crisis is a hectic place to be in, but it has been especially feverish during this one. The reason behind much of the excitement, as well as virtually all the manoeuvring, is the forthcoming elections.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In a curious book I have just read, entitled "The Book of Wonderful Characters," published in London in 1876, I find the following:

THIS is a book first of all for the practical men -- the engineer, the real estate owner or the underwriter but it is so written that a great deal of its contents are of interest to the ordinary reader, andit should find a place as a frequently-consulted reference book on the shelves of every public library.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The British Cabinet's "Shanghai committee" remained in London today, watchful for any emergency which might threaten British lives and property in the Far East.

This vast drama being borne in upon us today, in which plenty stands side by side with, poverty -- what meaning has it for education? An answer to the question from the standpoint of progressive education was made by Professor Counts of Teachers College, Columbia, University, in his address last week at the annual banquet of the Progressive Education Association in Baltimore, Md.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 20 -- Stiff Japanese protests are being prepared against the action of American marines who on Friday night made a surprise descent and simultaneous search in eight Japanese-owned cotton mills and confiscated two truckloads of weapons and signaling equipment.

The ninety-seventh three-day convention of the National Puzzlers' League, Inc., opened yesterday afternoon at the Hotel New Yorker, with a reception to the delegates, amateur puzzle enthusiasts from all parts of the country. Lawyers, physicians, editors, bankers, artists, school teachers and farmers were represented.

DALLAS, Feb. 19 -- Texans are going to witness another "dog fight" for the Governorship this Summer. It became inevitable this week when Mrs. Miriam A. Ferguson, the famous "Ma" who in 1924 was the first woman ever elected Governor, announced that she would again seek the Democratic nomination.

STARTING the last third of New York's musical season, the coming seventeenth week at the Metropolitan adds three operas to the current list -- "La Juive," "Das Rheingold" and "Romeo et Juliette" -- as well as three new or returning artists, Mme. Schumann-Heink, Grace Moore and Arthur Anderson.
Degrees will be given to 390 students at City College who completed courses during the Fall semester, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Morton Gottschall, registrar.
Three last period goals brought the Pennsylvania Military College polo team back from the rim of defeat at the Squadron A Armory last night for a victory over the Fort Hamilton team, 5 1/2 to 5.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 10 -- The provisional government is studying the proposed draft for a new general treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation with Uruguay, which was drawn up by the delegates to the bilateral section of the recent economic conference at Montevideo which was attended by delegates of Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 18 -- Maintaining only a minor connection with China's hectic political life. Dr. C.C. Wu, former Chinese Minister to Washington, is associating himself with an ambitious project to develop the island of Hainan, off the coast of South China, which is declared to be one of the richest areas in the country but sadly needs development.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 MOURNING BECOMES ELECTRA," as acted by the Theatre Guild's touring company, came to Chicago last Monday, and the playgoing intelligentsia is more or Iess agog on the subject. The outburst of newspaper praise was not so unanimous or rhapsodic as it was in New York; certain exceptions were taken to the work and certain remarks were passed about its desolating effect upon the patience and nerves.

Belief that Congress can be induced at its present session to adopt a reciprocal tariff policy for this country was expressed here yesterday by George F. Bauer, chairman of the recently organized World Trade League, non-partisan association for liberalization of this country's tariff.

The telephone companies have faced only a moderate reduction In their revenues through the depression. The gross operating revenue of the twenty-one associated companies of the Bell System and a subsidiary of one of these amounted to $979,727,721 in 1931, the reports to the Interstate Commerce Commission show, comparing with 51,003,719,716 in 1930, a decline of 2.39 per cent.

New record achievements for the three outstanding athletes of the indoor season -- Gene Venzke, George Spitz and Leo Sexton -- are in prospect tomorrow night when this trio of world's record-breakers compete in the twenty-sixth annual national indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.

TOKYO, Feb. 20 -- Dispatches received from Naotake Sato at Geneva today revealed such gloomy misapprehensions of the present situation in China that Foreign Minister Yoshizawa cabled a reply intended to reassure Mr. Sato and dispel the misunderstandings.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 20 -- Stiff Japanese protests are being prepared against the action of American marines who on Friday night made a surprise descent and simultaneous search in eight Japanese-owned cotton mills and confiscated two truckloads of weapons and signaling equipment.

The ninety-seventh three-day convention of the National Puzzlers' League, Inc., opened yesterday afternoon at the Hotel New Yorker, with a reception to the delegates, amateur puzzle enthusiasts from all parts of the country. Lawyers, physicians, editors, bankers, artists, school teachers and farmers were represented.

Wu, former Chinese Minister to Washington, is associating himself with an ambitious project to develop the island of Hainan, off the coast of South China, which is declared to be one of the richest areas in the country but sadly needs development.

The outburst of newspaper praise was not so unanimous or rhapsodic as it was in New York; certain exceptions were taken to the work and certain remarks were passed about its desolating effect upon the patience and nerves.

Belief that Congress can be induced at its present session to adopt a reciprocal tariff policy for this country was expressed here yesterday by George F. Bauer, chairman of the recently organized World Trade League, non-partisan association for liberalization of this country's tariff.

The telephone companies have faced only a moderate reduction In their revenues through the depression. The gross operating revenue of the twenty-one associated companies of the Bell System and a subsidiary of one of these amounted to $979,727,721 in 1931, the reports to the Interstate Commerce Commission show, comparing with 51,003,719,716 in 1930, a decline of 2.39 per cent.

New record achievements for the three outstanding athletes of the indoor season -- Gene Venzke, George Spitz and Leo Sexton -- are in prospect tomorrow night when this trio of world's record-breakers compete in the twenty-sixth annual national indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.

TOKYO, Feb. 20 -- Dispatches received from Naotake Sato at Geneva today revealed such gloomy misapprehensions of the present situation in China that Foreign Minister Yoshizawa cabled a reply intended to reassure Mr. Sato and dispel the misunderstandings.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest the editorial in THE TIMES about the repudiated bonds of our Southern States. I cannot pretend to have made a study of this question and therefore I write as much for information as for argument.

THERE was no disappointment a few days ago when M.H. Aylesworth, president of the National Broadcasting Company, reported to the organization's advisory council and summed up the activities of the past year. He announced that in the face of depression 231 clients sponsored programs and the gross revenue was $29,500,000, compared with $22,000,000 in 1930.

To the Editor of The New York times: There are few countries in Europe which, through the centuries, have fought for liberty as have the Southern Slavs. One of the outstanding results of the World War was their liberation from, foreign yoke and their final union by the creation of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia.

BEANS REARDON, the National League umpire who went to Japan with the touring teams last Fall, has been sighted on a Los Angeles side street wearing a flowery Japanese kimono he acquired in the Land of the Rising Sun. There's an idea for John Heydler. To add color to the National League campaign, he might equip all his umpires with brilliant kimonos.

With enactment of the Glass-Steagall bill assured, Wall Street is awaiting with interest the first indications of what use the Federal Reserve Board intends to make of its new powers. Some definite sign may be expected with the opening of business on Tuesday in the view of money market experts, for the Reserve Bank will have to take action if it wishes to forestall a rise in rates on open market bills.

Dennis King, who scored a personal success in the operetta,. "The Vagabond King," has been engaged by Horace Liveright for the star role in his forthcoming musical show, tentatively called "It Happened in Italy," Mr. Liveright said yesterday. Rehearsals of the production, which is based on the life of Lucrezia Borgia, are scheduled to begin on Feb. 29.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 20 -- An assertion that "undergraduate provincialism" makes It impossible for Jews to enter a so-called Christian community with the same opportunities for a successful collegiate career as their Gentile classmates is made by Austin M. Fisher, '32, of New York City, in an article appearing in The Wesleyan Argus.

ATOTHER legend of Hidden treasure has gone the way of moat-of the stories of burled fortunes and pirate gold. The latest such glamourous tale to prove mythical Is younger than most of its brethren, dating back only to the closing days of the Boer War and having to do with the supposed "Kruger millions."

The demand for Bibles by readers willing to pay for their copies had been sustained at a relatively higher level for 1931 than the willingness of contributors to give donations to pay for free distribution, it is revealed in a comparison of 1931 statistics issued yesterday by the New York Bible Society with the annual report issued for 1930.

FIFTY years hence the oldest inhabitants will probably reminisce about the hot Summer and the warm Winter of 1931. Why were the seasons so different from those of other years? Dr. J.B. Kincer of the Weather Bureau in Washington has analyzed 5,000 records obtained from different parts of the country and has found that New Mexico was the one State that seemed to have normal weather.

During his four months on camel-back in the hostile desert of Southern Arabia, Bertram Thomas was under the constant risk of attack and murder by fanatical tribesmen; he lay sleepless in freezing night temperature, sweltered under day temperatures far above 100 degrees, and lost thirty pounds on a diet of camel's milk -- about one quart a day.

The names of 157 university and college professors, representing forty-four institutions in seventeen States, were affixed yesterday to the petition started by A. Lawrence Lowell, president of Harvard, signed by Newton D. Baker and others and sent on Friday to President Hoover urging that Congress signify to the League of Nations that the United States "will concur in economic measures it may take to restore peace" in the Far East.

To the Editor of The New York Times: New York City is witnessing a dramatic struggle to keep its greatest industry -- the making of clothes, in this case especially the making of women's dresses -- from sliding back to sweatshop wages and conditions. Over 27,000 dressmakers are out on strike.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your leading editorial states that "the usual thing is to rule out everything except misconduct in office. It was alleged in Albany that there are court decisions holding that this is the proper course."
SHANGHAI (Monday), Feb. 22. (AP). -- It is part of Shanghai's vegetable garden and playground which has been turned into the newest battlefield by the struggling forces of China and Japan.
Louis Maurer, dean of American artists, celebrated his one hundredth birthday yesterday in the old red brick house at 404 West Forty-third Street, in which he has lived for sixty-three years.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 21 (AP). -- An agreement in the struggle for control of the Standard Oil Company of Kansas was announced tonight by Robert Stone, attorney for C. B. Wrightsman of Tulsa, Okla., the director and organizer of a stockholders committee. Under the agreement, the board of directors will be reorganized.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Washington was joined by thousands of visitors from all parts of the country today in the expression of homage to the character and spiritual leadership of the first President of the United States on the eve of the bicentennial celebration of his birth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- In reasserting at Buffalo yesterday his stand for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment Governor Roosevelt sought to strengthen himself in States where the wet sentiment is strong, yet in doing so, according to his followers here, it is not likely that be has seriously damaged his standing in the dry South.

"The Merry Widow" will be revived this afternoon at Erlanger's Theatre by Milton Aborn's company. "Near to the Stars" will begin a special matinee engagement at the Recital Theatre, in Sixty-third Street.

More than 5,000,000 volunteers have been added to the job-soliciting army through the adherence to the campaign of the United Action Group for Employment of most of the great fraternal organizations of the country, it was announced yesterday at the national headquarters of the movement at the Hotel Biltmore.

The choral school of the Metropolitan Opera Company, directed and trained by Edoardo Petri, gave its first public concert yesterday afternoon at the Engineering Auditorium. The chorus sang so well that its program, obviously chosen to display its versatility, would have been improved by more music like the first two groups and less of the exhibition pieces that followed.
Copyright. 1932. by The Associated Press. TOKYO, Feb. 21. -- It has been suggested that Japan might, whether from pique or policy, withdraw from the League of Nations. This is silly Idea.

More than 1,500 persons, many of them representatives of war veterans' organizations and patriotic societies, attended yesterday the official dedication of a high marble shaft commemorating the Bronx dead of the World War. The monument is situated in the section of Pelham Bay Park known as Memorial Grove, at Eastern Boulevard and Pelham Parkway, the Bronx.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 21. -- After trailing by 2 down during the greater part of the match, Tommy Aycock and Jack Toomer of Jacksonville, the latter the Florida State champion, turned back T. Philip Perkins of New York, former British amateur titleholder, and Howard A. Tryon of Detroit, the favorites, at the thirty-seventh hole to win the Miami Biltmore four-ball tournament today.

Evidenceo of a real improvement trend in the building situation of the New York City area are indicated, points out Allen E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports, who cites the fact that structural steel orders exclusively for building purposes in January aggregated 14,031 tons.

The National Puzzlers' League, currently in convention, unbent a little yesterday. In fact, it shattered its own tradition. Normally it is half a dozen social degrees (and a three-letter word meaning, to all intents and purposes, eternity) above the lowly Cross Word.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21. -- Leon Trotsky and thirty-six other Russian emigres living abroad were formally stripped of their Soviet citizenship today and forbidden "for all time" to enter the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics. The action was taken by the Presidium of the Central Executive Committee.

With the team race in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League at the most interesting stage of the season to date, the rivalry for individual scoring honors has grown apace and from now on the battle for the honor of leading the circuit marksmen should prove highly exciting.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 21. -- Iowans are going on record as being wet in a State-wide straw poll being conducted by The Des Moines Register and Tribune. Majorities are given to the wet side on all of three questions dealing with prohibition.

PARIS, Feb. 19. -- Recovery on the Paris Stock Exchange seems to have been consolidated. The fact that the week's French Cabinet crisis made no visible impression on Bourse quotations is taken to prove the market's soundness. In fact, investors are beginning to buy in some quarters, and the results indicate that there are few available securities for sale at current prices and that a great deal of money is ready for investment.

Harold Kramer, City College captain, who has been the leader in the race for individual scoring honors in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association race since the start of the season, still is showing the way according to the latest statistics.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21. -- One of the difficulties now confronting the steel Industry is the stabilization of prices, a movement for which has been in progress two or three weeks. Most of the steel business being done is in very small orders, making price maintenance not so difficult, but orders from the automobile trade are relatively larger and are eagerly sought by the majority of producers.

Dan Moffett, a member of the home club, won the four-and-a-half-mile handicap invitation road run conducted under the auspices of the St. Anselm's A.C. yesterday. The victor, with an allowance of three minutes, led home the field of twenty-five in 24:36.

Mr. JOUETT SHOUSE continues to instruct against the choice of instructed delegates. A perverse generation continues to seek them where it can or must. In Florida the Democratic Executive Committee voted almost unanimously to hold a Presidential preferential primary.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 21 (AP). -- United States soldiers and marines guarding the northern border of the International Settlement spent today in "watchful waiting" and in strengthening their defenses against stray bullets and shells.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith has decided to give formal consent to his supporters in Massachusetts to pledge themselves to him as candidates for delegates to the Democratic National Convention. An announcement to this effect is expected some time this week.

Copyright, 1932, by The Associated Press. SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 22. -- The dogged Chinese defenders of Kiangwan succeeded again today in resisting powerful attacks by Japanese forces on their stronghold and the Japanese were forced to direct the brunt of their drive on the right wing of the Chinese troops north of the town.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The Japanese Embassy was officially, advised today that the Japanese Ninth Division "has been and is concentrating action on the centre of the Chinese position," in an effort to "avoid danger to the International Settlement at Shanghai.

Throughout the suburbs in the metropolitan area, observance of the bicentennial of the birth of George Washington was begun yesterday. Centring in the churches, with patriotic and fraternal organizations cooperating, exercises were held in virtually all the communities of Westchester, New Jersey and Long Island, in some instances coupled with ceremonies at historic sites associated with the Continental campaign.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- To the London market the only really surprising thing about Thursday's reduction in the Bank of England rate was that, contrary to usual practice, the rate was lowered by a full 1 per cent instead of by 1/2 of 1 per cent. Although of late the market had not been expecting immediate reduction, it was really prepared for such action.

The irregularity of last week's advance on the Stock Exchange, and the lack of any distinct change in the business situation, have possibly caused disappointment. Yet whenever relief measures of important scope have been applied at a time of severe economic depression in the past, the immediate sequel has usually been the same.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Seligman entertained twenty guests tonight at a buffet supper at Casa Mia.

Each of almost 1,500 persons carried a bundle to the Imperial Theatre, Forty-fifth Street, west of Broadway, yesterday and in return received a ticket for a benefit performance last night at which radio and stage stars appeared. A brown derby which former Governor Smith "just took off" was auctioned for $115.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP). -- A city is growing up within the city of Chicago, and fifteen months hence it will officially come into being.

BABYLON, L.I., Feb. 21. -- Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, appealed today to the employes of the commission who will be laid off because of the paring of its budget by the Legislature to campaign for a reconsideration of the reductions or the introduction of supplementary appropriation hills.

BELLEAIR, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Babe Ruth, the home-run king, and Billy Burke, national open golf champion, met with a reverse today, bowing by 3 and 2 to Joseph B. Schlotman of Detroit and Walter Hagen, former national and British open titleholder.

Men and women of today were described as wabblers in their faith and convictions in a sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection, Seventy-fourth Street and Park Avenue, by the Right Rev. Hugh Latimer Burleson, Bishop of South Dakota and assistant to the Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in America.

The Community Trust. Again the New York Community Trust has reached "a new high record" in giving. With the mounting disbursements in 1931 for charitable purposes (nearly $200,000, as compared with $16,610 six years ago) there has been diminishing cost of administration.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21. -- Pronouncing his right arm to be as fit as ever, Hughie Critz, star infielder of the New York Giants, arrived in camp today to begin on the morrow the serious business of restoring himself to the second base job from which he was forced to retire when his throwing wing failed him.

Intercoastal steamship lines expect an increase in the volume of freight bookings this week because the new rates which were adopted last week by the newly organized intercoastal conference will be higher than those that have been charged on freight shipments during the rate war of the last year, Shippers have indicated that they will attempt to get their bookings arranged before March 1, when the new rates become effective.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Although the first organized Spring training operations of the Yankees are scheduled for tomorrow at Huggins Field, the pitchers and catchers, comprising the training squad for the first week, are discovering upon their arrival over the week-end that a small but important group of their team-mates has already started conditioning.

Textile High School's basketball team, which is leading in the Manhattan Division P.S.A.L. race with six victories in as many league games, continues to top the league in scoring with a total of 214 points for its six contests.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 21. -- An ice floe came put of the head of Manhasset Bay today to greet the members of the Frostbite Yacht Club as they went through a session of dinghy sailing races.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- On the ground that there has been, sniping from administration treetops, the Democrats today officially opened the "claim-the-credit" war. The first official bombardment came from Speaker Garner in the form of a statement issued through the Democratic National Committee.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas., Feb. 21 (AP). -- San Antonio was the gathering place for John N. Garner enthusiasts tonight, preparatory to booming the Texas Speaker of the National House of Representatives for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Tomorrow political leaders of the State will assemble to talk of "Chapparal Jack's" chances.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- President Hoover's managers, in formally opening his Presidential campaign by announcing that he will enter the Ohio primaries, find themselves confronted with a situation in some of the Middle Western and Northwestern States which they do not feel is as promising as that which Postmaster General Brown reported in Ohio, according to reports in political circles today.

A copy of the rare Gerhart Hauptmann. revision of Shakespeare's "Hamlet," which depicts the pensive Shakespearean character transformed into a man of action, will be included in the exhibition of the 70-year-old German dramatist's first editions, manuscripts and documents to be opened in Avery Hall, Columbia University, Feb. 29.

Prospects for improvement in business in the near future have grown definitely better as a result of a number of important recent developments, according to the current survey of trade by the Union Trust Company of Cleveland.
NEW YORK. The Right Hon. Sir Auckland Campbell Geddes, former British Ambassador to the United States, will arrive tomorrow on the Mauretania.

The people of the State of New York will be given an opportunity next Fall to pass on another constitutional amendment vitally affecting the State's conservation policy. Introduced at Albany some years ago, it has already twice passed both houses of the Legislature.

It has been some seasons since Walter Gieseking established himself in this city as one of the pianists who stand in a significant place, wholly their own, among leading virtuosi of this period, but it appears as merest statement of fact to remark that on no previous occasion in New York has Mr. Gieseking given such an absorbing and impressive performance as he did last night in Carnegie Hall.

The pamphlet report of the Midland Steel Products Company for 1931 shows a net profit of $775,744, after provision for Federal taxes, charges and depreciation, and a deficit of $111,796 after dividends on first preferred and on $2 dividend shares.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the League of Nations is by no means as defunct as politicians of the two major parties would indicate seems to be evident from the response to your recent editorial "The Governor and the League."

Modern standards of right and wrong are changing for the worse, because of little recognized effects of the modern system of education, of the press, and of motion pictures, the Rev. John Carter Smyth declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church, Columbus Avenue and West Fifty-ninth Street.

BOSTON, Feb. 21. -- Clarence C. Pell of New York, the defending champion, and G.R. Fearing 3d, young Boston player, were the survivors in the semi-final matches of the national racquets tournament at the Boston Tennis and Racquet Club today. They will meet in the final tomorrow.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Robert H. Goffe Jr. returned a gross score of 76 for the best round of the day, defeating William Spillane by 5 up and 4 to play in the initial matches of the New York Athletic Club's second annual Winter tournament on the St. Augustine links.
GENEVA, Feb. 21. -- League of Nations officials were busy today preparing for the convocation of the Assembly, to which the Sino-Japanese conflict has been referred.

BERLIN, Feb. 19. -- Thursday's reduction in the Bank of England rate strengthened the pressure by business circles on the Reichsbank to take a similar step; but in view of the leanness of the Richsbank's reserves, opinions differ sharply as to the advisability of such a step.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Arthur C. (Dazzy) Vance, veteran speedball pitcher, let it be known today at his Homosassa Springs home that he would affix his signature to a contract calling for $17,000, a cut of $5,500 from his last season's salary, but that he would not sign for the "cut of approximately 40 per cent" offered him by President Frank B. York of the Robins.

A great-granddaughter and other descendants of George Crabbe, English poet, listened to the Poet Laureate, John Masefield, and Dean Inge dissect the domestic life of their ancestor Feb. 3 at Trowbridge, Wiltshire, on the hundredth anniversary of the poet's death.

Theodore Dreiser, Waldo Frank, Edmund Wilson, Malcolm Cowley and thirteen other writers, in a letter to Kent Cooper, head of The Associated Press, read last night at a meeting at the Star Casino, attended by approximately 1,500 men and women, protested against what they describe as a "policy of misrepresentation by local representatives of the Associated Press in the Kentucky coal area and a deliberate misuse by them of The Associated Press facilities."

With the aid of a handicap of 2:30, Thomas Taylor of the Long Island City Athletics won the four-and-a-half-mile road run of the Manhattan Athletic League yesterday, the race being held under the auspices of the Greek-American A.C. Taking the lead at the three-mile mark, Taylor fought off the closing sprint of John Connolly and won by thirty yards.

A card party in aid of St. Margaret's Day Nursery, which, is at 213 Alexander Avenue, the Bronx, will be held Saturday afternoon in the Mirror Room of the Plaza. The party has been arranged by Miss Louise Madden, president of the nursery's board of managers.
PARIS. Feb. 21. -- The French are participating wholeheartedly in the Paris American colony's observance today and tomorrow of the 200th anniversary of the birth of George Washington.

Karl Carroll, producer of "Vanities," announced yesterday that he would relinquish possession of the new Earl Carroll Theatre a week from tomorrow because the business being done at the box office was "inadequate to meet the demands of those who were unalterably disposed to secure the theatre for their own pain."

George Washington was nominated yesterday by Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, as America's outstanding contribution to "that endless adventure which is the government of man."

The American Art Dealers Association estimates that during 1931 the American public received $136,242,187 in gifts of paintings, sculpture and facilities for art appreciation and education, according to an announcement yesterday by this national organization of art dealers at its headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21. -- Steel producers are not greatly disappointed by the failure of the demand for steel to increase at this time, a failure which has been emphasized indeed by a slight decrease in production in the last two weeks. Production of ingots in the fortnight is estimated at about 26 per cent of the present capacity, a shade less than that last week and a shade more than that of the week before.

The uses of the Navy in peace, aside from the protection of commerce and nationals, are little understood by the average citizen. He thinks of the Navy as the first line of defense in the event of war and it comforts him to know that in the emergency at Shanghai Americans are able to look to the Asiatic squadron for security.

Persons who devote the greater part of their time to worldly interests, giving only a little to religion, are like the man spoken of by the Prophet Isaiah, who after building a fire made a god out of one of the remaining logs, said the Rev. Dr. R. Moffat Giloon of Edinburgh in a sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 21. -- Yale's annual alumni University Day celebration tomorrow, which will call together several hundred graduates from all parts of the United States, will include participation in the George Washington bicentennial program with notable exhibitions in the Yale Gallery of Pine Arts and in the Sterling Memorial Library.

BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- Capacity to pay is a question of immediate interest which Russia now puts before the Western world. Disarmament has become platonic talk or political manoeuvring as the cannon thunder at Shanghai.
HAVANA, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Jockey Lavelle (Buddy) Ensor returned to the saddle at Oriental Park today and had the leg up on Captain J.S., the odds-on choice in the fourth race.

Copyright. 1932, by The Associated Press. SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 22. -- Japan at last has removed her mask and thrown down the gauntlet to the world. In delivering the ultimatum to China she put herself irrevocably on record that she has been waging an offensive war in China and means to continue it, despite the universal public opinion against it.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 22. -- The Japanese forces advanced two miles yesterday north and south of Kiangwan village, but had failed to take the village despite repeated assaults there, and today, which is gray and rainy, they are again pounding both Kiangwan and Chapei with heavy artillery and renewing their attacks.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- A rather marked change in sentiment has occurred recently among wheat traders both in this country and abroad and the change has resulted in higher levels of prices. It remains to be seen whether this is due largely to speculative interest and a belief that actual inflation in commodities in the United States is probable, according to trade views.

In the week preceding the overthrow of the Laval Ministry by the French Senate, the Minister of Finance, M. Flandin, was questioned in the Chamber of Deputies by Leon Blum, Socialist leader, with the query: "Who is paying for the war?" On the following day M. Flandin read the following statement of figures which M. Blum suggested be sent to the League of Nations.

Washington Day Events. The bicentennial of George Washington's birth is observed today. Tributes to his services and character were paid in sermons and special services in churches throughout the country yesterday, while exercises throughout most of the civilized world are scheduled for today.

The Manhattan Symphony Orchestra under Henry Hadley opened its concert last night at the Waldorf-Astoria with a memorial performance of "My Country" by Mortimer Wilson, the American composer who died last month. Mr. Hadley then surrendered the baton to Deems Taylor, who conducted his "Through the Looking Glass" suite.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- Viscount Hailsham, Secretary of State for War, announced today there was no news from Shanghai serious enough to warrant the evacuation of British subjects from the International Settlement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21. -- No decision on the Mooney pardon application has been reached by Governor Rolph, he announced here today on his arrival from Tucson where he attended the midwinter Arizona round-up as a guest of Governor Hunt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (Science Service). -- From the interior of China have come the first official reports of the drenching rains of last Summer which sent the Yangtse River into roaring flood. The financial straits China now experiences are largely due, the legation here states, to losses from the flood.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 21. -- A hearing on the Jenks State prohibition enforcement measure and the passage of a bill appropriating an additional $250,000 for the Hofstadter committee will hold the centre of the legislative stage this week.

TOKIO, Feb. 21. -- Japan's statement in answer to the latest League of Nations appeal not to undertake an offensive at Shanghai was sent to Geneva today. Officials here also termed the "Tanaka memorial" a fraud.

Much of the waning influence of religion may be attributed to the fact that many churches have become sepulchres and refrigerators rather than places of warmth and friendship, the Rev. Dr. George Caleb Moor said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church at Thirty-first Street.

God has been an accepted fact to all the great souls of history, Dr. Robert Norwood, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

An appeal for the peaceful settlement of the crisis in the Far East and the withdrawal of American military forces in China, together with an assertion that the world is now in danger of a war even more disastrous than the last one, was issued yesterday by Ed R. Murrow, director of the National Student Federation of America.

With the Hofstadter committee's investigation of the City Government at a virtual standstill, Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Committee of One Thousand debated the question of its success or failure with Senator John J. McNaboe yesterday over the radio from Station WOR.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP). -- A last-minute tussle over the legislation to expand Federal Reserve credit loomed today after Senator Glass charged that the administration had attempted to create an impression that all banks could not benefit under the Glass-Steagall bill's provisions.

Acting on the report of its committee on legislation, the New York County Lawyers Association has announced its disapproval of the bill introduced in the Assembly by Assemblyman Louis A. Cuvillier in relation to the incorporation of stock exchanges, their supervision by the State Banking Department, the licensing of stock brokers and the regulating of the buying and selling of stocks and bonds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Warning that any attempt by city governments to economize by shortening the school year would immediately cause crime to increase, William J. Cooper, Federal Commissioner of Education, took a firm stand today for maintenance of standards as demanded by the 15,000 school heads gathered here for the annual convention of the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Governor Murray today announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President.

BERLIN. Feb. 19. -- The matter of special interest to financial Berlin last week was the report on Germany's foreign trade in January, showing heavy decrease in the export surplus.
