It was commonly remembered that, if the monthly excess of exports were to remain at the low January level, not enough exchange would be provided automatically for the service of long-term bonds and the payment of interest on the short-term debts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP). -- John Barton Payne, chairman of the American Red Cross, said today that the organization had aided about 1,000,000 persons who had been stricken by drought, floods and unemployment during the last few months.

Characterizing the present system of charity relief in New York as a fiasco, John Haynes Holmes, Lon Ray Call and J.E. McAfee of the Community Service of Community Church issued a joint statement yesterday, entitled "Hanging the Destitute With Red Tape."

Posing as one of the five women Christian Science workers who had been conducting a service in Harlem Prison yesterday morning, Mrs. Jennie Goldstein, a prisoner, successfully passed a matron, descended four flights of stairs to the main office and was on the threshold of freedom when she committed an error that brought about her detection.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., Feb. 21(AP). -- Nate C. Browne, veteran flier, tonight hastened to prepare his second-hand monoplane for his proposed non-stop flight to Buenos Aires -- all the while hoping for favorable weather reports. He came here about midafternoon from the Portland Airport at Scarboro, where he left his plane last night after a four-hour flight from New York.

Apparently, Mr. DE VALERA will be able, with the aid of the Labor party, to form a Government for the Irish Free State and himself become President in place of Mr. COSGRAVE. The latter's defeat in the election was not wholly unexpected. For one thing", he had been too long in office and his Government had been too successful in surmounting formidable obstacles.

Scoring three goals in the final period to break a 1-1 deadlock, the New York A.C. sextet defeated the Nashua Club, champions of the New England Amateur League, by a score of 4 -- 1 at the New York Coliseum yesterday before 3,500 spectators.

NEW ORLEANS. La., Feb. 21. -- Trading in cotton here last week was much more active than in recent previous weeks. The sharp rise in securities and the growing belief that the measures adopted by the Federal Government to expand credit will bring about general improvement in business and industry stimulated trade buying and to some degree investment or speculative buying.

As regards GEORGE WASHINGTON, the language of eulogy was long since strained to the point of exhaustion. Nothing new can be said in his praise. All that has been said, or invented, in his dispraise has merely redounded to his greater glory.

New Bedford, showing far superior form, conquered the New York Giants by 5 to 2 in the Eastern final of the National Challenge Cup competition of the United States Football Association at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Six thousand soccer enthusiasts saw the game.

Declaring that no cause can go forward without enthusiasm, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers in his sermon, yesterday morning at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth. Street, said the power of maintained effort is a vital essential for building anything.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21. -- In historic Philadelphia churches in which George Washington worshiped he was eulogized today for his "spiritual" qualities.

Ossip Gabrilowitsch, frequent visitor here both as pianist and conductor, was at the Town Hall last night in his former capacity. It was announced as his farewell recital for this season here. In any event, it was an evening of truly distinguished, sometimes poignantly beautiful, playing and that part of this city's concert-going public which failed to occupy the seats that were vacant owes itself and a great artist humble apologies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Military training in colleges and universities is of educational value and does not tend to produce "a militaristic attitude inimical to world peace," according to a report to Secretary Wilbur by Ralph Chesny Bishop on a nation-wide survey made in co-operation with the department's office in education.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 21. -- Said by the police to have become angry when his friends refused to take him home from a party, Leroy Thompson, 34 years old, of Hamilton Township, is alleged to have shot and killed Elmer Lehrer, 40 years old, at the latter's home at 1,139 Nottingham Way today.

Arthur Anderson of Ohio, a war veteran of the submarine service and now the second young American basso to be introduced at the Metropolitan this season, made his bow to New York at last night's "opera concert." singing the air "Non piunandrai" from Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro" and, with Queena Mario and Georges Thill, the final trio from "Faust."

SHANGHAI, Feb. 21. -- American circles in Shanghai have been stirred by the Japanese protests against the action of the United States marines in searching Japanese-owned cotton mills and confiscating two truck loads of weapons and signaling apparatus, the latter being used by the Japanese in a manner likely to draw Chinese fire upon the American defense lines.

According to reports received from Liverpool through officers and engineers of incoming Cunard steamships, there is a good prospect that work will be resumed next month on the 73,000-ton superliner at Clyde Bank, known in the yard as 534. Sir Thomas Brocklebank, one of the directors, said before he sailed for England recently that the company had sufficient funds in hand to go ahead with the construction.

The eighth annual memorial service of the Jewish Theatrical Guild of America was held at 3 P.M. yesterday in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street. Approximately five hundred persons, many of whom belonged to the families of those remembered in the service, were present.

The Winnipeg Hockey Club gave a demonstration of the form which enabled it to capture the Olympic hockey title for Canada in the recent games at Lake Placid by defeating the strong Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Henry H. Curran, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, said today that if Washington were alive "he would not get a vote from the Anti-Saloon League or the W.C.T.U. -- but he would undoubtedly be elected."

CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- A sharp upturn in building permits, following the action of the building trade unions in accepting a 20 per cent cut in wages, and a marked increase in the number of out-of-town manufacturers seeking factory and warehouse sites in Chicago, were the chief sources of optimism in the Chicago business world last week, according to the Chicago Association of Commerce.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 21. -- Quotations for all grains show marked improvement and shipments are heavy, although wheat and flaxseed are below the total in 1931. The corn crop is expected to be better than the estimates and the amount exportable may be 275,800,000 bushels.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP). -- The Canadiens and the Detroit Falcons played to a 1 -- 1 tie tonight in a dazzling overtime National Hockey League match before 12,500 spectators, the largest crowd to see a National League game in Detroit this season.

Copyright, 1932, by The Associated Press. SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 22. -- The Chinese are taking advantage of America's and Europe's lack of a real appreciation of the Far Eastern situation. Due to ignorance of the relations between China and Japan, the big powers and the League of Nations are giving the world the impression that sympathy lies with the Chinese.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mex., Feb. 21. -- Durango, in light with 103 pounds, captured the $2,500 added George Washington Handicap, stake feature for 3-year-olds and upward at the Agua Caliente race track today. The winner was well backed, returning $5.60 straight and $2.20 to place.

LAREDO, Texas, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Sergei M. Eisenstein, Russian film director, who went to Mexico City from Hollywood to make a picture, has been refused readmission to the United States by immigration officials here.

Constant Use of Terms May Have Led to Misunderstanding. To the Editor of The New York Times: Much misunderstanding has resulted from the hurling back and forth of the words "inflation" and "deflation" by proponents and opponents of credit-relief proposals.

The Jewish people all over the world face a war of extinction, Dr. Joseph Tenenhauna, chairman of the executive committee of the American Jewish Congress, declared in an address yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the committee in the Jewish Club, 23 West Seventy-third Street.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 21. -- While outwardly the Japanese armed invasion of the Shanghai area seems to have effected the unification of China's political and military factions, signs are abundant that the divisions and dissensions created by more than twenty years of civil warfare and frequent betrayals are as deep as ever.

Whether or not proclamation of an independent Manchuria at Mukden is to have any real meaning depends on the movement of events elsewhere in China. If the issue at Shanghai is adjusted the realities in Manchuria will not have been greatly changed from what they have been for many years.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 63.7, which compares with 63.6 a week ago, 64.2 two weeks ago, 64.5 three weeks ago and 65.2 four weeks ago. This is the first weekly rise since November.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Feb. 21 (AP). -- The adventurous call of "buried treasure" was once more answered today when the small motor vessel Silver Wave put out of Vancouver carrying twenty-four men who held strong in their hearts the hope of uncovering the fabulous pirate wealth reported to lie buried on faraway Cocos Island.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 21. -- Through territory that was well known to the Father of his Country, the President and Mrs. Hoover journeyed today through the Old Dominion State to this, one of its oldest cities, to attend the Sunday morning services at old Christ's Church, as did Washington more than 150 years ago.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., today won the $4,000 Gasparilla open golf tournament, defeating Willie Macfarlane, former national open champion, 3 and 1 in the 36-hole final round.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- George Washington has given a name to county or town in all but eight of the States and in Pennsylvania he is recalled by at least nine community titles.

Some of the letter-writing members of the British public have been denouncing in the London papers the refusal of various film magnates to interest themselves in the films brought back by the British Himalayan Expedition. The explorers have the distinction of reaching the highest peak climbed by man and taking moving pictures of it and from it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In these early days of the Disarmament Conference a peculiar type of panicky defeatism seems to have seized upon public opinion. It is based upon the failure -- almost the refusal -- of large sections of the thinking population of this and or other countries to keep informed as to facts and figures bearing upon the conference.

Copyright, 1932, by The Associated Press. BOSTON, Feb. 21. -- Some new light was shed today upon the mysterious death of Miss Elizabeth Barrett Cook, 20-year-old Brookline society girl, by G.B. Beak, British Consul General here, who expressed the belief that the girl had sent the now celebrated hoax messages to herself.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- With Governor Roosevelt as the principal orator, the State of New York tomorrow will commemorate at a ceremony in Chancellor's Hall the 200th anniversary of the birth of George Washington.

Dr. Halford E. Luccock of the Yale Divinity School, preaching yesterday at Christ Methodist Church, Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street, scored the modern psychologists who interpret religion as an escape or defense mechanism.

SECAUCUS, N.J., Feb. 21. -- Fourteen patients in the old Contagious Disease Hospital in the Hudson County institutional community at Laurel Hill here were routed from their beds early this morning when a fire, preceded by the explosion of an overheated furnace in the basement, destroyed the three-story frame structure.

A preliminary report containing recommendations for liquor control in New York State following repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was made public yesterday by the conference group called together by Mrs. John S. Sheppard, chairman of the New York State Division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

The Board of Transportation disclosed yesterday that its own engineering and operating staff was conducting trial operatic of trains on the new Eighth Avenue subway line between 207th Street and Chambers Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- A new plan for Congressional reapportionment was being considered today by Governor Roosevelt, although it was admitted that hope for Republican cooperation in the Legislature was very slight.

Five gunners tied for the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. They were J.W. Eshelman, B.M. Higginson. R.B. Cole, S.O.S. Graham and D.L. Taylor. Each had 95 out of a possible 100 targets. In the first shoot-off, Eshelman and Higginson again tied with 23 each.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- Tariff weapons instead of troops and guns would be Britain's reply to Eamon de Valera if he should ever succeed in abolishing the oath of allegiance to the King and repudiating the pay ment of land annuities to the British Treasury.

Owing to the lack of sufficient demand for steel from railroad and automobile companies, the steel industry's rate of operations declined 2 points last week to 25 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. The publication says, however, that the current production covers only the minimum needs of the steel-using companies.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 21 -- After drawing a bye in the first round, George Lott of Chicago, former national doubles champion, defeated R. Fairbanks of Indianapolis, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, in the only second-round match of the Pan-American tennis championship which began today on the Flamingo courts.

HAVANA, Feb. 21. -- A Communist parade of some 200 persons carrying red banners was dispersed this morning at Fraternity Park in the centre of the city by police reserves, who had been held in readiness since mid-night, awaiting an outbreak of Red activities scheduled to begin today.

Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, who with her husband flew over the flooded regions of China last Summer. mapping the area and attempting to take medical relief to the stricken people, gave a vivid description of their experiences yesterday in an address carried over the combined networks of the Columbia and National Broadcasting systems.

The New York Americans finally prevailed over their city rivals, the Rangers, at Madison Square Garden last night. After receiving three successive defeats from their blue-jerseyed opponents in their past games this season, the American stick-wielders struck back with a vengeance and conquered the Ranger skaters by 3 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- With Ways and Means Committee leaders apparently determined to make a manufacturers' sales tax the basic part of the new tax bill, Secretary Mills has been asked to submit on Tuesday the draft of a bill carrying out such an impost as would be most acceptable to the treasury.

Materialism, blended with blatant paganism, is gripping the world, according to the Rev. Dr. Luther A. Weigle, dean of the Yale Divinity School, who preached yesterday morning in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Feb. 21. -- Asserting that the Presbyterian Church was "standing upon the brink of irremediable apostasy," the Rev. H. McAllister Griffiths, pastor of the Holland Memorial Preabyterian Church, in a sermon today called upon, the 1,300 signers of the Auburn Affirmation of 1924 to leave the ministry of the denomination.

A preference for the George Washington who has been "humanized" by modern biographers, rather than for the "idealized" figure presented in earlier histories of the first President, was expressed yesterday by several of the many ministers who based their sermons on the Washington bicentennial celebration, which begins today.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (AP). -- During the World War Sir Maurice de Bunsen was Under-Secretary of the British Foreign Office and as such frequently was spokesman, on England's war policies.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Here as the guest of Michigan Democrats and the Crusaders, Governor Ritchie of Maryland said this afternoon that, regardless of his Presidential aspirations, "there will be no monkey-wrenches thrown into the party machinery by my supporters."

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 20. -- Professor Irving Fisher, economist, of Yale, told 5.000 "subscribers" to the sixth annual issue of the Rollins College Animated Magazine here today that the Federal Reserve System could help to revive business and to stabilize the dollar by regulating the volume of currency and that passage of the Glass-Stegall credit expansion bill in Congress marked a definite upturn in business.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 21. -- T.E. Jansen Jr. of Boston and Beekman Pool of Harvard will clash in the final of the national squash racquets tournament tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Faced with the necessity for increasing revenues, correcting adverse trade balances, and protecting curency values, foreign nations were pictured as grasping at any trade-control measures available for accomplishing any of these ends, in a survey of the foreign tariff situation for 1931, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The Mineralites still are setting the pace in the American National Bowling League and though idle during the past week strengthened their hold on first place when the Dwyers dropped from second place to a tie for third as a result of losing two out of three games to the Broadway-Bayonne quintet.

Little hope for the adoption of the plan to convert the Whitestone branch of the Long Island Railroad into an extension of the Queens subway system is held out in the majority report of the Aldermanic subcommittee on Whitestone transit relief, made public yesterday.

Leaving his bed during the momentary absence of his nurse, Arthur Janes, 65 years old, a real estate dealer, of 126 Sycamore Avenue, Shrewsbury, N.J., jumped or fell last night from his room on the ninth floor of the Presbyterian Hospital of the Columbia Medical Centre.

The world's encyclopedia of armaments, the League of Nation's Armaments Year-Book for 1932, copies of which have arrived in this country, shows that Britain still rules the waves, that France is supreme in the air and that China's army is, on paper, the largest in the world.

IT'S too much to expect Gene Venzke to step out and break that indoor mile record again this evening, but he is an astonishing runner. At the moment, no one knows just how fast this lad can travel over the boards for a measured mile. He was off by himself when he rang up that 4:10 last week.

Four measures now pending before the State Legislature have received the approval of the committee on legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, it was announced yesterday, while twenty-one pending bills have been disapproved. At the same time the committee on legislation of the New York County Lawyers Association revealed its approval of two pending measures and its opposition to thirteen.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 22. -- The Seiyukai (Government party) of Premier Inukai was leading in returns today from Japan's general election by such a margin that its leaders contended the government had remained in power by an unprecedented victory.

David White and Leslie Flaksman, former members of the Harvard University track team, were yesterday selected to represent the United States in the Maccabee World Union Olympic meet to be held in Palestine this year. The selections were made at the first annual convention of the Maccabee Association of America at the Central Jewish Institute.

TOKYO, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Shanghai advices at the War Office here today said that General Chiang Kai-shek's famous forces were remaining aloof from the Ninteenth Route Army of Cantonese who are now defending Shanghai.

Followers of billiards will have an opportunity of witnessing two of the greatest fancy-shot exponents of the game tonight at the New York Elks Club, at 108 West Forty-third Street, when Charles C. Peterson of St. Louis and Isidro Ribas of Spain start the first of their three-night New York series for the world's championship.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- Political Paris rested from its labors today, taking stock rather dazedly of Andre Tardieu's compact new government with its startling innovations and generally agreeing that it would get through its initial test before the Chamber of Deputies Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP). -- President Hoover is represented by his close advisers to be unreceptive to the pleas of petitioning educators for was predicted tonight by those in high administration circles that he had no intention of entering the boycott movement.

Charley Peterson of St. Louis and Isidro Ribas of Spain, who are competing for the world's fancy-shot billiard championship, engaged in their first New York block at the Elks Club last night, and Peterson succeeded in reducing the margin, held over him by his rival by only one point.

BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- Adolf Hitler tonight was formally proclaimed the Presidential nominee of the National-Socialist party following an announcement that Colonel Theodore Duesterberg. Deputy Chairman of the Steel Helmet League, had been selected as the joint candidate of Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's Nationalist party and the Steel Helmets, which comprise former service men.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Espousal by the British Government of a new program of protection and imperial preference may have an adverse effect upon farm exports to the United Kingdom, the most important foreign market for American agricultural surplus, officials of the Department of Agriculture said today in a study of the outlook for foreign competition and demand.

The forty-first annual parade of the Kings County Volunteer Firemen's Association was held in Brooklyn yesterday with 40,000 spectators cheering as the long column of 3,500 men, wearing shining helmets and gay red jerseys, and manning brightly polished equipment of past and present days, swung through, the downtown streets of the borough.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22. -- An event not on the program provided the highlight of the show for the crowd of about 300 fans watching the first Spring training session of the Yankees today. It was, in fact, the only episode which evoked a round of cheers from the spectators.

When Governor ROOSEVELT made his speech in Buffalo demanding the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and the return to State control of the liquor traffic, all ears were turned to catch the echoes from the Southern States. They have been and still profess to be incurably Dry.

With recovery of business waiting for the consumer to return to the market, the nations of the world continue to make it more difficult to buy each other's goods. During 1930 there were six general tariff revisions upward in Europe, nineteen limited revisions and five general revisions in South America, in addition to the enactment of the Hawley-Smoot act in the United States.

TROTSKY now enjoys the distinction of being sentenced to perpetual exile for a second time. His name appears in a new decree at Moscow together with three dozen other "counter-revolutionists." Among them are several Menshevist leaders of whom TROTSKY in the past has spoken almost as candidly as he has of STALIN.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Emphasizing, the dangers of the Sino-Japanese conflict, Senators Frederick Hale of Maine and David A. Reed of Pennsylvania, chairmen of the Senate Naval and Military Committees, respectively, in radio talks over the National Broadcasting System tonight warned against any cut in national defense expenditures which would impair the efficiency of the army and navy.

The fertile Plain of Esdraelon, one of the great battlefields of the world, will be the site in Palestine of a George Washington memorial forest of at least 500,000 stately pine and eucalyptus trees, according to a resolution adopted yesterday afternoon by 200 religious, educational and Zionist leaders.

The Most Rev. Thomas J. Shahan, rector emeritus of the Catholic University of America at Washington, D.C., dedicated the recently completed edifice of the Dominican Fathers yesterday at 141 East Sixtyfifth Street in honor of the Rev. Charles H. McKenna, who was a pioneer in the organization in Roman Catholic parishes in this country of Holy Name societies, and rosary sodalities.
CAMDEN, S.C., Feb. 22. -- More than 5,000 persons assembled at the Springdale Track today for the first of the season's steeplechase races given by the Camden Hunt.

The flags of the United States and France were intertwined at New York University yesterday in a celebration of the bicentenary of the birth of George Washington, which centred around the part that the ardent young Marquis de Lafayette played in winning the freedom of the Colonies.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22. -- Wilmer Allison, Austin, Texas, national doubles champion; J. Gilbert Hall, East Orange, N.J.; Gustavo Vollmer, Cuban titleholder, and Marcel Rainville, champion of Canada, advanced without serious opposition through their second-round matches today in the Pan-American tennis championship on the Flamingo courts.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22. -- The Princeton swimming team won its fifth straight meet today by defeating Pennsylvania, 43 to 28.

Mayor Walker has called a conference, to be held at City Hall tomorrow afternoon, at which the Transit Commission will discuss its tentative $474,500,000 unification plan with the Board of Estimate and the Board of Transportation.

A figure of Christ, clothed in white and rising from the dead, has been clearly discerned in the variegations of the brownish marble on the wall of the sanctuary of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, it was disclosed yesterday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Sidney Wood, George Patrick Hughes, Mrs. Eileen Bennett Whittingstall and other favorites won their first-round matches in the annual Bermuda tennis championships today. Rain cut the play short.

DUBLIN, Feb. 22 (AP). -- The strenuous and victorious campaign sent Eamon de Valera, the leader of the Irish Republicans, to bed with a cold today, but not until he had hailed "a new era of peace and prosperity for Ireland."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The George Washington bicentennial celebration in the House, chamber today was followed by an ovation to Speaker Garner against which all the gavel-wielding prowess of the ruddy Texan could not prevail.

SHANGHAI. Feb. 22. -- A journey today to the Kiangwan front revealed that the Japanese were making slow progress indeed. Yesterday the hindmost Japanese batteries were firing over Futan University from a point less than a quarter of a mile away and were landing shells in Kiangwan village.

"A Church Mouse," the second longest-run play on Broadway, will end its engagement on Saturday night at the Playhouse, where it opened on Oct. 12. The comedy, featuring Ruth Gordon and Bert Lytell, will not be sent on tour, William A. Brady, the producer, said last night.

Jacques F. Halevy's "La Juive" crew a matinee throng to the Metropolitan yesterday, followed by Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann" to another sold-out house at night. A full day of French opera was of rare occurrence, indeed, and Mr. Hasselmans at the baton carried the dual event through with relays of singers, varied in each case by changes among the tenors after programs were in print.

Twelve Cylinders in Emporia. Far be it from the Editor and Owner of the Official Paper of Lyon County and City of Emporia to refuse a ride in Governor WOODRING'S "big what-cha-may-call-it-car." But when the natives got the idea that BILL WHITE had had a stroke and was being taken home in an ambulance, he was moved to remark that twelve cylinders were a few too many for Emporia.

A "comparative" exhibition of painting by two distinguished moderns, Andre Derain and Maurice de Vlaminck, will open privately today, and publicly tomorrow, at the Museum of French Art, French Institute in the United States, 22 East Sixtieth Street.

TOKYO, Feb. 23. -- Preparations for sending reinforcements to the Japanese troops at Shanghai are well advanced, following a report from Mamoru Shigemitzu, Japanese Minister to China, that help was needed. The request is now before the Cabinet, the consent of which is certain.
FLORENCE, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Premier Benito Mussolini's name as a dramatist will appear on the billboards of his second play, "Villa Franca," his collaborator, Giovacchino Forzano, said today.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- Harvard's basketball team defeated Haverford College tonight, 32 -- 19.

THE way the temperature went soaring yesterday, those hockey players had better hurry through their campaign before the ice goes out from under them. This has been a scrambled season on the rinks. When they tossed out the rubber for the first face-off the Boston Bruins were looked upon as one of the strongest combinations on ice. Now they are fighting desperately to get out of the cellar in the American Group.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 22 (AP). -- Dissatisfied with President Hoover's suggestion that power be given to him to reorganize the government, Democratic leaders tomorrow will ask the House to set up a special economy committee to recommend curtailment and consolidation of Federal activities and expenditures.

The meeting of the National Puzzlers' League ended last night at the Hotel New Yorker with a dinner, a puppet show and a series of informal speeches. But it turned out to have been just a semi-annual convention after all. At the end the cry was "On to Lima," in Ohio, where anagrams and cryptograms will provide further sport over Labor Day.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Having been interested in the textile industry all my life, I wish to stress the unfair conditions as they exist today in the silk branch of the textile industry.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22. -- The members of the American colony here, headed by Ambassador and Mrs. Clark, were occupied throughout the day with ceremonies in celebration of the Washington bicentennial.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The Ways and Means Committee hopes to turn part of the new tax measure over to clerks for actual drafting, after a meeting tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22. -- Two convalescing right arms, whose ailments in the past two seasons wrought no little hardship on the Giants, went on exhibition today for their first trial of the 1932 training campaign. One belonged to Joe Genewich. right-handed pitcher, and the other to Hughie Critz, second baseman.

GENEVA, Feb. 22. -- The Treaty of St. Germain, which disarmed Austria after the World War, was suggested to the World Disarmament Conference today by the American delegation as a yardstick to measure the armies necessary as national police forces.
FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Feb. 22. -- The memory of George Washington's mother, who is buried here, was honored with ceremonies today on the two hundredth anniversary of her son's birth.
GENEVA, Feb. 22. -- Ambassador Gibson and Senator Swanson were speakers at a Washington's Birthday anniversary dinner held in Geneva tonight, with Prentiss Gilbert as toastmaster.

MILBURN, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Attempting to emulate his 11-year-old cousin, who successfully scaled Washington Rock, a 250-foot precipice in the South Mountain Reservation here. Walter Kohler, 15, of 82 Nelson Avenue, Jersey City, was killed today when he lost his hold after he had made half the climb.

All the materials for a propaganda play about rule by gangsters have been industriously assembled in "The Inside Story," which was put on at the National last evening. Using the revolving stage technique, George Bryant and Francis M. Verdi, who are the authors, have shown us how insidiously racketeering controls the politics of a State.

On top the Empire State Building overlooking the Great Desert of Manhattan a number of distinguished explorers of other great deserts the world over met at a dinner last night to pay tribute to Bertram Thomas, first white man to cross the Rub'al Khali, great desert of Southern Arabia, believed by some to have been the land of the Queen of Sheba.

So far the Board of Estimate has pursued its economy program mainly by resort to a "suspense calendar" for public improvements not urgently needed. Some that are urgently needed have found their way there also; for example, the waste-disposal plants which the United States Supreme Court recently ordered New York to build without further delay.

George "Washington's part in the upbuilding of the United States and his manifold contributions to the nation's structure were extolled yesterday morning by Bishop William T. Manning and State Senator Seabury C. Mastick at the annual Washington's Birthday communion breakfast of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew of the New York Diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church at John Jay Hall, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- By his decision to become an active instead of a receptive candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Alfred E. Smith has brought delight to two widely separated political groups.

Paul De Bruyn, marathon champion of Germany and New York County cross-country titleholder, gave his best performance since arriving in this country two years ago by annexing first place in the Metropolitan A.A.U. 15-mile championship run, held in Jamaica yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 22. -- A small army of buyers from the so-called sterling countries invaded London today for the opening of the British Industry Fair, one of the world's biggest trade expositions.

Contract bridge experts failed to pile up the expected large scores while auction bridge players faded quietly from the scene yesterday at the opening session of the Eastern bridge tournament at the Hotel Roosevelt. A Women's Whist Club team of New York and a team from the Hamilton Club in Philadelphia took their places at the head of the team-of-four list, relegating the better-known teams to places further down.

The program of Chinese music presented last night at the New School was made possible through the work of Chih Meng, one of the directors of the China Institute in America, and the collaboration of Chinese students who wanted it understood that they were amateurs, rather than technically professional musicians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Secretary Stimson is considering a restatement of American policy in the Far East in the light of the Sino-Japanese crisis that will emphasize American support of the open door. But no official light has been cast on whether the government -- if the League requests it -- will ask Congress to join in an economic boycott of Japan.

With Republicans generally throughout the State responding favorably to the suggestion that Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies, of Chautauqua County, be the nominee for Governor next Fall, discussion among the party leaders during the last few days has turned to the nominee for United States Senator.
ARDEN, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP). -- A butler at the Arden Homestead, owned by W.R. Hunter, a New York broker, told The Associated Press, that Harry H. Blagden stopped there Saturday en route to New York.

Using the same Bible with which he took the oath of office, a tableau portraying Washington's inauguration as the first President of the United States featured the Washington Bicentennial celebration of the First Manhattan District, Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York, held last night at Freemasons' Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street.
BERLIN, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Both Hamburg and Dresden gave the name of Washington to streets today.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22. -- Declaring that Washington, "a practical man," would be the first to realize the necessity for the United States to participate in world affairs, Sir Willmott Lewis. Washington correspondent for The London Times, pleaded today for American leadership in "simple, homely things," such as the "sanctity of human life," in an address at the fifty-sixth commemoration day exercises of the Johns Hopkins University.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- In costumes worn, by their ancestors, descendants of pioneers and founders of the Republic from all parts of the United States rolled back the pages of history tonight at four brilliant and colorful balls held to celebrate the inauguration of the George Washington Bicentennial.

Non-partisan statesmanship at Washington has given the nation a comprehensive plan of action against abnormal financial conditions that should immediately inspire our people with renewed confidence, according to a statement issued yesterday by the economic policy commission and the national officers of the American Bankers Association.

Motor car output increased last week, but by slightly less than the normal seasonal rise, and the adjusted index records a further small decline to 37.1 for the week ended Feb. 20 from 38.4 for the preceding week and 55.9 for the corresponding week last year.

Holding command for almost the entire game, the Winnipeg Hockey Club, which won the Olympic title for Canada at Lake Placid this month, skated througn the Bronx Hockey Club to a 10-to-3 victory at the New York Coliseum yesterday afternoon.

LIVERPOOL, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Business in spot cotton was good today and prices closed eleven points lower. Quotations were: American middling fair 6.91d; strict good middling 6.46d; good middling 6.06d; strict middling 5.96d; middling 5.91d; strict low middling 5.81d; low middling 5.71d; strict good ordinary 5.51d; good ordinary 5.21d.
All of the markets will reopen this morning after having been closed for Washington's Birthday. Business generally was suspended yesterday throughout the United States.

GENEVA, Feb. 22 (AP). -- The League of Nations was considering tonight the possibility of inviting the United States and Soviet Russia to join in a commission which would act on finding's of the L ague assembly's special meeting called to consider the dispute between China and Japan on March 3.
DELHI, India, Feb. 22. -- As was expected when the round-table conference ended, the British Government will have to settle the communal question in India by itself.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Feb. 23. -- Rebuffed in every onslaught they had made on the centre of the Chinese line at Kiangwan, the Japanese today flung their full strength at the Chinese positions on both sides of the village in an attempt to complete a surrounding movement and starve out the handful of defenders still stationed in Kiangwan's blasted ruins.

The Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association, which is assembling in Washington this week, is the most important body of men and women representing what President HOOVER has called not only "our biggest business" but "our only indispensable business" -- the education of our children and youth.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22. -- Princeton outscorcd Tale, 26 to 25. In an Eastern Intercollegiate League series basketball game tonight, in which the Tigers led from the opening play and finished the first half with an 18-to-13 advantage.
NEW YORK. Bernon S. Prentice, accompanied by Miss Clare Prentice and Lincoln Ellsworth, has gone to the Jekyl Island Club, Brunswick, Ga.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Governor Roosevelt was understood today to have reached a decision on the charges against Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, and was said to be preparing a memorandum on his ruling.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- President Hoover, according to some of his advisers, is not expected to reply to Speaker Garner's charge that the administration has seized upon the results of Democratic cooperation in the economic legislative program as an opportunity for political sniping when its speakers parade administration accomplishments.

Something called Living Theatre Productions, Inc., had the idea of taking over the Recital Theatre -- or, if you are a stickler for form, Daly's Sixty-third Street -- yesterday to upset the calm of the holiday afternoon with a special matinee of "Near to the Stars," a play by one Nathaniel Irish.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- The stock market was irregular today, partly owing to Saturday's weakness in Wall Street. British Government funds declined slightly, the war loan dropping 1-16 to u99 7/8 and consols 1/8 to 86 1/2.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Even though accustomed to periodic raids by Japanese bombing planes, Chinese troops near Kiangwan were caught unprepared today when the swift pursuit planes entered the action. According to a witness, panic followed in the Chinese ranks when these pursuit planes swooped low over the roads leading to the rear and raked the marching troops, automobiles and motorcycles with machine-gun fire.

Stitch McCarthy, Mayor of Grand Street; Abe Rosenberg, Mayor of Orchard Street; Angelo Rizzo, Mayor of Mulberry Street, and John Leppig, Mayor of Avenue A, appeared in dark coats, with hats pulled down over their eyes, outside the banquet room of Teutonia Hall, Sixteenth Street and Third Avenue, at about 11 o'clock last night.

NEWARK, Feb. 22. -- For the first time in the twenty-two years that the meet has been held, Dickinson High School of Jersey City won the team trophy outright in its own interscholastic track and field meet held today at the 113th Infantry Armory.

BOSTON, Feb. 22. -- Mechanics Building was crowded today throughout the opening sessions of the twentieth annual exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club, and dog fanciers welcomed the return to the scene of former notable dog shows, where there was more than ample opportunity for visitors to look over the candidates on the benches.

It used to be Wall Street's occasional belief that the stock market, after the rest and rumination of a double holiday, would resume business with a new burst of significant activity. That does not often happen in these later days -- perhaps because, while the violent shock of liquidation has ended, the market and the public are still nursing their bruises.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22. -- The Yale swimming relay team today lowered the world's record in a 500-yard freestyle race before a large crowd at the annual alumni day celebration, setting a new international mark of 4 minutes 31 seconds and lowering the former record of 4 minutes 32 3-5 seconds, which was created by another Yale team, also coached by Robert J. Kiphuth.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 22. -- Looking out over the ground on which George "Washington's troops drilled with bleeding feet more than 150 years before. General John J. Pershing, the nation's last war General, today paid tribute to Washington, its first, as "one of the great captains of all time."
BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- The bill which the Germans must pay for the liquidation of the bank crisis last July was presented to them today.

Paulie Walker, Trenton, N.J., welterweight, encountered sterner opposition than he anticipated last night in his ten-round feature bout with sturdy little Phil Rafferty of the west side at the St. Nicholas Arena, and when the final bell ended the battle the decision of Referee Dorman and Judges Charles F. Mathison and George Kelly was a draw.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- Although George Washington's warnings against foreign entanglements was cited as an enduring basic principle of the foreign policy of the United States, this was qualified by the assertion of a willingness to concede "where concessions may be conducive to progress and stability" in an address tonight by Ambassador Walter E. Edge at the Washington bicentenary dinner.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Westchester residents attended Washington's birthday services in large numbers, many participating in programs arranged by bicentennial committees.

A Havana Fiesta Royal, the third supper-dance of The Imperial, given to aid Bellevue Hospital charities, was held last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Many of the subscribers entertained papties. A program was presented in settings characteristic of Cuban cabarets.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Feb. 28. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney's chestnut gelding, What'll I Do, won a second leg on the handsome Middleburg Trophy, a $2,000 silver bowl awarded the best hunter in the show, in the annual trials of the Middleburg Hunt run today at Oak Hill.

Public interest in questions of health and the cost of medical care has probably never been keener than at present. In the general anxiety to provide for the destitute, criticism often falls heavily upon the doctors. In the current Harper's a doctor's wife endeavors to give a correct view of some of his own problems.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 22. -- When a golden sun had settled in hiding behind a dark cloudbank at sunset today, nine races had been sailed in the dinghies of the Frostbite Yacht Club.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Feb. 23. -- The Chinese, apparently with heavy reinforcements, launched a counter-offensive in the Kiangwan-Miaoshin sector yesterday [Monday] and not only stopped the Japanese in their drive but drove them back.

Orders for women's apparel slackened here last week due to a desire on the part of buyers to await the offering of new dress and coat models based on the recent Parisian openings and also to test consumer reaction to the Spring apparel now being shown by the stores.

A Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad train smashed a small sedan at the Bethel Avenue grade crossing in Tottenville, S.I., about 3:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon, instantly killing a man and his small daughter, fatally injuring his young son and his sister-in-law and causing such serious injuries to his wife that she was not expected to live.

Six specific recommendations to provide for immediate operation of the Long Island Railroad's abandoned Whitestone branch as a temporary rapid transit line, were included in the minority report forwarded yesterday to the Board of Estimate by George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens.

PRINCETON. N.J., Feb. 22. -- Despite a six-goal allowance, the Princeton polo team was defeated today by the Pennsylvania Military College trio, 21 1/2 to 13. Pickering, playing No. 1 for the visitors, led in the scoring with nine goals. Firestone was the Tigers' chief scorer with five.

Two goals by Paul Callahan, one with less than two minutes to play, enabled Brooklyn Prep's hockey team to defeat La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale, L.I., 2 to 1, last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace. By its victory Brooklyn Prep retained the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association title.

Trapped in a blazing five-story tenement at 379 Broome Street, between Mott and Mulberry Streets, last night, sixteen men, women and children, comprising three of the eight families occupying the building, were rescued by the fire crews who answered two alarms.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22. -- Clever riding by Jockey J. Neel featured the racing at the Fair Grounds today as he brought home four winners, scoring in the first two races with Tennywood and Old Bill, respectively, in the fourth with Play Bird and in the sixth with Morsnuff.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 22. -- Every member of the Brooklyn club who donned a uniform and awaited the orders of Manager Max Carey at 11 o'clock this morning was convinced an hour and a half later that the conditioning process had begun in earnest.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- Opening strong, the Bourse became irregular today, although orders near the close prevented declines in a portion of the stock list. Saturday's market in Wall Street, together with reports from Germany concerning the situation of the banks there, caused selling.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- Today was a day of preparation in French political circles for a decisive test of the new Andre Tardieu Government before the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow. Estimates of the new Premier's margin of safety vary, but no one is even considering the possibility of defeat.

Frank Peer Beal, a member of the City of New York George Washington Bicentennial Commission, described as "astonishing" and "inconceivable" the opposition of Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, to the building" of a reproduction of Mount Vernon in Prospect Park, in a letter to Mr. Straus, made public yesterday.

With or without ghostly assistance, Speaker GARNER has fed to the insatiable Democratic National Committee, which has fed to a not highly interested country, the accusation that the Republicans are trying to hog the glory of all the sound economic and financial measures passed, preparing or proposed in Congress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my humble judgment, the address of Hugh S. Gibson, before the disarmament conference, at Geneva, is simply another pale ray of pacifist moonshine. In other words, it is just the inane sequel that might well follow such a hollow declaration as the Kellogg peace pact, which Senator Hiram W. Johnson of California happily pronounced "a piffle pact."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22. -- A nose victory in which the winner just lasted to save the purse, featured the George. Washington Handicap, feature at Hialeah Park today. Princess Zelda, owned and trained by E.J. Reed, and fresh from a decisive score at Havana, was the winner, finishing the mile and a furlong in 1:532-5.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I answer your recent correspondent. Mr. Pell, who seems to be more anxious for the future well-being of France than the United States of America? Possibly there is a reason for such attitude. However, rather than sneer at the opinion held by Senator Borah, I would take off my hat to that far-seeing statesman.

As a result of the consolidation of two syndicates, which was disclosed yesterday, the city of Newark, N.J., is expected to receive at least one bid today for its issue of $5,000,000 of improvement bonds, due in from one to forty years. When the city last offered bonds, which was on May 19, 1931, virtually all of the municipal houses in Wall Street were aligned in the several groups that submitted bids.

BERLIN, Feb. 22 (AP). -- After more than four months of enforced idleness, the Reichstag will meet again tomorrow afternoon for a brief session to fulfill the necessary legal requirements connected with the Presidential election.
After nearly a year of investigation into the administration of justice in the civil courts of the State, the legislative commission will begin this week to hold public hearings on proposed reforms.
DUBLIN. Feb. 22. -- The Irish Republicans and their Labor allies will have seventy-seven seats, a clear majority, in the new Dail, according to returns tonight from last Tuesday's Irish election.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 22. -- Following the booing of officials and Columbia players by Dartmouth rooters at the Dartmouth-Columbia basketball game here Saturday night, President Ernest Martin Hopkins of Dartmouth today tendered a note of apology to Dean Hawkes of Columbia, criticizing the action of the local student body and praising the work of the Columbia team, whose 42-32 victory over Dartmouth placed the Lions in the Eastern Intercollegiate League lead.

MONTREAL, Que., Feb. 22. -- Canadian newsprint exports in January were valued at $8,661,086, a slight increase over January of last year when the value was $8,641,937, and a substantial gain over December, when exports of newsprint were valued at $8,299,049, according to the report just issued by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics at Ottawa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- America cannot learn to avoid such a crisis as the present while its schools "are bound by the fetters of a narrow program conceived and established in a day when machinery was new And cities were uncommon," leaders in education told schcool heads from all parts of the country at the sessions of the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association today.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22. -- If H.O. (Fritz) Crisler is named head football coach at Princeton it will mark a departure from the time-honored Tiger policy of alumni coaching.

The holiday week-end was marked by inactivity in the realty field, only a few scattered fee and leasehold deals being reported. Numerous rentals of business space were listed, however, in addition to apartment leases.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 22 (AP). -- Georgia Democrats, in a primary March 23, will express their Presidential preference between Governor Roosevelt of New York and G.H. Howard of Atlanta. Superior Court Judge, who has announced he would seek the State's votes at the Chicago convention for Speaker Garner.

T.H. Lewis captured the annual shoot, for the George H. Lyon Memorial Trophy over the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday by breaking 196 out of a possible 200 targets. It was the best score in a field of 114 gunners.

PRINCETON. N.J., Feb. 22. -- The M. Taylor Pyne honor prize, the highest general distinction that Princeton University can confer upon an undergraduate, was awarded today to John. H. Rice of Macon, Ga., at the meeting of the National Alumni Association.
UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP). -- Utica citizens have pledged themselves to "free" $1,738,691 in a counter-attack upon depression.

QUEBEC, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Shorty Russick, grizzled little veteran of many a Northern trail, today drove his team of huskies in a well-beaten track to first place for the first day's forty-mile run of the three-day Quebec Dog Derby.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 22. -- John N. Garner, Speaker of the House, was boomed as the "next President" by Democratic leaders from all parts of Texas in an enthusiastic rally held here this afternoon.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Governor Roosevelt, Chief Judge Cardozo of the Court of Appeals, Joseph A. McGinnies, Speaker of the Assembly, and former Governor Nathan L. Miller, representing the three great divisions of the New York State Government, as well as the people, paid high tribute to the memory of George Washington at commemorative exercises held today under State auspices at Chancellors Hall in the State Education Building.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 23 (AP). -- General Araki, Minister of War, announced today that new troop reinforcements would be sent to Shanghai. War Office sources disclosed that the decision to dispatch additional soldiers to the scene of the battle with China was reached at a long conference at the War Minister's official residence last night.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, told the House of Commons tonight that so far as he knew no great powers were in a secret agreement with Japan and conniving with her aggression in China. This assurance was given in reply to one of several questions put by George Lansbury, leader of the Opposition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- President Hoover was the central figure today in the opening of the national celebration of the 200th anniversary of the birth of George Washington. Because the day was Washington's, the present President laid aside the cares of State to pay tribute to the first.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22. -- Yale University's income for the current year will fall short by $500,000 ot meeting expenses and all departments have been asked to make a 10 per cent reduction in their budgets.

Hearty endorsement of Cardinal O'Connell's recent statement of his opinions of radio crooning was expressed in a unanimous resolution adopted recently by the New York Singing Teachers' Association and made public yesterday by Frederic Warren, its presicent.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 22. -- H.O. (Fritz) Crisler, athletic director at the University of Minnesota, said today he probably would become head football coach at Princelon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The Norris anti-injunction bill will be taken up in the Senate tomorrow, fourteen years after the Nebraskan began agitation for such legislation. Senator Norris was working on a speech today which will open what promises to be lengthy and heated debate.
Memorial masses were held yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral and several other Roman Catholic churches of the city for the deceased members of Catholic societies and organizations.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Feb. 22. -- The navy's airship Akron, the world's largest dirigible, snapped her stern cables in a gust of wind this morning, and, swinging free of the car on which the tail was riding, bumped along over the ground in a 150-degree turn before she was brought under control.

The time for being surprised at a revival of "The Merry Widow" is long past, but not the time for lighting candles and playing waltz tunes in its honor, and so it turned out to be a festive and affectionate and altogether pleasant afternoon and evening with which Milton Aborn began the final fortnight of his Civic Light Opera season yesterday at Erlanger's.

After three unsuccessful expeditions to the East Indies in search of a sondaicus, the rare one-horned specimen of the Malayan rhinoceros, Arthur S. Vernay, hunter and collector, cabled yesterday from Penang that he had at last succeeded in his quest.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22. -- The outlawing of Trotsky by decree of the central executive committee is exciting a good deal of attention among members of the Communist party and foreign political observers here.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Cricket history was made today when the team of the Colony of Jamaica scored 702 runs for the loss of only 5 wickets against a powerful team of English cricketers and declared their first innings closed at that point.

ALBANY. Feb. 22. -- The future of the State unemployment relief program is expected to be decided tomorrow at a conference between Governor Roosevelt and relief board heads. The Governor will confer with Jesse I. Straus, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration: Philip J. Wickser. a member, and Cornelius N. Bliss Jr. and Colonel Joseph A. Hartfield.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Charges that Japanese soldiers were killing defenseless Chinese peasants behind the lines at Kiangwan were printed today in the American-owned Shanghai Evening Post-Mercury.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Assemblyman Louis A. Cuvillier, New York Democrat, made an unsuccessful attempt in the Assembly tonight to have that body take immediate steps to investigate a statement that motor-truck owners are raising a huge slush fund to defeat the bill increasing the license fees on heavy vehicles.

The application of the policies of George Washington to present-day conditions of preparedness was urged by leaders of the army and naval forces of this area at the Washington's Birthday celebration of the Veteran Corps of Artillery of the State of New York, held yesterday at the Hotel Pierre.

Net income of the Freeport Texas Company for 1931 amounted to $2,376,782, after depreciation, Federal taxes and charges, equal to $3.26 a share earned on 729,844 no-par capital shares outstanding. This compares with a net income of $3,124,184 in 1930, or $4.28 a share on the same capitalization.

More than 270 prominent citizens of the Middle West, Atlantic seaboard and South have endorsed the proposal to use economic measures to prevent war, which was submitted to President Hoover and Congress last week by A. Lawrence Lowell, president of Harvard University, and Harry A. Garfield, president of Williams College, according to an announcement yesterday by the American Committee on the Far Eastern Crisis.

ALBANY, Tuesday, Feb. 23. -- The Senate early today passed, by a vote of 28 to 23, the bill sponsored by Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter, providing an appropriation of $250,000 for his New York City inquiry committee in addition to the $250,000 voted by the 1931 Legislature.

Recognized genius has in nearly every instance been coupled with insanity and almost invariably "genius signifies a terrible martyrdom," W. Lange-Eichbaum, German author of "Genius, Insanity and Fame," an exhaustive biographical study of 800 men and women who have been admired as geniuses, writes in "The Problem of Genius," a brief summary of his conclusions translated by Eden and Cedar Paul, and published today by Macmillan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The Eighty-eighth Division of General Chiang Kai-shek's army appeared in the fighting at Shanghai for the first time today and slowed down the Japanese advance, Admiral M.M. Taylor, commander of the United States Asiatic fleet, reported to the Navy Department.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- With Chief Judge Benjamin N. Cardozo of the Court of Appeals assured of confirmation as an associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, Governor Roosevelt indicated tonight that he would promptly fill the vacancy on the State bench.

George Washington's determined stand for religious liberty and his part in having the principle of spiritual freedom written into the Constitution were hailed yesterday afternoon by spokesmen for the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths in a radio program broadcast from Station WOR under the auspices of the Greater New York Interfaith Committee.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 22. -- A formidable move is believed to be under way against the Japanese in Manchuria.

Quarrels over architectural modes are silly, in the opinion of Ely Jacques Kahn, architect and chief of the industrial arts section of the Chicago 1933 world's fair. He spoke yesterday afternoon at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, in connection with an exhibition of Joseph Urban's recent work.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- The Washington bicentenary was observed by Americans in London at a number of celebrations. United States Charge d'Affaires and Mrs. Ray Atherton held an "at home" at the embassy, which was attended by many resident and visiting Americans.

MALONE, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP). -- The mystery of the disappearance of Harry H. Blagden from a cottage at Lake Placid was cleared up today with the receipt by a State Police captain of a letter from Blagden admitting that his story of a dramatic kidnapping was imaginary.
BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- The bicentennial of George Washington's birth was observed in all the principal cities of Germany today, and for days the newspapers have been carrying appreciatory articles.

Imagination and thirst for adventure as much as physical strength made the Vikings what they were. Even in an age when mechanism takes the place of muscles their spirit lives on. For it seems there are electrical vikings who would export Norwegian electrical energy to Germany.

A Washington who, by his invincible will, "won in equal measure the glories of peace and the glories of war," as great in reality as his patterned, traditional figure, though he wined, wooed, flirted, gambled and took "desperate chances in battle," stalked the historic headquarters in Morristown, N.J., yesterday in a portrait depicted by Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22. -- Efrem Zimbalist, violinist, appeared tonight in a recital at the Everglades Club under the auspices of the Society of Arts. The concert, third of a series of five scheduled for the season, was marked by a full attendance of subscribers.

HARRISBURG. Pa., Feb. 22. -- Candidates pledged to support the popular choice for President at the April preferential primary will be in the field within the next two weeks for all places in the Pennsylvania delegation to the Democratic National Convention, it was announced today by Warren Van Dyke, president of the Roosevelt-for-President League, at the conclusion of a meeting of the organization.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 22. -- Until the American people accept Washington's maxim that "virtue or morality is a necessary spring of popular government we shall make no real start in rescuing ourselves from the ills that beset us," Bainbridge Colby, Secretary of State in the Wilson Cabinet, told Rotarians attending the Indiana district conference this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The text of President Hoover's speech at the opening of the celebration of the birth of George Washington follows:

The transformation of various proposals by national leaders for a better order of economy from the "tentative" blue-print stage to the stage of workable plans and "to realize them in actuality is the supreme task of this generation," Professor Charles A. Beard, former president of the American Political Science Association, writes in a book entitled "America Faces the Future," published today by Houghton Mifflin Company.

Samuel Seabury, who on Jan. 16 filed charges with the Justices of City Court against their chief clerk, Harry C. Perry, a former Tammany district leader, criticized the justices yetserday for their delay in the case.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- Helped by further improvement in sterling, British government funds provided the brightest feature of the stock Market today. With the exception of the war loan, which again changed hands at par, all the issues improved.

A report in recent cable dispatches from Cape Town that the government of the Union of South Africa had reached an agreement whereby a private concern would take over the government's diamond-cutting factory at Kimberley was denied yesterday by P.R. Botha, commercial secretary of the South African Legation in Washington.

State Senator A. Spencer Feld's bill providing for a referendum on capital punishment is one of nine additional bills pending in the Legislature that are disapproved by the New York County Lawyers' Association. In the latest instalment of its report on the present Legislature, made public yesterday, the association approves of six pending measures.

TOKYO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Sadao Araki, the War Minister who is directing the Japanese military policy toward China and Manchuria, said today that the army hopes to withdraw from the Shanghai area as quickly as possible and has no plans for a long-time occupation.

The Division of Information and Statistics of the State Department of Labor made public yesterday for the first time records on employment for a year in the construction industry. These figures will be made public monthly hereafter, similar to the employment figures for manufacturing industries.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 24. -- Following a day of desperate fighting yesterday in an attempt to break down Chinese resistance and recover lost ground in the neighborhood of Kiangwan, the Shanghai battlefield quieted down at Shanghai itself last night and this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The Hale bill, authorizing construction of naval vessels up to the maximum provided in the London Naval Treaty, was unanimously ordered favorably reported today by the Senate Naval Affairs Committee.

Mr. Straus saw the prospect of a Spring, a Summer and another Winter in which there would be heavy calls for the continuance of the relief work the commission has been conducting, even though industrial conditions should improve. His review of the situation was not hopeful of betterment.

As a result of the pressure of claims by several municipalities throughout the country which paid interest and principal on their bonds through the investment banking and brokerage firm of Kountze Brothers, now in receivership, Peter B. Olney Jr., as referee, yesterday directed the trustee, the Irving Trust Company, which had originally been appointed temporary receiver in equity, to start proceedings as quickly as possible so that settlement of claims can be made soon.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 23. -- Robert M. Short; a young American flier, was killed when his plane was shot down in flames while he was attacking Japanese bombers over the city of Soochow yesterday.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Captain Esse Boies of Diaz Creek, master of the 35-foot fishing boat Sea Toy, fitted a new anchor to his craft at Schellenger's Landing today, after a ninety-foot whale, he reported, had swallowed his old one and almost eaten the Sea Toy and the crew too.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Charges of issuing "indecent" films, violating the anti-trust laws and raising a "smoke screen" to prevent action by the authorities were made against the motion-picture industry today by Senator Brookhart. He urged a Senate investigation.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Carder will give a dinner for the French Ambassador and Mme. Paul Claudel tomorrow at 15 East Ninty-sixth Street.

GENEVA, Feb. 23. -- With singular unanimity, what has hitherto been regarded as the steering committee of the disarmament conference derided today that the time for trying to steer the conference anywhere had not yet come and that it was not the right body, anyway, to undertake such a task.

People streamed all day yesterday into St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, where they viewed in silence the figure of Christ, which is clearly discernible in the veining of the brownish marble on the wall of the sanctuary.

Additional universities and colleges in the metropolitan district revealed, the extent to which they are feeling the pinch of the depression yesterday, following Yale's announcement of a 10 per cent cut in its budget to take care of a $500,000 shrinkage in its annual income.

When the record-breaking budget was adopted last Fall Mayor WALKER blithely remarked that no one need worry, as the tax-rate would be cut. How that miracle was to be performed he did not explain. Controller BERRY wisely refused to commit himself to the 2.53 rate which the Mayor confidently predicted, while unofficial calculators were frankly skeptical.

Harrison R. Johnston of St. Paul, winner of the national amateur championship when it was played at Pebble Beach in 1929, has been named chairman of the selection of courses committee of the United States Golf Association, according to the list, of committee appointments announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 (AP). -- General Jose Uriburu, who stepped out in favor of a constitutional President, after a year and a half of rule in Argentina by force of arms, was challenged to a duel today by former General Alonzo Baldrich.

ADOLF HITLER, a dozen years ago a lance corporal in the Bavarian army and now a candidate against HINDENBURG for President of the German Republic, certainly has had a personal progress of which history will take note, no matter what may be the future of his picturesque career.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 23 (AP). -- Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight champion, easily outpointed Frankie Wine, blacksmith from Butte, Mont., tonight to win a newspaper decision. Dempsey weighed 194 and Wine 191.

Heavy buying by the Federal Reserve Bank to replace maturities in the portfolio of bills held for the account of foreign correspondents yesterday lilted the acceptance market out of the doldrums in which it closed last week and forestalled a threatened increase in open-market rates.
Unlisted trading was dull yesterday, stocks starting listlessly and turning weak in the afternoon.

In contrast with the operations of Japanese forces in Manchuria, where they had at least a color of legal right and moved to their objectives with speed and precision the undertakings of Japan at Shanghai have been sadly mismanaged. This is a belief to which even her warmest friends in other countries have been forced.

The annual meeting and election of officers of the Episcopal Actors' Guild of America were held yesterday at the Little Theatre, where an audience that filled most of the orchestra heard speeches by Leslie Howard, the Rev. Charles Breck Ackley and Sir Philip Ben Greet.

"Chautauqua" in Western New York has given its name to a geologic formation in the Upper Devonian because the outcropping was found by some geologist in the vicinity of Chautauqua Lake. But that region has the higher distinction of having given its name to a system of education which had its beginnings under the inspiration and leadership of two men.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation has been called for March 23, after the annual meeting on that day, to act on a proposal to reduce from $19.94 to $10 a share the capital represented by outstanding shares of stock.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- Officials of the Chicago Board of Trade took another step today to reduce the influence of the Department of Agriculture on the grain trade, the directors ordering an amendment to the rules posted for ballot. The amendment would permit the delivery of No. 1 and No. 2 yellow hard Winter wheat on future contracts.

SEATTLE, Feb. 23 (AP). -- With two men to be nominated for Mayor, results from today's primary election showed that John F. Dore, a lawyer, and Mayor Robert Harlin led the poll while Vic Meyers, jazz orchestra leader and spectacular "personality" candidate, trailed far behind former Mayor Frank Edwards, who was recalled last Summer.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- France served notice today in the form of a report on part of her war budget for 1932 that she intended to spend at least as much and probably more this year for war purposes than last.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- An estimate that the turnover of manufactured goods in this country totaled $30,000,000,000 was sent to the Ways and Means Committee today by Secretary Mills in connection with proposals for a general sales tax, which is being favored more and more by framers of the new revenue bill.
The architectural committee of the Fifth Avenue Association announced yesterday that the Empire State Building had won its 1931 gold medal and diploma.

Favorable price trends during the rest of this year, but no exceptional advances, are indicated by statistics for silver, corn, cotton, wool, raw silk and live-stock products, speakers declared last night at a meeting of the American Statistical Association in the Hotel Commodore.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Sixtynine years after the youth whose likeness it bears fell mortally wounded at Chancellorsville, a faded daguerreotype of two youthful lovers has been restored to the girl he left behind him. The story was unfolded here by Edgar Whritenour of North Haldeon, N.J., who located her after years of searching.

The new rates for automobile insurance, effective next Tuesday, were made public yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance. The new schedule in many instances is lower than the rates previously approved by the department on the application of the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters.

Three additional sectional Olympic track and field tryouts will be recommended to the American Olympic Committee when it meets here on March 6, it was announced yesterday by Chairman Joseph T. England of the 1932 Olympic Games Track and Field Committee, following a meeting of the committee.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Frederick J. Perry, the British ace, making his first appearance in the title tournament today, disposed of Captain Rendle of Bermuda, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Charges by the Shanghai Evening Post-Mercury that Japanese soldiers were putting defenseless Chinese civilians to the sword brought from a high Japanese officer today the assertion that they are "much exaggerated and in some portions untrue."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The nomination of Judge Benjamin N. Cardozo to an associate justice of the Supreme Court today was unanimously reported favorably by the Senate Judiciary Committee. The approval cleared the way for prompt action by the Senate, which will probably confirm the nomination tomorrow.

The MacDowell Orchestra, directed by Philip James, will give a concert tonight at 8:30 at the Seward Park High School auditorium. The orchestra is made up of musicians for whom work, instead of charity, is provided by the Musicians Emergency Aid. Katherine Bacon will be the assisting artist.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Water polo was definitely abolished at Princeton today when Dr. Joseph E. Raycroft, chairman of the department of hygiene and physical education, prohibited the use of Brokaw Pool for participation in the sport in a report to the board of athletic control.

The Bank of France, which last week completed a series of eleven shipments of earmarked gold aggregating $132,500,000 from this market to Paris, has revised its plans and will continue to make transfers of the metal until it has materially reduced the $500,000,000 of balances which it still holds in this market.

President Hoover was commended yesterday for adherence to his preelection pledges to support prohibition in resolutions adopted by the trustees of the New York State AntiSaloon League at their annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 23. -- Senorita Jacinto Aznar, 50 years old, prominent in Mexico social circles, was found dead this morning in her residence on the fashionable Avenida de los Insurgentes.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23. -- Par figures were lowered today in the first round of the fifty-four-hole St. Petersburg $1,500 open golf tournament, as Wiffy Cox of Brooklyn, Clayton Atridge of Tampa and Craig Wood of Deal, N.J., jumped into the early lead with elghteenhole scores of 69 strokes each. Par for the course is 72.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 23. -- Julius Seligson of New York, in the only match needed to complete the second-round singles, defeated Joe Lewin of New York, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4, in the Pan-American tennis championship on the Flamingo courts today. Lewin's cross-court shots forced Seligson to the base line throughout the second set, but the latter's fast pace and improved service enabled him to break through to a lead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The writ of injunction as invoked by employers in labor disputes was denounced in the Senate today as an instrument of "involuntary servitude" by Senator Norris in opening debate on his anti-injunction bill, which is to remain the pending business of the Senate until voted on.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The reply of Japan to the recent note of the Council of Twelve of the League of Nations consists of a covering letter from Foreign Minister Kenkichi Yoshizawa to the President of the Council, Joseph Paul Boncour, and a statement.

Another Indictment for perjury against former General Sessions Judge Francis X. Mancuso, who was chairman of the board of directors of the defunct City Trust Company, was handed up yesterday to Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley by the extraordinary grand jury which has been conducting a new investigation into the affairs of the City Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Further heavy liquidation of Federal Reserve member bank credit in connection with the efforts of banks to fortify themselves against withdrawal of deposits and the enactment of remedial legislation creating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were outstanding points in the American financial situation in January, in the opinion of the Federal Reserve Board.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23. -- Panetian, the gelded son of Galetian and Pan Maid, which used to race for George D. Widener, won today at Hialeah Park in the colors of C. Leroy King, having been disposed of at private terms before the running of the race. W.F. Mulholland, who trained Panetian for Mr. Widener, saddled him for Mr. King.

The Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate closed yesterday its public hearings on pending applications for bus franchises in Queens and set next Tuesday for final hearings on Manhattan applications.
