At that time it will hear arguments by S. Stanwood Menken, counsel for Bus Transfers, Inc., and Morgan J. O'Brien Jr., counsel for the Eighth and Ninth Avenues Railways Company.

When Cardinal O'CONNELL called the crooning of the most popular radio entertainers "a degenerate form of singing," he won the hearts of all admirers of the trained voice. There is no organization of audiences for good singing to congratulate him on his statement, but one group has come out with an endorsement for him.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Feb. 23. -- "It is apparent that Senator Brookhart chooses to reiterate the position he has taken for the last five years with regard to the motion picture industry," Will H. Hays said today. "He rests his conclusions upon many untrue and distorted statements that have been published and repudiated from time to time.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 23 (AP). -- The possibility of a sound setback faced the team of English cricketers now touring the West Indies under the captaincy of Lord Tennyson when, at the close of today's play against the colony of Jamaica, they found themselves needing 233 runs to save an, innings defeat.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23. -- No martial display with parades or the blowing of trumpets -- except in the newspapers -- marked the celebration of the fourteenth anniversary of the Red Army today.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- An extensive program for the development of State beach parks in Monmouth, Ocean, Essex, Morris and Burlington Counties was recommended today to Governor Moore and the Legislature by the New Jersey State Park Commission.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 23 (AP). -- Senator George H. Moses, Republican, of New Hampshire, a member of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, said today there would be no American economic boycott of Japan as a penalty for its campaign in China.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Speaker Garner is not involved in any movement to stop the candidacy of any Presidential aspirant, according to Representative Rayburn, who was appointed yesterday by the San Antonia Garner Committee as national leader for the Texas favorite son.

The ping-pong tournament to decide a delicate matter of supremacy between the local stage and the local newspaper world was held early this morning in what is brightly called the Chinese Room of the Algonquin Hotel. Several hours after it started, it seemed to have settled down, to the steady elimination of English actors by Howard Dietz.

With Mayor Walker broadcasting the first message, the Police Department's new radio alarm system, which will flash reports of crimes to policemen in Department automobiles cruising throughout the city, began operating yesterday. Commissioner Mulrooney said the service for the present would be limited to Manhattan but that in a short time 220 patrol cars equipped with radio apparatus would be in use in all parts of the greater city.

An audience that packed the main auditorium and galleries of the Engineering Societies' Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, heard Dr. Alexander Forbes of Harvard University lecture last night on the recent aerial exploration of northern Labrador.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Feb. 24. -- Turned back time and time again in their daylight assaults on the Chinese stronghold at Kiangwan during the bitter fighting of the last four days, the Japanese launched a desperate attempt to take it in the darkness before dawn this morning.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 23. -- The Japanese admitted today that their centre had been driven back nearly two miles around Kiangwan village and the race track, and at 4 o'clock this afternoon had not recovered any of the lost ground.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 23. -- I visited the no man's land north of the village of Kiangwan today, where most of the heavy fighting has taken place during the last two or three days, and found there the marks of a reign of terror.

Bond prices failed yesterday to show any definite trend on the Stock Exchange. The trading was the slowest of any full-trading-period day this year. Fluctuations were generally within narrow limits and the net changes were usually of small consequence.

Frederick J.H. Kracke, Brooklyn Republican leader and former United States Senator William M. Calder are slated to head the Kings County organization at the Republican National Convention in Chicago in June, according to a tentative slate of delegates and alternates made public yesterday.

In a letter to independent dealers in automobile tires F.A. Seiberling, president of the Seiberling Rubber Company, attacked yesterday the recent action of tire manufacturers in selling to large oil companies at or below the prices quoted to independent retail dealers.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- The revolting Conservative agriculturists called off their attack on the government's 10 per cent tariff bill in the Commons tonight when they received a concession in the placing of maize (corn) on the controversial free imports list.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Wabash Railway Company again voiced its objection today to the proposed consolidation of all Eastern railroads into four systems, rather than five as provided in the 1929 plan of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

More than 200 women attended the opening yesterday of the ninth annual institute and conference of chief occupational therapists of the State Department of Mental Hygiene at the Psychiatric Institute and Hospital, 722 West 168th Street. Mrs. Eleanor Clarke Slagle, director of the Bureau of Occupational Therapy, presided.

The four-story dwelling at 250 West Seventieth Street has been leased by Hattie M. Melhuish, broker, for Mrs. Marie Scott for five years. Irene Miller was associate broker in the deal. The house at 41 West Eighty-eighth Street was leased by the same brokers for Jennie Rothbaler for five years.

The following are the new and old minimum coverage rates for automobile insurance announced by the State Insurance Department. The new rates are effective March 1 and cover private passenger and commercial cars in this State.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 23 (AP). -- The sale of the Springfield Baseball Club of the Eastern League to the New York Americans was announced tonight after a seven-hour conference between representatives of both clubs.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 23 (Canadian Press). -- The importance of a favorable balance of trade is being brought home sharply to the Canadian people with the harrowing experience of the deflated dollar in New York, according to a statement issued today by H.H. Stevens, Minister of Trade and Commerce.

MAMARONECK, Feb. 23. -- Charles Newton Coryell Jr., 17-year-old high school student, was found dead in his room in the Coryell home at 71 North Chatsworth Avenue, tonight, with a bullet wound in his head. On the floor beside his bed was a Spanish type automatic pistol.

The possibility of holding a special race involving phar Lap, Australian champion now in Mexico preparing for the Agua Caliente Handicap, has been suggested by Victor Schaumburg, racing secretary at both Saratoga and Belmont Park, it became known yesterday when Mr. Schaumburg returned from a brief stay at Hialeah Park.

Brokers and speculators were so much confused yesterday as to the effect of the new rule restricting the lending of stock to the short interest that business on the Stock Exchange slowed to a walk. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,275,000 shares, compared with 2,430,000 on Friday, the last five-hour day of the previous week.

Charley Peterson of St. Louis reduced by 6 points the lead of Isidro Ribas of Spain last night in the second block of the New York competition in their match for the world's fancy-shot billiard championship, played at the Elks Club. Peterson was trailing by 35 points when play opened last evening.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 23. -- Since it has become evident from the exigencies of the military situation, coupled with official declarations from Tokyo, that Japan must widen the sphere of her military activities at Shanghai, as well as largely reinforce her army, speculation is rife here concerning the duration of the scrupulous neutrality of the great powers.
CAMDEN, S.C., Feb. 23. -- A fairly large number of visitors attended the hunter trials which were held today at Springdale.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:
ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- A bill giving permanency to the "disorderly conduct" law enacted at the special session after a plea by Police Commissioner Mulrooney, was passed by the Legislature today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP). -- Patrick Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, arrived here today from Nassau, with words of criticism for the prohibition laws and expressions of belief that the nation has benefittea greatly from its trials in less prosperous times.

"Cynara," of which Philip Merivale is the star, will be transferred next Monday evening from the Morosco Theatre to the Shubert. As already printed in THE TIMES, the succeeding attraction at the Morosco will be "The Warrior's Husband," which will open during the week of March 7.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP). -- The proposed system of home loan banks was alternately called a measure that would liquidate frozen realty assets in banks and one which would bring a huge governmental fund into competition with private resources in testimony today before a Senate committee.

The drive of the United Action Group for 1,000,000 jobs in its war against depression had found 78,076 jobs up to noon yesterday, it was announced, of which 9,116 were obtained for the twenty-four-hour period ended at midday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- Alexander Legge, president of the International Harvester Company, said in his annual report, issued tonight, that prices for farm products would improve and that agriculture would be the motivating agency to stem the tide of depression and inspire a return to prosperity.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- Ambassador Walter E. Edge reached Paris this afternoon in the boat-train from the Ile de France, after disembarking at Havre this morning. He was met at the Gare St. Lazare by Mrs. Edge, with their three children and members of the embassy staff.

The name of Rockefeller will be perpetuated in the midtown development that has been known popularly as Radio City, according to a decision of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Square Corporation, which announced yesterday that the official name of the $250,000,000 project would be Rockefeller Centre, in honor of its chief sponsor, John D. Rockefeller Jr.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23. -- All favorites, with the exception of John B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., came through their first-round matches today in the Dixie amateur golf championship.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23. -- Jockey Bob Finnerty, a New Orleans boy performed the uncommon feat of bringing home four victors, including Robert A. Fairbairn's Stimulator in the Bayou La Fourche Purse, which featured the program at Fair Grounds today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The Nationalist Government of China, in a statement transmitted to its legation here tonight, declared that it would not recognize the so-called "puppet" government set up in Manchuria under Japanese auspices last week nor any other government established there independently of China.
Nationalism in art won a victory last night in a debate at the Whitney Museum of American Art, but when the argument had ended, there seemed to be doubt about what constituted nationalism in art.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, left for Geneva this afternoon to be present at the first meeting of the general committee of the disarmament conference tomorrow. He had intended to remain in London until after tomorrow's meeting of the British Cabinet, but hastened his departure on the suggestion of Premier Tardieu of France.

The leading figure skaters of nine countries will participate in the charity ice carnival which will he conducted in Madison Square Garden tonight. The program has been arranged for the benefit of the convalescent relief division of Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau, and the proceeds will be devoted to carrying on the charitable activities of the organization.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 23. -- General Ma Chen-shan, erstwhile Chinese national hero because of his defense of the Nonni River and Tsitsihar against the Japanese last November but now denounced as a traitor, today telegraphed his swansong to Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang at Peiping.

Despite a succession of freak hands which made almost anything possible in the way of scores, the favorite contract bridge teams came through with points to spare yesterday to survive the final elimination round of the team-of-four event in the Eastern bridge championships.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 23. -- Insisting that the hospitality of the Japanese Army had been abused and charging that certain writers for Shanghai newspapers and some foreign correspondents had unfairly represented the conduct of Japanese soldiers on the Kiangwan front, Lieut. Gen. Uyeda announced tonight through the Japanese Consul General the cancellation of all military passes.

Oldest and Newest Maps. Within the week there has been reported the finding of the world's oldest map. Traced on a clay tablet, it was found 200 miles north of Babylon buried in a layer of ruins that was a living city more than 4,400 years ago.

GENEVA, Feb. 23. -- While preparations are going on for the meeting of the League of Nations Assembly on March 3 underground negotiations have been going on to determine whether events in the Far East have yet become serious enough for Geneva and Washington to consult and act openly together to achieve the objects of both the League covenant and the BriandKellogg pact.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Strips pf fabric were removed from the lower vertical fin and the framework of the Akron at the Naval Airship Station here today to determine the damage done to the dirigible's duralumin girders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The sixty-first gavel to be given to Speaker Garner of the House was presented to him today by Edward F. Williams, an admirer from Blythe, Cal., who told him that all residents of the Palo Alto Valley favored him for President.

BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- Terriers and sporting dogs today divided attention at the second day of the twentieth annual exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club in Mechanics Building. Another large crowd lined the judging rings to watch the experts sort the various winners.

Weakness was general in most all commodities yesterday, metals excepted, with new low prices being registered in four cash articles. These were oats, pork, silk and rubber. In contract silk, February dropped to $1.55, a new all-time low, and 5 cents under the previous minimum. Losses elsewhere were reported in the grains, sugar and rubber. Hides turned strong after midday and closed 10 to 20 points higher.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Vincent F. Jankauskas in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES makes some statements which I feel obliged to answer. He claims to state facts, and yet they are very disputable and partly obviously mistaken. A greater limitation of the word fact would seem advisable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Feb. 17 shows decreases for the week of $54,000,000 in loans and investments, $23,000,000 in net demand deposits, $24,000,000 in time deposits and $41,000,000 in government deposits, and an increase of $21,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

The defense of Joseph A. Broderick. State Superintendent of Banks, to the charge that he neglected his duty in failing to close the Bank of United States before he did, Is to be that he was seeking to save the bank, not only in the interest of its 400,000 depositors but also to avert a serious blow to public confidence in the banking structure of the State.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23 (AP). -- White Russians are being organized to seize the interests of the Soviet Government in the Far East, War Minister Voroshilov declared in an order published today in connection with the celebration of the fourteenth anniversary of the organization of the Red Army.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- Plans were reported here today for the construction early next month of the first eight units in what eventually will be a $1,500,000 development on a thirty-five-acre tract opposite the new White Plains High School on old Mamaroneck Road.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- The Bourse after yesterday's weakness rallied strongly today and the volume of trading was considerably larger. Despite the absence of indications from Wall Street which recently has greatly influenced the Paris market, domestic shares were buoyant at the opening and during the session the activity gradually was extended to other groups.
BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- Scoring a 2-to-1 victory over the Boston Athletic Association, the Harvard varsity fencing team won the New England three-weapon championship on the losers' strip tonight.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 24. -- Japan will be in no hurry to recognize the new Mancburian State, it is declared by the Foreign Office. Indications are seen that the State may not be entirely severed from China, but rather only partly detached.

Music conceived for violin and piano in terms of a closely knit fabric wherein tooth instruments equally sustain the composer's intent is all too frequently played in terms of violin solo and piano accompaniment. So frequently, in fact, that the joint recital of Yelly d'Aranyi and Myra Hess last night in the Town Hall often had the effect of illuminating in new and lovely ways the familiar compositions of the program.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23. -- Mrs. George White Baxter entertained with a luncheon today at the Seminole Club in honor of Mrs. George L. McAlpin. Guests were:

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,108,050 barrels, a decline of 30.250 from the week ended on Feb. 13, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production east of California averaged 1,600,750 barrels daily, compared with 1,634,800, a decrease of 34,050 barrels.

Felix Lachesnez-Heude, assistant general manager of the French Line for the United States and Canada, has been appointed general manager in charge of the company's services in the West Indies and on the northern coast of South America and will leave shortly for Fort-de-France, Martinique, to assume his new duties.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23. -- Ruddy of complexion and exuding good cheer which seemed to reflect the high optimism with which he regards his 1932 pennant chances, Manager John J. McGraw arrived in camp today to take active command of his Giants and embark on his thirtieth consecutive campaign as pilot of the New York club.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- After a four-hour conference, the State Senate and representatives of building and loan associations operating in New Jersey reached an agreement late today for the enactment of a credit pool of reserves to assure liquidity to the associations participating.

A spirited rally by the St. John's basketball team in the closing minutes of play enabled it to tie Rider College just before the game ended and then go into an extra period to win by 28 to 22, an Arcadia Hall, Brooklyn, last night. Field goals by Nat Lazar and George Slott at critical moments decided the battle.

BERLIN, Feb. 23 (AP). -- The Reichstag snapped under the strain of Presidential politics today and when the bedlam subsided, Adolf Hitler's chief lieutenant had been excluded for offering "a serious insult to the head of the State," President von Hindenburg.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Clinton E. Brush 3d of Memphis, Tenn., a junior at Princeton University, was elected president of the Princeton Triangle Club, undergraduate dramatic organization, and Shelley M. Smith of Ithaca, N.Y., was named vice president, it was announced here tonight.

The first step in the development of a large housing project on Central Avenue in Yonkers will be taken this week with the filing of plans for a group of small dwellings. The plans are for the first unit of an operation that will eventually represent an Investment Of about $1,000,000, according to an announcement yesterday by Henry A. Lenhart, secretary of R.C, Associates, Inc., of 11 West Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Investigation of the New York Stock Exchange was advocated by Senator Capper of Kansas in a speech broadcast over the Columbia network today. At the same time, the House Judiciary Committee announced that Richard Whitney, president of the Stock Exchange, will appear before it tomorrow to testify regarding short-selling, the subject of numerous bills introduced in the House.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Once again it is necessary for those interested in decent housing conditions in the city of New York to go to Albany to withstand the annual drive against those sections of the dwellings law which require the owners of old law tenements to make them somewhat more safe for their occupants and living conditions in them somewhat more sanitary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- No international complication is expected to result from the service of Robert McCawley Short, American aviator of Tacoma, Wash., in the Chinese air arm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noticing that you feature as the most prominent picture of Washington in THE TIMES Magazine today an enlargement of the miniature by Saint Memin, let me call your attention to the use of this portrait on the 8-cent postage stamp of the Washington commemorative issue recently put out by the Postoffice.

After the double holiday at the week-end, Wall Street had hoped for a more interesting share market than that which developed yesterday. The movement of prices was downward and many of the leading issues fell sharply, but the volume of business was small.

The mother and sister of Elizabeth Barrett Cook of Brookline, Mass., who died two weeks ago on the liner Chinese Prince, arrived here yesterday on the Italian liner Conte Biancamano and were met by relatives and by St. George Tucker Arnold of Boston, who was Miss Cook's fiance.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Feb. 23. -- The Westchester workshop of the County Recreation Commission announced today an exhibition of the oil paintings of Peppino Mangravite in the County Centre until March 19. There are 14 works on view, four of which are borrowed from Stephen Etnier, New York; Morton Goldsmith, Scarsdale; Duncan Phillips, Washington, D.C., and Edward Root, Clinton, N.Y.

Buyers Here Still Above Year Ago. Due to the holiday the number of buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday showed a marked decrease under the figures for the preceding week. This total, however, showed a gain over the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

A progrem, in which addresses and music were arranged in the form of a symphony, was presented at Town Hall yesterday under the auspices of the silver symphony committee of the Musicians Emergency Aid, the relief body headed, by Dr. Walter Damrosch.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- President Hoover is said to have prepared a special message to Congress seeking legislation to relieve the congestion in the Federal courts.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- In a sitting that often approached pandemonium, the Chamber of Deputies today gave Andre Tardieu's new government a generous vote of confidence by 309 to 262, thus putting an end within a week to the Ministerial crisis by bringing things just about back where they started.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23. -- With Henry Johnson, an important member of the pitching staff, consigned to the disabled list for a period of at least six weeks, and with Catcher Bill Dickey's holdout campaign becoming more serious with every passing day, the only favorable move in Yankee affairs today was the cutting in half of the resident holdout contingent by reason of Lyn Lary's coming to terms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Through their own resolution to create an "economy committee" of seven members, by which they hope to reduce governmental expenditures by more than $100,000,000 additional, the House Democrats today carried out Speaker Garner's threat of a "split" with the administration.
Eleven parcels in Manhattan and the Bronx were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday.

The Commerce High School quintet furnished an upset when it beat Textile, 29 -- 22, yesterday on the latter's floor in a Manhattan Division P.S. A.L. clash. The setback was the first suffered in seven league games this season by Textile, which is setting the pace, and also ended the losers' P.S.A.L. string of victories, which had reached twenty-six straight over a span of three years.

HARBIN, Manchuria, Feb. 23 (AP). -- General Jiro Tamon prepared once again today to lead his shock divsion Against the Chinese foe, this time eastward along the main line of the Chinese Eastern Railroad to the Imienpo district, where 7,000 Chinese troops are reported to be looting and terrorizing huridreds of Japanese and thousands of Korean residents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Nikola Tesla recalled a startling theory of the cosmic rays and radioactivity which he claimed to have discovered and announced many years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. Bank failures in January numbered 334, involving deposits of $275,411,000, according to a compilation issued today by the Federal Reserve Board. This was a slight improvement as compared with December, when 358 banks with deposits of $277,031,000 closed their doors.

Republicans have had so much heavy going that every compassionate heart must be quickened to find a lot of them in Congress thinking they have something to be cheerful about. Our Washington correspondent has been privileged to catch the accents of hope on these long-despondent lips.

Complaints that military training in the colleges and universities "militarizes the tone and temper of our national life" have led to a report to Secretary WILBUR covering a survey of fifty-four institutions. It was undertaken through a questionnaire sent to thirty-nine States and the District of Columbia by RALPH CHESNY BISHOP.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Through Farley at Tammany," although no doubt true in fact, cannot but serve to the injury of the Democratic party. It goes without saying that all political bodies in the large cities are in the business to keep alive their own peculiar institutions, and incidentally to lose no opportunity to add to their private fortunes.

Shot down by two hold-up men whom he had surprised yesterday in a robbery of a Sears-Roebuck store in Brooklyn, Patrolman John W. Johnstone fired three shots at the pair before he lost consciousness. The thugs retaliated by kicking the fallen patrolman in the face and chest, breaking two of his ribs and injuring him internally.

Smoke from a four-alarm fire which swept a vacant two-story building at 616-626 West Fortieth Street late last night and early this morning billowed eastward as far as Broadway and brought to the neighborhood a large crowd which witnessed one of the most spectacular blazes in recent months.

The New York Bicentennial Commission, which has charge of the plans for the celebration of the 200th anniversary of George Washington's birth, selected yesterday a site in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, on which a reproduction of Mount Vernon is to be erected.

TONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- Factors arising from the economic depression have so affected the Hebrew National Orphan Home here, said to be the largest orthodox Jewish institution of its kind in the country, that the filing of foreclosure proceedings against the home had placed it in imminent peril of being forced to close its doors, Harry Lucacher, superintendent of the orphanage, said today.

Controller Charles W. Berry announced yesterday that the basic tax rate for this year would be $2.59 per $100 of assessed valuation, imposed to raise a total tax levy of $517,122,624.80. The new tax rate is two points higher than the rate last year, $2.57.

After a Broadway run of twelve weeks the Benn W. Levy play, "The Devil Passes," will close its engagement at the Selwyn Theatre on March 26. A road tour of eight weeks' duration will begin in Boston on March 28. The engagement in Boston will be limited to a week, while a number of other large cities have been booked for one, two and three nights.

Failure of either the Kansas Democratic State Committee or a Statewide meeting of Democrats of that State in Topeka on Monday to adopt a resolution endorsing any Democratic aspirant for the nomination for President has been misinterpreted by Eastern newspapers as indicating a setback for Governor Roosevelt, according to a telegram from Governor Harry H. Woodring received yesterday by James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman and coordinator of the Roosevelt preconvention campaign.

BERLIN, Feb. 23. -- Julius Lieban, once famous as a buffo tenor and especially renowned for his personation of the dwarf, Mime, in Wagner's "Ring," a part he played in Angelo Neumann's traveling Wagnerian company in the '80s emerged from retirement tonight long enough to appear in this role in a performance of "Das Rheingold" given at the Staatsoper.

In the course of his comment on the "gay, heartless younger generation" in "They Don't Mean Any Harm," which was played at the Charles Hopkins last evening, Mr. Milne makes one definite point. They are a particularly obnoxious lot: Mr. Milne writes for them some of the most intolerable dialogue that ever flew off an actor's lips.

The decline of American Jewry is predicted by Maurice Samuel, Jewish author and critic, in "Jews on Approval," which Liveright is publishing today. Communal leaders, rabbis, the Jewish press and the philanthropic reputation of the Jews, according to the publishers, "all come in for their share of vigorous criticism" in the book, which challenges the assumption that Jews are more given to charitable enterprise than any other group.

TOKYO, Feb. 23. -- Japan's reply to the latest League of Nations plea for peace at Shanghai, dispatched today, for the first time in this controversy formally challenges the idea of the other powers that China is gradually evolving into an orderly organized State and needs only to be left alone.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The damage to the navy airship Akron when she snapped a stern cable at Lakehurst, N.J., on Monday and bumped along the ground near her hangar, smashing her lower fin and rudder, the steel cable cutting wide gashes in her envelope, is not serious, Rear Admiral William A. Moffett, chief of the Naval Bureau of Aeronautics, declared this afternoon.

The New York Americans rallied three times to avert defeat at the hands of the Toronto Maple Leafs in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. While a crowd of 5,000 persons looked on, the star-spangled sextet came from behind thrice to earn a 4-to-4 overtime tie with their rugged rivals from the North.

MONTICELLO, Ind., Feb. 23 (AP). -- Opening his campaign for the Democratic nomination for President here tonight, Governor William H. Murray of Oklahoma declared that the United States Government's present policy would lead to war with Japan within twelve months.

BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- The Cook brothers turned in a smart bit of hockey tonight to give the New York Rangers their first goal in a 2-to-0 overtime victory over the Boston Bruins, who forced the play throughout, but missed every scoring chance.
BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- Motor trouble stopped short today an attempt to set a new long-distance flight record by Nate C. Browne, former army flier, and Edward Muldowney, reported backer of the flight.

URBANA, Ill., Feb. 23. -- Retrenchment by deferring and eliminating expenditures for supplies and equipment and reductions in its physical plant operating during the present six months' period will permit the University of Illinois to save several hundred thousand dollars, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, president, declared today.

Contemporary Arts, the organization with headquarters at 12 East Tenth Street, which, for four years past has been giving unknown workers in the several arts their first chance, is having an exhibition of paintings by Revington Arthur, until March 4.

Fifty-one persons indicted for conspiracy to violate the Volstead act as a result of an investigation conducted by government agents into the carrying of cargoes of liquor in coastwise vessels without the knowledge of the owners of the boats failed to appear yesterday before Judge Marcus B. Campbell in the Federal court in Brooklyn to enter pleas.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Governor Roosevelt, in a special message to the Legislature today, warned the Republican majority against the menace of riots and fire hazards in the State prisons through elimination of maintenance items from the budget.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Addressing the Newark Rotary Club here today, Franklin W. Fort, banker and former representative in Congress, called upon American banking to lead the way to business recovery by changing its system of making loans to business and making these loans on the basis of appraised intrinsic value of business instead of fluctuating stock-market values.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has purchased a still-life painting by Luigi Lucioni which was exhibited in his recent one-man show at the Ferargil Galleries. Mr. Lucioni, who has just passed the age of 30, is already represented in other American museums.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 23. -- Bunting, which has been something of a lost art on most major league clubs since the advent of the lively ball, will be a rediscovered art on the Brooklyn club if Manager Max Carey has his way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The establishment of a central control office to market bonds held among the assets of suspended national banks was announced today by John W. Pole, Controller of the Currency. Dr. Paul Atkins, economist and banking expert, will have charge of the agency, which will function in cooperation with the New York Federal Reserve Bank, where it is located.
ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- A bill to establish a banking board was passed in the Assembly today in a form agreeable to Governor Roosevelt after a sharp debate and by a vote which cut across party lines.

Finland's prohibition experiment, as seen by two Finnish delegates to the World Disarmament Conference at Geneva -- Rudolf Holsti, former Foregin Minister, and Baron Yrsjoe-Koskinen, present Foreign Minister -- was discussed in talks rebroadcast in the United States over the National Broadcasting Company networks last night.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Former Governor Edward C. Stokes, one of the State's Republican leaders with whom Ambassador Edge conferred during the latter's recent visit to this country, expressed surprise today at reports from Washington that Mr. Edge had suggested a compromise plank on the prohibition question for inclusion in the national platform.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Samuel Insull, chairman of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company, said at the corporation's annual meeting today stockholders who retained their securities would receive handsome returns in the long run.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Secretary of State Stimson tonight sent for Senator Borah, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, probably to acquaint him with a statement bearing on the Sino-Japanese crisis which the government will issue tomorrow.

Recent paintings by Reginald Marsh are being exhibited at the Rehn Gallery, 683 Fifth Avenue, until March 12. If this display argues one fact more persuasively than any other, it is this Mr. Marsh ought to be working on walls. He would seem to be signally endowed with qualifications that make a successful mural artist.

The first seven railroads to report earnings for January show net operating incomes of $3,401,000, against $4,753,000 in January, 1931, and $6,376,000 in December, 1931. They had gross revenues of $31,796,000, against $41,956,000 in January, 1931, and $32,851,000 in December, 1931.

The Cathedral Boys High School five, showing the way in the Manhattan division of the C.H.S.A.A., was upset by Manhattan Prep, 17 -- 12, in a league test yesterday on the Prep floor. The defeat was the second in twelve games for Cathedral, which trailed at the half, 7 -- 2.

The Railroad Credit Corporation will meet today in the offices of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad here to consider applications for loans from about six railroads, in which, it was reported, the Missouri Pacific. Western Pacific, Erie and Nickel Plate were included.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- Today's selling movement in stocks and cotton spread to wheat on the Board of Trade here, and while the bread grain rose about 3/4 cent early, due to strength in bullish news from foreign markets, the close was 5/8 to 1 1/4 cents lower, with liquidation on the way down, especially in the March, which led the decline.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The Supreme Court today again refused to review a case in which the constitutionality of the present radio act was involved. The American Bond and Mortgage Company of Chicago, which with Trianon, Inc., was owner of stations WMBB and WOK, was the rejected petitioner for revise.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 23. -- "If we can get some of the fire of Washington's life, then the celebration will mean something," declared Governor A. Harry Moore in the principal address of the George Washington bicentennial exercises of Rutgers University in the Rutgers gymnasium here this afternoon.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 24 -- Sixty thousand additional men are being sent from Japan to reinforce the 25,000 already here, General Tsai Ting-kai, commander of the Chinese. Nineteenth Route Army defending Shanghai, told a group of forty newspaper correspondents today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., was low scorer in the second round of matches in the Dixie amateur golf championship over the course of the Miami Country Club today, turning in a card of 33, 35 -- 68, four under par, to defeat Lee Chase Sr. of Buffalo, N.Y., 4 up and 2 to play.

Mayor Walker said yesterday that when he had estimated the city's basic tax-rate last October as $2.54 for this year instead of the $2.59 announced by Controller Berry he was merely making an estimate based on data then available. He expressed resentment against newspaper editorials taxing him with having deceived property owners on what the rate would be.

HONOLULU, Feb. 24 -- Negotiations have been entered into with Clarence Darrow, noted criminal lawyer, to defend Mrs. Granville Fortescue and three others against second degree murder charges, it was learned today by The Associated Press.

To the Editor of The New York Times : It is said that when Herbert Spencer visited New York many years ago he was asked what differences he had noticed between the English and the Americans and that he replied, in substance, that his countrymen had, he thought, the greater capacity for indignation.
NEW YORK. Lady Harrington will return from California to the Plaza on March 3.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 24 -- Winnie Ruth Judd was sentenced tonight to die on the gallows May 11 for slaying Agnes Anne Le Roi.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Wheat for the hungry in Northwest farm regions was voted today by the Senate, while Congressional committees approved two other bills to provide jobs for the unemployed and direct Federal relief for the destitute.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 24 -- Dartmouth's basketball team dropped its third league contest in a row tonight when Pennsylvania won by 32-22. As a result Dartmouth dropped to fourth place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Spreading from China proper to virtually every Far Eastern port where her nationals are engaged in business, the Chinese boycott of Japanese goods is becoming increasingly effective, and in numerous instances is resulting in a greater demand for American manufactured products, according to reports to government officials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The text of the letter of Secretary of State Stimson to Senator Borah on the Nine-Power treaty and the Far Eastern policy of the United States, made public here today, is as follows:

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Dazzy Vance agreed on terms after a conference with Manager Max Carey today and will be in uniform Friday. The announcement, made by Secretary John German, did not reveal the terms but said they were "very satisfactory" to both the pitcher and the club officials.

Arturo Toscanini will not resume his post as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, it was announced yesterday by the directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society. He has notified the society that he made his decision on the advice of his physician.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Chinese dispatches from Harbin, Manchuria, reported today that General Ma Chen-shan, Chinese hero of the battle of Nonni River Bridge last Fall, had been assassinated in Harbin.

The completed design prepared by Charles Downing Lay, architect, for Marine Park, the 1,500-acre recreation centre that the city is building on Rockaway Inlet in Brooklyn at a total cost estimated at from $30,000,000 to $50,000,000, was disclosed yesterday by Park Commissioner James J. Browne of Brooklyn.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The new world's automobile speed record of 253.968 miles an hour, established today by Sir Malcolm Campbell of England, is the sixth to be set over a mile route here since 1927, when the late Sir Henry Segrave, also of Great Britain, startled the world by driving an automobile faster than 200 miles an hour over the ocean speedway.

The New York Central Railroad announced last night that it would apply to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan of $7,000,000 to aid in financing its west side improvement. The announcement was made following a meeting in the office of F.E. Williamson, president.
The New York A.C. retained the class A championship of the Metropoliton Squash Tennis League last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Announcement was made today by the American Friends Service Committee that President Hoover had contributed $2,500 for the use of the committee's coal relief section in feeding children in the bituminous coal regions of some of the States.

General Rafael de Nogales, who won his title in the Turkish Army in the World War and who engages from time to time in revolutionary activity in his native land, Venezuela, revealed yesterday that he had appealed to the American State Department to return to Venezuela the sword sent by President Gomez to General Pershing in 1925.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- British. Government funds again were the principal feature at today's session of the London Stock Exchange. The war loan rose to f1OO 1/3 and the conversion 3/2 per cent loan to u79 1/4. Cables and Wireless issues recovered sharply in the afternoon oh a rumor that an agreement had been reached with the Postoffice Department.

P. Hal Sims, leading the "Four Horsemen" contract bridge team of Willard S. Karn, Oswald Jacoby and David Burnstine, scored an easy victory over the Deal Club team headed by Mrs. Sims in the first of the "knockout" sessions of the Eastern bridge tournament yesterday afternoon at the Roosevelt.

PEIPING, Feb. 24 -- The Peiping Union Medical College, supported by the Rockefeller Foundation, was threatened with disruption today at a meeting of the Chinese staff to decide whether to dispatch doctors to operate a military emergency hospital at Shanghai.

Although reaffirming its unwillingness to commit itself to any rapid transit unification plan before it comes to it for official action, the Board of Estimate, under the leadership of Mayor Walker, decided yesterday at a City Hall conference with the Board of Transportation and the Transit Commission to participate in future conferences at which the same groups, and probably the spokesmen for the B.M.T. and Interborough, will discuss the State board's tentative $474,500,000 unification scheme.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 -- J. Monroe Holland, former president of the Chesapeake Bank, in the failure of which more than a year ago depositors lost heavily, was indicted by the Federal grand jury today on charges of filing false schedules of his estate and making false statements in the bankruptcy proceedings in which he is involved.

John R. Voorhis. Grand Sachem of Tammany Hall and former president of the Board of Elections, one of New York City's colorful characters who died Feb. 5 at the age of 102 years, left his entire estate, valued at "more than $20,000," to his two daughters and two grandsons.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Britain's hard-pressed taxpayers were gladdened today by economies of $37,933,300 (at ) in the government's civil estimates for the coming year.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- The will of William Lawrence Saunders, inventor and war-time chairman of the Naval Consulting Board, leaves the bulk of his estate of several million dollars to his daughters, Mrs. Louise Saunders Perkins of New Canaan, Conn., and Mrs. Jean Saunders Lancaster of Hewlett, L.I., and their children.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Establishment of regional loan agencies of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at Atlanta, Little Rock and Helena, Mont., and the appointment of additional members to serve on advisory committees already in existence was announced by the corporation today.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight ring champion, now seeking to regain his laurels, was commissioned an aide on the staff of Governor Laffoon today. Cheers echoed through the Capitol when Lieut. Gov. Chandler, presiding over a joint session of the Legislature, which the prizefighter addressed informally, said, "He'll be fighting for Kentucky from now on."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Wool importers and consumers, principally from Boston and Philadelphia, protested to the Treasury Department today against a ruling of the Customs Bureau in defining the clean content of wool as scoured wool. A hearing was conducted before Seymour Lowman, assistant secretary, and Customs Commissioner Eble.

The stake dates for the Westchester Racing Association's Spring meeting became known yesterday and show that the $75,000 Belmont Stakes will be run on June 4, the last Saturday of the meeting, as had been indicated. The National Stallion Stakes will be run the same day.

Sergei Rachmaninoff took issue yesterday, in one of his infrequent interviews, with the current opinion that modern music represents a period of evolution. To him, he said, it represents only retrogression. He did not believe that anything worth while could grow out of it, because it lacked the one great essential-- heart.

GENEVA, Feb. 24 -- The Swedish Government is making significant efforts to line up the smaller members of the League of Nations, especially the Scandinavians, Dutch and Belgians, for a strong hand in the Assembly in the coming discussions of the Sino-Japanese conflict.

A reduction in the quarterly dividend on the cumulative preferred stock of the Aluminum Company of America to 75 cents a share from $1.50 a share was voted by the directors yesterday. The company issued the following explanatory statement:

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- At a stormy session of the innkeepers of Berlin tonight, a suggestion by the chairman that they accept Chancellor Bruening's statement that the beer tax would be reduced by April 1 as settling the recent dispute over reduction of the price of beer was rejected and a resolution unanimously adopted not to sell a drop of beer for an indefinite period, beginning at midnight.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 -- The "Road to Vienna" was presented by members of the Romany Chorus tonight in the orange gardens of the Everglades Club before a capacity audience. The annual pilgrimmage of Gypsies to Vienna was portrayed under a tent borrowed from John Ringling of Sarasota.

The eighteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season next week will be marked by the debut of Franeesco Merli, Italian tenor, the first performance of the season of Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Sadko" and the return to the company of Beniamino Gigli, who has been away on a mid-winter concert tour.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Substitution by the Scantic Line of the Schenectady and Chickasaw for the Minnequa and City of Fairbury for reconditioning and remodeling under the construction loan agreement of Feb. 16 was authorized by the Shipping Board today.

PARIS, Feb. 24 -- Somewhat frregular at the opening, the Bourse recovered during the latter part of today's session and a good propertion of the list closed higher. The international stocks were depressed on account of Wall Street's position yesterday.

"Marching By," the operetta which ended a Chicago engagement of twelve weeks on Saturday night, was announced yesterday by the Shuberts to have its New York premiere on Thursday night of next week at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, formerly called Chanin's Forty-sixth Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- A 10 per cent tax on tickets for public amusements is being considered as a means of raising the $19,000,000 required if the State's unemployment relief work is to be continued through the Spring, Summer and another Winter.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 24 -- Police clashed twice today with radicals who marched into Kneeland Street, seeking to take a hand in the strike of 3,500 garment workers, which began at 10 o'clock. Two women and a man were arrested.

The report of the Electric Bond and Share Company for 1931 shows a net income of $25,050,084, equal, after preferred dividends, to $16,929,829, or $1.15 a share earned on 14,676,754 common shares outstanding at the end of the year, compared with a net income of $42,355,163 and a balance to common stock of $34,996,014 in 1930, equal to $2.43 a share earned on 14,384,736 shares.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Feb. 24 -- A police judge committed slander in denouncing a prisoner arraigned before him on a charge of wife-beating, a jury in Supreme Court here held today in awarding a $300 verdict in the $20,000 slander suit brought by Daniel Karelas, Yorktown Heights restaurant owner, against Delevan M. Baldwin of Bedford, formerly a justice of the peace at Yorktown.
The text of Governor Roosevelt's announcement, removing Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The action of Governor Roosevelt of New York today in dismissing Thomas M. Farley, Sheriff of New York County, aroused unusual interest in the national capital where it was considered largely a "showdown" between the Governor and the powerful Tammany machine of Manhattan.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Removal of Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, and a legislative investigation of the expenditures of funds by his department, were urged today at a public hearing before the joint public education committees on a series of amendments to the education law.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Detectives were trying tonight to break through the hysterical story of Mrs. Christina Smith, a young Buffalo widow, that a 3-month-old baby boy abandoned in the Union. Terminal Building here, was her own. The return of the child from Buffalo on a warrant is awaited.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- One of the questions put to the Foreign Secretary in the House of Commons concerning the Far East today undoubtedly was inspired by Secretary Stimson's note of Jan. 7 to Japan, in which Great Britain declined to cooperate at the time.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- Within a few days Adolf Hitler will accept his nomination for the Presidency against Paul von Hindenburg, and then one of the strangest electoral campaigns that has ever taken place will begin.

Mrs. Mary Mooney, 84-year-old mother of Tom Mooney, who is imprisoned in San Quentin prison, California, in connection with the San Francisco Preparedness Day parade bombing in 1916, arrived here yesterday to join in the nation-wide appeal of the International Labor Defense for the release of her son.

THESE "out of character" glimpses are always more interesting. John McGraw and Babe Ruth on baseball are a trifle hackneyed. They say just about what might be expected. But get John McGraw talking on contract bridge or Babe Ruth discoursing on the racing qualities of certain greyhounds and the conversation will be really entertaining.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A sales-tax expert of the Canadian Government was pressed into service today to help frame the proposed general manufacturers' tax section of the revenue measure by which the United States hopes to balance its budget in the fiscal year, 1933.

ELMONT, L.I., Thursday, Feb. 25 -- Two young Nassau County policemen were killed, probably instantly, shortly after 2 A.M. today in a collision on the Hempstead Turnpike opposite the Belmont Park race track between their two-seater car and an automobile, the driver of which disappeared after the accident.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The first arrival of the horse in Egypt and Palestine and how it led to the dismemberment of Egypt is described in a report received in London today from Sir Flinders Petrie, veteran archaeologist, directing his fifty-second expedition to Palestine.
In one of the most thrilling finishes of Columbia's season, the Blue and White team defeated Rutgers, 41-30, last night in an Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet in the Morningside pool.

Tuesday's reactions on the Cotton Exchange were followed yesterday by moderate rallies in prices as a result of covering and trade buying (which appeared to be promoted by fairly steady Liverpool cables), reports of a firm spot situation in the South, the stopping of the first March notices and advances in grain and stocks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Unanimous agreement on the Glass-Steagall credit expansion bill was reached by the Senate and House conferees this afternoon; plans were made to handle the conference report so swiftly in Congress that the measure would reach President Hoover by Friday night.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Feb. 24 -- Explosion of a 500-gallon still in a two-story house at 1,297 Third Avenue, here, this morning resulted in the injury of Eugene Steup, 49 years old, and his wife, Emma, 42, and gave firemen a two-hour battle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- When Ambassador Hugh. S. Gibson, acting chairman of the American delegation to the Geneva Disarmament Conference, suggested on Monday a yardstick to measure the armies necessary as national police forces he made no specific mention of the treaty of St. Germain with Austria or other individual treaties, the State Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Whatever economies must be made in the school budget under stress of the financial crisis, the study of music, art and literature should not be curtailed. So Miss Florence Hale, president of the National Education Association, told educators from all parts of the country, gathered at the sixty-second annual convention of the association's department of superintendence here tday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 24 -- Yale tonight defeated the strong Williams basketball team, conqueror of Columbia and Syracuse, by a 26-to-18 margin in a game in which the score was four times tied, the last time at 16 when Yale's team play swept it into a steadily increasing lead.

A criminal army of 1,000,000 persons is operating in the United States, and "25,000 gangsters alone have died by gun-fire since prohibition came in," the English-reading public has been told by Collinson Owen, an Englishman writing on crime in this country.

The police radio system which began operation on Tuesday brought results yesterday. It sent nine detectives closing in on two men accused of forgery, rushed reserves to midtown to clear crowds blocking five detectives who had captured a desperate gunman and sent squad cars hurrying to the scene of a hold-up in Columbus Avenue.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The Senate today passed the bill to establish a State banking board of nine members, and the measure, which was approved in the Assembly yesterday, was sent to Governor Roosevelt, who is expected to sign it.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Charlie Ruffing, burly right-handed pitcher on whom Manager Joe McCarthy is banking heavily for this year's pennant quest, joined the Yankee squad today and with Dusty Cooke donned his uniform for the first time.

LISBON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Far-reaching financial measures designed to tide Portugal over the present economic crisis were approved tonight at a special meeting of the Cabinet, over which President Carmona presided.

Twenty-six class offices were filled in the semiannual student elections at City College yesterday. Unopposed for the vice presidency of the class of 1934, Moe Spahn, guard on the college basketball team, was the only varsity athlete among the list of successful candidates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Short selling is essential to the maintenance of stock exchanges, and stock exchanges are necessary to provide a market for investors, Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, told a House judiciary subcommittee, today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 24 -- The Princeton varsity basketball team lost tonight to a fast Carnegie Tech five, 30 to 15. The visitors took a commanding lead at the outset and held it throughout the game. Jagnow and Smith led the Carnegie attack, the latter with 8 points and the former with 7.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In commenting editorially on the defeat of Smith for President in 1928, you state that "the ostensible cause was prohibition," but "the actual cause was religious bigotry." Thus you have forcibly and succinctly given expression to an opinion of which fair-minded men were certain, and to which hypocrites alone could take exception.

ALBANY, Feb. 24.--Governor Roosevelt removed from office today Thomas M. Farley, Sheriff of New York County, a pillar in the Tammany organization and a close personal friend of John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, who owes in large measure his present position to the energetic support of the Sheriff.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Speaker Garner, according to an unequivocal statement made today by one of his friends, Representative Sam Rayburn, of Texas, is not a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination and will not file in any State primary.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A suit for divorce charging Jack Pickford, film actor and brother of Mary Pickford, with cruelty, was filed today by Mary Mulhern, film actress. She accused him of constant nagging and criticism of her theatrical career.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Japan is now taking steps to begin the construction of four new 8,500-ton cruisers, one of them a flying-deck cruiser, according to official reports reaching the Navy Department.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday-3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names.

AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 24 -- Speaker Garner is not disposed to have his interest in the economic problems confronting the country diverted by efforts to obtain from him a declaration on the prohibition question, said in substance, a telegram which Mrs. Claude de Van Watts, president of the Texas Women's Christian Temperance Union received today.

The annual report of the National Lead Company, issued yesterday by Edward J. Cornish, president, showed net profit last year was $4,022,421, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $5.48 a share on the common stock. This compares with a net profit of $4,675.098 in 1930, which was equivalent to $7.58 a share.

The government of the Kingdom of the Netherlands will offer for subscription on March 2 a new issue of 250,000,000 guilders of 5 per cent bonds at par, according to cable advices received here yesterday from the De Twentsche Bank of Amsterdam by its New York representative, A. Philippi von Hemert of 68 William Street.

TOKYO, Feb. 24 (AP) --Censorship was invoked again today to cloak the movement of Japanese reinforcements to the Shanghai front. Only meager accounts of military preparations appeared in a few newspapers, the government apparently taking the position that, by controlling the news, it might be possible to disguise the seriousness with which the Shanghai situation is viewed.
HAMILTON, Ont., Feb. 24 -- Joseph Ira Fletcher, former Reeve of Binbrook, died today at Mapleside, where he had resided all his life. He had been ill for two months. His age was 63.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Willie Macfarlane, the veteran from Tuckahoe, N.Y., won the fifty-four-hole St. Petersburg open golf tournament today with a score of 209. He defeated Dave Hackney of Lowell, Mass., by one stroke, and received the $500 top prize.

Seth Hoffman is showing a group of his monotypes at the Macbeth Gallery. He has been working in this interesting medium for several years, and the experience thus gained results in some strong and beautiful prints. The large heads-- and in these seems to reside the most marked originality of treatment -- are powerfully modeled, while "Reclining Nude" demonstrates that Mr. Hoffman can also, when he chooses, employ delicacy of line.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, worked night and day for weeks trying to save the Bank of United States and, until a few hours before he closed the institution, had reason to believe that the other large banks of the city would prevent its failure.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- In a special message to the Legislature today Governor Roosevelt backed the request of the Democratic leaders for more examiners under the State Controller to insure a close investigation of up-State local government.

Von Grona gave a dance recital last night at the Recital Theatre which featured the debut of his new partner, Leni Bouvier, and also the first New York performance of a group composition entitled "Two Roads." Miss Bouvier proved to be considerably more interesting than the rather pretentious dance cycle.

With no fast steamships available, gold exports were confined yesterday to a shipment of $200,000 to Germany, but the Bank of France resumed, after a lapse of a week, the conversion of its dollar balances into earmarked gold by having $12,501,000 of the metal set aside in the vaults of the Federal Reserve Bank.

John J, McElligott, assistant chief of the Fire Department, who has spent twenty-six of his forty-seven years combating all kinds of fires in the city, is slated to be the new chief of the department, it was announced yesterday when the Municipal Civil Service Commission disclosed that his name headed the list of eligibles resulting from a recent examination.

No wonder the Republican leaders at Albany were a " glum-looking lot" when they left a conference called to discuss further means of unemployment relief. Only a few days before they had cut $21,000,000 from the Governor's budget, to the joy of their up-State taxpaying constituents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Army officers selected to attend the Command and General Staff School at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., for the 1932-34 course, which begins next September, were announced by the War Department today. The officers designated and their present stations follow:

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 25 -- Secretary Stimson's letter to Senator Borah, which is generally accepted by British correspondents in Washington as an authoritative statement of the policy of the United States in all matters concerning China, seems to have been released for publication at an hour unfortunately late for good display by the British press.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Hoover answered in a way today the attacks by Democrats in Congress on his consolidation plans by issuing a statement wherein he said that he was "delighted that the Congress is earnestly taking up the reorganization of the Federal machinery."

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted:

TOKYO, Feb. 24 -- Believing apparently that the Japanese public fails to realize the strength, of hostile feeling Japan's policy is evoking, Katsuji Debuchi, Ambassador to the United States, in an interview with Nichi Nichi's New York correspondent, warns the Japanese people not to take an optimistic view just because certain United States Senators oppose economic sanctions.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Mrs. Roy Pollard's Uluniu was the lone favorite to win at Hialeah Park this afternoon and he scored in the feature race, the Citrus Growers' Handicap, and had only a nose to spare. Uluniu is the 6-year-old gelded son of Rodgers and Assagai's Christine which won his debut at this course on Jan. 23, with five losing races between that effort and today.

Omission of the quarterly dividend of 5O cents on common stock was voted yesterday by the directors of the American Bank Note Company, who issued a statement that because of the "negligible" amount of current business, the surplus must be conserved for the payment of preferred dividends.

Fifteen prohibition agents under Administrator Andrew McCampbell visited Broadway and the financial district yesterday, raided seven alleged speakeasies and restaurants where liquor was served, arrested thirty proprietors,bartenders and waiters and seized fixtures valued at more than $250,000.

Secretary STIMSON'S letter to Senator BORAH was really sent to the address of Japan and all the other signatories of the Nine-Power treaty of 1922. It is a review not only of American policy as respects China, but of what had come to be thought of as the settled world policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- When the Appropriations Committee report accompanying the 1933 Treasury and Postoffice Departments appropriation bill was introduced in the House today, it was disclosed that it proposed the abolition of twenty-nine positions in the customs service.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 24 -- The business of restoring a slightly damaged infielder to his former high estate and developing, at the same time, a capable understudy, began in earnest in the Giants' camp today when Manager John McGraw ordered a prolonged infield drill with Hughie Critz and Freddy Lindstrom doing most of the work at second base.

BOSTON, Feb. 24 -- For the first time in the twenty years of the Eastern Dog Club show a cocker spaniel tonight was awarded the highest honors, best in show going to The Great My Own, the exquisite little black specimen which is owned by Leonard J. Buck of New York City.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company is offering directly to its security holders rights to subscribe to an issue of $40,000,000 guaranteed 8 per cent eight-year gold bonds, participating conditionally up to 2 per cent additional each year, with warrants permitting the acquisition of stock in the company. The bonds will be sold in amounts as small as $10.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson issued today in his letter to Senator Borah a forceful reminder that world naval ratios are dependent upon treaties affecting the Orient and asserted these pacts are threatened by the Sino-Japanese conflict.

Names of 192 applicants for admission to the bar, who have been instructed to appear before the committee on character and fitness of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Department, were made public yesterday by the committee.

Basing his assertions on a series of business statistics, Gilbert T. Hodges, president of the Advertising Federation of America, told the members of the Advertising Club at 23 Park Avenue yesterday that the country had turned the corner of the depression.

ALittle Jane Ruby, 12 years old, received a tonic last night which her family physician asserted would do more to hasten her recovery from pneumonia than any medicine he could prescribe. Her pet dog, Fluffy which had been stolen from in front of her home at 130-15 149th Street.

An elaborate pageant of tableaux vivants entitled "Honor to Washington" was presented before a distinguished audience last night in the Town Hall. It was the fifth in a series of historical pageants dealing with scenes and events of old New York, and, like its predecessor, it was produced under the auspices of the historical committee in the interests of the Town Hall's endowment fund.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 24 -- The semi-final round of the Bermuda men's tennis championship became an all-English affair today with the elimination of Berkeley Bell, the former Texan, who was the favored United States contender after Sidney B. Wood was forced out yesterday.
CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Senator Moses left for Washington today, saying as he departed that the Congress "political honeymoon" was about over.

The general program for the "Grand Operatic Surprise Party" to be presented by the entire personnel of the Metropolitan Opera Company at the opera house on Sunday evening, March 6, for the benefit of the Musicians' Emergency Aid, was made public yesterday.
GENEVA, Feb. 24 -- From that high platform of sentiment and idealism on which it has sat for the past three weeks, the disarmament conference fell with a thud this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Coast Guard estimates that "large, highly organized international combines" are operating 176 liquor-smuggling vessels along United States coasts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Wheat drifted higher rather than, advanced today on the Board of Trade here, the trade being slow until near the close, when fairly general commissionhouse buying developed. This was followed by short covering, but the May ran into selling orders around 62 1/1 cents a bushel, as on the previcus day.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Seeded players advanced in the annual women's invitation squash racquets tournament, which began today with a record entry of fifty-eight players at the Racquet and Swimming Club.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- The revival of the whipping post as a punitive device for National Socialists who traduce men in public office was advocated in the course of a long and turbulent debate in the Reichstag today, which dealt chiefly with the coming Presidential election and questions of campaign etiquette.

Efforts on the part of the Federal Government to hasten the economic recovery have not, thus far, stimulated the general demand for steel products, according to The Iron Age. This publication estimates that the steel industry operated in the last week at 26 per cent of ingot capacity a decline of one point from the preceding week.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Naturally I am pleased that I broke my own land speed record of 245.733 miles an hour here today on the sands of Daytona Beach. I made 8.235 miles better than I did last year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 --By means of a letter addressed to Chairman Borah of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, Secretary of State Stimson today accomplished four things of paramount importance:

Dr. Willy Meyer of 700 Madison Avenue, an internationally famous surgeon and an authority on appendicitis, was stricken with a heart attack last night while attending a meeting of the New York Surgical Society in the Academy of Medicine Building, at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, and died soon afterward despite the efforts of his colleagues to revive him with oxygen that was rushed to the academy by the police.

Science finds itself walking hand in hand with, everyday experience when it reports that the effect of unemployment on family spirit varies with existing tendencies in the family group. Where friction has been the rule, the situation is made worse by economic stress.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The following is the text of Governor Roosevelt's order removing Sheriff Farley:
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 24 -- Brown's basketball team was no match for Harvard tonight, the Crimson team winning without much effort, 32 to 19.
Isidro Ribas of Spain lengthened his lead over Charles C. Peterson of St. Louis by 13 points at the Elks Club last night in their world's fancyshot billiard championship.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24.--A heavier run of hogs here and in the West than expected caused buyers to operate with considerable caution today. Light weights declined 10 to 20 cents, while heavy and medium kinds were 5 to 10 cents lower. The top dropped 15 cents to $4.20, while the day's average was off 10 cents to $3.90.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- George Lott, Chicago, and Marcel Rainville, Toronto, Ont., overwhelmed the driving challenge of Joe Whalen and Hudson Hamm, Miami youths, today to advance to the men's doubles semi-finals of the Pan-American tennis tournament.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 24 -- The Japanese laid details for the attack on the Kiangwan sector with the break of day. Numerous big guns were moved forward and twelve Whippet tanks took up positions. As the atmosphere of the always thick morning-time cleared sufficiently to give the artillery visibility the guns roared and the tanks plowed forward.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover left Washington tonight for a week's rest in Florida, accompanied by Mrs. Edgar Rickard of New York, who had been her guest at the White House for several days; Mrs. Mark Sullivan and Captain and Mrs. Joel T. Boone.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24. -- The "3-year-old Gailmont," which ran in the third race at Hialeah Park yesterday, today was identified as the 4-year-old Aknahton, a horse which ran as Shem in the "ringing" case uncovered at Havre de Grace last Fall.

Yesterday's markets, drifted in somewhat irregular fashion, not apparently reflecting anything but the direction taken at the moment by surface speculation. Stocks advanced about as much as they declined the day before; the more active shares rose 2 to 3 points, with fractional losses from the best. The gains were equally shared by railway and industrial stocks.

Proposed tax increases, If placed in effect, will compel an increase in the amounts which customers of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York and its subsidiaries will have to pay for gas and electric service, President George B. Cortelyou warned in his annual report to stockholders, made public at the annual meeting yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The wets challenged the drys at a hearing held today on the measure to report the State prohibition enforcement bill, introduced by Assemblyman Jenks, out of the Judiciary Committee for a vote on the floor of the Assembly. At the hearing, the first on prohibition held at the Capitol in two years, the drys, mostly women, outnumbered the wets ten to one.

Forty-two photographs accompanied by terse captions are used by Dorothy Thompson to tell much of her brief biography of Adolph Hitler, which Farrar Rinehart brought out yesterday following its publication in a magazine. The book title is "I Saw Hitler."

Thomas E. O'Brien of 979 Park Place, Brooklyn, a partner in the law firm headed by former Lieutenant Governor Thomas F. Conway, is expected to be the Board of Transportation's choice as counsel to succeed John J. Fitzgerald, whose appointment to the Supreme Court bench will probably be confirmed today by the State Senate.

A slight rally yesterday lifted stocks on the New York Curb Exchange out of a lethargy in which no clear trend had developed. Closing: prices were fractionally higher. Foreign bonds also displayed some strength, while domestic issues were mixed.

A conference of Republican wets designed to help bring about the adoption of a wet plank for the Presidential campaign was arranged yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt of the Republican Citizens Committee Against National Prohibition.

Activity on the part of the Reserve Bank in the acceptance market represented the only diversion of an otherwise quiet money market. Outside interests also contributed to the demand, which was better than the supply. However, discounts on bills remained unchanged.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Among the first to congratulate Sir Malcolm Campbell today were L. Warren Saker, chief steward of the trials; Barney Oldfield, veteran American race car driver; Mayor Armstrong and other officials.

President HOOVER and the Republicans have brought upon themselves the penalty threatened by Speaker GARNER. They bragged too much. They weren't cooperative. They wouldn't play fair. So an Economy Committee, composed of three Democrats and three Republicans, has been appointed.

Against a background of ermine wraps and gleaming white shirt fronts, figure skating stars of nine nations enthralled a crowd of 12,000 at Madison Square Garden last night with their grace and skill. Their dexterity and artistry not only fascinated the spectators but were responsible for the sum of nearly $35,000 being turned over to the Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau.

HAVANA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Fortunate Youth, purchased by S.S. Friedlein from S.W, Labrot at Saratoga last Summer, today won the $5,000 Independence Handicap at Oriental Park as Cuban racing fans celebrated the country's national holiday.
Not Those Seattle Blues. Seattle has just held a primary election for Mayor, and from the outcome one may either be proud of America or persist in one's low opinion of America.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Kuo Min (Chinese) News Agency at Nanking said today that official Chinese sources had confirmed the death of Robert M. Short, an American aviator serving with the Chinese Army, who was reported yesterday to have been shot down in flames at Soochow.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity continues to sag and is now approaching the extreme low point for the week ended Jan. 2. The index for the week ended Feb. 20 is 27.7, as against 28.9 for the preceding week and 57.8 for the corresponding week last year.

RENO, Nev., Feb. 24 -- Richard Joseph Forhan, dentist and toothpaste manufacturer of New York, received a divorce today from Julia Ann Forhan, whom he married in Denver in 1889. He alleged five years of separation caused by continuous quarrels.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The government issued today the text of its wheat bill, which is intended to bring back into cultivation some 1,400,000 acres of land in Great Britain which is suitable to wheat growing but which has fallen idle since the war.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Government of the United States faces the greatest test of its foreign policy since April, 1917, If not since the beginning of its history. Does the Nine-Power treaty, which the United States and the other powers have signed, mean anything, or is it another scrap of paper?

" Children and the building of a " city establish a man's name in the "earth " was anciently written. The name of the first Scriptural city is still remembered, though its site has not been located. Thebes in Boeotia still keeps her mythical founder, CADMUS, in memory.

The financial measures now being taken by President Hoover and Congress in Washington were evaluated yesterday as "inflation, to prevent 1932 from being a year of relentless scaling down of capital values," at a conference conducted here by five members of the economics and business staffs of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, under the chairmanship of Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the institute.

In preparation for the general election soon to be held in France, campaign leaders announce that movies will be used to show the voters how the candidates look at home as well as on the platform, how they talk to members of their families as well as to the public, and other intimate details impossible to present at a political meeting.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Clarence True Wilson, general secretary of the Methodist Episcopal Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals, was charged with reckless driving in a warrant issued by James A. Bain, Deputy City Attorney, upon complaint of L.F. Welch of Portland.

A gaunt man walked swifty past the restaurant next door to the Hotel Somerset in West Forty-seventh Street at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, looking neither to the right nor the left. At a table near the window five men saw him. Their chairs shot back and they hurried to the sidewalk.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Hazarding a gusty cross wind which at times threatened to blow his powerful Blue Bird racing car off the course. Sir Malcolm Campbell of England set a new world's automobile speed record of 253.968 miles an hour on the Ocean Speedway today.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Creighton University of Omaha, Neb., with a fast and clever basketball team, won from the Army today, 39 to 32, in the final home game of the Cadets' season.

DAIREN, Manchuria, Feb. 24.--Dispatches from Harbin tell of widespread looting by the force of Chinese rebels against the Mukden regime which has seized the Imienpo region on the Chinese Eastern Railroad east of Harbin.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Feb. 25 -- After a night of desultory artillery exchanges Japanese airplanes appeared over Chapei at 7 A.M. today [Thursday] and then flew over Kiangwan, where they dropped many missiles, which did not explode. A second group of Japanese planes then flew over the village and dropped small bombs, whereupon immense fires appeared with startling quickness.
